column2: ATLANTA, Aug. 4 -- A monument to health and sanitation, which, if Atlanta is successful in its efforts, will not rise glamourously above ground, but will remain unseen below the surface of the city, is being planned to be paid for out of this city's share of the relief funds made available when Congress voted the $2,122,000,000 fund to aid the country.

A runaway horse, with an ice cream wagon careening crazily behind it, dashed along 224th Street, near Paulding Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday. Twenty children playing in the street were scattered as the horse ran past and a 7-months-old baby in a carriage was killed.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- While further acts of political terrorism were committed throughout Germany today, the groundwork was laid for negotiations aimed at bringing about participation in the government by Adolf Hitler and his National Socialists.

PARIS, July 28 -- As a sporting and social event the Davis Cup series has been holding the centre of the stage here and has not only proved to be a consolation for those kept in Paris these dog days but has drawn many French notabilities and some few Americans back from the seashore.

A movement has been initiated by the Junior Chamber of Commerce of New Brunswick. N.J., for the opening to pleasure craft of the Delaware and Raritan Canal. The plan, as presented at a recent meeting, also contemplates the establishment of greatly reduced toll fees.
ALTHOUGH property taxes are frequently credited with bearing most of the cost of building roads, the real burden is borne by motorists, an accurate survey of road costs shows.
To the Dramatic Editor: Mr. Brady is once more offering a nostrum for the ills of the theatre, and like all quack medicines it has the prime quality of ignoring facts.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The United States, although not the favorite, has a good chance of winning the classic marathon race tomorrow for the first time since 1908.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Governor Roosevelt today began work on plans to accelerate his campaign for the Presidency to high speed as soon as the Walker decision is handed down.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Officers and passengers who will be on ships at sea in the North Atlantic when the total eclipse of the sun takes place, Aug. 31, were requested today by the Hydrographic Office of the Navy to observe and make photographs of this solar event.

With trading more active than at any time in two years, prices rose 2 to 12 points on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in a runaway market in which speculators caught short of stocks were literally stampeded.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- At the entrance to the clubhouse driveway here there is a small, square granite block with the date 1864 cut in it, the same being the year in which a few shrewd gentlemen decided that Saratoga needed a race track to round out the program of attractions at the Spa. The track was built forthwith and the thoroughbreds have been running, on and off, ever since.

TOKYO, July 13 -- Baron Shidehara has almost completely recovered from the cerebral hemorrhage which struck him down in February after the fall of the Cabinet in which he was Foreign Minister. His name was on the list of the reactionary murder groups and his sudden illness gave rise to rumors, which many people believed, that he had been attacked by assassins.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The consulate at Lausanne was closed July 30 by the State Department, all records and archives being preserved at the consulate in Geneva. The services of Vice Consul Clifford W. McGlasson of Washington were terminated at Lausanne.

TORONTO, Aug. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Daniel Malone, who is asserted by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to be a "Sinn Feiner of the most radical type" and to have expressed the intention of shooting J. H. Thomas, British Foreign Secretary, is held by police here after being remanded for eight days on a nominal charge of vagrancy.
These orders were issued yesterday: Pensioned. ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS. SERGEANT -- George B. Campbell, 105th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed April 14, 1905.

LAKE GEORGE -- As the season swings into August many sporting and social events are being planned. If the present program is carried out the Sagamore Golf Club, run in connection with the Sagamore Hotel at Bolton Landing on Lake George, will be host to one of the three major golf tournaments held annually by the New York Golf Association.

The fourth annual Summer national championship tournament of the American Bridge League will open tomorrow afternoon in the convention hall at Asbury Park, N.J., and will continue throughout the week. Five national championships and more than a dozen open and special events are on the program.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- With 2,000 State guardsmen of four units ready to open their two weeks' encampment in Camp Smith, Peekskill, tomorrow, announcement was made today of the personnel of the Twenty-seventh Division staff, which, commanded by Major Gen. William N. Haskell, will start its annual two weeks' course of field training tomorrow.

LA PAZ Bolivia, Aug. 6 -- President Salamanca, at the opening session of Congress today, Bolivia's Independence Day, denounced the efforts of the nineteen nations of the Pan American Union for attempting to solve the Bolivian-Paraguayan conflict over the Chaco region.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Hoover named the members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board this afternoon, with former Representative Franklin W. Fort, Republican, of New Jersey, one of the original Hoover men of 1928, as the chairman.

Economic developments during the last ten days have been watched with keen interest by retail executives here. The rise in security prices and the greater firmness in basic commodities have been interpreted as factors of considerable importance in weighing prospects for the Fall retail period, which will open around Labor Day.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- All French Summer resorts and watering places are starting bravely to combat what it is now apparent will be their worst year since the war.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 6 -- The dramatic revelation of Premier Carl Gustav Ekman's relationship with the late Ivar Kreugrer caused his abrupt resignation today and the reconstructior of the Cabinet under the Finance Minister, Felix T. Hamrin.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The Boerse closed the week irregular, with a down-ward tendency for the majority of stocks. Actuated evidently by apprehensions that the week-end might bring political disorders, the provincial public held back orders. The turnover was small but the price movements rarely exceeded 1 per cent.

The more encouraging outlook for utility holding companies was reflected last week by sharp advance in the senior and junior securities of virtually the entire group. Buyers became confident that the efforts of executives and bankers to restore sound conditions were bearing fruit and that regulatory activity affecting operating companies in several States would be more helpful than harmful to the industry as a whole.

Among the constructive factors in business which have developed during recent weeks are a stabilization of the volume of member bank credit outstanding in the larger cities, the steadiness of security markets, the strengthening of commodity prices and the cessation of the outflow of gold to foreign countries, says O.M. Fuller, farm economist of the North Dakota Agricultural College.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Worth is launching "steam heat" day ensembles with thin transparent wool net or lacy frocks for indoor wear and warm heavy wool coats for out doors. The straight narrow silhouette is without a circular cut, the necessary fullness being given by pleats, gathers or slit skirts for the evening.
Advocates of repeal indignantly deny that the saloon is just around the corner.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Dale Alexander, Red Sox first baseman, sent a treacherous hopper past secon to rob Wes Ferrell, ace right-hander, of a no-hit, no-run game today as Cleveland defeated Boston, 3 to 0. Alexander's bounder hopped over Cissell just as the Indians' second baseman stretched his hands for it in the fourth inning.

MAYOR WALKER'S proposal for all city employes to give up a month's salary in 1933 has focused attention on the organizations and associations of employes within the various municipal departments. For it is through these organizations and associations that "voluntary" action is being taken on the Mayor's proposal, which is part of the plan for reducing the city's budget next year.

TELEVISION stations are beginning to receive fan mail. In the early days of broadcasting letters gave the first indication that public interest was captured. Announcers pleaded with listeners to report on distance and clarity of reception.

MANILA -- Campaigning is hard work, but if Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, Governor General of the Philippines, goes home in September to stump for President Hoover he probably will look upon it almost as a vacation. For no campaign trip ever planned could hold a candle to the recent inspection tour Colonel Roosevelt made through the Philippines during very hot weather.

FOR twenty-two years I have been working with boys and their fathers and mothers. Needless to say, I have never met a perfect boy or girl, nor seen a perfect parent. But I have discovered such a close relationship between children and the kinds of parents they have that I am interested in trying to discover what the qualities of perfect parenthood are.

FRANZ LEHAR'S new work, "Giulietta," may be produced not on the operatic stage but on the boards of the Vienna State Opera, according to reports in the foreign press. Some weeks ago the veteran composer was working on the new score from dusk to dawn during the hot weather and sleeping in the daytime so that the production would not be delayed.

PRECISELY fifty-eight years ago next Wednesday morning a relative who had been hastily summoned to the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Hoover at West Branch, Iowa, made a pleased inspection of the main reason for the summons and was afterward able to say: "Herbert was a sweet baby that first day, round and plump, and looked about very cordial at everybody."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- Taking a tip from their track and field friends, swimmers of the world opened the aquatic events of the Tenth Olympiad today by breaking three Olympic records and eclipsing one world's mark three times.

The Dodgers defeated the Pirates for the third consecutive time at Ebbets Field yesterday, taking a tight pitchers' battle, 2 to 1. The victory enabled Brooklyn to tie the Braves for fourth place. A crowd of 10,000 saw the league leaders suffer their seventh consecutive defeat.

IN 1930 Massachusetts observed her tercentenary birthday, and this book, apparently prepared by Clifton Johnson under the auspices of the Northampton Historical Society, is sent forth to become one of the permanent results of that celebration.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 -- Politicians are still dizzy trying to figure out what happened in last Tuesday's primary election and why. It was the most turbulent, precedent-upsetting, unguessable primary ever held in the State, and attracted more than 750,000 voters to the polls, a record vote for any primary election in Missouri.

In a weekly market review George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, says it was only during the last fifteen years that the American consumer learned about vitamins and of the curative value of proper food.

The event likely to hold the centre of the golf stage locally this week is the qualifying round for the national P.G.A. championship. This will be played on Wednesday over the course of the Rockville Country Club at Rockville Centre, L.I., and will determine the fourteen professionals from this district eligible to play in the P.G.A. championship at the Kellar course, St. Paul, Aug. 30 to Sept. 4.

THE author's Matsu is Count Matsumoto, young Japanese of the highest patrician class, hereditary head of an ancient family whose members for hundreds of years have ruled the richest, most powerful Buddhist monastery in Japan.

EVEN in the midst of business recession or suspense dude ranch enterprises out West proceed undeflated in traffic or earnings. It happens, too, that many who yesterday were guests are today the cowboys and cowgirls.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 -- This is the story of a flop that failed. Up to a month ago the Olympic Games, from the standpoint of attendance and widespread public interest, were attracting about as much attention as the next super-movie release. Were we not in the midst of a depression?

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- An investigation of the admission to bail by County Judge James F. Brearton of two men arrested here in a car stolen in New York was begun today by District Attorney Harry E. Clinton, after two New York City detectives had lodged complaints of violation of judicial procedure with the prosecutor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 6 -- The trots of the Nassau Driving Club at the Mineola Fair Grounds today were marked by a smash-up between Colonel Strong, driven by Gus Munz, and Nap Direct, with Willard Thomas up, in the 2:15 pace. Neither driver was hurt, but Thomas had to pull up Nap Direct.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Sao Paulo civil war against the Vargas Government, which involves almost 100,000 combatants equipped with modern airplanes, tanks and artillery and is the most intense conflict in the history of South America, entered its fifth week today with victory for either army most remote.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 2 -- Following the trails, almost four centuries old, of the earliest Spanish explorers, Captain Francisco Iglesias, Spanish aviator, famous in South America for his flight to this continent in the airplane Jesus del Gran Poder, will lead an expedition into the regions of the Amazon River early next year.

Senator BORAH'S speech at Minneapolis last week had the same theme as his previous radio address in Washington which stirred so ranch interest in Europe. He has got a new subject which perhaps no one else is so well fitted to lay before the American people. Mr. BORAH cannot now be suspected of partisan motives.
RENO, Aug. 6 -- Trial of the divorce action filed here some weeks ago by John Wanamaker Jr. against Pauline Disston Wanamaker is tentatively set for next Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 -- This is the story of a flop that failed. Up to a month ago the Olympic Games, from the standpoint of attendance and widespread public interest, were attracting about as much attention as the next super-movie release. Were we not in the midst of a depression?

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- An investigation of the admission to bail by County Judge James F. Brearton of two men arrested here in a car stolen in New York was begun today by District Attorney Harry E. Clinton, after two New York City detectives had lodged complaints of violation of judicial procedure with the prosecutor.

A meeting between the scale conference committee of Typographical Union 6 and a committee of the Publishers' Association of New York City ended yesterday in a deadlock on the question of what is to be arbitrated in connection with the contractual differences between the two groups.

With the exception of coffee, which reacted after several weeks of strength, the local commodity markets continued upward last week in sympathy with general trends in the outside markets and major commodities. Sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides, silk and silver closed with gains, while wool-tops, which had been going lower without resistance for many months' turned in the middle of the week and recovered some of the lost ground.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Superior steadiness and generalship enabled Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York, 1931 Wimbledon champion, to overcome the courageous stand of his more spectacular opponent, Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, today in a thrilling five-set singles final to the forty-second annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tourney.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- Vermont is a thrifty State. With an area greater than that of Massachusetts, it has a population less than half that of Boston proper. Many a comparatively small city has a larger annual budget. The Green Mountain State was spending less than $1,000,000 a year at the outset of the century and not until 1912 did it go above the $2,000,000 mark.

A violent thunder storm cooled off the city and its environs last evening after a day in which high temperatures and oppressive humidity had combined to cause discomfort. But the downpour and its attendant electrical display led indirectly to two deaths and widespread, although minor, property damage.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Judge Stack called the habeas corpus proceedings of Albert Walker today thirty minutes earlier than scheduled, after attorneys for both sides had conferred and reached an agreement.

WHEN President Hoover used the army to clear out of Washington the remnants of the Bonus Expeditionary Forces which had refused to vacate Federal property, he employed an agency that has been called upon by every administration from George Washington's on, to augment civilian forces in maintaining law and order.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- More than 100 surface ships, thirty submarines and 200 flying machines began "hostilities" this morning in great manoeuvres whereby the Ministry of Marine seeks not only to test the efficiency of the ships and crews of the Italian Navy but also to experiment in new methods of attack and defense with the cooperation of the air force.

Horse Power From Horses. THE brand new and efficient Board of Taxicab Control sat solemnly the other day to consider a code of regulations for horse-drawn cabs. And not one of the remaining twenty-six veterans of the equine '90s was interested enough to attend.

With a rendezvous off its Long Island Sound station at Glen Cove on Tuesday afternoon, the fleet of the New York Yacht Club will make ready for its annual cruise, which will start on Wednesday morning with the first squadron racing run, that to Morris Cove, New Haven Harbor.

OF the Victorians there are few so perpetually interesting as the Brontes. This, no doubt, accounts for the succession of biographies which began with that memorable volume on Charlotte by Mrs. Gaskell. It must be admitted that no biography since has held for the reader the same degree of excitement as the Gaskell "Life."

WHEN Gustavus T. Kirby, chairman of the Olympic Games Committee, looked at a motion-picture record of the finish of an intercollegiate race and saw that second place had been won by a man who had been completely ignored by the judges, he decided that the present stop-watch method of timing runners was unfair and inaccurate.

THE hors d'oeuvres of the earls Autumn hat feast (announced some weeks ago) was the Agnes toque, with its rakish ruby velvet bow or feather pinwheel set directly above the right eyebrow. Like all well-behaved appetizers it set the pace for the plat du jour which was to follow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Although there was no considerable change in our foreign markets covered in this week's survey by the Commerce Department, some countries reported a more cheerful tone in business conditions.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: Your reviewer of Dr. Hofmeyr's "South Africa," June 26, has committed so many blunders, clearly from an ignorance of facts which are commonplaces of South African life and history, that readers unacquainted with South Africa and her problems must be seriously misled.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 6 -- On the old parade ground here where they assembled fifteen years ago as recruits, 250 veterans of the Seventy-eighth, or Lightning, Division attending the annual reunion of the division, received today the Verdun medal in a spectacular international ceremony.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 6 -- The three-day Monmouth County horse show came to a close on the grounds of the Rumson Country Club today, with championships being awarded in four classes. In addition to the rosettes, competition in nineteen other events was held throughout the day.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- The efforts that members of the British Commonwealth are making at Ottawa to improve their trade relations are being followed with close and sympathetic interest in League of Nations circles. Few perhaps can appreciate the difficulties Ottawa has found more than the secretariat officials who have been up to their necks in the same sort of thing for the last five years.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 6 -- Louisville will enter its new fiscal year Sept. 1 with a cash surplus of more than $400,000. Most of its employes will be on a full salary basis, and the taxpayers are looking forward to another reduction in the tax rate by the end of the year.

FAR from being country clubs for the sons of the idle rich, American colleges are rapidly becoming semi-philanthropic institutions, stretching their resources to the utmost to educate a part of the needy students clamoring at their gates, if the findings of two recent surveys give a correct picture.
HARBIN, July 10 -- Away back in the hinterland of North Manchuria the Chinese villagers are beset by three major fears -- the Japanese, the Chinese soldiers and Chinese bandits.

A plan for employe insurance, unique in the annals of American industry and including the largest wholesale underwriting of ordinary life insurance ever accomplished in a single attempt, as well as a broad coverage of group insurance, has been made effective for employes of the Associated Gas and Electric System.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Light voting marked Kentucky's primaries today for United States Senate and the lower house of Congress, although ideal weather revailed over the State.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange increased materially yesterday and in sympathy with strong outside markets prices advanced a quarter cent to the highest levels of the week, ending at gains of 18 to 19 points.

Rumsey McGregor of New Rochelle was one of the six competitors to advance to the third round of the men's singles as play in the second annual Westchester County Public Parks tennis tourney opened at Trevor Park in Yonkers yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to Mr. J.L. Rogers's letter in THE TIMES of July 24, kindly allow a few remarks by one who was a member of the Metropolitan Opera House orchestra.

DESPITE the fact that demands on tires have increased enormously in recent years, their quality has outstripped these needs and the motorist today gets "six times as much mileage out of a tire as he did fifteen years ago," according to J.F. O'Shaughnessy, vice president of the United States Rubber Company, quoted in a recent issue of The Executives Service Bulletin published by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

SKOWHEGAN, Me. THREE generations of a New England family are analyzed and their separate stories recounted in Owen Davis's latest play -- and, unless the records err, his 319th -- "The Harbor Light," which recently was given its first professional performance by the Lakewood Players at Skowhegan, after a tryout in May at the University of Iowa.

With the number of bank suspensions last week holding unchanged at twenty-one from the total for the previous week, the declining trend of suspensions appears to be continuing, according to The American Banker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Since 1861 Chicago has had thirty-three administra- tive heads of police -- an average of one every two and a quarter years. Older inhabitants recall that back in the early '70s a Police Commissioner actually remained in office for as long as five years, thereby establishing a record never since equaled.

Substantial price improvement was registered in the wholesale markets yesterday, continuing the advance of the week. Particular strength was noted in the grains, cotton, silk and dairy products. Measurable gains were found in other staples.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The gas company here has made a second reduction of 5 cents per thousand to domestic consumers. Other utilities in the State are likely to make concessions in order to restore confidence.

To combat competition from chain grocery stores which are taking $35,000,000 to $50,000,000 in retail meat business out of their hands annually, retail butchers in the metropolitan area are organizing voluntary chain groups and have started adding grocery departments.

TWO exhibitions opened in New York last Monday. At the Grand Central Galleries is a group of water-colors by Joseph Pennell, sensitive studies of New York harbor in the several seasons and at various times of day. The new print group includes work by Childe Hassam, Stow Wengenroth, George Biddle and Martin Lewis.

A STEADILY decreasing number of vehicular accidents, resulting from an intensive safety campaign inaugurated in 1926, has been reported, by the Sheffield Farms Company. During 1927 there were 4.2 per cent fewer accidents than in 1926 although the number of vehicles had increased 5 per cent, it is said.

The adverse vote of the firemen dooms Mayor WALKER'S voluntary pay-cut plan, regardless of any action the teachers may take. Its success would have been a miracle. Enlightened self-interest must be enlightened indeed to command the support of all the hosts of government employes in so exigent a matter.

After study of the recommendations for changes in the magistrates' courts made by Samuel Seabury as a result of his inquiry for the Appellate Division, a special committee representing the City Club of New York made known its findings yesterday in a report released for publication this morning.

Reports that Governor Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, has developed great strength in the West and will carry several States there that usually have been Republican were brought here yesterday by party leaders who have arrived for conferences with James A. Farley, National Chairman, beginning today.

Four years ago the Regional Survey of New York and Its Environs said that "the question is beginning to be asked whether the use of the beaches must be discontinued." Only improvement of methods of sewage and garbage disposal could save them.

CLEVELAND. Aug. 7 (AP). -- Behind excellent twirling of Willls Hudlin and Jack Russell, Cleveland won a double-header today from Washington, 7 to 4 and 6 to 2. The twin victory which enabled the Indians to displace the Athletics from second place, was witnessed by 20,000 fans.
DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Ten thousand members of the Fraternal Order of Eagles were here tonight for their national convention which opens formally tomorrow.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- A thirty-five foot putt on the thirty-eighth green won the State amateur crown for Tommy Goodwin, 19-year-old Monroe golfer, at the Niagara Falls Country Club.

St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 316 West Forty-sixth Street, was crowded yesterday afternoon at the formal installation of the Rev. Conrad E. Schroeder as superintendent of the Bethlehem Orphan and Half Orphan Asylum at Fort Wadsworth. S.I. He goes to his new office from the pastorate of the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour, Mineola, L.I. Lutherans from all parts of the New York area were present.

SKYLAND, Va., Aug. 7. -- Because of the record-breaking heat wave which invaded even the high altitudes of his mountain camp. President Hoover today devoted himself entirely to rest and delayed work on his acceptance speech to be delivered on Thursday night.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Newark Bears and Rochester Red Wings divided a double-header before a crowd of 7,000 who braved threatening weather today. The league leaders took the first game, 4 to 3, and lost the second, 3 to 2, in an eight-inning overtime tussle.
An extensive recovery in construction in this city after last May's general building strike is shown by State reports, Alien E. Beals points out in the current Dow Service Daily Building Report.

Organization of a group to be known as the East Side Reconstruction Committee, whose aim will be to advance model housing projects on the east side, was announced last night by Harry H. Schlacht, former president of the East Side Chamber of Commerce and present east side divisional chairman of the Block-Aid Community Organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Wholesale commodity prices ranged from nine-tenths of 1 per cent to 3 per cent lower in June than in May in twelve of the fourteen foreign countries for which reports are at present available, the Department of Commerce announced today.
PARIS, July 30 (By Mail) -- The Ministry of Marine, by putting naval canteens on "the lemonade wagon," has raised a storm of protests from the Deputies representing wine growing districts.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7. -- The hopes of Japan in the aquatic events of the tenth Olympiad advanced today as Yasuji Miyazaki, a grammar school boy, sped to victory in the 100-meter free style final for men.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.1, compared with 60.9 a week ago, 60.8 two weeks ago, 60.2 three weeks ago and 59.6 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date was 66.3 in the first week of January.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Criticism of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for using its discretion in making relief loans to States, as when it turned down Pennsylvania's request last week, today brought replies from directors of the corporation, although they declined to be quoted individually.

MANILA -- American business men in the Philippines are not altogether unsympathetic with the national desire for independence. Many of the most influential are in a position where they could retire if they wished and avoid complete financial loss, and these, having many friends among Filipinos, fear independence only because of its possible consequences in a country to which they have become Sincerely atttached.

The achievements of Miss Helen Keller, despite being blind, deaf and dumb, were held up as an example of what one might make of a handicapped life in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which he is the pastor.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7. -- The Imperial Economic Conference, assembled to increase trade and friendly relations among all the countries of the British Empire, has resolved itself into a duel between Great Britain and the Dominion of Canada. Neither side is even pretending any longer that there is anything less than a duel so far as the two major countries are concerned.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 7. -- Trading was more active in the cotton market last week, and although price fluctuations were narrow, there was a general tendency toward slightly higher values, due mainly to the great activity and strength of the stock market, backed by the advance in wheat.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7. -- Lumber today assumed the leading place in the negotiations between Canada and Great Britain now in progress at the Imperial Economic Conference here. From authoritative sources it was learned that whatever amendments Canada may make to her trade reciprocity offer to the United Kingdom will depend largely upon what the British will be willing to do for Canada in the matter of lumber at the expense of Soviet Russia.
ASCUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Two Bolivian aviators were reported captured today when their plane was shot down and destroyed within the Paraguayan lines in the Gran Chaco.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Aug-. 7. -- Counsel for Libby Holman Reynolds announced today that she would arrive here between 1 and 2 P. M. tomorrow to surrender to Forsyth County authorities on the Indictment charging murder of her husband, Z. Smith Reynolds, heir to a tobacco fortune.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7. -- Production ot steel ingots last week dropped fully 1 point, from a rate of 15 to 16 per cent maintained for three weeks after a recovery from the short mid-year dip. While the decrease was somewhat disconcerting when steel-trade sentiment had been Improving for three weeks, some producers are deferring certain rollings to accumulate tonnage for more economical operation later in the month.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Boston Braves extended the Pittsburgh Pirates' losing streak to nine consecutive games today by taking both ends of a double-header, 2 to 1 and 7 to 6, before a crowd of 29,000.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 8. -- Prime Minister MacDonald has made a mysterious journey to Northern Ireland simultaneously with reports from the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa of a new effort to settle the Anglo-Irish dispute over the oath of allegiance and land annuities.

After winning the first game of yesterday's double-header from the Reds with comparative ease, the prospect of ascending to a tie with the Braves for third place by a second triumph apparently overawed the Dodgers, who dropped a two-run lead in the seventh, split the day's honors and fell from a tie for fourth to fifth place.

WILMINGTON, Cal., Aug. 7. -- Holland swept into the lead in the monotype yachting series today with four of eleven races sailed, and the United States, through disqualification of its boat in the fourth race, dropped from its position as a serious contender.

TOKYO, Aug. 7. -- Two new ]ow records for the Japanese exchange in two successive days last week, during the export season, when the yen exchange is usually firm, have startled the Japanese public, though bankers expected the fall. [The yen, worth 49.85 cents at par. fell last Friday to 26.06 cents from 26.69 on Thursday and 27.12 Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Governor Roosevelt of New York was characterized as "The Master Tree Planter" and Speaker Garner as "The Public Pork Distributer" by Representative Snell of New York, the minority floor leader, in a statement issued today through the Republican National Committee.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Trial of the government's anti-trust suit against Appalachian Coals. Inc., and 136 coal operators will enter its second week before a special three-judge Federal court here tomorrow. Court officials said they did not believe it would end before Thursday.
Jersey City took both ends of a double-header from Toronto at Jersey City yesterday, winning the first game by 6 -- 3 and annexing the second by 1-0.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The 2-year-old championship and the thoroughbreds which have a chance to gain it provided the principal subject for conversation over the week-end, following the decisive triumph of W.K. Coe's Ladysman in the United States Hotel Stakes.

According to ARISTOTLE -- according to the encyclopedia -- the State exists to secure the general good of the citizen, which is "the life according to virtue." It is refreshing to see in practical politics efforts to serve this ideal end. Such loftiness of purpose and practice, anywhere observed, must be a satisfaction to all seekers of the life according to virtue.

Good writing depends upon hearty eating. Such is the gist of a publication of the International Labor Office on Health and Occupation. The hazards of certain occupations are well known to insurance companies, and writing is supposed to be one of the safest.

A drive for Winter clothing for wore than 1,000,000 persons dependent upon relief in this State has been started by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration and the Home and Work Relief Bureaus operating in its system, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the administration.

V1GO, Spain, Aug 7. -- Twenty-two fishermen were lost in the sea when the fishing motor boat Azana capsized in a strong northerly gale off Cangas de Morrazo several days ago, it was learned with the return of only two survivors to the port today.

The National City Bank, as depository under the offer made recently by Saxon Public Works, Inc., of Germany, to issue new 6 per cent notes in exchange for the issue of 5s that fell due on July 15, announced yesterday that holders of more than 50 per cent of the $7,000,000 of matured notes outstanding had accepted the plan.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- A total of 15,149 stock companies were incorporated in the State during the first seven months of this year, compared with 15,194 companies incorporated during the corresponding period in 1931.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Near death from a terrific beating, John B. Colegrove, Taylorville banker under sentence for alleged irregularities in connection with the failure of his institution three years ago, was found lying on a friend's lawn here today.

Every effort to open the Eighth Avenue subway by Sept. 6, the day after Labor Day, is being made by the Board of Transportation. The non-arrival of spare parts essential for safe operation of the twelve-mile line between Chambers Street and 207th Street is the only contingency which will keep the line from being opened for public use by that time, it was reported yesterday.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP). -- The itinerary which Lieutenant Governor Herbert H. Lehman plans to follow when he departs from Albany on Wednesday for the second of two State inspection trips he has undertaken at the request of Governor Roosevelt was announced here today.

Since enactment of the law authorizing issue of national bank circulation on pledge of certain government bonds hitherto not possessing the "circulation privilege, something over $1,000,000 of new bank notes have been taken out. The amount will increase considerably, as some of the larger city banks have applied for additional circulation.

James Barton, an expert comedian and as good a dancer as you are likely to find anywhere in the musical comedy field, heads the vaudeville portion of the new bill at Loew's State Theatre. Mr. Barton is being well received by the audiences to whom his familiar, but apparently always welcome, specialties need no introduction.

To the Editor of The New YORK Times: Referring to THE TIMES editorial "West Side Finances," permit me to solve the "mystery" as to how the $25,000,000 estimate was arrived at for the construction of the entire west side elevated express highway.

CHICOPEE FALLS, Mass., Aug. 7. -- Two bandits entered the restaurant of the Falls Inn at 12:40 o'clock this morning, ordered eight men to stand against a wall and took between $300 and $400 from them and from the restaurant till.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The busiest of the Ministerial buildings that house the German Government these days is a solid structure of gray granite away from all the rest of the pleasant tree-lined street where the Landwehr Canal cuts through the city's heart.

ROCK HALL, Md., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Mr. and Mrs. Gorhan Clifton of Yayne, Pa., were rescued from their sinking motor yacht Gee-Cee today after it apparently struck a submerged log in the Chesapeake Bay near here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- With plow, hoe, rake and spade, the nation has swung into gardening on a scale never equaled before as a result of unemployment.

There is no doubt that the efforts made by publishers during the last two years have resulted in an improvement in the basic structure of the publishing industry, according to Cass Canfield, president of Harper Brothers, who also is president of the National Association of Book Publishers.

CHICAGO. Aug. 7. -- Scarcity of choice, heavy beef steers was a sustaining factor in the cattle market last week, with $9.70 the week's top. while yearlings touched $9.35, fancy heiferi $8 and calves $7. Other grades of steers, as well as cows and heifers, closed 25 cents lower, with leading steers in better demand at unchanged to 25 cents higher, and calves 75 cents lower than the previous week.

Assailing Sensational newspapers which convert "bad" news into good news for profit," the Rev. Thomas L. Graham of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral said in his sermon at high mass yesterday morning that such "dailies and weeklies, together with scandal-mongers in politics, society and business, kill the body and soul of our people."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Tony Freitas, Philadelphia southpaw, held the Chicago "White Sox to three hits to give the Athletics a 1-to-0 triumph in the second game of a double-header today, after Ted Lyons had outpitched Bob Grove for a 3-to-1 victory in the opener.

Cornered yesterday morning on the roof of a four-story loft building, where he had been chased by a policeman at whom he had fired three shots, John Evans, 25 years old, who gave his address as the Hotel Langwell, 123 West Forty-fourth Street, was arrested and charged with felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan law.

GARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Years do not weigh heavily upon Dr. Henry Fairfield Osborn, president of the American Museum of Natural History, who tomorrow will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday here at his home, Castle Rock.

Playing through four periods under the handicap of a badly cut left eye, Lieutenant McDonald Jones yesterday the Governors Island polo four to victory over an officers' team from West Point on the soggy field at Governors Island, 10 to 6.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The newly appointed Home Loan Bank board will lose no time in putting into operation the complex machinery of a nation-wide banking system which is expected by its sponsors to ease the mortgage burden on the struggling home-owner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The lack of public criticism concerning the negotiations by the Port of New York Authority for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for purposes of constructing a tunnel in the neighborhood of Thirty-eighth Street is surprising.

ALBANY. N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Albany came from behind today to win its second consecutive game from Buffalo. 7 to 6. Buffalo got a fiverun lead in the second inning, but three pitchers were unable to hold it. The home team drove Bloomer from the box in the fourth and Gould in the seventh.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 7. -- The speedy and energetic fashion in which Premier Ekman was removed from office yesterday for having accepted a check for 50,000 kroner [about $8,900 at the present rate of exchange] that the late Ivar Kreuger sent him from New York in February, is unanimously approved by the Swedish press today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7. -- The shrill blast of trumpets echoed through the cavernous Olympic Coliseum at twilight today, bringing a tremendous crowd of 70,000 persons to their feet in tense expectancy.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Starting after a 30-minute postponement because of a dead calm the Bozo, A.F. Broderick's entry in the Sound interclub class, came across the line a winner after a listless race today in a light wind which finally blew up from the southwest. Lucius Eastman's Axon was second.

Before the close of the year the new home of the Mercantile Library being erected at 17 East Forty-seventh Street, is expected to be opened. The structure covers a site fronting nearly twenty-six feet between Fifth and Madison Avenues opposite the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

Support for the Federal Administration's plan to use Reconstruction Finance Corporation funds for the repair and improvement of transportation systems was urged last night by W.S. Rugg, vice president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, in a radio address.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The first and most important stage of the war loan conversion is now completed. The Treasury promises a statement soon as to the amount converted under the government's offer of a bonus of 1 per cent for conversion during July, but meantime the City is busy forecasting this, and also the final, result.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Led by Captain C.T.I. (Pat) Roark, England's ten-goal star, who was making his Eastern debut in polo this year. the Aiken quartet defeated Sands Points, 14 to 11, in the weekly high goal exhibition today at the Sands Point Club.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Replacing the Eighty-seventh Brigade under General George R. Dyer, composed of the Seventy-first Infantry of New York, led by Colonel Walter A. de Lamater and the 174th Infantry of Buffalo, Colonel William R. Pooley commanding, New York National Guard Engineers and Medical units arrived at Camp Smith today for two weeks of intensive training.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- Two disturbances last night, one in East Prussia and the other in Silesia, have caused both the Socialist and Nationalist press, as distinguished from the Nazi organs, to demand the immediate issuance of the threatened Presidential decree increasing the penalties applicable to such cases.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Confident as the result of word from his managers that ample funds will be available for the national Democratic campaign, Governor Roosevelt returned to Albany tonight refreshed by a week-end at his Hyde Park home to face a momentous week which will include important conferences and a public hearing of the charges against Mayor Walker.

Every nation is eager to sclaim responsibility for the world depression, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared yesterday afternoon in the first of a series of sermons he will broadcast on Sundays over WEAF.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 7. -- There is a good possibility that Professor Augnste Piccard will begin his second ascension into the stratosphere from the Dubendorf Airfield here at about 2 or 3 o'clock Tuesday morning, but the same hour Wednesday seems more probable.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 7. -- They have stood their last watch, the thirty mariners Gloucester honored today, whose graves in uncharted ocean grottos are marked only by the racing whitecaps.

Since the departure for London three weeks ago of P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Line, there have been frequent reports from the British metropolis that the White Star Line would be acquired by the Furness, Withy Company or by the Cunard Line.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Justice of Peace Samuel Harrison, 79 years old, was married last night and staid Evanston forgot some of its dignity celebrating the event.

The third-party movement sought new adherents yesterday through an "open letter to the people of the United States" signed by 500 economists from all parts of the nation led by Professor John Dewey of Columbia University.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Dying winds prevented any one of the twenty-three yachts which started the annual Boston Lightship race of the Boston Yacht Club from finishing within the time limit tonight and the fleet had its thirty-five-mile drifting match in vain.

Mr. BALDWIN, in his remarks at the formal opening of the New Welland Canal, and Dr. MANION, in his historical review of the uniting by man-made channels of the waters of the upper and the lower lakes, did not forget the romantic part which the French explorers, voyageurs and priests had in finding the way by river, lake and portage into the interior of the continent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The discovery of a new hormone was announced today by the Carnegie Institution of Washington. This hitherto unknown hormone is found to have been produced by the anterior pituitarv gland in addition to the growth and the gonad stimulating hormones, already recognized by most investigators.

City officials in the higher salary rackets should accept salary reducions in 1933 substantially greater ban the 81-3 per cent cut that Mayor Walker has urged all city employes to take, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in a statement issued in his capacity of president of the Citizens Budget Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7. -- A piece of the only meteorite, according to scientists here, that ever struck a building, has been placed on exhibition at the Free Natural History Museum of the Academy of Natural Sciences.
Secretary Henry L. Stimson arrived in New York yesterday to make today what he announced as an important declaration of the policy of the United States in preserving peace under the Pact of Paris.

The Republic at Panama, William Nelson Cromwell, fiscal agent, has sold to the 50 Central Park West Corp. a mortgage for S120,000 on 164-166 W. 25th St. this mortgage was given originally to the City Real Estate Co. twenty years ago by the Nodrog Realty Co.

Montlcello, the home of Thomas Jefferson, which, was opened as a patriotic shrine by a group of citizens, in 1923, is in danger of foreclosure. Stuart G. Gibboney, president of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, appealed to the public yesterday for contributions to avert the threatened closing of the estate and its return to private hands.
Fog, often a welcome ally to fleets in war, closed down upon the fishermen as they started through Great South Bay for Fire Island Inlet and the ocean on Saturday morning.

The 143d anniversary of the War Department, created in New York on Aug. 7, 1789, when George Washington signed a Congressional act establishing a "Board of War and Ordnance," will be celebrated at 4 o'clock this afternoon at Federal Hall in Bryant Park.

VERDUN, Aug. 7. -- One of the monuments to those killed in the World War was dedicated at Douaumont, just outside Verdun, today by President Lebrun. Two Marshals, 101 Generals, veterans from every regiment, prelates of the Catholic Church, Boy Scouts and many thousands of civilians, from every province of France, looked on.

With or without leaders, the people of America will not always yield to an autocracy of crime or an autocracy of finance and big business, said the Right Rev. John Newton McCormick, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Western Michigan, in a sermon yesterday moraine at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Growth of the movement to curtail wasteful expenditures in county finances through centralization and uniformity in new financing is outlined in a symposium on county government presented by the National Municipal League in the current issue of its official publication, the National Municipal Review.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 -- All commodity and securities markets improved last week, with fairly active trading and firmer prices. Export buying of grains was active in the last half of the week, pushing wheat to the equivalent of 48 cents a bushel, 1 3/4 cents higher than the previous Saturday's close.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 7 -- The tennis and golf tournaments of yesterday at the Wyantenuck Country Club in Great Barrington was followed by a ball in the evening which attracted 200 persons. Dinners were given before the ball by Dr. and Mrs. John Dodge Peters, who had forty guests, at the club; by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scribner for their daughter.

SPRINGFIELD. Ill., Aug. 6 (AP). -- A second defeat for the $5 basic wage scale for Illinois miners was indicated tonight on the basis of unofficial returns from more than one-fourth of the State's 240 qualified union locals.

The Association of Community Chests and Councils endorsed yesterday the policy of the Federal Reconstruction Corporation in distributing the $300,000,000 fund at its disposal as a supplemental source of relief, rather than a substitute for local relief.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug, 7. -- A closing rally by John Hay Whitney's Greentree quartet earned for it a brilliant 11-10 triumph over Tommy Hitchcock's Sands Point team today at the Roslyn Polo Club. Originally the game had been listed for the Whitney estate at Manhasset, but because of early morning rains it was transferred here.
BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., announced today that it would discontinue on Aug. 31 the service between Boston and Portland, Me., which has been maintained for 109 years.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, in an address to the Institute of Politics today condemned the duties on Latin-American products inflicted by the Smoot-Hawley bill and subsequent legislation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- A bull market is on in wheat and all leading commodities. A feeling has developed rapidly in the last two weeks that the pilces of securities, agricultural products and other commodities have been too low. The long business depression has been discounted by drastic declines and an upward icadjustment is under way.

The best way to combat the depression is to fill the highest governmental positions in the forthcoming election with the most able men of the country, regardless of political affiliations, the Rev. Dr. Henry Hallam Tweedy of the Yale Divinity School declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the James Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Just how the layman can best observe the won ders of the solar eclipse on Aug. 31 including the corona, which is the "prima donna of the celestial opera," was described in picturesque and popular language by Captain Julius F. Hellweg, superintendent of the Naval Observatory, over a National Broadcasting Company network to night.

Pressure on deliveries for immediate retail selling and a greater degree of optimism featured activity in the wholesale markets here during the week. The number of buyers here was large and, while purchasing is being carefully done to meet the requirements of the individual store clientele, orders were placed for almost all types of Fall merchandise.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7. -- After the showing of the Nipponese in the opening day of swimming competition, they are calling it the Japanese crawl now, instead of the Australian crawl.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Senator Borah, in a telegram read at the Newport Summer conference today, opposed extension of the international moratorium or debt revision except under "a program which gives reasonable assurance the American taxpayer will receive better than the debts."

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 8. -- Following a crisis in the Nanking Government over the conduct of affairs in North China, now threatened with a new Japanese invasion, it was made known today that Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang had prepared an announcement to be issued at 5 o'clock this afternoon saying he would turn over his power in the north to two councils.

Major Maurice Campbell, former Federal prohibition administrator here, announced his support of Governor Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, yesterday by making public a letter written to the Governor April 6.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- To Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Rye today went the distinction of being the first to eliminate a seeded player from the Eastern grass court tennis championships, which started yesterday at the Westchester Country Club, as she rallied to defeat Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, 3-6, 6-2, 9-7, in one of the seven women's singles matches contested this morning.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Veterans of the Seventy-eighth Division at their annual meeting here today refused to censure President Hoover and Federal authorities for their actions in connection with the evacuation of the bonus army from Washington. A resolution, introduced from the floor, was defeated by an almost unanimous vote of the thousand veterans in attendance after a brief and heated debate.

SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Eleven passengers of the Agnes W., a sight-seeing boat were rescued from Oneida Lake tonight after the craft was in collision with the tug Matton 10, out of Waterford, a half mile off the beach.

At least nine new plays will be tried out this week by the Summer companies in New York and the near-by States. Of particular interest to Broadway is Rachel Crothers's new comedy, "When Ladies Meet," which will open tonight at the Cape Playhouse, Dennis, Mass.

For once the statisticians of the Weather Bureau agreed with the popular commentator and admitted it wasn't the heat yesterday -- it was the humidity. Although the temperature was normal -- at the highest 76 degrees, two degrees above average for the day -- the humidity ranged between 90 and 96 degrees.

Two youths were arrested after a chase yesterday afternoon and held in the West Forty-seventh Street station house on charges of assault and robbery in consequence of a hold-up of Arthur Bohm, a street peddler of ice cream, which occurred just prior to their flight before Patrolman Frederick Schuckman, the arresting officer.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Aug. 7. -- R. E. Welch, one-legged station agent of the Boston Maine Railway at Northumberland, N. H., realized his boyhood dream today, making successfully and in normal time the difficult ascent of Mount Washington by way of the trackside of the cogwheel railway.
DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Johnny Stone hit a home run in the seventh inning with Gehrmger on base today to break a deadlock and enable the Tigers to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 3 to 1.
Psychologists Contradict Duce. Premier MussoLINI'S views on war as a valuable tonic and tissue-builder for the human race are not shared by the American Psychological Association.

Sober and sensible opinion in both London and Dublin is that the threatened war of tariffs between Great Britain and the Irish Free State is an act of lunacy. Neither side wants it. Both sides stand to lose by it. Yet there seems to be 3 sort of fatal drift into it.

Recent proposals to erect large multi-family structures on the lower east side are opposed by the Bronx Landlords' Protective Association, Inc., which suggests that new buildings be limited to three stories in height, or that one and two family houses be erected.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- The trend of securities on the Bourse closely followed indications given by the New York market, and interest is still concentrating here on the development of the American market. Consequently, quotations generally were firm, with a large turnover.
BERLIN, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Deaths, injuries and further window smashing were reported overnight as Germany's political violence continued.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Although the market has continued to discuss the possibility of further reduction in the Bank of England rate, the absence of any change this week occasioned no surprise. Unless the Bank of France or the Federal Reserve lowers its rate, it is thought in the best quarters to be unlikely that the Bank of England will take any further action concerning its own rate.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- It was Saturday at the Saratoga track and a fine, breezy day, too. The volunteer guide, carrying weight for age gallantly, crooked his cane over his arm, pulled down the brim of his Panama and said solemnly:
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson will sail tomorrow on the Leviathan. On their return in the Autumn they will be at their home in Manbasset, L.I.

While Mayor Walker was completing his surrebuttal in the removal case scheduled to be heard before Governor Roosevelt at Albany on Thursday, formal charges against Dr. William H. Walker, the Mayor's brother, and four other physicians were announced yesterday by the City Affairs Committee.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Many of the crack skippers ox the Long Island Sound yacht-racing fleet assembled at the Sands Point Bath Club today and handled sailing dinghies in a special regatta. The event was called a sunburn event rather than frostbite regatta, the term used last Winter, and it attracted the largest spectator fleet of the Summer.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- The result of the Reichstag election is in general regarded favorably by German business men. The conviction held in such quarters is that the Hitler menace to public finance and to the currency has disappeared. Whereas Hitler's successes at the election of September, 1930, caused a panic on the Boerse, the past week's market was not at all reactionary.

Charlie Grimm, banjo player, general entertainer, portrait painter and between times a first baseman of extraordinary ability, made his debut as the new manager of the Chicago Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday and amid the generous plaudits of a gallery that totaled 15,000, despite the threatening aspects of the weather, led his team to victory over the Giants, 8 to 2, in the first grame of a double-header.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 7. -- For the first time Since Long Beach became "the city of dreadful night last Tuesday," the proprietors of 100 alleged gambling concessions along the Boardwalk took down their shutters tonight, switched on their flood lights and resumed business, encouraged by a court decision in their favor and delighted by the throngs of customers who attended the reopening event.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Sir Guy Standing's Lea, a six-meter boat, captured the second division handicap event, a highlight of the bimonthly races conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today. Over a six-and-one-half-mile course she triumphed over Hawk, owned by W.H. Smith, by 56 seconds in a thrilling finish.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 7 -- The Brooklyn Cricket Club today defeated Union County by 39 runs, with one wicket to spare, in a Metropolitan District Cricket League championship fixture at Warinanco Park. Union County, first at bat was retired for 76. Brooklyn responded with 115 for the loss of nine wickets.
RENNES, France, Aug. 7. -- A great bas-relief monument commemorating the union of Brittany with France was blown up by unknown persons at 5 A. M. today.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 7 -- Fifty persons, attending evangelistic services in a large tent at Greaterford, near here, were thrown into panic tonight when a high wind during a heavy rainstorm blew the tent over and they were trapped beneath the canvas and the flimsy supporting structure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of John Langdon Leighton chiding Secretary Mills for his activities in trying to arrange loans to railroads for repairing equipment, while probably an earnest criticism, shows that Mr. Leighton should read in his Bible the parable of the wise and foolish virgins.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading your editorial on on "Enjoing Bad Times," the thought occurred that one angle of the depression has not received its proper emphasis. It relates to the depression as a leveler. In this respect it is entitled to be known as the runner-up to the grave.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Goadby Loew, who have Mr. Loew's brother, E. Victor Loew, among their guests, gave a farge luncheon at Stoneacre this afternoon.
PARIS, Aug. 7. -- Lanvin features the Cossack influence in fitted and flared silhouette coats with fur sleeves, yokes and pockets, huge melon collars and fur or fabric bonnets.

His fishing excursion having proved beneficial, Speaker GARNER is reported ready to come East this week for a conference with Governor ROOSEVELT. At a total cost of 6 cents the Speaker has been notified of his nomination for Vice President and he has accepted.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Cal., met defeat in straight sets today as the men's singles in the Eastern grass court championship tournament swung into full stride on the courts of the Westchester Country Club. His conqueror was Harold MacGuffin of Philadelphia, who triumphed unexpectedly and rather easily at 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- The greatest track and field meet in history is over. When the wiry little body of Juan Garlos Zabala snapped the tape at the finish of the marathon yesterday the most devastating assault on existing records that has ever been known was brought to a fitting and dramatic close.

In a raid on an alleged gambling establishment at 134 West Fiftieth Street yesterday plain-clothes men of the chief inspector's squad arrested 120 men. Two were charged with operation of a gambling place and accepting bets and the others with disorderly conduct.

Watching New Price Influences. With the big question in the minds of both buyers and sellers, that of how far the merchandise markets will respond to new price influences, orders yesterday showed a gain. That runaway advancing markets are in store was scouted, but a degree of inflation was held likely in several quarters.

"The unexpected financial recovery of Great Britain has dealt a fatal blow to the French financial hegemony," in the opinion of Dr. Paul Einzig, foreign editor of The Financial News and of The Banker in London, whose Book, "Finance and Politics," has been published recently by the Macmillan Company.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Several luncheons were given at the Beach Club today. Mrs. Eugene Pitou entertained at the club for Mrs. Hudson Budd, Mrs. Starr Tyson, Mrs. Kirkwood Edmund Jewett and Kirkwood Edmund Jewett Jr. Others who had guests at luncheon were Mr. and Mrs. L. Gordon Hamersley and Mrs. George Crawford.

Signs of improvement in business and the recent continued advance in stock prices were attributed to the widespread popular belief that Governor Roosevelt will be the next President by Democratic leaders who gathered here yesterday for conferences with James A. Farley, national chairman.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 8 (AP) -- The State rested its case against Captain W.N. Lancaster today at the close of a hysterical session in which Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller told intimate details of her love for Lancaster and young Haden Clarke, the man Lancaster is accused of slaying.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- Chancellor von Papen today summoned all members of the German Cabinet to meet here tomorrow morning to pass on the anti-terrorism decree, which then will be issued. The decree is already worked out and needs only President von Hindenburg's signature.

Seventy-five thousand persons would be restored to employment if scrap iron and steel companies received banking credits for $15,000,000, according to messages sent yesterday by Benjamin Schwartz, director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, to Charles A. Miller, president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and to Eugene Meyer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Prime Minister MacDonald is still in Ireland. Whether he flew there to bring the six counties of Ulster back under the British Parliament and give President De Valera a republic of twenty-six counties or merely to rest in the Marquess of Londonderry's garden does not seem to concern London editors.
ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The futt text of Mayor Walker's surrebuttal in removal proceedings, as made public here today by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, follows:
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Announcement that Calvin Coolidge will take part in the campaign to re-elect Herbert Hoover was made tonight by Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

An excited advance In cotton precipitated yesterday one of the biggest demonstrations in stocks in three years, or since the climax of the bull market in 1929. Dealings on the Stock Exchange made up a total of 5,462,000 shares, while prices rose 2 to 9 points.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Shippers were good buyers of hogs today and the market generally was steady with Friday's. Shippers took about 22 per cent of the receipts, the broadest call in six weeks. Smaller packers had a hard time obtaining sufficient choice kinds.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, will arrive here Friday to review the students of the Citizens' Military Training Camp, with troops of the regular army also participating, it became known here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is amazing that in a world readily boastful of its knowledge there should exist so little real understanding. A modicum of perception respecting economics in general and international relationships in particular would go far toward righting our topsy-turvy conditions of today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Three naval officers were assigned today for additional duty as aides to the White House, the Navy Department announced. They were Lieutenant Donald R. Tallman, now attached to the Navy Intelligence Office; Lieutenant (junior grade) Harold C. Pound, Office Naval Communications, and Lieutenant (junior grade) Charles S. Weeks. Office Naval Communications.

General VON SCHLEICHER'S vigorous statement of the German case for equality of armaments in yesterday's TIMES stresses two main points. These are, first, the damage wrought to Germany's abstract rights, her reputation, and her self-esteem by the conditions of the peace treaties, and, second, the feeling of insecurity to which Germans are condemned as a disarmed nation surrounded by former enemies armed to the teeth.

TOKYO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- General Nobuyoshi Muto was installed today as Japan's supreme military and diplomatic representative in Manchuria, which means that the Foreign Office is definitely subordinated to the army in handling Japan's relations with the troublesome territory on the mainland.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Augustabernard shows a distinctive version of the lowered waistline in wide draped and bandaged effects tied at the side or in the front for dress wear. His sashes or fur belts are semi-fitted in his sport line. Front fullness is emphasized. In the back the peplum line curved by a tuck is interesting.

Consultation among signatory nations to mobilize "moral disapproval" of acts of aggression is implicit in the Briand-Kellogg treaty outlawing war, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State, declared last night in an address before the Council on Foreign Relations at its dinner at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- The trend of prices was upward on the Bourse today. The recovery in Wall Street continues to encourage trading here. A sharp rise in the London metal market today also influenced the Bourse favorably. All the leading international stocks, including Rio Tinto Copper, Royal Dutch Oil and Suez Canal rose sharply, but bank stocks and government bonds were rather more conservative.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 -- It became known today that Libby Holman Reynolds had been living in seclusion for several weeks at Oakington, estate of the late Commodore Leonard Richards, between Aberdeen and Havre de Grace, Md., on Chesapeake Bay.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8.-- Taking their cue from the United States track and field team, American swimmers and divers sent the Stars and Stripes up twice on the Olympic peristyle today as they carried off the women's 100-meter free style final and the men's 3-meter springboard championship in the Aquatic stadium before capacity crowds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Senator Claude A. Swanson and Representative Andrew J. Montague, two Virginia members of Congress, returning from, international meetings at Geneva, indicated today they did not expect any change in the situation regarding Europe's war debts to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- "The field of managerial discretion" among railroads was invaded again today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, which required as a condition to its approval of a three-year $99,200 loan to the Missouri Southern Railroad from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that the company agree not to pay its executives and officials more than $10,000 a year during the life of the loan.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 8 -- At a meeting here today to adjust factional differences, representatives of the Old Guard Democrats, headed by former Mayor David E. Fitzgerald of this city and Thomas J. Spellacy of Hartford, and of the New Guard, led by National Committeeman Archibald McNeil, agreed unanimously on the renomination of Governor Cross and on united support of Governor Roosevelt for the Presidency.

Mayor Walker's surrebuttal to the charges sponsored by Samuel Seabury -- the Mayor's last word in his own defense before the faces removal hearing Thursday at Albany -- was completed here yesterday afternoon and sent to Governor Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Lieut. Victor Point, French explorer, at the age of 30, won fame for leading the "China unit" of the Citroen-Haardt transAsiatic expedition.

The contemporary German prints from the collection of Erich Cohen of this city, which were placed on view yesterday at the Roerich Museum, provide a fair cross-section of the school. Thirteen artists have been chosen as representative. They are Max Liebermann, Kaethe Kollwitz, Max Slevogt, Lovis Corinth, Ernst Barlach, Will Jaeckel, Paul Kleinschmidt, Oskar Kokoschka, Georg Kolbe, Wilhelm Lehmbruck, Hans Meid, Ludwig Meidner and Hermann Struck.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Four young golfers, averaging less than 25 years of age, were among the five who qualified at the Jumping Brook Country Club today in the thirty-six hole test of the New Jersey section for the national professional golf championship.
F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War for Aviation, announced yesterday his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor, increasing the number of aspirants to six.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8 -- A baseball game between a team representing the Summer colony and a team of city officials will be one of the features of the ballyhoo to be given at Ker Arvor, the home of Colonel and Mrs. Snowden A. Fahnestock, on the afternoon and evening of Aug. 27 for the benefit of the Newport Country quota of the Rhode Island Children's Welfare Fund.

Cotton was the sensation of the markets yesterday. Rising almost $5 a bale in response to a crop estimate by the Department of Agriculture that was unexpectedly favorable, this staple accelerated a general advance in securities and commodities. On the New York Stock Exchange there was a turnover of 5,462,000 shares, the heaviest since May 5, 1930.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Aug. 8 (AP) -- The serial numbers of some bills deposited at the Bank of Nova Scotia in Albert, N.B., correspond with, those on ransom money paid in the Lindbergh kidnapping case but the plate numbers differ. Inspector John Bird of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, said tonight.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 8 -- Four men, instead of two, kidnapped him Friday night and held him for $30,000 ransom, John B. Colegrove of Taylorville told authorities today. The 67-year-old former banker is recuperating in a hospital here from the effects of lying bound in a weed patch for twenty-four hours a few miles north of Springfield, where his abductor's threw him.

Dispeller of blistering heats, a thought refreshing to body and soul blows from Connecticut. Arcadia is found; found where least it would have been looked for. Out of the hard-boiled has come the rare. Senator BINGHAM'S air of professorial superiority had almost passed into a legend when he associated himself with an element more important than air in the minds of many.

"Protesting as an ex-soldier, a writer and an American" against the "brutality" of the eviction of the bonus army, Sherwood Anderson, the novelist, of Marion, Va., will lead a delegation of American writers and editors, among them men with notable service records, to see President Hoover at the Whita House tomorrow.

State Senator William Lathrop Love of Brooklyn, the only Democartic Senator who voted in favor of continuing the Seabury investigation of New York City, failed to receive the approval of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee for renomination at a meeting of the district leaders in Brooklyn County headquarters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Three enlisted men of the navy were commended today for heroism above the call of duty. One of the men, William Henry Robinson of Wilmington, was commended for saving the lives of four men in a sinking boat near Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Without any predictions as to the probability of business recovery in the immediate future but feeling "very hopeful" over recent developments, Roy D. Chapin today took the oath of office as the ninth Secretary of Commerce, the second during the Hoover Administration.
The text of Secretary Stimson's address last night before the Council on Foreign Relations follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Bolivia was asked if she would agree to a cessation of hostilities in the Chaco at daybreak Wednesday, in a note dispatched late today by the committee of neutrals which has been exercising its good offices in that situation.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- William Ziegler Jr.'s Grand Time, which landed second back of Happy Gal in The Flash on the opening day here, captured the Saratoga Sales Stake, the feature this afternoon. The test was at five and one-half furlongs for 2-year-olds which were sold as yearlings by the Fasig-Tipton Company a year ago.

Harry F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, on his arrival here from California yesterday, confirmed reports that the protective committees of the Richfield Oil Company of California, which has been in receivership since January, 1931, have accepted Consolidated Oil's purchase offer of about $23,000,000, including cash and securities.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- To the great conglomeration of records they have already put into the books, the 1932 Olympic Games added one more tonight, when, for the first time in history, they brought the Big Three of Eastern football, Yale, Harvard and Princeton, into battle with the great triumvirate of the Pacific Coast, Southern California, California and Stanford.

A new type of railroad coach, double decked in interior design and capable of carrying forty-four more passengers than the ones now in use, will be placed on exhibition today by the Long Island Railroad in Pennsylvania Station and put into service next Saturday, George Le Boutillier, vice president of the road, announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 -- A project is under consideration by the Currency Committee of the Imperial Economic Conference for the establishment in London of a clearing house for trade balances designed to facilitate trade between member States of the British Empire and help stabilize empire exchanges.

Another clash occurred yesterday morning between the police and members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, now on strike for better working conditions, when 500 workers gathered in front of the Branch Trucking Company, Inc., at 308 Mercer Street, to protest against the shipment of unfinished clothing to out-of-town shops, where, the union asserts, the work is done by non-union workers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Two women were killed and six other persons were injured today in a collision of two automobiles on the New York-Trenton highway about five miles south of here. The accident was caused by the blowing out of a tire, according to the police.

Katherine Alexander has been engaged for the leading role in "Best Years." the Raymond Van Sickle play which Elizabeth Miele is producing in association with the Shuberts. Harvey Stephens, Jean Adair, Thomas Findlay, Leona Powers and Daniel Poole are other members of the cast, which went into rehearsal yesterday under the direction of Priestly Morrison.

Mayor Walker should resign immediately, both as a personal sacrifice to his party and as a legitimate protest against the unfairness and injustice of being forced to defend serious charges in an atmosphere that is bound to be political, former Mayor John F. Hylan declared in a statement yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- The United States took the lead in Olympic gymnastic competition today, scoring 103 points in the team exhibition of free exercises.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Republican wets and drys alike who have had personal contact with President Hoover in the last twertty-four hours expressed the belief today that he would interpret the resubmission plank of the party platform at the notification ceremony Thursday night entirely to their satisfaction.
