WENTWORTH, N.C., Aug. 8 -- Libby Holman Reynolds, garbed in the mourning attire of a widow, surrendered here this afternoon on an indictment charging murder of her husband, Z. Smith Reynolds, tobacco heir.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward H. Delafield gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Henry Suydam Satterlee and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A transcontinental trek of jobless World War veterans to a haven in Mexico was planned here tonight by Captaln Doak Carter, leader of a wing of the disbanded bonus army, upon, receipt of an offer from Charles P. Reiniger of Los Angeles to turn a tract of 15,000 acres over to the bonus marchers for colonization.

Through an indictment handed up by the grand jury at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon George D. Phelan, 39 years old, for twenty years a minor employe of J.S. Bache Co., brokers, at 42 Broadway, was revealed as the man who, more than two weeks ago, was placed under detention of private detectives in connection with a $695,000 shortage in the last thirteen years from the concern's $1.000,000 petty cash fund.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.-- James Francis Burke, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, died suddenly tonight in Garfield Hospital where he had been sent a short time before at the order of President Hoover's personal physician.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8 -- A considerable time must elapse before the Lake St. John Power and Paper Company, Ltd., can pay the interest on its first mortgage bonds, the National Trust Company, Ltd., has been informed as trustee, by the company. Interest on the company's bonds and debentures went unpaid on Aug. 1.

The 143d anniversary of the founding of the War Department, Aug. 7, 1789, when George Washington signed the Congressional act creating it, was celebrated yesterday at the reproduction of Federal Hall in Bryant Park, together with commemoration of the creation of the Northwest Territory.

Patrolman Henry Beard stood up in his police launch off the foot of Eighty-eighth Street at dawn yesterday, tried to pierce the Hudson's haze and sniffed experimentally the morning breeze on the river.

Ten years ago few British workingmen would have thought of using a week's holiday for a trip abroad. Last year, 16,000 of them went to the Continent, and for three or four years before that nearly as many. Before the Workers' Travel Association was organized, in 1922, such vacationists went to English seaside resorts.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Motorists and pedestrians about to cross the tracks of the Erie Railroad between here and West Arlington were startled today by the sound of a low rumbling and the sight of four freight cars speeding down the grade on the westbound track without an engine.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Senator Alben "W. Barkley, Democratic keynoter, fighting for a chance to be the first Kentuckian in thirty years to serve more than six years In the United States Senate,, increased his lead to more than two to one tonight as additional returns came in from Saturday's primary.

The program of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Albert Coates, which took place last night in the Lewisohn Stadium before a good-sized audience, included Mozart's overture to "The Marriage of Figaro," Schubert's sixth symphony, "La Valse," by Ravel, two passacaglias by Cyril Scott; the scherzo from Tchaikovsky's "Manfred" symphony, and Liszt's "Les Preludes."

Dr. James R. Angell, president of Yale University, and his bride, the former Mrs. Katherine C. Woodman, will sail tonight on the Leviathan of the United States Lines for a tour of Europe. Others booked to sail for Plymouth, Cherbourg and Bremen are Joseph H. Bagley, aide to Postmaster General Brown; Harvey S. Firestone and Mr. and Mrs. Russel Firestone and ninety-five Gold-Star Mothers.

An unexpected reduction in the estimate of this year's cotton crop, coupled with the news that arrangements are being made to relieve the Federal Farm Board of its holdings of that staple led yesterday to an advance that at one time reached $5 a bale on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Montauk's rod and reel fishermen are anxiously awaiting the catch of another broadbill. Swordfish have been sighted during the last few days and deep sea parties, forfeiting chances of getting some good tuna, are hoping that the ice will be broken some day this week.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Aug. 8 (AP) -- The discovery of fingerprints on articles in the home of Miss Jane Surget Merrill led to the placing of murder charges tonight against Richard H. Dana, 61 years old, and his housekeeper, Miss Octavia Dockery, 60, for the slaying of the 68-year-old wealthy recluse last Thursday night at her estate near here.

Sales of passenger automobiles and trucks to consumers in the United States in July by the General Motors Corporation amounted to 32,849 cars, compared with 56,987 in June and 85,054 in July, 1931, the corporation announced yesterday. Sales to dealers in the United States totaled 31,096 in July, against 46,148 in June and 78,723 in July last year.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Jupiter and Bissbi, United States and Swedish sloops, favorites in their divisions of the Olympic Games yachting, won their races today, after the Angelita, another Yankee craft, had clinched the championship in the eight-meter class.

State of Maine. The State of Maine has called for sealed tenders, to be opened at 10 A.M. tomorrow, on a new issue of $1,000,000 of highway and bridge bonds, bearing interest at the rate of 4 per cent and due on Aug. 1, 1951 to 1954.

A Horrid Plot. This hot and silly season is just the time for such gossip as that which surrounds Governor ROOSEVELT'S choice of next Thursday on which to hear Mayor WALKER in his own defense Thursday is not only Thursday; it is Aug. 11; and on Aug. 11, as every one should know by this time, the President is to deliver his speech of acceptance at Washington.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 8 -- A thunder squall which came over the Western horizon just at starting time caused the race for smaller boats, the second under Eastern Yacht Club colors in race week, to be postponed today, and the calm that followed the wind prevented sailing it later.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The Hoover Administration's method of negotiating the St. Lawrence Treaty was criticized today by Delos M. Cosgrove, vice chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, who told the Institute of Politics that although New York's interests are profoundly affected by the treaty "yet the representatives of the State were uninformed as to the terms of the treaty until they were printed in the newspapers."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Aug. 3 shows increases for the week of $352,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $296,000,000 in government deposits and $24,000,000, in time deposits, and decreases of $69,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $26,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Greta Garbo of the films came back to Sweden today and demonstrated that the aloofness for which she was celebrated in Hollywood was not meant for American consumption alone but applied also to her fellow-Swedes.

A plan for the elimination of competitive wastes among railroads east of the Mississippi River and north of the Potomac will be submitted at a meeting of the Eastern presidents' conference on Thursday. It has been prepared by a committee appointed by L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company and chairman of the conference.

Complaints that some dealers in securities were taking advantage of the present stock market boom to unload worthless securities, resulted yesterday in five raiding squads from the State Bureau of Securities, visiting five brokerage firms in the financial district.

COBOURG, Ont., Aug. 8 -- The Cayuga, owned by John Van Voorhis of Rochester, N.Y., today was declared the winner of the 160-mile Freeman Cup yacht race from Rochester to Cobourg. Her corrected time was announced as 20 hours 33 minutes 10 seconds.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8. -- President Ortiz Rubio this evening named Primo Michel, a lawyer, Minister of Industry and Commerce, filling the place resigned by General Abelardo Rodriquez. General Rodriquez has been nominated for the Ministry of War and Marine, succeeding Plutarco Elias Calles, who resigned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- National gold stocks increased $55,000,000 in July to a total of $3,973,677,808 at the end of the month, the Treasury Department announced today. Stocks were $975,000,000 lower than a year earlier as the result of raids against the dollar abroad and the drawing down of foreign balances in this country.

Domestic corporation bonds, notably industrial and railroad issues, led yesterday a brisk upward movement on the Stock Exchange in one of the most active markets of the year. Utility bonds, too, were strong, but since this group had not suffered so much as the other two, its actual gains were smaller by comparison.

The second and final volume of Leon Trotsky's history of the Russian Revolution is being prepared by Simon Schuster for publication in October. A possibility exists, however, that because of the great mass of material to be included, this volume may have to be split.

Railway executives will meet this week to consider a plan for Federal aid in purchasing new equipment. Doubtless some carriers have need of it. Orders for rolling stock placed last year were the smallest on record, including only 235 locomotives (compared with 926 in 1929), 10,880 freight cars (compared with 82,240) and actually only 11 passenger cars (compared with 1,254).

A tragic story of starvation and exhaustion in the Ecuadorean jungles while seeking new ore deposits and medical herbs, and of the death of his companion after their canoe had upset, was told yesterday by Harold Foard, 29-year-old chemist, of Braimwell, W. Va., who returned on the grace liner Santa Clara.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 8 -- William D. Roddy, who served for sixteen years as a first-grade detective attached to Brooklyn Police Headquarters and who was one of the best-known men in the New York Police Department, was appointed Chief of Police of this resort today by Mayor Frank Frankel on the recommendation of Police Commissioner Mulrooney and former Police Commissioner George V. McLaughlin of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The stock markets opened with a burst of strength today influenced by the upswing Saturday in New York. There was increased interest in American securities, and reports of the formation of a pool to strengthen the American commodity markets had a stimulating effect here.

Twice in the last seventeen months Coast Guard crews have brought or their heads the public maledictions of John Bendiksen, fighting skipper of Brooklyn. In February, 1931, Bendiksen complained that they had ruthlessly drilled holes in the compartments of his fishing schooner Good Luck, and last December he charged that a boarding crew had caused damage to the rail of his vessel in what he said were useless searches for liquor in both instances.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Slipshod work afield cost the Indians their first defeat in their last seven starts today, Washington scoring a 7 to 6 victory on only five hits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Joseph P. Tumulty, Secretary to Woodrow Wilson during the eleven years Mr. Wilson was Governor of New Jersey, and President of the United States, expressed unqualified praise for the debt cancellation proposals of Senator Borah and Alfred E. Smith in a letter written to the editor of The Newark Evening News, made public here today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Shaun Kelly Jr. was master of the hunt and his father was the hare in a paper chase held this afternoon at Glen Crannie, the Kelly estate in Richmond. Among others who rode were Mrs, John Drexel Jr., Miss Anne B. Clark of Princeton, N.J., who is a guest of Miss Aileen Kelly; Sydney Smith and Thomas Stevens.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 (AP) --Within the next few days all of Germany's outstanding political leaders will be in Berlin to participate in negotiations which will determine what part Adolf Hitler, leader of the National Socialist party, will play in the government that is to be presented to the Reichstag late this month.

The creation by New York banks of an organization tentatively called the Commodities Credit Corporation, with capital that may reach $100,000,000, as the core of a far-reaching campaign, inspired and directed by Eugene Meyer, for breaking the depression through a direct attack upon the deflation of raw material prices is nearing completion and is expected to be announced within a few days.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 -- The answer of the British delegation at the Imperial Economic Conference to the Canadian proposals for new trade agreements between the Dominion and the United Kingdom was handed to Prime Minister R.B. Bennett today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statements of Dr. Schurz, discussed editorially by THE TIMES, and the supplemental letter of Horatio Rubens, about the effect of our sugar duty upon the business of Cuba, and, reactivety, upon our own prosperity, are important and ought to open up a discussion of all sides of the Cuban sugar question.

The money market was listless, and despite the supply of funds business was small and quotations unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 per cent, outside trades at 1 and Federals at 1/8. Time money was quoted at 1 1/4@1 1/2, but little was taken outside of routine commitments.

Mayor Walker said last night at City Hall that he was willing to give up as much as 20 per cent of his $40,000 yearly salary if other high-ranking officers of the city would agree to the same reduction.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture's cotton forecast today was nearly 1,000,000 bales less than most private estimates had been.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- Opposition by Governor Roosevelt to stabilization activities of the Federal Farm Board was indicated today when the Democratic Presidential candidate conferred with a group pf cooperative farm leaders.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 -- By winning two races and finishing second in another, the Cold Spring Harbor Beach's crew jumped into the lead at the end of the first day of the fourth annual invitation junior series for the Commodore Robert Law Cup.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Dixiana Stable's Cee Tee scored a neck victory over Impish today in the Hinsdale Purse to account for a second straight race at Hawthorne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Washington Board of Trade today extended to President Hoover' "the heartiest commendation for his prompt action in preventing serious disorders by dispersing the several thousand invaders of the community when their riotous behavior placed them beyond the control of the civil authorities and endangered lives and property of our citizens, as well as the peace and safety of the nation's capital."

A petition by Harvey H. Boyce of Jericho, L.I., president of the MotoMeter Gauge and Equipment Corporation, for a two-year suspension, on the monthly alimony of $1,000 which he pays to his wife, Mrs. Margaret Boyce of Great Neck, L.I., was denied yesterday by Justice Hallinan in Queens Supreme Court.

Despite the military exposition in Bryant Park being called illegal yesterday by Walter R. Herrick, Park Commissioner of Manhattan, who suggested that the police were supposed to arrest those guilty of violating the City Charter, Company A of the Sixteenth Infantry, fifty in number, were holding their ground.

Negotiations between the Publishers Association of New York City and the scale conference committee of Typographical Union 6 having ended in a deadlock on the question of wage-scale arbitration, the publishers' committee anounced yesterday that all further dealings in the matter will be conducted henceforth exclusively with the officials of the International Typographical Union and its president, Charles P. Howard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your edition of Aug. 4, under the caption "Fight Organized on Marriage Clerk," published an announcement of the organization of a club for the avowed purpose of leading a fight on the local Democratic organization in the Twenty-second Assembly District of Manhattan.

Secretary STIMSON'S address before the Council on Foreign Relations last evening had but a single subject. This is the Briand-Kellogg treaty renouncing war. The Secretary of State showed, in a brief historical review, what profound changes it has necessarily wrought in the law of nations.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Gus Matuza of the Hempstead Country Club won the Long Island caddie championship at the Sound Shore Golf Club today by the margin of a single stroke. A field of 126 competed.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Winning four individual titles, Sweden today held the Greco-Roman wrestling championship of the 1932 Olympic Games.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday reached phenomenal proportions, considering the season. The total turnover was 5,462,000 shares, which made the largest volume for any day since Oct. 10, 1930. The pace of the trading was the most spectacular feature of the day.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- Ten world record performances which marked the Olympic track and field championships were stamped with official approval today and put on the books by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. Eight were credited to Americans, one each to Japan and Great Britain.
SHANGHAI -- The growth of Communism in China seems likely to be one of the most important movements in the next decade in that war-torn country, and possibly one of its great hopes of unity.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Grand opera with a galaxy of world-famous stars, a huge chorus, ballet, orchestra and stage band and a herd of elephants, camels and horses will be offered Chicago for the first time on such a scale when the Chicago Grand Opera Company presents Verdi's "Aida" at Soldier Field on Aug. 28.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- A cotton crop of only 11,306,000 bales was forecast by the Department of Agriculture today, based on conditions as of Aug. 1. This would be 5,790,000 bales less than last year's crop, and 3,352,000 less than the average for the last five years.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 -- The Chamber of Deputies passed a resolution today asking the Finance Minister to submit all information in the possession of the national government regarding the effects on the republic's foreign bonds of the province of Santa Fe's declaration of a moratorium, whether the country's credit abroad has been affected and what measures are possible to overcome ill effects, if any.

The man with the hoe is no longer an object of pity --" a thing that never hopes." With a job in hand he bridges the gulf which the poet imagined between him and the seraphim. Whether his garden industry is by hoe or plow, by spade or rake, he can fight his way back to salvation against the flaming sword.

Walter Lowenfels, who shared with E.E. Cummings the Richard Aldington Poetry Prize for 1931 and who announced last May that a theatrical company was being organized to produce his play called "U.S.A. With Music," filed suit yesterday in Federal court against the producers and authors of "Of Thee I Sing,' Pulitzer Prize play.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 -- The Soviet Union was not reverting to capitalism, not even to a "neo-NEP" in the sense of a New Economic Policy implying large private business or the employment of others for private profit. This was categorically asserted by L.M. Kaganovich, one of Joseph Stalin's closest henchmen and a member of the Communist Political Bureau, at a plenary session of the Moscow Province branch of the Communist party.

ASBURY PARK,. N.J., Aug. 8 -- While scores of persons disported on the cool beach nearby, more than a hundred contract-bridge devotees spent a sweltering afternoon at their favorite pastime in the municipal convention hall today as the American Bridge League opened its fourth annual Summer championship.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Secretary Stlmson's pronouncement on the implications of the Briand-Kellogg Pact is printed textually in The London Times tonight. Editorially, The Times says the declaration marks a real step forward in the organization of world peace and materially improves the prospects of the disarmament conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. (AP) -- The Phillies' pennant hopes received another jolt today when they dropped two games to the St. Louis Cardinals for their fourth successive defeat. The world's champions won the opener, 7 to 6, and then took the nightcap, 6 to 4 in eleven innings.

An appraisal of the estate of Wylie Blount Miller Jameson, antique dealer, disclosed yesterday that his 11-year-old son, Wylie, of Memphis, Tenn., inherited the residuary estate of $74,314 of the total net estate of $97,314. If the son had predeceased his father the residue would have gone equally to Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Gene Tunney.

Two 17-year-old girls who stowed away three weeks ago on board the Anchor liner Tuscania returned today in the same vessel after seeing Scotland from the upper window of a detention house in Glasgow, where they had to spend five days while the steamship was in port.

PENNSAUKEN, N.J., Aug. 8 (AP) -- The camping of thirty-five bonus marchers, including the wife and four children of one veteran, on the grounds of the Sixth Ward Republican Club "along Pennsauken Creek was protested by citizens tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The refusal of the New York firemen to accept a reduction in pay calls attention to the fact that New York is among the few cities which have not reduced the salaries of their employes in this period, when every one's income has been reduced.

The Hamburg-American Line announced yesterday that C.C. Wardlow had resigned as assistant passenger traffic manager, to follow his former chief, Emil Lederer, to the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, where Mr. Lederer now holds the post of sole arbiter.

The United States, by virtue of its large internal market, as contrasted with England and other nations, is in a better position to regain economic stability and to accomplish this end sooner than any other country, in the opinion of Patrick Duncan, Member of the Parliament of the Union of South Africa, who is visiting America as the guest of the Carnegie Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Hopes of home-owners that they may receive direct relief from pressing responsibilities were encouraged today when the Federal Home Loan Bank Board formally came into existence, although the absence of two of the five members caused the deferring of the initial formal meeting until tomorrow.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- Vionnet makes no startling changes in silhouette or skirt length, but abandons dull or pastel tones for pronounced colors -- rust browns, orange and mustard yellow for daytime wear and raspberry red for day and evening, some being trimmed with brown.

The taxicab presents an intensifying municipal problem. The American Mercury has an article this month on "The Taxi Runs Amuck"; the more staid American City discusses taxicab regulation from the viewpoint, not altogether dispassionate, of the street railroad man.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 9 (AP). -- As Senator Hattie W. Caraway slept soundly tonight, after the arduous campaign of the last week, returns from today's Democratic primary showed her far ahead in her race against six male opponents for renomination.

The Presidential election this year will be won not by transcontinental appeals to the nation but rather by intense political campaigning among independent voters in pivotal districts, Colonel E.M. House, confidant and adviser to President Wilson, writes in the September Cosmopolitan.
PARIS, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Market operators here seem agreed that the advances in Wall Street have been too rapid and that a reaction is bound to come.

TORONTO, Aug. 9. -- The defending champion, C. Ross (Sandy) Somerrille, advanced into the second round of the Canadian amateur golf tournament by downing Frank Corrigan, young Ottawan, 7 and 6, in a dramatic battle today.

GRAND ISLE, La., Aug. 9. -- The scrubwoman of the Middle West, who pointed the nose of her skiff down the Mississippi River and rowed away from civilization, has cast her lot here with the descendants of the pirate Jean Lafitte -- and she likes it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Two Federal agencies pushed ahead today with the specific aims of lifting the weight of economic depression from the shoulders of home owners and farmers.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Governor Roosevelt reiterated in a telephone conversation with a London newspaper editor today that "questions of politics do not enter into the Walker hearing."

Iowa, native State of President Hoover, which usually goes Republican by 100,000, will be carried this year by Roosevelt and Garner, it was predicted yesterday by Charles D. Huston, Democratic State chairman, and Richard F. Mitchell, national committeeman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. - The Interstate Commerce Commission reaffirmed today a previous denial of the request of the Cairo, Truman Southern Railroad Company for a loan of $75,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to discharge an indebtedness to a proprietor concern, the Tchudy Lumber Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Department store sales showed a decline from June to July of somewhat more than the estimated seasonal amount, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Although forced from the box in the ninth, "General" Alvin Crowder lasted long enough today to outpitch Mel Harder and give Washington a 4-to-2 victory over Cleveland.

After the recent sustained advance on the Stock Exchange, yesterday's pause occasioned no surprise. The market did not, as a matter of fact, lose any ground to speak of, but it did cancel all of its earlier gains and ended the day at just about the same level at which it closed the afternoon before.

Passengers due to sail tonight on her maiden voyage to Europe of the new United States liner Manhattan, for the Channel ports, include Henry P. Fletcher, former United States Ambassador to Italy; Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Dollar and Mr. and Mrs. H.J. Wigham.

OXFORD, England, Aug. 9. -- Recommendations designed to obtain world-wide recognition of a divorce decree granted by a competent court of any civilized country were unanimously adopted at the conference of the International Law Association here today.

The Central Savings Bank, plaintiff in a foreclosure action against Xceland, Inc., yesterday acquired On a $600,000 bid the Iceland Skating Rink, structure at 239-41 West Fifty-second Street and 242-64 West Fifty-third Street and two four-story buildings at 261-63 West Fifty-second Street, surrounding the Guild Theatre.

HAVANA, Aug. 9. -- A petition for the release of Dr. Pedro Herrera Sotolongo, a noted oppositionist lawyer, was presented to President Machado today by the editors of all the leading Havana Spanish-language newspapers and press associations.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The Eastern Yacht Club had 269 starters in its race today, the third of the midsummer series, and lacked only two boats of equaling the club record established here a year ago. A moderate southerly breeze, which shifted to southeast during the afternoon, sent the yachts over their courses in fast time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Dr. Stanley M. Rinehart, husband of Mary Roberts Rinehart, the novelist, who was seriously ill in Utica for more than a week, returned this morning to his home here, accompanied by his family. He stood the trip "exceedingly well," according to Dr. Roy S. Adams, his physician.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Gratification in Europe and irritation in Japan over Secretary Stimson's speech on the Kellogg-Briand pact in New York last night were both regarded with equanimity at the State Department today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Gymnastic experts of the United States and Hungary captured Olympic honors today in the Indian club, horizontal bar and pommel horse events.

Jean Acme Le Roy, credited with having made possible the first motion picture machine, and whose failure to obtain a patent for it cost him untold wealth, died a comparatively poor man in his little three-room apartment at 345 East Seventeenth Street yesterday morning at the age of 78.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- To insure greater immediate employment in Federal aid highway construction, the Bureau of Public Roads has agreed to the use or emergency highway funds supplied by the relief act on road projects for which contracts already have been let.

Although an absence of property sales continued to reflect the mid-Summer dullness of the Manhattan realty market, an encouraging activity in residential leases was indicated in reports received from brokers and papers filed in the Register's office yesterday.

The smallest cotton crop since 1923 is forecast in the August report of the Department of Agriculture. The estimate is 11,306,000 bales, compared with 17,096,000 last year. This is a reduction of slightly more than a third from the bumper crop dumped into the market in 1931, to the consternation of the Farm Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Senator Hebert of Rhode Island read parts of President Hoover's acceptance speech today, particularly the section dealing with prohibition, and as an avowed wet pronounced it good.

LUCERNE-IN-QUEBEC, Aug. 9. -- An imperial golf tournament for British Empire delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference is being organized and will be held at the Seigniory Club, Lucerne-in-Quebec, this weekend.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- A war to the finish against racketeers who have been trying to "muscle in" on the old Scotch game with pari-mutuel machines and lotteries was declared by the Professional Golfers' Association of America today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass, Aug. 9 -- The imperialism shown by members of the League of Nations, with especial mention made of Japan's recent action in Manchuria, was regarded by several speakers at the Institute of Politics today as being the cause for an increase in Communist activity in China.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's Seven Veils, ably ridden by Wayne Wright, conquered a field of six today in the Gateway Purse at Hawthorne.

The bond market was irregular on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but this did not prevent the averages of the various classifications of domestic corporation issues and foreign loans from making substantial gains. Trading was somewhat less active than at Monday's session, which was one of the busiest of the year.

Declaring that the 1933 budget must be at least $100,000,000 less than the current city budget if the city expects taxpayers to provide the money, the Citizens Union urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to seek new laws empowering it to fix all salaries of city-paid employes; to effect a flat saying of $40,000,000 next year on salaries and to take other economy steps.

From the Summer session of me Colleges of Political Augurs prophecies of curious radiance are to be expected. Before the campaign begins it is as easy as lying to tell how it is sure to end. Whoever has studied the vaticinations of these quadrennial Merlins finds an essential harmony in their methods.

Financing for the Jetter Brewing Company, Inc., of Omaha, Neb., in anticipation of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment or modification of the Volstead act, will he undertaken soon by a banking group headed by Harris, Ayres Co., which has taken an option on 600,000 shares of capital stock of the company.

Prompt action by States and cities to map out programs for the use of Federal funds for model housing, made possible through the $2,000,000,000 emergency relief measure passed by Congress, was urged yesterday by Robert D. Kohn, president of the Construction League of the United States and member of the committee on the economics of site planning and housing of the American Institute of Architects.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Flashing a strong attack in the latter half of the contest, the Burnt Mills polo team routed Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes, 14 to 4, today at the Meadow Brook Club in the final match of the Wheatley Cups tournament, the club's annual nine-goal event.

GENEVA, Aug. 9. -- League of Nations circles find Secretary Stimson's Interpretation of the Briand-Kellogg pact very welcome, especially at a time when undeclared war is going on in South America and Asia, with the former apparently nearing a head and the latter likely to reach another grave crisis in five or six weeks.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday involved 3,738,000 shares, compared with 5,462,000 shares on the day before. The market was irregular at the opening, but it advanced sharply in the first half hour. There was a period of irregularity in the late forenoon, followed by a spell of weakness in the afternoon that left the general list lower on the day.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals made it three straight over the Phillles by pounding out an 18-to-13 victory in a battle of booming base hits today.

Offerings to Bankers. Active bidding is expected today for approximately $7,060,000 of new issues of State and municipal bonds. The major issues are $3.076,000 for Maryland. $1,676,000 for Mount Vernon, N.Y., and $1,000,000 for Maine.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9. -- Cooperation of the Bank of England with, the central banks of the Dominions for the stabilization of empire exchanges and the raising of commodity values will be a leading recommendation of the monetary committee of the Imperial Economic Conference, it was believed here today, with the completion of a report by a sub-committee of the committee which is expected to be made public tomorrow.
Warm in their praise of the French defenders of the Davis Cup, but confident of a reversal next year, the American challengers came home yesterday aboard the Olympic.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States for the week ended last Saturday was 2,171,900 barrels, compared with 2,137,500 barrels for the preceding week, a gain of 34,400 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Of the total area involved in the Coney Island fire on July 13, only 4 per cent was of fire-resistive construction, it was revealed in a report of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters made public yesterday. The report estimated the property damage at between $3,000,000 and $5,000,000, with an insurance loss of about $2,000,000.

MADRID, Aug. 10 (AP). -- An armed attack on the Ministry of War, described in conflicting reports as a Communist assault and a movement of Rightist elements against the government, in which parts of the army were involved, began here early this morning.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Courtland D. Barnes, Courtland D. Barnes Jr. and Charles Tracy Barnes, who have been at Nonesuch House, Manhasset, L.I., since Spring, will sail today on the Manhattan for England.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- When the new liner Manhattan, with Captain George Fried in command, casts off her moorings and starts down the bay from New York tomorrow on her maiden voyage across the Atlantic, she will fly the coveted Merchant Marine Naval Reserve pennant, the Navy Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Admiral Richard H. Leigh, commander of the Battle Force, will relieve Admiral Frank H. Schofield tomorrow as commander-in-chief of the United States Fleet with his flagship, the Pennsylvania. Admiral Schofield has been on duty afloat since June, 1929, and has been ordered to the Navy Department as a member of the General Board.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (Canadian Press Cable). -- Coming from behind, Somersetshire scored a meritorious victory over Essex by the narrow margin of one wicket in a county cricket match concluded today. Nottinghamshire defeated Lancashire by 124 runs and Sussex won on the first innings from Kent.

MONCTON, N.B., Aug. 9. -- Acting on orders from the State Department, Henry Lee Walsh, United States Consul here, tonight forwarded to Washington a full description of the $90 in American currency turned in at the branch of the Bank of Nova Scotia at Albert, N.B., on Aug. 4 by Miss Carrie L. Anderson, Hampton, Va., a nurse, who is spending her vacation at the home of her sister there.

The new United States liner Washington, sister ship of the Manhattan, will be launched at Camden, N.J., Aug. 20 at 5:41 P.M., and will be christened by Mrs. T.V. O'Connor, wife of the chairman of the United States Shipping Board, it was announced yesterday by P.V.G. Mitchell, vice president of the United States Lines.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- The working of a naval instrument that enabled gunners aboard a battleship to identify the splashes of their own shells in crowded battle waters was described today before the United States commission hearing claims of British war inventors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having just returned from an unofficial and quiet observation of the British Empire Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa, may I point out a few facts which have not been emphasized in the news dispatches?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Meeting here tonight in a gathering said to be the largest and most harmonious Democratic gathering in more than ten years, the Westchester Democratic Committee unanimously endorsed Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, a resident of Purchase, for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

A letter calling for the election of State Senators and Assemblymen opposed to Governor Roosevelt's suggested repeal of the annual mandatory appropriation of $375,000 for premiums for county and town fairs was sent yesterday to officers and friends of these fairs throughout the State by Oscar W. Ehrhorn as President of the New York State Association of County Agricultural Societies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Through the medium of the fingerprint, the Department of Justice is developing an international clearing house for the identification of criminals.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 9. -- John Wanamaker Jr., formerly of Philadelphia, New York and Newport, R.I., grandson of John Wanamaker the merchant, obtained a divorce here today from Pauline Disston Wanamaker on ground of desertion, and half an hour later married Elizabeth Peltz Warburton, formerly of Philadelphia.

BAYSIDE, L.I., Aug. 9. -- With a low gross tally of 72, John J. Loftus of Hillcrest topped a field of seventy-five golfers and won the one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association over the links of the Old Belleclaire Golf Club today.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- The Boerse continued dull today. With the public taking no interest in either stocks or bonds, prices declined gradually, but in only a few instances more than 1 per cent. The uncertain political situation, especially the question whether the Nazis will enter the Cabinet, forestalls any improvement.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Frank Parker, Milwaukee's rising young tennis star, continued today to make a show of his opposition in the National Junior Championships, advancing to the quarter-finals with another love victory.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- While incessant discussion goes on in England concerning the British debt to the United States, little is being said these days about the war debts the dominions owe the mother country.

LYNN, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Representative William P. Connery Jr. of Lynn denounced the failure to pay the soldiers' bonus immediately and dubbed the National Economy League the "new-born favorite child of big business" in a luncheon address to the Lynn Kiwanis Club here today.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Plans for an "educational" campaign to advise business interests and communities of the State and nation of "the facts" in connection with the proposed improvement of the St. Lawrence River were outlined today at a meeting of the executive committee of the New York Waterways Association.

Irregularity marked the course of prices In the wholesale markets yesterday. The reaction was a sequel to the brisk upturn of the last week. Grains, cotton, provisions, rubber, hides and silk were easier, but coffee and sugar showed improvement, dairy products also showing strength. Other articles were unchanged.

However well Democratic leaders reporting to National Chairman FARLEY may think of their chances for success in November, there is no lack of local hope among New York Republicans. The consent of F. TRUBEE DAVISON to stand for the nomination for Governor if his name is put forward by the Nassau County Committee adds another to the list of the willing.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Dr. Theodore J. Grayson, dean of the Wharton School of Finance of the University of Pennsylvania, told the Rotary Club here today that humanity was on the verge of better times.

The first of three performances of the Albertina Rasch Cancers at the Lewisohn Stadium took place last night after fanfares of advance publicity that would have taxed the combined efforts of Diaghileff, Reinhardt and Rimski-Korsakoff to fulfill. Theliet motif of this trumpeting seemed to be that the Rasch ensemble, dancing largely to the music of Dimitri Tiomkin, Mme. Rasch's husband, and evolved the Great American Ballet, with emphasis upon "American."

The east side subway line between Brooklyn Bridge and Canal Street became a cavern of stifling yellow smoke at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, temporarily trapping more than 2,000 persons, after a power cable at Reade Street had been short circuited and set afire.

The probability that former Governor Charles S. Whitman would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator was reported yesterday. Mr. Whitman had luncheon with W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, and the matter was discussed.

The American Power and Light Company reports for the twelve months ended on June 30 a net income of $12,639,394, equal after preferred dividends to $1.15 a share on 3,013,813 common shares outstanding on June 30, against $15,739,536, or $2.48 a share, on 2,954,790 common shares the year before.

Mayor WALKKR'S demand that Governor ROOSEVELT sit as a trial judge tomorrow mistakes the whole nature of the proceeding. He complains bitterly that ha was not allowed to have counsel before the Hofstadter committee who could object to every question and cross examine witnesses till the cows came home.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9. -- After ten years the Soviet has revived the death penalty for theft -- theft of any kind of property, in transit by rail or water, especially the property of cooperatives and collective farms.
How many women are interested in trout fishing?

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an educator engaged also as a practicing engineer, I was interested in your summary of "A survey to determine what sort of college man achieves financial success ten years after graduating," as found from studies made at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 9. -- Bobby Pearce of Australia, world's single sculls champion, successfully stood off the challenge of Bill Miller of Philadelphia today as the Olympic rowing regatta program was launched in the Marine Stadium before a crowd of 10,000 spectators.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Aug. 9. -- Capturing a third straight Olympic six-meter title for the Scandinavian countries, the Swedish yacht Bissbi, under the hand of Tore Holm, today sailed to victory over Ted Conant's American Gallant, covering the ten-mile course in 2 hours 31 minutes 35 seconds.

A British, point of view regarding some outstanding events and figures in American history is given by A. G. Bradley, English historian, in his book "Colonial Americans in Exile," just published by E.F. Dutton Co. Inc. The "Boston tea party," he asserts, was the work of "Boston hooligans," John Hancock is referred to as that "prince of smugglers," and Thomas Jefferson is said to have been "obsessed by an anti-British craze."
COMMERCIAL PAPER yesterday -- 2 1/4 per rent for the best names. Monday -- 2 1/4 per cent for thE best names. ThE quotations are for three-four months paper.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Members of the Tuesday Bridge Club were guests at luncheon of Mrs. William Cox. The guests included Mrs. Paul Salembier, Mrs. Henry Dater, Mrs. William Leslie, Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop, Mrs. Frederic Bonner, Mrs. Frederick K. Hollister, Mrs. Carl Wolff, Mrs. Robert Appleton and Mrs. George Ethridge.
With preparations for his defenss completed, Mayor Walker plans to leave New York today for Albany, where he will face a public hearing in removal proceedings before Governor Roosevelt tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9. -- Prime Minister Bennett of Canada and Stanley Baldwin, head of the British delegation to the imperial economic conference here, are having a conference by themselves tonight at the Chateau Laurier in an attempt to bridge the wide chasm between their respective programs for tariff and trade agreements.

A New York business man or woman feels for taxi money at the approach, of a thunderstorm. Nervousness, headaches and fears are no longer the appropriate reaction. Nobody thinks of diving into featherbeds or huddling in cellars. In most large cities people go on about their ordinary business when clouds gather menacingly, merely turning on the lights and complaining of the humidity.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Promptly at 6 o'clock this evening Vincent Astor's large, white Nourmahal came to anchor in Hempstead Harbor. A gun boomed from her forward deck and the rendezvous for the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise was established.

After a twenty-eight hours' search by more than 200 detectives and uniformed police had failed last night to disclose any trace of 4-year-old Florence Markowaky, who disappeared early Monday evening from her home at 416 Junius Street. Brooklyn, police officials said they were of the opinion the child had been kidnapped.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9. -- Favorites, with one exception, pounded their way to victories today in opening bouts of the five-day program that will determine the 1932 Olympic boxing champions.

The August cooperative show at the Midtown Gallery, 559 Fifth Avenue, is both, varied and large. Some thirty oils, fifteen watercolors and thirty-five black-and-whites, by almost as many artists, make inclusive comment impossible.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- With prices slightly off in Wall Street today, London traders were snatching their profits and taking to cover, although general confidence appeared maintained in the soundness of the movement toward American recovery.

After six weeks of postponement and delay Isadore Gastanaga, Spanish heavyweight, and Charley Retzlaff, gangling Duluth (Minn.) fighter, fought their scheduled ten-round bout last night before about 3.000 persons at the Queensboro Stadium in exactly 2 minutes 43 seconds.

Flags bearing a huge red apple on a field of white floated from the staffs over the main entrances to the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. This is the non-political banner of a world-wide trade group, the International Apple Association, which has members in twenty-one countries from the Pacific Coast eastward to Finland and Egypt and from Canada to South America and Australia, New Zealand and Tasmania.

The Fall hat opening for 1932, with ensemble effects, sponsored, by the Retail Millinery Association of America, was staged in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night. Several hundred buyers and retail millinery merchants from various sections of the country were included in the large assembly which enthusiastically applauded the new hat creations for Fall.

Headed by Sherwood Anderson, a "Writers' Expeditionary Force" will leave for Washington this morning to challenge President Hoover to defend in his acceptance speech his ordered expulsion by Federal troops of the unemployed veterans from the national capital and to declare whether he intends to pursue during the remainder of his term, and if re-elected, his policy of "rule of starving men and women by militaiy force."

The General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders, of which Samuel Seabury is chief counsel, made public yesterday a report characterizing as "wholly inadequate" the information given to holders of the $4,500,000 bonds issued by S.W. Straus Co., covering the Squibb Building at 745 Fifth Avenue, regarding a plan for reorganization of the property.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- There are many in France who find Secretary Stimson's speech yesterday "admirable and illuminating as indicating an evolution of American opinion and the beginning of a new epoch in human history. There are others, and they also are many, who regard it as ideology and lawyers' hairsplitting.

The charge that both the State Legislature and Governor Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for the Presidency, had neglected their duty in failing to obtain legislation to abolish the seven-day week for thousands of workers in New York State was made yesterday by Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor. Mr. Waldman declared that the Socialist party advocated a six-hour day and a five-day week for all workers as a solution of the unemployment problem.

UNCLE HENRY McDANIEL, trainer of the Joseph D. Widener Stable and probably the dean of the big-time training corps of the turf, was leaning on the outside rail on the backstretch of the main track at Saratoga, stopwatch in hand. It was about the hour when "jocund day stands tiptoe on the misty mountain-tops." Horsemen get up early.

TUCKAHOE, N.T., Aug. 9. -- Miss Marion Fisher played twelve of the eighteen holes of her home club in par and turned in a card of 83 -- 1 -- 82 to annex the low gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Oak Ridge Golf Club today.
ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Governor Roosevelt asserted today that his decision on the case of Mayor Walker would have no effect on the national political situation, no matter what ruling he may make.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The invitation tennis tournament of the Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club got under way today. Among the leading players to advance were Jake Hess of Waco, Texas., ranked fourth in the tourney, and three seeded New Yorkers -- Jerry Lang, Percy L. Kynaston and Herbert Bowman.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Mrs. Norman Newman of Montclair, N.J., and Charles S. Lochridge of New York won the national contract bridge championship for mixed pairs this afternoon at the fourth annual Summer tournament of the American Bridge League, which is being held in the municipal convention hall on the Boardwalk here.

The special advice that President OSBORN of the museum gives out of his half-century of experience is that "breadth is the useful threshold for depth." His own activities began in the older, broader school and continued in the modern and more intensive one.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Sam Fink and Sam Gedden combined their efforts for a no-hit, no-run game as the Rugby Post of Brooklyn beat the East Side Post team, 8-0, today at the Municipal Stadium to capture the Southern New York State Junior American Legion baseball championship.

Members of the Publishers' Association of New York City, whose negotiations for a new wage scale agreement with Typographical Union 6 resulted in a deadlock last Saturday, were puzzled yesterday at the failure of Charles P. Howard, president of the international Typographical Union, to arrive in this city for a continuance of the negotiations.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 9. -- Libby Holman Reynolds, who surrendered at Wentworth yesterday under an indictment charging the murder of her husband and was released on 25,000 bond, sped away from Reidsville in a closed car early this morning, accompanied by her brother, Alfred Holman Jr., and an unidentified friend, after she had submitted to having her fingerprints taken by an expert from the Winston-Salem Police Department.

State Senator William Lathrop Love, the only Democratic Senator who voted in favor of continuing the Seabury investigation of New York City, defied the Kings County Democratic organization yesterday to refuse to redesignate him. Senator Love said that the issue of his redesignation was directly up to John H. McCooey, county leader, and he urged Mr. McCooey to "cut out the camouflage and get down to brass tacks."

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Aug. 9. -- Progress toward better packing of Alaskan salmon is sought through a newly invented skinning machine now being tried out by W.F. Schlothan, president of the Beegle Packing Company and of the Northern Machine Works.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Detroit made it three In a row over the Boston Red Sox by winning both ends of a double-header today, 5 to 2 and 9 to 7.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Two more seeded players were defeated today in the second round of the Eastern grass court lawn tennis championships on the courts of the Westchester Country Club.

Too many former Dodgers in the Cincinnati line-up spoiled the day for the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Reds finally winning in the tenth inning, 9 to 8, after Dan Howley had inserted eighteen of his twenty-three players into the game.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 9. -- In the four races on the program at the Grand Circuit opening this afternoon, favorites were defeated in all but one and, in that event, the 3-year-old pace, Harry Brusie, driving Calumet Calling, knew he was in the race with Mat D. in all three heats.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Victorious in his fight to retain his seat in the United States Senate, Alben W. Barkley, keynoter at the recent Democratic National Convention, received a pledge of support late today from his chief opponent in last Saturday's primary, former Senator George B. Martin.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9. -- Babe Ruth bounced a ball on the right-field pavilion roof with two on bases in the sixth inning today, thereby supplying what Vernon Gomez needed to consumate his nineteenth victory of the season. The Babe's homer knocked across the last three runs of the 5-to-3 score by which, the Yanks took their third straight from the Browns and their ninth victory in fifteen games played on the current trip.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 9. -- Led by T.V. Soong, the Finance Minister, all eleven members of the Cabinet resigned today.

The City Budget Commission an nounced after its regular weekly meeting at its headquarters, 350 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon that it would have ready for publication after Labor Day its entire program of municipal economies for recommendation to the city administration.

PEIPING, Wednesday, Aug. 10. -- Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang resigned again yesterday as commander In North China, but only after all the members of the Nanking Cabinet had given up their posts in protest against his alleged policy of compromise and non-resistance against Japanese aggression.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Hogs were in good demand today and prices were steady to strong, some sales being 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. An advance of 1 to 2 cents a pound in fresh pork loins in the last two days has made prices 10 to 13 cents for desirable weights, the highest since July 15.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, appeared yesterday before Federal Judge John M. Woolsey and asked a ruling on his plan to force landlords by threat of padlock to reveal the identity of tenants whom the government has been unable to serve with complaints in actions to close their establishments for violation of the prohibition law.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- A number of small dinner parties tonight preceded the performance of "Caprice" at the Casino Theatre by a cast headed by Violet Heming and Frederic Worlock. Among those entertaining were Mrs. Moses Taylor, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. William Goadby Loew, Mrs. Walter B. James, Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss and Mrs. Elisha Dyer.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the first bridge tournament in a series tonight at the clubhouse of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Many dinners were held before the contests.
A large quantity of cotton changed hands on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices ranged over limits of 30 points, ending 4 to 6 points lower than on Monday.

Several hundred employers in the men's clothing industry have agreed to the terms of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and are waiting to sign contracts with the union, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated.

Urging a further curtailment of crude oil production, Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute, in a letter to the membership, expressed the opinion that if producers in the United States would bring their output down to 2,000,000 barrels daily, properly distributed among districts, and hold it there, the situation would be improved.

Benny Leonard, who retired as undefeated world's lightweight champion seven years ago, is scheduled tonight to undertake one of the most serious ring assignments of his career as a comeback with designs on the world's welterweight crown. The local ring favorite is to battle Paulie Walker of Trenton, N.J., in the main event of ten rounds at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 8 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- A move directed by Eugene Meyer to assure banking credit for virtually all basic commodities has made progress described as satisfactory to the Federal Reserve Board's governor.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's all-star lacrosse team, led by Jack Worth of Hamilton, Ont., came from behind today and evened at one game each the Olympic demonstration series with Johns Hopkins College. United States representative.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 9 (AP). -- A denial that he threatened "to get rid" of Haden Clarke after learning the writer had succeeded him in the affections of Mrs. J.M. Keith-Miller was made today by Captain W.N. Lancaster, on trial for the killing of Clarke.

Gene Tunney, retired heavyweight champion, and Frank Hedley, president of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, played identical roles in two different subway trains affected by the Reade Street fire yesterday.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, national chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, appealed at a meeting tonight under the auspices of the Berkshire County branch for support of the movement to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment and to restore to the States the power to regulate the manufacture, sale and transportation of intoxicating beverages.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity has dropped to 18.5 for the week ended Aug. 6 from 21.3 for the preceding week and 42.7 for the corresponding week last year. Nevertheless, improved sentiment in the steel industry is reported from Pittsburgh, and last week's decline in operations is thought to have been for the purpose of providing for more economical operations later in the month by allowing orders to accumulate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Bulls in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade here took a breathing spell today and, with profit-taking by smaller operators who recently had been aggressive on the buying side, the market reacted as much as 2 1/4 cents a bushel from yesterday's closing prices.

Silver, crowded into an obscure market position, by the recent rise in other commodities, emerged yesterday with a rally of a full cent an ounce in the New York spot market. On the National Metal Exchange, where trading was the heaviest for a day in ten months, the advances ranged from 60 to 101 points on future contracts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Committee of Fourteen is on the point of collapse and will have to end a long record of effective public service unless $3,500 in further public support is promptly forthcoming.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9. -- Breaking a record in all four events, the markshattering proclivities of the 1932 Olympians were continued in the swimming today as the only two titles to be decided went to the faroff countries of Japan and Australia.

Two men attempted to hold up Benjamin Hersh, 48 years old, a collector for the John Hancock Insurance Company, as he was descending the stairway in a tenement at 328 West 113th Street yesterday afternoon. Hersh had leas than $100 in collections on him, but he refused to hand it over.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Hoover today rewarded the two prosecutors who put Al Capona behind the bars. Blocked by inaction of the Senate in rewarding the judge who sentenced the gangster to Atlanta, the President elevated George E.Q. Johnson, Federal District Attorney who worked up the case, to a Federal judgeship and promoted his chief assistant.

The positions of 144 draftsmen in the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance of the Board of Education were abolished yesterday by resolution of the board at a special meeting devoted largely to routine business. The step was taken, the resolution said, "inasmuch as the planning of new school buildings has practically ceased for lack of funds to carry out the same."

The presidents of the Eastern railroads will confer here tomorrow on proposals to reduce further the wages of unionized employes. It is understood a similar move is pending in the West. The reason for these actions is the steady decline in revenues, which have been insufficient in the cases of some of the largest roads to meet interest charges.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Evening Star, only London afternoon newspaper that commented today on Secretary of State Stimson's pronouncement on American foreign policy, said editorially that his speech in New York last night should mark a definite advance in the organization of world peace and stimulate disarmament.

Rewards and Punishments. Of Senator LOVE of the Eighth District, Kings County, the only Democratic Senator who voted to continue the Seabury investigation, the Citizens Union said in its latest report on the city's legislators: "Was courageous and outspoken in his views on city affairs and refused to subordinate his convictions to organization mandates.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Evening Star, only London afternoon newspaper that commented today on Secretary of State Stimson's pronouncement on American foreign policy, said editorially that his speech in New York last night should mark a definite advance in the organization of world peace and stimulate disarmament.

Rewards and Punishments. Of Senator LOVE of the Eighth District, Kings County, the only Democratic Senator who voted to continue the Seabury investigation, the Citizens Union said in its latest report on the city's legislators: "Was courageous and outspoken in his views on city affairs and refused to subordinate his convictions to organization mandates.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Twenty-seven contract bridge teams of four began the five-day struggle for the city of Asbury Park challenge trophy at the American Bridge League's Summer tournament in the convention hall here this afternoon, and tonight the cream of the country's bridge experts, all past and present holders of championships, began trying for the gold cup emblematic of the masters' pair championship.

Sources of economies in the city's expenditures that are being investigated by the Citizens' Budget Commission and which go far beyond the voluntary salary reduction plan proposed by Mayor Walker were outlined yesterday by Peter Grimm, chairman of its board of trustees, and Harold Riegelman, counsel to the commission, at a luncheon of the Penn Zone Property Owners' Association at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

RIO DE JANERIO, Aug. 10 -- General Goes Monteiro, commander-in-chief of the government forces on the eastern front, reported by radio today that the Federal troops had captured a large area from the rebel forces and that his army was continuing its advance westward without opposition.

Buffalo rallied for four runs in the ninth inning to set back Jersey City, 7 to 6, in the opening contest of a four-game series at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. Ollie Tucker of the Bisons and Lafayette (Fresco) Thompson of the home club hit home runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The assets of the banks under the Jurisdiction of the Federal Farm Loan Board, the Federal Land Banks, the Joint Stock Land Banks and the Intermediate Credit Banks amounted to $2,084,148,567 on June 30, according to the quarterly condition statement issued today.

The summons calling Mayor Walker before Governor Roosevelt for a hearing on removal charges was the first of the kind ever served upon an incumbent or City Hall. Nor has any Mayor of New York ever been removed by the Governor, although others have been made the object of charges.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 10 -- A message from Irumu, in the Belgian Congo, states that the Belgian expedition to Ruwenzori has succeeded in climbing the summit of the highest peak entirely in Belgian territory. The peak, hitherto never scaled, rises 5,100 meters (16,732 feet) on Mount Stanley to the northwest of Point Margherita at the limit of Belgian territory.

With the opening of an international campaign to sell an unlimited amount of Soviet Russian gold bonds redeemable on demand in the currencies of the countries in which they are marketed, it has bcome apparent to banking interests here that a far-reaching change in the relations between this country and Russia is taking place and that this foreshadows the eventual recognition of the Soviet regime by the United States Government.

Keen competition characterized the sale yesterday of a new issue of $1,000,000 State of Maine 4 per cent highway and bridge bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1932, and due from 1951 to 1954, at a price of 102.179, the highest of seven tenders submitted. It was made by a group headed by the Guaranty Company of New York and included the Bankers Trust Company and the Shawmut Corporation of Boston.

Three major appointments at Democratic national headquarters were announced yesterday. Evans Woollen, Indianapolis banker, was made chairman of the finance committee; former Governor Harry F. Byrd of Virginia chairman of the executive committee of the finance committee, and Daniel J. Tobin, former treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, was appointed chairman of the labor committee.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- Establishing some kind of a record by not listing a knockout in twenty-seven battles over the two day and night period so far, the world's leading boxers waded through another set of preliminaries in their drive today for Olympic championships.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The dressage, first event of the Olympic equestrian sports, was won today by Commandant Francois Lesage of France and his beautiful black gelding, Taine, winner of the international dressage of Geneva last year.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The market was heavy again today during a slack session of the Bourse. The belief persists here that the bullish market in New York cannot last. The metal market's failure to maintain the gains made in London and the pound sterling's weakness affected trading unfavorably here.

Orders Mainly for Initial Needs. Reports on the Fall business placed thus far in most department store lines indicate that in few cases has more than initial buying been done. The average of the orders placed on apparel and major accessories, it was estimated, will carry stores until about the third week of September, and beyond this date only in a comparatively few items having a slower turnover rate.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Racing into port here with an ugly squall behind them and their white sails framed in a wall of black, the craft of the New York Yacht Club tonight finished the first day's run of their annual cruise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The heroism of two navy men who demonstrated bravery far beyond the call of duty when the U.S.S. Memphis was sinking off Santo Domingo on Aug. 29, 1916, was officially recognized by the Navy Department today in an announcement that the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest award, would soon be conferred upon Commander Claud A. Jones, then a Lieutenant, and Machinst Charles H. Willey, since retired.

Influential members of the Association of Railway Executives indicated yesterday that they would give serious consideration to the proposal by the Federal Administration that the railroads borrow from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in order to put men at work repairing equipment.

Governor Roosevelt, writing in this week's Liberty, says watered stocks, unsound foreign loans and fake investments have been unloaded on the American public without protest from the National Administration.

In its letter to the Board of Estimate, the Citizens Union sets up a target big enough for all civic marksmen to aim at: a reduction of $100,000,000 in the budget for 1933. It is a large sum. But if every penny of it were actually left unappropriated, the city would still be spending more than it did four years ago.

The New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, is to receive $500 and the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital, 350 Lafayette Street, will get $200 from the estate of Theresa H. Kann, who died suddenly on July 30. Her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mayor Walker's proposal for a voluntary pay cut among municipal employes has been overwhelmingly defeated by the firemen, as it well deserved to be. I believe that the firemen as well as a great many other city employes would gladly cooperate in an economy program if it were put forward in an intelligent manner.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- Acceptance of twenty-eight men's world's swimmings records and thirty-five for women, including the sixteen for Miss Helene Madison of Seattle, was announced today by Dr. Leo Donath, president of the International Swimming Association.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 10 -- Ignoring the opposition of Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, to the erection of a jetty to prevent the erosion of the southeastern end of Oak Island, Beach, the town board here today voted to build a jetty of double piles to extend 200 feet beyond the ocean front in the vicinity of cottages, which were threatened with inundation during a storm last week.

The scheduled matinee of Chamberlain Brown's "Scrapbook" at the Ambassador Theatre yesterday was abruptly canceled after the audience had assembled for the performance. An announcement was made from the stage that there would be no showing, and several hundred dollars, it was reported, were refunded at the box-office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Shipping Board, which was reduced from seven members to three by the economy act, completed reorganization of its administrative bureaus today, and its business will be transacted in four bureaus and two offices as follows:

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- Enjoying a complete day of triumph in the swimming competition, the United States marched off with two Olympic titles today. Before a combined crowd of 19,000, Clarence (Buster) Crabbe won the 400-meter free-style crown in a pulsating sprint finish and Miss Georgia Coleman captured the 3-meter springboard diving laurels.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10 -- Francis Hartman Markoe gave a large reception this afternoon at his home here, where the paintings of two young American artists, Thomas Baker and Sterling Blazey, are on exhibition. Receiving with Mr. Markoe and the artists were Mrs. George Barton French, Mrs. Courtland T. Nicoll, Miss Rachel Hartley, Mrs. Howard Nott Potter and Miss Margaret Wheelwright.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Installation of the last of five stained-glass windows in the choir of the Princeton University Chapel, which are the work of Charles Jay Connick, noted artificer of Boston, Mass., and recipient of the honorary degree of Master of Fine Arts at the Princeton University commencement last June, has been completed.

The New York Stock Exchange will introduce on Monday a plan that will reduce clerical work and calculations by abolishing the quoting of premiums on security loans in fractions and establishing round figures instead. The result will be exactly the same on average, and smoother functioning of the "loan crowd" is expected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank board will designate the locations of branch banks only after the board's policies have been established, Chairman Franklin W. Fort announced tonight in an obvious effort to stop the flood of communications from cities requesting that branch banks be located in them.

Taking a double-header from the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday proved a difficult but not insurmountable task for Max Carey's Dodgers. They won the opener, 6 to 1, behind the excellent pitching of Van Mungo, in the regulation nine innings.

Four-year-old Florence Markowski, missing since Monday night from her home at 416 Junius Street, Brooklyn, was found yesterday noon by four detectives in a room at the Commodore Hotel, where she had been taken by a neighbor, Miss Rita Levine, who said she had kidnapped the child because Florence's mother had "too many children."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 10 -- Acting in an "emergency," officials of the United Mine Workers and the Illinois Coal Operators' Association today signed a wage agreement for a $5 basic wage to become effective at midnight. The conferees then issued a statement predicting that 25,000 Illinois miners would be back at work Monday.

The new 24,000-ton liner Manhattan, the largest steamship ever built in this country, sailed last night for Europe on her maiden voyage amid the shouts of 10,000 enthusiastic New Yorkers gathered at Pier 61, North River, he pier and the vessel were lighted with powerful army arclights, wihch were used to make motion pictures as the throng of visitors went up the gangways.

Ever since April, 1931, when the republic was proclaimed in Spain, there have been sporadic outbreaks of violence in different parts of the country, the three central points being Madrid, Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, and Seville.

The reason why scientists are not always good prophets in worldly affairs is that there is nearly always a point, sometimes discernible, sometimes imperceptible, where they forget science and become mere human beings. The engineer unconsciously sheds his charts and his differentials and succumbs to his beliefs or his prejudices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Hoover hurriedly put the finishing touches today to the speech with which he will accept again the Republican nomination for President, while party leaders coming for the notification ceremonies gathered at the capital.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Detroit made it four in a row over Boston by winning the final game of the series with the Red Sox, 6 to 2, today. It was Boston's eleventh straight defeat.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Routing Lefty Claset and Walter Brown, Montreal's mound aces, Newark continued its drive for the International League pennant today when it took both ends of a doube-header from the Royals, 5-2 and 6-2, before 6,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bolivia and Paraguay are again at odds over the Chaco territory. This is the second time in four years that the Chaco controversy has brought the two South American nations to the verge of war. In December, 1928, Paraguayan forces took by surprise the Bolivian outpost Vanguardia, precisely when the first Pan-American conference on arbitration was convening in Washington.

DUBLIN, Aug. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Both victory and defeat were the luck of the de Valera Government in the Senate today. The upper house was considering its own amendments to a government measure, after they had been rejected by the Dail Eireann.

Professor SURETTE, lecturer on music at Harvard, would be especially pleased by a New York scrubwoman's confirmation of his rather rhapsodic account, in his book on "Music and Life," of the magic effect of the symphony. As you listen to it, he wrote, "you have lived a thousand lives * * * each moment being a complete existence."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- St. Louis bats produced a sudden barrage of hits in the eleventh inning today and the Cardinals scored their fourth straight victory over the Phil- lies. The count was 11 to 5.

The New York Stock Exchange governing committee approved yesterday the listing of 108,362 common shares of $5 par value of the Checker Cab Manufacturing Corporation upon official notice of issuance in exchange for shares of common stock of no par value now listed on the Exchange.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Final negotiations for the lease of a 30,000-acre tract of land in Mexico for colonization by war veterans were completed here today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 10 -- Pleas that the United States abandon its policy of isolation in world affairs were voiced at the Institute of Politics today by speakers who declared that a tragic economic and financial situation called for constructive action by our nation.

Plans for a model housing development in Queens to represent an investment of nearly $20,000,000 were announced yesterday by Samuel Rosoff, subway builder. Details of the large-scale low-rental apartment project were announced by Jacob I. Goodstein, attorney for Mr. Rosoff, after the filing of a description of the site for approval of the State Board of Housing.

OTTAWA, Aug. 10 -- The report of the monetary committee of the Imperial Economic Conference, which had been definitely promised for publication tonight, has been held up until Friday, and perhaps for even a longer period.

Manhattan's subway system was still operating at reduced efficiency during the evening rush hour last night, as a result of a short-circuited power cable and the subsequent series of mishaps to the I.R.T. east side line on Tuesday.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, acting yesterday on the petition of Samuel Untermyer for a review of the election of the Irving Trust Company as trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Company, handed down an opinion sustaining Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee, in his method of calling that election without delay on June 1.

HERKIMER, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman finished the first day of an up-State inspection trip on his arrival here tonight, after receiving assurances from Democratic leaders in four Republican counties en route that their followers would support his candidacy for Governor.
Dwelling deals comprised the bulk of the realty trading reported yesterday in the New Jersey metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Restrictions upon the army personnel to whom goods may be sold by post exchanges have been ordered by the War Department.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Charleigh, racing in the white-and-blue colors of William Schmidt of Chicago, won the Park Ridge Purse, top race at Hawthorne today, by a nose over C.B. Shaffer's Sweet Scent. Siskin, favored in the six-and-one-half-furlong event, finished third, three and one-half lengths back.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Captain W.N. Lancaster, on trial for the slaying of Haden Clarke, declared today that he did not, in jealous retribution, kill the man who replaced him in the affections of his former fiancee, Mrs. J.M. Keith-Miller.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- There is every likelihood tonight that within a few days Adolf Hitler will be the Chancellor of the German Republic. Thus the impossible of yesterday, in view of the attitude of the present government, has become the best bet of today.
