The principal charges against Mayor Walker, as sponsored by Samuel Seabury and embodied in a formal demand for removal signed by Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, were placed before the Governor in the form of fifteen allegations. In substance, these were:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Although leader after leader brought to President Hoover today prophecies of re-election, there were several among the veteran politicians who said they had warned the President that a Republican victory could not be accomplished without "a real fight."

In the face of general expectation of downward reaction, on "technical" grounds, if for no other reason, the share market continued yesterday to drive forward. The railway issues led the movement and the average of prices, even after a slight setback in the fourth hour, was sharply higher on the day, with some of the market leaders up as much as 6 or 8 points or more.

Calvin Coolidge, former President of the United States, did not choose yesterday to discuss either politics or the hay fever, which, according to information given out at the White House Tuesday, prevented him from hearing President Hoover's acceptance speech in Washington today.

A proposal that a committee of American shipping leaders be named to study conditions in shipping and recommend means to eliminate harmful and useless competition was made yesterday at a meeting of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 -- Holding his last political conference until after the hearing of the charges against Mayor Walker, Governor Roosevelt greeted an imposing group of Democratic leaders today and was informed that a campaign speech by former Governor Smith "would add a million votes for the Democratic ticket."

Accompanied by a substantial rise in bonds, the stock market was swept yesterday to the highest level of the month-old rally in the second heaviest trading of the year. A total of 4,430,000 shares changed hands and the net gains ran from 2 points or so in the more sedate stocks to 6 and 8 points in the more volatile ones.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- The text of the decree signed by President van Hindenburg yesterday, which provides severer penalties for political offenses involving violence than were previously permitted and which goes into effect immediately, is as follows:

An evening devoted entirely to the music of George Gershwin, a departure for the Stadium concerts, will be presented by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium next Tuesday. Mr. Gershwin has composed especially for this concert a Rumba, described as a symphonic overture, written for full orchestra augmented by native Cuban instruments.

Close bidding by six rival syndicates featured the award at noon yesterday of a new issue of $3,076,000 State of Maryland 4 1/2 per cent certificates of indebtedness, dated Aug. 15, 1932, and due serially from Aug. 15, 1935 to 1947. Award was made at a price of 105.6079 to a group headed by the Mercantile Trust Company of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Rube Walberg recorded his fourteenth victory of the season today by pitching and batting the Philadelphia Athletics to a 6-to-3 triumph over the White Sox. The victory gave the Athletics a two-to-one edge in the series.

Papers just recorded in the Register's office include three notices of surrender of leasehold contracts, one for a midtown building and two for upper west side properties. Several quitclaims also have been filed. The latest list of lease contract revisions and quitclaims follows:

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Lawn tennis fans gathered at the courts of the Westchester Country Club today to watch the visiting quartet of English players run through their matches in the first two rounds of the Eastern Grass Court championship tournament.

Governor ROOSEVELT informed an inquisitive London newspaper man that "questions of politics do not enter into it." He was referring to the Walker hearing today. Probably he had it in mind to discredit the reports about the important political consequences of his decision.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Two professionals, one of whom never had seen the course before, returned par rounds of 72 to lead 111 starters in the first round of the New Jersey open golf championship at the Jumping Brook Country Club today.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The French Foreign Office delivered its reply today to Ambassador Edge's memorandum of last week setting forth the United States Government's needs and desires regarding commercial relations with France. Although the contents of the reply have not been revealed, it is hinted in various quarters that the French negotiators are taking care to insure that there is a substantial return for any concession they may make.

Mayor Walker will face Governor Roosevelt today in the same room in which the Governor presided over the hearing which resulted in the removal of former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, the first major Tammany casualty of the Hofstadter Committee's investigation.

Prince Hadji Tahar, who says he will be 103 years old on Aug. 14, announced yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Astor that he has been commissioned by his first cousin, King Ibn Saud of Hedjaz and Nejd, to reconstruct an Oriental city at the world's fair in Chicago.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- THE NEW YORK TIMES learns that Soviet financiers are preparing to offer an attractive investment to foreigners. During the next few days a campaign will be launched from Moscow under the supervision of American financial experts to sell bonds of a Soviet internal loan on a gold ruble basis exclusively.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 -- Singles by Lazzeri and Chapman behind a pass to Gehrig in the eighth inning put over the run by which the Yankees completed a clean sweep of their four-game series with the Browns today, winning, 7 to 6, after the score had been tied three times.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney and her niece, Miss Gladys Szechenyi, will arrive today on the Bremen. They will join Mrs. Vanderbilt at Newport, R.I.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 10 -- The eight-oared crews of Italy and the United States went into the final round of the Olympic championships today after two of the most thrilling qualifying races on record in international competition.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- A Washington bicentennial fete, to be held tomorrow and Friday at the 100-year-old cottage at the gate of Rockledge, Summer home of Charles H. Tuttle of New York, on the Bolton road, is expected to be one of the most colorful events of the Lake George social season.

The importance of Federal regulation of all forms of transportation and the need of equality between the interests of agriculture and the railroads, leading to a return of prosperity, were stressed yesterday in a discussion of the effect of the transportation problem upon the fruit industry by speakers at the annual convention of the International Apple Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

To the Editor of The The New York Times: In the musical comedy "Of Thee I Sing," which received the Pulitzer Prize for the best play of 1932, we see the campaign manager for the Presidential candidate, John P. Wintergreen, inspired with the decision to make love the issue of the election.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Residents of this community planned this afternoon to fight efforts to alter the rural character of their community when they were informed that Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close had issued a writ of certiorari for a judicial review of the proceedings last Spring at which the Town Board of Harrison refused to allow the L.C.W. Corporation to build houses in Purchase on less than five-acre plots.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 10 -- David Tolin, Corporation Counsel for this city, recommended today that the Long Beach Boardwalk be deeded to the Long Island State Park Commission for public park purposes, with the hope that it would be developed as has been Jones Beach.

Attacking his accusers as "irresponsibles" trying to bear false witness against him, and with the cheers and scattered boos of 5,000 persons in Grand Central Terminal ringing in his ears, Mayor James J. Walker left for Albany yesterday to face removal charges before Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt today.
Prices rose sharply $2 a bale yesterday and closed 17 to 19 points higher than on Tuesday in the heaviest trading on the Cotton Exchange in several months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- How far a prohibition agent may go in inducing individuals to sell liquor so that an arrest may be effected will be decided by the Supreme Court when it passes on the question of "entrapment" some time next Winter.

An easier tone in commercial paper, with a drop in short-date, primename bills to 2 per cent, from 2 1/4, furnished the only development of interest in the money market. The downward revision had been foreshadowed by a shading of the 2 1/4 rate, until more general buying established 2 as the prevailing discount.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 10 -- Races in which 412 starters answered the gun were sailed today in one of the busiest week-day programs in a long time.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 10 (AP) -- The vote by which Senator Hattie W. Caraway was renominated in yesterday's Democratic primary reached landslide proportions tonight as returns were tabulated from all but about 400 precincts, mostly small and isolated.

The profits taken by the illicit liqour industry in the last twelve years are estimated at more than $17,000,000,000 by Malvern Hall Tillitt in his book, "The Price of Prohibition," published today by Harcourt, Brace Co. About ten years ago, in the early years of prohibition, Mr. Tillitt made his first survey of the effect of the Eighteenth Amendment as applied in the Volstead act and reached a favorable opinion of it.

With Miss Helen Jacobs heading the American list and Mrs. Elsie Goldsack Pittman of England leading the three seeded foreign entries, the draw for the forty-fifth annual national women's lawn tennis championship, which starts at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, on Monday, was announced yesterday.

MADRID, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Monarchist leaders of the army, who rose in rebellion today against the sixteen months' old republic of Spain, failed in an attempt to seize the principal government offices in Madrid after street fighting in which at least eight persons were killed.

Resuming the advance with enthusiasm and in the second most active market of the year to date, stocks moved yesterday into new high ground for the movement. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to 4,430,000 shares, compared with 3,837,710 shares on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A group of writers headed by Sherwood Anderson, the novelist, called at the White House today to protest to President Hoover against the use of troops two weeks ago to evict the bonus marchers, but Mr. Hoover was too busy to see them, as was Lawrence Richey, the President's confidential secretary.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Zombro Hanover, 2:00 1/2, bay pacer owned by H. Stacey Smith of Newark, was drawn in the 2:10 pace on the Grand Circuit card at Charter Oak Park today after winning the first heat and losing the second. Guy the Tramp, which had failed all season to win and was wagered in the field, took the second and fourth heats to annex the event.

Unfilled orders for steel on the books of the United States Steel Corporation on July 31 amounted to 1,966,302 tons, the smallest amount ever reported, but the decline from the end of June was only 68,466 tons, which was much less than had been expected in financial circles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- After persuasion by various Democratic leaders, including Senator Robinson of Akansas, Democratic Senatorial floor leader, Senator Swanson of Virginia accepted the chairmanship of the Democratic Senatorial campaign committee today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The bull movement in wheat on the Board of Trade here was resumed today after a pause of two days. Much to the surprise of Eastern and local professional traders and others who tried to reinstate recently sold-out lines, there was no material pressure on the market when they started to buy.
The statement made by Mayor Walker on his departure for Albany yesterday afternoon follows:

Paramount Publix Corporation began yesterday a nation-wide campaign looking toward better business in theatres with the start of a two-day program of entertainment and previews of new pictures for about fifty motion-picture critics and editors from leading newspapers of fifteen cities of the East and Middle West.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A widespread decline in prospects during July was revealed in the crop report issued this afternoon by the Department of Agriculture on the basis of conditions Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- An agreement among ship lines to maintain uniform rates for the period ending Aug. 31, 1932, as fixed by a two-thirds vote of the parties to the agreement on shipments of general cargo and coffee from Santos and Rio de Janeiro to New York and United States Gulf ports was approved today by the Shipping Board.

Eight bids for construction of the three incinerator plants authorized by the Board of Estimate were opened yesterday by Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Department of Sanitation. The plants, which will be built in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, are expected by Dr. Schroeder to enable the city to comply with the order of the United States Supreme Court forbidding the dumping of city garbage at sea after June 30, 1933.

Cardinal Francois Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, arrived in this city last night at 9:55 o'clock from Worcester, Mass., where he had been visiting Assumption College, which is under the direction of the Augustinian Fathers of the Assumption. He had stopped off there on his way from Montreal to New York.
The New York State Conservation Department has released additional data on the plan inaugurated last season by which pheasant eggs have been distributed to girls and boys living on farms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Federal officials are interested in reports from New York of efforts to stimulate commercial relations with Russia, although they say they know nothing of the plan.

Even Senator HEBERT, who has assured the President that he will carry New York and New England, has made no claims that Arkansas will go Republican. Mrs. HATTIE CARAWAY, who has won the Democratic Senatorial nomination in that State over a field of six men, will surely be elected in November.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Home runs by Berger and Schulmerich gave the Braves a 3-to-2 victory over the Pirates in the second game of a double-header today after the league leaders had broken a ten-game losing streak by winning the opener, 5 to 2.
SAN PEDRO, Cal., Aug. 10 -- The United States gave a new twist to Olympic sailboat history today, carrying off major honors in the yachting competition of the international games.

HARBIN, Aug. 10 -- Strong evidences of a vast military movement, largely of religious inspiration and aiming to wrest Outer Mongolia from Soviet control, were met by your correspondent while touring Barga and other far-western regions adjacent to the Manchurian-Mongolian border.

A last-minute legal effort to take the removal proceedings against Mayor Walker out of the hands of Governor Roosevelt failed yesterday afternoon when Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan in the Bronx denied a citizen's application for an order to prohibit the Governor from considering the Seabury charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Busy with a round of conferences throughout the morning, President Hoover was reminded this afternoon that today was his fifty-eighth birthday anniversary when a group of youngsters gatheared on the south lawn of the Executive Mansion singing "Happy Birthday, Dear President, Happy Birthday to You."

Although Governor Roosevelt has declared that he does not regard politics and the possible effect on his candidacy for President as a factor in the Walker case, members of Tammany and friends of Mayor Walker have made attempts to get close friends of the Governor to consider the political effect of the Mayor's removal from office, it was learned yesterday.

Sixty European players, engaged by Earl Carroll for the tenth edition of "Vanities," sailed for New York yesterday from Havre and Plymouth on the Champlain. In this foreign contingent are Will Fyffe, Andre Randall, Edwin Styles, Andre Renaud, Max Wall, Harry Wills, Bruno Salto and two units of dancing girls, the Helen Jackson and Sparks troupes.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Clarke, Toronto shortstop, pounded two home runs as the Maple Leafs took an eleven inning game from Baltimore today, 11 -- 9.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 10 -- Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, will fly to Washington tomorrow morning to attend President Hoover's notification ceremonies as the guest of President and Mrs. Hoover. She had planned originally to make the trip on a train leaving at midnight tonight.

With the organization of the Home Loan Bank board, the last of the various relief plans urged upon Congress by the President has become a reality. The first task will be to establish from eight to twelve regional banks in different sections of the country.
CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Illustrated with pen sketches of camp life. The Camp Dix News made its first appearance here today, with 100 per cent circulation among the C.M.T.C. student officers.
Tine New York Central Railroad had in June its greatest net loss for any month this year, it was shown yesterday. The loss was $3,068,025, making the net loss for the six months $11,051,149.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- President William Green of the American Federation of Labor, here today to attend the convention of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Beverage Dispensers International Alliance, declared that railroad employes who have been asked to accept a 15 per cent cut in wages should fight that cut to a finish.

The limestone facade of the International Music Hall, 6,000-seat theatre in Rockefeller Center, was "topped out" yesterday by Dickson Turnbull, subcontractors for the builder, John Lowry, Inc. About 22,300 cubic feet of Indiana limestone were used on the exterior of this major unit in the Rockefeller development.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To those Democrats who believe that, generally speaking, tariffs are economically wrong in principle and therefore cannot be right in practice it is a shock to find the Democratic nominee for President enunciate a tariff policy which a high priest in the temple of protection rightly pronounces "the very essence of the Republican protective doctrine."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Naval operating bases at Key West, New Orleans, Pearl Harbor and in the Panama Canal Zone were abolished in an order issued by Secretary Adams today and administrative duties will be concentrated at Norfolk, San Diego and San Francisco.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Mayor James J. Walker arrived in this city tonight prepared to face the crisis of his official life at a removal hearing before Governor Roosevelt at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 10 -- Libby Holman Reynolds and Albert (Ab) Walker, who were indicted last week by a Forsyth County grand jury on charges of murdering Smith Reynolds, husband of the former Broadway singer, were not indicted solely on evidence found by the grand jury in its examination of the testimony given at the coroner's inquest, it was learned today.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- British Government funds opened strong on the Stock Exchange today, the recovery being due to the favorable impression caused by the revenue figures. The rises, however, were not fully held. Otherwise the markets were subdued in early trading in sympathy with yesterday's recession, in Wall Street, but finished firmer on better news from New York in the afternoon.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10 -- C.P. Rogers, receiver for the closed New Jersey National Bank and Trust Company of this city, sent today notices to the 1,440 stockholders advising them that they had been assessed the full par value of their stock, $25 a share, or a total of $2,800,000, payable on or before Sept. 12.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday against 276 stockholders, including thirty-five former directors of the closed Bank of United States, for $6,365,075. The suit is to force those named to pay the $25 a share assessed against them by the State Banking Department.

The British at Los Angeles. A first glance at the Olympic box score, with Great Britain registering less than one-fifth as many points as the United States and, what is more striking, trailing Italy, Sweden, Finland, France and Germany, would seem to demonstrate England's decadence in the world of sport where she was once so pre-eminent.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The Kenner, first run in 1870 and one of the oldest 3-year-old stakes in the history of American racing, today fell to the speed and courage of the Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret, the result marking the first time that the Wheatley colors had finished in front in the race.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 10 -- Gene Sarazen, British and United States open champion, failed today to qualify for the National P. G.A. Championship to be held at St. Paul next mouth. Recently he had been offered automatic qualification, but declined the honor.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10 -- Another party has been added to the list in honor of Miss Adelaide Whitehouse, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse. This will be an evening picnic party at Black Point Farm by Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Norman the evening of Aug. 19, and one of the features will be a moving picture program.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 10 -- The toiling figures of Merle Lavoy and Andrew Taylor, winding their way up Muldrow Glacier to recover the body of Theodore Koven, were observed yesterday from an airplane which flew to Mount McKinley from here.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- Floyd Vaughan, young Pirate shortstop, "cracked" at a crucial moment in the tenth inning today and the result was a 3-to-2 victory for the Chicago Cubs that dropped the Pirates out of the National League lead for the first time since June 26.

FULTON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman visited two State hospitals and two State schools on the second day of his up-State Inspection trip and arrived here tonight convinced that the provision made by the State for Its wards had improved considerably since 1930.

The Full Value Realty Co., Inc., samuel Kaplan, president, gave to Samuel H. Bennett of Cos Cob, Conn., a mortgage for $7,000, due according to the bond at 6 per cent, on the northeast corner of Amsterdam Av. and 107th St., subject to a first mortgage for $63,000.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- If there was truth in reports that Commissioner K.M. Landis came to Pittsburgh today to investigate charges of gambling among the Chicago Cubs, the baseball czar kept his mission to himself.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Never easing his pace for a moment, Wilbur F. Coen Jr. registered the most outstanding upset of the Eastern grass-court tourney to date when he turned back Fred Perry of England on the Westchester Country Club courts today, and as a result deprived the tournament of its defending champion.

Fox Film interests, which were voted out of control of the Roxy Theatres Corporation last April when Class A stockholders took control of the board of directors as a result of the omission of their dividend, are to take part in the direction of the Roxy Theatre under a proposed contract approved yesterday by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey.

GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- League of Nations officials, on closer study of the recent statement by Secretary Stimson, have gained the impression that it will facilitate League action not only in the Manchurian conflict but in Latin America. Uncertainty about the Monroe Doctrine hitherto has interfered with Geneva-Washington peace collaboration in the Western world.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- Three Americans advanced and two others were eliminated as candidates for Olympic boxing crowns whittled down the field in the 1932 championships today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- In a speech accepting the renominatlon at the Republican party for the Presilency, President Hoover tonight turned his back on what four years ago he termed "a noble experiment" and declared virtually for an end of national prohibition.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Walter Stewart's able relief pitching today helped the St. Louis Browns to a 6-to-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the opening game of the series.

Class-room supervision in elementary schools throughout the country, instead of having been banished for ineffectiveness as is generally believed, faces a brighter outlook today than ever before, Professor Milo B. Hillegas of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in an address to Columbia University Summer session students at Teachers College.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The stock markets generally were strong and cheerful today, the continued rise in commodities exercising a favorable Influence. British Government funds were well supported and prices were better.

The dependence of business recovery upon the return of the purchasing power of farmers and growers, as well as the divorcing of government from business and the removal of international tariff barriers, were among the factors emphasized by economic experts and executives of the International Apple Association yesterday in discussion of economic subjects.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 11 -- The unexpected arrival here tonight of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, chairman of the National Economy League, and Hanford MacNider, former national commander of the American Legion, with the expected appearance in the morning of Walter W. Waters, commander of the bonus army, portends an excited session tomorrow of the convention of the Massachusetts department of the Legion.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 11 -- The powerful crews of Great Britain and Canada, beaten respectively by Italy and the United States yesterday, came back strongly in the repechage today to qualify for the final round of the Olympic eightoared championship in which they will row on Saturday with the two afore-mentioned shells.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Wesley Ferrell pitched himself into a tie with Lefty Gomez of the Yankees for the most games won this season by shutting out Detroit while the Indians scored three runs today.

State Senator William Lathrop Love of Brooklyn, the only Democratic Senator who voted for granting additional funds to continue the Seabury investigation of New York City affairs, was denied last night redesignation for the nomination to succeed himself.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Fire and floods, with heavy damage to buildings, crops and highways and injuries caused by lightning, accompanied widespread heavy thunder showers which swept most of New England today.

Towns, villages and rural districts in more than twenty counties in New York State are being substantially improved and beautified by "made work" projects instituted as part of the State's campaign against unemployment, it was said yesterday by Walter W. Pettit, executive director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, who made public an analysis of reports on the work being done in the various localities.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The half-way stage of the New Jersey open golf championship was reached at the Jumping Brook Country Club today with the defending titleholder, John Kinder of Green Brook, one stroke in the lead. Kinder had the low card of the second round, 71, to give him even par of 144 for the thirty-six holes played to date.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 11 -- Just what mission took Libby Holman Reynolds to the Pioneer Point estate of John J. Raskob, near Centreville, Md., no one seems to know.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 11 -- A curb on American branch plants in Canada, of which there are now more than 1,000, will be the consequence of a recommendation, reported to have been agreed upon today by a special committee of the Imperial Economic Conference dealing with the question of empire content, if this recommendation is approved by the conference and ratified subsequently by the govenments of the United Kingdom and the dominions.

Agreements have been reached for a merger of the national financial advertising agencies of Albert Frank Co. and Rudolph Guenther-Russell Law, Inc. Special meetings of stockholders of the companies will be called early in September to vote on the plan.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Aug. 11 -- Holland took the fourth and final Olympic yachting championship of the current games today by finishing the eleven-race monotype series with a point total of 87. France was second, Spain third, Germany fourth, Canada fifth and Great Britain sixth.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- Quartered in separate hotels within a block of each other, the rival groups headed by Mayor James J. Walker and Samuel Seabury held councils of war tonight In preparing for tomorrow's continuation of the removal hearing before Governor Roosevelt.

Buying orders on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday were the heaviest in several years. They came from both trade and speculative quarters and were in such volume that prices rose almost $2 a bale and contracts changed hands at 8 cents a pound for the first time since the government's report was issued in August of last year.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Germany is displeased with the World Court's verdict in the Memel case. No official comment is forthcoming, but that of the newspapers runs all one way.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Captain Bertil Sandstrom of Sweden, who had an unofficial ranking of second in the dressage, first event of the Olympic equestrian sports yesterday, violated a regulation of the contest, a jury of appeal ruled today.

The Spanish Republic in the sixteen months of its existence has met and overcome graver challenges, as the event has shown, than the twenty-four-hour monarchist uprising headed by General SANJURJO. The same Seville in which he managed to exercise control for a few hours has witnessed serious labor strikes inspired by the Communists, and at least one attempt by the picturesque aviator hero RAMON FRANCO, which gave cause for anxiety.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The presentation of "Carmen" by Mme. Marguerita Sylva in the OpenAir Theatre, Sherwood Forest, at Oakland, scheduled for next Saturday for unemployment relief, has been postponed until Saturday afternoon, Aug. 27, at 4:30 o'clock.
NEW YORK. Elliott Schenck gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Nathalie Laimbeer. Miss Thais Lawton and Mrs. Huntington Tappin.

BERLIN. Aug. 11 -- The plan to make Adolf Hitler the next German Chancellor, after progressing beautifully last night, struck a snag today. The name of the snag is von Hindenburg. The Americanized version of the situation as the Germans explain it would be: "The old man won't stand for it."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 11 (AP). -- Union miners dissatisfied with the new $5 basic wage scale negotiated by their district officials held a protest demonstration in front of one of the reopened shafts here today but dispersed quietly at the appearance of special police details.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Board of Trade's returns of Great Britain's foreign trade in July are as follows:

It is no disrespect to the President's speech of acceptance to say that the section about prohibition dwarfs the other parts. Upon it public attention and curiosity were focused in advance. Contradictory reports flew about in regard to what Mr. HOOVER would say or omit to say.

Money market was at a standstill, quotations for every class of accommodation being unchanged on a minimum of business that ran chiefly to routine requirements. Stock Exchange call loans, time money and business paper were all quiet.

An optimistic view of shipping conditions on the Pacific Coast was expressed by R. Stanley Dollar, president of the Dollar Line and of the United States Lines, before sailing on the new liner Manhattan Wednesday night for a brief visit abroad. Mr. Dollar spent only one day In New York, at his offices at 29 "Broadway and at those of the Roosevelt-I.M.M. Company, with which he is associated in operation of the United States Lines.

Joe Lizzio, who has a perpetual cold, was chairman; Frank and Joe Garriola, Tony Mondi and Mike Poperello were delegates yesterday at the boy bootblacks' convention on racketeering in the shadow of the Pennsylvania Railroad Station on the Thirty-third Street side, just west of Seventh Avenue.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Following up its pioneer ascent of Huascaran last month, the German Andean Expedition has conquered another peak, almost as high, in the same range and apparently not yet on the map.

ROME, Aug. 11 -- The recent sweeping changes in the Italian Cabinet were followed today by even more sweeping changes in the diplomatic service. In his new capacity as Minister of Foreign Affairs Premier Mussolini announced at a Cabinet council held this morning a vast movement affecting about thirty Italian diplomats.

Offering will be made soon of a new issue of $20,000,000 Public Service Company of Northern Illinois first-lien and refunding-mortgage 6 1/3 per cent five-year sinking-fund ponds, Series G, by the same banking group which recently marketed $18,000,000 Commonwealth Edison Company and $20,000,000 Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company bonds, both of which issues were quickly oversubscribed.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 11 -- A joint session of Congress, alter hearing in executive session a report from the Foreign Minister, approved on Aug. 6 the international policy of the government "in the form set forth in the President's address," it was revealed here today.

Albert W. Harris, chairman of the board of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago; his son, Norman W. Harris, vice president of N. W. Harris Co. of that city; Jay Frederick Reeve, a Chicago lawyer, and the "John Doe Detective Agency" were sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for $50,000 damages by James G. Clark, a former University of Wisconsin student.

Editorial comment in newspapers over the country on President Hoover's acceptance speech emphasized his declaration upon prohibition, although some mentioned the economic phases. Interpretation of his expression regarding the dry law varied from terming it the "death" of prohibition to acclaiming it as a "stand against repeal" to charging a "straddle" on the issue.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- The British cruiser Dane arrived from Bar Harbor, Me., this afternoon. Captain C.H. Knox-Little, commanding officer, and his staff were dinner guests of Captain Gilbert J. Rowcliff, U.S.N., commanding officer of the naval training station.
PARIS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11 -- The heavy debts incurred in the last fifty years by the farmers of Chile through the issuance of mortgage, bonds by the Mortgage Bank, which is considered Chile's basic credit institution, are the subject of the gravest public dispute the Socialist Government has had to face.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Miss Edith Newbold and her sister, Miss Alice R. Newbold of Philadelphia, who is passing the Summer with her, gave a buffet luncheon today at Shingletop, their place in the art village. Among their guests were:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11 -- Governor Ritchie and other State Democratic leaders were guests of Howard Bruce, Maryland national committeeman, tonight at a dinner at which James A. Farley, chairman of the national committee and Franklin D. Roosevelt's campaign manager, was the honor guest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Heavy reductions in resources, loans and discounts and deposit liabilities of national banks of the United States during the fiscal year ended on June 30, as well as a sharp reduction in the number of these institutions, were announced today by J.W. Pole, Controller of the Currency.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Newark's pace-setting Bears won a 5-4 decision from the Montreal Royals in an International League game tonight.

GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- The League of Nations Secretariat, which is temporarily under the direction of its highest German member, Albert Dufour-Feronce, as acting Secretary General, has Informed Germany that her action in regard to League dues is contrary to the rules and clearly unacceptable.

Two changes in the election law, which he said would help to get honest elections in New York City, were urged yesterday by Louis Waldman. Socialist candidate for Governor, in a letter to State Senator Cosmo A. Cilano, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Constitution and the Election Law.

Morton Colton Nichols, well known in society, committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself in the bathroom of a suite he had engaged two days before at the Hotel Pierre, 6 East Sixty-first Street. His body was discovered last night after a maid, who had been unable to get into the apartment all evening, notified the management.

Wisely chosen are the Democrats who have been put in charge of raising the campaign fund for Governor ROOSEVELT. The subscription blanks have been handed over to two of the outstanding citizens of the country, Mr. WOOLLEN of Indiana and former Governor BYRD of Virginia.

Summer students at Columbia University are receiving instruction from an authority on modern literature who has just told them that the fashion of cynicism among novelists is waning. LAWRENCE is dead, JOYCE and HEMINGWAY are outmoded, and ambitious young Americans had better take some one else for a model.

If the thousands of city and county employes receiving $1,500 or less a year are to be asked to waive 8 1-3 per cent of their pay in 1933, such institutions as Columbia University should waive the tax exemptions which keep "hundreds of millions of dollars" from the city's coffers, according to an editorial in today's issue of The Chief, the civil service weekly of which Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial is editor.

PARIS. Aug. 11 -- The Bourse today was unable to resist the wave of optimism inspired by Wall Street's recovery, and quotations rose appreciably. The rise in coppers on the London metal market and the collapse of the Spanish rebellion also favorably affected the market here and further encouraged trading.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. David Oliver Shoemaker of New York and East Hampton, who is known on the concert stage as Vanda Nomicos, will give a song recital at Guild Hall tomorrow evening. Her program will Include songs by Gretchaninoff, Tchaikovsky, Rimsky-Korsakoff and Rachmaninoff.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Progress of the C.M.T.C. students in the infantry course at Camp Dix during the first half of their training month will be observed and thirteen companies inspected tomorrow afternoon by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Army Corps.

Sentiment has little or nothing to do with the promotion of highranking officers of the navy, but when two Admirals are raised to the most important commands and look back to service together on a small auxiliary in Cuban waters during the war with Spain, they may properly take pride in the remembrance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Under cheerful skies and in the gracefully historic setting afforded by the White House and the gardens and green lawns of the south grounds, President and Mrs. Hoover this afternoon entertained Republican leaders gathered here for the party's notification ceremonies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 --The text of Mr. Hoover's address accepting his renomination for the Presidency follows:

When the directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company assemble on next Wednesday to take action on the dividend on the common stock they will make their decision on the basis of long-established policies rather than on that of current earnings and business volume, according to the understanding in Wall Street.

ALBANY, N.Y. Aug. 11 -- Amid the scenes of his youthful induction into a public career, Mayor Walker was an attraction for crowds today while Governor Roosevelt and Samuel Seabury, his chief accuser, went their ways, quietly and unobtrusively.

Among the prominent passengers departing tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen are William A. Harriman, banker; Edna Ferber, novelist; Senator Frederic C. Wolcott of Connecticut and the following:

From the outposts of the solar system come the Perseid meteors that streak across the northeastern sky tonight. Sweeping around the sun in a period of 108 days, the earth cuts their orbit each year in August -- the only reason why they are seen at all.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read your recent news article about the abuse of jury trials in the municipal court. The evil is rampant. It is no exaggeration to say that nine out of ten demands for juries are interposed solely for a delay and serve no good purpose.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 -- After a long conference with the Ministers of the Interior and Agriculture, President Ortiz Rubio has rejected the petition of Doak E. Carter that 29,000 United States veterans of the World War be allowed to find a sanctuary in Mexico and to establish a colony near the American border.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, in an address prepared for delivery today said that through strong organization the farmers could benefit by the recent advances in grain prices, gain economic independence and make Congress listen, to their pleas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- High administration leaders disclosed tonight that President Hoover -- in line with his acceptance speech statement that he was "today organizing the private industrial and financial resources of the country" for a fresh drive -- intended to call business men from all sections of the nation to the White House soon.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Sixteen contract bridge teams of four, including all the favorites, qualified today for the knock-out rounds in the annual competition for the City of Asbury Park challenge trophy, a feature event of the American Bridge League's annual Summer tournament here.
Some suprisingly good catches of weakfish were taken during last week by Peconic Bay fishermen and reports from New Suffolk, L.I., yesterday were reminiscent of those earlier in the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Following an increase of $38,000,000 in the weed ended on Aug. 3, money in circulation for the following seven days decreased $21,000,000 to a total of $5,707,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve System's statement of condition issued today.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Today is Constitution Day in Germany. On this day, thirteen years ago, the Constitution under which the Reich now rules itself was promulgated at Weimar and the republic, as it is at present, was proclaimed. So today the black, red and gold republican banner flies everywhere in Berlin, sometimes side by side with the defiant black, white and red flag of the old monarchy.

Mrs. Emma B. Kennedy, philanthrot and widow of John S. Kenndy, banker and railroad builder, gave about $9,000,000 of her net cate of $9,798,304 to fifty-three reous, educational and charitable institutions. This was disclosed yesterday when Deputy Tax Commissioner Stephenron filed an appraisal fixing the total value of the estate at $10,020,092.

With the stock market pausing to catch its breath after a fresh display of speculative enthusiasm in the morning, the financial focus shifted yesterday to bonds, in which the trading was the heaviest since Dec. 18 of last year, and in which the net gains ran from 1 to 12 points.

GREYSTONE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- With a score of 90, Mrs. George Kite Jr of Apawamis won the low gross prize in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association today at the Hudson River Country Club.

Jean Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris and Superior General of the Sulpician Order, declared yesterday that France was "resolutely pacifistic." He vigorously denied that the people of France were eager for war, and said that "we accept, we even appeal for, disarmament -- provided," he added, "that we are assured of security and of the respect of our rights as well as those of all the other peoples."

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The renewal of football rivalry with Williams and a game with Brown in Providence are the innovations on the 1933 football schedule of Princeton University. This schedule and the one for 1934 were announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

If the American farmer had a monopoly in world markets, wheat would be selling at a fancy figure. The August forecast of the Department of Agriculture estimates the total yield of both Spring and Winter wheat at 722,000,000 bushels. This is nearly 20 per cent below last year's production, and with one exception the smallest crop since the war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Production of crude petroleum in the United States in June amounted to 61,835,000 barrels, compared with 63,230,000 in May and 75,011,000 in June, 1931.

The Man of Few Words. Mr. COOLIDGE, during his visit here, as usual chattered like an oyster. It is the bussiness of newspapers to send their emissaries to him in the event he may have something to say.

Benny Leonard, who retired seven years ago as undefeated lightweight champion and is now fighting his way back along the fistic trail to a welterweight title match, last night hurdled the obstacle presented by rugged Paulie Walker of Trenton.

OVER in Flatbush, where the pennant flame is burning fiercely, the fans now refer to their favorite outfielder as Frank Merriwell O'Doul. Happy-go-Iucky Lefty, good-natured and good-looking, has made more timely hits and great catches in the past two weeks than Frank Merriwell made in four dime novels. He has been winning doubleheaders singlehanded, which is a good trick in any league.

Statements attacking President Hoover and Theodore G. Joslin, the President's press relations secretary, because the writers' delegation of the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners was not permitted to see the President Wednesday to protest against the treatment of the bonus marchers, were issued yesterday by Waldo Frank, author, and James Rorty, poet, who were in the delegation.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Two pilots, one a veteran and the other an aspirant for a transport license, were mortally injured here late today when a plane in which they were practicing "spins" crashed from an altitude of 1,000 feet into a field on the edge of the Merrick Road.

Abolition of two executive positions in the Union Pacific Railroad Company, paying a total of $87,500 annually, and the election of F.W. Charske to succeed C.B. Seger as chairman of the executive committee were announced yesterday by the campany.

Financial users of cable service in New York are among those who forwarded appeals yesterday and on preceding days to President Hoover and the State Department asking for representation on the American delegation which will sail on Wednesday for the International Radio-Telegraph Conference in Madrid, which will convene on Sept. 3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Announcement of plans for selling Soviet Russian ten-year bonds in the United States created a sensation in government circles here today. It was regarded primarily as a gigantic trial balloon sent up with a view of developing Russian credits in this country and of crystalizing the scattered sentiment in favor of Russian recognition by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Dropping into Washington to consult party leaders, James A. Farley, national Democratic chairman, said today that all the Democratic State chairmen who had recently reported to him expressed confidence that Governor Roosevelt would easily carry each of their States if the Presidential election was held immediately.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- In the forty-fifth running of the historic Charter Oak Stake, for 2:10 trotters, staged this afternoon as the feature race of the Grand Circuit meeting, Ankabar, 2:01 1/2, owned by H.J. Schmoeger of Peoria, Ill., and driven by Doc Parshall, added his name to the long list of famous Charter Oak winners.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Rails down under bulging sails, the America's Cup yachts Weetamoe and Vanitie bumped their lead keels along Branford Reef today on the New Tork Yacht Club's cruise run here from New Haven. Their towering masts, with all the weight and strain on them, held, and the racers continued their contest.

Despite the recent sharp rise in stock prices, brokers' loans as reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank rose only $13,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The total was $345,000,000, or $14,000,000 above the low record reached the week before last.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Preliminary reports on the new miscellaneous Federal taxes for the last nine days of June, returns from which have been coming into the Treasury since Aug. 1, show substantial increases in revenue over the corresponding period of 1931.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- The official record of today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt in removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker follows:

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A subdued and earnest "Jimmy" Walker opened his fight against removal as Mayor of the city of New York with an impassioned plea to Governor Roosevelt to allow him to face his accusers and cross-examine them.

Wholesalers Increase Orders. Rising prices in primary markets brought a rush of orders from wholesale dry goods merchants this week. Seeking to cover requirements on staple merchandise for periods of forty-five to sixty days, the jobbers placed substantial orders for cotton piece goods.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Leaders of most dry and wet organizations in Washington, declined tonight to comment on President Hoover's pronouncement in favor of a change in prohibition.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs this afternoon expressed Itself as optimistic that a truce between Bolivia and Paraguay soon would be arranged, its optimism arising from conferences in the last couple of days between Foreign Minister Saavedra Alamas with other South American diplomats and from reports of the Argentine diplomatic representatives at La Paz and Asuncion.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- Enforcement of the commission merchant law for the year ended June 30 involved the handling of twenty-one insolvencies, Charles H. Baldwin of the Department of Agriculture and Markets said today in commenting on the report for the fiscal year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The lepers of the world are sending an SOS call, and theirs is a distress greater than that known by any other human beings. Many are applying in vain for admission to our overcrowded hospitals. Still others are being turned out of the hospitals because of lack of funds.

Following a conference between officials of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Transit Commission yesterday, three regulations which, It was hoped, would serve to prevent a repetition of the tie-up and confusion caused by the fire of last Tuesday were under consideration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Application for a $39,000.000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was filed today by the Delaware River Joint Commission for the Philadelphia-Camden Bridge.

MADRID, Aug. 11 -- An infuriated republican mob at Seville burned today the building of La Union, a newspaper which served as the mouthpiece, perhaps involuntarily, of General Jose Sanjurjo in his royalist revolt yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 -- The Imperial Economic Conference will end the major part of its work next Thursday with a closing plenary session at which it is hoped to publish the trading agreements that the nine British countries here assembled may have made.
Play will start on Sept. 3 in the open championship, most important of the year's polo tournaments, according to an announcement by the United States Polo Association yesterday.

MADRID, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Numerous buildings were burned in Seville today by the Republicans mobs while the polite continued to make wholesale arrests in "mopping-up" operations against the Royalist revolutionaries who held the town yesterday, while the rest of Spain gave itself over to public celebrations of the young republic's hardihood in its first great test.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many competent bodies are working on the proposed reduction of the budget, and while they know what they are seeking, they have not as yet offered any constructive suggestions to that end. I should think that the proper way to reduce the budget would be to do so by comparison.

While speculative interest in the share market abated only slightly yesterday by comparison with the day before, realizing halted the advance and erased virtually all the gains that had been recorded in the early dealings. The volume on the Stock Exchange was only a trifle below that of the previous day and it remained large enough to sustain the enthusiasm of the commissionhouse brokers.

Probably the most extensive broadcast preparations ever attempted to carry far and wide the voice of a figure in public life was set in operation last night at 10 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time, when President Hoover accepted the renomination of his party.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Russia's plan to stimulate her world trade by issuance of bonds payable in the currency of the country in which they are sold has been known in London for some time, and it is not thought likely that the idea will lead to any filip, so far as America is concerned, in the exchange of either goods or bouquets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The subway tie-up this morning disclosed how good-natured and generally self-controlled is the traveling public. Sweltering in the crowded cars for nearly an hour and a half, many more than 100,000 people were thrown out of gear in going to work or meeting appointments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The text of the speech of Representative Bertrand H. Snell tonight notifying President Hoover of his renomination was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending Aug. 10, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,376,000,000, a decrease of $40,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,329,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Premier Herriot, who is also Foreign Minister of Frannce, received several newspaper men today specially to communicate through them his appreciation of the speech and attitude of Secretary Stimson with regard to the Briand-Kellogg pact.

SEATTLE, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Mrs. Ella A. Boole of Brooklyn, president of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, commenting tonight on President Hoover's proposal that the States deal with the prohibition question individually, said that "the proposed plan will be opposed by the dry forces every step of the way."

The scope of the discussions to be held in Stockholm beginning on Aug. 15 concerning the possibility of reorganizing the enterprises of the late Ivar Kreuger was reported for the information of the Federal court here yesterday to Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee in bankruptcy, by George K. Hourwich, of counsel for the Irving Trust Company, trustee for Kreuger's bankrupt International Match Corporation.

Thirty-five cents out of every dollar paid in taxes in this country in 1942 will go to veterans and their dependents if present laws remain in force and no new ones are added, Roger Burlingame, First Lieutenant, 308th Machine Gun Battalion in the A.E.F., asserts in his book, "Peace Veterans -- The Story of a Racket and a Plea for Economy," published today by Minton, Balch Co.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I take issue with you in that part of your editorial "The Maddest Tariff War" wherein you state that neither side desires it to continue.
Small houses and residential plots comprised the bulk of the realty turnover in New Jersey reported yesterday.

Ernest Hutcheson, pianist and dean of the Juilliard School of Music, returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, which docked several hours late because of fog on the Atlantic. Mr. Hutcheson has been abroad two months, in England and on the Continent, and said he was more hopeful for the future of musicians than at any time in the last two years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: How strange it seems that since Grover Cleveland, in his first administration, exposed the shams of the so-called protective principle of the high-tariff party no new leadership for the rejuvenation of the free-trade policy has put in an appearance on the political stage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A board of five engineers, with Dr. Charles David Marx of California as chairman, was named today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to advise it in making loans to States, municipalities and public agencies for self-liquidating public works.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Constitution Hall, scene of the Republican notification ceremony, was well filled tonight long before the official party entered.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday ordered the common and preferred shares of the Brockway Motor Truck Corporation to be stricken from the list on Aug. 16 because, it was said, the company failed to live up to the agreement made for the listing of the shares, which provides for the publication of periodical reports.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- Churning the pale blue waters of the Olympic pool into a white froth, 19-yearold Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association of New York won the Olympic 100-meter back-stroke championship today to give the United States its third successive women's crown.

Without definitely predicting that Kansas, home of Vice President Curtis, would go for Roosevelt and Garner this Fall, Guy T. Helvering, Democratic State Chairman, declared here yesterday that thousands of Republicans in that State would vote the Democratic ticket.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Fritz Leiber Jr., 21-year-old son of the noted Shakespearean actor, will be inducted into the church as a licensed lay reader at ceremonies to be held in historic Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here on Saturday morning.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- Substituting for Governor Roosevelt, who has been delivering radio addresses on State finance, Mark Graves, Director of the Budget, declared tonight over Station WGY that mere catch phrases about "waste and extravagance" and "economy in government" could not take the place of legislative action.

Jersey City divided a double-header marked by nine home runs with the Buffalo Bisons at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. The home team gained the verdict in the first by a score of 12 to 11, but lost the second by 3 to 2. The Bisons earned the lead in the series, two games to one.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Frederic McKay, New York theatrical man, and Arthur Robinson, short story writer, are silent regarding the duel they fought in the dark of the moon on the beach the other night with rapiers after a studio argument over the histrionic ability of Greta Garbo.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 11 -- A further delay in the League of Nations investigating commission's report is probable as the Earl of Lytton, the chairman, who entered the Peiping Hospital on July 20, suffered a serious relapse yesterday, necessitating the abandonment of the work that he had been performing while in bed in the past fortnight.

LONDON. Aug. 11 -- Basing its observations on American information "from a usually reliable quarter," a section of the British press takes it for granted that the Lytton commission has upheld anti-Japanese accusations regarding Manchuria. It is added that the commission has included other charges of provocation against the Soviet frontiers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- After six successive defeats the Phillies came out of their slump today, to down the Boston Braves, 7 -- 2, a four-run attack off Bob Brown in the first inning paving the way for an easy triumph for Ray Benge. Virgil Davis led the attack with three hits which drove in four runs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Grain production by the principal producing States as indicated by the condition of the crops on Aug. 1 was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

The aims of the Puccini Grand Opera Company, which is giving a series of performances near Federal Hall in Bryant Park every Thursday night, were set forth yesterday by Philip F. Ienni, director of the company, and Jack Lewis, in charge of publicity for Federal Hall, at a luncheon given at the Democratic Club.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, flew from here this morning to attend President Hoover's notification ceremony in Washington. She was accompanied by her son-in-law and daughter, Dr. and Mrs. Richard Derby.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- The Boerse rallied today, contrary to expectations. The upswing was due chiefly to orders from abroad and was interpreted as a response to the government's decree increasing penalties against terrorism. Business generally remained quiet, with most of the transactions among speculators, the investing public being hesitant.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 11 -- A government communique today announces the investment by federal troop's of Queluz and Silveira, advancing the battle from twenty kilometers west of Capella.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Consolidated returns of corporations and subsidiaries are not authorized by the revenue act of 1932 in connection with payment of the manufacturers' taxes, according to an informal ruling issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 11 -- The World Court decided today by ten votes to five that under the statute guaranteeing the autonomy of Memel the Governor of the territory was entitled to dismiss Otto Boettcher, the German president of the council, who was ousted last February.

HELSINGFORS, Aug. 11 -- A continued substantial decline in liquor smuggling-July captures were one-seventh of those in July, 1931 -- has raised hopes here that rum-running has been definitely checked and has encouraged the Cabinet to propose a reduction in next year's grants to the coast guards by 15 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Dr. Henry B. Shmookler, 50 years old, one of the founders and for twenty-five years medical director of Mount Sinai Hospital, Philadelphia, was killed instantly this morning in an automobile accident on the Brunswick Pike, nine miles north of here.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 11 (AP). -- Haden Clarke was pictured as a morose young man, addicted to narcotics, who threatened to commit suicide "in a big way," at the trial today of Captain W.N. Lancaster, charged with slaying Clarke.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 11 -- Although the governmental crisis resulting from the resignation of the entire Cabinet continues, foreign diplomatic circles as well as Chinese officials look for a general diminution of Sino-Japanese tension as the likelihood of Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's retirement Increases.

After extending the recent gains and pushing the average of prices to the highest mark of the current movement, stocks encountered selling pressure in the early afternoon yesterday and, in spite of a rally in the last half-hour, closed with moderate net losses.

Negotiations between the Publishers' Association of New York City and Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, for a new wage contract resulted in a deadlock yesterday when Mr. Howard took the stand originally taken by the scale conference committee of Typographical Union 6 that the question of wages must be arbitrated jointly with that of the six-hour day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Nobile Giacomo de Martino of Italy, who is being succeeded as Ambassador from Italy by Augusto Rosso, has as probably his outstanding achievement in seven years of conspicuous diplomatic service here the funding of Italy's wartime debt to the United States.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 11 -- In a practice match on Waterbury Field at the Meadow Brook Club, the Eastcott polo team, which is entered in the national open championship, played eight periods to a 13-13 tie against a strong side of Long Island players that included Captain C.T.I. Roark, England's ten-goal star, who is to play with Aurora in the open.
DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 11 -- Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, the wonder girl of sports, is out to capture a new title -- the women's national golf championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Hoover's recommendations for prohibition reform as set forth in his acceptance speech tonight went a step beyond the Republican, plank adopted in Chicago.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Discussion of the perplexing problem of the Polish corridor at the Institute of Politics today revealed several interesting approaches toward a solution of that knotty question.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11, (AP). -- How a government agent braved death for four months to get evidence on a narcotic ring operating in New Jersey seashore resorts was detailed tonight by L.J. Ulmer, chief narcotic investigator here.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 12. -- With more than $200,000 on deposit In banks here and drawing only 1 1/2 per cent interest, the board of water commissioners voted today to invest $50,000 of the amount in short-term bonds of the city, if these are available. The bonds would be required to mature prior to Jan. 1, 1935, the date when the first heavy retirement requirements of the city's own water bonds must be met.

The way of the author of historical fiction is not always easy, even to one so experienced as Rafael Sabatini. "The romantic novelist who takes historical epochs for his backgrounds is in danger of becoming gradually less of a novelist and more of a historian," he writes his publishers, the Houghton Mifflin Company.

Although the Government of India has decided not to take part officially in the World's Fair in Chicago in 1933, an organization sponsored and patronized by some of the leading ruling princes of that country will insure India's participation at the fair on a very large scale.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12. -- By a margin of only two points, France displaced Holland as official winner of the monotype championship of the Olympic Games yachting races on a decision after a protest, and was awarded the title today.

If real beer is ever legalized again in this country, it will be at first "unpalatable to the shellacked throats of speakeasy patrons," Bob Brown forecasts in his book, "Let There Be Beer," just published by Harrison Smith and Robert Haas. The author, according to the publishers, is something of an expert on beer, having spent three years in Germany, England and the drinking centres of Europe accumulating material and sampling brews.
ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Governor Roosevelt's decision on Mayor Walker would not be delayed by a court battle over the legality of the ouster proceedings, it was made plain here tonight.

Magnus W. Alexander, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, announced yesterday that he had sent a letter to about 2,000 industrial enterprises recommending adoption of the trade acceptance plan.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- President Will Harridge of the American League today upheld a protest by the Tigers over the game against the Yankees Aug. 1 and ordered the game replayed because of the violation of the batting order rule.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The regimental colors of the 306th Infantry, a unit of New York's Seventy-seventh Division in the World War, were decorated this afternoon in a ceremony here, where the regiment, now a part of the organized reserve, has been in charge for two weeks of the Infantry C.M.T.C.

Henry Bruckner, Borough President of the Bronx, will leave today for the South of France and Spain on the Italian motorship Augustus. Sir William Firth, Cesare Fascalello, a member of the Academy at Rome; Dr. and Mrs. H. Harvay, Dr. and Mrs. A.M. Frantz, Mr. and Mrs. C. M. Thomas, N. Lee Smith, Mario Valenti and Andrea Cassullo, Apostolic Delegate to Canada, also will leave for Mediterranean ports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Despite the receipt of an "unsatisfactory" reply from Bolivia to a recent communication from the five neutral Latin-American countries outlining a basis for cessation of hostilities between that country and Paraguay in the Chaco, it was understood tonight that the neutrals were not receding at any point from their position that hostilities must cease and the dispute adjusted on the basis of the status quo ante.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Frances Harrell Marsalis of Centreville, Miss., and Louise McPhetridge Thaden of Baltimore were making wide circles over Curtiss Airport here tonight on a flight during which they hope to break the women's record of more than 122 hours for a refueling endurance flight in an airplane.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12. -- The United States won two Olympic Championships in the swimming stadium today and Japan captured only one title, but it was the aquatic marvels from the far-off land of the Rising Sun who stole the show completely.

A reaction which Wall Street has been anticipating more than a week overtook the stock market in the last hour of trading yesterday and produced one of the wildest breaks witnessed in a year or more. Net losses in the general group of trading favorites on the New York Stock Exchange extended from 2 to 7 points and in a handful of the weakest issues there were maximum declines of 10 to 13 1/2 points.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The jurors trying Captain W.N. Lancaster for the death of Haden Clarke visited the scene of the shooting late today after they had seen Clarke's skull introduced in evidence and had heard his death described as suicide by a criminologist.
IF It isn't one thing, it's another. It used to be California that was lording it over the East, but now conies this blast from another direction:

The Belgian expedition, which on July 28 climbed a high peak of Mount Stanley of the Ruwenzori range of East Central Africa and named it Point Albert in honor of the King of the Belgians, has designs on other unclimbed summits. These are in a field of mountains that were legendary until HENRY M. STANLEY caught sight of them on May 24, 1888, from Albert Nyanza.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, which has called a strike involving 20,000 workers in an effort to eliminate sweat-shop conditions and drastic wage-cutting, sent a letter yesterday to the retail clothing dealers throughout the country, including all the leading department stores in this city and elsewhere, asking them to support the union's efforts by refusing to handle merchandise produced under substandard working conditions.
Housing properties continued to provide the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday. Several New Yorkers were among the buyers.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 12. -- The flood of denunciations and revelations of China's political crisis, which threatened to undermine and wash away the entire foundations of government, have now subsided into the arid sands of political manoeuvring and the subterranean channels of obscure deals for power.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- National banknotes issued on the backing of 3, 3 1/3 and 3 3/3 per cent Treasury bonds must be retired at the end of three years after the effective date of the Home Loan Bank act, Attorney General Mitchell ruled today in an opinion requested by Secretary Mills.

Optimism continues to spread more over the country and is beginning to be reflected in improved wholesale trade, according to the weekly reviews of trade and business. Retail trade is reported to be holding its own, while the heavy industries, usually slow to recover, are continuing dull.

Money market closed the week quietly in tone and unchanged in quotation. Virtually little business was transacted. Stock Exchange call loans, time money, commercial paper and acceptances were all dull.

The story of Susanna and the two elders, which John J. Curtin, counsel for Mayor Walker in the removal charges before Governor Roosevelt, used yesterday to point his argument that the Mayor should be given the chance to cross-examine the witnesses whose testimony was being used against him, was cited as one of the earliest recorded examples of how the falsity of testimony could be proved by crossquestioning.

GENEVA, Aug. 12. -- The president of the governing body of the International Labor Organization today called a special meeting of that body for Sept. 21 to consider the convocation of an emergency session of the International Labor Conference to deal with unemployment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Two young women, performing on a trapeze in a circus on the Steel Pier here, fell seventy-five feet to the floor of the pier tonight when one of the women slipped as she was swinging by her feet. More than 10,000 persons milled about the pier as an ambulance from the Atlantic City Hospital rushed them to the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Angered by assertions that the State Department proposed to pass upon the flotation of a Soviet bond issue in the United States, Senator Glass today declared such a program by the department to be a "wanton usurpation of authority."

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman declared today that unless substantial economies were effected in the State's educational program, the public might threaten the established State principle of a sound education for every child on the ground that education was too extravagant.

Sees Turn in Fur Trade. The situation today in the fur trade is more favorable than at any time in the last three years, according to a statement issued yesterday to members by Harold Klugman, president of the American Fur Merchants' Association.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Teams from Indianapolis and Cleveland were eliminated today from the Union Printers' International Baseball Tournament. Each had lost two games, which puts them out of the running under the rules.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- Gustave J.S. White, C. Oliver O'Donnell, William H. Vanderbilt and Leonard M. Thomas have been added to the committee of which George Henry Warren Jr. is chairman, to arrange for a ball game between the Summer residents and city officials.

TOKYO, Aug. 12. -- Ambassador Debuchi at Washington has cabled verbatim Secretary Stimson's New York speech of last Monday. He makes no comment. Regarding his interview with Secretary Stimson, he merely said he would report orally on his arrival in Tokyo in September.

ARCHIE, Mo., Aug. 12. -- Meteorites which startled persons over a wide area south of Kansas City with their aerial bombardment left their calling cards on a farm near here, probably giving the world its first sample of the material of the Perseids, a group of shooting stars which appears annually at this time.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Vanda Nomicos (Mrs. David Oliver Shoemaker) gave her first concert of the East Hampton season this evening before a large audience at Guild Hall. Her program included songs in four languages -- Russian, French, German and English.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- There is no fundamental distinction between broadcasting stations and radio communication companies with respect to the utilization of electrical energy, the National Association of Broadcasters urged in a brief filed today with the Bureau of Internal Revenue in opposition to the 3 per cent power tax provided in the Revenue Act.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The overnight reaction in Wall Street had very little effect on the markets here today, but business was restricted, partly owing to the fact that the Stock Exchange will be closed tomorrow. British Government funds were firm and prices higher.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Two favorites, Louis Guy and Del Hanover, won and two other choices, Hollyrood Brown and Napoleon Grant, lost on the final day of the Grand Circuit meeting at Charter Oak Park today.

ICKORNSHAW, Yorkshire, Aug. 12. -- The strangest shoot of the Twelfth was on the moor here overtowering the birthplace of Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, where the unemployed took advantage of their ancient right of free shooting to reap handsome profits on the season's first birds.

There is nothing but admiration, so far, for Governor ROOSEVELT'S bearing in the Walker case at Albany. He has been firm but impartial, anxious to dispatch the business before him, and putting questions which show how closely and deeply he has studied the evidence laid before him with the charges.

Prize lists for the forty-seventh annual national horse show to be held in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 9 to 15, were sent to exhibitors yesterday, showing a total of about 540,000 in cash prizes, stakes and trophies.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 12. -- Semi-official Japanese dispatches from Chinchow, Manchuria, report that the Japanese commanders have decided to begin campaigning against Jehol immediately because, after twenty-six days of negotiations, Gonshiro Ishimoto, Japanese leader of an official mission to Jehol, continues a captive there.

Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland, unsuccessful contender for the Democratic nomination for President, will aid in the campaign for the election of Governor Roosevelt and will start by making a speech in Maine before the State election there in September.

An order for the examination before trial of Walter E. Sachs, Waddell Catchings and Sidney J. Weinberg in a stockholders' suit against the Goldman-Sachs Trading Corporation and others was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 12. -- One yacht was sunk, another capsized, one was dismasted and scores of craft lost sails and rigging in a severe squall which hit the yacht fleet today in the midst of the second Corinthian Yacht Club race o the annual midsummer series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES'S Washington dispatch regarding Mr. Lamont's new position in the steel industry says that "government experts are pleased that the Steel Institute has appointed a tariff committee."

SHANGHAI, Aug. 12. -- The famine and floods in Manchuria are becoming more serious daily. Henry Pu Yi, President of Manchukuo, donated $100,000 Mexican (about $30,000 gold) from his private purse for relief and the Manchukuo Government appropriated $400,000 Mexican.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 12. -- Although the forms of democracy will continue to be maintained in some countries, democratic realities ire going into eclipse for a time, with power passing into the hands of smaller groups of competent men, according to several speakers today at the Institute of Politics.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Surrey defeated Hampshire by eight wickets and Yorkshire defeated Essex by an innings and eight runs in first-class cricket matches concluded today.

MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 12. -- Share certificates of the Consolidated Paper Corporation, Ltd., are being issued to shareholders of the Canada Power and Paper Corporation to replace their holdings in the latter company which they deposited some time ago for exchange.
