Mortgage loans totaling $850,919 have been authorized by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. $720,994 being on city properties and $129,925 on farms. Ninety-four loans were on dwellings and nine on apartment houses. California got the largest share, $213,705.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A German soldier whose life was saved by an American in 1918, remembering a promise to the "doughboy" in the fury of battle, has sent to the Treasury Department a bracelet made of old German coins as "a sign of appreciation for a nation whose soldiers even in war treated their enemies with great consideration."
President Hoover's acceptance speech was hailed enthusiastically by Republican leaders in New York yesterday.

GENEVA, Aug. 12. -- One sentence fn the part of President Hoover's speech devoted to the Kellogg-Briand pact is outstanding for Geneva. It is the one saying "We shall, under the spirit of that pact, consult with other nations in times of emergency to promote world peace."

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 12. -- Drys are "puzzled" as to how they should cast their votes in November, Mrs. Ella A. Boole, president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, declared tonight in her address opening the national convention of the organization here.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Despite a finish which put him five over par on the last three holes, John Kinder, 23-year-old assistant professional of the Green Brook Country Club of North Caldwell, managed to retain his title as open golf champion of New Jersey in the seventy-two-hole tournament which ended today at the Jumping Brook Country Club.

With girls tossing roses in his path as he walked from the train to his limousine, Mayor James J. Walker returned here from Albany at 8 o'clock last night, confident that he has "met every challenge" thus far in his removal hearings before Governor Roosevelt.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A total of $61,725 was realized tonight for a total of fifty yearlings which were sold in the Fasig-Tipton sales paddock. The youngsters wore mainly from the Claiborne and Ellerslie Studs of Arthur B. Hancock, and this Kentucky breeder alone offered forty-five head for a total of $59,325 and an average of $1.318.

A report is current among transatlantic steamship companies that the conference of Atlantic lines will meet soon to adopt measures of curtailment in the West Indian cruise season of 1932-33, it was revealed yesterday. Inquiries among the lines elicited no definite information, although several officials admitted that such a move was "in the air" and that some agreement was believed inevitable for "the good of all."

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Bulls in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade here had an unprofitable day today, and efforts of large Eastern operators to sustain the market were unsuccessful. A heavy undertone developed at the start and prices dropped as much as 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish on profit-taking credited to the East before support developed.
Prohibition leaders in the metropolitan district expressed different views yesterday of President Hoover's stand for State control of liquor as outlined in his address of acceptance Thursday night.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Aug. 12 (AP). Dr. Otto Struve of Yerkes Observatory said the meteor display was more clearly visible this morning than last year, when the average number of "shooting stars" was a little better than one each minute.

CHICAGO, .Aug. 12 (AP). -- Willie Moran gave the Meadowbrook Farm's Miss Corinne a brisk ride in the stretch today to take down the Crestview Purse by a neck over Dr. J. Fred Adams's Rehoboth in the feature race at Hawthorne.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12. -- A band of Americans showed 20,000 spectators in this stadium today that they know something about this Canadian game, lacrosse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Copying Henry Clay, Senator Simeon Fess of Ohio, preparing his speeches which he will make in the political campaign, probably will try them first on the song birds that flit about the curved walk on his seven-acre estate at Yellow Springs, Ohio.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So little progress has been made in the proper disposition of sewage and so little hope can be held for a betterment of this condition in the near future that it appears to be a matter of only a few years when the Health Department will find it necessary to refuse permits for bathing at any of the beaches adjacent to the city.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Sterling pitching by Glint Brown enabled the Indians to hand Detroit its second straight defeat of the series, 3 to 1, and regain a tie for second place today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- England and the United States broke even today in quarter-final-round matches in men's singles of the Eastern grass-court championship tournament on the courts of the Westchester Country Club.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- German newspapers, preoccupied by the internal political situation, commented only briefly on President Hoover's acceptance speech. Most of them feel he revived the Old World's hope that the United States will actively cooperate in curing the world's ills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Three publishing and distributing agencies were ordered by the Federal Trade Commission today to stop selling encyclopedias under several different titles when the text is identical.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Harold F. McCormick tonight visited his former wife, Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, who is lying ill in the Drake Hotel. Mr. McCormick returned to Chicago yesterday morning from the West Coast, where he was attending the Olympic Games.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 12. -- The Detroit Yacht Club will have a double threat in the field tomorrow for the twenty-ninth renewal of the American Gold Cup speedboat championships on Lake Montauk, in which six craft are entered. Horace E. Dodge, the Detroit Y.C. entrant, has two boats in the classic, Delphine IV, the former Solar Plexus, and Delphine V, the only new boat in the race.
Wholesale markets wavered yesterday in their price trend. The grains, cotton and rubber were lower, but silk, lard and coffee were higher. Elsewhere, prices showed no change.

Maintaining that normal short soiling is an essential part of a free market in securities, Howard C. Sykes, president of the New York Curb Exchange, defends this practice on the various security exchanges in an article in the current issue of Credit and Financial Management, the official publication of the National Association of Credit Men.

The likelihood that Americans would soon have to start the day without their usual morning cup of coffee, merely because one political group in Brazil is trying to force another out of power, became apparent yesterday, when reserve stocks in this country dropped to slightly more than the requirements for the next twenty days.

State Senator William Lathrop Love of Brooklyn, denied redesignation by the Brooklyn Democratic organization of the Eighth Senatorial District because of his vote in favor of continuing the Seabury investigation, will run independently or enter a Democratic primary fight for the nomination, his friends declared yesterday.

A downward readjustment of sweeping proportions occurred yesterday on the Stock Exchange, thus spoiling some of the illusions of the new crop of speculators. The decline was of no greater scope than some of the advances of the last month, but it broke in rudely upon Wall Street's extravagant hopes.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Newark bears increased their league-leading margin to ten and one-half games today when they took their fourth straight from the Montreal Royals, 10 -- 6.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Mayor Walker faced Governor Roosevelt across a flat-topped desk in the Executive Chamber of the Capitol today and sought to explain away the "inferences and innuendoes" surrounding the Equitable Coach Company's franchise and Paul Block's gift of $246,000 in cash.

The Giants managed to tie a major league record at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but they couldn't tie the Dodgers, from which it can be readily taken that the Dodgers in their present state of exhilaration are above and beyond all records.

ALBANY Aug. 12. -- After two days Of crowds and testimony, the principal figures in the removal proceedings against Mayor Walker hurried out of Albany at the close of today's proceedings before Governor Roosevelt, most of them planning to return to their homes until the hearings are resumed on Monday.

The possibility of drafting former Governor Nathan L. Miller for the Republican nomination for Governor was reported yesterday when it became known that Mr. Miller had lunched and conferred with W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, at the Recess Club.

Acute weakness developed yesterday on the Stock Exchange, and the decline was the widest, measured by the averages, since Oct. 13, 1931. The composite averages, based upon fifty selected stocks, showed a fall of $4.74; twenty-five industrials broke $7.52 and twenty-five railway issues $1.96.
Window gazing may not be the favorite pastime of a fisherman, but it is always a sign of "fishing fever" to watch some of the anglers inspecting the tackle displayed in shops.

With the conversion of President HOOVER to State control of the liquor traffic, those who are prohibitionists first and partisans afterward are left with no Important champion in either major party. Governor ROOSEVELT and the Democrats are pledged not only to the submission of flat repeal, and to flat repeal itself, but they are on record for immediate modification of the Volstead act.

Cornelius F. Kelley, president of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, returned to his office yesterday after a month's stay in Europe, where he conferred with executives of copper companies relative to the establishment of a single sales agency for producers outside the United States.

Net losses in June after taxes and charges were reported yesterday by the Chicago Northwestern and the Lackawanna. The Great Northern reported an increase in net for June, but this resulted from the inclusion in revenue for the month of $2,488,011 in dividends received from the Burlington.

The revision of legislation affecting railroads and the further regulation of other forms of transportation were urged yesterday in resolutions adopted by the members of the International Apple Association at the closing session of the annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 12. -- Edward F. Woodward of Houston, Texas, broke 174 out of 175 targets to win the Auld Lang Syne classic, feature of the fourth day of the T. Clarence Marshall trapshooting classic at the Yorklyn Gun Club traps today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Two strong teams went down to unexpected defeats in the course of the first series of knockout matches this afternoon for the challenge trophy of the city of Asbury Park, one of the major events of the American Bridge League's Summer tournament here.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Mortem L. Schwartz, owner of Gusto, is going to take another crack at C.V. Whitney's Equipoise in the Whitney Stakes, one of the features, tomorrow. The famous handicap division star, which has lost only one race this year, defeated Gusto in the Arlington Cup race and will be conceding the three-year-old nine pounds tomorrow.

Human annals show no paralle to the unselfishness, the abnegation the utter devotion which They an now exhibiting in behalf of Mr. Hoover. Who are They? The persons groups and associations undesignated who are now "rigging" the Stock market; who are now, as Mr. WILL ROGERS suspects, buying and selling among themselves, in order to hasten the return of prosperity in order to assure Mr. HOOVER'S reelection.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- President Hoover was called upon by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today to specify what means he proposes to employ in accomplishing the results in many fields which he promised in his acceptance speed last night.

Anaconda Wire and Cable Company Six months ended June 30: Net loss after depreciation, taxes and other charges, $559,842, contrasted with net profit of $279,693, equal to 66 cents a share on 422,470 no par capital shares, in first half of 1931. Quarter ended June 30: Net loss after above charges, $323,396, against $236,446 loss in preceding quarter and net profit of $118,228, or 28 cents a capital share in second quarter last year.

PHILADELPHIA Aug. 12 (AP). -- Chuck Klein set the Phillies' home-run machinery into action today and paced the Phils to an 8-to-1 victory over the Boston Braves. The defeat dropped Boston to fourth place.

The first application for a loan under the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's recent offer to stimulate employment on the railroads by financing repairs to or construction of equipment was announced yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad. The road will seek $2,000,000 for the construction of 1,500 freight cars, providing work for about 1,400 men.

To the Editor of The New York Times. As a patriotic yet puzzled Amerian, may I ask why Secretary Stimon, in his speech, upholding the Kellgg-Briand treaty before the Foreign Policy Association, should throw a lighted match on troubled waters carefully smoothed with diplomatic oil?

The Metropolitan Museum or Art has acquired, as a wift from Edward S. Harkness, what is perhaps the only ancient Egyptian sem-priest's costume now surviving. The ancient linen was in a poor condition of preservation when it reached the museum, but there it was impregnated with a rubber solution and backed with cotton net so that it might be placed on exhibition.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Mayor Walker, who had explained before the Hofstadter legislative committee in New York City that large sums he had received from Paul Block, the publisher, were "beneficences," told Governor Roosevelt at the removal hearing today that his use of the word was unfortunate. The Mayor said:

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- President Hoover's speech of acceptance has aroused unusual interest in France, and both warm approval and hot disapproval mark the comments. The disapproval emanates mostly from those whose comprehension of American policy and doctrine is limited to trying to dictate what America ought to do.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Resolutions Committee of the Massachusetts Department of the American Legion, despite a personal appearance by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, in behalf of the National Economy League, voted tonight to report favorably to the State convention a resolution opposing curtailment of benefits now received by veterans.

Leasing of store space, notably in buildings on the lower east side, where renting has been inactive for many months, featured the business-rental contracts reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday. Some activity was noted also in the midtown garment district.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- A strong buying Movement during the week's closing session put prices on a considerably higher level on the Bourse today. The market will be closed until next Tuesday. Skeptics among speculators here seem to have been routed completely after President Hoover's nomination acceptance speech yesterday, which inspired great hopes in France for future cancellation of war debts.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The Morvich colt, Morfair, impressed observers as a more formidable 3-year-old than ever when he scored his third consecutive 1932 victory by taking the Saranac Handicap today over a heavy track and at a distance many felt was not suited to him.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12. -- A storm if protest from 7,000 fans greeted he decision by which Louis Salica if Brooklyn, America's hope for the Olympic flyweight title, was defeated tonight in the semi-finals by Stephen Enekes of Hungary, champion of Europe.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 12. -- William Scott, 18 years old, son of Thomas Scott, superintendent of the estate of Mrs. William H. Porter at Lattingtown, was critically injured today when an airplane he was flying crashed near Crescent Beach here.
ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- The official record of today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt in removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker follows:
BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- A day of negotiation, discussion and re-examination of positions has passed without appreciable change in the German political situation.

The present reciprocity treaty between this country and Cuba, made in 1903, is no longer adequate and should be revised to give Cuba greater leeway, Jose Gomez Mena, chairman of the Cuban delegation to the recent sugar conference in Belgium, said yesterday on his return here.

ABOARD S.S. MANHATTAN AT SEA, Aug. 12. -- After an entire day of rain and fog the weather cleared today and the new liner Manhattan continues to average more than 21 knots with only five boilers in use.

BOSTON, Aug. 12. -- Republicans and Democrats were just as divided today on President Hoover's prohibition stand, as announced in his speech of acceptance, as they have always been on any party issues, and their reactions reflected the party loyalty.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

A number of vaudeville theatres in the Radio - Keith - Orpheum Circuit outside New York, some of which have recently been dark, will be available for the booking of legitimate theatrical attractive through arrangements made by R. Victor Leighton and George Leffler with Harold B. Franklin of the R.-K.-O. organization.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, has been asked to serve as "Czar" of the silk dyeing industry of Paterson and vicinity, it became known here today after Alexander Patterson, secretary of the Silk Printers and Dyers Association, had returned from a conference with Mayor Hague in his office in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, today removed $614,742,100 from the list of Treasury certificates and notes acceptable for payment of income and profits taxes, in an amendment to regulations issued today with the approval of Secretary Mills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- President Hoover gave a bare hint of plans for another drive against depression -- probably the greatest yet instituted -- when he said today that he will soon call a conference of the various business and industrial committees already set up in the twelve Federal Reserve districts.

The Issuance of a permit for the operation of a small refreshment concession at the Cumberland Street entrance to Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn, was authorized "through a misrepresentation on the part of the concessionaire" and will become void after Sept. 15, according to an explanation of the incident by John J. Sullivan, acting Park Commissioner in Brooklyn, in a letter to Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

Denial of a renomination to Senator WILLIAM L. LOVE of Brooklyn is a challenge to the voters, as the secretary of the Citizens Union asserts. Here is a Democrat deserving of honor. Though a doctor by profession, his qualifications for public office are far above the average.

George Donnelly, secretary of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, who instigated the court fight over the legality of the ouster proceedings against Mayor Walker, is a real estate man in the Bronx and a member of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 )AP). -- Adolf Hitler left his vacation retreat in the Bavarian Alps today to talk with Chancellor von Papen tomorrow morning. After that meeting he probably will see President von Hindenburg.

In spite of the increased burdens which they expect to carry in 1933 the Department of Hospitals and Department of Correction filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate budget requests for less than the allowances provided in the 1932 budget.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Mrs. Henry W. Peabody, chairman of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement, said tonight that "the loss of President Hoover does not mean the loss of the Eighteenth Amendment."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Republican wets and drys alike engaged in an old-time love feast today over the prohibition declaration of President Hoover and criticisms of Democrats and professional prohibitionists were nearly drowned out in the thousands of messages congratulating him on his acceptance speech.

Expressing complete satisfaction with the manner in which their team has been directed on the field so far this season, the directors of the Brooklyn Dodgers announced yesterday the reappointment of Max Carey as manager for 1933.

Lessons of the Subway Tie-Up. The tie-up of traffic on the east side subway, which fortunately resulted in no serious injury or loss of life, will serve a useful purpose if out of it shall come some means of preventing such accidents when possible and limiting their effects when unavoidable.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Smithers will give a dinner Aug. 27 at Stony Lea, Locust Valley, L.I., for Miss Lydia Ahles and Eugene M. Geddes, whose marriage takes place Aug. 31.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- Sails swelling under blasts of a thunder squall, the fleet of the New York Yacht Club reached here this after noon with Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup sloop Vanitie showing the way over thirty-seven and a half miles from New London to Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe by 59 seconds, but losing on account of her handicap penalty by 3 minutes and 33 seconds.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12. -- The deadlock between Great Britain and Canada at the Imperial Economic Conference here is broken. This great effort of the British Empire to improve the commercial relationships among its several parts seems tonight, for the first time, assured of a material success.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- Harry A. Mackey, former Mayor, admitted today that he had received a monthly fee of $1,000 as counsel for the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company while chairman of the Pennsylvania Workmen's Compensation Board.

MADRID, Aug. 12. -- The Duke of Medinaceli, whose ancestors for centuries have been among the four most important families in Spain, was arrested today while fleeing across the border at Irun, bringing to 100 the number of nobles seized for suspected complicity in Wednesday's royalist revolt.
Attention shifted yesterday from the tangle in which the late Ivar Kreuger left his $1,000,000,000 organization after years of unchecked manipulation, to the names of the buyers of his securities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A three-year loan of $1,070,599 from the Re-construction Finance Corporation to the Mobile Ohio Railroad was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The money is to be used to pay taxes, equipment trust obligations and to make up a current operating deficit.

Criticism of President Hoover's acceptance speech on four points, emergency relief measures, the tariff, prohibition and agricultural relief, was expressed here yesterday by Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader of the Senate and nominee for Vice President in 1928.

INVERNESS, Scotland, Aug. 12. -- Weather and economic conditions combined to make the opening of the grouse-shooting season today one of the most disappointing in recent years. Many moors were not let and Americans were conspicuously absent apart from a few perennial enthusiasts such as J. Pierpont Morgan, who is always an early arrival in Scotland.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the recital given this evening by Frank Sheridan, pianist, at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.

One of the smallest weekly totals of new State and municipal financing in many months is listed for award next week. Although comprising thirty-five issues, the aggregate will amount to only $5,637,458, or about one-half of this week's total. The weekly average for 1932 thus far is $20,272,495.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Snatching a week-end interlude from the hearing on Mayor Walker, Governor Roosevelt will turn attention to the national campaign in the interim and on Sunday will confer with his running mate, Speaker John N. Garner, at his home in Hyde Park.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange opened fairly strong yesterday, but closed irregular. Representative issues of the domestic railroad and industrial groups averaged higher for the day, while utilities were generally easier. Foreign loans were irregularly higher, but United States Government bonds yielded ground.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Toronto Leafs took three out of four games of the series by splitting today's double-header, winning the first game, 10 to 8, and Baltimore taking the second, 3 to 0.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 12. -- Turning back the greatest challenge he has met since he won the championship at Amsterdam in 1928, Bobby Pearce of Australia retained his Olympic single sculls crown today in a thrilling race which produced a magnificent bid for victory by Bill Miller of the United States.

A year ago a citizens' committee, under the chairmanship of Dr. H.L. McBAIN of Columbia, reported to the Mayor the results of a study, extending over many months, of the status of librarians in the public libraries of this city. It found that the salaries of librarians were "not "commensurate with the high type "of service they render."

The possibility of making separate applications for consolidation of the railroads in the East under the plan recently announced by the Interstate Commerce Commission was discussed yesterday at a meeting of the heads of the four Eastern trunk lines in the Pennsylvania Station.

In a message sent yesterday from Southampton, L.I., to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, commended the stand taken on prohibition by President Hoover in his acceptance speech. In his message Dr. Butler said:
LONDON, Aug. 12. -- British opinion is distinctly irritated by President Hoover's attitude in war debts and tariffs as expressed In his acceptance speech.

The clerical delegation from the United Lutheran Synod of New York to the eighth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America, to be held in Philadelphia beginning Oct. 12 and lasting a week will include the president of the latter, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, of New Rochelle, N.Y.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12. -- The Imperial Economic Conference today pledged the support of the British Empire in any effort to be undertaken at the forthcoming world economic conference for the stabilization of currency and the raising of commodity values, but the conference here refrained from making any specific recommendations of a technical character pending international action.

Discussing farm relief in ins acceptance speech, the President seems to have had in mind his advice to Congress when he summoned a special session to deal with this question early in his Administration. He then said that "certain safeguards" must be observed in any plan to aid agriculture.

Increased activity in Manhattan realty was reported yesterday. A Washington Heights investment purchase and a Harlem sale by an insurance company were included in the deals. Two extensions of chain store leaseholds were recorded.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 12. -- William Graves, a member of counsel for Libby Holman Reynolds, who was indicted more than a week ago for the murder of her husband, Smith Reynolds, said today he had received an anonymous letter from Charleston, S.C., saying the writer had seen the tobacco heir commit suicide on the morning of July 6.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13. -- The 1932 Olympics, which end their spectacular sporting whirl of sixteen days with the closing ceremonies tomorrow, have far outstripped all records for gate receipts as well as performances.

THE accident that caused last week's tie-up on the east side I.R.T. subway line -- the piercing of a cable by a workman in the street -- is of a comparatively rare type, although it is not difficult to puncture the high-pressure cables from the surface level.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Suppose Jones, Brown, Smith and Robinson start out some evening to put in some time together. They don't say right out that they're going to put up one grand, all-night spree, but that's what it gets down to.

ROUSING himself from his recent inactivity, Jed Harris has become more than measurably excited about a new play, tentatively called "Both Your Houses," by Maxwell Anderson, and intends to rush it into immediate production.

ROME, Aug. 12. -- Rome has definitely decided to open the new Vatican Art Gallery on Oct. 28. By a curious chance the date coincides with that chosen by the Fascist regime to celebrate the tenth anniversary of its rise to power, but it was selected because it also marks the thirteenth anniversary of the Pope's episcopal consecration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- President Hoover turned today from the consideration of politics, which had engrossed him for more than a week, and again took up plans for a further drive on the force of the business depression.

DETROIT. ALTHOUGH there has been no pronounced evidence that the rising curve of commodity and stock prices has favorably affected motorcar buying, its continuance is regarded as likely to hasten the introduction of some 1933 models.

After having expended upward of $25,000,000 in its development, the standard Oil Company of New Jersey and its domestic marketing affiliations have begun the extensive marketing of a new motor oil made by the hydrogenation process which will take the place of other brands of oil previously sold.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles H. Coster is with her daughter, Mrs. Arthur Train, at Sols Cliff, Bar Harbor, Me.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP). -- To the veteran who came through the war unscathed the government owes gratitude, but, until assistance is needed, nothing more than it owes to any other loyal citizen, General Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs, declared today.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 13. -- The undefeated University of California crew won the Olympic eight-oared championship on Alamitos Bay today, with Italy second, Canada third and Great Britain fourth. The Americans triumphed by the narrow margin of one foot.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13. -- Eddie Flynn of New Orleans brought the United States its first 1932 Olympic boxing title when he scored a decision over Erich Campe of Germany for the welterweight championship in the Auditorium tonight.

The sum of $1,500,000, less than one-third the amount spent by the Democrats in the effort to elect former Governor Alfred E. Smith President in 1928, was set yesterday as the tentative amount to be disbursed by the Democratic National Committee in its campaign to elect Franklin D. Roosevelt.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 13. -- Gross operating profit of Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., in the second quarter of 1932 was $167,423, compared with $113,511 in the first three months of the year, the company reports. It adds that operating profits are dependent on sales, and the better showing in the second quarter reflects improvement in this respect.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Drinking is not a crime in this country; drinking is not a sin in any country. In the United States it is against the law to sell liquor, and therefore criminal; it is against the law to transport liquor, and therefore criminal; it is against the law to manufacture liquor, and therefore criminal.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Still rattling through the streets at a tempo no different from that of more halcyon days, Rochester's jade-green trolley cars soon will emerge from the maze of receivership tangles and bitter feuds in which they have been figuratively enmeshed for three years if plans of a group of bankers and bondholders to divorce them from the New York State Railways carry through.

An example in dauntless salesmanship was given Flushing Airport, on the outskirts of Flushing, Queens, yesterday afternoon. Hardly had Kingdom Thomas, a transport pilot, extricated John M. Allison of Lakehurst, N.J., a prospective purchaser, from the wreckage of the sports biplane in which they had crashed than Mr. Thomas sought to sell Mr. Allison the plane's motor.

Leon J. Garcey, managing director of Thomas Cook Son and director of the commercial service of WagonsLits, Inc., who is an American and makes his headquarters in Paris and London, said before sailing on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen early yesterday morning that he had been greatly surprised during his trip through the West to find people in a cheerful mood.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- White Mountains visitors have a full week ahead, with many affairs planned for their entertainment. A polo match will be played at The Balsams, Dixville Notch, today, between the local team and that from the Danvers Polo Club, which played at Maplewood during the week.

PEIPING, July 15. -- Far from the scenes of China's troubles with Japan and untouched by internal political upheavals and the scourges of communism, banditry, flood and famine, there rages unabated on the frontier between Tibet and Szechuan Province a war which has been in progress since late in March and shows no signs of reaching a conclusion.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 13 (AP). -- Rufus S. Lusk, national legislative officer of the Crusaders, an anti-prohibition organization, predicted tonight that "more States will be in open revolt against prohibition after the coming elections than seceded from the Union during the Civil War."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- Unquestionably the higher prices for stocks and the activity of the market are having a favorable influence upon public sentiment. Daily dispatches from various parts of the district report factories reopening and others increasing their payrolls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- President Hoover will accept tomorrow, on behalf of the United States, a statue of James Cardinal Gibbons, presented by the Knights of Columbus as the first act in celebrating the golden jubilee of the order.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -- William A. Schnader, Attorney General of Pennsylvania, Admitted today that he had received a salary from the Yellow Cab Company, owned by the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, as its general counsel.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13. -- A new world's record by Miss Helene Madison of Seattle, a clean sweep of the high-platform diving by three Americans -- Harold (Dutch) Smith, Mickey Riley Galitzen and Frank Kurtz -- and two more championships for Japan marked the close of the Olympic aquatic program before two crowds of 12,000 each in morning and afternoon sessions today.

TOKTO. IN 1930 United States Steel common stock was moving more or less comfortably between $197 and $134. On the Yokohama Silk Exchange raw silk was oscillating from a high of $595 to a low of $280 for a bale of 130 pounds.

MISS DELAFIELD'S previous work, especially the "Diary of a Provincial Lady," has led her readers to expect unfailing entertainment; they have become accustomed to her quiet but penetrating wit and to her minute and careful analysis of character.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- Germany, with the greatest percentage of unemployed of any country in Europe, spends relatively the least on doles. In the last fiscal year it was 3,300,000,000 marks [about $785,400,000]. This year, although unemployment has risen, the expenditures, with rates reduced, is expected to be kept under 3,000,000,000 marks [about $714,000,000,000] for an estimated 6,000,000 jobless, averaging $118 per person.

MADRID, Aug. 12. -- Spain can see only one man as Presidential timber in the United States, and that man is not Herbert Hoover. The reason, of course, is Franklin D. Roosevelt's stand on the liquor and the tariff questions, in the first of which she is more interested than most nations.

Wearing a self-contained breathing apparatus which heretofore had been used only when smoke, gas or fumes necessitated the use of a mask, Patrolman Edward Kiernan of Emergency Squad 18 descended to the bottom of the Delaware River Friday afternoon and recovered the body of George Martin, 12-year-old son of Patrolman Felix Martin of Traffic L, who was drowned Thursday afternoon when he attempted to swim the river at Delaware Water Gap.
GLASGOW, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Forty soccer teams swung into action today in the Scottish League, opening the season two weeks ahead of the English League, which begins play Aug. 27.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Great Britain's weekly reviews all comment on the Ottawa Imperial Economic Conference today, not hesitating to offer both criticism and praise.

LONDON. THE high plane on which modern commercial education is placed by world leaders in the field, as represented by those assembled from fourteen countries at the fifth triennial Congress of the International Society for Commercial Education, just closed here, may be seen from, the terms of this resolution:

STUTTGART, Germany, Aug. 13. -- Professor Erich Regener of the Stuttgart Institute of Technology has succeeded in sending up an unmanned balloon to the altitude of 92,000 feet (nearly 17 1/2 miles) with special apparatus for measuring and registering cosmic rays in the stratosphere.

GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 10. -- Ecuadorian members of Congress are not enthusiastic over their annual visit to Quito, as the present session of Congress, which convened today, promises to be a stormy one, and last year's experience with the gallery has put the fear of the mob into the hearts of many.

IF you are a girl facing your freshman year at college, a business woman just back from a vacation, or a society belle contemplating a season of gayety, you will want a light-weight woolen dress in which to launch yourself into the Autumn's adventures.

IF the individual is the microcosm of a nation, there is more than a little significance in this portrait of a suburban woman living in a suburb here identified as New Rochelle, but which with allowance for a few unessential differences, might be located anywhere on the American Continent.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 13 (AP). -- The Palm Beach Times said today that a move to rid the Everglades of unnaturalized Bahaman Negroes had been launched under leadership of the group of white farmers who recently ejected a colony of Filipinos.

SHANGHAI, July 15. -- Basic changes in China's educational system are provided for in a new law framed in secret by the Nanking Central Political Council, and referred to the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang party for secret consideration.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13. -- Inasmuch as inventories are exceedingly small in most of the retail outlets, an increase in wholesale business is expected to develop in this area within a short time.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 11. -- For the first time since 1880 the Democratic party in Tennessee faces the prospect of choosing in November between two candidates for Governor, each declaring himself to be the nominee. Regardless of what the State Primary Board does on Aug.
THE San Francisco Opera Company, about whose Fall season there has been some doubt, has definitely announced its opening for Oct. 15.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the barn dance in aid of the Southampton unemployment fund, which was held tonight in the large barn on the George Warrington Curtis estate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Apparently more interested in fishing than politics for the time being, Speaker John N. Garner arrived here tonight for a stop-over of a few hours en route to Albany to confer with Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Bond prices weakened on the Stock Exchange yesterday in trading that exceeded $7,500,000 in the two-hour trading period. Aside from a fair show of strength in some of the better-rated public utility issues, lower prices were generally in order throughout the list.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- With the notable exceptions of two former titleholders, Gene Sarazen and Leo Diegel, all of the big money winners of American golf qualified for the fifteenth Professional Golfer's Association championship over the rejuvenated Keller course, St. Paul, Aug. 30 to Sept. 4.

New York is maintaining its position as America's premier convention city, according to the annual report of the convention bureau of the Merchants' Association which shows an average of ninety-four events a month throughout the twelve-month period ending April 30, and attendance at the meetings continuing at normal and in many instances far above previous records.

ON Thursday and Friday of last week astronomers, professional and amateur, turned to the northeastern sky to watch the Perseids -- a shower of meteors that seems to come from Perseus, although it has no connection with that constellation.
One hundred delegates to the first world Jewish conference, representing 12,000,000 Jews in twenty-five countries, will open their sessions today at Geneva.

THE Mr. Hutchinson of "If Winter Comes," "This Freedom" and, particularly, "One Increasing Purpose," is almost entirely absent from this new and delightful bit of Summer fooling. Neither those readers who liked the novels of purpose which made their author a best-seller nor others to whom these works were anathema can fail to enjoy "Big Business."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- The Newark Bears made it six in a row and increased their hold on first place to eleven and a half games today by a 7-to-1 victory over the Buffalo Bisons in the first contest of a series.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- Miss Mildred P.S. Hooker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ransom S. Hooker of New York, who on Aug. 27 is to become the bride of Dyson Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan, was the guest of honor this evening at a large dinner with dancing given by Mr. Duncan's parents at their Summer home, Bonniecrest.

THIS first novel of Miss Curtis Brown's is quite one of the most delightful that has appeared for a long time. Aside from all qualities of insight and imagination, it has a polish and a self-assurance rare even among seasoned novelists.

NORMAN THOMAS, Socialist candidate for the Presidency, is the author (in collaboration with Paul Blanshard) of a book entitled "What Is the Matter with New York?" to be published this Fall by the Macmillan Company.

A TOTAL of 150 religious programs are broadcast (by 325 stations reporting) on Sunday from 11 A.M. to noon, according to a survey made by George H. Betts, director of research at the Northwestern University School of Education.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11. -- Roman Catholics increased in numbers to a greater degree than did those of other faiths in the census decade between 1921 and 1931, and now make up about two-fifths of the population of Canada.

Despite intermittent reversals last week, almost every commodity vital to world trade and industry appreciated substantially in value. In view of the fact that the rally in many of them got under way even before the upturn in securities began, more than a month ago, this record is considered remarkable.

LIOENELL ATWILL, who has trouped with the best of them from London to Broadway -- and back again through the years -- has apparently come to rest in Hollywood. This is not said in the spirit of requiem, by either the chief character or any one else.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- The French capital has seldom gone so completely on holiday as it has this August. Streets have the quiet, deserted look of a provincial town of Southern France during a midday siesta. There is less noise than there ever has been since automobile horns were invented for the destruction of the nerves of mankind.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I explain and, if possible, end a misunderstanding between France and the United States concerning the question of war debts?

Traffic on three railroad lines, the Hudson tubes, the Pennsylvania and the Lehigh Valley, in the Journal Square district of Jersey City was at a standstill for nearly two hours last night as the result of a fire that caused $10,000 damage to the Waldo Avenue bridge, a wooden structure spanning the tracks between the old Hudson City section and what is known as Railroad Peninsula.

HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 13. (AP). -- A gale from the Gulf of Mexico that struck Houston tonight reached a velocity of 72 miles an hour, dropping back to 48, an dat 11:15 P.M. was gathering force again, having reached 70 miles.

Discussing the present tendency to apply local legislation to the regulation of motor boats, Charles F. McKivergan, writing in the current issue of Motor Boating, advises boatmen that the best way to oppose legislation detrimental to their interests is to support legislation which, in their view, is sound and just.

RECENT seasons have given us novels of the South more serious than this one, novels which have included in the space of a fictional narrative more of the history of the South, more of its contemporary sociological problems, and more of its conjectural future.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 13. -- The Columbia Oval Cricket Club today defeated the Brooklyn Cricket Club, 117 to 107, in a New York and New Jersey championship game at Warinanco Park. W. King made top score of 42 for the winners before he was run out.
It is a far cry from the foreign policy of the Harding Administration to that outlined by President Hoover and Secretary of State Stilmson. A decade has brought a great change.

TORONTO, Aug. 13. -- Gordon Taylor, Montreal 22-year-old who has been playing golf only six years, is Canada's amateur golf champion for 1932. He lifted the crown by defeating Jack Cameron, Toronto veteran of the tournament wars, 5 and 3, here today.

PARIS. FRANCE has decided once again to try to force prosperity to come to its film industry by closing the market to the greater number of foreign films. Since Germany has done the same thing quite recently it means the unless there is a sudden and unexpected reversal of opinion here the American distributers on the European Continent will have to withdraw from the field.

OF all possible titles, for his book, Mr. T.V. Smith undoubtedly chose the one surest to scare away the greatest number of readers. The usual American reader may be quite willing to consign all philosophers to Hades, but he prefers to have them stay there and has little use for their resurrected shades, whether concerned with the matters of modern America or ancient Greece.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11. -- A significant anniversary in the history of Canadian development was celebrated recently in Winnipeg. At the annual convention of the Canadian Seed Growers' Association there was unveiled a monolith to commemorate the first shipment of wheat from Western Canada.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- President Hoover plans to leave Washington tomorrow afternoon aboard a small inspection boat of the Department of Commerce for a few days of fishing and rest in Chesapeake Bay.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11. -- A Federal injunction has stilled what promised for a time to be one of the most bitterly contested issues in New Orleans in many years. The ordinance, its opponents charged, aimed at nothing less than driving all the Negroes off the docks of the port.

POTSDAM, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- The necessity for further substantial economies in State administration was stressed today by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in a luncheon speech before the non-partisan committee which welcomed him at Ogdensburg.

Plans for a campaign, looking toward a boycott of British goods in this country in retaliation for England's tariff wall against Ireland, which grew out of the dispute over Irish land annuities, were made yesterday at the first session of a twoday convention in the Hotel Astor of an organization known as the Irish Race.

IT has often been suspected that Japan wished China to tie weak and in chaos. Does America wish Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti and other States on the Caribbean to be weak and in chaos? You wish them to be politically stable and socially prosperous; but as their defense against an exterior foe you are happy enough to be in a position to fear none.

To the Editor of The New York Times. One is tempted to believe, after reading Mr. Oliver M. Sayler's article "Composers and American Ballet," in THE TIMES of July 31, that that gentleman has been sadly asleep during the past ten years. The number of ballets written by young American composers during that period of years (and really intended for dancing) is staggering.

THOSE drama lovers who have made a point in recent weeks of visiting the never-morenumerous Summer playhouses have found themselves a little nonplused by the activities of the Group Theatre at Dover Furnace, N.Y. Shortly after the Group settled down, in the middle of June, for three months in the country it announced two plays, "The Party," by Dawn Powell, and "Success Story," by John Howard Lawson.

DEFINITE announcement of prospective test flights early in the coming year for air-mail service across the South Atlantic by Lufthansa shows that limitations of range with payload of present aircraft have been firmly kept in mind by the German experts.

BUENOS AIRES, July 17, 1932. THE favorable results obtained by the local administration in meeting the present operatic crisis in the Argentine are already surpassing the anticipations of the newly appointed and not wholly experienced board of directors of the Teatro Colon as well as of our highly skeptical press.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The Boerse opened firm today and continued lively until shortly before the close, when it became known that Adolf Hitler had declined President von Hindenburg's invitation to enter the Cabinet. This report led to a reversal of the optimistic attitude.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11. -- With its streets canopied by great trees, its vine-covered buildings on hills overlooking Lake Mendota, and Lincoln in bronze looking down from the campus, the University of Wisconsin at Madison seems like a story book university.

IT is a long story of many and changing moods, this that tells the history of how normal mankind has regarded the blind from Homer to Helen Keller. It would be difficult to find in the whole story of civilization another that would so clearly prove the bettering quality through the marching centuries of the human heart.

THESE two books are, each in its own way, contributions to the rapidly growing literature of what is wrong with the powers that be. "Democracy at the Crossroads," while it comes with its best foot foremost as an attempt to "restate some of the fundamental principles of the Democratic party," is equally a recital of Republican shortcomings during the past twelve years.

MADRID, Aug. 13. -- With fanfares, bands and cheering crowds here, the Spanish Republic today eulogized the heroes of the past week and in Seville silently stripped the rebels of their uniforms and honors.

Wages and Living Costs. If wages should be based on the cost of living, and admitting living costs have declined approximately 20 per cent since 1929, is it not reasonable to consider the size of the average family whom the worker is trying to support?

PARIS, July 26. EVER since the end of the season -- that is to say, since the latter part of June -- the theatre has been looking around to take stock of itself. This has meant not only a count-up of what has been achieved but has involved a searching of spirit and an attempt to find out what is wrong, and why.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- The horse show dinner was held at the Maidstone Club this evening. An amateur cabaret performance was arranged by the club's entertainment committee, of which Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey is chairman. It took the form of a burlesque horse show, in which today's horse show judges awarded a silver cup for "conformation, gait and manners" to debutante contestants in hunting costume, riding tiny wooden hobbyhorses.

HARTFORD, Aug. 11. -- Connecticut is reasonably sure of having a third party of home manufacture in the field this November, as the result of opposition of dry groups to United States Senator Hiram Bingham, and so a new hazard is created for those who would predict the result in the State.

TOKYO, July 30. -- Summoning his readers to be faithful to the spirit of Japan and envisaging Japan as the protector and policeman of Asia, General Sadao Araki, Minister of War, expounds the spirit of Japanese nationalism and applies it to present-day problems in a five-column article published in the Kaikosha (Army Club Magazine) and translated in The Japan Advertiser.

KIND words concerning "Spring Song," recently produced by the Hedgerow Theatre, were set down for all to read in The Philadelphia Public Ledger by Arthur B. Waters. "Spring Song," whose Broadway future is not known at the moment, is a play by Bella Spewack, and its Pennsylvania presentation acquires some local interest through the fact that a piece on which Mrs. Spewack and her husband have collaborated is in preparation by Herman Shumlin.
Because of intervention by the courts we must wait another week to find out whether Governor Roosevelt will set a new Olympic record in Tossing the Mayor.

MANILA, Sunday, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Soldiers of the Thirty-first United States Infantry early today helped control a fire that destroyed the insular government's records buildings, two Catholic colleges and other structures in, the ancient Spanish walled city with a loss estimated by Fire Chief Ortiz Vanderfort at $2,500,000.

How 245,539 unemployed men have been provided with lodging, meals and clothing over a period of three years was discussed yesterday by Walter D. Britt, president of the Emergency Shelter, 257-261 Broome Street, in announcing the serving of the millionth meal at the institution.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- The peasant suddenly has become the most important figure in the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics, and the agrarian question, which in the final instance means the food question, overshadows industry, new construction and even the Five-Year Plan itself.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 13. -- Thousand of people have gone and are going back to the land in the States of Washington, Idaho, Montana and Oregon. The Federal Land Bank of Spokane, that operates in these four States, estimates that 50,000 persons have left Northwestern cities since 1929 to return to the farm, either as part-time or fulltime farmers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 (AP). -- About 3,000 miners, opposed to the $5 daily wage contract, voted at a mass meeting today to strike. Virtually all locals of the Springfield subdistrict were represented.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics turned Lefty Grove and Tony Freitas on the Boston Red Sox today to annex both games of a double-header, 13 to 2 and 8 to 2. By winning the Mackmen took undisputed possession of second place.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 13. -- With the British internationalist, Captain C.T.I. Roark riding well at No. 3, the Aurora polo team of Seymour Knox won its practice game from Eastcott, 9 to 7, on Cochran Field of the Meadowbrook Club this afternoon.

GENEVA. WORLD-MINDED students from the United States and half a hundred other countries who foregather in Geneva for Summer seminars or full-time study are soon to have at their disposal close to 3,000 volumes from the private library of Count Johann von Bernstorff, who was Germany's Ambassador at Washington from 1908 until 1917.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- President Hoover appointed today Norman Armour, counselor of the embassy, at Paris, as Minister to Haiti. He will succeed Dana G. Munro, who has occupied the Haitian post since June 28, 1930. No intimation of Mr. Munro's intentions was given in the White House announcement, which merely said:

MAURICE BARING'S first book was published more than thirty years ago, and since that time he has produced some fifty volumes. It is an abundant harvest for a man not yet turned 60 and one who has led anything but a sedentary life.

Activity in the wholesale markets here during the week reflected a general feeling of improvement, with a tendency toward heavier buying noted throughout, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

REALLOCATION of commercial radio waves above 545 meters to permit the addition of more channels to the present broadcast band in the United States is being considered as part of the policy of the American delegation to the International Radio Conference at Madrid, which begins Sept. 3.

ALTHOUGH much of the correspondence of Charles Dickens has been given to the public during past years, these collections have hitherto lacked the letters of the novelist to Thomas Beard, whom the author of "David Copperfield" designated as "his father's oldest friend."

More than 200 Salvation Army officers in eleven Eastern States were notified yesterday of new appointments. They will proceed to their new posts on Aug. 24, and welcoming meetings have been planned in the various cities to which they have been assigned.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13. -- Lieutenant Pahud de Mortanges of Holland won the individual championship in the three-day Olympic equestrian event today. Mounted on a great gelding Marcroix, he triumphed in the jumping competition, last of the program, wresting honors from Lieutenant E.F. Thomson of the United States, who was mounted on Jenny Camp.

PARIS. ECONOMIC and social conditions may have favored the early emancipation of women in America, but with all of our advantages it is doubtful that we have accomplished more than -- if as much as -- French and English women.

WASHINGTON, Aug 13. -- Having blanked the Washington Senators with three hits for nine innings and finding himself no better than even with the enemy at that stage. Charlie Ruffing stepped to bat today with two out in the tenth inning and whaled a liner into the left field bleachers for a home run and a 1-to0 decision.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- A ball was held here tonight at the Westchester Country Club in celebration of the Eastern grass court tennis championship tournament which was played this week on the courts of the clubhouse, with the finals taking place today and tomorrow.

PARIS, Aug. 11. -- The first half of the Winter fashion openings shows the couturiers again disputing the waistline location. The majority are standing for the normal level. Jean Patou is lowering belts to the hips. Schiaparelli is advocating a Directoire front that drops toward the back.
DETROIT, Aug. 13. -- Ray A. Graham, one of the three Graham brothers, builders of the Graham-Paige automobiles, committed suicide in Chatham, Ont., this morning by drowning.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13. -- The establishment of a clearing house of imperial settlements as an instrument for "creating an area of stability among countries regulating their currencies in relation to sterling -- the phrase used by the monetary committee of the Imperial Economic Conference in its report yesterday -- was foreseen here today by financial experts after study of the report.

Holding a majority vote in a house that numbered 48,000, the largest gathering to assemble at the Polo Grounds this year, the Dodgers shot their dashing pennant drive to a new high level yesterday by wrenching two more games from the Giants who, in the face of an irresistible blast of hits, collapsed about their leader, Memphis Bill Terry, as gracefully as circumstances would permit.

WARREN WILLIAM'S latest picture, "Skyscraper Souls," which has been held over for a second week lit the Capitol, has enough dramatic and amusing moments to make it a thoroughly satisfactory entertainment.

Colonle George N. Hoffman, chief of the army engineers in the North Atlantic division, will hold a public hearing in Albany this month on the question of Federal aid for the New York State Canal system. The hearing will be in the State Education Building on Aug. 25.

OVERMANTEL mirrors were an important and characteristic feature of old-time rooms, as many Colonial shrines throughout the country testify. Since the fireplace is generally the centre of interest in an interior, the mirror above it was often made a most elaborate example of the wood-carver's art.

The seventh annual $60,000 Hambletonian Stake, richest light-harness event in the world, will be held on Wednesday at the mile track in Goshen. This contest will be the feature of the five-day Grand Cir- cuit meeting which opens tomorrow.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Equipoise stamped himself more than ever as the best thoroughbred in the handicap division when he scored a decisive and expected victory today in the Whitney Stakes, but there was a surprise in store for the 15,000 spectators as William Woodward's Happy Gal turned the tables on Caterwaul and Ladysman in the Saratoga Special and triumphed in a manner which left the 2-year-old situation in rather a muddled state.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12. SOMETHING faintly approximating a second blooming has been going on in the local theatres. At least it would have been a second blooming if the season had ever boasted a first. In any case, June and July, usually still with a deadly quiescence, proved active and interesting, and even now things are happening.

EUROPEAN and French devotees of the radio were happy to hear recently that arrangements have been made to broadcast performances from the Paris Opera. The director, Jacques Rouche, has made arrangements with the Company "Radio-Paris."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 13. -- The State Legislature, after struggling through seven futile weeks of its special session, will turn, beginning Monday, to a general sales tax as a means of obtaining money for unemployment relief.

A large program for the elimination of grade-crossings, but not at the expense of the railroads, is advocated as an unemployment measure by Milton W. Harrison, president of the Security Owners' Association, in a statement issued yesterday. He pointed out that, despite the increase in motor car registrations and train movements since 1924, accidents at crossings had decreased in number.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Business activity showed little change in most of our foreign markets covered by the weekly survey of foreign economic conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.
GERMANY has nine broadcasting organizations corresponding to the principal subdivisions of the country. Berlin is the radio nerve centre of twentyfour broadcasting stations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Music Money" is destined to attract wide attention because of its definite presentation of the pending adjustment between the phonograph and radio companies and the publishers and authors.

Rubber consumed in this country in July amounted to 28,272 long tons, or 27.7 per cent less than the 39,116 tons in June, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Substantially offsetting this decline was a drop of 24.9 per cent to 31,078 tons in imports of crude rubber in the month.

THIS monograph by Mr. Taylor represents the results of his research in an attempt to establish the date of the composition of "Love's Labour's Lost." The play has been assigned by scholars in the past to the early period of Shakespeare's work.

FREDERICK DELIUS'S revision of his early opera "Koanga" has received a great deal of notice in the London press recently, and negotiations for the production of the work in that city are proceeding. "Koanga" is a three-act work, with prologue and epilogue, to a libretto by C.F. Keary, based on the American George W. Cable's novel "The Grandissimes."
BUDAPEST, July 30. -- A local beauty specialist has been unwittingly the means of enabling a daring rascal to reap a rich harvest.

Tuesday was a feverish day for the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa. The British delegates were hot about errors in the proposed Canadian schedules and possibly a little hasty and choleric in replying. There was a fine prospect of a row. So sacred are statistics, especially when prepared in a hurry.

HAVANA, Aug. 10. -- The government policy of withdrawing American currency from circulation and substituting Cuban silver, adopted at the time of the recent issue of some $3,000,000 in silver, has brought about a steady decline in the value of the Cuban silver dollar, which is now quoted at a discount of 2 3/4 to 3 per cent in the local exchange market.

GENEVA, Aug. 13. -- The Women's Consultative Committee, established to give the League of Nations Council the views of important organizations on equality in nationality, broke up into two factions today. Delegates of four of the eight organizations, when defeated by the chair's casting a vote, left the room in the secretariat, where the committee had been sitting for the past three days.

Once more, after 2,600 years, the great East Gate of ancient Mizpah is open -- this as the result of excavations made at this historical biblical site by the Tel Nasbeh Expedition under the direction of Professor William Bade, dean of the Pacific School of Religion in California.
GENEVA, Aug. 12. -- Senator Borah's recent statements on international affairs nave made perhaps an even stronger and more hopeful impression in Geneva than Secretary Stimson's.

BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- Rhode Island, small but mighty, is manfully grappling with an unemployment problem big enough for a State many times its size. The problem existed even in the flush times of three years ago. Were business by some magic process to return today to the levels of 1929 the industrial trends of the past decade would still be manifest and the unemployment problem would still be present.

Since the enormous enhancement in market values between July 9 and Aug. 11 was accomplished without any more than a negligible increase in brokers' borrowings, the inference which Wall Street naturally draws is that the purchase of securities has been conducted, almost entirely, on a cash basis.

The larger part of the President's speech of acceptance dealt with domestic affairs. Of them he displayed a grasp and mastery which will test the ability of any rival who ventures to attack him on that score. But Mr. HOOVER did not omit to give his views about the foreign policy which he thinks the United States ought to pursue.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Del Hanover's track record for 2-year-old trotters, established last year, went by the board today as the Newbrook Stable's fast filly, Marianna, sped to a sparkling victory in 2:13 flat at the Weequahic matinee.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Hungary's water polo team was declared champion of the tenth Olympiad today, by the International Swimming Federation. The unbeaten seven was given a score of eight for the round robin series, with Germany second and United States third.

SAN FRANCISCO. Aug. 11. -- Sentor Samuel M. Shortridge, for all his reputation as one who takes bought in the matter of manoeuvres, has manoeuvred himself into an embarrassing position by repudiating his party, its platform and President Hoover on the issue of the World Court.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 13. -- The strike of milk producers in Sioux City territory for higher prices resulted today in disturbances during which hundreds of gallons of milk were poured out on nearly every highway entering the city.

THE editors of this volume have been inclusive; the 122 contributions cover the field of sport exhaustively. There are stories, poems and newspaper accounts about duck hunting and chariot racing, bull fighting, boxing, mountain climbing, football, baseball, tennis, golf, fishing and many others.

BUDAPEST, July 29. -- John Nagy, after walking about serenely under sentence of death, liable to be executed at any moment, met his fate quite suddenly this morning. As he opened the door of his house to go to his morning's work, an Italian bullet which struck him in 1917 entered his brain and killed him.
MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 13. -- Another reaching breeze that danced back and forth along the top of the compass brought the New York Yacht Club fleet here today from Newport.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- The late season in Southampton has become known for its outstanding musical and artistio events, but this is the first year that a series of operatic performances has been planned. A series of presentations of scenes from famous operas will be inaugurated on Friday night of this week by singers of the Metropolitan Opera and other well-known artists in costume.

STEEL is again a centre of interest. The burly giant, which in normal times accounts for about one-fourth of America's total industry, is bestirring itself, girding for action, looking ahead to economic recovery. And by these signs all industry is encouraged, for as steel goes, so goes the nation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- After spending a lifetime interpreting and applying the laws, that master of them, Oliver Wendell Holmes, finds legal technicalities will cost him $10,000 this fiscal year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having taught boys for thirty-two years in a New York high school, I was deeply interested in the arraignment of public education in THE TIMES Magazine by the warden of Sing Sing Prison.
LONDON, Aug. 12. -- In spite of hard times everywhere, England, and London particularly, is now in an enviable position among the world's chief tourist centres.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 13 (AP). -- A denial that he told the mother of Haden Clarke, for whose slaying he is on trial, that he was so confused on the night of the shooting he sometimes thought he had killed her son was shouted from the witness stand today by Captain W.M. Lancaster, British aviator.

What is expected to be the last meeting for the present special committee appointed by the American Kennel Club to revise the constitution and by-laws and also the rules of the governing body of kennel affairs in this country will be held this week in this city.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) . -- My Dandy, 7-year-old gelding, added a new chapter to the story of his speed and courage today when he captured the third running of the Illinois Owners' Handicap at Hawthorne, worth $8,100 to the winner.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Theodore A. Lightner and Michael Gottlieb won the masters' pair championship late this afternoon at the fourth annual Summer tournament of the American Bridge League here. Their victory gives them custody of the von Zedtwitz Gold Cup for the coming year.

STOCKHOLM. HOW the civilization of the North sought and found expression in sagas, ballads, history, religion, folkways and the arts constitutes the general theme of an elaborate and important series, "Nordisk Kultur," in thirty volumes, which will be issued at the rate of three titles per year within the course of a decade.
OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Four convicts escaped from Sing Sing this afternoon, but because their modesty exceeded their daring they were back, and in solitary confinement, an hour later.
BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The government early this evening announced its determination to continue in office and go before the new Reichstag.
Many hunters would like to walk through a field and watch the tall grass move and say to themselves, "Maybe that's a pheasant."

WASHINGTON. THE United States has a new social phenomenon -- great numbers of transient boys. This is a development of the depression, especially noticeable during the past year, and has become a serious problem for social agencies.

Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday that Mrs. Alice Eno Hopkinson, wife of Henry L. d'Aubigne Hopkinson, a member of the British diplomatic service, was entitled to receive the income of a $250,000 trust fund created for her by her greatuncle, Amos F. Eno, who died in 1915, despite the fact that her legal residence and domicile had changed.

NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 13. -- The annual reunion of the Canadian branch of the Hoover Family was held in Victoria Park, Ontario, this afternoon, with over 150 descendants of Abraham and David Hoover in attendance.

RADIO performers and announcers get more than fan mail. They are recipients of gifts galore. A flood of merchandise wearable, eatable and alive is found in the packages and crates that the express and mailmen deliver to the studios.

BEFORE I went to Europe I had an idea that the whole place was upset -- that there were strife and political unrest over territorial assignments. I have examined the matter and find that out of 450,000,000 people in Europe less than 10,000,000 are dissatisfied over territorial assignments.

NEWPORT -- The debutantes of the Newport season of 1932 are coming into their own this week, when four young women are to make their official bows. In keeping with the times and the trend of entertaining this year, the introductions will be made without the usual accompanying big "coming-out party."

TOTNES, England. THERE is something contradictory, to an American in England, in making a journey of many miles from the familiar environs of Piccadilly and professional London down into Devon to find on an old country estate what la perhaps the most significant dance movement in the country.

NOTHING lends itself more readily to the English type of suit than herringbone tweeds. That easy-to-wear, thoroughly satisfactory outfit that is associated with the English woman -- though American women have always taken to it readily -- is going to be the thing for town and country in the early Fall.

MADRID, Aug. 12. -- A handful of "generals of the King," retired for suspected disloyalty to the republic, virtually destroyed this week the hopes of their side. They gambled for a return to power and, paradoxically enough, strengthened by their display of force against it the regime they sought to destroy.

LONDON. THE publication of a new edition, even of a literary classic, is not ordinarily a matter of importance. But there are exceptions. Most possessors a Matthew Arnold's "Culture and Anarchy" will be surprised to learn that their own copy of it does not represent the book in its original form.

SEATTLE, Aug. 13 (AP). -- A criticism of President Hoover's recommendation that the States deal individually with prohibition, made by Mrs. Ella A. Boole, president of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, wag telegraphed to the Chief Executive today' by the national convention of the organization here.

LAKELAND, Fla., Aug. 11. -- A discharged Lakeland grocery clerk, who had spent several days in a vain effort to find another job, counted out half of his $40 savings, placed it on a bolita ticket and won $1,600.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The Pittsfield Polo Club, of which Donald M. Weston is president, is to play the Farmington Valley Club of Hartford on the Z. Marshall Crane field at Mr. Weston's estate, Holmesdale, at Pittsfield, on Saturday afternoon for the benefit of Berkshire Farm for Boys at Canaan, N.Y. Parking places are to be sold.

GANANOQUE, Ont., Aug. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Gananoque's paddlers today won the international canoe regatta with a total of 50 points. The Pendleton Club of New York was second with 15 and the Balmy Beach Club of Toronto third with 14.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1. -- Argentina's public debt, including national, provincial and municipal indebtedness, has reached a total of 5,397,876,326 pesos, $1,349,469,084), and the unfunded portion of it can no longer be covered from general revenues, according to the annual report of the Corporation of Argentine Bondholders.

WARSAW, Aug. 13. -- Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York, chairman of the Congressional Committee on Immigration, arrived here today, and although he is on a honeymoon trip he intends to investigate complaints made by both Jewish and non-Jewish would-be emigrants from Poland against American medical officers in the Warsaw Consulate of unduly restricting and delaying visas.

TODAY. 4:39 P.M. -- WABC-WEAF -- President Hoover speaks from Washington on the occasion of the unveiling ceremonies of a memorial to his Eminence, the late James Cardinal Gibbons. The statue, presented to the District of Columbia by the Knights of Columbus, stands in a park in front of the Shrine of the Sacred Heart Church in the capital city.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Seizing a brief interlude from the hearing on Mayor Walker, Governor Roosevelt completed plans today for a wide swing over the nation which will start on Sept. 12 on a tour to the Pacific Coast and the Northwest.

THE power of the Briand-Kellogg treaty cannot be adequately appraised unless it is assumed that behind it rests the combined weight of the opinion of the entire world, united by a deliberate covenant which gives to each nation the right to express its moral judgment.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Twice breaking the record for the 30-mile heat and setting a new mark for the 90-mile total race, Horace E. Dodge's Delphine IV, piloted by Bill Horn of Newport News, Va., captured the Gold Cup, America's premier speedboat prize, on Lake Montauk today, to register a decisive victory over George Reis's El Lagarto.

A detailed report of the first archaeological expedition to examine the ruins of the recently discovered ancient Maya city of Calakmul, found buried In the depths of the vast tropical forests of the Yucatan Peninsula, in the southern part of the State of Campeche, Mexico, is made public today by the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

EVEN for a celebrity who dreads no oblivion it is a wise precaution to be born a Scot. A nation, exulting in its monopoly of intellect, treasures as priceless whatever of tradition, of document or of pedigree appertains unto its men of genius.

THE theatrical history of the Marx Brothers is just about as confusing as their theatrical works. They were once -- along with a couple of relatives -- the Six Musical Mascots. Later they called themselves the Four Nightingales. One of them began as a singer in a church choir, and another ones held a job as a bellboy in a hotel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Inadvertent homicide -- one person killing another, almost always by shooting, without previous intent, but because one or both parties were armed when an unexpected situation developed -- is a frequent occurrence. The gun-toting habit is responsible for the loss each year in the United States of several hundred lives.

MEMBERS of the Grolier Club of New York who are unable to leave town for the Summer will find consolation in a remarkable exhibition now in progress at the club. The large display room is given over completely to a one-man show, revealing the talents of Bruce Rogers, this country's foremost designer of books.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 11. -- The conclusion of the non-aggression pact between Poland and the Soviet Union is a disturbing and highly unwelcome development for the Rumanian Foreign Office, which, since its own failure to achieve a similar treaty with the Soviets, has used every means in its power to prevent Poland from doing so.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Axon, owned by Lucius Eastman, was the winner of the Sound interclub class competition, one of the features of the thirty-sixth annual regatta conducted by the Huguenot Yacht Club today.

ONLY five of Broadway's theatres are lighted these nights. Roof gardens are half empty and speakeasies complain that no one is in a mood for pleasure. But before you take their dismal word for it, go out and spend a Sunday at Coney.

A new combination of equipment, the club-diner car, is being experimented with by the New York Central Railroadmen certain of its trains. So far, the innovation has not only helped the railroad to reduce the operating costs of these trains, but it has also proved popular with its patrons, many volunteering their commendations.
