ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 13. -- Unfavorable weather prevented Professor Piccard from making an ascent in his balloon today, and this and other factors caused him to postpone the attempt until next Wednesday or Thursday.

GOUCHER COLLEGE has committed itself to a modern experimental program in its personnel methods. Though its requirements were already liberal, it has taken this year a very important step by adopting the following paragraph of the report of its committee on admissions:

TWO exhibitions alleviated the midsummer heat of the past week in New York. The Roerich Museum hung a group of contemporary German prints from the collection of Erica Cohen of this city and the Midtown Gallery opened its August cooperative.

While selling pressure on the Stock Exchange subsided somewhat yesterday, the market continued its downward readjustment in active dealings. The volume was 1,756,000 shares. The decline was almost negligible by comparison with that of Friday, but there were scattered losses of considerable size.

Despite the reaction in bond prices yesterday the listed market showed last week the greatest advance in domestic corporation bond prices of any week this year but one, the exception being that ended on June 4, when announcement was made of the formation of the so-called "bond pool."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Driving out twenty-four hits and sending four twirlers from the mound, the Cities Service nine, representing Semper Fidelis Post of Buffalo, won the final game of the American Legion Junior State championship today, defeating Poughkeepsie, winner in the Eastern sectional games, by the score of 29 -- 8.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13. -- Except for an hour or so at the opening of the Ottawa race meet this afternoon and a little fishing in near-by streams tomorrow, the delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference have abandoned their usual prolonged week-end diversions to rush the preparations for closing their long parley next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Aug. 6 were higher than in the two preceding weeks, but considerably below the level of a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 13. -- England was eliminated today from the men's singles of the Eastern grass court championship on the courts of the Westchester Country Club when Henry W. (Bunny) Austin, the No. 1 ranking English player, was defeated in the semi-final round by Clifford Sutter of New Orleans in straight sets, 6-1, 6-3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Secretary Stimson in his New York speech last Monday night revitalized the Kellogg-Briand anti-war pact, in the opinion of Judge Yuen-li Liang, formerly judge of the Shanghai Court of Appeals, now technical delegate to the League of Nations and The Hague Conference for the Codification of International Law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- A complaint against the use of Federal troops in evicting the Bonus Army, signed by forty-one persons, including Dr. John Dewey, New York educator, and Roy W. Howard, of the Scripps-Howard newspapers, has been presented to White House officials.

A 17-year-old boy was fatally burned, a woman was seriously burned and at least fourteen other persons, mostly children, received either burns or injuries early yesterday morning when fire swept through two dwelling houses in not far separated sections of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Dorothee Gray McDonnell, 27 years old, divorced wife of Francis Roosevelt McDonnell, wealthy young broker of this city, ended her life early yesterday morning by swallowing an overdose of a sleeping potion in her apartment at 425 East Fifty-first Street, which she had occupied by sublease since July 1.

LONDON. HARD times have overtaken the English public schools. Increases in the fees which the schools charge, together with decreases in the parental incomes out of which the fees have to be paid, have combined to embarrass both the schools and the parents.

SOME activity was reported during the week for the first time on the new Fall lines being shown by stores here. This was about the only feature to trade developments. With only a few exceptions, furniture sales have not realized expectations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democratic convention made the biggest blunder in platform building in the history of political parties of our country in adopting the freak method for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment outlined in the Republican platform.

Moderate weakness in the share market yesterday was the result of more orderly selling and contrasted strikingly with the convulsive decline occasioned by the heavy unloading of stocks in the final hour of trading on the Stock Exchange on Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter to THE TIMES from the Treasurer of the State of Florida declaring that the State has never defaulted nor repudiated any part of its public debt, conflicts with the schedule of Florida's unpaid State debts given in the current (fifty-eighth) Annual Report of the Council of Foreign Bondholders in London, which estimates the total of outstanding repudiated Florida State bonds at about $6,650,000.

ON the way to the United States from France I conferred in Paris with General Pershing and in Versailles with Genera Bliss. Each of these officers put before me, for my consideration, the problem of getting more men to France.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13. -- Pepped up by the cool breezes of the Golden Gate Olympic athletes of the British Empire and the United States went through light work-outs today for the fifth Empire American track and field meet tomorrow. With them were five Japanese who also participated in the Olympic contests in Los Angeles.

PARIS. THE J. Walter Bountifuls of New York, descendants of the well-known Lady Bountiful, of whom you may remember reading, are in Europe again this Summer with their kinsfolk from Pittsbursh, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, Palm Beach and points between, but there are not so many of them as usual.

College and theological seminary presidents and professors will be the guest preachers today in several of the leading churches. Although many of the churches will have visiting clergymen, several being from Great Britain, a number of pastors are curtailing or interrupting their vacations to deliver the sermons in their own pulpits.

Reports have been drifting in from Los Angeles and from Texas that Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, Olympic champion track and field star, and all-around athlete, will compete in the next national golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 6 amounted to 496,033 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 14,654 cars fewer than in the preceding week, 238,697 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 408,124 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

AN all-Gershwin program will be given Tuesday night at the Lewisohn Stadium toy the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Albert Coates, with William Daly as guest conductor, will direct. George Gershwin and Oscar Levant will be piano soloists.

When play starts in the forty-fifth women's national tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, L.I., tomorrow, the leading player in women's ranks will be missing, as Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, now in France, will not defend her title.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Aug. 11. -- Governmentally speaking, Arkansas is pondering upon purse-strings and pocketbook locks. With a fierce political campaign in full swing the State is supplementing campaign promises with a generous turnover of initiative legislation.

INTO this volume of 642 pages Professor Callahan has packed all the facts and dates, without any surplusage of statement, of more than a century of relations with Mexico. It is, therefore, indispensable to diplomats, legislators and students.

PEARL BUCK, author of the latest Pulitzer Prize novel, is here for the first time since "The Good Earth" was chosen as the most noteworthy book of fiction of the year. Although she is an American, she comes more or less as a stranger; our ways are not her ways.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 13. -- R.H. Helsel broke 50 straight targets to capture the regular shoot at the Nassau Trapahooting Club today. F.C. Chapman won the high handicap cup, defeating H, Frankling in a shoot-off.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13. -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs gave a statement to the press this afternoon recognizing that whatever action was taken in the Chaco conflict must be taken by the commission of neutrals in Washington and stating that the commission had the cooperation of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru.

The eclipse of Aug. 31, 1932, at which the chances of clear weather are about even, furnishes the last promising opportunity until Aug. 21, 2017, for American astronomers to gather the vital scientific information offered by a total eclipse, Dr. S.A. Mitchell, director of the Leander McCormick Observatory of the University of Virginia, has declared in his study of solar physics during the past decade, just published by the Columbia University Press.

LONDON. WHEN the International Cinematograph Congress met here some six weeks ago there was considerable discussion about raising the standard of the motion picture. At that time James Welsh, a vice president of the association, suggested that if the public ever shows that it wants films of a higher standard, it will get them.

THE PRESIDENT OF SPAIN. TOPSY and tur are the children of revolution. A king occopies a royal palace and rules as his ancestors ruled for five centuries. Then a republican moves into the palace from a jail. A fewmonths later soldiers surround the royal-republican palace to protect the one-time prisoner from adherents of the king, while the jail is now filled with monarchists.

A summary of the work carried on by the Employment Stabilization Institute of the University of Minnesota reads drably like a brief explanation of any one of a hundred projects with similar aims. They all involve "an intensive study of the economic background" of the local unemployment conditions.

YONDER," says Mrs. Rawson "may mean almost any where but the place in which we stand * * * but that is where the old roads always led, and if they chanced to be New England trails or coach roads they led you to the even fairer land of 'yender.' "

IT has seemed to the management of Roosevelt Field that too little is done for the pleasure and entertainment of the private flier. There is a lack of organized fun where "birds of a feather can get together" and go places and do things in the companionship of kindred spirits.

PANAMA, R.P., Aug. 10. -- Foreign banks in Colombia are threatened with a strike on debts owed them, a boycott and an appeal to Congress to legislate against them by the committee of the debtors of foreign banks, which met recently in Bogota.

TEHERAN, July 12. -- Probably the wealthiest tribal chieftain and feudal lord in Persia is the Qavam-ul-Mulk who has been exiled from his ancestral domain in the Shiraz region and obliged by a law passed on June 7 to take in exchange for his properties in the tribal areas some scattered government estates in central and northern Persia.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 13. -- Into the burnished gold of a setting California sun rode the crew of the Golden Gate today to carry on the twelve-year-old tradition of American majesty in eight-oared racing.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y. -- One of the most picturesque events of the midseason in the Adirondacks will be the annual carnival in aid of the Elizabethtown Community House, which is to be an event of Thursday if the day is fair or, if not, of Friday.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 13 , (AP). -- Frankie Parker, Milwaukee's 16year-old tennis ace. today bowed himself out of competition among the younger set by winning the national junior singles title after being outplayed for two sets by Gene Mako of Los Angeles.

In his introduction to the first volume of his State Papers, covering the year 1929, Governor Roosevelt speaks of the great help the decisions and opinions of former Governors have been to him in the discharge of his duty, and adds: "It has been surprising to me often to find that many matters of apparently new present-day policy have some parallel or precedent in bygone years."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Martial law was proclaimed, throughout Chile today after the police and soldiers had put down a short-lived rebellion against the government by students of the University of Chile. The government explained that the proclamation of martial law was a precautionary measure.

Plans for the purchase of about 3,000,000 bales of cotton held directly or indirectly by the Federal Farm Board have taken such definite form that, unless there is an unexpected delay, they will be placed before the board in Washington early this week by a syndicate of cotton-mill and financial interests.

Fearing that numerous drives to effect tax reduction will "lead to unwise economy -- the worst sort of extravagance" or defeat the main purpose by approaching the problem from a variety of angles, John E. Edgerton, president of the Tennessee Manufacturers' Association and chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday urged business men to unite on a specific program and adhere to the plan until their objective is attained.

ALBANY, Aug. 13. -- With the removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker only half completed, it appeared today that three witnesses might be summoned to corroborate the explanations the Mayor has offered to Governor Roosevelt.

BAR HARBOR. -- The British Navy has fought and sailed away, and, the colonists hope, will return to fight another day on the tennis courts of the Bar Harbor Club. The honors -- in the International Maritime Tennis Tournament -- go with the departing guests, and a British naval victory is once more inscribed on the silver Mount Desert Trophy.

The open season for Fall hay fever starts tomorrow, according to medical experts, and "from this date until late October capricious breezes carry the sneeze-provoking pollen of the ragweed and the goldenrod indiscriminately to the nostrils of bankers and shipping clerks, lawyers and steel workers, ex-Presidents and taxi drivers."

BIRMINGHAM, Aug. 11. -- Some of the so-called "vested Interests" in Alabama, as elsewhere, have found cold comfort and little profit during the depression, but they are still surrounded by enough legendry of capital and income to make them presentable as a political issue.

In a letter recently published in THE TIMES an up-State correspondent remarks that the centralized schools, which are gradually superseding the little white schoolhouse, are shaping the farm boy and girl in "the cheap town mold." Being better equipped with material accessories, the centralized schools do somewhat urbanize the pattern of rural education.

AGAIN we have Sir John Saumarez, the actor-manager, in the role of a detective. Once before he has played this part in order to prove the innocence of the woman who afterward became his wife. In the present story it is Sir John's young friend, Peter Varley, who is in trouble.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- After an absence of a week from Great South Bay the yachtsmen who are enrolled in the yacht-racing squadron of the Westhampton Country Club resumed their weekly races off the Speonk shore today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Repeating their championship per formances at Southampton last month, two national horse show champions of 1930, Lady Margaret and Lady Mildred, triumphed today in the saddle classes of the East Hampton Riding Club's eighth annual show.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- State and Federal development projects on Long Island which are scheduled to begin within the next few weeks will furnish employment for approximately 2,500 men for a period of at least three months, and for some of that number until the Spring of 1933, it was revealed today by J.J. Darcy, superintendent of the State Department of Public Works, at his office here.

HELSINGFORS. JUST across the street from the ultra-modern Parliament bulk ing, where the Finnish legislators recently abandoned the vain battle to enforce prohibition stand a dozen freshly painted signs about twelve feet high advertising in gay colors whiskies, brandies, port,. rum aperitifs and French and Span ish wines.

Announcement yesterday by the Hahn Department Stores, Inc., that heads and buyers of the twenty-eight member stores will henceforth be granted authority and initiative in operations was seen here yesterday as a highly significant departure from centralized merchandising control which will open a "new era" in the market generally, particularly with respect to group buying and the relations between store buyers, salesmen and sources of supply.

Completion of a nation-wide survey to determine the most practical and effective means used to achieve reduction of retail operating costs was announced yesterday by the Controllers' Congress and the Store Management Group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- Certain things the City of London accepts for granted; for example, the return to the gold standard. It is convinced that the coming World Conference shall consecrate this return to gold as the common foundation for the currencies of all civilized countries.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Closing the first halt of their month of training today with a high record of efficiency in military, citizenship and athletic branches, students of the C.M.T.C. have been complimented by Brig. Gen. Howard L. Laubach, who says he expects the personnel to establish one of the highest ratings ever made by a similar camp.

THE appearance of Mayor James J. Walker before Governor Roosevelt at Albany in removal proceedings marked the climax of an inquiry by the Hofstadter Legislative Committee that has not only exposed the questionable actions of individuals but has thrown new light on the system under which New York City has been governed for many years.

LAKELAND, Fla., Aug. 11. -- Now that the first wave of excitement over conditions in Florida's prison camps has subsided, it appears that the facts are not nearly so ugly as they were commonly believed to be. Floridians generally have been aroused to action as a result of the alleged "sweat box" murder of young Arthur Maillefert, but that tragedy has come to be regarded as an isolated case of brutality.

The Lee, Higginson Trust Company of Boston has petitioned for the appointment of the Marine Midland Trust Company as successor trustee under the debenture agreement dated March 1, 1929, between the Kreuger Toll Company, the Lee, Higginson Trust Company and Lee, Higginson Co.

VIENNA. July 29. -- Austrians, like Germans, are accustomed to have a paternal State hedge in their lives with sanctions and prohibitions, but for Austrians is reserved the privilege of having this more or less benign control of personal liberty extended back literally to the cradle, for the Federal Chancellor's Department now controls the matter of the Christian names of baby Austrians.

ROME, Aug. 13. -- Guglielmo Marconi has made another advance in the science of radio communication by "bending" ultra-short radio waves which heretofore he had been unable to transmit through obstacles, he disclosed today.

Announcements of bond redemption calls last week, both for the current month and for future dates, were of small denomination and few in number. The total for August is now $56,069,000, compared with $26,116,000 in July, and $113,744,000 in August, 1931, for corresponding weeks.

OFFICIALS of the united States Postoffica Department are now considering a new departure in the handling of certain types of air mail which, if put into execution, will start something of a revolution in the fast-changing business of communications.

The Cherry Valley Club, located within two or three brassle shots of the Long Island station at Garden City, will be the scene of a little national amateur championship Tuesday, when the leading amateurs in the district gather for the elimination round to decide which of the metropolitan area's golfers will be eligible to play in the championship at Five Farms next month.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN Al Jolson's "The New Yorker" reaches the Broad way screen several million Manhattan residents will be able to sit in judgment on the boast of the local Chamber of Commerce that any part of the world can be duplicated within a few miles of Los Angeles.

Formal observance on Thursday of the thirteenth birthday of the German Republic was not a joyful occasion. One report speaks of the scene in the Reichstag chamber as a funeral rather than a holiday. The friends of the republic absented themselves. The official rites were performed by a Government that is supposed to be anti-republican at heart.

The New York Railways Corporation is preparing to submit to the Board of Estimate in the Fall a comprehensive plan of bus operation in Manhattan, including motorization of its own surface-car system, acquisition and motorization of the surface-car lines of the New York Harlem Railroad on Madison and Fourth Avenues and the linking of all motorized lines with the crosstown routes now under "outlaw" operation.

PROVINCETOWN. A of every living organism, change is an inalienable concomitant of art. It is nowise in accepting but alone in trying to interpret this truism that now and then we are forced to sound the tog whistle -- one of those low-couched fogs, giving little trouble to mariners who encounter it in their vista of centuries, though not infrequently a pea-souper at close range.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The veteran southpaw of the Reds, Eppa Rixey, blanked the Pirates, 3 to 0, today and registered his third victory of the season -- all of them over Pittsburgh.

WITH naval aviation appropriations severely curtailed for the coining fiscal year by the government's economy program, and with considerable agitation for disarmament in the air, as well as on the land and sea, the immediate future of the flying fleet is not considered bright.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- The release of 132,000,000 pounds of government-owned coffee on Sept. 1 will delay at least until the middle of October the threatened coffee famine, George S. Milnor. president of the Grain Stabilization Corporation, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- With apparently nowhere else to go and determined to be with a candidate who has a chance of winning, several ultra-dry leaders were, falling in line today behind the standard of President Hoover.

Mayor Walker, resting over the week-end at the Larchmont estate of his friend, A.C. Blumenthal, theatrical financier, spent yesterday relaxing and preparing for the final phase of the removal proceedings before Governor Roosevelt, which will begin tomorrow.

The block-aid campaign closed yesterday with a total of $1,311,994 collected, although when final figures are tabulated this week the amount is expected to reach $1,350,000. Stamp sales for the nineteenth week amounted to $25,977.31, it was announced yesterday by Wilton LloydSmith, chairman of the Block Community Organization.

With the passing of the Aug. 1 maturity date, generally regarded as the most critical of the year for the industry, the public utility companies have left most of their financial problems behind and are viewed as in good condition to meet the remaining refunding needs of the year.

MOTOR vehicle production in the United States and Canada in July amounted to 112,600 units, according to an estimate by the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce. This was 41 per cent under the production for the preceding month and 49 per cent under that for the corresponding period in 1931.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The text of the radio speech delivered tonight by President Harriman of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States follows:

The Presidential campaign began last Thursday night in Washington so far as the Republicans are concerned. For the Democrats it started weeks ago. But the Republicans were obliged to keep their big guns covered until Herbert Hoover, in delivering what is officially known as a "speech of acceptance," outlined the party position and informed the enemy to come and take it if they could.

THIS novelette is perhaps the first book to treat of aviation with any significance. Like other novels about flying, and like the true stories of fliers, it possesses thrills. It is unique for also possessing point. The conquest of the air, as the romantic-minded would put it, does not exist in this book simply because men love adventure and excitement, or because of the living poetry in such exploits.

The largest Dutch touring group to visit this country, 115 men and women, who arrived a week ago on the Holland-America liner Statendam, sailed away on the same ship early yesterday morning weary in body and mind. They went on board the Statendam at 9:30 o'clock Friday night and all retired immediately, confessing that the pace of New York was too much.

Professor Erich Regener came into notice by his measurements of the intensity of the cosmic rays in deep water. Like Millikan, he sank his instruments in mountain lakes, which are fed by melting glaciers and which are therefore uncontaminated by radium.

A second dividend of 15 per cent to the depositors in the American Union Bank was ordered paid yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler. The court by its action approved the application of Deputy State Superintendent of Banking August Ihlefeld, in charge of the liquidation of the bank, which was closed a year ago.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- Today, on the thirteenth day of the month in which the German Republic was founded thirteen years ago, negotiations between the present German Government and Adolf Hitler, Austrian house painter, who conceived a great movement for the regeneration of Germany and created out of it a private army with 13,500,000 votes behind it, have reached their climax.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 13. Japan's invasion of Manchuria was dictated partly by the desire to make a second Russo-Japanese war impossible, according to George E. Sokolsky, former editor of The Far Eastern Review and author of "The Tinderbox of Asia," who told the Institute of Politics today that every step taken by Japan in Manchuria today made such a war more remote.

OUT of the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry, which recently closed its twelfth season, is evolving a new technique for the higher education of manual workers -- a technique of imparting abstract ideas through chart and model, graph and machine rather than through the printed book.

CALUMET, Mich., Aug. 11. -- Without the new tariff of 4 cents a pound en copper effective June 21 the Michigan copper country did not have a chance to come back; with the tariff the copper mining industry in Michigan has as good a chance as any other line of business, says A. E. Petermann, general counsel for the Calumet Hecla and other copper mining companies in the Keweenaw Peninsula.

To Archbishop USSHER, who thought human history a matter of 4,000 years, ELIJAH must have been a Dawn Man. Only 3,000 years ago the prophet climbed Carmel to pray for rain and watch for "a little cloud out of the sea like a man's hand." On a ledge below him slept in death men who had hunted over Canaan fully 25,000 years before.

THE art of medicine embraces the understanding of illness, and if the physical and biological sci- ences are given a too exclusive attention they are apt to give to medical thought a too pronounced objectivity. We need to take count of the whole man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- An immediate change in the Volstead act to permit sale of non-intoxicating beer, with $6 a barrel tax, followed by prompt repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment, was advocated tonight by Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System, setting forth "the obstacles which confront economic recovery."

FOR five months the guns at Shanghai have been silent. Chapei, Woosung, Shiozawa, General Tsai, the Nineteenth Route Army that refused to run, these are once-familiar names now hazily remembered. The news reels and the rotogravure sections have long since sought fresh fields and other heroes.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The horse is on its last legs in London. Although drastic action is not yet contemplated, the police have decided to introduce regulations which will ultimately result in horse-drawn traffic disappearing from principal streets.

With gold returning to this country in a steady flow and the volume of money in circulation showing a tendency to decline, the Federal Reserve System is expected in the coming months to make less and less use of the privilege given it under the Glass-Steagall bill of using the United States Government securities as collateral for reserve note circulation.

REGULATED private enterprise, a device of comparatively modern invention, has been accepted, by many liberals as a solution of the problem of public utilities. It was installed to prevent what seemed to be the evils of unrestricted competition on the one hand and of unrestrained monopoly on the other, and there was quite a beating of drums and tooting of horns at the time.

MILE CHANEL first launched her luscious soft wool jersey, exquisite to the touch and lovely to behold, several years ago. Ever since the first yardage made its appearance its popularity has been gaining momentum. This Fall a New York house has turned its attention to this fabric and is putting out an interesting collection of sports dresses of the kind to be worn with or without a coat.

MOST omnibus collections of this kind are pretty dreary affairs; but here is an assortment of week-end literature which should succeed in pleasing almost every taste, without boring the most discriminating. For it contains both an amazing variety and an amazing quantity of good things.

NEW ORLEANS. HUEY PEARCE LONG, Kingfish and junior Senator of Louisiana, is back home mending his fences. Not that they need any great amount of mending. They are so strong that he has had time to run up to Arkansas and there, in the words of Mrs. Caraway, his Senate colleague, after her victory last week in the Senatorial primary, proved himself "invaluable in his efforts in my behalf."

TWO short years ago, the phrase "diversion of road funds" was quite unknown to the average motorist. Then, only $15,000,000 of the money contributed by motorists to road building through gasoline taxes and motor-license fees was used for purposes other than road building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Paul Knabenshue of Toledo, consul general at Jerusalem, has been assigned minister resident, and consul general at Bagdad. The consulate general there was raised last year to a legation bu this is the first appointment of a minister resident to that post.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Merchandise exports valued at $382,000,000 in the second quarter of 1932 were $224,000,000, or 22 per cent, less than in the corresponding period last year, while imports valued at $350,000,000 represented a decline of $189,000,000, or 16 per cent, in the same period, according to an analysis made public today by the Commerce, Department.

For twenty-one years from May 1, 1933, the building at 11 West Twenty-second Street, twenty-eight feet wide, has been leased by Helen Emily Moulton of Dinard, France, to the executors and trustees of the wills of Louis and Isaac Stern at a yearly rental of $5,000 in addition to the taxes,

An appeal to Secretary of War Patrick J. Hurley to lease to New York City for park purposes at a nominal rental the site now occupied by Fort Schuyler, which is to be abandoned, has been made on behalf of the City Club of New York by its president, Richard S. Childs, whose letter to Secretary Hurley was made public yesterday.
In its budget request for $19,811,598 for 1933 the Department of Hospitals asks $2,549,685 for food or $300,314 less than the same item in the corrent budget allowance.

In anticipation of a modification of the Volstead act or repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, the National Distillers Products Corporation has promised its stockholders that it will turn over to them, in due course, a part of it "irreplaceable inventory" of 700.000 cases of whisky "aged in the wood for fifteen years or more."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A 35-year-old psychopathic patient in City Hospital, who soon was to be released as cured, was in a state of delirium today as he brooded over an accident that caused the death of a fellow-patient, William Chase, 26.

A two-way Polish Corridor has been suggested hopefully in the discussions at Williamstown. It is Mr. ARNOLD TOYNBEE'S idea that the stretch of Polish territory interposed between Germany proper and East Prussia might be placed either under joint Polish-German or neutral jurisdiction, with complete freedom of transit for the two countries.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- A.F. Broderick's Bozo led seventeen craft across the finish line in the interclub class race of nine miles conducted under the burgee of the American Yacht Club today. Leading from the turn Bozo was clocked in 2 hours, 14 minutes, and 41 seconds.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 14 -- This was a day of rest for those aboard the racing craft in the New York Yacht Club's cruise. The schooners, sloops and yawls lay at anchor in the harbor and most of the yachtsmen and their guests came ashore to motor or roam about the countryside.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- With the Alabama, Champlain, Spinaway and Travers in prospect as outstanding events during the coming week nere, the meeting of the Saratoga Association is certain to go on to phases more interesting even than those which have entertained many thousands of followers of the turf during the past fortnight.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover's stand on prohibition, as outlined in his speech accepting the Republican Presidential nomination, was commended in a formal statement issued today by the national board of trustees of the Crusaders, anti-prohibition organization.

The problem today is how ,nations are going to live with each other, the Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, pastor of the Westbourne Church, Glasgow, Scotland, said yesterday at the Riverside Church, 122nd Street and Riverside Drive. Dr. Burnet is being considered as a possible successor to the Rev. Dr. Henry Howard, retiring pastor of the Fifth Avenue Pres-byterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

In spite of persistent rumors in the financial district that rapid transit unification is "just around the corner," there is virtually no hope for consummation of a unity plan for many months, it was indicated yesterday by responsible public officials.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- A comparatively light supply of choice weighty beef steers held the market at $9.75 a hundredweight throughout last week, with an occasional dip to $9.50. Medium to good grades of steers were in fair supply at around $8 to $9.25.

The dominating characteristic of the bar of this country is mediocrity, in the opinion of Dudley Cammett Lunt,' practicing attorney of Wilmington, Del., whose book, "The Hoad to the Law," will be published today by Whittlesey House, McGraw-Hill Book Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Hoover has called a national conference of the business and industrial committees of the twelve Federal Reserve districts to meet in Washington Aug. 26, to map a coordinated nation-wide program of action against the economic depression.

Two men who had climbed to the roof of a seventeen-story loft building at 225 West Thirty-seventh Street last night and had begun to cut their way through to the top floor with an electric hand-drill, according to the police, were checked in their effort by the arrival of two, patrolmen.

Plans were announced yesterday by W. Piotrowski, commissioner of the Polish National Alliance of America, for an elaborate reception for the Polish Olympic team on its arrival here from Los Angeles, where it made a creditable showing in the Olympic Games.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The financial markets here are being influenced quite remarkably by the recovery in Wall Street, which indicates the importance attached to developments in American markets. London's interest first became important a few weeks ago, when the extraordinary low level to which American securities had fallen led British investors to acquire substantial blocks of the better and obviously undervalued stocks.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. SHANGHAI -- China is determined to regain control of the foreign concessions, particularly in Shanghai, because they contain at present the only tangible and taxable wealth in the country. Longing eyes have been cast for some time at Shanghai, one of the busy ports of the world.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- Mayor James J. Walker returned here tonight to resume his fight against removal by Governor Roosevelt, after a Sunday afternoon conference with John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, at the Larchmont home of A.C. Blumenthal, with whom Mr. Walker spent the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Hoover was officially proclaimed the candidate of the Allied Forces for Prohibition today, when Dr. Daniel A. Poling of New York, chairman of the Allied Forces, speaking for the 1,500,000 members of the organization, declared that the President would be supported on the ground that he is opposed to "naked repeal" and that his policy will be one to "confirm the principle of Federal control for a national problem."

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14 -- The cotton market here last week was the most active in many months and prices made a wide advance. The October Option at its highest mark on Thursday was 149 points, or about $7 a bale, above the figure at the close of the preceding week, and was 254 points, or $12.50 a bale, higher than the low point of the year, reached on June 10.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The money market here is still quiet, with transartions small. Owing to the scarcity of short-term funds, banks are keeping in their portfolios the bills remitted to them by customers, so that capital at the market's disposal is not easily invested.

Control points for the Eastern wing of the Cord Cup race, one of the opening features of the National Air Races at Cleveland, to take place from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5, were made public yesterday by E.W. Cleveland, chairman of the contest committee of the race meet.
ALE MARS, Iowa, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Armed deputies rode produce trucks into this Western Iowa town today as the mid-West farm strike entered its second week.

A proposal for a five-day forty-hour week, with a minimum wage of $60 a week, was approved yesterday at a special meeting of Typographical Union 6 at Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, attended by about 1,500 members of the union.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The fourteenth, annual golf tournament ball of the Pittsfield Country Club was held last night, attracting a gathering of 200. Miss Virginia Rhoades had charge, being assisted by Mrs. Samuel G. Colt, Miss Friscilla Colt, Mrs. Thomas Flournoy, Mrs. William A. Whittlesey and the Misses Beatrice Bardwell and Katherine Louise Weston.

The Public Service Commission will welcome the opportunity to take to the courts for settlement the quesion of Us power to prevent the Associated Gas and Electric System from "siphoning" the profits of its dozen operating subsidiaries in this State. Chairman Milo R. Maltbic declared yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Out of the shadows of old St. Patrick's Church, the Rev. James R. Cox, founder and Presidential candidate of the Jobless party, today led the main body of his "Blue Shirt Army" toward the Jobless-Liberty party convention in St. Louis.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The actions of the wheat and stock markets on Friday and Saturday were disturbing factors in the bull movement in grains started recently, largely by local and Eastern interests. At the high point reached in midweek wheat prices were up 10 cents a bushel from the season's low mark, which was regarded as below cost of production.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- Californians bade adieu to the Olympic games today with the same enthusiasm with which they had welcomed them sixteen days ago. Another amazing crowd filled the huge bowl from rim to rim.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Although August is normally more or less a slow month, Stock Exchange trading at the present time is comparatively active, due to the inspiring example of Wall Street. Strength in commodity prices is another stimulating factor and, for the moment, afe. all events, markets are ignoring the still grave unsettlement in many countries, including Germany.

The government of New YorK City demands the best type of executive, the late Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson declared ia his annual statement to the members of Trinity Protestant Episcopal parish, the "mother church" of which is on Broadway, at the head of Wall Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times : An article by Henry Ford, entitled "My Views on Liquor and the Law," appeared recently in Collier's, a careful perusal of which leaves one with the uncomfortable conviction that the author knows very little about liquor and still less about the law.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Playing with the added incentive of new cups donated by Seymour Knox for the team making the highest percentage in the games leading up to the open championship, Sands Point and Greentree rode through eight lightning-fast periods of polo today.

That many of the steps now suggested by economists to insure financial security for working people have long been, advocated by the Christian church was asserted by the Rev. Dr. F. Ernest Johnson, exscutive secretary of the department of research and education of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America,"preaching yesterday morning in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church,West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your edition of Aug. 11, under the heading "The Chaco Dispute," you published a letter signed by Abbot Maginnis, former United States Minister to Bolivia, and also an anonymous letter from G.N. These communications are so erroneous and misleading that they cannot be allowed to pass without correction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Babe Ruth's thirty-third homer of the season, a single by Vernon Gomez with the bases filled to drive home the last two Yankee runs, and a neat job of ninth-inning relief hurling by Cy Moore composed the major elements making the Yanks' last stand of the year in Washington a 5-to-4 victory for the McCarthymen

An organized movement on the part of civic associations for a special session of the State Legislature to pass legislation allowing the city to reduce salaries over which it now has no power may follow a meeting of civic association heads in Brooklyn on Thursday.

Plans to organize a Radio League to aid in raising campaign funds for the re-election of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis were announced last night by Joseph R. Nutt, treasurer of the Republican National Committee. The league will have branches throughout the country with the double purpose of stimulating interest in Republican speeches and of obtaining contributions from the listeners.

Two persons were killed and five injured yesterday when the automobile in which they were riding on Shore Road, Brooklyn, got out of control and overturned at the intersection of Seventy-second Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14 -- Bailey's Beach attracted one of the largest gatherings of the Summer today. Another large assemblage was at the Clambake Club. The club gave a bake to which the members were privileged to take their wives and other guests.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- After spending a week-end of rest at A.C. Blumenthal's estate on Beach Avenue here, interrupted only by his visit to his physician in New York, Mayor Walker boarded a train at Harmon at 5:05 P.M. today and returned to Albany for the continuation of the hearing before Governor Roosevelt.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- The advance in Wall Street was the centre of financial interest here in the last week, and it is eagerly debated whether the advance foreshadows trade revival. Particular note has been taken of the rise in railroad, automobile and department store stocks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Naval Reserve aviation units in some localities reached a point of efficiency making them fit for immediate mobilization, but the strength of these units should be greatly increased, according to the Naval Reserve Inspection Board, which reported today on the inspections of 148 reserve fleet divisions and thirtyone aviation divisions.

The declaration that the city's tax burden must be reduced by $125,000,000 was made yesterday by former Mayor John F. Hylan, in a statement in which he outlined the personnel of a proposed budgetary commission that would take up the task of finding where cuts in city expenditures can be made with the least harm to government and individuals.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 14 -- The Argentine military mission to Paraguay, recalled to preserve Argentine neutrality in the clash with Bolivia, left this morning for Buenos Aires.

The Summer theatres will continue their tryouts of new plays this week, with at least six premieres scheduled. A new version of "Men Must Fight," a play of war in the future by Reginald Lawrence and S.K. Lauren, will be the bill of the Westchester Playhouse, Mount Kisco.

MONTREAL, Aug. 14 -- Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman devoted this day to obtaining information about the proposed water power development of the international rapids on the St. Lawrence River, in anticipation of an inspection of the Canadian development at Beauharnois tomorrow.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Frances Harrel, Marsalis and Mrs. Louise McPhetridge Thaden circled over Curtisa Airport here" tonight after two successful refueling contacts for a sustained flight in which, they hope to break the women's endurance record of 122 hours, established over Los Angeles on June 9,1931, by Edna May Cooper and Miss Bobby Trout.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Piling up the huge margin of 6,070 points in its forty-board match with the Knickerbocker Whist Club team, the Crockford Club contract bridge quartet won the city of Asbury Park Challenge Trophy at the Deal Club here this afternoon as the fourth annual Summer tournament of the American Bridge League came to its close.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 14 -- Democrats and Republicans among the delegates attending the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention here sought common ground today on which to fight repeal of prohibition in the political campaign.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Two young pitchers of the St. Louis Cardinals mowed down the league-leading Chicago Cubs today and gave the Redbirds a double triumph. St. Louis won the first game, 2 to 0, and the nightcap, 2 to 1, in ten innings.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 14 -- Panic caused by a large snake resulted in the death by drowning of about 100 persons on the Panchganga River, near Kolhapur, today. The latter city is almost 200 miles southeast of Bombay

It is easily understandable that the young people of today should be confused and at sea, declared the Right Rev. Elmer N. Scbmuck, Bishop of Wyoming In his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

HAVANA, Aug. 12 (By Air Mail). -- Characterizing all efforts now being made to obtain the Presidential nomination of the Liberal party for the 1934 elections as hostile acts toward his administration, President Machado today warned his party through a statement to The Heraldo de Cuba, government organ, that he would take energetic steps to prevent such, a nomination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Although changes in the prohibition laws are under discussion and may be made, it is "unthinkable" that the Department of Justice should now relax enforcement efforts, Attorney General Mitchell declared today in a circular to all officials and agents of the department.

A constructive program of municipal economy, for the consideration of the Board of Estimate, is fast taking shape. Influential citizen and taxpayer groups are apparently, in agreement as to its principal features and ready to recommend their incorporation so far as practicable in the budget for 1923.

Much unrighteousness, none the less grave because unintentional, is wrought in every-day existence merely by the negative act of forgetting, the the Rev. Dr. Henry H. Tweedy of the Yale Divinity School declared yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Thirty-seventh Street.

Public offering will be made soon of an issue of $5,000,000 Iowa Electric Light and Power Company first portgage ten-year 7 per cent bonds, Series C. by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and,, the N. W. Harris Company. Inc. This will be the first slop of the company in its program to reduce its funded debt 14 per cent wlthtn three years.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The Italian salvage ship Artiglio landed at Plymouth today with u200,000 [$696,000] worth of gold and silver recovered in the past week from the sunken liner Egypt.

Eddie Cantor, now in Hollywood, whers he is making "The Kid From Spain," a talking picture, for Samuel Goldwyn, has completed plans for his future stage, radio and screen work. Mr. Cantor has signed a new contract with Mr. Goldwyn which calls for him to appear in one picture a year for the next five years.

Plans for rebuilding the Ateneo de Manila, the college of the American Jesuits in the Philippines, which was destroyed by fire on Saturday, will be started at once, according to an announcement yesterday by the Rev. George J. Willmann, director of the Jesuit Philippine Procure, 501 East Fordham Road.

Steamship officials of the Atlantic lines said yesterday with regard to suggestions that have been made by travel agents for special low rates next Summer to induce foreigners to visit the Chicago World's Fair that the fares were so low now that the liners, with two or three exceptions, were not paying operating expenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- An appeal was made tonight to thirty progressive Senators by the Joint Committee on Unemployment of which Professor John Dewey of New York is chairman, for some of their number to return to Washington "to expedite public works."

No greater compliment could have been paid to HERBERT LEHMAN than the Republican suggestion that former Governor NATHAN L. MILLER should be that party's candidate against him. Mr. MILLER was an excellent Chief Executive of this State, and his record against waste and for efficient administration was in no way impugned by his defeat in 1922.

At 1:30 o'clock this afternoon play is scheduled to start in the fortyfifth women's national tennis championship tournament on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, L.I. The tournament will run until Saturday, when a new champion will be crowned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The bronze statue of Cardinal Gibbons presented to the people of the United States by the Knights of Columbus was unveiled this afternoon and accepted from the Supreme Council of the order by President Hoover on behalf of the government in the presence of an audience of more than 30,000 men and women from all parts of the country.

GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- The World Jewish Conference opened here today with a stirring appeal by Dr. Stephen S. Wise of New York in favor of what he called its "supreme objective," a decision on whether to convoke a world Jewish congress.

In his speech of acceptance President HOOVER did more than report definite actions and make concrete proposals. The political philosophy which in his mind underlies them he occasionally exposed to the light. A good part of it relates to his conception of the place and functions of the Federal Government in our system.

A mawkish sentimentality which, fundamentally is "sympathy without charity, pity "without love," and an attitude of emotional sophistication, toos often a product of jaded appetites" are two false concepts of out emotional life too prevalent today, the Rev. Dr. Joseph, A. Daly, Professor of Psychology at the College of Mount St. Vincent, said yesterday in the Catholic Hour broadcast over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Hoover cruised down the Potomac River tonight on his first extended vacation in seventeen months, a rest to be divided between fishing in Chesapeake Bay and a stay in the mountains.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Up-State Democratic leaders supporting Mayor John Boyd Thacher of Albany for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination today failed to win former Governor Smith's endorsement of their man.

LONDON. Aug 11 -- The relapse in sterling exchange, which, early the week, carried the rate to the lowest point since early January, is attributed largely to the revival in Wall Street. Not only British, hut Continental, buying of dollars to pay for purchases of American securities have been substantial, "while American funds deposited here during the recent scare about the dollar have been repatriated.

The Book League of America is sending out to its subscribers as its September selection "The Years of Peace.," by Leroy MacLeod, and Oscar Wilde's "Comedies." The former is a novel of the soil set in Indiana after the Civil War. Mr., MacLeod, who lives in Los Angeles, has been a farmer, reporter and advertising man.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- Dr. Leo Donath, honorary secretary of the International Swimming Federation, today expressed the belief that the Olympic aquatic championships which ended yesterday set a new high-water mark which will be hard to reach again.

The New York Central Railroad Company, including all leased lines, reports for the three months ended on June 30 a net loss of $9,732,297 after charges and taxes. This contrasts with a net income of $4,662,209 in the corresponding period last year.

Activity in the wholesale, apparel market held to previous levels last week with stores placing good-sized orders for Fall merchandise. Price advances in a number of lines were viewed as an encouraging factor by the stores but failed to cause any sharp, increase in the average volume of retailers' purchases.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 14 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.9, which compares with 61.1 a week ago, 60.9 two weeks ago, 60.8 three weeks ago and 60.2 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date was 66.3, in the first week of January.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14 -- Grain prices increased sharply at the beginning of last week, then declined and closed weak. Wheat closed unchanged from the previous Saturday at the equivalent of 48 cents a bushel and corn declined 2 1/2 cents to 32 1/2. Flaxseed, however, closed stronger than in the previous week at 65 cents a bushel, compared with 63 1/2.

Conferences will begin today in Stockholm, Sweden, among representatives of the Swedish Government, United States and French creditors and British security holders of the Swedish Match Company in order to determine the ultimate fate of that company prior to the expiration of the moratorium on Aug. 31.

Ninety-four candles will gleam this afternoon on Charles Benedict's birthday cake and the few boyhood chums of the guest of honor will sit with him at the table in his home at 150 West Thirteenth Street and talk of days that were and friends who were, but are no more.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Rebellion increased today against the miners' $5 basic wage agreement as union members massed in meetings protesting the scale and threats of a State-wide strike were made by dissenting miners.

Another brilliant Sunday again drew a huge throng to the shore resorts yesterday. But at most points a chill north wind proved a deterrent to bathers, and many who went to swim forsook the beaches for the boardwalks or turned back to their automobiles to go driving instead.

Twenty-five years ago there were few industrial research laboratories worthy of the name in the United States. Ten years ago the National Research Council was able to compile a list of 500. Today there are 1,600. How have they fared in these lean years? The American Chemical Society has been seeking the answer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The special taxation committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States has been asked by the executive committee of the national organization to make a thorough examination of the manufacturers' sales tax and other possible sources of Federal revenue from the standpoint of "means of curing inequities in the taxation system as set up in the last session of Congress," and report before Congress reassembles.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Like a wraith, there appeared darting along a busy street today the figure of a man protected from the noon sun only by a scant one-piece garment.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- Germany today has assumed an attitude of waiting. Everybody realizes that the situation produced, by yesterday's dramatic climax cannot last, but what form the change will take and what will happen to bring it about is difficult to discern ahead of events.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Bump Hadley held Chicago to five hits in the first game of a double-header today to give St. Louis a 5-to-0 victory, and the Browns came back with timely hitting to win the second, 9 to 5, and sweep the four-game series.

METZ, France, Aug. 14 -- The capital of the recovered province of Lorraine was the scene today of a great manifestation of patriotic loyalty to France in which President Lebrun, Premier Herriot and Edouard Daladier, Minister of Public Works, joined.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- Trapped in their stalls when flames swept early today through the Metropolitan Driving Club's house and stables near the Harvard Stadium in the Brighton, district, forty-four valuable horses, most of them owned by residents of Greater Boston, were destroyed in a $150,000 fire.

Three young gunmen and a 14-year-old girl who, the police say, had been reported missing from her Brooklyn home since June 22 were arrested early yesterday morning following the hold-up of the Green Room Restaurant at 261 West Fifteenth Street, where the girl had obtained employment only a few hours before as a hostess.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a large luncheon today at Claverack House, her home in Halsey Neck Lane, for Mr. and Mrs. Henry Codrnan Potter and members of the Hampton Players. The guests were seated at the long table, which was decorated with garden flowers.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Several hundred of the 1,100 spectators, mostly women and children, were thrown into panic tonight in the Music Hall Theatre at 13 Main Street here when a bomb, placed under a seat, burst into flame and exploded, scattering particles of glass and filling the motion-picture house with acrid smoke.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 14 -- "A splendid group of young men of whom New York, New Jersey and Delaware may well be proud," was the comment of Colonel Walter W. Metcalf of the 305th Infantry Reserve, in taking over today the command of the infantry C.M.T.C. at Camp Dix for the concluding two weeks of their course.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 -- Production of steel ingots has been substantially uniform in the last two weeks at about 14 per cent of capacity, following three weeks with a 15 per cent rate. July as a whole averaged 14.66 per cent, according to the ofcial report, against 15.96 per cent shown for June.

DUBLIN, Aug. 14 -- Ireland faces the prospect of conflict between two irregular armies as the result of the issuance today of a manifesto by the Old Free State Army Comrades' Association, which virtually threatens Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State Executive Council, with the formation of a "White guard" as an offset to the "Republican army."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- During the absence of President Hoover on his fishing trip Republican leaders will turn chiefly to raising funds for the campaign. The national organization will seek money strictly for the Presidential campaign, the sum needed being estimated at $1,250,000.

For the reason that the advance in share prices beginning in the second week in July was largely based upon hope and not upon business or industrial revival in the larger sense, it was to be expected that-conditions would be studied closely, and even critically, at the end of last week for any sign of a change that might have stifled that earlier hope.

Because of the prospect of smaller resources and an increase in the amounts required for private relief work in the coming Winter, community leaders are urging readjustment of social welfare budgets to meet community resources, according to a statement in the current issue of The Survey, out today.
NEWARK, Aug. 14 -- The Newark Bears maintained an eleven and a half game lead over Buffalo by dividing a double-header with the second-place Bisons today.

Amid the thunderous applause of a crowd of 45,000 that unequivocally was for them first, last or wherever they may happen to finish, the Dodgers extended their winning streak to six in a row at the Polo Grounds yesterday by upsetting the Giants in dramatic fashion in the first half of the day's double-header.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- At no time in the last two years have sentiment and actual buying of merchandise and other lines been so good as they were last week. There were 3,0OO buyers of merchandise here, with around 2.000 or more salesman and others who had come to get a line on business conditions.

HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 14 -- Seventeen persons were dead, at least fifty were injured and property damage was estimated today at many thousands of dollars in the wake of a tropical storm which buffeted South Texas last night and widened to a 200-mile front.
MANILA, Aug. 15 (Monday) -- The appointment of John H. Holliday of St. Louis as Vice Governor of the Philippine Islands was uniformly well received among Filipinos canvassed tonight.

Detailed tabulations, showing high and low birth and death, rates in the various parts of New York, records of fatal diseases, accidents and similar data are contained in a report issued by the Department of Health, entitled "Vital Statistics by Health Areas and Health Centre Districts."

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- Governor Roosevelt and Speaker Garner held a series of conversations in automobiles, at civic exercises at Peekskill, on the lawn at Hyde Park and finally at the Executive Mansion today, during which the Vice Presidential candidate gave assurances that he would follow the lead of the head of the ticket to the limit.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Reversing the result of their meeting at Southampton in the semi-finals last week. Clifford Sutter, New Orleans tennis star, defeated Gregory Mangin of Newark in four sets, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, 6-0, to win the Eastern grass court singles championship today on the courts of the Westchester Country Clab.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Jimmy Foxx hit his forty-third home run of the season in today's double-header as the Athletics and Red Sox divided honors, the Athletics winning the opener, 6 to 1, on Walberg's fine pitching, and the Sox taking the second game, 2 to 0.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds opened their last home stand against Eastern clubs today by winning a double-header from Boston, 3 to 1, and 9 to 3. By the defeats the Braves dropped to fifth place behind the idle Phillies.

The valuelessness of ownership unless it is followed by the voluntary act of possession was discussed by Dr. Clarence. A. Barbour, president of Brbwn University, yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church, of St' Nicholas, Fifth Avenue 'at Forty-eighth Street.

The 800 or more delegates attending the convention in the Hotel Astor sponsored by The Irish World voted yesterday to start Saturday a rigorous boycott of British goods, shipping and insurance until Great Britain ends her tariff war against Ireland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- World record time was eclipsed in two events and equalled in another and two other meet records were broken as Olympic athletes of the United States defeated a team from the British Empire, 6 events to 4, in their quadrennial competition in Kezar Stadium today.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- An assertion that the new American cruisers Portland and Indianapolis render the British 10,000 tonners obsolete is made in The Daily Telegraph by Hector Bywater, the well-known naval expert.

While some evidences have been apparent within the last few days of a slight improvement in the building industry, no appreciable activity may be expected, points out Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports, until there is definite assurance that building material prices have reached their lowest levels and until building trades wage adjustments are definitely settled.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- Olympic boxing crowns rested today upon the heads of eight doughty warriors of the leathered fist, representing five countries. They are survivors of the greatest International tournament ever held to determine world's amateur champions.
Marie Skarka gave to Mary Krulish a mortgage for $3,000, due in three years, at 6 per cent, on 445-47 E. 84th St., two dwellings, subject to a first mortgage for $17,300 held by the Emigrant Bank.

BALTIMORE, Aug. (AP) -- Jim Winford, Rochester pitcher, held the Baltimore Orioles to two hits today in the second game to win, 4 to 1. Baltimore took the first game, 13 to 7. In the opener Boyle and Sand each got four hits in four times at bat.

Alone at Last. After all It's probably only a minor tragedy, but it holds a sentimental interest for baseball fans, this story of the Post-Mortem Pennant. One man, at least, was faithful to the end. He stood by the flag. He should be decorated for galiantry in bankruptcy.

Canada and Repeal. Liquor shares on the Canadian Stock Exchanges boomed. as the result of President HOOVER'S stand against prohibition in his acceptance speech. It is argued that in the case of repeal it will be several years before American distilleries can put on the market hard liquor sufficiently matured for exigent palates, and Canadian producers are bound to profit in the meanwhile.

Out of work and despondent over his inability to provide for his wife and two small sons, Peter Larson, 51 years old, of 126 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, a Canadian veteran of the World War, attempted suicide last night by swallowing poison. Larson collapsed on the sidewalk at Southern Boulevard and East 183d Street, and was taken to Lincoln Hospital by Patrolman Lamonita of the Alexander Avenue station.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- "I am willing to campaign any place the Governor wants me to," Speaker Garner told reporters at the National Guard camp today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Linden Smith, now at Loon Point, Dublin. N.H., will leave early in November for Egypt.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The Bourse was generally steady again this week, but the advance movement was not so regular and was interrupted on Wednesday by a rather strong reaction. Developments in the market here closely follow those of Wall Street.
Although the hunting season is not, far distant, sportsmen in Canada are still fully occupied with the prevailing abundance of good fishing.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- The Olympic torch on the peristyle of the Los Angeles Coliseum flickered out with the fading twilight today in the presence of 95,000 spectators and the greatest carnival of sport ever held in this country passed into history.

Managers of both political parties are preparing to make the usual hullabaloo in the campaign before the State election in. Maine on the second Monday in September. It is an old and exploded superstition that " as goes Maine, so goes the Union." As Maine is a Republican State, the Republicans naturally make the most of the myth.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Otto H. Kahn, New York banker, has expressed willingness to sell to the town of Huntingdon a plot of 140 acres on the Cold Spring Harbor side of West Neck for park purposes, it became known here today. Supervisor William Watt said that acquisition of the plot had been discussed with David Bennett, business representative of Mr. Kahn, and William E. Gormley, a real estate agent of Huntington.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- A theoretical division of National Guardsmen moved across the Croton River in the face of "enemy" fire today and invaved Ossining after a battle along the river. Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commanding General, and officers of the Twenty-seventh Division Staff, directed the soldiers in an "attack" across the river, which included the placing of pontoon bridges and the laying of wire cables.

A hold-up man, frightened off by the cries of an insurance agent he had attempted to rob, tried to escape last night in a taxicab. But before the cab could get away a policeman swung onto the running board. The hold-up man refused to surrender when ordered, and was shot through the back by the policeman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Adolph Pons's Swivel made a show of a fast band of 2-year-old fillies today at Hawthorne to establish herself as one of the favorites for the $10,000 added Juvenile Handicap which will be run Saturday.

GREENVILLE, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The soldiers of four theoretical divisions left here silently and secretly tonight for the theoretical front extending from Freehold to Seagirt, where the annual war manoeuvres conducted by the Forty-fourth Division staff with Brig. Gen. Winfield S. Price, will begin with an "attack" at dawn.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- British Government funds received fresh support today and prices generally were substantially higher in expectation of an early favorable announcement of the cerversion loan result. The markets otherwise were irregular.

Frances Starr, stage and screen actress, was married yesterday afternoon to R. Golden Donaldson, a banker of Washington, D.C. The ceremony, which was performed by Dr. Victor Rheim, took place in Mr. Donaldson's apartment at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- Qouting President Hoover's references to foreign policy in his speech accepting the Republican nomination, a Foreign Office spokesman today pointed out a wide difference between the President's definition of the new non-recognition doctrine based on the Kellogg pact, and that given by Secretary Henry L. Stimson.

KANKAKEE, Ill., Aug. 15 (AP) -- E. E. Kennedy, secretary of the Farmers' Educational and Cooperative Union of America, announced today that the "holiday" of Illinois farmers striking for better prices was in effect.

In view of the sharp reaction which had followed the culmination of the rise last week, much interest attached to the course of the markets yesterday. They began the present week with a distinct though gradual renewal of the advance. This was most strongly manifested in the stock market, where, although volume of business was considerably reduced, a long list of stocks gained 2 to 4 points for the day, with some even larger advances.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Amory G. Hodges gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at the Meadow Club. Among her guests were:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to protest against a statement in THE TIMES of July 26, received by cable from Berlin (when I was absent in the White Mountains, by chance having that day climbed Mount Madison, 5,000 feet; no small job for a woman of 81), and repeated in today's TIMES, that four Germans had made an ascent of Mount Huascaran, Peru, 22,000 feet, never scaled before.

Domestic corporation bonds resumed their advance yesterday on the Stock Exchange, and, measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty issues, they more than made up Friday's losses. Railroad and utility bonds, especially, showed good strength, with industrial issues closing irregularly higher.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- In a fair southwest breeze nineteen sloops sailed in the second regatta of the August series, which was postponed on account of heavy weather last week, off the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Aug. 16 -- The resignation of Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang as the commander of the North China district has been accepted and a committee of eighteen has been appointed to take over the duties of the young marshal.

Guppies, platys, hellerii, Saimese fighting fish and several strange species of tropical fish never before exhibited in this country will be on display at the fortieth annual exposition of the Aquarium Society in the American Museum of Natural History Sept. 3, 4 and 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- As a result of a movement for the removal of inequalities in the new tax law, the enactment of a general manufacturers' sales tax will be proposed early in the next session of Congress.

Max Schmeling, former world's heavyweight champion, and Mickey Walker of Elizabeth, N.J., who voluntarily surrendered his world's middleweight title to seek the heavyweight crown, yesterday were matched by Madison Square Garden to battle fifteen rounds in the Garden's Long Island City Bowl on the night of Sept. 19, in a contest designed to establish an outstanding challenger for Jack Sharkey, world's heavyweight champion, next June.
Byron H. Uhl, Assistant Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, will complete forty years' service in the immigration department next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- In denying the application of a small Texas railroad for a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to finance improvements counted upon to make the road solvent, the Interstate Commerce Commission, by a close division, today interpreted a highly important clause in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation act.

Morris Green, theatrical producer, who was associated with A.L. Jones in the production of the original and subsequent editions of the "Greenwich Village Follies," filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court, listing liabilities of $272,650 and assets of no value.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A bullish development in the wheat market here today was that the amount of wheat on ocean passage totaled only about half as much as a year ago. A decrease last week of 2,664,000 bushels made the supply afloat 24,508,000 bushels, the smallest in a long time.

GRANITE, Okla., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Terrorizing citizens as they scattered in a frantic effort to elude pursuing guards, nineteen of the twenty-three convicts who escaped from the State reformatory here in the absence of their woman warden were still at large tonight.

In connection with the redemption yesterday of $33,390,000 of 6 per cent bonds of the Paris-Lyons-Mediterranean Railroad Company, the Bank of France released $28,502,800 of gold held under earmark for it at the Federal Reserve Bank, turning the metal over to Kuhn, Loeb Co., bankers for the road, who at once sold it to the Federal Reserve.
ALBANY, Aug. 15. -- Governor Roosevelt and Speaker Garner are in complete accord on campaign issues, the Governor declared today after the Vice Presidential, nominee had left for New York City.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15. -- The imperial economic conference has reached a critical but by no means fatal stage.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Members of the Silk Dyers and Printers' Association, an organization which includes manufacturers of this city and Greater New York, attended a closed meeting at a hotel here tonight at which a recent offer to Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City to become "czar" of the industry was said to be the subject for discussion.

Professor Frederick J.E. Woodbridge, Theodore Roosevelt Professor of American History at the University of Berlin for the last year, returned on the Holland-American liner Volendam yesterday and said the probability of Adolf Hitler and the National Socialists gaining power in Germany was not strong.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Trailing, 5 to 0, at the end of the first inning, the Newark Bears staged a brilliant uphill fight to defeat the New York Yankees, 8 to 5, in an exhibition game before a crowd of 5,000 today.

It is time there was a reaction to a larger and profounder conception of history, to the study of movements and their causes rather than events and their dates, Dr. T. R. Glover, public orator of the University of Cambridge and a fellow of St. John's College, Cambridge, England, writes in his book, "Greek Byways," to be published today by the Macmillan Company.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A grand jury investigation into reported attempts to corrupt the jurors who convicted Colonel Luke Lea of Nashville of violating the bank laws last August led today to the indictment of Wiley B. Noland of Haywood County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES today portions of a telegram from J. P. Battenberg, chairman of the Oklahoma Democratic Forum, to Governor Roosevelt are quoted. In regard to the proposed removal of Mayor Walker, the telegram states: "In our judgment, his removal would be a grave mistake from a party standpoint and positively detrimental to your own personal political fortunes."
After early irregularity, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday developed resistance and an improvement of nearly $1 a bale left quotations 16 to 18 points higher on the day.

OTTAWA, Aug. 15 -- Representatives of United States business interests operating in Canada have warned the Canadians that fully half of the more than one thousand American branch plants in the Dominion will leave Canada if the reported recommendation of the Empire Content Committee of the Imperial Economic Conference is adopted and put into effect.

Evidence from many sides points to a serious food shortage in Soviet Russia. The grain trade expects virtually no Russian wheat on the world market this year. The Moscow censorship has been lifted from the facts. There are soaring prices and resultant demoralization in industry.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 15 -- The Cold Spring Harbor crew took the lead as the annual racing for the junior championship of Long Island Sound started here today, the crew from across the Sound winning first place in the only race held. Tomorrow there will be one race in the morning and another in the afternoon.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- To the entire nation must go the credit for the success of the games of the tenth Olympiad, William May Garland, president of the organizing committee, said today as he sat back to review the international fiesta.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Ideal racing weather, a fast track and close finishes featured the opening of the Grand Circuit five-day racing meeting at Good Time Park today. A large first-day crowd was on hand to witness the four events.

Contemporary American writers receivs considerable attention in the new and enlarged edition of "A Guide to the Best Fiction," by Ernest Baker, director of the School of Librarianship, University of London, which Macmillan will publish today. This reference book covers the whole range of prose fiction, ancient and modern,in English.
