In an effort to Increase employment in all branches of the legitimate theatrical business, the Actors' Equity Association, speaking editorially in the current issue of its magazine, Equity, calls upon the Federal Reserve System to extend credit to Broadway theatrical producers and urges these producers to apply "to the government for that credit for the purpose of making new productions."
SANTA MONICA, Cal., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Jean Carmen, Universal screen actress, and Walter Lohman, business man, were married today at the beach home of Mrs. Constance Talmadge Netcher.

Reports from Washington state that Treasury officials are again considering the question of converting part of the Government's large short-term indebtedness into a longterm bond issue. England has recently converted a large part of her war debt into bonds bearing a lower rate of interest.

HAVANA, Aug. 15 -- A strike of physicians employed by mutual aid societies in Cuba will go into effect at midnight tonight, according to a notice to the Department of Health this afternoon from the Medical Federation of Cuba. Skeleton staffs will remain in the hospitals and only emergency cases will be admitted.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Prospects for a much smaller attendance at the Jobless-Liberty Party national convention than was predicted earlier by leaders of the group had caused State and county health officials tonight to suspend, at least temporarily, their plans for Injunction proceedings to prevent tha gathering because of inadequate sanitary facilities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Preference of operators of vessels flying the American flag for native seamen has resulted in a wider range of employment for American sailors than for many years, Arthur J. Tyrer, assistant director of the Department of Commerce Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, announced today after a survey.

Doubt that the Manufacturers Trust Company, as successor fiscal agent for the three issues of customs secured bonds of the Republic of El Salvador that aggregate $17,393,299, will be able to enforce the provision of the loan contracts and set up a customs receivership, was expressed yesterday by the Institute of International Finance through its director, Dean John T. Madden of New York University.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Beset by financial worries, executives of most of the nation's railroads will meet here Thursday for a general discussion of their problems, with emphasis on operation economies and the wage situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The United States delegates to the International Radio-Telegraph Conference, which will convene at Madrid on Sept. 3, have been instructed to fight any extension of radio message censorship, William B. Castle, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 15 -- The international masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress, in which twelve experts, including Dr. Alexander Alekhine, world's champion, will compete for prizes this week and next, was formally opened at a luncheon given in honor of the players at the Hotel Maryland today.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Friendship between Adolf Hitler, leader of the National Socialist party, and General Kurt von Schleicher, Minister of Defense in the von Papen Cabinet, if such friendship ever existed, is said to have been definitely ended as the result of the refusal by President von Hindenburg to accede to Hitler's demand for full executive power.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- More than 300 women of Suffolk County, including representatives from Southampton, East Hampton, Quogue, West Hampton, Stony Brook, Bellport, Cold Spring Harbor, Huntington, Sayville and Smithtown, attended the luncheon in behalf of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform given today at Canoe Place Inn, Hampton Bays, under the auspices of the Suffolk County branch of the organization.
LAFO FARO, Portugal, Aug. 14 -- We are in Europe at last, and a bit tired of long-distance sailing at the moment.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 15 -- A possibility that the trial of Libby Holman Reynolds and Albert (Ab) Walker on charges of murdering Smith Reynolds, the Broadway torch singer's husband, would be held within six weeks was advanced today by attaches of the Forsyth Superior Court after Governor O. Max Gardner notified the clerk of Superior Court that a special term of criminal court had been ordered for two weeks beginning Sept. 12.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The toll of the years counted today as the 1924 world champion Washington team bowed to the Nationals of 1932 in a baseball festival held as part of the George Washington bicentennial.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Disarmament problems were considered at a conference today of, State Department, army and navy officials but no attempt was made to reach conclusions concerning the naval conversations contemplated in the adjournment resolution of the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva.

Premier HERRIOT'S address at Metz on Sunday was a temperate statement once more of the French thesis that security must come before disarmament. Without mentioning names, his references were unmistakable. The "friendly voices " which have been assuring France that war has been outlawed and will henceforth, be impossible, are undoubtedly the voices of Secretary STIMSON and President HOOVER.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Plans for early construction of additional buildings in a "new Camp Dix plan," were confirmed today by Brig. Gen. H.L. Laubach, camp commander, who said that two appropriations totaling about $35,000 had been made available for improvements.

With the opening yesterday of bids for the removal of covers and barricades from the entrances to the twenty-eight stations of the new Eighth Avenue subway from Chambers Street to 207th Street, the Board of Transportation, began the final "clean-up" moves in anticipation of revenue operation by Sept. 6 or shortly thereafter.

Formal offering of an issue of $20,000,000 Public Service Company of Northern Illinois first lien and refunding mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds, Series G, dated July 1, 1932, and due on July 1, 1937, will be made today by a syndicate of banks in this city and Chicago at a price of 98, to yield about 6.99 per cent.

The purchasing power of the average weekly pay envelope in manufacturing industry has declined 27.3 per cent in the three years between June, 1929, and June, 1932, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc., of 247 Park Avenue.

DUBLIN, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Dr. O'Higgins, president of the volunteer division of the Saorstate Army Comrades' Association, declared today that the "White" army being formed was neither a menace nor a challenge to the Free State Government.

BLACKBURN, England, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Britain's vast cotton industry was threatened today with a strike which would involve almost 500,000 operatives. The central board of the Northern Counties Textile Trade Federation decided to call a strike Aug. 27 if the dispute over the new wage agreement is not settled.

Despite the modifications in the proposed Eastern railroad consolidation by the Interstate Commerce Commission, The Rail, official publication of the Chesapeake Ohio and the Pere Marquette Railways, says there is evidence of every disposition on the part of the executives to make the commission's plan work if it is possible to do so.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Thomas A. Mathis, Secretary of State of New Jersey, and Frederick L. Farr of Elizabeth were appointed equity receivers by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake today for the American Railways Company of Camden, a holding company for stock in street car and railroad corporations.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Richard H. Dana and his housekeeper guardian, Miss Ocativa Dockery, eccentrics, whose home is known as the "Goat Castle." were virtually exonerated today of charges that they killed their wealthy neighbor, Miss Jane Surget Merrill, on Aug. 4.

MONTREAL, Aug. 15 -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman obtained a picture today of the projected water-power development of the State Power Authority at Massena Point from an inspection of the Canadian development at Beauharnois, which, in physical layout, is almost identical with the ground covered in the New York plan.

Formation of a new Stock Exchange partnership, Rhoades, Williams Co., consisting of partners in the firms of Rhoades Co. and Williams, Nicholas Moran, has been arranged, the Exchange announced yesterday. The present firms will be dissolved on Aug. 31.

More than 120 men and women -- husbands and their wives, bachelors and spinsters -- crowded, yesterday morning, into a court room before Federal Judge John M. Woolsey, each waiting for what he or she hoped would be a turn to take the witness stand.

With a score of 66 in the morning and 64 in the afternoon, Willie Macfarlane, Oak Ridge professional, who defeated Bobby Jones in a play-off for the national open championship at Worcester in 1925, annexed all the honors in the one-day outing of the Metropolitan P.G.A. at the Hudson River Country Club in Yonkers yesterday.

A group of fifty indignant unemployed men and women stormed the office of the Efficiency Employment Bureau, on the second floor of 1,151 Sixth Avenue, yesterday morning after they had discovered that a clerk employed at that bureau had swindled them out of more than $500 by promising them jobs which did not exist.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- The publication by Le Matin of a lengthy extract from an interview given to THE NEW YORK TIMES recently by General Kurt von Schleicher, German Defense Minister, has provoked what may be regarded as the inevitable reply in the French Nationalist press.
The New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday was comprised mainly of housing properties. Two factory parcels and several plots also changed hands.

Acquisition of the New York Harlem Railroad's trolley lines on Madison and Fourth Avenues by the New York Railways Corporation and their inclusion in the bus franchise plan of the New York City Omnibus Corporation for motorizing all New York Railways surface-car lines will not of itself meet the objections of Controller Charles W. Berry and Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee, it was indicated yesterday.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Relief from the depression must be sought in a general return to the international gold standard, according to leading economists and monetary authorities, who told the Institute of Politics today that the risk of a return to gold by some of the paper standard countries may be overcome by banking devices and by the cooperation of the leading central banks.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- A nose finish thrilled observers today as the featured Troy Claiming Stakes was run for the thirtieth time. The winner was Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Poppyman, a son of Chatterton, which did not show nearly so keen an effort in his previous start.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I quote from THE TIMES editorial "The Case of Senator Love." You say: "Though a doctor by profession, his qualifications for public office are far above the average." Your use of the word "though" is masterly, and in other times it might be thought that you were trying to be funny.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 (AP) -- An emergency program of the Missouri State Highway Department, designed to give 12,000 extra men jobs in building and improving roads, was outlined today at a meeting of highway department officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The largest non-rigid airship in the United States, now under construction by the Goodyear Zeppelin Corporation of Akron, Ohio, and to be used by the Army Air Corps for coastal patrol work, is expected to be completed and ready for trial flights by Oct. 15, the "War Department announced today.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Janet Walker, wife of the Mayor, who recently underwent a major operation, has suffered a relapse because of her determination to be with her husband during the removal hearings before Governor Roosevelt, it was announced tonight by Dr. William Schroeder Jr., Commissioner of Sanitation and the Mayor's personal physician.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 15 -- Twelve hundred delegates and alternates to the annual convention of the Ohio Department of the American Legion booed Senator Robert J. Bulkley here today when he told the veterans that he could not favor immediate cash payment of the adjusted compensation certificates and later cheered him when he rebuked the administration for routing the bonus expeditionary force from Washington.

The evils and dangers of stream pollution are usually realized by fishermen more readily than by others. Even if he is not scientifically minded, the angler is brought face to face with the problem when he finds that the fish no longer thrive in some of the particular spots that were formerly filled with enchantment to him.

Earl Carroll, who has heretofore confined, his activities chiefly to musical shows, has placed in rehearsal "Disappearing Men," a melodrama by Samuel John Park. The play will be presented by arrangement with Roy Walling, a play broker, who was associated with Mr. Carroll about five years ago in several productions at Wallack's Theatre.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Gifford Pinchot, Pennsylvania's independent Governor, and the State Republican organization, for years vigorous opponents in the matter of utility regulation, today appeared to attain full agreement on a complete investigation of the Public Service Commission by the Senate.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Captain W.N. Lancaster, on trial for the love triangle slaying of Haden Clarke, was alternately denounced today as an overcareful murderer" and praised as an unselfish, noble character, in final arguments.

Gold was hauled by the ton like coal through the streets of the financial district yesterday while the largest transfer of precious metals ever made was under way between the old Assay Office in Wall Street and the new Assay Office at South Street and Old Slip.

George Small, college graduate who turned bandit and jail-breaker, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Algeron I. Nova in the Kings County Court to serve fourteen years in Sing Sing prison for the illegal possession of a pistol. He had been convicted as a second offender.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I report the result of my letter which THE TIMES printed requesting two used grand pianos for high schools in the Virgin Islands?

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Henry Delafield and Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell jointly will give a dinner-dance for their respective daughters, Miss Georgette Winthrop Delafield and Miss Mary Boileau Mixsell, on Sept. 21 at the Wee Burn Club, Noroton, Conn.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Like a city under martial law, this community of about 8,000 persons looked over far-flung barricades tonight and waited alert for the promised "march on Taylorville" of striking coal miners from Springfield and Southern Illinois.

The money market continued dull. Call rate ruled at 2 per cent all day, with a good supply on the outside at 1 per cent. Federal funds were quoted at 1/8 per cent. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance quotations unchanged.

SEATTLE, Aug. 15 -- Endorsement of President Hoover by the Allied Forces for Prohibition is unlikely to alter the determination of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union to keep out of the Presidential campaign, Mrs. Ella A. Boole, national head of the organization, said today.

When the steamship California of the Panama Pacific Line arrived yesterday from West Coast ports via Colon and Cuba, further details were given about the disappearance of two of the passengers between San Diego and Panama. They were Ernest Boulter, a landscape gardener, of Pasadena, Cal., who jumped overboard Aug. 3, and William Kerr Scott of Portland, Ore., who disappeared between 3 and 9 A.M. on Aug. 5.

THE Detroit Tigers are in town and with them is Gerald Walker, the hard-hitting outfielder, who ran out a hit in the wrong direction and found that the path to third base leads but to the bench. Gerald is a trifle temperamental, but he can hit a low curve and a fast one on the inside is deep-dish apple pie with cream for him.
Decreases varying from $50 to $1,400,000 were noted in nine city departmental budgetary requests filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate.

If all people of mature years could remember what they were like at 15 and 20, life would be much easier and less bristling with criticism of the young. Teachers particularly should have a vivid recollection of their own adolescence. A test for lasting memory of youthful feelings would be a fine thing for prospective schoolmasters, if such a thing could be devised.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Prices of hogs today were steady to 10 cents a hundred pounds higher, compared with Saturday, but sold somewhat under the best figures of Friday. Receipts were the largest for a Monday in four weeks, but about half of them were packing sows, leaving comparatively few choice animals available for sale after packers' direct purchases.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Reports heard today by the first World Jewish Conference asserted that Palestine is the only Jewish community that is flourishing both materially and spiritually.

Cheaper and Better. If Dr. GREEFF, Commissioner of Hospitals, makes good his promise, his department will set an unusual example of economy next year in food. In 1931 the patients' daily ration cost 32 1/2 cents.
HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The ravages of the Southern Texas hurricane became more apparent today as relief workers went among the hungry and Injured with food and medicine.

While trading was much less active yesterday than it had been many days previously, operations for the advance were resumed with considerable vigor and more than half of the losses of Friday and Saturday were cancelled. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,905,290 shares, against 3,705,890 shares on Friday, the last previous five-hour day.

LA PAZ, Aug. 15 -- President Hoover was accused of partiality against Bolivia in an editorial in La Razon today demanding that Bolivia definitely and finally withdraw from the Chaco negotiations in Washington.

With the purpose of bringing about closer cooperation between the various State organizations and increasing the chance of the election of Roosevelt and Garner, the Democratic chairmen of the six New England States organized yesterday the New England Democratic State Chairmen Associates after a conference with James A. Farley, national chairman, at the Biltmore Hotel.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- Labor trouble has arisen in the great coal fields of the Donetz Basin, it was revealed today, with the result that in the last two months between 20,000 and 25,000 miners had quit their jobs.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Although the investing public was still extremely reserved today and practically absent from the market, the movement of stocks was upward on the Boerse. Speculating interests were optimistic and expressed the conviction that Hitler would be able to suppress any illegal actions on the part of his followers.

DUBLIN, Aug. 15 -- George Gilmore, one of the militant leaders of the Irish Republican Army, and T.J. Ryan, local leader in County Clare, were wounded in Kilrush early this morning in a mysterious gun fight with Free State detectives. Both were arrested and are under guard in Kilrush Hospital.

Holders of bonds of the city of Coral Gables, Fla., have been notified by the protective committee that during the thirty days ended on last Friday, not a depositor had availed himself of the privilege to withdraw the bonds deposited in his name with the Bank of New York Trust Company, depository for the committee.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Favorites survived the opening day of play in the tenth annual national public parks tennis championship at Shawnee Park today. All first-round matches and four in the second round of the men's singles were completed.

With tears in his eyes and a break in his voice when reference was made to the appeal of bigotry used to carry his home State of Texas for President Hoover in 1928, Speaker John N. Garner, Democratic nominee for Vice President, denied emphatically yesterday that he was one of those Southern Democrats who voted against former Governor Alfred E. Smith four years ago.
BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A farm "strike" aimed at raising the price of wheat to $1 per bushel was started in North Dakota today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Through a calm sea the New York Yacht Club fleet came back to Newport today, Frederick H. Prince's America's Cup yacht Weetamoe showing the way by 4 minutes and 20 seconds over Gerard B. Lambert's older but larger canvassed Vanitic, and winning over her rival with handicap allowance by 8 minutes and 40 seconds.

The stockholders of the closed Federation Bank and Trust Company, at a special meeting last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania, adopted a new reorganization plan which virtually insures the reopening of the bank within the next three weeks.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- Although the Soviet Government is having difficulties at home, they are more than counterbalanced by the improvement in Russia's foreign relations.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The transcript of the third hearing before Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in the removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker follows:

ALBANY, Aug. 15. -- Twelve witnesses have been selected by Mayor Walker, after conferences with his advisers, to support his defense against the removal charges put forward by Samuel Seabury, it became known at the end of today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A plea for a return to an era of rigid public economy was made today by John J. Cornwall of Baltimore, wartime Governor of West Virginia and president of the United States Civil Legion.

Three detectives attached to the main office division of Police Headquarters yesterday encountered the object of a police search, an alleged swindler, standing almost in the shadow of headquarters a block away.

Speaker GARNER'S visit to his old friend at Albany must have disappointed the Republicans. They were hoping that he would make trouble; that the traditional, though not invariable, coolness between the President and the Vice President would show itself even in the early stages of the canvass.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Governor Roosevelt intimated to Mayor Walker today that if the large cash sums which the missing Russell T. Sherwood handled belonged to the Mayor, he must explain their source or face the fate of former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley.

Wholesale market prices advanced in yesterday's dealings. Grains and cotton showed gains, while in the metal group tin was the feature, closing strong. Silk declined slightly. All other staples were firm.

Major price reductions by two manufacturers of higher price domestic rugs and downward adjustments on carpets were features of yesterday's opening of Fall rug and carpet lines. Popular price floor coverings showed no variation from Spring quotations.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 -- Even Enrico Caruso's box-office records were broken by Lily Pons when her last operatic matinee yesterday filled the Colon Theatre as it has seldom been filled at prices which established a record for total receipts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)America's demand for chewing-gum has uncovered in Mexican jungles a lost city that 1,500 years ago was a metropolis of an Egypt-like civilization.

Mrs. Lawrence A. Harper of Oakland, Cal., runner-up to Miss Betty Nuthall in 1930, was among the favorites to gain the second round as the women's national tennis singles championship opened yesterday on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, L.I.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Frank Calo, Green Meadow, became the new Westchester County senior caddie champion today when he turned back Louis Barbaro, Rye, in a play-off over the Bonnie Briar Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Secretary Chapin of the Department of Commerce made a flight over nearby airways tonight to familiarize himself with what he regards as one of the most important branches of his department-that of the commercial airways maintained by the Federal Government, under the direction of Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aviation.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 15 -- Continued activity of milk producers and live-stock raisers on highways entering this city again resulted in disorders and Injuries to drivers of trucks today. Scores of trucks loaded with milk, farm products and live stock headed toward Sioux City have been turned back on nearly every highway after the drivers have been warned in no uncertain manner.

Until the day comes when Presidents do not seek re-election in order to complete a record, any administrative activity of theirs during a campaign will be stamped as political. It is so with the economic conference which Mr. HOOVER has summoned for Aug. 25 and 26, Democrats as well as Republicans being invited to participate.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Earl Cook held Albany safe for seven innings tonight but he weakened in the eighth and the Senators scored five runs and made a sweep of the three-game series by winning, 6 to 4. Jack Rothrock of Toronto hit a home run with one on to give the Maple Leafs en early lead.

Lieut. Gov LEHMAN'S speech on State economy at Potsdam was in the honest and forthright vein to which he has accustomed the people. He began by giving thanks for the fat years that lie behind, since, when taxes flowed into the State Treasury as from a horn of plenty, they were invested in schools and hospitals and prisons that will endure for years.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Five reached the third round as play in the junior metropolitan tennis championship tournament started at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club today. Competition in the boys' tourney also got under way, with six going into the quarter finals.

NEWPORT, R.I.. Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Bradford Norman was a luncheon hostess at Brook Farm today for members of the executive committee of the American Merchant Marine Library Association at which further plans were made for the fashion show and tea to be given at the home of Mrs. Skirvin Adams on Aug. 26 as a benefit.

The Class I railroads in the United States for the six months ended June 30 had total net operating income of $112,328,375, compared with $240,504,555 in the corresponding period last year, according to a compilation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- The front line of American tennis ranks in the sixteenth invitation tournament at the Newport Casino remained unbroken tonight when the first two rounds were completed, but the group of foreign invaders had dwindled from four nations to two, through the elimination of Canadian and Brazilian opposition.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- R.J. Hayes of Felham was the winner of the low net prize in the greenkeepers' tournament conducted by the green sections of the United States Golf Association and the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Century Country Club today.

The American Contemporary Art Gallery bravely opened its doors at 1,269 Madison Avenue yesterday at what is practically the nadir of the New York art season. Announced in advance as "a space -- and a roof -- for deserving pictures," the new gallery proved to be a small, street-level store informally hung with a dozen or so paintings.

Lieut. Gov LEHMAN'S speech on State economy at Potsdam was in the honest and forthright vein to which he has accustomed the people. He began by giving thanks for the fat years that lie behind, since, when taxes flowed into the State Treasury as from a horn of plenty, they were invested in schools and hospitals and prisons that will endure for years.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Five reached the third round as play in the junior metropolitan tennis championship tournament started at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club today. Competition in the boys' tourney also got under way, with six going into the quarter finals.

NEWPORT, R.I.. Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Bradford Norman was a luncheon hostess at Brook Farm today for members of the executive committee of the American Merchant Marine Library Association at which further plans were made for the fashion show and tea to be given at the home of Mrs. Skirvin Adams on Aug. 26 as a benefit.

The Class I railroads in the United States for the six months ended June 30 had total net operating income of $112,328,375, compared with $240,504,555 in the corresponding period last year, according to a compilation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Ronald G. Rideout, who told'a magistrate in city police court that reverses in gambling led to his holding up three Canadian banks, was sentenced to ten years in Stony Mountain Penitentiary with ten lashes today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 16. -- An international symposimum on Secretary Stimson's recent pronouncement that consultation to mobilize "moral disapproval" was implicit in the Kellogg-Briand pact was held at the Institute of Politics tonight.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 16. -- Further reports have been received here from the steamer Salvor, which, with the trawlers Sea Gull and Sea Rambler, are trying to recover about $4,000,000 in gold, silver and jewels from the steamer Merida, sunk twenty-one years ago off the Virginia coast, telling of the locating of the treasure ship.

A smoke bomb, which was dislodged accidentally from one of three Naval Reserve seaplanes returning yesterday from target practice above Center Island, Jamaica Bay, to their base at Floyd Bennett Field, crashed through the porch roof of the residence of Philip Schwab at 1,699 East Ninety-third Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad today filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of a $63,250,000 issue of bonds to pay 5 per cent. The purpose is to obtain funds for the retirement of a like amount of 4 1/2 per cent bonds which will mature on March 1, 1933.

A four-story addition to the Bank for Savings at the southwest corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street is to be erected at once to provide necessary facilities to meet the growing needs of the bank. It is the oldest savings bank in New York City, having been chartered 113 years ago.

Mrs. Mathilde McCormick Oser arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic on her way to Chicago to visit her mother, Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, daughter of John D. Rockefeller, who is seriously ill. Arrangements had been made for Mrs. Oser, who is accompanied by her husband and their two chil- dren, to fly from Newark to Chicago and an airplane was in readiness for the trip, but it was not needed.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- The market's trend was definitely upward and the mid-month liquidations were accomplished under the most favorable conditions at today's session of the Bourse, which reopened after having been closed three days. Yesterday's improvement in Wall Street and the market's rise today on the London Stock Exchange were stimulative influences here.

Tuesday, Aug. 16, 1932. The call loan market was quiet, money renewed at 2 per cent and continued at that figure all day, with the usual funds on the outside at 1 per cent. Other rates remained unchanged.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Mrs. Genevieve Dabkowski of Philadelphia, arrested last night on a larceny charge growing out of a mixup of handbangs, was discharged by Recorder Joseph Altman today, and the court directed that her fingerprints and other records in connection with her arrest be destroyed.

A.C. Blumenthal, who is supervising the theatrical enterprises of the late Florenz Ziegfeld, announced yesterday that he had completed arrangements with Billie Burke (Mrs. Ziegfeld) whereby he would continue the Ziegfeld "Follies" on behalf of her interests.

George Gershwin achieved last night what only Beethoven and Wagner have been able to do at the Lewisohn Stadium this year -- a program all to himself. And 17,000 persons, an all-time record crowd, for these concerts, jammed their way into all the available seating and standing room, including aisles, ramparts, towers, stairs and colonnade.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Amoz Alonzo Stagg, dean of America's football coaches, celebrated his seventieth birthday today, hale hearty and happy -- the most engaging figure in the game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Pilots entered in the eastern leg of the transcontinental air race as a prelude to the annual National Air Races at Cleveland began arriving here this morning, and before dusk tomorrow officials in charge of the event expect more than twoscore men and women pilots here to compete in the rich event.

The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads during the last few months have put into effect various economies, especially in passenger transportation, in order to avoid as much preventable waste as possible in the competitive relationship with each other, according to a joint statement by both carriers.

William C. O'Brien, who is employed in Washington as a legal expert of the Fostoffice Department, moved his hand yesterday to indicate an imaginary line drawn on the floor of the Federal Building and said to Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union:

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Armed officers, aided by many citizens, today kept roads open despite striking farmers, who seek to have all agricultural products withheld from market until higher prices can be obtained. There was no great activity by farm strikers in other parts of the State.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Favorites were beaten in three of the four events on today's grand circuit card. The one favorite, Jane Willet, owned by William H. Strang and driven by Ben White, won the 3-year-old trot, after dropping the second heat.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Rudolph, de Bourbon, 35 years old, automobile salesman and mechanical expert, said today he believed the elderly man found dead in a Paris hotel was his father, "Prince Edgar of Bourbon."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP). -- A rift between the Jobless and Liberty parties over a Presidential candidate, on the eve of their national convention planned to be held jointly at Creve Coeur Lake Speedway tomorrow, had caused the leaders of the groups to make plans tonight for two separate conventions.

OTTAWA, Aug. 16. -- All hope of Teaching an agreement at the British Imperial Economic Conference on Thursday, the day set, was abandoned today, and the heads of the nine delegations voted to postpone the plenary session and adjournment until Saturday night.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The controversy between the Lake George Board of Education and the Lake Players over the continued use of the high school for the presentation of plays reached a crisis this forenoon when three members of the board entered the school and evicted Paul Kunasz, the players' press agent, and G.C. Irwin.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 16. -- Listing badly and with a hole torn in her hull, the excursion steamer City ofMemphis was put ashore here tonight and her 748 passengers and crew of thirty-three men landed safely.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Chauncey Steele of Briarcliff registered a pair of victories today to gain the quarter-finals of the annual Junior metropolitan clay court singles championship at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 16. -- Newspapers in the South African Union are criticizing the government for sending an airplane and armored car expedition against a native chief in Southwest Africa because of a controversy over the flight of his wife and a fine assessed against him.

MADRID, Aug. 16. -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora signed today a legislative proposal presented by Premier Manuel Azana after a Cabinet meeting providing for the seizure of "all estates and unmovable property of those impricated in the recent revolutionary movement" of the Monarchists.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 16. -- The failure of Tommy Goodwin, Monroe youngster who has won both the New York State junior and amateur titles this year, was the major surprise at the Cherry Valley Club today when the entries from the metropolitan district underwent their qualifying ordeal for the national amateur golf championship to be played at Five Farms, Baltimore, Sept. 1217.

MAX CAREY stuck to his story. When he left here with the Flatbush Flock he said he was going to toss left-handers at the Pirates. He opened his invasion of the West by sending Joe Shaute to the mound against Traynor, Waner Co. Shaute is as left-handed as Colonel Eppa Rixey of Culpepper, Va., suh! and Colonel Rixey has won three hall games this year, all of them from the Pirates.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Referee Joe Mangold of Atlantic City gave Stanley Poreda, Jersey City heavyweight, the decision over the giant, Primo Carnera of Italy, in their ten-round bout tonight and almost precipitated a riot among some 10,000 fans.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 16. -- A second son was born to Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh at the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, Mrs. Lindbergh's mother, here shortly after 6:30 A.M. today.

A sentence of fifteen years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on Joseph Carlino, 19 years old, who pleaded guilty of participating in the hold-up of a Greenwich Village restaurant at dawn on May 31. Carlino, who in 1930 was sentenced to Elmira Reformatory from Nassau County on a robbery charge, was arrested, with Louis Lauza as they were fleeing with $18 Carlino had taken from the cash register.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 16. -- The Suffolk County Republican committee announced today that it had established a branch of the new radio league started by the national committee of the Republican party. The committee asserts that Suffolk is the first county in the nation to form a unit of the new organization.

On behalf of the people of the State of New York I extend an invitation to all travelers to visit the Empire State and to use and enjoy the facilities for public recreation that are to be found here, especially the great system of public parks described in this booklet.

William Snelling, a diminutive ink manufacturer of Allentown, Pa., was in New York yesterday acquainting purchasing agents with, "a high-grade blue-black permanent product" and other varieties of ink which he and his younger brother, Robert, sons of a prominent research chemist, had perfected in the cellar of their home and now are offering to customers.

Former Representative William H. Hill, who established a reputation for himself as a "harmonizer" in the Hoover pre-convention campaign in this State four years ago, was called in yesterday by Senator Felix Hebert of Rhode Island, Eastern campaign manager for the Republican National Committee, to serve in a somewhat similar capacity in the campaign now in progress to re-elect President Hoover for a second term.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 16. -- Russell N. Boardman, aged 34, who made a non-stop flight from New York to Istanbul, Turkey, in the Winter of 1931, with John Polando of Boston as his flying partner, was critically injured today when his plane crashed near the Springfield Airport.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Marble House, the residence of Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont, has been sold to Frederick H. Prince of Pride's Crossing, Mass. It will be occupied next season by Mr. Prince and his family.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, millionaire sportsman and aviator, will be the Democratic nominee for Congress in the First District to oppose Representative Robert L. Bacon, it was announced today by Philip N. Krug, Nassau County Democratic leader.

Kaye Don, holder of the world's speedboat record, arrived here from England yesterday aboard the liner Majestic. The British speed king is here to compete against Gar "Wood for the Harmsworth Trophy, which Wood defended successfully against Don at Detroit last Summer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during July was reported today by the Census Bureau at 278,656 bales of lint and 37,210 of linters, compared with 320,783 and 46,680 in June this year and 450,884 and 64,325 in July last year.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 16. -- If a strong third party with dry leanings develops in the Presidential campaign, the Woman's Christian Temperance Union probably would support it, according to a concensus today of many delegates to the organization's national convention here.

OTTAWA, Aug. 16. -- An era of wider trade reciprocity between Canada and Great Britain at the expense of the United States was foreseen by British and Canadian officials at the Imperial Economic Conference if they can iron out the difficulties between the two countries.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death at Monte Carlo of Harry Nelson Gay of Rome was appreciatively mentioned in an Associated Press dispatch May 1 speak in a supplementary way of his important public services, particularly to his own country, his loyalty to which was in no way impaired by his love of Italy and his long residence in Rome?
BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- Success in another great atom-smashing goal of science -- the disintegration of masses of atoms -- was announced today by the German General Electric Company.

Mrs. Janet Allen Walker, wife of the Mayor, arrived at Grand Central Terminal from Albany at 8 o'clock last night and was taken in a limousine to the family home at 6 St. Luke's Place. She will stay there and rest for the next two weeks. It had been decided that rest at home would benefit her as much as would a stay in a hospital.

"A balance of less than $500,000 remained in brokerage accounts maintained by Ivar Kreuger with Eastman. Dillon Co. of 120 Broadway to offset a loan of $1,000,000 made to that Swedish financier, it was brought out yesterday at an examination of Herbert L. Dillon, senior partner of the firm, and Roy B. Tomlins, its chief accountant, before Referee Henry K. Davis at his offices at 140 Nassau Street.

That a new school of tuna has come into the waters off Montauk is indicated by the appraisal of the fish that have been brought in during the last two days. For the most part the tuna range from twenty to forty pounds, according to the reports received.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The supply of cotton in the United States for the cotton year which ended July 31 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have been 23,170,748 bales, exclusive of linters. Consumption was 4,869,103 bales, net exports 8,706,890 bales and the carry-over on July 31 was 9,682,316 bales.

TOKYO, Aug. 16. -- Fresh falls of the yen exchange carrying it below 50 per cent of parity, the lowest level in its history, intensify anxiety concerning the future of Japan's currency, which has been growing ever since it became apparent that a heavy deficit was inevitable.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- A new pledge of support for the Federal Farm Board was urged today by James C. Stone, its chairman, at the annual meeting of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, a cooperative marketing association sponsored by the Farm Board.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Twentyeight stockholders of the Farmers' National Grain Corporation, gigantic farmer-owned and government-sponsored grain cooperative, agreed today that the agricultural outlook was improving and were informed that cooperative marketing was making rapid progress.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- Her masthead gold tipped in the dye of the falling afternoon sun, Frederick H. Prince's America's Cup yacht Weetamoe came through today to win the 33-year-old Astor Cup for sloops and yawls. Second to her was the other commissioned international big yacht, Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie, beaten 22 seconds as their bows bobbed and 4 minutes 54 seconds wtih her measurement handicap allowed by the rule makers.
Motor Trucks as "Feeders." Pioneers of the great days of railway construction would be startled if they could examine figures reported by the Interstate Commerce Commission for 1932.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The newspaper Osservatore Romano carried an editorial today charging that communism was at the bottom of the religious troubles in Mexico and that the Communists were acting in league with the Free Masons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs opened up with their heavy guns just in time to defeat Boston, 4 to 3, today, and retain their onegame margin over Pittsburgh for the leadership of the National League.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 16. -- Close fighting marked most of the games in the first round of the international masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress now under way at the Hotel Maryland. Only three of the six games scheduled reached a decision and three were adjourned, among these the encounter between Dr. Alexander Alekhine, world's champion, and Jacob Bernstein of New York City, three times winner of the Empire State title.

Prices of cotton made further improvement yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, advancing nearly $1 a bale to the highest levels in a year. At one time March, May and July contracts sold at more than 8 cents a pound, but when the December went above 7 3/4 cents the market ran into heavy profit-taking, and a 15point setback left the list 6 to 10 points higher than on Monday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 16. -- The Ohio Department of the American Legion in convention today demanded immediate payment of the bonus and condemned the use of "unnecessary force" in evicting the Bonus Expeditionary Force from Washington.

By producing "Domino" at the Playhouse last evening Mr. Brady has officially put a new season on record. Beyond that the accomplishment is not tremendous. For Marcel Achard's comedy, adapted from the French by Grace George, is an artificial trifle that talks most of its amusement away before the second-act curtain.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Another sale was held in the Fasic-Tipton paddock tonight. A total of $25,650 was bid for fortythree head which passed through the ring. This was for an average of about $597.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Sweet Scent, from the stables of C.B. Shaffer of Chicago, ran like the favorite she was today to score an easy victory in the Lake Hills purse at Hawthorne.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The shrinkage, in Germany's export surplus is continuing. For July it was only 66,000,000 marks [about $15,710,000], compared with 79,000,000 marks [about $18,800,000] or 90,000,000 marks if deliveries in kind on the reparation account are included.

The M.M.G. Company, Inc., Mary M. Gately, president, sold two six-family brick flats at 168-70 Seaview Avenue, Jersey City, to the Embro Realty Company. Assessed at $35,400, the houses were taken over subject to three mortgages totaling $22,800.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the publication of my letter entitled "Improvement and Invention" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 28 I have been endeavoring to arouse sufficient interest in the subject to get constructive action under way.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,144,200 barrels, compared with 2,171,900 in the preceding week, a decline of 27,700 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 14,400 barrels in Oklahoma and a rise of 11,000 barrels in California were the most important changes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Indictments charging three "bonus marchers" with assault to kill and assault with a dangerous weapon were reported by the District of Columbia grand jury today at the end of a two weeks' investigation into the rioting of July 28 which preceded the evacuation from Washington of the bonus seekers by military force at the direct order of President Hoover.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Dr. Roderick Macaulay late tonight said that Russell N. Boardman had shown marked improvement. The flier's worst injuries, Dr. Macaulay said, were a contused kidney and a possible fracture of the skull.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Seven 3-year-old trotters will face the starter tomorrow in the seventh running of the classic Hambletonian Stake, the outstanding trotting race in the world. The owners of these seven horses made their final payments of $500 each today, thus bringing the gross value of the stake, for the trotting division, to $48,339.26 and the gross for both the trotting and pacing division to $53,339.26.

BISHOP'S CROSSING, Que., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press). -- A pre-wedding trip of an American couple to the famous shrine at Ste. Anne de Beaupre, Que., was terminated here today by the death of the bride-to-be in an automobile accident.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP). -- By the narrow margin of one run, the Cleveland Indians today defeated the Athletics and squeezed past the Mackmen into second place. The score of the first encounter of the four-game series was 3 to 2.

Forty-three men have been invited to report for football practice at Columbia on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday by Robert F. Moore, assistant director of athletics. Of this group, eighteen were members of last year's squad and the remainder played with the powerful freshman aggregation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Roosevelt and Garner ticket will be elected and both Senate and House will be Democratic, Senator John S. Cohen of Georgia, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, predicted today.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Shouted assertions that the personal diary of Captain W.N. Lancaster carried death threats day after day to the man who stole the love of Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller were made today by State Attorney N. Vernon Hawthorne to the jury hearing the trial of Lancaster for the slaying of Haden Clarke.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The British Government tonight announced the terms of settlement intended to provide a political balance for the next decade at least among India's quarrelsome religious communities.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 16. -- No trucks carrying farm produce or live stock were allowed to enter this city today by more than 1,000 farmers picketing the highways. The selling strike of the farmers was also reported to have had some effect today at Des Moines, but the rest of the State in general is apparently untouched as yet by the strike.

The increasing demand placed on the city treasury by the various pension systems for municipal employes was reflected in the budgetary request of the New York City Employes' Retirement System filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate.

Theodore A. Peyser, insurance man, was picked yesterday by John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and the Assembly district leaders affected, for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District to oppose Mrs. Ruth Pratt, Republican, who is slated for renomination.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The stock markets were greatly heartened today by the overwhelming success of the war loan conversion. Gilt-edge Securities leaped forward in the morning and soon confidence spread to all sections of the exchange. The assented war loan jumped above par, although it later reacted slightly to u99 3/4.

While Wall Street was in a happy frame of mind yesterday as the advance was extended on the Stock Exchange, the reaction from the highest prices of the day tempered the enthusiasm somewhat and emphasized the importance of wheat and other commodities as a market influence.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Dissension among members of the Silk Dyers and Printers' Association over the offer to Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City to become "czar" of the industry was indicated here today with the announcement of the formation of a new organization of silk dyers, with Judge James H. White of the Bergen County District Court as president.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- An "order of the day" issued today by Count Helldorff, commander of the Nazi storm detachments in Berlin, extends the furloughs granted to them to Aug. 28, the day before the Reichstag convenes, and has occasioned some relief as indicating a further postponement of possible disturbance from that quarter.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The attack on the United States for refusing to recognize Soviet Russia was revived today by Izvestia, the government organ, which declared that non-recognition hurts the United States economically and increases the danger of world conflict.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16. -- The manager of the city 200 delivered the opening pitch of the Giants-Reds last-place series today. The game was preceded by an open-air vaudeville show and a snowball fight, with real snow, between Boy Scout troops, the day being devoted to "Zoo-Civic Day," the Zoological Society of Cincinnati sharing the profits.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 16. -- A government communique today says that troops under Colonel Playsant in the southern sector began attacking Xiririca this morning.

FLORENCE, S.C., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Higher prices for lower grades than were paid last year were received by growers in heavy opening sales today on the tobacco markets of Eastern South Carolina and border counties of North Carolina.

Declines in all classifications, with the exception of manufacturing, featured business failures for the week ended Aug. 11, according to Bradstreet's. Retail defaults fell off rather sharply from 416 to 373. The total number of failures for the period was 511, against 572 in the preceding week.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon left the Plaza yesterday to pass the remainder of the season in Newport.
J. Sidney Rambridge, Mayor of Salisbury, England, is sailing tonight on the Cunarder Berengaria. Others who will be on board are:

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Secrets of the mysterious interior of Kodiak Island, clues to the origin of the American Indian and meteorological information which may have a bearing on the forecasting of weather in North America are a few results of the navy's third aerial survey expedition to Alaska.

The city of Pittsburgh, Pa., awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,300,000 of 4 1/4 per cent bonds at a price of 101.6599 to a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and including the National City Company, W.H. Newbold's Son Co., Janney Co., Peoples-Pittsburgh Trust Company and the Philadelphia National Company.

MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press). -- Jersey City captured the opener of a four-game series today from the Montreal Royals, 9 -- 6. Chick Outen, the visitors' catcher, led in the attack with four hits, including two homers, driving in three runs.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Daily rehearsals are being held under the direction of Jack Devereaux, son-in-law of the late John Drew, in the John Drew Memorial Theatre at Guild Hall, for the four one-act plays to be given there on Saturday night by Maidstone Club members.

Declaring that the Seabury investigation, had disclosed "a spectacle at which every self-respecting citizen must hang his head in shame," George Boochever, chairman of the city finance committee of the Civic Council of Brooklyn, pictured New York City yesterday as "almost ruined", by the present political system and urged the adoption of the city manager plan, with proportional representation, to avert the disintegration of the City Government.

GENEVA, Aug. 16. -- The summoning of a world-wide Jewish congress in the Summer of 1934 will be decided on by tomorrow's plenary session of the conference representatives of nineteen nations. A commission was still discussing the details tonight, but it is certain that a resolution tomorrow will recommend the selection of delegates by means of elections in which Jews of all countries will be asked to vote.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16. -- In marked contrast to their effective bludgeoning of yesterday, the Dodgers today were able to collect only seven singles off the southpawing of Larry Frenche and suffered a 4-to-0 shut-out at the hands of the Pirates, who now lead Brooklyn by a game and a half.

When the Roxy reopens on Saturday it will offer the symphony orchestra, chorus, ballet, Roxyettes ensemble and its usual-features, Frank Cambria, new director of the theatre, announced yesterday. Adbertina Rasch will act as consultant in the arrangement of the ballet, Clark Robinson will be director of the stage productions, David Ross will be musical director and Russell Markert will supervise the chorus and Roxyettes.

The attractions of New York City are the best preventives of homesickness for the out-of-town visitors, according to a survey just completed among 794 non-resident New York University students by the university's Summer School News. The poll failed to uncover a single case of nostalgia, despite the known fact that many were visiting the city for the first time.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- For the second year in succession the silks of Mrs. Isabel Sloan, owner of the Brookmeade Stable, were in front in the Catskill Claiming Stakes, run for the thirtieth time here today. Helianthus's drive in the last sixteenth brought a nose victory over Frank E. Brown's Condescend.

In the first notable upset of the forty-third annual women's national tennis championship tournament on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco yesterday defeated Miss Sarah Palfrey of Sharon, Mass., in three sets, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4, 6--2.

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Miss Bea Gottlieb, Lakeville Country Club star, set a new women's record for the Hackensack Golf Club's long course today with a 79, one stroke under the mark made a year ago by Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol and in so doing won low gross prize in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Coming from behind in the eighth inning with a four-run rally, the Washington Senators scored a 5-to-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today in the first game of their series.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Markets at Sioux City and a few smaller Northwest Iowa towns suffered declining receipts today because of farmers' attempts to withhold the sale of their products pending higher prices.

A new Issue of $6,000,000 Iowa Electric Light and Power Company first mortgage 7 per cent bonds, Series C. dated Aug. 1, 1932, and due in 1912, will be offered today at par and interest. The offering group is headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and includes the N.W. Harris Company, Inc., Brown Brothers, Harriman Co. and Coffin Burr, Inc.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- The sailing of the Astor Cup race took place here today. Former Commodore Vincent Astor, donor of the cup, was a spectator on the Nourmahal and had a large party of guests. Other yachts that went out with guests were:

A decision whether to go ahead with, the plan for a commodities credit corporation, as proposed by Eugene Meyer, governor of the New York Reserve Bank, or to let the project lapse on the ground that the recovery in the commodities markets has made it unnecessary, is expected to be reached by bankers today or tomorrow.

The greater part of the estate of James Strange Alexander, former chairman of the board of the Guaranty Trust Company, and widely known in banking circles throughout the country, was bequeathed to his son and daughter, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the second in the series of bridge tournaments held tonight at the clubhouse of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Several dinners were given before the tournament.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- Although the forthcoming report on the conflict between Japan and China by the Lytton inquiry commission of the League of Nations is officially still kept in the dark, the British Government now has no doubt whatever that it will constitute a severe indictment of Japanese policy in Manchuria.
CRISFIELD, Md., Aug. 16. -- Making a full day of it around some of Chesapeake Bay's best-known fishing grounds, President Hoover today hauled in fifteen trout, one of them a three-footer.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with approval your editorial "Back With Other Citizens," and the endorsement thereof by Robert L. Cook, in his letter, "The Bonus March."

At the beginning of May a meeting of leaders of farm associations and farmers at Des Moines formed the Iowa Farm Holiday Association and put at its head Mr. MILO RENO, sometime president of the Iowa Farmers' Union, member of the Corn Belt Committee and miscellaneously eminent in agricultural economics and politics.

BRONXVILLE, N.T., Aug. 16. -- Miss Helen Silleck of the Greenwich Country Club carded an 88 to annex low gross honors in the women's Westchester-Fairfield one-day golf tourney at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

George Schlegel of Brooklyn has bought an English type stone residence at Hampton and Whig Roads, Fox Meadow, Scarsdale, from the Hampton-Whig Corporation. The house was built by Ole Larson from plans by Theodore Richards Jr. of White Plains.

The Count and the Professor were held in 150,000 ball each by Magistrate Burke in Yorkville court yesterday for hearing before the grand jury on charges of grand larceny. The police said the prisoners admitted that two years ago they swindled Valentine P. Greer cut of $25,000.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 16. -- The Pinchot Administration and the State Republican organization joined forces today to push through the Legislature the general sales tax bill, calling for a levy of 1 per cent. The measure, introduced in the house tonight, is expected to provide $12,000,000 to $15,000,000 for Statewide unemployment relief.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The Quotations are for 3-4 months' paper.

George F. Mand, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, asked Governor Roosevelt yesterday to withdraw his support of the proposal to grant twenty acres of the Fort Schuyler site to the New York State Merchant Marine Academy as a land base, in order that the entire site of fifty-six acres might be turned over to the city for use as a public park.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Taxpayers whose assessments total about $8,000,000, or one-fourth of the entire assessed valuation of the city of Glen Cove, filed protests today either in person or through, their attorneys on the annual grievance day session in the Mayor's office in City Hall.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Sixteen players remained in the men's national public parks singles tennis championship as the result of matches decided on the Shawnee Park courts-today.

Maria Olszewska, contralto, who has been with the Chicago Civic Opera Company since the Fall of 1928, has been engaged by the Metropolitan for the coming season, it was learned yesterday. Mme. Olszewska will undoubtedly appear in the leading contralto roles in the German repertoire, although her range takes in operas of various languages and such roles as Carmen.

Speaker John N. Garner, Democratic nominee for Vice President, called on former Governor Alfred E. Smith at the latter's office in the Empire State Building yesterday and said later that he had "hopes" that Mr. Smith would give active support to the national ticket.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Paul Derringer won a pitchers' battle with Flint Rhem, former St. Louis pitcher, as the Cardinals took the opening game of a series with Philadelphia today, 3 to 2. Each hurler allowed eight hits. Rhem gave way to J. Elliott in the last inning.

Politics, that new-found diversion of the Long Island North Shore which took so many fashionable people to the Chicago conventions, is to put on an extra-special performance this Fall. As if it were not distinction enough, for Nassau County to have DAVID DOWS of Charlton Hall as Its High Sheriff, the Democrats have induced CORNELIUS VANDERBILT WHITNEY to run for Congress against Representative ROBERT LOW BACON.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Louisiana received today the fourth loan made to a State by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for immediate relief of unemployment, $1,096,084 being put at that State's disposal. Loans previously have been made in similar comparatively small amounts to Illinois, Ohio and Michigan, out of a fund of $300,000,000 set aside for this purpose by the unemployment relief act.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Wholesale commodity prices advanced nearly 1 per cent in July as compared with June, but were about 10 1/2 per cent below the level of July, 1931, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced this afternoon.

The Girl Guides of India, who are affiliated, in a world organization, with the Girl Scouts here, are helping to break down the ancient Hindu barriers of caste and the prejudices between the different religious groups in that country, Miss Patricia Richards, who has worked for many years in the girls' organization there and in South Africa, said yesterday.

Julian Green has been traveling in Germany this Summer with a manuscript in his valise on which he has not been tempted to work since he left Paris. He intends, however, to finish it this year, he writes his publishers, Harper Brothers, who will bring out his "Strange River" next week.

TORONTO, Aug. 16 (Canadian Press). -- Opening a long home stand today the Toronto Leafs were defeated, 8 -- 1, by Newark when Charlie Sullivan, faltered late in the game. The Bears made fourteen hits off Sullivan and ten of the fourteen came in the last four innings.

VIENNA, Aug. 16. -- The Austrian Parliament will decide tomorrow whether or not to accept the Lausanne Protocol and with it a loan which the big powers are willing to grant Austria if she pleases France by renewing for ten years the Geneva Protocol's promise of no anschluss with Germany.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Wheat made a strong start and a weak finish today on the Board of Trade here. An early bulge of 1 3/8 cents a bushel, helped by rises in stocks and in Liverpool, brought in free selling by houses with Eastern connections and by holders of offers.

Wall Street itself was taken considerably by surprise at the character of yesterday's rise on the Stock Exchange. In numerous instances, prices scored a substantial overnight advance and, in the earlier trading, gains over Monday's closing ranged in the more active shares from 3 to 7 points.
BERLIN, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Scathing attacks were launched today against the government of Chancellor Franz von Papen by Adolf Hitler and by Ernst Thaelmann, chieftain of Germany's 3,500,000 Communists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- A three-to-one vote in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, with local option under government ownership and control of the liquor industry, has been cast in a referendum taken among the 25,000 enrolled members of the Socialist party, according to an announcement made here today by Clarence Senior, national executive secretary of the party.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The Investing public finally returned to the Boerse today, causing a somewhat accelerated advance in stocks which had been rising gradually in recent days. Gains of 3 per cent were not unusual. Banks tried to lead the public to buy securities which, they believe to be well founded because of apprehension that it might put its money in low-priced stocks which the banks regard as having lost all value.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- A New York National Guardsman was killed and two others were injured late today when two trucks filled with State soldiers returning from manoeuvres at Bedford plunged into ditches along the Amawalk Road and overturned.

BUFFALO, Aug. 16. -- Colonel William J. Donovan, former Assistant Attorney General of the United States and war-time commander of the 165th Infantry, the old "Fighting Sixty-ninth," made formal announcement here today that he would be a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination at the Republican State Convention, to be held late next month.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Prechampionship competition, for the Knox Cups produced another fast game of high-goal polo today as the Templeton team, led by Winston Guest at No. 2, turned back Greentree, 12 -- 10, on the estate of John Hay Whitney, Greentree leader.

Moving hurriedly on as if in great haste to reach a goal which nobody is likely to take away from them anyhow, the Yankees returned to the Stadium yesterday and forthwith advanced two more strides toward that day when they will present Colonel Ruppert with his seventh American League pennant by flattening the Tigers in both ends of a doubleheader.

STAMFORD, Conn, Aug. 16. -- As a result of the two races held today in the championship regatta of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, being held off here, the Black Rock and Indian Harbor crews are tied for the lead with 30 points each.

ST. JOHN'S, Que., Aug. 16. -- Turning homeward after a week's inspection of State hospitals, institutions and the Canadian power development at Beauharnois, Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman arrived here tonight on the last leg of his trip.

New life insurance produced in this country in July was 23.5 per cent less than in the same month last year, the decrease being the same as in June, according to a report sent yesterday to the United States Department of Commerce by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- Governor Roosevelt personally took over the examination of Mayor Walker at the hearing today of the removal charges against the New York City executive and asked what steps he had taken to find the missing Russell T. Sherwood and bring him before the Hofstadter Legislative Committee.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings won the first of a four-game series with Albany today, 5 to 2, scoring 4 runs in the seventh inning, after two were out, to break a 1-all tie. Tony Kaufmann, winning pitcher, started the rally with a single.

New high levels for the current advance in the prices of sugar, including two records for the year, were established yesterday in the markets here. One new high point for the year was reached by refined sugar, leading refiners announcing that they would move their prices up 10 points to 4.25 cents a pound.

When General FRANK T. HINES, head of the Veterans' Administration, appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee to make a statement about the cost of compensation for veterans of the World and other wars he had a limited audience.

Stalin's administration of the Five-Year Plan by a series of fitful drives rather than a single coordinated movement already has set back Russia's national economy at least twenty years, Isaac Don Levine contends in his new book, "Red Smoke," published today by Robert M. McBride Co.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Far-reaching orders for the confiscation of the property of Monarchists and nobles were issued by the local government today in its clean-up resulting from last week's one-day Monarchist rebellion.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- Sidney B. Wood Jr., one time Wimbledon champion, and Clifford Sutter, intercollegiate champion of this year, were the first of the ranking American players to fall before the attack of unseeded threats in the sixteenth annual tournament for the Newport Casino Cup, whose third round was completed today.

WANTAGH, L.I., Aug. 16. -- The Jones Beach life guard team won the North Atlantic Coast Life Guard tournament by one point over the Atlantic City team tonight in sixteen boat racing and life guard demonstration events held on the beach this afternoon and in the open-air pool tonight.
New Hampshire was claimed directly for Governor Roosevelt and Massachusetts indirectly by the State chairmen of those States in statements issued yeterday through the Democratic National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A report adverse to Japan by the Lytton commission on Manchuria will come as no surprise to officials here, because of the feeling long held that whatever provocation given by the Chinese, it was not extensive enough to warrant a campaign for the absorption by Japan of Manchuria.
ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- The official record of today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt in removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker follows:

More than six times as many males as females drown annually in the United States, which has 7,500 accidental drownings each year, according to an article in a recent issue of the statistical bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Drownings come next to automobile accidents and fall among accidental causes of death, the bulletin avers.

BENTON, Ill., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Five members of a student mine investigating party were jailed here today. They are Joseph Hamburger and Henry Forblade of Mena, Ark., and Fred Glatzer, A.O. Carlson and his wife, Beatrice, of Chicago.

The stand taken by President Hoover on prohibition in his speech of acceptance received commendation in a statement made public yesterday by S.E. Nicholson, secretary of the Anti-Saloon League of America as well as a member of the National Prohibition Board of Strategy and the Friends' Prohibition Board.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 16 -- Coal miners in the Taylorville region held stubbornly to their right to work today, despite an impending invasion by several thousand strikers which is scheduled for Thursday noon.

One of the most interesting and significant experiments in vocational guidance and college selection is being carried on under the auspices of Stevens Institute in a camp fifty, miles from its campus. It is called a "college camp," but the campers are preparatory school boys.
Robert Garrison has received a contract for the sculptural treatment of the main entrance to the R.K.O. Building in Rockefeller, Center, it was announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To those interested -- and all should be -- in the restoration of our foreign trade, your discussion of the Cuban economic situation is most valuable, particularly as men so conversant with Cuban affairs as Mr. Rubens and Mr. Todd join in.
Sales and leases of housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx featured mild real estate trading-yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- The stock market fluctuated little during an inactive session of the Bourse today. The trend was irregularly lower. Suez Canal, Fenarroya. Kuhlman, Air Liquide and Citroen all were slightly lower, while banks, electricals and international stocks such as Rio Tinto and Royal Dutch, were higher.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The stock markets were irregular today as a result of profit-taking. With sterling exchange on New York weakening to $3.47 1/4, British Government funds declined sharply in the forenoon, but renewed support in the afternoon caused a small recovery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Prohibition Bureau today reported an increase in the number of arrests and of defendants held by United States commissioners during July, as compared with June. There were declines in the number of cases placed on the docket, verdicts of guilty, pleas of guilty, acquittals and cases nolle prossed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Reiterating his hope and belief that Alfred E. Smith would take an active part in the campaign for the Democratic ticket, Speaker Garner left tonight for his home State of Texas expressing a desire to defer as long as possible the speaking part of the drive for votes.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 17 -- One hundred Berkshire friends of Willem Willeke, 'cellist, who has been conductor for nine years of Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's South Mountain String Quartet and Elshuco Trio, will give him a complimentary dinner at the Pittsfield Country Club on Thursday night, Aug. 25, in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his arrival in this country from Holland.

If Clerk TRIMBLE of the House of Representatives makes public, when they are submitted to him, loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since the Wagner bill became effective, some timid bank depositors and insurance policy holders may become alarmed.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The official Record of today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt in removal proceedings against Mayor. James J. Walker follows:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17 -- Protected by a heavy barrage after a preparatory artillery bombardment, federal infantrymen, were advancing today on the rebel lines at Lavrinhas, which was expected to fall at any moment, according to a communique from federal headquarters on the eastern front.

WELCH, W.Va., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Officials of the Lake Superior Coal Company announced today that 100 miners will return to work at the company's Superior mine tomorrow. The mine, closed for three months, will operate three or four days a week indefinitely.

SEATTLE, Aug. 17 -- Over her protest that she did not wish to be considered a candidate, Mrs. Ella A. Boole of Brooklyn, N.Y., was reelected today national president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union. The convention adopted a report which forecast "an uprising of the American people" for a new political party.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Through the fourth round, packed with thrills, surprises and uncertainties, eight choice players of three nationalities remained today to battle for the Newport Casino Cup.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- The injunction suit brought by four Brooklyn terminal companies to prevent the Pennsylvania Railroad from putting into effect its proposed "store door" collection and delivery of freight in New York and Brooklyn, was dismissed in the Federal District Court today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- H.O. Hamilton, New York architect, left today for the United States to continue work on his plans for the Palace of the Soviets, after having designed almost $100,000,000 worth of construction, for the Soviet government.
The Encyclopedia Americana, according to its own title page, is a library of universal knowledge. Thus it does not overlook Falls City, Neb., of which it reports:
The Goldman Band gave the final concert of its season on the Mall in Central Park last night. The band's last performance this Summer will take place tomorrow night on the New York University campus.

Government regulation of production and distribution of all common necessities, similar to the present regulation of public utilities, is urged by Richard E. Weldon, member of the New York bar, in his book, "The Price of Peace," published by the Darwell Publishing Company.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Mayor Walker admitted to Governor Roosevelt this afternoon toward the close of his examination by the Governor in removal proceedings based on the "conclusions" of Samuel Seabury, that four doctors who split their fees with his brother, Dr. William H. Walker, were still working for the city of New York.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug 17 -- For the first time since the Imperial Economic Conference began its sessions here it was revealed today that the conference probably would make no definite recommendation as to an increase in the empire content of material and labor in commodities produced in empire States necessary to make such commodities eligible for imperial preference.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 -- Memphis Bill Terry demonstrated some fine points in managerial efficiency today by collecting a home run, two doubles and two singles, hereby heading the onslaught which landed the Giants an 8-to-0 victory over the Reds in the second game of the series.
