The rise in bond prices, after having pursued an almost uninterrupted course of recovery during eleven successive weeks, continued yesterday, with numerous further advances of 1 to 5 points, raising the "bond averages" to a figure 32 per cent above the end of May; but the secondary advance in stocks, with which this week began, was checked.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The Marchioness, a bay filly which was bought at auction as a yearling for $3,000, today captured the seventh Hambletonian Stake, staged over the lightning-fast course of the Good Time Park, winning for her owner, Mrs. Ralph R. Keeler of Auburn, W.Y., a purse of $29,742.48.

Because he feared a fog would result from the low temperatures in the harbor, Captain Heinrich Molchin, master of the Hamburg-American motorship Milwaukee, brought his vessel through the harbor without stopping at Quarantine yesterday.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Insistence by the United States on full payment of war debts may bring default or repudiation, according to Dr. John H. Williams, Professor of Economics at Harvard University, who told the Institute of Politics today that drastic reduction of the war debts would stimulate international trade and would more than compensate for the loss of payments.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Dale Alexander did some important hitting behind the six-hit pitching of Paul Andrews today and the Red Sox won ball game, 7 to 3, at the expense of he Browns.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Hoover returned to the White House early tonight after a three-day fishing cruise on the Potomac River and Chesapeake Bay.

OTTAWA, Aug. 17 -- The efforts of the Imperial Economic Conference to achieve a uniform method of customs administration in the empire broke down today when the committee dealing with this matter brought in a report expressing the pious hope that it would be the endeavor of all the countries concerned to work toward curtailment and amelioration of the dumping and extra-tariff restrictions now in operation.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister MacDonald's effort to solve the problem, of communal representation in Indian Provincial Legislatures was generally considered today to be an equitable search for compromise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The number of aliens leaving the United States permanently in the last fiscal year was nearly three times that of the new immigrants admitted for permanent residence, according to a statement issued today by Secretary Doak.

Average daily, electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, was 208,800,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Aug. 13, as against 210,200,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 240,400,000 kilowatthours in the corresponding week last year.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- An airplane that will retrace the steps of aviation to study the flight of birds was awaiting a trial at Templeh of Airdrome near here, today.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y. Aug. 17 -- Swinging back into New York from Canada on the last leg of his up-State inspection trip, Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman inspected the new Plattsburg normal school here today, and drove twenty miles away to visit Clinton Prison at Dannomora, known among convicts as "Siberia."

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 17 -- Taking the final race of the championship series by a margin of fifteen seconds, the Black Rock crew, skippered by John W. Field, came through today to win the ninth annual championship of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound with a total of 51 points.

The Broadway Theatre, built for B.S. Moss and until recently operated by him, has been booked by Earl Carroll for the tenth edition of "Vanities," opening late next month. In an effort to regain possession of the new Casino Theatre, formerly the Earl Carroll, which he was forced to relinquish last Winter, Mr. Carroll started negotiations with the 755 Seventh Avenue Corporation.

Mayor WALKER complained at the Albany hearing that he had been compelled to "spend so much time on inferences or innuendoes." What did he expect? Did he imagine that an overt act of corruption could be proved? No one could have supposed that the Mayor would come out openly on the City Hall steps and offer to sell his official favor for $26,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Charleigh, recently purchased by William Schmidt of Chicago for $7,000, romped home in the Eclipse Handicap at Hawthorne today.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 17 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The qualifying plan used by the United States Golf Association this year to reduce the field of players in the United States amateur championship to manageable size apparently has worked out very nicely for all concerned.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The public, from whom Walter E. Hering once sought advice on disposal of his wealth, was his principal beneficiary, his will revealed tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The version of two State troopers of the incidents during a vigil of more than fortyhours in which they tried, with ultimate success, to serve a subpoena on Park Commissioner Walter R. Herriek, in response to which he testified in the Walker removal proceedings on Monday, became known here today following their reports to their superiors.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Bishop James Cannon Jr., who helped to carry Southern States for President Hoover in 1928, today assailed the prohibition stand set forth in the President's acceptance speech as "surrender to the speakeasies, bootleggers and nullifiers of the Constitution."

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Authorities looked tonight to underworld contacts of J. Earl Smith for clues to the mysterious slaying of the lawyer, found shot to death here this morning after participating in the defense at Fort Scott, Kan., of Harvey Bailey, identified as the leader of the largest bank robbery on record.

Mrs. Katharine Clemmons Gould, who obtained a decree of separation from Howard Gould in 1909, left a New York estate appraised yesterday at $100,914 gross and $90,646 net, the bulk of which was in jewelry worth $55,111, including a platinum and diamond chain worth $17,500 and a platinum and diamond tiara appraised at $12,000.

Professor Auguste Piccard and Max Cosyns, his assistant, started their flight intended to take them up twelve miles into the stratosphere, at 5:06 o'clock this morning Swiss time [12:06 A.M., New York Time], according to a broadcast carried to New York from Dubendorf, Switzerland, by the National Broadcasting Company.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- The $21,000,000 suit brought by minority stockholders against those who were directors of the Gillette Safety Razor Company in 1930 was settled today.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 17 -- Legislation to provide unemployment relief through a general sales tax and to investigate the relations of public utilities to the Public Service Commission was hastened by the Legislature today, nearing adjournment of its special session after eight weeks.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- The Jewish rence here called by American rs today, as forecast yesterday, oned a representative world sh congress to convene not later an the Summer of 1934, issued a manifesto calling on Christian peoples to abandon anti-Semitism and adjourned its four-day sessions.

The people of the United States must find some way to take out of the life of the nation the economic uncertainty and the waste and maladjustments that have produced depression after depression, said a "Labor Day Message" mailed yesterday to nearly 10,000 Presbyterian churches in the country under the title "The Challenge of the Present Economic Crisis to the Church."
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Renewed demonstrations took place today in the Paris wheat market, which was invaded by a delegation of wheat farmers protesting at declines in wheat prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Westchester County has been pictured in the public mind as an area composed of hills, valleys, forests, lakes, purling streams and a magnificent parkway system -- all of which is true. Further impression obtains that, with relatively few exceptions, its inhabitants reside on palatial estates and devote their lives to country clubs, hunts, golf, tennis, polo, yachting, cards, dancing.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Misses Alva Christensen and Mary L. Degive, two girls from Atlanta, Ga., climbed stiffly off a freight car in the railroad yard early this morning at the end of an adventuresome journey from New York.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 17 -- A decision is expected tomorrow night in the controversy among silk dyers over the plan to appoint Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City as dictator of the dyeing industry. The program also provides for the appointment of John Milton, Hague's friend and corporation counsel of Jersey City, as counsel for the group.

Reports emanating from the preserves of Central Park's upper watershed yesterday indicated that this year's fishing is far below par. The restocking of the streams has been allowed to lapse, apparently, and there are far too many minnows instead of perch swimming around.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- A tentative itinerary for Governor Roosevelt's invasion of the West revealed today that he would make the widest swing through the country of any Democratic Presidential nominee in many years.

THE breaking of records in the Olympic Games must have stirred up the golfers of the country. The divot-diggers went out the other day and smashed a long-standing record all to pieces. They took part in sectional qualifying rounds for the national amateur golf championship and practically every favorite got in.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Several remarkable bowling achievements featured play in firstclass cricket matches commencing today.Outstanding was the record of James Langridge, who; playing for Sussex against Gloucestershire at Cheltenham, secured seven wickets for eight runs. The Western County was dismissed for 86 runs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The bad erosion of the beach which occurred recently at Oak Island, five miles south of Babylon, brings up the subject of coast erosion and protection -- a subject little understood. It is indeed regrettable that many people consider themselves "experts" in the matter, probably by virtue of their proximity to the ocean.

Only five of the twenty concerns which submitted competitive bids for Queens bus franchises to the Board of Estimate last May have shown evidence of satisfactory finances, responsibility and stability, according to a report made public yesterday by the board's division of franchises.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The capital's dual air program, which will occupy the attention of most of the aviation world during the next four days, preparation for the start of the eastern leg of the $20,000 transcontinental air derby and the annual convention of the National Aeronautic Association, was informally opened today when the board of governors of the N.A.A. held its annual meeting.

Charles F. Kerrigan, assistant to the Mayor, denied heatedly yesterday that he had told Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., assistant to Samuel Seabury, that the Mayor did not expect the agents of the Hofstadter committee to be able to find Russell T. Sherwood, the Mayor's missing accountant and financial agent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Three directors of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board left Washington tonight for hurried trips to scattered parts of the country to sound out financial interests on the amount of stock subscription that may be expected for the eight to twelve institutions authorized by the act.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The 2-year-old champion of a year ago, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Top Flight, established herself more than ever as the best of the 3-year-old filies with a decisive victory in the fifty-second running of the Alabama Stakes, run today before one of the meeting's largest midweek crowds.

In his weekly radio addresses on State finance Governor ROOSEVELT has frequently called for suggestions how savings might be made in the annual appropriations for the support of the State Government. He has now received an answer from one highly responsible source.

Taking advantage of the trust's improved-financial position resulting from the prolonged rally in securities, the directors of the General American Investors Corporation voted yesterday to clear up an overdue dividend on its preferred stock. A regular quarterly payment of $1.50 a share was declared, as well as an additional $1.50 a share due to stockholders as a result of the inability of the company to make its July disbursement.

When the London round table conference adjourned last December with the main principle of a federated India established but with many concrete questions left hanging, Prime Minister MACDONALD warned the Indian parties and factions that if they failed to agree upon an electoral system, Great Britain would take it upon herself to proclaim one.

If Rip Van Winkle had gone to sleep after the campaign of 1928 or 1924 or 1884 or any quadrennium between and waked up this August, he would be consoled among many bewilderments to find that politics is the same thing over again. The old familiar voices would come to his ears.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- A proposal to settle the dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay by giving Bolivia an outlet to the sea through canalization of the Bermejo River from Juntas De San Antonio, Bolivia, to the Paraguay River was proposed in the Argentine Senate today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Deaths caused by automobile accidents in eighty-six selected cities were nearly 9 per cent fewer in the year ending Aug. 6 than in the year previous, the Bureau of the Census announced today. This represented a decrease of 10 per cent in the death rate per 100,000 population.

Province of British Columbia. The first public offering here of a new issue of Canadian securities since last September will be made today with the marketing of $2,000,000 Province of British Columbia 5 per cent bonds, dated Aug. 15, 1932, and due in 1934.

Any Old Eagle Will Do. Americans who can get enough of the new bicentennial twenty-five-cent pieces won't be disposed, to worry because on their reverse side the Treasury has permitted a golden eagle to supplant the traditional bald eagle.

One other member of President Hoover's Cabinet, in addition to Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, will probably be drafted by the Republican National Committee for the early campaign in Maine, where the election of State officials is held on Sept. 12.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 17 (AP) -- National Guard bayonets were dusted off tonight as guns blazed in the strife-torn Illinois coal fields.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Approval by the Interstate Commerce commission of a loan of $10,000,000 of the Boston Maine Railroad by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation opened the way today for the railroad partially to pay off bank loans of $5,500,000, to wipe out more than $1,000,000 of overdue vouchers and in other ways to clear its books current debts.

DUBENDORF, Switzerland, Aug. 17 -- Professor Auguste Piccard of Brussels University and Max Cosyns, his 26-year-old assistant, made a final inspection this evening of the "Nacelle" and gas bag in which they expect to ascend twelve of fifteen miles.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Lefty Grove hurled shut-out ball today to down Cleveland, 11 to 0, for his eighteenth victory of the season and put the Athletics back into second place, ahead of Cleveland. He defeated his old rival, Wes Ferrell, holding the Indians to four hits while the Macks were gathering fifteen.

Harrietts Lake and Roberta Robinson are the latest additions to the touring company of "Of Thee I Sing," opening in Detroit on Sept. 11. Miss Lake will be seen in the part acted here by Lois Moran, while Miss Robinson will have the Grace Brinkley role.

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Led by the peerless hackney mare, Seaton Pippin, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Moore's string of harness horses from the Seaton Hackney Farm, Morristown, N.J., scored a clean sweep in the breeding classes in which they were exhibited today at the opening session of the Cohasset horse show.
TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- Activities of Japanese munitions factories, together with heavier than usual imports of potential war material, are attracting the attention of responsible observers here.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The Walker hearing will enter a new phase tomorrow with witnesses other than the Mayor occupying the centre stage of the removal proceedings in the executive chamber.

The day before Ivar Kreuger shot himself in Paris last March, he was asked by cable to give "real and complete information" to his brokers here, Eastman, Dillon Co. of 120 Broadway, as to European selling pressure which had been increasingly pronounced in Kreuger securities on the three previous days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Citizens with grievances about conditions in municipal departments have made use of the New York Committee of One Thousand as a public service agency with which their complaints could be lodged, analyzed without charge by a staff of lawyers and, if found worthy, placed before the proper authorities for action.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 17 -- Despite heavy fog over the Atlantic for most of the voyage, the Manhattan, newest cabin liner of the United States Lines, under the guidance of Captain George Fried, arrived here at 12:55 this afternoon in record time for a cabin ship.

The East River Savings Bank, as plaintiff, yesterday bought in for $200,000 the seven-story building at 23-30 West Fifty-seventh Street, one of the realty holdings of the late Arnold Rothstein. The property was put up in foreclosure for a lien of $618,779.

With George Herman Ruth decorating the event with his thirty-fourth me run of the current campaign, e Yankee steam-roller extended its inning streak to ten in a row at e Stadium yesterday. The Yanks d it by the simple expedient of flatning the Tigers, who, once the ller started to exert a little pressre, are, flattened as easily as in the first two games of the series on Tuesday.
MONTREAL, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Montreal evened the series with Jersey City today, winning 6-5, on Pomorski's pitching though the righthander had to be relieved by Barnes and Fisher in the ninth.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Captain W.N. Lancaster, British flier, was freed today of a charge of murdering Eaden Clarke, young writer and his rival in love, by a verdict which precipitated a court-room demonstration that threatened to go beyond the control of bailiffs.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 17 -- A maority of the nineteen officers of the Forty-fourth Division Aviation Group of the New Jersey National Guard have threatened to resign from the New Jersey National Guard unless Governor A. Harry Moore reinstates Major Robert L. Copsey as commander of the unit, it became known here tonight.

Under good crop reports and influenced by reactions in securities and grains yesterday cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange declined more than $1 a bale at one time. The setback of almost $2 a bale from the high marks of the week attracted an active demand from trade quarters, and a reversal of trend in the last hour left quotations 11 to 14 points lower than on Tuesday.

Controller Berry intends to answer, possibly today, the questions concerning the city's financial condition put to him in a letter from former Mayor John F. Hylan, it was said yesterday at the offices of the Department of Finance in the Municipal Building.

PASADENA, Aug. 17 -- Quite as keen as on the opening day was the play in the second round of the international tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland today, decisions being reached in only two of the six games scheduled.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present status of rail passenger rates is one of strange anomalies. On the one hand, we are offered unprecedentedly low-priced Sunday excursions and weekend trips. On the other hand, those who are obliged to travel for business or pleasure, midweek, or on one-way trips, pay the standard wartime rate and the Pullman surcharge.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 17 -- British delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference said today they thought they had devised a formula for the solution of the Russian dispute that would tie accepted by Premier R.B. Bennett and his associate Canadian delegates. One of these Canadian delegates after seeing the formula said:

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Chicago's Cubs, led by a pair of rookies, defeated the Boston Braves in a 19-inning thriller at Wrigley Field today, 3 to 2, and boosted their lead in the National League pennant race to two full games over Pittsburgh.
NEW YORK. Rufus L. Patterson, accompanied by his daughter, Mrs. Casimir de Rham, and Dr. James I. Russell, left yesterday for his camp in the Blue Ridge Mountains in Western North Carolina.

Alfred C. Blumenthal, theatrical broker and friend of Mayor Walker, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday as a bondholder of the Paramount Publix Corporation, charging that the corporation had violated a guarantee to himself and other bondholders by pledging its "quick, valuable assets," consisting of twenty-three motion pictures valued at $10,000,000 to a banking syndicate as security for loans.

To Wall Street yesterday's stock market was much less colorful and interesting than those of the two previous days. The decline, which wiped out all of the morning's gains and part of Tuesday's, appeared to be the result largely of profit-taking induced by the maintenance of the regular dividend rate on shares of American Telephone and Telegraph.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- At the sale held by the Fasig-Tipton Company tonight forty-five head of the choicest stock bred by Marshall Field and other well-known followers of the turf passed through the ring for a total value of only $36,190, an average of about $804 per head.

Although domestic corporation bonds showed further gains on the average on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the upward movement was smaller than on Monday and Tuesday. Of the nine most active issues of the corporation group, three showed fractional losses, two held unchanged and four moved up 1/3 to 1/2 point for the day.

CREVE COEUR SPEEDWAY, ST. LOUIS, Aug 17 (AP) -- Two political groups, each intent on control of a proposed coalition party, split and held separate conventions here today, the Jobless party nominating Father James R. Cox of Pittsburgh for President and the Liberty party reaffirming the nomination of W.H. "Coin" Harvey of Montene, Ark.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- By bringing ailing Deputies to Parliament in ambulances and enlisting the special efforts of the Austrian State Railways to clear a landslide that would otherwise have prevented a number of supporters of the government from reaching Vienna from Tyrol, the Dollfuss Cabinet today succeeded in getting the Lausanne protocol and $42,000,000 League of Nations loan approved by eighty-one votes to eighty.

Added reports of the smashing of the atom recall its early entry into literature. So generally was the atom regarded in ancient Greece as the smallest indivisible particle of matter, that it was used by some satirical Greek poet in characterizing the "smallest" of men; that is, the least generous, the meanest or most narrow-minded.
PALMA, Mallorca, Aug. 17 -- Four prominent American colonists were arrested and fined today on a technical charge of not registering their passports.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 17 -- Paraguayan troops again attacked the Bolivian observation post at Huijay, according to a communique of the chief of staff late tonight. It says:

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Sands Point, with a new player in its lineup, maintained its standing in the lead for the Knox Cups by turning back Eastcott, 9 to 7, today on Cochran Field in another game among the high-goal teams preparing for the open championship.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Newark made it two straight victories over Toronto in the current series and gained its eighteenth triumph in twenty-one games between the two teams this season by winning the first half of today's scheduled doubleheader, 9 -- 1.
The American Lutheran Publicity Bureau, Inc., suite of offices in the Manufacturers Trust Building, 1,819 Broadway.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Ino. DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17 -- The Iowa farmers' holiday, a movement to withhold farm products from the market until a "fair price" is offered, remained "confined to Sioux City during its tenth day today.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- Chancellor Franz von Papen has received assurances that Adolf Hitler will not use his storm troops to seize the German Government, but in any event the Chancellor will not hesitate to suppress any revolt by force of arms.

By declaring the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share on the capital stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday, the directors carried out the expectations of the financial district. The action was viewed in Wall Street as a gesture of confidence by one of the most representative boards of directors in the United States.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- Germany's financial situation is far from improving, and the most pressing task before the von Papen Cabinet just now is that of raising additional funds, with or without the aid of the Reichstag when it assembles, to meet urgent needs.

Three California entries, two English players and one representative each from the New York district, New England and the Middle West survived the third round of the women's national singles championship on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, L.I., yesterday afternoon, and will compete today in the quarter-finals.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- World-wide interest is being aroused by the efforts of the British Government committee to end the "cut-throat" competition existing between rail and road transportation. The committee is under the chairmanship of Sir Arthur Salter and includes four railway chiefs, Sir Herbert Walker, Sir Josiah Stamp, Sir Ralph Wedgewood and Sir James Milne, and four equally well-known road transport men, C. Lem Gosselin, P.R. Turner, W.H. Gaunt and E. Graham Guest.

ALLENWOOD, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The "war" between New York and New Jersey ended this afternoon with the invading Empire State Red army withdrawing across the Shark River before a concerted driva from he south by the Blue army. Immeditely following the "defeat" of the Reds the officers and troops of the New Jersey National Guard participating in the annual manoeuvres returned to Seagirt.

Instead of celebrating the murder of John Bazzano of Pittsburgh last night at a dinner in a midtown hotel as they had intended to do, according to the police, fourteen men rounded up in the city before dawn yesterday were held in Raymond Street jail in Brooklyn, accused of the murder.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- A program for retirement of 130,000 tons of Italy's fighting ships -- practically one-third of the entire navy -- will be put into effect beginning on Aug. 25, with the purpose of saving money.

The chukar, described AS "the partridge of India," introduced into this country a few years ago, has been found' to be acclimatizing itself in Kansas, according to a dispatch from a game farm outside of Wichita.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- Accusations that William G. McAdoo was "faithless to his party" and that he had done nothing to prevent a campaign of intolerance which "crucified Alfred E. Smith" in the 1928 Presidential campaign were made by John J. Barrett at a Democratic luncheon here today for Justus S. Wardell, candidate for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

In a report of meetings of women teachers held in London this Summer, mention is made of one address which left the audience torn between horror and gratification. A wellknown woman novelist, discussing modern novels, told them, that " novelists are actually paid to make " the more degrading aspects of life " appear attractive."

LOUISVILLE. Ky., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Favorites advanced in today's play in the national public parks tennis tournament at Shawnee Park. All matches were completed except three in the men's doubles, which were stopped by heavy rain.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Twenty-seven years ago King Edward of England, a royal patron of yachting, gave a cup to the New York Yacht Club to be perpetuated in the Interest of the sport. It came to be considered the premier prize in American waters.

The steel age in industry has given way to the alloy age, according to Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in a statement issued in conjunction with the semi-annual report of the company's operations. Discussing the possibilities of the use of nickel in alloy, he said in part:

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Marco Hecht of the University of Pennsylvania, seeded first, and David Geller of Brooklyn, ranked eighth, were the first two tennis players to reach the semi-final round in the annual metropolitan clay court junior singles championship, when both registered quarter-final triumphs at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club today.

Legislation now before the Argentine Senate designed to regulate the production of petroleum in that republic, if enacted into law, virtually will force out of business eventually all American and foreign oil companies now operating in Argentina, according to oil executives here who have studied the bill.

TORONTO. Ont., Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- A picture of a nude figure, painted by John Russell, Canadian artist and prize winner at Paris salons, has provoked a difference of opinion between Mr. Russell and authorities of the Canadian National Exhibition Art Gallery, to whom the picture was submitted for display.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The controversy over publicity for Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans may be settled tomorrow when South Trimble, clerK of the House of Representatives, Issues a statement giving his position in the matter.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 18 -- Warning that they would resign if Marshal Chang Hsiao-Iiang was forced to quit as commander of the Peiping area was sent today by fifty-seven of the most important Northern Generals to General Chiang Kaishek, head of the Nanking Government.

Public school education in the city will cost $142,544,851.93 next year, according to the 1933 budget adopted yesterday by the Board of Education although $7,825,000 will be saved in comparison with the 1932 expenditures by economies effected through increases in the size of classes and temporary curtailment of many activities.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 17 -- When the 75-foot auxiliary fishing schooner Hilda Marie burned at sea early this morning Captain Edward O. Brex of Cape May, his wife, Hilda, and a crew of three unemployed men, inexperienced as fishermen, were rescued by Captain Herman Roberg and the crew of the Bobjack, a deep-sea fishing vessel from this port.

The appointment of Jouett Shouse, former chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee, as president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment wag announced yesterday by Pierre S. du Pont, chairman of the organization's executive committee.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The organization meeting of the State Budget Advisory Committee is to be held Monday afternoon at the Capitol, according to G. William Magly of Jamaica, L.I., who, with others, was named recently to the committee.

The American delegation to the International Radio Conference in Madrid sailed yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt, headed by Judge Eugene O. Sykes, acting chairman of the Federal Radio Commission. Others in the group included Dr. Charles B. Jolliffe, chief engineer of' the. commission; Walter Lichtenstein, executive secretary of the First National Bank of Chicago; Irwin Stewart, a solicitor of the State Department, and a group of technical advisers, interpreters and clerks.

Although the national average of steel ingot production has not risen above 14 per cent of capacity, prospects for business improvement are considered favorable, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. The publication notes many encouraging signs pointing toward an expansion.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- A single to centre by Fred Heimach in the eighth, inning was the opening shot of a Dodger rally that ended a pitching duel between the Brooklyn southpaw and Bill Swift, broke a 1-to-1 deadlock and gave Max Carey's men the third game of the series with the Pirates today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Bunching four hits in the seventh for three runs, Washington came from behind again today to make it two straight over the White Sox. The score was 4 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The largest favorable monthly trade balance so far this year was revealed today when the Commerce Department made available figures showing that exports exceeded imports by $28,000,000 during July, compared with a favorable balance in June of only $3,000,000.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 18 -- The Government of Manchukuo is abruptly reviving the old Russo-Manchurian boundary dispute, the Manchukuo Foreign Affairs Commissioner in Harbin handing the Soviet Consul General a demand for withdrawal of Soviet frontier troops stationed within sight of Manchouli.

After a conference with John J. Raskob, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and officials of the County Trust Company, which holds notes aggregating some $300,000, issued in return for obligations incurred by the committee during the 1928 Presidential campaign, James A. Farley, the new Democratic National Chairman, announced yesterday that the new national committee had assumed responsibility for the 1928 campaign debt.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- City Controller Szymczak, according to reports today, intends to offer for sale on Monday by competitive bidding a new issue of $8,000,000 of 5 per cent refunding bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1934 to 1941. He made no mention of the offer before he went today to Pittsburgh, where he made, a radio talk tonight.

The daily average rate of bank clearances in August to date has been substantially higher than in any previous period so far this year, according to compilations by R.G. Dun Co., which place this figure at 28.7 per cent below those of a year ago.

Somewhere out over the North Atlantic, J. A. Mollison, young Scottish airman, in his tiny Puss Moth plane, the Heart's Content, was headed last night for Harbor Grace, Nfld., the first scheduled stop on his attempted flight across the Atlantic and back.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was of almost normal midsummer proportions. The volume was 1,775,000 shares, compared with 2,874,600 shares on the day before. The price movement was narrow and Wall Street took only a scant interest in the proceedings.

In many respects, yesterday's most interesting sidelight on the financial position was the weekly Federal Reserve statement. Every one knew that a considerable addition had been made since a week ago to the system's gold, but the actual increase of $47,031,000 was impressive.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 18. -- Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., outstanding representative of the Pacific Coast, keeps in front in the international masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland.

WINDSOR, Ont., Aug. 18 -- A popular victory was scored in the fifth race, feature on the card at Kenilworth Park, when J. Whyte's speedy filly Dark Mist led home a field of eight 3-year-olds. Marvina, racing for the Pasadena Stable, was second and Huraway third.

Controller Berry, in response to questions put to him by former Mayor John F. Hylan, outlined yesterday the facts concerning the city's financial condition that Justice Hylan had sought. The picture he painted was not a rosy one, but it was accompanied by the declaration that a definite policy of retrenchment on the part of the City Administration would get it out of all its financial difficulties.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 18 (AP). -- A resolution providing for investigation of the Public Service Commission was put through the Senate today by unanimous vote and without a roll-call, but since the complete effectiveness of the inquiry depends upon Governor Pinchot's approval of a $100,000 appropriation, the proposal has a good chance of dying in his hands.

DESENZANO, Lake Garda, Italy, Aug 18. -- After remaining in the air slightly longer than twelve hours, Professor Auguste Piccard landed safely at 5:15 P.M. today in an open field near Monzambano, about four and a half miles south, of Peschiera, at the southern extremity of Lake Garda.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,352,000,000, a decrease of $24,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,237,000,000 compared with the corresponding week of 1931.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated the St. Louis Cardinals in both games of a double-header today, winning the first game, 10 to 4, and the second, 9 to 4. As a result, the Cardinals dropped to sixth place, the Braves supplanting them in fifth position by a fraction of a point.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Willis Sharpe Kilmer's homebred colt, Sun Archer, surprised many today by winning the nineteenth running of the Grab Bag Handicap, feature of a program organized in support of the George Washington bicentennial celebration.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 18 (AP). -- All was quiet on main highways into Sioux City tonight while hundreds, of farmers in three States maintained effective barricades in a strike against sales.

Edward R. Brevoort for eight years president of F. A. Potts Co., Inc., wholesale coal dealers of 143 Liberty Street, was killed shortly after 6 o'clock yesterday morning when he fell from a window of his seventeenth floor apartment at 55 Central Park West.

The American Institute of Steel Construction has started a movement to check imports of foreign building materials so that American mills may re-engage some of their workmen,' it was announced yesterday.

SCHOEN 1ST DIE MANOEVERZEIT, a film musical comedy in German, with Ida Wuest, Albert Faults, oretl Theimer, Paul Heldemann, Lillian Ellls, Susl Ralph, Olga Bassolt, Vickt Werkmelster. Margot Walter, Max Schipper, Carl Walter Meyer and Oscar Sabo; directed by Eric Schoenfelder; a Ben Fett Film production.

Twenty-five men, said to be unemployed members of the Marine "Workers' Industrial Union, were routed yesterday by city police from the Seamen's Church Institute at 25 South Street, after they had beaten two special officers, who, unsuccessful in opposing their entrance, had sought later to drive them from the building with drawn pistols.

New York City's hospitals were pictured last night by Dr. J. G. William Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, in a radio address, as carrying on efficiently and determinedly in the face of incalculable difficulties, ministering to the city's unprecedented number of sick poor in spite of the restricting of finances by the depression.

SEAGIRT, N. J., Aug. 18. -- Major Robert L. Copsey, who was relieved as commanding officer of the Forty fourth Division Aviation Group of the New Jersey National Guard at the direction of Governor A. Harry Moore on Tuesday, was reinstated by the Governor today.

Plans for the retirement of indebtedness of the American Gas and Power Company to the Birmingham Gas Company, a subsidiary, are being worked out with the conditional approval of the Alabama Public Service Commission along lines that call also for the refunding of $1,250,000 of 4 1/2 per cent notes of the Birmingham company which will mature on Oct. 1.

The formation of a new partnership of Ira Haupt Co., succeeding a firm of the same name which has been dissolved, was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. A firm of Tobey Co. is to be formed on Sept. 1, while the partnership of Tobey Dickenson is to be dissolved on the same date.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The foreign invasion of the Newport Casino invitation tournament was checked today when the remaining foreigners, F.J. Perry of England and Jiro Satoh of Japan, were eliminated. The tournament was reduced to an all-American semi-final round, but only after four of the most hotly contested matches, each going the full five sets, that have been seen here in many years.
SPRING GREEN, Wis., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Frank Lloyd Wright, internationally famous architect, is establishing an experimental school here to guide the lives of young men and women.

Two little sisters, playing in front of their home at 1,171 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, with their parents within call, were wounded last night when two men; believed to be gangsters, ended a quarrel on the opposite sidewalk by exchanging four shots.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Holders of debentures of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., brought suit today in the Federal District Court here to compel ten banks in this city and New York to surrender the securities that they hold as pledges for loans made to the company.
Rejection of "mechanized music" in the next few years was predicted yesterday by Ernest Schelling, composer, pianist and conductor, on his return from Europe in the French liner Champlain.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 18 -- The Australian cricketers reluctantly said farewell to Canada today, having completed, their official tour of the Dominion and United States, although several exhibition matches will be played in, California before they sail from San Francisco for home at the end of the month.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 18. -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan, hunter of the cosmic ray, has set a new trap for these greatest of all energy messengers that come from the clouds in space. It is a sensitive, self-recording electroscope, ten times as sensitive as any he has hitherto known.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times : Rebellions against high protective tariffs have broken out constantly in America's history, have failed and been followed by further raising of the walls. The Dingley act of President Cleveland's second term raised the high duties of, the McKinley tariff to higher levels; today we have the Smoot-Hawley tariff, which far-seeing business men have condemned as perhaps the greatest menace to our economic recovery.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 18. -- Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman finished a nine-day inspection trip of State institutions today after traveling more than 1,000 miles by boat and automobile. He stopped at Lake George tonight to catch up on correspondence and expects to reach Albany tomorrow.

A new link to replace Mail Street when the old postoffice downtown is demolished has been proposed by property owners in the vicinity. Mail Street runs from Park Row to Broadway, between City Hall Park and the postoffice. The proposed link would be slightly to the south of Mail Street and would form a more direct connection between Beekman Street and Park Place.
TORONTO, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press).-- The Toronto Leafs' losing streak was extended to eight straight games as they dropped a double-header to Newark today, 2 -- 0 and 2-1.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18. -- Six American teams and four from foreign countries were seeded in the draw for the men's fifty-first annual national doubles championship tennis tourney which begins Monday afternoon on the grass courts of the Longwood Cricket Club in Chestnut Hill.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 18 (AP). -- The text of Senator L. J. Dickinson's speech, notifying Vice President Curtis of his renomination, follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Victory in November for the Democratic Presidential ticket by a vote nearly if not quite as overwhelming as that cast for Woodrow Wilson in 1912 was predicted today by Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18. -- The formula which the United Kingdom delegation to the Imperial Economic Conference has produced for the prevention of unfair competition by Soviet Russia in the British market does not specify Russia by name. Neither does it suggest the methods by which the unfair practices may be circumvented and it does not define dumping.

The French Line plans to enter the new steamship known only as the T-6 in the international trade in 1934 and then will have accommodations for the construction of even larger ships if it is considered necessary to add to its fleet, according to Paul Conard, assistant general manager of the Chantiers de Penhoet, which built the new French liner Champlain.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- There is an old German sayin, "Who holds Prussia holds the Reich' so it is significant that the apparently hopeless deadlock in Reich politics is being met by a flank movement in the form of a renewal of negotiations between the Centrist and National Socialist counties for agreement over the control of Prussia, now governed by Reich commissioners because of the parliamentary impasse there.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18. -- The threat of deportation hung over the head of every alien gangster in the Pittsburgh district today.

The most obvious inference from the statement of our foreign trade in July is the great shrinkage in volume of both exports and imports. Compared with the same month last year, the total value of outward and inward trade combined is reduced by $169,000,000, or 45 per cent.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The wool market is experiencing the largest concentrated buying within a given period for years and prices are responding buoyantly to the increased manufacturers' demand, local wool authorities said today.

PORTMARNOCK, Irish Free State, Aug. 18 (AP). -- J. A. Mollison left his bride of three weeks today and took off on a projected round-trip flight to New York. His bride, the former Amy Johnson, watched his ship as it disappeared in the west. A few minutes later she got into a plane and sped away to catch up with him and accompany him on the first hundred miles or so of his journey.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18. -- The rebels in Sao Paulo are reduced to eating war bread, composed of wheat flour and manaicoca flour, according to the newspapers here. "Whole wheat bread is forbidden under heavy penalties.

Five members of President Hoover's Cabinet will bear the brunt of the fight in the Eastern States to re-elect him for a second term, according to announcement made yesterday at Eastern campaign headquarters of the Republican National Committee at the Wadorf-Astoria.
ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 18. -- The arguments at today's proceeding before Governor Roosevelt, taken up almost entirely by John J. Curtin's plea for dismissal of the charges against Mayor Walker, follow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is the same old America. Those flat, black farm lands of Illinois are still producing. Out in Iowa the corn crop this year is estimated to be more than 350,000,000 bushels. Thousands of head of cattle and swine are still grazing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Within two days after announcing that it must refinance bonds totaling $63,250,000 by March, 1, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad today applied to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan covering half of that operation.

In Germany the political situation has been clarified during the last few days in respect to HITLER'S relations to the von Papen Cabinet and the Hugenberg Nationalists. The latter, three dozen strong in the new Reichstag, are usually spoken of as HITLER'S allies.
OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 18. (Canadian Press). -- Following is the official summary of the report of the Imperial Economic Conference committee on methods of economic cooperation:

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 18. -- Hollywood won a signal victory at the Imperial Economic Conference here today when the dominions let it be known that they did not intend to surrender the privilege of viewing films produced in the United States.

The receivership created last June for the Fox Theatres Corporation by Circuit Court Judge Martin T. Manton, sitting as a District Court judge, was the result of collusion between the Fox corporation and the Chicago and Title Trust Company, it was charged yesterday by A.C. Blumenthal, one of the largest individual-creditors of the Fox corporation.

OSSINING, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The State Parole Board heard Owen Madden's plea for release today in Sing Sing Prison, then adjourned the matter for one month "for further consideration." Madden returned to his cell.

A World-Famed Doctor Lord DAWSON at the meeting of the British Medical Association in celebration of its hundredth anniversary said of physicians that their ministry not only lightens human burdens, but that the very pursuit of their profession makes doctors of every nationality and clime into comrades who, animated by the same ideals, think and work together -- "the gold of endeavor with the alloy "of conflict."
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Harsen Rhoades, who have been passing the Summer in Honolulu, are returning Monday to the Carlyle.

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- French gold cover as shown by the Bank of France's weekly statement issued today reached a figure unequaled since pre-war times with 76.90 in proportion to sight obligations amounting to 106,000,000,000 francs. The gold reserve there exceeds the paper circulation by nearly 5,000,000,000 francs.
Several business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

James F. Geraghty, Commissioner of Licenses, ordered Miss Hannah Cohn, head of the Efficiency Employment Agency, at 1,151 Sixth Avenue, yesterday to reimburse the fifty jobless men who last Saturday and Sunday "were swindled out of $501 and a diamond ring by Sidney Hirsch, an employe of the agency, who promised them jobs that did not exist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Loan activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will be made public, South Trimble, clerk of the House of Representatives, announced today. This course has been strongly opposed in official circles.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 18.--Miss Helen Dreiser, 32 years old, daughter of Theodore Dreiser, novelist, was injured slightly in an automobile accident at McKeel's Corners and the Sawmill River Road early this morning.

If Governor ROOSEVELT finds his patience sorely tried by the quibbling and dilatory methods of the Walker defense, the public is not only wearied but disgusted by them. What has become of the once frank and fearless Mayor? When the legislative investigation was first proposed he challenged the committee to come on and do its worst.
BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- One of the most important surprises of the Radio Exposition opening here tomorrow is a device known as "interfilm television," developed "by the Zeiss-Ikon works.

Paying a tribute to Ellsworth Vines as the coming champion of the world and denying that he has any intention of turning professional, Henri Cochet of France, recognized as the world's greatest tennis player, returned to this country on board the Champlain yesterday for the first time since 1928.

PORTMARNOCK, Irish Free State, Aug. 18. -- J. A. Mollison, young Scottish airman, took off at 11:35 o'clock this morning [6:35 A. M. New York Time] in an attempt to fly his Puss Moth monoplane Heart's Content to New York and back to England. He took off from the same stretch of beach near Dublin from which Air Commodore Charles Kingsford-Smith and his crew started westward in the Southern Cross on their trans-atlantic flight.

In view of "honest difference of opinion among investors as to whether or not stocks in fixed, trust portfolios should be sold out for failure to pay dividends," arrangements have been made whereby holders of Corporate Trust Shares may have the indenture applicable to their particular holdings modified so that the elimination will be compulsory or not, as they wish.

The speech of Vice President Curtis at Topeka, Kan., accepting the Republican nomination for re-election and containing an enunciation of a policy toward prohibition distinctly drier than those expressed in the Republican platform and President Hoover's acceptance speech, was not broadcast in New York and Chicago, chief centres of wet sentiment, although it was broadcast from 48 other stations in a coast-to-coast network.

SEATTLE, Aug. 18. -- Strong opposition to repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment was expressed today, in the report of the resolutions committee, which was adopted by the Woman's Christian Temperance Union in national convention.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- Realizations pressed upon the price level of the Boerse today, but as the profits were immediately reinvested there was another general advance. Cheap stocks again were preferred by the speculating public. Among leading stocks. Farben advanced more than 1 per cent.

The purchase of two loft buildings in the Penn zone yesterday marked the return to active trading of Norman S. Riesenfeld, operator, who made the first outright purchase of a property in that section in some time.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 18. -- Truck delivery of milk, live stock and all other farm produce from Northwest Iowa and South Dakota to Sioux City was practically nothing today, but some supplies continued to trickle into the city from Northeast Nebraska.

Three members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will be represented as composers on the programs of the orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow and Sunday evenings. Saturday will bring the first New York performance of "Carnival," by Theodore Cella, first harpist of the orchestra, and the premiere of "Simfonietta," by Zolthan Kurthy, violist.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Executives of twenty Class I railroads held a conference here today for further dissussion of another wage cut for union employes, first broached at a meeting of Eastern Railroad presidents in New York last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- President Hoover and Senator Bingham reed today to let bygones be bygones on the prohibition issue, each use his influence in presenting a lid front for the Republican ticket November.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted materially yesterday and prices held within a 10-point range for several hours. Steady buying by houses with domestic, European and Oriental mill connections absorbed contracts on recessions, imparting resistance to the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The treaty between the United States and Canada providing for the construction of the St. Lawrence waterway is "just another ill-advised governmental business venture," in the opinion of Representative Lamneck, Democrat, of Ohio.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The semi-final bracket in the annual metropolitan clay court junior singles championship was filled today as Richard Hebard of White Plains, second seeded star, and Carl M. Rohmann, University of Virginia sophomore, triumphed in quarter-final tennis encounters at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club.

In Brassey's Annual for 1932, Captain ALTHAM of the British Navy wrote that "in view of the insuperable difficulties which have so far beset a Franco-Italian naval agreement, it would appear likely that Italy will also start building capital ships again."

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18. -- Every man in the Giants' line-up, except Waite Hoyt, broke into the hit column today. This made heating the Reds, 7 to 3, a comparatively easy task and enabled the New Yorkers to sweep the three-day series. They headed for Pittsburgh tonight with a winning streak of four straight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Municipal broadcasting station WNYC, in New York City, obtained an extension today until Sept. 30 for the installation of monitoring equipment to keep it within fifty cycles of its assigned frequency.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox took a thrilling fifteen-inning game from the Browns, 7 to 6, today to gain the edge in the three-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- An unorganized reserve of Army Air Corps pilots, numbering at least 100,000 competent fliers ready for any emergency, was advocated today by Senator Hiram Bingham, president of the National Aeronautic Association, before the annual convention of the association.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. CAMP FOUR, Nanga Parbat, Kashmir, Aug. 7 (by runner to Astor, Aug. 18). -- Our men have all come down, here for two or three rest days while waiting for coolies and are trapped by a bad storm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Bank checks and gasoline led the way in July in producing the largest amounts of revenue from the special excise and miscellaneous levies in the new billion-dollar revenue act.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 18 (AP).-- The controversy partly responsible for the destructive Chino-Japanese conflict of last Winter has come up again to disturb the peace of the Far East.

China's root problem is a tremendous pressure of population upon available resources, Dr. J. B. Condliffe asserts in his book, "China Today: Economic," recently publlshed by the World Peace Foundation. The author was for several years research secretary of the Institute of Facific Relations and was called from that post to the Secretariat of the League of Nations to undertake the task of preparing the League's world economic survey.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Yorkshire, leader, and Sussex, runner-up in the county cricket championship race, retained their positions today as the result of victories over Somerset and Gloucestershire.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Alexander Keiles and Price Colvin, Baltimore, advanced to the semi-final round of the men's national public parks doubles tennis championships today by defeating Theodore Drewes and Robert Norton, St. Louis, in four sets, 6-2, 7-5, 3-6, 6-4.

Declaring that Democratic leaders were trying to "set a trap" for Republican voters in the Presidential campaign by stressing the repeal plank of their party, former Representative James H. MacLafferty of California told members of the New York Young Republican Club at a luncheon yesterday in the Lawyers' Club not to be "fooled again," as, he said, Republicans were in 1916.

OAKLAND, Cal., Aug. 18. -- Designed primarily as a freight carrier for long hauls, a large flying wing with a non-stop flying range of 7,500 miles, it will participate in the National Air Races in Cleveland late this month.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 18.--Charles Curtis, formally accepting Republican renomination for the Vice Presidency today, declared to party leaders that he was personally opposed to repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, thus taking a stand quite the contrary of President Hoover's recently altered attitude.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- An average increase in retail food prices from June 15 to July 15 was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor on the basis of returns from fifty-one cities. The prices on July 15, however, were on the average 15 per cent lower than on July 15, 1931.

Regular Lines to Gain in Fall. Possibility of a 10 to 15 per cent gain in sales of regular lines of merchandise this Fall was seen here yesterday in some retail quarters. During the Spring the sales of regular lines dropped to around 50 to 60 per cent of the merchandise sold by many stores, it was pointed out.

Represenatives of twenty-six civic associations, at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel Touraine in Brooklyn, voted to petition Governor Roosevelt to call a special session of the Legislature to pass laws restoring to the Board of Estimate full control over all salaries paid by the city.

For the week ended Aug. 13 the adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production is again higher, equaling the previous high mark of 71.2 for the week ended June 4, as compared with 68.6 for the preceding week and 94.0 f.or the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Monetary gold stocks of the Federal Reserve Banks increased $41,000,000 between Aug. 10 and Aug. 17 to $4,046,000,000, but were $937,000,000 less than a year ago, according to the Federal Reserve Board's condition statement issued today.

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 18 -- A varied program of hunter, saddle and harness classes brought out a large and enthusiastic gallery for the second day's sessions of the four-day Cohasset Horse Show today. Among the winners of feature saddle classes was Silver Dare, gray gelding owned by the Misses Peggy and Jane Patterson, Brooklyn, N.Y., and ridden by Mrs. James A. Hewlett of Jericho, L.I.

When the Hudson View Sanitarium, Inc., Harold S. Kohn, treasurer, bought from Regina Friedel the five-story building at 633 W. 152d St., it gave back a purchase money mortgage for $7,OOO, payable in six years, at 6 per cent, and subject to two mortgages aggregating $37,600.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 18. -- News of the safe arrival in Tangiers, Africa, of six students who crossed the Atlantic in a fifty-four-foot ketch reached here today in Associated Press dispatches forty-two days after their departure from this port.

Splitting of medical fees was condemned on three sides yesterday. Dr. Morris Rosenthal, director of the bureau of arbitration of compensation of the New York County Medical Society, declared that some physicians had worked up what he regarded as a "compensation racket," made possible only by a system of split fees.
To the Editor at The New York Times: Your editorial "Enjoying Bad Times" must have been of great comfort to many readers, as it has to me.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- New contentions in his fight against removal by Governor Roosevelt were raised in Supreme Court today by Mayor Walker in obtaining a snow-cause order to block the hearings in the Executive Chamber.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Intense interest has been caused here by the announcement in Rome that Ilaly will retire 130,000 tons of naval vessels this month to save money.

The Pennsylvania Railroad will Inaugurate electric train service next February between New York and Philadelphia, according to plans outlined yesterday by M. W. Clement, vice president in charge of operations. The greater part of the construction work has been, completed, Mr. Clement said, and instructions have been issued to push the task at all points between the two cities, with Feb. 1 set as the date that the project must be completed.

Whether or not he foresaw it, the first plain effect of the President's call for a change in the Eighteenth Amendment has been to divide prohibitionists. Four years ago he seemed to them, to be the Moses who would lead prohibition to the promised land.
Compared with the excellent offshore fishing enjoyed by Long Island anglers during the previous week, yesterday's round-up of reports shows fewer of the larger catches.

United States Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, former Secretary of Labor, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury for the part he is alleged to have played as director general of the Loyal Order of Moose in operating two lotteries of that order.

The protective committee for holders of bonds and notes of the Fisk Rubber Company that is headed by Ferdinand Eberstadt began yesterday an action in the United States District Court in Massachusetts, seeking an immediate distribution of 40 per cent in cash to these security holders.
PARIS, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Satisfaction with the assistance given him by the Democratic National Committee for the State campaign in Maine was expressed yesterday by John H. Dooley, State chairman, after a conference with James A. Farley, national chairman, and Robert Jackson, head of the Speakers' Bureau.

HONOLULU, Aug. 18. -- The possibilities of establishing an advanced base 500 miles west of the main Hawaiian group were demonstrated here today when six patrol planes from the fleet air base at Pearl Harbor flew non-stop from Oahu to the French Frigate Shoals in slightly more than six hours.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Aggressive buying of wheat through houses with Eastern connections came at the psychological moment today on the Board of Trade here and swept prices up 2 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel from the early low points, after local pressure and scattered liquidation by longs had carried the December off 5/8 cent from Wednesday's finish to equal the inside figure on the current down-turn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the letter by Senor Pablo M. Ynsfran, Paraguayan Charge d'Affaires in Washington, I would request your courtesy for the purpose of repeating the suggestion previously made by me. I do not think it necessary to argue at this time the merits of Bolivia's claim in the controversy.

The directors of the Railroad Credit Corporation at their monthly meeting yesterday authorized additional advances totaling slightly more than $5,800,000 to various railroads in order that they may meet their fixed charges. This organization, which is collecting about $5,000,000 monthly from the freight surcharges which took effect on Jan. 4, so far has authorized loans and commitments of approximately $30,000,000 to thirty-five roads in the United States.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 18. -- Striking miners marched on the Taylorville coal region in overwhelming numbers late today as civic leaders, law-enforcement officers and staff officers of the National Guard awaited events before determining whether to call out troops.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to your newspaper publisted on Aug. 15, Pablo M. Ynsfran, Paraguayan Charge d Affaires, undertook to inform the American public upon certain juridical points in connection with the Chaco dispute. Such a procedure invariably leads to misunderstanding of the problem by the public.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- A 5,000 meter race between Lauri Lehtinen of Finland and Ralph Hill, American star from Oregon, expected to settle the dispute over their famous finish in the recent Olympic Games, tonight resulted in victory for neither, as Janusz Kusocinski of Poland romped off with the decision.

A plan for bringing the large excess funds of the New York banks to the aid of commodity borrowers in other sections of the country where, as an aftermath of the banking troubles earlier in the year, credit is scarce or impossible to obtain, was announced last night by Mortimer N. Buckner, president of the Clearing House Association.

A parade and brief addresses by members of the staff of Borough President Henry Hesterberg marked the reopening yesterday of that part of the Coney Island Boardwalk between West Twenty-first and West Twenty-fourth. Streets which was destroyed by fire on July 13.

Proper administration, of the Federal Home Loan Bank act will prevent thousands of "unnecessary and unjustified" pending foreclosures of mortgages on homes and will stop "nefarious, illegal financial transactions exacting usurious and excesoive rates of interest," Representative F.H. La Guardia of New York said last night in a speech broadcast from station WOR.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18. -- The annual recital by Bernardo Olshansky, Russian baritone, took place this afternoon at Gissa-Bu, the home of Mr. and Mrs. La Motte T. Cohu, in the Shinnecock Hills.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Lord Kylsant, former Royal Mail chairman, was released from Wormwood Scrubbs Prison just after 7 o'clock this morning. His year's sentence dated from the dismissal of his appeal on Nov. 4, but his good conduct -- he was assistant librarian in the prison -- earned the usual remission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation late today lent $6,000,000 to Illinois and $768,000 to Ohio for unemployment relief work, but made a clear inference that no more loans would be forthcoming unless these States took additional steps to help themselves.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- If reductions in the State budget are to be made in the Department of Public Works, Mark Graves, Budget Director, declared in an address over station WGY tonight that fewer new roads must be built, the Barge Canal appropriation must be pruned and construction of public buildings sharply curtailed.

Wholesale market cash prices closed strong. Grains moved higher, while spot cotton, closed at a new high for the year, up 15 points. Metals as a group were firm with the exception of tin, which eased off. Other staples were unchanged.

Copyright, 1932. by The Associated Press. BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Aug. 18. -- Adolf Hitler, leader of Germany's 13,700,000 National Socialists, declared today that he had no intention of marching on Berlin.

In the only match completed before the rain set in, Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Cal., defeated Mrs. John Van Ryn, the former Miss Marjorie Gladman of East Orange, N.J., yesterday to grain the semi-final round of the women's national championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

During the last year the Spelman Fund of New York made appropriations of $1,908,000, according to its annual report issued yesterday. The income of the fund was $373,486.89, and the excess of appropriations over income has been charged against the principal, which at the end of the year was $6,188,424.39.

BELOIT, Wis., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Seven bank robbers, who used six frightened girls as shields against the gunfire of policemen, held up the Second National Bank of Beloit today hands of a bandit, he was relieved of his rifle and forced to lie on the floor with the others.

Geraldine Farrar, American opera star, will arrive today on the French liner France. On the ship also are Jean Assolant, French flier; Justice Edward P. Pierce of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts and Professor Charles Carron of Rochester University. Others on board are:
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's French Duchess, 3-year-old daughter of Epinard, won the Old Elm Purse, best event of Hawthorne's program today.

MADRID, Friday, Aug. 19. -- With a passenger list containing the names of many Dukes, Marquises, Counts and Generals, the cargoboat Spain No. 5 will leave Cadiz in a few days bound to Bata, in the fever swamps of Africa. The noble passengers, however, will rate as ordinary persons deported to Africa without trial for complicity in the Royalist rebellion last week.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18. -- The Soviet airplane industry has made remarkably progress in the last three years.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 18 (AP). -- The text of the speech of Vice President Curtis, accepting renomination, follows:

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The quiet precincts of Williams College, where the Institute of Politics is being held, reverberated today to a sharp conflict of opinion on the events that led up to the Chino-Japanese clash in Manchuria last September. Chinese and Japanese speakers transferred the dispute from the sanguinary plains of Manchuria to cloistered academic halls.

James Allan Mollison, born in Scotland twenty-six years ago, already has two notable long-distance flying records to his credit. On Aug. 6, 1931, he completed a flight from Australia to England in 8 days 21 hours 25 minutes when he landed on the shingle beach at Pevensey Bay, only ten miles from Hastings and near the place where William the Conqueror landed in 1066.

Taxicab drivers employed in New York siphoned more than 1,000,000 gallons of gasoline from the tanks of cabs last year and either sold the fuel or used it in their own private cars to cut down personal running expenses, according to a statement made last night by Adolph Mohr, a supervisor for the Yellow Taxi Corporation.
ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- Mayor James J. Walker threw the fight for his political life into the courts today.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The stock markets were quieter today, about the only bright feature being recovery in British Government funds. The assented war loan improved, and several others regained early losses.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

In a Chinese Garden. The children were gathered in the garden and Chang Po, the Schoolmaster of the Bamboo Grove, read to them the verse about The Pear Tree from The Book of Odes, very old. Su Tung, the Philosopher, sat under the cedar by the little brook, thinking.

Largely as a result of sharp declines in the value of their inventories of manufactured goods and consequent unsually large markdowns, Sears, Roebuck Co. reported yesterday for the twenty-eight weeks ended on July 16 a net loss of $2,893,734 after taxes, depreciation and other charges.

A committee representing some of the stockholders of the Rio Grande Oil Company has been formed to oppose the acquisition of that company by the Consolidated Oil Corporation, according to reports from Los Angeles. A letter to stockholders has been mailed asking that they forward proxies to the committee opposing the acquisition on the present terms.

The Tammany executive committee at a meeting in Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon designated Assemblyman Joseph. T. Higgins of the Fourteenth Assembly District as candidate for the Democratic nomination for Sheriff and thereby served notice on Governor Roosevelt that it stood by former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, whom the Governor removed from office and who is leader of the district represented by Mr. Higgins.

A forward movement of prices was shown yesterday by all groups of bonds listed on the Stock Exchange, domestic railroad and industrial securities making the major gains. Public utility issues and foreign loans showed fair progress on the average, and United States Government bonds moved upward in unison, gaining 1-32 to 8-32 point for the day.

Bringing specific charges of election frauds and intimidation of voters by thugs stationed in polling places, Socialist party leaders appeared yesterday before the joint legislative committee on revision of the election laws in the Municipal Building and recommended sweeping changes in the voting procedure to assure honest elections.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 18. -- The war fever, which had subsided somewhat last week, has been aroused again by reports of new clashes with Paraguayan troops in the disputed Chaco region.

HARRISON, N.Y. Aug. 18 -- Two former metropolitan amateur champions, Maurice J. McCarthy Jr. and Leonard Martin, engaged in a duel for the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Green Meadow invitation tournament today, but picked a poor day for it.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18. -- It is the unanimous and officially recorded opinion of the British Imperial Economic Conference that the United States has been and still is guilty of "dumping of services" because of the way it conducts its merchant marine on the Pacific Ocean.

An effort to reoganize the Michigan Fuel and Light Company, the Northern Indiana Fuel and Light Company and the Wisconsin Fuel and Light Company, all subsidiaries of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation, now in receivership, is being made by the receivers and others engaged in working out the affairs of American Commonwealths.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- Two large dinner dances were given here tonight.

CAVALLARO DI MONZANBANO, Italy, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Auguste Piccard and Max Cosyns came down to earth this afternoon after having gazed on the world from the greatest altitude ever attained by man -- more than ten miles.
BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The Federation of German Industries came out today as opposing new public enterprises on a large scale -- that is, against the government's plans for unemployment relief.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Federal forces operating in the Mantequeira region have repulsed the strongest rebel offensive since the rebellion in Sao Paulo began six weeks ago, the Ministry of War announced tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) . -- Americans and other foreigners beleaguered in Sao Paulo, Brazil, because of the rebellion against the Getulio Vargas Government may depart on Aug. 27 if they so desire.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Benny Leonard, former world's lightweight champion, scored an easy victory tonight over Mike Sarko in their six-round feature bout at the Long Beach Stadium. Leonard showed much of his old-time skill, blocking his opponent's best-meant punches, and retaliating with a wicked right to the chin.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Seeking the electoral votes of the key State of Ohio, Governor Roosevelt left here on the Lake Shore Limited at 10:45 o'clock tonight for Columbus where a gathering of Democrats will hear tomorrow his first major speech in his campaign for the Presidency.

The Tri-Utilities Corporation, which had book assets of nearly $400,000,000 when it went into receivership a year ago, will have its remaining assets sold at auction in Wilmington, Del., on Aug. 30 for a minimum price of $11,000. Other assets have been acquired by banking and other creditors with which they were pledged to secure loans.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Geraldyn L. Redmond gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Among her guests were Mr. and Mrs. James B. Tailer, Mrs. W. Tilden P. Hazard and Everett Fabyan.

REVAL, Estonia, Aug. 19 -- The result of the Estonian plebiscite on constitutional reform, including the establishment, of the office of President and the reduction of the number of seats in the Parliament from one hundred to eighty, giving a majority of 10,000 votes against the amendments, has caused tremendous surprise all over Estonia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Immediate establishment of eight regional agricultural credit corporations was forecast late this evening when the Reconstruction Finance Corporation designated these districts with principal offices in Columbus, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Sioux City, Wichita, Fort Worth, Salt Lake City and Spokane.

The estimated school budget for 1933, to be presented by the Board of Education to the Board of Estimate, is a little less than 2 per cent below the total of 1932. It is stated that the measures taken "will not "materially affect the efficiency of "the schools," though it is insisted in the next sentence that when conditions return to normal "progressive advancement" will be renewed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- W. Kingsland Macy, State Republican chairman, in Syracuse for a conference with Republican leaders of the Syracuse area, issued the following statement tonight on the subpoena obtained by Mayor Walker calling upon him to appear as a defense witness:

High praise for navigational skill and precise calculation of fuel capacity was accorded James A. Mollison yesterday for his flight from Ireland to New Brunswick by Dr. James H. Kimball of the United States Weather Bureau, friend and patron of ocean fliers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Aug. 13 there was a letter of protest against the desecration of General Grant's memory by importuning veterans selling tawdry souvenirs at his tomb. But why not go further and raze the tomb? It is one of the ugliest buildings in the world, on one of the finest sites any city of the world has to offer.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- The German Cabinet sat all the afternoon and until late evening debating how to find money to meet the pressing needs of the Reich, including the financing of the all-important program for mitigating unemployment this Winter.

The all-Beethoven program at the Lewisohn Stadium last night attracted an audience of close to 10,000 persons. Albert Coates directed the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Third and First Symphonies and the "Egmont" overture. The audience responded with great warmth to the interpretations of these works.
