LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Dooley Mitchell, Washington favorite to win the men's national public parks singles crown advanced to the semi-finals today by defeating Robert Norton, St. Louis, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Warning that exceptional scoring may be expected next week when the grand American trap shooting tournament proper gets under way was issued today in the second round of preliminary events.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The stock markets generally were firm today, with bear covering in some quarters. Yesterday's advance in Wall Street improved sentiment here. British Government funds started better, but reacted in the afternoon.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal captured both ends of a double-header from Jersey City today, 1 -- 0 and 3 -- 0. Claset pitched a three-hit game in the opener in a great duel with Mattingly, who allowed five hits. It was Claset's seventeenth victory of the season.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The engagement of Marjorie March, young English stage actress, and Walter Bibo, writer and magazine publisher, was announced here yesterday by Miss March.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Two new champions of the air, Mrs. Frances Harrell Marsalis of St. Louis and Mrs. Louise McPhetridge Thaden of Baltimore, steered their Curtiss Thrush plane into their sixth night in the air tonight after surpassing the women's endurance refueling record of 123 hours, established over Los Angeles by Miss Bobby Trout and Miss Edna May Cooper on Jan. 9, 1931.

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- A new beta ray so powerful that a flash of it lasting only one ten-thousandth of a second caused the death of a mouse will be toned down at the University of Berlin for experiment on cancer.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 -- Aid from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bringing the ready cash of the Union Trust Company of this city up to $20,000,000, sufficient to meet any demands of the depositors, this afternoon halted a run on the bank and its eighteen branches which began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Aided by half a dozen Chicago errors, Washington took a double-header today from the White Sox, sweeping a four-game series. The scores were 4 to 3 and 3 to 1. Bill McAfee, pitching his first league game since he joined the Senators last week, held the Sox to five hits in the nightcap to win with ease, after Fred Marberry had kept them in cheek in the first.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 19.--The Imperial Economic Conference ended its real work tonight with the settlement of the last of the arguments that could be settled. Tomorrow there will be formal ceremony at which such agreements as have been reached will be signed with a public flourish of good-will as the finale to a month of bitterness that has been too intense to be concealed.

One of the two players who constituted the bulwark of the defense against the designs of England's two representatives on the women's national championship trophy was eliminated from the tournament at Forest Hills yesterday and in her place stands a 20-year-old Los Angeles girl, whose name has no place in the national ranking.

While the commodity and financial markets gave no emphatic response yesterday to the overnight announcement of the formation of a corporation which will supplement the present banking facilities in the financing of raw material purchases, there were further indications that the increased stability recently shown represents more than a passing phase in the current financial readjustment.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Governor Roosevelt indicated today that it would take more than Mayor Walker's own denials of wrongdoing to clear him of the "inference and innuendo" in Samuel Seabury's fifteen "conclusions" that he is unfit to remain in office.

The Treasury's first report on the operation of the new revenue law reveals a striking discrepancy between estimate and result. The figures cover the last ten days of June, the law having taken effect on the 21st of that month. During this period the manufacturers' excise taxes and those on telephone messages, bank checks, safety-deposit boxes and oil pipe-lines brought in a total of $2,732,000.

ROTHESAY, Scotland, Aug. 19. -- The American challenger Jill today took a commanding lead in the series of races for the Seawanhaka Cup, defeating the Scottish defender Maida for the second successive day. The winner will be decided on a three-out-of-five basis.
THE Cubs are still leading In the National League merry-go-round and, in a tight race, it's pitching that counts. The Cubs have it in quality and quantity.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Competition for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup started on Long Island Sound today under the direction of the Larchmont Yacht Club. W.H. Wheeler Jr.'s Cotton Blossom came in first, defeating T.S. Clark's Astrild, the second of a fleet of five boats, by 2 minutes and 27 seconds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Efforts to unravel the corporate snarls left by Samuel Insull when he surrendered control of his vast utility enterprises will be influenced greatly, according to La Salle Street financiers, by the decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals in the dispute over collateral between the receivers and creditor banks in New York.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Boston finally broke its losing streak at Wrigley Field today by slashing out fourteen hits for a 6-to-5 victory-over the Cubs.

To the intermittent controversy about the identity of the world's greatest men, John Buchan, British writer, adds a little fuel by his suggestion that "the greatest recorded effort of the human genius" is no that of any modern man, but of Julius Caesar.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19. -- Unleashing a brilliant sprint in the final 200 yards, Jack Lovelock, 19-year-old curly-haired New Zealand school boy, stepped the fastest mile ever run over the dirt track of the Montreal Amateur Athletic Association tonight as returning Olympic competitors of Great Britain, New Zealand and South Africa matched strides with Montreal track stars in a twilight meet.

In its application to the Interstate Commerce Commission on Thursday for a loan of $31,625,000 from, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad indicated that the funds would be used to induce holders of its issue of $63,250,000 of 4% per cent convertible bonds, due March 1 next, to assent to a plan for meeting the maturity.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Marco Hecht, University of Pennsylvania sophomore, and Richard Hebard, Hill School senior, seeded first and second, respectively, advanced to the final round of the annual metropolitan junior clay court singles championship when each accounted for straight-set semi-final tennis triumphs at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club today.

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 19. -- Hugh Bancroft Jr., son of the Cohasset Horse Show president, featured the third day's sessions of the Cohasset exhibition on the Bancroft estate when he retired the Challenge Cup for hunt teams, presented by his sister, Mrs. William C. Cox. Possessing two legs on the trophy, won in 1930 and 1931, Bancroft left no doubt as to the superiority of his hunters today, when they placed one-two.

About $3,000,000 of convertible 7 1/2 per cent gold notes of the Pennsylvania Electric Company, due in 1935, will be offered to the public early next week by a banking group headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation. This is part of a $5,330,000 note issue which was bought by bankers to provide in part for the payment at maturity of the company's 3 1/2 per cent gold notes due on Aug. 1.

NANKING, China, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Paul Noulens and his wife, a Swiss couple, were sentenced to death today on a charge of conducting Communistic activities in China. The sentence was immediately commuted to life imprisonment.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 19 -- Canada definitely lost her battle today at the Imperial Economic Conference for an increase in the empire content of commodities produced in the empire as a qualification for imperial preference. Canada's fight was directed toward the end of compelling the more than 1,000 United States branch plants in this Dominion to use a greater measure of Canadian material and labor.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Rochester defeated the Albany Senators in the last game of the season between the two clubs, 7 to 4, today. Puccinelli and Myers led the attack of the Red Wings. Each had three blows. Barton had three for Albany.

The Army transport Republic is scheduled to dock this afternoon at the Government pier at Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, with army officers returning from China, the Philippines, Hawaii and Panama. During her present trip the ship has had three navigating officers and is carrying one of them as a passenger.

Until Professor PICCARD publishes his scientific records we can do little more than admire the courage, good judgment and skill that made it possible for him to achieve a new altitude record of 54,120 feet with apparently no more discomfort than was to be expected at a temperature that reached 5 degrees below zero, Fahrenheit, within the car.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 19. -- The "liquidation" of all but twenty churches, chapels and houses of prayer in Soviet Russia was said by the newspaper Osservatore Romano today to have been ordered in a secret decree issued by the Soviet Government.

At Williamstown, in the course of a sharp exchange between Chinese and Japanese spokesmen, Dr. NITOBE pointed out the existence of a Manchurian paradox. As a matter of fact, it will be found in other places than Manchuria. If the people of Manchuria were being victimized by Chinese bandits and reduced to famine by Chinese misgovernment, argued Dr. NITOBE, the outside world would make no protest, because these are "internal matters."

The nation, said LINCOLN, could not endure half-slave and half-free. But the Republican national ticket of 1932 expects not only to endure but to triumph half-Wet and half-Dry. The party platform pledged as candidates only to submit to the voters the Eighteenth Amendment, leaving to them to choose the stand which they, as individual voters in the various States, would take.

An adequate supply of fish and waterfowl will be among the problems which experts from both this country and Canada will discuss during the convention which will bring together representatives from the Dominion and the United States next month.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 19 (AP). -- A milk war between producers and distributers of this territory, which had flared alongside a farmers' strike for higher prices for all produce, terminated tonight.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 19 -- Governor Pinchot renewed his application today to the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a grant of unemployment relief funds for Pennsylvania.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Secretary Ogden L. Mills made two addresses here today, outlining in one activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to combat the business depression. In the other he declared that President Hoover's policies, as contrasted to proposals made by the Democrats, present a "picture today of order against confusion."

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper. * * * Sheet, Towel and Spread Prices Up. Shortening of discounts in additional lines of leading branded sheets and pillow cases, a general advance in towel prices and further rises in bedspread quotations were features of the primary dry goods market yeserday.

CHICAGO. Aug. 19. -- The aggressive buying of wheat that marked late trading yesterday on the Board of Trade here was absent today, and scattered commission house and local Belling lowered prices almost as much as they had advanced on the previous day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Still clinging to life with a tenacity that amazed not only the doctors but all those around her, Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick lay breathing gently but steadily tonight in her apartment in the Drake Hotel at the point of death.

Jean Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris and Superior General of the Sulpician Order throughout the world, accompanied by the Rev. Joseph Gregroire Bastien, will sail for home today on the French liner Champlain. He has visited the houses of his order in the United States and Canada.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 19. -- The Peabody Coal Company began its retaliation tonight upon leaders of the 10,000 striking miners who invaded this region and by peaceful picketing succeeded in stopping work at the four mines operated by that company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The United States Supreme Court has ordered New York City to cease dumping its garbage at sea. To comply with this mandate requires incineration. It is estimated that five incinerators will he needed. Bids for construction of such plants recently opened by the Board of Estimate approximated $700,000 each.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Suit for $100,000 damages against Representative William L. Tierney, Democrat, of the Fourth Connecticut District, was filed in Superior Court today by Dr. James S. McCarthy of New Haven, who charges that Mr. Tierney failed to return attorney's fees in connection with settling the $5,000,000 estate of his wife, Mrs. Margaret H. McCarthy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Monks Star, racing with Annie Ormont as the Wood F. Axton entry, had no trouble in winning the best race of today's Hawthorne card, the Minnetonka Purse, a five and one-half furlong test for 2-year-old fillies.

Mrs. Walter E. Webel, mother of Walter E. Webel Jr., 22-year-old youth who was shot and killed on Aug. 2 by Deputy Sheriff Vincent Glynn, nephew of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, while the latter was trying to serve on him a court order in an alimony case, caused a disturbance in the Flatbush Court yesterday when she attempted to strike the prisoner.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 19. -- Sir Josiah Stamp, one of the directors of the Bank of England, who arrived here aboard the Orontes on a holiday cruise, has teen watching the rise in prices of American hogs and told your correspondent today he regarded that as one of the indications that the United States had "turned the corner."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A drastic slash in Federal expenditures and a way to raise additional taxes, in the face of an indicated Treasury deficit of about $2,000,000,000, would constitute a problem for the next session of Congress, Senator King, a Democratic member of the Finance Committee, said today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended tonight the first in a series of performances by artists of the Metropolitan Opera Company at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.
Copyright, 1932, by The North American Newspaper Alliance and London Dally Express. All rights reserved. SAINT JOHN, N.B., Aug. 19. -- I'm satisfied; but I'm disappointed, too.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press) . -- Middlesex defeated Glamorgan by ten wickets in a county cricket fixture concluded today. Leicestershire and Surrey won one-wicket victories over Nottinghamshire and Northamptonshire, while Derbyshire conquered the All-India visitors by nine runs in a friendly game at Ilkeston.

The Electric Bond and Share Company, which for four years has resisted the Federal Trade Commission's efforts to examine its financial affairs under authority of a Senate resolution directing an investigation of public utilities, was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox to comply with a subpoena duces tecum issued by the commission.

The work of organizing the Commodities Finance Corporation which is to finance the purchase, carrying and marketing of commodities for borrowers who are unable to obtain credit accommodation through the usual banking channels was pushed forward yesterday with the appointment of a board of nineteen directors composed of an executive of each of the banks subscribing to the corporation's $50,000,000 note issue.

James Allan Mollison, Scottish distance flyer, joined the smallest and most select company in aviation yesterday, those who have conquered the broad Atlantic wastes alone. Only two other aviators have flown the North Atlantic solo: Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Miss Amelia Earhart.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19. -- The two-fisted strategic move of having the whole line-up go to bat in one inning, which Manager Terry employed so successfully in Cincinnati, was thrown into play as soon as the Giants began their operations against the Pirates today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- H. Ellsworth Vines Jr. of Pasadena, Cal., national champion, and Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, will meet at 10:30 o'clock tomorrow morning in the singles final of the Newport Casino invitation tennis tournament.

The new United States liner Washington, sister ship of the Manhattan, will be launched at 5:41 P.M. today at the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden, N.J., in the presence of officials of the lines, the shipbuilders and the "United States Shipping Board. Mrs. T.V. O'Connor. wife of the chairman of the Shipping Board, will be the sponsor.

After rehearsing for a week, Ted Healy has withdrawn from the cast of "The Passing Show," now in preparation, because of a dispute over the terms of a contract between him and J.J. Shubert, who is producing the revue for the Producing Associates, Inc.

In the event of Mayor walker's removal after next Tuesday, the last day for filing petition for nominees for the Fall elections, members of the five county committees, about 25,000 in number, would have to be called together to nominate a successor, and the New York County members, by virtue of their large majority, would dominate the procedure, according to Jacob A. Livingston, member of the Board of Elections.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Senator Reed Smoot and Utah's two Representatives in Congress, the veteran Don. B Colton and Federick C. Loofbourow, who is serving his first term, come up for renomination at State and Congressional Conventions of the Republican party here tomorrow.

Three American girls, two from Wellesley College and the other from Bryn Mawr, returned yesterday on the Deutschland of the Hamburg-American Line after completing their junior year at the University of Munich.

Bequests of approximately $50,000 to institutions in this city were included in the will of Heinrich E.F. Sandhagen, merchant, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court. The remainder of the estate, totaling more than $500,000, was left to immediate relatives and friends both in this country and abroad.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 19 -- A proposal, backed by New Jersey members of the Delaware River Joint Commission, that a $39,000,000 loan be sought from the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation was blocked at the monthly meeting of the commission here today.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday under commission house and hedge selling and closed with losses of 9 to 14 points on the day.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. MOSCOW, Aug. 19. -- Mary Degive and I were bound we would see Russia by automobile and without any escort. Well, we did what we set out to do. We didn't see all of Russia, but we saw plenty.

With offerings of $40,153,000 of new bond issues this week, activity in this field was the greatest since the week ended on July 15, when new flotations amounted to $81,977,750. The market this week was featured by an issue of $2,000,000 Province of British Columbia two-year 5s, representing the first public offering of a foreign issue since last September, when financing was done for the Canadian National Railways.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Of the 1,757 law students who took the June examination for admission, to the bar only 759 were successful, the State Board of Law Examiners, consisting if John Kirkland Clark of Manhatan, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, announced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Temporarily victorious in its long court struggle with the Electric Bond and Share Company, the Federal Trade Commission was wondering today whether the decision that the company must produce records desired was the end of the litigation or merely the beginning of new court proceedings.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Buffalo and Baltimore broke even in a double encounter today. Four homers provided all the Baltimore tallies as they took the opener, 4 to 2, then the Bisons took the second by 13 to 3. Buzz Arlett made his fiftieth circuit blow of the year in the first game:

Cardinal Hayes will be the celebrant of a pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Sunday, Sept. 4, at 9 o'clock, which it is expected will be attended, by more than 2,000 Negro Catholics. The service will be the chief feature of the annual convention of the Federated Colored Catholics of the United States, to be held in this city Sept. 3, 4 and 5.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The American Derby winner of 1930, J.A. Best's Reveille Boy, captured the thirtieth running of the leatured Champlain Handicap today after overcoming many difficulties. He was unruly at the post and the break found him unprepared.

In glaring contrast to the dark and empty theatres of Broadway today stand the prosperous theatres of Russia, filled nightly with eager and interested audiences, said Elmer Rice, playwright and producer, upon his return to this country last night aboard the North German Lloyd liner Columbus from a four-months' trip abroad, two months of which was spent in Russia.

DESENZANO, Italy, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Professor Auguste Piccard, the only man who has looked twice upon the world from ten miles above it, plans to ascend to the stratosphere again next Summer from the north-west shore of Canada's Hudson Bay.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- With trading scarcely any more active than yesterday the, stock market showed improvement, today. Some shares made advances, but the remainder of the list closed without any significant change. Wall Street's recovery yesterday made a good impression, here and contributed to the firmness.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The War Department released the following orders today:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Praise and criticism today greeted Vice President Curtis's declaration against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and for rigid enforcement of prohibition.

United States Senator James J. Davis, former Secretary of Labor, who was indicted last Thursday by a Federal grand jury for operating a fraternal lottery, sent word yesterday through counsel to Louis Mead Treadwell, Assistant United States Attorney, that he would enter a plea of not guilty on Aug. 30.

Dr. WILLIAM H. WALKER, on the stand before the Hofstadter committee, repeatedly denied that he had ever split fees with any of his colleagues on city workmen's compensation cases. The evidence indicated that he had done so again and again.

The $1,500,000 new capital necessary to reopen the Federation Bank and Trust Company has been obtained, it was said yesterday at the offices of the institution, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There appeared in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 18 what is apparently a statement of an attempt of two State troopers to serve upon me a subpoena issued by Governor Roosevelt. The account is not a correct recital of what actually occurred.

The membership of the fur division of the Needle Trades Workers' Industrial Union, a "left wing" organization, at a meeting last night at Cooper Union, attended by 3,000, voted to ratify the agreement signed late Thursday night with representatives of the New York Fur Trimming Manufacturers' Association, Inc., bringing to an end the strike in the fur trade in which 4,000 workers have participated since July 27.

SKYLAND, Va., Aug. 19. -- President Hoover, accompanied by a small group of official associates, arrived at his Rapidan camp near here just before sundown this evening to spend a few days in relaxation and quiet work on government problems.

The Yankees' winning streak of ten in a row came to grief at the Stadium yesterday before a gathering of 17,000. Whereupon the McCarthymen, always eager to please their constituents, immediately set about the task of starting a new one.
Mayor Walker came home last night, after a grueling week in Albany, on Paul Block's private car Friendship. The band that met him at the station played "Happy Days Are Here Again."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- An agreement amounting to an international cartel, arranged between producers of synthetic nitrogen in ten European countries and the natural nitrate industry of Chile, is expected to be signed on Sept. 15, according to cabled advices reaching the Commerce Department today.

MADRID, Aug. 19 -- Terror shook the aristocracy of Spain today after the government's declaration of war upon it in the form of property confiscation and exile, which are considered in some quarters as steps toward proletarlanlsm.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- In the longest sale of the season at the Fasig-Tipton paddock, the yearlings of Phil T. Chinn and T.C. McDowell were sold tonight. Fifty-four head passed through the ring for a total of $76,525, an average of $1,417 per head.

Very different from the run of transatlantic planes, with their high-horsepower engines, often supercharged, and their great lift, is The Heart's Content, which brought James A. Mollison from Ireland to New Brunswick on the first solo crossing of the North Atlantic in a westerly direction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--Declaring that "when a billion dollars is being spent annually for the relief of World War veterans and we can't get suitable appropriations for national defense, something is wrong," Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, chief of naval aeronautics, urged the National Aeronautic Association today to do everything in its power to help promote an adequate defense system.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19.--A party was given tonight for Miss Adelaide Whitehouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse, by Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Norman at their Black Point farm in Portsmouth. There were about eighty guests present, most of them young people.

Bonds advanced sharply in price yesterday on the Stock Exchange, with domestic corporation issues again leading. Most of the active railroad issues jumped 1 to more than 12 1/2 points, with public utility and industrial bonds closing substantially higher.

Assistant Mayor Charles F. Kerrigan in a statement yesterday accused Controller Charles W. Berry of "skulking somewhere in the rear and sniping away at his own colleagues" instead of aiding the city economy program. The statement was a virtual declaration of war between the Mayor and the Controller and brings into the open a situation that has long been smoldering.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Saturday, Aug. 20 -- The Ohio Democratic State Convention will be asked today to adopt a platform endorsing, the national platform in its entirety.
Housing property deals in Manhattan and the Bronx again provided the bulk of realty trading in those two boroughs yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise is returning to New York tomorrow on the Leviathan, after a week in Europe spent at Geneva in connection with the World Jewish Conference, well satisfied with the preparatory work.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Communism has made no real progress in Latin-America and while the labor movement is radical, it is a reform movement, according to the opinion expressed at the Institute of Politics today by speakers who surveyed economic, political and social conditions in the Southern Hemisphere.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 19. -- While Dr. Alexander Alekhine, world's champion, made short work of A.J. Fink of San Francisco in the fourth round of the international tournament at the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland today. Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., leader in the competition, again acquitted himself with credit by drawing against Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club.

Through the efforts of his parish priest, a detective and an assistant medical examiner, James Gillespie of 533 East Eighty-fourth Street, an unployed building laborer in needy circumstances, was able yesterday not only to identify and claim the body of his 9-year-old son, James Jr., at the morgue but also to arrange for a private funeral today.
MIDLAND, Mich., Aug. 19. -- A crash between two automobiles here early this morning resulted in the deaths of a mother, father, their four young children and the father's brother-in-law.
ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- The final arguments today of John J. Curtin for the dismissal of the Walker charges by Governor Roosevelt follow:
A variety of Improved and unimproved holdings, ranging from dwellings to a possible cemetery site, comprised the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

One sure conclusion emerges from the procedure of Mayor WALKER'S lawyers at Albany. They may be justified in resorting to every technicality and exploring every possibility in his behalf, but in the very act they tacitly admit that he has lost his case before the Governor.
BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- The ninth annual Radio Exposition opened today at the Kaiserdamm Fair Grounds with the speeches, music and crowds customary on such, occasions the world over.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Athletics defeated Cleveland in both games of a double-header today, 9 to 7 and 3 to 2, to share three victories out of the four-same series with the rival Indians and strengthen their hold on second place.

DESENZANO, Lake Garda, Italy, Aug. 19. -- We have again penetrated the stratosphere successfully, this time rising to 16,500 meters, or 54,120 feet, slightly more than ten and one-third miles. On our previous ascent we reached an altitude of 51,793.2 feet.

A group of prominent French astronomers who are journeying to Louiseville, Que., to view the forthcoming eclipse of the sun from a specially fitted-out observatory, were among the passengers arriving yesterday aboard the French liner France, which returned after a thirty-five day "Viking cruise" in Arctic waters north of Europe.

New State and municipal bond Issues planned for award next week through, competitive bidding amount to $14,740,802, the largest total since the first week in July, mainly because of the decision of the city of Chicago to offer $8,000,000 of 5 per cent refunding bonds on Monday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19. -- Van Lingle Mungo, upon whose pitching performances down the pennant stretch rests much of Max Carey's hopes for a flag in his first season as manager, again made good in a big way today. He shut out the Reds, 6 to 0, putting the Dodgers into second place, half a game ahead of the Pirates and two games behind the league-leading Cubs.
In a sensational break of 1 1/3 cents, the Japanese yen yesterday fell to a new low of 22.75 cents, at which level it was 55 per cent below parity.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Three of the four former winners of the Green Meadow Golf Club's invitation tourney reached the semi-final round of the 1932 event today, two of them after some difficulty.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Clara Zetkin, 75-year-old Communist member of the Reichstag, who as senior member of that body is slated to act as its speaker pro tem. when it convenes Aug. 30, was reported today to be seriously ill in Moscow. She was said to be suffering from a recurrent attack of malaria.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 -- Baron Uchida's speech on foreign policy when the Diet opens is expected to introduce the subject of a Monroe Doctrine for Asia, it is reported. Whether he really intends to inject this new and difficult issue into the present troubled situation must remain problematical until he speaks, but a socalled Japanese Monroe Doctrine for the Far East has been frequently mentioned recently.

Roosevelt Field was all set to welcome J.A. Mollison, Scottish aviator, yesterday afternoon and then, when word finally came that he had set his little plane down in New Brunswick and would rest overnight, officials and spectators reluctantly dispersed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I comment upon THE TIMES editorial "Spain's Good Fortune"? The writer speaks of the "success" of the Spanish Republic in dealing with the "churches and religious orders."

Closing prices for yesterday's wholesale cash markets were irregularly lower. Grains, spot cotton, raw sugar, rubber and silk declined, while in the metal group advances were noted in tin. Other staples maintained their stand.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -- The anti-Communist movement here has developed into an antl-Semitic campaign, which was described in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon as alarming and threatening to public order.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Seven events were decided on the getaway day's program, .of the Goshen Grand Circuit meeting today. Hbllyway owned by J.B. Reynolds of Kansas City, Mo., won the Tanglewood Stake, the feature event on the card. Favorites were beaten in five of the seven events.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday made up a total of 2,169,000 shares, compared with 1,775,000 shares on the day before. The movement of prices was highly irregular. There was a fractional gain at the opening, followed by a slow decline and then a rally at midday.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Edward F. Schlee, who with William. S. Brock flew from Detroit to Tokyo in 1927, today revealed that he had paid $2,700.50 of his own money for a "public banquet" tendered to the fliers in Detroit upon their return from the flight.

Captain Mollison's Solo. Whether the flight of Captain MOLLISON from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield Ridge in New Brunswick could have been continued to New York without a stop was a question of fuel and the aviator's endurance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Employment in a selected group of industries, upon which the Bureau of Labor Statistics bases a monthly survey, decreased 3 per cent and the payrolls declined 6.1 per cent in July as compared with June, according to a report by the bureau.
TORONTO. Aug. 19 (AP). -- Canadian meteorologists are apprehensive regarding the plan of Professor Auguste Piccard to try a balloon ascension to the stratosphere next Summer in Northern Canada.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Indicating from the bench that he would disregard the argument that the home rule amendment to the State Constitution deprived Governor Roosevelt of the power to remover Mayor Walker, Supreme Court Justice Ellis J. Staley heard argument today on one of the two legal moves to halt the Walker removal proceedings.

Notes amounting to $1,165,000 of $1,500,000 3 per cent issue of the Lowell Gas Light Company due on June 15 have been deposited so far with the Second National Bank of Boston upon the recommendation of the Savings Bank Association of Massachusetts in efforts being made for an early reorganization, according to a letter just mailed to note-holders by the association.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The Twenty-seventh Division staff, New York National Guard, with Major Gen. William N. Haskell in command, completed the theoretical advance of a division of troops from the Croton River today, ending the war games which have been under way this week. About 5,500 guards men will be shifted tomorrow in arrivals and departures at Camp Smith and Pine Camp.

The fourteen men arrested toy the New York police last Wednesday in connection with the murder of John Bazzano, Pittsburgh restaurant owner, who was found stabbed in Brooklyn Aug. 7, were discharged yesterday by Magistrate Folwell in Flattoush Court for lack of evidence.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Aug. 19. -- Achieving the first westward solo flight across the North Atlantic, Captain James A. Mollison, 27-year-old Scotsman, brought down his plane, The Heart's Content, at Pennfield Ridge at 11:45 A.M., Eastern Standard time today, 30 hours and 10 minutes after he had hopped off from Portmarnock, Ireland.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 19 -- The city of Dinant intends to raise, to its civilian martyrs shot by German soldiers at the beginning of the World War, a monument in which the balustrade designed by Whitney Warren, American architect, for the library of the University of Louvain will be utilized.

Cancellation of the allied nations' war debts to the United States would lot increase the tax burden upon the American people, it was declared yesterday in a statement issued by the New York Credit Men's Association through its assistant secretary, John F. Otis.

During a time of economic depression and shifting human values the mail-order catalogue preserves its vision of a better life. O men of little faith! Is this a vanquished nation? Wet the second finger of the right hand and turn the pages of the mail-order bulletin. This is a working nation.

AMERICA is the new heaven and new earth toward which a shipload of travelers are bound each in search of some new thing -- of a new opportunity, of a new liberty of the spirit or of the body, of escape from family worries, intimate obsessions or ruined careers, of freedom for the varied impulses of the soul which the older countries of the earth had confined by necessity or long custom.

AN auburn-haired girl in tights and spangles is hoisted, hanging by her neck, to the top of a tall tower. One hundred and fifty feet beneath her the eager crowd at Coney Island watches, while the daring aerialist releases her neck from its encircling web, at the same time clinging to a thin rope cable with her legs.

ROME, Aug. 19 -- The recent earthquakes that have shaken the Italian Cabinet and diplomatic service to their depths will be followed soon, according to current reports, by further changes in the composition of the government. Military circles again are speaking insistently of a project that was widely ventilated some years ago for uniting the Ministries of War, Navy and Aeronautics into a single Ministry of National Defense.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- Premier Richard B. Bennett of Canada, in his address at the closing session here today, summed up as follows what he regarded as the achievements of the imperial economic conference:

The subject of parachutes for passengers on airlines is raised with increasing frequency. Guy M. Ball, an engineer of the Irving Air Chute Company, discussed the matter in detail before a recent meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

The movement to lower the rates on the Delaware and Raritan Canal, recently instituted by the Junior Chamber of Commerce of New Brunswick, N.J., has gained in momentum and scope within the last week or two, it is reported. The cooperation of the Waterway League of America has been obtained and various individuals in private and official life have joined the campaign.

COSTUME as distinguished from clothing -- dress for effect and not for covering -- is the concern of this volume. Since all the world is a stage "totus mundus agit histrionem" -- and we are all players when we are "dressed up," the author, though a theatrical producer of international scope, has included in his survey a field much wider than the title, taken literally, would indicate.

LOS ANGELES, Aug 18 -- Before another Watch Tower observation is taken in these parts the August primaries will have been held and several hundred candidates will know whether they are nominated or cast into outer darkness. The latter fate is for most of them.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- The Liberal Opposition, led by former Prime Minister Mackenzie King, is preparing to attack in Parliament the agreement between Canada and the United Kingdom, made at the Imperial Economic Conference here.

IT was a fortunate coincidence for science that a few days before Professor Piccard made his second record-breaking ascent into the stratosphere Professor Regener should have sent unmanned sounding balloons to a height of seventeen miles and there measured the intensity of the cosmic rays with automatic instruments.

The syndicate of cotton mill owners and financial interests that was formed for the purpose of buying cotton held by the Federal Farm Board and that of the cotton cooperatives which the Farm Board is financing, has submitted its plans to E.F. Creekmore, president of the Cotton Stabilization Corporation and James C. Stone, chairman of the Farm Board.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Aug. 20 -- Captain J.A. Mollison plans to fly to New York City tomorrow, landing there at about 5 P.M., he said today after fog forced him to abandon a flight to the air pageant at Montreal. He intends to pilot the Puss Moth plane in which he yesterday concluded the first solo westward flight across the Atlantic.

FOX is getting ready to film Joel Sayre's football satire, "Rackety Rax," on a grand scale. Ben Lyon, now acting opposite Sally Eilers in "Hat Check Girl," will share the spotlight in the production with Marian Nixon, and a supporting cast has been assembled that includes Minna Gombell, Irving Pichel, Allan Dinehart and Greta Nissen.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Restoration of the Arc de Triomphe de Carrousel in the Tuileries Garden to its original form, made possible by Thomas Cochran, partner in J.P. Morgan Co., has just been completed. For the first time in 100 years it is again revealed in its architectural splendor as it appeared when erected by Napoleon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- The annual tennis-week ball was held this evening at Shady Lawn, the estate of Mrs. R.T. Wilson, which is being occupied this Summer by Mrs. Skirvin Adams. More than 300 guests were present. Mrs. George Mesta assisted her sister in receiving.

A request that the United States Tariff Commission, in its investigation of methods of tariff valuation, gather information through public hearings at which witnesses for and against the substitution of American for foreign valuation may present their claims, will be made by importers before the close of the month.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Delegation leaders at the imperial conference united in the view that a rise in the general level of wholesale prices throughout the British Commonwealth was most important and also that international action to this end was "urgently necessary."

RADIO has a new device called a velocity or ribbon microphone, representing a new departure in sound pick-up. Engineers in the laboratory of the R.C.A.-Victor Company responsible for the design contend it handles sound with a fidelity never before possible and, in addition, solves a number of studio problems.

The bond market, although its continuous rise has already lasted a month longer than the rise in stocks, advanced again yesterday, numerous railway issues moving up 2 to 5 points. In many respects, the action of that market has been the real key to the financial situation.

THIS is a profound book, and one that is vital and vigorous from the first page to the last. Though it lacks the massed bulk of illustration and example which supported Spengler's "Decline of the Western World," in the depth and impact of its ideas it is no less thought-provoking and potential in its influence than the famous work which proclaimed the doom of our civilization.

MANILA, July 16 -- Governor General Roosevelt, in addressing his first message to the Philippine Legislature today, demonstrated that there are circumstances under which it is possible to make bricks without straw. He was faced with the necessity of suggesting improvements and forward steps, while at the same time he was confronted with rapidly declining revenues.

American business, which has set the standard of the world in production, willingly destroying millions of dollars in obsolete buildings and equipment, must now remake the outworn machinery of distribution. says Frederick M. Feiker, Director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce, lecturing on "Modern Trends in the Organization of Business" at the George Washington University Summer Sessions in Washington, D.C., in the course on government and business.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- The twenty-fourth annual Stoctbridge exhibition for artists and sculptors who at any time have lived or worked in the Berkshire and Litchfield Hills was opened this afternoon with the varnishing day tea and reception.

ON Aug. 31 the moon will swim between the sun and earth. Dusk will fall as the lunar shadow rushes over New England, and the stars will shine. During the hundred seconds of the total eclipse blood-red tongues of hydrogen will lick the rim of the sun and the corona will burst forth in all its lustrous glory.

THE immense popularity of detective stories, usually stories of murder, has resulted first in a humber of books dealing with actual crimes, solved and unsolved, and more recently in an unusual interest in the psychology of the murderer.

PARIS UNDER the influence of the warm sobriety of l'Orangerie, where there is being commemorated the hundredth anniversary of Manet's birth, it is hard to believe that he was ever a celebrity du scandale.

About thirty years ago, a Hoosier lad, dressed in "blue jeens" pants and a hickory shirt, drove a load of apples along the banks of the Wabash to Terre Haute, where he sold his cargo for 25 cents a bushel. That was the first time this boy, born and reared in a log cabin near the banks of the famous Indian river, ever had seen electric lights.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Mark Koenig, the former New York Yankee, saved the Cubs from almost certain defeat today by hitting a home run with two mates on bases and two out in the ninth. The blow gave the Cubs a 6-to-5 victory over Philadelphia.

FROM family records, old diaries and newspaper clippings, as well as from more generally available sources, Roberta Frye Watt -- who is, incidentally, a granddaughter of one of the town's pioneer leaders, Arthur A. Denny -- has compiled this interesting and valuable account of the founding of Seattle.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The statuary which marks the source of the Seine at St. Germain-Sources-Seine, the commune near Dijon, is to be restored by the French Government, so that it will appear once more as the artist Jouffroy planned it in 1853.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 -- Setting a pace that caused all opposition to wither and Jail by the wayside, Fred Tomlin of Glassboro, N.J., today won the second annual open championship of the Grand American trapshooting tournament by posting a perfect score on 200 targets at a 16-yard rise.

Plans for a progressive kindergarten and primary school at Angora, Turkey, were outlined yesterday by Dr. Beryl Parker, assistant professor of education at the New York University School of Education, before sailing on the Saturnia to spend three years in Turkey, where she will assist in the development of primary education at the invitation of the Turkish Government.

Long forward strides have been made by R.C.A. Communications, Inc., and by the Radiomarine Corporation of America in recent months, according to W.A. Winterbottom, vice president and general manager of the former company, and Charles J. Pannill, executive vice president of the latter.

BAR HARBOR -- There is already a hint of Autumn in the air of this Summer resort, but no suggestion of slackening in the program of the season's activities. The Summer colonists are crowding more outdoor sports into their days and indoor festivities into their evenings as the season draws to a close.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 18 -- State-wide primaries have resulted in a peculiar situation in regard to the Kentucky Congressional nominees. The balloting gave Louisville two Republican candidates, Representative Maurice H. Thatcher, who was renominated, and Frank B. Russell, while the Democrats endorsed nine candidates, none of whom lives in this city or county.

In a world which so many thousands of learned spademen are daily digging up until the longest life has become too short to master archaeology, even if there were nothing else to be studied or done, the discovery reported from Athens last week may be but as a pinhead compared with this orb o' the earth.

Technological Improvements have come with such rapidity in the last three years that only 55 per cent of the workers thrown out of employment by the current depression could be re-employed if industry resumed operations at the 1929 peak of production, Howard Scott, directing head of Technocracy, a research body seeking through an engineering approach to find an answer to present-day, economic problems, told THE TIMES yesterday.

Charging that legitimate merchandise sources are being neglected by resident offices and that local buying practices in a number of instances must be improved if they are not to develop into "rackets," a group of six salesmen, in the men's apparel field here yesterday told of their experiences in trying to do business with buying offices here.

GANGWAY for the old ladies! If they are personally as charming and interesting as the books they write -- and they must be or they could not write such books -- the flappers of today will soon have to yield the centre of attractiveness to these dames in their tenth decade!

RAMSEY, N.J., Aug. 20 -- A new method of providing work for jobless men was disclosed here today when it was learned that the borough would award a contract for the construction of public works to an organization recently formed by men without jobs.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 20 -- A permanent village of veterans, designed to be self-supporting, is being created in Estelle Manor, about four miles from Tuckahoe, N.J., near here. Already fifteen veterans, most of them from the bonus marchers' forces, are on the location, cutting timber for barracks to be built next week.

AN international adventure! That is what many people called the first trip of American boys, who, a few years ago, went abroad to be entertained in the private homes of European families. It did seam adventurous to submit redblooded boys, 15 to 19 years of age and used to the American way of living, to the ways of foreigners.

UNTIL now there have been but two translations into English of that great Viking chronicle. "Heimskringla," or "Lives of the Norse Kings," done by Snorre Sturlason. who was born in Iceland in 1178, dying there in 1241.

Survival of big yacht racing is a question in England as well as this country. This year there have been but Weetamoe and Vanitie, of the America's Cup creations, in commission. Frank C. Paine brought out Shimna, the only Class M sloop on the New York Yacht Club cruise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Cleveland went on a hitting rampage to take the second game of a double-header with Washington today 11 to 5, after the Senators had won the first, 4 to 2.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The second of the three-race series for the Manhasset Say Challenge Cup was held today by the Larchmont Yacht Club, over a course of sixteen miles. Cotton Blossom, representing the Stamford Yacht Club. was the winner.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Quite a large number of American, women, traveling abroad resent, it seems, having their real age stated on the passport which they must show frequently to European immigration officials and hotelkeepers, in compliance with the strict police regulations affecting foreign visitors.

ZANZIBAR, July 11 -- Cloves spell prosperity for Zanzibar; clove growing is threatened with ruin; ergo, all Zanzibar from the Sultan to the meanest beggar is feverishly watching the clove market. This time, unfortunately, it is not simply a matter of prices.

OMAHA, Aug. 18 -- If a group of hard-boiled dairymen in the neighborhood of Sioux City had not dumped several truckloads of milk all over the clean Iowa highway, the Corn Belt might never have realized that a great farm holiday was being carried on in its midst.

LONDON, Aug. 3 IT is a truism that a dramatist's work is entitled to be judged by an ideal performance. When we read a play, such a performance may be freely accorded to it by the imagination -- if we have imagination enough and enough knowledge of the stage.
Another week of more or less localized sniping in golf and then the big guns will start roaring in earnest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during July at 51.7 per cent capacity, on a single-shift basis, compared with 57.7 per cent for June this year and 86.3 per cent for July last year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Wavering from the east, an air that was lazy and indifferent just would not blow this afternoon, and left 101 sailing craft in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's Sound championship regatta, the club's forty-seventh annual race, floundering about.

PARIS. THE campaign to make Paris a silent city continues to occupy the mind of the people and to fill the note books of the police. To a certain extent it is succeeding. New Yorkers, waking with a headache to the ballet mechanique of the garbage cans, may well think with envy of a city where there seem to be no garbage cans.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senator Reed Smoot was renominated by acclamation by the Republican State Convention today after it had adopted a platform, declaring "the Republican party does not bind its candidates or individual members to any definite course of action as to the question of modification" of the prohibition amendment.

NO one was better qualified to be the historian of the Cuban revolution of 1895-98 than Horatio S. Rubens, who acted as general counsel to the junta in New York. A graduate of the College of the City of New York and of the Columbia Law School, he entered the office of Elihu Root and became his managing clerk.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- Nine members of the British Walker Cup team arrived today on the White Star liner Britannic and immediately were taken to The Country Club, the scene of the sixth Walker Cup matches between the best amateur golfers of America and Great Britain Sept. 1 and 2.

IT was a large and difficult task hat Donald Young, Assistant Professor of Sociology in the University of Pennsylvania, set for himself when he decided to write this book. For the racial groups in this country are many and varied and the social relationships of even one of them form a tangled pattern, while the interconnections of all of them with one another and with the country as a whole are still more highly complicated.

With, games today at Sands Point and at Greentree Field, the newest of the high-goal polo competitions, the Knox Cups, swings into the second week of play. Sands Point, led by Tommy Hitchcock, and Aurora, Seymour Knox's side, which includes Captain C.T.I. Roark, the British internationalist, play in the regular Sands Point Club game at Port Washington.

MADRID, Aug. 3 -- Census figures rolling into Madrid indicate a very unpleasant situation for the men of the nation. According to current compilations, there are 500,000 more women than male voters in a total electorate of 13,000,000.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Europe, like America, is beginning to believe the tide of the world depression has turned, although, like America, it has next to nothing tangible on which to rest its faith.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Rochester received a setback from Jersey City today in the first game of the final series of the season between the two clubs.

FOR the third year in the last four the National Air Races are to be at Cleveland. They start next Saturday and extend through Labor Day, a ten-day program of air pageantry in which the crack pilots of the army, navy Marine Corps and commercial flying join.

The inclusion of Fred A. Bradley and William L. Ward, Republican leader of Westchester County, in the list of witnesses called by Mayor Walker for the defense in the removal proceedings before Governor Roosevelt was regarded here yesterday as having removed all doubt as to the line of questioning to be put to the seven Republican leaders for whom John J. Curtin, defense counsel, obtained subpoenas.

WITH the world's supply of coffee so far in excess of the demand that Brazil found it advisable to burn 9,000,000 bags in the last year, the United States faces a possible coffee famine within the next few weeks.

While his Democratic supporters were circulating a petition to insure his designation on the ticket in the forthcoming primaries, State Senator William Lathrop Love of the Eighth District of Brooklyn was urged for designation on the Republican ticket yesterday in an open letter sent by R.E. McGahen, secretary of the Citizens Union, to Lewis L. Palmitier, who has been mentioned as the Republican candidate.

Going Places -- Sometimes. ACCORDING to popular belief -- among housewives, at any rate -- woman's work is never done. Neither, apparently, is the highway builder's job. And this brings this column back to a subject upon which certain observations were made some weeks ago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Tex Carleton singled in the tenth to enable George Watkins to score the run which gave St. Louis an 8-7 victory over the Boston Braves today. Carleton, the Cardinal's hurler, who allowed twelve hits, hung up his seventh pitching victory of the season.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Scores of house parties are being given here this week-end. Among the guests are golfers playing in the Maidstone Club's first annual invitation tournament for the Maidstone Bowl. Play began yesterday and will be concluded tomorrow.

AS announced the other day in the news, Robert Garrison, American sculptor, has been awarded a contract for the sculptural treatment of the main entrance to the R.K.O. Building on the Radio City side of Rockefeller Centre. Mr. Garrison's sculptural theme will appear in three panels, the work to be completed in time for the opening of the building in October.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 20 -- The Brooklyn Cricket Club today defeated the Columbia Oval eleven in a Metropolitan District Cricket League game at Warinanco Park by a margin of thirteen runs, with one wicket to spare. Columbia Oval, first at bat, was all out for 67, Brooklyn scoring 80 for the loss of nine wickets.

FROM time to time Anzia Yezierska's name crops up into the columns of book reviews with books bearing titles like "Hungry Hearts" and "Salome of the Tenements," and because of her personal background and history they demand some attention.

FOR his plot the author has utilized one of sea fiction's standbys -- the lone woman stranded aboard a ship manned by a crew of barbarous shellbacks, with intensive drama provided by the tremendous psychological reactions her presence evokes in one and all of the company.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Torrential thunderstorms tonight broke the British heat wave after it had persisted for the third successive day. The mercury was 10 degrees lower than yesterday -- 86 in Central London and 89 at the Royal Observatory at Greenwich -- but millions of Londoners, unaccustomed to tropical temperatures, suffered another tiring and trying day.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA., Inc. The tax burden of the people of the United States can be reduced $1 for every man, woman and child if Congress will heed the request that has been made to it and eliminate certain beneficiaries from, the Veterans' Bureau payroll.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday were narrow and trading was slow, indicating a diminution of speculative interest. The total volume was 661,000 shares, compared with 1,756,690 shares on the previous Saturday. The market was slightly lower at the opening and then drifted idly to and fro.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Stillman Rockefeller will give a dance for their niece, Miss Clifford Watson, debutante daughter of Captain and Mrs. Edward H. Watson of Greenwich, on Sept. 22 at the Round Hill Club, Greenwich.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The convention of the Pennsylvania Department, American Legion, ended today after the delegates had gone on record as denouncing the President and Congress for permitting a "spectacle alien to the pages of our history" in the rout of the bonus army in Washington.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 -- Hack Wilson blazed his way to a bit of glory on Redland Field today and the Dodgers, playing at high speed and with determination and alertness, left for home with a clean sweep of the three-game series with the Reds. Brooklyn is only a game and a half behind the pace-setting Cubs and holds a similar margin over the Pirates.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 -- Athletes of the United States won forty-one championships in the tenth Olympiad, or more than one-third of the total number decided in the sixteen days of competition.

IN ten days the contract which broadcasting stations have with the American Society of Authors, Composers and Publishers for the use of copyright music expires. The composers are demanding an increased toll from radio. The broadcasters are equally insistent that they will not agree to a higher percentage tax.
COLUMBUS, Aug. 20 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech, as delivered here today and broadcast by the NBC network, follows:

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 20 -- The full tevt of the statement on monetary policy made by Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, before the Currency and Finance Committee of the Imperial Economic Conference, became available today with the publication of a preliminary report of the proceedings upon adjournment of the conference.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan sprang to the defense of Controller Charles W. Berry yesterday in a statement contesting the truth of the attack made on the Controller by Assistant Mayor Charles F. Kerrigan and directing attention to what Mr. Hylan said were the Mayor's deficiencies in handling the city's financial program.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 20 -- While India's communal leaders continue to denounce the British Government's minorities award, the moderates who recently broke with the British are using it as a stepping stone to renew their cooperation.
COLUMBUS, Aug. 20 -- Alice in Wonderland, the Jabberwocky, White Knights, The Mad Hatter, Humpty Dumpty and other fiction characters found their way into Governor Roosevelt's campaign speech today.

Little Joe Sewell, who is about one-half the size of George Herman Ruth, knocked in four times as many runs as the big Bambino at the Stadium yesterday. The result of their combined output was more than sufficient to enable the Yankees to roll on to another victory as the McCarthymen launched a four-game series with the Browns.

PARIS. ONE of the most interesting features of the first Winter showings is the tendency to reunite sports and town modes, which for some time past have been definitely separated. This is evident in the number and variety of "little suits," that have more than verified the style prophecies concerning them.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered $1 a bale yesterday, closing 11 to 12 points higher than on Friday.

VENTNOR, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Miss Evelyn Fogler of the Women's Swimming Association of New York is the new national junior long distance swimming queen. She gained this title today by finishing first in the annual ocean race staged by the Ventnor athletic commission before nearly 10,000 onlookers.

DENVER, Aug. 15 -- A controversy that has flared up between Colorado and New Mexico intermittently for a generation is about to be settled and the correction of errors in the survey which established the boundaries between these States will be definitely and finally rectified within a few months.

The striking advance on the Stock Exchange since early Summer is commonly ascribed to belief that a turn for the better in the general business situation is at hand. This explanation is not unreasonable, seeing that production and consumption had fallen below the level usually set as the limit of bare necessity.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 20 -- Thanks to two victories in as many adjourned games from the first and second rounds, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris now leads the field in the international masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland.

LONDON, Aug. 4, 1932 A SMALL but faithful number of enthusiasts gathers once every year in Haslemere, a miniature town at the foot of the southern downs, to listen to the music and to the speeches of Mr. Arnold Dolmetsch.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Isn't there any possible way in which the broadcasters could be prevailed upon to give to the radio audience the entire program of the concerts broadcast on Saturday and Sunday evenings by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra from the Lewisohn Stadium?

Participation of eight leading retailers of the country in the conference of business and industrial committees called, by President Hoover for next Friday to organize "a program of action along the whole economic front" placed emphasis during the week upon the consumption end of business recovery.

With her boilers cold and her decks deserted, the George Washington, the ship that took President Wilson to the peace conference, will leave New York Harbor tomorrow towed by naval tugs, en route to the graveyard of ships off Solomon's Island in Chesapeake Bay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note in THE NEW YORK TIMES that all boys who are to be transferred to Warwick are first to spend two weeks in a clinic. These boys have already undergone many physical, neurological and psychological tests and their histories are doubtless accessible.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Larry French checked the Giants' winning streak today after five straight successes. But after losing the first game of the double-header, 3 to 2, the Giants' bats generated fifteen hits in the afterpiece for an 8-to-1 triumph.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 20 -- A crowd of 12,000 persons waved and cheered enthusiastically as the new United States liner Washington, completed up to four decks and 15,500 tons and designed to be the largest merchant ship ever built in America, slid down the launching way of the New York Shipbuilding Company here this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Four special cameras mounted on a 700-foot elevation between Limerick and Limington, Me., will record the solar eclipse Aug. 31 for the Naval Observatory.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- The Weequahic track record of 2:13 for 2-year-old trotters, established last Saturday by Marianna, a bay filly by Peter Volo, was broken, today when the same juvenile trotted a spectacular mile in 2:12 1/2 in winning the 2 and 3 year-old class event.

In the September Scribner's, Mr. FRANK R. KENT has an article on the political outlook, printed under the title, "The Battle Lines Are Drawn." If so, they are drawn in a way to confound military strategists. No one can tell to which corps which division belongs. Certainly the lines drawn in 1928 are now completely obliterated.

STOCKHOLM SWEDEN'S nearest neighbors, Norway on the west and Finland on the east, have tried complete prohibition and have given it up. Denmark, to the south has greatly reduced consumption of spirits through high taxation.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 20 -- A man who during his military career has served enough, army "chow" to have placed two full meals before every man, woman and child in the continental United States, plus Alaska and our island possessions, is the busiest soldier in Camp Dix.

Jewelry valued at $14,000 was stolen from an automobile occupied by three women as it halted for a red light at 116th Street and Park Avenue early Thursday night, it was revealed yesterday by the police. The thief is believed to have been a roughly dressed youth who asked for and received a dime "for a cup of coffee" from one of the unsuspecting women.

Four weeks ago the Imperial Conference met at Ottawa to revive British trade, but not to build a Chinese Wall around the Empire. On this point Canadian and British delegates were emphatic. Premier BENNETT declared at the first meeting that "while the trading potentialities of the Empire are "great, even one-quarter of the human "race cannot profitably shut itself off "from contact with the rest of the "world."

PROBABLY no one is playing a larger part in the government's fight against depression than Eugene Mcyer Jr. Yet comparatively little is known about him personally, even though for fifteen years, since President'Wilson appointed him a member of the advisory committee of the Council of National Defense, he has been an important figure in national affairs.

The ill humor of the officers who must inspect the passports of travelers at the piers when foreign liners arrive or depart usually is traceable to the mistakes or lack of understanding on the part of the travelers, writes an unnamed passport officer in The White Star Magazine, house organ of the White Star Line.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- Montagu C. Norman, governor of the Bank of England, arrived here today from Liverpool on the White Star liner Britannic. He traveled under the name of "Professor Clarence Skinner" and was accompanied by a secretary, the ship's personnel having been instructed not to reveal the banker's identity.

THE liberation of human beings by modern machinery from age-old daily hours of toil and the question of what is going to be done with the consequent increased leisure looms on the horizon as one of the most vital, most interesting and most pressing problems of the present day.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The possibility of a new German Constitution, in which the word "republic" would not lie mentioned, emerged today as one way out of the present political crisis.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- Los Angeles bankers are convinced that this is the logical place for one of the new home loan banks, and a campaign to sell the idea to Washington is well under way. The arguments are cogent. Not only is Los Angeles the largest city west of Chicago, but it is the metropolis of the fastest growing area in the country and itself the site of a vast home building activity.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- Extraordinary police precautions were taken this afternoon and tonight to prevent threatened attacks on Jews as part of anti-Communist demonstrations. Mounted policemen, armed with rifles, patrolled the streets of the business district and Jewish neighborhoods where movie theatre patrons have been insulted and individual Jews beaten almost nightly this week.

TO Julian Huxley, visiting Russia in the Summer of 1931 "as one of a party of scientific and medical men and women organized by the Society for Cultural Relations," the most important aspect of the Soviet Union was that it was "a scientific experiment and the only one ever yet carried out in such a field and on such a scale."

TOKYO, July 30 -- Despite his claim that he was forming a new party to purify Japanese politics, Kenzo Adachi, Home Minister in the last Min seito Cabinet, is accused in a statement issued by Minseito "party officials, of having distributed large sums of money to induce members to join his party which, having now enrolled twenty-six members of the Diet, is legally recognized and entitled to the privileges of a party in the house.

OLIVE MURRAY CHAPMAN is that young English woman with an urge to be up and going somewhere and a very strong inclination for the Arctic Circle whose previous book, "Across Iceland," showed that she travels with intelligence and writes with skill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- When Secretary Mills in his Providence speech yesterday referred to Republican "unity" and "consistency" he probably had in mind the "unity" of, President Hoover and "Vice President Curtis on the prohibition issue, Senator Fletcher of Florida said today.

Opposition to the efforts of railroad executives to reduce wages further is justified unless there is a guarantee of lower freight rates, according to the Alexander Hamilton Institute, which asserts that cutting wages without slicing freight rates means further impoverishment of labor and the public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a Presidential complex inherent in the American system of government. Through the years has grown up a definite feeling that it is almost a disgrace for an occupant of the Presidential office not to be renominated and elected for a second term.

Completion of the largest hydro-electric power project in the world will be celebrated by the Soviet regime in Russia on Thursday when the Dnieper River dam and power plant will be dedicated. In the opinion of the Soviet the beginning of operations at the plant will be the greatest achievement of its program to date.

ROME, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini, who already holds four posts in the Italian Government, contemplates naming himself Minister of Defense and amalgamating the Ministries of War, Navy and Air into one portfolio, it is learned on reliable authority tonight.

TOURISTS all are divided into three classes when they go on board ship. The purser divides them into First Cabin, Second Cabin and Tourist Third. But when they go ashore on the other side they promptly undo his work and arrange themselves in categories that have nothing whatever to do with passage rates.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Fifteen members of the Finnish Olympic team took part in the post-Olympic track meet today and carried off ten prizes. In the eleven events the visitors captured seven firsts, two seconds and one third.

THERE is much to say about shoes. First and most important, they are cheaper; although that is not a style note, it is of definite style importance, for it means that one can have more shoes to match one's costumes.

OUT of the dignified ceremonial, the impressive eloquence and the plain speaking behind the scenes that have marked the course of the first Economic Conference of the British Commonwealth of Nations, assembled at Ottawa, this fact emerges: that the main issue has been settled, and settled in the negative.

THE BULLETIN of the New York Public Library is a monthly periodical which appears to grow in usefulness to bookmen with the passing years. Each number has at least one distinctive contribution on some bookish subject, or a bibliographical dissertation, or a description of a special collection, or an account of a noteworthy exhibition.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Rumbles of opposition among picketing farmers to proposals that milk trucks be permitted to pass through their blockade carried a possibility tonight of new disorders in their noselling campaign which has virtually stopped truck shipping into this market.

HARBIN, July 25 -- With practically the full length of Manchuria railways under Japanese control, there is every indication that the Japanese air force will bear the brunt of mopping up the isolated but extensive areas in which the scattered anti-Manchukuo armies are still holding out.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- "The success of the conference is not only assured, but an accomplished fact," declares The Times in a leading editorial on the empire parley concluding at Ottawa today.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Charles H. Mayo Jr., young Long Island golfer who recently shared the lead in the qualifying trial in this district for the national amateur championship, added to his laurels today by winning the Green Meadow invitation tourney for the second time in three years.

Nowadays when a New Yorker sees quail, it's news. Tramping through fields on vacation time or on a hunting trip usually constitute the principal opportunities for most city residents to observe game birds.

SOUTHAMPTON -- One of the outstanding social events of the coming week will be the large supper dance to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill on Saturday night at the Orchard, their place in Hill Street, to introduce to society Mr. Merrill's daughter, Miss Doris Merrill.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, July 25 -- In these days of world-wide depression it should be news when any city -- particularly a city in war-torn Manchuria -- experiences a boom. Yet that is just what is happening at Changchun. The establishment of the Manchukuo capital in this sleepy old Chinese city brought thousands of new residents here -- employes of the new government and their families.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club defeated the veteran St. George eleven in Brooklyn yesterday in a New York and New Jersey Cricket Association match. The victors were first at bat and compiled a total of 138. The visitors responded with 70.

BY wireless from Umanak, Greenland, to Berlin, and by cablegram from Berlin to New York, comes this sufficiently harrowing report from Dr. Arnold Fanck and the company which is making "S.O.S. Iceberg" for Universal:

Railroad issues again led the listed bond market into higher ground yesterday, THE NEW YORK TIMES average for forty domestic corporation issues mounting to a new high point for the year. The foreign, bond average likewise reached a new high mark for 1932, but on a much smaller advance.

The investigation of lotteries, which resulted last Thursday in the indictment of United States Senator James J. Davis, six other Individuals and the Western Union Telegraph Company, has uncovered no evidence which would warrant Federal action here against promoters of other enterprises, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A greater use of trade acceptances to increase the outstanding volume of rediscountable commercial paper and thus increase the nation's banking credit was urged by the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce today.
PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Four main problems confront France and in this vacation period all four are receiving very close attention and examination by those ministers of departments who remain in Paris.

Commissions to take testimony in England and Scotland in connection with the claim of Thomas Patrick Morris, 52-year-old Brooklyn housepainter, to inheritance in the $30,000,000 estate of Ella Virginia Von E. Wendell, were appointed yesterday through an order signed by Surrogate James A. Foley, who has presided at the previous hearings in this case.

RICHMOND, Aug. 18 -- Maybe it means a good deal and maybe it means nothing at all, but the average Viirginian is feeling more optimistic about the business situation than he felt a month or six weeks ago. Everybody down here is careful about making predictions, but there is no question that people are in a better frame of mind than they have been for some time.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 20 -- William W. Patten of Schenectady won the championship of the Green Mountain Boys' Golf Association today with a low gross score of 76 at the Ekwanok Country Club. Dr. W. D. MacDonald of Stamford, Conn., was second with 77.

A NOVELIST charts his unsteady progress from fledgling into bird, and does it with such graphic candor and in such detail that the reader cannot avoid experiencing some of the thrills and exhilaration of a beginner in the art of flying.

THE Summer doldrums in music, which have been warded off for the past few months by the concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium, the New York Orchestra at George Washington Stadium and the Goldman Band and which are now ending or ended, are about to set in.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article by Mr. A. Lehman Engel on "Native Ballet Composers," printed in THE TIMES of Aug. 14, seems to me to be based on such a complete misunderstanding of my letter in THE TIMES of July 31, and of the subject therein discussed, that I cannot let it go unchallanged.
If Governor Roosevelt should remove Mayor Walker, it would be the first time that a prolonged Walker vacation was prescribed for the sake of the city's health rather than the Mayor's.
