HOLLYWOOD THE day of the restricted talking film seems to have passed. Where once the screen believed that because it was audible it should confine itself to the limits of the stage which it was imitating it is now expanding to the proportions of the old-time motion picture.

Three false telephone calls to Police Headquarters kept about 150 policemen, detectives and firemen in the midtown area busy yesterday morning. The calls, which were less than fifteen minutes apart, ended when a squad of breathless detectives from the West Forty-seventh Street station arrested Joseph Margolis, 19-year-old clerk, in a telephone booth in the Salmon Tower Building, 11 West Forty-second Street.

Improvement bonds and warrants of several municipalities, together with parts of issues of foreign loans, were the chief additions last week to the list of senior securities called for redemption before their maturity dates. They increased the total for August to $56,143,000, which compared with $26,120,500 in July and $113,789,000 in August, 1931, for the corresponding week.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- Romance no longer is exiled from the Soviet Union and the Society of Proletarian Writers, which had outcast romance in favor of the most rigid materialism, has been dissolved and a new society formed, called the Union of Soviet Writers, with Pegasus less fettered.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18 -- In the heart of the Peace Tower which rises over the entrance to the Canadian Parliament Buildings is a magnificent memorial chamber where centre the nation's thoughts of its sacrifices in the great war. In the chamher is a splendid altar, and on the altar a vacant casket which is to hold a book of remembrance on which will be inscribed the names of Canada's war dead.

TWO of the nine poitical parties in the United States are still looking for Presidential candidates. The Prohibition and Liberty parties have finally hauled in their "Man Wanted" signs, but the National party and the People's ticket still have theirs on display.

The Russell Sage Foundation has published a book on "Immigrant Gifts to American Life," by ALLEN H. EATON. It brings to notice the outstanding contributions, especially in the arts, that have been made to the culture which has been developed in a land that has been more hospitable to aliens than any other nation in the world's history.
MADRID, Aug. 20 -- In what is regarded as a final drive against the "big aristocracy," the Duke of Fernan-Nunez, another of Spain's great peers, was arrested at his home here today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- Ellsworth Vines Jr. of Pasadena, Cal., national champion and Davis Cup star, today won his second successive leg on the Newport Challenge Bowl when he defeated Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, fellow internationalist, in the final match of the sixteenth annual invitation ournament of the Newport Casino Lawn Tennis Association.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Thls will be Robert E. Lee Week here. Festivities beginning tomorrow and continuing through Friday will commemorate the 125th anniversary of Lee's birth and pay homage to the great Southern General, besides reviving White Sulphur's historic past.

IT is not at all strange that it should have occurred to the late Edgar Wallace to wonder what would happen if American racketeers should begin operations in London or that his lively imagination should have seized upon the possibilities of such an event and woven them into one of his characteristic crime thrillers.

For the third week the series of super-value sales promoted by a leading store created sell-out events, while other spectacular promotions also drew customer response, according to analyses by shoppers, of the Meyer-Both Retail Reporting Bureau.

VIENNA, Aug. 1, 1932 FOREIGNERS are always struck by the magic of the Vienna Opera lighting effects -- the natural drawing-on of dusk, the setting of the sun, the rising of the moon as the stars twinkle through a darkening sky.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Scattered comment from the few political figures remaining in Washington indicated emphatic approval of Governor Roosevelt's speech at Columbus by Democrats and at least one liberal Republican, and a general reticence on the part of Republicans to comment at all.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The upsets which have marked The Travers Stakes and racing at this course never were more emphasized than today when Morton L. Schwartz's Gusto, winner of the Arlington Classic, the greatest money winner of the year and the colt many considered the 3-year-old champion, finished fifth in the sixty-third running of The Travers, the oldest test of its kind in this country.

PARIS CAN the life of a man who is for the most part unknown to them be of interest to American readers? I think so, at least to those who, as students or professors, wish to know and to understand the French academic world.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 18 -- Because politicians could not decide which way to jump, the manufacture, possession and transportation of intoxicating liquor is still a high crime here. The effort to liberalize the Wright "bone dry" law died in a partisan flare-up in the special session of the General Assembly, and thus Indiana, where the people by preference and custom take their liquor straight, remains legally the driest of dry States.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Three dinner dances were held here tonight. One of the largest took place at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Hosts before the dance included:

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- It was a light weather day on Moriches Bay today, and a fleet of fifty-two yachts gathered off the Westhampton Country Club, on the Speonk shore, were sent away in the lightest of east winds. In the Star Class, the feature division, the winner was Chuckle II, owned by Harold, Elizabeth and G.C. Halstead Jr.

THE Winter silhouette, to be correct, will have to be built from the ground up, or rather from the inside out.The modified Victorian hour-glass figure that is resuming the glorified position it once attained must be treated with judgment to make it conform to the athletic proportions of today.

A number of well-known clergymen from England and Scotland will occupy pulpits in Manhattan today. Ministers from other cities of this country will preach in some of the other edifices. Some pastors who are at home will discuss the prohibition planks in the national political platforms.

SHANGHAI, July 25 -- Comparisons of the general condition of China in midsummer of 1931 with conditions existing today reveal that not only have the year's hopes been unfulfilled but that the country is today worse off in almost every particular than it was in July of last year.

MR. DANIELS, who is now Professor of Transportation in Yale University and was formerly a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has evolved a singularly happy method for telling the story of the railroads of America.

Eugenists from all over the world will attend the Third International Congress of Eugenics today and tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History. At general and sectional meetings they will discuss advances in the study for the physical and mental improvement of the human race.

MISS LEAHY can congratulate herself that she has done a new and wholly unique "stunt" on her first entrance into the publishing world. For she has published, compiled, edited and in part written a volume like nothing else heretofore brought out, the conception of which seems to have been wholly her own idea.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- The factions in the Reichstag are beginning to hold their caucuses to decide the positions that they will take when it meets ten days hence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Twenty-eight racing planes and their pilots are here awaiting the starting gun tomorrow afternoon that will send them off on a transcontinental grind to Bartlesville, Okla., and return to Cleveland, where $20,000 in cash prizes will be awarded to the winners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Although some few cheerful signs appeared, the tone of business in those of our foreign markets covered in the current weekly survey of the Commerce Department continued generally dull.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- Not the outcome of the Presidential campaign will be the major interest of the electorate of New Hampshire. Not the possible disclosure of the preferences of the people as to the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment will be watched with keenest attention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent press dispatch told of an altar stone, used as early as 1675 in France, which is in the crypt of St. Francis Xavier's Church in St. Louis. The stone was brought to St. Louis by Farther Marquette when he was tracing the course of the Mississippi River, and, the article continued, "is believed to be the oldest in America."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 20 (AP) -- President John H. Walker of the Illinois Miners' Union, moved today to stem the spreading "dual movement" within, his organization as striking miners extended picketing activities.

GLOUCESTER, Mass. THOSE familiar with grand old Mr. Hare's "walks" in the Eternal City may recall that of his guidebooks the most precious opens with a quotation from a letter Dr. Arnold wrote to his wife in 1840: "Again this date of Rome; the most solemn and interesting that my hand can ever write."

Purchasing for early Fall selling reached its peak during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Buyers in the market expressed genuine concern over the lack of dresses available for immediate delivery, reporting that slow deliveries resulted in lost sales.

Restoration of purchasing power to workers through, elimination of "sweatshop" conditions and through more adequate wages and establishment of minimum standards for the manufacture of goods is regarded as vitally necessary to speed the apparent business gains now developing by various factors in the men's clothing trade here, who are planning a concentrated drive to attain such an objective before, the end of the year.

THE BURNING BUSH" carries on the story of Paul Selmer which Mme. Undset began in "The Wild Orchid." Factually, it takes him through the war and post-war period, and concludes with his children adolescent and himself middle-aged; it brings about changes in his business, deaths in his family, differences between himself and his wife.

VACATION days, the American legend goes, are the happiest in childhood's calendar. But actually, according to a survey of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection, for four-fifths of our 32,000,000 children they are probably the dreariest and least developing time of year.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 20 -- John J. Looney of Floral Park, driving Hal Kennedy, a bay gelding, which was a big winner last year in the upstate circuit, scored today at the Nassau Driving.Club trots.

The Question of Equality. H. Audino misinterprets the statement of our forefathers that all men are created equal. By this they meant that a political group of men were equal to any other political group; in particular, they meant that the English in the American Colonies were politically equal to the English in the mother country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The recent pledge unanimously adopted by the railroads to continue to utilize, even more extensively than they have in the past, their organizations in the field of research and experimentation and take all other available measures in order to secure the utmost in safety of rail transport and operating efficiency, brings to the fore many things that already have been accomplished in that direction by the rail carriers of this country.

NEW COPY" is a collection of the unpublished work, stories and sketches of Columbia students. By and large, it is disappointing. The stories, as a whole, possess an air of preciousness which is but poor compensation for the notable absence of the stuff of life.

MADRID, Aug. 19 -- General Jose Sanjurjo's fate seems to depend on whether he can succeed in establishing that the insurrection which he led last week was republican, as he insists, instead of ultimately monarchist, as every one believed.

Tommy Paul, National Boxing Association featherweight champion, will show before local boxing followers Thursday night at the Coney Island Velodrome, where he is to meet Lew Feldman, Brownsville contender for the title, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Aug. 13 declined to the previous low level reached in the last week of July and were 33 per cent under a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

ALL Summer long, from June 28 until this day of our Lord, the Stadium concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society have been going on at the Lewisohn Stadium much as they have been going on for previous years.

SHANGHAI, July 25 -- The brisk warfare which has been proceeding for the last two months between Chinese and Tibetans along the western border of Szechuan Province and the eastern border of Tibet is now assuming unexpected international political importance.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Four races were sailed today among the Stamford Yacht Club boats, Little Hope, owned by Jesse A.B. Smith, winning the afternoon one-design-class event over Fred Underwood's Virginia. White Donna R., owned by Richard Gould, defeated E.W. Pinkham's Estrellita in the Star class event.

TWO books by Rainer Maria Rilke are announced for publication in October by W.W. Norton Company. One, called "Stories of God," is said to be the most successful of Rilke's prose works. It is not a collection of unrelated short stories, but a series of connected tales written around a central theme, and written consecutively for book publication alone.

SIDLING into the elegant aerie of Billy Rose, an atelier which caps one of the loftier skyscrapers in West Forty-second Street, a recent investigator was brought up Sharp at the sight of one of his -- Mr. Rose's -- myrmidons prostrated before an oil painting of P. T. Barnum, muttering some queer abracadabra the while he made passes over an incense burner.

ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- With Mayor Walker looking to the courts to save him from removal by Governor Roosevelt, it appeared today that his defense before the Governor to Samuel Seabury's charges against him would centre around the contention that he was the victim of a Republican plot.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 20 -- Libby Holman Reynolds, who is at liberty under $25,000 bail pending her trial in Superior Court here for the murder of her husband, Z. Smith Reynolds, is in seclusion at Oakington, Md., and appears to be "somewhat improved in health," her lawyers, William Graves and Benet Polikoff, said today on their return to this city from a conference with their client.

LONDON. THE gardens of Marlborough House, one of the royal palaces of London, were filled a few weeks ago with a brilliant assemblage. Rows of chairs on the lawn faced toward a carpeted dais in front of a white cloth bordered with blue, which veiled a large recess in the age-mellowed garden wall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 20 -- Savagely ripping into the economic policies of the Hoover Administration, Governor Roosevelt demanded Federal regulation of Stock Exchanges today as part of a detailed program for curbing abuses under the current financial system.

GLANCING back over the Olympic performances at Los Angeles, it appears that one thing has been overlooked, especially by the cynics. The athletes and officials at Los Angeles at least equaled the Olympic record for keeping the peace.

Except for a spectacular advance in the near-by positions in coffee futures, commodities on the local exchanges moved irregularly last week and the upward movements in some were terminated. Sugar showed no trend, as did silver and wool tops, while cocoa and hides continued their advances and rubber and silk receded.

WE live in the richest world that has ever existed. Still, hundreds of millions of people are nearly starving and a steadily growing part of the world's population is exposed to frightful misery. At least 20,000,000 of good workers are out of work and a great additional number can find only half-time work.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- After Lausanne, as is well known, Mussolini himself took over the portfolio of Foreign Affairs. Now, when this most efficient and successful of modern dictators does anything, political and diplomatic circles in Europe do not fail to take notice.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- Relations between Peru and Argentina are rapidly becoming strained as a result of Argentine petitions for clemency for Juan de la Torre, Peruvian Aprista leader, who is under arrest in Lima.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Sao Paulo rebellion in Brazil will end successfully within the next two weeks in spite of the fact that it entered its seventh week today without much change, a representative of the rebels here declared today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Speaking at Williamstown before the Institute of Politics, Dr. Gregory resented the indifference to the need of conserving capital shown by the teachings of John Maynard Keynes and Foster and Catchings. Though it was not Dr. Gregory's intention, of course, to minimize otherwise the teachings of these men, it is very easy to bring good teachings into disrepute because a man may have produced some bad ones.

THE be-all and end-all of life. Colette seems to imply, is love the love of the sexes raised to so high a plane of sensitive artistry that its portrayal in her novels seems always a new experience, a revelation, to the reader. Like a nightingale's madrigal.

LONDON THERE has just appeared in The Quarterly Review a remarkably candid and outspoken survey of present conditions in the book world. Its author is Arthur Wough, himself equally distinguished as a publisher and as a man of letters.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The first seeded pair of Marco Hecht and Richard Hebard advanced to the final round in the annual metropolitan junior doubles clay court championship by defeating Gerard B. Podesta and Carl M. Rohmann in a semi-final encounter, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, at the Briarcliff Lodge Sports Club today.

THE authors of that excellent book about the Bronte family. "The Three Virgins of Haworth," have now turned their attention to George Eliot. And as Emilie and Georges Romieu are French, one will find in the present biography the Gallic point of view and the Gallic approach which gave to the Bronte work its distinguishing mark.

Eighty-two members of the Italian Olympic squad left for Naples shortly after noon yesterday on the Saturnia of the Cosulich Line, leaving behind their boxing and the gymnastic teams, which are in Chicago preparing for a series of exhibitions in this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing Prison, in an address before the National Education Association, accused public education of being derelict in its duty of character training. Now he repeats the accusation and elaborates his position in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine.

THERE are some writers -- almost invariably good ones -- whom one values for their quality for some highly individual essence which pervades all their work and which is not to be identified with style, at least in the confused and limited sense in which that word is commonly used.

The cessation last week of open market purchases of United States Government securities by the Federal Reserve System, after twenty-five weeks of uninterrupted buying marked the end of the greatest credit-expansion program ever under-taken by a central bank.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the invitation subscription dance which was held tonight in the Colonial ballroom and the Japanese room of the Meadow Club.

BUXTON, England THE first International Summer School of Dance, which will have come to an end just as these lines appear, affords an excellent point of vantage from which to survey the English dance field.

REPORTS from Italy indicate Marconi is "bending" tiny radio waves. The longer waves "bend" themselves around the curvature of the earth. But up to now the ultra-short wave experimenters found it a puzzle to send waves only a few inches long further than the visible range.

ANOTHER of those little gestures which create intangible links in the chain that binds together the far-flung dominions of the British Empire has just been exchanged between Australia and Canada. At the founding of Canberra, the capital of the Island Continent, Canada sent many varieties of native trees and shrubs which have proved thriving exotics in their new home.
Miss Nellie Halstead, 21-year-old English track star, who participated in the Olympic Games, stepped off a train from Montreal yesterday morning into a city of raised eyebrows and curious glances.

MADRID, Aug. 3 -- Proceeding on the assumption that the law is to protect, honest citizens and not gangsters, the Spanish Government in a single year has ended one of the biggest nation-wide attempts at mob rule any nation has faced.

Staten Island had a narrow escape at the hands of the Newark Cricket Club in a New York and New Jersey Cricket Association championship match yesterday at Livingston, S.I. After the Jerseymen had batted brilliantly for 167 and declared their innings closed the Staten Island batsmen made 74 with nine wickets down when time was called and the game declared drawn.

GENERAL PERSHING, in his book, "My Experiences in the World War," animadverts severely upon the work of the General Staff in the War Department in the early stages of the war. It therefore becomes important to show from the records precisely what took place and to do justice to that particular body of men.

THERE came into being on Jan. 22, 1932, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, one of the most powerful and wellconceived instrumentations ever devised to meet the greatest financial crisis that ever confronted this nation.

CAMP RAPIDAN, Va., Aug. 20 -- The mode of life and recreation at President Hoover's Rapidan camp was recorded on hundreds of feet of motion picture film and in several dozen "still" photographs today when a battery of photographers and the newspaper correspondents who regularly "cover" the President's doings were guests at the mountain retreat.

AMIXTURE of psychology and liberal religion affords the means which Mr. Gilkey suggests for the better-management of that inner equipment with which one must make one's way in the world. He considers ten kinds of personal problems, all of which most people find more or less troublesome at one time or another, either within themselves or complicating their relations with others.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Led by the brilliant player Rhyan Chand, who scored seven goals, the men's field hockey team of India, Olympic champion, again overwhelmed the United States, winning on the Merion Cricket Club field today by 20 to 1.
OTTAWA, Aug. 18 -- Second only to the Imperial Economic Conference is the interest being displayed in Canada this Summer in various phases of the tremendously important transportation problem.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- During a few hours' stay in Chicago today, Vice President Curtis declined to be interviewed regarding his stand on the prohibition question and his divergence from the views held by President Hoover.

BELFAST, Aug. 12 -- Success of the Democratic plan to modify the Volstead law would "result in the immediate production, sale and importation of beers, stout and light wines," and the "revival of American industry will synchronize with the opening of the breweries," Peter Fletcher, president of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., said recently in an interview with the Belfast Telegraph.

RAIN is one of those problems that the cinema folk are always running into, and in so many different forms that they cannot always fall back on precedent. Real rain, the rain that drops from heaven upon the place beneath, is out of the question for cinematic purposes.

TOKYO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A prediction that Japan would recognize the new State of Manchukuo by mid-September was made here today as General Nobuyoshi Muto left Manchuria to take over the posts of Supreme Military Commander, Ambassador on a special mission and Governor General of the Kwantung leased territory.

Police of Berlin last Sunday were on emergency duty and the Reichswehr was standing by to reinforce them if necessary. The Nazi storm troops had gone out to their mobilization centres for the week-end and the government authorities had warnings that the extremist leaders might attempt the long-threatened march on Berlin.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- Under the influences of the usual week-end dullness, reinforced by the hot wave, transactions on the Boerse shrank substantially today. There was renewed realization selling, but in spite of it the market showed considerable power of resistance.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18 -- Complete figures of the nine Canadian Provinces show that in 1931 there was a reduction of 21.8 per cent in the number of divorces granted in the Dominion when comparisons are made with the preceding year. For 1930 the figure was 875, which set a Canadian record, and for 1931 it was 684, the fewest since 1926.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Charges that the builders of Hoover Dam are abusing their commissary privileges, exploiting their employes and causing unfair competition for Boulder City and Las Vegas merchants were made today by Senator Oddie of Nevada in a telegram to Secretary Wilbur.

THE eclipse of the sun due on the afternoon of Aug. 31 undoubtedly will attract thousands of visitors to the zone in which it will be total. Although a partial eclipse will be observable throughout this portion of the country, the sun's disk will be entirely obscured only in the shaded region indicated on the accompanying, map.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The old-timers who galloped around the bases when "lynch the umpire!" was a popular cry will turn back the pages of time and loosen aching joints in one more game tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- About 15,000,000 Americans, of whom 8,000,000 are reported to be destitute, will require this Winter relief in clothing, which can be met only in part by the 500,000 bales of cotton voted by Congress, according to James L. Fieser, vice chairman in charge of the administration of cotton relief for the Red Cross.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The signing of the Ottawa agreements today produced a feeling of sober satisfaction in Britain, but nothing approaching enthusiasm.

BERLIN, Aug.19 -- More than hall a million Germans look gloomily into the immediate future these days. This time it is not the economic depression that worries them, nor the failure of their political party to come into office; their fear is that a new era is dawning in Germany which may force them to purchase bathing suits.
OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The committee considering the questions of empire content ant export bounties at the Imperial Economic Conference made the following report today:

IF Colonel William J. Donovan gets the Republican nomination for Governor, his opponents as well as his friends will lay their plans in accordance with one generally accepted theory. This is that when Donovan gets into a fight he keeps on fighting until the party is over.

ADOLF HITLER, after a Reichstag election which netted him only a little more than one-third of the popular vote instead of the majority confidently predicted, nevertheless felt justified in demanding of President Hindenburg that he be placed in control of Germany with the full powers of "a Mussolini."

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 20 -- William B. Woodbury of 156 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, was re-elected president of the Lake George Association for the twelfth, consecutive time at the annual meeting conducted this afternoon in the Lake George Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- In behalf of American coffee roasters, who, as a result of a revolt closing the ports of Sao Paulo, are facing a shortage of the product and a price rise, the Federal Farm Board has asked permission of the Brazilian Government to expedite sales of coffee obtained in a barter with Brazil for wheat last year.

Since Vice President CURTIS took at Topeka the Dry side of the Republican platform, the Democrats have a balance for Republican attacks on their own nominee for second place. Whenever Republicans from now on talk to the East about Mr. GARNER being a "radical" who would pour private and public moneys into pork-barreis, the Democrats can retort that Mr. CURTIS is a "Dry."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Pan-Americanism as a sentimental movement dealing vaguely with, "brotherly love" among nations is almost defunct in Latin America, and what is needed now is a constructive, vital economic policy between the "United States and Latin America, according to statements made before the Institute of Politics today.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Representative Allen T. Treadway, Republican, of Massachusetts, charged in a statement today that the decision of South Trimble, clerk of the House, to make public reports of Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans was made to gain favor with Speaker John N. Garner.

Sixteen delegates to the Eugenics Congress here arrived last night from Europe on the Red Star Line tourist ship Westerland. They were met at the pier, foot of West Eighteenth Street, by representatives of Columbia University and escorted to the International House, where they will live until they depart Tuesday night for Ithaca.

THE Reich Government plans to bring the entire German broadcasting system, in which individual States and political parties still wield strong local influence, under centralized Reich control. Two Federal commissioners will be appointed to supervise German broadcasting, according to a program which Baron E. Wilhelm von Gayl, Minister of the Interior, has worked out with Federal representatives for reorganizing the radio service.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Winston Guest's Templeton team kept pace with Sands Point in the lead for the Knox Cups by defeating the Hurricanes, 14 to 9, at the Roslyn Polo Club today before a crowd of 5,000 which turned out to contribute to charity through the Roslyn Neighborhood Association, sponsor of the game.

TOKYO, Aug. 20 -- Departing for Manchuria today, General Nobuyoshi Muto, in a farewell statement to the people of Japan, declared the task in Manchuria was to provide guarantees for the future of the Japanese race. The time for formal recognition of Manchukuo was near, he said, and he warned obstructionists in Japan, whoever they might be, that they would be combated relentlessly.

HERE are presented in parallel columns the two, historic documen ing to General March, the first was prepared by General Persh, tained Pershing's idea of what his instructions as A.E.F. co tary Baker, contains the official instructions to Pershing concerning h

A NEW six-cylinder "Speed Wagon" and eight-cylinder heavy-duty four-ton truck, powered by Reobuilt Gold Crown engines, have been announced by the Reo Motor Car Company. The "Speed Wagon" is priced at $1,095 and the truck at $2,995.

DALLAS, Aug. 18 -- Texas is awakening to a realization that its economic recovery, along with, that of the nation as a whole, is intimately, bound up with the European war debts owing to the United States. There is a growing body of intelligent public opinion in favor of their downward revision and even their ultimate cancellation, if necessary, that has not yet been reflected in Congress by our representatives.

AGAIN Wall Street has been having big days -- big days that intervene between less busy days, days that tax the huge stock-trading machine almost to its utmost. What is a big day like? In what way does it differ from other days?

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Miss Jane Bancroft of Cohasset rode her brilliant chestnut mare, Likely Lady, to a sensational triumph today at the concluding session of the four-day Cohasset Horse Show, handing the great Flowing Gold, owned by Mrs. Florence F. Dibble of Newbury and ridden by Thomas Walsh, a setback in the three-gaited saddle horse championship sweepstake.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The truth about hay fever is simply this: It is produced by pollen from over so many different plants, but the fumes from things like hot tar will cause it synthetically and so will carbon monoxide from automobile exhaust or any other offensive effluvia.

A 500-HOUR endurance test -- one of the longest and most severe tests in the history of modern aircraft engine development -- has just been successfully completed by the Wright Aeronautical Corporation at Paterson, N.J. This test on the Conqueror engine was conducted to determine the durability of new valve and valve actuating mechanism at high power output and high temperatures encountered with Prestone cooling.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 18 Michigan has cut its State property tax $6,000,000 since 1930 through the simple expedient of spending less money. It has made possible a $10,000,000 reduction of local taxes for highway purposes by providing that the entire amount received for automobile license plates shall be distributed among the counties. Hitherto only half the receipts have been so distributed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A 21-year-old Baltimore stenographer, Clyde D. Martak, won the National A.A.U. marathon championship tonight in a thrilling finish marked by the collapse of the favorite in the last few strides.

PREPARATIONS for the coming theatre season in Russia are being made in the spirit of the scheduled nation-wide celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the birth of the Soviet Republic on Nov. 7, 1917, judging by items found in recent issues of Moscow papers.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Pounding four local hurlers for sixteen hits, including homers by Quellich and Partridge, which provided five runs, the Albany Senators repulsed the Bisons in the opening game of the series today by a score of 12 to 8.

Asserting that his most thrilling experience during his ten-day stay in the United States had been when he looked down from the 102d story of the Empire State Building with "Monsieur" Alfred E. Smith as his guide, Jean Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, sailed for home yesterday on the Champlain of the French line.

In the reorganization of the affairs of the American Kennel Club now in process and which undoubtedly will be completed not long after the annual meeting next February, there will be many changes of vital importance to the whole kennel world of the United States.

The Interstate Commerce Commission took just about nine months to act on the application of the trunk lines for allocation of the railroads in trunk line territory; that is, east of Chicago and St. Louis, north of the Mason and Dixon Line, west of the Hudson River and south of the Great Lakes, but including the three coal carriers running from Hampton Roads westerly through the coal region.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- The Bat, sailed by Beck Crabbe and owned by Commodore Edward Crabbe of the Toms River Yacht Club, won the historic Toms River challenge trophy today in a stirring battle.

WHATEVER may be said against the low order of comedy in some of the sequences in "Horse Feathers," the new Marx Brothers picture which is now at the Rialto, this broad humor is spiced invariably with shrewdly twisted wit and originality.

DUDLEY DIGGES, who has played many parts in his long acting career, is to be seen this week in "The First Year," Which is at the Roxy. A popular way to begin a discussion of Mr. Digges's rise in the theatre is to recount his preliminary struggles as a $12-a-week clerk in St. Louis during his first months in this country.

TO determine what is the average prevailing speed of motor vehicles on Connecticut highways and in the various cities of the State, the Department of Motor Vehicles is making use of a new device, known as the speed detector, a development of the Eno Foundation for Highway Traffic Regulation, Inc.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- The Imperial Economic Conference ended its stormy career this morning in the Canadian House of Commons with a plenary session at which twelve separate bilateral trade agreements were signed by the plenipotentiaries of the nine British countries concerned.
LAKE PLACID -- The third annual show by the Lake Placid Horse Show Association, to be held Friday and Saturday, will be notable alike because of its new features and its attendant social events.

WARRING elements coursed in the blood of Gioia Rincati, born of one of the most aristocratic families of Florence. From her maternal grandfather -- hence the title of the book -- she inherited the whimsical irresponsibility of the Celtic temperament, from the paternal grandmother the selfish hautiness of the Polish Wilidskis; and commingling with these two alien strains was the cultural background of the Rincatis.

CURTISS FIELD, L.I., Aug. 21 -- The two new holders of the women's endurance record, Mrs. Frances Harrell Marsalis of St. Louis and Mrs. Louise McPhetridge Thaden of Baltimore, had been in the air 156 hours at 2 A. M. this morning. In a message which they sent down during a contact by their nursing ship the two women declared they intended remaining until "Monday or probably Wednesday.''

BERLIN, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Barriers hindering the exportation of German goods must be removed it Germany is to meet her foreign debt payments, Professor Hermann Warmbold, Minister of Economics, declared today.

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- The Cuban Government today anticipated the second $500,000 monthly payment due on Aug. 31 on the $2,375,125 loan from the Chase National Bank and other American banks by depositing $250,000 with the Chase National Bank.

UNIVERSAL has six of its more important productions of the season ready for September and October release. First comes "Back Street;" from the Fannie Hurst story, which may reach Broadway during the coming week. Directed by John M. Stahl, it features Irene Dunne and John Boles, with George Meeker, June Clyde, Zasu Pitts and James Donlan.

INDUSTRY is about to demonstrate what it has done for the extension of applied art in America. This development can scarcely be called a renaissance -- it is an awakening to values born of our own time, artist minds having become inspired by wheel and lathe.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick's fight for life was considerably weakened tonight when she suffered an unexpected collapse. She rallied quickly, however, and her condition was restored to that of the mid-afternoon when she was reported resting comfortably.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Head Play, the Kentucky 2-year old colt racing in the silks of Mrs. William Crump, won the Hawthorne Juvenile Handicap today, beating Gloritone by two and a half lengths at Hawthorne. Miss Brilliant was third. Head Play ran the six furlongs in 1:13 over a fast track under top weight of 120 pounds.

NOTHING finishes a costume so completely as gloves. In this approaching Winter of styles that promise to promote a restrained elegance they will be more conspicuous than when fashion flowers into frills and furbelows.

THE lure of the great city, with its myriad interests and its human variations, has been irresistible to more than one writer in the past, and will prove irresistible to more than one in the future. A city that is truly vast -- New York, London, Paris -- offers a field that exploration can never exhaust.
SCHEDULE OF MATCHES TODAY. 2:30 P.M. -- Final of Singles Championship -- Miss Helen Jacobs vs. Miss Carolyn Babcock.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Successful use of artificial sunlight, ultra-violet rays, as an antiseptic in 200 cases of surgery was reported today to the second International Congress of Light by two American physicians.

Retailers who specialize in highgrade merchandise having quality and style appeal will have this Fall their first opportunity in three years for a more profitable season, according to Charles J. Oppenheim Jr., president of Jay-Thorpe. His conclusion, he said yesterday, is based primarily upon the changed tempo of American thought and only secondarily on the variety of choice in merchandise to be presented to the shopper.

MANILA, July 16 -- The attack of Filipinos on the sincerity of the Philippine mission which has just concluded its work in the United States has become so outspoken as to demand analysis. The most recent step is a resolution of the Philippine Civic Union reviewing the entire case against the mission, which has been forwarded to the President of the United States, members of Congress and the newspapers.

ONE of the most interesting developments of the week in the world of the air was the purchase of 2,500 miles of airlines, known as Alaskan Airways, Inc., by Pacific Alaska Airways, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Pan American Airways.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Men and women will fly on terms of equality in the Pacific wing of the national air races.

MORGAN CUNNINGTON has a quaint point of view, halfway between reverie and faree. Out of the vortex of modernity, as it whirls around, he seizes symbols to arrange in an elliptical pattern of sharp contrasts. He is a fabulist.

DREAMS of empire, long a cause of friction among the nations of Europe, persist despite the territorial settlements made after the World War. Leaders in Italy and Germany recurrently talk of the need of more territory, the Italians seeking it as an outlet for their growing population and the Germans calling for revision of the Treaty of Versailles, which deprived them of great areas.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 20 -- Lieutenant George McLellan of Providence, 27-year-old former army pilot, and Mrs. Grace Reed West, 30, a Portland school teacher, were burned to death today when a dual control Gypsy Moth plane at the Scarborough Plying Field was caught by a cross wind, plunged into a gully fifteen feet deep and burst into flames as the gasoline tank exploded.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 -- After what seemed to be ten years of futile fighting what he branded as a utilities dominated Public Service Commission, Governor Pinchot at last finds events playing swiftly and powerfully into his hand. Disclosures have led the Republican State organization to make a show of vying with the Governor to bring about a thorough investigation by the Senate of the relations between the commission and the utilities.

EFFORTS to revise the college curriculum are now widespread. Wherever such work is in progress there is an increasing realization of the responsibility of education as a social force. As a result, teaching is being viewed in its large and fundamental aspects.
Next month, on Sept. 6 and 7, the Cohasset Yacht Club of Cohasset, Mass., will hold the Massachusetts women's sailing championship.

The number of stockholders of leading American corporations continued to increase during the first half of this year, exceeding the pace set in 1931 and nearly equalling the growth in 1930, when public buying of stocks after the 1929 break was at its greatest volume.

PAULINE LORD, one hears, may do her next Broadway acting in the Gallic "Prenez Garde a la Peinture," which, in an adaptation by Sidney Howard and under a title yet to be selected, will be brought forth by Mr. Miller.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Investigators into the death of the Rev. Joseph P. Cournoyer, 43-year-old Catholic priest, lean toward a theory of suicide, it was learned on high authority tonight, but they have not reached a conclusion about the death of Miss Lavinia Moran, a school teacher, whose partly clad body was found in a rectory bedroom.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Neptali Bonifaz, President-elect of Ecuador, was declared ineligible to hold that office by Congress today by a vote of 48 to 36.

SHANGHAI, July 25 -- The abrupt announcement from Nanking that after Sept. 1 all shipments of cargo to China must be accompanied by Chinese consular invoices has caused consternation in import circles in all Chinese ports. Chinese and foreign firms alike are protesting, not only against what amounts to a new import tax of about 10 per cent, but primarily because the new regulations will seriously hamper trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- After ten days' consideration, the Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a $31,625,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. The money will be used to pay off in cash 50 per cent of bond maturities faced by the railroad on March 1, 1933.

FOUR HUNDRED years ago Francisco Plzarro, an illiterate Spanish soldier of fortune, set out from Tumbez in northernmost Peru to conquer the empire of the Incas. With only 163 men. he crossed the colossal rampart of the Andes and captured the Inca Atahualpa.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Two organizations in the silk dyeing industry trod independent paths today, each announcing that it intended to proceed with its plans to stabilize the trade.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The United States must expect to lose the greater part of its export business in wheat with the United Kingdom, according to views in the trade here, if the reports are correct that empire-grown grain will receive a preference of 6 cents a bushel on imports.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Athletics and Chicago divided a double-header today, the White Sox winning the first game 6 to 4 and the Mackmen taking the nightcap 14 to 8. Philadelphia came from behind in the second game with an eighth-inning rally in which ten runs were made.

TORONTO, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto defeated Baltimore twice today, winning the first half of the double-header, 5-2, to break a nine-game losing streak, and taking the nightcap, 4 -- 0. Sullivan outpitched Smythe and Foreman in the opener, while the second was a pitching battle between Art Smith and Ken Holloway.

TRADE volume held up fairly well during the week, although there was no special feature to the business. Until back-to-school merchandise and early Fall lines move into greater demand there is not likely to be much greater retail activity, since the season is one of miscellaneous offerings to wind up the Summer.

MONTREAL, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals checked Newark's winning streak after five games today when Frank Barnes shut out the league leaders with four hits and Montreal won, 5 to 0. The defeat did not reduce Newark's lead, as Buffalo also lost, while the Royals gained a game in their four-place race with the Rochester Red Wings, who also were defeated.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Outdoor activities are marking the waning days of the Summer season along the North Jersey shore, with polo and power and sail boating vying for interest among seasonal sojourners.

Apparently the chief aim of Governor ROOSEVELT at Columbus on Saturday was to convince his party and the country that he is prepared to take the offensive in this campaign. His speech, at least the first part of it, was bold and aggressive. He at once carried the war into the enemy's camp.

The next session of Congress will be a lame-duck session -- perhaps the last. But though many members will be going out of office, they will not by any means have abandoned hope of coming back. For that reason they watch closely the election trends which run against them, and are often willing to anticipate what their successors have been commissioned to do.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Physicians attending Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick in her critical illness were amazed tonight to find their patient "stronger than she had been in three weeks."

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The sorely pressed Canadian farmers get the benefits coining and going in the trade agreement signed yesterday between this Dominion and the United Kingdom. They get important concessions for what they sell and hope to sell in the United Kingdom markets and may well expect to get lower prices in some of the goods they buy because of the lower Canadian tariffs against Great Britain.

West End Avenue's normal Sunday afternoon calm was shattered yesterday by a hold-up. Discovered by the police, the three men who were attempting it jumped from a secondstory window, landing in a cement courtyard. Two of them were captured -- with broken legs -- and the other, after dropping his pistol, got away.

Stitch McCarthy, who, as chief of the New York League of Locality Mayors, has something of a reputation to uphold, was down to his ears in corn last night. For the better part of the evening he was hiding behind the cobs. He was, in a manner of speaking, upholding his reputation; but in the process his dignity suffered slightly.
DENVER, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A "new force" for producing disease-killing rays within the human body was announced in a report to the American Chemical Society here tonight.

DUNLAP, Iowa, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A blockade against the important Omaha market was decreed tonight by Iowa farmers joining in the strike movement which has maintained barricades against truck shipping of farm produce into Sioux City for a week.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A steady increase in optimism, in leading lines of merchandising and manufacturing in all sections of the country is attracting attention here. An enlargement of confidence, an increase in employment and a gradual betterment all around are reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The effect of the depression is illustrated in the internal revenue collections for the fiscal year 1932, which, Commissioner Burnet announced tonight in a preliminary statement, were $1,557,729,042, or $870,499,711 less than, in 1931.

A four-point program of individual action to relieve the present depression, with emphasis on courage, thrift, charity and non-acquisitiveness, was outlined yesterday by the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of the South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., in a sermon at the Riverside Church.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The Conservation Department has just issued a general order, having all the force of law, regulating the seasons and take of migratory fowl in the State of New York and bringing such seasons and dates into conformity with regulations issued in July by President Hoover through the Federal Department of Agriculture.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 21 -- Many visitors gathered at the Greenbrier yesterday and today for Robert E. Lee Week, which begins tomorrow with the opening of the restored President's Cottage as a museum, and the dedication of the Robert E. Lee and Old White rooms.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 21 -- Official figures show that the gold mines of Northern Ontario had an income of a little more than $31,000,000 from production in the seven months ended on July 31. The actual value of the gold was a little more than $27,300,000, while added to this was the premium on exchange of around $3,750,000.

The physique of the average American male of the present generation in the form of a plaster model representing the composite measurements of 100,000 veterans of all racial stocks after their return from the World War, is to be placed on view today for a month, at the Museum of Natural History.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- The increase of 5,000,000 marks in the Reichsbank's reserve, as reported for the second week of August, was due to larger inflow of exchange bills from the export trade and the reduced demand for interest payments abroad. The increase of the reserve was greatly welcomed, since the end of the month usually witnesses a considerable drain on exchange for meeting foreign coupons.

Miss Evelyn Higgins, 25 years old, bf 2,540 Boulevard, Jersey City, daughter of Major William Higgins, a member of the staff of Governor Moore of New Jersey was in a critical condition last night from a bullet wound received mysteriously early yesterday.

There is no way God can help the unemployed except through the employer, Dr. Paul C. Warren told the congregation in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Loans made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation between July 21 and Aug. 1 will be made public tomorrow by South Trimble, Clerk of the House, and the effect of the publicity is awaited here with keen interest.

Behind the dashing play of Lieutenant McDonald Jones, the formidable Governors Island polo team overcame a five-goal handicap and turned back the First Divisio four. 12 -- 8, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Reservation in the fourth contest of the five-game series for the Colyer Trophy.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- Further signs of improvement in steel demand are seen in the warehouse trade, jobbers having slightly heavier distribution in several products, while they are buying with a little more freedom. No improvement in general demand is reported among the steel mills.
Manhattan realty transactions announced over the week-end indicated a demand for housing properties.

Governor Roosevelt's speech at Columbus, Ohio, on Saturday was attacked yesterday as "childish" by Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire. Senator Moses, who is running for re-election, telephoned from his home in Concord to the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee, which made his comment public.

With the prospect that the United States Treasury in the current fiscal year will have to refund from $3,500,000,000 to $4,000,000,000 of short-term obligations, raise several billion dollars for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and cover a possible deficit in the budget, movements are gaining headway in financial circles looking to the organization of taxpayers to head off governmental expenditures.

By means of a distinctive color scheme, employing violet, green, blue, yellow and red tiling for wall bands and name panels, the Board of Transportation has made it possible for riders on the Eighth Avenue subway to determine at a glance their approximate location even if they fail to see the station names.

Free licenses will be issued to jobsss men and women, in New York State to fish in the various bodies of water in the State where fish are plentiful, according to a plan worked out by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, it was anounced yesterday.
Five persons were killed and more than thirty injured in automobile accidents in and around New York yesterday.

Richard G. Herndon's forthcoming enterprise, "The Impromptu Revue," is scheduled to open at the Belmont Theatre next Monday evening. Its company will be composed of the most talented perrormers discovered at a series of auditions for people in all branches of the theatre.

The bodies of two young Brooklyn underworld characters were found yesterday morning sewed in sacks in a vacant lot in Somerset Street near Fourth Street, Harrison, N.J. They had been stabbed many times, evidently with ice-picks, their skulls fractured and about their necks lengths of clothes line were knotted.

Within scarcely more than a fortnight Austria has lost two former Chancellors who deserved well of their country in the difficult years since the war. Startlingly close upon the death of IGNAZ SEIPEL, who saved Austria from financial collapse in 1922, comes the death of JOHANN SCHOBER, whose best work was done not as Chancellor but as Commissioner of Police.

Internal dissension within the Communist movement in China, which has split the extreme radical party into many opposing groups, as well as the lack of an economic situation that would lead to political extremes, make it highly doubtful that there ever will be a duplication of the Russian upheaval in the largest nation of the Far East, Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, author of "The Good Earth," declared yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The trade agreement concluded between Canada and South Africa in negotiations running parallel with the proceedings of the Imperial Economic Conference is the first in the history of these two dominions, and places their commerce upon a treaty basis.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- After the Boston Braves had won the first game of a double-header today from the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 to 5, in a tussle that went fourteen innings, the second contest had to be called after the sixth because of darkness, with the score tied 2-2.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Drifting with the veering tide and every breath, the five Class R sloops competing for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup endeavored to sail through their final race today, but there was not enough breeze to waft them half around the course.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The Bourse has been rather irregular this week, but with the general undertone unchanged. Prices were sometimes steady, at other times unsettled -- a fact chiefly due to the very small turnover. The public is still out of the market and apparently not interested in the recent rise of prices, while many professional operators are on their vacations.

Dividend requirements of Drug, Inc., for the six months ended on June 30 were more than covered, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday, which showed for the period, after all charges, a net income of $7,684,021, compared with $10,656,053 for the first six months of 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Friday, Aug. 10 Dr. Morris Rosenthal, director of the bureau of arbitration of compensation of the New York County Medical Society, in discussing fee-splitting, is quoted as follows:

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Two lawyers today visited the Suffolk County jail here and spent some time with Victor Downs, 44 years old, of Quogue, who with his wife, Mitzi, 25, and Joseph Hoginski, 22, of Riverhead, are being held on murder charges in connection with the death of Frank Tuthill, 50-year-old Quogue "corn doctor."

NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Oliver B. Bridgman, who have been passing the Summer at the American Yacht Club, Rye. are now motoring through New England and the White Mountains. They expect to return to 1,220 Park Avenue after Labor Day.

SKYLAND, Va., Aug. 21 -- President Hoover practically ended tonight a short vacation which began a week ago when he embarked for a fishing cruise down the Chesapeake Bay and wound up with another visit to his Rapidan Camp near here.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- Apart from a few revenue duties, the policy of the United Kingdom with respect to India in the past has been one of free trade. By the import duties act of 1932, however, a general duty of 10 per cent ad valorem was imposed on all imports with the exception of certain essential foodstuffs and raw materials.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The two regiments of the Ninety-third Brigade, composed entirely of National Guard units from New York City, marched into Camp Smith with colors flying today for two weeks' training. Their arrival opened the first encampment here this season of a group which did not include up-State units.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The seventh week of the rebellion of the Sao Paulo Constitutionalists against President Getulio Vargas's government started today with no indications of a cessation of hostilities.
OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The official Summary of the Imperial Economic Conference treaty between Great Britain and Canada follows:

Detectives on the staff of Police Commissioner Mulrooney raided an apartment at 524 West 160th Street yesterday afternoon, where they found five men alleged to have criminal records who are accused of being members of a gang implicated in several murders and diamond robberies.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 -- Leo Sexton of the New York Athletic Club today bettered his unrecognized world's shot-put record with a toss of 52 feet 11 1/4 inches.
OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The official summary of the commercial treaty drafted between the United Kingdom and Australia at the Imperial Economic Conference here reads as follows:

Ten maxims, or "getting ready for schools hints," were given yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health, for the parents of New York children who will begin their classes in three weeks. They were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Seeking the pot of gold that holds $20,000 in cash awards when they reach the end of a double rainbow next Saturday, twenty-eight commercial aviation pilots began today a long race from here to Bartlesville, Okla., and back to Cleveland, Ohio.

NEW YORK. "Nebulous Proposals for Reform." From The Herald-Tribune (Rep.). "Destructive criticism," declared Governor Roosevelt, in opening his address at Columbus on Saturday, "is never justified for its own sake. But to build we must first clear the ground."

The great need of the world and of every individual today is a reverence for life, the deliberately developed lack of which has given the racketeer and criminal the power they wield in this country and elsewhere, Bishop Elmer N. Schmuck of Wyoming declared yesterday in his sermon at the morning service in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

With the dual purpose of stimulating business and celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of a famous thoroughfare as a business street, a "Fifth Avenue "Week" will be held from Oct. 1 to 8, inclusive, it was announced yesterday by Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, Inc.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- The annual dog show was held by the Rhode Island Kennel Club today at Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt's Oakland Farm in Portsmouth. Some of the dogs of the colony were being shown. Several dog lovers offered special prizes.

The union inland freight terminal, which is under construction by the Port of New York Authority on the block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, will be dedicated Sept. 16 and its terminal facilities opened for business on Oct. 1, the Port Authority announced yesterday.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Rochester and Jersey City divided two games today, the Wings winning the first, 6 -- 0, and losing the second in eleven innings, 4 -- 3.

As in Hylan's Day. Political bosses outside New York City have professed themselves unable to understand why Tammany's iron control of city officials recently seems to have slipped from the office of Controller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians easily defeated the Senators today, 11 to 5, as Wesley Ferrell scored his twentieth victory of the season. The Cleveland ace now has won at least twenty games in each of his four years in the majors.

Those ardent hunters who have been watching restlessly for the first signs of Autumn to hie forth into the woods and marshland for their favorite sport, may gain some renewed hope from the announcement made yesterday by the State Conservation Department relative to the regulation governing the taking of migratory fowl in the State of New York.
OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The official summary of the treaty between the United Kingdom and Newfoundland, as drafted at the Imperial Conference here, reads as follows:

An evil genius still pursues the Farm Board. One year ago this month it "swapped" 25,000,000 bushels of its surplus wheat for 1,050,000 bags of Brazilian coffee. Prices of the latter product have been rising smartly. Political disturbances are reported to have closed the port of Santos, through which Brazil ships most of her coffee to the United States.

Increased confidence, advances in various commodities and a better response to store promotions brought a large volume of orders for apparel and domestic goods into the local wholesale markets during the week. A sharp increase in the number of buyers in town developed, but while these store representatives ordered liberally, they maintained a certain degree of caution in their commitments.

Captain James Allan Mollison, blue-eyed, sandy-haired, modest young aviator who set out in the rain from Ireland last Thursday morning to conquer the Atlantic, wrote a new chapter in aviation history at 4:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon when he set his tiny plane down gently on Roosevelt Field and then flushed 10 the cheers of 5,000 exultant welcomers.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The newly revised Sanitary Code will go into effect on Sept. 1, Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., Commissioner of Health, announced today. The changes were made by the Public Health Council. These changes, Dr. Parran pointed out, have the full force of law throughout the State outside of New York City.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Illinois coal industry's bid for a stake of $60,000,000 a year in increased revenues today faced a temporary stalemate as striking miners planned to extend operations into counties where pits still were working.

Churches that are in difficulty today would find a solution for their problems if they returned to the teachings of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Abdel Ross. Wentz, Professor of Church History at Gettysburg Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon as guest preacher at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- July was the first month of 1932 that showed a really noticeable expansion in industrial activity, the Labor Department Employment Service reported today, adding that "a more optimistic feeling prevailed, with the outlook for August considered encouraging."

The Civic Reptertory Theatre today will begin rehearsals of "Liliom," the production with which Eva Le Gallienne's group wilt reopen after a season's hiatus. In addition to Miss Le Gallicnne and Joseph Schildkraut, who will nave the roles they played in the original New York presentation of the Molnar piece, the cast will include Leona Roberts, Beatrice Terry, Walter Beck, Paul Leyssac, Harold Moulton, Donald Cameron, Sayre Crawley, Nelson Welch and Florida Friebus.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The top price of choice hogs has hung near the $5 mark for almost three months. The figure declines 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight below that level and reacts sharply. The high point last week was $5.10 at the start, while the low was $4.80 at mid-week, with the finish $4.90 for selected lights.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- The Harvard Business School reports placement of this year's graduating class at about 85 per cent of normal for this time of year. Three-quarters of the class of 395 are taken care of, and there is in every class a fringe of men for whom the school has never undertaken placement work.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- A highly critical week in German politics was ushered in today. During it the negotiations from which it is hoped to produce that working Parliamentary majority for which everybody hopes but which nobody seems to know how to create except by jumping on the National Socialist bandwagon, will be pressed to a conclusion.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A survey of developments reported within the past week in the textile, shoe and other industries of New England, made public today by the New England Council, showed continued trend toward better business.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the recital by Stewart Baird, baritone diseur, this afternoon at Woodhull House, the residence of Lawrence Smith Butler.

A fortunate coincidence brings the twenty-fifth anniversary of Fifth Avenue as a business street at a time when a celebration of its high standards serves a double purpose. A silver jubilee for the avenue comling three or four years ago or three or four years in the future would as happily have served to recall the movement of fine stores and the establishment of quality merchandising along its pavements.
CHARLEY JAMIESON, Cleveland outfielder, has gone on the voluntarily retired list, leaving the Indians without a left-hander of any kind on the ball club. That ties the record.

Ambrose E. Vanderpoel has added to his holdings a twenty-three-acre estate on the east side of Morris Turnpike in Millburn Township, N. J., between Chatham and Summit. Eugene V. Welsh arranged the sale for Mrs. Agnes G.C. Nash of Washington, D.C.

Boodle's Club in St. James's Street must be one of the oldest of London, of all, clubs. Originally a proprietary club like White's and Brooks's, it was founded by a Mr. BOODLE, whose Dickensesque name queerly contrasts with the membership of his shelter for aristocrats.
Entries for the men's national singles championship tournament, to be played at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills beginning Sept. 3, close tonight.

Johnny Alien, the trim young right-hander who was once a hotel clerk and who last Spring was not expected to do much more this year than grace the Yankee scorecard with a number, hung up his twelfth victory of the season at the Stadium yesterday as he turned back the Browns on three hits.

QUEBEC, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press) -- "A victory for the empire and a triumph for democracy" was the characterization placed on the Imperial Economic Conference by J. H. Thomas, British Dominions Secretary, in a speech delivered on board the Empress of Britain prior to the sailing of that ship from here today with the United Kingdom and Indian delegations.

It would not misrepresent the public's attitude to say that the recent emphatic rise on the Stock Exchange was regarded first with relief, then with exultation, and at last with perplexity somewhat mixed with doubt. Probably this latest viewpoint was attributable to absence of any simultaneous movement of spectacular recovery outside the Stock Exchange.

DENVER, Aug. 21 -- Chemistry's wide-flung research battlefront against disease, ignorance and inefficiency will be outlined in scores of papers and addresses to be presented at the meeting of the American Chemical Society, opening here tomorrow. Discoveries in pure and applied science will be announced and improvements on older methods will be explained.

Significant changes in methods of city administration have taken place in many communities throughout the country because of the demand for savings in local government costs, Peter Grimm, chairman of the board of trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission, declares in a statement made public today.
BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Detroit and Boston split a double-header today, the Red Sox taking the opener, 3 to 1, and the Tigers the second, 4 to 2.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 21 -- One Trenton man was shot to death and another wounded, perhaps fatally, early this morning by a Hunterdon County farmer who, according to his statement to the police, was the intended victim of a hijackers' raid.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 21 -- In a few days I will take off on my return flight to England, to complete the first round trip between Great Britain and the United States by plane. There are problems which none but the flier could recognize, and these must be solved -- this time in my return crossing.

New plays again feature this week's bills of the Summer theatre companies in New York and near-by States. Prominent among these plays is "Dear Mistress," a comedy by Kathryn McClure, which will be presented tonight at the Country Playhouse, Westport, Conn., as the fifth production of the New York Repertory Company.

An alert New York Athletic Club baseball team bunched its hits to subdue the New York Police Department nine, 8 -- 4, at Travers Island yesterday. The policemen outhit their hosts but the blows were scattered for the most part.

Nick Pappanicolaou, a member of the Greek Olympic team, captured two first places in the fourth annual track and field games held by the Hellenic Athletic Club Hermes at Ulmer Park yesterday. Pappanicolaou, wearing the colors of the Hermes Club, was the victor in the high jump and the broad jump.
OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The trade treaty drawn up here between Canada and the Irish Free State was explained in an official announcement as follows:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The mid-August ball last night at the Wyantenuck Country Club in Great Barrington, which followed golf and tennis tournaments, brought out a company of 200 of the younger set from South Berkshire towns.

MONTREAL, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Walter (Doc) Gautreau, veteran Montreal second baseman, took over the managerial reins relinquished by Eddie Holly today and ran into a serious setback when the Newark Bears won both games of a double-header, 6 to 1 and 6 to 3.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Marco Hecht, University of Pennsylvania sophomore, won the metropolitan clay court junior singles tennis championship today, the former De Witt Clinton High School star triumphing over Richard Hebard, Hill School senior, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, at the Briarcliff Lodge.

KIEL, Aug. 21 -- The wreck of the German naval training ship Niobe, which sank in a squall July 26 with sixty-nine officers and cadets, was lifted to the surface today by salvage vessels in Kiel Harbor, where she had been dragged from the Baltic Sea.

Otto H. Kahn, New York banker, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after spending three months in England and France and said he had nothing to say for publication upon financial or economic conditions abroad or in the United States.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 22 -- Japanese troops yesterday captured Nanling, thirty miles from Chaoyang inside the Jehol borders, and are continuing their advance, using airplanes and armored cars. General Tung Fu-ting abandoned Nanling after four hours' resistance and retreated thirty-three miles inside the Jehol borders.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- Official statements were issued today upon the joint authority of the nine British countries participating in the imperial economic conference to indicate the scope and character of ten of the twelve bilateral trade agreements which were signed yesterday at the final session.

State Senator William Lathrop Love of Brooklyn, who was denied renomination by his party because of his vote to continue the legislative investigatioin of the city government, declared yesterday that when County Leader John H. McCooey took this step it marked the end of his leadership.
This table shows the comparative receipts of income taxes for the fiscal years 1930, 1931 and 1932, by States; also per cent of decrease, 1932 compared with 1931.

Joe Walcott, the Negro boxer who thirty years ago fought the best of them, was taken, to Bellevue yesterday from the cellar he wistfully called his home. Once welterweight champion of the world -- and still rated as one of the best in boxing history -- he was suffering from heart trouble.

The same public that countenances the most striking shams of politics and business is quick to brand the slightest let-down in religious vigor as lamentable hypocrisy on the part of the organized church, declared the Rev. Elden H. Mills, minister of the First Presbyterian Church of Forest Hills, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway at Fifty-sixth Street.

SIOUX CITY, Aug. 21 (AP) -- As the farm strike entered its second week, blocking highways leading into Sioux City, Mayor W.O. Hays in a statement today urged a conference of Governors to consider the situation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Traders in wheat here were unusually bearish at the close of last week, due to reports of the Imperial Conference in Ottawa, Ont., and to weakness in the Winnipeg market, which for a long time has been relatively stronger than Chicago.
John De Carlo, a patrolman of the West Forty-seventh Street station, shot and killed Miguel Gill; 19 years old, a dishwasher, in front of his home at 318 West Fifty-second Street yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- Back home from Ohio, where his address indicated that he would base his campaign, on a fight against the "economic superpower." Governor Roosevelt today was considering a direct appeal to the "forgotten man" for funds to finance his drive for the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Both the State Department and the Republican National Committee made reply today to the speech of Governor Roosevelt in Columbus yesterday.

PORTSMOUTH, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Redlands Ribbon o' Hollybourne, a Sealyham terrier owned by the Hollybourne Kennels of S.L. Froelich of New York City, today was named best in show at the twenty-eighth annual exhibition of the Rhode Island Kennel Club at Oakland Farm, the estate of Senator William H. Vanderbilt.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- While the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association's weekly Sunday regatta was being held off the Seaside Park Yacht Club today, the sensational German-built aero-racer received the first of a series of tests which will last for a month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is not the action under judicial authority in New York in the form of an order restraining the Governor from removing Mayor Walker of New York an abnormality under general law, and in particular under constitutional principles as laid down by the Court of Appeals of that State?

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Fred Dorset of Augusta, Ga., flying one of the slowest planes in the race, led the cross-country fliers into Winston-Salem late today for the first stop in a 2,369-mile handicap derby to the National Air Races in Cleveland.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Norman Thomas, the Socialist nominee for President, in an address here today, voiced agreement with "almost all the things Governor Roosevelt said about President Hoover" in yesterday's speech at Cleveland, but remarked that "worse" could have been said.

The membership of Typographical Union 6, at a meeting yesterday at Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, voted 336 to 135 to uphold the stand of the Union's Wage Scale Conference Committee, in negotiations with, the Publishers' Association of New York City, that the question of a new wage scale must be arbitrated jointly with the proposal for a six-hour day.

ROME, Aug. 10 -- To eliminate aerial bombardment effectively, as proposed by the Geneva disarmament conference, it would be necessary to dispense with all planes, civil as well as military, weighing more than 1,430 pounds, Italians contend.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 21 -- The "lightning" strike movement, planned for tomorrow in the Northeast Lancashire cotton manufacturing towns has failed, but it is expected that a disastrous stoppage, affecting the whole industry, will be commenced next Saturday.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- More than twenty-five scientific expeditions, numbering some 250 scientists from all parts of the world, and the two major radio broadcasting companies, who have chosen points in New Hampshire and Maine as the best places to observe and study the total eclipse of the sun a week from next Wednesday, have more than 70 per cent assurance of a perfect afternoon.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 21 -- Continuation by Great Britain of the preferences granted in the British tariff act of 1932 is the basic principle of treaties concluded by the United Kingdom with South Africa, New Zealand and Southern Rhodesia.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Eppa Rixey, veteran left-hander, today won his fourth straight game from the Pittsburgh Pirates -- the only games he has won for the Cincinnati Reds this year -- by a score of 2 to 0. The Pirates have not scored a run off him in eighteen innings, as he shut them out Aug. 13.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- Stock certificates valued at $5,000, purchased a few days ago from an innocent party by a San Francisco bank, have been found to be part of some securities that disappeared strangely three years ago in New York City.
BUFFALO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons increased their second-place margin by defeating the Albany Senators twice today, 10 -- 8 and 4 -- 3.
