After seven years of campaigning, Miss Helen Jacobs finally has been rewarded with the highest prize in American women's tennis.

MADRID, Aug. 21 -- The death penalty not only for General Jose. Sanjurjo but also for his son, Captain Justo Sanjurjo, and for Lieut. Col. Emilio Infante, his aide de camp, and General Garcia de Herrans, who accompanied them on their flight from Seeville, were demanded today by the Prosecuting Attorneys for the Province of Aragron when the State completed its preparation of evidence against the leaders of the recent monarchist revolt.

The name which for years has been proudly borne by one of the world's famous trains -- "The Flying Scotsman" -- making fastest time between London and Edinburgh and Glasgow, must now share that designation with the literal flier, of Scottish birth, Captain MOLLISON, who has made the first flight alone across the Atlantic westward.

Construction awards during the first half of this month totaled $55,378,500 in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains, compared to $116,553,100 in the corresponding period a year ago, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reports. Awards in the metropolitan area of New York were $6,545,000 and $25,504,200 for the same respective periods.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Sands Point, with Thomas Hitchcock Jr. playing close to the top of his ten-goal form, swept over Aurora at the Sands Point Club today to maintain its perfect record at the top of the standing in the Knox Cups polo series, while at John Hay Whitney's field in Manhasset, Eastcott won an extra-period game from Greentree to take undisputed possession of third place.

Abolition of the mandatory salary requirements for city employes whose salaries are protected by State legislation is essential to budget reduction next year, Budget Director Charles L. Kohler said in a statement yesterday.

A short and sun-tanned Scotsman stood in the midst of a struggling mob in Hangar F at Roosevelt Field yesterday and told the United States he was in a hurry to fly back across the Atlantic because "I've just beer married a short time."

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The monthly reviews of the London banks are devoting considerable attention to the recovery of commodity prices and its effect on the business outlook. For a long time past bankers in this city have refused to give any forecast of the financial future.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Lon Warneke shut out Philadelphia today, winning his eighteenth game of the season, as the Cubs took the second game of the series, 2 to 0.

The present calls for a great satirist or humorist to laugh away contemporary foibles, in the opinion of Dr. Joseph J. Reilly, professor of English at Hunter College, whose volume of essays on literary figures was published recently by the Macmillan Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 12 appears a letter signed A.H.H., whose idea is that by increasing the fee for a trial by jury in the Municipal Court the abuse of jury trials would end. He would increase the fee from $3 -- the fee now being $6 -- to $25.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest in THE TIMES recently the reference to an article published in The Virginia Guardsman by Major E.W. Opie of the Virginia National Guard concerning the origin of "taps," the famous bugle call.

A movement to write in the name of former Governor Smith on the ballot at the election in November has come to the attention of local Democrats and is causing some uneasiness to the managers of the campaign of Governor Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, it was learned yesterday.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 21 -- Adjournment checked temporarily the advance of two of the leaders -- Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris and Isaac Kashdan of New fork -- in the fifth round of the international masters tournament of the California Chess Congress today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21 -- Heavy selling of wheat in the United States and Canadian markets slackened the demand in Argentina but did not affect the price, which held steady throughout the week and closed unchanged from the previous Saturday at the equivalent of 48 cents a bushel.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Membership in the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America is larger now than ever before in the 143 years' history of the General Assembly of that denomination. The total communicant membership Stands at 2,009,875, and the net gain in membership in the year was 10,744.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. Frances Harrell Marsalis and Mrs. Louise McPhetridge Thaden, holders of the steadily increasing refueling endurance flying record for women, flew over Roosevelt Field today to dip in salute to Captain J.A. Mollison, who had just arrived on the last lap of his transatlantic flight from Ireland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The only thing accomplished at the Washington conferences of business leaders and industrialists is, I believe, an emphasizing and publicizing of the gravity of the depression. It takes no such a convocation to discover that business needs "coordination and expansion."

While, in accordance with custom, a Republican campaign book will be published soon, the acceptance speech of President Hoover, according to Representative John Q. Tilson of Connecticut, head of the speakers' bureau at Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee, will furnish the texts for most of the campaign speeches from now until election day.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The best field gathered in four years will begin play tomorrow in the fifty-first annual national doubles championship on the grass courts of the Longwood Cricket Club in Chestnut Hill.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The Ottawa agreements have aroused free-trade newspapers and those who hoped for "full-blooded empire free trade" to search for scapegoats. The middle view is that a new foundation, of empire has been laid in pacts of mutual advantage and that, with this achieved, the British nations can commence building for the future.
ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- Mayor Walker returned tonight to this city, where his public career began, ready to battle before Governor Roosevelt and in the courts to Keep his office.

Police of the Missing Persona Bureau were asked last night to search for Laura Logunoff, 15 years old, who left her home at 319 North Fulton Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., last Friday night after writing a note to her family in which she said: "I hope all will be happy after I'm gone."

It is an old controversy, started by Senator GLASS, which Governor ROOSEVELT revived by saying in his Columbus speech that he, if elected, will not permit "international bankers or others to sell to the investing public of America foreign securities on the implied understanding that these securities have been "passed on or approved by the State "Department or any other agency "of the Federal Government."

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Essex easily defeated Gloucestershire by an innings and 119 runs, and Nottinghamshire overwhelmed Worcestershire by an innings and 130 runs, in county cricket matches concluded today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 22. -- Robert E. Lee Week began here today with the opening of "Old White," the cottage he occupied in the Summers of 1867,1868 and 1869, and the unveiling of a new equestrian portrait of the General. It was denominated the Day of the United Daughters of the Confederacy.

As a step in its effort to reduce the cost of city administration the Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a list of the economies practiced by other cities compiled by the commission in its study of New York's budget.

New York and New Jersey authorities are cooperating in a hunt for the slayers of the three sack murder victims whose bodies were found last Sunday, two of them in a vacant lot at Harrison, N.J., and the third in North Bergen, N.J. The police are convinced that all three were murdered in New York and their bodies taken in automobiles to where they were found.

It is doubly agreeable when so much censure falls upon public service to hear from an authoritative source praise of the "high efficiency," "rigorous honesty," "keen sense of responsibility" and "unusual devotion to the city" of one departmental head.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, was a guest today of Mrs. John Markoe of Philadelphia at Larchesa, her Summer home here. He arrived yesterday from Boston.

The Standard Oil Company of Kansas purposes to go out of existence as a corporation following the sale of its refinery and pipeline properties to the Standard Oil Company of Indiana for $3,400,000, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by C.B. Wrightsman, president.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Massed protests of the American railroads, industries, agriculture and the professions against the government's throttling of private enterprises were laid before the Shannon Congressional committee here today.
ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt mapped plans for a drive to capture Western and Mountain States at a conference tonight with J. Bruce Kremer, an overnight guest.

CURTISS FIELD, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Well, we did it! We surpassed the former 123-hour women's endurance record established by Miss Bobbie Trout and Miss Edna May Cooper by 3 days 1 hour and 5 minutes. Are we happy? Well, that would be superfluous.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Jersey City defeated the Rochester Red Wings today in the final game of the season between the two rivals, 7 to 3.

The money market continued in the quiet state that it experienced during last week. Call loans were quoted at 2 per cent, with outside money at 1 per cent. Federal fund 1/8 per cent. Time loans, commercial paper and acceptance rates remained unchanged.

A tangled tale of Dominican politics, international intrigue and possible revolution confronted Magistrate Ford in West Side Court yesterday when Carlos Duran, who said he was the personal bodyguard of the onetime Provisional President of Santo Domingo, Rafael Estrella Urena, was charged with violation of the Sullivan law.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22. -- The Soviet Government is having difficulty in promoting the goods turnover which the Kremlin spokesman, L.M. Kaganovich, recently declared the most important immediate problem.

The steamship America, which had been lying idle in Hoboken for several months because of the depressed condition of the Atlantic passenger trade, started yesterday morning in tow of three naval tugs on her last sea trip to the graveyard of ships off Solomon's Island, Chesapeake Bay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Refreshed by his five and a half days' rest. President Hoover returned to his desk at the White House this morning and delved into a mass of work chiefly relating to his program for economic recovery. He arrived in Washington soon after 9 o'clock from his Rapidan camp.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Reception of the Home Loan Bank system in various parts of the country has exceeded expectations and the problems of organization have decreased somewhat in magnitude, members of the board reported today on their return from trips taken to study prospects.

The will of Miss lone May Spears, who died at her residence, 218 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, July 20, was filed yesterday in the office of Surrogate Wingate in that borough. The petition accompanying the will set forth the value of the personal property "is upward of $20,000" and that the value of the real property is not known. It is believed the estate will total more than $1,000,000.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 22. -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's Lout won the first of a series of five Star Class races for the midget championship of Long Island Sound today off the Pequot Yacht Club.

The plan to erect an eighty-three-story commercial building on the site of the Hippodrome, occupying the block front on the east side of Sixth Avenue between Forty-third and Forty-fourth streets, has been abandoned by the Fred F. French, Opera tors, Inc.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- With the exception of French rentes the market was slightly weaker during an inactive session today on the Bourse. Even international stocks dropped a little under Friday's closing prices. The pound sterling was lower, while the dollar was higher in the money market.

With some points in Georgia reporting three to more than five inches of rainfall over Sunday and with a sharp advance in stocks and bonds, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday moved upward $1 a bale to the highest marks of the last year.

Establishment of free immigration for individuals biologically classified as healthy, "physically and mentally, somatically as well as germinally," was advocated yesterday by Dr. D.F. Ramos of Havana, who delivered the principal address during the session on immigration control yesterday, morning at the Third International Congress of Eugenics, which opened its two-day meeting at the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The number of Americans living abroad increased by over 18,000 last year, according to estimates by the State Department today, based on consular reports. On Jan. 1, 1932, there were 404,317 Americans resident abroad, as compared with 386,272 on Jan. 1, 1931.

Emphasizing the burden of taxation to the railroads, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Lines, said yesterday that the New York Central Railroad, as it was now constituted, had paid more than half a billion dollars in taxes in the last seventeen and a half years.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The "farmers' holiday" movement picked up today a momentum which carried it into many parts of the Middle West.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Chicagoland amateur champions defeated the Italian Olympic boxing team tonight, four matches to three, in Chicago Stadium. Only seven matches were fought, as Vito Melis, Italian flyweight, was injured in training and could not compete.

A benefit "sail to nowhere" on the Hudson River aboard the excursion steamer Shinnecock ended somewhat abruptly at the starting point, the pier at West 129th Street, yesterday morning after a free-for-all fight had developed among 500 passengers, mostly Negroes, over the swimming prowess of a white man.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22. -- For the second successive local playing day, the Giants and Pirates shared a double-header today. The visiting bats failed to click against Heine Meine, as the Giants lost, 6 to 1, in the opener, but recovered to give the Terrymen a 4-to-3 decision in the afterpiece.

The need for razing the old sections of Brooklyn where frame structures almost sixty years old are now standing was stressed yesterday in a statement by Joseph H. Fink, secretary of the housing committee of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities. Mr. Fink announced that a commitee of architects and builders was touring the borough for suitable sites upon which to erect model tenements.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Guy Dutfy, owned by H.J. Schmoegr of Peoria and driven by Dr. H.M. Parshall, snatched a stirring fourheat victory in the 2:18-2:22 trot, feature of the Grand Circuit program which opened at the Illinois State Fair track today.

It is hard to make out the net result of the trade agreements reached at Ottawa. They are not yet published in full. Moreover, the summaries given out are covered with qualifications and contingencies. Some of the concessions and arrangements between Great Britain and the Dominions run for three years, others for five, and a few for ten, but all of them are subject to modification or cancellation on short notice.

JEFFERSON, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Attorneys for Cyrus S. Eaton today suffered their second set-back in their fight to win $1,000,000 in legal fees incurred in their successful battle to block the proposed merger of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

Eugenic reforms must be adopted within the next hundred years if civilization is to go on, was the message of Major Leonard Darwin, son of Charles Darwin, founder of the modern theory of evolution, read last night at the Third International Congress of Eugenics, which opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.
PARIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Lieut. Col. Alfred Dreyfus, central figure in the sensational treason case of nearly forty years ago, has not been forgotten in his declining years.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- Three members of the newly created Board of Taxicab Control appeared before Governor Roosevelt today and testified that Mayor Walker had never asked them to limit the number of taxis or do any favors for the Parmelee Transportation Company, whose banket, J.A. Sisto, gave him $26,500 in bonds in December, 1929.
ATLANTA, Aug. 22. -- J.H. Tuohy Jr. of Olean, N.Y., won the second leg of the 2,369-mile transcontinental handicap aerial derby from Washington to Cleveland today, landing here at 2:58 P.M.
ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- Testimony at today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt in removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The present necessity in the economic crisis, as during the war years, of holding gains won for children in health protection, schooling, family life and social relationships, whatever else must be sacrificed, was emphasized today by Miss Katherine F. Lenroot, acting chief of the Children's Bureau, in the absence of Miss Grace Abbott, in a statement issued on the eve of the bureau's twentieth birthday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Boston Braves won from the St. Louis Cardinals, today, 7 to 2, by heavy hitting and then the Cards took the second game of a double-header, 3 to 0, when Tex Carleton pitched his second victory of the series.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP). -- With increased enthusiasm on the part of the players and devotees of the game in evidence and with increased purses to attract the, leading professionals of the world, the annual Glens Falls open golf tourney will be held Sept. 8, 9 and 10 at the Glens Falls' Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Three scientists of the Bureau of Standards left today for Nova Scotia with two truck loads of equipment to study the eclipse of the sun there Aug. 31 in an effort to obtain data which may lead to information on the cause of fading and interference of radio reception.

The swordfish again are running off Montauk and the pessimistic anglers, who had about given up hope because of their inability to sight a single one in recent days, have turned optimists. The swordfish made their reappearance on Saturday, some fifteen miles out, and while the party of fishermen responsible for the discovery came in Sunday night, after two days' battling with no fish, they were overjoyed at having relocated their haunt.

Plans to reduce the funded debt of the Power, Gas and Water Securities Corporation by more than 50 per cent and to make it possible to continue payment of interest on the remainder are embodied in a letter sent to bondholders.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 22. -- A draw between Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris and Samuel D. Factor of Chicago marked the play in the sixth, round of the international masters tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Governor General Theodore Roosevelt of the Philippines, in deciding to return to the United States and take part in the Presidential campaign in support of President Hoover, has not been sent for, but has acted on his own volition, Secretary of War Hurley said today.

Invention and perfection of a process for the treatment of cotton, rayon and silk fabrics so as to render them creaseless was announced recently by Dr. Kenneth Lee in his address as chairman at the annual meeting of the Tootal Broadhurst Lee Company in Manchester, England, according to the correspondent of The London Times.

HAVANA, Aug. 22. -- Senora Mariana de la Torre, the first woman ever court-martialed in Cuba, who was sentenced on July 7 to serve fourteen years in prison, has been pardoned by President Machado, it was revealed at the Presidential Palace this morning.

Colonel William J. Donovan, who last week announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor, although a pronounced wet, took his stand yesterday decisively in favor of President Hoover's formula for dealing with the prohibition problem, enunciated in his recent speech of acceptance.

QUEBEC, Que., Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- To the Quebec lumber industry the results of the Imperial Economic Conference are "far from satisfactory," declared Premier Taschereau of Quebec in a statement today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- After rejecting an offer of 95 for $1,000,000 of city bonds maturing on Jan. 1, 1934, City Controller Szymczak announced today that he would receive bids on Thursday for all or any part of $8,000,000 of 1932 refunding bonds, which are "full faith and credit obligations" of the city.

DENVER, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The discovery at Johns Hopkins University that spiral springs form life-like models of the mysterious, unseen "leashes" binding atoms together in solid substances, was reported to the American Chemical Society here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Federal Radio Commission today granted construction permits for ten new transmitters for oceanio radio Communication to the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company. This presaged entrance of that company into international radio communication on a large scale.

Birth selection rather than birth control as the best means for the improvement of the human race was advocated last night by Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, in a prepared address read for him by Dr. William K. Gregory of the American Museum of Natural History, before a distinguished gathering of scientists from many parts of the world, during the general assembly of the Third International Congress of Eugenics.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Published reports of a local rising aimed at the Provisional Administration of Dr. Getulio Vargas were found tonight to be untrue and Rio de Janeiro was normal except for a minor disturbance earlier in the day.

Lawrence Saunders, the name which appears as that of the author on the title page of "Six Weeks," to be published today by Covici, Friede, Inc., is really the pen name of Burton and Clare Ogden Davis, made by combining the maiden names of their mothers.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 22. -- Within a month the Royal Commission investigating the Canadian railway problem will report to the government. It is doubted that there will be unanimity in the report, but it is assured that extension of the principle of government ownership will not be recommended.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Happy Time colt Rush Hour, owned by Sylvester W. Labrot and backed down in the betting from 15 to 1 to 8 to 1, won the twelfth running of the featured Consolation Claiming Stakes by a nose today at Saratoga.

With a record of eight days four hours and five minutes of continuous flying behind them, two tired women pilots landed their monoplane last night at Curtiss-Wright Airport at Valley Stream, L.I. Even then they did not land until C.S. (Casey) Jones, manager of the airport, ordered them down.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- The danger of having only one matron for forty women prisoners in the Women's Day Court pens at Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street, Manhattan, is pointed out in a report of an inspection recently made by Commissioners Cecilia D. Patton and John S. Kennedy and formally approved by the State Commission of Correction.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The dispersal of the remaining stock of Harry F. Sinclair's Kancocas Stable began here tonight and will be completed tomorrow night. Yearlings, mares and foals, to the number of forty head, passed through the ring tonight and brought a total of $41,125. for an average of about $1,028.
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- With the publication of the Ottawa agreements today, Great Britain quietly accepted the momentous fact that tariffs have become a permanent policy of her government.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City shot a par-breaking 75 over the course of the Peoria County Club today to win medal honors and prove that she is ready for any kind of competition in defense of her women's Western Golf Association championship.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Tuesday, Aug. 23. -- The approach of the first anniversary on Sept. 18 of the famous Mukden incident, which was the spark that touched off the blaze of Manchurian hostilities, finds the Japanese facing a situation that is far more serious than when they took up arms in this region a year ago.

BUFFALO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Good pitching by Joe Bartulis and timely hitting by his mates enabled the Buffalo Bisons to make it three straight victories as they closed their four-game series with the Albany Senators today. The score was 4 -- 3.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Miss Frances Robbing has arranged a horse show for the benefit of the Southampton unemployment fund. It will be held on Labor Day at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. The proceeds will be used in the relief of needy families and the care of school children this Winter.

The petition for authorization to reopen the Federation Bank and Trust Company was filed yesterday afternoon with the State Banking Department. It was received by August Ihlefeld, deputy superintendent of banking, who said Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick would have it before him for consideration today.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- A shorter workday and shorter week would assure employment to all adult workers, the State Painters' Union was told today by John Sullivan of New York, president, and John M. O'Hanlon, secretary-treasurer, of the State Federation of Labor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 22. -- The opening of the trial of five Nassau County policemen for manslaughter in connection with the alleged "third-degree" slaying of Hyman Stark was postponed today until Wednesday by Supreme Court Justice John B. Johnston at the request of Charles R. Weeks of the defense counsel, who requested additional time for the study of the medical phases of the case.

Preparatory to working out plans to provide employment for the jobless next Winter, L.B. Roberts, director of the City Work Commission, has sent to the heads of the various city departments a form to be filled out, showing what work projects they have and how many men will be needed during a four month period beginning Oct. 1.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 23. -- Every evening newspaper office in Dublin, according to The Daily Herald today, received a telephoned warning from the Irish Republican Army that no reference was to be made to the seizure of Donamon Castle, near Roscommon, which was seized Sunday by 300 armed men.

Any one going to Russia looking for cruel, bearded Bolsheviki might as well save the time and money, Mrs. G. MacDonald Bowman of Richmond, Va., president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, said when she landed yesterday in Brooklyn from the Norwegian American liner Stavangerfjord, accompanied by a party of fifteen Federation members.

Wall Street began the week by staging a series of buying demonstrations which established stock prices at the highest level of the year and lifted the average of bonds into new high ground for the year. The volume in the share market on the Stock Exchange was 3,175,000 shares, compared with 2,169,340 on Friday, the last previous five-hour day.

Long Island won two out of the three events decided at the Old Belleclaire Golf Club at Bayside, L.I., yesterday, Frank Strafaci, 16-year-old caddie at the Shore View Club in Brooklyn, taking the metropolitan caddie championship, and the team title going to the district also.
Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson Cabinet, will speak for Governor Roosevelt and John N. Garner; the Democratic nominees for President and Vice President, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Loans of $49,711,056.10 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to nearly 450 eligible borrowers during the last nine business days in July were shown today in its first monthly report to Congress, made public by South Trimble, Clerk of the House.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Big Fred Marberry, after a season devoted mostly to relief pitching, shut out Cleveland today with one hit -- a single by Porter, the first man to face him. Washington won, 4 to 0.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The first death sentences pronounced by the special courts instituted under President von Hindenburg's anti-terrorist decree's have resulted in a storm of fairly serious extent. It is a Nazi-made storm, of course.

An attack on the allowance of 40 cents a mile by the United States Government to Senators and Representatives for traveling expenses to Washington to attend a session of Congress is made by William P. Helm, Washington newspaper correspondent, in his book.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Aug. 17 shows decreases for the week of $42,000,000 in loans and investments, $52,000,000 in government deposits and $5,000,000 in time deposits, and increases of $25,000,000 in net demand deposits and $15,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

DUBLIN, Aug. 22. -- The most important development in the Irish Free State in the last few days has been the public appearance of the Army Comrades Association, a new body of former Free State soldiers, formed recently under the presidency of Colonel Thomas O'Higgins, brother of the late Kevin O'Higgins.

Were it within the province of the directors of organized baseball to allow teams to exchange uniforms just to enliven things on a sultry August afternoon, there could not have been effected a greater surprise than that which came to pass at the Stadium yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prohibitionists are fully justified in their desperate fight to retain the Eighteenth Amendment within the Constitution, for it is the most colossal mechanical instrument for "reformation by force" ever conceived in this nation, and, if it could succeed, would be one of the greatest triumphs for moral progress ever produced, not only in the machine age but in all ages.

TOKYO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Expectations that Japanese troops will be moving against Chinese armies again this Fall received semi-official confirmation here today. A Foreign Office spokesman intimated that the favorable Autumn weather probably would see a determined Japanese military action in Jehol.

At Annapolis Royal on Thursday last Nova Scotia honored the memory of PAUL MASCARENE, whose services to the Crown had been obscured by the passing of time until he was well-nigh, forgotten. Although born in Languedoc, he was a British soldier and colonial statesman, valiant in war and sagacious in peace.

A curious experiment about which little is known in this part of the country has been started in Texas. In the Southwest, where literary and artistic communities are persistent, news of Kristenstad has spread. It is a town less than five years old, composed of thirty families, all owners of homes and farms.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- A legal impasse, of such import that it provoked a hint of "physical conflict" if Mayor Walker is ousted, appeared to have been reached here today in the Mayor's efforts to save his office by court order.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Aug. 20 there appeared a letter by Julian B. Thomas of Brooklyn. It deals with the subject of saving for the city 17,500,000 by Improving the efficiency of the money actually spent. Before commenting on the subject wish to give a short summary of it: city built and operated incinerators versus privately built and operated Incinerators.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The National Socialist party attorney, Hans Frank, telegraphed President von Hindenburg and Chancellor von Papen tonight, strongly protesting against the death sentences imposed at Beuthen and urging an immediate pardon for the convicted men.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 22. -- Prime Minister Lyons, commenting on the United Kingdom-Australian accord at Ottawa, said that, considering the empire's varied interests, the Australian agreement "is a tribute to the able and energetic manner in which we have been represented at the conference, and the agreement is received with the greatest satisfaction."

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Five Atlantic class sloops, with women, skippers and crews, today began the Long Island Sound elimination for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of the long Atlantic Coast.

DETROIT, Aug. 22. -- The world's fastest motor boat, with her pilot, Kaye Don, British speed ace, at the wheel, cut a foaming wake over the Harmsworth course in Lake St. Clair today at a speed variously estimated from 110 to 115 miles an hour.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 22. -- Harry Eichelberger, who tossed away his football toga for a set of golf clubs at Stanford, hauled out some magic pitch shots today to beat a record field in the first eighteen-hole struggle for the Western amateur medal.

Dr. Otto Kiep, German Consul General in New York, will sail today on the Europa of the North German Lloyd for his annual vacation in Germany. Others booked for Channel ports, on the same ship, include Baron Paul von Schell, secretary of the Hungarian Minister at Washington, Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Menjou, and W.H. White, general manager of Thomas Cook Son.
STOCKHOLM. Aug. 22. -- After protracted secret negotiations the reconstruction committee of the Swedish Match Company has recommended that the company should continue its activities.

With a view to relieving a shortage of wheat in Chile and of reducing surplus stocks of nitrate held in that country, conversations have been carried on by spokesmen of the Chilean Government with United States commercial attaches in Santiago and Valparaiso looking to barter of at least 40,000 tons of nitrate for about 2,500,000 bushels of wheat held by the Federal Farm Board.

SEAGIRT, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Preparations to oppose the granting of appeals for tax reductions by railroads in New Jersey, including the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the Erie and the Lehigh, were discussed here today with Governor A. Harry Moore at his Summer home.

Banking Superintendent Joseph A. Broderick got permission from Supreme Court Justice Carew yesterday to settle obligations of $499,915 held by the Bank of United States against A.J. Kobler, owner and publisher of The Daily Mirror, for $150,000 in cash and possibly $20,000 or $25,000 more.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter on "New Industries," by Herbert Wachsmann, in THE TIMES of Aug. 17, should be very interesting to those who have paid special attention to the part that is being played by new enterprises and small business organizations in the depression.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Harold O. Barker and the members of their family who are now in East Hampton, L.I., will be at the Pierre for the Autumn and Winter.
MONTREAL, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Newark Bears' march to the 1932 International League pennant continued uninterrupted today as they took their third straight game of the series with Montreal, 11-7.
The final concours of the work of Summer students in the Art Students' League went on view yesterday afternoon at the league's gallery, 216 West Fifty-seventh Street. It will remain until Sept. 2.

For the last twenty years the Federal Government has watched with patience and annoyance the destruction of most of the American flags it has flown from a fifty-foot staff on the roof at the north end of the old Post Office Building in Park Row.

Not a Startling Change. It is too much to expect that the death of WILTON LACKAYE, the unforgetable "Svengali" of almost forty years ago, trill be allowed to pass without a few ironic compliments to the Mauve Decade when Trilby's posing in the Parisian studios for "the altogether" represented the utmost in literary daring.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 22. -- Although mining operations were resumed by the Peabody Company today, only a thin trickle of coal was hoisted from one of its four large mines in the Midland tract. The other three continued idle. Just forty-eight of the 1,500 miners who ordinarily work the pits braved picket lines and reported for duty.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- A two-bagger by Tom Oliver with two on and two out in the last of the ninth scored two runs and gave the Red Sox a 6-5 victory over Detroit today.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Laurens Morgan Hamilton of Sloatsburg, nephew of J.P. Morgan, has been designated by the Republican committees of Richmond and Rockland Counties as a candidate for State Senator. He will be unopposed in the September primaries for the nomination, and his opponent is expected to be Senator Harry J. Palmer of Richmond, who has the Democratic designation for re-election.

Nearly three hundred years ago RICHELIEU, framing the statutes of the French Academy, made the preparation of a grammar of the French language one of its duties. Did the Cardinal have a mischievous inkling, an ironical premonition, of the disagreeableness of the task enjoined, the reluctance to perform it ?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- In presenting a charter recently to the new American Federation of Government Employes, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged that "misrepresentation and fraud" led to the withdrawal of the National Federation of Federal Employes last Fall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading your editorial a few days ago, commenting on the taxicab industry as outlined by a writer in the current issue of The American Mercury, and then reading the letter in THE TIMES today from Abe Weisinger, president of the Associated Taxicab Industries, Inc., I am tempted to say that the argument in favor of limitation of cabs is strengthened.

The Transatlantic Passenger Conference has drafted a tentative agreement under which cruises to the West Indies during the Winter season by ships of the conference lines will be limited to fifty-eight and minimum rates fixed by the conference will be charged.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Cubs increased their lead over Brooklyn in the National League championship race to three games by winning their third straight from Philadelphia today, 8 to 4.

In response to a week-end accumulation of buying orders, stocks and bonds joined yesterday in one of the liveliest advances of the year, with the former showing net gains of 2 to 9 points and the latter of 1 to 10 points.
TORONTO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Toronto Leafs scored their third straight victory over Baltimore and the sixth triumph in the last seven games between the two teams by winning today, 11 -- 2.

The North American Company has been able to pay off all its bank loans, amounting to $9,013,375, since June 30, according to the quarterly statement issued by Frank L. Dame, chairman, and Edwin Gruhl. president, supplementary to a statement of condition as of June 30.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Nine of the ten seeded teams moved into second-round brackets as the fitty-first national doubles championship began today.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 22. -- Comment on the Ottawa accord between the United Kingdom and New Zealand is being reserved pending the publication of the complete statement on the concessions made by New Zealand.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 22. -- Governor Olson, the only Farmer-Labor Governor, today expressed himself as in favor of the movement of the Iowa farmers and as willing to join with other Governors in an "arbitrary plan" of declaring martial law to aid the cause.

CHARLES CITY, Iowa, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Inflamed by what they asserted was favoritism in the variation in wages paid to workers from the city relief fund, a group of unemployed men today abducted Miss Marion Stull, Floyd County Overseer of the Poor, and held her prisoner for several hours.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 23. -- The main purpose of Kojiro Matsukata's visit to Baku, Russia, is to ascertain how Soviet oil might replace American oil on the Japanese market in the event of a commercial boycott. At present Japanese companies import Californian oil largely, and in view of the uneasy international situation they want to examine alternative sources.

OTTAWA, Aug. 22. -- The revision of Canada's treaties with Australia and New Zealand is the first aftermath of the Imperial Economic Conference. The agreement with New Zealand is more generous than that with Australia. Canada now desires to bring this more in harmony and also to smooth out minor details in both treaties.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The friends and relatives of the late Theodore Roosevelt seem to for get that this distinguished citizen was himself a severe critic of the Republican party, breaking away from it in 1912 to lead the Bull Moose movement.
CAPTAIN WALTER H. WELLS leaned back in his chair and said to Captain Lawrence McClung Jones, called Biff:

Without any definite stimulus in the news, and seemingly altogether as a result of accumulating financial cheerfulness, the week's markets opened yesterday with a burst of enthusiasm. Advances running from 4 to 6 points, with an exceptional 9 3/4-point rise in Union Pacific shares, occurred on the stock market.

Offering of an issue of $8,915,000 Dayton (Ohio) Power and Light Company first and refunding-mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1941, will be made today by a banking group headed by the Guaranty Company of New York, and including the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh, Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, J. W. Seligman Co., W.E. Hutton Co., Coggeshall Hick and Field, Glore Co.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- "A distinct change in spirit within recent weeks" presaging possible improvement in economic conditions was noted tonight by Secretary Chapin in his radio debut as a member of the Cabinet. Speaking over the National Broadcasting Company's network, Mr. Chapin discussed in general President Hoover's nine-point program for economic relief, praising it as "a clear-cut and forceful statement of his constructive aim to bring about a happier picture."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Government scientists here expressed the belief today that measurements of cosmic radiation might have been obtained by Professor Auguste Piccard in his flight into the stratosphere over Switzerland which would be of great assistance to the scientists now at work on the polar year program at the College-Fairbanks Station in Alaska.

MANILA, Aug. 22. -- The departure of Governor General Theodore Roosevelt for the United States, to take part in President Hoover's campaign for re-election, has stirred up a wave of protest among American leaders in the Philippine Islands.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- World's trapshooting scores were smashed right and left today as class championships of North America were decided in the third day's events of the thirty-third annual Grand American Handicap tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Cotton cloth totaling 110,000 yards, first conversion of 500,000 bales of government-owned cotton, voted by Congress to clothe the needy, was ordered shipped to fifteen cities today by the Red Cross.
Small flats constituted the bulk of the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

When the American Trader of the American Merchant Lines arrived at Quarantine yesterday from London, the immigration officials were informed there was a stowaway on board who said he had hidden on the ship to get to America because he had no country to go to in Europe.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The stock markets opened generally firm today, although British funds were dull, with the exception that selling continued by speculators, easing prices further.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The legend of Cyrano de Bergerac, boasting Gasconada made immortal by Edmond Rostand, French playwright and poet, received its world premiere in operatic form here tonight on a huge, open-air stage, where the poet-swordsman here strutted to the music of a Russian composer.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Robert Moses Grove slammed a homer and a single to account for four runs and added a masterful exhibition of hurling today to give the Athletics an 8-to-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox and chalk up his nineteenth triumph of the season.

During an inquiry yesterday in the District Attorney's office into the shooting and killing of 19-year-old Miguel Gill by Patrolman John DeCarlo last Sunday in front of the youth's home at 318 West Fifty-second Street, the patrolman was ordered arrested by James T. Neary, Assistant District Attorney, in charge of the Homicide Bureau.

Patrolman Peter Coogan of the West Sixty-eighth Street station rode down Fifth Avenue about 5 A.M. yesterday in a Bellevue Hospital ambulance with nothing to trouble him but an alcoholic patient within. When the vehicle reached Thirtyfirst Street, he heard the shattering of glass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The text of the first monthly report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the secretary of the Senate and the clerk of the House under the terms of the unemployment relief act, made public today by the clerk of the House, follows :

Two workmen were killed, a third was injured and several had narrow escapes from death when a sixty-foot steel boom carrying a sixteen-ton girder broke in the New York Central Railroad yards at Tenth Avenue and West Eighteenth Street yesterday morning.

Wholesale market cash prices closed slightly higher. Spot cotton was at a new high for the year, up 15 points, together with advances in silk and rubber. Grains were steady, while dairy products and tin declined. Other staples remained unchanged.

BENTON, Ill., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Illinois's mine disorders shifted from Central to Southern Illinois today as one miner was killed and at least six other miners and a child were slightly wounded in two clashes at Zeigler, near here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Under a reorganization of the army structure, the armed land forces of the country have been grouped into four field armies as the force which will function for mobilization in event of a national emergency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. --Emphatic denial that his decision in favor of publicity for Reconstruction Finance Corporation reports was influenced by a desire to placate Speaker Garner, as charged by Representative Treadway, Republican, of Massachusetts, was made today by South Trimble, Clerk of the House, in a statement accompanying the publication of the first of the reports.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Discussion of "The World and Manchukuo" split the Institute of Politics today into two camps, one vigorously defending the actions of Japan in Manchuria and the other bitterly condemning them. A middle view, that of an American, balanced the conflict of motives and interests and offered a concrete suggestion of Japanese-Chinese cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Farm relief through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is expected by corporation officials to get under way in about three weeks.

The fifteenth season of concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium was brought to a close last night. Albert Coates conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in an all-Wagner program and Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay, the former Anna Case, appeared as the soprano soloist.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Shooting for the first time on a rifle range, a first-year student in the C.M.T. C., at Camp Dix, today, made a perfect score of 75 straight hits at 200 yards. He is Robert Hallahan of 427 Allen Avenue, Brooklyn. This feat was duplicated later by a fourth-year cadet, Student Sergeant Hartley Long of 147 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

Copyright, 1932. by The New York Times Company. All rights reserved. ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, Cape York, Greenland, Aug. 22. -- The Peary Memorial Monument at Cape York has been completed. One month from the day when the party landed and camp was made the slender shaft of the finished memorial rises nearly sixty feet into the air on the highest point of the cape, 1,500 feet above the sea.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Preparations for flights to the National Air Races at Cleveland, which open Saturday, were begun here today with the arrival of an entrant for a race to the field and the announcement that three members of the International Racing Team would leave Floyd Bennett Field tomorrow for Cleveland.

Setting an example which it is believed many other large enterprises are preparing to emulate, the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that an outlay of $5,000,000 had been authorized for replacements and improvements at its plants. At the same time, Myron C., Taylor, chairman, said in an interview that the general buying movement in the United States "cannot be long delayed."

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 23 -- Having played daily unceasingly for a week, the competitors in the international masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland, with the consent of the committee, agreed to a truce today and hostilities were abandoned for the day.

After making a careful inspection of the grandstands and bleachers to make certain there were no Dodgers lurking about for scouting purposes, as had been the case on Monday, Manager Joe McCarthy unveiled his cannonware at the Stadium yesterday and forthwith scouted the idea that the Yankees are in a batting slump.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Stanley M. Bruce, former Prime Minister of Australia, and H.S. Gullett, Minister of State for Trade and Customs, who were the two chief Australian delegates at the recent imperial conference at Ottawa, will arrive here tomorrow for a three days' visit and will be received by President Hoover.

A theory that control of the sex of an unborn child may be achieved by either lowering or raising the acid content of the expectant mother's blood stream was advanced here yesterday before the Third International Congress of Eugenics at its concluding sessions in the American Museum of Natural History by Dr. Jacob Sanders of Rotterdam, Holland.

Raoul Banet-Rivet, assistant managing director of the French Line in charge of operations, denied yesterday that the French Government contemplated a policy toward its merchant marine which would lessen control now exercised by the executives of private lines.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 23 -- Crushing her first round opponent, Miss Marion Callahan of Madison, Wis., and setting her second new course record in two days, Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City today marched on toward a second straight women's Western golf championship.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 23 -- The greatest battle in the history of Brazil, according to Federal informants, ended yesterday with the victory of 10,000 Federal troops over the Sao Paulo rebels.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23 -- This city will apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of at least $6,500,000 to carry out two municipal projects, it was announced by Mayor Congleton today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Apparent discrepancies in the alleged statement made here early today by Mrs. Mitzi Novak Downs, implicating her husband, Victor Downs, in the murder of Doc Frank Tuthill, eccentric character of Quogue on the night of Aug. 6, have led Assistant District Attorney L. Barron Hill to continue his investigation of Mrs. Downs in the hope of breaking down her story.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A teacher of Forestville, N.Y., despondent at her failure to obtain employment, hired an airplane here today for a ride and when 1,800 feet aloft over a wooded section near Annapolis leaped out of the open cockpit to her death.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Arbitration of all industrial questions involving workers and employes was urged today by Lieut. Gov. Lehman in an address to the State Federation of Labor, which opened its three-day convention with 500 delegates present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Hitler and Mussolini tactics are being followed by Colonel Thomas O'Higgins in the creation of a new White army in the Irish Free State, a sort of law-and-order army designed to check anarchy and secret organizations that threaten the government.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Boston Braves advanced, to fourth place in the National League race by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 to 3. today in the final contest of a five-game series.

Increased activity in the security and commodity markets was reflected yesterday in rising prices for memberships in the leading local Exchanges. A membership in the New York Stock Exchange was sold at $160,000, an increase of $10,000 from the previous sale, and the highest price since February.

The achievement by eugenics or its ultimate goal, the betterment of the human race, is impossible under the capitalistic system of economics, in which the profit motive predominates, the Third International Congress of Eugenics was told yesterday during its closing sessions at the American Museum of Natural History, by Professor H.J. Muller of the University of Texas.

The Transit Commission reported "progress" yesterday after another of its many conferences with Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company spokesmen on the proposal for unification of all rapid transit lines. The meeting was marked by the presence of Thomas L. Chadbourne and H.B. Swope, for the first time formally participating in these parleys.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Reinald Werrenrath, baritone, and Bruno Huhn, conductor and composer and for many years a Summer resident here, are arranging an evening of music at Guild Hall for Aug. 31. Mr. Werrenrath will sing several compositions by Mr. Huhn.

Financial requirements of the government for the third quarter of the year, which will necessitate the flotation on Sept. 15 of about $1,000,000,000 of securities for refinancing and other purposes, were discussed at length yesterday at a meeting held in the Federal Reserve Bank by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, officials of the Federal Reserve and leading bankers and government bond dealers.

Net income of the United Gas Corporation and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30 amounted to $6,728,055 after expenses, reserves for depreciation and depletion, minority interest, interest and taxes. This is equivalent, after dividends on the $7 preferred stock, to approximately $4 a share on 884,680 shares of $7 second preferred stock on which there are accumulations.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- The annual book and magazine drive in behalf of the American Merchant Marine Library Association and the Seamen's Church Institute of Newport will begin on Aug. 29 and continue to Sept. 3.

Jan Welzl, who has been classified by some readers of his story, "Thirty Years in the Golden North." as anamiable Munchausen of the Arctic and by others as a fiction, appears to be far from imponderable, according to a photograph of him just received by the American publishers of his book, the Macmillan Company.

Tammany Hall under the guidance of Mayor Walker, struck two blows at Governor Roosevelt yesterday. It denied renomination as the party candidate to Assemblyman Langdon W. Post, who heads a "Young Men for Roosevelt Movement," and pushed into up-State territory in an attempt to insure control of the next State convention that will nominate a candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Repercussions over publication of Reconstruction Corporation loans to banks and other institutions failed to materialize today and two Democrats on the House Banking Committee, Chairman Steagall of Alabama and Representative Hancock of North Carolina, expressed the belief that the publicity would have a beneficial effect on depositors of borrowing institutions.

The Commerce Department's classified statement on origin and destination of gold imported and exported during July shows that the month's exports went to five different countries, while imports came from thirty separate countries, of which eleven sent more than $100,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Enterprising minds have hatched a multitude of panaceas, for our economic troubles. Most of these have taken, the form of relief programs, such, as farm, unemployment and home-loan bills. While relief at this date is humane and essential, it is only half a program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Fraud orders issued by the Postoffice Department have resulted in a saving of billions of dollars which otherwise would have been lost by "gullible Americans" who sought to "beat the depression" by investing in foreign lotteries, according to Horace J. Donnelly, solicitor of the department.

Belief that the Democratic disaffection in New England, caused by the failure of the Democratic National Convention to nominate former Governor Alfred E. Smith for President, was diminishing and that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt would carry Massachusetts, was expressed yesterday by both Senator David I. Walsh of that State and Mayor James M. Curley of Boston.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Aug. 23 -- Bound on a voyage which will carry them to most of the capitals of Europe, George Hutchinson's "Flying Family" arrived at the St. John seaplane base in the Sikorsky amphibian City of Richmond at 4:05 P.M., Eastern Standard Time, today.

BARRE, Vt., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Clyde A. Lee of Oshkosh, Wis., and John Bochkon of Brooklyn, N.Y., took off for Harbor Grace, Nfld., at 9:15, Eastern Standard Time, today, on the first leg of a flight to Oslo, Norway.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP SALVOR, NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 23 -- We have definitely found the strongroom of the treasure ship Merida, and our divers are that much nearer the recovery of the $4,000,000 in gold and silver bullion and the probable wealth in jewels aboard the sunken liner.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Patsey Hanover, owned by W.S. Clayton of Freehold, N.J., won the feature event, the three-year-old pace, at the Orange County Fair races today in straight heats, defeating the Scottvue Stables' Comtessa in three stirring finishes.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Testimony at today's hearing before Governor Roosevelt in removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker follows: count that is referred to, the memorandum is a letter from Mr. -- or a memorandum from Mr. Max Block to Mr. Paul Block, it isn't the letter to Mr. Trosk that I was referring to in my examination.

An international movement of women to obtain the release from Italy of the family of the late Giacomo Matteotti, Socialist Deputy who was killed by Fascists in Rome some years ago, has been launched from London under the leadership of Sylvia Pankhurst, who has addressed an appeal to American women to join in the movement.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Aug. 23 (AP) -- One of three flying expeditions, bent on crossing the Atlantic had completed its first jump tonight, while the other two, planning to make Harbor Grace their first stop, were awaited anxiously here as darkness set in.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Four persons were brought to the Brooks Memorial Hospital here late this afternoon suffering from injuries received in an automobile accident at Westfield in which an automobile traveling east with the Sweet family of 12 East Eighty-first Street, New York, and a westbound car driven by Donald McMasters of Akron came together.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- For the first time since its inauguration in 1913, the Sanford Stakes fell to Willis Sharpe Kilmer, when his home-bred colt, Sun Archer, came from far back today to win in a thrilling stretch drive. Raymond Workman was in Sun Archer's saddle and scored a double on the day, as he previously had gotten home first with the Anall Stable's Larranaga in the Irish Lad Purse.

Scores of public officials and nearofficials have been journeying to Washington to see if they could obtain funds from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation under its enlarged powers, and if so on what terms. They have come home somewhat sobered.

The National Plays, Inc., has been formed as the first step in the plan of the Actors' Equity Association to establish a rotary stock production circuit. It is authorized by the incorporation papers to make "theatrical representations of all kinds."

THE stocky, gray-haired man with the horn-rimmed spectacles was introduced as the coach of the Australian Olympic track and field team, Ernest Richard Terry, better known as Mick Terry in the land they call Down Under. He was asked immediately about Boy Charlton, the famous Australian swimmer who was thought to be a world-beater and who finished nowhere in particular in the Los Angeles tank.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 23 -- Major Hallamaa, chief of the Aviation Bureau of the Finnish Ministry of Defense, has been dismissed, it was learned today, because of having divulged alleged military secrets to Commander Bruce Leighton, U.S.N.R., representative of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, of the United States, in connection with negotiations for the purchase of American airplane motors.

Who are the closest observers of the rise on the Stock Market and the signs of improving business? Undoubtedly the politicians and party managers. Others may Inspect the daily news and the reports and forecasts in the hope of getting light on what is going to happen to their investments, or to the companies in which they are interested.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Pat Malone held the Phillies to six hits today as the Cubs won, 5 to 1, to take a lead of three and one-half games over the idle Brooklyn Dodgers in the National League pennant race.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago gave Americans in Berlin some interesting and to them rather surprising news of Chicago at a luncheon given for him today by the American Club. Crime, said Mr. Cermak, has "practically" been eliminated from his city.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 23 -- The Riverside Yacht Club's Hoosier Girl, which finished last in the first two Star Class races for the midget championship of Long Island Sound yesterday and this morning, sprung a surprise this afternoon by winning the third race of the series of five.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Regulation of buses and other highway common carriers by the States and Federal Government is favored by the great mass of highway users, "contrary to the impression that the railroads are seeking to create," Thomas P. Henry, President of the American Automobile Association, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Aiming to "safeguard the financial health and physical well-being of its licensed companies," the Federal Power Commission made "an unqualified demand" today upon the Clarion River Power Company and the Pennsylvania Electric Company for a complete report on the latter's reported purchase of the Clarion River properties.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Cannonading three pitchers for fourteen hits, including five home runs, the Athletics today buried the Chicago White Sox under a 15 to 7 score to take the series, three games to one.
TORONTO, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Baltimore Orioles wound up their last visit to Toronto with a double victory over the Leafs today. They won the first game 9-1 and the second 2-1.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 23 (AP) -- World's harness racing records were bioken today during the second day of Grand Circuit racing at the Illinois State Fair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the recent fire at Coney Island, city officials, fire-prevention engineers and others have been working on plans to make the Boardwalks fireproof, at Coney Island, Rockaway and Atlantic City. It will cost the taxpayers almost $250,000 to reconstruct the Coney Island Boardwalk.

The annual outing of the New York State legislators from New York City was held at Rockaway Park yesterday, in the Park Inn Baths, but the time-honored tug-of-war between the wets and the drys went into discard because there was no one willing to own himself on the side of prohibition.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A financing plan to enable the fattening of Southwestern cattle on the abundant feed crops of the Middle West was disclosed today by Chicago packers with the announcement that already 14,000 Herefords had been moved from Kansas and Oklahoma ranges to Central Illinois fields.

DENVER, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A longer youth for the human race, brought about by the food factor in vitamin G, fresh conquests of disease and a general advance in the health of the world's population, was forecast before the American Chemical Society here today.

Paul Reynaud, member of the Chamber of Deputies for the Second Arrondissement of Paris and former Minister of Colonies and Minister of Finance in the Cabinets of Premiers Tardieu and Laval, arrived yesterday on the French, liner Ile de France en route to Washington to attend the annual convention of the American Bar Association from Sept. 12 to 15.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Canada's crack yachtsmen upon their arrival today for the international yachting series began immediate preparations to retain their laurels in the annual sloop series with the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association which will start here on Saturday.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- A largo number of buying orders brought about a good recovery on the Bourse today. Led by a remarkable rise in Canadian Pacific, the market began an upward movement right after the opening this morning. International stocks such as Rio Tinto, Royal Dutch and Central Mining made the host gains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Senator Barkley, who was temporary chairman of the Democratic National Contention, today challenged the accuracy of the State Department's denial that it had never approved foreign loans. He cited a statement made by Secretary Stimson in answer to a resolution of Senator Glass in which the Secretary said he acted under authority of Article II of the Constitution in approving or disapproving foreign loans.

Thor Solberg, a Brooklyn manufacturer, and Carl Petersen, co-pilot and radio expert, started for Oslo, Norway, via Harbor Grace, Nfld., at 5:43 A.M. yesterday from Floyd Bennett Field, the municipal airport on Barren Island.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers staged a two-run rally in the eighth Inning today to defeat the Red Sox, 5 to 4, and take the odd game of the five-game series.
WICHITA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Unable to release his faulty, retractable landing gear, Major James H. (Jimmy) Doolittle, noted speed pilot, staked his life on a skid landing here today and won.

F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War, was endorsed yesterday for the Republican nomination for Governor by the executive committee of the Republican County Committee in Nassau, where he lives. It was announced soon after from his home in Locust Valley, L.I., that from being merely a "receptive" candidate for the nomination, he now would become an active contender.

Justice John H. McCooey Jr. signed an order in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday requiring S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of 565 Fifth Avenue to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed and a temporary injunction issued restraining the corporation from the sale of securities except under certain restrictions.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Commenting on the prospects for success of the negotiations for improved commercial relations between France and the United States, which have just been begun, Le Temps tonight says:

After having gloomily predicted the decline of mankind unless something is done to stop the socially unfit from propagating, the eugenists ended their third international congress in New York. Thereupon the geneticists opened their sixth international congress at Ithaca, N.Y., to discuss the mechanism of heredity.

Secretary HURLEY, doubtless for the purpose of correcting an impression that prevails at Republican headquarters and elsewhere, has been good enough to inform the country that Gov. Gen. ROOSEVELT'S announced return from the Philippine Islands, from which he will sail on Sept. 15, is solely the result of his own wish and will.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- There was marked expansion in business on the Stock Exchange today and bullishness prevailed in all markets. The recent drop in British Government funds brought fresh support and prices recovered briskly.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Amy Johnson Mollison has planned to fly east to west across the Atlantic next month, and now is studying blind flying and piloting heavy airplanes at Hamble Air Field, Hampshire. Captain J.P. Saul, who made the east-to-west crossing with Kingsford-Smith, is eager to accompany her as navigator, but Mrs. Mollison says she wants to make the flight alone.

WINCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Gene Sarazen, British and American open champion, took a commanding lead of 6 up after eighteen holes of his thirty-six-hole exhibition match with Francis Ouimet, national amateur champion, at the Winchester Country Club today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES radio station WHD made radio contact with the airplane Enna Jettick at 10:30 A. M., Eastern Daylight Time, yesterday and thereafter exchanged the following messages, "Pete" being the signature of Carl Petersen:
WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The J. Ernest Stern Cup polo tournament got under way at the Norwood Country Club today with two games.

ISLAND PARK, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Alexander Rosenswaike, Chief of Police of this village, was removed from office by the Board of Trustees on a charge of accepting a bribe here today, following a secret meeting of the trustees last night. He was the second police head of a Nassau County community to be ousted from office within the last month.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 23 -- Two storms hit the Western amateur golf championship today.

Not in many years has big game been so plentiful as it promises to be for the coming hunting season in Canada, according to the results of a survey Just announced by the Canadian National Railways. The survey was made over a wide area and came from experienced and reliable guides and amateur hunters who live in the territories investigated.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- A vigorous defense of speculative commodity markets, including the Chicago Board of Trade, was made today in a public letter bearing the signature of Arthur W. Cutten, capitalist and trader. The letter is exceptional since Mr. Cutten ordinarily is reticent.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the third in a series of bridge tournaments held tonight at the clubhouse of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Several dinners were given before the tournament.

Selling of cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange was resumed yesterday by the Federal Farm Board or by cotton cooperatives following the cessation of such selling last Thursday. It was estimated in the trade that approximately 15,000 bales of Farm Board or cooperative cotton had been sold yesterday on the exchange.

VIENNA, Aug. 23 -- Karl Egon Alma and Dr. Fritz. Alma, partners in the banking concern of Alma Co., were arrested today in connection with alleged embezzlement in the placing of Upper Austria bonds on the New York market in 1925.

The Red Admiral stood upon one foot among the beech-mast, acorns and grain and dreamed of the wooded slopes and the sea-fronted crags. His bright eye was dimmed with ennui as he appraised the spectators. Instinctively he longed for the tall timber and the sweep of the open plain.

John Ellis Manley has been selected general secretary of the National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the organization, 420 Lexington Avenue. Mr. Manley is the fourth person to hold this office since it was created sixty-three years ago and succeeds Fred W. Ramsey, who had filled the position since the retirement of Dr. John R. Mott in 1928.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Limitation of the coming economic conference to consideration of two problems, expansion of credit to industry and agriculture and spread of employment, will be asked by President Hoover when business leaders from the twelve Federal Reserve districts meet here Friday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Washington Senators pounded three Cleveland pitchers for fourteen hits today, but were forced to go thirteen innings to win, 5 to 4.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Turning attention to the need for campaign funds, Governor Roosevelt will go on the air Thursday night with what is expected to be an appeal to the "forgotten man" for contributions for the party war chest.

Elmer Rice, who returned last week from Europe, will not attempt to establish a repertory theatre here this season, as was erroneously reported by his office, Mr. Rice is now rehearsing "Counsellor-at-Law,'' which will reopen at the Plymouth on Sept. 12 with Paul Muni in his original role.

More than 3,000 workers engaged in making dolls and stuffed toys in seventy-five shops in the city went on strike yesterday for more wages and better working conditions following a call by the Doll and Toy Workers' Union.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 23 -- Determined upon a march to Franklin County to force cessation of work in the coal mines at Zeigler tomorrow, 30,000 Central Illinois miners gathered tonight for what they termed a "peaceful picketing expedition," in protest against the $5 daily wage scale.

Improvement in cotton prices continued yesterday, and July contracts on the New York Exchange sold within 6 points of 8 1/2 cents a pound, the list ending 5 to 6 points higher than on Monday. Less than three months ago, July contracts sold below 5 cents.

DENVER, Aug. 23 -- The housewife's trouble with lumpy sugar may soon be a thing of the past, for H.V. Moss told the American Chemical Society today of a substance which, added in the manufacture of sugar, prevents lumping and caking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The special pleading of Secretary Mills shows conclusively to what lengths the Republicans have been driven to bolster up their claims of efficiency. They have assisted a large number of banks, large and small, by loans of the taxpayers' money, fo sooth, but have done nothing to remove the causes or continuance of the depression.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Added to "A Plea for Beauty" of Elizabeth G. Dow an today's TIMES goes my own for a clear-cut working definition of "Beauty," with the help of which one could tell apart all beauty from all ugliness. Till now I thought that I can tell a beautiful building when I see one.

An Unsuspected American Isle. Nearly 405,000 Americans make their home in foreign countries, by no means all of them domiciled at San Jean de Luz and St. Juan les Pins and engaged in putting the last touches to that novel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A late issue of your paper, under a Washington, D.C., date line, carries the announcement that the board of strategy of the Republican National Committee has decided to recall from his Far Eastern post for the duration of the Presidential campaign the recently appointed Governor General of the Philippine Islands, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., to speak for Mr. Hoover's candidacy.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. J. Cheever Cowdin, who have been passing the Summer in Au Sable Forks, N.Y., are at the Carlyle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Hoboken Manufacturers Railroad Company sought today permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue three-year 6 per cent notes for $320,000, the funds to be used to buy rolling stock, improve terminals and dredge the harbor.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 23 -- When the Institute of Politics lifted the curtain today on the problem of national economic planning it revealed two Harvard professors making a gingerly approach toward the question, while one business man plunged boldly into the discussion with a concrete scheme which was severely criticized by a British and a German economist.

Our Ambassador in Paris and the French Minister of Commerce have begun informal negotiations for a new commercial treaty. France has revived the "quota" system of war days and used it effectively to curtail imports of wheat, leather, rubber fabrics, machine tools, electrical apparatus and other goods produced in the United States.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- Reports are current again here that the plan to merge the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation has been revived and that a deal is under way for an exchange of common shares on an even basis.
DES MOINES, Aug. 23 (AP) -- As softening of its campaign from compulsion to persuasion was demanded in several sectors, the farmers' holiday movement rolled on today into new territory.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The final lot of Rancocas Stable mares and yearlings, as well as the stallion Lucullite, were sold in the Fasig-Tipton paddock tonight for $38,100. The receipts for the two nights of the Rancocas Stable sale, for the entire stock of one stallion, forty-two mares and thirty-three yearlings, totaled $79,225.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23 -- The Socialist party, for the first time within the memory of election bureau officials, filed a full slate of candidates for county and legislative offices as the time for filing designations for the primary closed at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The more liberal drys of the country, many of whom are puzzled over the best method to achieve their end, are planning an active campaign for the re-election of President Hoover, according to an announcement made today by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Monty Dewire, farmer of Hamilton, Ind., and Mrs. H.S. Grigsby, Oklahoma City hotel owner, today won the North American clay target championship in their respective divisions.

The Sanitation Department stepped to the forefront in the city's economy program yesterday by announcing a budget reduction of $2,001,481 for next year, with most of the saving effected in personal service expenditures.

In order to erect and defend "a "platform to the free and liberal "expression of progressive thought " * * * on the problems of the day," ALFRED E. SMITH has decided to become an editor. It is an interesting step in a great public career. The New Outlook deserves the felicitations it doubtless will be receiving on heading its staff with a man whose views influence a large group of Americans.

Alfred E. Smith, who was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination two months ago, became the editor yesterday of The New Outlook, a non-partisan monthly magazine, the first issue of which will appear on Sept. 25.

After a further advance, which carried many active shares to the high point of this upward movement, the stock market yielded, irregularly, evidently under pressure of realizing sales. As markets traditionally go, it was high time that the forward impetus should have relaxed; much longer uninterrupted continuance of the rise at the recent pace would have honeycombed the market with speculative commitments.

Four men, in the act of moving their furniture from an apartment at 135 Barclay Street, Newark, were taken into custody yesterday by the police there for questioning with regard to the Harrison, N.J., sack murders and a third slaying, the victim of which was found last Sunday morning in the marshes near Monmouth Beach.

Lord Weir, former Secretary of State and president of the Aircraft Council of England, sails today for his homeland in the Cunardier Mauretania. Also on board, bound for Plymouth, Cherbourg and Southampton are: J.B. Forbes-Watson, Albert Coates, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestre; A.M.
