Hayman, Moir Mackenzie, delegate to the Empire Economic Conference at Ottawa; Marquis Guadalimam, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Prince.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The crack Japanese team of Jiro Satoh and Takeo Kubawara passed out of the tournament today as all six of the seeded American combinations advanced to the quarter-final round of the national tennis doubles championship with H.W. Austin and Frederick J. Perry of England and Henri Cochet and Marcel Bernard of France.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club won the low gross honors in the oneday tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Sands Point Club today after matching cards with Mrs. L.C. Rosenberg of Salisbury.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Higher prices for wheat prevailed today on the Board of Trade here, but buying was not sufficient to absorb all the profittaking and selling against orders that appeared above 55 cents a bushel for the December, and the close was at intermediate figures, with net gains of 1/2 to 5/8 cent.

A few hours after Mrs. Caroline Weeks, 24-year-old mother of two children, had been found strangled to death in her home at 380 Eighty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, her father-in-law, Charles E. Weeks, admitted that he had killed her, the police announced last night.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Neither the Reich nor the Prussian Government will be influenced by threats or political pressure in enforcing President von Hindenburg's recent anti-terrorist ordinances, they made it clear tonight in a statement given to the press with the information that the government would like to see it on every front page.

A plan for a comprehensive reorganization of the Central Public Service Corporation, affecting its entire $357,000,000-system and including the formation of two new corporations, was announced by the management yesterday. The plan, which is entirely voluntary, substantially simplifies the capital structure of the system and stabilize its financial position.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) -- President Hoover today assured Senator Smoot of Utah that the silver question would be discussed at the World Economic Conference and that he would appoint some one representing the silver point of view as a member of the American, delegation.

In the second heaviest trading of the year to date, 117 issues on the New York Stock Exchange established new highs yesterday and the general level of prices was advanced well above the closing quotations of Monday. The market lost part of its gains in an afternoon reaction, but ended the day with net advances in active issues ranging from a fraction to more than 3 points.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Russell T. Sherwood was able to "gamble without a risk," Samuel Ungerleider, a broker associated with J.A. Sisto in taxicab financing, admitted today while testifying before Governor Roosevelt in Mayor Walker's defense. He denied that the missing accountant's connection with the Mayor helped win him the place of a preferred customer.

Paul Kelly has been engaged for an important role in "The Pure in Heart," the John Howard Lawson play which will be the Theatre Guild's second production of the season. As previously announced, June Walker and Osgood Perkins also will figure prominently in the play.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Larry French, dapper Pirate southpaw, bobbed up as a Giant-queller again today for the second time in the series, and the Terry battalion was turned back, 4 to 3. The six-game series ended with honors even.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Lady Louis Mountbatten and the Marchioness of Milford Haven, both relatives of the royal family, will leave England next week on an adventurous trip into the Persian desert. They will take with them neither companions, servants nor luggage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Norman H. Davis of New York, who was one of the American delegates to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva, was the luncheon guest of President Hoover at the White House today and reported at length on the disarmament problem.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 23 -- John Hay Whitney's Greentree riders welcomed their regular back, H.W. (Rube) Williams, in his return to action today by breaking into the winning column in the Knos Cups high goal polo series. The victors had lost three previous starts.
Money market continued dull. The official call rate was 2 per cent, with the usual fund on the outside at 1 per cent. Other rates remained unchanged.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Two of the happiest men in baseball, on their own say-so, sat back in their chairs today and watched ink dry on a piece of paper that settled the management of the Chicago Cubs for another year.
MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 23 (Canadian Press.) -- The following protective committee for first mortgage bondholders of Price Brothers Co., was announced as formed today:

President Hoover will deliver at least three addresses in his campaign for re-election, according to an announcement made yesterday at the headquarters of the Republican National Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria by Senator Felix Hebert of Rhode Island, Eastern campaign, manager.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- A new decree against "speculation" -- directed against private trade by non-producing middlemen -- instructs Ogpu (the secret police) and local authorities to suppress it energetically, with a penalty of up to ten years in concentration camp for violations.

An imposing list of universities, State school superintendents, sectarian educators and all kinds of teachers is to be found backing the proposed legislation to allocate 15 per cent of the radio facilities of the country to educational institutions. It is nothing to wonder at that the broadcasters oppose such measures.

The directors of the Commodities Finance Corporation, the $50,000,000 company formed by New York banks to finance the purchase, carrying and marketing of commodities for raw material users, held their organization meeting yesterday and elected as president Mortimer N. Buckner, chairman of the New York Trust Company.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 23 -- A prediction that conditions would be "back to normal by 1934" was made by Roger W. Babson, business statistician, in an address before members of the Board of Trade at a luncheon here today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Federal forces operating against the rebels of Sao Paulo reported today that among prisoners taken yesterday was a son of former President Washington Luis.

Five persons, in addition to eight named in an original indictment, have been made defendants in the government's investigation of the activities of the National Diversified Corporation, it was revealed yesterday when a sealed indictment was opened in Federal court and three of the new defendants were arraigned.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- It will take one more race to determine the champion women's yacht crew of Long Island Sound. Three more elimination contests were held today by the American Yacht Club. Miss Lorna Whittelsey skippered the Indian Harbor Club's Clown to two victories, and one was taken by Mrs. Willis Wood at the helm of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club craft Zest.

Football, for the first time in the history of the sport at City College, showed a profit last year, according to the annual financial report of the City College Athletic Association for the period from July 1, 1931 to June 30, 1932, released yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics at C.C.N.Y.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Mrs. Thomas Clark Howard, Miss Sarah Woodward and Miss Anne S.P. Chew have been added to the list of young women who will act as models in the fashion, show Friday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Skirvin Adams for the benefit of the American Merchant Marine Library Association.

The next meeting of the advisory committee of German creditors under the "standstill" agreement, which is scheduled for Oct. 1, probably will be held in this city. Definite arrangements for holding the meeting here have not been made, but a proposal to do so was advanced at the last meeting, held in London at the beginning of July.

PARIS, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press). -- After a visit to the Russian Embassy here today, John Amery, son of L. S. Amery. said the legal Chancellor had offered to obtain passport visas so that he and Una Evelyn Wing. 22-year-old actress, could be married at a frontier town in Latvia.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Aug. 24 (AP) -- East met West here tonight when Roy Hunt of Norman, Okla., and Chappy Lenox of New Haven, Conn., led their respective air caravans of the National Air Derby into Bartiesville.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Ted Lyons and Frank Grube, battery for the White Sox, collected six hits between them today as Chicago rapped three Red Sox pitchers to win the opening game of the series, 7 to 3. Stumpf hit a home run into the right-field pavilion with one on in the third.

The State of Illinois, whose finances were strengthened recently by the granting of a loan of $3,000,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, borrowed $1,000.000 yesterday on approximately a 4.04 per cent basis. The loan took the form, of an issue of $1,000,000 of 4 per cent waterway bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1939, which was awarded through competitive bidding at a price of 99.76.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- A stir was caused at the White House today when Edward T. Clark, who was confidential secretary to ex-President Coolidge, appeared at the desk usually occupied by Theodore G. Joslin, private secuetary to Mr. Hoover since a year ago March.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24. -- After eating a sandwich in the municipal airport's restaurant. Amelia Earhart Putnam brushed the crumbs off her hands, climbed aboard her transatlantic Lockheed monoplane and shot away toward the Atlantic Coast at 12:26.54 P.M. today.

MADRID, Thursday, Aug. 25. -- Spain was on guard early today against a new Royalist outbreak while the Supreme Court secretly debated the fate of General Jose Sanjurjo and three aides for participation in a revolt two weeks ago.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The wounds of Hyman Stark and the manner of their infliction with blackjacks, corrugated rubber hose, fists and feet were described to a jury in Supreme Court here today by District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards as he opened his case against five Nassau County policemen on trial for manslaughter, charged with having beaten to death Stark who attacked and robbed the mother of a brother officer.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 24. -- Amnesty involving about 20,000 offenders, convicted under the recently ended prohibition law, but who have not yet served their sentences, partly because of congestion, in the prisons, is contemplated by the Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Louisville Nashville Railroad was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to abandon its seventy-seven-mile railroad from Frankfort, Ky., to Irvine.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24.--A project for the erection, of a hotel, bus terminal, automobile service station, and garage on a site opposite Newark Airport at a cost of $500,000 was disclosed here today by Mayor Jerome.T. Congleton. Mayor Congleton said that he had prepared a resolution to be introduced at a meeting of the city commission next Wednesday to authorize a fifty-year lease of land owned by the city adjacent to the airport.

American Safety Razor Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries -- Six months ended June 30: Net profit after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, $304,802, equal to $1.52 a share on 200,000 no par shares, against $505,744, or $2.53 a share, for first half of 1931.

A new form of investment trust, combining features of both the general management and the fixed types, but differing from the established forms of either, has been organized by Calvin Bullock, Inc., sponsor of more investment trusts than any other Wall Street institution.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Football secrets of the late Knute Rockne of Notre Dame and Pop Warner of Stanford University and formerly of Pittsburgh will be revealed by famous coaches at the first annual Villanova College Coaching School, which opened today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church urged its followers today to ignore the Presidential candidates in November and to vote for the election of dry members of Congress who will uphold the Eighteenth Amendment.

In a statement issued yesterday from her office in the State Building, Miss Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, challenged the veracity of figures given out in Washington for publication last Monday purporting to show that industrial conditions were improving and that there was evidence of expansion of employment opportunities.

The immediate development of five large park areas in the New York region into self-sustaining recreation centres is advocated by the Regional Plan Association, Inc., in a bulletin to be published next week, as a specific measure to meet the growing demands for improved and extended public park areas and to provide useful employment for the jobless.
Alfred E. Smith, Mayor Walker and John F, Curry head Tammany's slate of delegates to the State convention, inspection of the lists on file in the Board of Elections revealed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The text of the address delivered, before the Japanese Diet by Count Uchida, as made public tonight by the Japanese Embassy, was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Adhering to its policy that loans to States and municipalities are only for those that help themselves, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation advanced $225,000 today to the City of Birmingham and Jefferson County, Ala.

BENTON, Ill., Aug. 24. -- Routed by scattering gunfire in a clash in the darkness with Sheriff's deputies, 10,000 striking coal miners were turned temporarily from the Franklin County line late tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's Watch Him won the feature event at Hawthorne today over the mile and sixteenth route. Playdale was second and Rehoboth, early pacemaker, was third in the Worth Purse.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 25. -- Anti-Japanese terrorist activities of boycott organizations are growing more intense and Japanese forces began today patrolling three streets here where Japanese business centres.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Miss Lorna Whittelsey still is the champion woman, skipper of Long Island Sound. Besides settling that point today, she earned the right to defend her Atlantic Coast class title in the contest for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup, which starts off Cohasset, Mass., Sept. 6.

Nothing is more important in the Regional Plan for New York and its environs than recreation grounds, including bathing beaches. Until the Interstate Park was thrown open many New Yorkers had little conception of what delights the freedom of outdoors held for them.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Colonel William J. Donovan, active Republican candidate for Governor, sneaking here today on the same program with Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse, who has been called a "receptive" candidate, termed Governor Roosevelt, Democratic Presidential nominee, "a candidate sniping at President Hoover's program."

Conrad H. Mann of Kansas City, Presidential appointee to the National Business Conference, and four other defendants who were indicted last Thursday with United States Senator James J. Davis, following an investigation of lotteries allegedly conducted by three fraternal orders, entered pleas of not guilty when they were arraigned yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

A painful lack of clear thinking and straight talking appears in the correspondence between Mr. HOOVER and the Chairman of the Prohibition Allied Forces, the Rev. Dr. POLING. The President Irankly states that he no longer agrees with the methods and plans of the national prohibitionists.

The Citizens' Budget Commission widened its field of study of the 1933 budget yesterday by forming an auxiliary committee of 140 representatives of civic and business organizations in the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The principal achievement of the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa was a demonstration to the world of what ought to be done in the struggle for economic recovery, Stanley M. Bruce, former Prime Minister of Australia and leader of that country's delegation to the conference, said in an interview tonight.

The annual convention of the New York State American Legion will open at 10 o'clock this morning in the Grand Ball Boom of the Brooklyn Elks Club, Boerum Place and Livingston Street, Brooklyn, with 1,184 delegates and alternates present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I call your attention to a letter I wrote to The Law Journal the other day with reference to the topic of jury lees in the Municipal Court, which subject is discussed by Mr. Schneider in THE TIMES of Aug. 22?
PROVIDENCE, Aug. 24. -- The following address teas made by Secretary Hurley at Rocky Point today and was broadcast tonight over a National Broadcasting Company chain:

Captain James A. Mollison, who arrived in New York last Sunday at the end of his solo flight from London, cut down on his program of luncheons and sightseeing yesterday in an attempt to obtain some rest in preparation for his return flight. He learned from Dr. James H. Kimball that conditions were becoming worse rather than better over the Atlantic and he gave up all hope of starting today.

Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of mammals and reptiles at the New York Zoological Park, the Bronx, is to sail today on the United Fruit steamship Calamares for Panama to search for the bushmaster, one of the rarest of vipers, which is found in the forests along the banks of the Chagres River.
ROME, Aug. 24 (AP). -- It was learned today from a reliable source that Premier Mussolini is considering conversion of the Italian public debt after the example of England.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The large banks in New York City, Chicago and other Federal Reserve centres possess unused power to issue 70 per cent of the $917,000,000 in new national bank notes possible under the Glass-Borah temporary currency expansion program, the reserve board stated today.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The only way to end unemployment is to establish a universal five-day week and six-hour day, said William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in addressing the convention of the State Federation of Labor today.

PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 24. -- Four Brooklyn terminal companies, whose suit to restrain the Pennsylvania Railroad from starting its proposed motor-freight trucking service in the New York area was dismissed in Federal Court heve "Wednesday, won the right today to appeal from the decision.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Judge John M. O'Connor found John Bain, his sons, Robert and John H. Bain, and son-in-law, W. Merle Fisher, guilty of conspiracy today to defraud creditors of their twelve banks and indicated that he would sentence the elder Bain tomorrow to eighteen, months in the penitentiary.

GARWOOD, N.J., Aug. 24. -- There were no bidders for Garwood's issue of $225,000 bonds, including $186,000 sewer bonds and $39,000 assessment bonds. Borough Clerk Walter Mc-Manus announced today. Bids were scheduled to be received last night. Mr. McManus said the borough had sixty days in which to sell the bonds privately.

An offer to purchase the American Republics Line, owned by the government and operating between Boston, New York, South Atlantic ports and the east coast of South America, has been submitted by Moore McCormack, 5 Broadway, to the United States Shipping Board, it became known yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 25. -- The plainest defense yet heard of Japan's policy in regard to Manchuria was made this morning by the Foreign Minister, Count Yasuya Uchida, in his address to the House of Peers in opening the special session of the Imperial Diet.

"WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Cotton shippers in the lower Mississippi Valley this year will ship their cotton at the lowest freight rates on record. For the first time they will have carload rates and the Federal barge lines on the Mississippi will meet the railroad rates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Shipping Board today approved an agreement signed by the America France Line, Baltimore Mall Steamship Company, Inc., Compagnie Generale Transatiantique, County Line (Intercontinental Transport Services, Ltd.) and United States Lines, effective from this date.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- After a dull morning session on the Bourse today the market took a sudden spurt in the afternoon and a flood of buying orders sent prices climbing. Suez Canal, Rio Tinto Copper and Royal Dutch Oil again made the best gains, but French Industrials, electricals and banks also rose.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- At the Orange County Fair Grounds today the 3-year-old Invader broke the world's record for trotters of that age by racing the second mile heat over the half-mile track in 2:05 3/4. The previous world's record for 3-year-old trotters on half-mile tracks was 2:06 1/4.

Following is the full text of the plan for economic recovery and stabilization worked out by the board of directors of the Advertising Club of New York, concurred in by the American Federation of Labor and approved by officials of the Advertising Federation of America and the Association of National Advertisers:

Continuation of adequate service at the Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases rests with, the public, Fred M. Stein, president, declared yesterday in the annual report, made public through,the United Hospital Fund. Mr. Stein reported that despite every possible economy, including a voluntary pay cut of $40,000, the net dificit for 1931 was $103,251, or more than double that of 1930.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent address of Mark Graves, Director of the Budget, over WGY, relative to reductions in the State budget, was an interesting and timely contribution to the important subject of the high "cost of government.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- Efforts were made in a conference between Centrist and National Socialist leaders to resume negotiations for a temporary coalition in the Prussian Diet and the Reichstag which would provide a parliamentary government for Germany, "tolerating" or dispensing with the von Papen Cabinet, as seemed more desirable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some newspapers found material in an incident of police jurisdiction which caused the arrest of one Carlos Duran. To the court he made the untruthful assertion that Rafael Estrella Urena is Vice President of the Dominican Republic.

Text of Advertising Club's plan for economic recovery, Page 12. What was characterized as the first direct step ever taken to bring about joint, action by industry, commerce and labor in a plan for economic recovery and stabilization was announced yesterday by the Advertising Club of New York.

Application for the listing of $31,672,100 of certificates of deposit for Interborough Rapid Transit Company ten-year secured convertible 7 per cent gold notes has been made to the New York Stock Exchange. Holders of the notes are to have at least thirty days to deposit them under the agreements of July 19 between them and the committee headed by J.P. Morgan.

Aurora and The Hurricanes will meet Sept. 3 in the first game of the open championship, most important of the polo season's events, according to the announcement of the draw made last night by the United States Polo Association.

Mount Washington during Winter is to harbor on its summit a group of scientific observers. The plan may be considered a part of the Washington Bicentennial Celebration, as well as of the second polar year program. From the peak bearing the name of Washington there is to be special communication and cooperation with the rest of the world, though with no entangling alliances.

A narcotic speakeasy, frequented, according to the police, by children as well as adults, was raided at 6 P.M. yesterday by detectives and Federal agents at 310 East 107th Street, a block from the scene of last year's "baby killing" -- a killing believed to have been the result of a narcotic gang war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- President Hoover presented the Congressional Medal of Honor today to Commander Claude A. Jones for extraordinary heroism outside the regular line of duty when the old Memphis was destroyed by a hurricane and tidal wave off Santo Domingo on Aug. 29, 1916.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug." 24. -- Enmity-aroused among the, Hitlerites by Professor Emil Gumbel's anti-Fascist writings was the explanation advanced here today by the German educator for his dismissal from the faculty of the University of Heidelberg.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The Royal Geographical Society learned in a laconic message from Greenland today of the death of H.G. Watkins, leader of the British Arctic Air Route Expedition. The message said:

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- Evidence of a highly skilled and artistic civilization that existed in Palestine in the Middle Bronze Age, about 1700 B.C., has been dug from a huge mound at ancient Kiryath Sephr, now known as Tellbeit Mirsim, near Hebron.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 24 (AP). -- E.L. Oliver of Cincinnati, director of research for the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, Freight Handlers and Express and Station Employes, declared before the Shannon Congressional committee today that practices of the Postoffice Department in fixing parcel post rates would, unless stopped, make it necessary for the two largest express companies to go out of business.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Deputy sheriffs and farmers attempting to blockade roads leading into Omaha clashed tonight for the second time during the day.
HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Two American airplanes rested on Newfoundland soil tonight, one a ruined reminder of transatlantic hopes, the other with its nose pointed toward the east.

Copyright, 1932, by The North American Newspaper Alliance. CAMP FOUR, NANGA PARBAT, Kashmir, Aug. 14 (By runner to Astor, Aug. 24.) -- The weather is taking a drastic and perhaps even fatal hand in our effort to climb to the top of Nanga Parbat.

F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War, and the latest to enter his name in the now lengthened list of active contenders for the Republican nomination for Governor, in the course of a Visit yesterday to Republican national headquarters, voiced the opinion that Governor Roosevelt already was aware that his home State was lost to him and with it the Presidency.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Frank Samuels of the Sunningdale Golf Club led a field of sixty-two starters in the one-day Westchester County golf tournament, held today over the Westchester Country Club's west course.

Taking cognizance of "sensational facts disclosed" in connection with purchases and sales of securities by officers and directors of corporations, Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, made a report yesterday on the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's investigation of stock market practices, and in it he said the Exchange "has no control over corporate officers, but is unalterably opposed to the misuse of confidential information."
Dictators and Decalogues. ADOLF HITLER demands more than, leniency for his five followers sentenced to death for the murder of a Communist opponent under peculiarly atrocious circumstances.

TOKYO, Aug. 6.--A "Japanese Monroe Doctrine" for all Asia from Suez to Kamchatka, except American and European colonies and possessions, was first suggested by President Theodore Roosevelt, says Viscount Kentaro Kaneko, a Privy Councillor, in an article he will contribute to the September number of "Contemporary Japan," the organ of the Foreign Affairs Association of Japan.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP). -- A program of opposition to further railroad consolidations until Congress enacts legislation protecting labor from resulting unemployment was determined upon today by the Railway Labor Executive Association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Unable to conduct a successful assault upon the pitching of Charley Root and Bob Smith, the Dodgers today went down to defeat in the opening game of the important series with the league-leading Cubs, 7 to 4. A pennant-mad crowd of nearly 30,000 cheered the Cubs on to victory.

The Hudson Theatre, recently redecorated and refurnished, will reopen the week of Sept. 19 under the direction of Harry Askin and Hugh Ford. The former will manage the house, while the latter will supervise the productions made there.

Although there is still an "almost complete stagnation in buying by such important consuming groups as the automobile industry and the railroads," there has been a moderate seasonal increase in orders for some steel products from miscellaneous sources, according to The Iron Age.

The upward movement of prices of domestic bonds on the Stock Exchange, which had been interrupter by only two minor setbacks this month, was reversed yesterday and a long list of issues in the railroad, utility and industrial groups lost 1 to more than 9 points for the day.

Once more Tammany Hall has notified a member that those who fail to "go along" will not be permitted to hold office. Assemblyman POST made the Tenth District Democratic and distinguished himself at Albany, thereby winning credit for Tammany, which had nominated him.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 24 -- Accusing the Democratic party of having "no program" and its present standard bearer of suggesting none "save the vague reference to a new deal," Secretary of War Patrick J. Hurley today made reply to the Ohio speech of Governor Roosevelt.

An outstanding supporter of Alfred E. Smith at the Democratic National Convention, former United S.tates Senator Peter Goelet Gerry, leader of the Democratic forces in Rhode Island has taken his stand definitely under the Roosevelt banner.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24. -- Fond Giant dreams of gaining a tie for sixth place with the world's champions by winning today's game were smashed by the young pitching ace of the Cardinals, Jerome (Dizzy) Dean,' whose rangy form dominated the 6 to 2 St. Louis victory in the series opener.
ALBANY, Aug 24. -- Governor Roosevelt snatched a few hours from his duties with the Walker hearing tonight to draft two speeches to be made in the next three days.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 -- Decisively outplayed in the first two sets and apparently headed toward summary defeat when they trailed at 0 -- 2 in the third chapter, Henri Cochet and Marcel Bernard of France staged a remarkable rally today to defeat Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, and Gregory Mangin of Newark in the national doubles tennis championship, at the Longwood Cricket Club.

TORONTO, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Toronto lost its second double-header in two sucessive days when the Albany Senators opened a six-game series today with two victories, each won by the same score, 4 to 3, the first in twelve innings and the second in seven.

Of all birds that make joyous music give us the campaign songsters. These minstrels, Republican and Democratic, must enjoy their art, though their profuse strains are poured out on a too cold, unfeeling public. Yesterday Boston's sweet singer -- succeeding "Honey FITZ," retired -- was in our city, chirping into the happy ears of Chairman FARLEY.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 24. -- Lieutenant Raymond P. Rutledge and Sergeant Orville B. Simmons, mechanic, of the United States Marine Corps, were tolled in an airplane crash at 5 P.M. today, when the lieutenant attempted to drop a message to a ground patrol.

Eng Su-foon and his ten partners in the Lung Wet Wash. Laundry Company, 426 East 109th Street, broke away from the traditions of their forefathers yesterday, but soon reverted to them, convinced of the incomprehensibility of Occidental ways.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- Setting an example to other departments, the French Ministry of Finance will publish tomorrow an official notice that from Oct. 1 all salaries and wages in the department will be cut 5 per cent. In this Ministry alone the saving effected will be $4,000,000 a year.

DUBLIN, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press). -- A new Irish "army" appeared today, sponsored by Frank Aiken, Minister of Defense, and bearing the name of the National Guard. It is understood to be a volunteer reserve in which young men weaned from the Irish Republican Army will be trained and drilled to protect the government of President Eamon da Valera against extremist threats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Please accept my appreciation for your fair and accurate editorials about Spain. At the same time allow me to say a few words to the Jesuit father Laurence K. Patterson. He says: "The churches do not exist in Spain; there is but-one church there, the Catholic."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Marguerita Sylva, who had planned to present "Carmen" at her open-air theatre in Sherwood Forest, Oakland, on Saturday, today was compelled to give up the venture. She wanted to aid the unemployed musicians, but found the expense of an orchestra of thirty musicians and the chorus of thirty singers, together with other overhead items, would leave little for the jobless.

The Indians, who at one time this year were harboring serious pennant ambitions, invaded the Stadium yesterday to open their final series of the year on the Harlem. Although their intentions may have been of the best, they were almost run off the reservation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The first major step in, the administration's program of relief to home owners through the liquidation of about $20,000,000,000 in frozen mortgages was taken today by the Home Loan Bank Board when it divided the United States and Territorial possessions into twelve separate districts and assigned to each a specified capitalization on which the district bank will operate.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 24 -- In disposing of Herman Steiner of New York in the seventh round, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris today opened a bigger gap between himself and one of the quartet pursuing him most closely in the international masters' tournament at the California Chess Congress.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 24 -- Charles (Chick) Evans, Chicago's famous veteran of the fairways, turned back the challenge of youth in the Western amateur golf championship today, only to be eliminated by another veteran.

Fee splitting, although condemned as unethical by the American Medical Association, cannot be considered prima facie evidence of fraud, the grievance committee of the State Board of Medical Examiners ruled yesterday at the preliminary hearing of charges that Dr. William H. "Walker, brother of the Mayor, and four other physicians divided fees in connection with city compensation cases.

Total revenues of manufactured and natural gas utilities in the first half of this year were $347,288,325, compared with $374,229,461 in the first six months of 1931, a decline of 7.2 per cent, according to the American Gas Association. Customers of the 409 reporting companies numbered 13,931,649 on June 30, compared with 14,224,242 the year before.

A charge of attempted extortion against Patrolman James C. Creed of the West Thirtieth Street station was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Erwin in Washington Heights Court. The magistrate refused to permit Assistant District Attorney Irving Mendelsohn to ask the policeman what he had been doing in a speakeasy at 687 Lenox Avenue on Aug. 1, when he arrested Lewis Foto, alleged bartender, on a charge of violating the Volstead act.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Fifty amateur golfers from all parts of New York State, New Jersey and New England will start play tomorrow at the Sagamore Golf Club in the second annual tournament for the Sagamore Cup. The tourney ends on Saturday.

WINSTON SALEM, N.C., Aug. 24 (AP). -- R.J. Reynolds Jr., heir to the tobacco fortune founded by his-father, said here today he believed his younger brother, Smith, shot to death at the Reynolds home July 6 after a liquor party, was murdered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Frederic M. Sackett, Ambassador to Germany, and Norman H. Davis of New York, member of the American delegation to the disarmament conference at Geneva and Under-Secretary of State in the Wilson Administration, were appointed by President Hoover today as the American members of the organizing committee for the international monetary and economic conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Senators turned back the Tigers, 2 to 1, in the opener of a four-game series today as Monte Weaver hung up his nineteenth victory of the season.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 24 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's Lout won the midget championship for Sea Class boats on Long Island Sound today at the conclusion of a three-day meet in which five races were sailed by ten of the leading Sound club entries.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- The danger of financial and political chaos in the New York City Government if Mayor Walker is removed by Governor Roosevelt, was predicted today by John J. Curtin in a brief filed in the Supreme Court.

After the rapid and sustained recovery on the Stock Exchange, widely ascribed to the belief that it foreshadowed trade revival, there has apparently arisen a feeling of perplexity, if not disappointment, that the course of general business is so slow in fulfilling the expectation.
Money market continued inactive. Loans renewed at 2 per cent, with outside funds quoted at 1 per cent. Other rates were unchanged.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Pirates scored six runs in the first two innings today and then surrendered to the Phillies, 9 to 6, in the first of their four-game series.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin, motion-picture comedian, filed suit today in an attempt to prevent film careers planned for his two small sons by his former wife, Lita Grey Chaplin.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24. -- Twenty-one new cases of infantile paralysis were reported in this city today as officials of the Department of Health, with the cooperation of physicians and hospital clinics, sought to control the disease which has caused an average of one death a day since Aug. 1, and is threatening to assume the proportions of an epidemic.

BUFFALO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Home runs by Reis and Jordan in the eighth and ninth frames tied and then won the game for Jersey City in the opener of a series with the Buffalo Bisons today. The score was 6 to 5. Fine relief pitching by Les Sweetland and hard hitting by Fresco Thompson also featured the contest.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The Huron Handicap for the second time fell to a son of Man o' War when the Glen Riddle Farm's War Hero, winner of the Travers last Saturday, duplicated the feat of Crusader in 1926 and scored in a driving finish today at Saratoga.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Brother Hanover, the Hanover Shoe Farm's entry, of Hanover, Pa., circled the oval in two heats in 2:06 3/4 to win the National Handicap trot at the Illinois State Fair Grand Circuit races today.

The frreverent and anonymous authors of "Washington Merry-Go-Round" have continued their gossipy appraisal of Washington personalities in "More Merry-Go-Round," which will be published today by Liveright, Inc. They find something to say, often facetious and more often derogatory, about Washington figures, from the President and Chief Justice down to the capital bootleggers.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The stock markets continued strong today, with a large increase in business, dealers reporting good buying. Some striking gains were made by the industrials. The Exchequer returns helped British Government funds, which advanced.
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- With a fresh breeze blowing out of the south, twenty-eight sloops sailed in the seventh race of the August series of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 24 -- A gallant bid on the home nine by Mrs. Austin Pardue of Minneapolis today fell just short and Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City moved into the quarterfinal round of the women's Western golf championship.

At the President's call a hundred or more leaders of American Industry and banking will meet in Washington tomorrow. It is planned to bring together for the first time members of the special committees recently created in the twelve Federal Reserve districts "to consider "methods of making the large funds "released, by the Federal Reserve "Banks useful .affirmatively in developing business."

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Aug. 24. -- Clyde Allen Lee and John Bochkon, for whom Harbor Grace waited up most of the night, roared over Conception Say and circled to a smooth landing at the airport this morning at 7:20 o'clock, Eastern Standard Time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Electrical transcription records are subject to taxation under the revenue act imposing a tax upon "records for phonographs," the Treasury declared today in a requested ruling.

The Toy Association, an organization of doll and toy manufacturers, declared yesterday through James L. Fri, its director, that only a small percentage of the 3,500 workers in the doll industry have been affected by the strike called by the Doll and Toy Workers' Union of Greater New-York.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- Steve Crothers of Chestnut Hill, Pa., Pennsylvania State trapshoot titleholder, was crowned champion of champions in the feature event of today's program of the thirty-third grand American handicap tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Efforts to obtain aerial photographs of the swiftly moving shadow cast by the moon on the earth will be made by the National Geographic Society during the eclipse of the sun Aug. 31.

A sharp and sudden drop in the prices of Interborough 5 per cent bonds and 6 and 7 per cent notes gave rise yesterday to many rumors and reports in the financial district, where the decline was interpreted in some quarters as indicative of failure of pending unification negotiations with the Transit Commission.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 24 (AP). -- A gain of net income for July of nearly $12,000, compared with June, and an increase in operating revenues of more than $12,000 in the saute period were reported today by the Norfolk Western Railroad.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., Aug. 24 -- Boston's team of amateur boxers triumphed in all four classes of competition in the second annual international amateur boxing tournament, with teams representing New York and Nova Scotia, at Dilboy Field tonight before 4,500 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--The chairmen of the twelve business men's committees which will meet here on Friday for the economic conference called by President Hoover were arriving in Washington today, and will confer with Secretaries Mills and Chapin tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Hedging pressure against the movement of new Canadian wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade today, which was felt in spreading operations, carried prices in all markets off about a cent from yesterday's finish.

The long-waged battle between composers and broadcasters over payment for the use of copyrighted music on the radio, which reached a deadlock in July, resulted in an amicable agreement yesterday when the National Association of Broadcasters consented to pay the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers a substantially increased annual fee.

A virtual stampede developed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday when the most aggressive buying movement in several years advanced prices more than a half cent and left the list 47 to 50 points higher than on Tuesday.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Robert E. Walker gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Her guests were Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry 2d, Mrs. Clifford V. Brokaw Jr., Mrs. John W. Mackay, Mrs. John J.C. Herndon and Mrs. John W. Aitken.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The Hawley-Smoot tariff more than anything else was responsible for the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa, according to American, Canadian and British economic opinion expressed today at the Institute of Politics, where Dean P.E. Corbett of McGill University conducted the first of two special conferences on the Ottawa meeting.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday were irregular and Wall Street's interest in the market was not so pronounced as on other days in the recent past. However, the volume of business ran to an impressive figure even by comparison with the uncommonly heavy trading of the day before.

As a result of the internal hostilities in Brazil little coffee has left Santos since early in July, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange reported yesterday. It added that there were in this country or afloat for ports here only 422,540 bags of coffee from that country, or approximately thirteen days' supply.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- A large audience filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when members of the Hampton Players, under the direction of Henry Codman Potter, presented their fourth and final production of the season, "The Cat and the Canary," the mystery play by John Willard.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Jim Levey's home run with one on in the eleventh inning gave the Browns a 5-to-3 victory over the Athletics today after Philadelphia had tied the battle with two homers in the ninth.

ANGMAGSALIK, Greenland, Aug. 24. -- In the prime of his youth, H.G. Watkins, most promising of British Arctic explorers, has perished in an accident in a native kayak canoe, one of those strange sealskin-covered craft in which a single occupant laces himself, becoming virtually a part of the boat.

The moderate reaction which occurred in the stock market Tuesday afternoon was carried 1 to 3 points further in the early business yesterday, but the declines were nearly all canceled in a later recovery. At the close net advances ranging from a fraction to 2 or 3 points had been generally scored.

The champion young mermen and mermaids of the east side and west side, who had spent the Summer training in wading pools, made swimming history yesterday by setting up their own titles and finding champions to grace them. In fact, Enzzo MagnozzI, who lives at 131 West Fifteenth Street and is going on 13, is the new free-style wadingpool champion.
DORTMUND, Germany, Aug. 24.--Dr. Hans Luther, president of the Reichsbank, addressed the Congress of Cooperatives here today on the world financial outlook and his speech was frankly optimistic.
DARBY'S HARBOR, Nfld., via St. Kryan's, Nfld., Aug. 24. -- We are both feeling fine today after a good night's rest and being well taken care of by friendly people.

It was learned yesterday from officials of the steamship companies concerned that the agreement between the Cunard and White Star lines for pooling the profits, after paying the operating expenses, of the liners Berengaria and Majestic had been terminated by mutual consent.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Boston upset the Cincinnati Reds with a four-run rally in, the fifth, inning of their first contest today to win, 5 to 2, but then lost its punch and dropped the second game, 3 to 1.

A father and his son, the latter a youth of 16, appeared together in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday morning, charged with collaborating in a hold-up. It was the first time, veteran police officials said, that such a case had come to their attention.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- Governor Roosevelt blocked today Mayor Walker's attempt to trace all his troubles to a Republican anti-Tammany plot and heard three new witnesses testify in support of the Mayor's defense to the charge that an Equitable Coach Company employe bought him a $10,000 letter of credit.

WASHINGTON, Aug 24. -- The Idle shipping tonnage of the world totaled 14,000,000 on June 30, an increase of 35 per cent from the preceding fiscal year. The American idle tonnage, included in the world total, was 3,425,000, an increase of 31 per cent over the previous year, while the British idle tonnage was 3,470,000, an increase of only 7 per cent over the preceding year.
THE bellboy said: "Mr. Morgan? Not here. Guess you'll find him down in his Wall Street offices -- if you can get in."

The present open season for fishing has been one of the best in a long while, both in the plentitude of fish caught and in the number of persons taking an active interest in the sport, according to veteran fishing-boat captains, dyed-in-the-wool anglers themselves, and dealers in and manufacturers of fishing equipment of various kinds.

Before he sailed yesterday on the Cunarder Mauretania, Albert Coates, the Anglo-Russian orchestra conductor, said he would not have known there was a depression in the United States if he had not been told of it.

DENVER, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The $1,000 American Chemical Society prize for the "most promising young chemist in North America under 30 years of age" was presented tonight to Dr. Oscar K. Rice of Harvard University.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 24 -- Although Francis Ouimet, national amateur champion, won by 2 and 1 from Gene Sarazen, open champion of Great Britain and the United States, at the Brae Burn Country Club today, the six-hole advantage which Sarazen held after the first eighteen holes at Winchester yesterday gave the New York professional the match by a margin of 4 and 2.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 25. -- Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City today reached the semi-final round in defense of the women's Western golf title, but only after a bitter twenty-one-hole battle with Miss Jean Armstrong of Chicago.

A career that promised to be brilliant was cut short when H. G. WATKINS was drowned last Saturday in Greenland. With the passing of SCOTT and SHACKLETON, England had been looking to this young man to represent her in penetrating the unknown. Mr. WATKINS, at 24, had the support of the Royal Geographical Society when he proposed to undertake the traverse of Antarctica from Weddell Sea to the Bay of Whales in 1933.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 25. -- Willem Willeke, 'cellist and director of the South Mountain String Quartet and Elshuco Trio, was the guest of honor at a dinner which eighty of his Berkshire friends gave him tonight at the Pittsfield Country Club in observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his arrival in this country from Holland.

VANDALIA, Ohio., Aug. 25. -- Like a hero of an Horatio Alger book, 17-year-old Bobby Olds, Lansing, Mich., farm boy rose to trapshooting fame and fortune today by outshooting 700 or the country's best marksmen to win the preliminary Grand American Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- American operated aircraft flew 24,668,414 miles on scheduled air lines in the first six months of this year, carrying 248,954 passengers, 4,342,507 pounds of mail and 712,638 express pounds, Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, announced today.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., Aug. 25. -- James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, interviewed on his sixty-fifth birthday anniversary here today, declared that "if the election were held now, Roosevelt would sweep the country." This statement, he said, held good until election day, provided the Governor "did not make a slip."

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Berea College at Berea, Ky., will receive $100,000 upon the death of the children of Henry G. Keasbey, a manufacturer, whose will was probated today. The will leaves Mr. Keasbey's estate of $300,000 in trust for the children and other relatives.

ALBANY, Aug. 25. -- A spirited clash between Governor Roosevelt and Corporation Counsel Arthur J. W. Hilly over the practical effect or the city of fee-splitting by city-employed doctors provided a dramatic climax to today's session of Mayor Walker's trial on Samuel Seabury's conclusions.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- George W. Hill of New York, president of the American Tobacco Company, has contracted, through James Roosevelt, for a $2,500,000 insurance policy, the largest in the history of New England.

The Rev. James K. Shields, State superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League in New Jersey, made public yesterday an open letter to the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, taking him and his organization to task for getting behind President Hoover, as the "best value" in the campaign, even in preference to William D. Upshaw of Georgia, Presidential nominee of the Prohibition party.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press). -- In the presence of the Papal Legate, Francis Cardinal Bourne, and many foreign Bishops and abbots the rebuilt Buckfast Abbey was consecrated today, after twenty-five years of steady labor by the monks.

Two new American flags whipped in the breeze on, the banks of the Hudson yesterday. Beneath them on half-built shanties thrown together out of old tin and weathered planking were chalked, symbols that a few weeks ago were flashed around the world -- "B. E. F."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Although fewer and smaller forest fires were reported last year than in 1930, with a decrease in the burned-over area of 688,150 acres, more than 50,000,000 acres suffered damage amounting to $67,000,000, according to the United States Forest Service.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 25.--John G. Anderson, veteran of many a links campaign and winner of some fifty odd competitions, and his left-handed partner, Walter Purcell, led the qualifying round in the second annual best-ball invitation tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Loans to North and South Dakota aggregating $200,000 were made available today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for direct and work relief.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The stock markets continued active today, with business improving and the tone generally cheerful. At the opening there were lively dealings in the internationals, the ticker having difficulty in keeping pace with the rapidly changing quotations.

The studied address of the Japanese Foreign Minister, Count UCHIDA, yesterday was not really directed to the House of Peers in Tokyo, where he spoke. It was plainly intended for the United States, for Great Britain, and especially for the League of Nations.

A new and powerful swing toward a demand by the American Legion for immediate payment of the bonus certificates, totaling $2,500,000,000, was evident yesterday as the New York State convention of the Legion opened in Brooklyn, with 4,100 delegates on hand and an estimated total attendance of 20,000.
MADRID, Aug. 25 (AP). -- General Sanjurjo and two of his aides were found guilty of conspiracy to put on the vacated throne of Spain Don Juan Carlos, the third son of former King Alfonso.

The Marguery Restaurant in the Marguery Hotel at 270 Park Avenue was named a defendant yesterday in a padlock suit filed in Federal Court by Earle N. Bishopp, Assistant United States Attorney, charging violation of the prohibition law.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Suit for a receiver for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad was filed in Federal court here today by Charles and Dora B. Gans, owners of $3,500 in 4 per cent Series. A prior lien mortgage bonds of that railroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Creation of a powerful committee of banking and industrial groups to "act as a central point of contact" in bringing public and private agencies into a closer organization to end swiftly the business depression will be recommended to the National Conference on Credit and Employment to be held here tomorrow.

James and Adele Venturo sold to the Composite Construction Corporation of Newark the four-story, thirty-four-family apartment house and a one-story concrete store building, on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 100-14 Seventeenth Street, northeast corner of Johnson Place, West New York.
PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Continued increase in the American gold reserve was reflected, as had been anticipated, in yesterday's Federal Reserve report. Addition of $25,936,000 to the system's gold, during the weekly period just past, made the increase since June 15 $192,198,000, or something over 40 per cent of the decrease earlier in the year.

Believers in continuity of policy and the stability of institutions will be happy to hear that the Barnacles and Tite Barnacles and the Circumlocution Office which they administer with such deliberation are still "going strong." Lord Chief Justice HEWART and a few other defenders of "the rights of Englishmen" attack in vain the good old, evergrowing bureaucracy.

Five robbers, all carrying pistols and one of them also armed with a sawed-off shotgun, invaded the Marlboro branch of the Irving Trust Company at 311 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. They disarmed the guard, forced the manager to open the safe and fled with $17,300 in cash.

WITH practically every one else agreeing that the Olympic Games at Los Angeles had established a real entente cordiale in the world of sports, Oscar Soderlund of Sweden, a delegate to the games and president of the International Boxing Federation, rises to file what amounts to a minority report. He is in favor of abolishing the Olympic Games because they "seethe with chauvinism."
Again the leading German film producing company reaches back into the heroic past for a subject for a military picture calculated to quicken the pulse of German spectators.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 25. -- An attempt to shift the blame for the "third-degree" beating that caused the death of Hyman Stark from the five Nassau County policemen on trial in Supreme Court here for manslaughter to Assistant District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr. and Detective Joseph Hizenski, whose mother Stark had beaten and robbed, was begun by the defense today.

Thirteen persons were injured last night when a bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company crashed into the rear of an automobile in Diagonal Street near the viaduct, Long Island City, then veered from the roadway and struck the side of a building at 31-28 Queens Boulevard.

Lew Feldman of Brownsville out-pointed Tommy Paul of Buffalo, recognized by the National Boxing Association as the featherweight champion, in the feature ten-round bout at the Coney Island Velodrome last night. A crowd of more than 7,000 saw the battle in which Paul's title was not at stake.

The sale of the old West End Theatre, at 362-370 West 125th Street, running through to 19-23 Hancock Place, was announced yesterday by Ernest J. Cohen, a broker, who said contracts had been signed for the sale of the property to the Eight Avenue and 125th Street Corporation Samuel Derecktor, president.

After analyzing the budget requests of forty-four city departments for next year, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday that their economies, extended to all departments, would show an inadequate reduction next year of only three-quarters of 1 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- American-born golf professionals, led by Horton Smith, today defeated, by the slender margin of one point, a band of foreign-born stars under the command of Tommy Armour in the first day of their two-day battle for supremacy.

A field of 167, drawn from all sections of this country, Canada and Great Britain, will start play in the qualifying round of the national amateur golf championship, opening at the Baltimore Country Club Sept. 12.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- Notification that they were to receive L100 each ($346.06 at the current rate) under the will of Lord Inchcape, as "a slight memento" of loyalty and fidelity to him, was received today by 200 captains of the Peninsular Oriental and British India Steam Navigation companies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25. -- A crowd of 1,500 persons, assembled on Reyburn Plaza opposite City Hall for a ''hunger" demonstration, was dispersed by police this afternoon with ten arrests and injuries to at least four.
ALBANY, Aug. 25. -- A summary of the testimony at today's and tonight's hearings before Governor Roosevelt on the removal charges against Mayor Walker follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- John Bain, South Park Commissioner and banker, convicted of conspiracy to defraud depositors and investors of $13,000,000, was sentenced today by Judge John M. O'Connor to serve an indeterminate sentence of one to five years, the maximum, term, at Joliet.

The din of a radio which continued during broadcasting hours for a day and a half, to the annoyance of neighbors, led to the discovery yesterday morning of the body of David Jay Ely, an attorney, in the third floor apartment of Mrs. Edward Swift Isham, his cousin, at 1,040 Park Avenue.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Dorothy mine of the Y and O. Coal Company at Glen Robbin, near here, resumed operations today with 350 men employed. The mine had been closed five months, but operators said there were enough orders now to keep it running until at least Jan. 1.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Aug. 25. -- Although numerous transatlantic liners were in the path of the monoplane Green Mountain Boy, in which Clyde Allen Lee and John Bochkon left here at 6:02 this morning (Eastern Daylight Time), on an attempted flight to Oslo, no reports of the fliers having been sighted had been received here tonight.

If a young man identified with the disapproved Younger Generation is a true interpreter for his fellows, the next younger generation should find their elders putting no obstacles in their path. Mr. JOHN WEAVER was taken by every one for a fair type of his group.

Most of the children of Russian emigres are looking forward to a time when a different and new Russia will require their services, writes Marie, former Grand Duchess of Russia, in the second volume of her memoirs, "A Princess in Exile," to be published today by the Viking Press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Under a Treasury ruling made public today a "call" is an agreement to sell and is taxable under the 1932 revenue act, but a transfer of a certificate of stock pursuant to the "call" is not taxable, being only a fulfillment of the original agreement.

August Heckscher, veteran philanthropist, who will celebrate his eighty-fourth birthday today in his apartment at 375 Park Avenue, is outspokenly optimistic over the immediate spiritual and material recovery and progress of the United States and Europe.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25. -- In one of the most desperately fought tennis matches seen here in years, Wilmer Allison of Austin. Texas, and John Van Ryn of East Orange, N.J., the defending champions, overcame George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago and Frank Shields of New York today to reach the final round of the national doubles tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The pamphlet report of the General Motors Corporation on its operations in the first half of 1932, which was issued yesterday, shows that sales in the second quarter of the year amounted to $147,134,818, or $2,528,898 Jess than in the first quarter, although 198,659 cars were sold in the second quarter, against 197,256 in the first quarter.

ALBANY, Aug. 25. -- Cooperation betweem employers and workers for shorter hours or a shorter week was advocated today by Governor Roosevelt in a telegram to John Sullivan, president of the State Federation of Labor, at its closing session in Utica.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once more, at Columbus, Governor Roosevelt has remembered the forgotten man, once more he has told the truth, and so once more he must be labeled a radical and demagogue.

Competition for the properties of the Richfield Oil Company of California, which has been in receivership since January, 1931, appeared yesterday to be now only between the Consolidated Oil Corporation and the Cities Service Company. Consolidated Oil a few weeks ago made an offer to the various protective committees, which was accepted tentatively in principle.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Sands Point continued its unbroken march through the Knox Cups polo series at Bostwick Field today, defeating Aurora, 14 to 4, to gain its fourth straight victory, and at Meadow Brook the Hurricanes won their first game in the series by conquering Eastcott on Cochran Field, 16 to 12.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Fifty-six entrants teed off today in the eighteen-hole qualifying round of the second annual golf tournament of the Sagamore Golf Club.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA. DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 25 -- The National Farmers' Holiday Association resulted from the experience and education which was finally drafted into a resolution by the old Corn Belt Committee, composed of practically all farm institutions in the Middle West.

One of the busiest days of the year on the Stock Exchange brought no important changes in the average level of prices. The market was strong at the opening and in the late forenoon established new highs for the movement. Stocks remained strong until about 2:15 o'clock when reactionary tendencies appeared.

SPRINGFIELD, III., Aug. 25 (AP). -- Mrs. Ralph Keeler's champion daughter of Peter Volo, The Marchioness, which won the Hambletonian Stake last week, added another rich Grand Circuit victory in winning the Futurity trot, $2,000 added, today at the Illinois State Fair.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 25.--Signs of approaching improvement in business and economic conditions were descried upon the industrial horizon by Albert Linton, president of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, in a talk tonight before the Leaders' Club, an organization of insurance men.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Governor A. Harry Moore, arriving at Camp Dix today to inspect and review the State's National Guard Air Squadron was "snap-shotted" from a passing plane, and by the time his own plane had circled the camp and landed he received finished prints of his photograph.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The creation of new races of men by the intensive study and application of Mendelian laws of heredity to human beings was urged here today before the International Congress of Genetics by Dr. C.B. Davenport of the Cold Spring Harbor Genetic Station of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

The Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, representing what is regarded as the most important producer element in the city's garment industry, yesterday sent a letter to Grover A. Whalen, president of the Advertising Club of New York, endorsing the club's seven-point plan of action for economic recovery and stabilization as made public on Wednesday with the approval of the American Federation of Labor.

Assemblyman Langdon W. Post, friend of Governor Roosevelt, who was refused a redesignation at the last moment, announced yesterday that he would run independently for re-election in the Tenth District.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The address of Count Uchida, the Japanese Foreign Minister, before the Diet in Tokyo on the Manchurian question is regarded here in the larger sense as a defense of Japanese policies before the world and in a special sense as intended primarily for the League of Nations.

Organization of a national committee for economy in government was completed here yesterday at a meeting of representatives of more than seventy national and State trade associations at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The meeting was held under auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 25. -- The Pennsylvania Securities Commission, cooperating with the Federal Power Commission and the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, has barred sales in this State of new bond issues of the Pennsylvania Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation.

UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 25. -- By an overwhelming vote today, the State Federation of Labor endorsed the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt for President. The vote was viva voce in the convention, but was reported to be 188 to 12.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Aug. 25. -- When 1,000 angry farmers threatened to storm the jail, county officials tonight released on bonds fifty-five men who had picketed near-by highways in an effort to blockade the Omaha market.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Consistent hitting by the Red Wings evened the series with Newark today, as sixteen hits off Jablonowski and Nekola were good for a 6-to-2 victory.

ALBANY, Aug. 25. -- A clash occurred here today between speakers advocating Federal improvement of the New York Barge Canal and army engineers who were conducting a hearing on the Gavigan-wagner bill.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The Glen Riddle Farm's good fortune and the luck of Man o' War prevailed again today when Speed Boat, bearing the familiar black and yellow silks, and a daughter of Man o' War from Friar's Carse, won the featured Adirondack Handicap at 8 to 1 at Saratoga, amid general surprise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ending Aug. 20 stands at 65.4, as compared with 65.2 for the week ending Aug. 13.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The semi-final round of the J. Ernest Stern Cup six-goal polo tournament was played at Norwood Country Club today and the Norwood Club team and the Monmouth County Country Club of Eatontown emerged victorious to gain the finals on Saturday.

Donald H. Dickerman, owner of a chain of dancing and dining places in Greenwich Village that relied on "atmosphere" rather than liquor to attract customers, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court.

Replying on behalf of the Administration to Governor ROOSEVELT'S Columbus speech, Secretary HURLEY described the President's address of acceptance as having left nothing to be desired "for depth of understanding, directness, candor, clarity and * * * generous recognition of the brilliant services and patriotism * * * of his political opponents."

Captain James A. Mollison will take off from Roosevelt Field, L. I., either today or tomorrow, depending upon weather conditions, for St. John, N. B., on the first leg of his return solo flight across the Atlantic, he announced yesterday afternoon.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the recital by Edward Lankow, former basso of the Metropolitan Opera, which was given to night at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.

TORONTO, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Toronto ran riot against Albany today and won the third game of the series, 9 to 2. Led by Murray Howell, who had a perfect day at bat with four hits, including a double, the Leafs fashioned sixteen safeties.

Plans for meeting an approaching emergency in the financial affairs of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company were discussed at a special meeting of the board of directors and the executive committee yesterday afternoon. A program which involves the $31,000,000 note maturity on Sept. 1 is being worked out and will be announced soon, probably this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Aggressive buying of wheat on the Board of Trade here today by houses with Eastern connections gave rise to a renewal of the rumors current for some time that a strong pool had been organized to try to advance prices.

The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, headed by Thomas W. Lamont and formed under an agreement with the Mexican Government in 1922 to protect the interests of holders of Mexican securities and to receive payments of interest overdue on the securities, filed suit yesterday in the Supreme Court for permission to account for the revenues received under the agreement.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Corey of 151 East Seventy-ninth Street and Paddy Green Farm, Old Brookville, L. I., will give a dinner dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Carolyn Corey, at the Piping Rook. Club, Locust Valley, L. I., on Sept. 8.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- Negotiations at a secret meeting place near Stuttgart between the National Socialists (Nazis) and Centrists for an agreement to produce a working majority in the Reichstag, thus providing for a return to parliamentary government in Germany, remain at a stand-still.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 25. -- Another draw for Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris was recorded today in the eighth round of the international chess masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland.

Changing needs of new generations are chief factors considered in the revision of the Methodist hymnal, declared Robert G. McCutchan, dean of the School of Music of DePauw University, Greencastle, Ind., in an interview yesterday. Dean McCutchan has been in Brooklyn for the last four days collaborating with the ten members of the Methodist Hymnal Committee, who have been working in the Hotel St. George on the revision and classification of the song-book.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in THE TIMES entitled "Where Praise Is Due" pays a well-deserved tribute to Commissioner Richard C. Patterson Jr., who has been for five years the head of the Department of Correction in this city, having charge of the prisons and other disciplinary institutions.

What Secretaries Are For. On Saturday the distinguished Siames savant, Penh Yahn arrived in New York for the purpose of studying the American Government He lost no time in applying himself to a diligent examination of the newspaper headlines.
MULVANE, Kan., Aug. 25 (AP). -- Dr. S. T. Shelly, who came to Mulvane on horseback in 1880, was host today to nearly a thousand of the 4,500 "babies" he has helped usher into the world.

TOKYO, Aug. 26. -- Premier Salto, in his address to the Diet today described the relief measures the government had planned to meet distress in agricultural and other communities. Their principal features are:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Brokers' loans by New York banks increased $10,000,000 in the week of Aug. 17-24, the Federal Reserve Board stated today in its weekly report on member banks in central reserve cities.

MADRID, Aug. 25. -- General Jose Sanjurjo was sentenced early today to die for leading the revolt at Seville two weeks ago, but, after an all-day session in which it threatened to break up, the Cabinet ordered his sentence commuted to life imprisonment.

Mrs. McCormick's leadership in Chicago society was as absolute as that of the first Mrs. Potter Palmer in her day. It remained unchallenged throughout her lifetime, partly due to an attitude born of her position as the richest woman in Chicago and the daughter of the richest man in the world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Hammering three pitchers for sixteen hits, Washington earned an 8-to-5 victory over Detroit today and forged into third place in the American League as Cleveland lost to the Yankees.

The thirty-ninth annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, which embraces 144 mutual savings banks, will be held at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, on Sept. 22 and 23, Paul W. Albright, general secretary of the association, announced yesterday.

Textile Orders Continue Heavy. Activity continued widespread in the various textile markets yesterday, with price advances numerous. The Cone Export and Commission Company withdrew all prices on denims, in order to check the market situation thoroughly.

Charitable bequests totaling about $50,000 were listed in the will of Mrs. Sarah Frances Fabbricotti, widow of Luciano Fabbricotti, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates' Court. Mrs. Fabbricotti died Aug. 13 in her apartment at the Murray Hill Hotel.

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- The whole Eastern section of France from Rheims to Metz, including the cities of Verdun, Thionville and Pont-a-Mousson and the Ardennes, Marne and Moselle districts relived wartime scenes tonight during a sham air raid staged on a large scale as part of war manoeuvres directed by Marshal Petain.

CRANBURY, N.J., Aug. 25. -- At a meeting of twenty-five Central New Jersey potato growers here today it was decided to start a campaign to halt the sale of potatoes in Monmouth, Middlesex and Mercer Counties, Jersey's chief potato-growing counties, until Sept. 19, in an effort to obtain better prices for the crop.

Claude Neon Electrical Products Corporation, Ltd. of Delaware and subsidiaries -- Six months ended June 30: Net profit after Federal taxes and other charges, 5246,764, equivalent after $12,698 7 per cent preferred dividends, to 89 cents a share on 262,550 no par common shares, compared with $362.760, or $1.29 a share on 269,523 common shares, in first half of 1931.

Bight men and a woman were arrested yesterday after a clash between police and Communists who had attempted to storm the headquarters of the Home Relief Bureau, in Public School 43, in Boerum Street, between Manhattan Avenue and Lenox Street, Brooklyn.

MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press). -- The Montreal Royals divided a double-header with Baltimore today, losing the first, 10 -- 9, but taking the nightcap, 7 -- 2. Boyle, McGowan and Shiver hit homers in the opener, McGowan getting his second in the nightcap.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (AP by Mail). -- Official figures reveal that in the first three months of this year thieves looted 40,000 freight shipments, stealing 1,538 tons of merchandise and foodstuffs. These were disposed of at handsome profits in the private market, where everything brings exorbitant prices.

COULTERVILLE, Ill., Aug. 25 -- Prodded on by about sixty State troopers armed with pistols, a demoralized mob of 15,000 miners moved north toward their homes in Central Illinois tonight, cowed by the reception given them by sheriff's deputies at the Franklin County line last night.

Eight thousand passnegers will arrive today in thirteen steamships. Among them are Judge Max Levine of the Court of General Sessions, who is returning from Europe on the Leviathan. He will be met at Quarantine by 200 of the Grand Street Boys Association, of which he is president, and by several political leaders.

Reports that the German Government would seek a revision of private debts held abroad are positively denied by Dr. LUTHER, president of the Reichsbank. While it is necessary to maintain "constant watchfulness and ever-careful husbanding of the Reichsbank's exchange resources," he declares that there will be no "unilateral interference " by the Government in German interest obligations."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 25. -- An International conference of the signatories of the four-power treaty at the Washington Conference which dealt with the defense of insular possessions might evolve a "face-saving formula" to bring Japan and the United States together and iron out the Manchurian imbroglio, according to several speakers at the closing session, of the Institute of Politics today.

Twenty-seven members of the Polish Olympic team arrived here yesterday. They were met by General. J. Rouppert, head of the Polish Olympic delegation, which preceded them to New York, and were greeted by a large crowd of Polish delegations headed by Anthony Piostroski, commander of the Polish National Alliance of America.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25. -- The Giants collected seventeen hits in winning today to even the series with the Cardinals, one game each, but their margin of victory, 6 to 5, was so scant that the last four innings were played under tension and with brilliance worthy of a higher cause than sixth place.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, who broke one political precedent by making big acceptance speech to the convention which nominated him, broke another last night by a nationwide radio appeal for contributions to the campaign fund for his election.
The first marlin caught this season off Montauk was reported yesterday and the game fishermen apparently are coming into their own with swordfish, tuna and marlin running and biting well.
