PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Crashing out seventeen hits that included, home runs by Foxx and McNair, the Athletics overwhelmed the St. Louis Browns 15 to 5 today and evened the series at one game apiece. The victory was the tenth in a row for Tony Freitas, the young south-paw.

Many veterans are included among the thirty-six men invited to report for the first practice of the City College football squad on Sept. 6 at Lewishohn Stadium, according to an announcement made yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 25. -- The University of Manitoba's $1,600,000 endowment trust fund has shrunk to an estimated $100,000 or less, and tonight its chief guardian lay seriously ill in bed with a theft charge against him while officials of two other institutions started a hurried examination into their accounts.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange surged upward asain yesterday, rising a quarter cent despite the heaviest profit-taking since the advance started, and ended the day with gains of 11 to 14 points.

The balance sheet of the New York Central Railroad, as of June 30, filed with the New York Public Service Commission yesterday, shows that current assets were $76,324,832, against $93,181,110 on June 30, 1931. Current liabilities, on the other hand, had increased from $94,832,360 to $107,537,160.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- The shrinkage of another great fortune, at one time estimated to exceed $40,000,000, was brought to light with the death of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick. The gift of her father, John D. Rockefeller Sr., that fortune is now but a fraction of its former worth and, moreover, is largely tied up in real estate instead of the Standard Oil securities that originally formed it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On July 1, when we were in the lowest depth of our financial doldrums, a Paris dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES made this interesting comment on the Wall Street state of mind, as viewed by European observers:

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- The public came back into the market today despite the fact that most of it was supposed to be away on vacations. A buying wave sent prices still higher in the market's uninterrupted upward trend of the last two days. Only professional speculators were credited with the buying movement which was responsible for the market's advance getting started on the Bourse earlier in the week.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 25. -- Charlie Seaver, one of Stanford's star football candidates for 1932, scored a touchdown from the kick-off in the quarter-finals of the Western Amateur Golf Championship today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While reading with interest the articles of General March, with no personal information as to the qualifications of General Pershing as a diplomat overseas, I desire to express my view of the Tacna-Arica difficulty.

PEIPING, Aug. 25 -- Roy Chapman Andrews, the American anthropologist, closed the headquarters of the Central Asiatic Expedition here today and announced that henceforth he would have headquarters in Mukden, Manchuria.

HAMBURG, Aug. 25. -- The giant project of breaking up 10 per cent of Germany's merchant ships, chiefly of older types, which are now laid up in various harbors, will be carried out in the near future.

As every good hunter knows, there is nothing like a trusty double-barreled gun to bring down big game, and it took all of two shots, right on the mark, for the Yanks to overcome the Indians in the second game of the current series at the Stadium yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Walter Hammond, vice captain of the Gloucestershire County Cricket Club, today scored 264 runs against Lancashire at Liverpool, eclipsing the highest score of his career and setting a new record for the Liverpool grounds.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 25. -- Governor Pinchot asked the Republican State Committee tonight to obtain the withdrawal of Senator James J. Davis as a candidate for re-election and in case of his refusal, to "pre-empt a, ticket and run a clean Republican against him."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Large powers have been conferred on Oswald F. Schuette to negotiate details of the copyright contracts to be entered into between broadcasters and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. It was announced today by the National Association of Broadcasters with headquarters in this city.

A brace of army carrier pigeons shot into the air at Bryant Park yesterday afternoon. Winging their way directly into the face of the blistering sun, they soon disappeared in the cloudless blue sky, bound for their home loft at the Army Signal Corps centre at Fort Monmouth, N. J., more than forty-five air-line miles away.

Aspirants for major nominations at the Republican State Convention, to be held during the first week of October, continue to call on former Representative William H. Hill, assistant Eastern manager of the Hoover campaign, with headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria.

The only high or low figure for the year reached in yesterday's statement of the Federal Reserve was in rediscounts, which went to the low figure of 1932 to date. In the subjoined comparative table, all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 24, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,336,000,000, a decrease of $16,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,161,000,000 cormpared with the corresponding week of 1931.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Red Sox took the second game of the series from Chicago, 5 to 4, today, Benny Tate, formerly of the White Sox, and Dale Alexander furnishing the principal offense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Federal regulation of interstate bus and truck operations, as urged by the railroads for years and repeatedly sanctioned with reservations by the Interstate Commerce Commission, will be pressed more vigorously than ever before with the reconvening of Congress in December.

Patrolman Francis X. Murphy of 146 West 103d Street heads the list of 698 policemen eligible for promotion to sergeants, which was compiled yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission after 8,000 men had taken the tests.
BERLIN, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Reichbank's statement as of Aug. 25 shows the following changes in reichmarks:

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 25 (AP). -- A hotel guest tentatively identified by police as David R. Ettinger, official of a Chicago optical company, died of poison in his room here today four days after he was reported kidnapped in Chicago.

EAST ST. LOUIS, III., Aug. 25 (AP). -- Eldon Cessna of Wichita, Kan., led the transcontinental air derby today into East St. Louis, the night control point, arriving from Jefferson City at 2:52 P. M. [Central Standard Time].

The aggregate or bank clearings at twenty-two leading cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday night amounted to $3,684,548,000, a reduction of 35.1 per cent from that of the corresponding period last year, according to reports received by R. G. Dun Co.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The fighting Phils downed the tottering Pirates in both ends of a double-header today, 11 to 3 and 6 to 5, to set up a record of seven consecutive victories over the Corsairs, and moved into fourth place in the National race.
Unsung heroes, whose names will be forever lost to history, were going about their accustomed ways last night, after they had filled their brief roles of glory in a tiny epic of Times Square.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The decrease in the size of the American Merchant Marine in the fiscal year ended June 30 was smaller than in any year since 1923, according to Arthur J. Tyrer, Assistant Director of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection of the Department of Commerce.

Thursday, Aug. 25, 1932. Money market was quiet and unchanged. The official call rate held at 2 per cent, with outside money quoted at 1 per cent. Federal funds 1/8 per cent. Time loans, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25. -- Bolivia is continuing troop movements into the Chaco and other war preparations, according to reports from Argentine points near the frontier, the most important recent move having been the transfer of a concentration camp from Villazon to Tarija.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Staging two assaults on William Watson Clark in the third and fourth innings, the Cubs took the second straight game of the series from the Dodgers, 9 to 3, today and increased their first-place lead over Brooklyn to five and one-half game.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
From Labrador comes a mocking inquiry to us who dwell in cities, and attempt to meet the obligations which we have undertaken from a sense of duty to those who are "in the same boat" with us:

Henry Wadsworth Longfellow Dana, former Columbia University professor who was dismissed from that institution in 1917 because of his anti-war activities, has been refused permission to land in England, according to a London dispatch to The Baltimore Sun.
MADRID, Aug. 26. -- The government today began building up the support of the Centre, aid from which it knows to be necessary in the Cortes to prevent trouble from the extreme Left and Right wings.

The prospects are for a student body this year as large or larger than last year at the Biblical Seminary, 235 East Forty-ninth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. Wilbert W. White, founder of the seminary, is the president. The school will reopen for its thirty-third year Sept. 28.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 26. -- More than a score of pilots, professional and amateur, will take off at this field at daybreak tomorrow in two trophy races which will terminate at the National Air Races at Cleveland, of which they are a part.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- More than 1,000,000 out or 14,025,800 foreinborn persons over 10 years of age in the United States on April 1, 1930, were unable to speak the English language, according to census figures.

Accepting the Democratic nomination for Vice President in a letter to Senator Alben W. Barkley, made public yesterday, Speaker John N. Garner charged President Hoover and the Republican leaders in Washington with failure to meet the depression courageously or to take adequate relief measures.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The woman who has been looking after Mayor Walker's personal business affairs since Russell T. Sherwood dropped from sight a year ago admitted before Governor Roosevelt today that she had kept her predecessor's income from the Sheriff by sequestering it in New Jersey.
ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- A summary o the testimony today before Governor Roosevelt in the Mayor Walker removal proceedings follows:
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- A man who became disgusted with trapshooting and quit for eleven years today won the richest prize in the gun world.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 26. -- Winning their semi-final matches with little difficulty today, Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City, the defending title-holder, and Miss Lucille Robinson of Des Moines, Iowa, went into the championship round of the women's Western golf tournament.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S radio appeal for campaign contributions rightly attempts to fit the political coat this year to the cloth. He remarks, what everybody knows to be true, that in many past Presidential elections too much money has been collected and spent.

Still Plenty of Room Ahead. Scores of thousands of passengers on the I.R.T., reading that the company had gone into receivership, must have looked up if they had a seat, or around them if they stood up, and tried to discover signs of the change.

Supreme Court , Justice Black granted yesterday an injunction sought by the investment brokerage firm of Pirnie, Simons Co. to restrain the New York Stock Exchange from interfering with, its method of selling securities by the so-called "package" method.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Use by the larger railroads of a "formula" worked out by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in financing further repairs and replacements against future needs was urged by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, representing the railways, before the National Conference of Business and Industrial Committees today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26. -- The Soviet Commissariat of Heavy Industry today issued its formal acceptance of Colonel Hugh. L. Cooper's work as consulting engineer for Dnieprostroy, the world's largest hydroelectric plant, the construction of which was begun early in 1927.

After irregular fluctuations in the morning trading on the Cotton Exhange yesterday prices surged upward into new high, ground for the year and closed 22 to 24 points higher than on Thursday. For a time, a renewal of the previous day's heavy profit-taking by professional operators caused a setback of a quarter cent, but prices advanced nearly $2 a bale in sympathy with the violent rise in the stock market and closed at the top.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 26. -- Rapid Chinese evacuation of the Chapei district or Shanghai was started today by panic aroused by continued "sight-seeing excursions" of Japanese marines, together with rumors that Japan is planning retaliation against terrorist boycott activities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In its desire to cooperate with the municipal authorities in cutting the city budget, the Department of Education has very recently submitted its budget requests, which included certain economy measures. Among these is one which those of us in the field of education of New York City believe to be open to serious criticism.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 26. -- Two members of the Argentine military mission recently recalled from Paraguay to preserve Argentine neutrality have returned "incognito," according to an intercepted radio message made public here today.

Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals signed an order yesterday requiring the Hofstadter legislative committee to show cause why William J. Flynn, Commissioner of Public Works in the Bronx, should not be permitted to appeal from the recent Appellate Court decision striking from the Supreme Court records parts of affidavits which Samuel Seabury, counsel to the committee, had opposed as scandalous.

TORONTO, Aug. 26. -- For the third time in as many years Miss Margaret Ravior, Philadelphia girl, won the women's ten-mile professional marathan swim in Lake Ontanio today, leading in a field of twenty-nine.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- Throughout today the German Cabinet has been in continuous session. Tonight it was still at work, discussing and revising its economic program and planning the strategy to be adopted at the convening of the Reichstag next week.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The 1,200 students from New York, New Jersey and Delaware now in training at the Citizens' Military Camp here marched for an overnight stay in the woods tonight commanded by the third group of faculty officers since they arrived here nearly a month ago.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Aug. 26. -- All five highways converging here in this gateway to the great produce market of Omaha were blocked this evening by Farmers' Holiday pickets, reorganized from the scattered forces dispersed yesterday by Sheriff P.A. Lainson, and the Sheriff described the situation as "dangerous and acute."

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26. --In all the half century's history of the national doubles championship France has never qualified a team for the title round. Once again she stood repulsed today as Henri Cochet and Marcel Bernard went down in defeat in the semi-finals at the hand of Ellsworth Vines and Keith Gledhill of California.

A theory that "a mediocre engineer is a more advanced, type than the best of living poets or painters," is maintained by Clifford Bax, British writer, in his biography of Leonardo da Vinci, recently published by D. Appleton Co.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Yorkshire today won its county championship cricket match started Tuesday, defeating Hampshire by 172 runs.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Ralph Manny's Blue Streak captured the weekly race of Sound Interclub craft conducted by the American Yacht Club today. A fleet of fifteen, the largest this season, sailed.

Count D. de Martel, French Ambassador to Japan, will sail today for Havre on the Ile de France of the French Line, and Michel Clemenceau, son of the late Premier of France and noted as an author, will also he on board. Others on the ship include:
Real estate trading in Manhattan yesterday centred on the west side, where the sale of a large apartment house and the leasing of other residential properties were reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- W. S. Bronson, general counsel for the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railroad, told the Interstate Commerce Commission Suspension Board today that he "did not see how" the Pittsburgh West Virginia "could keep out of the hands of the receivers" if it were not permitted to reduce its coal rates from the Pittsburgh district to Cleveland, Lorain and Huron, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Net profits accruing to American bankers from German loans floated in this country since 1923 amounted to approximately $50,000,000, according to calculations made public today by the Brookings Institution. These profits, excluding overhead expenses, were made on a volume of business aggregating $1,280,000,000 -- the purchase price paid by the bankers for these loans.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Aug. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The Newfoundland Government steamer Argyle today called at Merasheen Island in Placentia Bay to pick up Thor Solberg and Carl Petersen, who have dismantled their ill-fated sesquiplane and...

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 26. -- With two more games added to his score as a result of his winning from Isaac Kashdan of New York in the ninth round and from Samuel Reshefsky in their adjourned match from the fifth, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris today attained a total of 8 points in the international masters tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland.

Filing a 1933 budget request for $125,000, the Board of Taxicab Control, which has figured prominently in testimony in the removal proceedings against Mayor Walker, disclosed yesterday that it expected to be selfsupporting as soon as a schedule of hack license fees is drawn up.

With an assist for Swinburne Sit down and shake with laughter, Or sigh with vagrant tears, For this is what comes after The fame of fleeting years. Lazzeri does not treasure The swing he took in vain, That brought St. Louis pleasure And brought the Yankees pain.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP). -- New records were made today in the opening heats of the fifth running of the mid-East regatta as the outboard classic got under way before 10,000 spectators on the Muskingum River. Class B and C races were run today.

The net operating income of the first thirty-six railroads to report for July totaled $6,586,000, compared with $25,663,000 in July of last year and with $42,120,000 in July, 1930. The net operating income in June of these railroads amounted to $8,758,000, as compared with $25,881,000 in June last year.

New bond financing this week dropped to $21,911,000, but the offerings were more diversified than in any week so far this year. The flotation included two public utility issues, one railroad loan, one State loan and one issue for a finance company.

Mayor Walker, just back from Albany, last night gave James A. Mollison, the aviator who made the first westward solo flight across the Atlantic, the official welcome to the City of New York, and her medal. The ceremony, brief and friendly, took place at the Hotel Plaza.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Speculative operations by Eastern interests were again today the dominating influence in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here, but unlike yesterday's trading the transactions were largely on the selling side, and as a result prices declined 1 cent from yesterday's finish at the extreme.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- An organization certificate for the Commodities Credit Corporation of Manhattan with $2,000,000 capital has been approved by the State Banking Department, it was announced today.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Another warm political campaign closed in Texas, tonight between former Governor Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson and Governor Ross S. Sterling, with Speaker John N. Garner refusing to take sides in tomorrow's Democratic Gubernatorial run-off primary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is an old saying about chickens coming home to roost. Which reminds one apropos the hearing now being held before Governor Roosevelt on the charges against Mayor Walker, that this very same James J. Walker was a member of Assembly and voted for the impeachment of Governor William Sulzer.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Elaine Marguerite Richman, 3 years old, was proclaimed the champion of the annual baby parade, held here today. There were 250 children, 10 bands and 50 floats in the line of march, and prizes were awarded to 53 entries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Spurred by a declaration from President Hoover that the "major financial crisis" had been successfully overcome, business and industrial leaders called together from over the nation set up a central council of war today for a vigorous new attack on what remains of the depression.

TOKYO, Aug. 8. -- "The Japanese people are locked in their own territory by treaties. As long as the Nine-Power Treaty and the anti-war pact are construed in their present sense, Japan cannot expand in the Far East. If we are to progress we must break down this fence of treaties."

The city, which has a financial interest in the Interborough, as well as a civic one, showed no disposition to plunge in as an interested party yesterday. Whether it will do so eventually was regarded as possible, but not certain.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 26. -- More than 2,000 residents of New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and other States prominent socially, politically and in military circles attended tonight the annual Governor's ball, held in honor of Governor and Mrs. A. Harry Moore at the Hotel Monmouth here.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Anxiety over a possible outbreak among 1,726 women, and girl employes of the needlework industry here, who have been on strike since Monday, led Mayor James B. Armstrong to call for police help from the State to patrol the town.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Colgate University's new economy athletic policy, announced today as the plan of the Colgate University Athletic Council, includes some curtailment in inttercollegiate and freshman competition with a corresponding emphasis on students' participation in intramural athletics.

Adjourning the "Walker hearing over 'the week-end, Governor Roosevelt came to the city last night prepared to make a strong demand for prohibition repeal today at a campaign rally at Sea Girt, N.J. Mr. Roosevelt reached the city after a motor trip from the State Capitol with Martin Conboy, a special legal aide for the Walker case.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Red Sox took a free-hitting game from the White Sox, 11 to 8, today to gain a 2-to-1 edge in their four-game series.

The Rev. Dr. Lewis T. Reed, general secretary of the united Congregational and Christian Churches pension boards, announced yesterday the recent establishment of an old-age pension retirement fund for lay workers of both churches. The fund, authorized by the general council of the two churches, has been chartered under the laws of New Jersey, he said.

Closing prices in the bond market on the Stock Exchange showed yesterday a hodge-podge of advances and declines in the lightest day's trading this week. Railroad and industrial bonds averaged lower, while utilities were higher. Aside from the heavy dealings in New York rapid transit issues as a result of the receivership order for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, few individual issues were particularly active.

SPRINGFIELD, III., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Cold Cash, by Peter Scott, of the Blue Ridge Stable, Kansas City, Mo., won the $2,000 free-for-all pace, the feature event of the Grand Circuit races at the Illinois State Fair today.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Newark took a two-to-one edge on the series with the Red Wings by winning today's game, 11 to 2, in easy fashion.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The reign of John G. Anderson and Walter Purcell in the Winged Foot Golf Club's four-ball best-ball invitation tournament was brought to an end today when they went down to defeat in the second round before young Charles H. Mayo Jr. and his partner, Jose Suarez of Lido.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 26. -- Robert E. Lee week, attended by many distinguished visitors, ended here tonight with the Lee Monument Ball, a brilliant replica of the first one given, fiftyfive years ago at the Old White Hotel to raise funds for the Richmond (Va.) statue of the General on Traveler by Mercier.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George Daingerfield of Baltimore are at the Chatham.

Sharp gains in cotton this week, coupled with price advance in other basic textile commodities, have caused the most widespread buying movement the textile industries have witnessed since the depression began, flooding the selling houses with orders, a survey of these markets revealed yesterday.

There was immediate response yesterday to the preceding night's radio appeal of Governor Roosevelt for small contributions to the Democratic national campaign fund. James A. Farley, national chairman, expressed satisfaction at the result.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 26.--C. Everett Bacon of Lake George and New York, who won the inaugural event last year, gained the final round today in the second annual invitation tourney of the Sagamore Golf Club.

Forty-four communities throughout the country will offer new issues in the aggregate amount of $12,161,135 next week. Although a total of $14,740,302 of new issues was up for award this week, the largest single block, that of $8,000,000 City of Chicago bonds, failed to sell.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Unless a permanent endowment is raised for the institute of Politics the twelfth annual session which ended yesterday is likely to be the last, it was revealed today when Dr. Harry A. Garfield, chairman of the institute and president of Williams College, made public a memorandum to the board of advisers.

Assemblyman Langdon W. Post of the Tenth Assembly District in Manhattan, who, foliowing the refusal of Tammany Hall to designate him for a renomination in the primaries, announced that he would run as an independent candidate, announced yesterday that he had retired as president of the Union of Young Democratic Clubs of New York State, an auxiliary of the Roosevelt campaign, to give his whole time to his own campaign for renomination and re-election.

The American Legion of New York State, which is expected to vote a demand today for immediate payment of the bonus certificates totaling more than $2,000,000,000, listened yesterday at its convention in Brooklyn to an attack on the bonus proposal by General John F. O'Ryan and greeted his utterance with mingled applause and boos.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- A moratoriutn on foreclosures on first mortgages by receivers of closed national banks until the various Home Loan Banks are set in operation has been ordered by J.W. Pole, Controller of the Currency, at the request of Franklin Fort, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, who sent a similar request today to all State banking superintendents.
To the Editor of The New York Times: We have established here upon Ibamba a research, station which has as its objective the accomplishment of a twofold plan.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates turned on the Phillies today and with Leon Chagnon hurling fine ball, shut out the slugging Quakers, 8 to 0.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Comparing the State of New Jersey to a family that must live on a reduced income for the next year at least, Governor A. Harry Moore outlined an economy program today for the suggested use of all heads of State departments.

The annual report of the United States Shipping Board covering its survey of the marine insurance field, released yesterday, showed that the hull insurance market for American underwriters in 1931 remained about the same as in 1930; that cargo insurance premiums received by both American and foreign companies had decreased substantially, and that American ship owners send ocean-going hull insurance premiums direct to foreign markets in large amounts.

Corporation Counsel HILLY, whose "scholastic education" has made him remarkably cautious and deliberate, is collecting information about the splitting by four doctors of fees in compensation cases. It is unnecessary to dwell, though there is opportunity enough, on his reluctant and evasive testimony.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Great Britain's delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa came home today apparently well satisfied with what had been accomplished and ready to begin the work of tariff balancing with non-empire countries.

The management by Governor Roosevelt of the governmental affairs of the State and the conduct of John N. Garner, his running mate on the Democratic national ticket, as Speaker of the House of Representaitves will be targets for attack by Republican campaign orators from the very start of the active speaking campaign.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Northway Stable's Gallant Sir, making his first start since he ran eighth in the Kentucky Derby, romped to an easy victory in the Rolling Green Purse at Hawthorne today.
Housing properties, including two Jersey City apartment structures, comprised the bulk of New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Paced by Ed Dudley, the sharpshooter from Wilmington, Del., who added 67 to his 69 of yesterday, the American-born golf professionals today rounded out a 10-to-8 team victory over their foreign-born colleagues at the Oak Park Country Club.

A drop of 30 per cent in department store sales in this district in July compared with July of last year and a fall of 9 per cent in chain store sales will be shown in the report on business conditions in the Sept. 1 review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Three blue ribbons went to the black gelding Upperland, owned by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr. of Buffalo, at the opening session of Lake Placid's third annual horse show today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Salient points in the principal speeches today before the National Conference of Business and Industrial Committees were:

Responding to the confident predictions made in Washington as President Hoover's conclave of business and industrial leaders was opened, the share market rallied sharply in the late dealings yesterday. Not only were earlier losses in many parts of the list erased, but the main body of stocks approached closely the highest levels of the current advance.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Phil Turnesa and Mrs. H.B. Fellman of the Elmsford Golf Club captured the low-gross honors today in a mixed Scotch foursome tournament conducted by the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association over the Rockwood Hall Country Club course with a score of 79.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26.--Critics of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, particularly those who have contended that it is being operated for the sole benefit of "big business," were challenged by Atlee Pomerene, a Democrat and chairman of the corporation's board, in a speech he made today before the national conference of Business and Industrial Committees.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- New vistas for science, offering further promise for a future when man will be able to select his heredity and to speed up the slow processes of evolution, were visioned today at the sixth International Congress of Genetics.

Trade reports to Bradstreet's Weekly from fifty-five leading cities contain some distinctly reassuring factors, that publication announced yesterday. While the heavy industries remain generally dull, here and there in these lines tare indications of a turn for the better.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 (AP). -- S.C. Huffman paced the national air derby field into his home town of Cincinnati today, leading the Eastern wing of aviators to a landing at 4:25 P.M. (Central Standard Time) on a flight from Indianapolis.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26. -- Six closed Philadelphia banks and nine others in cities elsewhere in Pennsylvania will make payments to depositors ranging from 5 to 15 per cent within little more than a month. Dr. William D. Gordon, State Secretary of Banking, stated today.

OSLO, Saturday, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Airdrome officials here calculated this morning that if Clyde A. Lee and John Bochkon had remained aloft their gasoline supply must by this time have been exhausted. But lights were kept burning for them and great projectors swept the darkened sky.

Customs Agent J.H. Van Wle, dressed in the overalls of a truckman, drove a van to the offices of the Meray Box Stationery Company, 621 Broadway, yesterday and delivered a large packing case which had arrived in this port a week ago in the steamship France.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- A fashion show held this afternoon at Shady Lawn, the home of Mrs. Skirvin Adams of New York, netted a substantial sum for the American Marine Library Association.

Ex-Governor WHITMAN, who is willing to change that title to Senator WHITMAN, is the latest to have found "in my travels" how New York State and the nation are going in the Presidential election. According to him, Mr. HOOVER will carry New York and the country by a larger majority than in 1928.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP). -- An exciting ninth-inning finish today gave Lefty Grove his twentieth victory of the season, the Athletics defeating the St. Louis Browns 5-4. Simmons's single to deep short with Cochrane on third and two out won the game after the Browns had tied the score at 4-4 in their half of the ninth.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Friend Hoar gave dinner dance tonight in the Colonial ballroom and the Japanese room of the Meadow Club for their daughter Miss Hosanne Hoar, whom they will formally introduce to society at supper dance at the Pierre on Dec. 28.

The Chilean Nitrate Sales Corporation, the selling agency in this country of the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, or Cosach, announced yesterday a reduction of $11 a ton in the price of nitrate of soda to $25 a ton for delivery this month and in September.

Accommodation for at least 200,000 persons who are expected to attend the political rally at Sea Girt, N.J., this afternoon, at which Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Presidential candidate, will be the principal speaker, were completed last night by Democratic leaders in New Jersey, who predicted one of the largest political gatherings in the history of the State.

Moses J. Stroock, lawyer and chairman of the Board of Higher Education, who died on Oct. 27 last, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,001,052 gross and $900,876 net. His public gifts were $5,000 to City College, $20,000 to the Federation for the "Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, and $2,000 to the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great deal has been written in the last few days about doctors and the treatment of workmen's compensation cases. Eminent members of the Academy of Medicine and the County Medical Society have termed it a "racket."

In speaking yesterday to the industrialists and bankers in Washington, the President alluded to the "conferences similar to this nearly three years ago." He had in mind the meetings he arranged in the Fall of 1929 to steady public confidence immediately after the stock market crash.

MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals failed to hold a six-run lead against Baltimore today and the Orioles scored an 11-to-7 victory. McGowan hit his thirty-first homer of the season and Packard his twenty-first for Baltimore.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- By taking the third mile heat of the free-for-all trot at the Orange County Fair Grounds today, Ross F. Stout's Bray Stout, chestnut horse by Chestnut Peter, won the event. The victor, driven by his owner, was timed in 2:06 3/4.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The stock markets were less active today, with profit-taking in evidence, and the tendency was irregular. British Government funds were easier in the absence of fresh support. Industrials generally were lower, although in the afternoon the tone improved somewhat, with prices partly recovering, particularly among textiles, which had fallen on the unfavorable labor outlook.

London is easily the noisiest of the larger European cities, according to S.K. Wolf, director of the acoustic consulting department of Electrical Research Products, Inc., 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, who has just returned from a visit abroad. After lecturing in Montreal on noise abatement Mr. Wolf went to London, Zurich, Berlin and Paris.

There are ways of keeping young in spirit and attitude even in advanced years. A novel one was suggested by a contributor to The Manchester Guardian, who observed that most of the delegates to the Congress of Pre-historians in London were vigorous of body and eager of spirit, whatever their age.
ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- The State Department of Education today made public the list by countries of those high school pupils who are eligible for university scholarships.

There are ways of keeping young in spirit and attitude even in advanced years. A novel one was suggested by a contributor to The Manchester Guardian, who observed that most of the delegates to the Congress of Pre-historians in London were vigorous of body and eager of spirit, whatever their age.
ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- The State Department of Education today made public the list by countries of those high school pupils who are eligible for university scholarships.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 26 (AP). -- The prediction, that improvement would continue in the oil industry, made by the official publication of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, was approved today by leaders in the industry here. Control of production of crude oil, reduction in refinery runs and a 6,000,000-barrel decrease in stocks of crude oil and its products since Jan. 1 were regarded as favorable.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper. Fall Merchandise Now to Fore. The week saw the end of active consumer response to Summer clearances, retail executives here reported yesterday. From this point, attention will be centred almost exclusively on initial Fall offerings, with next Saturday's volume expected to provide a gauge of consumer interest.

Governor MOORE of New Jersey, elected on an economy platform, is trying to live up to his pledge to reduce the costs of government to a minimum. In a communication to heads of departments, bureaus and commissions yesterday he compared the State with a decline in revenues to a family with a diminished income.

TOKYO, Aug. 26. -- Frankly anticipating worse relations with the United States and welcoming the prospect of isolation, Kaku Mori, chief secretary of the late Seiyukai Cabinet of the slain Premier Inukai, in an interpellation in the Diet on foreign policy yesterday, gave strident utterance to the nationalists' "Back to Asia" ideals.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26. -- Governor Pinchot's demand for the resignation of Senator James J. Davis as a candidate to succeed himself for a full term was ignored today by the Philadelphia Republican City Committee, which gave a blanket endorsement to the party's national and State tickets.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company consented yesterday to an equity receivership, and appointment of two receivers, Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray, was immediately made by Presiding Judge Martin T. Manton of the Circuit Court of Appeals.

After fluctuating irregularly within a narrow range yesterday, the share market closed with moderate gains. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 3,100,000 shares, compared with 4,200,000 shares on the day before. There was a period of weakness in the early afternoon, but the general list rallied near the close under the leadership of United States Steel, and the final prices were at or near the best for the day.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- An approximation of the provisions of the will of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick became known tonight.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The second annual Economic Conference for Engineers, which opens at the Stevens Institute Engineering camp here tomorrow, will have for its general theme "Money and BankIng." Continuing through Sept. 5, lectures will be given by prominent educators and business men.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- Despite yesterday's reports that the government plans a compulsory loan from private capital in order to finance an economic reconstruction program, the Boerse rallied today after initial nervousness. Several stocks rose sharply, Siemens Halske advancing 5 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26. -- The three-day battle for sixth place ended with the world's champion Cardinals in sole possession by a two-game margin, thanks to their 4-2 decision over the Giants in the series finale today. The eminent Jerome Dean scored his second five-hit victory over the Terrymen in three days.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 26. -- Gus Moreland, pride of the Texas fairways, and Ira Couch, young Chicago broker, charged into the finals of the Western amateur championship today.

Drawn and tired-looking, with much of the spring gone out of his step, Mayor Walker returned from Albany at 8 o'clock last night and was greeted by a brass band and a large crowd in the Grand Central Terminal.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Trading was active on the Paris Bourse today for the first time in a considerable period. For some time only desultory transactions among professionals have marked the sessions. Today numerous orders, apparently from the general public, revived the market and activity developed steadily until the closing.

The United Aircraft and Transport Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30, a net income of $944,306 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 28 cents a share on 2,084,393 shares of common stock, against $1,648,104, or 61 cents a share on 2,083,791 shares, in the first half of 1931.

ROME, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The International Institute of Agriculture estimated today that 1932 wheat production in the Northern Hemisphere, excluding Russia and China, would be 1,000,000 metric tons less than the 1931 production. Rye and barley crops are expected to exceed their 1931 totals greatly, and oats to a lesser degree.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 26. -- After the manslaughter indictment against two of the five Nassau County policemen on trial for the fatal "third-degree" treatment of Hyman Stark had been dismissed by Justice John B. Johnston in Supreme Court here today Deputy Police Chief Frank J. Tappen, one of the remaining three defendants, took the witness stand to deny that he had even touched the prisoner for whose death he had been directly blamed.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Premier Herriot is leaving Paris tomorrow for a few days' vacation on the Island of Guernsey, where he will meet the British Home Secretary, Sir Herbert Samuel, but their meeting, it is said, will have no political significance. Their mutual holiday was arranged during the Lausanne conference.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- While a crowd of 40,000 happy North Side fans. including 20,000 women, roared and shrieked their delighted approval, the onrushing Cubs completed a clean sweep of the three-game series with the Dodgers by taking the final game, 10 to 4, today and now hold first place by six and one-half games ever Carey's crew.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The Whitney family swept the important races on the Saratoga care today, the thirtieth running of the Mohawk Handicap falling to C.V. VVhitney's Clotho, while Spar scored for Mrs. John Hay Whitney in the Bounding Brook Steeplechase, and Mrs. Payne Whitney's St. Brideaux won in the Dandelion Handicap.

John Marino, one of four men who held up more than thirty men in a suite of offices in the Pershing Square Building, 100 East Forty-second Street, on May 18, obtaining a small amount of money, was convicted quickly on a robbery indictment by a jury in General Sessions yesterday.

Charles Wurtzburg, 30 years old, of 115 Mosholu Parkway, an electrician for the I.R.T., rushed to help his assistant, Patrick Costello, 31, of 859 Home Street, whose foot had caught on a third rail after the rush hour yesterday morning while they were making repairs on the elevated 167th Street station of the Jerome Avenue subway in the Bronx.

Joe McCarthy's cannonaders were still functioning perfectly at the Stadium yesterday with the result that the Indians, who are rapidly becoming the vanishing race in the American League, suffered their third straight beating at the hands of the Yankees.

Full support of the Republican leaders in the Eighth Senatorial District in Brooklyn for the candidacy of State Senator William L. Love, to whom redesignation was denied by the regular Democratic organization in the Senatorial district, was announced last night upon the "voluntary, and gracious retirement" of Lewis L. Palmitier, who had been designated as the candidate by the regular Republican organization.

A close and full record of the Negro's progress in this country and in Africa has been kept during the last twenty years by the Phelps Stokes Fund. It has just published its report for the last decade. While the goals toward which both white and colored leaders are striving are still a long way off, the advance in so short a time is remarkable.

John Marino, one of four men who held up more than thirty men in a suite of offices in the Pershing Square Building, 100 East Forty-second Street, on May 18, obtaining a small amount of money, was convicted quickly on a robbery indictment by a jury in General Sessions yesterday.

IN the afternoon of next Wednesday the moon will swim between the earth and the sun. Millions in New England and Canada will witness a total solar eclipse, the most awe-inspiring of all celestial spectacles. Everywhere in the United States an eclipse of some kind will be visible; in New York there will be one of 95 per cent totality.

LONDON, Aug. 11. THE Malvern Festival has now stated its case for 1932. All the plays, arranged by Sir Barry Jackson under the general title of "Four Hundred Years of English Drama," have been performed.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Picket lines of the farmers' holiday movement slowly tightened about this capital city today as the centre of activity in the fight for higher farm prices shifted for the third time in two weeks.

GILLESPIE, Ill., Aug. 27 (AP). -- An interstate policy committee of Indiana and Illinois union coal miners will be formed next week to direct a new offensive against coal fields working under the new $5 basic wage scale, strike leaders said today.

A rapidly spreading blaze for whtoh two alarms were sounded destroyed the lumber yard of the James H. Dykeman Corporation and damaged the factory of the National Packing Box Company at Nevins and Union Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday. Two firemen were slightly injured when a pile of lumber crashed to the ground.

The Staten Island piers, built by the city in 1919 at a cost of about 130,000,000, can be developed as the centre of a great terminal for waterborne freight if the Federal Government is willing to create a free port Of entry at which commerce from foreign countries may be sorted and classified for transshipment to ether countries without payment of port fees to the Federal Government, according to Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.
Desiring to leave nothing to chance, the Yankees pressed relentlessly on toward their pennant goal at the stadium yesterday by once more scalping the Indians.

DOUGLAS FAIRBANKS sailed from San Francisco last Thursday on a big game hunt in Japan, China and Manchuria, with, the long-haired tiger for his immediate objective. The adventurer's first stop probably will be Japan.

NEW YORK. Captain the Hon. Bede Edmund Hugh Clifford, Governor of the Bahamas, and his aide, Lieut. Commander Edward Edmonstone, are visiting Mr. and Mrs. George Leary Jr. at The Lindens, Water Mill, L. I., over Sunday.

CHICAGO. Aug. 27. -- Prices of wheat were swept upward today to the highest levels since Aug. 12 and a material expansion in the speculative interest was evident.Lack of pressure at the opening of the Board of Trade lifted prices as much as 2 1/2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish before the bulge was checked.

VIENNA, Aug. 26. -- The death of former Chancellor Johann Schober, leader of Pan-Germanism in Austria, and the passage by two votes of the Lausanne protocol in the Austrian Parliament this week, cleared the way for Austrian participation in the plan for Central European economic reconstruction which France now is expected to revive.

WARSAW, Aug. 26. -- As one mixed with the crowd of 500,000 pilgrims in Czestochowa, the Polish Lourdes, gathered for the 550th anniversary of the Miraculous Madonna's Jasnagora Monastery, one felt the intensity of religious feelings of this country which is Rome's stronghold in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- A nation-wide drive, organized along the lines of war-time Liberty Loan campaigns, for spreading available employment to more workers in all industries was launched today as the nation's business and industrial committees started a new offensive against the depression.

GREENVILLE, Me., Aug. 27. -- Professor Oliver Dimon Kellogg, head of the department of mathematics at Harvard University, died suddenly of a heart attack as he was climbing Double-top Mountain, near here, early today. He was 54 years old.He was an internationally known authority in mathematics and dynamics and the theory of the potential.

A "DOUBLE-HIGH" rear axle providing two gear ratios has been incorporated as optional equipment on the Franklin twelve, it is announced. The change from one gear ratio to the other is made by a flip of a lever on the instrument panel.

Encouraging consumer response to Fall goods on display in retail stores was responsible for a heavy volume of purchasing in the wholesale apparel market last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

FREEFORT, L.I., Aug. 27. -- After he had failed in two attempts, Leo Sexton, New York Athletic Club athlete of Garden City and Olympic shot-put champion, surpassed his unrecognized world's record of 52 feet 11 1/4 inches today at the first annual track and field games of the Nassau County Firemen's Athletic Association when he made a toss of 53 feet and one-half inch.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 27. -- United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey made the following comment on Roosevelt's speech:

DESPITE the business constriction which has shrunk the purses of peasant and potentate alike, Uncle Sam is bending every effort to assist domestic manufacturers of automotive products in expanding their trade abroad. No country is too small or remote for the activities of the government's mercantile missionaries, who comb the markets of the world in endeavors to extend the sale of American motor vehicles, accessories, parts and servicing equipment.

IT has been shown that those were hasty critics whose sensitive patriotism was alarmed at the notion that the eagle on the new George Washington bicentennial quarter was the wrong eagle -- not the American eagle, but the golden or European variety, smacking of the sort of imperialism that goes with crowned heads, and is thus abhorrent to all good republicans.

HOLLYWOOD. IF it were possible for quality to keep pace with quantity, cinema audiences would be destined for several rare treats during the coming months. For this week fifty-two features are in production at major studios, the highest point since Hollywood went garrulous, and ten more are in work on the independent lots.

AMERICA, and the phenomenon known as the Americanization of Europe, have had a singularly energizing effect upon three-fourths of Mr. Chesterton's latest collection of thrusts at a naughty world. If the book were merely a recital of the old sins of gin, Jazz and hurry, one might consign it forthwith to the dust bin reserved for vieux jeux. But Mr. Chesterton is not content to explore surface phenomena.

SKYLAND, Va., Aug. 27. -- Around the open fireplaces of his Rapidan Camp "Town Hall," the President and Mrs. Hoover chatted tonight with a group of guests outstanding in half a dozen different businesses and professions.

An amendment to the Multiple Dwelling Law toward a more liberal policy in the conversion of business structures for residential purposes is being sought by the Penn Zone Property Owners' Association, announces President Samuel Kheel.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 24.-- Democratic hope for the immediate, peaceful and effective amalgamation or two highly strategic Congressional districts of Virginia, as ordered by the last General Assembly, was buried with the body of Representative Henry St. George Tucker at Lexington, July 25.

SEEKING to equalize conditions that pit semi-stock cars against special racing machines in the Indianapolis speedway race, officials, engineers of motor car plants and racing car builders have collaborated in framing new rules for 1933. Semi-stock racers, representing factory-built construction, gave the "specials" a hard run on the speedway May 30.

The Vancouver Sun expresses dissatisfaction with the policy pursued by the Imperial Conference at Ottawa. "With "Premier BENNETT following Mr. HOOVER'S lead on high protection, isolating "Canada and driving down the volume "of outside trade," it asks, "how is it "possible for Canadians to sell their "products and pay Canadian debts?"

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The Plainfield Cricket Club today defeated a short-handed team of the Veteran St. George Cricket Club by 74 runs in a Metropolitan District Cricket League match at Cedar Brook Park.

SARANAC INN, N.Y. -- The annual Saranac Inn invitation motor-boat regatta is to take place on Saturday on the Upper Saranac course at the inn. The event is of special interest this season because it will include the first competition for the Saranac Inn Cup, a splendid new trophy recently presented by Walter E. Frew of New York, chairman of the board of the Corn Exchange Bank.

Many distinguished American and foreign leaders in various walks of life will lecture in the 1932-33 program of the Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia Universitly, Russell Potter, associate director of University Extension, announced yesterday.

THE battery was radio's early team-mate. Pioneer listeners will probably always remember the "A" and "B" batteries. The all electric, press-a-button radio sent them into the discard. That ended the trials and tribulations of the battery going "dead" just when an important program was about to begin.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- More New Englanders will be going to the path of totality of the sun's eclipse on Wednesday than will go to the ballot boxes for the Presidential election in November, Professor Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, suggested in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcast System.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Scattered signs of improvement in some of our markets abroad appeared in the Commerce Department's current weekly survey of conditions.

HELSINGFORS, Aug. 17. -- Remarkable details are published in the Finnish press about a huge waterway from the White Sea to the Gulf of Finland, in the Baltic, that the Russians are reported to be completing post-haste while surrounding the work with utmost secrecy, so that very little has been heard about it, though building operations began about three years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 (AP). -- With Southern California again the chief battleground, and the prohibition question vying with personalities as the chief issues, a primary election campaign which brought out a registration increase of 288,687 voters will wind up at the polls Tuesday.

MAURICE CHEVALIER'S latest picture, "Love Me Tonight," which is attracting crowds to the Rivoli, may not be as sharp in its humor or as swift in its movement as the films which the French performer made under the guidance of Ernst Lubitsch, but it possesses several cleverly photographed sequences, a poetic charm in some parts and four or five appealing melodies.

IT HAS become quite the thing to talk of character-education and to consider means to achieve it. Throughout America today there is almost feverish activity in search for some method, some program, to apply to bring to fruition this age-long desire for practical virtue -- virtue in the things of daily life -- as the major outcome of the educational process.

Scarcity of supply brings higher prices, and no other sound way of making and keeping them, higher is known. Such movements as the farmers' holiday, now spreading through, the Middle West, are designed to promote scarcity. Hitherto the agrarian, effort has taken the form, of reducing the crop.
The Department of Public Welfare spent $20,554,888 in 1931 and provided direct relief for 243,512 persons residing in the city, according to its annual report made public yesterday.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27. -- Old Main, Bucknell University's largest and oldest building, was destroyed by fire early today with a loss estimated at more than $500,000. All records were saved, and insurance covered most of the material damage.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 28 (Sunday). -- After eight hours of deliberating the jury which is to decide the fate of the three Nassau County policamen on trial in the Supreme Court for manslaughter in the death of Hyman Stark had not yet reached a verdict at midnight last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Two veteran Cub right-handers, Burleigh Grimes and Bob Smith, held the Giants to one run in eighteen innings today, and the pennant-pointing victors set back the Terrymen in both games of a double-header by scores of 6 to 1 and 5 to 0.

Asserting that one of the principal obstructions in the way of improvement in business is the problem of the worker who has no job and cannot get one, The Lamp, official publication of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, declares that a quick way of ameliorating the severity of the emergency is the sharing of existing work and payrolls among a larger number.

INTEREST in Summer clearances has shown an abrupt drop in retail trade, and demand during the week turned to Fall offerings. Buying of a scattered type was reported, although it was also noted that better-grade goods here and there are meeting with much better response.

BENITO MUSSOLINI, the Italian dictator, is reported in the Frankfurter Zeitung of Aug. 7 as having come to the conclusion that neither the existing "Marcia Reale" nor the Fascist fighting song "Giovinezza" is good enough to be counted as the Italian national hymn.

Twenty-two men selected for outstanding work in building the R.K.O. Sound "Theatre in Radio City will receive certificates of merit and gold craftsmanship buttons tomorrow at 11:45 A.M. from the New York Building Congress. The exercises will be held in the theatre, which is at the southwest corner of the Rockefeller Center blocks bounded by Fifth and Sixth Avenues, Fortyeighth and Fifty-first Streets.

THE poet in most of us dies young, and few writers, unless they give their lives to poetry, retain for long that capacity to see things for the first time which is poetry's essence. But there is an element of poetry in all art of a high order, and that holds as true for the novel as for any other form.

There is no sincerer friend of peace and disarmament than Viscount CECIL. His article in today's NEW YORK TIMES Magazine will attract every reader who sympathizes with his generous purpose. He reviews the resolution arrived at by the recent Disarmament Conference. He finds it excellent in principle, but vague and indefinite.

THE competent manner in which Captain James Allan Mollison eased his little sport plane across the North Atlantic west-ward and the confident and casual manner in which he went about his preparations last week in New York for his return flight have started speculation once more on the oft-discussed prospect of commerical trans-oceanic flying.

FOR those who care for statistics, the management of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts makes known this week all the relevant figures of the season that ended last Monday. A few of the most interesting are herewith presented.
Small houses and residential plots comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Banking department heads in twenty States today wired to Franklin W. Fort, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, giving pledges of cooperation in his mortgage moratorium plan, made public at the national economic conference here yesterday.

MOTOR vehicle commissioners of eighteen States and automobile manufacturers will cooperate in advancing measures for safety on the road, according to plans outlined at a meeting last Tuesday of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators and representatives of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce in the chamber's headquarters here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The impression made upon me by President Hoover's speech of acceptance, in which he gave a long and detailed review of the depression with great emphasis upon its world-wide relationship, was that he was trying to find a satisfactory excuse for its long continuance.

VERONA, Aug. 12, 1932. WHATEVER difficulties may confront Italian opera houses in this crisis year, there is one institution which, far from curtailing, is expanding its activities. This is the annual Summer opera festival in the great Roman Amphitheatre of Verona.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Three exhibitors dominated the third annual North Shore Horse Show, held today on the grounds of the Old Field Club. They were headed by Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester, N. Y., whose representatives were awarded one championship and six blue ribbons, together with lesser awards in the hunter division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Pulbic Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church, amplified in the board's weekly clip sheet today his opposition to the prohibition view of President Hoover.

WHOEVER visits Niagara Falls during the next several weeks should not forget that within a few hours' drive of that famous cataract are some of the most picturesque and popular resort regions of Eastrn Canada.

Reflecting the change in the outlook for this year's yield of cotton, which is expected to be the smallest since 1923, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday advanced $2.50 to $3 a bale, with demand the broadest and most active in several years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a further three-year loan of $7,251,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Southern Railway, sanctioned conditionally a second advance of $684,450 to the St. Louis Southwestern and rejected a request for $50,000 from the Uvalde Northern.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Washington made it three straight from Detroit today, winning 6 to 2, with a sudden onslaught late in the game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Captain Emory S. Land has been designated chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair of the navy, it was announced today.

SILVER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP). -- The fifteenth annual Silver Bay Conference on Industrial Relations was told today by John B. Andrews, secretary of the American Association for Labor Legislation, that "the wretched failure of hastily organized emergency relief adequately to cope with the hunger and distress of the unemployed is becoming increasingly obvious to everybody."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a large supper dance tonight at The Orchard, to introduce to society Mr. Merrill's daughter, Miss Doris Merrill. Nearly a thousand guests accepted invitations.

In a digest of the recent annual report of the New York State Board of Housing, the Monthly Labor Review, in commenting on the mooted question of whether tax exemption results in lower rentals says that proper regulation, tax exemption indubitably aids in the production of desirable housing at lower rents than could be afforded otherwise.
BARIM, Manchuria, July 21. -- If opium raising is not a government monopoly in Manchuria it has, at least, the government's benediction.

DENVER. Aug. 27 (AP). -- Candidates to fill the unexpired term of Senator Waterman will be selected by vacancy committees of the Republican and Democratic parties under a ruling today by Secretary of State Charles M. Armstrong. Meantime Governor W. H. Adams had no announcement to make as to whether he would appoint a successor to Mr. Waterman to serve until the general election on Nov. 8.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The principal defects of our economic system are financial, according to Warren A. Persons, former Professor of Economics at Harvard and statistician for the Harvard economic service, now consulting economist in New York.

A thunderstorm accompanied by a high wind swept over the city early last evening at the close of a day in which above-normal temperatures and oppressive humidity had caused discomfort. Lightning struck several places in and about the city, including a school on the lower east side.

THE suggestion has recently been made that if and when the war debts owing to this country are reconsidered account should be taken of the debts repudiated by the Southern States before and after the Civil War. The vast majority of these debts were owed to individual bondholders in Great Britain and amounted, according to the United States Treasury, to at least $77,650,000 at the time of repudiation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Rails under water in a real wind from south-southwest, 116 sailing craft took part today in the New York Athletic Club's annual regatta, the sixteenth of the Long Island Sound championship series.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 27. -- Mrs. Miriam A. ("Ma") Ferguson swept into a narrow lead over Governor R.S. Sterling in the race for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination late tonight in tabulation of the vote in today's run-off primary.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- A bankruptcy notice has been issued in the High Court here against Captain Bruce Bairnsfather, creator of "Ole Bill" in the war period and more recently illustrator of American magazines and author of American comedy sketches.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Without any desire or intention to prejudge the novel points which are being advanced before Justice Staley, it nevertheless seems well to direct attention to a few fundamental constitutional limitations which appear largely to have been overlooked.

The American Legion of the State of New York demanded immediate payment of the Federal bonus, totaling more than $2,000,000,000, by a vote of 499 to 138 yesterday as its annual convention came to an end in Brooklyn.

The cost of operating a ship becomes greater the longer it carries barnacles, grass and other sea growth, a survey by the National Council of American Shipbuilders shows. As the volume of such impediments increases the amount of power must be increased, a study of the records of a group of vessels shows.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27. -- Returning to their winning ways after losing the entire series to the Cubs, Max Carey's still hopeful Dodgers scored their first triumph in five games when they defeated the sixth-place Cardinals in the first of a four-game series today, 8 to 3.

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- Notable as new-costume jewelry notes are Vionnet's three-crystal curtain-ring bracelets, one of silver, one matching the gown and the front one in a contrasting color. Lyolene attaches chased prystal saucerrim bracelets as a pretty finish to long, plain sleeves.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Peter Daylight, owned by John Patten of Elizabeth, N.J., and Sasha, owned by Bill Strang of Brooklyn, scored in the feature events of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today, which was sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Nine-cent cotton for immediate delivery materialized today as futures continued a spectacular advance in heavy trading and the October contract moved up to 9.18, or approximately $20.25 a bale above the year's lows, reach on June 12.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board tonight announced the twelve cities in as many Federal Reserve districts in which regional banks of its system will be established by Oct. 15.

Plans for the 1933 international exhibition of modern painting have just been announced by the College Art Association. This ambitious show, organized by the association, will open at the Worcester Museum on Jan. 1 and, its stay there concluded, will come to New York.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- The main activities in the Summer camps and colonies along Lake Champlain will end with Labor Day. This week will bring the final contests in water sports for many of the camps, preliminary to closing either the latter part of this week or early next.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Bank debits outside New York increased for the week ended Aug. 20, but the average for the first three "weeks of the month was below that for the July period, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Careful study of 23,000 evening primrose plants now being cultivated at Princeton University for genetical research may help determine the complexities of hereditary behavior in both plants and animals and may reveal important principles which can be used in the practical breeding of better races.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 27. -- Leading the field by 2 1/2 points, with only two more rounds to go, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris went definitely on record today as victor in the international masters tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland.

WHEN Jacques Cartier was sailing up the St. Lawrence, on his second voyage to America 397 years ago this Summer, he asked an Indian whom he had impressed as pilot the name of the great stream. The reply was, "A river that has no end."
CHICAGO. CHICAGO'S art sensation of a decade was its open-air fair in Grant Park, just south of the Art Institute and bordering the edge of the Loop.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Overcoming a two-goal handicap in the opening periods, and gaining a lead of 7 to 2 in the first half, the Norwood Country Club polo team today triumphed over the Monmouth County Country Club of Eatontown, 10 to 8, in the final match for the J. Ernes Stern Cup.

FURNISHINGS in the Italian-period style are being increasingly employed by decorators who wish a variation from the popular Colonial and English eighteenth century motifs. Early types of carved walnut tables and cabinets or credenzas of the seventeenth century supply the nucleus for dignified dining room ensembles.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Never in the history of Massachusetts have so many candidates sought public office at one time as now are entered for the primaries which fall on Sept. 20. In 1930 the total of candidates for nominations for the offices now to be filled again was 1,328, of whom 55 per cent were Republicans.

EUREKA, Nev., Aug. 23. -- Senator Tasker L. Oddie and Congressman Sam Arentz, Republican incumbents, both come up to the barrier this Fall, but each in a preferred position In his particular race, at the polls, with the odds on him by reason of having been a winner two times straight.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17. -- Of the various actions and happenings which have eased the tension between Bolivia and Paraguay and apparently averted war in the Chaco Boreal, history will attribute much importance to one which so far has received little public attention.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Miss Virginia May Duryee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Duryee of Suffern and Brooklyn, and Royal S. Copeland Jr., son of United States Senator Royal S. Copeland and Mrs. Copeland of Suffern, were married this afternoon at Christ Episcopal Church here.

THE farmers' "holiday" movement, news of which came out of the Middle West last week, bears in its origin a striking resemblance to other agrarian uprisings which have swept the West since the Civil War. Economics has invariably been at the root of these movements, several of which have resulted in the formation of fullfledged independent political parties.

Governor Roosevelt and his party returned to the city about 7:30 o'clock last evening, after being delayed several times by heavy thunder showers and traffic congestion along the route from Sea Girt. At Woodbridge the party was forced to halt because of the blinding downpour, and lost its motorcycle escort.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney announced yesterday that uniformed policemen had voted by 17,979 to 699 to surrender one month's pay next year, and at the same time the Uniformed Firemen's Association said the New York State Federation of Labor had adopted resolutions in Utica supporting the firemen in their strong opposition to the cut.

A NEW series of books covering all the important sciences and various aspects of social and philosophic thought is announced by Ray Long and Richard R. Smith. "New Vistas of Modern Thought" is the general title of the series.

HALTED by the depression in its program of industrial expansion, the Southern States today hang undecided between farm and factory. Naturally the present retardation of manufacturing has stimulated movements back to the land in all sections of America.

NEWPORT. -- Even though September is near, the program of benefit entertainments to attract members of the Summer colony, and in a measure to be sponsored by them, shows no signs of diminishing. The present week will close with two such affairs.

Irving T. Bush, chairman of the Bush Terminal Company, was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of attempting to revoke an irrevocable trust established by him in 1923 for his wife, who has since divorced him, and two daughters with 10,000 shares of common stock of the terminal company having a par value of $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Paul C. Daniels of Albion, N.Y., third secretary of the American legation at La Paz. has been designated third secretary of the legation at Managua.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Dick Neale of Kansas City, Mo., professional outboard motor boat driver, today won the Dawes Cup race, classic event of the mid-East Regatta held on the Muskingum River. His best time for the four-mile course was 5 minutes 20 seconds.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Nothing has cheered the French business world so much for many months as the though that, whoever wins the American Presidential election, there is almost certain to be sufficient change in the liquor laws as to permit legitimate resumption of wine exports to the United States.

BUXTON, ENGLAND. THE most distinguished event of the program of the First International Summer School of Dance, namely a dance recital in the Opera House by Anton Dolin, Alicia Markova and Derra de Moroda, proved to be one more revelation of the disillusions that the Buxton conference has presented to foreign eyes.

DESPITE the ever-mounting figures of passengers and express carried by scheduled air transport in the United States, a huge preponderance of single-engined and small planes is shown by an interesting breakdown of the aircraft statistics which has been prepared by the Department of Commerce.

MUNICH, Aug. 14, 1932. THE Munich festival may not be actually dying of dry rot, but it is sorely afflicted with that malady. Although the performances have been steadily going downhill ever since Bruno Walter was deposed from his Bavarian eminence, those that I have heard at the Prinzregenten and the Residenz Theaters these past weeks have unquestionably been the most listless and disheartening in a decade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- A reduction of at least $1,000,000,000 in the Federal budget as a prime ''essential" to general business recovery is urged by Bernard M. Baruch in the leading article in the current issue of The Nation's Business.
SHIRAZ, July 30. -- Three hundred road guards on duty in the Shiraz region, who mutinied in the week of July 15, are reported to be daily robbing travelers and looting villages.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Breaking 50 straight targets, D.C. Henderson topped a field of twelve gunners at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- A quiet, gray-haired man, has taken over the reins of President Hoover's newest business rehabilitation machine. He is Henry M. Robinson, Los Angeles banker-lawyer-businessman, who was named yesterday as chairman of the permanent central committee created by the President's business conference to coordinate government and business efforts toward recovery.

"There is curious coincidence," The London Times editorially observes, "between the lean years through which "the bees are passing and the years "of depression." In a period when even bread is endangered for some and life needs sweetening for all, it is too bad that there is a loss of honey also.

State committees of the American Engineering Council throughout the country will aid in carrying out the provisions of the Emergency Relief and Construction Act of 1932, called the most important measure from the standpoint of engineering and employment with which these committees have had to deal since they were organized last year to mobilize the engineering profession behind President Hoover's program to overcome the depression.

Notes and Oddments. Herr Hitler's delay in making himself dictator of Germany is not impossible to explain. He may be looking about for a judge to issue an injunction, against anybody trying to interfere with Hitler's crossing the Rubicon.

Dr. Sidney Yankauer, ear, nose and throat specialist, whose offices were at 121 East Sixtieth Street, died yesterday of heart disease at Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 50 years old. His home was at 288 Lincoln Street, Flushing, Queens.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 27. -- The government of Dr. Alfredo Baquerizo Moreno was overthrown today by part of the Quito garrison, supported by civilian partisans of Naptali Bonifaz, who was disqualified last Saturday as President-elect because he was said to be a Peruvian.

ITHACA, Aug. 27. -- A new first chapter of the Book of Genesis, giving the ultra modern version of the story of creation, in the light of new knowledge gained by science during the past five years ton the hidden forces that distinguish the animate from the inanimate, was presented here today before the sixth international congress of genetics of Dr. C. C. Hurst, pioneer genetist of Cambridge University, England.

Last week's activity in plans for the refunding of bonds, as disclosed by the number of calls issued, was the least in many years.
