Part of one Issue of municipal notes was added to the list to be paid this month, several small lots of municipal bonds were called for September and a block of sinking fund bonds of an industrial corporation was announced for payment in Novemebr.

LOS ANGELES is to have a season of grand opera this Fall, after all. That this should be news is surprising enough, remembering that Los Angeles was the city that made the Olympic Games of recent memory an unmitigated success. But opera, of course and the Olympic Games are different things, and last Spring it was announced that the city was abandoning its opera.

DEAUVILLE, Aug. 17. -- The interests which run the casino and the Royal, Normandy and new Golf Hotels at Deauville are adapting their prices to the requirements of this era. As a result that stretch of the Norman coast which bears the name of the Plage Fleurie and comprises Deauville, Trouville and their picturesque environs was over-whelmed with visitors for the Assumption holidays.
BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- Throughout today the German Cabinet has again been in session, clearing the decks for action in the next critical week, when the Reichstag is to meet.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- A judicial determination of Governor Roosevelt's power to remove Mayor Walker was expected to precede the reopening of the Mayor's hearing before the Governor Monday night in the Executive Chamber of the State Capitol.

DETROIT, Aug. 27. -- Gar Wood is "optimistic" over his chances again to defend successfully the Harmsworth Trophy in his races with Kaye Don, Sept. 3 to 5, but he expects that sooner or later the British quest for the plaque will succeed.

FORTY-THREE years ago he was a humble Captain of artillery in the French Army, thirty-seven years ago he was one of the living dead on Devil's Island, thirty-three years ago he was the central figure in an "affaire" that shook the French Republic to its foundation.

Speculative Interest seemed to be centered largely in the public utility group on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but substantial advances occurred in other sections of the list. Transactions were the third heaviest of the year for a Saturday, making up a total of 2,201,000 shares, compared with 661,350 shares on the Saturday before.

To reach ports of the Gulf of Mexico steamships running down the Atlantic coast must round not only the long peninsula of Florida but the keys extending for more than one hundred miles south and west of it. For many years there has been talk of a canal from Jacksonville to the west coast; nothing has come of it except a survey or two.

WHILE the world of music waits for the coming of the new season, the N.B.C. Artists' Service announces its list of recitals for most of the year, beginning with the American debut of Mark Wollner, German violinist, in Town Hall on Oct 14.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. MILWAUKEE, Aug. 27. -- Had not a young First Lieutenant named John J. Pershing pulled a few political strings to get into the Spanish-American War and in Cuba met Teddy Roosevelt, there might not have been any General Pershing of World War fame, says Judge Edward S. Matthias, Ohio Supreme Court.

REGARDING German debts abroad, I would like to refer to a recent interview given by Dr. Warmbold, the Minister of Economics, in which any idea of unilateral interference by the government in German interest obligations was unequivocally repudiated.

IT is a very serious and sobering word that Mr. Burlingame has to say to his former companions in arms. And considering how recently the "B.E.F." had the eyes of the nation centred upon it and how strenuously its moving spirits have tried to "keep the eyes there, it is also a very timely word.

When MENDEL'S laws were rediscovered at the beginning of the century, and it was found that with their aid the transmission of a few characteristics could be predicted from one generation to another, biology seemed to be in a fair way of becoming as constructive as engineering".

Industrial companies were advised by consulting engineers during the week to make comprehensive forecasts of their working capital requirements from now until the end of 1933, which requirements will be steadily increased if the rise in commodities continues.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Throughout all of the publicity given to the railroad situation the rail executives have maintained one stock demand, namely, that the government and public must save the railroads from financial disaster by the granting of both increased rates and financial aid.

BERLIN. FROM year to year the consequences of the fearful madness that plunged mankind into the World War become more terribly evident in all countries. Innumerable intelligent men are tracing the causes of the economic and political crisis and write thick volumes about it in every civilized tongue.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 27. -- Harry L. Cunningham, 50 years old, resident partner in the W.E. Hutton Co. brokerage firm and a pioneer in the Detroit automotive industry, died suddenly of heart disease early today in his home on Pontchartrain Boulevard.

The receivership to which the Interborough Rapid Transit Company consented on Friday, while helpful to the cause of unification, is not likely to advance immediately the negotiations between the city and the companies further than they have now progressed, according to the opinion expressed in well-informed quarters yesterday.

IN 1664 a London magistrate named Aleyn received a complaint that a house had been burglarized. He began a most Vigorous and as it proved, a most unscrupulous investigation. He interrogated servants and followed up clues.

With games today at Sands Point and at Bostwick Field in Old West bury just about finishing the more serious preparation, the high-goal polo teams will begin tapering off their practice this week for the open championship of the United States Polo Association, the most important event of the season, which opens at the Meadow Brook Club on Saturday.

The New York Athletic Club baseball team was defeated by the Mohawk A.C. of Yonkers, 5 -- 1, yesterday on the victors' diamond at Glenn Park. Stanley Perk, Mohawk pitcher, limited the losers to eight hits and struck out seven.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Pushing across four runs in the seventh inning, the Pirates today downed the Boston Braves in the initial game of their series, 7 to 4.

DURING a century of transition, the "Don Quixote of legitimacy," as Metternich is called, has stood like a statue, the symbol of reaction, adored by die-hards and by democrats detested. No angel has been painted so white, no devil so black as this admired, this execrated autocrat of Austria under the Hapsburgs.

IN mid-afternoon on Wednesday, when the sun should be shining in all its glory on the maple leaves of Canada, a dark shadow about 100 miles wide will creep down from Hudson Bay and across the Dominion toward New England, where it will pass out to sea.

Over the rolling terrain of The Country Club at Brookline, Mass., where Jess Sweetser won the national amateur title ten years ago by defeating Willie Hunter, Jess Guilford, Bobby Jones and Chick Evans on consecutive days, the picked golfers of Great Britain and the United States will meet on Thursday and Friday of this week in the Walker Cup matches.

WATCHING young Rigan McKinney guiding a jumper over the hurdles at Saratoga, there arose the casual question: "Where did that boy get his love for the turf?" The answer has come in a letter, and it's unfortunate that it's too long to print in full. But the story goes something like this:
LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The luxurious "Health Palace" on Harley Street, to which London medical specialists subscribed u430,000 with the idea of running a clinic on American lines, has failed.

AN inveterate traveler who prefers "hoofing it" with very little money in his pocket to more expensive and conventional ways of journeying, John Gibbons gets something out of his travels and puts something into his travel books that one finds nowhere else.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Two hundred thousand cotton operatives were called out on strike in Lancashire today, plunging the cotton industry into the worst labor dispute Britain has known since the great coal strike of 1926.

JULIAN GREEN'S new novel is something of a departure from his others. In many respects it is typical enough at its author, but in this new book Green's wholly grim and morbid atmosphere is somewhat relaxed, and the settings suggest the world we live in rather than the narrowly enclosed and steeply heightened world of Julian Green's other books.

ARE you listening? Poetry and grape juice -- autos and Wagner -- pickles and close harmony -- soft drinks and lullabies -- Beethoven and canned meat -- and J.P. McEvoy tunes in for the moonstruck static of Radio Land.

WASHINGTON. WITH the rehearing of the Black Tom and Kingsland explosion cases scheduled to begin on Nov. 1, the public will again brush up its memory of two great disasters whose causes were in dispute even before America entered the World War.

ON the last Sunday of August it is the duty of this column to terminate its annual villeggiatura and come bristling into print with news of the local theatre. That task required no feat of magic in the impetuous days of two or three years ago, for then a theatre-goer might follow his avocation with modest diligence throughout the Summer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The day of the physician who treated everything from, lumbago to laryngitis may be returning.

Improvement of the quality of advertising is the major factor needed in bringing down the cost of advertising to the stores, according to P.A. O'Connell, president of the Nation Retail Dry Goods Association and head of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston.
Under the impetus of a wide advance in cotton and a moderate rise in grain, the security markets ended the week yesterday with a fresh demonstration of strength.

While the prices of sugar and coffee moved irregularly last week, those of other commodities on local Exchanges, including cocoa, rubber, hides, silk, silver and wool tops, mover into higher ground. September coffee continued to soar spectacularly as a result of continued inability of the market to get shipments of the bean from Santos.

The heavy dealings in bonds last week on the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange resulted in the establishment of some high records for 1932. On the Curb the turnover for the week was the largest of any week in the history of that market.

Headed by Janusz Kusocinski, 10,000-meter champion, the Polish Olympic delegation sailed for its homeland on the Pulaski at noon yesterday. Eighteen athletes were in the party of twenty-eight. Among the large crowd at the pier to bid the group farewell was Acting Consul General Joseph Kubisz of New York.

WHILE New York City has been debating ways and means of reducing its expenses and thus attaining a balanced budget, other important municipalities have put into effect various measures of economy. They have found their receipts considerably lower this year, owing to a reduced tax levy and to other factors, and have planned their expenditures accordingly.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 27. -- Pacifists from all over the world met in a militant spirit here today to open the first Anti-War Congress. Under the leadership of Henri Barbusse, French war veteran and author, nearly 2,000 delegates enthusiastically fired the opening gun in the campaign to make war on war.

A gain of 2,452 for the first six months of this year is shown in numbered motor boats in figures announced yesterday by the Bureau of Navigation of the Department of Commerce. The craft include outboards of more than 16 feet in length and inboard boats under 16 gross tons operated on Federal waters in the United States.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 27. -- The three fastest miles ever trotted in the Nassau Driving Club events at the Fair Grounds were witnessed in the free-for-all trot today.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, July 21. -- Foreigners in Manchuria cling to their rights of extraterritoriality by only the slenderest thread. And just how long the thread will remain intact is by no means certain.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Aug. 27. -- While the law-enforcement authorities in this area were gambling against time to avoid bloodshed in the farmers' rebellion, the large dairies, against whom the strike is directed, served an ultimatum today that they would not negotiate on higher milk prices until the blockade was lifted.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived here yesterday from the Channel ports with 1,908 passengers, the largest number westbound on the ship this year. Of this number 1,536 were citizens of the United States.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 27. -- New Jersey boys carried off the major honors in the Citizens' Military Training Camp "Olympics" this afternoon that closed a month of athletic training for about 1,300 students from New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

Seven weeks after the beginning of the present advance in prices of stocks, which, has been more than 100 per cent, Wall Street has begun to appraise the flood of buying orders which have been pouring into brokers' offices, bringing a succession of 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 share days to the Stock Exchange.

Among the magisterial rebukes which Secretary HURLEY last week heaped upon the unconscious head of Governor ROOSEVELT was one accusing him of basing his campaign on discontent, and seeking to "make politics out of human misery." In this the Secretary of War displayed the enthusiasm of a discoverer.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- The advance in stock prices continued at today's session of the Boerse, although there was no large scale speculating owing to the week-end. The public, however, was unusually active, evidently in anticipation of the government's economic program, which is announced in advance reports as an end of deflation.

VENICE. IF you have the privilege of following a king in his visit to an art exhibition, you may safely bet that people will be more interested in watching his reactions than in concentrating devoutly upon the works shown along the walls.

ROME, Aug. 26. -- Unemployment which had been decreasing steadily though slowly since March, increased in July. On June 30 there were 905,000 unemployed and on July 31 there were 931,000. The increase, though foreseen because the number of jobless is always at the minimum in June.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Canadian sailors from the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club of Montreal had little "difficulty outscoring America's challengers in two international challenge cup races on Barnegat Bay today. With two more contests scheduled for tomorrow, the series score tonight gave the Dominion windjammers a total of 33 points to 25 for the local crews.

Further evidences that the Federal Power Commission intends to carry on an active campaign to obtain more complete Information and, if necessary, to exercise closer scrutiny over public-utility holding companies, as demonstrated in the ruling last week on the acquisition of the Clarion River Power Company by the Pennsylvania Electric Company, were the subject of much conversation in public-utility and banking circles last week.

SHANGHAI. Aug. 8. -- Chinese and foreign merchants, and the small foreign community in China in general, are joining in protests against the new tariff increase, amounting in some cases to 30 per cent, which was made effective without warning on Aug. 4 upon all goods imported.

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- Housewreckers had begun to tear down another old landmark of Paris -- St. Lazare prison for women. The unfortunate tenants of this somber edifice were all transferred several days ago to La Petite Roquette, which henceforth will house feminine offenders against the French penal code.
THE London Telegraph says that G.W. Pabst, the German director, was in London making preparations for his production of "Don Quixote." The Telegraph's story continues:

WHAT am I going to wear when I get back to town? A question many are asking themselves right now. Knowing this, we took our notebook and pencil in hand and sallied forth for a few suggestions. We found that one can get charming early Autumn things without too great expense.
MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, CLEVELAND, Aug. 27. -- With the flourish of trumpets and the firing of a cannon, the National Air Races for 1932 were started here today and will be continued for ten days.
One hundred and six new members have been added to the instruction staff of New York University, Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown announced yesterday.

MR. McCLEOD'S novels, of which this is the second, offer a good illustration of the dilemma of contemporary writing. Our age is committed to fiction as its chief form of expression and to realism in its fiction, with the consequence that essayists, dramatist and fantasists are turning out realistic novels.

Belief that export trade and export interests are being slighted by the present administration in its consideration of general business problems grew throughout the trade here yesterday and moved several of the leading export executives to condemn Washington officials for what they termed a disregard of the importance of foreign trade in national prosperity.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Although on Summer vacation in East Prussia, President von Hindenburg again this week-end faces decisions of a momentous nature, even involving settlement of an argument between Chancellor von Papen and Defense Minister von Schleicher over Adolf Hitler's storm troops.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- The Hawthorne Gold Cup goes to the Pacific Coast and will find a place in the trophy chest of Norman W. Church of Los Angeles.

DIVORCE -- and the institution of marriage -- are difficult subjects to discuss intelligently, because individual temperaments matter as much as national laws and traditions. Yet there are certain general trends to be observed in France, England and the United States, which point to a contagious change in the marriage mores of the Western World -- as well as sharp differences which point to racial characteristics.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 27. -- The mystery of Greenland's eastern mountains has been solved by Dr. Lauge Koch, Danish explorer and chief of the Danish Government's East Greenland Expedition, who has just reached here after a daring flight yesterday from Greenland to Akranes, Iceland.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 24. -- Within three weeks Georgia will have relief from the wordiest, most vituperative pre-primary campaign with which this State has ever been afflicted, for on Sept. 14 a wearied and largely disgusted electorate will go to the polls to nominate Democratic candidates for Congress, State and county offices.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 27. -- While mining men decline to predict the effect of the 4-cent preference which Canadian copper will have when shipped to the United Kingdom under the agreement reached at the Imperial Conference in Ottawa, they incline to the belief that Manitoba will benefit greatly and that Flin Flon and Sherritt Gordon, that Province's main copper producers, will soon be able to speed up production and employ more men.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- After the Summer's recess, play was resumed today in English soccer. Play began two weeks ago in the Scottish League. Nearly 750,000 spectators saw today's games.

DR. E.F.W. ALEXANDERSON and Dr. Irving Langmuir of Schenectady's House of Magic will keep an eye on the eclipse to observe any influence it may exert on radio waves. They have selected Fryeburg, Me., as the site at which to make observations on a carbonpaper facsimile recorder.

Carloadings of the Chicago Great Western Railroad this month, including last Thursday, were 1,639 more than in the corresponding period in July, according to Patrick H. Joyce, president. If this decided upturn continued until the end of the month, he said yesterday, he believed the company would show a profit from operations in August.

SHANGHAI, July 27. -- Now that the Lytton commission, which was sent to the Far East by the League of Nations to investigate and try to settle the Sino-Japanese dispute over Manchuria, has finished its investigations and is compiling its report, tooth Nanking and Tokyo are deeply worried.

HAVANA, Aug. 24. -- The steady decline of the Cuban silver dollar, which has implanted the peculiar situation of a dual currency system in the island, composed of Cuban coinage and United States currency, is extremely puzzling not only to foreign residents but to Cubans themselves.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1. -- Both Nanking and Moscow are vitally interested in the revival of a monarchical movement in Manchuria and in Inner Mongolia, even though it is suspected that Japanese propagandists and organizers are the sponsors of the scheme.

PARIS. IN France one of the best sellers in vecent weeks has been the long-awaited grammar of the French Academy. It was issued as an attractive little volume, beaurifully printed and published at the popular price of 15 francs.

Women swimmers again will be in the limelight this week. Six of the young mermaid stars are to compete tomorrow night in the natatorium at New Brunswick, N.J., in conjunction with the appearance of the Hungarian water polo team, which captured the Olympic championship at the recent games.

President HOOVER told the business leaders at Washington that the defensive battle against financial collapse has been won. It remains to drive home the counter-offensive against depression. To what factor may we attribute in largest measure the nation's successful stand against financial dissolution? To what factor may we justly look forward with confidence in the approaching counter-drive for economic liberation and restoration? To national unity.

In stressing price of the services rather than its quality, retailers inadvertently have been encouraging the growth, of pernicious practices in the resident buying field, a canvass of views of executives of leading offices indicated here yesterday. These executives said a number of evils undoubtedly exist.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The German medical profession, already overcrowded, is threatened with becoming so much more congested that thousands of young physicians before long are likely to be without patients.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Twenty-five airplanes, ranging from little sport types to 160-mile-an-hour racers, roared off into a barely perceptible westerly breeze for Cleveland, 490 miles away, this morning in competition for the Leeds and Lawrence trophies to be awarded at the National Air Races.
BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Red Sax won a free-hitting game from the White Sox today, 13 to 10, and made it three out of four for the series.

TOKYO, Aug. 27. -- The government knows definitely that the narrative portion of the report of the League of Nations inquiry commission on Manchuria will impugn two of the main points in Japan's juristic case.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The youngest team to win the national doubles championship in more than a quarter of a century wrested the title from Wilmer Allison of Austin. Texas, and John Van Ryn of East Orange, N.J., today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

BAR HARBOR. -- The Bar Harbor Club is holding a novel tournament tomorrow, called "the parent-and-child tennis tournament." Age, sex or previous condition of servitude are not to be considered among the requirements for entrance. There will be silver cups for the winners and runners-up.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26. -- Governor George White and up-State member of the legislature have been enlisted in a movement striking at one of the worst of great city evils -- the slum -- which has interested Cleveland this month.

BERLIN. PROBABLY to no country in the world could the whole-some American process known as debunking be applied more profitably that to Germany -- externally and internally. The world is full of legends about Germany, mostly unfounded or based upon foundations so flimsy that they are no foundations at all.

The Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game yesterday issued an important announcement to all hunters throughout the East who contemplate following the sport in that State. In the form of an official notice, it was similar to that issued a week ago by the State of New York, and served to supplement the Federal regulations as fixed by the United States Bureau of Biological Survey.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Hereditary differences are twice as potent as are differences due to environment in causing variations between identical twins, it was reported today before the International Congress of Genetics by Dr. H.H. Newman of the University of Chicago.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- The coming solar eclipse on Aug. 31 is the main topic of conversation at White Mountain resorts, where many reservations are being made at hotels, inns and even farm houses. It is expected that one of the largest throngs ever assembled in the White Mountains will be on hand for the event.

A LITTLE specialized training is proving such a sturdy weapon in the hunt for jobs at present that the free employment exchange of the Girls' Service League is making itself an educational institution on a sizable and varied scale. It not only is giving training for office work, but is diverting girls, where possible into other fields, including that standby of a not-long-forgotten era, housekeeping.

THE Three Choirs Festival will open at Worcester in England next Sunday afternoon. "Elijah" and "The Messiah" will, as usual, occupy the first and last mornings of the festival. Two new works will be heard: Vaughan Williams's "Magnificat," conducted by the composer, and Karol Szymanowski's "Stabat Mater," performed at the Liege Festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music in 1930 and now to be given in England for the first time.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 27. -- Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City conquered Miss Lucille Robinson, Des Moines (Iowa) college girl, today to win permanent possession of the women's Western golf championship trophy.

Most of the larger Protestant congregations of the city will hear visiting clergymen today, several from England and Scotland and others presidents or professors of universities or theological seminaries. Seldom has there been a Summer when so many of the pulpits have been occupied by educators.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Jersey City collected eighteen hits in turning back Buffalo by 10-7 today in the final game of the series. The Bisons made a total of fourteen safeties.

IN August two years ago. Lord Meston read before the Institute of Politics at Williamstown three papers which, with some changes, he has made into the six chapters of this book. An epilogue summarizes with occasional interpretative comment the work of the Round-Table Conference for India which met in London in December, 1930.

Rising wholesale prices provide the long-awaited opportunity for the stimulation of that large percentage of consumer purchasing power which has been held in check through fear and because prices previously were steadily dropping, according to views now gaining ground in retail circles.

CONNOISSEURS of murder will, of course, have heard of the famous Jewett-Robinson case which so profoundly disturbed New York during the 1830s. James Gordon Bennett the elder reported it himself for his small, struggling Herald, and reported it with a flamboyance worthy of the modern tabloid.
LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Mrs. James L. Mollison (Amy Johnson) today cabled to her husband not to start his return flight from New York until weather conditions were completely favorable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Restriction of coffee shipments by Brazil's blockade of the great coffee port of Santas has prompted State Department efforts to obtain Brazilian relaxation of a contract limiting monthly sale of coffee bartered for Farm Board wheat.

PARIS. -- None of the many important outcomes of the Lausanne conference surprised the European countries more than the surprise and apparent resentment which was caused in the United States by the publication of the "Gentleman's Agreement." This surprise was all the greater because the whole Lausanne conference had been undertaken and carried through in fulfillment of President Hoover's own suggestion that the European nations should first clear up the position between themselves.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Demanding outright prohibition repeal as a social and economic necessity, Governor Roosevelt told a throng, estimated at 100,000 persons today that President Hoover and the Republican party were attempting a "circus stunt" to appeal to both wets and drys.

Today Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown will be 71 years old, completing more than a half century of service as an educator, the last twenty-one years of which he hag been chancellor of New York University. He has already announced that he will retire as soon as the university council is able to name his successor.
Millions of persons all over the nation will stare skyward next Wednesday afternoon to witness the greatest show the heavens have to offer, an eclipse of the sun.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To suggest a new departure in the general plan of education in the high school may seem presumptuous in one who is not of the teaching profession, but who is a mother of children and an interested observer of child life and educational development of the childish mind.

THE Group Theatre, which has been rehearsing diligently through the Summer at Dover Furnace, N.Y., feels that its first production of the season will be ready for local showing about the third week in September. This will be the John Howard Lawson play.

PARIS. JEAN PATOU'S lowering of the waistline down to the hips came as the big surprise of the Paris Winter fashion openings. From the fashion writer's standpoint surprises are likely to be welcome, because they mean news; but it would not be so amusing if it meant throwing away one's whole wardrobe, as would be inevitable if this radical change were too quickly or too literally accepted.

None of the British dominions or Great Britain herself can say she got, the best of the bargain in the recent Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa, Stanley Baldwin, head of the British delegation, said yesterday in a radio broadcast in London heard in the United States over the Columbia Broadcasting System's network.

Two flame-shooting mechanical monsters will engage each other at Detroit starting Saturday in a renewal of the international supremacy for speed through the water. They are Lord Wakefield's new Miss England III, to be driven by Kaye Don, and Gar Wood's new Miss America X.

LISTENERS who complain of radio being choppy, that is, too many fifteen-minute programs, which seem to no more than get under way than they terminate, will find a different situation on Friday night. When the clock strikes 8 the gong signals to Olga Albani, soprano, the Cavaliers Quartet and Rosario Bourdon's orchestra to begin an hour of entertainment over WEAF.

ROME, Aug. 14. -- The advent of the "talkie" has given a great Impetus to the moving-picture industries in Germany, France and Italy, which now see the possibility of shaking off the domination Hollywood has exercised for many years.

UNDER the learned title "Bibliographia" there is being issued a splendid series of studies in book history and book structure. The general editor is Michael Sadleir, and he has gathered about him a group of clear-headed, thinking young men, who know how to make accurate observations and logical deductions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Uncle Steve Sumner at the age of 83 years has answered the demands of racketeers and gunmen by turning his house into a fort, with armor plate panels in the walls and steel window screens. Uncle Steve is, and has been for thirty years, secretary, treasurer and business agent of Chicago's Milk Wagon Drivers' Union and sees no reason for abdicating in favor of the underworld.

Application will be made to the Federal Loan Home Bank when it opens for business here about Oct. 15 to help refinance $10,000,000 worth of mortgages, most of them on small homes and apartments, it was announced yesterday at the offices of State Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick.

There is increasing concern that children should be "well-born." But the Children's Bureau, now twenty years old, is more interested in children after they are born. This institution was made possible by an act of Congress in the Administration of President TAFT, although it was recommended in a message three years earlier by President ROOSEVELT.

SUMTER, S.C., Aug. 25. -- Some 417,500 Democrats, or more than three-fourths of the State's estimated voting strength have enrolled to vote in Tuesday's primary, in which a United States Senator, six Congressmen, nine district solicitors, all members of the State House of Representatives and about half the members of the State Senate will be nominated.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 17. -- The new Rumanian Minister of the Air Forces in the recently formed Vaida-Voevod Cabinet, Radu Irimescu, has many friends in the United States and is chiefly known in the financial circles of New York, where he lived for a time as head of the Chrissoveloni Bank.

ASBURY PARK. -- An international yacht race in which Canadian yachtsmen will contest for the American-Canadian sloop title and a baby parade in which nearly 700 children will participate are to be events of the coming week on the North Jersey shore.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- The unusually full program of social and artistic events of the past week promises to continue throughout the remainder of the season. With a gay round of entertainment attendant upon the debutante parties now under way at many estates, the younger set as well as the older members of the colony are much occupied, and plans for the last two big week-ends of the Summer promise to keep up the pace.

NORMA SHEARER will be seen in the Lynn Fontanne role in "Strange Interlude" when Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer'a cinema version of the O'Neill drama goes into the Astor this Wednesday. Miss Shearer was born in Westmount, a suburb of Montreal, Canada.

TORONTO, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Toronto captured both ends of a double-header with the Albany Senators today, winning 8 to 1 and 5 to 4. This double victory gave the Leafs the edge in the series, four games to two.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 27. -- Gus Moreland strode off the Rockford Country Club fairways tonight with the Western amateur crown perched on his brow and an invitation to compete on America's Walker Cup team in his pocket.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24. -- Those who find pleasure in speculating on political probabilities predict that Washington this year will cast its electoral vote for Roosevelt and Garner. The plurality, however, will be much smaller than was indicated by the wave of Roosevelt sentiment which swept the State after the Democratic national convention adjourned.

The first campaign address in this State by a member of President Hoover's Cabinet will be delivered on Labor Day at the New York State Fair at Syracuse by W.N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, according to an announcement yesterday at the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PERHAPS because Americans love titles the author of this sequel to "The Education of a Princess" signs herself again by one which ceased to have validity fifteen years ago and which will probably never again have any significance in Russia except as it outlaws its possessor.

LISBON, Aug. 17. -- For several years there has been much agitation on the part of packers and exporters of Portuguese sardines for the reorganization of the industry which is the second largest of the country and from which 30 per cent of the government's internal revenue directly and indirectly is derived.

BUENOS AIRES. Aug. 27. -- The Argentine, Brazilean, Chilean and Peruvian Republics, whose frontiers touch Bolivia and Paraguay, are preparing to declare that a state of war exists in the Chaco unless the present military movements are suspended.

TRANSMISSION of weather maps over the teletypewriter circuits of the Federal airways system has been found to be practicable in tests by the Aeronautics Branch, Department of Commerce. Maps were transmitted in this way with complete success over an experimental circuit which included five airports and the Washington office of the airways division.

There is increasing concern that children should be "well-born." But the Children's Bureau, now twenty years old, is more interested in children after they are born. This institution was made possible by an act of Congress in the Administration of President TAFT, although it was recommended in a message three years earlier by President ROOSEVELT.

SUMTER, S.C., Aug. 25. -- Some 417,500 Democrats, or more than three-fourths of the State's estimated voting strength have enrolled to vote in Tuesday's primary, in which a United States Senator, six Congressmen, nine district solicitors, all members of the State House of Representatives and about half the members of the State Senate will be nominated.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Fifty-one yachts, enrolled in the yacht racing squadron of the Westhampton Country Club, had an interesting regatta on Moriches Bay off the Speonk Shore today. The wind was south southwest and strong.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24. -- When Governor Rolph, with that lavish geniality which has endeared him to thousands, suggested to the State convention of the American Legion that California should advance the money to cash the bonus certificates of the State's veterans no one took him very seriously.

MADRID, Aug. 26. -- Slashing at the dons, the Spanish Government has enacted a land seizure bill which, if carried fully into effect, will cause the forfeiture of all the land of those legally proved to have been involved in the recent revolt.

PERHAPS because Americans love titles the author of this sequel to "The Education of a Princess" signs herself again by one which ceased to have validity fifteen years ago and which will probably never again have any significance in Russia except as it outlaws its possessor.

LISBON, Aug. 17. -- For several years there has been much agitation on the part of packers and exporters of Portuguese sardines for the reorganization of the industry which is the second largest of the country and from which 30 per cent of the government's internal revenue directly and indirectly is derived.

BUENOS AIRES. Aug. 27. -- The Argentine, Brazilean, Chilean and Peruvian Republics, whose frontiers touch Bolivia and Paraguay, are preparing to declare that a state of war exists in the Chaco unless the present military movements are suspended.

TRANSMISSION of weather maps over the teletypewriter circuits of the Federal airways system has been found to be practicable in tests by the Aeronautics Branch, Department of Commerce. Maps were transmitted in this way with complete success over an experimental circuit which included five airports and the Washington office of the airways division.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24. -- Those who find pleasure in speculating on political probabilities predict that Washington this year will cast its electoral vote for Roosevelt and Garner. The plurality, however, will be much smaller than was indicated by the wave of Roosevelt sentiment which swept the State after the Democratic national convention adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Officials at the War and Justice Departments assumed blank expressions when informed today of the charge of Assistant Secretary of War F. Trubee Davison in New York that Communists were counterfeiting World War discharge papers to enable their workers to carry on subversive activities in the ranks of the American Legion.

Declaring that Governor Roosevelt is on the popular side of the two main issues of the day -- the economic condition of the country and prohibition -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City yesterday said the State of New Jersey would be carried for the Democratic ticket in November.

With the general tenor of sentiment continuing to improve, indications are that virtually all of the actual Rains of the preceding weeks have been maintained in trade and industry, while in some cases further advances have been made, according to reports received from Federal Reserve centres throughout the country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- Miss Adelaide Whitehouse, debutante daughter of former State Senator and Mrs. William F.H. Whitehouse, was informally presented to society at a dance given by her parents for more than a hundred guests at the Clambaka Club tonight. Her official debut will take place during the Winter in New York.

LONDON. THE latest indictment of modern fiction comes from the ranks of the novelists themselves. In addressing a group of women teachers. Storm Jameson has been denouncing "the cast-iron optimism displayed by those novelists who have the public by the ear today."

Adjournment of the Imperial economic conference at Ottawa leaves export interests here as much in the dark regarding future trade prospects with the British Empire as they were before the sessions started, leading export authorities said here yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- After battling for nineteen holes, the Rothenberg brothers, Rudy and Walter, finally managed to defeat another home-club pair, George Voigt and John Kadel, in the final round of the four-ball best-ball invitation tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Despite the severe test to which the nation's democratic institutions have been put in meeting the economic crisis, no grounds have appeared on which to pronounce these institutions a failure. Professor Frederic A. Ogg of the University of Wisconsin, editor of The American Political Science Review, declares in an article in Current History for September, entitled "Does America Need a Dictator?"

NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 26. -- On Thursday, Sept. 8, the voters of Niagara Falls will go to the polls for the fourth time in eighteen years to decide the question of the form of government that is to control the city. The city of Niagara Falls is the result of the merger on March 17, 1892, of the two former villages of Niagara Falls and Suspension Bridge.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP). -- A base on balls to Wetherell with the bases filled won for Rochester today, 6 to 5, in their game with, the Newark Bears.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A topic which is just as vital as the prevention of war and the present depression is automobile accidents. The deaths caused by motor vehicles for 1931 exceed even the figures of the World War of 1917-18 when 50,510 members of the American Expeditionary Force were killed in action.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Carrying with them a new instrument for photographing the sun's corona, members of a Cornell expedition left here today for New England to study and photograph the eclipse Wednesday.

The flogging of credit was resumed last week in Washington, As or many previous occasions, the President, apparently convinced that lack of confidence in the fundamental well-being of the nation's business is the one barrier to moderate prosperity, called together a group of important business men.

A NUMBER of new programs will filter through the September air. Some of the string trios and studio ensembles which held the radio "fort" throughout the Summer will soon be relieved as Autumnal and Winter artistry returns to the microphone.

IN writing briefly about the Russian theatre it is difficult to determine whether one should lay one's emphasis upon the method of its organization, its significance as a social institution or the substance of its representations. It is impossible to write of one without touching upon the others, since all three are organically inter-related.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Equaling the highest score ever made in a Grand American doubles championship, O.C. Bottger of Fairfield, Iowa, today won the twin-target title of North America by cracking 191 targets out of a possible 200.

Domestic corporation bond prices rallied briskly on the Stock Exchange yesterday during the two-hour trading period, with transactions in these issues aggregating only $4,234,000 of the total turnover in the listed market of $5,508,OOO. The previous Saturday's total dealings reached $8,110,000, of which railroad, utility and industrial bonds accounted for $6,403,000.

Tanned from an outdoor life in his native Germany, Max Schmeling, former world's heavyweight champion, returned to this country yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, prepared to launch a campaign he hopes will gain him the return of the crown he lost in June to Jack Sharkey.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Aug. 12. -- Though the Japanese leaders in Manchuria hope that by harvest time next year this country will be at peace and that Japan may then begin to reap immense profits from Manchurian trade and investments, there is considerable head-shaking among many leaders who believe that Manchuria will be a second Korea so far as Japan is concerned.

IN the period between 1890 and 1900 few New York managers would willingly consider producing a play that did not have Wilton Lackaye in the cast, George C. Tyler said last week. "He had one triumph after another. He was everything.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25. -- Buffalo is one centre which will undertake to organize a systematic campaign of opposition to the St. Lawrence seaway. Whether the objections that have appeared in Chicago and Quebec assume a cooperative character remains to be seen.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Now that the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa is over, much more will be heard in coming months of Great Britain's trade relations with the Scandinavian nations, Argentina and all non-empire countries which come within Britain's economic orbit.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The fastest time in the history of the Grand Union Hotel Stakes, first run in 1901, was made today at the Saratoga track when W.R. Coe's Pompey colt Ladysman won in 1:11 for the six furlongs and turned the tables on William Woodward's Happy Gal.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 7. -- Astonishing charges of the use of force, of intimidation at the point of the bayonet, and of attempts at briber on a colossal scale, are officially made today against the Japanese in Manchuria and against the Manchukuo Government, in a formal statement issued by Sir Frederick Maze, Inspector General of the Chinese Maritime Customs.

ALTHOUGH the author of this book employs none of the stock phrases of the psychologist, his novel is, none the less, a penetrating psychological study of the mind of a murderer both before and after his crime. It is not a mystery story, for nothing is hidden from the reader, but it is a detective story and one of a most unusual sort.

SOME 3,000,000 of the unemployed workers in the United States today will not be able and do not expect to return to their old occupations, according to the estimate of Robert B. Hill given before a recent seminar conducted by the Association for Personality Training at the Russell Sage Foundation.

INTEREST in a subject that every four years takes a leading place in the news is revived with the opening of national committee headquarters for the Presidential campaign. That subject is election funds. With a deficit still hanging over from 1928, and with money harder to get this year, the Democratic National Committee has tentatively decided to limit its disbursements to $1,500,000 in its drive to elect Franklin D. Roosevelt.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Taking the lead with the sound of the starter's gun and clinging to it tenaciously all the way, Johnny Allen, youthful Plainfield (N.J.) pilot, crossed the finish line the winner of the Stone Harbor Gold Cup perpetual trophy race today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- A "death spectrum" has been produced at the Smithsonian Institution in experiments on the effects of various light wave lengths on a living organism.

After a year of violent fluctuations, the pound sterling has entered upon a period of relative stability in the neighborhood of $3.46 1/4. In the opinion of foreign exchange experts. It has at length been brought under complete control at a level satisfactory, for the time being, to the British fiscal authorities.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange had risen about a cent a pound earlier in the week, the upward movement was resumed yesterday at the opening of trading under the largest volume of buying orders filled in several years. Gains of about $3 a bale carried all months above the level of 9 cents a pound and ran July contracts to within a quarter cent of the 10-cent figure.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Funeral services for Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick were held in her Lake Shore Drive mansion today. There were tributes of thousands of flowers. Only twoscore of the city's millions, some from exclusive social ranks, others among the humblest of her servants, were present at the rites that preceded her burial in Graceland Cemetery, where 20,000 persons pressed forward, taxing the efforts of the police to the utmost.

NEUDECK, East Prussia, Aug. 27. -- In striking contrast to the bitter partisanship of the present there stands out a little scene here today reminiscent of that older Germany that still endures beneath the political antagonisms now afflicting the Reich.

MONTREAL, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Baltimore Orioles took the series from Montreal four games to one, winning the final today, 7-2. Cunningham went the route, limiting the Royals to four hits and blanking them after the first with one blow.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Governor Pinchot vetoed today a bill passed by the Legislature which would have permitted Pennsylvania and Philadelphia to accept from the Delaware River Joint Commission revenue bonds instead of cash for the money the State and city expended for construction of the Delaware River Bridge.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 25. -- Recent events have placed Governor O. Max Gardner as completely in control of the Democratic party machinery in North Carolina as former Senator Furnifold M. Simmons ever was at any time during his thirty years of dominance in State party affairs.

MOSCOW and New York appear to invite comparison. The two greatest cities ou the world's two greatest republics -- the stronghold of capitalism and the centre of communism. Surely here is material for a study in contrasts.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 28. -- Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts addressed 6,000 Democrats of Fairfield County today at the annual outing of Sheriff Thomas F. Reilly at the local fair grounds and urged a change in the National Administration.

At a meeting of its members in Stuyvesant High School yesterday Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) accepted in principle a proposal of the Printers League Section of the New York Employing Printers Association to arbitrate the wage scale in the new agreement about to be negotiated for the book and job division of the trade.

Lieutenant McDonald Jones took an appropriate farewell of Governors Island and the reservation's polo circles yesterday. Competing in his last game on the field where, for the past three years he has been an outstanding figure, Jones led the Governors Island's quartet to a 12-4 victory over the Fort Monmouth team, while a crowd of 3,500 persons looked on.

Markets Commissioner Thomas F. Dwyer made public yesterday. a schedule of proposed license and permit fees, which would extend the supervision of his department over many more food-handling agencies than it now controls. More than $500,000 a year would be added to the city's revenues.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Replying to Governor Roosevelt's Sea Girt speech which criticized President Hoover's prohibition proposals, Representative William E. Hull of Illinois declared tonight that the Roosevelt utterances "failed utterly in candor" as to the situation in the Democratic party as to prohibition.

Advances in prices of securities and commodities are probably attributable to a reaction from the extreme pessimism of recent months, combined with occasional signs that recuperative forces are beginning to operate in some directions, rather than to any clearly visible change in the industrial and commercial situation as a whole, says the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company.

To save farmers in this and adjoining States from the necessity of dumping the produce from their harvests on the market and thus disastrously affect prices, plans are being made to create a Regional Agricultural Credit Corporation for the First Federal Land Bank District, which, besides this State, includes all of New England and New Jersey.

Such a storm as swept this city on Saturday evening gets into the news chiefly because of the damage it does. Lightning struck several buildings; two boys were drowned; fishing-boats were driven to find shelter; airplanes found their way with difficulty; trees were blown down; holiday crowds were drenched, and even the Governor and his party were halted in their return to the city by the "blinding downpour."

The road to the highest self-realization is "self-mastery," declared the Rev. Dr. Albert G. Butzer of the West Side Presbyterian Church, Ridgewood, N.J., in his morning sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, yesterday.

The steamship Harpoon of the Shepard Line yesterday entered a lifeboat crew in the annual international lifeboat race which will be held in the Bay Ridge Channel next Monday morning under the auspices of the Neptune Association. The Harpoon is the second American ship to enter, and brines the total of entrants to ten.

The country's sense of values has become distorted through a too great "headline-consciousness," Dr. Joseph B. Bernadin, assistant rector, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the All Angels' Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

A fairly good volume of reorders for Fall merchandise featured activity in the wholesale markets here during the week. Unexpected consumer interest in the new fashions resulted in wire and air-mail requests for quick delivery merchandise. These calls are almost impossible to fill because of the low stocks on hand.

It is "a self-willed, blase, tired and disillusioned" world in which we live today, the Rev. Dr. J. Stuart Holden, rector of St. Paul's Church, London, declared yesterday morning in a sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. He blamed the condition on a lack of international good-will.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- Ultramodern music, such as Leopoid Stokowski has sometimes offered to Philadelphia orchestra audiences, and received protests in return, will have no place on the programs this season. The concerts will be "almost entirely devoted to the acknowledged masterpieces."
To the Editor of The New York Times: Fabian Franklin's comments on valuing stocks are interesting and timely, and it is good to hear from that finely tempered intelligence on any subject.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Corn traders expect private crop reports due on Sept. 2 to show about as much corn as the government reported in August. The latter report indicated 2,820,000,000 bushels, of which 2,111,000,000 bushels were in States of largest production.
Former Governer Alfred E. Smith shunned yesterday an opportunity to meet his successful rival for the Democratic nomination for President, Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 28. -- Intense interest was caused in official circles tonight by reports from Tokyo that Admiral Nomura would come to this country as a good-will envoy because of the tension in Japanese-American relations over Manchuria.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Giving a fine demonstration of team play, the Eastcott four defeated the Templeton polo players in a highly interesting game at the Sands Point Club today, 15 to 9.
John J. Kiely, Postmaster, has issued the following statement on the regulation of registered mail.

Passenger rates on transatlantic lines will be Increased at a meeting at the North Atlantic Passenger Conference to be held in October at Paris or London, according to shipping men in touch with the situation. The rates which have been in effect since last April, and which represent a decrease of about 20 per cent below the rates of last Winter, have resulted in increased traffic, but in lower income for the lines.

CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 28 -- Preparations for observing the eclipse of the sun from here on Wednesday are now entering their final stage. All the large instruments of the expedition from the Franklin Institute, Philadelphia, are now erected and the remaining time will be spent in perfecting the delicate adjustments and rehearsing so that all movements of the astronomers during the 988/10 seconds of totality may be used to the best advantage.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 28. -- While the last leg of my roundtrip flight from England to America will be somewhat more than coasting, my mind is a great deal easier today than it was when I left Dublin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- American Legion officials here declared today that thirty-one of their State organizations had already adopted resolutions instructing delegates to the coming national convention to vote for immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- Senator Charles J. Hewitt, Chairman of the Joint Committee on Economy in State Departments, announced today that he had received a survey and report on the Department of Taxation and Finance made by Griffenhagen and Associates.

WESLEY CHEEK FERRELL, tall, curly-haired and confident, is fast becoming a real pitching problem. The great record of the big right-hander from North Carolina is well known to baseball fans. Since be first stepped into the big league four years ago he has never failed to win at least twenty games in a season.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- Business sentiment in Berlin this week was dominated by nervousness concerning the possible political developments after the expected dissolution of the new Reichstag. Financial circles seem to fear the effect on foreign capitalists of a constitutional struggle in Germany, while manufacturers, importers and exporters are apprehensive about the supposed projects of the Papen Cabinet regarding industrial planning.

The mistake made by economic leaders today in attempts to solve the depression problem is their belief that "the pocketbook," rather than God, is almighty, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge declared yesterday in his sermon at High Mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- With only slight variations in demand for steel mill products, total has been undergoing virtually no change recently. While predictions of substantial improvement before the end of the year have been general in the trade there have been few of improvement in August.

Life insurance companies represented, in New York, which carry 80 per cent of the business in force in the United States, showed new business of nearly $14,000,000,000 in 1931, according to a complete report announced yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Absence of any avowed candidates for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, while there are at least five aspirants for the Republican nomination for Governor, has brought some of the party leaders to believe that it may be best to nominate one of the Gubernatorial candidates for the Senate, it was learned yesterday.

Waning spirituality and the substitution of the clang of the cash register for the song of God made the present depression inevitable, according to the Rev. Hillyer H. Straton, son of the late Dr. John Roach Straton and pastor of the First Baptist Church, Muncie, Ind., who delivered the morning sermon yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, where his father was pastor until his death in 1929.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 27 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.9, which compares with 61.8 a week ago, 61.9 two weeks ago, 61.1 three weeks ago and 60.9 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date, was 66.3 in the first week of January, The average of June, 187 at 59.3, was the lowest.

The Government or Costa Rica, through J. W. Seligman Co., fiscal agents for the republic's 7 per cent dollar bonds due on Nov. 1, 1951, and outstanding in an amount of slightly more than $7,000,000, announced yesterday a plan for meeting payments of interest on the issue during the next three years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Eleven recommendations for coordination and maintenance of municipal transportation facilities were proposed today by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States headed by Chester I. Barnard of Newark, president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, and were transmitted to the chamber's member organizations for a national referendum.

ITHACA, Aug. 28 -- A genetic garden, with thousands of varieties of living plants, grown here over three and a half acres of ground, which demonstrates what genetics can do in improving old species and creating new ones, Is among the novel features of the Sixth International Congress of Genetics.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The slaughter of cattle for market has decreased each year since 1926, while the number of cattle has been increasing since 1927, moetly in breeding stocks and principally in the Corn-Belt States west of the Mississippi River, says C.V. Whalin of the Bureau of Agriculture Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture.

The upturn of business sentiment has stimulated a twenty-five-per-cent increase in concert bookings within the last month, according to an announcement yesterday by George Engles, director of NBC Artists Service, which manages the services of about 125 artists.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- For the fifth time in seven years the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association was forced to lower its colors to the Corinthians of the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club of Montreal as the Dominion skippers scored a 43-to-35 triumph today as the annual international series concluded.

TOKYO, Aug. 28. -- Because of anxiety in high quarters over what is regarded as growing tension, in Japanese-American relations, Vice-Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura has been directed to sail from Yokohama next month on a good-will mission to the United States.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The United States has already spent $6,000,000,000 on World War veterans and will spend $21,500,000,000 by 1945 if payments continue under the present law Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, chairman of the national committee of the National Economy League, said in a statement today.

James Maxton, member of the British Parliament, believes that "the conservative element in human nature, which always resists change, is on the side of the continuation of the present order in Russia." This statement is made in his biography of Lenin, issued recently as one of the initial volumes in the series of biographies which D. Appleton Co. will publish.
BUFFALO, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Fine pitching by Bill Gould who achieved an 8-2 triumph in the opening game, enabled the Buffalo Bisons to break even with the league-leading Newark Bears today.
BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The Bureau of Statistics has published the result of its survey of Germany's foreign indebtedness as of next February.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (AP) -- On the eve of the new school term, opening Sept. 1, the central committee of the Communist party has issued an edict marking a significant departure from the Communistic theory of education followed since the beginning of the Soviet regime.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- More than a hundred persons were present this afternoon at a reception and tea given by Mrs. Edward V. Hartford at Seaverge in honor of her daughter-in-law, Mrs. G. Huntington Hartford 2d, who before her marriage was Miss Mary E. Eppling, and Miss Mary Booker, a niece of Mrs. Hartford, who are her guests.
When Misfortune Primes the Pump Who shall say what is economic and what is uneconomic? The president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad thinks it is often hard to tell.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- The reduction of 24,000,000 francs in the gold reserve of the Bank of France, reported for last week, made the total reduction 270,000,000 since July 15. This has occurred notwithstanding the information, in well-informed circles, that the bank would continue to repatriate the gold now held for its account in foreign markets, especially in New York.

The Golden Gate Bridge and Highway District, incorporated in 1923 to remove the water barrier between San Francisco and the north coast section of California by means of a 6,400-foot suspension bridge, plans to offer at 2 P.M. on Wednesday the first block of $6,000,000 of bonds of the total authorization of $35,000,000, according to word received here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fowler gave a large buffet luncheon today at Hither House for Mrs. Fowler's daughter, Miss Mollie Flagg, who will be introduced formally to society at a dinner-dance on Thanksgiving Day at the River Club in New York.

Brokers reporting realty activity in the metropolitan area over the weekend indicated by their announcements that there is a good demand for homes in the suburbs. Most of the houses taken over the week-end were acquired by lease, these deals showing that the Fall house hunting season is being maintained.

Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, yesterday urged the city administration to intervene in the Interborougrh receivership to protect its own extensive interests, and not to wait "until the horse has escaped before locking the stable door."

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- "Montagu C. Norman's visit to the United States is unquestionably connected with stabilization of the pound," writes Isidore Ostrer, economist and editor of The Sunday Referee, in an article prominently displayed in his paper today.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Albert (Whitey) Michelsen of New York, member of the American Olympic team, today won the Boston Olympic Club's marathon race from a brilliant field on the Rockingham Park mile track. The veteran crossed the line leading John Sample of Lynn, Mass., by three-quarters of a mile.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 18 (by Science Service) -- Collecting specimens of a new species of a rare plant genus among the geysers on the lakebottom of an extinct volcanic crater was a thrilling experience of the three Boy Scout naturalists who are adventuring and exploring in Costa Rica.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- Attorney General John J. Bennett replied today to Secretary Hurley on his statement made Thursday at Providence, that Governor Roosevelt had failed to enforce the laws of New York State to protect the public against fraudulent sales of securities.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 28. -- Despite reports that the "farmers' rebellion" was weakening in the Omaha-Council Bluffs area, picket lines in this section tightened today. They were established on six of the thirty-two roads leading into Des Moines in an attempt to bar all farm produce from that city.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Thrown from their racing automobiles as the tiny machines side-wiped and then locked together, two drivers were killed this afternoon in the full view of a crowd, of 6,000 persons which was attending the opening meet of the season at the local speedway.

It is no longer possible to doubt that the national convention of the American Legion will overwhelmingly demand immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus. One State after another has been declaring for it. On Saturday the Legion convention of New York -- "God forgive her, she's a kneelin' with the rest" -- voted for it by 499 to 138.

MUKDEN, Monday, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Bands of Chinese raiders early this morning attacked a number of strategic points in Mukden and forced Japanese authorities to call out all available troops and police. Severe fighting was going on in the streets at daylight.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 -- Volcanic asbes are again falling in large quantities in the Andean provinces of Argentina and arc accompanied by strange atmospheric disturbances.

ITHACA, Aug. 28 -- In the hypothetical "best of all possible worlds," genetically speaking, the ideal society, in the opinion of J.B.S. Haldane, British scientist and author will have no room for "the perfed man," for the simple reason that no such entity can exist, even as an abatraction.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Baltimore twice took the measure of Rochester in two fast games today, 7 to 1 and 5 to 0. The Orioles won the first with a cluster of seven runs in the sixth off Jim Winford, who had not given a hit previously. The game was played in 1 hour 24 minutes.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- Steel production schedules for this week indicate a moderate strengthening in employment conditions in this district, with prospects that September will register progressive betterment. The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Republic Steel Corporation will enlarge their output, and the Ohio works of the Carnegie Steel Company will resume operation after a week's intermission.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- There was breeze aplenty today for the Larchmont Yacht Club's last special regatta of the season. One racing boat was sunk, another was dismasted, and spars and halyards let go in profusion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- To provide capital for the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks, the new banking system's board of directors will tackle this week the job of selling $128,000,000 in stock.

With the bulk of the Republican national campaign fund, if precedent holds good, to be collected in this State, announcement was made at Republican National Committee headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that a fund-raising agency to operate jointly for the Republican National Committee and the Republican State Committee was in process of formation, with Henry Rogers Winthrop as its chairman.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians and the Boston Red Sox today divided a twin bill, Cleveland batting hard for a 10 to 1 victory in the first game and the Red Sox registering a 4 to 3 triumph in eleven innings in the second contest.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Four firemen and one civilian were injured this morning in a $150,000 blaze of undetermined origin which swept through Orchard Street in the heart of the business section here.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28. -- Subscribers to the home town newspaper buy from 12 per cent to 21 per cent more merchandise from local merchants than the non-subscriber, while subscribers living in near by rural or smaller communities buy from 9 per cent to 35 per cent more merchandise from advertisers than non-subscribers buy, according to a summary of investigations released by the journalism department of the University of Southern California.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The impression produced in financial circles here by the outcome of the Ottawa conference has been favorable. It is realized, however, that it is impossible immediately to assess the value of many agreements which had been concluded, or their probable effect. Some of them, indeed, are tentative.

Montagu C. Norman, governor of the Bank of England, conferred with New York bankers here over the week-end, having arrived unannounced Saturday from Bar Harbor, Me, for a conference at the Federal Reserve Bank, presided over by Governor George L. Harrison.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- New York City's 1932 budget of $631,000,000 may be reviewed before Governor Roosevelt if he decides to let James E. Finegan, independent Brooklyn Democrat, press his charges of neglect and inefficiency against Mayor Walker.

When a town which habitually enjoys a music season abandons its citizens to silence -- or the radio -- concert artists and their managers blame the depression. The theatres may be dark and the talkies showing to half-filled houses at cut rates, though musicians hang on; but when music is gone they take it that business is really bad.

Delegates to the New York State American Legion Convention in Brooklyn proved their good faith by voting in favor of an amendment to the World War Veterans act, which would save the government more money than immediate payment of the bonus would cost, Dr. George J. Lawrence, of Flushing, newly elected State Commander of the Legion, said yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "Seven-Point Economic Plan" of the Advertising Club is a distinct recognition of the responsibility of capital toward labor, but it falls far short of recognizing other important factors in the present disorganization of the nation's business and industry.

SKYLAND, Va., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Close attention was given by President Hoover today to the Sea Girt speech of Governor Roosevelt as it appeared in newspapers brought to his Rapidan camp by a marine airplane carrying the White House mail.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Premier Herriot, oa reaching Havre en route to Jersey to take part in the Victor Hugo fete and incidentally to confer with Sir Herbert Samuel, the British Home Secretary, greeted the athletes of the French Olympic team, returning from Los Angeles, and made a brief political address before municipal officials and a large crowd gathered to see him sail.

HONOLULU, Aug. 28. -- Efforts of the War Department to have declared Illegal at least a part of the Federal road-aid system of Hawaii were revealed yesterday with an announcement by Governor Judd that he would depart for Washington on Sept. 7 for a series of conferences with government officials.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28. -- With the first game of today's double-header already in the Cardinals' winning column, Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean pitched his mates to victory over the Dodgers in the nightcap and gained new fame while a Sunday crowd of 13,500 loudly acclaimed the new idol of St. Louis fandom as he retired with a damaged ankle after the eighth, Sylvester Johnson succeeding him on the mound in the ninth.

PASADENA. Cal., Aug. 28. -- Acknowledged victor of the internaional masters tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland, in which he had made certain of first prize before the semi-final round, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris suffered his first setback when he succumbed today to Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., Member of the cup-winning United States team and last year's champion of the Marshall Chess Club of New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Wheat is expected to receive greater attention by Eastern speculative interests who have been in the market for some time. They bought on the breaks last week and sold on the bulges, so that the market would not advance too fast.

The headliners of a generally entertaining vaudeville program at Loew's State Theatre this week are Owen Moore, stage and screen actor, and Ann Pennington and Charles Judels. Appearing in a sketch entitled "Help Wanted," Miss Pennington, dancing star of many a "Scandals," and Mr. Judels are assisted by Roy Roberts and Wally Coyle.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 28. -- Illinois Wesleyan University will accept farm produce to the full amount of a student's tuition and pay a premium above the market price.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 28. -- The tiny Puss-Moth monoplane, Heart's Content, which bore Captain Mollison on the first solo crossing by air from Europe to North America, was guided lightly across the runway here by the flier this morning and at 11:48 o'clock bounded into the air on what is scheduled to be the first round trip between the two worlds.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 28. -- The trial of Deputy Chief Frank J. Tappen and Detectives Harry Zander and Leslie W. Pearsall of the Nassau County police for manslaughter in the death of Hyman Stark, fatally beaten while a prisoner, ended in a disagreement in Supreme Court here today.

The Down Town Republican Club of Los Angeles has canceled a dinner and rally as a result of a postcard poll which showed that 70 per cent of its members were supporting Governor Roosevelt, the Democratic nominee for President, according to information received by the Democratic National Committee and made public here yesterday.

French sheep-raisers, according to Le Temps, are distressed by the scarcity of shepherds and are carrying on a vigorous recruiting campaign. Year by year the number has diminished. The profession is dying. At first thought the automobilist feels a cruel joy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- After losing three straight games, the Detroit Tigers turned a furious batting barrage on the Washington Senators today and won the final game of the series, 15 to 7.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Howard McMichael's Grey Fox showed the way to sixteen rival craft today in the last of the series of Star Class races held by the Port Washington Yacht Club on Manhasset Bay.

MUENSTER, Germany, Aug. 28. -- In this city, the birthplace of his predecessor and rival, Dr. Heinrich Bruening, and the capital of his own native State of Westphalia, Chancelor von Papen today sounded the keynote of the German Government's attitude in the parliamentary struggle opening this week.

Babe Ruth, being of a sort who never allows himself to become discouraged by any passing adversities, bit two home runs at the Stadium yesterday as the Yankees opened a five-game series with the White Sox before a gathering of 32,000 admiring clients.

At Sea Girt Governor ROOSEVELT discussed the subject in which the great throng that greeted him was chiefly interested. The succession of Democratic victories in New Jersey has been attributable to the Dry faction in the Republican party there.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- France was again warned today by Finance Minister Germain-Martin that her economic situation was far from satisfactory and that drastic sacrifices as well as the same spirit of united cooperation with which the nation avoided bankruptcy in 1926 would be necessary before the 1933 budget could be balanced.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The possibility of an Anglo-French commercial agreement as a sequel to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa is expected to be discussed by Sir Herbert Samuel, the British Home Secretary, and Premier Edouard Herriot of France when they meat tomorrow on the Channel Isle of Jersey.
MONTREAL, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal opened a six-game series with Albany today, winning two games, 3 -- 1 and 2 -- 0.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Harsen Rhoades of the Hotel Carlyle have left for Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 28. -- The United States Coast Guard destroyer Welborn C. Wood, in command of Lieutenant C.W. Lawson, arrived at Section Base 4 pier here at 7:45 A.M. today with two of her starboard propeller blades broken, owing to a collision with a whale, which was estimated to be about ninety feet in length.

As a result of the fee-splitting between Dr. William H. Walker brother of the Mayor, and four city physicians, Governor Roosevelt has been asked by the City Affairs Committee to start an investigation into all aspects of the payments made to city physicians in workmen's compensation cases.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Shanty Hogan's big bat blasted a homer into the left field bleachers with two on bases in the ninth today, putting the Giants one run ahead and threatening to terminate the Chicago Cubs' winning streak, the longest one the National League has evolved this season.
