OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Aurora and the Hurricanes, the two polo teams which will contest the opening match of the national open tournament on Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club, engaged in a Knox Cups game today at Bostwick Field.
Every candidate for Congress will be asked the following question within a few days by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform:

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, Cleveland, Aug. 28. -- A move is on foot, it was revealed here today, to Join New York and Chicago by a second airmail line through the acquisition of a substantial stock interest in Trans-American Air Lines by representatives of the Cord interests.

The philanthropic and sociological achievements and the improvement of inter-racial relations in America and Africa in two decades are described in the "Twenty-Year Report of the Phelps-Stokes Fund," just published. The report reveals a series of investigations and undertakings which have resulted in improved education for the American Negro, in better conditions for the African Negro, in aid for the American Indian, in model tenements and help in many other fields.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 28. -- Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson, first woman Governor of Texas, and Governor Koss S. Sterling were fighting a neck-and-neck race today for the governorship as the end neared in the tabulation of the vote in yesterday's Democratic run-off primary.

The real menace to world peace in the Manchurian situation is not in the quarrel between China and Japan, which can be adjusted in time, but in the interference by the Western countries, George E. Sokolsky, author and American student of Far Eastern affairs, declared yesterday afternoon in an address broadcast from Station WOR.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 28. -- Bolivia has refused, it was learned today, to surrender three forts taken from Paraguay in the disputed Chaco region, and a Cabinet shake-up has followed the decision, two Liberal members having-resigned.

Senator Robert F. Wagner made public yesterday a letter addressed to Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, charging that there has been undue delay by the Federal Government in putting into effect the relief and construction act under which Congress appropriated $322,000,000 for public works as a measure of unemployment relief.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Guardsmen of the Ninety-third Brigade, composed of 2,200 men from New York City, marched in review at Camp Smith near here today before United States Senator Robert F. Wagner. Several thousand visitors, including veterans of the two regiments, cheered the 165th Infantry, formerly Known as the old Sixty-ninth and the "Fighting Irish" of Manhattan, and the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn.

Senator Robert F. Wagner made public yesterday a letter addressed to Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, charging that there has been undue delay by the Federal Government in putting into effect the relief and construction act under which Congress appropriated $322,000,000 for public works as a measure of unemployment relief.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Guardsmen of the Ninety-third Brigade, composed of 2,200 men from New York City, marched in review at Camp Smith near here today before United States Senator Robert F. Wagner. Several thousand visitors, including veterans of the two regiments, cheered the 165th Infantry, formerly Known as the old Sixty-ninth and the "Fighting Irish" of Manhattan, and the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Reds and Phillies divided, a double-header, 2-1 and 3-2, today, giving Cincinnati the long end of a three-game series.

In reponse to requests from many parts of the country, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, in a copyrighted interview with The Associated Press on unemployment, spoke of the success that has met the campaign of America's largest industrial unit, in distributing work among its 220,000 employes.

New Yorkers of the '90s -- at least those who were in the habit of promenading along the green lawns and pebbled lanes of Central Park -- may recall that brave band of ever-alert custodians known as "sparrow cops."
An unknown versifier daubed an inflammatory couplet with red paint in letters four inches high along the west wall of Grant's Tomb some time between sundown Saturday and day-break yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The agreements of the recent Ottawa Imperial Economic Conference granting preferentials in Empire trade, Senator Bull of Tennessee declared today, resulted from the American policy of "economic nationalism" which "comprises every known method of obstructing international capital and trade such as high tariffs, quotas, exchange restrictions and embargoes."

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Four days before John A. Machray, university governor and Church of England Chancellor, makes his first court appearance to answer to theft charges, auditing of books of the two institutions whose funds he controlled has revealed the following facts:

Mr. GARNER'S letter of acceptance is a temperate Democratic campaign speech. Our Republican friends, who are trying to make him one of their main issues, are hard put to it to draw any comfort from his words. He is not ebullient or "fiery" or destructive or "radical" or anything else that he ought to be to correspond with the blood-freezing portrait of him that they wish to draw.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Trade in all lines is steadily enlarging in this part of the country, the gains in the last two weeks having been more pronounced than they were previously and covering a wider range of commodities. Credits are expanding and there is a disposition to regard the depression as rapidly disappearing.

No aspect of the economic situation has been watched more anxiously than the course of staple prices. This was believed to be the real key to possible revival. Absence of any definite and continuous check to the downward movement was one of the principal causes for discouragement.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28. -- Five of America's Walker Cup players enjoyed their first practice rounds over The Country Club course today in preparation for the biennial Walker Cup matches with Great Britain's amateurs next Thursday and Friday.

The Summer theatres, approaching the end of their season, will again try out several new plays this week. At White Plains, starting tonight, the County Centre Theatre will present "Home is Best," by Charles Divine, which is scheduled for Broadway production in October by Clovelly, Cracraft and Berkeley.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- In a spanking breeze out of the west, which hauled around and blew out of the northwest shortly after the start, twenty-eight sloops sailed in the eighth race of the August series off the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Harvesting and threshing of Spring wheat and small grains in the American Northwest are about complete. The yields are irregular, especially in Western and Northwestern Dakota and in Montana. In parts of the latter State they are extremely small.

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, CLEVELAND, Aug. 28. -- Ben O. Howard, Kansas City mail pilot, demonstrated dramatically today his ability both as a designer and a race flier. In the first fast event of the National Air Races for 1932, which ended their second day of a ten-day program tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Stock market activities at London are running well ahead of the customary midsummer volume. This is particularly the case with industrial securities, many of which have now doubled or even trebled their value, as compared with the low levels earlier in the present year.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Aug. 28. -- After a slightly faster trip than he made previously from St. John to New York, Captain James A. Mollison today brought down the Heart's Content in a large field at Nerepis, about eighteen miles from here, at 4:30 P.M., Eastern Standard Time.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 28 -- Great activity featured the cotton market again last week and prices soared to new high levels for the season. The market strongly resisted all reactionary tendencies.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28. -- Soviet Japanese relations' are now in a fluid state of unusual interest as far as world politics are concerned. In recent dispatches the writer asserted Russia and Japan had reached the decision that friendship was better than hostility, but this should not be interpreted as implying the existence of a definite agreement or even an entente cordiale.

Considerable readjustment in the line-up of next week's theatrical productions was made yesterday. Max Rudnick's variety-revue, "Folies Bergere," which had been scheduled for the Sam H. Harris Theatre during the coming week, was suddenly withdrawn, its last performance having been played on Sunday evening in Newark.

The market for United States Government bonds, notes and certificates of indebtedness, which has dwindled so much in the last few days that trading yesterday was almost at a standstill, is awaiting the announcement by the Treasury of its financing plans for Sept. 15, which is expected soon after Labor Day.
DES MOINES, Aug. 29 (AP) -- James C. Stone, chairman of the Federal Farm Board, today viewed increases in the securities and live stock markets as indications of business recovery.

ALBANY, Aug. 29 -- Following is the text of Supreme Court Justice Ellis J. Staley's decision in the suits by Mayor Walker and George Donnelly, secretary of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, challenging Governor Roosevelt's power of removal:

Saturday's rise-in stocks was carried somewhat further in yesterday's early trading; but the advance did not hold, and the subsequent reaction left most of the market, at the last, with a net decline. Bond prices also lost ground slightly for the most part; declines ranged from 1 to 3 points, but there were some advances.

The great strike in Manchester has been precipitated directly, not on the question of wages and working conditions, but on a demand for the reinstatement of 3,000 union members who struck last Spring and have not been able to get back their jobs.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The Bourse was very strong today with steady advances all along the line, while the total number of shares dealt in greatly increased. Prices opened above Friday's levels, rose steadily and closed at the highest points of the day.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 Prices soared in brisk trading on the Boersa today. For many years Berlin's Boerse has not seen such a boom, and brokers and clerks had long since lost experience in handling a sudden storm of buying. Those who had taken a chance on Chancellor von Papen's economic plan, which had been held absolutely secret, realized substantial gains, and it is expected the boom will not be confined to one day.
MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 -- There were two slow closed-course races for low-powered machines at the National Air Races today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a one-time member of the Priorities Committee of the War Industries Board, I can testify to the high regard felt by all the members of that organization, and especially by Judge Parker, chairman, for General March and for his rare ability in sending the army abroad and bringing back the men for demobilization.

The draw for the annual men's national singles and the veterans' national singles tennis championship tournaments, which will get under way at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills on Saturday, will be made at noon today at the Hotel Vanderbilt.
New Yorkers went shopping for smoked glasses yesterday and adjusted camera lenses in preparation for the show of shows -- tomorrow's eclipse of the sun.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Herbert Sutcliffe, Yorkshire's first wicket batsman, who will be one of the bulwarks of the English cricket team which will visit Australia this Winter, completed his 3,000 runs for the season today by scoring 122 not out for his county in the match with Sussex.

P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company and chairman of the board of directors of the United States Lines Company, is to return today on the White Star liner Olympic from London, where he went to confer with the White Star directors about the payment of the balance of money due to the I.M.M. on the sale of its ships.

Richard F. Hoyt, banker and aviation financier; the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, of which he is chairman, and the New York Air Terminals, Inc., the New York Airways, Inc., and the Pan-American Airways, Inc., of which he is chairman of the executive committee, were sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for $3,070,000 damages by Elmer H. Holmes and the Holmes Airport, Inc., which he founded.

Hungarian amateur boxers captured the honors at the international tourney staged before 1,000 persons by the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island last night, when they won two out of three bouts against American opposition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES has so many bouquets cast at its feet from different parts ot the world that it is probably weary of praise and might prefer a little criticism for a change. But I feel constrained to throw another nosegay at this time.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Word was received here today of the death on Saturday of Oliver C. Semple, former member of the Public Service Commission. He succumbed to a coronary embolism at Bradford, Vt., where he was passing a vacation with his wife. His age was 71.

A suit to foreclose a mortgage on the twelve-story building at 70 Wall Street was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against the 70 Wall Corporation and the 1932 Holding Corporation by the Com Re Company, Inc., which acquired a consolidated mortgage for $410,000 from the 44 Wall Street Corporation.
Housing deals, including a Jersey City apartment house resale, comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 30 -- The silk exchanges in Kobe and Yokohama closed yesterday as buyers forced the price of silk up almost 100 yen ($23.25 at the current rate) a bale to 1,100 yen ($255.75) and sellers failed to come forward.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- On the eve of the opening of the new Reichstag, Chancellor Franz von Papen flatly told Adolf Hitler today he could not take a hand in the government of Germany and Herr Hitler replied in kind tonight.

Acting with the approval of the Attorney General of the United States, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, yesterday voided an indictment voted two years ago against Martin J. Healy, Tammany district leader, who formerly was a deputy commissioner in the Department of Plant and Structures.

Men of Chief Inspector O'Brien's staff staged last night what experts called one of the nicest raids since the prohibition law went into effect. Every one was so friendly. The object was the New Stork Club, an alleged -- if exclusive -- speakeasy at 51 1/2 East Fifty-first Street, just off Park Avenue and diagonally across from both St. Patrick's Cathedral and St. Bartholemew's Church.

Although Rudy Vallee, orchestra leader and radio entertainer, and his wife, Fay Webb Vallee, former moving-picture actress, have not separated, a Reno divorce is likely unless difficulties that have arisen between them can be harmonized, Hyman Bushel, attorney, said yesterday in announcing that he was acting for both sides in the dispute.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 29 -- The seizure of the government by Conservative supporters of Neptali Bonifaz has precipitated a civil war in which religion is involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A suspension of histilities in the Chaco for sixty days from Sept. 1 was proposed to Bolivia and Paraguay today in an identic note by the Committee of Neutrals which is exercising its good offices for peace. During the truce the plan would be for a peaceful solution of the issues to be worked out.

GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 29 (AP) -- President-elect Neptali Bonifaz's rebels were reported this afternoon to have been dislodged from the capital, Quito, today after a brisk engagement, the government announced, and federal troops were thought to have regained control for the first time since Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Jesse H. Jones, a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said tonight in a radio address, as released by the National Broadcasting Company, that "We have authorized $50,000,000 for Cotton Cooprative and Cotton Stabilization Corporations to enable them to hold their cotton until 1933."

SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The extreme outsider, 25 to 1 in an eight-horse field, J.A. Coburn's Eva B., won the thirtieth running of the Kentucky Claiming Stakes, feature today at Saratoga in a race that saw interference several times from the head of the stretch to the wire.

William V. Creighton, who died last Sept. 17, leaving a net estate of $116,548, gave nearly $70,000 in public bequests, the appraisal showed yesterday. Shares equaling a sixth of the residue, or $11,544 each, went to the Stuyvesant Square Hospital, New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, Little Sisters of the Poor, House of Calvary, Rosary Hill Home and Presbyterian Hospital.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Marty Sampson, 161 1/2, Lynbrook middleweight, outpointed Larry Marinucci, 155, Brooklyn, in the feature six-round bout at the Long Beach Stadium tonight. The show was for the benefit of the Nassau County Police Fund.

Irregular prices in quiet trading characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Railroad bonds were weaker, as were public utility issues, to some extent, while industrials were higher, on the average. Leading foreign loans showed some improvement, but United States Government securities were irregularly lower.
SIMLA, India, Aug. 29 -- Indian importers of non-British cotton piece-goods will pay from 31 1/4 to 50 per cent ad valorem as a result of new duties announced today by the government of India.

The United States Shipping Board has completed the junking of undesirable ships which were left in the waters of New York as remnants of the government's high-pressure wartime building program, Frank J. Denniston, manager of the New York district of the Merchant Fleet Corporation, the operating division of the Shipping Board, announced yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Orme Wilson, of Washington, D.C., are with Mrs. M. Orme Wilson at the Pierre.

A new Chancellor is sought for New York University. Many will hope that he may not speedily be found, provided the administration of Chancellor BROWN is prolonged. His seventy-first birthday warrants a claim to the "otium" which CICERO described as "the most ex"cellent and supremely desirable "object to all sane and good and "fortunate men."

FRYEBURG, Me., Aug. 29. -- The valleys of the White Mountains bristled with giant telescopes and cameras today as astronomers from all over the world drilled their staffs for the big show on Wednesday.

Chairman MACY'S entirely "neutral" machine is reported to be dealing, in the masterly manner to be expected, with a pressing geographical problem. In justice to all, it has been felt until lately that the Republican nomination for Governor should go to an up-Stater and that for Senator to a citizen of this city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- In a game marked by thirty-three hits, including six triples, Washington defeated St. Louis in the first contest of the series today, 7 to 6, in thirteen innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The loan of $50,000,000 to cotton cooperatives and stabilization corporations to enable them to hold their cotton until 1933, referred to in the radio address of Mr. Jones tonight, would amount to about $25 a bale on approximately 2,000,000 bales now held by all these agencies, it was explained tonight by a government official.

The adoption by this country of a national planning board, manned by engineers, physical scientists, statisticians, economists, accountants and lawyers is advocated by Stuart Chase, writer on economics, in his book "A New Deal," to be published today by the Macmillan Company.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- Don Juan Francisco de Cardenas, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, was guest of honor at a luncheon given today by Mrs. Duncan E. Cameron at her residence. Little Clifton Berley. Among the guests a former Spanish Ambassador, Don Juan di Riano, who for some time has made his permanent home here.

A tiny black and white racing monoplane sped across the United States yesterday almost with the speed of a rifle bullet. Crouched deep in the stream-lined cockpit James Haizlip, the four-foot eleven-inch flying partner of Major James H. Doolittle, held the throttle wide open throughout the vaulting journey from Los Angeles.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- A stone cusp in the roof of the Henry VII Chapel of Westminster Abbey fell to the ground today just as the afternoon service was concluded.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Nearly $225,000,000 has been added to the theoretical wealth of farmers from the recent advance in the grain markets. Much of this is an actual gain, many producers having refused to sell freely their new wheat, oats, rye and barley crops, while corn is yet to be harvested.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 29 -- A sensational story was printed here today by Adeverul to the effect that Prince Louis Windischgraetz had written to Admiral Horthy, Regent of Hungary, threatening to reveal the "true story" of the franc forgery case in Hungary.

S.E. Nicholson, secretary of the Anti-Saloon League of America, yesterday again took up the cudgels for President Hoover and the President's stand on prohibition. In a public statement issued from Media, Pa., where he is convalescing after a serious illness, he took emphatic exception to an attack on the President's prohibition policy by Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The stock markets began the week bouyantly, the strength in Wall Street and commodity prices helping sentiment. British Government funds opened better, became irregular and then improved again.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 29 -- Scoring his second consecutive victory in the international masters' tournament of the California Chess Congress at the Hotel Maryland, Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, emerged as winner of second prize, just one point below Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, whose brilliant work up to the semi-final round had earned for him the top honors.

The French Ambassador to Berlin was recently quoted in the Paris Charivari with reference to the political future of Germany. He said that in his opinion, "before Spring "comes a Hohenzollern -- if not WIL"LIAM II himself -- will be seated "again on the throne of his fathers.

Nearly 1,000 workers in Rockefeller Center, together with representatives of the owners, builders, contractors and architects of the development and officials of the New York Building Congress, attended the craftsmanship exercises yesterday honoring mechanics engaged in erecting the Raidio-Keith-Orpheum sound motion-picture theatre in the Radio City section of the three-block office and amusement project.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 29. -- George S. Goble, a deputy sheriff of Atlantic County, who was said to have escorted a prisoner from the county jail at Mays Landing as his companion on a party here last night, was sentenced today to sixty days in jail on charges of drunkenness and disorderly conduct, and also wa sheld on a charge of atrocious assault and battery.
MONTREAL, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Albany Senators beat the Royals today, 6-3, as Buck Newsom outpitched three Montreal hurlers. Newsom gave only seven hits.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 29 Our mission accomplished, Andy Taylor and I have returned to Fair banks bringing with us the body of Theodore Koven. Thursday we leave for Jersey City, where we understand he is to be buried.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Aug. 29 (By The Canadian Press) -- Two fliers of viking descent, who set out from New York six days ago to retrace the Lief Ericson trail by air, arrived here today on a freight train. Their sesquiplane, smashed in the nose dive which ended their transatlantic plans for the time being, was brought along in crated form.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- Adolf Hitler, in an address to a National Socialist

City Hall Place, the little downtown street where Cardinal Hayes, Paradise Jimmy Oliver, Blanche Walsh and other notables were born, is soon to be absorbed into the site for the new Federal court house, it was disclosed yesterday. Mgr. William Cashin, pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, announced that he would abandon the parish house at 20 City Hall Place tomorrow and set up new quarters at 318 East Eighteenth Street.

In accordance with recommendations made last month by the London conference of creditor banks under the German standstill agreement, banks in the United States adhering to the arrangement have agreed to adopt a schedule of maximum rates of interest on credits extended to German institutions, it was announced yesterday by F. Abbot Goodhue, president of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company and chairman of the subcommittee of American banks.

DES MOINES, Aug. 29 (AP) -- In Cherokee County, Northwest Iowa, 1,000 farmers marched on the Cherokee County courthouse and demanded of county officials that they ignore charges of obstructing a highway, filed last week against I.A.I. Birch, Marcus farmer.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Chairmen of the Democratic committees of five New England States, Senator David I. Walsh and other party leaders conferred today at a Boston hotel.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 29 The Rev. Frank H. Simmonds, known as Father Simmonds to his parishioners in this city, was well known throughout Episcopal circles in the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- In an analysis of July's domestic exports, amounting to $104,210,000, the Commerce Department today said crude materials amounted to $27,588,000, crude foodstuffs $5,507,000, manufactured foodstuffs $10,116,000, semi-manufactures $14,071,000 and finished manufactures $46,928,000.

MANILA, Aug. 29 -- The final showdown on the attiude of the Legislature toward the independence mission in Washington is expected tomorrow, when the houses meet concurrently to discuss the possible return of the mission, as well as the local attitude toward pending legislation in the United States.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 -- Declaring that "financial and credit affairs are clearly and positively better," A.W. Robertson, chairman in this Federal Reserve District of the banking and industrial committee of President Hoover's national committee on rehabilitation, urged members of the Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce and other business leaders in an address today to spread money now in improvement or alteration work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Special three-cent stamps will be issued by the government to commemorate Daniel Webster's 150th birthday anniversary and the 250th anniversary of William Penn's arrival in America. Postmaster General Brown announced today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Ray Ruddy, brilliant young swimmer from the New York Athletic Club, defeated Oliver Halassy, one-legged member of the Hungarian Olympic swimming team, in a 500-yard free-style match race at the Municipal Natatorium tonight.

Beginning his pruning of the 1933 city budget, Budget Director Charles L. Kohler struck out yesterday an item of $2,180 for mandatory salary increases among the employes of the city's law libraries. Although he did not say so, this action was taken by observers as foreshadowing similar action on all the mandatory increases for city employes, estimated to total about $3,000,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Norvall C. Wolcott, 23, who disappeared more than two years ago and supposedly drowned in the ocean near San Pedro, Cal., in November, 1930, returned to his home several days ago, his father reported to the police today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- It is now considered possible that outside interests may bid for the stocks of the Insull operating companies that the banks in New York purpose to offer at auction on Wednesday. Since the sale first was advertised last May it has been assumed that the banks would bid in the collateral themselves.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29 -- The new comedy. "Love -- Common and Preferred," by Mrs. Nina L. Duryea of The Mill in Stockbridge, had its premiere before a capacity audience at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge tonight. The performance was a Playhouse benefit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- After two months of fairly active operations, the automotive industry in July reduced its production to 111,139 vehicles, a decline of 71,935 under the previous month's total, which brought the July output to the lowest point this year, the Commerce Department announced today.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 29 -- The Eastern Yacht Club junior crew with Chandler Hovey Jr. as captain, today won the opening race of the series for the national junior sailing championship and the Sears Cup. Leading throughout the eight-mile course, the Eastern youngsters left astern five crews representing various sections of the New England and Long Island Sound coast and led with 6 1/4 points.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- Despite the sending of a telegram by Alfred E. Smith to Maurice J. McCarthy today denying that he had favored Justus S. Wardell in his race with William G. McAdoo for the Senatorial nomination, David F. Supple, who had asserted that the New Yorker had opposed Mr. McAdoo, stuck to his guns.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Coincident with the reinstatement today of two of the Nassau County policemen suspended as a result of the "third-degree" death of Hyman Stark, District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards announced that no action would be taken toward a new trial for Deputy Chief Tappen and Detectives Pearsall and Zander until the assault indictments against ten other officers have been disposed of.

The season of meals in the open air will soon be over. For some strange reason which children, of a generation or two ago could never understand, mothers used to oppose outdoor eating. It was a great treat to go on a picnic, but just as much of a party if cold dishes and hot coffee were spread outside the house for a Summer supper.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A call for submission by Thursday of final estimates of departmental needs in the next fiscal year has been made by J. Clawson Roop, Director of the Budget.

The United Cigar Stores Company of America, operator of more than 800 retail tobacco stores in all of the principal cities and towns of the nation, passed yesterday into the hands of the Irving Trust Company as receiver in bankruptcy.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Arrangements were made today to seek permission from the widow to perform an autopsy on the body of John Dahl, wrecking master and head diver on the treasure-seeking ship Salvor, who died last night after a short illness.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Detroit and the Athletics halved a double-header today, Philadelphia winning the first game, 8 to 3, with a six-run rally in the eighth inning, and the Tigers capturing the second contest, 10 to 7, by breaking a tie with three runs in the ninth frame.

In a letter to Secretary MILLS Senator WAGNER charges "undue delay" in starting the program of public works authorized by Congress. He states that "forty-two days have "already elapsed since Congress "passed that law"; so far as he is aware, "work has not yet begun upon the projects enumerated."

The adjusted index of automobile production stands at 27.2 for the week ended Aug. 27, as against 26.8 for the preceding week and 51.5 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, amounted to 25,265 cars and trucks, as against 24,565 cars and trucks in the preceding week and 47,787 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.

The 125 destitute veterans who started building a B.E.F. camp last week on the narrow strip of unoccupied land between the New York Central Railroad tracks and the Hudson will not have a home for long if orders given to them yesterday by police and park authorities are rigidly enforced.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The attempt to produce quick relief from depression is not likely to be of much permanent value, according to Dr. Henry Parker Willis, professor of banking at Columbia University and first secretary of the Federal Reserve Board.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- With the Harmsworth Trophy race only five days away, Gar Wood, the defending champion, and Kaye Don, the challenger, awaited favorable weather to send their two giant speed boats around the Lake St. Clair course on test runs -- final preparation for the first heat of the race Saturday at 6:30 A.M.

Major Edward G. Murray, founder of the Edward G. Murray Lighterage and Transportation Company and the Murray Transportation Company, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his Summer home at 1 Park Avenue, Larchmont Manor, N. Y. He was 53 years old and had been ill for some time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a further loan of $1,400,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad for meeting fixed interest obligations due Sept. 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the Jefferson. Day dinner former Governor Smith declared that in our present crisis he would take no interest in victory for his party unless such a victory gave promise of advantage to the nation. His decision about whether in October he will be quiet or active may decide the outcome of the election.

The teletype machine, an instrument that at the pressing of a typewriter key converts alphabetical characters into sequences of dots and dashes to be sent over a wire line to a recording mechanism that reverses the process and rewrites the letters on a sheet of paper, has been adapted for long-distance radio and is now in use between San Francisco and the Hawaiian Islands, according to W. A. Winterbottom, vice president of RCA Communications, Inc.

A traffic policeman was forced lo "trail" two men in an automobile for about a mile between Secaucus and Jersey City yesterday when the bumper of the car in which the policeman was riding became entangled with the bumper of a car he was pursuing.
Policeman in the Park. Time in New York City has for once turned back in its flight and restored to Central Park its special police force, the "sparrow cops" of a generation ago.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29 -- The entire American Walker Cup team was on hand at The Country Club today and all of the players except Captain Francis Ouimet, who has been ill with a cold, were out tuning up for the matches with the British amateurs Thursday and Friday.

Unfolding a variety of play, doubtless as a preparatory manoeuvre for their coming part in the next world's series, the Yankees wrenched two more games from the White Sox at the Stadium yesterday before a gallery of 17,000 that seemed to consider the performance a decidedly satisfactory one.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 29 -- Disorder on a wide scale developed in the farmers' holiday movement in this State today as the roll of sluggings, fights and acts of violence mounted. Pressure was brought to bear on Governor Dan Turner to order out State troops to protect farmers who might desire to ship their products to market.

With the "forgotten man" a frequent theme of Governor Roosevelt in campaign utterances. Mrs. George A. Wyeth, president of the Women's National Republican Club, alluded yesterday to his running mate on the national ticket, Speaker John N. Garner of the House of Representatives, as the "forgetting man," in a speech at the opening session of the club's school of politics.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 29 -- The big push for the professional golf championship of America opens over the well-trapped Keller fee course tomorrow with every important pro of the nation, excepting Gene Sarazen and Leo Diegel, in the drive.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Caustic criticism of the Federal Farm Board and the board-sponsored American Cotton Cooperative Association for speculative activity in commodity markets was voiced today by Russell Clark, president of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, before the Shannon Congressional committee investigating government competition with private business.

Two suits involving $138,000,000 against the eight American directors of the International Match Corporation, were authorized yesterday by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee in bankruptcy. The International Match Corporation was controlled, before his suicide, by Ivar Kreuger, the Swedish financier.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The St. Louis San Francisco Railroad filed a motion in Federal court today asking dismissal of the receivership petition filed last week by two holders of prior lien mortgage bonds of the road.

The Actors' Dinner Club, which, has been serving free meals to unemployed theatrical people since December, soon will be compelled to cease operations unless financial aid is obtained, it was jointly announced yesterday by the League of New York Theatres and the Actors' Equity Association.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- With the stage set for another of Germany's periodic political crises when the Reichstag meets tomorrow, interest in that event was almost eclipsed today by the remarkable proposals announced by Chancellor von Papen yesterday for the revival of German industrial activity by remitting a portion of the future taxes thereon.

The Rio Grande Oil Company has sent to stockholders a letter saying the offer of the Consolidated Oil Corporation for their company should not be considered merely from the standpoint of the market prices of the two stocks.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The "first evidence of an important interrelationship between a color variety in mice and the spontaneous incidence of breast cancer" was presented by Dr. C.C. Little, former president of the Universities of Maine and Michigan, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratories at Bar Harbor, Me., and chairman and general secretary of the organization, before the Genetics Congress today.

The first sixty-two railroads to report for July had net operating income of about $9,820,000, against $48,286,000 in July, 1931, a drop of 79.6 per cent, and against $71,915,000 in July, 1930, a fall of 86.3 per cent. In June their net operating income was $9,902,000, against $43,3O1,0OO in June, 1931, a decline of 77.1 per cent.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 29 -- John Mattheys, defending champion, advanced to the third round in the annual Lido Country Club men's title tennis tournament today when he triumphed over Harold McTigue, 6-3, 6-2, in a second-round engagement.

A shortage of shrimp in Barnegat Bay has caused a lot of woe among fishermen who haunt that part of the Jersey shore. Captains reporting yesterday had long faces because of the fact that weakfish have begun to run in the bay and it is almost impossible to get bait-shrimp for them.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 29 (AP) -- A tropical storm from the West Indies brought high winds and heavy rain to the lower east coast of Florida tonight, but no damage was reported in any section except to crops in the Redlands District, about thirty miles south of Miami.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Superior Judge E.F. Hahn today approved a compromise of the $15,000,000 suit brought by preferred stockholders of the Owl Drug Company against the United Drug Company, the Louis K. Liggett Company and Drug, Inc.

Monetary gold stocks of the country rose to $2,866,500 yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported. The statement showed a net gain of $2,699,000 through the release of stocks earmarked for foreign eign account and imports of $167,500 of which $153,500 was from India and $14,000 from Mexico.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Rosy cheeked and animated, Renee Adoree returned to Hollywood today to resume her movie career. Nearly two years ago she entered a Prescott (Ariz.) hospital for treatment of a pulmonary ailment. She lay in bed for seventeen months.
Radio broadcasting organizations saw their hopes fade yesterday for a rich harvest from political campaign broadcasting.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson took the lead in the Democratic Gubernatorial run-off primary race tonight and ran her count to 404 votes more than Governor R.S. Sterling on the basis of a slow trickle of belated returns.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Four persons were arrested today when police broke up a demonstration by more than fifty alleged radicals in front of City Hall. The demonstrators had sought food, work and a dole for the unemployed from Mayor James M. Curley.

Public dislike this year of administrators of laws -- and taxes -- seems to have defeated Governor STERLING of the Lone Star State. If Mrs. FERGUSON holds her slight lead and survives any court contest which may be instituted, she will again, be the Chief Executive of Texas.

Whether the further reduction in union wages proposed by the railway managements will be effected by a percentage reduction in pay or by revision of basic rates and working rules will be discussed today at a meeting of the Eastern presidents' conference in the Bankers Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Heavily oversubscribed, the Treasury's offering of ninety-one-day bills dated Aug. 31 was sold at an average rate equivalent to .32 per cent on a bank discount basis, Secretary Mills announced today. Bids were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks.

The Manhattan Maternity Hospital and Clinic ot 327 East Sixtieth Street, which has served Yorkville for twenty-seven years, will close tomorrow night and pass out of existence as a separate institution.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 29 -- Strikes by consumers of electricity as a means of enforcing lower rates are threatened in two cities of Mexico.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Chancellor von Papen's remarkable capitalization of tax remission has aroused considerable interest in the British press, but no newspaper yet announces it as corollary to cancellation of reparations.

A few years ago a typical American city was minutely described in a book called "Middletown," Within the limits of an article in the August Harper's EUGENE BAGGER attempts the same sort of picture of a French city. He selected Nimes, a city of 84,677 in the heart of the French South, chiefly because of its richness in historic background.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Governor Roosevelt was back at the capital today with his aids still hopeful that Alfred E. Smith would take an active part in the Presidential campaign in spite of his having spurned the invitation to a luncheon at the Long Island home of D. Basil O'Connor.

WASHINGTON, Aug 29 -- A comprehensive circular containing regulations and instructions for applications from prospective borrowers for self-liquidating projects was issued by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a churchman I want to thank THE TIMES for the editorial entitled "Yea-and-Nay Prohibitionists." The action of the allied forces for prohibition in supporting the Republican candidate who had just declared that he favored the manufacture, sale and consumption of liquor in any State which desired it demanded the masterful rebuke of your editorial.

ALBANY, Aug. 29 -- While criticizing the manner in which Governor Roosevelt is conducting the trial of Mayor Walker, Supreme Court Justice Staley ruled today that the courts were powerless to intervene.

Fluctuations were highly irregular on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The market was mixed at the opening, rallied in the late forenoon and then drifted up and down, to close with slight net losses on the day. The total volume was 3,900,000 shares, compared with 3,070,000 shares on Friday, the last five-hour day of the previous week.

OVER in Flatbush the citizens will tell you that the astronomers are all wrong. The eclipse occurred last week and was total in Chicago. It lasted for three days (a new interstellar record) and the Robins are still in the penumbra, trying to grope their way out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- While administration officials are convinced that the national convention of the American Legion in Portland, Ore., next month will demand immediate cash payment of the veterans' bonus, the administration is opposed to taking any official steps to prevent such action.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 2 per cent for the best names.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29 Plans have been completed for the large street fair in aid to the Southampton unemployment fund which will take place on Saturday afternoon and evening in Monument Square and Agawam Park. The section will be blocked off by tall barriers of evergreens and Autumn flowers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The last wil of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, dictated and signed by her on Aug. 4, three weeks before her death, was filed this afternoon in the Cook County Probate Court.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Struggling through the late stages of the game in semi-darkness and with rain falling the Newark Bears gained a 7-to-6 decision over the Bisons in the twilight portion of tonight's scheduled double bill. The second game slated under the lights was called off because of wet grounds.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Cleveland did little hitting today, but the Red Sox pitchers were unable to find the plate, the visitors winning, 6 to 3.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Emil Denemark's Switch captured the featured race at Hawthorne today.

Except for the paucity of offerings in the outside market which resulted in a tightening in the rate to 1 1/2 per cent, where 1 had previously ruled, there was no other feature to the business in money. Stock Exchange rate remained at 2 per cent and Federal sold at 1/8. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A primary campaign enlivened by a bitter feud in Democratic ranks and attracting national interest in the contests for both, the Democratic and Republican nominations for United States Senator closed in California today, with a record registration of voters eligible to decide the issues tomorrow.

Because of the action of the Republicans in withdrawing their own designee for the State Senate from the Eighth Senatorial District and substituting as their candidate Senator William L. Love, who had been rejected by his own party, the King's County Democratic organization is contemplating a denial of a Democratic endorsement for Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, Republican, who will seek re-election in the Second Judicial District this Fall.

LANCASTER, N.H., Aug. 29. -- Dr. Walter Adams, director of the Mount Wilson Observatory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, and a staff of astronomers labored on the Fair Grounds today setting up apparatus to read the mysteries of the eclipse.

MANCHESTER, England Aug. 29 -- A direct appeal to the King to intervene through the government in the labor dispute in the Lancashire cotton mills was sent to Balmoral today by Joe Compton, a former Laborite member of Parliament, who wields great influence in the mill districts.

Because of the action of the Republicans in withdrawing their own designee for the State Senate from the Eighth Senatorial District and substituting as their candidate Senator William L. Love, who had been rejected by his own party, the King's County Democratic organization is contemplating a denial of a Democratic endorsement for Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, Republican, who will seek re-election in the Second Judicial District this Fall.

LANCASTER, N.H., Aug. 29. -- Dr. Walter Adams, director of the Mount Wilson Observatory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, and a staff of astronomers labored on the Fair Grounds today setting up apparatus to read the mysteries of the eclipse.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- With the appointment today of Nathan William MacChesney, lawyer, to the post of director of the National-Hoover-Curtis Organization Bureau and committees, by Chairman Everett Sanders of the National Republican Committee, the national campaign organization in Chicago was completed.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Sands Point finished its preparation for the open polo championship with an Impressive display of power and team-play on John Hay Whitney's Greentree Field today, turning back Greentree by 17 to 9 in a fast, sometimes rough and often very-well-played game.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Emma Brook, Freehold mare, took the 2:23 trot in straight heats at the opening of the Flemington fair races today.

QUEBEC, Aug. 30 -- Decreased purchasing of liquor by thirsty American visitors is responsible for Quebec Province's first deficit in thirty-four years. Liquor commission receipts, which were $9,000,000 last year, fell off $1,500,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30 and a deficit of $584,708 has resulted.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 30 -- A resolution calling upon the town board to fight the proposed abandonment of two streets leading to the beach at Cold Spring Harbor was adopted here tonight at a meeting of about 1,000 persons, called by the Cold Spring Harbor Civic Association to urge public support of their efforts to retain the streets as public highways.

In the New York cloak and suit industry it has just been settled by agreement that employers who make use of electrically operated pressing machines shall pay $8 weekly for every machine into a fund for the relief of unemployed pressers. This reads very like the ancient law of deodand by which any inanimate object which has been accidentally the cause of a man's death is forfeited to the crown for pious uses.

LONDON, Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Sussex was defeated for the first time this season in a county cricket match which concluded today. Yorkshire, already secure at the head of the championship table, won from its southern rival by 167 runs.

WASHINOTON, Aug. 30 -- Study of the naval problem, in view of limitation conversations that are due to be held among the principal naval powers during the recess of the general disarmament conference at Geneva, is to be undertaken in the government soon after the return to the capital of Secretary Stimson and Admiral W.V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Bahama Islands may be the last visible portion of an ancient Atlantic mountain range, according to gravity tests reported by Lieutenant Joseph P. Lushene, of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A flurry which for a time resembled the "international complications" of a novelist's plot was caused today when the District of Columbia police broadcast gave notice to police throughout the country that the automobile of Dr. Herbert Feis, economic adviser of the State Department, had been pillaged and "important government papers" taken.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30 -- Admiral and Mrs. William S. Sims opened their home this afternoon for a sale in the interest of the Grenfell Mission, work in Labrador. Mrs. Sims was assisted by her daughter, Miss Anne Sims, and by Mrs. John Dufais, Mrs. Henry Howard, Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander, Miss Agnes C. Storer and Miss Eleanor Scattergood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Henry Scattergood of Villanova, Pa., who is visiting in Jamestown.

Dr. J.R. BRINKLEY, who in 1930 as an Independent candidate for Governor of Kansas got 183,000 votes -- besides, it is said, a lot which were not counted -- and means to better the performance this year, came to "BILL" WHITE'S town and possessed it.

There will be no change in the agency of the White Star Line in the United States and no increase in the fares on the steamships of the Atlantic Conference Lines in the near future, it was declared yesterday by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company and chairman of the United States Lines Company, who returned on the White Star liner Olympic from his semi-annual trip to London.

SACRAMENTO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Passage of a bill for cash payment of the soldiers' bonus by the next Congress was predicted before the annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today by Darold De Coe. commander-in-chief.

SIGNOR BENIAMO BENGOUGH, who now catches at odd moments for the St. Louis Browns, was once asked to disclose the professional advice he gave to pitchers, by sign language, when certain noted hitters took their stances at the plate. What did he call for when Al Simmons stood there with upraised bat and two on and two out? What curve for Foxx? What change of pace for Goose Goslin?
TOKYO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The United States fleet was one of several questions affecting foreign relations which were brought up in the Diet session today.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Activity continued on the Bourse today and the volume of transactions was large in comparison with that of most sessions throughout the Summer. On the eve of the end-of-the-month settlements the technical situation on the Bourse indicated firmness.

About thirty parcels of Manhattan and Bronx real estate were put up for bidding at auctioneers' stands yesterday. Included In the long list were four downtown buildings formerly controlled by Grigori Benenson and the home of the Automobile Club of America in East Fifty-third Street.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- In an article on the German demand for armament arity, published today, General urt von Schleicher. Minister of Defense, amplified his idea of the reorganization of the German Army which he recently said the government contemplated if other nations ailed to reduce their armaments to the German level.

FRYEBURG, Me., Aug. 30 -- Final rehearsals for their eclipse activities were staged in the valleys and on the heights of the White Mountains at dusk tonight by astronomers from all corners of the earth. As darkness purpled the surrounding peaks they had only one concern -- the weather.
James F. Maguire leased the threestory dwelling at 145 West 103d Street to Joseph Bernasconl, wholesale baker. The Houghton Company and Joseph P. Day negotiated the lease.

This afternoon the moon will steal across the face of the sun and millions will forget their cares in contemplation of nature's most magnificent spectacle. Over the earth the shadow of the moon will rush with a speed as overwhelming as when AMOS predicted "I will cause the "sun to go down at noon, and I will "darken the earth in the clear sky."

Upon the main questions brought before the court in the Walker case the decision of Judge STALEY at Albany is clear and conclusive. Without departing from a long line of judicial decisions, he could not have held that the Governor, in the performance of an Executive act, is subject to injunction or a writ of prohibition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Press reports that Governor General Theodore Roosevelt would leave his post in the Philippines and return to the United States, ostensibly to take part in the campaign to re-elect President Hoover, occasioned no small surprise when published a few weeks ago.

Ray Ruddy of the New Tork A.C. scored his third straight triumph in match competition over Oliver Halassy of the Hungarian Olympic team in a 1,000-yard free style match race, one of the feature events of the international aquatic meet held last night at the Jerome Cascades pool.
"Ballyhoo of 1932" has set back its scheduled opening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre until Tuesday night of next week. This will leave Labor Day evening (Monday) without a theatrical premiere.

When July contracts for cotton touched 10 cents on Monday, which was an advance of nearly 100 per cent in three months, many holders attempted to take advantage of the higher price level, and yesterday a more general profit-taking movement developed on the Cotton Exchanges here and in New Orleans and Liverpool.
NEW YORK. Arthur Williams will give a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Myron C. Taylor at Brook Corners, Roslyn, L. I., on Sept. 18.

Staten Island fishermen are wondering what has happened in their waters. For years and years, in fact as long as the oldest of the old-timers can recall, bluefish have run two or three days a week at Great Kills every season and then have disappeared.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Governor Ritchie pledged to Governor Roosevelt today the full support of the party organization in Maryland and promised to make a series of campaign addresses for the national ticket. The former rival of the New York executive for the Presidential nomination said the candidate's strength in Maryland was such as to leave little doubt that he would capture the "free State's" eight electoral votes.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 -- For twenty years Peter Buydos of New Britain has been keeping vigil to find the man accused of killing his brother, Andrew, then 19 years old, in the mining town of Shanktown, Pa. Once, three years ago, the accused man, Mike Tkach, was almost captured in Cleveland, Ohio.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will be asked today to advance $50,000,000 for model apartment developments in New York City, it was announced last night at the conclusion of an executive meeting of the State Board of Housing in the City Club, 55 East Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Treasury experts will complete their studies of quarterly financial requirements and market conditions in a few days to fix the amount of the Sept. 15 financing and the rate on the securities to be issued.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Opinion here is hardening against the unions and the employers' associations in the Lancashire strike and the greatest pressure is being brought to get the Cabinet to intervene. The union leaders are blamed for exploiting the strike to demonstrate the solidarity of their organizations while a similar spirit of "stark, irrational antagonism" is said to animate many groups of employers.

A slightly easier tone in Street funds, which dropped to 1 1/4 per cent. from 1 1/2 on Monday, was the only incident of the business in money. Offerings were in good volume, but demand was poor. The Stock Exchange rate was maitained at 2, as previously. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were quiet.

Isaac F. Marcosson, writer, inherited $729,286 as residuary legatee under the will of Mrs. Caroline Frevert, sister of David Graham Phillips, novelist, the appraisal of her estate disclosed yesterday. Mrs. Frevert, who described Mr. Marcosson as "my tried and loyal friend," left an estate of $863,525 gross and $786,816 net.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 30 -- The Conservative rebels who have held Quito for four days have surrendered and federal troops will enter the capital tomorrow, according to a telegram from the Minister of War sent at 7 P.M.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A cotton cooperative reputedly financed by the Federal Farm Board and the American Cotton Cooperative Association was accused of slandering a private firm to secure business, in testimony presented to the Shannon Congressional committee today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 30 -- That a split in the Nassau County chapter of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform is likely was evidenced today when, at a meeting of the advisory board of the New York State group and the county chairman in the Republican headquarters here, a motion to rescind a resolution adopted by that body on July 26 was defeated.

With Lou Gehrig smashing two tremendous home runs into the right-field bleachers, his thirtieth and thirty-first of the year, and Tony Lazzeri contributing still another four-master, the Yankees concluded their final home stand of the year against the West at the Stadium yesterday with the proper dramatic flourish the occasion seemed to demand.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The Cubs winning streak reached eleven straight, a new major league seasonal record, by reason of their 4 to 3 victory over the Giants today in the fourth game of the current series.

The Republicans will run this year the most economical national campaign in a generation of party history, according to Joseph R. Nutt, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, who with Everett Sanders, Republican national chairman, was in this city yesterday for a general discussion of plans and finances in the Eastern part of the country.

H. Ellsworth Vines Jr. of Pasadena, men's national tennis singles champion, and Henri Cochet, French star, were yesterday drawn for the top and bottom places, respectively, in the bracket of ninety-two players who will compete in the men's national title tourney, starting at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills on Saturday.

The protective committee, of which J.P. Morgan is chairman, issued yesterday a call for the deposit with it of the $132,000,000 in outstanding 5 per cent Interborough Rapid Transit Company bonds, as the first step toward consolidating the position of Interborough security-holders in the legal battles that the company's receivership may bring.
BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The dreaded assembly of the new Reichstag took place today, and it was as peaceful as a Summer day.

The plan of W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, for an "open" State Convention received a severe jolt yesterday. William L. Ward, veteran leader in Westchester, breaking a precedent of more than thirty years standing, at a hurriedly called meeting of Republican leaders from every city and town in Westchester, put through a unanimous endorsement of Colonel William J. Donovan of Buffalo and New York City for the Gubernatorial nomination.
WARSAW, Aug. 30 -- News concerning a rising of Ukrainian peasants living in Polesta, Eastern Poland, which had been kept from the public, leaked out today.

Druggists and cosmetic dealers throughout Greater New York are interested in the exposure of an alleged racketeering association which has heen raising prices, terrorizing shop owners and building a membership for itself in Brooklyn and Queens, it was announced yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Michael Kern of Kings County.

The bus Diogenes, carrying the five members of the prohibition research committee, halted before the Waldorf-Astoria late yesterday afternoon, having covered 12,000 miles since June 1 while members of its crew combed thirty-six States and the District of Columbia in an effort "to find one drunkard who has been reformed by the passage of the Eighteenth Amendment."
For two hours this afternoon the eyes of man will stare at the glories of the heavens and the brains of man will try to record and to comprehend the flaming wonder of our universe.

PASADENA, Aug. 30 -- The California Chess Congress, the masters' tournament which has held the attention of the chess-playing world for the past two weeks and in which Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris was the victor, was formally declared closed at a farewell dinner at the Hotel Maryland last night at which prizes were awarded in the four classes.

Reports to date indicate that the Class I railroads had net operating incomes of about $124,478,000 in the first seven months of the year compared with $295,085,000 in the same period last year, a decrease of 57.8 per cent. Gross for the period was estimated at $1,841,000,000, against $2,564,538,000 in the same period last year.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 30 -- Mastering a strong west wind that blew several favorites out of the picture, Olin Dutra of Santa Monica, Cal., captured the medal today in the 36-hole qualifying round of the championship tournament of the National Professional Golfers' Association.

Willingness on the part of Governor ROOSEVELT and his friends to let ALFRED E. SMITH take his own way and time to come out with active support of the Democratic ticket is not only tactful but is good politics. It is based apparently on the idea that such action by the candidate of 1928 is a certainty, unless he would appear in an entirely new role -- deserting some of his firmest friends.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The budget asked for by the Taxicab Board of Control is rather a stiff one and should be carefully considered, But if it accomplishes its purpose, and brings order out of chaos and stops the great cruising evil, it will be worth while.

After threatening 65,000 school teachers, policemen and firemen with the loss of their mandatory salary increases next year by slashing several small mandatory increases from the budget on Monday, Budget Director Charles H. Kohler took a different tack yesterday and announced that the elimination of such increases was a matter for the Legislature to decide.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Governor Roosevelt, it was believed here today, would disregard Supreme Court Justice Ellis J. Staley's criticism of the rules of procedure he has adopted for hearing Mayor Walker's defense to Samuel Seabury's conclusions that the Mayor is unfit for public office.

An injunction restraining the Radio Engineering Laboratories, Inc., of Long Island City, from infringing further on patents used in the manufacture of radio apparatus known as the 'oscillating audition" and the "feed back circuit," which are held by the Radio Corporation of America, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the De Forest Radio Corporation was handed down yesterday by Judge Campbell in United States District Court in Brooklyn.

The first public offering of bonds of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company in the New York market since July. 1930, will be made today with the marketing of $2,500,000 convertible 6 per cent collateral trust bonds, due on March 15, 1942. The offering will be made by a syndicate composed of the National City Company, Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and Wood.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Showing no ill effects from his recent illness, Francis Ouimet, who is to captain America's Walker Cup golfers in their matches at The Country Club Thursday and Friday against Great Britain, played the course in 74 strokes today.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 (AP) -- It was learned authoritatively today that President von Hindenburg had provided Chancellor von Papen with a decree dissolving the Reichstag. The date on this decree has been left blank. It is up to the Chancellor to decide when and if he shall use it.

MAGOG, Que., Aug. 30 -- On the golf course of the Hermitage Country Club at Magog some sixty astronomers and astrophysicists from American, Canadian, British and Dutch universities have set up their instruments in preparation for the eclipse of the sun tomorrow.

Joseph A. Esquirol, the Democratic organization's designee for State Senator from the Eighth Senatorial District, was asked yesterday by tHe Citizens Union "to do everything in your power to bring about the Democratic renomination" of his opponent in the primaries, State Senator William L. Love, although the legal period for formal declination has expired.

MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Abolition of eleven high positions in the traffic department of the Canadian National Railways was announced today. Changes include reorganization of duties and retirement of four officers who have spent many years with the system and its component parts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Washington Senators kept up their heavy hitting today, jumping on Blaeholder, Fischer and Kimsey for fifteen hits to take the second game of the series with St. Louis, 11 to 7, and even the season's games between the two clubs at nine-all.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 30 -- New Orleans took the first game of the American Legion junior championship baseball series today, but had to come from behind in the ninth. inning to gain the verdict over Springfield, Mass., champion nine of the eastern half of the nation-wide tournament.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Following the example of Britain, a large-scale conversion of the public debt is being prepared by France. This project, according to unofficial reports, is likely to be launched in October and it will affect a total sum in the neighborhood of $4,000,000,000.

Buyers Here Show Drop. A large drop in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary Hurley's recent radio address, in which he replied to Governor Roosevelt's Columbus speech, is interesting -- not for the force of its counter-arguments, but because it reveals the traditional desire of the Republican party to maintain the status quo, and particularly to avoid bringing about any reforms which would be likely to curtail private business enterprise.

HONOLULU, Aug. 30 -- Producers and canners of Hawaiian pineapple completed today the formation of an association that it is hoped will be a step toward the economic rehabilitation of the industry, which has suffered severely in the last two years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The State Department received today the following report on the recent Chinese raids at Mukden from Myrl S. Myers, Consul General:

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,114,000 barrels, compared with 2,110,800 in the preceding week, a gain of 3,200 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 4,550 barrels in Coastal Texas and a decline of 3,450 in Oklahoma were the most important changes.

An early rally in railroad bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was not maintained and prices slumped in the late dealings, with the net result that a considerable list of representative issues lost a point or more for the day. Utility bonds, likewise, were weaker, but industrial bonds on the average, showed advancing tendencies.

Speculative interest was concentrated yesterday in the shares of companies that are expected to benefit from the improvement in commodity prices. Copper and rubber stocks were particularly strong. About 135 issues on the Stock Exchange went into new high ground for the year.

Another of Harlem's recurrent factional disputes occurred yesterday morning, when some twenty or thirty members of the Oriental-Occidental Society invaded the club rooms of the "Tiger division." of the Universal Negro Improvement Society at 78 West 133a Street, effectively wrecked the place and seriously injured one person.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30 -- The city of Santa Fe is having difficulty raising $106,000 due on Oct. 1 on its Blair Co. (now Bancamerica-Blair) loan. The Mayor has been in Buenos Aires trying to negotiate an extension, and it was announced upon his return to Santa Fe he would convoke the City Council tomorrow to consider emergency measures.

Stanley M. Bruce, former Premier of Australia who was a delegate to the Ottawa conference, is to sail tonight on the "White Star liner Olympic for England, accompanied by J.A. Alexander. Other passengers booked for the liner include E.C. Riddle, governor of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia; Dr. George Kovacs, the Rev. F.E. Oliver and Gherardi Davis.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Winning both of today's races on Buzzards Bay, the junior crew from the Squantum Yacht Club of Boston Harbor took the lead with 16 1/2 points in the series for the national sailing championship and the Sears Cup.
Mayor Walker, now confined to bed by orders of his physician, will try to attend the funeral of his brother, George F. Walker, tomorrow morning, members of his staff said yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Taking his first action on a statement recently announced that the personnel of the government of New Jersey should be reduced by 5 per cent as the part of a general program of economy. Governor A. Harry Moore directed Attorney General William A. Stevens today to drop nine assistants from his staff.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity has slipped back to 18.5 for the week ended Aug. 27 from 19.8 for the preceding week; a year ago it stood at 43.3. The actual rate of operations, according to Steel, has dropped back to 14 1/2 per cent of capacity, after a small rise to 15 1/2 per cent the week before.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 80 -- Top Flight, Morfair and Tred Avon, champions or close to it in their respective divisions, met defeat today at Saratoga in one of the most interesting renewals of the Delaware Handicap, when all bowed to the comparatively obscure Flagstone, outsider in the betting and bearer of the Linton Farms colors.

Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon was in this city yesterday preparatory to returning today to his post in London. His presence here, simultaneouly with that of Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, attracted wide interest. The two men did not meet, however, Mr. Mills having said good-bye to Mr. Mellon in Washington.

Charges that Negro workers employed in flood-control camps financed by the Federal Government along the Mississippi River are living under conditions of "virtual slavery" are contained in a report of an investigation made public yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

Blackjacks and fists, fingernails and teeth were used in the Children's Court yesterday when about 100 Communists and sympathizers rioted in the corridors in protest against the conviction of two schoolgirls for participation in another radical demonstration on Monday.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has come to the rescue of the Federal Farm Board, which has itself been rescuing American agriculture since 1929. A director of the corporation states that $50,000,000 has been authorized "to enable them to hold their cotton until 1933."

A special meeting of shareholders of the Commercial. National Bank and Trust Company has been called for Sept. 7 to approve winding up the affairs of the bank's affiliate, the Commercial National Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Traders in wheat on the Board of Trade here were impressed today with the reactionary tendency in stocks and cotton. While the break in general was attributed to profit-taking in technically weak markets, there was not the aggressive buying of wheat by houses with Eastern connections that had been in evidence of late.
William H. Wittpenn sold to Kathleen Kissel the two-story brick dwelling on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 201 North Street, near the Boulevard, Jersey City.

Hammer and saw were wielded busily by the sun-tanned arms of 125 veterans yesterday as the shanty camp which a New York contingent of the B.E.F. has been busily erecting on the banks of the Hudson approached completion.

R.E.M. Cowic, president of the Railway Express Agency since its formation in 1928 and connected with the express business since 1883, resigned his position at a meeting of the agency's board yesterday. The resignation is effective today.

Leading manufacturers of railway equipment are completing the organization of a company to borrow funds from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for financing the purchase of equipment by the railroads, it developed yesterday. The organization, to be owned by the incorporators, will be incorporated in Delaware as the Railroad Equipment Financing Corporation with a nominal capitalization of about $100,000.

The agreements reached at the recent Imperial Economic Conference in Ottawa will help restore prosperity in the countries of the British Empire and should serve as a lead to the forthcoming world economic conference, declared W. Downie Stewart, Minister of Finance and customs of New Zealand yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Treasury's announcement of a new conversion loan had a good effect on the Stock Exchange today and there also was satisfaction with Neville Chamberlain's attitude regarding the embargo on capital issues. British Government funds showed general improvement.

The reactionary trend which prevailed in practically all markets yesterday elicited little comment, except that it was time for such readjustment. Particularly in stocks and bonds and cotton, the recent advance had been both exceptionally rapid and exceptionally prolonged.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 30 -- The six United Kingdom cotton representatives who attended the Ottawa Imperial Economic Conference presented their report today to the joint committee of cotton trade organizations. Only small concessions are expected from the dominions and the most that can be said of them is that they are "at least a move in the right direction."
The French liner Paris arrived from Havre and Plymouth yesterday bringing 870 passengers, including many who are prominent in the theatre, motion pictures and art.

WASHINGTON. Aug, 30 -- An appeal for quick action on Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans for financing construction self-liquidating projects, and especially those proposed for New York, was made to two of the corporation's directors today by Senator Wagner, a leading sponsor of relief legislation in Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- Max Carey's Dodgers bade farewell to St. Louis today until next year with a victory over the Cardinals that gave them an even break in the series of four games. But they made no gain on the Cubs and lost ground to the Pirates, whose double victory strengthened their hold on second place.

Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, returned yesterday on the White Star liner Olympic from a world concert tour which he commenced last September, going through the Panama Canal. He returned from the East Indies by way of the Suez Canal to Egypt and South Africa.

Despite the scientific investigations made to date into the record of those early Americans, the Mayas of Yucatan, the aurfaca of the problem scarcely has teen scratched, Edward Herbert Thompson writes in his book, "People of the Serpent," published today by the Houghton Mifflin Company.

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, Cleveland, Aug. 30 -- The fourth day of the national air races for 1932 was dedicated to the army, and the Seventeenth Squadron of the first-pursuit group from Selfridge Field early in the morning apprised the citizens of Cleveland that it was Army Day.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 30 -- An objection to the current conference of representatives of big business who have been summoned to Washington by President Hoover to lead the way back to prosperity, was made here tonight by Robert D. Kohn, former president of the American Institute of Architects and now chairman of the National Committee for Trade Recovery, organized to promote public works under the Wagner act for emergency relief and construction.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Red Sox shelled Wesley Ferrell, Cleveland Indians' star hurler, from the hilltop today and took the game, 6 to 2.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- A new discovery in plant breeding, regarded as epoch-making, which permits growing of tropical and sub-tropical fruits in northern climates and allows crossing of varieties of seeds requiring entirely different periods of vegetation was announced at Cornell University today during the last general session of the International Congress of Genetics.

TORONTO, Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Reaching three Toronto pitchers for fifteen hits, Jersey City opened a three-game series today with a 12-7 victory. Chick Outen collected four of the victors' hits, two of them doubles, and drove in four runs.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Three hundred young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware, who had been attending the Coast Artillery Citizens' Military Training Camp here, returned to their homes today after completing a month's training.

The annual East-West tennis team matches that will bring together a number of outstanding players are to start today and continue tomorrow on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club in South Orange, N.J.
