CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 30 -- A regiment of youths, tanned by the August sun, marched out of camp here today to special trains and buses to return home after a month of military training. Brig. Gen. H.L. Laubach, camp commander, praised the work of the students and said that the "camp had been most satisfactory in every way."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Ten highways in Sioux Falls were picketed today by farmers who hoped to get, by preventing the marketing of milk, an increase of 50 cents, or $1.75 a hundredweight. Nearly a month's negotiations preceded the beginning of this "strike" today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Taking a runaway lead from five other contenders in the State primary today. William G. McAdoo, former Secretary OF the Treasury, seemed well on his way toward a Democratic Senatorial nomination late tonight.

The Eastern Presidents Conference met yesterday at the Bankers Club to discuss a further reduction in railroad union wages, following which it was indicated that this reduction would be brought about through a percentage cut rather than through alterations in basic rates of pay and in working rules.

An amendment to the certificate of incorporation in order to remove any doubt of the power of directors to authorize the purchase of preferred stock regardless of whether or not there is an impairment of capital or an accrual of dividends will be presented to stockholders of the Interstate Equities Corporation at a special meeting following the annual meeting on Sept. 13.

United States Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, former Secretary of Labor, who was indicted with six others Aug. 18 after an investigation of lotteries conducted by fraternal orders, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am amazed at the statements attributed to Dr. J.P. Normano of the Harvard University at the session of the Williamstown Institute of Politics. I feel certain that he must have been incorrectly reported. I desire, as a Latin-American, to present conclusions based on a long and careful study of inter-American relations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Pairbypair, from the stables of Mrs. John D. Hertz, was too good for a small but select field of sprinters today at Hawthorne and won the Garden City Handicap in handy fashion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Coordination of all unemployment relief efforts for the approaching Winter will be the aim of a conference called by President Hoover to convene here Sept. 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In their conscientious and eager attempt to diminish the expenditures of the Board of Education for the coining school year, authorities recently announced that they were contemplating discontinuing continuation schools for adults.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A case that may determine the authority of the Federal Power Commission to pass on the cost of licensed hydroelectric power projects at completion reached the Supreme Court today from Pennsylvania.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Miss Bea Gottlieb, member of the Lakeville Club and runner-up in the metropolitan championship this year, won the low gross prize in the oneday tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Club today, but only after a card-matching process.

Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland called at Democratic national headquarters at the Biltmore Hotel on his way to Albany to visit Governor Roosevelt, his successful rival for the Democratic nomination for President, and informed James A. Farley, national chairman, that he wanted to help in the campaign to elect Governor Roosevelt in every way he could.

Governor Roosevelt has determined that it will be necessary to call a special session of the Legislature to provide additional unemployment relief, but probably will not summon the legislators until after the Presi-dential election.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug 30 -- J. Howard Demarest, 65, was found deal in his apartment here early this morning, a suicide. He had shot himself through the head with an old-fashioned pistol, one of the few remaining curios he had picked up on one of his world tours of years ago.

An outdoor are exhibition opens today at Manhattan Beach, to continue through Labor Day. It is sponsored by Joseph P. Day, Inc., and contains work by more than one hundred artists of Manhattan and Brooklyn. Many of these artists participated in the Washington Square market early in the Summer.

OMAHA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Mayor R. L. Metcalfe today ordered city officials to break up the blockade established just outside the city limits by farm holiday strikers last night. He invoked a section of tho City Charter that gives Omaha Jurisdiction for three miles beyond its limits.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Remaining assets of the Tri-Utilities Corporation of New York were sold for $69,335 at public auction, today by order of the United States District Court.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Another investigation into alleged police brutality was started today by Nassau County authorities when a Long Beach life-guard complained to the District Attorney's office that he had been beaten and knocked unconscious by three Long Beach policemen last Saturday.

CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 30 -- Despite heavy clouds that completely obscured the sun at the critical hour this afternoon and an airplane accident dear by a few minutes earlier, astronomers of the Franklin Institute eclipse expedition here spent the last available moments testing and rehearsing for the long-awaited event.

Representatives of the intercoastal steamship lines conferred yesterday at the Waldorf Astoria in an attempt to reach an agreement which would be binding on all lines covering the regulation, of freight rates and frequency of sailings. At the close of the meeting it was admitted no agreement was reached.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Senator E.D. Smith, seeking his fifth term in the Senate, was leading his three opponents for the Democratic nomination as unofficial returns came in from today's primary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a member of the bar, the futility of proceedings supplementary to judgment has been constant" and consistently impressed upon me. The weakness and ineffectiveness of our rules of procedure with reference to these proceedings have repeatedly drawn comment from bench and bar, but to date no remedial steps of any consequence have been taken.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- Everything was ready today on the Boerse for another big advance, but several large banks concluded that it would be better to have the market go at a slower pace and threw into it large amounts of securities. These were eagerly bought by the public, which was overanxious to participate in the expected rise.

The wife of a Columbia University instructor and an unemployed Negro were found guilty of disorderly conduct by Magistrate Aurelio in Harlem Court yesterday afternoon, after being arrested last Monday during a riot at the Home Relief Bureau in Public School No. 39, 235 East 125th Street.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 30 -- The "farm holiday" movement in this area, which flared up into violence yesterday, received a setback today when Sheriff Keeling and thirty deputies made a sortie to convoy milk and produce trucks and disperse pickets.

On the complaint of three banks from which he allegedly obtained $300,000 on false representations, James E. Spiegelberg, head of the firm of L. Spiegelberg Sons, cotton converters of 890 Broadway, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for mail fraud.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30 -- Montreal is polishing up her smoked glasses, but is a bit gloomy about the weather. Tonight the entire sky is overcast, with the possibility of rain tomorrow, and there is a curtain of mist for many miles to the east.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- An error by Jack Smith in the eighth inning of the second game gave the Newark Bears the opportunity to gain an even split with the Bisons in a combination twilight and electric light double program tonight.

Radio experts will be busy today watching the needles of sensitive recorders and listening to the action of electromagnetic waves as the shadow of the eclipse creeps down from Canada and across New England on its way out to sea.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30 -- Fifty-one proved Communists were shipped from the City of Puebla last night to the federal penitentiary here. From the capital they will go eventually to the Islas Tres Marias, Mexico's lonely, rocky penal settlement in the Pacific Ocean.
With the Oct. 1 moving day barely a month away, leasing of apartment space in various sections of Manhattan has taken on new life within the last week, according to reports received from brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Consideration of the campaign strategy of the Republican party -- where the drive is to be hardest, where the money is to come from and where most of it is to be spent -- was taken up at a conference at the White House last night between President Hoover and party leaders.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Aug. 1, 1932, shows the following principal changes during July. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

Plans for the reorganization of the Fisk Rubber Company have been completed, it was announced yesterday by the committee in charge, comprising Orrin G. Wood, chairman; Karl H. Behr, Carl P. Dennett, William E. Gilbert, Harold P. Janisch, Theodore G. Smith, W.B. Stratton, John C. Traphagen and John N. Willys.

The American Federation of Musicians, Local 802, has rejected a proposal of the League of New York Theatres, representing Broadway managers, for reductions in the current wage scale contract, which has another year to run, it was said yesterday by Edward Canavan, president of the union.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Roscoe Pound, Dean of the Harvard Law School and a member of the Wickersham Commission, today endorsed the attitude of President Hoover on prohibition as a conservative appeal to "thinking people who seek progress toward a stable, workable plan rather than sensational plunges from one extreme to another."

Looking Down for the Stars. There is one extraordinary thing about the pictures of scientists getting their telescopes and cameras ready for today's eclipse. Such instruments are represented as pointing upward to the sky in the general direction of where one would normally expect the sun and the moon to be.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Jimmie Haizlip, new speed king of the National Air Races, tore in from New York at a 238-mile-an-hour gait today.

Asserting that the Consolidated Gas Company paid $2,500,000 more in dividends in 1931, the second year of the depression, than it did in 1929 or 1930, largely at the expense of the consumer, Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, announced yesterday that the Socialist party was preparing to apply to the Public Service Commission for an immediate downward revision of New York City light and power rates.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the annual recital by Rafaelo Diaz, operatic tenor, which took place this afternoon at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.

Mayor Walker, suffering from nervous exhaustion, was ordered to bed yesterday by his physician, Dr. William Schroeder Jr., Commissioner of Sanitation, it was announced from the Mayor's apartment at the Hotel Mayfair.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Declarations against prohibition repeal were written into the Democratic and Republican State platforms at the meetings of the Kansas party councils here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Jimmy Foxx's forty-eighth home run of the season broke up a tie today, gave the Athletics a 6-to-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers and provided Lefty Grove with his twenty-first triumph of the year.

GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Ecuadorean Government announced tonight that the rebel forces at Quito had accepted their terms for ending the revolt and that Federal troops would enter the capital early tomorrow.

Anders Jordahl, described as having been the confidential agent in America of Ivar Kreguer, the Swedish match monopolist, failed to appear before Henry K. Davis, referee in bankruptcy yesterday, and Jacob K. Javits, attorney for the petitioning creditors said he would seek to have Jordahl held in contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Paraguay rejected today the suggestion of the Committee of Neutrals for a suspension of hostilities with Bolivia for sixty days dating from Thursday on the basis of the status quo, in a note received at the State Department today.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will be urged to establish a regional agricultural credit corporation in the First Federal Land Bank District, it was determined today after a conference called by Charles H. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Sweeping a three-game series, Washington defeated the Browns, 7 to 6, today with the aid of some hard and timely hitting and six St. Louis errors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Superior Stables' Charleigh, which cost William Schmidt of Chicago $7,000 two months ago, ran to an easy victory over a fast field today in the Dearborn Handicap, Hawthorne's top event.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The second annual economic conference for engineers conducted by the Stevens Institute of Technology at its Summer camp here in cooperation with the alumni associations of eight leading Eastern engineering institutions, was addressed tonight on the stabilization of price levels by Norman Lombard of New York, former vice president of the Stable Money Association.

The general banking situation in this district and in the country as a whole was further strengthened in the last month, according to the current review of credit and business conditions published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The French Government is considering the possibility of convoking Parliament in the middle of September to get consent for its huge loan conversion scheme, it was learned today. The Cabinet council will meet tomorrow to discuss the matter, and if a decision is taken it is expected the whole plan will be put through by the beginning of October.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Thirteen persons, including six women and two children, in buses on a pleasure trip were injured near here today in a crash involving two buses and two automobiles. About 100 other women and children in the buses were shaken up.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 31 -- The wildest epidemic of overtime matches in the history of modern golf shook professional championship play today, tumbling Walter Hagen and Al Watrous out of the national title drive after dramatic, record-breaking struggles.

Import Volume Rises Sharply. A rising volume of imported merchandise, carrying the total to the highest level established in more than four months, was reported by government officials here yesterday. The volume is well above the seasonal increase expected at this time, importers said, and can be attributed directly to the improved state of general business.

Average daily electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, was 208,900,000 kilowatt-hours for the week ended Aug. 27, as against 209,200,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and the low record of 208,800,000 kilowatt-tours for the week ended Aug. 13.

The city's new Eighth Avenue subway will be opened for operation on Monday, Sept. 12, it was reported yesterday in usually well-informed quarters. The date is that favored at present by the Board of Transportation, although it is still subject to change.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The national Woman's Christian Temperance Union said in a statement today that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt's prohibition repeal policy "constitutes a surrender to the lower powers."

A series of hold-ups and robberies in Brooklyn, one in the fashionable Columbia Heights district, were reported to the police yesterday. Shortly after 11 A.M. William McVey, superintendent of a twelve-story cooperative apartment at 1 Pierrepont Street, was held up and robbed of a $671 payroll which he had just withdrawn from a near-by bank.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug 31 -- Mrs. Jacob Byers's Fleet Flag, a gelded son of Man of War and Lady Comfey, found the sloppy going much to his liking today at Saratoga and scored at 5 to 1, amid general surprise, in the featured Amsterdam Claiming Stakes.

The money market was dull. Virtually little new business was involved, routine requirements making up the bulk of the day's turnover. Quotations for all classes of accommodation -- Stock Exchange day loans, maturity money and business funds -- were all steady.

Mr. WILLIAM L. WARD, time-honored boss of the Westchester Republicans, is an Elder Statesman of such vigor and humor that one hesitates to reprove him; but is it quite seemly in such a magnifico of the machine to disturb its majestic working?

Money rates in August were little changed from those prevailing in July, call loan charges on both local stock exchanges remaining stationary throughout the month at rates in effect in the closing week of July, while time loans were made at fractionally higher quotations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A suggestion that President Hoover and the members of his official family should agree on just how much the administration knew about conditions prior to 1929 was made today by Senator Wagner on the basis of the statement made in Boston by Secretary Adams that the Executive knew, things were riding too high.

Miss Hilda Aberg, who was found in charge of the New York penthouse apartment of Ivar Kreuger at 791 Park Avenue after his suicide in Paris, and who described herself as the housekeeper there at the Kreuger bankruptcy hearings, is named corespondent in a divorce action brought by Mrs. Iola Sunstedt against Hugo Sunstedt which came before Supreme Court Justice Miller yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug 31 -- President Hoover left his busy desk this afternoon to join with millions of other Americans in gazing at the eclipse.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Augustus Saint Gaudens, 23, grandson of the sculptor, was found unharmed on an uninhabited key twenty-eight miles south of Miami, late today, by Pilot Cal Latham, who made an aerial search after Coast Guard patrol boats had failed to find the youth.

The sun made monkeys of the baboons in the Bronx Zoo yesterday, caused a flurry of excitement among the owls and mocked the premature nocturnal excursions of the wary beaver and wild ducks. But not even a partial eclipse could stir Peter the Great, the sluggish hippopotamus, or Chang, Central Park's elephant, from their habitual torpor.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- In the form of a somewhat voluminous note resuming its recent conversations with the French Ambassador in Berlin, the German Government has presented to France its case for revision of the armaments conditions in the Treaty of Versailles and for Germany's right to equality with other nations in armaments.

Within the next few waeks the city will move to obtain new salary legislation at Albany permitting elimination of mandatory salary increases from the 1933 budget, Budget Director Charles L. Kohler said last night after he had cut $169,965 from the departmental requests of ten departments.

New York City's oldest hospltal will open today the newest centre for the care of the city's sick. The skyscraper medical centre of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College Association, covering three blocks from York Avenue to the East River and Sixty-eighth to Seventy first Street, was opened for inspection yesterday and will be ready to day to receive patients.
BUFFALO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons beat the league-leading Newark Bears in the final of the six-game series today by a score of 4 to 2, making it all even for the stay.

DES MOINES, Aug. 31 -- The farmers' "holiday" which was to have forced up the price of farm products to "production cost" in thirty days was halted tonight following the shooting of fourteen pickets earlier in the day in Cherokee County.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- Seasonal improvement in industrial activity in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve District, with the trend of commodity and security prices continuing upward, is reported in the monthly business review of the Federal Reserve Bank.
ABOARD THE PHILADELPHIA INQUIRER SPECIAL AIRPLANE OVER LIMERICK, Me., Aug. 31 -- In a cold world turned topsy-turvy for the moment, the moon sailed across the face of the sun this afternoon.

TORONTO, Aug. 31 -- The fittest, survivor of the 191 swimmers who plunged into the chilly waters of Lake Ontario this morning, George Blagden of Memphis, Tenn., splashed across the finish line early this evening, winner of the $7,500 first prize money in the annual Canadian national exhibition marathon swim and holder of a new record for the race.

FRYEBURG, Me., Aug. 31 (AP) -- A mysterious mist across the lens of one of the cameras set up here by the Northwestern University eclipse observation party caused Captain Barnett Harris, leader of the group, much concern today.
The moon marched across the face of the sun yesterday and a trail of twilight was streaked across the Western Hemisphere.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month more than doubled that of any previous month this year and was the heaviest since April, 1930, when 111,041,000 shares were dealt in. On Aug. 8 5,462,340 shares were traded, the largest business for a day this year.

To the Editor of the New York Times: One evening a short time ago, the weather being warm, I rode by automobile to Rockaway intending to sit awhile on the beach, as I had many times in the past years. Going by way of the new causeway over Jamaica Bay, I arrived there very quickly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Flying at an altitude of five miles near the centre line of the eclipse zone, the aerial unit of the National Geographic Society's eclipse expedition, conducted by Captain Albert W. Stevens and Lieutenant Charles D. McAllister of the Army Air Corps, had an unobstructed view of the eclipse throughout totality.

Heat, combined with oppressive humidity, caused the collapse of three persons in the city yesterday. Although no records were broken and the maximum temperature was only 82, the humidity was unusually high during most of the day, causing wide-spread discomfort.

A group of New York scientists who were unable to journey into the path of totality of the eclipse left their instruments and tables of celestial mechanics behind them yesterday and, from a perfect coign of vantage 1,000 feet above the dust and haze and heat of the city's streets, enjoyed the phenomenon as a spectacle instead of a problem.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- Governor Roosevelt viewed the eclipse from the rear of the Executive Mansion today and was interviewed by correspondents at the same time.

Robert Adams resold to William and Elizabeth Hilger the six-family flat at 33 Thorne Street, Jersey City, recently acquired, under foreclosure. David P. Kuehne of Englewood conveyed the two three-story frame tenements at 148-50 Steuben Street, Jersey City, to the Bridge Development Bond and Mortgage Company Inc.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Albany divided a double-header with Montreal today to close a six-game series. The Senators took the first, 11-7, and the Royals the second, 3-0. In the opener the two teams hammered eight pitchers for thirty-four hits. Pomorski gave only 5 hits to win the nightcap easily.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Harwood, director of the Maria Mitchell Obervatory, stationed a crew of assistants on a picturesque stone tower at Highland Light today on the hunch that perhaps Cape Cod would have better "seeing" than elsewhere.

CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 31 -- Though astronomers can predict eclipses years in advance, they cannot predict the weather even a few weeks ahead. This was strikingly shown here today when the elaborate efforts of the eclipse expedition from the Franklin Institute, Philadelphia, were completely frustrated oy thick clouds.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Chancellor von Papen, it is learned, will refrain from dissolving the new Reichstag only if, his Cabinet is empowered by a special emergency law to govern for six months without parliamentary support.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The annual baby parade attracted a crowd here today conservatively estimated at 106,000. More than 2,000 persons, including military detachments, a group representing George and Martha Washington and their contemporaries, and the baby parade entries themselves, participated.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Mobilizing some 2,000 policemen, Lord Trenchard, the Commissioner of Metropolitan Police, opened today an offensive against increasingly active motor bandits who are terrorizing London and the countryside.

MAGOG, Que., Aug. 31 -- A completely overcast sky made it impossible for the sixty scientists who had come here from British, Canadian, American, Dutch and Czechoslovak universities to carry out the elaborate plans they had made for registering the various aspects of the eclipse.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At first thought, the clergy have nothing to do with Labor Day. But on second thought, labor means the utilization of earth's powers to produce crops, the smelting of metals, the mining of minerals, the weaving of fibres, the harnessing of nature's elements,

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Plans for eradicating some of New York City's "slum areas" by tearing down outworn tenements and replacing them with more modern dwellings were placed before the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Senator Moses, Republican of New Hampshire, in a speech tonight described Governor Roosevelt as a "nursery rhyme" candidate.

The Danish survey of East Greenland, concerning which Professor KOCH makes another report upon his arrival in Iceland by airplane, promises to give the world a complete description of the geology, coast line, ice cap ranges, meteorology, mineral value and grazing lands of that side of the vast island.

The redemption of bonds in August before their maturity dates showed a marked increase over the total in July, more than doubling the amount retired in that month, but was only half the amount retired in August, 1931. Bonds aggregating $56,243,000 were called for payment last month, against $26,120,500 in July and $113,795,000 in August, 1931.

SYDNEY, N.S., Aug. 31 -- I have been compelled, reluctantly, to the decision not to fly back across the Atlantic, which would have given me the satisfaction of making an Atlantic round trip flight to add to my gratification at being the first to make the westward air crossing solo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- White House aides said today that President Hoover had personally suggested to Governor Theodore Roosevelt that he remain at his post in the Philippines rather than return to this country to take an active part in the electoral campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Admiral Richard H. Leigh, Commander in Chief United States Fleet, and Rear Admiral Claude C. Bloch, commanding Cruiser Division 3, Scouting Force, will visit Portland, Ore., during the national convention of the American Legion, the Navy Department announced today.

In response to Governor Roosevelt's recent radio appeal for contributions to the Democratic campaign fund, 2,678 supporters of his candidacy have made individual contributions totaling $9,835, it was announced last night at the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee in the Hotel Biltmore.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The thirteenth annual Dutchess County horse show opened today, in conjunction with the Dutchesa County Pair. Several prizes were won by entries exhibited by Kenneth E. Archer of Kingston and the Tipperary Stables of Waterbury, Conn., but one of the most popular victories of the day was gained by an entry owned by Mrs. James A. Roosevelt, mother of Governor Roosevelt.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Premier Edouard Herriot and Sir Herbert Samuel, the British Home Secretary, completed their talk on the isle of Jersey today and were closeted for several hours on shipboard on their way to Guernsey.

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 -- Major James H. Doolittle flying at times close to six miles a minute, broke the world's land plane speed record here this afternoon. Over the official three kilometer course he flew the Gee Bee racer four times, averaging 293.193 miles an hour.

The heads of the four Eastern trunk lines, at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Railroad station yesterday, reached the greatest measure of accord on consolidation since the Inerstate Commerce Commission issued its integration plan on July 21. After conferring for three hours they adjourned until Sept. 13.

The new Furness-Bermuda liner Queen of Bermuda will be launched today at the yards of Vickers-Armstrong, Ltd., at Barrow-in-Furness, England, according to cable advice received yesterday by H.G. Blackiston, director of the Furness shipping interests in the United States.

In a report of their activities during their first six months in office, the receivers of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation show that running expenses of that holding company have been cut to onetenth of their previous amount and that the indebtedness of associated or subsidiary companies to banks and others has been reduced more than $1,327,000.

A survey of the administration of funds for veterans' relief by the New York City Department of Public Welfare has disclosed "worse than waste" in much of the expenditure of about $8,000,000 in two and a half years, according to a report submitted four months ago, the contents of which were revealed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Holding his lead over Senator Samuel M. Shortridge, Tallant Tubbs of San Francisco, advocate of immediate repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, stood out today as the apparent winner of the five-sided contest for the Republican Senatorial nomination as returns of the California primary neared completion.
Members of the bond crowd of the New York Stock Exchange were notified yesterday by Ashbel Green, secretary, of rules govering the placing of bids or offers for bonds.

YORK, England, Aug. 31 -- Sir Alfred Ewing, 77-year-old engineer, opened the annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science tonight by expressing fear lest modem man be overwhelmed by the fruits of his own knowledge.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- Conditions of Sino-Japanese tension in Shanghai are accelerating rapidly, almost duplicating the developments of the fortnight preceding the opening of hostilities here on Jan. 28.

Control of the common stock of the Hood Rubber Company, Inc., has been purchased from the B.F. Goodrich Company by the principal executives of the former company, headed by Arthur B. Newhall, president and general manager, it was announced yesterday.
FRYBBURG, Me., Aug. 31 -- The eclipse party of the Van Vleck Observatory, Wesleyan University, stationed at Center Conway, N.H., reported that it carried out its complete

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 31 -- With a large gallery of 1,500 spectators turning out to see the Davis Cup and nationally ranked players in action, the East gained a 2-to-1 lead over the West today as the annual intersectional team matches opened at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Max Baer, Livermore, Cal., defeated Ernie Schaaf, Boston heavyweight challenger, in a ten-round battle tonight, with the bell depriving him of a knockout victory.
OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The aerial expedition in an autogiro directed by myself and sponsored by Harvard College Observatory was entirely successful.

Renewed activity in the leasing of space for branch offices of Wall Street brokerage houses in the midtown west side garment district was reported yesterday by Harris Newmark, realty dealers, who announced the renting of stores on Seventh Avenue to three stock firms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in THE TIMES regarding the bonus proves that you apparently have not gone deeply enough into the psychology of the American Legion members. You say you understand and can sympathize with the feeling of the members of the Legion -- and hence would not admonish them at this time for their fervor in favor of immediate payment of the bonus.

Grim and, silent, W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, was preparing yesterday for a showdown at the Republican State convention, a month hence, with his opponents of the socalled Hoover group within the Republican State organization.

For the Treasury at Washington the second month of the new fiscal year ended yesterday with a far better showing than the first. During July, when, it was hoped that new taxes and economies had at last brought the Government's books into approximate balance, the Treasury accumulated a deficit of $264,000,000.

Declarations of dividends in August continued the downward course of payments to shareholders which they have followed so far this year. Payments voted for 615 corporations aggregated $250,104,547 compared with $134,577,492 for 710 corporations in July and with $388,744,811 for 849 corporations in August, 1931.

Prices or bonds of domestic corporations continued to decline on the Stock Exchange yesterday, industrials losing ground as well as rails and utilities. Trading, however, was slightly more active than on the previous day. United States Government issues were irregularly lower.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31 -- While thousands of spectators were disappointed along the path of the umbra tip of the total solar eclipse in New England yesterday, my pilot, Randy Enslow, and I climbed high above the thick banks of cumulus clouds and photographed the eclipse in all its splendor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "One of Many" urges us to vote for a second-term Hoover as against a first-term Roosevelt. The gentleman naively suggests that Mr. Hoover will, if re-elected, be able quietly and undistractedly to work without stint or limit to bring the country back to pre-depression "prosperity."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Shipping Board approved an agreement between the Arrow Line and Dollar Steamship Lines, Inc., today for through shipments from Atlantic ports of call to the Orient, with transshipment at San Francisco or Los Angeles Harbors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The second investigation in barely a year of charges of unfair treatment of Negro laborers in Federal flood control projects in the Mississippi Valley is being made by the War Department.

Football practice at Columbia will get under way today at Baker Field, with morning and afternoon sessions scheduled for forty-two aspirants, twenty-five of whom are sophomores. Coach Lou Little and his assistants have been laying plans for the coming campaign for the past few days and everything iIs in readiness for the arrival of the Blue and White's football standard bearers.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Outstanding in the stock markets today was a further advance in British Government funds, which were strengthened by the revenue figures and the war loan and treasury bond announcements. Other sections of the market were quiet and price movements mostly lower on profit-taking.

Following a day of complete rest at his Hotel Mayfair apartment, Mayor "Walker was reported last night to be recovering from the nervous exhaustion, which caused him to be ordered to bed on Tuesday. As a result, his friends said, he planned to attend the removal hearing scheduled to open before Governor Roosevelt at Albany at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Drivers of twenty-two live-stock trucks loaded with hogs, who attempted to run the farmers' blockade into Sioux City from Nebraska,

A new building for the Third District Magistrates' Court and the Fifth District municipal court of Queens in the Beach Channel Drive between Beach Ninetieth and Beach Ninety-first Streets, Rockaway Beach, was dedicated yesterday afternoon with exercises outside the court house attended by 4,000 persons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Kiki Cuyler's fourth homer in the four playing days of the Giants' series came with two on bases and two out in the tenth inning today, climaxing a five-run rally by which the pennantpointing Cubs wiped out a four-run lead gained by the Giants in the first half of the extra inning to win their twelth straight victory, 10 to 9.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Bolivia, in a note received by the Committee of Neutrals today, declared its readiness to sign a truce for thirty days on the basis of the military status quo in the Chaco during which negotiations would be attempted for a peaceful solution of the controversy, and the neutrals in a note to Paraquay urged that government to accept such an arrangement.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Darwin P. Kingsley, chairman of the board of the New York Life Insurance Company, of which former President Calvin Coolidge is a member, is critically ill at his home in Dunemere Uane here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The Central West Public Service Company announced today that it had made arrangements to pay the $281,000 past due interest on its first lien collateral bonds. At the same time it extended to Sept. 15 the time in which holders of its three-year 7 per cent notes may deposit them under the plan for conversion.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a luncheon today at Claverack House for Miss Helen Iselin Goodridge, who will be introduced to society in the Fall. Miss Goodridge and her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hunt Barber, have passed the greater part of the Summer with Mrs. Barber in Southampton.
Exhibition plans of the, Museum of Modern Art for the approaching season were announced yesterday. Four of the six projected shows will be devoted to American art.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The German demand for equality in armaments has suffered a sharp rebuff at the hands of the British Government.

Racing to the bedside of her dying mother in England, Mrs. Clive Payne, wife of the marine superintendent of the Panama Canal Zone, completed the first half of her 5,000-mile dash early this morning when she boarded the White Star, liner Olympic in Gravesend Bay from a tug which had rushed her from Jersey City.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Philip R. Clarke, president of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, today called "premature"' rumors that a new bank would be organized to take over the business of the Central Republic.

Charles W. Schumann, head of Schumann Sons, Inc., 15 East Fifty-third Street, which concern has been in the jewelry business in this city for more than eighty years, was arrested last night as the instigator of a robbery of his establishment on July 19 in which jewelry valued at $135,000 was stolen.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Templeton and Aurora came through to victories today as the high-goal polo teams finished their preparations for the start of the national open championship on Saturday.

In the sense of temporary inability to do the work of the world, thousands of people in this country today would be ruled out by strict laws of efficiency. The social conscience is pricked by their mute plea for help. Some of them are intelligent, in good health, well-balanced emotionally, but their old occupation has vanished.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While "everything goes in politics," one has learned to look for something a little different in THE NEW YORK TIMES than the charge of hypocrisy directed against the Allied, Forces in the editorial "Yea-and-Nay Prohibitionists," carried in the issue of Aug. 25.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 31 -- After battling for twelve innings to a 5-all tie, darkness halted the second game today of the American Legion junior championship series between New Orleans and Springfield, Mass.

Failing eyesight prevented Edwin F. Hyde, nonagenarian eclipse enthusiast and retired banker of 36 West Fifty-eighth Street, from seeing yesterday's astronomical phenomenon. Mr. Hyde, who has traveled thousands of miles to see four total eclipses of the sun, said yesterday that he had planned to go to New England, but decided to abandon the idea a few days ago.

Edward P. Morse, who founded the Morse Dry Dock And Repair Company and who at his death on Aug. 26, 1930, was chairman of the board of the United Dry Docks Company which absorbed the Morse company, left an estate of $1,919,125.99 gross and $1,645,953.83 net, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday in the Kings County Surrogate's office.

The new United States liner Manhattan is due today on her maiden westbound voyage. She is bringing back from the Channel ports W. Irving Glover, Assistant United States Postmaster General, Major R. A. Gilmore, E.H. Rigg, J.F. Melton and R. Yearwood.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- Autumn grain-sowing in the Soviet Union is reported unsatisfactory, 7,000,000 acres having been sown up to Aug. 25, compared with 15,000,000 up to the same date last year. The Ukraine is decidedly weak, many areas having accomplished less than a quarter of their monthly program.

The formation of five new Stock Exchange partnerships, two of which were created through the merger or reorganization of existing firms, was announced yesterday. The new firms are Erdman Co., Tenney Co., Tobey Co., Rhoades, Williams Co. and Kennedy Co.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Patsy Hanover captured the 3-year-old pace at the Flemingtor Fair in straight heats today, finishing the first mile in 2:07. Tondinella Stout, Clarksburg (W. Va.) gelding had to go 2:14 1/4, to take the final whirl in the 2-year-old trot and win the race.
MONTREAL, Aug. 31 -- There was a sweep of shadow, a sudden click of a curtain, even through the clouds, and the darkness of the moon swept across this city today.

BASE CAMP, NANGA PARBAT, Kashmir (by runner to Astor), Aug. 31 -- We are now back at our base camp, not, of course, to give up, but to collect new forces and start at last on our final attack to reach the summit of that formidable Himalayan peak, Nanga Parbat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Senator Tydings, former chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, is figuring on the Democrats gaining control of the next Senate which meets in December, thus giving them complete control of Congress in the last part of the Hoover Administration.

SACRAMENTO, Aug 31 (AP) -- President Hoover's use of the army to evacuate bonus marchers and their familes from Washington was criticized in a resolution adopted today by the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- To the request of the new Reichstag's officers, including its Nazi Speaker, for an immediate audience to plead their case for continuance of the session, President von Hindenburg replied today with the polite suggestion that they wait.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 31 -- Disqualifications which, involved three crews, of which two were leaders in the point standing, upset the standing in the series for the national junior sailing championship at the Beverly Yacht Club today. The Squantum and Westerly Yacht Club entries lost all their points scored in the fourth race when they passed a government buoy on the wrong side.

THE jolly British golfers are about to shoot at the Walker Cup again, and, on the records, the safest place for innocent bystanders to locate themselves is right beside the big silver trophy. Not a shot will come near them.

Through immeasurable feet of used motion-picture camera film, Broadway watched a globe of shadow slide athwart what it likes to considers its secondary source of light, the sun, yesterday and decided the advance notices of the "show" had been too good.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 31 -- The advance in cotton prices above 8 cents a pound has cheered the entire South. To be sure there was a tune when cotton sold as high as 42 cents, and early in 1929 it was still 20 cents. The continued drop in prices since then, when it reached the low of 5 cents early last Spring, has made for all the agonies of deflation.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- Plans to call 2,100 men back to work in September to recondition a large number of cars and locomotives for the Reading Company, at a cost of $1,200,000, were announced today by Charles H. Ewing, president of the railroad.

Charges that prisoners held over night in West Side prison were not permitted, as the law provides, to telephone or send messages to their friends or attorneys so they might obtain bail were made yesterday in Yorkville Court, only to be denied later, after an investigation, by Sidney W. Brewster, the prison warden.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A new German tariff decree just promulgated and providing for "drastic increases in import duties" on a wide range of imports, including many from the United States, will become effective on Sept. 6, the Commerce Department was advised today by K. C. McLean, acting commercial attache at Berlin.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 31 -- America's team supremacy over Great Britain, proved in six previous matches, will be put to another test tomorrow and Friday, when the hand-picked golfers of the two nations meet in another international competition for the Walker Cup.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Ecuadorean revolt at Quito flared again today as the Federals and the rebels disagreed over the terms of an armistice.

Dr. William Lathrop Love, State Senator for the Eighth Kings County District, who la fighting for the renomination refused him by the McCooey Democratic machine, won a pcint yesterday when he obtained first place, on the ballot for the Sept. 20 primaries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Additional taxes must be paid by all corporations, partnerships and individuals which during 1932 have filed returns for the fiscal year under the rates of the 1928 Revenue act, the Treasury Department ruled today.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Rochester Red Wings took advantage of the near-total eclipse of the sun in the second inning to score five runs today, which led to a 9-to-6 victory over Baltimore in their final clash of the season.
ISLAND POND, Vt., Aug. 31 -- With the sky overcast during the moments of eclipse totality, there were only a few breaks in the cloud canopy here during the entire day.
TORONTO, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) -- After winning the first game of today's double-header, 12-9, the Toronto Leafs lost the second to Jersey City, 5 to 3, and the series two to one.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Eastern and local speculators who recently "were aggressive buyers of wheat turned, to the selling side today on the Board of Trade here and found a lack of forcible support. Prices dropped about 2 cents from yesterday's finish, with liquidation under way in the September.

Minority Report on Eclipses. The show is over. The battalions of astrophysical scientists encamped on Canadian soil will now devote a couple of days to recuperating from their arduous labors extending over a period of no less than 102 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Chinese Legation made public today the full text, of the speech of Dr. Lo Wen-kan, the Chinese Foreign Minister, at the weekly memorial service for Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Nanking on Monday, in which he attacked Japan for her course in Manchuria and replied to the recent address of Count Uchida, the Japanese Foreign Minister, before the Diet in Tokyo.

FRYEBURG, Me., Aug. 31 -- Millions of faces, ghastly in unnatural twilight, turned toward the vast vault of heaven in the valleys and on the summits of the White Mountains in this district today as the moon and sun, only slightly veiled behind a thread of cloud, enacted an awesome drama in the sky.

On a clear, frosty morning in November, 1884, Thomas A. Gallagher walked from his home at Rivington and Pitt Streets to old Postoffice A, at 595 Broadway, to take his first job as a postal clerk. He was ten minutes early. Yesterday, at the age of 70, he retired from the service with a record of never having been late or absent in forty-eight years.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: I read with interest and approval THE TIMES editorial on "The Bonus Danger." This bonus menace is indeed a very serious one and must be stopped if possible. The American Legion is showing very little that it is a patriotic organization in its present attitude.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Escape of Joseph Matchok, 35 years old, of Hackensack, from the Mercer County jail here this morning was followed by the suspension of two guards by Sheriff Charles N. Reichert pending an investigation. Others may be suspended also or discharged, he said.

The Eastern Palliament Corporation, which until Tuesday had been known for thirty-two years as Wallach Brothers, retailer of men's clothing, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court.

Following the precedent set by the negotiations at Chicago last Winter which resulted in a year's voluntary reduction of 10 per cent in railway union wages, the railroad managements plan to carry on negotiations for a further decrease through meetings between a committee of nine railroad officials on the one hand and the twenty-one members of the Railway Labor Executives' Association on the other.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The Boerse opened relatively weak today, due to realizing by speculators, but later a strong rally carried prices of favorite stocks above yesterday's highest levels. Business which at first was quiet picked up rapidly when another wave of buying followed that of recent days.

The last day of August saw brisk renting of apartments in widely scattered sections of Manhattan. Brokers and renting agents announced long lists of new rentals yesterday, the terms of the leases indicating an undiminished demand for suites to be occupied this Pall.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- Chinese Irregulars, estimated to number 5,000, were reported to have made another daring attack early this morning on Mukden City, headquarters of the Japanese command in Manchuria.

GRAY, Me., Aug. 31 -- Under the influence of a northerly breeze, cirrus clouds which had kept the group at a nervous edge all the morning cleared at 1:30 this afternoon and the sky remained beautifully clear for the Harvard party located here throughout the progress of the eclipse.

While there have been few indications in the steel industry thus far that the anticipated September expansion will "attain more than small proportions," many developments show that the "ground work for some measure of business recovery is being laid, according to The Iron Age.

Although the recent Joint announcement of the League of New York Theatres and the Actors' Equity Association stated that the Actors Dinner Club was "now on the rocks financially," the club will continue to serve dinners to jobless theatrical people in Its quarters under Loew's State Theatre, according to Colonel Earle Boothe, its business manager.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- The Republican members of the Summer colony turned out in full force this evening to attend the dinner rally given at Newport Beach, under the auspices of 'the Men's Republican Club of Newport County, of which Colonel Snowden A. Fahnestock is president.

Veteran boatmen around Babylon Bay report better fishing than at any time this season and many declare they never had seen the blues and weaks run in the bay as they have this week. Captain Ray Whittaker, with a party on his boat Comfort, made two catches on Sunday, going out in the morning and again in the afternoon and winding up the day with nearly 100 blues.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Radio scientists here who poked inquisitive wave-lengths today into the atmospheric area some eighty miles above the earth during the eclipse, face the prospect of revising their theories to fit a new set of facts.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 -- Battling through four and a half hours of baseball, the Dodgers captured both ends of a double-header from the Reds today and left for home tonight with a record of nine victories out of fifteen games played on the Western trip.

ALFRED, Me., Aug. 31 -- Scientists of the Kyoto Imperial Observatory in Tokyo came the longest distance to catch the eclipse In the White Mountains -- a full 10,000 miles -- and were rewarded, they announced late today, with what they believe to be the most perfect corona pictures ever taken.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Tony Freitas's winning streak was halted at ten straight today as the Tigers shaded the Athletics, 5 to 4, and evened the series at two victories apiece.

Mortgagees, including banks and holding companies, again were active yesterday at liquidation sales of real estate in Manhattan and the Bronx. Tenement houses, small residential buildings and some vacant lots were among the properties put up for bidding.

Everything, including Mr. MCADOO, seems to have gone very Wet in California. Though until recently one of the strongest supporters of the Eighteenth Amendment, Mr. McADOO had to announce his complete adherence to the Democratic national platform -- which demands repeal and "immediate modification of the Volstead act" -- before he could be assured of his party's nomination for United States Senator.

Except for a moderate advance in the railway shares, there was little in yesterday's stocit market to interest Wall Street, although transactions on the Stock Exchange made up a total of nearly 3,000,000 shares, compared with 3,301,000 on the previous day.

Arrival here yesterday of between 800 and 1,000 model gowns, selected by buyers at recent Paris openings, show that a preponderance of the new Fall and Winter models will feature shades of brown and green, with black the most popular, trimmed with white, in materials of heavy crepe, velvet, sheers, jersey and cotton velvet.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Fowler McCormick, son of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick and the only one of her children who was not estranged from her at one time or another, was the only heir to her estate who appeared in the Cook County Probate Court today to testify to the legal details concerning her death and her heirs.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 (AP) -- More than 150,000 German World War veterans, representatives of the Steel Helmet Federation, numbering 1,000,000 members, started to advance on Berlin today for their thirteenth convention.

Speed and stunt-flying are the attractions at the National Air Races. Of the two, it is stunt-fiying that most people go to the field at Cleveland to see. "It was the stunt"ing show that made the turnstiles "click," said EDWARD P. WARNER describing the spectacle in 1931.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Having again engaged Raffaele De Riggi as conductor, the Westchester Symphony Orchestra announced today that the first of a series of six concerts during the 1932-33 season will be given Oct. 13 in the Westchester County Centre here.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- American and French economic experts met today at the Ministry of Commerce to seek a settlement of the question of French fruit import quotas, which have caused a cut in United States fruit exports to France of nearly 40 per cent this year.

CANBERRA, Aug. 31 -- Joseph A. Lyons, Australian Prime Minister, made his first authoritative general review of the Ottawa Imperial Economic Conference in relation to Australia when the House of Representatives reassembled this afternoon.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- Hiroshi Saito, Counselor at the London Embassy, has been appointed Counselor at the Washington Embassy, where he will act as Charge d'Affaires. Mr. Saito, who is regarded as one of the ablest of the younger diplomats, has ten years of American experience.

Public offering of new securities in August by banking houses here was little changed from the volume in July, and as has been the case for more than a year, bond issues predominated. Twenty-six issues were marketed at $121,238,000, of which twenty-five were for bonds aggregating 120,638,000 and one for stock totaling $600,000.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- The New York State Gas and Electric Corporation was directed by the Public Service Commission today to furnish electric service on rural lines after Jan. 1 to about 300 farmers in sixteen counties who have applied for such service and have complied with the requirements of the company's filed schedules.

Joseph Hergesheimer, novelist, sailing on the Italian liner Roma for Italy this morning, saying he was going to Germany "where a man doesn't have to take a drink unless he wants to." He said the liquor question had become so tense in this country that life was uncomfortable for a man who doesn't care to walk around day and night with a glass in hia hand.

Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, presiding over the Board of Estimate yesterday in the absence of Mayor Walker, ordered an investigation into charges that favoritism was being practiced in the allotment of work relief by the City Commission Work Bureau of the Emergency Relief Administration.

The Seabury investigation, sweeping as it was, only scratched the surface of New York's corruption because of limited funds, time and human endurance, William B. Northrop, nephew of Samuel Seabury and his aide in the investigation, and John B. Northrop, attorney, assert in "The Insolence of Office," published today by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

NEW YORK. Lieut. Col. William Mechling Colvin, U.S.A., and Mrs. Colvin will give an afternoon reception with dancing Sept. 22 at Old Orchard, Belle Haven, Greenwich, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Lucette Colvin.

The week's reaction in all markets which have participated in the recent rapid advance continued yesterday, but not with continuous movement in the one direction. Prices on the Stock Exchange declined 2 to 4 points in many active shares, but in most of them the greater part of the early loss was recovered as a result of quick purchases before the close.

Five years after they broke oft athletic relations because of conflicting views on the question of eligibility standards, Army and Navy have declared a truce and entered into an agreement for a three-year resumption of rivalry in all branches of sport.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- It was confirmed here today that the German Government had submitted to Paris a memorandum setting forth its ideas on the reorganization of the Reichswehr in the event other members of the League of Nations fail to disarm to the German level.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 31 -- The Central Bank issued a report this evening which says: "A feeling of confusion, uncertainty and distrust still prevails in banking and industrial circles concerning the general situation here since the necessary conditions for reaction are lacking.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- At a rally of all the cadets and officers at the United States Military Academy, held at the cadet mess tonight on the eve of starting football practice and academic work, Lieut. Col. Walter K. Wilson, executive officer at the military academy and acting superintendent in the absence of Major Gen. William D. Connor, announced the resumption of athletic relations with the Navy.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Execution by the city of a fifty-year lease on four acres of land at the Newark Airport for a $500,000 hotel, bus terminal and service station project was authorized by the City Commission in a resolution adopted today. The lease will be to Frank S. Tyrol, New York lawyer, representing a group whose identity has not been made known.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's revived Pirates beat the Boston Braves, 2 to 1, today, making a clean sweep of the four-game series. It was Pittsburgh's fifth triumph in a row.

The construction industry in New York, needs its own board of trade, representing all interests in this field, to unify building practices, to act as a supervisory body over building work, and to prepare for the next era of expansion, which, in the housing division particularly, should not be long delayed, in the opinion of Alien E. Beals, head of the Dow Service Building Reports.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- With the case of Mayor Walker still in abeyance, Governor Roosevelt buckled down today to drafting the address he will deliver Saturday at Bridgeport, Conn., and to speeches for his first swing through the country.

While static clicked somewhat more than usual yesterday afternoon, radio men studied the effects of the eclipse on transmission and reception and gathered data to ponder over for weeks in an effort to solve some of the mystery of the sun's influence on world-wide communication.

Gold continued to flow into the United States in August, the net gain being $107,888,100, which increased to $156,896,800, the increment for two months. At the Port of New York imports of gold last month totaled $15,678,900, against exports of $18,050,300, while earmarked gold decreased $100,500,500.
PARIS, Sept. 1. -- France's reply to Germany's request for revision of her military status will be drafted in consultation with Great Britain.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Melbourne Higgins will return to the Plaza Sept. 15 from Hot Springs, Va.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Authority to issue $20,000,000 6 per cent, five-year notes which it proposes to offer in exchange for an equal amount of three-year notes maturing Oct. 1, was sought today by the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad in an application filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

An independent bondholders committee for the General Vending Corporation 6 per cent ten-year secured sinking-fund gold debentures due on Aug. 15, 1937, has proposed a plan of reorganization for the company, providing for the formation of a new company in which the stockholders will be solely General Vending bondholders, who will receive their recurities on a pro rata basis.

The Bensonhurst National Bank, 8,510 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, was robbed of $5,000 yesterday afternoon by eight armed men who held sixteen persons at bay while they looted the vault and tellers' cages and took more than $300 from six persons waiting to make deposits.

Bustles, providing a new note in collections of imported dress models viewed here yesterday, attracted attention in style circles. Taking the form of a small oblong pillow about seven inches long and four inches wide, packed with a sawdust-type of filling, they added a Victorian touch to one silk jersey evening dress with pleats falling to the hem of the dress.

For the fourth consecutive session on the Cotton Exchange a profit-taking movement resulting from the rise of nearly 100 per cent had a depressing effect on prices yesterday, buying and selling power was to 13 points on the day.

Another day of muggy heat caused widespread discomfort and one prostration in the city yesterday. The highest temperature recorded was 87 at 3 P.M. That came within one degree of the season's record, but was five degrees short of the record for the date, 92, established in 1924.

The total savings of the American people at the end of 1930 were $57,000,000,000, according to a compilation by the National Industrial Conference Board. At the close of 1931 savings deposits in bank and trust companies and assets of life insurance companies, which can be used as fair indices of savings, amounted to $48,375,000,000, as compared with $47,365,000,000 at the close of 1930.

Reflecting the fact that business has been well maintained, the Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries report for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $1,100,330 after depreciation, taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 60 cents a share on 1,050,000 common shares, and compares with a net of $1,320,093 or 77 cents a share in the first half of last year.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 1.-- Paraguay, it is learned here, has rejected the offer of a thirty-day truce with Bolivia until Bolivia returns Forts Boqueron, Toledo and Corralee. The offer was relayed from Bolivia yesterday by the Washington neutrals.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 1. -- Though Mayor Wu Te-chen today sternly warned terrorist anti-Japanese societies of his intention to arrest and severely punish bombers and purveyors of threats and pledged his best efforts to maintain law and order, the exodus of frightened Chinese from Chapei continues.

Assuming the office of Mayor of the city of New York is not a new task for Joseph V. McKee. Mr. McKee became Acting Mayor eleven days after he was installed as President of the Board of Aldermen on Jan. 1, 1926. and has since held the post many times during Mayor Walker's absences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Severe criticism of the Federal Radio Commission is made in the report of the committee on communications of the American Bar Association, of which Louis G. Caldwell, former chief counsel of the commission, is chairman.

Blackfish have begun to run in Peconic Bay and the fishermen in those waters again are happy. For the last week or so anglers have had poor fortune indeed with weakfish in the bay and while porgies were plentiful the weaks didn't seem to be biting.

Automobile traffic on the lower level of the Queensboro Bridge was snarled for two hours last night and thousands of Manhattan-bound motorists were delayed as the result of four successive collisions between a Queens-bound automobile and four others bound for Manhattan.

YORK, England, Sept. 1. -- A new theory to explain why all living matter is dissymmetric, instead of symmetric like non-living matter, a puzzle that Pasteur tried to solve, was offered today before the British Association for the Advancement of Science, at its annual meeting, by Dr. W.H. Mills, president of the chemistry section and reader in stereochemistry at Cambridge.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 1. -- Yale will issue no football season books to the general public this Fall, but will reduce its schedule of prices generally for admission to the bowl and will receive public applications for all games.

Answering questions in the Parliament at Tokyo, the Japanese Foreign Minister frankly said that "world opinion" is pronounced against the course pursued by Japan. Yet he asserted that the Japanese Government is determined to adhere to the plans already adopted "and in the face of all opposition."

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- Irregularities marked the Bourse session today. While rentes and a few domestic stocks were well traded, selling affected numerous internationals. Failure of Wall Street to maintain its improvement during the last few sessions also is watched with some uneasiness here, with the result that there is a diminution in trading.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1. -- Advancement in the wide "revolutionary" social program, especially in the agrarian and land distribution plans of the Mexican Government, was described today by President Ortiz Rubio in his address opening the Thirty-fifth Congress.

Pope Pius XI has sent a letter commending the revision of the Catholic Encyclopedia, which is now under way, to the Rev. John J. Wynne, the editor, and his associates. The letter was received yesterday at the offices of the encyclopedia, 141 East Twenty-ninth Street.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- With Governor Roosevelt an interested spectator during a part of the afternoon session, the thirteenth annual Dutchess County Fair horse show came to a most successful conclusion late today. The Chief Executive motored to the Fair Grounds from his home in Hyde Park.

In connection with their plans to get an expression of the American public's views on economic and trade problems, particularly the question of whether foreign debts should be remitted, the American Defense Society and the National Action Committee were merged at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night.
LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Some three-cornered hitting among Germany, France and Britain has followed the "further moderate regulation of imports" announced by the German Chancellor last Sunday.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Representatives of American, commercial companies whose business will be seriously affected by the new German import duties, announced in Washington yesterday and now formally gazetted here descended in a body upon the United States Commercial Attache today to demand protection from their government.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The outstanding debt structure in the United States was analyzed here tonight by Dr. Lionel D. Edie of the Capital Research Company, in an address to the second annual economic conference for engineers, conducted by Stevens Institute of Technology at its Summer camp here in cooperation with the alumni associations of eight leading engineering institutions of the East.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP). -- In the wake of a scrambled Senatorial primary, California Republicans are taking stock of their party's prospects under the titular leadership of 34-year-old Tallant Tubbs, scion of one of San Francisco's oldest and wealthiest families.

Serious charges against the administration by the city Department of Public Welfare of the funds for veterans' relief are made in the report of an expert investigator employed by the State Department of Social Welfare and the State Department of the American Legion.

Domestic copper prices were advanced another 1/8 cent a pound yesterday to 5 7/8 cents, delivered in the Connecticut Valley, to the end of 1932. Foreign prices also were moderately higher at 5.95 cents a pound, c.i.f. Hamburg, Havre and London. Domestic sales remain small.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The Federal Power Commission today cleared the way for a final settlement of the question of who shall use the power developed on Eighteen-Mile Creek, New York, now controlled by the Niagara Falls Power Company and claimed by the City of Lockport.

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, Cleveland Sept. 1. -- Fighting a gusty and treacherous quartering wind, Major James H. Doolittle failed by a fraction to day in setting a new world's land plane record. The famous racing pilot, with a new-type propeller and other slight changes in his equip ment, flew the tricky Gee Bee racer four times, twice with the wind in so far as he could, and twice against it over the three-kilometer course.
The following statement was issued last night by Mayor Walker on his resignation:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a visitor to New York's splendid and colorful State American Legion convention to whom every conceivable courtesy was shown, possibly I should not speak concerning the conduct of that body; but as a citizen believing in fair play I cannot refrain from expressing one regret.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- A musical revue, "Rye 900," was presented tonight at the Westchester Country Club by members of the younger set of the club.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

SACRAMENTO, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars, in national encampment here, passed a resolution today "seriously censuring" Federal officials responsible for using the army to drive bonus marchers from Washington, D.C., last July.

Even though the last week included the final days of the month, when a reduction is normally expected, bank clearings throughout the country were $118,500,000 larger than in the preceding week. Reports to R.G. Dun Co. from leading centres indicate total clearances for the week ended on Wednesday of $3,803,039,000, a decline of 36.7 per cent from a year ago.
A few of the New York scientists, photographers and aviators who went to New England for the eclipse returned yesterday, bringing for the most part a tale of woe.

THIS is the way it should go out over the air waves from Police Headquarters: "All police cars stand by! All police cars stand by! Important news. Ball game today at Polo Grounds between all-star team of Junior Police Athletic Club and team from St. Mary's Industrial School of Baltimore. Notify all small boys to proceed at once to nearest police station for tickets, which will be given away.
ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- Governor Roosevelt held a general council of war tonight with the chief advisers of his campaign for the Presidency.

In answer to the appeal for assistance to the Actors Dinner Club, made early this week by the League of New York Theatres and the Actors' Equity Association, William H. Matthews, director of the Emergency Work Bureau, said yesterday in a letter to Dr. Henry Moskowitz, executive adviser of the league, that the club, which serves free dinners to jobless theatrical people, was receiving aid from the relief committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here appeared today to have paused to get its bearings, and with a lack of aggressive operations by the larger professionals on each side prices held within a range of around 1 cent a bushel.

The General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders announced yesterday that it would seek modification of a plan of adjustment proposed for $5,238,000 of bonds outstanding on the Alden Apartments, at Central Park West and Eighty-second Street, and the Dorset, at 26 West Fifty-fourth Street, by S.W. Straus Co., who sold the bonds.

A heeting held last night in McKinley Square, 169th Street and Boston Road, the Bronx, under the auspices of the International Labor Defense, Bronx branch, broke up in a general fight when somebody hurled a milk bottle at the speaker. Two persons were slightly injured and a crowd of about 1,000 was dispersed by a police emergency squad.

In the long and now acute controversy between Bolivia and Paraguay over their respective rights in the region known as the Gran Chaco, a point seems to have been reached where national pride threatens to interfere with a peaceful settlement. A comprehensive plan of arbitration has been urged upon those two republics by nineteen neutral nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The cornerstone of the new Supreme Court Building on Capitol Hill will be laid on Thursday, Oct. 13.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation has not extended its electric service into some rural districts up-State, as it was ordered to do on Wednesday by the Public Service Commission, chiefly because the commission had previously failed to authorize the capitalization of the costs of previous similar construction, it was said yesterday at the offices of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, which controls the operating company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for financing the construction of self-liquidating projects are expected to begin within the next week or ten days. One of the first applications to be acted upon will be that of the City of New York for the erection of the Triborough Bridge, at a cost of $26,000,000.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Jose M. Ferrer Jr., who is passing the Summer with his mother at the Honeysuckles, her, home in the Shinnecock Hills, gave a large buffet supper there tonight.

The expectation that the United States Treasury will borrow upward of $1,000,000,000 on Sept. 15 through the sale of notes to run not more than five years and of short-term certificates of indebtedness rather than by the sale of long-term bonds is interpreted by specialists in United States Government securities to mean that the Treasury will take no chance of weakening the position of its outstanding long-term bonds.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Sept. 1. -- The body of Z. Smith Reynolds, who was fatally shot on July 6, was exhumed on Aug. 23 at midnight and an autopsy was performed by Dr. W. N. Dalton, Forsyth County Coroner, assisted by four Winston-Salem physicians and surgeons, it was learned tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- The stock markets were better today, with, profittaking less in evidence. Outstanding were British Government funds, which were in keen demand at rising prices. Textiles strengthened further, and rayons were active. Both Canadian Celanese and American Celanese were higher, as were British Celanese and Courtaulds.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Johnny Risko, the veteran Cleveland boxer, tonight won a twelve-round decision over King Levinsky of Chicago.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 1. -- The blockade of Sioux City and ineffective picketing at other places in Iowa, Nebraska and South Dakota continued today despite a nine-day truce in the farmers' holiday movement called last night by Milo Reno, national chairman.

This week a musical comedy opened on Broadway. Next week there will be a play for the new season. In another month it will be in full swing, and New Yorkers who stayed at home during the Summer or took their vacations in places far removed from the thickly set Summer theatres of New England will look eagerly for signs of good dramatic entertainment to come.

The greatest question of the time, Will Durant asserts in his book, "On the Meaning of Life," to be published today by Ray Long Richard R. Smith, is not communism versus individualism, not Europe versus America, not the East versus the West, but "whether men can bear to live without God."

Retirements, abolitions of positions and changes in positions were announced yesterday by the Central Vermont Railway. This followed similar adjustments made earlier in the week and continued yesterday by the Canadian National Railways, which control the Central Vermont.
The letter written by John J. Curtin to Mayor Walker, upon which the Mayor justified his resignation, follows:

President Hoover is seen a sure winner in the national election by Senator Moses or New Hampshire, who at present, however, concedes him a majority of only twenty-two electoral votes, placing his total at 288.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Late-inning rallies gave the Baltimore Orioles a 12-to-11 victory over Jersey City tonight. After Charles Perkins had held the Birds hitless for five innings he lost control and the Orioles landed on his three successors for three big innings and the game.
Although the local art season seldom shows much activity until late in September or early in October, there was a premonitory flutter yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- No great concern over the effects on the American export trade with Germany of that country's drastic upward revision of import duties to become effective Sept. 6 was evident in official circles today. On the basis of 1931 German trade statistics, it was calculated that not more than $4,000,000 of this country's annual exports were involved.

With the opening of offices in the Federal Reserve Bank Building at 33 Liberty Street and the election of John G. Peterson, vice president of the Chase National Bank, as manager of its two operating subsidiaries, the Commodities Finance Corporation, organized by New York banks to supplement existing credit facilities in financing the purchase, carrying and orderly marketing of raw materials, was ready yesterday to make its first loans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is unfortunate that there is so wide a misunderstanding of the sales tax, especially the manufacturers' sales tax, thrice rejected last Winter and Spring by the House of Representatives. This was a proposition to tax all manufacturers 2 1/2 per cent on their sales.

In an effort to avert a rate war in the intercoastal shipping field representatives of the fifteen principal intercoastal lines threshed out their problems until 2:30 A.M. yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria and finally settled enough of their difficulties to warrant the renewal for a six-month period of the United States Intercoastal Conference agreement, under which they have functioned during the last six months.
