WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Government employes and their families are prohibited from expressing publicly their views upon the soldiers' bonus, under new regulations promulgated by the Civil Service Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A brace of home runs in the sixth inning brought about the downfall of young Tommy Bridges today and gave the Athletics a 5-to-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers. The Athletics won the series, three games to two.

W. Irving Glover, Assistant Postmaster General, returned on the maiden round-trip voyage of the new United States liner Manhattan yesterday, hopeful for the future of the American merchant marine and pleased with the passenger and mail liners that have put to sea in the last few years under the guidance and aid of the United States Government.

When Cicero Did the Probing A reader of THE TIMES who knows his MARCUS TULLIUS CICERO has been struck by the fact that two thousand years ago investigators of public officials were confronted with much the same problems as they are today.

It was in the railway shares that Wall Street found an excuse to whip up its lagging optimism yesterday. There was a lively advance, late in the day, in such stocks as Santa Fe, Atlantic Coast Line, Kansas City Southern, Union Pacific, Southern Pacific, Louisville Nashville and Baltimore Ohio.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Government officials were surprised by Paris newspaper accounts of the "memorial" setting forth Germany's armament demands, supposed to have been handed to Andre Francois-Poincet, French Ambassador, by Foreign Minister von Neurath, first because the "demands" are said to be inaccurate and second because it had been agreed between the Foreign Minister and the Ambassador that nothing would be made public concerning the transactions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Broadcasters of the country have the right under the terms of the radio act to refuse the use of their radio stations to political candidates, but to adopt such a policy would be "shortsighted," Harold A. La Fount, acting chairman of the Radio Commission, said today in answer to inquiries from operators as to whether they should allow candidates to use their facilities.

CONWAY, N.H., Sept. 1 (AP). -- L. J. Comrie, superintendent of the Nautical Almanac, the Royal Naval College of London, England, said today that there were at least two general causes for the reported lateness of totality.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The second increase in the price of foods this year was decreed by the government today when ration stores heavily boosted the cost of meat, eggs, cheese and sour cream.

When the football teams of the Military and Naval Academies played a game for the relief of the unemployed at the end of the regular season of 1931, in spite of the eligibility controversy that had made a sort of armed truce between them, it was predicted that the old relations in competitive sports would be resumed.

VIENNA, Sept, 1. -- In a speech delivered today as a luncheon guest of the Vienna Anglo-American Press Association, Chancellor Dollfuss announced that Austria was fully prepared to live up to all her foreign obligations, was making preparations to abolish exchange restrictions soon and had asked her neighbors on the eve of the Stresa conference to negotiate concerning the conclusion of preferential treaties.

YORK, Pa., Sept. 1 (AP). -- An autopsy performed on the body of Jeffrey E. Rees, 27, of North Bergen, N.J., found beside the Lincoln Highway near here today with a bullet wound in the chest and one in the head, strengthened the belief of investigating officers that the man was murdered.

A reliquary containing fragments of the bones of three of the Jesuit martyrs of North America has arrived in this country from France and will be installed at a special ceremony at the Shrine of the Martyrs at Auriesville, N.Y., on Sept. 11.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1. -- Tom Creavy showed a St. Paul gallery today just why he was champion of American professional golf as the battle to dethrone him charged into the quarter-final salient.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- The Soviet press is filled with tirades against middlemen, or "speculators," as they are called here, with such headlines as, "No mercy for bloodsuckers," and, "Leniency and liberalism toward speculators is a crime against society."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 31, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,331,000,000, a decrease of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,107,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- Luncheons were given at their residences today by Mrs. Samuel P. Colt, Mrs. William Hayward, Mrs. Skirvin Adams, Mrs. Chartes R. Russell, Miss Julia Berwind and Mrs. Nathaniel Thayer.

More than six thousand week-end cruise passengers will sail today on eight ships bound for Canadian ports or Bermuda. The cruise ships are the Acadia, Belgenland, Berengaria, France, Georgic, Pan America, St. Louis and Transylvania. The Berengaria, France and Belgenland are all due today and will sail on cruises after a short stay in port.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Adolf Hitler reappeared here tonight, after an absence of two weeks, at a huge rally in the Sportpalast where he held a capacity audience spellbound with attacks on Chancellor von Papen's Cabinet, on Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Nationalist leader, and even on President von Hindenburg himself.
The 1932 football season opened here yesterday in a manner that indicates that New York's coaches plan to bring their charges into good physical condition without any waste of time.

Short-term time money softened fractionally to 1 to 1 1/4 per cent, the distant periods continuing at 1 1/4 to 1 1/2. The quotations were nominal, the little turnover that was reported going at the outside figure. No other changes were reported, Stock Exchange call loans, acceptances and commercial paper markets being quiet and steady in rate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- Another of Chicago's elevated railroads, the Northwestern, defaulted today on its first mortgage bonds. It has an issue of $12,708,000, but $3,129,000 is in its sinking fund. Thus the default was on the $9,579,000 outstanding.

Close competition for award yesterday of the new issue of $1,500,000 State of Maine 4 per cent highway and bridge bonds, enabled the State to borrow on approximately a 3.80 per cent basis. The award went to a syndicate composed of the First National Bank, New York, Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Darby Co. and Graham, Parsons Co., at a price of 102.199.

The feeling of resentment in Tammany against Governor Roosevelt because of the way in which he has handled the hearings on the charges against Mayor Walker seemed to be on the increase last night as it became known that Mayor Walker had resigned and that he would appeal for vindication by seeking reelection.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that beginning on Nov. 1 bonds that have matured would be removed from the list unless special circumstances warranted their retention. The new practice, it was said, would be followed because the public did not always realize that matured obligations might have lost some degree of negotiability.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The German demand for arms equality is regarded here as a continuation of a struggle Germany has made since the war to rid herself of what she considers unjust provisions of the Versailles Treaty, but not necessarily as pointing to an immediate break in the situation or the withdrawal of Germany from the General 'Disarmament Conference at Geneva.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The Brookmeade Stable of Mrs. Isabel Sloan scored a double today when her Dunlin colt Snap Back captured the featured Senator Kavanaugh Handicap and the converted jumped Pontentate was first in the Whitehall Purse.

WILLIAMS GROVE, Pa., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, declared in a speech today that President Hoover had preserved the United States from political and economic perils, social disorders and uncontrolled deflation.
James J. Walker resigned last night as Mayor of the City of New York.

BARROW-IN-FURNESS, England, Sept. 1. -- The new luxury liner Queen of Bermuda, 22,000 tons, built by the Vickers-Armstrong shipyard for the New York-to-Bermuda service of the Furness-Withy Company, was launched today by Lady Cubitt, wife of Sir Thomas Cubitt, Governor of Bermuda.

The Yankees almost went into a total eclipse of their own at the Stadium yesterday when Alvin Crowder, crack right-hander of the Senators, came within two put-outs of gaining the distinction of being the first pitcher to shut out the McCarthymen this year.

A committee of nine officials appointed for the purpose by the railroad managements will soon prepare thirty-day notices for a 20 per cent wage reduction to be served on the unions on or about Oct. 1, but will accompany the notice with an offer to arbitrate.
RHINEBECK, N.Y., Sept. 1.-- Governor Roosevelt was hailed today by the people of his home area as he made a visit to the Dutchess County Fair to watch his two sons ride in the horse show here.

The circumstances under which he became Mayor favored James J. Walker, as the election had shown the public was weary of the Hylan Administration. The choice of Mr. Walker by Tammany was popular, and its popularity grew as the nimble wit and engaging personality of the candidate carried him to victory on election day.

The Lexington Avenue Civic Association forwarded to the Board of Estimate yesterday a discussion of plans for a new bridge over the East River at Thirty-eighth Street in preference to an underwater tunnel at that point, and asked the board to appoint a committee of experts to decide whether a bridge or tunnel there would be more advantageous.

Fearing that the closing of the Lying-in and Hanhattan Maternity Hospitals, coincident with the opening yesterday of the new New York Hospital Medical Centre, might result in lack of sufficient accommodations for maternity cases on the east side of Manhattan, Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Hospital Commissioner, yesterday asked that the Manhattan Maternity Hospital be kept open, at least temporarily.

Standing firm on his plan for an "open" Republican State convention and confident that he can see it through, W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, declined yesterday to comment on the indications of coming factional strife growing out of the political tour de force by William L. Ward of Westchester in putting through an endorsement of Colonel William J. Donovan for the Republican nomination for Governor.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Springfield (Mass.) American Legion junior nine today defeated New Orleans, 5 to 1, in the third game of the East-West championship tournament.

The influence which national banknote circulation is beginning to have upon the position of the Federal Reserve Banks under the increased note-issuing privilege conferred by the Glass-Borah amendment to the Home Loan Bank bill was indicated in this week's Federal Reseve report.

The reactionary decline in stocks seemed yesterday to be checked. A few early declines were more than canceled before the closing and, although most of the day's net advances were only fractional, scattered recoveries of 1 to 3 points were fairly numerous.
The New York Cocoa Exchange membership of George Blum of Paris has been sold to Harold L. Bache, for another, at $2,500, an advance of $500 from the previous transaction, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Paraguay replied today to the suggestion at a thirty-day truce in the Chaco in an inconclusive note to the committee of neutrals, which left the door open to further negotiation. Bolivia made the original suggestion for a truce of that period and it was adopted by the committee of neutrals and submitted yesterday to Paraguay.

A police guard will be available for every drug store threatened by racketeers in Brooklyn, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County promised yesterday. He said he would ask Police Commissioner Mulrooney for 20,000 men, if necessary, to stamp out vandalism in the borough.
ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- Mayor Walker's resignation from office and his bitter attack upon Governor Roosevelt were received tonight at the Executive Mansion without comment or great surprise.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The eclipse excitement closed today in a mystery -- "What is the new thing in the sun that the Japanese saw?"

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company formally defaulted yesterday, as had been expected, on the payment of interest and principal on the $31,000,000 in ten-year 7 per cent secured notes. The default was for $51,672,100 as the principal and $1,108,423, the semiannual interest payment.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Kaye Don and Gar Wood, rival speed-boat pilots, today completed final tests on the two fastest craft in the world in preparation for the first heat of the Harmsworth Trophy race at 6:30 A. M. Saturday on Lake St. Clair.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Although finishing second in the 2:13 trot, Volo Yorke, Suffield (Conn.) gelding, established a new State record of 2:05 3/4 for trotters over a half-mile track in the second mile at the Flemington Fair today. Joe Watts took the final heat and race in 2:06 1/2.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 1. -- Loyalist forces occupied Quito at 7 o'clock tonight, according to a telegram from the Loyalist Minister of War at Rio Bamba, half way to the capital.

Paul Block, publisher, who testified at the removal hearings that he had neither sought nor expected favors from the city in return for his gift of $246,000 to Mayor Walker, will run an editorial today in his newspapers, setting forth his views on the Mayor's resignation.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Steel Helmet War Veterans' convention, which met here today with 150,000 delegates representing 1,000,000 war veterans, had the effect of stealing the spotlight from Adolf Hitler, National Socialist (Nazi) leader. He returned from a brief automobile ride to his quarters in the Kaiserhof Hotel and was surprised to find the place lined with men in gray uniforms closely resembling the outfits of the Reichswehr.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A decision by Secretary Mills on whether funds are available to carry out the public works program authorized in the relief act to stimulate employment is expected the latter part of this month.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 1. -- The American Walker Cup forces, led by Francis Ouimet, national amateur golf champion, made a clean sweep of the Scotch foursomes against the British team today, and the point score for the series at The Country Club now stands: United States 4, Great Britain 0.

The business Interests of New York Cilty must guard against "dangerous and foolish" legislation if the present bankruptcy system is to be protected from the "ghouls and harpies" who would befoul it. Federal Judge John. C. Knox declared yesterday in speaking before several hundred Rotary club members at a luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.

ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- Discussing the millions of dollars increase in expenditures by the State for educational purposes, Mark Graves, Director of the Budget, in a radio address tonight over WGY stated that the increase was due, not so much to strictly State-controlled activities as to contributions for local school purposes.

The New York State Merchant Marine Academy is proceeding with its plans for a shore base at Throgs Neck, former site of Fort Schuyler, in the Bronx, it was announced yesterday when the school training ship Empire State arrived at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn after a ninety-two-day cruise in American and foreign waters.

A four-alarm fire, caused by the explosion of an oil heater, destroyed the La Cour Ironworks at Van Pelt Street and Borden Avenue, Long Island City, and burned fifteen feet from the top of the 100-foot steeple of St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church at Borden and Greenpoint Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading of "Safeguarding Warwick Boys," THE TIMES of Aug. 21 prints a letter by E.C. Kemp of Cornell University which brings up several interesting points. Mr. Kemp is concerned for one thing with the fact that boys "who are to be transferred to Warwick are first to spend two weeks in a clinic."

William C. Walsh and Eugene Birne, employes of the Public Welfare Department, said yesterday they had been reduced from six days' work to two days after bringing charges of discrimination, incompetence and ineligibility in the department before the Board of Estimate at last Wednesday's meeting.

George Schilling, a city employe for the last eighteen years and now secretary to David Lazarus, Commissioner of Records in the Surrogates' Court, was held in $10,000 bail in Yorkville Court yesterday charged with complicity in a conspiracy with Charles Schumann to arrange for the robbery of the latter's jewelry establishment on July 19.

Samuel Seabury, whose investigation has resulted in the resignation of Mayor Walker, was exploring quaint London bookstalls on Aug. 25, 1930, in search of rare first editions on political economy, when the call came to him by cable to explore the jungle of the magistrates courts in New York as referee for the Appellate Division.
PARIS, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Grand opera in New York appears kely to "break even" financially during the coming season, and the prospect is highly encouraging in view of last year's experiences and the fact that some large cities have been forced to abandon, their programs entirely, Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Company, announced yesterday.

William E. Von Glehn, 35 years old, for nearly twelve years the head bookkeeper of the Fourteenth Street branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, which up to February was a branch of the Chatham Phenix Bank and Trust Company, was arrested on a larceny charge yesterday when he admitted to officials, according to the District Attorney's office, that in the last ten years he had stolen about $87,000 of the branch's funds.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Miss Betty Pietsch of the Tamarack Country Club scored an 81 to capture the low gross honors in the Women's West-chester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day handicap golf tournament today at the Rye Country Club. Miss Pietsch played the first nine holes in 42 and the inward route in 39 to finish 4 above women's par.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 1. -- Lieut. Commander John L. Hall, graduate manager of athletics at the Naval Academy, and Major Philip B. Fleming, who holds a similar position at the Military Academy, will meet with Dr. Mercer, director of athletics at the University of Pennsylvania, as soon as the latter returns from a vacation, and will settle details connected with the use of Franklin Field for the Army-Navy football game on Dec. 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The resignation of Hanford MacNider as Minister to Canada was announced today at the White House.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Playdale, from the French Lick Springs Stable, scored an easy triumph in the Woodlands Purse, Hawthorne's best event today.

The "share-the-work movement" conceived at a conference of President Hoover with business leaders in Washington last Friday to lessen unemployment throughout the country was definitely started yesterday with the opening of national headquarters in the Federal Reserve Bank Building at 33 Liberty Street.

MARION, Mass., Sept. 1. -- The Eastern Yacht Club junior crew, consisting of Captain Chandler Hovey Jr., Albert Goodhue Jr. and George Poor, today won the national junior sailing championship and the famous Sears Bowl.

In the most sensational market since the closing months of 1929, stocks made in August the biggest advance in three years. Embracing all groups, the market forged ahead to a new high point for the recovery, which started early in July. Except for two minor reactions, the rise was uninterrupted throughout the month.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange rallied moderately yesterday under the leadership of railroad issues, which reversed their trend of the last few days. Quite a representative list of rail bonds was marked up 1 to more than 5 points.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2. -- Twenty-six players opposed Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, world's champion, in an exhibition of simultaneous chess play held under the auspices of the Los Angeles A.C. at its club-house last night.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2. -- The food shortage hit foreigners in the Soviet Union today when the "closed stores" which supply foreign technicians and correspondents announced that individual rations were limited to a half pound of meat daily, two pounds of bread, one ounce of butter and three ounces each of fish, sugar and flour, and other equivalent restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- New excise and stamp taxes increased the government's income by $10,716,000 in August, a total of $54,557,746 having been collected from miscellaneous internal revenue during the month on the basis of July business, as compared with $43,861,681 in the corresponding period last year, the Treasury announced today.

The Far Eastern Steamship Conference, consisting of ten leading ship lines operating to Far Eastern ports from New York and other ports on the North Atlantic, announced yesterday a new rate policy, to be effective immediately, which is designed to attract a larger share of freight traffic to the conference ships.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Captain Fraiche's single in the tenth gave New Orleans a 5-to-3 victory over Springfield, Mass., today and the American Legion junior baseball championship.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Averell Harriman gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Earl E.T. Smith, who are staying at the St. Regis.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Sept. 2. -- Cutting away from their powerful parent body, delegates claiming to represent 75 per cent of the coal miners of Illinois and Indiana decided at Gillespie, Ill., today to divorce themselves from the United Mine Workers of America and form a new union.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Many colonists and their guests attended the second and last in the series of operatic performances by artists of the Metropolitan Opera which took place tonight at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.

A second trust-fund suit against Irving T. Bush, chairman of the Bush Terminal Company, in behalf of his daughters, Beatrice B.B. Bissell and Eleanor T. Bush Allen, both of California, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday, on the ground that Mr. Bush is attempting to revoke a trust fund created for his daughters last May.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- Germany's request for equality in armaments has had a somewhat different effect from that which perhaps was anticipated by the Reich Government. It has opened a wide diplomatic discussion directly among the principal Foreign Ministers of the world on future disarmament prospects.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Athletics had little trouble winning both ends of a double-header from Boston today, the first game, 7 to 3, and the second, 15 to 0.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Pirates bunched hits in the first and seventh innings today and, with Larry French pitching another fine game, shaded the Reds, 2 to 1. It was Pittsburgh's sixth straight victory.

With a final statement denouncing Mayor Walker's resignation as the act of a man who had no other recourse, Samuel Seabury yesterday laid down the case which has occupied most of his time since early this year, and sailed for Europe on the French liner Paris.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- The chief reason why the French and Americans were unable to reach an accord yesterday on a commercial treaty is the rigidity of the United States tariff system, a communique from the Ministry of Commerce intimated today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Benny Leonard easily outpointed Phil Rafferty of the west side in the main bout of six rounds at the Long Beach Stadium before a crowd of more than 2,000 tonight. Leonard weighed 151 1/2 and Rafferty 146 1/2.

Fire firemen and seven passers-by were injured shortly after 10 o'clock last night when an explosion on the tenth floor of a fifteen-story building at 39 West Thirty-second Street shattered most of the windows in the building and sent bits of glass and metal window sash flying as far as fifty feet.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 2. -- Chino-Japanese tension grew more grave tonight when 700 Chinese almost clashed with a detachment of Japanese marines at the most important street intersection on the Bund in the International Settlement here.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press). -- After an uphill fight the Players defeated the Gentlemen today by 47 runs. Behind 83 runs on the first innings, the professional cricketers compiled 370 in their second venture at the wickets, the innings beinf featured by Worthington's 129 runs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Loans to Utah and Idaho totaling $690,000 for emergency relief were authorized today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and brought to $17,906,746 the amount of advances for this purpose to States and municipalities.

YORK, England, Sept. 2. -- The "nearest thing to perpetual motion" was described today before the British Association for the Advancement ot Science during a discussion on the superconductivity of metals. This phenomenon -- one of the most wonderful in modern physics -- is the result of inducing electric current in metals at extremely low temperatures.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Sweet Chariot, the black son of Black Servant and Song Bird, captured the second half of the Consolation Claiming Stakes, feature to-day, giving the Sagamore Stable of Mrs. Charles Minot Amory its third score in the event.

PRAGUE, Sept. 2. -- The newspaper Ceske Slovo publishes a report today that Prince Louis Windischgraetz named three Ministers of the present Hungarian Government and a number of other prominent persons, including former Premier Bethlen, as immediatley involved in the Hungarian franc forgery case.
The Treasury Department became 143 years old yesterday and its anniversary was celebrated here and in Washington with a program arranged by the George Washington Bicentennial Commission.

The prospect that James J. Walker's candidacy for Mayor this Fall will cause a Democratic feud even greater than those which existed when Samuel J. Tilden and Grover Cleveland were running for President has made it doubtful that Governor Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, can carry New York State, with the result that he may lose the Presidency entirely on the Walker issue unless something can be done to bring Tammany to his support.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2. -- The Federal Government has been almost uniformly victorious on all fronts in combating the Sao Paulo revolt, according to a resume published today at the beginning of the eighth week of the rebellion.

The general exodus from the city for the holiday week-end will find many members of society participating in entertainments and sports events arranged at fashionable beach clubs on the North and South Shores of Long Island. At the Atlantic Beach Club, Atlantic Beach, the proceeds from the various diversions will be turned over to the Actors' Dinner Club, which at this time is greatly in need of funds.

An alleged speakeasy atop a seventeen-story apartment house on the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, where customers enjoyed cool breezes and a superior view of Manhattan, was raided late Thursday night by agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, it was revealed yesterday when three prisoners were arraigned before United States Commissioner Cotter.

A picture of conditions in the South far different from that to which romantic Writers have accustomed their readers is given by Paul Green in a note to his novel, "The Laughing Pioneer," recently published by Robert M. McBride Co.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The United States does not intend to become involved in the discussions between Germany and France over the German plea for arms equality other than to stand as always, as its opinion may be asked, for disarmament as a general proposition, quite apart from the terms of the Versailies Treaty.

The fact that Robert Jackson, secretary of the Democratic National Committee and head of its speakers' bureau, has been susd for $353,857 alleged to have been withheld fraudulently from the funds of the Accumulative Royalties Corporation, of which he was secretary and treasurer in 1928 and 1929, became known yesterday when an application in his behalf was made to Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler for an extension of time to prepare a formal answer.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As a member of the Spanish, nobility, I feel it is my duty to comment frankly on what THE TIMES correspondent in Madrid says in his article of Sunday, Aug. 28.

To Wall Street the broad advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday seemed to be another of a lengthening series of upswings based upon the belief that trade and industry will begin to show improvement after Labor Day. The day's comment indicated clearly that such an inference was being drawn.

Takings of raw silk by domestic mills in August were the largest on record for any month, with the exception of October, 1930, and showed a 29-per cent increase over the same month of 1931, according to figures issued yesterday by the Silk Association of America.

Prices moved forward yesterday in all sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange in trading which amounted to more than $12,000,000. Railroad issues led the advance. Domestic industrial and utility issues pushed higher, while in foreign loans the improvement was less marked.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Repeal of all import prohibitions in effect since April 4, 1930, has been ordered by the Australian Government, and sharp reductions in duties, some as much as one-third under existing levies, have been made on a wide field of commodities in many of which the United States is interested, the Commerce Department was informed today.

Of the total of $19,107,699 of new State and municipal bonds listed for award next week, $11,500,000 will represent the requirements of the State of Mississippi for deficit, refunding and hospital purposes. Whether the State will receive a bid for the entire amount is considered problematical, although the interest rate may be named by the bidders as high as 6 per cent.

Some 150 unpublished letters by Henry James, dealing with his interest in the theatre, are to be included in "Theatre and Friendship: Some Henry James Letters," to be issued this month by G.P. Putnam's Sons, with a commentary by Elizabeth Robins.

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, CLEVELAND, Sept. 2. -- As they rounded the turn before the grand stands, two contestants in an event in the National Air Races today locked wings and crashed. Their planes fell thirty feet to the airport like a single crippled bird, still locked.

A formal demand is to be made upon Patrick J. Commerford, deposed supervisor of Local 125 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, to pay $6,600 to Jacob Fanken as receiver for the union, it was decided at accounting proceedings yesterday before Referee Carroll Hayes at 39 Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- With the signing of a new national labor agreement between the Full Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers Association and the Hosiery Workers Federation, nearly fifty plants are starting up on full day and night schedules, re-employing some 5,000 workers in various parts of the country, Emil Rieve, president of the union, stated today.

Veteran Campers in Riverside Park. In a humane and sensible ruling the Park Department announces that the B.E.F. squatters on the Hudson River toward the lower end of Riverside Park may remain in their shacks, subject to good behavior -- like Federal judges and other public officials.

Hubert Prior Vallee, better known as Rudy Vallee, and his wife, the former Fay Webb, signed a formal separation agreement late Thursday night and Mrs. Vallee left the city yesterday afternoon on the Twentieth Century Limited for an undisclosed destination with her father and mother.

Returning yesterday from several weeks' stay in Europe, former Supreme Court Justice Daniel J. Kenefick of Buffalo, who has been urged by his friends as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, predicted that Governor Roosevelt would lose his own State in the election and that the Walker episode would be a factor in the loss.
BERLIN, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2. -- Charlie Chaplin, who has made millions in the movies, today won his legal battle to keep his two sons, Charles Jr., 7 years old, and Sydney Earl, 6, off the screen. He successfully moved to restrain his former wife, Mrs. Lita Grey Chaplin, from fulfilling a contract with Fox Films, to feature the two boys.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 2 (AP). -- More intensive picketing of highways into Sioux City was ordered late today by Woodbury County leaders of the farmers' non-selling "strike," which is now confined to the territory around Sioux City in Iowa, Nebreska and South Dakota, involving five counties.
LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The Tibetan Government's permission for a Mount Everest expedition was unexpected.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 2. -- An issue of $500,000 of 6 per cent tax-anticipation bonds, payable on Dec. 22 next, was authorized today by the Board of Freeholders. The bonds have been purchased by banks in the county. The resolution sets forth that $1,571,964 in taxes will be due this year.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Beau Geste, the Great Notch, N.J., gelding, had to go in 2:11 1/2 to win the 2:19 trot at the Flemington Fair races today, followed closely by First Hanover in the first two heats. First Hanover led the field in the final heat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- With the home run boys, Kiki Cuyler and Mark Koenig, setting the pace, the Cubs defeated the Cardinals, 8 to 5, today for their thirteenth consecutive triumph and retained their seven and one-half game lead over Pittsburgh.

MONTREAL, Sept. 2. -- The longstanding hockey feud between the National and American leagues came to an end tonight with the American league resuming its minor league status and becoming subject once more to the N.H.L.'s player draft.

The Committee of One Thousand and James E. Finegan of Brooklyn, two of the sponsors of charges against James J. Walker, apparently were agreed yesterday that an election in November would be legal, while the City Affairs Committee, whose charges against the Mayor had been dismissed by Governor Roosevelt more than a year ago, welcomed the "attempt of Walker to vindicate himself at the polls."
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 2. -- Ed Dudley went into the semi-finals of the national professional golf championship today with a stirring effort that easily featured the day's play.

Legislation to rectify abuses growing out of the State law giving preference to disabled veterans in appointments and promotions will be sought by the Civil Service Reform Association, it was announced yesterday.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Three American service fliers today revealed how they jumped from their plane in the darkness of a jungle storm and then, due to a tenacious search by fellow marines, two of whom lost their lives in the quest, finally reached safety.

The monthly index of commodity prices compiled by Bradstreet's shows an average advance of 5% per cent during August, comparing with the rise of 4% per cent computed by Dun. Bradstreet's adds that this is the third consecutive rise in the monthly index and is the largest percentage increase that has occurred in any month since July, 1925.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Sept. 2 (AP). -- No arrangements have been made at the Mayo clinic here for a visit of President Pascual Ortiz Rubio of Mexico, it was said at the clinic tonight.

ALBANY, Sept. 2. -- Deeply stirred by the threat of defeat in New York State through the situation caused by Mayor Walker's resignation, Governor Roosevelt turned from the hearings today and mapped final plans for his Presidential drive.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The Saratoga Association's meeting will come to an end tomorrow with the Hopeful Stakes, $40,000 guaranteed, one of the richest races of the year, and the Saratoga Cup, one of the country's distance classics, as the features.

TOKYO, Sept. 2. -- Japan's rights of interposition in Manchukuo's affairs under the treaty to be signed soon will be less onerous, a spokesman of the Foreign Office stated today, than those involved in the United States agreements with Cuba and Panama.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 2. -- Franklin W. Fort, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, urged delegates to the convention of the United States Building and Loan League here today to do their best to help make a success of the new system.

The problem which Mr. TEAGLE and his committee have set out to solve is one in long division. It is to increase the " divisor" by one million and yet with the present "dividend" find a "quotient" in work that will provide a livelihood for the greater number.

Twenty-five of the best-known contract-bridge players will convene this afternoon at the Deal Club in Elberon, N.J., for a three-day tournament to decide individual master's contract bridge championship for the coming year. To the winner who makes the most of his good cards and the best of his bad ones over 150 hands played round robin against all the other contestants the Willard S. Karn Gold Cup will be awarded for the coming year.
Joseph V. McKee moved through his first trying day as Mayor with a modest and self-effacing attitude that reflected itself in everything he did.

The albacore, Which gives fishermen plenty of excitement and, when he is running well, supplies plenty of food, has made its appearance off Fire Island Inlet within the past few days. Fishing for them off shore has provided plenty of sport and plenty of fish, according to Captain F.R. Merritt, who reports the first ample catches of this fish.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 2. -- The opening of the twenty-fourth annual Pittsfield Country Club tennis tournament today for the county championships attracted many of the best Berkshire players. Miss Helen Rice is defending her title as winner in women's singles last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- President Hoover personally ordered reinstatement to the postal service today of Ben H. Kerr, clerk at Gary, Ind., recently dismissed on charges of "repeated delinquencies," one being that he had introduced a bonus resolution at an American Legion post meeting "contrary to the expressed wishes of the President."

Following four days of heavy profittaking, which had carried prices Lack more than 1 1/4 cents a pound from the high levels of Monday, the market on the Cotton Exchange turned abruptly yesterday and recovered about $3 a bale. So much long cotton had been liquidated in the reaction that fewer contracts were available when the upturn developed, and the list closed 43 to 47 points higher than on Thursday.

HAMILTON, Ont., Sept. 2 (Canadian Press). -- "Astoundingly successful" results rewarded a group of scientists who studied the eclipse at Action Vale, Que., it was announced here today. After working unceasingly for many hours on the combined computations of their totality eclipse data, the results were announced as "far beyond expectations."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Mayor Walker's resignation was accepted by Republican leaders here as productive of a schism in the Democratic party assuring, in their opinion, the carrying of the State by President Hoover in November. This was the view expressed privately by Republicans close to the administration who for weeks have been asserting that Republicans would carry the State in the Presidential contest.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 2. -- Recent dispatches said that the Hutchinson family intended to fly over Greenland and Iceland en route to Scotland. George R. Hutchinson some time ago applied to the Danish Government for permission to fly over Greenland, but the government refused, as relief work on the inland ice is almost impossible.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Mrs. Joseph V. McKee, wife of the new Mayor of New York, marked the promotion of her husband today by going shopping in Mamaroneck.

DETROIT, Sept. 2. -- Gar Wood with his Miss America X and Kaye Don with Lord Wakefield's Miss England III are set for their first race tomorrow in the eighteenth staging of the competition for the Harmsworth Trophy, emblematic of world's speed boat supremacy.

Two thugs were shot dead and two policemen, a bystander and a third robber were wounded when police interrupted a hold-up of a pawnshop at 537 Court Street, Brooklyn, shortly before noon yesterday. Patrolman Peter De Carlo lies near death in the Holy Family Hospital, his body paralyzed by a bullet which lodged in his spinal cord.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Rumors that excited the grain market were in circulation today on the Board of Trade here, and heavy buying by houses with New York connections in the last few minutes of trading advanced prices sharply, making the close within a fraction of the top at net gains of 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel.

Whether the city will seek to intervene in the equity receivership proceedings now pending against the Interborough Rapid Transit Company will depend on a report to be made to Mayor McKee and the Board of Estimate next Tuesday by Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly, who was ordered yesterday by Mayor McKee to take "aggressive action" to protect the city's interests.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Unorganized dairymen in the New York milk shed will be asked again to unite under the banner of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., in an effort to control the surplus milk supply and stabilize the market.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 (AP). -- George Blaeholder had the better of it in a pitchers' duel with Ted Lyons today, and while each of them allowed eight safeties, the St. Louis Browns made their hits count to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 1, in the series opener.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- The Bourse rallied today after the irregular session yesterday, and the majority of the losses were more than canceled. Trading was active throughout, with some stocks which yesterday were most attacked, again well demanded.

Dennis J. Mahon, who has served on occasion in the last few months as Acting Mayor and Acting Aldermanic President when not in his own post as vice chairman of the Board of Aldermen, became the real Aldermanic President yesterday with a salary increase from $7,500 to $25,000 a year.

Want of coordination is the last thing one would have expected of Republicans. It is a basic policy of the Administration. Can it be absent from the managers and actors of the Republican show? Everybody seems to be spouting on his own hook.

The united front achieved last year by the transportation companies in the matter of railway wages has been reconstituted for the purpose of seeking further action. A committee of nine officials has been appointed to represent carriers in all sections of the country.
PASADENA, Cal., Sept. 2. -- With air forces of two nations at their command, Dr. Robert A. Millikan and two assistants set out last night on an 8,000-mile cosmic-ray-search expedition.
Editorial comment on Mayor Walker's resignation in the newspapers of New York and other cities follows:

Governor ROOSEVELT acted with great dignity and, we believe, with good political judgment when he received Mayor WALKER'S resignation without comment. Why should he answer Mr. WALKER'S virulent and hysterical attack upon him for the manner in which he has conducted the hearing at Albany? The thing speaks for itself.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- Representatives of American companies marketing office equipment in Germany conferred today with officials of the Ministry of Economics on the effects of the newly decreed tariffs on typewriters, adding machines and cash registers, which are hit hardest by the new duties.

Sharp advances in stocks, bonds and commodities yesterday were interpreted in Wall Street as a reflection of the widely prevalent belief that definite improvement in trade and industry will set in after Labor Day.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- Comment here on James J. Walker's resignation testifies to the impression he made on the popular imagination on his two visits to Berlin in 1927 and 1931 as an unconventional "Lord Mayor" of the American metropolis. The Vossische Zeitung runs nearly two columns captioned "Jimmy," in which it dwells on his "charm, elegance, ready humor, pointed wit, gayety and optimism."

KINGSTON, R.I., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Ernest Lee Jahncke declared today that the American people could judge by Speaker Garner's record in the House what might happen if the Democratic party gained control of the Executive as well as the legislative branch of the government.

The second large realty sale to be made in Jersey City within the past month was recorded yesterday when Samuel and Morris Meltzer sold to Corbin Apartments, Inc., of 539 Broadway, Bayonne, the five fourstory brick apartment houses on a plot 225 by 100 feet at 122-36 Corbin Avenue, near Pavonia Avenue, a short distance from Journal Square.
The money market was quiet and featureless. Business was at a minimum, at quotations which showed no variation from those which have been standing for some time.

Republicans in this city generally were in a happy frame of mind yesterday when they contemplated the effect of the resignation of Mayor Walker in the camp of their Democratic opponents. But such party leaders as were in the city, from Chairman W. Kingsland Macy of the Republican State Committee down, refrained from comment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- President Hoover today proclaimed the week of Oct. 9 as National Fire Prevention Week, urging that it be made an occasion of special note this year on account of the "deplorable" loss of life and property due to fires.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 2. -- Appeal to American and Canadian organists to lead the way in the establishment of new high standards of organ building was voiced today by Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City at the concluding sessions of the convention of the National Association of Organists and Canadian College of Organists.

Yesterday was the hottest day of the year and the hottest Sept. 2 in the forty-six-year history of the New York Weather Bureau. The mercury stood at 92 degrees at 3:20 P.M., and with the city sweltering in a sullen, leaden, moisture-laden ground haze the day set a record for discomfort as well as temperature.

Performing in a manner that would have reflected credit upon the uncanny powers of the late Houdini, the Yankees squirmed out of another shutout at the Stadium yesterday to equal the all-time major league record of 132 consecutive championship games played in a season without once being held scoreless.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 2. -- With its four junior members coming through in fine shape, the American team retained the Walker Cup today at The Country Club, the final point score of the 1932 matches being 8 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the last few days several members of the bar have used this forum to express their grievance against the present jury practices in our courts. The general assertion is that there are too many jury trials and that consequently it takes too long for a trial to get under way.

Heavy engineering contracts for the week ended Aug. 29 totaled 518,056,000, an increase of $1,300,000 over the previous week and a gain of more than $3,000,000 over the figures for two weeks ago, according to figures compiled by The Engineering News-Record.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Leaders of some agricultural organizations are critical of the new Federal program under which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will make loans to farmers and cooperatives on a strictly financial basis.

THE firing will start at Forest Hills today but Ellsworth Vines and Henri Cochet will not swing into action until Monday. The ranking players are giving some of the lesser lights a head start, so to speak. Still, the general-belief is that those who start later will last longer, especially in this hot weather.
Play starts today on the famous stretch of International Field at the Meadow Brook Club in the climax event of the polo season, the national open championship.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The acting Cabinet of Prussia, with Chancellor von Papen as Federal Commissioner presiding, today commuted to life imprisonment the death sentences of the five Nazis at Beuthen who were convicted of "political homicide" in beating and kicking to death a Communist in the presence of his mother.

A group of about thirty persons joined in a boisterous demonstration yesterday in Harlem court when Magistrate Aurielo sentenced Mrs. Eleanor Henderson, wife of a Columbia University instructor in economics, to ten days in the workhouse, and Samuel Brown, a Negro, to serve six months, for their alleged part in a disturbance at the Home Relief Bureau in Public School 39, 235 East 125th Street.

Fall Selling Gains Headway. Interest in Fall merchandise gained during the week, retailers here reported yesterday. The high temperature which obtained on several days served to militate against the purchases of coats, but a good demand for dresses was noted.

The New York Stock Exchange suspended yesterday dealings in the stock of the Crex Carpet Company on the ground that "certain unusual transactions" in the shares had been disclosed by an investigation made by the committee on business conduct. It was said that the State Attorney General had requested information concerning transactions in the issue and that this had been given to him.
Columbia's football team went through rooming and afternoon workouts yesterday at Baker Field, but the tempo was slowed because of the heat.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 2. -- Action believed to herald a combined Japanese-Manchukuo military attack on Jehol Province, west of Manchuria, was taken today when Manchukuo's Foreign Minister, Hsieh Chieh-Hsi, dispatched to Nanking a warning of the intention of the Manchukuo Government to adopt "appropriate measures to clear Jehol of outlaw elements."

Although City Clerk Michael J. Cruise certified to the Board of Elections yesterday that there was a vacancy in the office of Mayor, to be voted on at the November election, it appeared certain that the courts would be called upon to decide whether Joseph V. McKee is Mayor for the rest of the year or for the remaining part of the term vacated by James J. Walker.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 2. -- An assertion that the disputed Chaco region is controlled by foreign enterprise and that the Paraguayans would rather fight them than Bolivia is contained in a statement published here and attributed to Paraguayan workmen.

With the strongest international field to gather here since 1927 in the lists, along with eighteen of the twenty ranking players of the United States, the men's national tennis championship will start at 1:30 this afternoon at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.
A 23-year-old chauffeur was mysteriously shot dead last night, about 250 feet from the residence of former Mayor Walker, by three assailants in an automobile, who escaped.

Member of German-American Himalayan Expedition. Copyright, 1932, by N.A.N.A., Inc. BASE CAMP, NANGA PARBAT, Kashmir, Aug. 28 (By runner to Astor, Sept. 2). -- Today, at last, Willy Merky, Rand Herron and Fritz Wiessner set out for a final push to conquer Nanga Parbat.

"Labor Sunday" will be observed in the churches tomorrow. Many pastors will discuss means of helping unemployment. Two "labor" services will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by arrangement of Bishop William T. Manning. At the 11 o'clock service the preacher will be the Rev. Dr. Floyd Van Keuren, who succeeded Bishop Charles K. Gilbert as secretary of the Social Service Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Renewed indications of the sharp decline in trade between the United States and Soviet Russia were given today in Russia's foreign trade figures for the first five months of 1932, which showed that purchases in America had dropped to 16,678,000 rubles from 131,504,000 in the corresponding period a year ago.
LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The current issue of The Economist, whose editor is Sir Walter Layton, reiterates its recent assertion that the United States has passed its crisis.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2. -- The 1,750,000 railroad workers of the United States will fight with every resource a proposed 20 per cent wage reduction, according to labor leaders here who have canvassed the sentiment of the twenty-one unions comprising the Railway Labor Executives' Association.

Edward Corsi, United States Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, who has been studying labor conditions in Italy, is to return today on the Italian motorship Vulcania, accompanied by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore Cotello. Others returning on the ship from Mediterranean ports include:

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- Bonds continued to advance at today's session of the Boerse, the average gains exceding those of yesterday. Many issues advanced 3 per cent and more partly because the offerings were not sufficient for the demand. Mortgage and municipal bonds and certain Reich issues were the centre of interest.

No evidence of "discrimination or favoritism of any kind" in the city's unemployment relief work was found by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration in a report made public yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the administration.

Increased buying confidence is stimulating activity in industry and trade, according to the weekly reviews of business. Factories are reopening in many places, although for the most part the improvement has not yet been felt in the heavy industries.

A new plan for the reorganization of the company which owns the Squibb Building at 745 Fifth Avenue, for the erection of which S.W. Straus Co. issued and sold about $4,500,000 in leasehold bonds, has been worked out through the General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders, of which Samuel Seabury is chief counsel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is my opinion that the high character and the true devotion exemplified in Senator Wagner's tenure of office, particularly during the past year or so, have not been given sufficient public recognition.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2. -- One of the most artistic entertainments given here this Summer took place in the Casino Theatre tonight for the benefit of the Newport Country League for Animals.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Gallant Sir of the North-way Stable, outsider in a four-horse field, raced to a surprise victory in the Sprint Championship Stakes, feature of Hawthorne's closing program today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Rochester advanced to within half a game of the first division again today by beating the Montreal Royals, 3 to 2.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 2. -- In the feature match of the semi-final round of play for the Isham Cup at the Ekwanok Country Club today, A.L. Walker Jr., of Richmond County, played par golf to defeat H. Law Weatherwax of Albany, 4 and 3.

EAGLE PASS, Texas, Sept. 2 (AP). -- About 1,000 residents of Eagle Pass and perhaps 12,000 to 16,000 from the Mexican city of Piedras Negras were driven from their homes today as the Rio Grande and other streams in Southwest Texas went on a rampage.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The German Government, through its Ambassador to Washington, it is announced here tonight, is about to apply to the American Government to permit it to postpone for two and a half years the payments due under the mixed claims award and for repayment of the cost of the American army of occupation.

Five young men from New Jersey, including a youth who told the police he was the son of Chief of Police Thomas J. Wolfe of Jersey City, came to New York yesterday afternoon to find romance -- and visit a burlesque show. They saw part of the burlesque show, brought seven police radio cars and the gun squad to West Forty-second Street and were instrumental in delaying traffic for twenty minutes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Part of the famous collection of jewels of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormlck has been found in her safety deposit box, Eugene Holland of the State Treasurer's office revealed today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Speaker John N. Garner, Democratic nominee for Vice President, is being accused by the Republican National Committee of having been friendly to the importation of Mexican peon labor to compete with American labor.

Amid the enthusiastic cheers of 50,000 spectators, most of them typical representatives of the city's youth, the Junior Police Athletic League's first season was brought up a triumphant and successful close at the Polo Grounds yesterday. A team of All Stars, recruited from the ranks of the 5,000 boys who played baseball this Summer under the league's supervision, defeated the St. Mary's Industrial School nine of Baltimore, 9 to 4.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Hohenzollern princes and miltary leaders of the old imperial regime received a tumultuous welcome tonight at a meeting of 20,000 members of the Steel Helmet (war veterans') organization in the Sportpalast. The gigantic hall was decorated with the imperial black, white and red, without one republican banner.

LINDEN, N.J., Sept. 2. -- One person was killed and eleven injured in an automobile accident involving six cars on the State highway here today near the entrance to the Linden Crematorium. The police said that the accident had resulted from a "pile up" of traffic, caused when an automobile driven by Angelo Giordano of 824 Hunterdon Street, Newark, pulled out of line.

Whether the President of the Board of Aldermen, Mr. JOSEPH V. McKEE, who now becomes by law Mayor of New York, is to serve out the full unexpired term of Mayor WALKER, lawyers disagree. Probably the question will be taken into the courts.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The stock markets finished the week cheerful and active. British Government funds were not as firm as they were yesterday and prices occasionally were lower, due to some profit-taking, but the tone generally was good.

All the important markets advanced yesterday. The rise in stock prices was broad and aggressive, net gains in the more active issues running from 1 to 5 points. Dealings on the Stock Exchange amounted to 3,487,000 shares, or nearly 1,000,000 more than on the previous day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- A plot to extort $20,000 from Mrs. Robert Ludlow Fowler Jr., prominent socially in New York City and Boston, was disclosed here today at the hearing in city court of Frank Beattie, 22 years old, who said he lived at 719 East 233d Street, the Bronx.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Eight men employed in the division of water resources of the State Policy Commission, whose salaries total $42,680, were ordered dropped from the State's payroll on Sept. 15 by Governor A. Harry Moore in a letter he sent today to State Treasurer Arthur Middleton and State Controller John McCutcheon.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Fifteen cruising auxiliaries are ready to start at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow in the eighth annual race to Cornfield Lightship and return across Long Island Sound. The distance is about 100 miles and the boats must finish on Sunday to be within the time limit.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 17 -- Marshal Feng Yu-hslang, erstwhile "Christian General," who is now in retirement on Taishan, the Chinese sacred mountain in Shantung Province, has issued a public statement declaring that, though he pleaded illness as his reason for not meeting the League of Nations Commission, he was not ill, but merely ashamed to greet the delegates of Geneva who ars investigating the Sino-Japanese controversy over Manchuria.
One hundred new-born fish floated indolently in twelve inches of limpid green water at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 19 -- Despite the tightening of parly lines as the time draws nearer for the mid-September elections to the Second Chamber of the Swedish Riksdag, the present campaign offers fresh evidence of the fact that there is no clear-cut, dominating political majority in control of administrative problems.

The pairings and starting times for the qualifying round in the national amateur championship, to be played at the Five Farms course of the Baltimore Country Club on Monday and Tuesday, Sept. 12 and 13, have been announced by the United States Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The hum of sewing machines, reminiscent of war days, will begin throughout the country on Tuesday, when volunteer women workers set about the task of sewing cotton cloth into wearing apparel for the destitute under the direction of the Red Cross.

IN the situation created by international debts growing out of the World War, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler finds a parallel to that following the American Revolution, but with debtor and creditor positions geographically reversed. In an address delivered recently before the American Club of Paris, he cited American authority for what he believes to be the lesson.

EDMONTON, Alta., Aug. 27 -- A new party, known as the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation, with members in Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, was formed this month at a meeting in Calgary, and has been making clear its position as the most radical political force to appear in Canadian politics.

The United States Shipping Board has voted to surrender the marine documents of 124 government-owned vessels as a means of removing them from the market and increasing the value of privately owned tonnage. The vessels will be disposed of only as scrap, and steps will be taken soon to have them scrapped, the board announced.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Scoring six runs in the first inning, the Chicago White Sox pounded four pitchers for nineteen hits to defeat the St. Louis Browns, 13 to 8, today and even the series.

Political parties and candidates are still keeping up an agitation about the war debts. Just think, they say, about the loss of $250,000,000 a year to the United States Treasury on that account! But if they had looked at the rise in the value of stocks during August, they would nave seen that an addition to the property of the holders was made in a single month to the amount of $4,000,- 000,000.

OUT of the West come reports of farm strikes, of farmers' unions organized to prevent traffic in farm products until higher prices have been conceded; of the withdrawal of crops from the market until the farmer gets a measure of relief.

FROM time to time there are books which, regardless of their importance or lack of importance, even the busiest reviewer lays down with regret. Mr. Thompson's account of his forty-odd years among the living and dead Mayas is one of them.

PANAMA CITY, Aug. 26 -- Many difficult problems will face the National Assembly just a month before Dr. Harmodio Arias succeeds Dr. Ricardo J. Alfaro as President of the republic. The controversy between the renters and landlords, which threatened public order and resulted in the suspension of constitutional guarantees, will be one of the most urgent pieces of business the Assembly faces.

OSLO IT is only on the rarest of occasions that Gustav Vigeland, the Norwegian sculptor, opens the door of his studio in Oslo to visitors. One of these opportunities came not long ago, when Norway, through its various organizations, acted as host to the nineteenth congress of the International Union of Press Associations.

It is only twenty-eight years since the first subway was opened in 1904 and trains ran from Brooklyn Bridge to Broadway and 157th Street, Manhattan. That was the beginning of city rapid transit, unless you count the elevated steam railroad which half a century ago ran from the Battery to Central Park via Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON "PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE," some one wrote about a dozen years ago, "is the sole part of old-time Washington that has kept anything like its pristine unloveliness and it intends to keep that appearance as long as it can."

PEIPING, Sept. 3 -- Armed Japanese gendarmes, without consulting the Chinese police, raided a boarding house today in the Chinese city, took an inmate to the Japanese barracks in the Japanese Legation quarter, and are holding him there on unannounced charges.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Vittorio Podrecca's Teatro dei Piccoli and Vienness Sanger Knaber or boys' chorus are among the finest European artistic productions which S. Hurok is taking back with him to the United States for the coming season.

As the Summer holiday season nears its end, an atmosphere of doubt pervades political prediction. People who in July had thought the Democratic Presidential candidate a "sure winner" begin to talk of "HOOVER'S prospects rising." Not infrequently, one is informed that the result is an "even chance"; occasionally, somebody reports "betting odds on HOOVER."

The accumulation and conservation of reserve funds during prosperous times for use in periods of business stagnation is unquestionably the most frequently recommended method for preventing the recurrence of as serious a depression as the current one, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, which crystallizes the opinions of leading business executives on means to combat depressional unemployment.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Plans for the erection of a memorial to Joyce Kilmer, American poet, who was killed in the World War, in the proposed new building of Good Samaritan Hospital here were announced today by Frank H. Janke Sr., general chairman of the hospital building fund committee.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- The State election in Maine falls on Monday week. Eoth political parties are exerting themselves to the utmost to mobilize their greatest possible strength at the polls, Maine is the only State in the Union which has an election before the balloting for President in the following November.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Sept. 3 -- George T. Russell, 35 years old, of 268 Weequahic Avenue, Newark, was killed here today when a motorcycle on which he was riding crashed into a municipal garbage truck on Lyons Avenue near Nesbitt Terrace. Half an hour later an automobile driven by George M. Denman, 64, of 139 Wright Street, Newark, crashed into the truck, injuring Mr. Denman and two passengers in his automobile.

A distinguished British scholar and editor, recounting some of his observations during a recent visit of several months in America, raises a question which is "probably the most critical now confronting the civilized world." It was first suggested to him by one who had made a lifelong study of the "color problem," that it was "characteristic of "the unspoilt Negro to prefer an order "to a request."

WISCONSIN has decided to allow all political parties to broadcast their campaign views on government free of charge. The cost element is met by the free use of the State-owned stations. The State will undertake no censorship, but limits the programs to State and national issues.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Miss Chloe, a black mare owned and ridden by Gilbert C. Barrett Jr. of Hempetead, L.I., captured the saddie-horse championship of the twenty-third annual Smithtown Horse Show today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The estate of Julius Rosenwald, philanthropist and capitalist, valued at $45,000,000 at his death on Jan. 6, has been estimated to have a gross value of $32,000,000 for State and Federal income tax purposes. Market holdings, the most valuable item of the property, which had depreciated $17,086,316 by June 24, the low mark, have now recovered $15,683,876 with the current rise in exchange prices.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Speaker of the Reichstag and a member of Adolf Hitler's National Socialist party, decided today to provide plenty of time for negotiations looking toward a coalition of the Hitlerites and the Centrist party.

DOING one's own housework in college on a cooperative plan of share and share alike, in responsibilities as well as costs, with 50 or 100 other boys or girls, was not popular previous to 1929, but now more students than can be accommodated are seeking to live on this basis.
Editorial comment on the political situation following Mayor Walker's resignation, in some of New York's foreign language newspapers, follows:

It was in 1879 that EDISON succeeded in producing his first successful incandescent lamp. Of what use was it without electric energy? The question had occurred to him long before he embarked on the experiments that led to a carbonized cotton thread which glowed when it was electrically heated in a vacuum.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Pete Jablonowski won his eighth game for the Newark Bears today when three Albany pitchers, Milstead, Zumbro and Newsom were clubbed for twelve hits in an 8-5 defeat. Jess Hill and Bob Barrett hit homers.
COPENHAGEN, Sept. 3 -- The "flying family" of Hutchinsons has reached Godthaab, Western Greenland, safely after a flight across Davis Strait from Labrador.

THERE seems to be an idea abroad that the periods during which records boom balance the recognized musical season, that when the opera houses and the concert halls are running full blast gramophones accumulate dust. Actually the reverse is the case.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 THIS year the Berlin stage has capitulated completely to the dog days. At the moment there is not a single entertainment to recommend the peregrinating American. Formerly Reinhardt or Charell had some huge varicolored show that left the intellect quiescent but played vigorously on the feeling for line, color and tonal beauty.

THE MATCH KING," dealing with the spectacular career of Ivar Kreuger and adapted from the novel by Einar Thorvaldson, went before the Warner cameras last week. Lily Damita is playing the role that Jack Warner hoped he could induce the vacationing Greta Garbo to take, and Warren William is in the title role.

Indications that another large utility system has been able to save itself from receivership were seen last week In developments relating to the Central West Public Service Company. Heartened by deposits exceeding 93 per cent for the proposed exchange of matured three-year notes for a new three-year issue of gold notes, the company decided to pay back interest on the three series of its first lien collateral bonds.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The British press devoted considerable space to Walker's resignation. Commenting on the ex-Mayor's charge that the hearing was an inquisition, a Manchester Guardian editorial asks:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The Ninety-third Brigade, composed of National Guardsmen from New York City under the command of Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan, lined up today at Camp Smith for final inspection before returning home tomorrow after a two-weeks' course of Summer training.

IT is clear that the Soviet Communist party has issued an edict making a significant departure from the communistic theory of education, followed since the inception of the Soviet regime, in favor of a more individualized scheme of education, thus abolishing group instruction in the elementary and secondary schools of Russia.
Although the outcome of the Walker Cup matches in Brookline was surprising, the surprise was only in the one-sidedness of the result.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee said last night that he was determined to make a substantial cut in next year's budget and would take personal action toward this end on Tuesday, when hearings on departmental budget requests resume before Charles L. Kohler, Director of the Budget.

HARTFORD, Sept. 1. -- The caucus and convention system of selecting political candidates, which Connecticut has never seriously considered discarding in order to have the direct primary, is due to function again next week when both major parties hold their nominating conventions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Evening-up in wheat for the double holiday was under way on the Board of Trade here. At the opening a rush of commission-house buying lifted prices about 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish, but roost of the trading thereafter was within a fraction of 58 1/4 cents for the December, with selling increasing around 58 1/2 cents and buying developing at 58 cents.

SO far am I from anticipating immortality, in the language of the poets." wrote Brackenridge toward the end of his life, "that I think twenty years will about do." This statement, of course, does not mean what it says. It implies that twenty years distinctly would not do -- and here, over a century after Brackenridge's death, is Dr. Newlin's biography.

MONEY fluctuations, breaking the bounds of foreign exchange tables, enter the reneral news record and arouse assing curiosity about world curencies -- how they came to be, what et their par values and why they ave so many different names.

THE summertime playground of all the Atlantic seaboard is a sand bar on the edge of the ocean, where a white line of surf marks the narrow barrier that protects this slowly subsiding continent from the waves and tides of the great waters.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 -- Expanding with an apparent observed explosive force of 11,000 miles a second, a rate calculated to have doubled every 1,400,000,000 years, the universe may not have increased in size more than thirteen times in 100,000,000,000 years.

THE Puccini Grand Opera Company will present two operas this week in front of Federal Hall in Bryant Park. On Thursday evening "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be presented and on Saturday night "Aida" will be the opera.

PARIS. UDAY SHAN-KAR has been attracting much favorable attention during the last two or three years by the performances of Hindu dances and music which he and his company have been giving throughout Europe, and his work takes on new interest for America on account of the tour which he plans to make there after his opening in New York in November.

Twelve innings of alternately thrilling and painful baseball were played to a crowd of less than 8,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday before Bill Terry's Giants wrested the decision from Max Carey's Dodgers by a series of weird happenings. The score was 5 to 3.

NEWPORT -- Today finds the villa colony here filled with guests who came for the week-end and for the holiday. Hardly a villa or cottage is not housing one or more guests, for it is the last big week-end of the Summer and one that has been gay with entertaining, dinners and luncheons.

THE World War was fought not only with guns: it was also a war of ideas fought out with propaganda. In this propagandist conflict Germany was beaten more decisively than on the field of arms. The story of how this happened, and why, copiously documented, is told by Dr. Friedrich Thimme, archivist of the German Government archives in Potsdam, in "Weltkrieg ohne Waffen" ("World War Without Arms").

THE extent to which the business of air transport has entered into the carrying of goods is reflected by a comprehensive fourteen-page folder in colors which is about to be distributed by General Air Express, the joint operation which provides doorto-door pick-up and delivery of parcels through the cooperation of seven airlines and a telegraph company whose field of operations is the nation.

A former champion whose almost unparalleled daring was entrancing tennis galleries eighteen years ago and a youth from Milwaukee who had not yet seen the light of day then, shared the spotlight yesterday as the fifty-first national singles tournament got under way at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

ACTUAL improvement in business or greater confidence for the near future is reflected in the expressions of automobile executives as they survey the situation of their own companies and the industry in general.

Although the rise of approximately 100 per cent in the prices of stocks since July 8 has reduced the yield on representative issues to one-half the return of two months ago, these securities still show an average yield more than double that which prevailed at the peak of the market in 1929.

Bonds of several municipalities were called last week for payment in September and numerous lots of foreign issues, principally German, for redemption in future months also were added to the list of those that are to be retired before maturity. The total for September is now $25,325,000, compared with $56,019,000 called for August and $110,999,000 for September, 1931, at corresponding dates.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 3 -- A meeting of representatives of the neutral nations which have been intervening in the dispute over the Chaco betweer Bolivia and Paraguay was prolonged until daybreak this morning and is again going on tonight.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 3 -- A close finish in the Victory Class featured the sixtieth annual Fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today. C.L. Smith's Reveille, sailing in a fleet of ten boats, came through to defeat Blue Jacket, owned by V.A. Romagna, by the small margin of 2 seconds to capture the honors.

FOR the second time since broadcasting began, the savants of radio research have had the opportunity to study the effect of a total eclipse of the sun on electromagnetic waves -- once in 1925 and again in 1932. They hoped on both occasions to learn more about the Kennelly-Heaviside layer called the "radio roof" or "mirror."

BERLIN ON June 24, memorial day of the dastardly assassination of Walter Rathenau, German Minister of Foreign Affairs, solemn exercises were held in Berlin, in Parliament and at the Rathenau tomb at Niederschoenweide.

FOR months, with characteristic zeal, Germany has been paying fervent tribute to the genius of Goethe, this year marking the centennial of his death. The climax of the celebration was reached last Sunday. Goethe's birthday anniversary, when a series of Summer festivals, representing the earlier and lighter phases of the poet's talent, as well as his greatest works, drew throngs of young people to Weimar and Frankfort-on-the-Main.

AFTER a good many years of misinterpretation Shakespeare is beginning to come into his own again. Not on the stage; in the United States, at least, he is rarely played and never with much recognition of his modern spirit. But the faithful commentators still find in Shakespeare the vitality of a master poet whose depth and compass keep him essential to a full understanding of life.

FOR some weeks past people on Long Island have been interested in tall steel towers from which lights flashed forth at night; the more observant ones noted that the tower platforms were the scenes of quiet activity. Often far into the night shadowy forms moved about an instrument that occasionally gleamed under an electric torch; one heard familiar names and unfamiliar numbers called out and repeated.

James J. Walker yesterday placed his future fate in the hands of the city's voters, asserting that the people themselves must decide his course without any urging from him. He disclosed his stand in an interview, the first since his resignation last Thursday night.
