ELBERON, N.J., Sunday, Sept. 1 -- David Burnstine of New York was in the lead at the close of the first day's play early this morning in the individual contract bridge masters' championship of the American Bridge League, being contested at the Deal Club here.

PARIS THE latest pose of the sartorial neo-experts is to say that there is nothing new in Winter fashions; but this observer found the recent openings full of novelty, though the Paris couturiers were wise enough not to do anything too radical -- like abruptly changing our skirt lengths or shoulder lines -- and thus put all our last season's clothes beyond the fashionable pale.

A sea-purse, an eddying movement of the undertow, formed off Rockaway Beach between Beach Ninety-fifth and Ninety-sixth Streets yesterday afternoon, endangering the lives of scores of bathers. Only prompt work by lifeguards who put out aboard catamarans and other available craft prevented casualties.

Advance buying by retailers on a sixty to ninety day basis in major textile lines was described as a timely and opportune step by P.A. O'Connell, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and head of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston, in an interview with a TIMES reporter.

The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, concluding a three-day session yesterday, announced the beginning of a campaign to eliminate sweatshops from the industry. The board recommended the formation of an association of manufacturers, retailers and the union to cooperate in the campaign.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES correspondent of Aug. 14, John L. Sundean of Minneapolis, raises some important questions regarding the practicability of the heretofore untested method of amending the Constitution, by the reference of proposals to "conventions in" the States rather than to the "Legislatures of" the States.

A feeling of doubt that former Mayor James J. Walker would persist in his intention of seeking popular vindication by running again for Mayor developed yesterday in Democratic circles, although no tangible reason to doubt that John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey.

Any broad movement for the replacement of obsolete machinery and equipment in industrial plants, which is widely recommended, will be delayed for a considerable time through the inability of manufacturers to finance the purchases of capital equipment, according to opinions expressed here yesterday in engineering and machinery circles.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Under the presidency of President Lebrun, the French Cabinet today discussed at length what action should be taken with regard to the German request for opening a discussion tending toward the revision of Germany's military status as laid down in the Treaty of Versailles.
A further recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday advanced all months except October to or above 9 cents a pound, and the day ended at gains of 14 to 17 points.

Opening and closing their performance with a pair of eye-filling home runs, the Yankees turned back the Senators at the Stadium yesterday, 6 to 5, in their final meeting of the year with Walter Johnson's men. They forthwith recorded another cluster of brilliant achievements in the presence of a crowd of 15,000.

THIS handy little book will be an invaluable companion for any visitor to the scene of the Battle of Gettysburg who wants to view the historic place with intelligence and understanding. Mr. Storrick is eminently fitted by lifelong association to furnish just such all admirable guide book to the battlefield, at once informing and appealing, as he has made.
New York's great annual Labor Day migration to beaches, mountains and restful country places reached its culmination yesterday, and last night the city, as nearly as it could be, was deserted.

The fiftieth anniversary of the installation of the first electrical plant in New York, at 257 Pearl Street will be commemorated in a series of celebrations beginning today, arranged by the New York Edison Company.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 3 -- Connecticut Republican leaders today worked out the principal part of the slate to be presented at the State convention Wednesday.

Secretary of Labor DOAK is trying to settle a case interesting to campaign contributors and collectors. In the early Fall of 1931 the Republican National Committee was hard up. Mr. THOMAS J.A. JOHNSON, a rich Boston marble dealer, who is also described as "city greeter for Mayor CURLEY," was inclined or persuaded to do something for its relief.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Legal beer by March 4 if President Hoover is re-elected and has an opportunity to put the Republican prohibition reform plan into effect was predicted here tonight by Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire, in an address before 500 Suffolk County Republicans in Southampton High School.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Twelve cruising auxiliaries representing nearly as many different yacht clubs, got off to a good start on a long reach to Eaton's Point and then headed eastward down the Sound this afternoon in the eighth annual Cornfield Light race, under the auspices of the Huntington Yacht Club.

The requirements for a fair trial and the provisions of Section 34 of the public officers law do not countenance, in my judgment, the wholesale receipt and use of testimony taken by an investigating committee, where the accused officer has not been represented by counsel or afforded the opportunity of cross-examination.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's address here tonight was as follows:

MADRID, Aug. 24 -- Spanish monarchists have decided not to unite under one head alter all, and the romantic Carlists, whose struggle was the background for a colorful Conrad novel, will go on being as romantic and impractical as ever.

THIS is Mr. Lever's first novel, although some readers will remember his brief and amusing "A Stitch in Time," published a few years ago by the Nonesuch Press. "Nymph Errant" describes a highly unconventional Wanderjahr in the life of a young English girl just out of a correct finishing school in Lausanne.

CMPUS days are almost here again. Mad hours of shopping are about to be wedged into the short space of time between Labor Day and the exciting moment when trains are boarded for colleges and schools. Clothes are exciting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Aug. 27 were below those both for the two preceding weeks and the corresponding period last year, according to the survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Labor Day week-end, marked by the arrival of scores of visitors and featured by the playing of the seventh annual Fairacre Challenge Cup golf tournament, officially opens the Fall season at Virginia Hot Springs.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Billy Winn of Kansas City, holder of the New Jersey State auto record over a half-mile dirt track, won the bicentennial handicap at the Flemington Fair today, driving the twenty miles in sixteen minutes and forty-four seconds, in a Murray tire special.

BERLIN, Sept. 3. --A drastic reorganization of the Prussian civil government was decreed today by the provisional government under Federal Chancellor von Papen that will amount in certain respects to the breaking up of Prussia into a number of States.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- By winning the $48,400 Hopeful Stakes in decisive fashion on the closing day of the meeting today, W.R. Coe's Pompey colt, Ladysman, pushed his total winnings to $101,135, the greatest for a juvenile this season, and established himself firmly as the best 2-year-old to show thus far this year.

From Paul A. Sorg, general manager of the Regional Rural Association, comes word that the association, which has headquarters at Mountainville, N.Y., will open tomorrow an exhibition of work by New York artists who have painted subjects within the area covered by the association.

AMERICAN LITERATURE AND CULTURE," a compact attempt to hit the high spots of three centuries of American expression, leaves a blurred impression in the mind of the reader. The book has its virtue; it provides informative summaries of certain key figures -- Jonathan Edwards, Emerson, Thoreau -- that offer excellent short introductions to their work.

The Crex Carpet Company, whose stock was suspended from trading on the Stock Exchange Friday because of "unusual transactions," has offered to cooperate with the Exchange's investigation of the situation in the issue, it was announced yesterday by W.H. Kedmond, president of the company.

To the Editor of the New York Times. Will Federal aid to the American transportation system be confined to keeping the roads out of the hands of receivers by Advances from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, or will a more enlightened and constructive policy, looking to the upbuilding of the business of the carriers, be adopted?
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Americans and others returning to their homes this Summer are taking back a picture of a new and changed London.

PREFACING its story by a few remarks to the effect that while the erstwhile German "Price Commissar," Dr. Karl Goerdler, hadn't done anything to reduce the rates for spiritual fare, but had limited his work to cutting the prices of foodstuffs, , the Berlin Vossische Zeitung of Aug. 18 reported a substantial drop in opera and theatre tickets for the coming season as the result of a newspaper campaign and last year's poor business.

M.R CHASE has not been quite fair to himself in picking a title for his book. To invoke a New Deal as the cure for a sick economics is to suggest that the sole trouble is with the luck of the cards. A new deal has usually meant a reshuffling of the cards as between the haves and havenots in favor of the latter.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- The ultrapro tectionists of the United States who have witnessed the painful and disputatious labors of Congress when it is proposed to increase any import duty by half or even as much as a few cents should envy Germany, whose official "autarchists" by an autocratic stroke of the pen can summarily raise duties to ten times the original figure without turning a hair.

SOUTHAMPTON -- There is every indication that the many social activities that fill the program for the last important holiday of the season will continue throughout the coming month. Although it is regarded conventionally as marking the end of formal entertainment, so many members of the Summer colony remain throughout the Autumn that Labor Day and a cessation of important social events have lost their former significance.

Efforts of the present administration to combine an adequate navy with its economy program were stressed yesterday by Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, when on behalf of President Hoover he welcomed delegates to the eighth annual convention of the Fleet Reserve Association at the Hotel Astor.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- A report submitted by the Association of Teachers of the Province of Saxony to the Prussian Ministry of Education has called the attention of the public to what may be called the most alarming aspect of the economic depression and political unrest in Germany.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 -- A caucus of more than 200 Senators and Deputies voted unanimously tonight to support General Abelardo L. Rodriguez for the Presidency of Mexico, left vacant by the resignation last evening of President Pascual Ortiz Rubio.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 3 -- Heavy fighting on the southern and eastern fronts is revealed in a weekly review issued by the government today of the operations against the Sao Paulo rebels.

After a discussion of the use of troops against the B.E.F. in Washington, in which President Hoover was criticized by several speakers, the national convention of the Society of the Fifth Division voted yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker to close the debate at this session without taking any action.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Five young women will make their social debuts this week on the North Shore of Long Island, and in anticipation of the events most of the members of the young set have returned from Newport, Saratoga and other resorts.

An example of extensive modernization which is expected to provide increased revenue and help to lower the large number of vacancies which is to be found in many old apartment houses is furnished by the work now in progress on the old Mott Haven Apartments at 428-46 East 138th Street and 425-43 East 137th Street, in the Bronx.

Dr. Ernst F.W. Alexanderson, who took an automatic radio recorder to Fryeburg, Me., on Wednesday to capture the action of the elusive waves in ink, returned to his laboratory in "the House of Magic" at the General Electric Company, Schenectady, N.Y., to study the results as registered by a wavering needle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Juan Orts Gonzalez in a letter in THE TIMES on Aug. 25 makes misleading statements regarding facts of public record. There are not "200 different religious orders in the Archdiocese of Valencia." Annuario Ecclesiastics for 1927 publishes the statistics of religious orders in the dioceses of Spain.

There are many kinds of fishermen and most of them have very rigid codes under which they conduct their sport, but it is doubtful if in all the world of anglers there is a code so severe as that maintained by the big-game fishermen who go in for sword fishing.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 30 -- Announcement by Oregon's senior United States Senator, Charles L. McNary, the Republican floor leader, that the prohibition issue would probably be disposed of by Congress before the Christmas holidays and Submitted to the States has introduced new element of interest in the election of legislators to the Oregon Legislature.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Clarence True Wilson, executive secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals, is going to vote for Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President.

PARIS, Aug 26 -- Every American visitor has discovered with varying degrees of annoyance, when first patronizing the Paris Opera or one of the theatres, that it is the custom of the country to tip the usher. And to the further embarrassment of the American visitor, after he has somehow been made to understand what is expected of him, the usher generally has complained that the tip was insufficient.

HAMILTON, Ont., Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Hamilton Centre of the Royal Canadian Astronomical Society prepared today to send to Greenwich, England, the photographic plates its party took of the total eclipse of the sun last Wednesday at Acton Vale, Que.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest the statement of Mr. Coates in your issue of yesterday concerning the unemployment situation existing among musicians.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 1. -- Although the Kentucky Presidential and Congressional campaigns are well under way, the Republican party has not selected a Senate nominee to oppose United States Senator Barkley, Democrat, incumbent, who served as keynoter at the Chicago convention.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- Gar Wood, in his motor boat Miss America X with her 6,400-horsepower engines, today won the first race of thirty-five miles for the Harmsworth Trophy. But in a way it was a victory hollow as to competition.

To the Dramatic Editor: Looking back at the many celebrations that have been held during the past months in honor of the memory of George Washington, it does seem as if the theatre should have taken a more active part. The world of the theatre is under a deep obligation to the great George, if for no other reason than that he had a birthday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Germany'a new tariffs, which will go into operation on next Tuesday, will affect various lines of exports from the United States. Graham W. Parker, research fellow in the Graduate School of Business Administration at Harvard University, discussed today the changed outlook in Germany for the office equipment industry In this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Announcement in a recent issue of THE TIMES of proposed reorganizations in the Institute of Politics at Williamstown is a matter of profound interest to the public at large, and particularly to those of us who for many years have been members of this institute.

The persistence with which Germany pursues her policy of removing from her shoulders the penalties the Treaty of Versailles placed upon her for having lost the World War must evoke admiration, regardless of one's ideas of the merits of Berlin's claims.

POLITICIANS are drawing up their ethereal battle lines. The fact that broadcasting to a coast-to-coast audience is expensive is causing some careful figuring. Already several speeches have been pulled away from the microphone so that more monetary ammunition would be left in the war chests for a heavy barrage of words in October.

LONDON WHAT is the type of early environment most helpful to a literary career? In an article contributed to an autobiographical series in The Daily Herald, Ethel Mannin thanks her stars that she was born of working-class people -- her father was a plumber earning L3 a week -- and that she left school at 15 to earn her own living.

WHILE Edgar Wallace was still alive it was often rumored that he employed "ghost" writers. It did not seem possible that one man could produce so many books, plays and newspaper articles as he did. Mr. Wallace always denied these rumors and once offered a reward of $5,000 to any one who could prove them to be true.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean of the Cardinals today wrecked the Chicago Cubs' sensational string of victories, shutting out the National League leaders, 3 to 0, in the second game of a double-header. The Cubs gained their fourteenth in a row by winning the opener, 5 to 4, in eleven innings, before an overflow crowd of 43,000.

NEWPORT, K.L., Sept. 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Astor opened their large home this evening for a subscription dance. Mrs. Astor was assisted in the arrangements by Mrs. C. Oliver O'Donnell and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington.

With a continuation of their upward movement, prices of almost all the commodities quoted on the local exchanges reached higher levels last week. Virtually the only exception was sugar, which moved in a narrow range and closed with some positions lower than a week before.

FOR the third time since depression overtook the United States in 1929, the country is hoping for a Fall revival. Evidence of this hope is to be found not only on the Stock Exchange, where security prices have approximately doubled since the end of June.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- After the rout of that political interloper, Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, in the Spring Senatorial primary, Senator James J. Davis was considered as much, as elected to succeed himself for a full term. The November balloting was to be a mere formality as far as the Senate contest was concerned.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 1 -- An unmistakable feeling of optimism has replaced the misgivings that had oppressed the Commonwealth for many months. The new confidence arises from several sources. It received its first impetus from overseas trading figures for 1931 and 1932, which were disclosed last month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- United States foreign trade in July, valued at $186,186,878, was $40,000,000 less than in the preceding month, and the shipments to twenty-three of the thirty-nine principal foreign markets were smaller, according to final figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, Ga., Sept. 1 -- Not content with claiming to have been the first. State that officially defied the authority of King George and and Britain through the Mecklenburg Declaration of Independence, North Carolina now lays claim to the honor of having the first town in ths United States named for George Washington.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- A bronze bust of George Washington, copied from Houdon's statue of the first President, disappeared mysteriously last night from a pedestal where it had been placed on Feb. 22, to mark the spot where Washington and Rochambeau, the French general, met during the Revolutionary War, to plan the victorious Yorktown campaign.

Cardinal Hayes will complete forty years in the priesthood next Thursday. At his request, there will be no public celebration of the anniversary. He was ordained in St. Patrick's Cathedral on Sept. 8, 1892.

THE farmers' holiday movement in the Middle West has focused attention again on the status of agriculture in the nation. Nowhere are the situation and its implications more clearly revealed than in the Northwest. In this great area the dominant topic is the drop in farm prices.

THROUGH the sticky days of late August Harry Moses has been busy assembling a company to appear with Colin Keith-Johnston in J.B. Priestley's first solo piece for the theatre, "Dangerous Corner," which will be Mr. Moses's initial production of the season.

PARIS, Sept, 2 -- That very human man, Edouard Herriot, who is Premier and Foreign Minister of France came back to Paris yesterday from a little trip to the channel island to find that Germany, in his absence had asked for revision of the military clauses of the Treaty of Versailles and that there was a good deal of fat in the fire.

The annual report of the Register's office of the Borough of the Bronx shows that a total of 80,040 instruments were filed or recorded, apportioned as follows: Chattel mortgages, 44,902; deeds, 11,625; assignments, agreements and certificates, 9,455; mortgages, 4,685; miscellaneous, 179; notaries public and Commissioner of Deeds certificates, 4,032.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Discovery by J. Townsend Russell, archaeologist, of a great Solutrian workshop in the foothills of the Pyrenees in Southern France which possibly was an open-air tool and weapon factory of 50,000 years ago, is reported by the Smithsonian Institution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the past few weeks we have been entertained by the conducting of Albert Coates, Anglo-Russian, who has been a highly honored guest conductor at the Stadium concerts. In addition, he has from time to time offered more or less diverting comment on affairs both American and Russian.

Three Discoveries. SUPERANNUATED vehicles are much in evidence on British roads; "caravanning" has reached the proportions of a boom among motor tourists in England, and derivatives of the American road-house -- but with certain trimmings -- are becoming regular institutions in and beyond the environs of London.

PARIS, Aug. 22, 1932 SCARCELY a year ago almost no one in Paris interested himself any longer in jazz -- from the musical point of view, of course. We continued, however, to dance fox-trots to the sound of more or less mediocre jazz bands, which played most frequently tunes put in vogue by the films or the music halls.

MADRID, Sept. 2 -- If one wishes to see "the best people" in Madrid now one must go to jail. A scurrilous story has it that three social climbers threw bricks at a policeman last week in the hope of going there, but they could not make the grade.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Governor Roosevelt's "record" on questions affecting Wall Street, labor and unemployment and public utilities was assailed here tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, in a Labor Day week-end address delivered over the radio.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Aug. 31. -- Southern California is slowly digging out from under an amazing primary election containing as many surprises as an auction sale and giving considerable pause to administration followers.

"PROFESSOR SKINNER." A FEW days ago a White Star liner put in at Boston and there landed an elderly man with an academic calm and a scholar's beard. On the passenger list he was set down as "Professor Clarence Skinner," but interviewers who know their rotogravure sections recognized him as Montagu Collet Norman, Governor of the Bank of England and frequent transatlantic commuter from Threadneedle Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Two hundred and twelve of the world's greatest astronomers, including eighty-three from abroad, gathered here today for the opening session of the International Astronomical Union.

LONDON. THERE is excellent promise of a good crop of new pictures later on in the year, but at the present time the sort of stuff which the people concerned with the exploitation of the film business seem to think quite good enough for Summer audiences is bad enough to arouse a sense of dissatisfaction with the cinema generally which it will take a whole series of first-class works to eradicate.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- High scoring featured league soccer games played in England and Scotland today, with teams which have shaped up well in the opening games of the season continuing to record victories.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 3 -- A. L. Walker Jr. of the Richmond County Country Club won the thirty-six hole final for the Isham Cup at the Ekwanok Country Club today, defeating A.F. Lynch of Winged Foot, 6 up and 5 to play. Without the aid of a single long putt, Walker maintained a pace better than even fours and was three strokes above par when the match ended.

CLEVELAND THE transcontinental record, which was broken today, will be cut again at the races next year. Furthermore, the record will continue to be cut, in my opinion, until airplanes are approaching the 600 miles an hour limit."

After a pause of two days for the Labor Day week-end, the stock market will have to prepare this week for its severest test since the recovery got under way nearly two months ago. Having been swept forward to its present level chiefly by expectations and promises, it will have to depend upon the realities for its further momentum.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- Great surprise and no little indignation was caused in Italy by the press campaign launched in some foreign countries, notably France, first on the occasion of the Italian naval manoeuvres and then repeated last week for the army manoeuvres.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Entries arriving daily for the fourth annual Glens Falls open golf tourney which will be in progress Thursday, Friday and Saturday on the Glens Falls Country Club links, indicate that the 1932 field will not only be comprised of the top ranking shot makers of the country but also a majority of the youthful stars.

New York's most vital problem, real estate taxes and assessments, will be the subject of a series of six articles by Dr. Richard T. Ely, the first of which will appear next Sunday, Sept. 11, in the Real Estate Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals held fourth place in the International League today as Gowel Claset won a tight lefthanded duel from Bud Teachout, 3 to 2.

According to the official schedule received by the directors of the Italian Line here recently from the head offices in Genoa, the new 54,000-ton 28-knot liner Rex was to have made her speed trials off the Italian Riviera on Sept. 1, but up to the closing hour yesterday no word had been received on the subject from Genoa.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 3.-- Full support for the national program of economic recovery was pledged by the United States Building and Loan League in the closing session of its annual convention today, when resolutions predicting success for the Federal Home Loan Banking system were adopted.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Though the Coun- cil of Ministers issued no communique today regarding the contemplated loans-conversion plan, it is understood the scheme was unanimously ratified and it was decided to convoke Parliament Sept. 16 in extraordinary session to give the needed authorization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. (AP) -- Declaring labor has given an outstanding example of conservative stability, Secretary Doak in a radio address tonight asserted that the shorter workday and week was the only way to meet mechanization of industry. Miss Mary Anderson, chief of the women's bureau of the department, called for legal action to compel establishment of the five-day week as a means of spreading employment.

MR. CLARK offers an authentic problem, one now more vital in England, where women have so outnumbered men since the war, than in America. What is the woman, approaching middle- age, whose vocation demands celibacy, to do with her life?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The organization of the army is criticized in a report on the national defense act by the Foreign Policy Association today as unsound as to some of its provisions and as conflicting in the theories underlying the law with the definition of "defense" and the disarmament proposals of President Hoover at the Geneva General Disarmament Conference.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 3 -- In the first running of the 122d Cavalry Racing Association steeplechase and race meeting at Mountain Glen Farm, Mount Carmel, today, C.K. Bassett, riding for Franklin Baker Jr. of Penn's Park, Pa., scored the only double victory of the meet.

Although there has been no appreciable increase in the volume of retail sales as yet, the sentiment among retail merchants is decidedly better, and they look forward to a rather satisfactory September business, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Farm strike picketing in Iowa had subsided today to camps on two highways near Sioux City, but plans for extension of the non-selling holiday proceeded in Minnesota and Wisconsin.

WELLINGTON, Aug. 9 -- W. Downie Stewart, New Zealand Minister of Finance, and A.D. Park, Secretary of the Treasury, who attended the Ottawa Conference of the British Empire will journey in London to negotiate for a conversion loan for this country's mountain of foreign bonds.

PERHAPS the new guards of Central Park will inherit the design nation of "sparrow cops" which used to make their predecessors writhe hack in the 1890s. The old time park policemen lived down their designation, but it took them years to do so.

By breaking 99 out of a possible 100 targets, F. Dickerson won the high scratch cup at the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club yesterday. He had a straight string of 98, missing his 99th bird

MANAGUA, Sept. 3 -- Donald Leroy Truesdale of Lugoff, S.C., a second lieutenant in the Nicaraguan National Guard, received the Congressional Medal of Honor and John Hamas of Philadelphia, a first lieutenant in the National Guard, received the Navy Cross today.

Speculative interest was intensified yesterday in advance of the extended week-end and stocks moved into new high ground for the Summer bull market, showing net gains of 1 to 5 points. More than 2,440,000 shares changed hands in the two hours of trading on the Stock Exchange.

TORONTO Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Dividing the spoils in today's double-header against the Maple Leafs, the Buffalo Bisons lost more valuable ground in their chase for second place and were forced to be content with an even break in the four games played.

FLORENT SCHMTTT and Alexander Tansman, European composers, will visit this country during the coming season and will play their own works with orchestra and chamber music ensembles. Mr. Schmitt will appear in November with the Boston Symphony in the first performance of his new "Symphonie Concertante" for piano and orchestra.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Once more appealing for consideration for the "forgotten man," Governor Roosevelt made a bid here tonight for harmony among the warring factions of the Democratic party in New England.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Mrs. L. Wadhams Dodge gave a garden party here at Guestwick, Colt Road, this afternoon to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Lucy Bannard Dodge. Mrs. Dodge, a niece of the late Otto T. Bannard, New York banker, was assisted in receiving by her sister, Mrs. William F. Pearson, and a niece, Miss Sally Pearson, both of Washington.

Growth of an acute sense of community responsibility among manufacturers framing future employment policies is one of the most notable developments brought about by the current depression, William J. Barrett, member of the President's Organization on Unemployment Relief, told THE TIMES yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The announcement in your issue this morning to the effect that the Soviet Government has engaged Miss Emma Redell to appear with the leading symphony orchestras of the Soviet Union, and as guest Wagnerian performer, brings to the fore some pertinent questions.

A movement to increase the prices of automobile tires approximately 11 per cent is expected to be launched this week by leading manufacturers. Recent advances in the prices of cotton and rubber, the principal materials used in tires, have strengthened the position of the industry materially, and the manufacturers are ready for a new attempt to reduce competition and raise quotations.

PRESIDENT WILSON interfered only twice with the military operations of the War Department during the war, while I was Chief of Staff, and both times he was wrong. The first of these was the Siberian Expedition, the other, sending American troops to Murmansk and Archangel, northern Russia.

THE English will fight just as much as any other people to resist changes they dislike. We have already got rid of two kings by fighting and made three violent revolutions to prevent ourselves from being governed contrary to our wishes, and should a revolutionary situation arise today the wealthy classes would fight as they fought for Charles the First and against James the Second.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 -- A "moratorium on all attempts to garnishee or attach the wages of heads of families in satisfaction of debts was announced by Judge Stanley Struble when he started his term in the equity room of the Common Pleas Court.

THE young Frenchman who writes under the name of Georges Simenon and who is introduced to the American public by the simultaneous pubiication of these two novels is only 28 years old and has already written 280 detective stories.

FROM Moscow comes word that there is to be an important departure from the plan of education which was introduced in Russian schools by the Soviet regime. That plan is said to have incorporated many features of the "Dalton plan," a system widely used in the United States and originated by Miss Helen Parkhurst, headmistress of the Dalton School of New York City.

ROME, Aug. 22. -- An exceptionally good wheat crop was forecast in Italy at the beginning of the present season, but the unusually cool and rainy Summer which was a feature of this year has to a certain degree negatived the hopes of Italian agriculturists.

OTTAWA, Canada, Sept. 1 -- An interesting correspondence was provoked by fin Ottawa newspaper when it published an editorial suggesting that President Hoover's pronunciation in his public addresses did not attain to the degree of perfection which might be expected of one in his exalted post.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 10 -- Arapuni, New Zealand's giant Stateowned hydroelectric generating plant, is headed for the scrap-heap. And with it will go $9,000,000 of government money, painfully raised and spent over seven years in a huge development which has ended in being one more taxpayers' liability.

Average tariff rates assessed against dutiable goods imported into the United States rose more than 6 per cent this year, according to statistics made public yesterday by the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc. The statistics are intended to refute recent claims by politicians that this country's average duty rate is not increasing.

As tomorrow is Labor Day and today has been designated as "Labor Sunday," there will be read from many Protestant pulpits the whole or part of the "Labor Sunday Message for 1932" as prepared by the Commission on Social Service of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America and sent out by that organization.

HAVANA, Aug. 16 -- Correcting erroneous impressions created by recent press dispatches originating here, Treasury Department officials today asserted that Cuba's funded debt as of June 30, 1932, technically speaking, totaled $182,452,120, which includes the sugar stabilization bonds in the amount of $28,708,120 now in the hands of investors.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Sept. 4 -- Chang Tsung-chang, former war lord of Shantung Province, who used to take his harem of more than thirty wives and concubines to wars in a private train, was assassinated by two youths yesterday afternoon in the railway station at Tsinanfu, according to brief official messages from Peiping.

TORONTO, Sept. 3 -- Winning the 220-yard dash at the Canadian National Exhibition track and field meet today, Ralph Metcalfe, Marquetta University marvel, shattered the world's record of 20 4-10 seconds. His time was 0:19.8 but the following wind was so strong it is unlikely his mark will be recognized.

PROFESSOR GEORGE J. COX of Columbia University contributes the leading article, "Modern Art and This Matter of Taste," to The American Magazine of Art for August. And a particularly delightful article it is -- humorous, keen, full of straight thinking.

COMMERCE, Ga., Sept. 1 -- Georgia poets and composers of religious songs are to have a memorial erected in this honor. The site has been selected and other preliminary work done in connection with the erection of this monument. The Georgia State Singing Association in a convention recently held at Toccoa got the matter under way and it has progressed now to the point where the memorial seems certain to be erected.

Three senior records were shattered in the Richmond County A.A. U. swimming championships at the Midland Beach Pool, Staten Island, yesterday. The record breakers were Hugh Olsen, 220-yard free style for boys; Ray Mullane, 110-yard free style for boys and Miss Ethel Steiniger, 110-yard free style for girls.

THE contemporary American is not primarily a citizen. Since the beginning of the century he has been a man in a hurry, so diverted and distracted by new things, new speeds, fabulous opportunities for personal expansion, that he has lost his early zest for citizenship. Not that he has ever ceased to regard himself as something pretty choice and privileged in the way of a citizen.

Public officials realize the necessity for constructive action in reducing the burden of taxes now placed against real estate, and are struggling with this problem while tax boards throughout the country are being swamped with petitions for assessment cuts, says State Senator Joseph G. Wolber of New Jersey.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Commodore William Hale Thompson, dauntless navigator of the Illinois, Mississippi and Ohio Rivers, whose political possibilities he explored and exploited when he was a more conspicuous figure on the prairie landscape than he has been for some time, according to intimations from Republican State headquarters, Has prevailed upon for- mer Governor Len Small, who heads the State ticket, to launch his cam- paign in literal fashion on or about Sept. 10.

WILL ROGERS is, among other things, a motion picture actor, and this week his latest picture, "Down to Earth," may be seen at the Roxy. The cowboy comedian, probably America's most characteristically native wit, was born in Oolagah, Indian Territory, on Nov. 4, 1879.

On the calendar of the Federal Treasury Sept. 15 is a date of unusual importance. The first quarterly income tax payments for the new fiscal year will be received that day, furnishing comparison with last year's receipts. On the same day two blocks of short-term certificates of indebtedness mature, amounting to $712,000,000, and these issues will require new financing.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES story of the death of Tom Vallance needs a little straightening out for accuracy's sake.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Mortage tax receipts in the State dropped to a gross of $4,008,960 and a net toal of $3,902,150 for the fiscal year ended June 30, it was announced today by Thomas M. Lynch, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance. It was the fifth consecutive year that receipts have dropped below the figures for the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- National bank-note circulation backed by 3, 3 1/3 and 3 3/3 per cent bonds under the authority of the Glass-Borah amendment to the Home Loan Bank act amounted to $64,854,600 on Sept. 1 out of $772,015,768 of all such paper in the hands of the public or the issuing banks, the Treasury Department reported today.

A SERIES of lectures on the subject of post-war finance, addressed by one of the world's foremost practical economists to a group of students, "without any economic knowledge or previous interest," have been gathered into Sir Josiah Stamp's unusually instructive and useful volume.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 3 -- Turning back a dramatic challenge by Tom Creavy in a stirring overtime struggle of thirty-eight holes, Frank Walsh of Chicago today joined Olin Dutra, the par-breaker from Santa Monica, Cal., in the final of the national professional golf championship.

HOT weather during the week served to restrict early consumer buying of Fall apparel and accessories. Purchases of dresses, however, were reported as good and active buying of apparel and other items for school and college openings was noted.

To the Eidtor of The New York Times: At the moment of farmer "uprisings" it is interesting to recall an editorial in THE TIMES of Jan. 20 of the present year dealing with the delights of the cultivation of the soil and related matters. At present things do not appear quite so pleasant, the farmers' movement being just another product of the prevailing depression.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Townsend Ashmore and her daughter, Miss Eulalie Ashmore, arrived on the Lafayette and are with Mrs. E. Reeve Merritt at Elfland, Oyster Bay. Miss Ashmore will be introduced to society in New York this season.

Further conferences took place in Washington last week regarding the $50,000,000 loan arranged to be made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the cotton cooperatives against some 2,000,000 bales of cotton, and the future policy of the Federal Farm Board for the disposal of the remainder of its cotton holdings.

Whether Tammany Hall was still a political power in this city was the question uppermost in the mind of Premier Mussolini when Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, visited him recently at his Summer home at Carpena, near Bologna, Mr. Corsi revealed yesterday when he returned on the Vulcania.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Many dinner dances took place tonight at the country clubs and shore clubs in Westchester County in celebration of the holiday week-end.

After more than two centuries the controversy between Delaware and New Jersey over title to the east bank of the Delaware River included within a ten-mile circle from Newcastle remains unsettled. It is one of the most curious relics of the day when grants were made by English kings and members of the royal family.

BETWEEN RED AND WHITE" is more than a war novel. It must be dignified with the name of chronicle, a chronicle of the death agony of the White Russian cause, which, even though little is known about it in this country, must have been ghastly and titanic in its reverberations.

LAREDO, Texas, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Te men apparently were swept to their deaths here late today in the angry flood waters of the Rio Grande a few hours before the stream was believed to have reached its crest.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Twelve policemen of the West Orange force were held at bay for nearly four hours this afternoon by a demented man armed with a knife and an axe, who had climbed to the roof of a front porch of a house at 17 Valley Way.

Transatlantic ship lines operating from New York are preparing for the flood of apple cargoes which crowd the waterfront piers each year with the arrival of September. The addition of modern tonnage to the fleet of vessels serving New York, equipped to carry perishable fruit, places the lines in position this year to handle a greater volume than ever before, the Port of New York Authority says.

A meeting of the producers of copper outside the United States is scheduled to be held in October in some European city, probably London, to discuss production and the sales quota of each company in those markets that are not protected by tariffs.

IT is easy to understand the urge of a master printer to exercise his art on a favorite book, to print it with all the skill and resources at his command, so that its text becomes inevitably associated with his name. In paying tribute to a work of literature in this fashion the printer is restrained by nothing but the limitations of his own imaginings and the equipment of his plant.

QUITE naturally Vera Caspary's novel of the Jewish Piera family brings to mind G.B. Stern's chronicle called "Tents of Israel" in England and "Matriarch" in America. And, unfortunately for Miss Caspary, her novel will Inevitably be compared to Miss Stern's to the latter's glorification, which, in a manner of speaking, is rather unfair.

Most of the details necessary to the unification of the Italian steamship lines as planned by the Fascist Government have been completed, and early next year the schedules of the newly created Italia Line, which is a combination of the Cosulich, Lloyd Sabaudo and Navigazione Generale Italiana will be in effect.

THE art of borne decoration in Germany -- as shown in several exhibitions this Summer -- is closely connected with housing provisions and new architectural plans for various types of dwellings and apartment homes. In the "Sun, Air and Room for All" exhibition in Berlin, there were displayed varied styles of mass-production houses whose interiors were carefully studied so that their furnishings might afford the greatest amount of convenience in the smallest amount of space.

JUST before Albert Coates, who came across the Atlantic this Summer to conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, sailed back to Europe, he left suggestion for American broadcasters. He said that radio needs more depth, color and direction, which he sums up as "more living sound."
HARBIN, Manchuria, Aug. 2 -- There has never been a place quite like North Manchuria.
WHAT a funny clock!" exclaimed Alice. "Why, it tells the years and months instead of the hours and minutes."

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Unless the world economic conference is allowed to discuss tariffs and war debts "it will be condemned in advance to failure," The London Times warns in a blunt, outspoken editorial today.

THE present state of worldwide depression and unrest had its origin in a complex of political, social and economic conditions so intricate that relief from its consequences can be effected only by the disinterested cooperative action of the different nations based upon the best counsel of their wisest and most experienced men.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Sheriff Ira McCloskey of Clearfield County announced tonight that a man describing himself as Garret Schenck, Hopewell (N.J.) fish merchant, is being quizzed in connection with the Lindbergh kidnapping case.

FIRPO MARBERRY of the Senators was casting a spell over the Yankee bats at the Stadium on Friday and a tall, hatless, sorrel-topped spectator in the grand stand was looklng at the performance with mild disapproval.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Abolition of the property tax in its present form led a list of recommendations made today to the United States Building and Loan League by its committee on home taxation.

All the markets reflected again yesterday the prevalent mood of hopefulness. Speculative interest was largely concentrated in stocks, in which there were further wide advances and extremely heavy dealings. In bonds the gains were more moderate.
JUST a half century ago, two young men in their early teens clogged their way to the front of the stage of a Bowery museum and sang:

ALBANY, Sept. 3 (AP) -- An opinion by Attorney General Bennett expresses the belief that Chief Judge Cuthbert W. Pound of the Court of Appeals, appointed by Governor Roosevelt, must run for election this Fall.

A SPECIOUS and colorful novel of New England and the West of a half century and more ago, this is the story of eight sisters, the Harts of Charlestown. Mass.; of their girlhoods, courtships, marriages and wedded lives over the period from pre-Civil War days into the mid-1870s.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Ray Benge kept nine Boston hits well scattered today and the Phillies defeated the Braves, 5 to 3. The Phils pounced on Ed Brandt in the fourth, bunch- ing four hits and two passes for four runs.

Thirty-six standing committees of the Merchants' Association of New York have been organized, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president, to carry on investigations and studies on which the association will base its recommendations and activities during the current, fiscal year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Wings, driven by Walter L. Haines of Atlantic City, won the free-for-all race for the Governor's Trophy at the Margate-Longport Speed Boat Association's South Jersey regatta today. A crowd of 10,000 saw Wings triumph at an average speed of 42 1/2 miles an hour.

MANCHESTER, vt. AS we all know, the woods these days are full of lawyers, doctors and retired business men who have taken up art-either modestly, on the side, or boldly, by way of a profession. To date the clergyman-artist is, comparatively, a rara avis.

The resignation of former Mayor Walker does not change the status of the fugitive Russell T. Sherwood, George Trosk, an associate of Samuel Seabury as counsel to the Hofstadter committee, said yesterday in response to inquiries.

CAIRO, Sept. 2 -- With much rejoicing genuine holiday spirit, accentuated by a brilliant pyrotechnical display and elaborate decorations, Cairo this week celebrated the symbolic ceremony of "the cutting of the Khalig," a ceremony unique in the entire world.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The West Harrison Independent Fire Company, which has been negotiating for several months in an effort to compel wealthy residents of Purchase to contribute funds in return for fire protection, announced today a professional benefit theatrical performance to be held in the Purchase Community House on Sept. 21, to which Lieut. Gov. Herbert Lehman and others have subscribed.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 3.--Miss Marion Durand of Rye today rode her chestnut gelding Norge to victory in the championship jumper class, one of the features of the twelve-event program of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club's first junior horse show.

SIDNEY FRANKLIN, Brooklyn's contribution to the bullfight arena, stopped off in Hollywood to give Samuel Goldwyn a few professional pointers for his bullfight scenes in Eddie Cantor's new comedy, "The Kid From Spain." Last week he arrived in New York, picked out a comfortable berth on a Spanish Royal Mail liner and generally gave the impression that he thought he was going to Barcelona to fight some new bulls.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Flying New York's airways in quest of the Republican nomination for Governor, F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War in charge of aeronautics, hopes to match the feat of his close friend and college chum. David S. Ingalls, Republican Gubernatorial candidate in Ohio.

HAVANA, Aug. 25 -- No settlement has yet been brought about of the conflict between the Medical Federation of Cuba and the mutual benefit societies of the island, which caused a walkout of the staffs of the hospitals of these societies on Aug. 18.

The Conference for Progressive Labor Action, formed three years ago as a synthesis of progressive labor elements to fight "reactionary" labor leadership, opened yesterday its "first official convention" at the Irving Plaza, Irving Place and Fifteenth Street, as a revolutionary organization, distinct from both Socialists and Communists and rooted in "American realities."
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 31 -- How to whittle boom-time governmental structures down to a depression tax rate is a problem harassing Indiana taxing officials these days.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The "price" of "selling out" the "prestige" of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to "booze-makers" was asked here today by the American Business Men's Prohibition Foundation in a second statement of challenge, following the open letter of its president, Richard H. Scott, addressed last week to Henry I. Harriman, president of the Commerce Chamber.

THE solar eclipse has come and gone and fifty scientific expeditions comprising about 200 professional observers are now packing up their instruments. For most of the expeditions the elaborate preparations had been made in vain. The sky was overcast from Canada almost to the Atlantic Coast.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Two dramatic ninth-inning home runs by Jimmy Foxx and Eric McNair today gave the Athletics a 4-3 victory and a clean sweep of the three games with the Boston Red Sox. Foxx, first up in the last inning, tied the score with his fifty-first home run, his second of the game, and McNair followed with his sixteenth homer.

Two big track and field meets are scheduled to be held in the city this week. The seventy-sixth annual meet of the New York Caledonian Club is scheduled at Ulmer Park in Brooklyn tomorrow afternoon and a victory meet in celebration of America's triumph in the Olympic Games will take place at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday afternoon under the auspices of the Wethered J. Boyd Council, Knights of Columbus.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Ray Ruddy of New York won the annual three-mile swin on the Potomac today for the sixth consecutive year. He stroked the distance in 1:15:49 3-5 and led his team, the New York A. C., into its seventh victory for the President's Cup, put up in 1924 by President Coolidge.

FORT HALL, famous trading station of the Northwest, considered by Ezra Meeker the most important point on the Oregon Trail, stood on the banks of the Snake River in the southern part of what is now the State of Idaho. It had a dramatic, a thrilling and a colorful history.

Judges for the annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 13, 14 and 15, 1933, were announced yesterday by John G. Bates, chairman of the bench show committee.

STANLEY HIGH, journalist and publicist, thinks that the most important and most immediate menace of war that now looms before the world rises out of conditions in the Far East. "All that has been needed in the past," he argues, ''to usher in catastrophe has been enough war machinery and enough of the war mind.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 25 I read with amazement the ridiculous and short-sighted point of view of Comrade Albert Coates, the head of all symphony societies of Soviets, who, after a fairly long engagement with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium, was indescribably surprised when told that there is a depression in America.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Due to the fact that the Great South Bay race week and cruise took away one of the Saturdays, it was necessary for the yacht racing squadron of the Westhampton Country Club to sail an extra race on Moriches Bay off the Speonk shore today.

LONDON WHERE Langland dreamed and brooded centuries ago, where Piers Plowman had his vision, Bernard Shaw dreams and prophesies today. He is the Monarch of the Malverns; beStriding the hills with a vigor that would make many people fifty years his junior footweary after a few hours, and holding court with his liege subjects in all kinds pf public places except public-houses.

MR. MILNE, essentially a bookman and best known, perhaps, as for some fifteen years literary editor of The Chronicle, has chosen for his latest work an engaging title which may give the reader expectations too large or vague for fulfillment.

LAKE PLACID -- Golfers entered for the various Labor Day events here and elsewhere throughout the region expect next season to play on the new eighteen-hole championship course now building at Whiteface Inn on Lake Placid as well as on the new eighteen-hole course of Paul Smith's Adirondack Club, just completed at Paul Smith's on the St. Regis chain of lakes.

PROBABLY at no time before the modem era, when art, in common with other phenomena, has become individual or universal rather than sectional, was European painting so united in character as during the late fourteenth and early fifteenth centuries.

A tendency for bank assets to become "frozen" as a result of the increasing indirectness of the banking processes in furnishing working funds to industry and commerce and the increasing directness in lending for purposes of providing fixed assets is described by the National Industrial Conference Board as having contributed to the high mortality of banking institutions in recent years.

SEVERAL local exhibitions opened last week at the Grand Central Galleries, too late to be reviewed here: Monotypes by Seth Hoffman, together with prints by Arthur E. Davies, John E. Costigan, George Tobin, Alfred Hutty and Margaret Law, and a group of etchings, "Children of the Slums," by Margery Ryerson.

The Eighth Avenue subway will begin revenue operation at 12:01 A.M. next Saturday, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. At that hour the twenty-eight stations along the twelve-mile route from Chambers Street to 207th Street will be opened to the public without formal ceremony.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Stockholders of the Waterbury Clock Company will vote on Wednesday on a proposal of James R. Sheldon of Waterbury to purchase $500,000 of preferred stock on conditions demanding a general reorganization. The company is in temporary receivership while efforts are being made to finance numerous large orders.

A New York City wrestles again with its budget problem, it becomes more and more apparent that the chief hope of any substantial saving in 1933 lies in a cut in salaries. How large do these loom in the budget, what services, do they cover, how are they fixed, and what are the "mandatory" provisions of which so much is heard?

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 3 -- An opening rush and a great rally in the seventh gave the first victory of the National Open Polo Championship today to the Aurora team led by Seymour H. Knox. Before a crowd of 6,000 on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club, Aurora turned back the Hurricanes, three times champions, 11 to 9.

New York Stock Exchange member firm borrowings in August amounted to $331,699,320, a gain of $90,139,377 over July, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. This was the first increase since March, the monthly figures since that time showing declines.

Several clashes occurred between Hugh Frayne, American Federation of Labor organizer in the East, and speakers from the floor last night at the conclusion of the first day's session of the eighth annual convention of the Federated Colored Catholics of the United States.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 3 -- The Norwood Country Club's polo teams staged a round robin today and the Yellow squad emerged victors over the Blues and Whites. The Yellows scored 9, the Whites 7 and the Blues 6.

Business and industrial leaders throughout the country have entered September with the brightest hopes in more than two years. With some gains already made, they are confident that a really sound basis for general improvement has been laid.

Citing a recent declaration of policy by the National Lead Company, Charles C. Faulding, vice president of the New York Central Lines, said yesterday that a "back to the rails" movement seemed to have started and that it should improve the purchasing power of the railroads.

BY authorizing a Bowdlerized edition of "Lady Chatterley's Lover," that novel by the late D.H. Lawrence which raised controversy on both sides of the Atlantic when it was originally published in Italy, the literary executors of the novelist have now made available to the general English-speaking public what proved to be Lawrence's final work of fiction.

FIFTY years ago men rode in horse-cars to and from their work and walked in gas-lit streets. What New York regarded as rapid transit was visible in steam-operated elevated trains with locomotives equipped with underslung pans to catch hot ashes and drippings.

MADRID, Sept. 3 -- That Mexico is finally willing to treat with the United States on the allotment of wave lengths to clear up radio interference in the United States from south of the Rio Grande is one of the outstanding developments of the first day of the International Radio and Telegraphic Conference, which was opened by Premier Azana this morning.

DETROIT. IT has been some time since the automobile business outlook has been regarded as meriting the adjective "brisk," but that is what one hears in various parts of the motor capital these days. The coming of Labor Day, traditional end of the Summer doldrum season, actually finds the outlook brighter than the industry expected.

Further strength was manifest yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation bonds continued their upward trend, and leading foreign loans were unusually strong, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of ten foreign issues mounting to a new high point for the year.

NOWHERE in America, except in Westchester County, N.Y., is education for "the impending era of leisure" being treated as a public problem, as it is in some of the Northern European countries, according to Dr. George Lundberg of Columbia University, who has just returned from an informal study of conditions abroad.

SKYLAND, Va., Sept. 3 -- In the quiet of his Rapidan mountain camp President Hoover gave word to his aides late today that his week-end was to be one of rest and that he planned to take part in none of the ceremonies commemorating Labor Day.
Business will be suspended In all of the financial centres tomorrow in observance of Labor Day. The security and commodity markets, as well as the banks, will be closed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 3 -- Jerane Storrs Ibershoff, 20 years old, a Smith College junior and a prominent Cleveland society girl, was murdered in the Pennine Alps in Switzerland on Thursday by a vagabond who stoned her to death, according to word received this morning by her mother, Mrs. A.E. Ibershoff of Cleveland Heights.

OTTAWA, Canada, Aug. 31 -- The second largest telescope in the world is being constructed at Newcastle-on-Tyne, England, for service in a Canadian observatory. This observatory is being constructed a few miles north of Toronto as a memorial to the late David A. Dunlap, through funds contributed by his widow and son, and it will be administered by the Department of Astronomy of the University of Toronto.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Defeat of the proposed charter amendment limiting the general property tax to $61,000.000 this year, and reducing it another million in four succeeding years, means that the economy plans perfected by Mayor Frank Murphy and his advisers in June, and made effective at the beginning of the fiscal year July 1, will remain in force.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Thirty-six boats in four classes raced today in the weekly regatta of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club.

When Mrs. John Van Ryn, the former Miss Marjorie Gladman of California, sails on Oct. 5 with her husband, the famous Davis Cup star, and three other leading players who are to tour Australia and several other countries, she will be the first American woman tennis player of high ranking to invade the antipodes in many years.

AMONG the art colonies here about, the end of the Summer season is high. Several of the shows have closed ere this; some are scheduled to conclude tomorrow. Others have yet a little time to run. For the benefit particularly of those who may be planning for this holiday week-end excursions to or through the various near by places in which Summer exhibitions are being held, the following notes have been prepared:

ONE contemplates the scheme of Mr. Saunders's book with wondering curioslty, what can he do in a little more than 200 pages with a theme so vast and so complicated? For his purpose is to study the civilizations of India, China and Japan, to link together as Asia's cultural heritage the life streams of the three and to view their combined contributions to world culture in their present significance.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- Easing of the political tension which for months had-cakened the financial community's confidence in the stability of the German Government, caused another boom at today's Boerse session. For many years the market has not displayed such a strong tone on a Saturday.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 3 -- A sharp protest was made today by the Japanese military authorities here against the manner in which International Settlement policemen handled two truckloads of Japanese marines yesterday when they nearly clashed with a mob of Chinese on the Bund, one of this city's busiest thoroughfares.

CHANCHUN, Manchuria, Aug. 10, -- Establishment of a network of automobile roads to supplement Manchuria's already extensive railway facilities is proposed as one of the key projects in the comprehensive development program launched by the young government of Manchukuo.

40,000,000 Delinquent Acres. five States -- Michigan, Minnesota, South Dakota, Oregon and Wisconsin -- had 40,000,000 acres of land de linquent for taxes at the end of 1931. As their total population is about 12,000,000, it makes three and one-third acres per person delinquent. Pennsylvania has about 10,000,000 people, and it it had a proportionate acreage delinquent, Would have 33,000,000 acres, or 5,000,000 more acres delinquent for taxes than the whole State contains.

WHEN Englishmen write books on American history, the result, whether the book is good or indifferent, is likely to be provocative. They bring distinct opinions and a new perspective to the task. By formal standards this is not a very good book.

The basis for a strong revival of purchasing of textile products exists at the present time, The Textile Organon, published by the Tubize Chatillon Company, asserted yesterday, citing numerous instances of how purchasing power has been increased by stock and commodity gains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- There were improvements in some countries covered by the current weekly survey of business conditions abroad made by the Department of Commerce, while in others the pace continued slow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, gave an interview today setting forth the policies of the Federation in the present political campaign. Mr. Green also discussed some of the issues and the political and economic conditions of the day.

HOLLYWOOD THE rush of pictures continues in the studios. In the greatest production spurt in the last three years, Hollywood is assured of a minimum of four months of capacity shooting which may, or may not, herald the end of the depression.

Notes and Oddments. Man's highly perfected digestive machine, says one British scientist, releases his energies for mental progress. SHAKESPEARE, according to this theory, wrote "Hamlet" because he did not have to spend all day absorbing beefsteak into his body cells.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Pigeon Hole, the 7-year-old gelded son of Hollister and Pigeon Pie, easily captured the Olympia Fields Purse before 15,000 at the opening of the Lincoln Fields race track today. It was his seventh victory in succession.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept, 1 -- Completion of the first season of training by a fully manned and equipped regiment of mechanized cavalry was one of several activities which during the last year have claimed for Fort Knox, which is thirty miles from Louisville, the interest or the entire country.

GERMANY demands in principle the same rights as other nations with regard to her army structure, its organization and division among different types of arms, its equipment with arms, the fortification of our frontiers and arms manufacture.

ALTHOUGH film producers are justified in taking advantage of the searching eye of the camera in their versions of novels and plays, it is a great mistake to dilute the story, which, unfortunately, happens all too frequently.

PARIS, Aug. 20 THE theatrical season is well over. Only eight of the Paris theatres -- excluding music halls and suburban houses -- are open, and the Comedie-Francaise itself was closed for four days in the middle of the month for structural alterations.
QUEBEC, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Captain James A. Mollison sailed for home today aboard the liner Empress of Britain.

Elimination of many rental and sale signs and a general agreement covering the rental of exterior wall space for advertising is projected for the Pennsylvania zone by the Penn Zone Property Owners' Association, Samuel Kheel, its president, announced yesterday.

INTEREST in the problem of proper stopping distances for motor vehicles was stimulated recently by a new regulation issued by Police Commissioner Mulrooney. This was to the effect that the handbrake on an automobile or truck should be able, by itself, to stop the vehicle in fifty feet at twenty miles per hour.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Activity in tex- tiles and allied industries continued to be the feature of the New England business situation this week. The volume of wool sold in the Boston market in August was larger than in any month in a number of years. Prices continue strong and are now 25 to 30 per cent above recent lows.

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, CLEVELAND, Sept. 3.--Major James H. Doolittle established a world's land plane speed record here at noon today. Flying the Wasp-powered GeeBee racer from which he has obtained such tremendous speeds in the last three days at the National Air Races, he averaged 296.287 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Production of crude petroleum throughout the United States in July totaled 66,310,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,139,000 and a reduction of 22,000 barrels from the daily average of the preceding month, the Commerce Department announced today.
To the Dramatic Editor: The August Forum printed an article by Lee Simonson which is most encouraging. It presents an entirely new idea and should go far to save the American theatre.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Many members of the Summer colsny, with holiday guests, and visitors from adjacent towns, attended the large street fair in aid of the Southampton Unemployment Fund which was held this afternoon and evening in Pond Lane and Agawam Park.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 2 -- How long the present Karolyi Government will choose to remain in power has become a matter of speculation since Monday's defeat of its Minister of Agriculture in a by-election in Mezocsat by Tibor von Eckhardt, who is the most active force in the small landowners' party, headed by Gaszton Gaal.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The political unrest which is believed behind the resignation of President Ortiz Rubio had its immediate beginning in a dispute between the President's brother Francisco, and Vicente Estrada Cajigal, then Governor of the federal district of Mexico City.

ALTHOUGH Bear Mountain has been a playground for motorists from New York City for several years, there doubtless are many who have but a superficial knowledge of the beautiful wild park lands that adjoin it to the westward. Here, among the wooded mountains and sparkling lakes of the Harriman section of the Palisades Interstate Park, are to be seen some of the finest panoramas in the State.

W.R. BURNETT wrote an unusual novel of dramatic action, realistic in detail, in "Little Caesar." He followed it with a lesser work, "Iron Man," but a first-rate prizefight story. His third book was a "Western," which is better forgotten.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 3 -- A 19-year-old Baltimore taxi driver, Philip Jachelski, won the 50,000meter national championship walk today from a field of fifty-five entries, who started under a blistering sun.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in a pre-Labor Day statement said yesterday there was not so much promise for industrial betterment in the country in the "long-range future" as in the immediate present, declaring that "industry has thus far done but little to put its house on a solid foundation."

INSPIRING as are new records for speed, such as Captain James G. Haizlip's splendid dash across the continent in 10 hours 19 minutes last week, their chief interest, after all, lies in the possibility of converting the lessons of plane and motor design which they teach to the uses of everyday aviation.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Fearing that Vice President Curtis might be heckled because of his dry stand, Philadelphia Republican leaders, it was revealed today, have suggested to Edward Martin, State chairman, that a speaker of "wetter" tendencies, such as Secretary Mills, be substituted for him as the keynote orator for the party's Pennsylvania campaign.

The "religious depression" resulting from lack of religious education is a far greater problem today than the business depression, said the Rev. Henry Hammer in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The Bears made a clean sweep of their series with the Albany Senators today when they took both games of a double-header, 5 -- 1 and 5 -- 4.

A feature that will enlist several airplanes is being arranged for the marine pageant entitled "Marineo-scope," to be held Saturday night at the Sands Point Bath Club for the benefit of the Nassau Speedwell Unit. Flying in formation over Port Washington Harbor and Long Island Sound, the planes will converge over the club in the glare from a battery of searchlights.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The week's moderate rise of 37,000,000 francs in the gold reserve at the Bank of France was probably due to release of gold previously earmarked at Paris for account of some European bank. Commenting on the slight decrease of 8,000,000 in the bank's foreign exchange holdings, well-informed bankers do not expect any great alteration in that item during coming weeks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 4 -- In the presence of some of the world's leading astronomers, Sir Frank Dyson, astronomer royal of Great Britain, president of the International Astronomical Union, now in session here, laid the cornerstone for the main building of the new Oak Ridge station of the Harvard College Observatory this afternoon.

MT. VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- In a tense match featured by spectacular shot-making, Jess Sweetser and Tom Kerrigan defeated Jerry Travers and George Voigt, 3 and 2, in an eighteen-hole four-ball exhibition match at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Increasing trade activity in commodities and advances in securities and cotton are gradually influencing grain prices and farm products in general. The upward movement is irregular and is expected to continue so for the next two months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your occasional editorials upon certain homely subjects are a delight. How we chuckled over the dissertation on blueberry pie, and now comes the one on eating out-of-doors, with its valuable hints as to the proper ritual.

Sara Teasdale, who is writing a biography of Christina Rossetti, writes to her publishers, The Macmillan Company, that she has been following the trail of Christina in England. Miss Teasdale went to Cambridge for its associations with Charles Cayley, to whom Christina's later love poems were addressed.

SKYLAND, Va., Sept. 4 -- Back from a western tour of more than two months, Ray Lyman Wilbur, Secretary of the Interior, gave President Hoover today an account of political and business conditions as he found them in his travels.

Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, arch-foe of Tammany and an independent Democrat, will be proposed as a fusion candidate for Mayor to run against James J. Walker, it was disclosed last evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The body of William H. Berger of New York City was brought to Chicago today from Newcastle, Ind., where he died Saturday in a hospital, following an auto- mobile upset on Wednesday in which his daughter, June, 7 years old, was killed and his wife, Addie, was injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Senator Claude A. Swanson of Virginia, chairman of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, suggested in a letter to Senator Howell of Nebraska today that the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, of which the latter is chairman, should investigate the controversy between the Republican National Committee and Thomas A. Johnson of Boston over a $25,000 check which Mr. Johnson mailed to the committee in the latter part of 1931.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The fight waged by railroad labor in the last session of Congress against elevating Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson to the Circuit Court of Appeals apparently will be pursued with equal vigor this Winter in the event -- as is probable -- that President Hoover resubmits the nomination.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 4. -- Miss Barbara Stoddard, second daughter of Major Louis E. Stoddard, long time president of the United States Polo Association, and granddaughter of the late Henry Darlington of Pittsburgh, attained her majority today and came into possession of the estate inherited from her mother, Rebecca Darlington Stoddard.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Fadian Kowalik, White Sox rookie, was unable to hold the Browns in the first game of today's doubleheader, St. Louis winning, 7 to 5, but Paul Gregory allowed only six safe blows in the aftermath, and Chicago won, 5 to 1.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- Sentiment in business circles and on the Boerse this week was wholly under the influence of the Cabinet's scheme to reanimate industry. The plan of State subsidies to productive enterprise, whereby the Reich, although penniless, provides industry almost immediately with a large sum of cash as an unrepayable gift, has naturally excited controversy.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 -- The steel trade seems to be as confident of a marked upturn in steel demand as it has been at any other time since the middle of July, when sentiment began to swing to the favorable side. No concern is shown over the failure of production to increase to date.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Twenty-Ninth Division Association at its closing business session today passed resolutions condemning President Hoover for his action in the expulsion of the Bonus Expeditionary Forces from Washington.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 3 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 62.5, which compares with 61.9 a week ago, 61.8 two weeks ago, 61.9 three weeks ago, and 61.1 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date was 66.3 in the first week of January.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Three women were instantly killed, one man was fatally injured and eight other persons were more or less seriously injured in one of the worst automobile accidents ever to occur in this district when two cars, one driven at an excessive rate of speed, met head-on this afternoon at a spot on the Albany Post Road about five and a half miles south of this village.

Nine years after the tragic but glorious failure of MALLORY and IRVINE to gain the summit of Mount Everest, another British expedition will make an attempt to conquer the highest mountain in the world.
