It will go out to India under the auspices of the Royal Geographical Society and the Alpine Club.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Pastime an Atlantic Class sloop owned by Donald Agnew, won the thirteenth annual handicap Stratford Shoal yacht race, which finished today. The event, conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, started at 9:40 last night and attracted a total of forty-eight entries.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 4 -- Senator William E. Borah expects to make several speeches discussing the economic situation and prohibition within the next few weeks, it was learned today. In response to requests from various sources, he plans to continue the discussion begun in his Minneapolis speech Aug. 3, in which he called for a settlement of war debts and reparations as essential to recovery.

From the time it began operations in January to Sept. 1, the Railroad Credit Corporation made $30,937,199 available to railroads for the meeting of interest payments, according to the monthly report of the organization to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Extension of long-term credits to Soviet Russia, as well as the removal of other obstacles, will be necessary if the United States is to compete with the nations of Europe for Russian trade, Peter A. Bogdanov, Soviet agent in America, said yesterday in a radio address over Station WOR.
LAREDO, Texas, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The raging Rio Grande carried its threat to life and property south of here today after causing possibly ten or fifteen deaths and enormous damage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Jesse W. Nicholson, president of the National Woman's Democratic Law Enforcement League, made public today a letter to Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, protesting against a request which she said had been made for a contribution to help to re-elect President Hoover.

Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the local army corps area, advocated printing the story of the American Expeditionary Force in a form available to the public, so it would know what was accomplished overseas during the World War in the course of an address last night at the annual dinner of the Society of the Fifth Division in the Hotel New Yorker.

A call to save fish and water fowl menaced by the drought of the past few weeks was issued yesterday by the American Game Association. Though Federal aid and that of State conservation departments has been sought and obtained, the work is so big that the appeal has been made to individual sportsmen, who, it is believed, can do tremendous good it they will act at once.

New York was almost a deserted city yesterday. The greater part of its population, taking advantage of the week-end and Labor Day, joined the exodus for shore and mountain resorts which set in Friday and continued until late Saturday night. But with heat and humidity vying to make the stay-at-homes as uncomfortable as possible, a goodly part abandoned their plans for a restful Sunday and trailed along in the wake of the shore-bound crush.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Federal, State and county investigators tonight are pondering the long story of Garret Schenck, 46, Hopewell (N.J.) fish peddler, who says he was held captive by a private detective for seventy-six days following the Lindbergh kidnapping.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4. -- The growing encroachment of government into the field of liberty constitutes a serious threat to this country, and if we are to keep government within its proper limits we must forestall conditions that tempt it to try further invasion, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said here tonight in an address at the Parrish Art Museum.

CLEVELAND AIRPORT, Sept. 4 -- A line storm coming up with the speed of a gale, enveloped four women pilots this afternoon at the national air races while they were striving for the highest prize for their sex on the program, the Aerol Trophy and purses amounting to $5,000.

Four Negroes were burned to death, five others were injured and seven firemen overcome by smoke when flames swept a five-story tenement at 53 East 104th Street early yesterday morning. Three of the dead were members of one family.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Eight skillful criminals perpetrated one of the most sensational and lucrative robberies in Chicago's history early this morning when they fled with cash estimated at $1,000,000 taken from safe deposit boxes, after seizing an entire building and holding ten persons, including two children, prisoners for fourteen hours.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 4 -- Divisional General Abelardo Rodriguez was named Provisional President of the republic today at a plenary session of Congress, composed of 150 deputies and forty-five senators. The resolution of election was unanimously adopted and the new executive took the oath of office at once.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Thrashing easily through cresttopped seas, raised by a snorting southerly breeze, Miss Susan Robertson of the Women's Swimming Association of New York won the national A.A.U. senior long-distance swimming championship decided at Jones Beach under the auspices of the Long Island State Park Commission today.

The 175th anniversary of the birth of Marquis de Lafayette in 1757 and the eighteenth anniversary of the beginning of the first Battle of the Marne in 1914 will be observed in various parts of the country tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the Lafayette Day National Committee at 44 Wall Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4 -- Great activity and wide fluctuations in prices were prominent in the cotton contract market here last week. New high marks for the season were reached on Monday, when the October traded as high as 9.48 cents a pound and December at 9.66, or 435 and 437 points respectively above the season's low levels, reached on June 10, or an advance of approximately $21.50 a bale.

Ten lifeboat crews from as many ship lines are scheduled to face the starter's gun at 11 A.M. today for the sixth international lifeboat race under the auspices of the Neptune Association of New York. The boats will line up outside the Narrows off Fort Wadsworth and the finish will be off the pier at Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Edison Hedges of Atlantic City drove his motor boat. Flying Eagle, to the national 125 cubic inch championship today in the third and concluding ten-mile heat of the title contest. Hedges secured second place in the final run, first place going to Joe Bartlett's Wooden Horse, which had previously obtained a second and third place.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church South declared tonight that he had not decided how he would cast his vote in the Presidential election in November.

With Fred Waring and his orchestra, the Pennsylvanians, at the Palace, and with Morton Downey and Georges Carpentier headlining at Loew's State, both of the Times Square vaudeville houses have assembled special bills to support their feature pictures during Labor Day week.

The fiftieth anniversary of a new electrical era, which began when Thomas A. Edison opened the first commercial electric lighting and generating plant in the world at 257 Pearl Street, was commemorated yesterday afternoon with simple ceremonies on the site of the original plant.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- More than 5,000 representatives and delegates of the Companions of the Forest, a national women's welfare organization, gathered here today to inspect the Annie E. Poth Home for aged and convalescent members of the organization.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The most significant contribution that could be made to the economic life of the nation at present, according to Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, is preparation for the next depression ahead.

The "Labor Day message" issued by the Commission on the Church and Social Service of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America was criticized as not in line with the method and principles of Christ in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Harrison Rockwell at the Little Church Around the Corner, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Cooperation between capital and labor, special justice and deeper impregnation of our social system with the spirit of religion were some of the elements of a better social order emphasized yesterday in sermons at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where Labor Sunday was celebrated with services in the morning and afternoon.

NEW CASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, Sept. 4 -- The sixty-fourth Trades Union Congress which meets here tomorrow is likely to prove the most important in the organization's history. It will have to shape a new industrial and fiscal policy amid the clamor of those determined to air many industrial grievances.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Crooning has been recognized by the Worcester Music Festival. Instructions to the festival chorus to learn to croon have been given by Albert Stoessel, director.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4 -- The presentation of "Incidents in the Life of the Empress Eugenie," by Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner, daughter of Otis Skinner, the actor, at Guild Hall tonight was witnessed by a large gathering of Summer residents and their guests.
The following editorial is printed in today's issue of The New York American under the heading "Walker's unjustifiable attack on Roosevelt."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Rochester scored three runs after two were out in the final inning of the second game to triumph by 8 to 7, after losing the first 4 to 3, to the Montreal Royals today.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Stephen Guerin, 70 years old, was murdered with an axe in the barn of his farm on the road between Brook-side and Mendham near here today, and his niece, Miss Bessie Guerin, 23, was wounded seriously by shots fired by an assailant who the police believe was demented.

MEXIA, Texas, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A 14-inch rain in this section today washed out several stretches of railway track, marooned a trainload of excursionists here and sent the Navasota River to flood stage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- A steady return of confidence, a decided increase in buying of all classes of merchandise and raw materials, more jobs for the unemployed and an occasional mention of a small increase in wages marked the course of business last week.

ELBERON, N.J., Monday, Sept. 5 -- David Burnstine was in the lead in the individual masters' contract bridge championship of the American Bridge League at the close of play at the Deal Club here early this morning. With 120 of the 150 boards scheduled for the event completed, he had accumulated 327 1/2 match points.

President BUTLER'S Southampton address on the eve of Labor Day has come to be a September event to which a larger audience than the local colony looks forward. This year he discusses an old theme with fresh illustration. It has to do with the keeping of Government "within the limits which it can "successfully occupy and to which "we are accustomed," and with the responsibilities of the people in the sphere of Liberty.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians and the Detroit Tigers battled rain and darkness in a scheduled double-header today, the Indians winning the first game, 11 to 3. The second was called with one out in the fourth and the score tied, 3 to 3.

Traffic along the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad was badly disrupted for more than three hours late yesterday afternoon and last night by the derailment of the electric locomotive of a New York bound Atlantic City express just west of the New Jersey entrance to the Hudson River tunnel leading to the Pennsylvania station.

Approximately 6,500,000 employes of 30,000 business and industrial organizations are now covered by about $10,500,000,000 of group life insurance, according to a Labor Day statement given out by William J. Graham, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in charge of this type of insurance.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- An international conference will start at Stresa on Lake Maggiore tomorrow which will seek means to relieve the financial distress of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The conference has no treaty-making powers but is merely a kind of committee of experts charged with reporting to the European Union Commission at Geneva on two problems:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Francis Hartman Markoe gave a large buffet supper and musicale tonight at his residence in Water Mill for Mr. and Mrs. William C.T. Gaynor, whose marriage took place last Wednesday. Mrs. Gaynor is the former Miss Primrose Whitfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Whitfield of New York and Cluny Lodge, Southampton.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Three United States consular officers were captured by brigands near Kermanshah, Persia, last Thursday night, but were rescued late today by Persian troops, according to information reaching the United States Legation at Teheran.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Although somewhat hampered by the "graduation" of several of its star players, the Sing Sing varsity football squad is making preparations for what is expected to be its most successful season since last season, it was announced here today by Warden Lewis E. Lawes.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Buffalo routed Toronto, 15 -- 6, as Ray Schalk Day was celebrated today.

In Labor Day messages issued yesterday from their campaign headquarters, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, and Louis D. Waldman, the party's Gubernatorial nominee, called for the support of American labor, declaring that neither the Republican nor Democratic parties or their candidates were to be trusted by the workers.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 4 -- Olin Dutra, the towering star from Santa Monica, Cal., captured the national professional golf title at the Keller course today, climaxing one of the most remarkable campaigns in the ancient game's history.

BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 4 -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of Aug. 31, as made public here today. Figures are in Swiss francs at par, 19.3 cents.

Abrupt renewal of the rise in stocks and bonds, after a three-day halt which could hardly be described as definite reaction, awakened fresh conjecture. So prompt a return to the forward movement was hardly expected even by Wall Street. It might mean only that the recent departure from reasonable intrinsic values had not yet been corrected.
The house at 223 East Sixty-second Street has been leased furnished by Mrs. Gladys Billings to Mrs. E.N. Stone through Louis Carreau, Inc., broker.

A cablegram from Pope Pius XI bestowing his blessing was read yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral at a special mass attended by almost 4,000 Negroes. The mass featured the eighth annual convention of the Federated Colored Catholics of the United States, which will close a three days' session here tonight.
The New York Americans inflicted a crushing 6-to-1 defeat upon the New York Giants in the first soccer clash of the season between the local rivals at Starlight Park yesterday before 2,000 persons.

THE big case scheduled for the Forest Hills supreme court this week is Vines v. Cochet, on appeal. There is an outside chance, of course, that it may never come to trial. It may be removed from the calendar on a writ of supersedeas waved defiantly by some other contestant. But until that happens, the Vines-Cochet case will be the subject of much legal and extra-legal debate.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4 -- The grain markets strengthened here last week on unfavorable reports of crops in the Northern Hemisphere which coincided with unfavorable weather in Argentina and heavy damage by locusts. The improvement in prices was due almost entirely to improvement in United States and European markets, as the demand here was inactive and exports were light.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Herbert Dowsett's Hula Star of the Pearl Harbor Yacht Club of Honolulu led the Barnegat Bay fleet of international star class sloops today in the second race of the fourth annual Bamberger trophy series. Her margin was more than 12 minutes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Trade sentiment on corn is more divided. Heavy receipts and large stocks have created a bearish feeling among a considerable percentage of the trade. They predict that September will decline to a carrying charge discount under December and that eventually there will be carrying charges from December to May.

The five-game Colyer trophy series between the Governors Island four and the First Division polo team of Fort Hamilton ended yesterday on the Governors Island field with the home team overcoming a four-goal handicap to vanquish the visiting players by 11 to 8 in a game witnessed by 2,000 enthusiasts.

TOKYO, Sept. 4 -- Captain Wolfgang von Gronau and his three companions, who are flying leisurely around the world from Germany, completed their passage of the bleak north Pacific islands today at 3:35 P.M. (1:35 A.M. Eastern Standard Time) when they alighted at Lake Kasumigaura, the Japanese naval base near Tokyo.

"McCooey in Strategic Position" runs a headline. That is understatement. The boss of Brooklyn has it within his power, should the courts hold that JAMES J. WALKER is eligible to run for Mayor again on Nov. 8, to deal a terrific blow nationally to the Democratic party, with which he, titularly at least, affiliates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The selection of General Rodriguez for the Presidency of Mexico is regarded here as bright with promise for the immediate future of that country and for increasing good relations between Mexico and the United States.

Obtaining deliveries in practically all lines of merchandise was a matter of prime concern to buyers operating in the wholesale markets here last week. Retailers found their early purchases insufficient and hastened to place increased orders for immediate shipment for many kinds of goods.
NEW YORK. Ralph B. Strassburger of Paris, who has been at the Waldorf-Astoria, has gone to his country place at Gwynned Valley, Pa.

With Babe Ruth seated on the sidelines nursing a bruised toe, and some 10,000 sympathizers resting peacefully in the stands, the Yankees opposed the Red Sox at the Stadium yesterday and expended little energy in demonstrating the disparity between the playing merits of a team that will soon enter a world's series and one that is hopelessly embedded in the cellar.

TOKYO, Sept. 4 -- The special session of the Japanese Diet, called to deal with emergency relief measures, ended tonight after the government had succeeded in passing most of its measures without change.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 4 -- Religious education has not made expected progress, according to a report announced today at Yale University by Drs. Hugh Hartshorne and J. Quinter Miller, the former a member of the research department of Yale Divinity School and the latter general secretary of the Connecticut Council of Religious Education.
Last week's business in the wholesale markets was notable for the sustained strength in the grains, cotton, rubber, silk, hides, copper and zinc.

PEIPING, Sept. 4 -- Sitting on the balcony of the German Hospital here and surrounded by white-robed nurses and physicians, members of the League of Nations investigation commission at a simple ceremony at 8 o'clock this morning signed two copies of their 400-page report on Manchuria.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Although all the Cabinet Ministers were out of town today and nothing definite happened here regarding Germany's demand for equality in armaments, it is quite evident that this morning's show of military force by the Steel Helmet (war veterans) organization in Berlin has made the situation more difficult to handle.

Adjustment of the machine to higher social purposes rather than to the ambition and desire of a few for accumulation of wealth at the expense of the many is the great problem confronting modern industrial civilization, declared the Rev. Charles B. Ackley in a sermon yesterday at St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th Street.
A purchase money mortgage for $1,000 was given by Secondo J. Borasio to Helen H. Gilmore on the south side of 91st St., 239 feet west of Columbus Av., subject to a first mortgage for $13,500.

In a recent biography of Colonel RICHARD MENTOR JOHNSON, the Kentuckian who did or did not kill TECUMSEH at the Battle of the Thames and was Vice President under VAN BUREN, there is an account of an interview between him and Old Hickory.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Its picket lines no longer blocking market-bound trucks, the farmers' "selling holiday" this week reaches the conference stage.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Government moved today to consolidate its collectivization farm gains by decreeing that peasants leaving collectives could not regain the land they contributed to the communal enterprise.

Christianity cannot face change and disturbance, outbreaks of radicalism and revolutionary thought and action with the careless optimism that sings "God's in His Heaven; all's right with the world," the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- With Governor Roosevelt resting for a brief week-end after his first New England campaign trip, former Governor Smith loomed today as one of the key figures in the fight to capture the electoral votes of Northeastern industrial States.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- Their powerful speed boats tuned up again, Gar Woed and Kaye Don tonight grave official notice that they were ready for the second Harms-worth Trophy race tomorrow on Lake St. Clair.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee made it clear yesterday in an interview at his Summer home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., that paring the city's budget was only one phase of a general program of administrative improvement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 4 -- A resolution favoring immediate payment of the bonus to veterans of the World War, but disapproving the activities of the Bonus. Expeditionary Force at Washington, was passed this afternoon at a business session of the Jewish War Veterans of America, assembled here at their annual convention.

A new policy of pier construction and rental, in which the city instead of the lessee would finance the construction of all pier sheds and limit pier leases to a maximum of five years, is recommended by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie in a statement to the Mayor on department matters.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S speech at Bridgeport on Saturday took up for discussion several subjects in which Connecticut has almost as keen a concern as has New York. Both States are wrestling with questions of retrenchment and relief of the taxpayers.

We trust that ex-Mayor WALKER will not think it an intrusion on the privacy to which he has retired with the ready assent of the public, if his attention is called to a slip which he inadvertently made in his attack upon the Governor. After accusing Mr. ROOSEVELT of the grossest unfairness and injustice, he bitterly alleged that the Governor was moved only by "political expediency."

The thoroughbreds come back to the metropolitan area today with the opening of the Autumn meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park. The running of the $2,500 added Fall High-weight Handicap is the feature today. The twelve-day meeting will close on Sept. 17, but in that interval will be contested some of the most important stake events in American racing history.

Led by Ernie Riedel, international double-blade champion, the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York scored twenty-four points to win the annual Labor Day regatta of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association at the Knickerbocker Canoe Club on the Hudson River yesterday.

When Governor ROOSEVELT at Sea Girt referred to Mr. HOOVER'S remarks on prohibition as "pussycat words" he was gravely rebuked by a section of the Republican press. This language was unworthy, he was told, when employed against the President of the United States.

In an exchange of pistol shots early yesterday morning Patrolman John Meenan of the West Forty-seventh Street station killed one robbery suspect and seriously wounded another on Tenth Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Bingham were hosts at a large dinner with music at their home, Hopedene. About fifty guests were present at the dinner and others came in later for the music.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- In a game held up for an hour and twenty-five minutes by a downpour and finished in the rain, Washington defeated the second-place Athletics today, 8 to 6.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Three small children lost after nightfall in a swampy thicket two miles from their homes here covered themselves with leaves, said their prayers and went to sleep. They were found at 4 o'clock this morning by a searching party.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- More than 100,000 Steel Helmet men, German veterans of the World War and younger men trained by them, paraded today on Tempelhof Air Field As many spectators, men and women, cheered them and that German unity for which they stand.
BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A double by Bob Holland, recruit left fielder, with the bases full and two out scored two runs in the last of the ninth to give the Braves a victory over the Phillies today.
The most celebrated amateur tennis player in the world will step out on the centre court of the Forest Hills Stadium for the first time in four years this afternoon.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4 -- Many entertainments were given for week-end and holiday visitors in Berkshire. The final chamber music concert arranged by Willem Willeke at Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's Temple of Music on South Mountain. Pittsfield, attracted a company of 500 this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The educational service rendered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and other newspapers in connection with the eclipse is of inestimable value. On the afternoon of Aug. 31 I stood with several hundred other watchers upon a hilltop in New Hampshire.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- An excess of cattle of common to medium grades and a scarcity of fancy to finished steers made a peculiar market here last week. Fancy steers were readily taken at $9.85 to $10 a hundredweight, while the other grades met an indifferent call and most steers sold within a range of $6 to $8, with the close at $5.50 to $7.50, the best of the general run bringing up to $9.
BELLPORT, L.I., Sept. 4 -- In the second of the three-day invitation regatta of the Bellport Yacht Club today, sixty-seven boats took part.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Harvesting of Spring wheat in the Canadian Northwest made good progress last week and most estimates are for 450,000, 000 bushels in the Provinces of Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba, compared with 384,000,000 bushels harvested last year and an average of 404,000,000 from 1926 through 1930.
Real estate transactions reported in New Jersey over the week-end indicate a good demand for housing properties in scattered areas.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Pirates played their last game of the season in Cincinnati today and defeated the Reds, 5 to 2.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The rise in commodity prices, which has now been in progress throughout the world for a series of weeks, is now attracting -wide attention. It is generally agreed that the movement has reached a stage where it may be described as general and emphatic.

The Story of a Tractor. Not every Plan is to be accepted as being, by definition, a model of inspired thinking and magnificent execution. Mr. DURANTY, writing from Moscow about the grave food shortage, says that the peasants are slow in bringing in the harvest and sowing for Autumn, and one reason is the lack of horses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democracy of the Empire State is asking itself if the Republican claim, "that the tendency of Democrats to upset the apple-cart just when the apples are almost within their grasp," is to be tragically demonstrated in the bickering within the party over its Gubernatorial candidate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Lon Warneke won his twentieth victory of the season today as he shut out the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 to 0, and ended the Chicago Cubs' home stay with the eighteenth triumph in twenty games. Warneke allowed only three hits, all singles.
TOKYO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The third special session of the Japanese Diet this year ended late tonight after appropriations had been made for the relief of farmers, fishermen and small merchants.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Cornelius Shields piloted his Aileen to victory in the Sound Interclub Class race, feature event of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's special regatta on Long Island Sound off here today. Twenty-three craft, divided into five classes, competed.
A consistent offensive by its batsmen gave the New York A.C. nine a 9-to-6 victory yesterday over the Englewood Field Club before a large holiday crowd at Travers Island.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 5.Closely contested races marked the thirty-third annual speed boat regatta conducted in Great Egg Harbor Bay today by the Ocean City Yacht Club.

New public financing in the United States in the first eight months of this year, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal bonds, amounted to only $441,121,000, according to a compilation announced by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of National Statistical Service, Inc.

Typical but Not Unrivaled. Following the retirement of AL CAPONE to a life of meditatlon at Government expense, Chicago herself seemed to withdraw from the fierce red light that beats up from the underworld.

Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter committee, whom prominent Republicans had suggested as a fusion candidate for Mayor to run against James J. Walker, will not consent to be drafted as a candidate, it was disclosed yesterday.
The New York A.C. baseball team took an easy 8-to-5 victory from the Fordham Lyceum nine yesterday at Travers Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Encouraged by a pledge of support from the United States Building Loan League, the board of directors of the Home Loan Bank System returned to Washington today to make final plans for a $134,000,000 stock-selling campaign.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 5. -- Eighty delegates representing fifteen European countries gathered today at this resort on the shores of Lake Maggiore for the opening session of a conference designed to unscramble the economic tangle in Central Europe.

Prompt action by the city to obtain Federal court consent to intervene in the pending I.R.T. receivership proceedings was urged upon Mayor McKee yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, at a three-hour conference in the Mayor's Summer home in Mamaroneck.

WAYCROSS, Ga., Sept. 5. -- The discovery of a possible means of eliminating sap stain, popularly known as blue stain, from pine paper pulp, was revealed hare today by Dr. Charles Herty, New York scientist.
The Society of the Fifth Division, Veterans of the World War, conclud- ed its three-day convention yesterday with the annual meeting of the or- ganization at Fort Jay, Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Farm Board's definite plan as to its wheat and cotton stocks was made public after a week of negotiations between the board and the Reconstruction Corporation following announcement that the corporation had allotted $50,000,000 as a loan to enable the cotton to be withheld.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Sept. 6. -- Immediately on the heels of the departure from China of the members of the League of Nations inquiry commission on Manchuria, seventy Chinese guilds issued a declaration today inviting all Chinese merchants to join in making effective "the economic blockade against Japan which is provided in the League's covenant."

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, Cleveland, Sept. 5. -- Major James H. Doolittle won the 100-mile Thompson Trophy race here this afternoon with an average speed of 252.686 miles an hour, while this morning Mrs. Mae Haizlip of St. Louis broke the world's land plane speed record for women with a speed of 255.513 miles an hour.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- At one of the largest Labor Day outings ever held in this State the Republican, Democratic and Socialist candidates for United States Senator in this region delivered campaign addresses here today in Olympic Park. Their audience, composed mainly of trades union members from Northern New Jersey, numbered more than 15,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Newark baseball fandom's nineteen-year wait for a championship team was ended today when the Bears won both ends of a double-header from Jersey City to clinch the International League pennant. The scores of the games, played before a crowd of close to 10,000, were 3 to 0 and 5 to 3.

A great burst of speed in the final furlong gave the Anall Stable's Larranaga, a gelded son of Apprehension and Garden of Allah II, the victory in the Fall Highweight Handicap as the Fall meeting began at Belmont Park yesterday before 15,000 persons.

There were mighty few spots along the near-by coast lines where fishermen did not gather during the long week-end and the waters of Long Island territory were especially well-fished and with excellent result, judging from those who haves so far reported.

A million a day is too much even for a city of 7,000,000 inhabitants to spend on official salaries. The "staggering" total of $368,695,064 reported by the Citizens Budget Committee covers the personal service items in the budget for 1932. whether payable directly from local taxes or out of other public funds.

A warning that unemployment re- lief in this State for the year begin- ning Nov. 15 will require $150,000,000 from public and private sources was sounded yesterday in a report made public by the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration of New York State.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP). -- A tropical storm which lashed great Abaco Island in the Bahamas today was reported by the Weather Bureau tonight as moving slowly northwestward from a point in the Atlantic Ocean approximately 140 miles northeast of Miami.
SKYLAND, Va., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Rest and relaxation was the Labor Day order today at President Hoover's Rapidan camp.

Twice within an hour last night bottles of phosphorus thrown from the balconies of motion picture theatres in the Century chain in Brooklyn sent large numbers in the audience hurrying to the streets and resulted in alarms for fire apparatus. Four persons were burned by the phosphorus on the second occasion and three more were hurt in the scramble to get out of the theatre.

GENEVA, Sept. 5. -- Press reports that Germany will not attend the meeting of the disarmament conference's budgetary limitation commission Sept. 12 are interpreted here as the first move toward execution of the threat the Reich's chief delegate made when the conference adjourned.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, in a Labor Day address today to 28,000 persons attending the opening of the New York State Fair, declared the country gave evidence of a change for the better in economic conditions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- Favorites in the girls' national tennis championship, which got under way today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, advanced without much difficulty. Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Cal., seeded No. 1, reached the fourth round with the loss of only two games in her two matches.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5. -- J. George Fredman, an attorney of Jersey City, was elected unanimously commander-in-chief of the Jewish Veterans of the United States at the closing session of the annual convention of the organization here today. William Berman of Boston, former adjutant general, was named senior vice commander-in-chief and Harry R. Raymond of New York City, junior vice commander-in-chief.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5. -- Following is the text of the Labor Day address given here today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor:

One of the first large philanthropic events planned for the Autumn is a fashion show and entertainment to be held Oct. 6 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the social service auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital. It is being sponsored by many prominent women of society, several of whom will appear as manikins in the fashion show.

MONTREAL, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal and Buffalo opened a six-game series by dividing a double-header before a holiday crowd of 7,000 today. Buffalo took the opener, 5-1, and the Royals a nine-inning nightcap, 5 -- 4.

The fact that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has been deluged with applications from various States and their political subdivisions for loans is not likely, in the opinion of municipal bankers, to lessen the volume of financing which would normally be done at this time through dealers.

EASTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- The condition of Darwin P. Kingsley, chairman of the board of the New York Life Insurance Company, who has been ill at his Summer home on Dunemere Lane for two months, was not so favorable today as it had been for the last two days.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- Chancellor von Papen's program for reanimating industry by anticipating part of the tax revenues for the five years beginning with 1934 and lending them to industry in advance became a law today without Reichstag aid by a simple stroke of a pen.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 5. -- Thirty Dutch Marines, summoned by wireless, rushed aboard the Holland-America liner Rotterdam when she dropped anchor off the new waterway today, after the crew insisted on putting in at Rotterdam, the home port, in defiance of orders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- In her first statement in the Presidential campaign Senator Hattie W. Caraway of Arkansas, the first woman to sit in the Senate for more than a day, said today that the people cannot be "fooled" as to the administration's economic program.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John W. Davis have left their Summer home, Mattapan, Locust Valley, and are at the Mar- shall House, York Harbor, Me., for a brief stay.

Rowing with even greater skill than marked their triumph a year ago, eight oarsmen and a coxswain of the Norwegian America liner Bergensfjord crossed the line five lengths ahead of their nearest rivals in the sixth annual lifeboat race of the Neptune Association of the Port of New York yesterday in the Narrows off Bay Ridge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It a German-American or a German living in the United States inherits money in Germany he cannot receive it at this time. When inheritance taxes, , are paid and the executor is ready to have the money transferred to America the postal authorities inform him that he must get a permit from the Reichs-Finanz-Amt, Stelle fur Divisenbewirtschaftung, to send money out of the country.

"The Book of Common Worship," edited by Bishop Wilbur Patterson Thirkield and the Rev. Dr. Oliver Huckel, is to be published by E.P. Dutton Co., probably this month. About three years ago John Macrae, president of the publishing house, conceived the possibility of publish- ing a book of common prayer for those communions outside of the Catholic, and Protestant Episcopal Churches.

YORK, England, Sept. 5. -- The be- lief that the neutron is a new ulti- mate particle like an electron or proton was challenged today by Dr. James Chadwick, young Cambridge scientist who discovered the elusive neutron last Winter.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- The committee on economic improvement of the powerful Commercial Federation, representing 450 syndicates throughout the country, addressed a letter to the government today strongly condemning the idea of a Franco-American commercial treaty.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP). -- My Dandy, the old campaigner from the Reichert Brothers' stables, came up with one of his best efforts today to win the $2,500 added Labor Day Handicap at Lincoln Fields.

An average increase of 9.2 per cent in the workmen's compensation premium rates, involving more than $18,000,000 in added premiums, has been asked of the State Insurance Department by the Compensation Insurance Rating Board, according to an announcement yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Miss Frances Robbing's brown gelding Brian Boru wad the victor in the class for local hunters, one of the feature events of the horse show of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club today. Garry Owen, another brown gelding owned by Miss Robbins, received second prize in the same event.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 5. -- In- tensive exploration in the western part of the Sahara Desert to relocate and study a great meteorite with an estimated weight of a million tons, was recommended today to the French Government by the commission on meteors of the International Astronomical Union, how holding its fourth meeting here.

As Mayor Joseph V. McKee begins his active pruning of the 1933 budget this morning he will be informed by the Citizens Budget Commission that the city pays more than $1,000,000 a day for salaries of its employes, or a total of $368,695,064 a year.

With dusk settling upon the scene after five hours of torrid competition, 7,000 wilted spectators witnessed two of the most remarkable pull-ups to victory in recent championship history yesterday as seventeen out of the eighteen American and foreign seeded players advanced to the third round of the national singles at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

ELBERON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Making a brilliant up-hill fight after a bad start the first day, Howard Schenken of New York won the individual masters' championship of the American Bridge League as the three-day competition of twenty-five past and present contract bridge champions came to a close this afternoon at the Deal Club here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- A refinancing program whereby the surplus of cotton and wheat now held by the Federal Farm Board and its affiliates will be held off of the market during the marketing of this year's crops was announced tonight.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 5. -- The sale of a group of fifteen Publix the- atres in the South, all formerly operated by Publix Theatres Corporation, to a new company now being formed by R.B. Wilby, of Atlanta, and H.F. Kincey, of Charlotte, N. C., was announced here today.

In the presence of New York's largest baseball crowd of the year, totaling 70,772, the Yankees demonstrated clearly their right to be hailed as the prospective champions of the American League at the Stadium yesterday by overpowering the Athletics, fading titleholders of 1931, in both ends of a sweltering afternoon's double-header.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Poling's letter printed in THE TIMES today is truly an amazing doc- ument. It throws a floodlight on the workings of the prohibition mind.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Thou- sands joined in a typical holiday crowd at the opening of the Trenton Fair here today. The exposition, which started its forty-fifth year, will continue until Saturday, closing with auto races on the half-mile dirt track.
SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Barnegat Bay's 1932 yachting season closed today with record entry lists, hard-fought battles and a large spec- tator fleet ashore and afloat.

Prominent figures in the history of the Negro race were pointed to in support and justification of the race's appeals for political, social and industrial equality by speakers yesterday afternoon at the concluding session of the eighth annual convention of the Federated Colored Catholics of the United States in St. Mark's Hall, 65 West 138th Street.

In observance of the greatly misnamed "Labor Day holiday," all American markets suspended business yesterday, and no prices were quoted either for securities or commodities. In view of Saturday's rather extraordinary week-end rise, on the Stock Exchange and elsewhere, the course of today's markets will be interesting.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5. -- Albert D. Graham, 50 years old, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of Baltimore, Md., and Joan Lowell, author of a book of deep-sea reminiscences, were rescued by life guards in rough water about 100 feet off shore today.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- The State Federation of Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew and kindred associations, at its closing session today, dealt primarily with the role the community centre can assume during the present economic emergency.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Ted Phelps of Great Britain, world's professional single sculls champion, frustrated the come-back attempt of Major Goodsell of Beverly Hills, Cal., in a 4,000-meter race over the Olympic rowing course today, winning by a boat length in 17 minutes 6.2 seconds.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Violence broke out afresh in the farm strike area today and four drivers were injured when pickets besieged a caravan of produce-laden trucks.

The Columbia football squad, in training at Baker Field, experienced its first contact work of the season yesterday, indicating that actual scrimmaging is not far distant. Coach Lou Little ordered only one drill yesterday, but double sessions will be resumed this morning.

A boy of 18 who has committed a misdemeanor may be a "case" to a social worker, but to a racketeer tie is a "punk." A man of 30 who has never worked regularly enough to earn his own living may be classified as one of the chronically unemployed by an investigator, but to a racketeer he also is a punk.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to the so-called "fee-splitting" which has come into so much publicity of late, it does not seem to have been made clear that this particular case had absolutely nothing to do with the practice of fee-splitting as it is known in the medical profession.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 5. -- President Moncada, after a conference with the national Board of Elections, issued a decree, which went into effect Saturday, placing the sale and distribution of distilled liquors under the control of the Nicaraguan National Guard.

Business will be resumed this morning in all financial centres after having been suspended yesterday in observance of Labor Day. The financial and commodity markets as well as the banks were closed yesterday.

Miss Susan Robertson of the Women's Swimming Association of New York, winner of the national long distance swimming championship on Sunday, added to her fast-growing cluster of title laurels by capturing as she pleased the metropolitan A. A.U. senior one-mile free style crown yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates closed their home season today by winning their tenth straight game and a double victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 to 3 and 3 to 1.
New York City's millions and the nation at large turned back last night from the Labor Day holidays that marked the end of the Summer doldrums and the beginning of the sprightlier Autumn.

SIMLA, India, Sept. 5. -- The Earl of Willingdon, Viceroy of India, an- nounced today that, owing to the round-table consultative committee's failure to make the contribution to the work of Indian constitutional reform expected of it, a new round-table conference would be called in London in November.
Making the most of his last day of rest before returning to his duties at City Hall this morning, Mayor Joseph V. McKee passed a quiet Labor Day yesterday in and near his Summer home in Mamaroneck.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- As Governor Roosevelt announced today the detailed program for his tour of the country he was hailed by Bernard M. Baruch as a defender of the nation's institutions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Senators picked up two full games today in their race for runner-up honors, taking a double-header from the Red Sox, 6 to 2 and 9 to 3, while the Athletics were dropping a pair to the Yanks. They were still three games behind the second place Athletics, however.

Just a few thousand miles removed from the glens and crags of their native Highlands, where the gowan and bell-heather blow, about 2,000 members and guests of the New York Caledonian Club, many resplendent in tartan, kilts and bonnets of the clans, gathered yesterday on the greensward of Ulmer Park in South Brooklyn for the seventy-sixth annual outing of the organization.

Never out of the first ten at any time and leading the last seven miles, William Steiner, unattached, won the National A.A.U. 20-mile championship run, feature event of the A.A. U. track and field program contested yesterday at Ulmer Park in conjunction with the seventy-sixth annual games of the New York Caledonian Club.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The next move in the current Chaco dispute was awaited with great interest here today. It was generally believed that an impasse had been reached and that the recent exchange of notes was at an end.

MONTREAL, Sept. 5. -- That United States gold pieces are less valuable in Canada than United States bills of the same denomination has occasioned some surprise among American visitors to Montreal this Summer, the prevalent impression being that one kind of American money was freely interchangeable for other American money at par.

Hardship and disease, inaccurate maps and jungle insects, lack of ammunition and provisions and a threat of mutiny from his exhausted half-breed guides have forced Desmond X. Holdridge, 26-year-old leader of the Brooklyn Museum's Brazil expedition, to abandon his first attempt to pierce the mysterious "half-world" in Northwestern Brazil, according to messages from Holdridge made public here yesterday by Lee Trenholm, the expedition's New York manager.

It is stated in Berlin that the German Government will notify the United States of its intention to postpone payments due on account of war claims and cost of the American army of occupation. The difficulty is the now familiar one of "trans- fer."

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Milt Gaston's pitching and batting gave the Chicago White Sox a 3-to-1 victory over Detroit in the second game of their double-header and an even break for the day, the Tigers winning the first contest, 5 to 3.

DETROIT, Sept. 5. -- International speed supremacy on the water had a disappointing finale today. Gar Wood drove his mahogany thunderbolt, Miss America X, to a second victory over Kaye Don and Lord Wakefield of Hythe's Miss England III, but only after the British boat's motors had balked in the very first of the thirty-five miles, and stopped completely at the end of thirteen and one-quarter miles.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Chicago's Cubs had their lead in the National League trimmed today by the down and almost out Cincinnati Reds, by splitting a double-header, losing the second, 6 to 5, after winning the first, 9 to 2.
BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- Al Fraser of Philadelphia died today in the flames of seven light stock automobiles which burst into fire after piling up during a race on the Readville track.

THE early arrivals at Forest Hills yesterday saw Bunny Austin of jolly old England run through the first set against Berkeley Bell, the tumbling Texan. Austin came dressed for the occasion. He was practically in running costume. With his white linen hat and his flannel shorts, the little English player looked like an A.A. Milne production.

Zlatko Balakovic, European violin- ist, who recently returned from a 27,000-mile world cruise in his own yacht, is sailing today for Genoa on the Italian motor-ship Vulcania for a concert tour on the Continent.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 5. -- The government announced this morning that at daybreak last Thursday a group of Peruvian civilians captured the town of Leticia, on the upper Amazon northwest of Iquitos. The seizure was made without bloodshed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- Calvin Coolidge, presenting "The Republican Case" in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post, out tomorrow, asserts that the record of two generations "discloses that the safety of the country lies in the success of the principles of the Republican party."
With the playing today of the first of the semi-final-round matches, the Templeton team, led by Winston Guest, enters the national open polo championship.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Scor- ing two firsts and a second in the scheduled three-heat match race, the Red Bank Yacht Club's Miss Columbia earned a clear-cut triumph over Pierre Proal's Miss Red Bank today on the Shrewsbury River.
WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The Norwood Country Club polo team won a hard-fought contest with Burnt Mills at Norwood today. The score was 9 to 8.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- Mrs. Edward V. Hartford and her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. G. Huntington Hartford 2d, returned from New York to their home, Seaverge, for the "white elephant" leap-year party which a group of the debutantes and sub-debutantes gave there tonight through the courtesy of Mrs. Hartford.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- A capacity crowd which attended the opening of the six-day race meeting at the New York State Fair today saw Fred E. Kraft's speedy colt, Hibala, upset pre-race calculations when he won in a romp over the Belair Stud's Pardee in the $3,000 Labor Day Handicap.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Baltimore and Albany split their holiday doubleheader today, Baltimore winning the first game, 7 to 6, and Albany the second, 5 to 4, in the eighth inning of what was to have been a seven-inning contest.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5. -- The biennial State conventions of both the Democratic and Republican parties, to select State tickets, national electors and candidates for United States Senator, will be held almost simultaneously this week.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 5. -- The Arundel Boat Club won the featured junior eight-oared race before 5,000 spectators in the forty-first annual Middle States regatta on the Patapsco course today.

Since employers are unable to guarantee employment to those willing to work, the American Federation of Labor has decided to favor an unemployment insurance law that will protect workers when employment is not available, according to Joseph P. Ryan, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council, in a Labor Day address yesterday over Station WOR.

The report of the State Temporary Relief Administration must give satisfaction to the people of the State. The relief -- both work and home -- supplemented local effort. Community or district was the unit of public assistance. More intimate is the private help that comes of personal sharing and giving.

Contrary to fears stimulated by recent events, there is no evidence of any organized Communist or radical Socialist movement in Latin America, according to a report made public yesterday by the Committee on Inter-American Relations in cooperation with the National Foreign Trade Council, with offices at 1 Hanover Square.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5. -- Provisional President Abelardo L. Rodriguez announced today, his first day in office, nine members of his Cabinet, and two undersecretaries to take charge of the remaining two departments until Ministers are appointed.
Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. CLEVELAND, Sept. 5. -- Well, I did it, set a new world speed record for women!

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- The Giant banners were trampled twice today to make an uproarious holiday for about 12,000 Philadelphia fans. The scores were 3 to 2 and 5 to 4, the latter defeat eventuating on the strength of a brisk ninth-inning finish in which the Phillies came from behind with two runs to snatch the victory.

Unless the $2,000,000,000 relief and construction act, which he sponsored, is at once brought into full operation the nation faces a Winter of "indescribable cruelty," although the public mood is conducive to restoration of confidence, Senator Robert F. Wagner said last night in a radio address over Station WEAF and a National Broadcasting Company network.

A twenty-five-foot cabin cruiser, with six persons aboard, set out from Moriches Bay, L.I., about 6 o'clock Sunday night to go bluefishing on the Atlantic. A mile off shore, the boat grounded on a sandbar and overturned. The owner was drowned. Four of his guests were rescued by the Coast Guard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- A challenge to the forces opposed to organized labor and to "social advancement" was broadcast today by Frank Morrison, secretary of the American Federation of Labor, over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- The text of the Labor Day address of Secretary William N. Doak of the Department of Labor delivered at the State Fair here was as follows:

TORONTO, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Rochester won two games from Toronto today as the teams opened a five-game series. The Red Wings won the first by 9 -- 5, bunching their hits off Guy Cantrell in three innings and finally driving him from the box in the ninth.

Secretary of Commerce Roy D. Chapin has accepted the post of honorary chairman for the nation of the committee sponsoring "Fifth Avenue Week," it was announced yesterday by Captain William J. Pedrick, presi- dent of the Fifth Avenue Association. Governor Roosevelt will be honorary chairman for the State, and the asso- ciation is awaiting acceptance of its invitation to Mayor McKee to be honorary chairman for the city.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- Labor Day in Boston was a fine holiday for the Braves and 17,500 fans, but resulted in an unpleasant out-of-town journey for the Dodgers, for they dropped both ends of a double-header, descended to four games below the second-place Pirates, and helped McKechnie's men to rise to fifth place.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Three harness races featured the opening day of the Trenton Fair today. A dead heat occurred in the third race and necessitated a special heat to determine the winner.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The Stock Exchange opened strong today, stimulated by continued firmness in commodities and cheerful news from the Paris and Berlin markets. Buying orders poured in and bidding was very lively in the first hour. British Government funds, however, were somewhat overshadowed by the more speculative activity and prices declined.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES Mr. Bocher criticizes my proposal that the Federal Government should provide youth with financial aid to attend college in order to reduce labor. He contends that "the colleges are already crowded with persons who have no business there."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- There was a large attendance this afternoon at the horse show arranged by Miss Frances Robbin in aid of the Southampton unemployment fund, which was held at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. After the events tea was served at small tables on the terrace.

The Fort Monmouth polo four defeated Governors Island yesterday on the latter's field in a game for the Fifth Division Cups. Outplaying the home team in the last half of the contest, Fort Monmouth emerged victorious by the score of 11 to 8.

MONTREAL, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press). -- A triple disqualification, a rarity on race tracks, was imposed by the officials today in the fourth race at Blue Bonnets. Tout Feu, Logwood and Step Off, which finished first, second and third, were all disqualified and Nipigon was declared the winner.

It cannot be said that the "case" which ex-Mayor WALKER was going to take to the great multitude of his admirers and supporters in this city is going very well for him. He was rebuked yesterday by Mr. HEARST for the violence and bitterness of his attack on Governor ROOSEVELT.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- The Bourse began the week strong. Opening quotations showed decided advances over Friday's closing levels and after brief profit-taking in the middle of the day prices continued upward, closing at the highest points of the day. Optimism, which already was strong here, was strengthened by the firmness in foreign markets, particularly in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Bringing total government borrowings to $2,540,601,000 this fiscal year, the Treasury will put $1,150,000,000 in notes and certificates on the market on Sept. 15, Secretary Mills announced today. The notes, amounting to $750,000,000, will be of five-year maturity with a 3 1/4 per cent rate.

Alan Fox, one of the original supporters of President Hoover in this State, was reprimanded publicly last night by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, for alleged interference in the party organization in Queens in support of the candidacy of Colonel William J. Donovan for Governor.

The medical world for medical men, eliminating lay members from hospital and other medical boards, may be desirable but it is not possible at present, according to Dr. Gustav Kolischer, Chicago urologist, who spoke last night at a dinner of more than 100 members of the American Congress of Physical Therapy, of which he is president-elect.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Thirty thousand holiday visitors have viewed the National Atlantic City Flower and Garden Pageant in the Auditorium, which was featured today by gladiolus competition. Tomorrow's outstanding events will be the national championship for flower arrangement classes and competition in the Federated Garden Club classes.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Miss Lorna Whittelsey sailed Lucius Eastrnan's Axon to victory in the Sound Interclub Class yacht race, which was a part of the Fall regatta conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5. -- A company of 100 attended the annual Labor Day luncheon at the Lenox Club. Among those who entertained were Mrs. Edwards Spencer, who had a table for thirty, and Mrs. Carlos M. de Heredia, who had a party of sixteen in honor of Mrs. Nicholas Brown.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Secretary Stimson is due to return to the State Department tomorrow after a vacation in the Adirondacks, to find Japanese recognition of Manchukuo a prospect of the immediate future. Indication are that the recognition will be extended in a week or ten days.

The rapid promotion of General RODRIGUEZ from Governor of Lower California to Minister of Industry and Commerce, Minister of War, and now Provisional President of Mexico, is due to personal merit as well as to the influence of General CALLES, the acknowledged political power.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Indians won both games of a doubleheader from the Browns today, 12 to 9 in the first contest and 6 to 4 in the nightcap.

The Girl Scouts' organization has moved its national headquarters to the RCA Building at 570 Lexington Avenue, where it has leased for a long term from the owners, the Bartholomew Building Corporation, the twentieth and twenty-first floors and a store 18 by 44 feet on the ground floor of the Fifty-first Street side of the building.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 5. -- For the first week in September, following Labor Day, iron and steel production schedules in this district show encouraging tendencies, particularly in the resumption of blast furnaces, which were "standing by" in July and August.

The Citizens Budget Commission announced plans yesterday for a series of twelve radio addresses to be broadcast during the next thirty days explaining the work of the organization and describing recent efforts to effect a reduction in municipal expenditures.

Once Truth was one, and the united prohibitionists personally conducted it. They sat on the necks of both parties. The Democrats back-slided. Mr. HOOVER became the hope and chief of the faithful. Suddenly he dumped prohibition and prepared to sacrifice the amendment, but he couldn't lose all the prohibitionists.

Not all inmates of insane asylums are insane, but some seek haven there from what they consider a worse fate outside, according to assertions in "Behind the Door of Delusion," published today by the Macmillan Company.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The World's record of 2.14 1/2 for trotting a mile under saddle, established eighteen years ago, was broken by Happy the Great from the Newbrook Stables at the holiday races today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5. -- The Marchioness, sensational campaigner which recently triumphed in the classic Hambletonian at Goshen. N. Y., responded to the clever handling of Will Caton by registering a victory today in the Horseman Futurity, $6,300 headliner of the first day's program of the Grand Circuit races at the Indiana State Fair Grounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Sept. 5. -- Paul Bern, motion-picture executive, ended his life by shooting today in the $60,000 home which he presented to Jean Harlow, the platinum blonde of the films, following their marriage two months ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has been assured of almost unanmious support of its proposal for a sixtyday moratorium on home mortgage foreclosures.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Striking Iowa farmers relaxed their road picketing activities today while their leaders met here in closed session to discuss plans for continuing the "higher commodity price war."

ROTTERDAM, Sept. 6 -- The Holland-America liner Rotterdam's mutinous voyage ended at 5 o'clock this morning when she was met at the quayside by police. The only passenger left aboard was a New Yorker, Miss Florence Partene, who, hearing the ship was returning to Southampton, had obtained the captain's permission to go there instead of landing at Boulogne with the other passengers.

"The Thinker," by Al Smith. Some one remarks the noticeable difference between the speed developed by Major DOOLITTLE in going from point to point and the pace hitherto maintained by a great Democratic leader in clarifying his attitude toward the Roosevelt candidacy.
Three travelers returned yesterday from Europe on the White Star liner Majestic with optimistic opinions regarding the trade outlook in England and the business prospect in the United States.

SYRACUSE. N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Captain Tom Lombardi and four other regulars from last year's team were included in the group of forty-six football players who reported to Coach Vie Hanson for the first practice of the 1932 season at Syracuse University today.

PARIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- France has informed the United States that the cause of disarmament would be endangered if Germany's request for arms equality were approved, it was learned today from an official source.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In view of the imminence of an International Economic Congress, in which all countries are vitally concerned, it is essential as a preliminary to ascertain what is really the cause of the universal business stagnation.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Unbusinesslike methods and, in some instances, illegal practices are employed in the handling of Asbury Park's finances, the State Department of Municipal Accounts charged today in a report on the 1931 audit of the city's affairs.

Declaring that potential repair, maintenance and modernization of home, commercial and industrial structures in every American community could be made worth "three and a half billion dollars to America's unemployed," Frederick M. Feiker, Director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, has promised the full cooperation of the National Committee on Reconditioning, Remodeling and Modernizing in a nation-wide campaign to accomplish that purpose.
Ths initial adventure of Frankie Parker in quest of the men's national tennis championship came to an end yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 6 -- James J. Walker will not seek another term as Mayor of New York City, Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, predicted here tonight in an address before a rally of several thousand party followers.

For the first time since 1900, when customs declarations were put into use on incoming passenger ships after enactment of the Dingley tariff bill, a departure from this practice was made on the piers yesterday when eight cruising vessels with 6,726 passengers landed, in addition to five other ships with 3,000 more, a total of 9,622 persons on thirteen liners.

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 6 -- Women sailors will put out tomorrow morning to strive for their yacht racing championship. The contestants will be the crews which won in the elimination contests held along the Atlantic coast. They gath ered today at the Conasset Yacht Club.

Overriding the Board of Elections and his opposition on the Board of Estimate Mayor McKee yesterday denied a ballot-printing contract to the M.B. Brown Printing and Binding Company and awarded the contract to the Burland Printing Company on a bid $50,000 lower than that of the Brown concern.

The broadcasting companies expect the Eastern Intercollegiate Association to lift the ban on radio descriptions of football games this Autumn which was announced in June by Major Philip B. Fleming, representative of the United States Military Academy and president of the association.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 6 -- The importance of radio apparatus as a means of studying the activity of the sun was called to the attention of the commission on solar physics of the International Astronomical Union, meeting here today, by Harlan T. Stetson, director of the Perkins Observatory of Ohio Wesleyan University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Speculation as to a change in the secretariat of the White House was set at rest today when Theodore G. Joslin returned to his post as the public contact secretary to the President.

Daily gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,127.250 barrels, compared with 2,114,000 in the preceding week, an increase of 13,250 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Small gains were recorded in most districts, the increase of 6,300 barrels daily in East Texas being the largest.
''Best Tears," a play by Raymond Van Sickle, will open tonight at the Bijou Theatre. Katherine Alexander and Harvey Stephens will head the cast.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The New Jersey State Federation of Labor opened its annual convention at the Labor Lyceum here today. The interest of the 300 delegates centred in the contests for president and secretary. Nominations will be made tomorrow and the elections at the closing session Thursday.

So far as financial markets were concerned, the prevalent disposition yesterday seamed to be not to take for granted the Immediate beginning after Labor Day of the Autumn trade activity which Wall Street gave Semblance last week of expecting. Outside buying orders seemed to have been inspired by Saturday's rise on the Stock Exchange, and active shares went 1 or 2 points higher in yesterday's preliminary trading.

Spokesmen of the United Mine Workers of America and the anthraite operators met yesterday at the request of the employers at the Anthracite Institute, 19 Rector Street, to discuss a proposed wage reduction of 20 or 25 per cent for the approximately 140,000 miners in the three hard-coal districts of Northwestern Pennsylvania.

MONTREAL, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Royals dropped both games of a double-header to the Buffalo Bisons today, 4-3 and 7-0, and also dropped out of fourth place in the International League standings as Rochester went into the first division.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The announcement yesterday by Chairman Stone that the Federal Farm Board will sell no more cotton and wheat until next year places the marketing of those commodities squarely back into the hands of the cotton and grain trades, and the public will look to them for constructive efforts to raise prices, Senator L.J. Dickinson of Iowa, who is helping manage the Republican campaign from the party's Western headquarters, declared today.

YORK, England, Sept. 6 -- Evidence that London is sinking and its great buildings, like St. Paul's Cathedral and the Bank of England, are slowly "tilting over" was presented to the British Association for the Advancement of Science today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Oh Dave, running in the colors of Lair Parrish, made a runaway of the fifth event best race at Lincoln Fields today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Opening, as temporary chairman, the Republican State Convention here tonight, Frederic C. Walcott, United States Senator, declared the Hoover Administration, if continued in power, would revise the banking laws. Bank failures had been caused, he asserted, by a dearth of bankers who knew their business.

A theoretical gain of $7,287,742,341 in the value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange was recorded in August, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. This advance is the largest for any month since August, 1929.

Charles T. Inglee of Brooklyn was elected president of the American Kennel Club yesterday, succeeding Dr. John E. de Mund, who had served as head of the governing body of the organization for ten years. Dr. de Mund resigned last week because of ill health.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Sharp revisions in the borrowing habits of American wage earners, indicating a turn toward normality coincidental with the upward trend in general business, are shown in a cross-section report today by L.C. Harbison, president of Household Finance Corporation, of the personal loans made by the company in its ninety-one branch cities during the first six months of this year.

Things in the theatre take on a rosier hue with the appearance of "Here Today" at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last evening. George Oppenheimer of the Viking Press wrote it during the spare time for which publishers are notorious; wicked George Kaufman staged it and may have tampered with the lines.

A few years ago former Prime Minister BALDWIN, in a stirring address as president of the British Classical Association, described the procession of nations which passed the torch of learning: on to the Ultimi Britanni. Rome, after running her mighty race, "holding her torch on high," surrendered it into other hands because there were not enough Romans left to carry on.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 6 -- Hostility to the Hutchinson family's flight was accentuated today by the receipt by the Greenland Board of a cablegram from its administrator at Godthaab suggesting that there had been an attempt to deceive the party into believing the Danish Government had granted them permission to land in Greenland.

A vigorous rally in foreign bonds, notably German loans, offset in part the irregularly lower prices for domestic corporation issues on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Although there was a sizable accumulation of orders over the holiday, the turnover amounted to only $11,822,000, compared with $12,153,500 on Friday, the preceding five-hour trading day.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- Two British players came through with a pair of victories each in the Women's Middle States tennis tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

Operations for the rise were resumed yesterday in aggressive fashion, encouraged by the announcement over the week-end that the Federal Farm Board's wheat and cotton would be withheld from those markets this year and by the pronounced strength of the security markets in European centres on Monday.
L.A. PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 6 -- A Paraguayan attack on a Bolivian outpost in the southern part of the disputed Chaco region was announced tonight by the General Staff.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 6 -- Warning insurance companies to beware of excessive costs of acquiring new business and the tendeny to cut rates, George S. Van Schaick of New York, State Superintendent of Insurance, delivered the main address at the annual conference of Canadian Insurance Superintendents at the opening here today.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 6 -- The Central European States which, together with the great European powers, are trying to work out a scheme for their economic and financial rehabilitation disclosed a certain measure of unanimity today at the second session of the conference that augured the attaining of at least partial success.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The Second Summer Conference Course in Industrial Relations will be held under the auspices of the Industrial Relations Section of Princeton University at the Princeton Graduate College from Sept. 19 to 24, inclusive, according to announcement made here today by J. Douglas Brown, director of the section.

LONDON, Ont., Sept. 6 -- Dr. Angus D. McLachlin, captain of the University of Western Ontario champion rugby team, was proclaimed a hero today after he had rescued eight persons from drowning in Lake Erie.

After the successful treatment of internal cancers with high-frequency currents had been reported yesterday to the American Congress of Physical Therapy, in session at the Hotel New Yorker, by its new president, Dr. Gustav Kolischer, Chicago urologist, a corroborating statement from Dr. Nikola Tesla, electrical inventor, was presented.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- The text of the German arms equality memorandum submitted to the French Ambassador on Aug. 29 follows :

An exhibition which augurs well for the new season opened yesterday at the Cheshire Galleries in the Chrysler Building. Miron Sokole, who has contributed occasional pieces to group events at the Chicago and Detroit Art Institutes and at the Marie Harriman Gallery in this city, is having his first one-man show.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- Heavy realizing sales at today's session of the Boerse prevented continuation of the series of spectacular booms, but despite the fact that plenty of securities were available the majority of both stocks and bonds advanced slightly, as the enthusiasm of the public was not greatly slackened.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A new treaty of friendship between the United States and Haiti was signed by Dana G. Munro, Minister to Haiti, on Saturday, the State Department announced today.

Representatives of three political parties spoke over WJZ last evening on the issues among them in direct reference to the election in November. They spoke under the auspices of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education and the University of Chicago Press.

Deadly wassail, which the police believe was a mixture of painters' alcohol and milk brewed over an open fire killed five unemployed seamen and prostrated three others yesterday after a Labor Day party in the desolate metal dump known as Hoover City, at the foot of Henry Street, Brooklyn.

James J. Brennan, president of Theatrical Protective Union 1, and Dr. Henry Moskowitz, executive adviser of the League of New York Theatres, each insisted yesterday that it was up to the other to make the next move in the deadlock existing over a new wage agreement.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 6 -- A long-hitting barrage which started to reach its objective before the echoes of the opening bell had died away carried the youthful Templeton team through to the final of the national open polo championship on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Dismissal of the Federal indictment charging Conrad H. Mann, president of the Kansas City (Mo.) Chamber of Commerce, and Frank E. Hering of South Bend, Ind., executives of the Fraternal Order of Eagles, with violation of the anti-lottery law was asked yesterday in Federal court by Albert H. Ottinger, their attorney.

A public hearing on charges that there have been irregularities and favoritism in the handling of the City Work and Relief Administration Bureau, of which Lawson Purdy is chairman, probably will be held this morning in the offices of the Commissioner of Accounts, James A. Higgins, at 2 Lafayette Street.
