With economy as his major theme, Mayor Joseph V. McKee slashed right and left yesterday at the sources of waste in City Government and threw overboard spending policies that had been firmly fixed by the previous administration. The results of his second full day in office were:

To the Editor of The New York Times: An evening paper quotes the opinion of Dr. Scarr, meteorologist of the New York City Weather Bureau station, to the effect that the coming Winter is likely to be colder than usual. Dr. Scarr's opinion -- it is not an official forecast -- is based upon the fact that the last five Winters have been above the mean Winter temperature at New York City.

NEW YORK. Lady Faith Montagu, eldest daughter of the Earl and Countess of Sandwich, will arrive on the Europa today with her great-aunt, Miss Josephine MacLeod. They will go directly to Ridgely Manor, Stone Ridge, N.Y., the country place of Lady Faith's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Hollister Sturges, where Lady Faith will be joined by her brother, the Viscount Hinchingbrooke.

On Labor Day, from three different angles, three prominent Americans took up the question of whether our established institutions face any threat in this Fall's elections. In New Jersey, Mr. STEWART, the Democratic nominee for Senator, asserted that one answer to the claim of a Republican monopoly of business brains and talent was that " whenever a particularly important " job has to be done, the President " draws from the Democratic "ranks."

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, sept. 6 -- While police were quelling disturbances of unemployed outside, the Trades Union Congress today unanimously adopted a resolution urging the abolition of war debts as a possible solution of the industrial depression. The congress then was informed the General Council hoped to raise u500,000 as a first instalment on a fund to support workers engaged in the Lancashire textile strike.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6 -- It took split heats to decide the two feature events of the Grand Circuit races at the State Fair Grounds today when Spencer McElwyn, the Dallas colt, driven by Berry, won the $3,000 2-year-old Horseman Futurity Trot and Raider, the Buffalo (N.Y.) colt, took the $3,338 3-year-old Horseman Futurity race.

BELLEVILLE, Ont., Sept. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Sir Gilbert Parker some years ago purchased a home in Belleville, where his parents and sister resided for many years. Camden East, where he was born, is a few miles north of Napanee, in the public school of which town he received his early education.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- The German Foreign Office made public tonight the text of the aide memoire handed to Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador, by Baron von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, on Aug. 29, in which the German position on the question of arms equality was set forth at length.
FISHERS ISLAND, N,Y., Sept. 6 -- With a fresh breeze out of the west making the going rough, sixteen sloops took part in the races off the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

VIEGE, Switzerland, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A 20-year-old Swiss has confessed, the Swiss Telegraphic Agency reported today, that he murdered Miss Jerane Ibershoff of Cleveland, Ohio, who was felled with a rock at the foot of Zermatt Mountain in the Alps last week.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Further attacks in the French press today have led to the belief in American circles that a definite campaign is being financed by powerful industrial interests against American efforts to negotiate a most-favored-nation treaty.
The uncertainty whether Tammany will put forward former Mayor Walker as a candidate for the office he resigned last week continued yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Publication of the government's letter to employers and workers in the great Lancashire textile strike reveals that Sir Henry Betterton, Minister of Labor, who commands in his department men of wide knowledge, experience and Judgment in industrial diplomacy, is of the opinion that a reasonable ground is not discoverable for hoping that intervention in the form of mediation would bring the disputants to an agreement.

CLEARFIELD, Pa., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Warrants were turned over to the State police tonight for the arrest of nine men accused by Garret Schenck, Hopewell (N.J.) fish peddler who charges he was held captive seventysix days following the Lindbergh kidnapping.

L.O. Head, who was elected last week president of the Railway Express Agency, took official occupation yesterday of his offices in the company's headquarters here. He had been vice president of the company at Chicago with jurisdiction over the western department and a portion of the central department.

The 175th anniversary of the birth of Lafayette was celebrated in New York yesterday in ceremonies at which the first battle of the Marne in 1914 was also commemorated. During the day a wreath was laid on the statue of Lafayette in Union Square and last night several speakers took part in a program sent over the air.

Mayor McKee's order reducing the salaries of department heads to a maximum of $12,000 a year means the loss of nearly half his salary to Dr. William Schroeder Jr., head of the Department of Sanitation and the friend, physician and traveling companion of former Mayor Walker.

What was described as the nucleus of a golf museum was brought here yesterday from Scotland on the White Star liner Majestic by John Campbell, an engineer of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company. He was sent abroad by the James River Country Club to find out if sufficient interesting material could be obtained to form a collection.

The New Amsterdam Brewing Company, recently organized by a group of men who believe the manufacture and sale of beer having an alcoholic content of more than one-half of one per cent will be legalized in a reasonably short time, announced yesterday a plan to build a $2,500,000 brewery in New York City.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept 6 -- Bernard F. Gimbel's chestnut gelding His Elegance, with Miss Caral Gimbel up, added another blue to the big collection he has aready won this Summer when he took first in the lightweight hunter class, one of the feature events on the second day's card at the Rochester Horse Show today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Republican National Committee was unable to raise enough money to meet current expenses from June 1 to Aug 31, according to its report filed today with the Clerk of the House by Joseph R. Nutt, treasurer. For the first time in a decade the committee has an actual deficit, which amounts to 59,002.83, due to the fact that it has an unpaid note of $15,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 6 -- After considerable difficulty in the selection of an impartial jury, the second trial of Deputy Chief Frank J. Tappen and Detectives Leslie Pearsall and Harry Zander on manslaughter charges growing out of the "thirddegree" death of Hyman Stark, 28year-old thug, who attacked and robbed the mother of a Nassau County detective, opened here today.

Prospects for the re-election of the Hoover-Curtis ticket are growing better every day, and there is no doubt that the President will be re-elected by even a greater majority than he had four years ago, Senator Henry H. Hatfield of West Virginia declared yesterday in a statement issued through the Republican campaign headquarters here.

John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, warned last night in an address at the Madison Club, his home organization, at 908 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, that even should State Senator William L. Love be reelected over the organization designee, "there may be some contest should he attempt to be seated."

The seamen's strike in Holland will not interfere with the scheduled sailings of ships of the Holland-America Line and the port of Rotterdam will remain the company's terminal, officials of the line said yesterday. The liner Statendam will sail Friday as scheduled and will proceed to Rotterdam, regardless of the strike situation, it was said.

Fordham University launched its sixth football campaign under the direction of Coach Frank W. Cavanaugh when thirty-three candidates for the 1932 varsity eleven reported for the initial sessions of the season at Fordham Field yesterday. Two drills, aggregating five hours of work, were conducted, the first in the forenoon and a second one after luncheon.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians made a clean sweep of their four-game series with the St. Louis Browns by winning both games of a double-header today, 4 to 3 and 6 to 0.

Mayor McKee and the Board of Estimate were advised yesterday by Corporation Counsel Arthur J. W Hilly that Intervention by the city in the pending Interborough and Manhattan Railway equity receivership proceedings in the United States District Court might imperil the fivecent fare contract.

Lawrence Richey, confidential secretary to President Hoover, was among the lucky anglers who fished in Long Island waters over the Labor Day week-end. Mr. Richey, with Lewis Strauss of Kuhn, Loeb Co., was a guest of the Montauk Yacht Club and, with Mr. Strauss, fished on Saturday, Sunday and Monday from the club's yacht, Montauk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The three American consular officers who were captured by brigands in Persia last Friday night and subsequently rescued by Persian troops arrived at Teheran at 3:30 yesterday morning after a rough and hazardous experience, the State Department was informed today by Charles C. Hart, the American Minister.

Mayor McKee, accompanied by Controller Berry, paid a flying visit to Wall Street yesterday and in less than thirty minutes made arrangements for the first loan to the city under his administration of $10,000,000 to $15,000,000 at the lowest rate of interest paid by the city since last November.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Money to meet its needs until next June is assured to this city, it was said at the City Hall, as the result of an agreement made today by a syndicate of bankers here and in New York to buy an issue of $4,000,000 of Newark's temporary bonds carrying an interest rate of 5 per cent.

Most of the Tammany talk about running Mr. WALKER again for Mayor turns on the idea, or claim, that he is entitled to a "vindication." What does this mean? It does not refer to his personal character. It has no concern with his repute as a faithful member of Tammany Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial referring to the "whispering" about religious prejudices that did so much mischief in 1928 states: "In that year the Republican 'whispers' sought to profit by the fact that a Catholic headed the Democratic ticket. This year they think to win votes by asking why a Catholic was left off the ticket.

An appeal to the Democratic party leaders in the city to be "real leaders, not gravediggers," and put the Commonwealth above their "special interests" is made in an editorial published in The New Yorker Staats-Zeitung this morning. The tenor of the editorial indicated that they would be leaders by denying renomination to James J. Walker.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 7 -- A forecast of the Lytton commission's report to the League of Nations on Manchuria, which was corroborated to a considerable extent in guarded statements by officials and commission circles, appeared in today's Asahi.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A slight reduction in Winter wheat acreage was forecast by the Department of Agriculture today. Reports based on farmers' intentions showed that about 39,805,000 acres would be planted to wheat this Fall, compared with 40,172,000 last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- In the government's $700,000,000 building program 230 buildings had been completed by Aug. 31, representing a total cost of $71,400,219, the Treasury Department announced today.

The average American has an inaccurate idea of the appearance of one of the men who figured most conspicuously in American history, William Penn, it appears from Arthur Pound's book, "The Penns of Pennsylvania," just published by the Macmillan Company.

EL PASO, Tex., Sept. (AP) -- Pascual Ortiz Rubio, who was President of Mexico until last week, emphatically denied on his arrival here today that he resigned because of differences with General Plutarco Elias Calles, "strong man" of Mexico.

Jaunty and smiling, former Mayor fames J. Walker returned yesterday from a week-end rest at the home of A.C. Blumenthal in Larchmont, and in an interview with a score of newspaper reporters on the sidewalk in front of Mayfair House at Sixty-fifth Street and Park Avenue, indicated that nothing had occurred to cause him to alter his determination to seek vindication by running for Mayor again.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago wound up his missionary tour of Europe today with a vigorous defense of his city at a luncheon at the American Chamber of Commerce. He will sail for home Thursday.

One of the gamest finishes of the season was seen at Belmont Park yesterday when Miss Mary Coming's Illusive, a daughter of General Lee and French Doll, lasted to win by a head in the featured Mineola Claiming Stakes.

The Treasury announces borrowing of $1,150,000,000 in the financing of Sept. 15. Since $712,500,000 maturing short-term loans will be taken up with the proceeds, the Government's total interest-bearing debt will be enlarged by $437,500,000. It will be brought to $20,195,600,000, which would compare with $15,773,710,000 on Dec. 31, 1930, when the debt reached its low level.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Governor Roosevelt made a rapid swing today into Central New York to rally the Democratic leaders up-State for the November election. He returned to the capital to find the fight to oust James A. Farley as State chairman apparently abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Three World War veterans, all with excellent records, will appear before the Federal grand jury Friday to testify that they saw dynamite, guns and pistols in the "bonus army" camps which were broken up by the police and Federal troops, according to an announcement at the Department of Justice.
PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The Forstmann Woolen Company announced that beginning on Sept. 12 it would inaugurate the five-day week and thus increase the present employment by a minimum of 10 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Sept. 6 -- Three developments in the investigation of the suicide of Paul Bern, film executive and husband of Jean Harlow, screen star, served tonight only to deepen the mystery of why he took his own life.

Production and consumption of petroleum made an approximate balance in 1931, according to estimates by Valentin R. Garfias and Raymond V. Whetsel of the foreign oil department of Henry L. Doherty Co. The world's consumption last year they estimate at 1,373,034,000 barrels.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, Off Greenland, Aug. 30 -- Last July the Morrissey wended its way along the icebergs and pack ice which surrounded the Nugsuak Peninsula and deposited the two members of the University of Michigan expedition who were to set up camp and prepare Winter quarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- More than 12 per cent of the 948,367 New Jersey women classified as "home makers" are "gainfully employed," in addition to their family activities, according to returns of the 1930 census.

The State of Kentucky, which endeavored last April to market $13,500,000 of new bonds to refund State warrants of that amount issued in the last five years, but was thwarted by an adverse court decision on the legality of the issue, plans to embark upon a program designed to bring the market value of the warrants back to par.

Heavy rains in the Southwest, torrential at some points in Texas, and the announcement that government-financed cotton would be held off the market caused a sharp advance in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here. May contracts touched 9.70 cents a pound, a rise of about $2 a bale and within a quarter cent of the high mark for the season, made a week ago.
RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Tobacco from North Carolina's new bright belt lived up to its name as the "golden weed" today, and farmers smiled at soaring prices as the markets opened.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, said yesterday he would not run for Mayor on a Republican or fusion ticket. His statement was occasioned by the opinion expressed last Saturday by Republican leaders of rive of the six Assembly districts in Queens that he would be the logical Republican candidate for Mayor if an election were held this Fall.

Municipal Court Justice William A. Keating of 979 East 219th Street, who served on the bench of the First Municipal Court District of the Bronx for the last five years, died last evening in St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been a patient for a week under the care of his brother, Dr. John H. Keating, and several consulting physicians.

To the Editor of The New York Times : The opinion of Justice Staley will long endure as a shining example of what an opinion should not be After reaching the inescapable decision that he had no judicial power over the Governor, the Justice officiously assumed the role of private counsel to the Mayor.

Buyers' Total Highest in 3 Years. Due to the holiday the number of buyers regsitered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a large decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total was also well under the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

A squad of twenty-seven candidates reported for the first City College football practice of the season yesterday. Included among them were three veterans who had not been expected to turn out. The three, all backs, are Harry Schneer, George Clemens and Adolph Cooper.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The stock market after an irregular opening today forged ahead in the afternoon with lively dealings in the internationals on expectations of strength in Wall Street. There was good provincial support for textiles on hopes of an early settlement of the cotton mill strike and shares improved.

UNION CITY, Sept. 6 -- Six nurses of the North, Hudson Hospital of Weehawken, N.J., residents of a nurses' home at 117 Forty-fourth Street here, were rescued today by telephone linemen and firemen after they had been trappd by a fire that flamed up the staircase of the building.

In his Labor Day address at Pittsburgh, President GREEN of the American Federation of Labor "sol"emnly warned industry and indus"trial management" against the consequences of reducing wages. He described as fallacious the theory that reductions are justified because of lower costs of living and insisted that wage-cutting has intensified and prolonged the depression from which business has been suffering.

HAVANA, Sept. 6 -- Lieutenant Francisco Echenique, Military Supervisor of Marianao, a suburb of Havana, was instantly killed and Major Estanislao Mansip, Negro Chief of Police, was gravely wounded this morning when a bomb they were examining exploded.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 6 -- Though the schedules attached to the Anglo - Australian trade agreement reached at Ottawa will remain confidential until the return of H.S. Gullett, Commonwealth Minister of Trade and Customs, a statement issued on behalf of the government says they will increase two-way trade with Great Britain.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Announcement that the Federal Farm Board would hold back its wheat for the remainder of the year was not unexpected by the trade. However, it had a decided effect in the wheat pit at the opening of the board of trade here today, general buying carrying prices up 2 cents from Saturday's finish, the May selling at a new high mark for the season.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- France's reply to the German request for reconsideration of the military conditions of the Treaty of Versailles is expected to be completed and perhaps delivered by the end of this week.

While the major commodity markets here advanced early yesterday and then reacted, prices on the minor exchanges continued upward to the close of trading, some of them making the widest gains of the year. Coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, wool tops and silver were among the staples which appreciated steadily.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- Kaye Don, British speedboat pilot, announced today that the damage that put his challenger. Miss England III, out of the Harmsworth Trophy race yesterday was more serious than at first believed and that the craft would be shipped direct to England for repairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The directors of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, the largest bank in the Middle West, voted today to nationalize that institution. They voted also to set up special reserves of $40,000,000 out of surplus to cover possible losses and they reduced the dividend rate to $8 a share annually.

CORMORANT LAKE, Man., Sept. 6 -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan arrived here tonight with two other physicists from Pasadena, Cal. Tomorrow Dr. Millikan and his assistants will go aloft in their "flying laboratory" to study cosmic rays at high altitudes.

The Eighth Avenue subway, which will begin revenue operation a 12;01 A.M. on Saturday, was in spected yesterday by engineers of the Transit Commission, who reported that it was ready for safe operation.

The new parade ground of Camp Mulrooney, the police recruit training camp in Pelham Bay Park, was officially dedicated yesterday by the Police Commissioner after a military display by 500 "rookies" that brought enthusiastic applause from several thousand spectators.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Announcement that the Federal Farm Board would hold back its wheat for the remainder of the year was not unexpected by the trade. However, it had a decided effect in the wheat pit at the opening of the board of trade here today, general buying carrying prices up 2 cents from Saturday's finish, the May selling at a new high mark for the season.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- France's reply to the German request for reconsideration of the military conditions of the Treaty of Versailles is expected to be completed and perhaps delivered by the end of this week.

While the major commodity markets here advanced early yesterday and then reacted, prices on the minor exchanges continued upward to the close of trading, some of them making the widest gains of the year. Coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, wool tops and silver were among the staples which appreciated steadily.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Although numerous States competed, New Jersey entrants, both amateur and professional, won the most coveted prizes in today's events in the national Atlantic City flower and garden pageant in the Auditorium.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity shows a further small decline to 17.6 for the week ended Sept. 3 from 18.5 for the preceding week and 41.7 for the corresponding week last year. The actual rate of operations, according to Steel, dropped a point to 13 1/2 per cent of capacity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Reiteration of Germany's demand for equality in armaments, as voiced today by Defense Minister von Schleicher, with the assertion that Germany would do what was necessary for defense and was ready to defend East Prussia, caused disquiet here.

ST. GEORGE, Bermuda, Sept. 6 -- The first phase of the New York Zoological Society's latest scientific venture has begun in preparation for the descent of William Beebe and Otis Barton one-half mite into the sea.

At the two-day auction sale of Long Beach lots held over the Labor Day week-end by Joseph P. Day, auctioner, 148 lots were sold for $92,700. Many of the buyers bought lots for improvement with dwellings for their own occupancy, Mr. Day said.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- The simultaneous offensive started Friday on all fronts, a Federal communique asserts, is developing favorably for the Federals.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- The presence in Paris of Senator David A. Reed of Pennsylvania, who arrived last night to be a guest of Walter E. Edge, United States Ambassador, for a week has caused some French newspapers to think that he intends to have important interviews with Premier Herriot and other French officials to give the Washington Administration's views on disarmament and war debts.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press) -- April the Fifth, winner of the Derby this year, will start in the classic St. Leger at Doncaster tomorrow, it was announced today. F. Lans, who rode the surprise horse to victory at Epsom Downs will again have the mount.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A jury of seven men and five women, after three days of deliberation, today convicted Frank J. Egan, ousted City Public Defender, and his associate. Albert J. Tinnin, and recommended they be imprisoned for life for the slaying of Egan's former friend and client, Mrs. Jessie Scott Hughes.

It is painful to hear Chairman MACY publicly admonish Mr. ALAN Fox, organizer of Hoover clubs, first on his own hook and now subject to the control of the State Committee. The chairman threatens to "fire" the organizer, whose chief accuser is Borough President HARVEY of Queens.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- The simultaneous offensive started Friday on all fronts, a Federal communique asserts, is developing favorably for the Federals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7 -- The expanding universe now has a secure place in science, declared Sir Arthur Eddington, Plumian Professor of Astronomy at Cambridge University, speaking tonight before the International Astronomical Union at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was influenced by the approaching government crop estimate, but prices held within a range of about $1 a bale and ended unchanged to 6 points higher than on Tuesday.

The unemployment census ordered by Mayor McKee to determine the exact number of unemployed in the city and of the destitute and truly needy among them will begin on Monday, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney after a conference in his office at Police Headquarters.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 7 -- A committee to study the proposal of James R. Sheldon for reorganization of the Waterbury Clock Company was appointed by the stockholders today and report recommendations to them on Sept. 15. It is proposed to issue $500,000 of preferred stock, to transfer voting power from the common shares to the preferred and to elect a new board of directors to end the temporary receivership of the company.

One cause of action, in a suit by Mrs. Nanette Gude Bayne, daughter of the late O.J. Gude, outdoor advertising man, against her former husband, Jasper Bayne, and others for $750,000 for libel and for conspiracy to ruin her reputation, was stricken out yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Rosenman.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 7 -- The Munson Steamer Munloyal, which was reported early today to be in distress about 350 miles southeast of Frying Pan Shoals and at the mercy of a hurricane, sent word by wireless at 8:30 o'clock tonight that her officers did not know exactly where she was.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- The league-leading Cubs today made an inauspicious start on their last Eastern trip of the season by dropping a double-header to the Braves, 11 to 4 and 2 to 0. The double defeat cut Chicago's lead over Pittsburgh, which split two games with Brooklyn, to five games.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The second day's session of the annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor was adjourned abruptly late today, after an hour of dispute over the question of seating nine union local delegations whose votes were known to be in favor of one candidate for secretary of the federation.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The trial of three Nassau County policemen for manslaughter in connection with the alleged "third-degree" death of Hyman Stark, burglary suspect, seemed to be nearing its close here late this evening. The State had rested, and indications were that the jury would get the case about noon tomorrow.

A campaign aiming to prevail upon chain stores and large retailers to stop buying their women's garments from substandard and sweatshop sources and make possible thereby a general improvement of conditions in the garment industry was begun yesterday by the cloak and suit commission at a meeting in the office of George W. Alger, impartial chairman of the industry, 132 West Thirty-first Street.

If this "Yankee Nation" ever prided itself on anything, it has been on its ability to drive a shrewd trade. From selling wooden nutmegs and swapping horses up to arrangements for foreign commerce, we have always boasted of our power to make shrewd bargains.

ROTTERDAM, Sept. 7.-- Captain Van Dulken of the liner Rotterdam, discussing the ship's mutinous voyage today, said he gave the crew a signed document promising to return to Rotterdam only when he discovered his vessel was in danger near Boulogne with the fall of the tide.

JOHN VAN RYN, ex-Princetonian, suddenly developed a stubborn streak in the tennis debate at Forest Hills yesterday. He was playing Henri Cochet in the first match on the stadium court and proceeding peacefully out of the tournament, as was more or less expected, when a great change came over him. Cochet had two sets in and was leading, 7 -- 6, in the third set.

The plea advanced Tuesday night by Ralph K. Jacobs, chairman of the courts committee of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities and an Assistant District Attorney in Kings, for he establishment of a magistrate's court for the arraignment, trial and sentence of youths from 16 to 19 years of age brought from Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald yesterday the announcement that such a project would be launched this Fall.
A mortgage on 36 W. 28th St. on which $37,OOO is due was extended to Sept. 1, 1835, at 5 per cent in an agreement made between Laura A. Bohne, owner of the premises, and the Central Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- A denial, in the name of Secretary Hurley, of charges that the War Department leased the Newark Army Base illegally to the Mercur Corporation was filed today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.

GLEN COVK, L.I., Sept. 7. -- Three Brooklyn youths were rescued from Long Island Sound today by the crew of a ferryboat, after a cabin cruiser from which they had been fishing caught fire and sank about a mile off shore from the estate of J. P. Morgan near here.

All fishermen are supposed to fee philosophers. If luck is against them today they take it in good grace and await a better day. In course of time every angler gets about all the fish he wants; but he is never satisfied at that, for if he has had good luck with blues, for instance, and he has also brought in a good string of striped bass or blackfish, he still seeks some other variety.
MONTREAL, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) . -- Montreal won the closing double-header of a six-game series today from Buffalo, 6-5 in ten. innings and 5-2.
Lou Salica, America's amateur boxing flyweight champion, squared accounts last night with Steve Enekes, Hungarian fighting lad who is the Olympic champion.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Rudy Vallee and his young actress wife, the former Fay Webb, have been reconciled.

Heads of city departments, whose salaries are to be cut to $12,000 annually from the present figures of $15,000 to $22,500 under Mayor McKee's economy program, continued to indicate yesterday that they would accept the proposed reductions. In addition, Controller Berry and the Borough Presidents promised to cooperate in the Mayor's economy program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorials as well as many other authentic utterances of recent circulation point unmistakably to the logic, wisdom, good public policy and inevitableness of the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Lehman as candidate for Governor of New York on the Democratic ticket.
TORONTO, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Rochester swept the five-game series with Toronto by taking both ends of today's double-header, 17-9 and 6-1.

A call for the observance of a "special week of penitence and prayer" beginning Oct. 2 to discover for the nation "the way to peace and power" has been issued by leading clergymen of most of the Protestant denominations, it was disclosed yesterday in the September issue of the Federal Council, the official organ of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- An average of thirteen persons a week write or telegraph. Republican campaign headquarters here that they think "Who But Hoover?" would be a very apt campaign slogan.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 7. -- After the liveliest campaign the Pine Tree State has witnessed in the last generation, its voters will go to the polls on Monday and elect a Governor and a State Auditor, three Representatives to Congress and members of both branches of the State Legislature.

The Hoover Administration was urged to use the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to prevent wagecutting by the railroads, in a statement issued through the Democratic National Committee yesterday by Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Operation of a fortnightly joint service by the Prince and Silver Lines in their New York-Far East round-the-world voyages from Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific Coast ports, was sanctioned by the Shipping Board today.

The valor of American racquets cut a broad swath through the foreign field in the men's national tennis championship yesterday, leaving Henri Cochet of France as the sole remaining invader in the running as the play reached the quarter-finals at the West Side Terms Club in Forest Hills.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- The Farm Board was accused of an attempt to mislead the public in declaring that its wheat holdings had been almost entirely removed from the American market, in a statement by Peter B. Carey, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, today.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith is expected to issue a statement defining his position on Democratic national, State and local politics within the next few days.

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 7 -- Miss Clara Dinsmore of the Edgartown Yacht Club, Martha's Vineyard, took a long lead today toward the women's sailing championship by winning two races of the five to be held by the Cohasset Yacht Club for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup.

ATHENS, Sept. 7 -- The possibility of a military coup d'etat, accompanied by serious bloodshed, increases steadily as the elections on Sept. 25 approach. Newspapers of all political shades openly discuss the danger, and both Premier Venizelos and his principal opponent, Panayoti Tsaldaris, threaten each other with unconstitutional action.

Wednesday, Sept. 7, 1932. The money market was quiet, with quotations for all classes developing no change from the preceding session. Funds were in good supply, but demand was small. Stock Exchange day loans were 2 per cent but Street trades went at 1 1/4 and Federal funds at 1/8 Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were firm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Norman H. Davis of New York, a member of the American delegation to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva, who, with Frederic M. Sackett, Ambassador to Germany, will represent the United States on the Organing Committee for the world Monetary and Economic Conference, conferred with State Department officials today on matters connected with both conferences.

Drawing attention to an increase in the national average of steel ingot production this week from 13 to 14 1/2 per cent, The Iron Age in its weekly review expresses the opinion that "further gains in operation this month are largely dependent on the volume of incoming business for immediate requirements, as steel mills have virtually no backlog tonnage on their books."

Two men who are charged with having mulcted the public of $1,700,000 in a scheme that involved the supposed sale of plain clay bricks were placed on trial yesterday before Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy and a jury on an indictment alleging mail fraud in ten counts.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Miss Frances Snyder of Apawamis captured the low gross prize in the qualifying test and triumphed in the first round of match play as the two-day, nine-hole match play golf tournament of the "Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association opened today at the Green Meadow Country Club course.

Representatives of the longshoremen of the seven principal North Atlantic ports of the United States conferred here yesterday afternoon and last night on terms of a wage contract which they plan to submit next Monday to a committee of steamship owners.

Mayor McKee announced yesterday that he would be ready within a few days to announce the course he believes the city should follow to protect its substantial interest in the Interborougb. receivership now pending in Federal court. The policy will be based, he disclosed, not only upon recommendations already made by the Transit Commission, Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly and Samuel Untermyer, but also upon his own independent investigation and study.

Only a few days of vacation remain for more than 1,000,000 children who must return to their desks in the city's public schools Monday. With an estimated enrolment of 1,095,580 pupils, there will be an increase over last term of nearly 7,000 students, all the increases being in the high schools.

Ed-win P. Maynard, chairman of the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Trust Company, who this month celebrates the completion of fifty years in banking, finds the United States showing definite signs of pulling itself out of the economic depression. The upturn, he feels, is plainly visible.

CORMORANT LAKE, Man., Sept. 7. -- After being forced down on a lake about 300 miles from here, Flying Officer R.A. Gordon returned to this base today bearing delicate recording instruments which he car ried 21,000 feet into the air yesterday to allow Dr. Robert A. Millikan to record the effect of altitude upon cosmic rays.

The unexpected presence last night of Mrs. Johanna Lindloff, president of the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association, at a mass meeting sponsored by the Teachers' Committee to Protect Salaries at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, and her insistence on stating the position of her organization led to heckling, arguments and almost to a free-for-all fight.

Plans for taking a direct part in the settlement of the country's railroad, difficulties were announced yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, members of which hold 15 per cent of the railroads' bonds. The announcement, made by Wilson G. Wing, president of the association, stated that a committee on railroad investments had been formed by the savings bankers under the chairmanship of Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Sept. 7. -- A rowdy scene was caused in the State Parliament today by supporters of J. T. Lang, former Premier of New South Wales, in the ladies' gallery, who loudly clapped and cheered Mr. Lang on his arrival.

While common stocks were rising during August so extensively that a theoretical gain of more than $7,000,000,000 was added to the value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange, bonds also continued the advance begun a month before.

Rallying behind the first-rate pitching of Freddy Heimach at Ebbets Field yesterday the Dodgers eked out a 4-to-2 victory over the Pirates in the nightcap, after losing the first game, 8 to 3, while a crowd of 12,500 fans, who spent the early part of the afternoon jeering their favorites, rewarded their climactic triumph with welcome applause.

Patrolman Peter De Carlo, who was fatally wounded last Friday when he and other policemen frustrated a hold-up in the Red Hook district of Brooklyn, received an inspector's funeral yesterday at the Church of St. Mary Star of the Sea, Court Street and Fifth Place, midway between the scene of the shooting and his home.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Governor Roosevelt swept through rock-ribbed, Republican Vermont in whirlwind fashion today and declared to enthusiastic crowds that he had an even chance or better to capture the electoral vote of the Green Mountain State.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Collegiate football tactics -- the master plays of university coaches, particularly the formations made famous by the late Knute Rockne -- are being taught the members of the Sing Sing eleven of 32 in secret practice, It was learned today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- C.V. Whitney's Magnifico won the $2,000 guaranteed Grange Handicap, feature race at the State Fair today. The victor paid 3 to 1.

Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, who returned yesterday on the Europa, accompanied by Mrs. Celler, predicted that beer and light wines would be legalized at the next session of Congress. In anticipation of this he said that he went abroad as a member of the Judiciary Committee to study the licensing systems of various European countries.

Supporters of Colonel William J. Donovan for the Republican nomination for Governor have arranged for three Brooklyn political leaders to attend a private dinner tonight at Colonel Donovan's home, 1 Beekman Place, it was revealed yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 7. -- A world's record was hung up for 2-year-old pacers in the first heat of the Frank P. Fox $6,477 stake during the Grand Circuit meeting at the State Fair Grounds today, when His Majesty, driven by Walton, flashed across the finish wire in the remarkable time of 2:02.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- France's reply to the German request for equal armament rights and the suppression of the limitations of the Treaty of Versailles was laid before the Cabinet by Premier Herriot today and will be communicated, it is expected, to Berlin toward the end of the week.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 7 -- Rallying around an American flag, a crowd of striking farmers today repulsed 100 Sheriff's deputies who tried to provide safe passage through picket lines near here for a caravan of live-stock trucks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Roused by curiosity over the recent controversy with regard to the B.E. F. colony established at the foot of West Seventy-ninth Street, I went there to see for myself what it was like. What I saw made my heart stand still and kept me awake all night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Details of a campaign, to bring out a vote of 50,000,000 in November were outlined to President Hoover today by Sourtlandt Otis of New York City, president of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce and head of a "get-out-the-vote" drive.

Forward passing will play a large part in Columbia's football offense this Fall, Coach Lou Little revealed yesterday as the Blue and White commenced serious preparation in this department. The afternoon drill was given over chiefly to testing the passing and receiving ability of the backs.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 7. -- Conviction that preferences could be given to European grain exporting countries without spoiling the markets for overseas producers, and that the United States would not object to exempting them from the operation of the most-favored nation clauses in its treaties was expressed by the French and German delegates today at the conference on Central Europe.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The first word of Ruth's departure received by Roth or Arthur Fletcher. Yankee coach, came from newspaper men who had heard Ruth was seen, boarding a Michigan Central train.

PEORIA, HI., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Deputy Sheriff C.O. Skinner was held in the county jail tonight for lack of bail on a murder charge growing out of the death last week of a prisoner in the Tazewell County Jail at Pekin.

DETROIT, Sept. 7. -- Threatened with what he fears is an attack of appendicitis, Babe Ruth hastily checked out of the Yankees' headquarters at the Book-Cadillac Hotel tonight, and, accompanied by Mrs. Ruth, boarded the 8:30 P.M. train for the East, due to arrive in New York about 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.
LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Ambassador Mellon arrived here today, refreshed by his vacation, but even more uncommunicative than when he landed at New York a month ago.

E.R. Bradley's Barn Swallow, a daughter of Black Servant from Blue Warbler, gave the master of Idle Hour Farm his third victory in the $22,400 Matron Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday after a claim of foul left the result in doubt for almost a quarter of an hour.

An exhibition of paintings by George Peixotto has just opened at the Balzac Galleries, 229 Park. Avenue, to remain until Sept. 29. Mr. Peixotto, who says he is "proud to continue the solid traditions of Degas, Renoir, Uuveneck and Eakins," has carefully selected twelve canvasses as representative of his artistic aims over a considerable period -- from 1877 to 1893.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While on a vacation in the Maine woods, where I kept in touch with the world by the daily receipt of THE NEW YORK TIMES, I read with interest a letter of Samuel Grabel suggesting that an investigation be had of the civil courts of this city, particularly the Municipal Court and the City Court.

MAHWAH, N.J., Sept. 7. -- While temporarily deranged, Norman Falconer, 56 years old, former real estate man and accountant in New York, killed his wife with a hammer while she slept this morning at their home on Beveridge Road in the exclusive Cragmere Park section here.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee indicated yesterday that his next point of attack in his drive to cut city expenses would be the salaries protected by mandatory legislation in the Education Department and the Board of Transportation.

The responsibility of the individual for the happiness and well-being of the world as a whole is stressed by Hendrik Willem van Loon in "Van Loon's Geography," to be published today by Simon Schuster. The book has been chosen by both the Book-of-the-Month Club and the Scientific Book Club.
Red Delegations at City Hall. Communist leaders could not conceal surprise when Mayor MCKEE granted their request for an opportunity to set forth their views on the unemployment situation.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 7 -- On a plat form which called for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and revision of the State enforcement act and opposed increase in State taxes, the Republican State Convention today put a full ticket in the field, headed by former Governor Jonathan H. Trumbull, who has been drafted from his retirement to become again a Gubernatorial candidate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Elsie Goldsack Pittman and Miss Joan Ridley, both of England, won their way to the semi-final round of the women's Middle States singles championship today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- A flood of realization sales brought a heavy reaction in prices at today's session of the Boerse, which for several days had experienced one of the most spectacular booms in its post-war history, resembling somewhat the Hoover moratorium boom last year.

Several hundred football officials and coaches from throughout the East will gather at the Hotel McAlpin on Saturday for the annual interpretation meeting of the rules committee of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association.

WASHINGTON, Sect. 7. -- "Housing clinics" are proposed in a report published today by the President's Conference on Home Building and Home Ownership. Poorly planned and inefficient housing is held largely responsible for much needless impairment of home and family life.
Back from the frontiers, the Giants entrenched themselves in the Polo Grounds yesterday to complete their remaining string of games and forthwith bowled over the Reds.

About twenty properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were put up at auction yesterday. As a result of the forced sales, the offerings were bid in by interested parties, most of these being banks and holding companies for lending institutions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Deluged with applications for direct loans from home owners, the Federal Home Loan. Bank Board is speeding its preparatory work so that the twelve regional banks may be opened on Oct. 15 as originally contemplated. Stock subscription books will be opened on Sept. 15 and subscriptions will be received up to the actual time of opening the regional banks.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Kansas City Star quoted Henry Bern today as saying that Paul Bern had supported in a sanitarium a woman with whom he lived many years before his marriage to Jean Harlow.

CLEARFIELD, Pa., Sept. 7. (AP). -- John Mahalleck, State trooper, was busy today serving warrants on nine men charged by Garret Schenck, a Hopewell fish peddler, with holding him captive for seventy-six days following the Lindbergh, kidnapping.

With his popular strength increased greatly by his inauguration of a program of economy and salary slashing, Mayor Joseph V. McKee became yesterday a possibility as the nominee for Mayor on the regular Democratic, independent Democratic or fusion tickets.

Automobile shares led a broad advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday as Wall Street gave credence to predictions of increased business for the leading motor-car manufacturers. The stocks of motor accessory companies participated in the rise.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Baltimore made only six hits, but scored seven runs tonight and won from Albany, which collected twelve hits, 7 to 6. The victory put the Orioles back in second place.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7. -- A stack of dirty dishes in a home which had been closed here for the Summer, led to the discovery that an intruder had moved in during the family's absence, slept on the best beds and used up all the canned goods in the kitchen.

Increases in premium rates for workmen's compensation insurance have been asked in the case of 619 classifications, decreases are proposed for seventy-eight classifications and 112 classifications remain unchanged, it was disclosed yesterday at the State Insurance Department.

Fortified by the authoritative view of the tri-district executive board that a wage reduction should be opposed with every resource, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and his associates, conferred for the second time yesterday afternoon with the anthracite operators' committee, which has asked for a "wage modification."

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 7 (AP). -- A new treaty between the United States and Haiti providing for "Haitianization" of the Garde d'Haiti, among other things, was submitted today by the Haitian Government to its Parliament for ratification.

With no great stir of activity -- in fact, with a smaller total business than Tuesday's -- yesterday's stock market resumed its advance, practically canceling the previous day's declines. The forward movement was distributed pretty evenly throughout the list; it affected railway shares equally with industrials.

KENOSHA, Wis., Sept. 7. -- Definite trends upward in economic recovery were cited before the Wisconsin Methodist Conference here today by John J. Phoenix of Dolavan. president of the Bradley Knitting Company.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Golf professionals from scattered parts of the country were assembling tonight for the Glens Falls open tourney, which has grown steadily in importance since it was inaugurated in 1929.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. -- 7 "Business has struck bottom!" Ralph Wilson, vice president of the Babson statistical organization, told the nineteenth National Business Conference here toay.

Less than $90 separated the first and second bids yesterday for an issue of $3,052,323 city of Los Angeles (Cal.) bonds. It was one of the lowest "covers" on municipal bonds awarded in recent weeks through competitive, sealed bidding.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Sept. 7. -- If Paul Bern had another woman in his life prior to Jean Harlow, Marino Bello, his widow's stepfather and counselor, knew nothing of it and he said today that Miss Harlow was not concerned or else did not know of it.

Prices of New York City bonds rose sensationally yesterday, gains of 2 1/2 to 4 1/4, points on the long-term issues representing the greatest advance for a single day in the history of the market. With the city's long-term debt aggregating approximately $2,265,000,000, the net increase in the market value of bonds outstanding in the hands of the public amounted to $45,300,000 yesterday on the basis of an average gain of 2 points.

It is to be wished that it were possible to place in the hands of every contributor to the Gibson Committee Fund a copy of the report of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau set up primarily for the purpose of administering work relief during the past year.

By the nomination of former Governor TRUMBULL, the Connecticut Republicans have put up probably the strongest man they could find. He may have to be mighty strong to beat Governor CROSS. Judging from tha speech, of Senator WALCOTT as temporary chairman, of the State convention, the prospects of the righteous in Rorabackia are not so rosy as reports of Democratic disaffection have indicated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Increasing prospects for a Republican victory were reported to President Hoover today from both the East and the West, coupled with tidings of new confidence as to the eventual outcome of the economic stress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade lacked today the activity that had been such an outstanding feature recently. According to trade gossip, some Eastern and local operators are said to believe it is a little prelnature to attempt to bring about a sustained advance in the face of the heavy hedging pressure against the movement of the Spring grain crop on both sides of the International line.

A resolute advance in the last two hours of trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday tended to remove the uncertain attitude which the speculative element had adopted in the morning. There was a burst of strength shortly before the close, and the net result was a rise of more than $2 in the average of fifty stocks, of $3.19 in twenty-five industrials and of 87 cents in twenty-five railway issues.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Indian Runner, a son of Dis Donc -- Indian Maiden, owned by D.A. Wood, raced to a new track record for seven 'furlongs today in winning the Oak Park Purse at Lincoln Fields.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Frank J. Helmle of Knollwood, 61-year-old devotee of golf, turned in a 41, 42-83 card today to lead the field in the first round of the fifth annual Westchester County senior championship over the Knollwood Country Club links.

DETROIT, Sept. 7. -- Drastic readjustments of wage schedules, it is stated in some quarters, are being drafted by the Ford Motor Company to affect the entire organization excepting workers now employed at the minimum scale. Officials of the company refused to comment.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The stock markets were irregular today on profit-taking and yesterday's late reaction in Wall Street, but quotations were only slightly easier. Dealers believed a continued sharp rise would lead to an unhealthy position. Commodities were lower in several instances, rubbar touching 3 1-32d.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Barring a last-minute compromise, Connecticut Democrats were ready to carry their factional fight over the make-up of the State ticket to the floor of the State convention tomorrow morning. The convention opened at 8 o'clock tonight with a keynote address by Robert P. Butler, a Hartford lawyer, but no controversial questions came before the first session.

Thirty field workers of the Near East Foundation, scheduled to sail within the next four days for their posts were told by directors of the foundation last night that they were true missionaries, though without creed or dogma. The meeting, held at the Gramercy Park Hotel, 52 Gramercy Park, was the second session of a two-day conference of the foundation, which was known formerly as the Near East Relief.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Thirty-three women have accepted invitations to serve as members of the Women's Hoover Committee of New Jersey, the State Republican Committee announced today. The work of organizing the commission for the pre-election work for President Hoover was undertaken by Mrs. Edna B. Conklm of Morristown and Mrs. Elizabeth C. Verga of Camden, vice chairman of the State committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- A great new astronomical observatory, housing an 80-inch reflecting telescope, is to be constructed and operated under a cooperative agreement between the University of Chicago and the University of Texas.

Although the daily ingot output of the nation's steel companies declined last month to a new low level, the total production of steel ingots increased 39,869 tons, August containing two more working days than July, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- President von Hindenburg will return from Neudeck in East Prussia tomorrow, the negotiations between the Centrists and the National Socialists looking toward a Parliamentary coalition to confront and displace the von Papen Cabinet will be resumed, and the political pot will boil in the hope of making a palatable stew for the newly elected Reichstag when it meets Monday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- James Roosevelt, son of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was one of the speakers at a Democratic rally, was the guest to day with his wife of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Parish at their home here.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 7. -- The annual exhibition of painting, sculpture and decorative arts and crafts under the auspices of the Pittsfield Art League opened this afternoon at the Berkshire Museum at Pittsfield. Miss Priscilla Colt of Pittsfield, granddaughter of the late Zenas Crane, founder of the museum, is showing five pieces of pottery.
MADRID, Sept. 7 -- The National Assembly approved tonight a law providing for the distribution for social welfare of about $30,O00,O00 worth of confiscated Jesuit properties.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, Sept. 7. -- With more enthusiasm than hitherto displayed, this year's meeting of the delegates to the Trades Union Congress today cheered George Lansbury, leader of the Parliamentary Labor party, when he opened an attack on "that great Frankenstein monster called the money market."

More Orders for Better Goods. Reports in the markets here indicate that consumer demand for better merchandise is shaping up more favorably than was anticipated earlier. In a number of cases, it was reported, buyers who concentrated almost entirely on medium to low end lines have made hurried additional trips to the market here to purchase better lines, particularly dresses.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 7. -- President Hoover was urged today by Representative Bowman of West Virginia to use his offices in releasing about $5,000,000,000 which are said to be tied up in solvent and operating banks.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 7 -- While Akira Ariyoshi, the Japanese Minister to China, was visiting Nanking today to exchange platitudes with the Chinese officials there was a distinct tightening of Chino-Japanese tension at Shanghai, Peiping, Canton and other population centres.

Men's clothing, the value of which was estimated at $60,000, was destroyed by vandals some time during the week-end in the plant of Jack Siegel, 160 Fifth Avenue, the police disclosed yesterday. The estimate of value was made by Mr. Siegel.

The Musicians' Emergency Aid Committee will be reorganized on a permanent basis in October, Walter Damrosch announced yesterday. Proceeds of the five symphony concerts which are to be given in Madison Square Garden this season will be used to establish a permanent endowment fund.

"How not to do it," according to CHARLES DICKENS, "was the great study and object of all public departments and professional politicians all around the Circumlocution Office." It has been the great study and object of public departments and professional politicians all around our own Peripatetic Office.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 7 -- A hurricane was reported 360 miles southwest of Bermuda at 8 o'clock tonight and is expected to pass the islands before sunrise. The residents are busy securing their houses against the expected storm.

Because Mayor McKee will be unable to participate, the Board of Transportation canceled yesterday its plan for an official inspection trip over the new Eighth Avenue subway line, with the members of the Board of Estimate as guests. The trip was to have started at 3 P.M. tomorrow on board one of the regularly scheduled trains.

Dr. William L. Love, to whom the Democrats denied redesignation for the State Senate, but who is seeking re-election as an independent in the Democratic primaries and as the Republican candidate, charged John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, yesterday with attempting: to influence his vote for a continuance of the Seabury inquiry into New York City's municipal affairs when legislation relating to it came before the State Senate last Winter.

Democratic Governors of New York and New Jersey whom Tammany has opposed or secretly knifeo as Presidential candidates have been elected -- CLEVELAND and WILSON. The Democratic Governor of New York whom Tammany favored was beaten for the Presidency -- ALFRED E. SMITH.

Mothers are still terrorizing their young. In "Best Years," which was acted at the Bijou last evening, old Mother Davis does all that she can to wreck the life of her most unselfish child. Since the child is played by Katherine Alexander with all the suppressed emotion of which this fine actress is capable, Raymond Van Sickle's play has its moments of anguish.

The prediction that "dry" members of Congress will have disappeared, as far as New York State is concerned, after the November election, was made yesterday by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, New York State Chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The 10 per cent cut in expenditures provided in the economy act applies to the $100,000,000 Federal building program included in the unemployment relief act, Controller General Mc-Carl ruled today.

A rise of $3,556,700 in monetary gold stocks was reflected in yesterday's report of gold transactions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A gain of $1,735,600 resulted from the release of metal earmarked for foreign account, $299,900 of the amount being reported as additional for Monday.

Mrs. Thais Kisleff Blazer, wife of Dr. Alfred Blazer of 256 West Tenth Street and understudy to Mme. Leontovitch in "Grand Hotel," was accused yesterday of striking her husband's lawyer, David Schenker, while the latter was telling the matrimonial troubles of the Blazers to Supreme Court Justice Untermyer.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I saw some happenings at the old Pearl Street Edison station that seem to have been forgotten.
The Publishers Association of New York agreed yesterday to arbitrate the question of wages and hours with Typographical Union No. 6, it was announced at the offices of the association, 280 Broadway.

YORK, England, Sept. 7 (AP). -- There are reasons for believing that the fairies of folklore were an actual race of men -- perhaps driven out by the influx of modern man -- the British Association for the Advancement of Science was told today.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Trading subsided today on the Bourse here and the session was comparatively dull. Irregularity in raw materials and in Wall Street, together with Defense Minister von Schleicher's declarations in Germany regarding East Prussia, which were viewed as unfavorable politically, fostered offerings which accumulated during the day.

Waistlines slightly elevated in the front and lower in the back, sleeves puffed from shoulder to elbow and high necklines were the high lights of the first collective exhibit for Fall and Winter held by the Fashion Originators Guild of America last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 7 -- E. L. Beard and his 14-year-old son, E. L. Beard Jr. captured the Long Island Father and Son Championship today at the Cherry Valley Club and took possession of the John M. Ward trophy for the year.

NEW YORK. Colonel and Mrs. James M.S. Waring will give a dinner Saturday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Sarah M. Chase, daughter of March F. Chase, and their son, Mowton Le Compte Waring, whose engagement has been announced.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Newark divided a doubleheader with Jersey City today, winning the first 3-2, and losing the final, 7 -- 4. Pete Jablonowski registered his ninth triumph in ten starts when he blanked Jersey City until the last inning of the opener.

Greater centralization of borough and county governments and less elasticity in budget-making were suggested last night as means of reducing the city's tax burden by Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the board of directors of the Irving Trust Company.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 29 (AP by Mail). -- After considerable delay ever the details, the Socialist Government's production and employment scheme has finally been put into effect.

KATONAH, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Norman Falconer had been office manager of H.E. Wood Co., a food brokerage concern, until it went out of business in 1930, Harry E. Wood, head of Wood-Hopkins, Inc., real estate brokers, of 100 Hudson Street, Manhattan, said at his home here tonight.

Treatment of all types of pneumonia cases by applying high-frequency current to patients' chests has resulted in saving thousands of lives in the last few years, the eleventh annual session of the American Congress of Physical Therapy, meeting this week at the Hotel New Yorker, was told yesterday by Dr. Harry E. Stewart, director of the New Haven School of Physical Therapy, and Commander C.S. Stephenson of the United States Naval Hospital, Brooklyn.

WARSAW, Sept. 7 -- General Douglas MacArthur, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, was met on his arrival here tonight by officers of the Polish General Staff and members of the Polish Government and the United States Embassy. After a hearty handshake with General Kasiorowski of Poland, General MacArthur was introduced to a score of other Polish officers.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Thirty seconds after the start of an extra period of sudden-death play, Gerald Balding poked through a short drive yesterday that carried Greentree into the final round of the national open polo championship, winners over Eastcott, 11 to 10, in one of the most bitterly fought games of any championship ever held.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 7. -- In answer to the 1932 football call forty-seven candidates for the New York University football team reported for the opening practice today at Farmingdale. Howard G. Cann, commencing his first season as head coach at N.Y.U., had invited fifty.

MONTREAL, Que., Sept. (AP). -- Retirement of eleven officers of the Canadian National Railways and abolition of fourteen offices were announced by the company today. This brings the total of offices abolished in interests of economy to fifty.

YORK, England, Sept. 7. -- Giving money to spendthrifts was the novel remedy for the depression proposed today by Professor John Rotherford Bellerby to the economic section of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

It will cause no surprise that the Federal Farm Board has a new policy. More than four months have elapsed since it last announced a program, and this is about as tongas the political and economic difficulties of its position permit it to follow one line consistently.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Winning all three heats, Invader captured the Governor's Cup in the feature harness racing event, the 3-year-old trot, on the Fair Grounds track today. The times were 2:09 1/2, 2:08 1/2 and 2:11 1/2.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- The Reichstag, reassembling Monday, will probably be sent home before the week is out. That is the prospect tonight, for the chances that any understanding can be reached whereby it will continue to "tolerate" the present Cabinet are virtually at the vanishing point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The strange disappearance of Colonel Raymond Robins, militant dry leader and personal friend of the President, at a time when he was on his way to an audience with Mr. Hoover, was revealed at the White House today.

An indictment charging three officials of the City Pharmaceutical Association with conspiracy was said to have been handed up by the Kings County Grand Jury yesterday. Assistant District Attorney Edward D. Kelly said he had finally persuaded one druggist, whose name he would not reveal, to testify on methods of the association, which is accused of racketeering.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8. -- The Netherlands Minister and Mrs. J.H. van Royen gave a dinner at their Summer home tonight. They will remain in Newport until the end of the month.

ATHENS, Sept. 8. -- Following attacks upon, him by Panayoti Tsaldaris, royalist leader, Premier Venizelos of Greece tendered his resignation to President Zaimis this afternoon. The President, however, refused to accept it and M. Venizelos is continuing in office.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 8. -- Another world's record developed at the lightning-fast track at the State Fair Grounds today during the Grand Circuit harness meeting, when Mac I Win, a 3-year-old, owned by C.F. Crowley, Cleveland, won the second heat of the Governor's 2:15 class pace in the fast time of 2:01.

Streamship owners and longshoremen prepares yesterday for their conference on Monday at which they will seek an agreement on wages and working Conditions for the coming year. Committees of the two groups met during the day but refused to announce the programs they will submit next week.

In no field of business is there greater need at present for vigorous and intelligent advertising policies than in finance, Francis H. Sisson, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and incoming president of the American Bankers Association, old members of the New York Financial Advertisers yesterday at their first luncheon of the season at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Electa Matilda Ziegler, widow of William Ziegler, founder of the Royal Baking Powder Company, who died on, Sept. 1 in her ninety-first year, left more than a quarter of her estate to the E. Matilda Ziegler Foundation of East Forty-second Street, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

The joint salary committee of sixty-two teachers' organizations in the city, representing virtually all of the 36,000 members of the public school teaching staff, voted unanimously yesterday against any reduction in salary schedules and reaffirmed its opposition to any attempts to interfere with statutory protection of their pay.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8. -- Frank J. Helmle, Knollwood Country Club golf champion, won the fifth annual Westchester County Golf Association's senior championship tournament, concluded today over his home club's course. Competing in Class B, for players from 60 to 70 years of age, Helmle, who is 61, carded a gross 171 for the thirty-six holes played during the two-day event.

Further reduction of the productive capacity of the cotton textile industry is necessary to make a lasting improvement in that line of business, Russell H. Leonard, treasurer of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company, said yesterday in a statement issued in conjunction with the annual report for the year ended on June 30, He said in part:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, after a survey, has discovered that homefinancing institutions in only eight States are now eligible to participate in the system as "member borrowers."

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Lieut. Col. Theodor Duesterberg, deputy leader of the Stahlhelm league of war veterans, will soon move his headquarters to Berlin, your correspondent was authoritatively informed today, and thereafter will take an even more active part in the affairs of the organization than heretofore.

BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Miss Mary Brodie, a registered nurse, 44 years old, was found living in the woods on the estate of the late Princeton Foster in North Babylon today. For more than a week she had existed on a meager amount of food begged in the village, with the leaves of a maple grove for her roof and a pile of old clothing for a bed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter fiom Joseph Braxton in reference to the recently publisned letter to Dr. Daniel A. Poling moves me to offer his contribution to the present confusion of thought and action on the wet and dry issue.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 8. -- The French and German plans for the rehabilitation of Central Europe are in almost complete agreement, it became known today when the French presented their proposals at secret meetings of the Stresa conference.

Charges against Samuel Kaplan, president of Local 306, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators, are being investigated and officers of the local are being examined by the national executive committee of the international at its headquarters, 1,450 Broadway, it was disclosed yesterday.

Reports from 167 Class 1 railroads to the Bureau of Railway Economics showed that in July they earned a net operating income of $11,596,000, against $56,960,000 in July, 1931, a drop of 79.6 per cent. This was the largest percentage of decline in any month this year.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published an article by Mr. Strunsky on "The German Democracy." Mr. Strunsky is very enlightening, but comes to two rather illogical conclusions.

Testifying yesterday before the board appointed by Mayor McKee to investigate charges of favoritism and discrimination in the operation of the work bureau of the City Emergency Work and Relief Administration, Major Leo B. Roberts, its director, protested that the charges were without foundation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Many inquiries as to the future of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra brought the assurance today from Charles H. Hamill, president of the Orchestral Association, that the season will open on Oct. 14. Negotiations regarding wage scales and personnel were arranged satisfactorily with the Chicago Federation of Musicians early in June and were announced at the time.

Like hounds baying after their quarry, the Government is after business. Not for itself, but for the ultimate benefit of merchants and manufacturers, it is following the trail of odor in commerce. The Department of Commerce has carried out perfumed experiments in selling silk stockings, and the results show that the hounds are on the right scent.

War whoops, shrill soprano versions of popular songs and the patter of boys' feet echoed and vibrated in the vast stations of the Eighth Avenue subway yesterday as youthful hoodlums invaded the hollow silence with the lifting of the station barricades.

Acute weakness in the cotton market which resulted from the publication of the government's crop forecast was assigned in Wall Street as the principal cause of the reaction on the Stock Exchange. The break in stocks just about canceled the advance of the day before.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Albany defeated Newark, 2 to 1, today, although held to three hits by Holsclaw. Two of them, with a base on balls and out, netted Albany both runs in the second inning. Newark grouped three of the seven safeties Campbell allowed for a tally in the third.

Just 100 years after rapid transit made its first appearance in New York City in the form of horse cars trundling along Fourth Avenue and just twenty-eight years after the first underground railway on Manhattan introduced what was fondly thought to be A transit millennium, the new Eighth Avenue line will open its gates tonight to the subterranean traveler.

A blustering northerly gale, swirling out of the Arctic region, descended upon New York yesterday, lashing shipping along the coast and doing widespread damage ashore. In its wake came abnormally cooler weather and in some sections frost.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wettach Jr.'s Trillora Farm entries of Crumpet and By Request proved a winning combination at the last afternoon's session of the Rochester Horse Show today when they made a perfect performance to take the class for pairs of jumpers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Ted Lyons pitched and batted the White Sox to a 4-to-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox in a ten-inning battle today. Lyons yielded only six scattered hits over the long route, singled in the tenth, moved up on Funk's sacrifice and scored on Hayes's hot grounder past Alexander.

The price of copper declined yesterday 5 to 15 points in the foreign market, but the domestic price was firm at 6.25 cents a pound for deliveries until the end of the year, with some producers willing to accept contracts for the first quarter of 1933.

HAVANA, Sept. 8. -- The Patriotic League, an unofficial organization acting in conjunction with the secret police in apprehending enemies of the government and one of the most unpopular and feared organizations in Cuba, has been disbanded by Brigadier Antonio Baincairt, the new Chief of National Police.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 8. -- Two petitions, requesting that the Independent Republican party be given a place on the ballot at the State election, have been filed in the Hartford district, with the avowed intention of defeating Hiram Bingham, Republican candidate for Senator, because of his stand on prohibition repeal.

What is needed in America today is renewed faith in the masses, V. F. Calverton, author and editor of The Modern Quarterly, asserts in his book, "The Liberation of American Literature," published today by Charles Scribner's Sons.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8. -- Astronomers who observe the next two total eclipses of the sun will find conditions quite different from those which prevailed for the eclipse last week. Only a couple of tiny islands in the South Pacific Ocean offer any hopes for the next, on St. Valentine's Day, 1934, while the one after that, on June 19, 1936, can best be observed from Central Siberia.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Stockholders of the St. Louis-San Francisco railway have been called to attend a special meeting here Monday morning for ratification of the financial readjustment plan, against which an injunction suit was filed in New York today.

The football teams of Columbia and Manhattan took part in their first scrimmage of the year yesterday at Baker Field before several hundred spectators. It was an informal combat, with no touchdowns being scored and the coaches directing the play.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Pardee, William Woodward's three-year-old, won the $2,000 added Governor's Handicap over a mile and seventy yards at the State Fair today. Footmark, from the stable of J.G. Lang, followed a half-length behind and C.V. Whitney's Magnifico, victor in the Grange Day feature yesterday, was third.
LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Airplanes dipped in salute and sirens hooted as the steamship Empress of Britain, bringing J.A. Mollison home after his east-west Atlantic flight, entered Southampton tonight.

The rapid transit subway service of New York, to which the independent city-owned system will add twelve miles of route today, already comprises about 210 route-miles, made up of seventy-five miles of subways and forty miles of elevated roads operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Corporation, and ninety-five miles of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Corporation's holdings of subway and elevated lines.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Jim Winford, making his last start before joining the St. Louis Cardinals, reeled off a sparkling triumph as the Rochester Red Wings vanquished the Buffalo Bisons tonight, 8 to 2.
