A will making a "Mrs. Dorothy Bern, my wife," the beneficiary of practically his whole estate was made twelve years ago by Paul Bern, the motion-picture executive who committed suicide Sunday in California, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- When Colonel Raymond Robins failed to keep his engagement Tuesday, the White House began making inquiries.
LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The executive committee of the Anti-Saloon League, which is now in session here is expected to adopt a resolution pledging the organization to keep out of the Presidential campaign and devote its activities to the election of members of Congress who will oppose the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

With the official opening of the Eighth Avenue subway at one minute after midnight tonight the city will embark upon the most significant and widespread municipal operation project in the nation's transportation history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The United States Chamber of Commerce has started a broad inquiry today into the possibilities of introducing shorter work periods in all American industries, with a view to the spreading of available employment in the present emergency; and adoption of the shorter hours as a permanent economic policy.

An injunction suit against the directors of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway and also against the readjustment managers of the road who comprise the executive committee of the directors, to declare void the readjustment plan affecting the holders of prior lien and consolidated mortgage bonds, was started yesterday in the Supreme Court by Cornelius A. Sullivan in behalf of himself and other bondholders.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Sept. 8. -- Paul Bern, husband of Jean Harlow, died of "a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the head," a coroner's jury investigating his death decided today. The jury heard half a dozen witnesses testify to what few facts are known of the film executive's death.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 8. -- The rehabilitation, of silver was urged as a step toward restoring prosperity by John Hays Hammond in an address today at the annual business conference at Babson Institute. He declared that the people of the world should "exert their influence in behalf of such rehabilitation."
A Welcome Change of Direction. Just how the natural forces of economic life operate in a revival of business may be illustrated in the case of the optical trade or the osteopath and massage trades.

The Cubs collected only three hits off Ed Brandt in the first seven innings of the opener, but they broke loose in the eighth with five blows and scored all their runs. Triples by Hartnett and Cuyler and singles by Jurges, Herman and English furnished the Chicago runs, Cuyler's three-bagger driving in the last two.

Langdon W. Post, who has repre- sented the Tenth Assembly District at Albany for the last four years, but who was refused redesignation by Tammany Hall this year because of his stand for the immunity bills asked by the Hofstadter committee, will open headquarters at 52 West Eighth Street tonight for his campaign on an independent Democratic ticket.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- The political fate of former Mayor James J. Walker of New York City remained in doubt tonight, as John F. Curry, leader of Tammany; John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, and David S. Rendt, Richmond County chairman, arrived to attend the meeting of the Democratic State Committee here tomorrow.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- A warning that, if necessary to serve the interests of the workers, the American Federation of Labor would organize an independent political party, was sounded by William Green, its president, in addressing the closing session of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor here today.

Seven and a half acres of shale land, one of the principal items, according to the government, in the Southern Cities Supply Corporation's valuation of its properties, were purchased from the Bama Brick Company for $76,000, Harry Watkins Sr., president of the latter company, testified yesterday in Federal court.

BUENGS AIRES, Sept. 8. -- The Chilean Foreign Minister, it is learned here, emphatically denied today that the ABC-Peru conversations at Santiago contemplated a blockade of Bolivia and Paraguay. The denial is interpreted in some quarters here as indicating disagreement among the ABC-Peru group, the possible breaking up of the bloc and assumption of new positions on the Chaco question according to the individual conveniences of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru.
PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Senator Henry Berenger, former Ambassador to the United States, in a widely quoted article in the Agence Economique to-

New York City teachers return to their desks this morning to prepare for their million pupils next week. The public may have the impression that the matter uppermost in their minds is compensation. This is an unwarranted inference. The teachers are as a rule the least self-seeking group of citizens.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 9 (AP). -- An arrangement recognizing China's sovereignty in Manchuria but proposing the establishment of its autonomy under Japanese advisors, official sources here said today, was recommended in the report of the League of Nations inquiry commission which is now filed with League headquarters at Geneva.

At midnight the new subway will be opened. People who have read about it and wondered if they would live to see it in operation may ride in the handsome new green cars marked "City of New York " twelve miles for a nickel. They will find the cars commodious and the platforms more spacious than those to which they are accustomed.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- News of the good Wall Street session on Wednesday and the rises in copper and tin prices stimulated the French Bourse at the start today and trading was fairly brisk. Toward the closing, however, extensive profit-taking developed.

Reversing the general practice of the Federal court in such cases, Judge Julian W. Mack ruled yesterday that the City Bank Farmers Trust Company may file a claim for $98,000,000 in the bankruptcy proceedings against the International Match.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 8. -- The Connecticut Federation of Labor adopted resolutions this afternoon favoring the six-hour day and the five-day week and endorsing the work of William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, and John R. Alpine, director of the United States Employment Service.

A few old books, carefully preserved in a Vermont farmhouse, have affected the history of this country by helping to mold the character of one of its Presidents, it is revealed in an article by former President Calvin Coolidge in the October Cosmopolitan Magazine, out today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Enthusiastic over assurances of support for the Gubernatorial nomination, Lieut. Gov. Lehman emerged from conferences with Democratic leaders here today to deliver at the State Fair a vigorous speech in which he demanded elimination of waste in governmental expenditures and the continuance of research work to aid both producers and consumers in solving their problems.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 8. -- At midnight last night the jury in the case of the three members of the Nassau County Police Department charged with manslaughter in the first degree in connection with the death of Hyman Stark had not reached a verdict.

A score of foreclosed properties were offered at auctioneers' stands yesterday. Fifteen are in Manhattan and five in the Bronx. All were bid in by the plaintiffs, who brought the foreclosure actions because of defaults in interest payments, nonpayment of taxes,

At least the'clouds of political depression have been utterly pushed away. To both parties the political skies are so bright that they can't safely be looked at save with smoked glasses. In what distant age did GEORGE M. STEARNS offer to assemble and address all Vermont Demo- crats in his back yard?

New construction contracts last month were 4 per cent above the July total in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountins, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. The August aggregate, $133,988,100, compares with $128,768,700 for July and $233,106,100 for August, 1931.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The North German Lloyd Company today announced it had designated the liner Westfalen as a floating air station in mid-Atlantic to facilitate the establishment of regular air mail between South America and Europe.
TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Miss Katharine Rawls, 14-year-old Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) girl retained her women's national A.A.U. 300-meter medley swim title tonight.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 (AP). -- A Telegraphen Union dispatch from Warsaw today said Governor Krahelsi of the Polesia district will be replaced by Colonel Kostek Biernacki, Governor of Nowogrodek, noted for his severe treatment of Opposition Parliamentarians when he was commander of Brest Litovsk prison.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Secrets of success in sports and work were told in discoveries about "warming up," reported today to the American Psychological Association at its three-day session here at Cornell University.

A committee that will undertake to formulate some plan of relief for small home owners in trouble with their mortgages and to lay such a plan before the local loan agency of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was announced here yesterday. Frank A. Vanderlip, retired banker, is chairman.

After a week of flurry and rumor and heated language about the Mayoralty of New York, a calmer and saner spirit is beginning to prevail. It is already certain that there will be no snap-judgment action. Even the Boss of Tammany Hall now admits that it will seek no decision before the middle of October.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The action of the cotton and stock markets and a tremendous movement of cash wheat in the Canadian Northwest led today to free selling of futures and a lower range of prices on the Board of Trade here. A small advance was made at one time, but it was followed by a selling movement after the government's cotton report had been issued and cotton had dropped $5 a bale.

This is bass weather. That chill that necessitated the addition of an extra blanket last night was welcomed by every fisherman whose heart is set on catching bass. It meant that his old friend now was ready to come out and do battle on a thousand lake fronts and as many rivers and streams.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A cotton crop this year of 11,310,000 bales was forecast by the Department of Agriculture today on the basis of the crop's reported condition on Sept. 1.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Miss Caroline Corey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Lyle Corey, whose Summer home is on the Chicken Valley Road in the Glen Head colony, was introduced to society tonight at a large supper dance given at the Piping Rock Club by her parents.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Monte Weaver, pitching his first year in the majors, recorded his twentieth victory of the season today in Washington's 3-to-1 triumph over the St. Louis Browns. Weaver allowed four safeties and the Browns' only run was unearned.

The directors of the American Petroleum Institute at their regular meeting yesterday recommended to its member companies, which constitute virtually the entire oil industry in the United States, that as an emergency action working schedules be reduced to a maximum of forty hours a week or an equivalent.

Harry A. Wheeler, president of the Railway Business Association and former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, was elected president of the Railroad Equipment Financing Corporation at an organization meeting yesterday. The corporation was formed to help railroads to buy equipment at this time through loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee struck body blows at two Tammany sources of patronage yesterday when he announced plans to consolidate the city's inspection services and its purchasing agencies into two compact, efficient units at what he expects will be a substantial saving.
BOSTON, Sept. 8. -- "What is 'Al' Smith going to do?"

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- Governor Roosevelt drafted plans today for his tour of the West, which his campaign managers hope will bring hitherto Republican electoral votes to the Democratic candidate for the Presidency.

Fewer than a thousand fans braved the Autumn chill and the brisk breezes at Ebbets Field yesterday to see the Dodgers romp away with the final game against the Pirates, 12 to 2, giving Brooklyn two out of three in the short series.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Playing a characteristic round of steady golf, Densmore Shute, former West Virginia State amateur champion and more recently a leading contender in the ranks of golf professionals, clipped three strokes from par and recorded a 68 to assume the lead in the first round of the Glens Falls open tourney today.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 8. -- As Governors, their representatives, agricultural leaders and politicians of Middle Western States were gathering here late today for the conference of Governors growing out of the farmers' 'strike' there seemed no well-defined plan for the meeting, aside from the general thought of "doing something for the relief of the farmers."

The Anall Stable's Larranaga ran his streak to four in a row yesterday at Belmont Park when he was just up to win the thirtieth running of the featured Manhattan Handicap in what was one of the closest finishes in the long history of the race.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Survival of the Unfit" prompts me to say a few words about our experience with the blind.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Over a course swept by a blustery, cold wind, T.T. (Teddy) Meehan, 17-year-old St. Paul's student, today won the qualifying round of the annual Long Island junior championship, outstripping thirty-five rivals in the race for the medal.

The National Players, Inc., which was recently formed, plans to offer condensed versions of popular Broadway plays in motion-pictur ehouses. The first will be a one-hour version of Arnold Ridley's "The Ghost Train," opening a three-day engagement at the Staten Island Paramount Theatre next Wednesday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 8. -- The question of an economic blockade of Bolivia and Paraguay if war between them is declared has not been broached in the conversations between Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru at Santiago, the Chilean Minister notified the Bolivian Foreign Office today.

Although city officials have decided to forego any official ceremony to mark the opening of the Eighth Avenue sub-way at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, the West Side Association of Commerce, which considers the event "too important to go unheralded," voted yesterday to hold a celebration of its own.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mayor Walker's resignation has raised two legal questions: (1) Whether Mr. McKee has become Mayor and (2) whether there can be an election for Mayor in November of this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Reconstruction Corporation expects to have the 1932 relief act in full operation within a fortnight.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP). -- The master of the Munson freighter Munloyal advised Coast Guard headquarters today that his vessel was in no immediate danger in the tropical storm area off the Florida coast and would not require their assistance.

An unexpected drop of $5 a bale in the price of cotton turned an exuberant stock market sharply about yesterday after prices had been lifted to new high ground for the Summer movement in the second heaviest trading since Oct. 10, 1930.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The full text of the new treaty of friendship between the United States and the Republic of Haiti, made public today by the State Department, together with the exchange of notes between the two governments, follows:

Harry Gold, 25 years old, owner of a book store at 97 Fourth Avenue, was indicted by the grand jury yesterday on the charge that he criminally possessed recently a copy of the original edition of Edgar Alien Poe's book of poems, "Al Aaraaf." published in the first half of the nineteenth century.
BROOKSVILLE, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Raymond Robins maintained a Winter home here. Recently he donated 2,200 acres of land near here to the Federal Government for a farm experiment station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Haiti will receive in large measure by the end of 1934 benefits that would have accrued in 1936 at the expiration of the present treaty with the United States, under the terms of the treaty of friendship signed last Saturday by Dana G. Munro, the United States Minister at Port au Prince, and Albert Blanchet, the Foreign Minister of Haiti.

It was an ideal day for an Army-Navy game, except that the high wind might have spoiled the kicking. As Sidney Wood and Wilmer Allison, shivering in their overcoats, came out to start their match on the stadium court, a suggestion was made that they play under Winter rules. It sounded like a good idea, but, unfortunately, it was vetoed by the committee.
PARIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Edward Carrick, grandson of the famous English actress, Ellen Terry, and son of Gordon Craig, scenic designer and author, will assist in the direction of Shakespeare's "Macbeth," which will be revived at the Old Vic, London, on Nov. 21, according to word received here.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The stock markets opened strong today, particularly the internationals, which rose rapidly following the resumption on Wednesday of the advance in Wall Street. Some irregularity developed as a result of profit-taking, but soon the market went ahead again on firm Continental reports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Private families in New York State at the time of the census in April, 1930, numbered 3,153,124. Of these 1,155,036 or 36.6 per cent, owned their homes; 1,957,733, or 62.1 per cent, were tenants, and 1.3 per cent made no statement as to tenure, the Census Bureau announced today.

In a day which was marked by more or less contrary movements in the different markets, with Wall Street apparently interested only in the cotton crop estimate, yesterday's Federal Reserve statement merited quite as much attention. The system's gain of gold for the week was shown to be $21,612,000, which was more than had been anticipated.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon chatted informally today about the coining American election, President Hoover's chances and business conditions at his first conference with American correspondents since his return to England.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- It is understood that the British Government has decided not to use the option expiring next Thursday provided by the Melton-Baldwin debt agreement for obtaining a partial postponement of the next American debt instalment.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Colonel Frank Knox, president and publisher of The Chicago Daily News, said over the radio tonight that the American people have "already passed several mileposts along the road back to normal times." Speaking over a network of the National Broadcasting Company, taking "Signposts of Improvement" for his text, he said:

The market for foreign loans showed to better advantage on the Stock Exchange yesterday than did that for domestic corporation issues. Trading was moderately active, the daily volume continuing at about $11,000,000. United States Government bonds closed irregular, with the lower-coupon Treasury issues showing the principal gains for the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- An all-British final in the women's Middle Stages tennis championship was made possible when Mrs. Elsie Goldsack Pittman and Miss Joan Ridley won their semi-final round matches at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, in a speech last night before the members of a newly formed Republican club at 162-38 Hawtree Avenue, Howard Beach, declared that Mayor Joseph V. McKee, in conferences with other members of the Board of Estimate, had announced his intention of cutting the city budget from $60,000,000 to $100,000,000 less than it was for this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 7, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,330,000,000, a decrease of $1,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,098,000,000 compared with the corresponding week of 1931.

The report made yesterday by the Department of Agriculture indicating a cotton crop 4,000 bales larger than had been estimated a month ago was the biggest surprise that the cotton trade has had in years. Prices broke more than a cent a pound, or $5 a bale, on the contract exchanges here and in New Orleans and stop-loss limits being uncovered when tens of thousands of bales were thrown on the market.

The Republican State Committee met yesterday at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, and, acting with the smoothness and celerity of a Tammany caucus, selected Buffalo for the Republican State Convention, and Oct. 3 and 4 as the dates.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 8. -- A squad of ninety-three, the largest ever to report for the football season, is expected tomorrow as Dartmouth swings into its preliminary work.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- "The German people are beginning to realize that the Hitler-Goebbels program is a lot of blatant braggadocio, full of sound and fury, that signifies nothing," according to Samuel Lamport, president of the Lamport Export Corporation of New York, who is on his way back to the United States after a visit to Russia.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Cardinal Hayes celebrated the fortieth anniversary of his priesthood at St. Joseph Sanitarium and Mountain School at St. Joseph, four miles from Monticello, today. Hundreds of telegrams were received by Cardinal Hayes from prominent church dignitaries and citizens.

Yesterday's weekly statement of the Federal Reserve reports another substantial addition ($21,612,000) to the system's gold, bringing the total gold reserve to $2,794,573,000. On June 15, when the large recall of " reserve credits in America " by the European central banks came to an end, it had fallen to $2,561,195,000.

Colonel William J. Donovan, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, visited his campaign headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday for the first time, and in a press interview predicted that President Hoover would carry New York State.

The formation of an endowed national theatre by the established producers and other representative stage organizations is again urged by the Theatrical Representatives of America, Inc., in the September issue of its magazine, The Quill. The proposal is made at this time in answer to the recent suggestion of the Actors' Equity Association that the Federal Reserve System be asked to extend financial aid to responsible producers.

MADRID, Sept. 8. -- After the practical rounding out of Spain's Constitution in a period of more than eighteen months, the Cortes tonight finished its task of creating a new nation within a nation by voting the last article of the Catalan autonomy statute.

Commodity prices broke yesterday, the reaction being most severe in cotton, which sagged 97 to 104 points. Grains, rubber, silk, hides, sugar and cocoa all gave ground. Metals, as a group, were firm, zinc moving to a new high for the year, with moderate gains in tin.

Playing under the most trying weather conditions that have obtained in the tennis championship in many years, George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, second ranking player of the country and runner-up for the title in 1931, passed out of the fifty-first national singles tournament yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- Only by repeal or amendment of laws passed during the past ten years could the present $102,000,000 for State aid be changed to the $37,000,000 of the 1922 budget, Mark Graves, director of the budget, said in a radio address tonight over WGY, continuing his talk of last week on education.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Vishnu from the Nevada Stock Farm and the public choice went down in defeat today in the Galewood Purse, featured race at Lincoln Fields.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., Sept. 8. -- Representative Augustine Lonergan defeated Professor Harry Morgan Ayres for the Democratic Senatorial nomination today in one of the stormiest conventions ever held by the Democratic party in this State, stirred by a fight over the Lieutenant Governorship.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 8. -- Mgr. Francis J. Spellman of Whitman, Mass., was today consecrated Auxiliary Bishop of Boston, Mass., and titular Bishop of Sela. He will be the auxiliary to Cardinal O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston.
Flats and dwellings in various communities comprised the bulk of the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Playing well in spite of the winds sweeping the Green Meadow Country Club course, Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill defeated Mrs. Hugh McDonald of Scarsdale, 3 and 2, to win the two-day nine-hole match-play tourney of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association today.

Retail Credit Situation Better. Current payments by retailers on dress purchases on the whole are satisfactory, with the likelihood that the Fall season will see the restoration of many stores to their former high credit standing, according to the consensus of views expressed at the interchange group meetings of the dress council of the Credit Clearing House held yesterday at the Garment Credit Conference Club.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8. -- Visitors to the Harvard School of Architecture in the old Fogg Museum Building will find that William Crowninshield Endicott, whose effigy in the entrance hall is a handy place for striking matches, has a new vis-a-vis.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- The French Ministry of Commerce agreed today to more favorable treatment for Americaid fruit exports to France after meeting with Commercial Attache Allport and his two assistants. Although not directly connected with other negotiations under way for a Franco-American commercial treaty, today's successful results lead embassy officials, to hope that the French Government does not share the feelings expressed in the present widespread press attack against the proposed treaty.

MADRID, Friday, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Two projects affecting the future course of Republican Spain became a reality early today when the Assembly put through, the "agrarian reforms" after granting autonomy to the rich Province of Catalonia.

Despite a substantial reduction in operating expenses, the net loss of the Interborough Rapid Transit system for July was more than twice that in the same month last year, exclusive of the full requirements on Manhattan Railway modified guarantee stock, the dividend on which is payable if earned.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Play opened today in the handicap division of the high-goal polo tournaments at the Meadow Brook Club when Thomas Hitchcock's Sands Point team came from behind to defeat Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes, 12 to 9, in the first test of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament.

The anthracite miners stoutly resisted the cut yesterday at their meeting with the operators. They contended that economies could be effected in many directions before touching wages. The operators maintained just as vigorously that a substantial wage reduction was necessary to stabilize the industry.

Further improvements in bank clearings is indicated in the reports for the week ended on Wednesday night. Although the latest period comprised only five business days, the aggregate of settlements was greater than in the preceding week, which comprised six business days.

Babe Ruth, looking bronzed, robust and not at all sick, though possibly just a trifle worried, stepped off a train yesterday at Grand Central Station from Detroit, whence reports had preceded him that his immediate and future participation in baseball was being threatened with an attack of appendicitis.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 to 0, today, the three runs being scored in the first inning, when Hurst, with two men on base, drove his twenty-third home run of the season.

Lists of apartment rentals announced by brokers yesterday indicated an undiminished demand for housing accommodations in Manhattan. The sudden, spurt in Fall house hunting has exceeded the expectations of renting agents and is viewed in real estate circles as the most encouraging aspect of the current market.

SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me., Sept. 8. -- Convinced that her husband has been either kidnapped or murdered by bootleggers, Mrs. Raymond Robins said at her Summer home here tonight that he had received many telephone calls threatening his life after he had started open warfare on violators of the national prohibition laws, and that several weeks ago an anonymous call warned him that unless he stopped his campaign he would be killed.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Senator Robinson told the Democratic State Convention, today that overcapitalization of utilities through mergers and consolidations had led to evils that must be corrected, and he suggested a cure through the Democratic plank calling for Federal regulation of rates of utilities operating across State lines.
PARIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The French press emphasized today that France felt she had no right to reply to the German aide memoire demanding arms equality without consulting the other powers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Two sons of the former Crown Prince of Germany tonight found themselves confronted with a crowded social calendar for their stay in Chicago. Prince Frederick William, arriving here after a three weeks' tour of the West Coast, in which he avoided Hollywood, was greeted here by his older brother, Prince Louis Ferdinand, who is learning about motors in the Ford factory at Detroit.

Concentrated doses of ultra-violet rays, sixteen times stronger than the amount that produces sunburn, have been found to be the most effective and beneficial means for bringing relief to sufferers from erysipelas, a highly contagious, inflammatory skin disease caused by a specific bacterial infection, it was reported yesterday at the eleventh annual session of the American Congress of Physical Therapy, meeting this week in the Hotel New Yorker.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who passed this week in New York, returned yesterday to Beaulieu, their place in Newport.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 8. -- Joe Engel, president of the Chattanooga Southern Association Baseball Club, tonight announced that he was placing in the hands of Commissioner K.M. Landis an appeal against the vote of the Southern Association directors, which today prohibited a play-off game here tomorrow between Knoxville and Chattanooga, on the result of which the league pennant might hang.

A panama hat floating in the Hudson River off Hoboken, N.J., yesterday afternoon delayed the ferry Lackawanna for fifteen minutes, caused the loss of a newly painted boathook and brought Hunter Kinbrough to police headquarters.

For the first time since Feb. 24, when it began its great credit-expansion campaign, the Federal Reserve System this week reduced its holdings of United States Government securities. Although the open-market purchases, which for many weeks had been carried out at the rate of $100,000,000 weekly, virtually ended three weeks ago, the Reserve System had reported minor increases in its portfolio of government securities in each succeeding statement.

NEWCASTLE, England, Sept. 8. -- Arthur Henderson told the Trades Union Congress today that the German demand for equality in armaments was a challenge to all the allied powers to redeem their pledges made in the Treaty of Versailles.

Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, former Republican national committeewoman, and head of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, called on Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley yesterday afternoon, at Democratic headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

BOSTON, Sept. 8. -- Harvard and Army will lead the fight for the return of radio broadcasts of the major football games of the East when the twelve leading colleges and universities meet tomorrow night in New York to reconsider the action taken last Spring in barring the games from the listening public.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). --With a host of theories and a scarcity of clues, Federal agents today joined in an intensive search for Colonel Raymond Robins, prominent prohibitionist, who disappeared while presumably on his way to Washington to keep an appointment with President Hoover.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9. -- Owen Johnson won today for the ninth consecutive year first prize for the best display of fruit, flowers and vegetables grown on a gentleman's estate at the Stockbridga Grange Fair In Town Hall here. Mrs. Arthur F. Schermerhorn received first award for 150 varieties of gladioli and fifty varieties of dahlias.

Robert Jackson, secretary of the Democratic National Committee, and chairman of the speakers' bureau for the Roosevelt campaign, won yesterday his application for an extension until after the election of time to answer a suit brought by the Accumulative Royalties, Inc., of which he was formerly president and treasurer, for an accounting of $353,857 of $1,000,000 alleged to have been received by him for the company's stock.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- The French Cabinet will meet tomorrow to approve the reply to Germany's demand for equality in armaments. The reply is understood to constitute a conditional negative but will leave the question of Germany's rights entirely open.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 9. -- A fierce battle on land and in the air, the big clash of the Chaco conflict, was being fought today in the disputed wilderness, according to a General Staff communique.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- The Bourse weakened today and closed with the tendency down-ward. Among the causes noted by financial writers was the drop in the price of cotton following the United States Government's crop estimate. Several other circumstances contributed to the decline, including the prospect of an external moratorium in Argentina, uncertainty over the French disarmament negotiations with Germany and general profit-taking after the recent substantial advances by French and international stocks.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9. -- Despite the complaints of food and commodity shortages, excessive labor fluctuation in the factories, confusion on the collective farms and transport shortcomings, which are a constant topic in the Soviet press nowadays, there are bright spots to indicate that the Bolshevist system of overcoming difficulties by "drives" and shock brigades still functions successfully.

Orchestral compositions will be received by the Juilliard School of Music for entry In the publication competition among American composers. The winning composition is to be published without expense to the composer. Manuscripts must reach the school before noon on Oct. 1.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 9. -- The agrarian countries of Central Europe, whose economic rehabilitation is the main purpose of the Stresa conference, said what they thought in the economic committee today of the methods of attaining this end proposed by France, Italy and Germany.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- Although no decision has been yet taken by the Cabinet it is expected that France will follow the example of England and not ask for an application of the postponement clause of the Mellon-Berenger debt agreement. That will mean France will be prepared, if no other trrangement is made, to meet her next payment due on Dec. 15.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Lily Pons, the French singer who for two seasons has starred in the Metropolitan Opera in New York, revealed today that she and her husband had been estranged since April. They probably will not be divorced until Spring, she said.
Purchases by several New Yorkers were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

While trading was much less active yesterday than on the day before, the market conditions were similar and Wall Street attached about the same significance upon the day's price movements. The rally in cotton caused a partial recovery in stocks at one time, but the general list on the Stock Exchange closed with moderate net losses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. -- (AP) -- Japan's appropriation of nearly $40,000,000 at the third special session of its diet for the relief of farmers, fishermen and small merchants emphasizes the State into which her trade has fallen.

Scheduled to sail today for Havre on the new French liner Champlain are a number of scientists who attended the Astronomical Congress at Cambridge, Mass. Among them are Andre Danjon, Raymond Jouast, Gaston Fayet, Henri L. de Azambuja and Count d'Acosta Loba.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Recent discoveries about "age and human ability" were reported to the American Psychological Association tonight in the presidential address of Dr. Walter R. Miles of Stanford and Yale Universities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Arthur W. Cutten, a leading operator in the grain and stock markets, defended the grain trade again today and attacked United States Senator Dickinson of Iowa for recent utterances concerning the Federal Farm Board. Mr. Cutten was particularly incensed by Senator Dickinson's invitation to the trade to "do something constructive in the market" now that the Farm Board had removed itself as a market factor.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Personal convictions will be overruled by his instructions as an Iowa American Legion member, Hanford MacNider said here today, with the result he will not oppose a move at the national American Legion Convention to demand immediate payment of the bonus.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The International Astronomical Union, closing its sessions today at Radcliffe College, elected Dr. Frank Schlesinger, director of the observatory and Professor of Astronomy at Tale University, as president. Dr. Schlesinger succeeds Sir Frank Dyson, astronomer royal of Great Britain, who held the chair at this meeting.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Scoring five runs In the first inning, Newark went on to win tonight from Albany, 13 to 3. The 1932 International League champions hit Shealy freely.

Charging that the indictment returned against him in this district was being used in Pennsylvania to prevent his re-election as United States Senator, James J. Davis, former Secretary of Labor, took steps here yesterday to assure a speedy trial of the charge that he violated the lottery law while serving as Director General of the Loyal Order of Moose.

The Governor of the Bank of England, Mr. MONTAGU NORMAN, has returned in safety and in silence to his native land. His brief wandering on the foreign strand of America left no footprints behind him to tell where he had been, what he had done, or, above all, what he had said.

Sent by his wife for a physician when she noticed that something was amiss with their 6-year-old son, who was found later to have been smothered to death and whose wrists had been slashed, William Henry Tubbs, 32 years old, of 40-18 169th Street, Flushing, Queens, disappeared yesterday morning.

Everett Sanders, Republican national chairman in an interview yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, indicated that it had been definitely decided that President Hoover would make no campaign tour of the country.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 9. -- After overcoming his opponent's three-hole lead and squaring the match, Keenan Morrow, 15-year-old Pomonok boy, halved the fifteenth hole, which he should have won, then lost the next two holes, the match and the Long Island junior championship to Jack Moffett, young Maidstone golfer, at Cherry Valley today.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday to members a table showing the Federal and New York State taxes required on sales and transfers of foreign shares represented by American certificates.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP). -- After hearing arguments bearing on financial difficulties of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, Federal Judge Charles B. Faris took under advisement today the company's motion for dismissal of a receivership suit recently filed by two holders of $3,500 of the road's prior lien bonds.

The opening of the new Eighth Avenue subway was celebrated last night by the West Side Association of Commerce with speeches deploring the lack of official ceremonies and the past reluctance of the city administration to put the subway into use.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The first task of Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, on returning to his duties today was to spring to the assistance of Premier Herriot of France in the difficulty arising from the Franco-German discussions of armaments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest the letter written by George Imken in which he states, or at least assumes, that our railroads have made little or no progress-in the matter of loco-motive boiler water treatment.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in August totaled $20,016,493,967, an advance of 3.6 per cent over the preceding month. All of this improvement was attributed to the turnover in New York City, where clearings aggregated 112,666,982,889, an increase of 8.4 per cent, while outside of the city there was a decline of 3.8 per cent with the total at $7,349,511,078.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9. -- The petroleum control bill, which foreign companies say will force them out of business in Argentina, passed its first reading in the Senate today.

Within a few hours after the 44-year-old pleasure boat Observation went to the bottom of the East River an investigation was under way in the office of George Z. Medalle, United States District Attorney, to determine if negligence on the part of any one connected with the craft's river crossings would warrant a man-slaughter charge.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept 9. -- Tightening of his safety belt saved George A. Davidson's life while his three companions on an airplane trip were burned to death when the ship struck the side of a mountain.

A demand that Republican and Democratic State committeemen in New York City make public the programs they had undertaken or would initiate in their districts to relieve overcrowding in the public schools was made yesterday by George Dyson Frieu, chairman of the emergency committee on school overcrowding, in a letter to all district leaders.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9. -- Thomas Albert Dwight (Tad) Jones, Yale football and baseball star as an undergraduate and more recently head coach of Yale football and chairman of the Yale graduate advisory football committee, has been agreed upon by Republican leaders as the candidate for Congress from the Third District.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Belief was grooving among Chicago friends of Colonel Raymond Robins tonight that the prohibition leader, who vanished in New York last Saturday while preparing to leave for a conference with President Hoover in Washington, is somewhere in Chicago unharmed.

The largest directory of college and university alumni and alumnae ever printed, containing 99,721 names, the first complete Alumni Register of Columbia University, has just been issued by the Columbia University Press.
Operation of the Eighth Avenue municipal subway began at 12:01 o'clock this morning.

Facts and figures about the new Eighth Avenue subway, as compiled yesterday by the Board of Transportation, should bring joy to statisticians of the "end-to-end" school and good cheer to those who revel in startling comparisons.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- A committee of nine executives, representing the railroads of this country, decided here today that a 20 per cent permanent reduction in the basic wage scale of all classes of employes, effective Feb. 1, 1933, was necessary.

Victor J. Dowling, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division, who returned from Europe on Thursday, began, yesterday his official duties as an asgociate temporary receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company. He moved from the offices of the law firm of Chadbourne, Stanchfield Levy, at 25 Broadway, to the special suite prepared for him and his associate, Thomas E. Murray Jr., in the offices of the Interborough, at 165 Broadway.

Presiding over a special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday at which $500,000 was appropriated to extend veterans' relief to the end of this month, Mayor Joseph V. McKee said he soon would consult the taxpayers of the city on whether additional relief appropriations should be made.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation, meeting today, recommended that Congress reduce the gold content of the dollar as a means of restoring price levels of agricultural products and of enabling farmers to meet their obligations.

AT a meeting of the American Psychological Association at Cornell University, Dr. E.B. Skaggs of the College of the City of Detroit advanced a theory long held by Nick Altrock of the Washington Senators and Dizzy Dean of the St. Louis Cardinals, among others.

In an effort to provide shelter and food for jobless single men who are not heads of families and therefore ineligible for unemployment relict from the city, a group of men has obtained the use of a deserted seven-story tenement house at 145 Ridge Street, which is now being converted into a hostelry for two hundred and fifty men.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 9. -- While the Republican campaign in Rhode Island was formally opened a fortnight ago and two members of President Hoover's Cabinet, Secretary Mills and Secretary Hurley, already have spoken before Republican audiences in the State, active campaigning will not really begin until after the Democratic and Republican State conventions on Oct. 7 and Oct. 11 respectively.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Sept. 9 (Bahamas News Service). -- The deaths of eleven persons on the Island of Abaco in Monday's storm and tidal wave became known here today for the first time when Governor Clifford of the Bahamas made an airplane trip to the stricken settlements.

Holders of long-term Greek loans outstanding in the United States, which are in default as to interest and sinking fund, were advised yesterday by the Institute of International Finance against taking definite steps until after the meeting of the League of Nations Council this month.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- With John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, in complete control, the Democratic State Committee today picked Albany as the State convention city and adopted a resolution, "enthusiastically" ratifying the Democratic national platform and pledging "its active and loyal support" to Governor Roosevelt, nominee for President, and Speaker Garner, nominee for Vice President.

Hard luck was a close companion of the steamboat Observation. Previous to yesterday's explosion, which ended her forty-four years of service, she sank twice and twice caught fire. The vessel, a wooden steam yacht, was built in Brooklyn in 1888 and was commissioned as the Jean.

The first step for reorganization of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation was taken yesterday when its receivers applied in Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., for permission to give their option to repurchase the American Gas and Power Company to a new company to be owned entirely by security holders and creditors of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Replying to an inquiry, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that the stock transfer tax does not apply to transfers to brokers for the purpose of making a sale to a customer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Heavy oversubscriptions resulted from the Treasury's offering of certificates and notes dated September 15, Secretary Mills announced today. The ratio of subscriptions to offerings was nearly 6.5 to 1.
NEW YORK. Charles Delavan Wetmore gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for Sir Henry and Lady Thornton.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- Clearing the decks for his invasion of the West, Governor Roosevelt was assured today by former Senator James A. Reed that the whole Mississippi Valley would back the Democratic slate this year.

TOKYO, Sept. 9. -- The Cabinet finally approved today the Manchukuo-Japan protocol and it will be submitted to the Emperor tomorrow. The Privy Council will begin consideration of it immediately and the process of ratification will be completed a few days later.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9. -- Sensational bursts of speed were shown at the State fair grounds track today at the clfosing of the Grand Circuit meeting, featured by the Hotel Lockerbie 2:05 pace, the three heats of which were clocked in 1:59 3/4, 1:59 1/2 and 2:00 flat.

Ordering every city department to slash its 1933 budget request by 20 per cent, Mayor Joseph. V. McKee set his budget-reduction goal at $80,000,000 to $100,000,000 yesterday and expressed the belief that the retrenchment would aid business recovery throughout the nation as well as in New York City.

The association of the New York Hospital with the Cornell University Medical College and other institutions gives to the city a second medical centre with imposing resources for the care of the sick, the teaching of physicians, the training of nurses, and research.

A new device to produce synthetically the type of electrically charged, health-giving air produced by cosmic rays on mountaintops and in bright sunshine weather was described for the first time here yesterday before the annual American Congress of Physical Therapy, during its closing sessions at the Hotel New Yorker, by Dr. William Bierman, director of physical therapy at Beth Israel Hospital.

Melvin Ott, striving mightily to salvage something from, a wrecked season that will see few prizes distributed at the Polo Grounds this Fall, propelled himself into the thick of the fight for the National League home-run hitting honors by helping himself to two more circuit blows yesterday to givs himself a string of five in the last five games.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9. -- President Abelardo Rodriguez granted his first interview to a group of Mexican and foreign newspaper men this morning at the National Palace, the conference lasting only ten minutes. The Chief Executive was laconic in the extreme, but answered a half dozen questions regarding his immediate policies.
BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Sept. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
A house in Highview Av., Ardsley, was rented to Robert Peabody of Yonkers by the Homeland Co., which also leased a dwelling in Homewood, Yonkers, to J.B. Norton of Pelham.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Hiss Alexandra Murray Bacon, eldest daughter of Representative and Mrs. Robert Low Bacon of Arlough, Westbury, was formally introduced to society tonight at a dance given by her grandmother, Mrs. Robert Bacon, at Old Acres, her estate at Old Westbury.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The London Times, in editorially referring to the fact that the British Government has not yet officially entered the discussion of the German demand for arms equality rights, although now in possession of the German and French views, says:
Following Thursday's break of 1 1/4 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and, under orderly trading, closed at gains of 16 to 19 points.

The yacht Saelmo, long famous in New York waters as the gathering place of political notables and participant in harbor parades that heralded the arrival of world figures to the city, will leave the Tebo Basin in Brooklyn this morning to start a new career as a patrol and inspection boat in Chasapeake Bay.

MADRID, Sept. 9. -- The Spanish Cortes passed today the agrarian reform bill, which is perhaps the most far-reaching measure of social reform enacted outside of Russia since the war. At one fell swoop it dispossesses the nobility of all its vast land holdings, handing them over to those who till them.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 9 (AP). -- A conference of Mid-Western Governors and their representatives today studied a wide variety of proposals in a quest for a definite program of farm relief.

Spokesmen, for the United Mine Workers of America told the anthracite operators at their conference yesterday that if by joint action the industry could obtain a reduction of freight rates on hard coal there would be no need to ask the 140,000 miners to take a wage reduction.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- A rousing stretch run today gave A.A. Baroni's Waylayer a thrilling victory over a good field in the Will County Handicap at Lincoln Fields.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 9. -- A government bill requesting that Congress confer upon President Olaya Herrera special powers for use only after consultation with the Finance Board, to be exercised from the close of the present session until the end of July, 1933, was published in Espectador tonight.

"WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Governor Pinchot's charge that there was "unreasonable and unnecessary delay" in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's action on an unemployment relief loan requested by Pennsylvania drew a sharp retort from corporation officials today.

The market value of bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased 1,457,499,716 in August, according to the compiliation issued yesterday by the Exchange. This was the largest advance since June, 1931, and compared with gains of $1,261,999,683 in July and of $496,711,657 in June of this year.

Four hundred traffic executives of commercial groups, railroads and other transportation groups inspected the new union inland freight terminal at Eighth and Ninth Avenues and West Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets yesterday morning as guests of the Port of New York Authority.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- Two University of Pennsylvania students -- Chesley Alien of Plainfield, N.J., and William Henderson of Philadelphia -- were among the winning drivers at the opening of the Eastern divisional and American Power Boat Association championship outboard regatta on the Schuylkill River today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The Dahlia Society of New Jersey won today the American Home Achievement Medal offered at the National Atlantic City Flower Pageant for the dahlia exhibit contributing most of the progress of that flower.

BINGHAMTON. N.Y., Sept. 9. -- After questioning of house guests in the fatal wounding of Robert Jewell Eaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin C. Eaton, at their Summer home at Chenango Lake Wednesday night, District Attorney Glenn F. Carter and Coroner Earl W. Wilcox of Chenango County today announced that no further investigation will be necessary.

The board of governors and the labor committee of the League of New York Theatres met simultaneously yesterday afternoon to consider the extended deadlock over the new wage agreement with the stagehands' union. According to Dr. Henry Moskowitz, executive adviser of the league, the board of governors accepted the report of its labor committee and empowered it to arrange for a settlement.

Puzzled by the Sanitation Department's delay in awarding contracts for the construction of three new incinerators costing $962,000 each which must be completed by next July in compliance with a United States Supreme Court order, Mayor Joseph V. McKee said yesterday he would ask an explanation of the delay next week from Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Haig in his letter to THE TIMES states: "Taxes ara primarily devices for transferring to the public treasury a share of the social income. Switching from the income tax to the device of excises does not tap a new source of revenue in any fundamental sense."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9. -- T.A. (Tony) Torrance, British Walker Cup team captain, breezed around the Five Farms' course in 68 strokes today, two strokes under par, to register low score among contenders for the national amateur golf tournament starting Monday and emphasize the overseas challenge for the American championship.

A new mechanical lecture service, to be known as the "Illustrated Voice," was announced yesterday by the Western Union Telegraph Company and the Fairchild-Wood Visaphone Corporation of 60 Hudson Street.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Although somewhat less active, the wool market has easily maintained its price position and is even slightly dearer on the whole than it was a week ago. Medium qualities are especially strong, since they are in very light offering.

TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Miss Eleanor Holm of New York established a new world record of 2:57.8 in retaining her Women's National A.A.U. 220-yard back stroke title tonight. The previous mark, held by herself, was 3 minutes 3-5 seconds.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9. -- Santiago dispatches say it was proposed at the recent ABC-Peru conversations there that Chile cede to Bolivia a strip of territory affording an outlet to the Pacific, that Paraguay pay part of the cost of this territory, the United States arranging a loan to Paraguay for that purpose, and that Bolivia evacuate the Chaco positions occupied since June 1.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The presiding staff of the newly assembled Reichstag waited on President von Hindenburg today, a customary courtesy. Three of them also wished to tell him that the Reichstag should not be dissolved, and why.

The complete program of the conference on regional planning, government and administration, to be held at New York University Oct. 18 and 19, was announced yesterday by Dean Frank H. Sommer of the School of Law.

Friends of Controller Charles W. Berry have begun to put him forward as a possible candidate for the Mayoralty this Fall, it was disclosed yesterday. They are arguing for his candidacy on the grounds that economy in government will be the appeal to the voters this Fall and point to the Controller's persistent demands for reductions in the city budget during the last few years of the Walker administration.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey announced yesterday that it would soon apply for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to be used in providing employment. The proceeds would be used in repairing locomotives, cars and marine equipment, the company estimating that if the loan was granted it would put 460 men to work beginning on Oct. 1.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y. Sept. 9. -- Two Westchester professionals bridged the gap that separated the rest of the field from Densmore Shute, pacesetter at the end of yesterday's initial round of the Glens Falls open golf tourney, by par equaling rounds of 71 today.

Crowded with workmen bound for their jobs at the new $9,000,000 pententiary on Rikers Island, the 44-year-old steamer Observation was blown to bits at 8:03 o'clock yesterday morning in the East River off 134th Street, in one of the worst marine-industrial accidents of the city's history.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP). -- In a hitting spree in which each team used three pitchers, the Washington Senators defeated the St. Louis Browns, 6 to 4, today to make It two straight in the series.

Outside money on call continued firm, the rate moving up to 1 3/4 per cent, compared with 1 1/2 on Thursday. Demand for money accounted for the drying up of offerings at the lower figure. Elsewhere Stock Exchange rate was 2 per cent, as previously, with time money, commercial paper and acceptances unchanged.
A transaction involving the purchase for investment of tour tenement buildings in the midtown section of the east side was announced yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Term., Sept. 9. -- Judge K.M. Landis today stepped into the Southern Association's most thrilling finish in its thirty-one seasons of activity and enabled Chattanooga to press its hunt for the pennant.

The Rev. Dr. Gordon H. Baker, who resigned last March as pastor of the Washington Heights Baptist Church, Convent Avenue and West 145th Street, on account of ill health, soon will organize a new undenomi-national church. His motto will be "a church with a minimum of organization and overhead expenses, with a maximum of service to the city and to the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Supporters of the Eighteenth Amendment were urged today by the executive committee of the Anti-Saloon League to centre their political efforts this Fall on the election of dry members of Congress. A statement of policy, which was adopted, declared that the league could not endorse the stand taken on prohibition by either President Hoover or Governor Roosevelt, and refused to compromise with the prohibition planks of either major party.

The continued upward trend in prices of commodities and securities, together with the reopening of industrial plants throughout the country, has increased optimism, even though activity in most lines remains below the levels of last year, according to weekly reviews of trade and industry.

Gasoline and Civic Education. Mayor McKEE might win additional public support for his campaign to cut city expenses if he could manage to dramatize the New York City tax-dollar as effectively as one filling-station proprietor in Tennessee has succeeded in vitalizing the price of a gallon of gasoline.
LIMA, Sept. 9. -- The Cabinet resigned this morning over internal differences. It is expected that all members will return to office except Ricardo Caso, the Minister of Public Works.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

ORADELL, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Miss Josephine Merrill of the Montclair Golf Club shot a 90 over the windswept Hackensack Golf Club course today to win gross honors in a one-day tourney of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 9. -- Insurgent activities nave increased in the last few days in the Northern departments, and rebel leaders have made threats to keep the country in turmoil during the coming elections.

The assertion that Christianity is hardly to be considered at all as a force in directing the current or objectives of American life is made by Morris Markey in his book, "This Country of Yours," just published by Little, Brown Co. The author wished to learn what this country and its inhabitants are really like.

New issues of bonds and notes offered publicly this week aggregated $11,207,000, comprising six State and municipal issues and one piece of public utility financing. Last week's total was $6,392,000 and for the corresponding week a year ago the amount was $79,366,000.

Captain George A. Forsyth, who was piloting the steamboat Observation when she was blown up yesterday, and who was fatally injured by the blast, was one of the best-known tug boat men in New York Harbor, where he had been engaged for more than forty years.

Twenty-three new courses in nine departments will be offered by the Hunter College evening session during the coming term. More than 500 classes are scheduled in the 369 courses included in the curriculum, covering academic, cultural and commercial subjects. Most of the courses, in addition to carrying credit toward degrees, enable teachers to satisfy the "alertness" requirement of the Board of Education.

TODAY'S MATCHES. 11:00 A.M. -- Final set of Cochet-Allison semi-final match. 1:00 P.M. -- Final of veterans' singles. 2:00 or 3:00 P.M. -- Final of singles. If Cochet wins the semi-final, title match will start at 2. If Allison wins, title match will start at 3.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Formal announcement of the resignation of J.W. Pole as Controller of the Currency today disclosed that he had remained at the head of the national banking system during the recent trying period at the insistence of President Hoover.

Twenty-nine Star class fleets have been named to be represented in the international races to be held by the Pequot Yacht Club off Southport, Conn., starting on Sept. 17. The list was announced yesterday by George W. Elder, president of the association.

Mrs. George Rudnick of Tibbetts Brook, women's municipal golf champion, and Frank Strafaci of Dyker Beach yesterday captured the low gross prizes in the women's and men's divisions respectively of the New York Municipal Golf Association one-day handicap tournament at the Dyker Beach course in Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A majority of the people of our country are convinced that the Eighteenth Amendment was a mistake and that national prohibition must be abandoned. Wisely the President has gone beyond his party platform in recommending that the liquor question be turned back to the States.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs increased their lead in the National League pennant race to six games today as they defeated the Braves, 5 to 2, in their final clash while the Pirates were idle.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The German debt to the United States was the subject of a discussion today between Secretary Mills and Reudolf Leitner, counselor of the German Embassy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading Calvin Coolidge and Senator Smoot in The Saturday Evening Post and rereading President Hoover's acceptance speech, I am ready to hand the palm to the Republicans. Economic conditions may be fundamentally sound, but Republican reasoning is much more so.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- President Hoover announced today that in order to aid employment he had ordered the speeding up of public construction to the extent of nearly $200,000,000.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- For the first time since the press campaign opened last week against granting a most-favored nation treaty to the United States, reaction favorable to the American viewpoint developed here with the publication today of a letter from the Association of Silk Manufacturers of Lyons to the government.

The fatal explosion on the wooden steamboat Observation yesterday was one of the three worst marine disasters in the history of New York Harbor. The other two were the burning of the excursion steamer General Slocum on June 15, 1904, and the sinking of the Linseed King, on Dec. 20, 1923.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The purposes for which the Board of Taxicab Control was created formed the most fundamental basis for the charges that were brought against Mayor Walker which resulted in his resignation.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The North German Lloyd liner Westfalen, which has been chartered by the Deutsche Lufthansa to serve as a floating airport and refueling station in the middle of the South Atlantic Ocean for a regular transatlantic air service between British Gambia in Africa and the island of Fernando Noronha off Brazil, left Bremen today for a three-day test of the necessary equipment in the North Sea.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. BASE CAMP, Nanga Parbat, Kashmir, Sept. 3 (By runner to Astor, Sept. 9.) -- Our expedition to climb to the summit of the great peak called Nanga Parbat has come to an end -- at least for this year. But already our climbers are hoping that the undertaking may be resumed next year.

Cotton, which halted the early advance on Thursday on the Stock Exchange by falling $5 a bale in response to a government crop estimate that was at variance with the expectations of speculative interests, made a partial recovery yesterday. The stock market, however, remained nervous and unsettled, with final results that were unsatisfactory to the majority of the Wall Street community.

With the Army and Harvard leading the fight to repeal the proposed ban on the broadcasting of major football games in the East this Fall, the Eastern Intercollegiate Association at a meeting at the Columbia University Club last night voted to permit members of the association to make their own decisions in the matter of broadcasting gridiron contests.

The central theme of the discussions at the convention of the American Bankers Association in Los Angeles from Oct. 3 to 6 will be excessive taxation and public expenditures, according to the program for the three general sessions announced yesterday by F.N. Shepherd, executive manager of the association.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 10. -- The mysterious cessation of the anti-Communist campaign in Fukien Province, whither the famous Nineteenth Route Army was sent after its valiant resistance to the Japanese in February, is now explained in advices from Fukien telling of the serious disintegration of discipline in the ranks of the Nineteenth Route Army through successful Communist propaganda, with the result that a large percentage of the rank and file refuses to fight against the Reds.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- For the second straight year Mrs. Elsie Goldsack Fittman of London and Miss Joan Ridley of Ipswich, England, won the women's Middle States doubles tennis championship today, beating Miss Anne Page of Merion and Miss Alice Francis of Orange, N.J., in the final round at St. Martin's, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

When Governor SMITH in 1927 signed the bill recommended by the Commission on School Finance and Administration he said that the cost of education in this State is "growing by leaps and bounds," but that "the best must be provided for our children."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Jerome J. Belden entertained with a luncheon for twenty-five today at Gull Crest. After the luncheon Mrs. Charles H. Sabin spoke on the aims of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, of which she is the chairman.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Prices of wheat held today within a range of 3/4 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here, traders being inclined to go slowly on either side of the market, pending developments and the issuance of the government's report on grain crops late in the day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Starting in the sixth inning to overcome a six-run handicap, the Red Sox tied the score in the ninth today and added three more in the tenth to defeat the White Sox, 9 to 6, in the second game of their series.

New municipal borrowing of only $15,350,534 is scheduled for next week by various communities throughout the country. Although this week's calendar of issues up for award aggregated $19,107,699, the principal piece of new financing, that of $11,500,000 State of Mississippi bonds, failed to attract a bid for the entire amount, although the State received a number of propositions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Republican Presidential campaign this month will centre in the wheat, corn and West Coast States, according to a decision reached today by advisers of President Hoover, who are concerned over the reported unfavorable trend in the West.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Dr. Vernon Robins, city chemist, long in ill health and now seriously sick, has not been told of the strange disappearance of his brother, Colonel Raymond Robins.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The overnight setback in Wall Street caused heavy profit-taking on the London Stock Exchange this morning, but this was well absorbed and before noon prices began to rally. British funds were more active and quotations improved.

WASHINGTON. Sept 9 (AP). -- Legion officials here predict advocates of immediate bonus payments will control more than four-fifths of the votes at the American Legion convention in Portland, Ore., next week.

DETROIT, Sept. 9. -- Lou Gehrig drove home eight runs In the first nine innings of play today to tie the league record, but pennant-clinching operations were at a standstill for the Yankees because the Tigers out lasted them to take a 14-to-13 decision in the fourteen-innlng first game, then appropriated the abbreviated afterpiece, 4 to 1.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 9 (AP). -- An unofficial announcement was made tonight that Paraguayan troops had succeeded in capturing Fort Boqueron, one of the strong points of Bolivia in the disputed Chaco territory, which has been the centre of considerable military activity during the last twenty-four hours.

Polo will reach the climax of its season today when Greentree and Templeton ride out on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I., to decide the national open championship. Greentree, led by John Hay Whitney, and Templeton, formed by Winston Guest, are to start play at 4 o'clock.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- State revenue from stock market profits tax-action dropped 82 per cent in 1931, compared with 1930, Henry F. Long, State Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation, said today in his annual report.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9. -- The story of Paul Bern's association with the mysterious Dorothy Millette was revealed by his brother, Henry Bern of New Rochelle, N.Y., today after her strange disappearance had been disclosed.

Survivors of the Observation disaster questioned in hospitals by Assistant District Attorney Martin Frank contributed little to the search for the cause of the explosion that blew the boat to pieces. One man said the boiler had appeared to be hotter than he had ever seen it before, although this did not alarm him.

G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, well-known amateur rider who recently strengthened his racing stable, surprised most observers yesterday at Belmont Park when he brought his own colt, Masked Knight, home first at 12 to 1 in the featured Ramapo Handicap.

Tammany leaders at Albany, in attendance upon the meeting of the Democratic State Committee, were at first afraid of intruding upon a much-occupied and hard-working Governor. "Why bother him," asked Mr. CURRY plaintively, "when he baa so much to do?"

The scene of yesterday's tragedy off the foot of East 135th Street was still crowded with activity late last night as workmen of the Department of Plant and Structures strung floodlights to assist policemen from the emergency squads in their task of dragging for bodies from rowboats.

GEORGE, Bermuda, Sept. 9. -- As the half mile of telephone cable was looped on the deck of the Freedom Wednesday afternoon and the broadcasting men put the last touches to their instruments in preparation for test dives in the "bathysphere" by Dr. William Beebe and Otis Barton, a slight breeze arose and steadily increased until scarlet hurricane signals were up.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- A slight increase in crop prospects in August was reported today by the Department of Agriculture, with larger production of corn, oats and hay leading the upward move.

Earl Sparling, former Washington newspaper correspondent and author of "Mystery Men of Wall Street," is the author of "Kreuger's Billion Dollar Bubble," just issued by Greenberg. The author deals with Ivar Kreuger's personal life as well as with, the ramifications of his intricate financial structure.

Heavy engineering contracts for the week ended Sept. 6 aggregated $14,259,000, a decrease of $3,797,000 from the previous week, with Federal Government awards less than half as much as for the last week in August, according to reports received by Engineering News-Record.

Whether Babe Ruth will take his place in the Yankee line-up when the first game of the world's series begins at the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, Sept. 28, probably will be decided within the next day or two.

A suit to prevent the Prudence Company, Inc., from withdrawing from a collateral fund in the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company $883,260 in cash, said to be part of a sum received as a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was disclosed in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday when a decision, of Justice John E. McGeelan was handed down denying the motion of the Prudence Company to dismiss the suit for legal insufficiency.

Restoration of the government to representatives of the people of Haitl has marched forward since the mediation of the Forbes Commission in March, 1930. Of this an immediate result was the signing of an agreement by President BORNO and also his opponents to take the first steps.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Samuel M. Nicholson of Providence has selected Friday afternoon, Sept. 16, for an "at home" at her Summer estate, Marymount. There will be dancing from 5 until 9 o'clock and a buffet supper will be served.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Department store sales in the United States during the first eight months of 1932 were 24 per cent lower than in the corresponding period last year, and the percentage decline in August, as compared with August, 1931, was the same, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Connecticut Democrats are spirited and independent chaps. Their State convention on Thursday, if somewhat vociferous, turned out to be entirely halcyon. Governor CROSS is another professor who insists on his own way and gets it. He served notice that he wouldn't run again unless the whole ticket was satisfactory to him.

Wednesday, Sept. 28, was decided upon officially as the opening date for the world's series at a meeting yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt presided over by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis and attended by representatives of both leagues.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Julius S. Rippel, Newark banker and specialist in municipal bonds, declared here today that the moratorium for Germany had been largely responsible for stringent financial conditions affecting the marketing of city bonds during the last year.

SPEED the parting guest. That was the slogan of Ellsworth Vines at Forest Hills yesterday. M'sieu Henri Cochet had to catch a boat for France. Always the gentleman, Ellsworth Vines saw to it that M'sieu Henri was not delayed by their engagement in the final round of the tennis championship. In sixty swift minutes Ellsworth had M'sieu Henri bundled up and headed for the boat.

Two 7-year-old gorillas, Moina and Mok, that became the guests of the London Zoo recently, are already so popular that The London Morning Post says of them: "Let us attend their daily receptions, try to learn their 'little language,' and make them feel, those cousins a million years removed, that we appreciate their freedom from the burden of multiple complexes which is called modern civilization."

The largest crowd to witness a tennis match in this country since 1927 saw the world's most celebrated amateur hammered down yesterday by the most appalling speed generated by a racquet since William Tilden was at the zenith of his career.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The nation's political attention will turn next week to eight State primaries.

HAVANA, Sept. 10 -- A gun battle this morning in the small town of San Antonio de los Banos, near Havana, between Rural Guards and an alleged communistic group result- ed in the death of Rafael Valdes Perez, 18, and the wounding of several persons.

TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Miss Katharine Rawls, Florida's 14-year-old marvel, won the women's national A.A.U. championship for the 880-yard free-style swim tonight to make a grand slam of four titles in four events entered.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A pair of errors in the fourth inning that netted the Philadelphia Athletics three runs put the skids under Cleveland toda yand the tribe dropped a 4-to-3 game to the visitors in their last engagement of the season.
PARIS THERE are a number of very interesting outlines in the new Paris mode for evening; and, indeed, there is a silhouette for almost every type of figure.

BOSTON TO visit the Print Department of the Boston Museum this Summer on the day of the eclipse was to have the majesty of dark and light overwhelmingly affirmed, nature demonstrating it without, the print room echoing the demonstration within.
