PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Next week-end that patient sufferer, the French rentier, will once more be placed on the operating table and made to undergo without the possibility of a protest the amputation of another limb.

With the resumption of classes in several of its fifteen colleges, schools and divisions, New York University will begin its second century this week. The openings of various branches of the university will continue through Oct. 3, although the majority of classes will be under way by the end of next week.

A PRESS dispatch with a Philadelphia date-line informs us that in view of this time of uncertainty, financial depression and muddling through, not only commercial but musical circles in the Quaker City will pursue conservative policies.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Yacht racing on Moriches Bay came to an end for the season of 1932 with an open regatta for all classes sailed under the auspices of the yacht racing squadron of the Westhampton Country Club off the Speonk shore today.

BROADCASTING will be continued from the Metropolitan Opera House during the coming season, according to Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the organization, who declares that success of last year's presentations proved "broadcasting has come to stay."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- As a help to avoid a receivership for the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company through default on $20,000,000 of gold notes maturing Oct. 1, the Interstate Commerce Commission approved a $6,800,000 loan today to the road from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 11 -- The Board of Trade today authorized extending Soviet trade credits in Britain from twelve to eighteen months in the hope of stimulating Russian orders for British goods. This is the first gesture the government has made to the Russians since the Ottawa conference and it indicates the British are about to make a determined drive to push their exports into the Russian markets.

Announcements made last week of bonds to be retired in September and future months before maturity were few. Those for this month consisted of several small lots of municipal bonds and those for later months of parts of institutional and other loans. Bonds to be redeemed in September now total $25,329,300, against $56,069,000 in August and $114,734,000 in September, 1931, at corresponding dates.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- A new human, electrical meter which reads the fugitive currents induced in the skin by emotion and disease was described to the American Psychological Association today.

Seventeen football games, that will bring together outstanding elevens from all sections of the United States, have been scheduled for the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium this season, it was announced yesterday by Ray McCarthy, director of football for both parks.

Marked activity in apartment rentals in various parts of the city and opening of the Eighth Avenue subway, which civic interests hailed as likely to foster improvement in leasing and building on the west side, featured the opening of the Fall real estate season last week, following the Labor Day lull.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- Another obelisk will be added to the thirteen of various epochs already in Rome when an enormous monolith of pure white Carrara marble will be placed in position on its base within the next few weeks beside the entrance to the new Mussolini Forum.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The gift of 13,000 acres of forest land to New York State College of Forestry at Syracuse University by Mr. and Mrs. Archer Milton Huntington of New York City was announced tonight by Chancellor Charles W. Flint of the university.

LONDON THE recent marriage of a London publisher named Peter Llewellyn Davies recalled the fact that the magic of authorship sometimes plays strange trirks with human life. Long ago, in the days when Mr. Davies was a very small boy, a well-known magician named J.M. Barrie put a spell on him which holds to this day.

To the satisfaction of 15,000 cheerfing racegoers, William Woodward's Faireno proved his right to the 3-year-old championship when he defeated the best horses of the age in the fortieth running of the $7,500 added Lawrence Realization Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Henceforth young naval officers must remain unmarried for two whole years after they leave the Naval Academy. If they don't, they will cease to be naval officers.

The Association of Federation of Workers, comprising employes of institutions affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, has written to the individual directors protesting unpending salary reductions planned in the new federation budget to go into effect this month, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Miss Margaret W. Browne, whose body was reported washed ashore at New York, left the capital about three weeks ago for a visit to that city.

Business "birth control," elimination of 500,000 "needless" retail stores, selective selling, nation-wide education in retailing and closer supervision of credit granting are essential steps in the lowering of distribution costs, now swollen out of proportion to production's share of the dollar spent over retail counters, according to Carl Fast, merchandising counselor.

For the second successive session both trading and fluctuations of prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were smaller than on any preceding day in a month. With no important selling pressure but with constant absorption of contracts by consumers, the market displayed a steady undertone and closed at net gains of 1 to 4 points.

THE dramatic story of the destruction or the German High Seas Fleet, first by the Internal mutiny of Bolshevist sailors and finally by the imperial officers who ordered the historic scuttling at Scapa Flow," is told by Langhorne Gibson and Paul Schubert in "Death of a Fleet," which Coward-McCann will publish on Sept. 14.

LONG ISLAND. Sumner Ballard gave a dinner last night at his Summer home in Syosset in honor of Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly. Mrs. Twombly will also be an honor guest at a dinner to be given by Mr. and Mrs. James Blanchard Clews on Sept. 26 at La Lanterne, their home in Brookville.
STRESA, Italy, Sept. 10 -- The Austrian financial situation was explained at today's committee meeting of the Stresa conference by Dr. Viktor Brauneis, general director of the Austrian National Bank.

IN the early days of electric power, public utility companies stopped their machinery when a thunderstorm loomed because of the risk they ran from lightning. Interruptions were so common in some cities that they were not considered news unless trolley cars were stopped for at least a few hours.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 12. HUNGARY is putting up a game light to save her theatre. If ever a nation was down and out economically, Hungary is that one. Thirteen years of crisis, relentless and uninterrupted, have brought about conditions unprecedented in the history of the nation -- and to my surprise have found it to be the most optimistic and cheerful of all.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Don Brennan held Albany to three hits in pitchings his twenty-third victory of the season for Newark in the second game of the double-header with Albany today. The score was 13 to 1.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31-- The League of Nations is soon to hear a South American echo of one of Europe's many political problems growing out of the new map that was drawn at Versailles, when a petition is sent to Geneva in the name of 200,000 Croatian emigres, identical with a petition being circulated in the United States, asking that Croatia be freed from Serbian rule and restored to independence.

Strength in United States Government bonds and irregular prices for domestic corporation issues and foreign loans characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The turnover was a little more than the average for the two-hour trading period, amounting to $5,170,000.

An appeal to the nation's 4,000,000 veterans to bring pressure to bear upon the American Legion against approval of the proposal for immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus was made last night by Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan in a radio address under the auspices of the National Economy League.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- The United Property Owners' Association has inaugurated a drive in Bergen County to enroll 10,000 members to work for lower taxes. The organization is active in tax matters and budgets. It intends to investigate and bring legal test cases where it is found necessary to restrain officials from unnecessary public expenditure, and in the interest of lower governmental costs.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 10 -- Directing his appeal to the "forgotten man" not to change the nation's leadership during the present crisis, Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, in an address here tonight closing the Republican campaign in Maine for Monday's State election, declared that President Hoover had come to grips with the country's economic problems, but that Governor Roosevelt apparently had not.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Six fishing boats sank at their moorings in Pouch Cove today during a fierce northeast gale. Sixty others were in danger and it was feared that all would sink.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- To be a member of the French Academy, is a high honor much coveted by men of letters, but not worth a great deal financially, judging from a survey just made for the Paris Midi. The increased prestige does not seem to be followed by a corresponding gain in book sales.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22 -- Contributions totaling approximately $11,000,000 in Chinese money were made by Chinese in all parts of the world to support the Nineteenth Route Army, which fought against the Japanese at Shanghai last February.

NEWTON D. BAKER is a little man physically, but that is the only small thing about him. As Secretary of War he united a remarkably alert mind with a mastery of the apt word, and a sense of fairness and justice I have never seen surpassed in any one.

Most of the churches which have been closed for the Summer will reopen today. During last week many pastors returned and will resume their pulpits this morning. Others will come home from their vacations this week. Many of the churches which are not in the heart of the city will not start Sunday evening worship until the beginning of October.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The monument at Meaux, commemorating the battle of the Marne, the gift of the American people to France and one of the largest war memorials yet built, will be presented to the French Government tomorrow by Ambassador Walter E. Edge in the presence of President Lebrun, Premier Herriot and other high officials.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee, theoretically the target for a City Hall demonstration of 7,000 Communists yesterday, turned the tables on the Communist leaders in an open discussion of the city's relief program and sent them away complaining that he had tried to feed them "molasses syrup."

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The wheat crop of all Canada was estimated today at 467,150,000 bushels by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. Last year the crop was 304,144,000 bushels. The bureau also estimated the total crop of oats at 422,529,000 bushels, that of barley at 88,050,000; rye, 12,725,000, and flaxseed, 3,129,500.

SPOKANE, Sept. 10 -- Men with ropes around their waists, dangling over cliffs of dizzy heights, sheer rock walls more than 1,000 feet in some places above the forest-covered floor of Glacier National Park in Montana, was the thrilling spectacle witnessed in the construction of the intermountam highway.

TOKYO, Aug. 20 -- A scheme to assassinate the Premier, Viscount Makoro Saito; the Finance Minister, Korekiyo Takahashi, and the Home Minister, Baron Tatsuo Yamamoto, has dwindled under police inquiry into the swindling of a politically-obsessed doctor by a thug who spent in riotous living the money paid him by an official of a patriotic society for the "removal" of the three statesmen mentioned.

It one of the mysteries of literature that one writer should survive to a later generation while another, as well or better known in his own time, is neglected or forgotten. No less strange is the way in which the revolving wheel of chance brings back to renewed favor one who has been temporarily in eclipse.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Pardner, bay gelding, owned and exhibited by James Butler Jr., annexed the Wyoming challenge plate, feature event of the third annual Tanrackin Horse Show on the estate of Gustavus T. Kirby today.

With the captain, a former deckhand and two former firemen of the destroyed craft held as material witnesses, Bronx authorities decided yesterday to hold a grand jury investigation, beginning Tuesday, of the explosion that wrecked the steamer Observation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- The Soviet Union is conducting a public health and medical supervision campaign on a gigantic scale, the scope and depth of which far exceed anything the world has previously known.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange decreased 246,952 shares in August to 1,934,647 shares on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday. The reduction reflected the large short-covering movement during the first two weeks of last months, when stocks were rising rapidly.

ONE of the signs of maturity in individuals or communities is their discovery of what is best and most personal in them, and the subsequent development of these characteristics to their most complete expression.

MUNICH ADOLF HITLER. What would he be like? What is the secret of his strange power? I wondered, vaguely, as I wandered in the streets of Munich. It was the Munich of the past that I was seeing, Museums, full of relics.

Successful Fall promotions and fewer mark downs and returns will be the objective of the fashion presentation and style conference to be held next Wednesday under the auspices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The commerce of New York has suffered recently from propaganda designed to show the port to be overcrowded and expensive and to attract business to competing port cities, according to a report submitted by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie to the Mayor.

The United States Seniors' Golf Association, whose slogan, "Once a senior always a senior; sometimes venerable, but never aged," has become known the world over, will hold its twenty-eighth annual championship at the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y., on Tuesday, "Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Charges that twenty-eight national labor groups are in the hands of gangsters, radicals and crooked politicians will be made in a nation-wide radio campaign to be sponsored by the American Federation of Labor.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 10 -- With Monday's polling expected to be the closest Maine election in a Presidential year since 1916, the Republican and Democratic State Chairmen issued statements tonight claiming victories by small majorities.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Both major parties in the Nutmeg State are enjoying a brief breathing spell after a week which has witnessed their State conventions. By the beginning of next week they will be busily engaged in preparations for their campaigns, which, it is predicted, will be replete with interest and confront both Republicans and Democrats with a real test of their fighting qualities.
Cheers for Charley Grimm and jeers for the once popular Flatbush idol, Dazzy Vance, punctuated the progress of the one-sided game at Ebbets Field yesterday, which the high-flying Cubs won, 9 to 2.
WASHINGTON WITHDRAWAL from the market, for a few months at least, of the wheat and cotton held by the Federal Farm Board marks a new chapter in the story of that body, now three years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said tonight that economic conditions apparently are improving and that "though at times they will be fluctuating the trend is decidedly upward."

DETROIT. A DIESEL-POWERED passenger automobile for 1933 is raceiving considerably more attention than other prospective developments this far in advance of the appearance of next year's models. While there is no official confirmation even of its being offered, it is said that the car will be introduced in the medium-price field, at $1,500, by a new manufacturing concern.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- "Who holds Prussia, holds the Reich" was an old adage under the imperial German Constitution, when, with the King of Prussia Kaiser of the Reich and the State's Premier the Chancellor, Prussia's hegemony in the German federation of States was uncontested.

In today's Special Features Section of THE TIMES an article by NEWTON D. BAKER begins with the declaration: "America will be on trial this Winter." He was writing as Chairman of the National Citizens Committee on relief and welfare. His special subject is the severe test of the charitable impulses and resources of the American people which is certain to be made during the coming months.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Four days before he took his life, Paul Bern, motion picture producer and husband of Jean Harlow, passed a medical examination for $85,000 of life insurance. This was revealed today by Dr. Harry M. Brandel, medical examiner for the Prudential Life Insurance Company.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 10 -- A panel of seventy-five talesmen was summoned today by Supreme Court Justice John B. Johnston for next Monday for the trial of three members of the Nassau County Police Department on charges of assaulting Alexander Drangel, one of the prisoners arrested with Hyman Stark, who died as a result of a beating received at Police Headquarters here.

JUST around the corner -- if, by chance, you should happen to be in Sixth Avenue at a point near its junction with Fourteenth Street -- there is in generation these bright September mornings a project which bids fair to be in the light of past accomplishments, one of the surest approaches to prosperity that the present theatrical season will have to offer.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Immensely important iron deposits have just been discovered in Western Siberia, 125 miles from the metallurgical plant at Kusnetsk -- now called Stalinsk -- and less than seventy miles from the railway.

Application of statistical theory to the control of manufacturing operations, in order to reduce costs and to simplify standardization problems, is spreading rapidly through American industry and will have a farreaching effect upon every branch of industrial operations, engineers predicted here last week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Football practice under Princeton's new coaching staff headed by Fritz Crisler will commence next Thursday when ninety men are expected to appear in uniforms on University Field. Coach Crisler, who succeeded Al Wittmer as football mentor at Princeton, will give his men two practices earh day until college opens on Sept. 28, when only afternoon sessions will be held.

KRESIMIR BARANOVIC, the 38-year-old director of the opera company in Zagreb, chief city of the Croatian section of Yugoslavia, has composed an interesting and novel work under the title of "Strizeno-koseno" (Shorn or Mowed), which recently had its premiere in Zagreb under the direction of the composer himself.

BOOKS with the borrowed label "Now It Can Be Told" --implying that the veil has at last been torn from naked fact, hitherto discreetly or fearfully hid from the curious public eye, and unctiousiy intimating that the naked fact is ugly -- have become a drug on the market.

No. 1, 424 Yards -- Par 4. A comparatively easy starting hole. Two bunkers have been added to the fairway since the P.G.A. championship in 1928. The drive is downhill and then there is a rise to the green. The large green is undulating, welltrapped in the rear and on two sides.

JUST as predicted, the remote spiral nebulae appear to be running away from us and the velocity of recession increases in proportion to the distance. The disturbing thing is the rate at which the expansion is going on. The system doubles its diameter in 1,300,000,000 years at the present rate.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 10 (AP) -- An order was issued by the Chancery Court today requiring creditors, stockholders and debenture holders of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation to show cause on Sept. 23 why the receivers for the corporation should not be authorized to assign their rights to repurchase 50,000 shares of preference stock and 105,000 shares of the common stock of the American Gas and Power Company.

CITY HALL PARK, centre of all the principal urban activities of New York for three-quarters of a century after 1800, and still the political hub of the metropolitan universe, is to be restored, though the actual restoration may take a year or more, to something like the state of a "grove in the midst of the city" which was the refreshing aspect of its best days.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 -- These are lid-lifting days in the Greater Pittsburgh district. Following the investigation that resulted in the conviction of Mayor Kline and a former director of the city supplies department on charges of irregularities in the awarding of contracts, a grand jury went to work on Allegheny County affairs under the preceding Board of Commissioners.

THERE is no limit to the energy of bibliographers. In their restlessness they seem to have explored every known field of literature. And yet every season produces fresh evidence of the fact that no subject can be considered finished, bibliographically speaking.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31 -- Two months of civil war in Brazil have brought the two largest armies in American history to a deadlock in such manner that there now seems little probability of the great spectacular battle which was to open the way either for a rebel advance on Rio de Janeiro or a federal advance on Sao Paulo.

VIENNA, Aug. 26 -- Though the economic repercussions of the great war still seem perceptible enough, its documentary precipitate as preserved in the world's archives is rapidly fading. This is true, at any rate, of the Vienna archives, where the damage already done by time is so great that a method of preventing further deterioration is being sought.

IN his novel "The Fortress" Hugh Walpole carries the reader through the third part of his fictional history of the Herries family, the first volume of which was "Rogue Herries" and the second "Judith Paris." Judith, it will be recalled, was the vehement but immensely capable daughter of "The Rogue" and the gypsy woman he had made his wife.

LA PAZ, Sept. 10 -- Paraguayan troops, launching their second attack on Fort Boqueron in a day of intensive fighting, were hurled back in disorder this evening, according to a dispatch from General Quintanilla, commanding the Bolivian Fourth Division in the Gran Chaco.

HOLLISTER, Mo., Sept. 8 --The Ozark country, or at least that part of it known as the White River district, is a country of caves, coon dogs and hospitable folk, not to mention original and odd-sounding names. Visitors seldom fail to wonder at such names as Gobbler's Knob, High Lonesome, Loafer's GlorY, Gald Joe, Virgin's Bluff, Naked Joe, Possum Trot and others no less characteristic.

Philadelphia cricketers yesterday advanced in the play for the championship of the United States Cricket Association at Dunwoodie in Yonkers, where the Ardmore Cricket Club defeated and eliminated the eleven of the Westchester County Cricket Club, winners of the cup last year, in a semi-final round contest.

SUMTER, S.C., Sept. 8 -- The Democrats will have a second primary on Sept. 13, but nothing can happen to change the fact that when Congress meets again Thomas S. McMillan, heretofore the State's only wet Representative, will have plenty of company among his colleagues from South Carolina.

NOT very much has yet been published about the service given by the Frontier Nurses down in the isolated mountain region of Kentucky, although there has been a book or two and some articles describing the work. Ernest Poole's new volume, therefore, will introduce many readers to a new subject that is alive with human interest, most appealing in its story of happy and willing sacrifice and beneficent results, intriguing and picturesque in its background.

THE balloting to be held tomorrow in Maine to elect State officers and Representatives to Congress once more raises the issue of the validity of this early election as an indicator of the political trend in the nation.

The ruling of Internal Revenue Commissioner David Burney that New York State by bottling and selling the natural carbonated waters of Saratoga Springs has gone into business and must pay the Federal tax of 2 cents a gallon on the product has been referred to Attorney General Bennett for determination as to whether or not an appeal should be taken.

Although Professor CLAUDE E. ROBINSON, in his pamphlet "Maine -- Political Barometer," has pointed out that Maine is no such thing, her September election is preceded by sleepless nights for the two National Committees. This is because a legend is sometimes stronger than a fact.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 25 -- In the storm and stress of the outrolling economic tide there remains one governmental unit of the United States which has not a dollar of indebtedness -- that is the Territory of Alaska.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Governor Roosevelt called upon the people of the State today to observe Constitution Day on Sept. 17 and urged that citizens make efforts to familiarize themselves "with the fascinating study of the drafting of the Constitution, its development, its effects and its contents."

HARBIN, Manchuria, Aug. 8 -- Every so often, reports emanate from Changchun of the intention of the Manchukuo government to enact measures for conservation of fish and game in Manchuria. As yet, nothing definite has resulted, and Manchurian wild life continues to get along without any legal protection.

PANAMA, R.P., Sept. 6 -- At last Ecuador has a real revolution in which many lives were lost and a number of bitter battles were fought, although what is known as the "Constitutional Government" has not been overthrown, as has been the case in a number of other Latin America revolts of recent date.

FOR the first time this year some of the stores reported for the week that sales on several days had run ahead of the corresponding figures of a year ago. Cool weather brought a brisk demand for Fall goods, and this business combined with volume on school and college outfitting to send up totals.
BERLIN THE Ufa blazed the season open before the middle of August with three films that ordinarily you would have expected them to save for the end of September or even later in the Fall or Winter.
IT is clear today that Germany cannot participate in further deliberations of the disarmament conference until the question of German equality has found fundamental clarification.

LAKELAND, Fla., Sept. 8 -- Economic tension in Florida is decreasing as citrus growers prepare to harvest a slightly smaller crop at prices which undoubtedly will be higher than they were last season. In fact, there are signs that point toward better prices than have been obtainable in three seasons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Fortyone projects in the emergency Treasury-Postoffice building program were announced today by Secretary Mills and Postmaster General Brown. They will have a limit of cost of $53,690,000 and include an office building for New York City, the maximum cost of which was $6,350,000 in the original list.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The financial set-up of fourteen utility companies of the Associated Gas and Electric Company group will be investigated by the Federal Trade Commission at hearings beginning Tuesday.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Prime Minister MacDonald, whose chief anxiety is to prevent failure of the disarmament conference, today assumed personal control of British foreign police relating to disarmament and the German demand for equality in armaments.
TORONTO, Sept. 10 -- Bob Pirie, Toronto, today won the Canadian National Exhibition one-mile amateur swimming race.

Walter White, secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a telegram yesterday to President Hoover suggested that the government pass "definite word to contractors on public work that a just proportion of the employment thus provided must be given to colored workers."
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 10 -- The address of Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, here tonight, closing the Republican campaign in Maine, was as follows:

THE General Motors Truck Company has introduced a six-cylinder engine of 400 cubic inches displacement which develops a maximum of 112 1/2 horsepower and 296 foot-pounds of torque, it is announced by S.P. Landers, managrer of the New York branch.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- The third double-header to three days here netted the Yankees a double triumph in their final games of the season with Detroit today. They outslugged the Tigers to win the first game, 11 to 10, then took the nightcap in the tenth inning, 4 to 1, while a crowd of about 8,000 derived thrills without profit.

The railroads of the country are prepared to submit to arbitration their demand for a 20 per cent reduction in wages, it was reiterated yesterday in management circles. This was considered significant for the reason that arbitration is optional under the railway labor act.

OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- When Colonel Hanford MacNider came to Canada a little more than two years ago as Minister from the United States he had two objectives in mind. He wanted to see erected in Ottawa an adequate office building for the accommodation of American Government officials, and he hoped to see completed during his term of office a treaty between the two governments for construction of the St. Lawrence seaway.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 - Professor Henry Fairfield Osborne, president of the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, returning from a four weeks' tour of the fossil fields of the Northwest, halted here for a few hours today and told of a museum expedition unearthing a new group of dinosaurs, one of which is 70,000,000 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Business activity continued fundamentally unchanged in American foreign markets this week, according to a survey by the Department of Commerce.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Sept. 10 -- Proxies for more than 70 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Rio Grande Oil Company have been deposited in favor of sale to the Consolidated Oil Corporation, it was announced today by Charles Jones, executive vice president of the former company.

LONDON, Aug. 25, 1932 THE Promenade season is in full swing once more and every night of the week the Queen's Hall is filled with an audience that jests at heat waves and stifling atmospheres. The general scheme differs slightly from that of last year.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- The most agreeable surprise of the year in the Bay State issued from the office of the State Insurance Commissioner a few days ago. In the face of warnings in the newspapers that the people would have to endure another boost in automobile insurance rates, Commissioner Brown has blandly put out a tentative schedule for 1933 which shows a general reduction.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 8 -- Arizona, like other States, has been industriously striving to get all the money it can from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. There has been a wide, almost ludicrous, gap between what it asked and what it is likely to obtain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Plans for the relief of distressed owners of mortgaged homes went forward rapidly today with the announcement by Franklin W. Fort, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, that subscription books for the purchase of capital stock in system banks would be opened Wednesday in sixty-five cities.

While 5,000 children and parents, guests of the Liberty Republican Club of the Seventeenth Assembly District, looked on, the Republican party administered a severe defeat to the Democratic party yesterday afternoon on the North Meadow in Central Park.

CORNWALL, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- For the seventeenth time in her comparatively brief career on the bench on this side of the water, Champion Nancolleth Beryl of Giralda was named best in show today in the final judging of the eighth annual show of the Storm King Kennel Club held on the Kenridge Farm race track.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Replying to a request for his views on the nation's military and naval establishments Governor Roosevelt of New York said in a letter published today in The Army and Navy Journal that he believed in an "adequate" national defense.
Babe Ruth will not have to undergo an operation.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- France's reply to the German request for a discussion between the nations of the question of revision of the armament conditions of the treaty of Versailles was approved today by the Cabinet and forwarded to Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador in Berlin, to be communicated to the Reich Government.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10 -- Apprehensive holders of Arkansas bonds may find something more than a forlorn hope in the nomination of J. Marion Futrell as the Democratic candidate for Governor. The nomination is equivalent to election in Arkansas.

ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- The approach of the general elections on Sept. 25 is marked by bitterness unusual even in Greek politics, which have always been renowned for the intensity of the passions they arouse.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- United States Senator Felix Hebert, New England manager of the Hoover-Curtis campaign and Mrs. Herbert; Governor and Mrs. Norman S. Case and State Finance Commissioner and Mrs. Frederick S. Peck were guests at a large luncheon given by former State Senator and Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse at their residence, Stone Villa, today.

HOLLYWOOD THE screen is actually to be cleaned up. After many promises and many false starts, the Hays office, known officially as the Association of Motion Picture Producers, has at last made an issue of the many flaming stories that have reached the audiences in recent months and has called a halt.

THE week of Oct. 17 at the Majestic Theatre, Brooklyn, is being reserved for Guy Bates Post. Working on that information, scouts have brought to light the fact that Mr. Post will appear there -- and later on Broadway, if all goes well -- in "Circumstantial Evidence," a play which Bernard Merivale, cousin of the theatrically better-known Philip, has adapted from the German.

Prices moved last week in a narrower range on local commodity markets as the prolonged and broad upward trend came to a halt in some quarters and was somewhat restrained in others. Quotations for the near-by months in coffee and for cocoa, hides, wool and silver continued to gain moderately, while contracts for coffee in the distant months and for rubber and silk turned lower.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 10 -- The women golfers of the Greenwich Country Club will hold an invitation tournament over the course of the club on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. On the opening day the qualifying round for eighteen holes will be played, with the first and second round matches in all flights to take place the second day and the semi-finals and finals on the third day.

THAMES WILLIAMSON has evolved a sound, effective technique in creating tales that deal with strong, simple, inarticulate men and their womenfolk who are close to the earth and rooted in a tradition remote from present-day civilization.

After fluctuating nervously but within a narrow range in the first hour and a half of trading, the stock market closed yesterday with a firm tone and with most of the pivotal issues showing slight net gains. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange approximated 1,500,000 shares.

THE large flat geography books which children were formerly expected to study in school had one advantage which Mr. Van Loon's contribution to the subject lacks -- they could be used to conceal smaller and more exciting books such as "Ned at the Btock-House," "The Mysterious Avenger" or one of the Old Sleuth series.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Three St. Louis hurlers were unable to stop the Washington Senators today as they batted out fourteen safeties and took the final game of the series, 10 to 4.

WHEN "Mr. Robinson Crusoe" opens at the Rivoli on Sept. 21, admirers of Douglas Fairbanks will see the bounding one in a story he has wanted to do for sixteen years. For it was back in 1916 that he broached a certain plan to friends.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Public expenditures, regardless of the source of taxes, must be brought within the range of the people to meet the cost without burden to themselves or to their business and industry. This necessity faces every governmental unit, whether national or local.

SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me., Sept. 10 -- Still believing her husband is in the hands of the bootleggers, Mrs. Raymond Robins said tonight at the home of her sister, Miss Mary Dreier, that she is confident he will be released ultimately.

SAN DIEGO, or, for that matter, most of the territory in Southern California, once so remote, is now an automobile trip of one week's duration. Reliable cars and improved highways combine to make this achievement possible for the majority run of road driver instead of the few professional experts at the wheel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- What chance have the Democrats to carry President Hoover's own State against him in November? The question, a subject of some desultory discussion before the primaries of Aug. 30, has been thrust forward since that date and the soothsayers of both parties are endeavoring to read the riddle by the light of the primary returns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Sept. 3 were slightly above the preceding week's total, but continued well under the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly index of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

FROM far dim centuries there has come down to us a singing voice so poignant-sweet, so arresting, so perfect that for twenty-five hundred years mankind has said, with unanimous and unceasing wonder at its beauty, that Sappho of Lesbos is the greatest or all women poets and one of the greatest of all the poets who have ever lived.

The week's news was 90 per cent political, which is natural for the first se'ennight after Labor Day. By American tradition the real Presidential campaign does not begin until the first Monday in September has been duly celebrated, although that is more than two months after the party candidates are nominated.

A general increase in activity, in Fall ready-to-wear, children's wear, school supplies and housewares departments developed in local retail trade during the week, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer Both Retail Reporting Bureau.

PARIS PARIS in the middle of the Summer, especially this Summer, contains practically nothing of interest in the way of dance performances, but it is nevertheless possible to glean here a wealth of gossip and no little actual information of what way things are tending.

CRISTOBAL, Canal Zone, Sept. 5 -- Two elderly Englishwomen, one a counselor of Harrow-on-the-Hill, who visited this port recently, were disappointed because they could not find a speakeasy in the Canal Zone, and left with serious doubts as to the veracity of two American residents of the Isthmus they had met on board ship coming out from England.

TOKYO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The storm of protest which has developed during the last two days over the photographing or several Japanese business and industrial buildings by the National City Bank of New York assumed a more serious aspect today and led to diplomatic action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Hoover today set for his administrative officers the task of cutting appropriations for the next fiscal year by "at least" $500,000,000 from the funds voted at the last session of Congress.
BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The last-place Cincinnati Reds today opened their final series in Boston with a 5-2 victory over the Braves. Cy Johnson held Boston to seven well-scattered hits.

ON a Vermont hillside this week gayly sweatered girls are thronging the campus of a brand-new college which has the highest tuition, the least pretentious buildings and the most revolutionary curriculum of any in the United States.

HIGHER standards of decoration in every man's house now demand not only that chairs and tables shall be useful, windows correctly curtained, wall and floor coverings harmonious, but that all the furnishings should seem at home.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Two former national amateur golf champions were suffering from ailments today that gave promise of hampering them when play starts for the national amateur crown at Five Farms on Monday.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Ninety-seven entries sailed in a regatta here today as the Little Egg Harbor Yacht Club of Beach Haven closed the 1932 New Jersey yachting season by playing host to the sailing skippers of seven yacht clubs on Barnegnt Bay as well as Atlantic City yachtsmen, helmsmen from the Barnegat Light Yacht Club of High Point and innumerable local windjammers.

THIS very charming book tells the life story of a tadpole as he changes to a frog. He makes the acquaintance of insects, newts, lizards, snakes and other creatures, some harmful and some harmless, who inhabit the Blue Pool, is instructed by the Patriarch, the great frog of many Summers, who hints that Wagtail may become Patriarch himself some day.
James J. Walker sailed for Europe yesterday, but he promised to be back in twenty days. The trip was for his health, he said, and "to set away from desks and telephones."

ON the edge of Siberia, in the foothills of the Ural Mountains, the little village of Vertne Uralsky is proud of possessing one of those revered symbols of the new culture, a phonograph. Vertne Uralsky is on inaccessible Asiatic village, but from still more distant Asiatic villages come peasants who wonder at Vertne Uralsky's culture.

The first intrusion of established export associations into the field of tariff discussion was heralded last week by the action of the American Manufacturers' Export Association in voting to make a thorough study of tariff boards or commissions established in Canada, Great Britain and a number of nations on the European Continent.

LISBON, Aug. 20 -- The return to Brazil in the near future of Dr. Julio Prestes, who was elected President in 1930 but who was never inaugurated because of the revolution which overthrew the Washington Luis Government and installed Dr. Getulio Vargas, Dr. Prestes's political opponent, as chief executive, depends entirely upon the progress made by the Sao Paulo rebels in their fight against the federal government.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 10 -- The semi-final chapter was written today in the thrilling diamond struggle of Chattanooga and Memphis for the Southern Association pennant.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 10 -- Members of the American Legion began arriving in force today for the national convention, opening Monday, with the rank and file prepared to rush through a demand for immediate payment of the bonus before they adjourn next Thursday.

GENEVA, Sept. 10 -- The League of Nations has not yet received Tokyo's reported request that publication of the report of the Manchurian inquiry commission under the Earl of Lytton be delayed until a declaration it wishes to make on it is received.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 3 were 559,727 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 21,754 cars more than in the preceding week, but 200,144 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 296,922 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Largely as the result of a sweeping non-seasonal rise in freight car loadings, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index for the week ended Sept. 3 shows the most substantial advance recorded since the beginning of the present year. The combined index for the week ended Sept. 3 is 53.3, as against 52.4 for the preceding week and the low point of 52.2 for the weeks ended Aug. 20 and Aug. 13.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Miss Nancy Nicholas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry I. Nicholas of Rolling Hill Farm, Syosset, was introduced to society this evening at a large dinner dance at Clayton, the country home of Mr. and Mrs. Childs Frick in Roslyn Harbor.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 10 -- A government, communique today stated that the beginning of the third month of the civil war found the federal artillery on the eastern front hammering the Paulistan positions, especially Cruzeiro. In the Minas Geraes sector, it was stated, federal forces were progressing slowly toward Campinas, taking small villages en route.

FOR a thousand years, more or less, the Western World has been hunting for and finding new trade routes to Asia. The caravans took their precarious and devious ways through Persia, across Tibet and into China. The mariners of Portugal led the search along the coast of Africa, around the Cape of Good Hope and thence north and east through uncharted seas.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Ernest Lee Jabncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, said at a Republican dinner tonight that Governor Roosevelt "pledges his party to re- peal, knowing full well that the Democratic proposal to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment will be de- feated by Democratic votes in the Southern States."

A diamond ring inscribed "Christmas 1876" led to the identification yesterday of the body found by seamen Friday night in the Narrows off Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, as Margaret W. Browne, 45 years old, of 1,316 New Hampshire Avenue, N. W., Washington, D.C., social secretary to Mrs. Charles F. Adams, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. F. Trubee Davison, wife of the Assistant Secretary of War.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 10 -- There were ninety-nine starters this afternoon in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual Fall regatta, but there were only fluttering breaths of air most of the time, and none of the large classes was able to finish before the moon came up over Long Island Sound, so results were called off.

LONDON EVERY day for the last ten years the Prince of Wales has received a letter from an unidentified woman. The letters are all alike. Each one begins "My dear Prince," and then follows a Bible text, nearly always from the Book of Revelation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The silks of R.M. Eastman were carried to victory in the featured Homewood Purse at Lincoln Fields today when Cathop scored by two and a half lengths over the Coldstream Stud's Sweet Scent. Dixiana's Cee Tee was third.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- The German Stock Exchanges have reacted to the speech of Chancellor von Papen in which he outlined the fundamentals of the government's new economic program with a notable upward movement affecting both stocks and bonds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Extensive changes in the curriculum of the Naval Academy will be made for the first time in many years during the next academic year, the Navy Department announced today. The explanation of the change, in brief, was that there had been too much "technical" training at the academy and not sufficient "cultural" knowledge.

Creaking at every joint and looking not at all like the trim machine that a year ago this time was galloping on to a pennant and a world's championship, the Cardinals steamed into the Polo Grounds yesterday for their final appearance of the year here and for a few fleeting moments endeavored to put on a bold front.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10 -- By a wider margin than any final of recent years has been decided, the young Templeton team hammered its way to the national open polo championship at the Meadow Brook Club today, defeating the crippled Green-tree team, 16 to 3, in a match which lacked the suspense an the crowded action of those which had gone before it in the tournament.
PARIS ONLY a few days ago a Russian writer, just come from Moscow, paid me a visit. We compared his country and mine.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The first detailed story of how the so-called Oldoway skeleton was proved to be comparatively recent, instead of being, as was contended, "the oldest known specimen of homo sapiens," is told in the current issue of "Nature," by P.G.H. Boswell, geologist of the Imperial College of Science.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored three runs in the ninth inning today to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 6 to 3 and make it two victories in three starts during the series.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- If only fifteen months ago the question had been put to any responsible Frenchman, "Will France ever repudiate her debt toward the United States?" the answer would have been an indignant "Of course never!"
LABOR has given, most serious attention and consideration to the economic, financial and social developments which have taken place during the past ten years.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Former champions were outpointed and new champions crowned as the final events of the horse show at the State Fair Grounds were run off today. One of the closest contests was that between Miss Patricia Bonsall's Peach Melba and J.U. Kuhns's Solid Gold for the five-gaited championship, the decision finally going to Solid Gold.

The touching off of bombs in front of two Loew theatres in the city after closing time Friday night, which was laid by the police to labor troubles, as was the hurling of bottles of phosphorus from the balconies of two theatres in the Century chain in Brooklyn, earlier in the week, caused Police Commissioner Mulrooney to station patrolmen in all Brooklyn motion picture theatres yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 -- A hint of a revolt against the all-powerful junior Senator from Louisiana, Huey Kingfish Long, is noted by some observers in the current Senatorial campaign. These men interpret the action of seven parishes in refusing to recognize pro-Long "dummy candidates" as an indication that the Blaster of Louisiana may have a little trouble on his hands before long.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Miss Helen Fulton, 18-year-old Chicago tennis player, today won the girls' national singles championship, beating Miss Bonnie Miller of Los Angeles in the final round at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, 6 -- 2, 11 -- 9.

With the reopening of the city's schools this week, preparations for one of the outstanding years in scholastic sports history will get under way and until next June there will be little interruption in schoolboy athletic activities except for the Christmas and Easter holiday recess periods.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- Some of the political wiseacres are discussing the possibility of the tie vote in the Republican primary in the Ninth Congressional District becoming the basis of a contested seat which, if the next House is controlled by the Democrats, might give California another Democratic Representative.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. LAST Thursday the College Art Association opened here, at the Guild Hall, one of the new season's traveling exhibitions: a show devoted to the work of six modern painters of three nations. Why these particular painters?

MANILA, Aug. 6 -- In connection with the proposal of an additional levy upon the sugar industry in the nature of a production tax of 1 1/2 centavos a picul, as a means of obtaining additional government revenues, the Philippine Sugar Association has made an analysis of the extent to which the government is already dependent upon sugar.

TO many seekers of rest and recreation this is an ideal time to visit the popular playgrounds of the New Jersey shore. The run from New York to Atlantic City or Cape May and return does not greatly exceed 350 miles, no matter which route is chosen.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Speeches stressing the need for economy were made at the annual Republican Club field day at Forest Park today by F. Trubee Davison of Locust Valley and Mayor Holland B. Marvin of Syracuse, two of the leading Republican candidates for Governor.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Yale's opening football lineup against Bates College, Oct. 1, will be confined mainly to last year's veterans. The squad, numbering 100 players, will report Thursday.

Canadian Olympic stars gained a major share of the honors at the Yankee Stadium yesterday when the Wethered J. Boyd Council of the Knights of Columbus staged its victory track and field meet before a handful of spectators.

The race began its literature with its story-tellers in rune or epic. And it still loves them beyond its teachers and preachers, its statesmen and scientists. Sir GILBERT PARKER, the story-teller of the North, will continue to tell his stories long after it is forgotten that he ever sat in Parliament or was a leader of world conferences.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Sept. 10 -- Bradford Washburn and Walter Everett of Boston arrived here today on board the steamer Queen en route from Juneau to Seattle, bringing with them details of the final attempt of the Harvard Expedition to reach the summit of Mount Crillon, the highest unclimbed peak in the Fairweather Range.

WITH both major parties pledged to a prohibition referendum and the doom of the Eighteenth Amendment already pronounced by one of our Presidential candidates, the point of view of speakeasy proprietors, as business men faced with a crisis, becomes interesting.

The United Cigar Stores Company of America, a New Jersey corporation, transferred $2,000,000 of its assets in cash to a new corporation formed last March in Delaware, Rudolph M. Hirschwald, an attorney representing Pennsylvania creditors, charged yesterday at a hearing in bankruptcy held in the Post Office Building.

LONDON THE British Radio Exhibition, held at London's largest exhibition hall, Olympia, closed triumphantly, showing that in these days of depression one industry at least is enjoying a phase of unprecedented prosperity.

Calvin Coolidge and other prominent national leaders, it was reliably reported in Wall Street yesterday, are expected to become members of a non-partisan commission for the purpose of making a thorough study of the country's railroad problems, with a view to recommending remedial legislation at the next session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Confronted with the refusal of Paraguay to agree to a suspension of hostilities in the Chaco without "adequate guarantees" and of Bolivia to suspend mobilization in the present circumstances, the commission of neutrals, in an identic note to both governments, today urged them to suspend hostilities immediately and to agree to a period of three months of negotiation, dating from Oct. 1 at the latest.

THE current trend to radio stories has now led Warner Brothers to delve into the lives of the feminine broadcasting contingent. "Radio Girl" is the title of a radio-musical film which will have an early production. Its leading player will be Bebe Daniels, who is engaged at the moment on the final episodes of "Silver Dollar," in which she will be seen with Edward G. Robinson.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation increased 3,293 tons in August, the first gain reported in seventeen months, it was announced yesterday. The increase was interpreted in Wall Street as a sign of improvement in the steel industry and in the many lines of business which consume steel.

DURING one of those uneventful week-ends when these chronicles are generally written a volume of The Spectator unaccountably turned up on this desk. And there was Addison, two hundred years ago, bowing low before the art of tragedy.

A continued demand by the United States upon its European debtors that they meet their inter-allied debts according to present terms will disarrange the exchanges of the world and place a serious obstacle in the path of a resumption of foreign trade, in the opinion of the New York Credit Men's Association.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- The itinerary and detailed time table of the special train which will take Governor Roosevelt over the route of his campaign tour through twenty States was announced tonight as follows:

Whether willingly or reluctantly, about 1,095,580 children, the enrolment estimated by the budget committee of the Board of Education, will go to their classrooms tomorrow morning for the Fall term of the city's public school system, and 36,000 teachers will be at their posts to resume the business of instructing New York's youth.

GOING to college need less and less condemn a boy or girl to four years of rigid preparation in traditional academic subjects with little regard for his special interests. With the liberalizing of the college entrance requirements and the evolving of new courses, light and joy are increasingly being let into the once narrow confines of the preparatory school.

BOGOTA, Sept. 6 -- El Tiempo in belated comment on the victory of the American athletes in the Olympic Games, says from it can be developed a theory that will explain in part the civilization of the United States.

RICHMOND, Sept. 8 -- The lively controversy now in progress here over the advisability of the appropriation by this city of a sufficient sum to provide necessary rights of way in connection with the James River development project, has attracted the attention of the entire State.

THOUGH Jeffrey Amherst's reputation as a soldier of the King has often been told in song and story, it was only with the discovery in 1925 of his complete journals that scholars and the historically minded were able to survey thoroughly the building of that reputation from the hero's own point of view.

At the close of 1931 the Federal Reserve Banks charged off against their surpluses $8,158,268 for depreciation on their holdings of United States Government bonds, which amounted on that date to $360,368,000. Since then, under the stimulus provided by Federal Reserve purchases of more than $1,000,000,000 of United States Government securities and the return of confidence in the dollar, government bonds have risen to a point where only two issues are still below par.
Several apartment houses were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

A revival of the diamond-cutting trade in Antwerp during August, which led to an increase in workers' wages, was reflected here last week by a rise of 10 to 15 per cent in the prices of the smaller cut gems and of 30 to 35 per cent in the larger stones, dealers in the New York market reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The Chicago police joined today with local Federal agents in the search for Raymond Robins, as the belief grew that the missing prohibition and social service leader is somewhere in this city, where he has been reported seen by two more acquaintances.

JOEL M'CREA, who may be seen opposite Dolores Del Rio at the Mayfair this week in "Bird of Paradise," had one ambition in his young life, and that was to be a motion-picture star. Before he ever went to college the young man took a course of study at the Hollywood High School and dreamed about the near-by splendor of the studios.

The boats which took part in the races for the Gold Cup at Montauk last month will resume their rivalry in the contests for the President's Cup, one of the most important prizes in motor boating, in the regatta to be held at Washington on Friday and Saturday.

Speed Vs. Safety. TO preach safety is to invite empty pews. As a conversational topic, no less than in practice, speed offers considerably greater exhilaration. Yet safety and speed bear a close relation, so close indeed that, like the scales of a balance, the first goes down as the second goes up.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 10 -- Onta produced minerals to the value $41,006,401 in the first six month of this year, or $9,983,209 less than in the same period last year. The output of metals was valued at $3840,362, against $38,352,872 a year before, but by adding the different of exchange between United States and Canadian funds, the total brought up to $37,319,482.

Mail orders for "rush" merchandise, particularly ready-to-wear and accessories, and for goods required for fill-in purposes for current selling, featured buying activity during the week in the wholesale markets, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

THE publication one year ago of Thomas Rourke's first novel, "Thunder Below." brought to him considerable acclaim. His theme was the disintegration of the rigid northern morale in a Central American jungle outpost.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Densmore Shute, the slim Ohioan, bettered par today with consecutive rounds of 70 and 68 to coast over the final thirty-six holes and carry off the winner's purse of $1000 in the Glens Falls open tourney with a 72-hole total of 280, five strokes ahead of the field.

TODAY. 11:00 A.M. -- WEAF-WJZ -- William Beebe, undersea explorer, from Nonsuch Island, ten miles off Bermuda, will describe what he sees through the window of his steel encased ball known as the bathysphere, 2,640 feet below the surface of the sea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The belief that amnesia or Russian imperialists are responsible for the mysterious disappearance of Raymond Robins gained strength today among Federal officers here.
AMERICA will be on trial this Winter. Her relief and human service needs, according to all reports, threaten to be more extreme than any our generation has ever known.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 10 -- The long-awaited statement on the liabilities and assets of Ivar Kreuger's estate was published today, showing a deficit of $191,762,730 at current rates of exchange.

RADIO will pump high power into the autumnal air More electricity will be radio-diffused across the land. More than a dozen stations are stepping up their wattage, which means they will have stronger voices. Eight members of the National Broadcasting Company's chains have been authorized by the Radio Commission to add 297,000 watts to the network.

Mrs. Mary Schweinert of 42 Riverside Drive and Brielle, N.J., has been sued for $256,400 damages by Edith Jacobs, a private secretary, on the ground that Mrs. Schweinert caused Joseph J. Gottman, a medical student, to break an engagement to marry Miss Jacobs.

Discovering new girl swimming wonders is almost an old story with the Women's Swimming Association of New York. So many really brilliant and speedy mermaids have been turned out by this organization in recent years that it doesn't cause much wonderment when some new miss is brought forth and declared to be a coming Ederle or Boyle or Bleibtrey or Holm or Madison.

LONDON THE literature of centennials usually consists merely of attempts at a revaluation of the central figure. It brings to light little new material for such an appraisement. The centenary of Scott's death, however, bids fair to enrich considerably our knowledge of his life and work.

AFTER eight years of persuasion, the Dalai Lama of Tibet has given permission for another British expedition to attempt to climb Mount Everest. Tibet's ruler and Everest have something in common: inaccessibility. The last 900 feet of the world's highest mountain have yet to be conquered; the world's most mysterious ruler has been inter- viewed and photographed, but he has yet to succumb to a talking movie apparatus or speak into a microphone.

MADRID, Sept. 9 -- The Spanish Cortes has just created a new "pocket State," conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that minority rights can be respected without weakening a nation. Only those aware of the persecution of minorities in European countries can appreciate the importance of this creation.

Sporting good houses report an increased sale of sporting guns of various character, as well as assorted equipment for hunting, again marking the fact that it will not be long before the hunting seasons are on in full blast. In some of the Eastern States the open season on certain wild waterfowl opens on Oct. 1.

Reports from London predict that the British Government will take no action at this time to obtain a partial postponement of service on its war debt to the United States. During the present fiscal year England is committed to pay $30,000,000 in principal and $131,100,000 in interest.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee and the Democratic State Committee, was the guest of his friends and neighbors of Rockland County tonight at an informal testimonial dinner at the Haverstraw Elks Club.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Mayor Cermak of Chicago, "advance man" for the Windy City's forthcoming World's Fair, has sailed homeward, satisfied in the accomplishment of his mission of telling the world that Chicago is far from being as bad as it is painted.

THERE is an unending fascination about the life and career of Queen Elizabeth that imbues each new biographical study of her with an importance and freshness all its own. Providing there is assiduity in research, intelligence in approach and imagination in handling, the ambitious biographer is bound to bring out something unexpected and instructive.
RADIO operators along the Atlantic seaboard and on ships at sea during the World War were always on the alert for the wartime call NIL. That was the S.S. George Washington.

The new Eighth Avenue subway which was thrown open to the public at 12:01 o'clock yesterday morning, passed its first real operating test successfully by handling smoothly and efficiently its first rush-hour traffic.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Mariana, the Newbrook Stable's fleet 2-year-old trotting filly, chalked up another victory when she defeated Happy the Great and Maid McElwyn in the feature event of the weekly matinee today.

NEW YORK'S most stubborn shipping problem is on Manhattan Island itself. Before engineering skill had reached its present high level, the difficulties of hauling across water loomed large. Today great bridges and tunnels link Manhattan with the mainland.

HONOLULU, Sept. 10 -- The legal end of the so-called Ala Moana case, in which four Honolulu youths are under indictment for an alleged criminal assault on Mrs. Thalia Massie, was envisioned here today as John C. Kelley, Honolulu's public prosecutor, prepared to sail Wednesday for New York to meet Governor Lawrence M. Judd and Harry Hewitt, the Territorial Attorney General, on Oct. 3 for a conference with Pinkerton detective officials.

With the passage of the revenue act imposing a Federal tax of one cent a gallon on gasoline, the goose that lays that particular golden egg took on an added burden. Already much had been demanded of her. Every State now has a gasoline tax, running from two cents a gallon in Connecticut to seven in Florida.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Pittsburgh defeated the Phillies in both ends of a double-header today, 5 to 2 and 5 to 4. Fifteen errors were made during the afternoon, eight by the Phils and seven by the Pirates.

The fact that the private thoughts of the characters are heard in the pictorial version of Eugene O'Neill's play "Strange Interlude," as they were in the original, begets the idea of a reviewer giving his own mental reactions on the first night of this film.

THERE is a good bit of abnormal psychology involved in this new story of the retired Shakespearean actor. Drury Lane, who made his first appearance as a detective in "The Tragedy of X." The story deals with the Hatter family, whose members, because of their pronounced eccentricity, are known as the "Mad Hatters."

IN an extended article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 14, 1932, reviewing the Seabury inquiry certain statsments were made with referencs to William J. Flynn, Commissioner of Public Works for the Bronx, to which Mr. Flynn has taken exception.

The reign of Francis Ouimet as national amateur golf champion, begun a year ago seventeen years to the very day after his former triumph in the event, either will be extended or terminated during the coming week on the Five Farms course of the Haltimore Country Club.

Adequate protection for American holders of the two issues of Bulgarian Government loans issued under the auspices of the League of Nations, which are now technically in default, is afforded by the appointment by the Council of the League of an American citizen, Louis P. Sheldon, as trustee for the issues, according to a statement issued yeaterday by the Institute of International Finance, through its director, Dean John T. Madden of New York University.

ROME, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Another possible indication that Italy is dissatisfied with her relations in the League of Nations was unofficially seen here tonight in the appointment of Baron Pompeo Aloisi as head of the Italian delegation to this Autumn's Assembly of the League.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Still following their custom to start Harvard's varsity football practice not earlier than Sept. 15, the Cambridge coaches will not assemble their candidates on Soldiers Field until next Thursday morning. The players will report the previous afternoon to receive equipment.

RIO DE JANIERO, Aug. 26 -- Since July 9, when the Sao Paulo revolt first started, news from that city has been difficult to obtain. No telegraph or telephone communica- tions, mail or newspapers have been available. However, travelers just arriving from Sao Paulo, who were there on the day the revolution began, have brought information of interest.
ARMONK, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The formal opening of the Westchester Aviation Country Club was celebrated here with an air meet this afternoon and a supper dance tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade here were easy in undertone today, with wheat at the inside about 1 cent under Friday's finish, September corn selling at a new low mark on the crop, and September oats equaling the bottom figure of the season.

GERMANY'S army is once more a subject of discussion in European chancelleries. The issue, presented in the arms equality memorandum of Chancellor von Papen's Government is: Shall Germany be free to reorganize her army on a basis corresponding to that of other nations, or shall she continue to be bound by the restrictions established in the Versailles Treaty?

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 8 -- With the State primaries set for Sept. 13, interest in Arizona is concentrating on the question whether George W. P. Hunt will make a national record by being elected Governor for the eighth time. For most candidates it appears that the question will be settled at the primaries, since the Democrats have a majority in party registration which would seem to insure victory.

President Wilson used to say that we had nothing against the German people but that we were fighting those in control of the German nation, who, drunk with a dream of power, had thrown their people into a great and bloody war.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- The Boerse opened quiet today, as a decline had been generally expected. Prices, however, failed to show a downward tendency and speculators who yesterday had liquidated most of their engagements began buying. This led to a general rally in stocks, which closed at the highest quotations of the day.

Carveth Wells, explorer and lecturer, returned from a visit to Russia yesterday on the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm, and asserted that his visit had convinced him that Russia was the "greatest menace in the world."

A YEAR ago next Sunday, during the night, a section of track of the South Manchuria Railway was blown up in the vicinity of Mukden. This act of aggression against Japanese property was attributed to Chinese troops. The next day the Japanese army stationed in Manchuria was set in motion.

As the anniversary of England's suspension of gold payments approaches, many signs are indicating that Great Britain, before any great lapse of time, will have to consider gold resumption. Adoption of a definite policy in that direction may be deferred, irrespective of other reasons, until the proposed "world monetary conference" shall have been held.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Publication of my letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently led to some interesting comment, among which was the letter of Edward F. Chandler.

ROME, Aug. 29, 1932 THE unusual number of open-air opera seasons running in Italy this Summer, taken in conjunction with analogous dramatic enterprises, points to the increasing favor enjoyed by these outdoor presentations in the peninsula.

THE first impression produced by the Democratic candidate for the Presidency is that of the fortunate man who is doing what he most likes to do, a man who enjoys his present office, is eagerly on his way to one he will like better, and in all circumstances maintains a "smilin' through" philosophy and a singular zest for the adventure of life.

THE Richard Wagner Memorial Association, organized to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of Wagner's death -- the anniversary proper is Feb. 13, 1933 -- announces that arrangements are being made for performances of most of the operas and music-dramas of Wagner at the Mecca Auditorium during January and February, 1933.

Enforced retirement of all city officials and employes eligible for pensions, the elimination of every un- necessary job in the army of 148,000 municipal employes and abolition of many positions that are considered necessary were forecast yesterday as the heads of twenty-seven city de- partments dug into their budget esti- mates after Mayor McKee's order for a 20 per cent reduction in each budget.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Paterson, defeating Staten Island, 120 to 23, at East Side Park today, qualified for the final of the annual cup competition of the United States Cricket Association. The victors will meet Ardmore of Philadelphia in the final next Saturday and Sunday.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Humble Oil and Refining Company announced today it would cut by 50 per cent its purchases of crude oil in the East Texas, North Texas and Panhandle fields, effective Monday.

TORONTO, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Montreal swept the three-game series with Toronto to close the International League season locally today by winning both ends of a twin bill, 6 -- 5 in 13 innings and 12 -- 0 in the seven-inning nightcap.

A rule that no employe can be displaced by a machine until executives of the company find some other work within the organization for the displaced worker has proved the most profitable regulation ever adopted by one of the larger producers of metal and metal products, the chief executive said here yesterday.
The new changes in the football code were discussed in theory and demonstrated yesterday at the annual interpretation meeting of the rules committee of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 20 -- With the approach of Autumn, it becomes evident that the Nanking Government's fourth annual campaign against the Communist armies and organized bandits of Central China will end, as did its predecessors, in a stalemate.

WHILE we are still discussing methods of dealing with the depression of the last three years, we are emerging, or about to emerge from it, unprovided with any method of dealing with the boom into which we will move as heretofore, to be followed inevitably and probably more rapidly by another depression.

Three distinct movements, all aimed at establishing better commercial relations with Russia regardless of the Administration's attitude toward ofcial recognition of the Soviet, have been started by American business men in the last ten days, it was learned yesterday.
THE following exhibitions have opened in local galleries since the first of the month, augmenting the list of attractions current here and there about town through the Summer:

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 10. -- Taking life easily, as he had been ordered by his physician, former Mayor James J. Walker declared tonight that he was feeling better than he had for some time. He attributed this improvement to the sea air, which in the few hours since his departure from New York this morning had stimulated him, he said.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- British diplomacy knows that the German demand for equality in respect to armaments is the opening move only in an action intended to destroy the peace treaty altogether. Hence the anxiety felt in London about the situation in Europe.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Scoring 531 out of a possible 600, the 107th Infantry, New York National Guard, rifle team today won the interstate regimental team match of the New Jersey State Rifle Association tournament on the State ranges.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10 -- The unusual activity of the Foreign Office here yesterday has led to the belief that the ABC-Peru conversations have been renewed here after more than a week's suspension, during which they centred at Santiago de Chile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Details of the new arrangement entered into by the French Government concerning the quota system imposed upon exports of American products to France were received by the State Department today from Ambassador Edge in Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10. -- Guy Ellsworth of Big Moose, N.Y., 20-year-old driver, today had his name inscribed on the $6,000 Sir Thomas Lipton Trophy when he captured the fifth annual outboard competition on the Schuylkill River.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Demanding "reasonable and logical preparedness," Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman praised the State Militia as "a school for citizenship" as he laid this afternoon the-cornerstone of the new $650,000 armory of the Thirty-first Fleet Division of the New York State Militia in East Main Street, this city.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Contrasting pictures of the plight of the American farmer, on one hand at the brink of revolution to save his home, on the other afflicted with economic ailments not nearly so severe as described, were painted for Governors and representatives of nine agricultural States today.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- There is a noticeable cooling today in all political camps of any enthusiasm for a new election. Particularly in Hitlerite circles, the drums that were beginning yesterday to sound the call are muffled today after President von Hindenburg's cool reception of the Reichstag's presiding staff.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Conferences to help formulate views on national and international problems were held here today by Governor Roosevelt with Owen D. Young, Senator Wagner of New York and Senator Swanson of Virginia.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Sept. 11. -- The Rumson Stars turned back the hardriding Smithtown poloists, 11 to 10, in an extra-period match at the Monmouth County Country Club today. It was the first defeat for the Long Islanders since they invaded Monmouth County for a series of games a week ago.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 11. -- The cotton market here developed greater activity last week, than in any similar period in several years. The course of values was dominated principally on this government's forecast of the crop, based on conditions on Sept. 1.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 11. -- Despite a rolling sea, former Mayor Walker of New York did not experience today the seasickness he had dreaded. On the contrary, he announced that he was feeling better all the time, and when the ship heeled over on one occasion he remarked:
