The reactions of movie audiences to newsreela shown in various parts of the city in the last few weeks indicate a marked diminution in the popularity of James J. Walker and a corresponding increase in that of Samuel Seabury, a canvass of movie-house managers revealed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Examiner said today that it bad located a handbag belonging to Miss Dorothy Millette, the missing "other woman" in the life of Paul Bern, film executive, who committed suicide, and that the bag contained letters from Bern.

Theodore S. Clark's Class R sloop Astrild won the forty-mile City Island to Lloyd's Neck buoy yacht race yesterday, taking first place on corrected time over R.H. Amberg's Silhouette, the first boat actually over the finish line. This triumph came in the sailing class, and another Manhasset Bay Yacht Club entrant, the Azor, chartered by Robert Baruch, won in the auxiliary class.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals extended their winning streak to seven straight when they won a double-header from Rochester today, 2 to 1 in ten innings and 7 to 0. A crowd of 9,000 saw the Royals move further ahead of the Red Wings in the battle for fourth place.

The Summer amusement season in the Rockaways came to an end yesterday with the exodus from the resort bungalow and cottage colonies of city dwellers bent on getting back to their permanent homes for the opening of the schools today. Coney Island's last week of the season opens tonight with the beginning of the thirtieth Mardi Gras.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Sept. 11. -- Plans for quick military defense of New York and Philadelphia and the New Jersey seacoast against a simulated enemy invasion were outlined at Camp Dix tonight at a conference of 200 officers of the First Army Division, under the command of Brig. Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook.

WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 11. -- Stanchly unholding the place of religion in modern life, Dr. Robert A. Millikan, American physicist, maintained that there was no real conflict between science and religion when he addressed a church congregation here this morning.

New York City is one of the largest public buyers in the world. On this continent its expenditures for supplies, materials and equipment are exceeded only by those of the United States Government. Its purchases comprise a vast array of articles, ranging all the way from thumb-tacks to steam rollers and the varied commodities acquired for the benefit of the thousands of inmates of the city's penal and charitable institutions.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Braves sent the Cincinnati Reds deeper into the National League cellar today by taking both ends of a double-header, 13 to 3 and 10 to 1.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 11. -- The Massachusetts State auxiliary training ship Nantucket arrived here last night from Madeira islands off the coast of Africa after having nearly foundered Thursday during a hurricane which struck the vessel 166 miles south of Nantucket.

That employers are risking a sacrifice of complete protection of their employes in their efforts to prevent the proposed increase in workmen's compensation insurance rates is the opinion of A.C. Pearson, chairman of the board of The Spectator, an insurance business paper.

Walter P. Chrysler, automobile manufacturer, has accepted the post of general chairman of the Crusaders Victory Fund campaign in New York City, it was announced by his office yesterday. Up to the present, Mr. Chrysler had not been identified with any anti-prohibition group, the announcement said.

ALBANY, Sept. 11. -- The death rate from suicide in the first half of 1932 was 19.2 per 100,000 population and was lower than the rate for the first four month's of the year, but in July was the highest in seventeen years, Dr. J.V. Deporte, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Health Department, reported today.

The North German Lloyd liner Columbus is due today from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg. On board is Dr. Julius Curtius, former German Minister for Foreign Affairs, who will lecture here. He is accompanied by Mrs. Curtius. Others include Walter Ehrich of the Ehrich Galleries, Heinz Schuengel, resident director of the North German Lloyd, with his wife; Adrian H. Larkin, son-in-law of Paul D. Cravath and Thomas H. Roulston, owner of chain grocery stores.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Benjamin Reath Riggs of Philadelphia, wife of the first secretary of the American Legation at Berne, Switzerland, is expected tomorrow at the Weylin for a brief stay. She is sailing this week to join Mr. Riggs in Berne.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Lieutenant Governor Herbert Lehman was the guest of honor at Camp Smith today, where he reviewed the 369th Infantry Regiment, composed of Negro troops from Manhattan. The troops are the last to train at Camp Smith this season.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 11 (AP). -- In specific proposals for farm relief, representatives of nine mid-Western States today declared themselves in favor of tariff revision, sound currency expansion, moratoriums on farmer debts and an orderly marketing program.

During the campaign of 1928 HERBERT HOOVER neither mentioned ALFRED E. SMITH nor indicated that he knew he had an opponent firing speeches at him all over the country. Since that policy was part of the strategy of a winning fight, it is political instinct to try it again.

There has been "enough of moaning about the failure of the church," according to the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker Jr., rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. In his sermon yesterday morning he said:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Miss Mabel Choate will open her villa, Naumkeag, at Stockbridge on Tuesday and Wednesday for an exhibition and Christmas sale of articles made by infantile paralysis patients of Vermont. Members of the committee are:

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons beat the Toronto Leafs in both halves of a double-header today to run a winning string to four in a row. The scores were 8 to 2 and 9 to 1. Fussell gained his fifteenth victory in the opener.

The reaction which occurred on the Stock Exchange last week seemed to disturb nobody's composure. On the whole, it was accepted as a wholesome variation on the previous all but uninterrupted rise. What experienced watchers of a market take into account at times like this is not its incidental variations, but its general trend.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 11, -- Westchester County political leaders are grooming their candidates for November contests, and on Sept. 20 primary designations will be made. Tuesday there will be a special referendum in Scarsdale to settle a problem of governmental consolidation which is non-political and of great economic importance to taxpayers of that community.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11. -- With the two Hoppings, father and son, going very well in the forward positions, Eastcott rode through to the semi-final round of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament, most important of the season's handicap polo events, before a crowd of 6,000 at the Sands Point Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- President Hoover's issuance of Attorney General Mitchell's report on eviction of the bonus army was termed "a political alibi" in a statement today by R.B. Ellison, national organizer of the Khaki Shirts of America and former national contact officer of the bonus expeditionary force.
Amassing the high total of fiftyone points, the Knickerbocker Canoe Club of New York won the WestChester County canoeing championship held on Tibbetts Brook Park lake in Yonkers yesterday.

Warning real estate owners in this city that they must make concerted effort at once to obtain equitable assessment of their property, Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday that Mayor Joseph V. McKee's attacks on the city budget at last indicated real relief from the current tax burden.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns broke a losing streak of eight games by defeating the Boston Red Sox, 7 to 1, today, but Boston took the second game of a double-header, 8 to 3.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Wheat markets of the world are showing remarkable strength in the face of large supplies in North America and generally favorable crop prospects in the Southern Hemisphere, combined with the erratic action of the cotton and sacurity markets.

ANGMAGSALIK, Greenland, Sept. 11 (AP). -- A motor boat left this port tonight to hunt for the flying Hutchinson family, whose transatlantic plane was believed to have been forced down thirty miles southwest of Angmagsalik in Kjoge Bay. It was feared, however, that George R. Hutchinson, his wife and two small daughters and a crew of four had met death in a forced landing.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Customs agents today boarded the $250,000 pleasure yacht Prudence of New York and behind a secret panel in one of the saloons found more than 1,500 cases of choice pre-war liquors with a retail value of about $250,000. Yacht and liquor were seized and placed under guard, while the crew of seven, including Captain Norman McWilliams, was arrested.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The where-abouts of Raymond Robins, dry leader and social worker, who disappeared after leaving New York a week ago to keep an appointment with President Hoover, remained unknown today, while three more persons came forward with stories that they had seen him in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- A national assembly of welfare and relief workers to lay plans for the coming months will open at the White House Thursday with an address by President Hoover and a reply by Newton D. Baker.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11. -- Newark divided a double-header with Baltimore before more than 10,000 fans today. The visitors won the first game, 8 to 5, while the Bears captured the second contest, 4 to 0.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- For the second day in succession racing on Long Island Sound had a moonlight ending when the American Yacht Club's dual class regatta today wound up without wind enough for a single finish. Fog also was rolling in when a fleet made up of thirty-three Interclub and Atlantics took tows into harbor.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Scoring a brilliantly executed birdie 3 on the nineteenth hole, Mrs. Mark R. McGarry won the women's club championship of the Westchester Hills Country Club today, defeating Mrs. Emmett F. Whalen, 1 up.

What is believed to be the first step by organized American medicine to regulate the payment of medical bills was taken yesterday upon the findings of a special committee of the Medical Society of the County of New York appointed to investigate the results of a financing plan which has been in an experimental stage for more than a year.

The test of the churches is the treatment of the unemployed, P. Whitwell Wilson, journalist and former member of the British Parliament, declared in an address yesterday morning from the pulpit of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, Sept. 11. -- State and county officials and representatives of farm bureaus and other conservationists will take part in the annual reforestation tour of the Conservation Department, beginning Sept. 23 at Saratoga Springs and lasting three days.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- Simultaneously with the news that France's reply to the German demand for equality in armaments would be made public tomorrow at the same hour that Chancellor von Papen, making his debut before the Reichstag, would be discussing the matter there, it became known tonight that Adolf Hitler had decreed the installation of a "military portfolio" in the National Socialist organization.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's fifty-second home run of the season in the seventh inning with Haas on base represented the margin by which the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Tigers, 5 to 4, in a series opener today.

COBLENZ, Germany, Sept. 11. -- A plebiscite two years hence undoubtedly would order the return of the Saar Basin to Germany, speakers declared today when the federated Saar societies from German cities held their twelfth annual convention here.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 11. -- The Chattanooga Lookouts won their first Southern Association pennant today by defeating the Knoxville Smokies, 5 to 0, in the final game of the season.

There were 364,401 holders of stock of the General Motors Corporation on the dates of record for the last dividends on common and preferred issues, compared with 359,046 in the previous quarter, it was announced yesterday. The increase of 5,353 stockholders was the smallest for any quarter in more than a year.
Jersey City rallied in both games of a double-header against Albany to triumph twice, 6 to 5 and 5 to 3, at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority defended yesterday its proposal to apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan with which to finance the Midtown Hudson Tunnel at Thirty-eighth Street, terming the project an essential link in the general plan for traffic control in the port district.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The text of Attorney General Mitchell's report to President Hoover on activities of the bonus army in Washington read:

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, inc. My definite impression, having looked over the Eastern football field and talked with coaches at our recent demonstration game and rules interpretation meeting, is that the East will see generally improved teams and consistently well-played games when the major rivals get together from mid-October on.

DUBLIN, Sept. 11. -- President Eamon de Valera suggested in a speech at Kilkenny today that the disputed land annuities could be put in the custody of the Bank for International Settlements pending arbitration by a "fair court."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- On the eve of the American Legion convention in Portland, Ore., President Hoover tonight laid before the country a report on the Department of Justice's investigation of the Bonus Expeditionary Forces, which were driven from Washington by troops July 28 after battles with the police and bloodshed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prohibitionists seem to be much upset about what will take the place of the amendment when it is repealed, and apparently expect the return of the saloon, on the ground that when they get permission to drink, the people will demand a place in which they can drink -- and this will be, by whatever name it is called, a "saloon."

JERUSALEM, Sept. 11. -- The verdict on the question of bigamy, which is expected to evoke worldwide religious discussion, among Jews, is now being awaited from the Jerusalem rabbinical court of appeals in a suit brought by the influential leader of the Yemenite Jewish community in Palestine to obtain an order compelling his elderly wife to give him a divorce.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11. -- There has been notable steady improvement in the general business situation in the last ten days, especially in those export commodities usually listed as index factors of the republic's economic situation.

Acting as if each held the other largely at fault for a campaign of considerable misfortune and an exceedingly low ranking, the Giants and Cardinals spent the better part of four hours knocking each other down at the Polo Grounds yesterday as they brought their social relations of the year to a close before a gathering of about 12,000.

SONNING, Berkshire, Eng., Sept. 11. -- Preliminary reports of finds of the greatest interest and importance have just been received by me from American expeditions working at Damghan in Northern Persia under the direction of Dr. Erich Schmidt.

When a man who has worked his way through college and has struggled to a difficult success proudly says, "I am glad my son will not have to do those things," he is in nearly every case deliberately, though unconsciously, planning a handicap to his child's success in life, the Rev. Dr. Clarence A. Barbour, president of Brown University, declared yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Mgr. Stephen J. Donahue, private secretary to Cardinal Hayes for the last twelve years, has been named pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name of Jesus, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street. This announcement was made at all the masses in the church yesterday.

With a still hopeful crowd of 15,000 Flatbush fans on hand at Ebbets Field yesterday, Charley Grimm's Cubs moved closer to the pennant by taking the second game of the series, 3 to 1, and increasing their lead over the idle second-place Pirates to six games.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11. -- The world's leading amateur golfers, including Francis Ouimet, United States champion, and John DeForest, British, titleholder, will he on parade at the Five Farms course tomorrow when the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the national amateur championship gets under way.

PARIS, Sept. 11. -- The United States reciprocated today for France's gift of the Statute of Liberty by presenting a huge monument near Meaux, where, exactly eighteen years ago, the French stopped the Germans when Paris seemed certain to fall.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11. -- As "improvement after Labor Day" had become a familiar phrase in references to the steel trade's future, developments in the last week were awaited with great interest. There was an increase of fully 1 point in the steel ingot producing rate, to at least 15 per cent, and that met the majority of predictions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- In a pamphlet entitled "Power Records of Hoover and Roosevelt," made public today by Judson King, director of the National Popular Government League, the conclusion is stated that "judged on their records, President Hoover would influence the nation's power policy toward control by private interests for the indefinite future, while Governor Roosevelt would help determine the nation's future power policy in the public interest."

The outstanding problem of the day is "to find leaders who cannot only see facts, but who can also see the Lord," declared the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill in the first of a series of "Sermons for Hard Times" at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday morning.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Sept. 11. -- More than 100 persons were reported killed or injured, about 600 robbed and an unknown number kidnapped when bandits derailed the regular Changehun-Harbin train last night near Hsitun.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- While the foreign exchange holdings as reported in Thursday's Bank of France statement increased slightly, rising 16,000,000 francs for the week, the bank's gold reserve again decreased 8,000,000. This is the fifth weekly decrease in two months.

Despite intimation of the white vestry that their presence would be unwelcome, more than two hundred and fifty Negro parishoners of the All Souls Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, attended the 11 o'clock service yesterday morning. About forty-five white parishoners also attended the service, which was the first on the Fall schedule.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of wholesale prices of Great Britain as of Sept. 7, based on 1913 as 100, is 89, against 85.2 a fortnight before, a gain of 4 1/2 per cent, and 83.1 on Sept. 18 of last year, just before the British suspension of gold payments.

"Take my finger prints," Gerardo Scarpato told detectives a year ago last June when they had done with questioning him regarding the murder of Giuseppe (Joe the Boss) Masseria. "Take them for your books. I think you will need them. I may be next."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Seven cities have already telegraphed the Home Loan Bank Board that they will set up voluntary organizations to push the sale of their regional Home Loan Banks' stock when the books of subscription are opened Wednesday.

Founding Fathers Take Rest Spain's Constitutional Convention has adjourned after a fourteen months session, in the course of which it provided the new republic with a fundamental law and no less than 200 statutes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection, with your news from Athens bearing on the political situation in Greece and the possibility of a military dictatorship, I desire to make a few observations that may assist readers who are interested in Greek affairs to understand better the aims of the Military League.

Religion is the living out of "one's true best self," the Rev. Dr. Charles Reynolds Brown, dean emeritus of the Divinity School of Yale University, said in a sermon yesterday morning in the Riverside Church on the subject "How Can We Make Religion Real?"

Raymond Massey will be Katharine Cornell's leading man in Sidney Howard's play, "Alien Corn," opening on Broadway late in the Fall, according to word received from London. Mr. Massey and his wife, Adrianne Alien, recently arrived in London after nearly a year's stay in the United States, during which they acted in this city and in Hollywood.

It is not often that one who is in skill as well as at heart a poet or an artist can make other gifts than one's own poetry or art. The donation of 13,000 acres of forest land by Mr. and Mrs. ARCHER M. HUNTINGTON to the New York State College of Forestry is a noteworthy exception, though it is only one of many public gifts from the same source.

An official list of missing, compiled after the police had canvassed the homes of all the men believed to have been on the destroyed steamer Observation, fixed at twenty-two yesterday the number of persons whose bodies have not been found but who are believed to be dead.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 10. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.2, which compares with 62.5 a week ago, 61.9 two weeks ago, 61.8 three weeks ago and 61.9 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date was 66.3 in the first week of January.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The Fishers Island Yacht Club held ita annual skippers' luncheon today, at which trophies were awarded to the members of the club who participated in the season racing program.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11. -- Gilbert Bettman, Attorney General of Ohio and Republican nominee for United States Senator, at a Republican dinner here last night challenged his Democratic opponent, Senator Robert J. Bulkley, to debate "the repeal and modification issue any time and any place he chooses."

Pennsylvania has long been known as a great black bass fishing country. Scores of anglers from this section go annually on their pilgrimages to spots they have discovered, and among these is the Delaware River. In and about Fond Eddy is one of the really fine small mouth bass fishing grounds.

Walter Busch of the City Island Yacht Club retained his Atlantic division championship yesterday in the deck-sailing double sail canoe race in the waters of East Chester Bay off the Island Canoe and Yacht Club at City Island.

For years the Anti-Saloon League was a sort of super-government. Both parties heeled meekly after it. Congress was its echo. Now it calls as loudly as ever, yet nobody but its members and some of its affiliates heeds the call. The long "continuance of the Eighteenth Amendment unchanged" now seems as unlikely as it once seemed sure.

On the heels of James J. Walker's abrupt departure for Italy, it became known yesterday that efforts would be made on his return by influential Democrats to persuade the former Mayor not to run for election this Fall.

Thousands every day are perplexed about their duty to those who beg in the streets for "a cup of coffee " or "something to eat." Even when one has given to the limit of his ability in support of organized movements for relief, he is not altogether free of the uncomfortable feeling that comes of refusing to give.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Washington's Senators continued their belated winning sweep today by taking two games from the Chicago White Sox, 2 to 1 and 9 to 4.

A new study of the problems arising from the war debts owed by European nations to the United States, to be carried out by a committee of nationally known, men under the chairmanship of Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, was announced yesterday.

The Citizens Budget Commission has asked Mayor McKee to take steps to bring about immediate and complete abandonment of the four-year bond plan of financing subway construction. In a letter made public yesterday, but delivered at City Hall on Saturday, it urges this course not only as a matter of budget relief in 1933 but also as a safeguard for future subway financing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- An assertion that some Republican orators are turning their backs on President Hoover's explanation of the cause of the economic depression, and adopting the Democratic diagnosis that it was due to stock market promotion, is made by W.W. Howes, Democratic National Committeeman from South Dakota, in a statement Issued through the Democratic National Committee.

A clash of opinion developed yesterday between the Emergency Shelter, of which Walter D. Britt is director, and the Welfare Council of New York City over the shelter's distribution of food and shelter tickets among the unemployed as a means of stopping panhandling in the streets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before it is too late, property owners should call a halt on the ambitious designs of speculative builders, politicians and laissez-faire owners of blocks of slum dwellings to take advantage of the tax-exemption provisions of the State housing law and the easy money to be had from Federal agencies, and thereby to further increase the oversupply of medium-priced housing in New York.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The cost of running the Mayor's office in this city has increased 144 per cent since 1927, and if the city's assessments were "at a proper level" it would be found that the municipality had borrowed in excess of the 10 per cent permitted by law, according to an analysis of Yonkers finances made public today by the Crestwood Citizens' Association.

The importance of education, which he called "the foundation of our State," was stressed by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in his sermon at high mass yesterday. He asked the prayers of the congregation for the 20,000,000 children in this country who will go back to school today and for their instructors.

The condition of Babe Ruth was reported unchanged yesterday as the Yankees famous home run hitter spent his fourth day confined in his apartment on West Eighty-eighth Street awaiting developments in what may prove to be an attack of appendicitis.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11. -- The Motion Picture Theatre Owners' Association of Connecticut, representing the owners of small houses, has petitioned Governor Cross to check the large movie chains from making contracts for exclusive showings of pictures.
The new Eighth Avenue subway carried 171,267 revenue passengers during the first twenty-four hours of operation, yielding a gross income of $8,563.35, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Republican national headquarters, through Henry J. Alien, director of publicity, has begun a postal poll of men and women whose names appear in "Who's Who in America," asking them to express their preference in the Presidential contest.

The assurance of building trades peace that arises out of the present accord on wage rates removes the most formidable obstacle to a resumption of constructing activity, declares C.G. Norman, chairman of the board of governors of the Building Trades Employers Association, through the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

Representatives of steamship lines and union longshoremen will meet this morning at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street, to discuss terms of a wage contract to become effective on the piers of the deep-sea ship lines Sept. 30, when the present agreement expires.

ALBANY, Sept. 11. -- Back from a final week-end at Hyde Park, Governor Roosevelt was prepared tonight to embark tomorrow on his campaign in the West, which he insists will be as much a fact-finding trip as a political tour.

Plans for an intensive equipment modernization movement throughout industry designed to put back on the payroll 1,620,000 workers in factories manufacturing machinery, equipment and plant facilities were announced yesterday by A.W. Robertson of Pittsburgh, chairman of the National Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation and chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 9. -- European central banks which have maintained gold payments show remarkable enhancement in strength of their reserves as compared with a year ago, just before the suspension of gold payments at the Bank of England. The latest statement of the Bank of the Netherlands, dated Sept. 5, reports gold holdings of 1,033,000,000 florins, compared with 657,000,000 on Sept. 7, 1931.

ATLANTA, Sept. 11. -- Georgia Democrats will go to the polls Wednesday in one of the most important primary elections in a decade. Two candidates are to be chosen for the United States Senate, ten for seats in the House and others for Governor and various State offices.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11. -- The Bolivians were still in possession of Fort Boqueron this afternoon, according to dispatches passed by the Paraguayan censors. The Paragruayans, it was stated, had forced their way within the enclosure, only to be driven out by strong Bolivian reinforcements.

COPENHAGEN, Monday, Sept. 12. -- The "flying family" of Hutchinsons was forced down at sea yesterday off Greeland and at 4 o'clock this morning (11 P.M. Sunday in New York), no trace of them had been found.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Returns in the fifteenth census as tabulated and announced today by the Census Bureau showed that there were living in New York City in 1930 a total of 1,722,954 families and that the percentage of home ownership had nearly doubled since 1920.

The Socialist party's attitude on public questions is set forth in a book being published today by the Falcon Press. It is called "Socialist Planning and a Socialist Program." Edited by Harry W. Laidler for the League for Industrial Democracy, it includes an introduction as well as an article by Norman Thomas, Socialist condidate for President.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice that one of your correspondents has recently passed favorable comment on the plan advanced by Judge Morris of the Municipal Court with respect to the payment by check of fines imposed in the magistrates' courts for minor offenses.

At Portland, Ore., today the American Legion meets in national convention, and before its sessions end is confidently expected to vote overwhelmingly in favor of immediate payment of the adjusted certificates of the veterans. A year ago, after a special appeal in person by President HOOVER, it voted two to one against it.

A noticeable increase in retail activity throughout the country last week was reflected in the substantial volume of reorders and open orders placed in the local apparel markets. Although individual commitments were not very heavy, they were numerous.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11. -- Maine voters to the number of about 250,000 will go to the polls tomorrow to elect a Governor, three Representatives and a full list of State and county officers in one of the most important elections in the history of the State.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Thousands of pilgrims witnessed the closing session today of the Diocesan Court which has been collecting evidence for process of cause for beatification of Catherine Tekalwitha, Mohawk Indian maiden, at the Auriesville shrine of the North American martyrs.

Collapse of most of the upbuilding activities conducted by the Jewish Agency for Palestine is threatened because of a shortage of funds, according to Louis Lipsky, national chairman of the American Palestine Campaign, 111 Fifth Avenue. His statement to the executive committee of the fund-raising body was made public yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11. -- The Yankees, playing their first game in Cleveland's new stadium, had the misfortune to encounter Wesley Ferrell, just back from an enforced ten-day vacation, well rested and keenly primed for battle. The result was a 5-to-4 defeat in the series opener with a 25,000 crowd shivering in the shadows of the vast galleries circling the playing ring.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of Manhasset, L.I., in addition to gaining numerous honors in the regular classes, scored a double victory this afternoon in the closing event of the fifth annual Soldiers' and Sailors' Club horse show when she took the hunter championship and also carried away the reserve ribbon.

Captained by Moritz Haeusler, just back from Vienna, Hakoah opened its soccer season brilliantly with a 3-1 victory over the reorganized Brooklyn Wanderers before a crowd of 1,500 at Hawthorne Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

VIENNA, Sept. 11. -- Police in Wiener Neustadt tonight stopped a motor car driven by the Chinese film actress, Anna May Wong, on instructions from the police of Langenwang, in Steinnark. The Langenwang police said the car knocked down and injured an unidentified cyclist, whose condition prevented the taking of a deposition.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- No surprise was caused at the British Foreign Office when Premier Herriot of France let it be known yesterday that it was impossible to envisage Prime Minister MacDonald's suggestion for preliminary conversations among Britain, France, Italy and Poland on the German demand for arms equality, as this would have menat deferring the French reply to Germany.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Monday, Sept. 12. -- Charles E. Du Bois, wealthy New York jewelry buyer and Summer resident at Great Herring Pond, was arrested at 1:30 o'clock this morning for questioning in connection with the disappearance of his wife, Edith M.L. Du Bois. He has contended that she has been on a vacation trip in Canada since Aug. 10.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- Banks regard the existing outlook for German finances and the national currency as more favorable. They point to signs that the derangement of the system of international payments, which is the most serious remaining obstacle to recovery, is disappearing.

Pursuant to his policy of "seeing " every citizen, or group with legitimate business at the City Hall, Mayor McKEE received on Saturday a delegation of Communists. Their ostensible purpose was to propose plans for relief of unemployment in the city.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- There is a widespread impression in London tonight that the British Government has received assurance from Washington that a moratorium on war debts will be granted before Dec. 15 if Great Britain keeps quiet on the subject until after the November elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Helene Madison, Seattle holder of many swimming records, was launched formally upon a motion picture career today. John Clein, independent talkie producer, announced Miss Madison had signed a contract for the filming of an island picture of feature length.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 11. -- Representative Percy H.Stewart, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, today charged United States Senator W. Warren Barbour, his opponent, with "trying to conceal President Hoover's dryness under a wet bushel."
WASHINGTON, Sept 11. -- Completing a four-year task, the Geographic Board has issued its "First Report on Foreign Geographic Names."
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11. -- Thomas Powers and Mr. and Mrs. Charles F.P. Richardson gave small dinner parties at the Muenchinger King this evening.

Reports from Boston of an announcement that former Governor Alfred E. Smith was expected to speak for the Roosevelt-Garner ticket in October there were met with diplomatic denials by the friends of the former Governor here yesterday.

The scheduled fifteen-round bout between Max Schmeling, former world's heavyweight champion, and Mickey Walker, former world's middleweight champion, signed by Madison Square Garden in the interests of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is chairman, will be held in the Garden's Long Island City - Bowl on Sept. 23, instead of Sept. 19, its original date.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the attitude of some newspapers -- and also individuals -- toward the quondam Mayor of New York, we are reminded of the newspapers of Paris, which, in 1815, announced the departure of Napoleon Bonaparte from the Isle of Elba, his march across France and his entry into the French capital, as follows:

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 11 (AP). -- While Josephus Daniels, Secretary of the Navy in the Wilson Administration, would advise young officers leaving the Naval Academy not to marry, he declared here today he considered it "pretty high-handed for the government to say they cannot marry."

TOKYO, Sept. 11. -- The Peiping correspondent of the newspaper Asahi reported tonight that Tibetan forces, mobilized with British assistance, were advancing on Yunnan Province and the Kokonor region with the object of declaring the independence of Greater Tibet.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 11. -- A resolution condemning President Hoover by name for the manner in which the bonus expeditionary force was handled in Washington is expected to be forced out upon the floor of the American Legion National Convention, which will open officially here tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with a gteat deal of interest various letters printed in your editorial page dealing with Lieut. Gov. Lehman's announcement of his candidacy for Governor.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Activity on the London stock market continues to grow. The business currently done is on a larger scale than at any time since the revival commenced, rather more than a month ago. Speculation is undoubtedly increasing and values, especially for industrial securities, have now reached levels which largely discount (and perhaps overdiscount) any trade improvement which may have occurred already, or which is likely to occur in the next few months.

NOW for the amateur golf championship at Baltimore! The firing will start this morning and continue through the week, come rain, shine, low water or high tide. Does any prophet, with or without honor in his home sector, care to step up now and name the ultimate winner of the battle in the bunkers at Baltimore?

GENEVA, Sept. 12. -- Lack of money is handicapping the American delegations now, when the German move for equality or rearmament is threatening to wreck the hopes for President Hoover's plan for economizing one-third on the world's arms expenditure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Oliver Wendell Holmes, former Justice of the Supreme Court, has presented to the Folger Shakespeare Library his father's one-volume edition of Shakespeare's plays, containing the bookplate of the "Autocrat of the Breakfast Table" and a wealth of marginal notes made by the physician and essayist.

The gayest bank lobby in Manhattan yesterday was that of the city's oldest bank, the Bank for Savings in the City of New York, at 280 Fourth Avenue, which is presenting its Autumn flower show. Fifty-nine of the hundred-odd employes in the down-town, branch are entered in the extra-official competition, their exhibits being neatly ticketed and arranged on a series of tables so placed as not to obstruct the more quotidian affairs of the institution.

With weather reports generally favorable, the plane American Nurse, bearing William Ulbrich, pilot; Dr. Leon M. Pisculli of Yonkers and Miss Edna Newcomer, is expected to take off from Floyd Bennett Field this morning for a flight to Rome. Oyer Florence, Italy, Miss Newcomer plans to drop-from the plane by parachute as a tribute to Florence Nightingale, founder of modern nursing.

Distributers of dairy products, makers of artificial limbs and army and navy uniform manufacturers protested yesterday to the Shannon committee, created by Congress to investigate alleged government competition with private business, at the first session of a two-day hearing here in the Federal Building.

One of the evidences that we have come into a consolidated world is a United States Government report about the spelling of foreign geographic names. It has just been published by the United States Geographic Board -- a pamphlet of 113 pages for sale by the Superintendent of Documents, Washington, for ten cents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Department of Justice, through the Acting Attorney General, Thomas D. Thatcher, issued the following reply to General Glassford:

ARDSLEY - ON - HUDSON. N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Headed by Miss Joan Ridley of England, a field of sixty-four started play In the women's annual invitation lawn tennis tournament today on the turf courts of the Ardsley Club.
LUBBOCK, Texas, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The Texas Democratic Executive Committee tonight found that Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson led Governor R.S. Sterling in the run-off Democratic primary by 3,333 votes.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12. -- The Fall plowing got under way at Five Farms this morning and by high noon there were many anguished walls for farm relief. Eric Fiddian of the British Walker Cup team went to the turn in 4D strokes, leading to the general belief that he was driving with a hayrake and using a pitchfork for his pitch shots. But he was philosophical about it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest some time ago that druggists contemplate organizing for the purpose of compelling the cosmetic-shop owners, who have made serious inroads into the pharmacy business, by selling patent medicines, package drugs, , to employ registered pharmacists for the protection of the public.

PAUL SMITHS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Mrs. Edward F. Hutton of New York opened Camp Huttridge, the Hutton Summer place on the Upper St. Regis Lake, yesterday for the raffle of Ed Corbin's boat and aided not only in bringing about the return to the veteran guide of his treasured craft, but also in enabling him to realize his desire to build a new cabin.

Mortimer Lanzit has been elected president of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of its board of directors at 1,359 Broadway. Mr. Lanzit has headed the legal department of the Lefcourt organization since its formation five years ago.

Directors of the Broadway Association voted yesterday to ask Police Commissioner Mulrooney to take immediate steps to "rid Broadway and the midtown amusement district of the growing number of panhandlers, itinerant merchants and undesirable advertising displays."

BALTIMORE, Sept, 12. -- Johnny Fischer, 20-year-old University of Michigan junior, who sprang into national golf prominence by his victory in this year's intercollegiate championship, set a blistering pace in the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the thirty-sixth annual United States amateur championship on the Five Farms course today.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Whether the recent Chino-Japanese conflict in Shanghai was a war or merely an incident, as the Japanese and Chinese Governments contend, is a matter that courts of the United States and Great Britain will be asked to decide.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic National Committeeman from New Jersey and Democratic leader of that State, who acted as floor manager for Alfred E. Smith at the Chicago convention, may be drafted by the national committee for service in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 12. -- A widespread search today for the "Flying Family," the Hutchinsons was fruitless. All signs point to the probability that their amphibian machine sank with its eight passengers after an emergency landing near the hostile cliffs on the coast of East Greenland.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 12. -- The fight over the proposal to censure President Hoover for the forcible eviction of the bonus army from Washington In July began today in the resolutions committee of the American Legion, meeting here in national convention.

An indication that the national Republican leaders are taking an interest in the New York Mayoralty situation was noted yesterday when Chairman Macy of the Republican State Committee made it known that he would confer with the five Republican county leaders in the city today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- A special committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce, ending today a series of conferences on the plight of the railroads, have arrived at the conclusion that too much regulation by the Interstate Commerce Commission is a primary factor in the present financial troubles of the carriers.
States where primary elections will be held today are Arizona., Colorado, Louisiana, Michigan, New Hampshire, Vermont, Washington and South Carolina.

The new Eighth Avenue subway, operating yesterday for the first time under normal wekday traffic conditions, made a perceptible dent in the volume of rush hour traffic on the Interborough west side line, according to unofficial reports supported by visual observation.

Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of reptiles and mammals at the Bronx Zoo, returned yesterday on the United Fruit liner Calamares from an unsuccessful expedition to Panama, where he searched for the bushmaster, the largest poisonous snake on the American Continent.

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 12. -- A lead amassed in the first two days of racing before last week's northeaster forced a postponement over the week-end enabled the Edgar-town (Mass.) Yacht Club crew captained by Miss Clara Dinsmore to win the women's national Bailing championship and a leg on the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup today as three final races were staged off the Cohasset Yacht Club.

Ambassador EDGE in his speech on Sunday dedicating the American memorial of the Battle of the Marne declared that the American people are inclined "instinctively to throw "their moral and, if needs be, their "material weight" against any invading and aggressor nation.

It is well understood that if the law remains unchanged, and the city chooses to continue managing its own venture in rapid transit, the fate of the five-cent fare on the new subway will hang on the result of operations in the third year. The act of 1924 makes provision for a three-year experimental period, during which the nickel remains inviolate.
AUGUSTA, Me., Tuesday, Sept. 13. -- Maine has apparently gone Democratic for the first time in eighteen years with a startling upset in this traditionally rock-ribbed Republican State.
Flats and dwellings comprised the bulk of the realty turnover in New Jersey, reported yesterday.

The charge that proper consideration was, not given to determine if seventy investigators out of a group of 140 retained in the office of the Work Bureau of the City Emergency Work and Relief Administration were deserving of work relief was made yesterday by James A. Higgins, Commissioner of Accounts, in concluding public hearings in his investigation of the bureau.

STRESA, Italy Sept. 12. -- The delegates of Germany, France and Italy reached an agreement in principle tonight on a plan destined to give to the Danubian agricultural countries preferential treatment in European markets.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The stock markets were quiet and irregular today. British funds were the brightest feature, prices rising generally. Little trading was done in the industrial issues. The tone was dull and quotations mostly were easier. Textiles, however, were firm on hopes of a settlement of the labor dispute.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Smith will give a dinner Thursday at Penllyn, their country place in Brookville, L. I., for Miss Helen Whitney Bourne and Miss Susan Cutler, debutantes of the season, before the dance to be given by Mr. and Mrs. George S. Brewster to introduce their daughter, Miss Frances Brewster.

Tuna fishing in the region of Ambrose Lightship, a venturesome project in which a number of veterans of this section take part about this time every year, didn't have its official inaugural with anything like great success, if the experience of a party of five which put out Sunday from Simms Bay, Rockaway, on board the Blueboy, Captain Carl Jensen, means anything.

The adjusted index of automobile production is 25.6 for the week ended Sept. 10, as against 25.5 for the preceding week and 45.3 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, amounted to 23,087 cars and trucks, as against 22,963 cars and trucks in the preceding week and 41,228 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept, 12. -- Henry Herman Harjes and John F. Harjes, who, with their mother, Mrs. Henry Herman Harjes, have been guests of Edward J. Berwind and Miss Julia Berwind at The Elms, will conclude their stay tomorrow. This evening the Messrs.

Sweeping Light, the Manna colt which gave such promise last year as a juvenile in the string of Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt, was first in the Nassau Claiming Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday in the colors of Herbert Pulitzer.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- Various factors combined to force prices down on the Paris Bourse today. Conversion of the public loan, Wall Street's reaction and the decline in cotton prices all contributed to the market's drop. Mining stocks and Suez Canal, however, were exceptions to the general trend and made fair gains in a midday rally, but closed under last Friday's final quotations.

A two-year contract as playing-manager was signed yesterday by William H. Terry in the offices of the New York Giants, thus bringing to an end the many rumors concerning the ultimate fate of the successor to John J. McGraw.
More than 1,000,000 children returned to school yesterday for the Fall semester, their Summer vacations ended.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- The search for Raymond Robins, prohibition advocate and reformer who has been missing for more than a week, continued fruitless today, and Dr. Daniel A. Poling, New York dry leader who flew here from Portland, Ore., to aid in the search, discounted reports that he had been in Chicago.
PORTLAND, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The resolution of censure offered by the Pennsylvania Department of the American Legion is as follows:

The linesmen of Columbia's football squad came in for a major share of the attention yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions went through morning and afternoon sessions. While the back-field aspirants continued to practice passing and formations, the forwards had grueling sessions that saw the veterans and new-comers battling for positions on the first eleven.

New York Edison interests believe that their greatest danger is in over-regulation or the "substitution of the business judgment of the commissioners for the business judgment of boards of directors," according to their chairman, Floyd L. Carlisle, who gave the companies' attitude toward regulation at a dinner last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of Edison service.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12. -- Bobby Jones was on hand at Five Farms today in the role of critic. Although he now has been out of competitive golf for two years, he still remains an outstanding figure in the domain of golf. His autograph is more desired than that of any other star.

MUKDEN, Sept. 12. -- Helpless at least for several weeks more against the rapier-like thrusts of the Chinese volunteers who are disorganizing the entire transportation system in Manchuria, the Japanese are planning a thorough clean-up as soon as the tall grain is harvested.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 12. -- A Chinese punitive campaign against Manchukuo may be opened when Japan recognizes the new State Thursday, Lin Sen. Chairman of the Chinese Government, said today.

The quiet dignity and absence of elaborate ceremony, which Mayor Joseph V. McKee declared would be the keynote of official receptions to distinguished guests, marked his reception yesterday to a group of foreign pilots who took part in the recent air races at Cleveland.

Directions to the police to seize all slot machines found to be operating as gambling devices and to arrest the operators were issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Mulrooney in a conference at Police Headquarters, held while 470 slot machines seized previously were being broken up by sledge-hammers at the police garage at First Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

PARIS, Sept. 12 (AP). -- In reply to Germany's demand for equality in arms, France notified the Berlin Government that by modifying her armaments Germany not only would violate the Treaty of Versailles but also would make it impossible to bring about eventual general disarmament.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks won the qualifying round in the women's annual invitation golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today with a gross score of 87. The low-net prize went to Miss Elizabeth Thomas of Woodway, who had a 74.

Testimony that the boilers of the Steamer Observation were in dangerous condition for at least two weeks before the explosion that destroyed the boat in the East River last Friday was laid yesterday before the board of inquiry convened by the Steamship Inspection Service at the Custom House.

FARMTNGTON, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Herbert Knox Smith, who was a Mrs. Gertrude D. Smith, widow of member of President Theodore Roosevelt's Cabinet and later a Bull Moose leader of Connecticut, today announced that she will be a Republican candidate for the House of Representatives in the Connectitcut General Assembly at the November elections.

Appointment of a receiver in Canada last week for the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., was in line with the plans of a bondholders' committee formed in June, according to a statement issued yesterday by the committee's chairman, Joseph P. Ripley, vice president of the National City Company.

Trading in the shares of National-Bellas-Hess, Inc., successor to the National Bellas Hess Company, Inc., began on the New York Curb Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The company was reorganized recently.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Miss Ethel Douglas Southwick, who died at Larchmont on July 10, in her fifty-fourth year, left the bulk of her estate to charity and for educational purposes, the filing of her will here today disclosed. The largest bequests were $10,000 for the study of personality at Columbia University and a similar amount to the French Hospital for a study of asthma.
PARIS, Sept. 12. -- The following is the text of the French reply to Germany's memorandum of Aug. 29, asking a revision of the arms limitation clauses of the Treaty of Versailles:

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- Governor Roosevelt departed by train shortly before midnight for a trip across the nation and back again in the hope of capturing enough electoral votes in normally Republican States to win residence in the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Federal Radio Commission is not giving legal advice to broadcasting stations in Connection with their rights in broadcasting speeches of political candidates. The commission is talking the view that it has no right to enter into matters of this kind unless it has a specific case before it.

Fifth Avenue, in celebration of "Quality Week" from Oct. 1 to 8 as a feature of its silver jubilee as a business street, "will lead the way in a nation-wide movement to raise business standards, promote quality buying and revive confidence in established business institutions.

Discussion yesterday in some quarters of the financial district of the probable early entry of New York City into the market with an issue of long-term bonds in the amount of $50,000,000 was characterized by the Controller's office and by specialists in the city's bonds as considerably premature.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP). -- A home run by P. Waner with his brother, Lloyd, on base in the first inning helped Pittsburgh defeat the Phillies 4 to 2 today, making a clean sweep of the three-game series.

VIENNA, Sept. 12. -- The Wiener Neustadt police announced today that they were misled in the identity of a Chinese woman named Wong, who a volunteer interpreter had informed them, was Anna May Wong, the film actress. In reality the woman detained is Mary Wong of New York.

TORONTO, Sept 12. -- Mrs. C.O. Iselin's Magyar, by Stefan the Great-Royal Despatch, captured the Galllpoli Purse, featured offering at Thorncliffe today. The victor made a strong finish to score by three-quarters of a length over the Hastings Stable's Star Crest.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The Board of Trade's returns of Great Britain's foreign trade in August are as follows: Exports of British products, u28,550,000; re-exports, foreign goods, u3,490,000; total exports, u32,040,000; imports, u53,310,000; excess of imports, u21,270,000.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 12. -- A "counter attack initiated by the Fourteenth Infantry caused serious losses to the Paraguayan regiment of cadets which was attacking Fort Boqueron," says a general staff communique this afternoon. "This morning a patrol of three enemy airplanes bombarded Fort Arce ineffectively.

A committee of steamship owners submitted a new wage contract to representatives of the 30,000 longshoremen of the North Atlantic ports, calling for a reduction of 20 per cent from the present wage scale, at a meeting of representatives of both groups yesterday afternoon at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12. -- A key of gold unlocked the massive bronze doors of the Edward L. Doheny Jr. Memorial Library at the University of Southern California for the first time here today. Attending the dedication ceremonies in Bovard auditorium were the donors.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- The French reply to Germany's request for direct discussion of the possibility of revision of Germany's military status, as laid down in the Treaty of Versailles, was made public this evening. It had been handed to the German Government yesterday.

Influenced by excellent over-Sunday weather in cotton-growing sections and by weakness in outside markets generally, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke more than a half cent yesterday and ended at losses of 41 to 45 points.

The restriction of immigration by the United States has had its telling effects upon Jewish-life in America, according to Paul Masserman and Max Baker, authors of "The Jews Come to America," recently published by the Bloch Publishing Company.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The captain and crew of the 122-foot liquor-la den yacht Prudence, together with a New York broker alleged to have acted as a contact man in disposing of the countraband, were arraigned today before Edwin C. Jenney, United States Commissioner.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday a net loss of $14,601,668 in the first seven months of this year. Its current liabilities exceeded its current assets by the unprecedentedly high margin of $35,000,000 on July 31. The Pittsburgh Lake Erie and the Rutland, subsidiaries of the New York Central, showed decreased returns for the seven months.

A record-shattering home run by Johnny Frederick in the ninth inning gave the Dodgers the final game with the Cubs, 4 to 3, sent Burleigh Grimes walking glumly toward the dugout and brought the major portion of the 5,000 fans at Ebbets Field scampering happily onto the play-ground yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- About 400,000 persons are employed on Federal buildings under construction at the present time, Ferry K. Heath, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said in a radio talk broadcast tonight over a nation-wide network of the National Broadcasting Company.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Donald Agnew sailed his sloop Pastime, representing the American Yacht Club of Rye, to a seven-second victory over William J. McHugh and his Mistral of the Norwalk Yacht Club in the opening race today of the coast championship of the Atlantic Class.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Following is the reply of General Pelham D. Glassford, Superintendent of Washington Police, to the report of Attorney General Mitchell on the "bonus army":

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- In connection with the presence here of Clark Minor, president of the International General Electric Company, there have been rumors that reorganization of Allgemeine Elektrizitaets Gesellschaft, involving reduction of its capital stock, now 185,00,000 marks ($44,030,000 at the current rate), of which the national concern holds a substantial part, is under discussion.

Henry G. Darling leased to the R.K.O. Procter Corporation, Harold B. Franklin, president, the theatre at 139-43 West Twenty-third Street, 75 feet wide, and the basement and street floors in 134 West Twenty-fourth Street, in the rear of the theatre, for dressing rooms, , for four years from June 1, 1932, at $12,500 a year rental, in addition to taxes and assessments, and subject to mortgages for $383,333.33.

Speaking at a dinner of Past Commanders of the American Legion in Portland, Ore., last night, Secretary of War Hurley said that he had not intended to touch upon the eviction of the Bonus Army from Washington but was led to do so by remarks made in a preceding speech at the dinner by Floyd Gibbons, a former war correspondent and radio announcer.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: In the abuse of political organizations, and particularly of Tammany Hall, for the waste and extravagance of city administration, no mention is made of the civic or welfare organizations that are largely responsible for the present cost of government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- In a sharp retort to the Department of Justice's report on the Bonus Expeditionary Force made public by President Hoover yesterday, General Pelham D. Glassford, superintendent of Washington police, stated tonight that he found in the report "a number of assertions affecting the police which are in conflict with police records or with facts knows to the Police Department."

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- Germany tonight is back in political turmoil. The Reichstag has been dissolved and part of it is resisting dissolution. It was adjourned until tomorrow after adopting, by a vote of 513 to 32, a Communist motion of no confidence in the von Fapen Cabinet.

At Stresa, on Lake Maggiore, delegates of fifteen nations are meeting to consider plans, for the economic recovery of Central Europe. Their discussions are not hampered by the restrictions which will govern the forthcoming World Economic Conference.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Mayor Joseph H. Loehr answered criticisms of his administration made yesterday in a report of the Crestwood Citizens' Association with the statement here today that the city of Yonkers bad never been in better financial condition.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 12 -- For the first time in his long fight against the public utilities Governor Pinchot today achieved control of the State Public Service Commission by appointing to the board his private secretary, P.S. Stahlnecker, and his Secretary of Revenue, Dr. Clyde L. King.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12. -- Ben Chapman blazed a triple along the right-field foul line with the bases filled and two out in the twelfth inning today to break a tie and score a victory for the Yankees. On top of Ben's wallop, Bill Dickey sailed a homer into the right-field grand stand, making the final score 8 to 3.

Guests of the four major air mail lines of the country gathered last night for dinner in the hangar of Eastern Air Transport, Inc., at the Newark Metropolitan Airport and listened to addresses by Roy D. Chapin, Secretary of Commerce, and Walter P. Brown, Postmaster General, on problems and future of air transport.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12. -- Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas, explaining to the Senate Argentina's participation in the recent diplomatic negotiations with other neutrals in regard to the dispute of Bolivia and Paraguay over the Chaco region, announced that Argentina soon would rejoin the League of Nations and would propose that the League adopt as a universal policy the refusal to recognize territorial changes growing out of war or force.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Unemployment relief loans totaling more than $1,000,000 were granted to Missouri and West Virginia today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 (AP) --- Chancellor von. Papen tonight made it most clear that he would prevent any attempt by the Reichstag to reconvene tomorrow. The government, he said, in a letter to Chairman Goering, would "make any such meeting impossible."
NEWARK, Sept. 12. -- The pennant-winning Newark Bears celebrated Al Mamaux night tonight with an 11-to-4 victory over Baltimore before 8,000 fans.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 12 (AP). -- Charles DuBois, a Tuckahoe (N.Y.) jeweler, was released from police custody late today after a judge had refused to issue a complaint charging him with the murder of his wife. The judge said he could not issue a complaint because the investigators had been unable to find the woman's body.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- A plan for the reclassification of the 2,500 employes of Westchester County on a basis of employment for merit rather than political influence was adopted unanimously by the Board of Supervisors here today after sharp criticism had been directed by both Democratic and Republican members of the board-against the County Park Commission, with particular reference to the operation of Playland, an amusement park at Rye.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Lord Wakefield, known as the patron saint of speed for the British on land, water and in the air, announced tonight his decision "for personal reasons" not to participate further in motor boat contests.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Liquidation by houses with Eastern connections on the Board of Trade here helped today to send down prices of wheat as much as two cents from Saturday's finish and to the lowest level since Aug. 25. Winnipeg sold at a new bottom mark for the season because of continued heavy hedging pressure, and even export sales of about 1,000,000 bushels were unable to check the Canadian decline.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The United States will continue to insist upon a thorough clean-up of slavery and insanitary conditions in Liberia by an international agency clothed with adequate authority, and will resist any effort of Liberia to block such a move, the State Department announced today.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., Sept. 12. -- Flying at an altitude or 8,000 feel over the Plum Island bombing course, two teams competing for the 1932 Air Corps markmanship honors today made identical scores of 980 out of a possible 1,000. while the lowest team was credited with a score of 701.

An attempt by Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, to have Madison Square Garden schedule the former heavyweight champion's fifteen-round bout against Mickey Walker for Sept. 22, which falls on Thursday, instead of the following night, was over-ridden yesterday on the strenuous objection of Jack Kearns, manager of Walker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- President Hoover has been advised by the Republican strategy board of the political wisdom of making at least two campaign speeches in the agricultural West where the farmers' "holiday strike" has centred, at West Branch, Iowa, his birthplace, and in Minnesota, and two more addresses in leading cities, one in Chicago and the other in New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With regard to the reports which have recently appeared in the press about the three American consular officers who were captured by bandits at the Bidsork Pass while traveling to Teheran, and who were then safely rescued by Persian troops, I am pleased to give you the following information in order to clarify the reports and make them more complete:

Mayor Joseph V. McKee summarily dismissed Thomas F. Dwyer, Commissioner of Public Markets, from office last night because of his failure to produce a plan to make the Bronx Terminal Market self-supporting.

After a Summer spent in Hollywood in the fulfillment of motion-picture contracts, Paul Muni returned last rights to the leading role in Elmer Rice's play. "Counsellor-at-Law," which had a run of thirty-six weeks at the Plymouth Theatre last season and which temporarily closed there on July 16 pending the return of Mr. Muni.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 12. -- The roar of artillery and naval guns about historic Fort McHenry tonight on the 118th anniversary of the Battle of North Point in a mimic bombardment and defense of the old grass-covered battlements culminated in a brilliant flare of rockets and searchlights which showed the Stars and Stripes still floating as when the flag inspired Francis Scott Key to write "The Star-Spangled Banner."
"The Babe is right back to normal and he will be out in a couple of days."

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Demand for hogs was less aggressive today. While shippers were somewhat more interested than of late, the offerings were large and the quality generally was poor. Prices were steady at the start, but gradually declined and finally were 5 to 10 cents a hundred-weight lower than on Friday last, packing sows showing a loss of 10 to 20 cents.

Praise for the work Mayor McKec has already done and the hope that he will carry on as he has started were expressed last night by Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a radio address over Station WOR. The address was one of the series of talks on the city budget being conducted by the Citizens' Budget Commission.

Dr. Julias Curtius, former German Minister of Foreign Affairs, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus and reached his suite at the "Ambassador Hotel only a few minutes before word arrived in this country of the dispute over dissolution of the Reichstag by Chancellor von Papen.

CAMDBN, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Giuseppe Pirelli, a Camden justice of the peace, was shot and killed at noon today when an automobile in which he was riding with a friend was forced to a curb by another car occupied by gunmen. As Pirelli sought to escape, his assailants opened fire.

Reaction tendencies were noted in the wholesale markets yesterday, with sharp price declines in the grains, cotton, provisions, sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides and silk. Coffee was up, other articles steady.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- With a round of 76, Robert M. Clough led the way in the qualifying round of the New York Athletic Club's twentieth annual championship golf tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 (AP). -- France's reply to Germany's request for equality in armaments "is not calculated to bring nearer the solution of this serious problem," Chancellor von Papen said tonight in a radio broadcast to the German people.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman will take up the reins of the State government tomorrow "when Governor Roosevelt's train leaves the State's borders. The Lieutenant Governor plans a busy week. He will spend the day tomorrow, at the Capitol, and Wednesday will visit the State Agricultural School at Cobles-kill and motor to Oneonta, where he will address a joint luncheon of the Chamber of Commerce and Kiwanis and other civic clubs.
Two customs guards were charged with felonious assault and suspended from the Customs Service, yesterday as the result of the shooting of a Negro late Sunday night at the Bush Terminal in Brooklyn.

Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, former Secretary of Labor, co-defendant in two superseding indictments returned last week by a Federal grand jury, will go on trial alone next Monday on the charge that as director general o the Loyal Order of Moose he violated the lottery law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Construction of the famous Dotsero cutoff, one of the most important pending railway projects in the Far West, virtually was assured today when the Interstate Commerce Commission approved a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan of $3,850,000 to the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company for that purpose.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Jimmy Moran, racing in the white jacket of Mose Goldbiatt of Cincinnati, today won the featured six-furlong Lake Forest Purse at Lincoln Fields, aided somewhat by a mishap to the pacemaker, Pancho Lopez.

MONTREAL, Sept. 12. -- Despite last year's small crop, an operating profit of $567,940 for the year ended on June 30 is shown in the annual statement of the Alberta, Pacific Grain Company. Operating profit in the previous year was $665,724.

None of Governor ROOSEVELT'S campaign activities thus far has touched in importance the journey which he began last night and which will take him to the Pacific Coast. He will make four full-length speeches on the trip and the rest of it will be devoted to "fact-finding."

Delegates representing the textile centres in fourteen Eastern and Southern States gathered yesterday at the opening of the biennial convention of the United Textile Workers of America, in the Hotel Wood-stock, in West Forty-third Street, to frame policies involving a drastic change in operations and to oppose actively further wage cuts contemplated in the industry.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 12. -- Sunburned to the point where his face is peeling and he was forced to apply olive oil to his cheeks to prevent their blistering, former Mayor Walker of New York nevertheless insisted today that he is resting well and enjoying his trip.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sept. 11 an article under the title "Croats Form Plea for Independence." wherein it is stated that 200,000 emigre Croatians have signed a petition to the League of Nations asking that "Croatia be freed from Serbian rule and restored to independence," and that an identical petition is being "circulated in the United States."

MTNEOLA, L.I., Sept. 12. -- The charges of assault in the second degree against nine Nassau County policemen in connection with alleged attacks on three fellow prisoners of the late Hyman Stark, were dismissed here this morning, when three of the policemen were scheduled to go on trial before Supreme Court Justice John B. Johnston.

General PERSHING will receive congratulations upon his seventy-second birthday in France today. He is there as chairman of the American Battle Monuments Commission, making his annual visit in that service. By act of Congress he is still General of the Armies, and to the end of his life will be so honored.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Live stock receipts dwindled again here today as picketing continued on major highways in an effort to keep farm products from the market.

Several members of society who had been traveling separately in Europe during the Summer returned yesterday on the Ile de France as members of a group that had formed one party for the trip back. They were Mrs. Duane Armstrong, Mr. and Mrs. Hiter King, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Gerli, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Terbell, Miss Rosalind Kress, Miss Eileen Brown, Richard Wharton, Bruce Fenn, James Frank and Elbert F. Wilmerding Jr.

Mayor McKee announced yesterday his intention to make the preservation of the five-cent fare the paramount consideration in his handling of the city's transit problems, including the financing of new city subways and the unification of rapid transit lines.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 12. -- The outstanding football record made by Tulane in 1931 leads many experts to place its team this year as the best in the Southern conference.
Mark Twain Could Actually Laugh. A literary season still young has already produced a first-class sensation in the form of a book which sets out to prove that MARK TWAIN was a humorist.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Jean Harlow was back at work before a motion picture camera today, portraying another of the "siren" parts which brought her fame. She was trying to forget, she said, the strange suicide a week ago of her husband. Paul Bern, motion-picture producer.

The emphatic decline in yesterday's stock market, repeated in many quarters of the bond market, was primarily in the nature of somewhat belated reaction from a prolonged advance which had as yet experienced only casual readjustment. It was quite evidently pressed by professional speculators for the decline; the net reduction of 11 per cent in that account, as reported by the Stock Exchange for August, doubtless made such renewal of activities the less surprising.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12. -- The Five-Year Plan is not finishing in a blaze of glory. Though perhaps more successful than appears at first sight, it is much below the program, especially in the basic industries.

Two exhibitions opened downtown yesterday, an "International Show" of paintings, sculpture and lithographs at the Eighth Street Gallery, 61 West Eighth Street, to continue until Oct. 15, and a group exhibition at Gallery 144 West Thirteenth Street, which will remain until Sept. 30.

No change was perceptible in rates or conditions in the money market at the opening of business in the new week. Turnover was small, and quotations for all classes unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 per cent, street trades at 1 1/2, and Federals at 1/4.

Reflecting a falling off in the number of passengers carried in the year, the pamphlet report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30 shows a decline of $726,028 in net income from the total for the preceding year.

Hitchcock's, the most famous beanery in New York, is passing into new hands after seventy-nine years. A padlock was on the green door at 22 Beekman Street yesterday and a sign in the window read, "Closed for Alterations. Watch for Our Opening."
To the Editor of The New York Times: The dangers inherent in a lack of solid philosophical basis for thought are nowhere more evident than in the recent discussions of prohibition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Throughout the extensive period of hoarding, which at the peak was estimated at $1,600,000,000 by Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the Board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, there was comparatively little hoarding of gold, according to Treasury figures made public today.

At least two persons were killed and five others injured when fire swept a five-story tenement at 208 Eldridge Street early this morning. Two alarms were turned in before the blaze was finally got under control. A gasoline can found later in the second-floor hallway led firemen to believe that the fire might have been started by an incendiary.

Samuel Kaplan, president of Motion Picture Operators' Union 306, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor; Jack Winick, a director of the union, and Arthur Farkash of the Empire State Motion Picture Operators' Union visited Police Commissioner Mulrooney's office yesterday in response to a call to tell whether they could shed any light on recent bombings, in Loew's theatres.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Reports describing "the withdrawal" of Bolivian troops from the long-contested battlefield of Fort Boqueron upon the appearance of 15,000 Paraguayan reinforcements were published here tonight.

Syracuse, N.Y. The City of Syracuse, N.Y., awarded yesterday a new issue of $775,000 local improvement and emergency relief certificates, dated Sept. 14, and due on Dec. 14, to the Guaranty Company of New York. The price paid was a 1.58 per cent basis.
