MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (by mall) -- Attempts to reform the classic Russian ballet so as to make It more expressive of Soviet culture by substituting make-believe farm women and factory shock brigaders for the orthodox characters of fantasy, meet with the unqualified disapproval of Victorina Krieger, a ballerina of the old school, who still is billed as a star.

Reactionary influences ruled the stock market yesterday and price movements were downward most of the day. Trading on the Stock Exchange was heavy, the turnover exceeding 4,000,000 shares. The general list turned heavy soon after the opening and continued to lose ground until the beginning of the last hour, when there was a moderate rally.

WASHINGTON, Sept. -- 12. -- The Democratic National Committee and allied organizations expended $321,111.78 from June 1 to Aug. 31, according to a report filed today by the Democratic National Committee with the Clerk of the House. Receipts during this period were $353,154.20, leaving a balance of 32,048.42.

Reactionary influences ruled the stock market yesterday and price movements were downward most of the day. Trading on the Stock Exchange was heavy, the turnover exceeding 4,000,000 shares. The general list turned heavy soon after the opening and continued to lose ground until the beginning of the last hour, when there was a moderate rally.

WASHINGTON, Sept. -- 12. -- The Democratic National Committee and allied organizations expended $321,111.78 from June 1 to Aug. 31, according to a report filed today by the Democratic National Committee with the Clerk of the House. Receipts during this period were $353,154.20, leaving a balance of 32,048.42.

The need for a drastic revision in freight rates on anthracite coal in order to lower the cost to the consumer has been unanimously agreed upon by operators and miners, it was reported last night following the adjournment of a wage conference between the operators and the spokesmen of 140,000 members of the United Mine Workers of America.

Mayor McKee, in moving yesterday, by means of a lawsuit, to assure his continuance as Mayor until Jan. 1. 1934, indicated his belief, in the opinion of political observers, that he need not expect support from Tammany.
Comment of some of the leading newspapers of the country on the result of the Maine election is epitomized below:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A declaration that the Democratic victory in Maine "imposes need for renewed and stronger effort that the people may fully understand the issues at stake" was the answer of President Hoover to the news of the party upset in the Pine Tree State, which seriously disconcerted Republican leaders here.

An extensive investigation into labor troubles among motion picture operators in Bronx theatres was started yesterday by District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin with the questioning of thirteen witnesses. At the same time it was officially revealed that twenty-two sticks of dynamite, enough to "demolish a city block," had been discovered in the projection room of Loew's Paradise Theatre, Grand Concourse and 188th Street, early last Friday, while 3,000 men, women and children were inside.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Controller Morris S. Tremaine stated today that within the past six weeks he had bought New York City securities amounting to $1,785,000 for State investment and trust funds of which he is the custodian. These investments have shown a realizable profit for the State of $110,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today approved the first self-liquidating loan under the unemployment relief act when it agreed to advance $40,000,000 toward an estimated $283,586,000 required to finance the vast metropolitan water district of Southern California.

Business failures during the week ended Sept. 8 touched a new low for the year, according to Bradstreet's. The decline in retail delinquencies was particularly sharp, a total of 257 retail failures being reported as against 301 in the preceding week. Decreases were also noted in the wholesale and jobbing and manufacturing groups, but there were increases in the number of banking and commercial service suspensions.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- Prices fell sharply throughout the list on the Bourse here today. Wall Street's reaction, following declines in grain and the disturbing political situation in Germany, caused a concerted selling movement, led by professional speculators.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP). -- E. Leroy Mercer, dean of the University of Pennsylvania Physical Education Department, announced today that permission has been granted for the radio broadcasting of the Pennsylvania-Cornell football game on Thanksgiving Day.

Yesterday being a second Tuesday, the regular monthly dinner and puzzle fest of the Riddlers, local branch of the National Puzzlers' League, was held last night in the Hotel New Yorker, the custom of meeting on the second Tuesday in each month having been faithfully adhered to by members of the club for the last forty-nine years.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Government spokesmen said today that the administration would now proceed with a twelve-month political and economic program that would include the drafting of a new Constitution. The date for new Reichstag elections, which by law must occur within sixty days of dissolution, remained a Ministerial secret.

"Too Long in This Condition" was the pibroch, that Pipe-Major Ross played a few days ago at the contest held at Portree, in the Isle of Skye. It was brilliant Summer weather, and the pipers came from far and near to compete in this island where "the great MacCrimmons," the pioneers of the art known as piobaireachd," had their college.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Sept. 13. -- Brig. Gen. Harry Burgess, Governor of the Canal Zone, announced his departure and the end of his administration of the Canal Zone at a meeting of the heads of departments today and with Mrs. Burgess sailed on the Grace liner Santa Clara tonight.
BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- The Reichstag is gone today, "spurlos versenkt," after six expensive hours of existence, and Germany is back to what she had in government before it was elected.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13. -- The Chilean revolt is expected here to deprive former President Ibanez of his Ambassadorial rank and leave him a plain exile again. He has not yet presented his credentials.

The Shannon Congressional Committee, investigating alleged government competition with private business, closed its sessions here yesterday after hearing complaints of salvage operations by the Coast Guard and of mass production of brushes by prison labor in Leaven-worth penitentiary.

The City of New York should join with Chicago in a campaign to disabuse Europeans of their conviction that the two cities are the world's "wickedest," Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago asserted last night when he arrived here on the Bremen after a six weeks' European tour.

Removal of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company as trustee under two $50,000,000 issues of debentures of the International Match Company is asked in a suit filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by an independent debenture holders' protective committee of the match company.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York has decided not to write in article on "The Democratic Case," which The Saturday Evening Post announced last week would appear in an early issue.

Registration will be continued this week at the Institute for Adult Education of De Witt Clinton High School. Mosholu Parkway and Navy Avenue, the Bronx. In the first three days of registration last week 125 women, or about 60 per cent of the total enrolment last year, were registered. Courses include literature, art, psychology, languages, music, history, economics, civics, biology and science in the home.

John Cavanagh, president of the Hat Corporation of America and Dobbs Co., received the tributes of his fellow merchants in Fifth Avenue, for his contribution to the hat business in more than forty years of activity, at a luncheon in his honor yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 13. -- The Stresa conference reached its first crisis today when a British delegate officially stated that Britain would have nothing to do with the fund proposed as an alternative means by which European industrial countries which could not grant preferences, or were unwilling to do so, could help Danubian agrarian States.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13. -- The four players to reach the semifinal round of the annual three-day women's invitation golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today were Mrs. L.G. Federman of Glen Oaks, Miss Rosalie Knapp, Women's National; Mrs. P. Arneill, Wood-way, and Mrs. L.C. Dubois, Wee Burn.

READING, Pa., Sept. 13. -- Rip Hanover, 2:00 3/4, world's champion 2-yearold pacer, added the Reading Futurity, with a value of $2,140.72, for 3-year-olds, to the successes of the Hanover Shoe Farm on the opening day's light-harness card at the Reading Fair today.

As had been expected, the Group Theatre will use Maxine Elliott's Theatre for its second Broadway season, opening on Sept. 26 with John Howard Lawson's "Success Story." The Group is planning to otter its second play, "Party," by Dawn Powell, during the Christmas holidays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The controversy between the commissioners of the District of Columbia and General Pelham D. Glassford, Major and Superintendent of Metropolitan Police, as to who was responsible for calling out troops to quell the bonus riots on July 28, continued today with a denial by the latter that he had known the soldiers had been summoned.
The word has been going about to watch Columbia this Fall. Yesterday it reached the ears of Lou Little.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Irving Hadley held the Boston Red Sox to fire hits while his team-mates of the Browns were pounding a quartet of hurlers to give St. Louis a 9-4 victory today in the final game of the series.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13. -- In the Cleveland Stadium, which rivals their own home grounds for spaciousness and which formed an admirable setting for the brave deed they were doing, Joe McCarthy's Yankees today clinched the American League pennant beyond even mathematical contradiction by scoring their hundredth victory of the season, a 9-to-3 triumph over the fourth-place Indians.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The principal distributing companies tomorrow will raise the price of gasoline by 3 pence a gallon to 1 shilling 7 1/2 pence, of which 8 pence will represent the tax and 11 1/2 pence the gross amount received by the companies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The governments of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru, as neighbors of Bolivia and Paraguay, were invited by the commission of neutrals today to make "constructive suggestions" looking to a cooperative effort to avoid further bloodshed in the Chaco and a peaceful solution of that controversy.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Miss Joan Ridley of England, seeded No. 1, today won her first two matches to enter the third round of singles in the women's annual invitation lawn tennis tournament on the Ardsley Club's turf courts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Helen Hanning in THE TIMES is an excellent example of how well-meaning people in this country confuse the results of the State Housing Board operations with what has been achieved in slum elimtiation in Europe.

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 13 (By Canadian Press). -- The British Columbia Government, it is understood, has under consideration a definite offer from British and United States interests to purchase the government-owned and operated Pacific Great Eastern Railway, on terms that would extend the line to the Peace River district, liquidate the $20,000,000 bond guarantee at present on the road and leave a balance to apply to general debt reduction at completion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are so many scintillating facets to your editorial "Reason Returning" that only the most obstinate or the most skeptical reader can fail to detect the propriety of the entire article.

Another racket -- one that has caused the manufacturers of watches considerable concern -- has been discovered and, the police think, temporarily ended. After a number of weeks of investigation, headquarters detectives yesterday had six men under arrest, charged with implication in a scheme by which dials bearing the names of high-grade watchmakers were attached to cheap watches and the whole sold as genuine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Sixty-eight per cent of the persons tried for violations of the national prohibition law by juries in the Southern District of New York in the year ended June 30 were convicted, the Department of Justice announced today.

While leading newsprint manufacturers admitted yesterday that their industry was filled with rumors of impending price cuts, partly intended to meet competition from the Scandinavian countries and to convert surplus stocks into cash at a time when the industry has been afflicted with bond defaults and receiverships, none would confirm a report that price readjustments might be made on or before Oct. 1.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. J.E. Fleming of Raritan Valley captured the low gross award in a oneday golf tournament at the Montclair Golf Club today after a tie with Miss Marion French of Rock Spring. Each scored a 90, but matching of cards gave the prize to Mrs. Fleming as a result of a birdie 3 she had scored on the 381-yard first hole.

Following the failure of court action brought by four terminal companies in Brooklyn to block door-delivery by railroads here, the railroads announced yesterday that they would file these tariffs as scheduled tomorrow. For a time the court action threatened to delay this action by the railroads.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting will give a dance tonight at Hamilton Farm, their place in Gladstone, N.J., to introduce to society Mrs. Cutting's daughter, Miss Victoria Brady. Dinners in advance of it will be given by Mrs. Grafton Pyne, Mr. and Mrs. C. Douglas Dillon, Miss Molly Flagg and Mrs. Evander B. Schley.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Elisha Dyer entertained with a luncheon today at Wayside.

GENEVA, Sept. 13. -- What economy was left of the American disarmament delegation moved today from the Hotel Bergues, one of the principal centres of international life in Geneva, to a flat just under the attic at 33 Quai Woodrow Wilson, which is to be its future office.

Candidates are like former candidates; they wait to acquaint the public with their views on perplexing questions until they think the time is ripe and until they have matured their opinions. President HOOVER pursued that course with regard to prohibition.

Panama Jungle Fails a Scientist. Curator DITMARS is back at the reptile house in the Bronx Zoo, after a scientific mission to Panama from which he returned even more empty-handed than if he had been an astronomer in search of a total eclipse.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- An agreement establishing a conference in the trade from North Brazil ports to United States Atlantic ports was approved today by the Shipping Board.

ANGMAGSALIK, Greenland, Sept. 13. -- The flying Hutchinson family and its crew are safe. They were located at 2 o'clock this morning, local time, on a desolate part of the ice-ridden Greenland coast near Ikerssauk by the British trawler Lord Talbot, which pushed its way through floating ice to the point where its crew had seen a flare earlier in the night.

A plan for Soviet-American trade, believed to overcome previous objections from both sides, would be laid before members of the American Manufacturers' Export Association next week at a meeting called to discuss prospects for Russian business, it was learned here yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13. -- The unearthing of forty-nine bodies, 10,000 years old, today focused the Interest of scientists the world over upon a wooded hillside near Pittsburgh.

Twenty-three more bodies were recovered yesterday from the East River, bringing to sixty-eight the total of men known to have been killed when the steamer Observation was destroyed by an explosion last Friday off 134th Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The new broom, Mayor Joseph V. McKee, having swept a few hundreds of thousands of dollars out of the pockets of the faithful, I am of the opinion that a few suggestions from the grateful taxpayers may be acceptable.

Asked yesterday whether he had any plans to make the Central Park Casino a "place for the common people," Mayor McKee treated the question as a joke and told a little story about his first and only visit to the rendezvous so popular with former Mayor Walker.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the nickels are being dropped into the turnstiles of the new Eighth Avenue Subway, how few will stop to think of all the toil, the sweat and the blood that went into this great work and benefit to the people!

W.L. Ross, president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, announced yesterday further details of the plan approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission for meeting the maturity of $20,000,000 of unsecured three-year 6 per cent gold notes on Oct. 1.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 13. -- The political overturn in this normally Republican stronghold was complete tonight with the realization that Maine has elected a Democratic Governor.

BERLIN, Sept. 13. -- The Cabinet was too busy all day with domestic troubles to discuss the French reply to the German memorandum asking equality in armaments, even though the issue is a pressing one, since the bureau of the disarmament conference is to reconvene at Geneva Sept. 21.
BOMBAY, Sept. 13. -- Hindu opinion here is greatly agitated over Mahatma Gandhi's threat to fast to death. Trouble is feared if the prevailing excitement increases.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- In a letter sent today to Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee of New York, Governor Roosevelt promised prompt action to clarify existing abuses in the workmen's compensation law, and especially fee-splitting in cases in New York City.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Chicago White Sox today spoiled Washington's bid to equal the American League season mark for straight victories, by taking the final of the series, 4 to 1, and breaking the Senators' winning streak at nine straight.

A fisherman who has practiced his art and skill in the streams and lakes of a dozen States and Canada in the course of a fairly long career has just come back to town with the tale of the hardest fight he ever had with a Northern pike, a fifteen-minute battle that was little less than titanic, even if this pike was by no means the largest he ever caught.

Amplifying the move started by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks to direct attention to the difficulties of the railroads, the Security Owners Association announced yesterday that it would campaign for Federal and State legislation to bring about coordination of railroad and highway services under control of the railroads.
MONTREAL, Que., Sept. 13. -- Reports today from New York that leading newsprint manufacturers are giving serious study to the price problem, aroused considerable interest here.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- A better-than-seasonal gain in factory employment and payrolls took place in New York State in August, the Department of Labor announced tonight. The report was made by Miss Frances Perkins, Industrial Commissioner.

The snowball of returned prosperity will roll downhill with the same impressive momentum that marked the coming of the depression, Roger W. Babson writes in "Fighting Business Depressions,'' published today by Harper. He takes for granted that 1933 will be the year marking the depression's end.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- As far as Governor Roosevelt is concerned there is no "trouble" between him and former Governor Smith, according to a letter from the Democratic nominee received today by George Murphy, politial editor of The Hastings Press.

Plans for acquisition of the White Motor Company of Cleveland, Ohio, one of the largest manufacturers of commercial vehicles, by the Studebaker Corporation of South Bend, Ind., were announced yesterday in a statement signed by A.R. Erskine, president of the latter, and R.W. Woodruff, chairman of the board of directors of the former company.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. John E. Craig won the sweepstakes award this afternoon at the annual Autumn flower show of the Great Neck Garden Club which was held in the Community House. The exhibit was one of the most complete ever staged by the organization.

Preliminary steps to restore the men's clothing industry to its former high plane were taken yesterday, when more than fifty important executives voted to establish an association embracing all divisions of the trade, with a virtual dictator or "czar" at its head.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Frown as he may when the monthly bills are due, Mr. Average Citizen's checks for living costs are the smallest since the war days of 1917.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Long wheat came out freely through commission houses early today, partly on stoploss orders, and carried prices on the Board of Trade here into new low ground on the present downturn. December at the inside was 6 3/4 cents a bushel below the high point of a week ago.
NEWARK, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Newark Bears concluded their season's home stay today by losing to the Orioles, 7 to 3.

Mayor McKee will have his first chance to delve into the workings of the Sanitation Department tomorrow when the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate examines in executive session the department's recommendation that contracts for three new incinerators be given to a firm whose bid is about $250,000 higher than that of the low bidder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A note of cautious hopefulness for better world economic conditions is sounded in the first world economic survey of the League of Nations, a copy of which was received by the State Department today from Geneva as a matter of courtesy and information.

DOVER, Del., Sept. 13 (AP). -- Supporters of Governor C. Douglass Buck tonight said that unless all indications fail, he will be renominated by the Republican State convention which meets here tomorrow.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Two home runs today hurt the pennant chances of the Pittsburgh Pirates and gave Ed Brandt, the Boston Braves' southpaw ace, his 15th victory of the season by a 3 -- 0 margin.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- France soon will add to the value of her reply to Germany on arms by going further than has been expected along the road to disarmament as laid down in the proposals of President Hoover, it is reported here.

MINEOLA, Sept. 13. -- Betty Francis, chestnut mare, with owner, William Entwistle, Philadelphia, driving, won the 2:15 class pace in three straight heats today in a field of nine closely matched sidewheelers. Her fastest mile, 2:10, came in the second brush.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Dowager Queen Marie is criticized by the Transylvanian newspaper Patria on the ground that the recent christening of the son of Princess Ileana amounted to a public demonstration that a link existed between the "discredited Hapsburgs" and the Rumanian royal family.

Coat of adequate medical treatment of workmen's compensation cases can be substantially lowered if insurance companies will "clean house" and eliminate all connivance at unprofessional practices, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Governor's Committee to Review Medical and Hospital Problems in connection with Workmen's Compensation Insurance, wrote yesterday to George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The thirteenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American oil paintings at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington will open Dec. 4 and close Jan. 15. The William A. Clark prize awards will be given this year as usual: First prize, $2,000, accompanied by the Corcoran gold medal; second, $1,500, with the Corcoran silver medal; third, $1,000, with the Corcoran bronze medal, and, fourth, $500, which carries also an honorable-mention certificate.

Germany's proposals to the French Government, with respect to disarmament -- or, rather, German rearmament -- contained a request for confidential negotiations on the subject. To this the French reply is that nothing could suit France better.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 13. -- Charges that former Mayor Harry A. Mackey accepted "considerable sums" of money from the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company under a "straw" name and that he committed himself, before entering the Mayoralty, to certain transit policies on promise of support for the Governorship were made today by A.A. Chapman, former secretary to the late Thomas E. Mitten, transit operator, in a letter to Governor Pinchot.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Sept. 14. -- The Chinese Government prepared today to seek to invoke the Nine-Power treaty and Article XVI of the League of Nations covenant as soon as the Japan-Manchukuo treaty of recognition is signed tomorrow.
A movement for "equitable adjustment of assessments" of property onthe west side of Manhattan was begun yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The decline in Wall Street, together with unfavorable Continental advices, caused the stock markets here to open weak today. In the forenoon prices strengthened, but renewed weakness developed in the afternoon on American influences. Sterling fell to $3.47 3/4 and caused British funds to drop.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 13. -- Federal troops have captured the important city of Silveira after an all-night battle with the Sao Paulo rebels, it was announced today.
COPENHAGEN, Sept. 13. -- The Royal Greenland Board has ordered its representative at Angmagsalik to render the Hutchinson family every possible assistance in the way of clothes and provisions.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 13. -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, tonight hailed the big Democratic victory in Maine as a definite indication that the tide in this country had turned from the Republican leadership of President Hoover and as a forerunner of victory at the national election in November.

BUCHAREST, Sept 13. -- A sensational story that Archduke Anton von Hapsburg, husband of Princess Ileana, recently was expelled from Czechoslovakia, where he had piloted his mother-in-law, Queen Marie of Rumania, who also left in high dudgeon, was published tonight in the newpaper Lupta.

Supreme Court Justice McGeehan reserved decision yesterday on an application in behalf of Mrs. Louise Dinehart, wife of Alan Dinehart, actor, to punish the Fox Film Corporation for contempt of court for failure to obey an order to turn over Dinehart's salary to a receiver, who was appointed to collect unpaid alimony of $150 a week in a divorce action.

James Joseph (Gene) Tunney, former heavyweight champion of the world, will sail on the French liner Ile de France tonight when it departs for Plymouth and Havre. He will be accompanied by his infant son and a nurse, Mrs. Catherine Billings, who is the godmother of Mrs. Tunney.

Although the Democratic victory in Maine was widely discussed, Wall Street did not entirely make up its mind yesterday as to the significance of the news. No one was prepared to "call off" operations for the rise simply because the Republicans had lost in the first important test.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, in an interview given to a delegation of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom yesterday, declared that he favored disarmament, readjustment of the war debts and recognition of Soviet Russia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Coming from far back J.E. Hughes's Silent Shot fought his way to a neck victory over North Mill in the Manos Purse, a five and one half furlong test for 2-year-olds, today at Lincoln Fields.

GENEVA, Sept. 13. -- Information reaching high League officials today strongly indicated that Germany had not found sufficient satisfaction in the French reply to cause her to attend the meeting of the Disarmament Conference Bureau, convoked here for Sept. 21.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was weak yesterday, heavy selling totaling $12,767,000, driving a long list of issues down 1 to more than 7 points for the day. Second-grade railroad bonds, especially, were hard hit. Final prices, in most instances, were closer to the lows of the day than to the highs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The address by John Hays Hammond before the annual business conference at Babson Institute reported in your issue of Sept. 9 commands the attention of those who would like to see an end of depression.

An agreement between the four Eastern trunk lines which will enable them gradually to expand their systems under the terms of the consolidation plan announced by the Interstate Comerce Commission on July 21 will be in sight on Sept. 23, it was disclosed yesterday, following a meeting of the interested managements in the Pennsylvania Station.

Evidently under the continued impetus of professional sales for the decline, Monday's reaction in prices for both stocks and bonds went further yesterday. The "bear selling" was presumably supplemented by closing out of speculative accounts for the rise, and the severity of the day's earlier readjustment thereby emphasized.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- President Hoover today instructed J. Clawson Roop, director of the budget, to begin at once a detailed investigation of the possibility of consolidating and reducing the number of Federal agencies, and to prepare the necessary executive orders for a reorganization of the entire structure of the government.
Eight thousand fans who gathered in Ebbets Field yesterday were rewarded by seeing the Dodgers take both ends of a double-header from the Cardinals.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The motto of the United States Senior Golf Association, "once a senior, always a senior, sometime venerable but never aged" seemed more appropriate than ever today, when Findlay S. Douglas, national amateur golf champion in 1898 scored a record-breaking 74 in the first eighteen holes of the twenty-eighth championship of the organization.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The Lord Talbot, which rescued the Hutchinson family, is a vessel of 325 tons. One of the largest and best equipped trawlers of the Aberdeen fleet, it specializes in fishing in Greenland waters.

Buyers' Arrivals Reach New High. A new peak in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted. This total was the highest for any week since the first week in February, 1930. For the week the number of buyers listed was 1,300, against 453 in the preceding week and 1,051 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

There seems to be no doubt that the George and Vulture Inn, between Cornhill and Lombard Street, will have to go the way of like relics that have succumbed to the march of progress in London. The present lease expires in 1935. Two of the alleys leading to the old inn are undergoing "improvements" in the form of commercial buildings.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., Sept. 13. -- Dropping seven 100-pound bombs from an altitude of 5,000 feet into a circle that measured 100 feet in diameter, Lieutenant Charles W. O'Conner established today what the Army Air Corps declared to be a world record for consecutive hits from that height.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 13 (AP). -- Representative John H. Overton, backed by Senator Huey P. Long, with a lead of more than 36,000 votes, defeated Senator Edwin S. Broussard in the Louisiana Senatorial race on returns from today's primary.
ST. GEORGE, Bermuda, Sept. 13. -- The last two days have been full of excitement in the first diving attempts this year with the New York Zoological Society's bathysphere.
Housing properties again led in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday. The leading item was an apartment house sale in Jersey City.
Influenced by other speculative markets yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke more than a quarter cent and ended 28 to 31 points lower than on Monday.

LA PAZ, Sept. 13. -- Fighting between Bolivian and Paraguayan troops at Fort Boqueron increased in intensity this morning as the battle entered its fifth day, according to a general staff communique. The Bolivians were reported fighting tenaciously and still occupying the fort, a key position on the Gran Chaco battlefront.

The money market was quiet, de- mand for accommodation being light, notwithstanding the good supply of funds on offer. Quotations in all instances remained unchanged from Monday. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 per cent, Street trades 1 1/2 and Federals 1/8.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 13. -- The American Legion national convention took a day off today to treat Portland to the military spectacle of its annual big parade and this evening while the marchers made merry in the streets the resolutions committee went into an all-night session laying the ground-work for tomorrow's battles on the floor.

Tax Commissioner John R. Crews, leader of the Sixth Assembly District in Kings, pledged last night the four delegates from his district to the Republican State Convention to Colonel William J. Donovan. Mr. Crews bolted the compact between Frederick J.M. Kracke, Kings Republican leader, and W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, for an "open" convention with no pledged delegates and a fair field for all aspirants for the Republican nomination for Governor.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 13. -- W. Neal Fulkerson Jr. of the Cherry Valley Club, with a fine 75, was the low-gross prize-winner in a one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association over the Lido Country Club course today. Seventy-eight competed.

A money-market turnover of more than $2,000,000,000 will be involved in tomorrow's fiscal operations of the Treasury, which will include the redemption of $712,000,000 of maturing issues, the sale of at least $1,150,000,000 of new issues, the payment of interest on outstanding obligations and the quarterly tax collections.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The second race of the Atlantic Class Championship, held today by the Larchmont Yacht Club, was won by William J. McHugh with hla Mistral, representing the Norwalk Yacht Club, leading home the Pronto, owned by the Misses Helen and Ruth Bedford of tha Pequot Yacht Club of Southport, Conn., and Kingsley Kunhardt's Noiram of the Bellhaven Beach Club.

Numerous leases in anticipation of increasing business this Fall were reported by realty brokers yesterday. The midtown area was particularly active, both in the garment centre on the west side and the light manufacturing section of the Grand Central zone.

The big monoplane American Nurse, carrying William Ulbrich, pilot; Dr. Leon M. Pisculli, the owner, and Miss Edna Newcomer, a student nurse from Williamsport, Pa., took off from Floyd Bennett Field at 7:16 A.M. yesterday on a non-stop flight to Rome, and with clear weather aiding it, was believed to be far out on the Atlantic last night, roaring steadily toward its goal.

Detectives and Federal agents whose duties require them to keep posted on the activities of gangsters and racketeers appeared yesterday before the State Board of Parole to tell what they know about Owen Madden, convicted slayer and alleged racketeer, whose appeal for release from prison on parole comes up today for a second time when the board convenes at Sing Sing prison.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Grain exports last week from the United States amounted to 924,000 bushels, against 933,000 bushels the previous week and 1,461,000 bushels during the corresponding week of last year.
PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 14. -- Dr. Paul Gorguloff went to his death on a guillotine outside the Sante prison at dawn today for the assassination of President Paul Doumer.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Daniel Probst, 37 years old, an experienced flying instructor, and William Fitze, 26 years old, a student flier of Chatham, N.J., were killed today when the D.H. Moth biplane in which they were flying crashed into a marsh near the Lehigh Valley Railroad, about a mile and a half east of Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Maine Democrats elected a Governor in the 1880 September election by a majority of 170 votes, but since that time no Democratic Governor has been elected in a Presidential year until yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13. -- Keeping up the fine brand of golf he displayed yesterday, Johnny Fischer, slightly built University of Michigan junior, captured the medal in the qualifying round of the thirty-sixth national amateur championship at the Five Farms course today.

The Maine September election may not be a good "political barometer," but it is a pretty efficient seismograph. It accurately records the occurrence of an electoral earthquake. No other description fits the totally unexpected overturn on Monday.

Thomas F. Dwyer, ousted as Markets Commissioner by Mayor McKee, defended his administration of the Bronx Terminal Market yesterday and drew a sharp contrast between what he said was the Mayor's lack of interest in the market for six years and the sudden interest he took when he became Mayor.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- No hint came from Downing Street today that the government would do anything but sit tight on its communal decision. The government is resolved not to withdraw its award until the Indian communities agree among themselves. The only move the government is likely to make is to allow Mr. Gandhi to be released before his hunger strike begins.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, analyzing today the wet victory in Maine, which had been dry for fifty years, said the trend there against the Eighteenth Amendment was indicative of a nation-wide opposition to its continuance.

E.R. Bradley's 2-year-old filly, Barn Swallow, winner of the Matron Stakes last Wednesday, made he standing more pronounced at Belmont Park yesterday when she won the featured Tomboy Handicap by a length over the same rival she defeated in the Matron, Iseult.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Allotments of $41,577,260 were made by the War Department today for rivers and harbors and flood control works in pursuance of the program of expending nearly $200,000,000 on public construction announced last week by President Hoover as a move to aid employment.

GENEVA, Sept. 13. -- Foreign Minister Benitez of Paraguay, replying to the note of the President of the League of Nations Council, cabled today that he was informing the commission of neutrals of Paraguay's readiness to suspend hostilities.

John H. McCooey, Democratic National Committeeman, whose support would be necessary if Tammany sought to put James J. Walker back in the Mayor's chair this Fall, called at City Hall yesterday morning, to meet the new Mayor, Joseph V. McKee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Insull Utility Investments, Inc., one of Samuel Insull's investment concerns, owed approximately nine times as much as it owned when it was placed in receivership on April 16, according to an auditor's report filed today in Federal court here.

SEA BRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 13. -- John Leiseuring Kemmerer, wealthy coal operator of Short Hills, N.J., beached his yacht, Frances-Marion, in the Shrewsbury River near here tonight in a perilous effort to keep the boat afloat after it had struck a submerged wreck off the New Jersey coast.

J.T. Walter of Brighton Beach has bought a six-room Colonial type house in Ravensdale, Hastings-onHudson, through the Homeland Company, which also sold two plots in the Lake Katonah colony at Katonah to A.C. Sweeney of this city.

Arbitration of the demands made by the anthracite operators for a wage reduction loomed as a possibility yesterday when the joint conference adjourned after an all-afternoon session at the Anthracite Institute, 19 Rector Street.

Final returns from Maine's State election, showing the Democrats had elected their candidate for Governor and two of the three Representatives in Congress came as a hard blow to the high functionaries at the WaldorfAstoria headquarters of the Republican National Committee.

Mr. GANDHI gives notice to Prime Minister MACDONALD that he will starve himself to death unless the British Government gives up that part of its proposed electoral system for India which gives the Untouchables in districts where they constitute a majority a second vote within a separate constituency.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 13. -- The Socialist regime of Provisional President Carlos G. Davila was unexpectedly overthrown today, scarcely three months after it had seized power.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,167,700 barrels, compared with 2,127,250 in the preceding week, a gain of 40,450 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. Increases of 23,500 barrels in Kast Texas and of 11,700 in Oklahoma were the most important changes.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, reviewing the firemen's parade at the Coney Island Mardi Gras, won an ovation last night when he shared a pitcher of beer with other members of his party in the reviewing stand at Surf Avenue and West Tenth Street.

The North German Lloyd Line announced yesterday that it had renewed its lease on Pier 4, Brooklyn, for one year at a rental of about $250,000 to provide docking space for its ships pending the completion by the city of Pier 32, North River, which it plans eventually to occupy.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 13. -- Former Mayor Walker of New York refused today to comment on Mayor McKee's dismissal of Commissioner of Markets Dwyer and his instigation of a suit to prevent a Mayoralty election this year.

What action, if any, the city should take to protect its interests in the pending Interborough and Manhattan Railway Federal Court receivership proceedings would be threshed out at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate tomorrow afternoon, Mayor McKee announced yesterday.

It took the Giants a long time this year to gain some measure of revenge on the Cubs, but they finally succeeded in the second game of the double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday, thereby annoyingly interrupting the Chicagoans' hasty march to the National League pennant.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoreman's Association, submitted yesterday to the members of the association the wage contract which had been offered by representatives of the steamship lines at a meeting of joint committees of longshoremen and owners on Monday.
Acting on orders from prohibition headquarters in Washington, Federal agents raided and closed nearly 200 cordial shops in this city yesterday.

Leon Miller, who escaped from the Great Meadow prison at Comstock, N.Y., on Aug. 23, was Leon Kraemer, notorious safe-blower and hold-up man who was serving a sentence of forty years for his part in the activities of the Richard Reese Whittemore gang, it became known yesterday.

Speaking at the opening session of the convention of the National Identification Association yesterday morning at the Hotel New Yorker, Charles H. Sheraton of New York, chairman of the board of directors of the organization, advocated the fingerprinting of every person in the country who openly advocates revolution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To many old-timers like myself, who can look back for sixty-odd years, the story in THE TIMES of the closing of Hitchcock's famous beanery had a specially pleasant interest. No one of this sophisticated era can realize what those good old days were like, with their simple pleasures and the simple fare of which Oliver Hitchcock's coffee and cakes were the symbol.

The extraordinarily large sub scription to the Treasury's September offering of new loans, with their very low interest rate, has elicited puzzled comment. That the Government's offer of $1,150,000,000 one-year and five-year obligations would be taken by the market nobody doubted.

General agreement that "coal is a sick industry" was voiced at the anthracite wage conference yesterday by operators and mine workers, but proposed methods to revive the industry did not evoke such unanimity except as to the need for drastice freight reductions.
Sale of several properties by a receiver featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday. Continuation of the brisk housing turnover also was apparent.

With little ceremony and no witnesses except a policeman and a few informal representatives of the building trades -- who happen to work there -- the Union Club yesterday afternoon laid the cornerstone of its new home at Park Avenue and Sixtyninth Street.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan gave his political hat a tentative toss toward the Mayoralty ring yesterday afternoon with the declaration that he will run for Mayor as an independent in the event a special election is held this Fall, if he is fully convinced the people want him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is generally accepted that speakers at political rallies place the most impossible interpretations on statements made by an opposition candidate. Pew men, however, succeed as well as Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills in nig address at Portland, Me., on Sept. 10.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Miss Rosalie Knapp, champion of the Women's National Club, won the annual women's invitation golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today by defeating Mrs. L.C. Dubois of the Weeburn Country Club, 7 and 6.

Insurance companies have asked for an increase in workmen's compensation premiums in New York State which would place an added burden on industry estimated at $18,000,000. The average increase would be a little over 9 per cent. This follows a total increase of a little over 25 per cent last year.

THE HAGUE, Thursday, Sept. 15 -- A partial settlement of the shipping strike has been reached. The contact commission and the shipowners' association concluded terms which ship officers at meetings in Amsterdam and Rotterdam have accepted. The men in Amsterdam also accepted the terms, but at Rotterdam the sailors decided to continue the strike with greater determination.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Grover C. Neff of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company will be elected president of the Middle West Utilities Company, by the directors tomorrow, succeeding Martin J. Insull, it was announced today by Edward N. Hurley and Charles A. McCulloch, receivers of Middle West Utilities.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 14 -- Former Mayor Walker suffered a slight attack of indigestion early this morning, but after Dr. Giovanni Valenzi, the ship's surgeon, had prescribed for him, he quickly shook it off. He remained in his cabin most of the day, however, and had nothing for lunch except a little bouillon.

Opponents of Mrs. Ruth B. Pratt, candidate for renomination for Congress from the Seventeenth Congressional District, charged yesterday that she had recently sent out improperly under her Congressional franking privilege more than 70,000 letters to voters in her district, with copies of a pamphlet in which she described the achievements of the Seventy-second Congress to date and reviewed her own votes on important measures.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- In spite of the exhilaration consequent to yesterday's pennant-clinching, the Yankees, in opening their final league series in Chicago today, showed not the least vestige of consideration for the White Sox, who are earnestly trying to clinch seventh place away from the Boston Red Sox.

The wreckage of the ill-fated steamer Observation, cast among the flotsam and jetsam of New York waters after the explosion at the foot of East 134th Street, claimed two more lives yesterday when two boys were swept into the treacherous eddies of Hell Gate while they were playing on a raft fashioned of the steamer's timber off Astoria Park, Queens.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- One of those breezes in which a sheet has a pull and a deck has a spring swept the fourteen Atlantic Class sloops today through their third and final championship race off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

ROME, Thursday, Sept. 15 -- Italian air officials expressed apprehension early today in the absence of any reports of the transatlantic plane American Nurse after it had been out of New York for forty-one hours.
The new Eighth Avenue subway has already achieved a distinction not accorded, so far as the record shows, to the lines of the Interborough or B.M.T. A song has been written about it.

Confirming reports of a plan to establish Soviet-American trade, Stanley E. Hollis, managing director of the American Foreign Credit Underwriters, Inc., yesterday issued a statement in which he said the plan was expected to provide the means by which American sellers could accept Russian business and meet all reasonable credit requirements without assuming more than a small fraction of the credit risk involved.

Babe Ruth, who has been out of the Yankee ilne-up since last Thursday, due to illness, will report to Manager Joe McCarthy at Philadelphia next Wednesday, ready to see action in the two-game series with the Athletics, 1931 American League champions, it was announced from the office of the New York Yankees yesterday.

The Long Island Association of Sportsmen's Clubs has gone on record as opposed to the Fall liberation of quail reared in captivity, favoring liberation only in the Spring. Delegates to the annual meeting of the association held last week at East Islip so voted.

It seems that the Maine election was a blessing in disguise for the Republicans. According to Senator HEBERT, Eastern helmsman of the national committee, " there is real hope." Now Republicans know the program they must make to obtain national victory.

THE PAS, Man., Sept. 14 -- "The eclipse had no effect upon the cosmic ray and my work on the Arctic barren lands shows the cosmic ray is an electron, not a wave, as Dr. Robert Millikan believes," Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago, declared today on his return here from a trip inside the Arctic Circle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Twenty original etchings in which scenes from the life of Washington are illustrated by eminent artists in America were presented to President Hoover today by John Taylor Arms of New York, president of the American Society of Etchers.

While the recovery of another body and the death of one of the injured in Lincoln Hospital brought the total of known deaths in the Observation disaster to seventy-one, the Federal and county investigations of the explosions that wrecked the steamboat in the East River off 134th Street moved forward yesterday.

Twenty Grand, owned by the Greentree Stable of Mrs. Payne Whitney and champion 3-year-old last year, will make his first 1932 start today at Belmont Park in the Irish Lad Purse. Whether the famous son of St. Germans and Bonus, which has been called the greatest thoroughbred since Man o' War, is the Twenty Grand of old is a point which has racing followers deeply interested.

Quotations for Over-the-Counter Securities are unofficial. Those included in these tables are obtained from many brokers and dealers. The source which supplied any quotations in this list will be given upon request.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Governor A. Harry Moore was asked to remove Mayor Clarence E.F. Hetrick and members of the city commission as a result of a recent State audit of city accounts, in a letter sent today by the New Jersey Vigilantes Society, which has headquarters here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your timely "Uncle Sam Can't Bargain" was answered thirty-one years ago by an enlightened protectionist, in President McKinley's last speech. Failure to follow the policy of reciprocity which he advised has led to increasingly high Republican tariffs and increasingly less protection.

Space at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, with about fifty feet frontage on the avenue, has been leased by the Blockton Realty Corporation, E.B. Levy, president, to the Famous Amusement Corporation, A. Josephson, president, operators of Sportland at Long Beach.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14 -- Governor Roosevelt, in a letter just received by former Ambassador Richard Washburn Child, chairman of the Newport conference, outlined his opinion as to the basis for international peace, saying:

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Playing the most stubborn kind of defensive polo, with just enough of an attack to make that defense pay, Earle W. Hopping's Eastcott team stopped the new open champion, Templeton, today, and gained the final round of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Following is the text of President Hoover's statement concerning the proposed payment of a soldiers' bonus:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed during August was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 402,601 bales of lint and 47,620 of linters, compared with 278,656 of lint and 37,210 of linters in July this year and 425,030 and 61,807 in August last year.

CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 14 -- This city, which, witnessed the launching of the "white navy" first modern steel warship after the Civil War era, viewed today another maritime innovation when the seatrain New York slid down the ways of the Sun Shipbuilding Drydock Company before a throng of maritime, governmental, transportation and financial notables.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Eastern speculators who made valiant attempts recently to bull the wheat market on the Board of Trade here were regarded today as having thrown up the sponge and with having liquidated the last of their holdings. Heavy selling by houses with Eastern connections started prices downward after a small, early advance, and the December broke 3 cents a bushel from the early high.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., Sept. 14 Lieutenant Charles W. O'Conner, Fifty-ninth Service Squadron bomber, and Captain Eugene Eubank, Forty-ninth Bombardment Squadron, who established a new Air Corps bombing record yesterday by dropping seven bombs from 5,000 feet upon a 100-foot circle and thus put themselves in position to carry off the 1932 bombing honors in the finals today, failed on the final flight.

Plans for a nation-wide attack on unemployment under the direction of President Hoover's coordination committee of the national "share-the-work" movement were laid down yesterday at a meeting of the committee, assisted by business men and industrialists.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- A farewell luncheon was given today to Albert Halstead, United States Consul General in London, who reaches the retirement age the end of this month.

Thirty-six manufacturers of radio sets, tubes and accessories, together with several makers of refrigerators and air-conditioning equipment, will exhibit and demonstrate their wares for a week in the Hotel Edison, beginning Monday morning. More than 10,000 dealers and distributers of such merchandise east of the Mississippi River have been invited to attend.

Delegates from more than 200 councils of the Civil Service Forum, representing virtually all the city, State and Federal employes in the city, voted unanimously last night to invite Controller Charles W. Berry to address their members on "The Preparation of the 1933 Budget."

Listing of 110,892 additional shares of common stock of the City Stores Company and of voting trust certificates for 1,178,833 shares of common stock and 86,745 shares of class A stock was approved yesterday by the New, York Stock Exchange. The additional common shares will be listed upon official notice of their issuance to bankers upon the renewal of notes held by them for the company.

By means of rigid economy and good government Chicago is emerging from the financial quicksands which have gripped her for the last few years, Anton J. Cermak, Mayor of the Illinois city, told a group of bankers and representatives of insurance companies yesterday at a private luncheon at the Chase National Bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Books were opened at 7 o'clock tonight at offices throughout the country for subscriptions to stock in Federal Home Loan Banks, through which the rediscounting and "making liquid" of mortgages on homes are expected to relieve materially the country's credit stringency.

Tammany went into court yesterday and laughed down as a "jury plea" the argument that the city's welfare required the retention of Joseph V. McKee as Mayor until the end of James J. Walker's unexpired term. The argument was made by former Governor Nathan L. Miller, appearing as counsel in Mr. McKee's suit to bar an election this Fall.

Merchandise having a retail value of $1,170,000,000 will be purchased during the last four months of the year by member stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was stated yesterday by P.A. O'Connell, president of the organization and head of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston, in presiding at the Fall fashion presentation and quality merchandise conference of the association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Chairman James A. Farley of the Democratic National Committee left last night for the West to confer with the Democratic leaders in California, where the candidacy of William G. McAdoo has caused some party complications.

OIL CITY, Pa., Sept. 14 -- Production of crude oil in the Bradford district for the week ended Sept. 10 was 25.905 barrels daily, compared with 27,937 in the previous week and 27,279 in August. The Allegany district produced 6,863 barrels daily against 7,118 in the previous week and 7,419 in August.

Cotton Drop Worries Goods Trade. The persistent decline in cotton during the last week caused some uneasiness in cotton goods selling circles here yesterday, as agents felt that a continued drop may force down prices on finished goods and result in a large number of cancellations from buyers later in the season.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Sept. 14 -- The Smithtown poloists were defeated for the second time today since they invaded Monmouth County ten days ago when they lost to William Ziegler's Great Island four, winner of the Hempstead Cups, 7 to 6. Smithtown enjoyed a four-goal handicap.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- "During his four years in the Executive Mansion at Albany, Governor Roosevelt has gained physically, shaking off every important vestige of his serious illness," Senator Copeland of New York declared in an address before the American Hospital Association today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Declaring that "we always pay the price for inflated prices," Dr. Lewis H. Haney, Professor of Economics at New York University, warned against "false prosperity forced upon us by the present government policy," in addressing the annual convention of the American Trade Association executives here today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 14 (AP) -- After reading President Hoover's formal statement saying immediate payment of the cash bonus would be "a fatal threat to the entire program of recovery," Ray Kelly of Michigan, a candidate for commander of the American Legion, said tonight:

ORAN, Algeria, Sept. 14 -- A troop train carrying 500 officers and members of the famous French Foreign Legion plunged into a ravine near Tlemcen today and the Havas News agency said probably 120 Legionaires had been killed and 150 more seriously injured.

CRANFORD, N.J., Sept 14 -- The township committee today sold $20,000 emergency relief bonds to the police and firemen's pension fund. The bid was $19,000, at 5 per cent. There were no bidders, however, for $14,000 improvement bonds, and $84,000 assessment bonds, which constitute the remainder of a series of $116,000 assessment bonds and $58,000 improvement bonds, which were authorized early this Summer.

An increase of one point to 15 1/2 per cent of theoretical capacity in the national average of steel ingot production this week is noted by The Iron Age. The publication reports gains in Pittsburgh, Chicago and Youngstown districts, and losses at Cleveland and Buffalo.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- Increased foundry orders indicate an upward trend in business, according to reports made here today at a regional meeting of the Steel Founders Society of America.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, told the Advertising Club today that revival of a legalized liquor traffic would aid business and society.
LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 14 -- The tremendous vote registered throughout Maine on Monday is the most significant factor of the election to me.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Led by Burnett, Averill and Cissell, the Indians pounded out a 9-to-0 triumph over Boston today in the first of a three-game series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading your editorial comments on the opening of the new subway, one might be led to think that a new foundling had been thrown on our doorsteps. The fact that the Independent Subway was opened without formal speeches or blaring of trumpets does not, in my mind, take away the importance of the great occasion.
TOKYO, Sept. 14 -- Japanese consuls in China have been instructed to warn their nationals against attempting to celebrate the conclusion of the Manchukuo treaty.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 -- Eric Alexander McRuvie, the wisp of a Scot and the last Britisher in the amateur golf championship, went out in the first round of match play when young Charley Yates of Atlanta conquered him by 3 and 2. Yates, a husky blond youngster and a sophomore at Georgia Tech, was too strong for McRuvie, who was playing the odd most of the way.

Mathematics From Down East. Maine has earned the gratitude of the nation by introducing a revolutionary and welcome change in the operations of vox populi. Hitherto it has been commonplace that if the election were held today our man would be sure to win.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Social Service Department at the Metropolitan Hospital faces an increasingly serious situation.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, Sept. 13 -- The monument at Cape York in memory of Admiral Peary having been finished, my promise to the Eskimos of giving them a trip on the Morrissey to see all their friends and perhaps, if time would permit, also do some hunting, has been carried out and the time came for us to part.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Thursday, Sept. 15 -- Japan and the new Manchurian State of Manchukuo entered into a defensive alliance today which also carried with it Japanese recognition of the new government. The protocol was signed at 9:10 A. M (9:10 P.M., Wednesday, Eastern Daylight Time).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- August exports of cotton to Continental Europe amounted to 278,000 bales, a gain of 73,000 bales over July, but exports to Great Britain amounted to 67,000 bales, a loss of 17,000 bales, and shipments to the Far East were 101,000 bales, a decline of 47,000, the Department of Commerce said today.

Scrimmaging of an Intensive nature occupied the Columbia football squad yesterday morning at Baker Field. The men staged a two-hour hard-tackling affair that contained all the earnestness of a regulation game. Coach Lou Little sent the first two teams against each other, but no touchdowns were permitted.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- The German Government itself has now undertaken the physical training of German youth-male, not female. By a Presidential proclamation issued today the government has embarked on a scheme for assuring physical fitness in all able-bodied young men who seek it and has appropriated an initial sum of 1,500,000 marks [about $357,000] for the purpose.

Admitting, according to the police, that he and another man had stolen more than $300,000 from gullible victims by means of the "switch game," William P. Hunt, 45 years old, of Fort Lee, N.J., appeared at the line-up in Police Headquarters yesterday, charged with grand larceny.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Roy Hansen's hurling, coupled with five doubles by his team-mates, gave the Phillies a 4-1 victory over Cincinnati today.

Opening of the Union Inland Freight Terminal tomorrow marks a notable step in the development of the "Comprehensive Plan" to which the Port Authority was originally dedicated. Progress has been slow. Methods of handling freight in the port district had become fixed by long habit.

While other railroads are awaiting a decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission on a form of door-delivery they may use in the New York district, the Pennsylvania Railroad will begin today a van-type trailer service to provide door-delivery of carload lots of freight in Greater New York.

The Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion, of which Archibald W. Griffin is commander, issued a statement yesterday opposing the demand for payment at this time of the balance of the veterans' adjusted compensation certificates. The post called to attention that many ex-service men in the Legion are opposed to the bonus.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- That the French bill for the conversion of rentes probably will not win the desired unanimity when Parliament votes on the plan over the week-end was made evident today in an article by Leon Blum, leader of the Socialist party, in his newspaper, Populaire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Niagara Frontier Bridge Commission applied today for a self-liquidating loan of $7,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Commission for the erection of two bridges to Grand Island, in the Niagara River near Buffalo, N.Y.
Real estate activity in Manhattan was confined yesterday almost entirely to housing property. Leaseholds featured the trading.

Mme. Frances Alda, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Company, opened studios yesterday .at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in which to train young singers for the opera, concert stage and radio broadcasting. She plans to devote a large part of her time to these activities, and will soon be heard in weekly vocal recitals over the National Broadcasting Company's network.

Max Carey's Dodgers still retained a slight hold on their mathematical chance for a pennant by registering their third straight victory over the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday, 3 to 1. Added to a triumph in the final game with the Cubs, the Brooklyn string of triumphs now has reached four.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Invader, the Guy Axworthy 8-year-old colt, winner of the third heat in the Hambletonian Stake, captured the 3-year-old stake today, establishing a new track record for colts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Formal notice was given by President Hooper tonight to the nation and the American Legion that he would continue to oppose veterans' bonus legislation. Such a proposal, he said, constitutes a "fatal threat to the entire program of recovery."
ATLANTA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Richard B. Russell Jr., Georgia's 34-year-old bachelor Governor, appeared late tonight to have won the Democratic nomination for Senator.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Rebecca Newcomer sat near a radio at her home here today, anxiously awaiting some word of the progress of the flight of her daughter, Miss Edna Newcomer, in the airplane American Nurse.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- The market made a remarkable recovery today on the Bourse. After sober reflection it was apparently concluded by the professionals that yesterday's selling wave had been unjustified by events and had gone too far.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14 -- Miss Penelope Winslow was hostess at a beach party for a group of young people at Bailey's Beach today and Mias Olive Whitman had luncheon guests at her home on Price's Keck. Miss Whitman will not return to New York until the end of the month.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Six players, including three members of the seeded list, today triumphed in third-round matches to reach the singles quarter-finals of the women's annual invitation tennis tournament on the turf courts of the Ardsley Club.

Lieutenant James Harten, six feet tall, who was once an aide to former Police Commissioner Arthur Woods, was assigned yesterday as aide to Mayor Joseph V. McKee. He will take the place of Acting Captains Thomas F. O'Connor and John Howard, who guarded the Mayor's office during the terms of James J. Walker.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 11 -- Speaking from the steps of the Kansas State Capitol, Governor Roosevelt presented today to an immediate audience of about 10,000 persons and a vastly larger radio audience his program of farm relief, on which he expects to carry all or most of the disaffected agricultural States of the Middle West.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Prime Minister MacDoriald has issued a new and biting criticism of his former Labor party colleagues, now forming the Opposition in Parliament.

In his address at Topeka yesterday, devoted almost exclusively to farm troubles, Governor ROOSEVELT said many true and sensible things, along with some that seem doubtful or at least ambiguous. He was frank and honest in admitting that he knows of no short-cut to revived farming.

Acute weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday was ascribed partly to the late reaction in the wheat market. There were rumblings also in Wall Street of fresh difficulties in Germany, which may have been a market factor. Commission houses continued to emphasize the "corrective" character of the recent downward readjustment.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 14 -- A great all-round athlete in his day and a basketball mentor of renown, Howard Cann steps into the football picture this Fall to tackle one of the biggest jobs confronting any member of the coaching fraternity.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The main ticket office of the Boston Terminal Company, the Boston terminus of the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Boston Albany Railroads, was robbed of $19,000 in cash during the temporary absence of the cashier this morning.

General Bartolome Blanche, Commander-in-Chief of the army, clung to the rains of government in Chile tonight despite a threat of Colonel Arturo Merino Benitez and his Chilean air force to bomb the Presidential Palace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Revised figures for the allotment of government securities dated Sept. 15 were announced by Secretary Mills today, and showed that the subscriptions were $7,421,198,900 on an offering of $1,150,000,000. The total allotments were $1,285,848,500.

Top Flight, 3-year-old daughter of Dis Donc and Flyatit, and leading money winner of her sex in the history of world's racing, is to be retired at the end of this season, her owner, Cornelius Whitney, stated over a nation-wide radio network from Belmont Park yesterday a few minutes before the filly won the sixty-second running of the Ladies' Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A demilitarized zone 20 kilometers (12.42 miles) wide between the armies of Bolivia and Paraguay in the Gran Chaco was proposed to those governments by the committee of neutrals today, coupled with an "urgent appeal" for immediate cessation of hostilities.

The rate of electric power output shows a sharp rise, the seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Sept. 10 being 216,600,000 kilowatt hours, as against 209,300,000 kilowatt hours for the preceding week and 237,300,000 kilowatt hours for the corresponding week last year.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 14 -- The legislative committee of the American Legion ended a long battle on the bonus question tonight and wrote its report, embodying a demand for immediate and unqualified payment. The vote was 21 to 9, and it was said that there would be no minority report.

The stock market, whose reactionary movement had hatted on Tuesday afternoon, continued its moderate recovery yesterday morning, but gave way again in the later hours of trading. Wall Street assumed, no doubt correctly, that the early recovery indicated tentative "covering" by recent speculative sellers for the decline, and that the subsequent weakness reflected renewal of speculative pressure.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 -- At the end of the dreaded eighteen-hole matches in the national amateur golf tournament today, Francis Ouimet, de fending champion, and two former titleholders, Chick Evans, winner in 1916 and 1920, and Jesse Guilford the 1921 king, were among the eight survivors of the first two rounds.
TOPEKA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The folllowing is the text of Franklin D. Roosevelt's address here today:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 14 -- Eighty-six candidates for the Harvard varsity football squad registered at Soldiers Field today, drew equipment and took the necessary physical examinations. These men and any additional candidates who may report will participate in the opening practice of the season at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

READING, Pa., Sept. 14 -- Evan Hanover, 2:06 1/2, by Guy McKinney, 1:58 3/4, owned by the Hanover Shoe Farms, won the seventh renewal of the Reading Fair Futurity for 3-year-old trotters, valued at $6,522.16, featuring the Central Circuit racing at the Great Reading Fair today.
DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Detroit pounded four Washington hurlers and made their hits count today to win the series opener, 8 to 3.
NEW YORK. Mrs, Earl E.T. Smith grave a luncheon yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria for Mrs. Henry Delafield Phelps and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman.

The Atlas Corporation, an investment trust which has acquired several similar organizations since the stock market deflation began, is about to clinch control of the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, a trust whose assets were valued at a maximum of $200,000,000 in the early days of its history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Three foreign debtors, Estonia, Latvia and Poland, have notified the Treasury Department that they will take advantage of the option granted in the debt-funding agreements by postponing for two years the payment of principal on their debts to the United States due Dec. 15.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Governor Moore could not be reached tonight for comment on the letter of the New Jersey Vigilantes Society, asking him to oust the government of Asbury Park. The Governor had gone to his Summer home at Sea Girt, N.J.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Miss Victoria Brady, daughter of the late James Cox Brady and stepdaughter of Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting, was introduced to society tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Cutting at one of the largest dances of the early debutante season.

A gain of $4,140,700 in monetary gold stocks was shown in the gold transactions reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank, $2,443,500 representing the net release of gold held under earmark for foreign account and $1,697,200 imports of gold received here.

Though Maine furnistred the political sensation of the week, there were developments among Democratic voters in the South which ordinarily would have attracted much attention. One was the news from South Carolina that COLE L. BLEASE, once "COLEY the Unbeatable," has again heen denied a Senate seat and that his permanent elimination from national affairs may be hoped for.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Seventy-three Yale football players were outfitted today for the opening practice of the season for Tale tomorrow. The university Department of Health reported tonight that every player was in fit condition.

George Jean Nathan goes deep into the private lives of seven, of his more intimate friends in "The Intimate Notebooks of George Jean Nathan," published by Knopf today. He tells how Sinclair Lewis, Theodore Dreiser, Eugene O'Neill, Clarence Darrow, Jim Tully, H.L. Mencken and Ernest Boyd talk, how they appear in close association and, rather particularly, how they drink.

Mayor McKee and a committee of three will discuss this morning the bids received for construction of three new incinerators, in an effort to reach a decision on the Sanitation Department's recommendation that the contract be given to a bidder whose estimate exceeds the low bid by about $250,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Monte Parke, 16-year-old brother of Ivan Parke, demonstrated real riding ability at Lincoln Fields today as he accepted his first mount.

ANGMAGSALIK, Greenland, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The George R. Hutchinsons, no longer a flying family, were safe and sound here today after their rescue yesterday by the trawler Lord Talbot, and they faced the problem of getting away from Greenland before the long Arctic Winter closes in.

By winning both ends of a doubleheader yesterday the Newark Bears closed their season's series with Jersey City at Jersey City. The scores were 6 -- 5 in twelve Innings and 10 -- 7 in the abbreviated seven-inning second game.

John Peel of Spartanburg, S.C., organizer for the United Textile Workers, asserted at the convention of the union at the Hotel Woodstock yesterday that Red Cross flour was being distributed in the mill villages of the South in such a manner as to aid employers in their present policy of paying "starvation wages."

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- The Boerse opened today with quotations below yesterday's closing prices, but in the course of the day the market's tone improved, so that yesterday's level was reached again by a majority of stocks. The rally started with I.G. Farben, which again was above par.

Assistant District Attorney Edward F. Breslin of the.Bronx questioned fifteen witnesses yesterday in his investigation of labor troubles among motion picture operators, which have been blamed for recent bombings and other malicious practices in theatres. Four more witnesses will be questioned today, but the grand jury investigation set for tomorrow may have to be postponed, Mr. Breslin said, because that body is occupied with the inquiry into the Observation disaster.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 14 -- Five State detectives, all experts in murder cases, were assigned today to solve the mystery surrounding the disappearance of Mrs. Edith Du Bois, following a conference between the police and John Sullivan, Assistant District Attorney, in Dedham.

Representatives of manufacturers, retailers, landlords, hotel men and others united yesterday in opposition to proposed increases in workmen's compensation insurance rates at a public hearing on the rates in the State Office Building before George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- United States Consul General George Hanson at Harbin, Manchuria, has not reported here on his representations to the Manchukuo authorities for increased protection against brigandage, but the State Department said today such an act would in no sense constitute recognition, even by implication.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 -- A bill introduced in Congress this afternoon establishes a national flaxseed control board, prohibits trading in flaxseed except by persons previously registered and attempts to fix an export price of twelve pesos a quintal, equivalent to 78 1-3 cents a bushel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- National Republican headquarters made public tonight a telegram from Senator Smoot which declared that tariff proposals outlined by Franklin D. Roosevelt in his Topeka address "means that the Roosevelt 'new deal' is a new deal, for peasant labor abroad and a raw deal for the producer in America."

The Abbey Theatre Players from Dublin will open at the Martin Beck Theatre on Oct. 18 for a four weeks' engagement in a repertory of fulllength and one-act plays under the personal direction of Lennox Robinson, author and managing director of the group.
TORONTO, Sept. 14 -- R.S. Mc. Laughlin's Happy Hopes captured the $2,000 added Clarendon Plate as Thorncliffe Park today, defeating Mrs. I. Webster's Syngo by a neck in a driving finish.
