BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- President von Hindenburg put an end today to the barrage or paper missiles with which he and Chancellor von Papen have been bombarded for the last two days by Hermann Goering, the National Socialist President of the defunct Reichstag.

MONTREAL, Que., Sept. 14 -- Reports that Price Brothers Co., Ltd., had reduced the price of newsprint were confirmed here tonight by an executive director of the company. The reduction, which is now in effect, makes the price to the company's customers in the United States $47.50 a ton f.o.b. New York, compared to the former price of $53 a ton, or $5.50 a ton less.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Braves executed the first triple play made in Boston in several years today while taking the second straight game of their final series with the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 to 2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We learn from the letter of Professor Felix Frankfurter, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, that "the opinion, of Justice Staley will long endure as a shining example of what an opinion should not be," that it is "a flagrant abuse of judicial power"; and that it "has helped to weaken the lawful processes of government." Shades of John Marshall!

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Plans to meet the relief problems of the Winter will be worked out at a conference which will be opened at the White House tomorrow with a speech by President Hoover. Remaining sessions will be held in the Mayflower Hotel, with Newton D. Baker as chairman.

DE QUINCEY should be alive to write the story of the exchange of Greek and Turkish populations between Thrace and Anatolia, as once he wrote "The Flight of a Tartar Tribe." The latter was about the Journey of 500,000 semi-barbarians, half of whom perished from cold and heat, starvation and thirst, or from the weapons of those pursuing them day and night.

Mrs. H.E. Manville of Pleasantville, N.Y., whose daughter is the wife of Count Folke Bernadotta of Sweden, will sail to visit the Count and Countess today on the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm. Others booked are Mrs. Ruth Randall Edstrom, wife of the chairman of the Olympic Games general committee and president of the General Electric Company of Sweden, and Nils E. Wahlberg, vice president of the Nash Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Building projects totaling $20,810,000 in expenditures were announced by Secretary Mills and Postmaster General Brown today. The range of cost for the buildings is from $100,000 to $300,000, but the individual costs were not disclosed.

The State Parole Board at its regular monthly meeting in Sing Sing prison at Ossining, N.Y., listened yesterday to the pleas of eighty-two inmates seeking release on parole. Among the applicants was Owen Madden, alleged Broadway racketeer, in prison for the last two months for violation of parole, who asked the board to give him another chance and permit him to return to New York City.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Miss Constance Regan of Old Westbury, L.I., won the quality sweepstakes cup this afternoon at the annual Autumn flower show of the Garden Club of Long Beach, of which Mrs. Edward A. Isaacs is president, held in Community Hall here.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A demand of foreign consuls in Manchuria for increased protection against brigandage was presented to the Manchukuo Government today by United States Consul General George A. Hanson as half-naked victims of the recent train wrecks told of harrowing experiences.

Mayor McKee has called upon Maurice Hotchner, chairman of the Board of Taxicab Control, to defend today at a City Hall conference the board's recent request for an appropriation of $125,000 in the 1933 budget. Indicating clearly that he would not approve so large a sum, the Mayor declared that Mr. Hotchner would be told that the board would be allotted only the amount that its chairman could prove to be absolutely necessary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- With more than 100 leading commodities averaging price increases of better than 9 per cent above the low point of the depression period, Secretary Chapin asserted today that a "distinct change" was evident, but he added that the change "may or may not indicate a change in trend."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Hoover has definitely decided to take the stump and personally carry the "issues at stake' to the electorate, it was learned today after Governor Roosevelt's Topeka speech on the farm problem had been analyzed by administration advisers.

The International Agricultural Corporation and affiliated companies report for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net loss of $847,770 after all charges, including depletion, depreciation and interest. This embraces a profit of $199,761 on bonds purchased and a gain of $200,000 by the reinstatement, in part, of the investment in Kaliwerke Sollstedt Gewerkschaft, previously written off.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Unless one of the remaining ninety seniors who compose the second half of the field that begins play tomorrow sets a new scoring record, Findlay S. Douglas will become the new senior golf champion of the United States.

Two plays, both opening on Wednesday evening, have been added to next week's list of theatrical premieres. They are "Triplets," a farce by Mark Linder, which is announced for the Masque Theatre, and "Only the Young," a comedy by Cecil Lewis, which will be presented at the Sutton Show Shop, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street.
STRESA, Italy, Sept. 14 -- After Britain's refusal yesterday to give either, preferences or monetary contributions to relieve Danubian countries, the Stresa conference marked time today.

Baltimore, Md. The city of Baltimore, Md., plans to enter the market on Sept. 29 with a new issue of $3,879,000 of 4 per cent bonds, due variously from 1936 to 1964, according to private advices received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Most of the officials who will administer agricultural loans through agricultural credit corporations in seven Western Federal Land Bank Districts were named late tonight by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as a new step to speed its farmaid program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Hugh R. Wilson, the United States Minister to Switzerland and alternate delegate to the general disarmament conference at Geneva, was designated by President Hoover today to represent the United States at the meeting of the bureau of the conference, which will open at Geneva next Wednesday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 14 -- The hope of taxpayers lies in the Federal administration of taxes, Robert Murray Haig, president, told the National Taxation Conference here today. Professor Haig, a member of the faculty of Columbia University, declared that nationalization of the tax system seems inevitable.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City sailed yesterday for Europe aboard the French liner Ile de France. Although he denied that he was sailing when reporters met him aboard the ship and said he was there only to bid good-bye to James J. Tunney, the former heavyweight champion, who also was a passenger, he remained on board when the ship left and it was announced at his office that he had sailed.

Westchester County yesterday became one of the focal points in the efforts that are being made by Massachusetts and New York authorities to ascertain the fate of Mrs. Edith Du Bois, the wife of Charles Du Bois of Tuckahoe.

Walter Reade, theatre owner, of 299 Park Avenue, has been sued in the Supreme Court by Herbert Paul Field, former advertising company executive, for $250,000 damages for alleged alienation of the affections of Helen Paul Field, who conducts a millinery and gown shop.

Brokers and renting agents yesterday reported another long list of apartment rentals in Manhattan buildings. The mid-September Fall househunting centred in the Park Avenue section, where leases of several large apartments were closed.

With the perspiring assistance of Thomas Mitchell, who acts like a steam locomotive, the Spewacks have tossed another one of those melodramatic lampoons at the newspaper profession in "Clear All Wires," put on at the Times Square last evening. It is brisk, noisy, extravagant and funny in "The Front Page" and "Broadway" tradition.

Increased activity in the national campaign in the East by both the major parties, it was clearly indicated yesterday, will be one of the immediate results of the Republican defeat at Monday's election in Maine.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The German Government dispatched a formal communication tonight to Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament Conference, the contents of which were not revealed, but it is believed to constitute a confirmation of Germany's more recent avowals not to participate in further sessions of the Disarmament Conference or its subordinate organs unless Germany's demand for arms equality or an alternative equivalent is fulfilled without further equivocation.

A sentence of ten years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions yesterday on a nattily dressed man of 25 who gave the name John Evans, believed to be fictitious, on his plea of guilty to attempting to hold up a drug store at Seventh Avenue and Eighteenth Street on the night of Aug. 7.

Unless President HOOVER was sadly misinformed, he could not have expected that his powerful and convincing statement about the bonus would have any effect upon the "American Legion, except perhaps to exasperate and inflame it. The predictions of an overwhelming vote demanding immediate payment were more than verified yesterday.

Under no circumstances would the railwaymen of the country agree to any additional wage reduction, Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen and chairman of the National Association of Railway Labor Executives, declared last night at a meeting of the National Citizens' League for Economic Recovery at Town Hall.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in August amounted to 22,372 long tons, compared with 28,272 tons in July and 27,586 tons in August, 1931, it was announced, yesterday by the Rubber Manufacturers Association.
LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The number of men at work in Rockefeller Center has risen to nearly 5,000, owing to the recent expansion of operations in the midtown amusement and commercial development, and much of the ground lost last Spring because of a building-wage dispute which tied up work for several weeks has been regained, it was announced yesterday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 15 (AP). -- In retaliation, for the arrest of twenty-four farmers at their picket posts by sixty special deputies earlier in the day, a band of farm strikers tonight ambushed three car loads of deputies and pelted them with missiles as they sped through blockade lines.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Twenty Grand made a victorious return to the races yesterday after an enforced absence of about a year, capturing the Irish Lad Purse at Belmont Park in a driving finish. The reappearance of the famous son of St. Germans and Bonus, which has been compared to Man o' War, swelled the attendance, as few horses of recent years have gained such a hold on the imagination of racegoers.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The British view of the German armaments problem definitely hardened today into a firm denial of Germany's right to increase her armed forces. After a long period of apparent indecision, the British are understood to have taken a stand squarely against the rearmament which General von Schleicher, Defense Minister, and other German spokesmen have been demanding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 14, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,293,000,000, a decrease of $37,000,000 compared with preceding week and an increase of $1,040,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- An unidentified man and woman were fatally injured about 4 o'clock this morning when a Frank Martz bus was in collision with a truck parked on Route 6 near here. The bus driver, fifteen of the other sixteen passengers and the helper on the truck suffered broken bones and lacerations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Vice Admiral Joel R.P. Pringle, commander of battleships in the Pacific Fleet, is critically ill on his flagship, the West Virginia, which is steaming for San Pedro, Cal., so he may get adequate medical attention, the Navy Department was advised today.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15. -- Extension of the postal service while the present three-cent rate is in effect was opposed by Walter F. Brown, Postmaster General, in an address before the convention of the National Association of Postmasters here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Secretary Stimson refused today to discuss Japanese recognition of Manchukuo or the Far Eastern situation in any way and the indications were he did not intend to break his silence soon. The attitude was generally accepted as confirmation of official forecasts that the United States would await the report of the Lytton commission to the League of Nations on its Manchurian observations.
The quotations are for three-four months' Paper.

ROME, Sept. 15. -- Italian airplanes were carefully searching today all uninhabited sections of the coast from Rome northward, as well as the wild regions of the interior of Sardinia, in the hope of finding a trace of the airplane American Nurse, which took off from New York Tuesday morning with two men and a woman aboard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Moved by the plight of unemployed teachers and students who are prevented from carrying on their professions and their studies by the economic situation. Dr. A.C.C. Hill Jr., formerly a fellow of the Brookings Institution and Professor of Economics at Springfield College, Massachusetts, announced plans today for forming a "depression college," designed to bring together impecunious students and unemployed professors.

The Railroad Credit Corporation authorized $4,500,000 loans, comprising eight loans to as many railroads, at its monthly meeting here yesterday. This brought the total made or authorized since the corporation began operations early this year to $35,000,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Receipts of hogs today were well above trade expectations and in excess or requirements, resulting in a slower demand and declines in prices of 10 to 20 cents below the general market of Wednesday. The top was off 15 cents to $4.50 a hundredweight, while the day's average was 15 cents down at $4.05 and the lowest since June 23.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Washington Senators combed Elon Hogsett's offerings for five runs in the first one-third of an inning today, but the Tigers finally won in the tenth, 8 to 7.

HURON, S.D., Sept. 15. -- Addressing a mixed political gathering the State Fair today, Secretary Hurley defended the Hoover Administration and challenged Governor Roosevelt to name specifically what schedules of the tariff he would reduce.
TOKYO, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Japanese Government officially denied today that the signing of the treaty at Changchun was "derogatory of any treaty to which Japan is a party."

After falling yesterday to the lowest level reached in the recent decline, the stock market braced itself in the afternoon and ended the day with moderate net gains. The rally was as vigorous as the early decline. It was the result apparently of a belief in speculative circles that the reaction had gone far enough to correct the technical position of the market, temporarily at least.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Losses incurred by an American woman playing a "system" over the green tables in the gambling casinos at Monte Carlo and other French resorts were held deductible from gross income in the preparation of Federal income-tax returns in an opinion today by Clarence M. Charest, chief counsel for the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The assessed valuation of the town of East Chester, including the villages of Tuckahoe and Bronxville, has increased approximately $1,100,000 since last year, according to the new assessment roll released today by Town Assessor Edward A. Matthews.

In the face of the declining security markets, brokers' Joans, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, advanced $62,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. This was the largest increase since the gain of $73,000,000 reported for the week ended on July 1, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Commenting upon Governor Roosevelt's Topeka speech criticizing the stabilization activities of the Federal Farm Board, Representative Snell of New York said in a statement today that the most prominent politicians demanding the stabilization of farm products were Speaker Garner, Senator Robinson and other Democrats.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Waner brothers hit Huck Belts hard today, accounting for five hits, and the Pirates gained a 3-to-2 victory over the Braves in their last clash of the season.

The 30,000 longshoremen employed on deep-water ship line piers of the North Atlantitc ports notified their employers yesterday that they would not sign a wage contract that included a reduction to 70 cents an hour for a 44-hour week and $1 an hour for overtime from the present scale of 85 cents and $1.20.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (AP). -- A diplomatic correspondence between Russian and Manchukuo authorities relating to the ownership of certain locomotives used on the Chinese Eastern Railway was made public here today, and in the documents was a reiteration of the Russian claim to ownership of that line.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The theoretical use of mustard gas sprayed by planes on enemy concentrations, and a simulated barrage laid down with a new type of toxic smoke shells along the entire front enabled the First Division to withdraw from endangered positions late this afternoon and re-form its line of defense in the tactical battle now raging in New Jersey to save New York and Philadelphia from an invading "Red" army.

Miss Julia P. Farnham, daughter of Mrs. Paulding Farnham of 1 West Sixty-seventh Street, who is a noted sculptor, was married to Acting Captain James P. Meehan of the mounted division of the city police on July 30, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK., N.J., Sept. 15. -- TWO New York gunmen, identified by the police as remnants of the Vincent Coll gang, were killed here early this morning by a hail of gang bullets on Meeker Avenue, a well-lighted connecting thoroughfare, while bystanders fled and motorists ducked in terror.

Under a continuation of the selling movement that has been under way a week, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke $1 a bale yesterday, making a loss of more than 2 cents a pound from the level prevailing when the government's crop estimate appeared.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 15. -- A prediction that the United States was about to enter into a new liberalism was made here tonight by Governor Roosevelt in an informal speech to a hundred Colorado party leaders at a dinner in the Brown Palace Hotel.

GENEVA, Sept. 15. -- The Disarmament Conference Bureau thus far has received no notification of Germany's intention to withdraw, but in view of recent official utterances the receipt of such notification would cause no surprise.
TOKYO, Sept. 15. -- The compensation that Japan gains in return for her past sacrifices and future re-

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Indians pounded Durham and Weiland for twelve hits, two of them home runs by Kamni and Cissell, to win their eighteenth game of the season from the Red Sox today, 7 to 2. Besides his home run, Kamm collected a triple, a single and a base on balls for a perfect day at bat.

More than 3,000 persons, including representatives of State and municipal governments, railroads and manufacturing interests, are expected to attend the dedication today of the Port Authority's new Union Inland Freight Terminal occupying the block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets.

A plan for modifying the original contract for a proposed merger of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation and the Armour Fertilizer Works will be submitted to the directors of the former company, It was announced yesterday by John R. Miller Jr., chairman of a committee sponsoring the merger.

ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- Dormant accounts in savings banks in the State now total between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000, it was revealed today in a bulletin published by the Secretary of State. The names of several thousand depositors are listed and more will be given in the October issue.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The surplus of German exports over imports in August was 97,000,000 marks [a mark is worth 23.78 cents]. The volume of exports was about the same as in July, although there ought to have been an increase because of seasonal influences.

The Japanese Government proceeded yesterday to carry out its announced purpose to recognize the "independent State" of Manchukuo, carved out of Chinese territory. In the protocol signed when recognition of this new Government was extended by Japan, with consummate gravity, there are the usual expressions found in treaties of offensive and defensive alliance.

BUTLER, Pa., Sept. 15. -- Mayor Charles H. Kline of Pittsburgh walked out of court a free man today when Judge Thomas D. Finletter threw out his conviction by a Butler County jury on a malfeasance charge in the purchase of city supplies.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- A moment after 33,000 marks [about $8,000] in currency, part of the weekly payroll of the Berlin Street Car Company, had been loaded into an automobile at a bank in the Berliner-strasse, the most-frequented street in the suburb of Charlottenburg, at 8.30 this morning, three men stepped from a handsome limousine near by, opened fire on the four men guarding the money, grabbed the canvas bags containing it and sped away.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- The stock market today was unable to continue with the recovery organized yesterday by bullish elements. Following weakness in Wall Street yesterday, there was a break here and prices generally slid downward, wiping out most of yesterday's gains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- A tremendous business in cash wheat has been under way recently and export sales and the country movement have commenced to overshadow all other influences on the Board of Trade here. It is estimated that in the last four days European and other buyers, including Chinese, have taken around 10,000,000 bushels of Canadian wheat, the largest aggregate trade in cash grain in several years.

Melvin Ott's thirty-sixth circuit clout of the waning campaign tied a number of things in the final clash of the year between the Giants and Cuba at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It momentarily put Master Melvin on even terms with Chuck Klein of the Phillies in their duel for the National League's home-run title and it dead-locked the ball game in the last half of the ninth.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The victory of Miss Joan Ridley of England, seeded No. 1 player, over Miss Florence LeBoutillier of Westbury featured the quarter-finals today in the women's annual invitation tennis tournament on the Ardsley club's turf courts, as all four members of the seeded list gained the singles semi-finals, scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.

The Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., a Mellon-controlled organization, has made a contract with Soviet Russia to exchange aluminum wire for crude oil, and shipments of crude oil are already being made from a Black Sea port to Montreal, it was revealed here yesterday.

Mr. Hoover Loses 5,000,000 Families. Governor ROOSEVELT may now point out that Mr. HOOVER, not satisfied with the vast multitude of Forgotten Men already on his conscience, proceeded on Wednesday to forget no leas than 20,000,000 additional men, women and chidren.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 15. -- T. Henry Clarkson of Lido, the defending champion, shared the lead with B.T. Alien of Wheatley Hills today with a score of 86 at the half-way mark of the fourth annual thirty-six hole tournament for the Lone Island Golf Association's senior championship at the Lakeville Country Club.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Willing Spencer has left the Savoy-Plaza for Newport, where she will pass the remainder of this month with Mrs. John Thompson Spencer.
PARIS, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

ST. CHARLES, Ill., Sept. 15 (AP). -- While the frustrated spider looked on -- with raging eyes, as many witnesses attested -- Mayor I.G. Langum tonight freed a 10-inch garter snake that had been held prisoner in its web for twenty-five days.
Sales and leases of private dwellings and apartment houses featured the real estate market in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The 132 directors who will open the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks will be selected by the Home Loan Bank Board within a week, Franklin W. Fort, chairman, announced today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The first annual flower show of the White Plains and Central Westchester Horticultural Society and the Westchester section of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State was opened here tonight at the Playland Casino by State Senator Seabury C. Mastick of Pleasantville.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 15. -- Senator Borah said in a statement today that "it would have been far better for the standing and refutation of the Legion if it had postponed action" on the resolution demanding full cash payment of the bonus.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- President von Hindenburg's order calling for the training of German youth has been noted in France not only as another Illustration of what is called the systematic German method of breaking down the restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles but as evidence of the clearly-defined militaristic policy of the present government.

ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- The Department of Correction does not hold Warden Joseph H. Wilson responsible for the recent escape of Leon Kraemer from Great Meadow prison, Commissioner Thayer said today. He made a personal investigation at the prison the day alter the escape, he said.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15. -- The Berkshire Hunt and Country Club issued 300 invitations today for a "horse show" dance Saturday night. The seventh annual horse show will open at 2 P.M. tomorrow. It will be continued all day Saturday starting at 10 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- In the period from Jan. 1 to Aug. 31, 1932, the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment expended $237,984.72, with receipts of $249,357.52, according to its report, filed today with the Clerk of the House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A dresses today by President Hoover, Newton D. Baker, Walter S. Gifford and Survey D. Gibson at the sessions of the Welfare and Relief Mobilization Conference were as follows:

After a slight further decline, irregularly distributed, the stock market rose more sharply than on any recent day. It closed with few net losses, and with the day's net advances for active shares ranging from 2 to 4 points. In this action of prices, the market again conformed to its usual course in the secondary stage of readjustment during an aggressive "bear movement."

Negotiations for revision of the wage scale of the United Mine Workers of America slowed down yesterday because of the illness of John L. Lewis, union president, who was confined to his room in the Hotel Pennsylvania suffering an attack of indigestion.

There is almost no possibility of fee-splitting in workmen's compensation cases among physicians treating cases handled by private stock insurance companies and the practice is non-existent, James A. Beha, general manager of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, said yesterday.

Joseph E. Widener, president of the Westchester Racing Association, which conducts the sport at Belmont Park, and vice chairman of the stewards of The Jockey Club, announced yesterday at Belmont Park that he was retiring from steeple-chasing and that he would sell his jumpers in the paddock tomorrow.

NEWPORT, R.I. Sept. 15. -- There was a large attendance last night at the piano concert by Miksa Merson for the benefit of the milk fund of the Newport Overseers of the Poor and the Family Welfare Society in Rogers High School hire. Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, her sister, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, Mrs. Gibson Fahneatock, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander, Mrs. Vincent Astor were among the patrons.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 15 (AP). -- Mrs. Dorothea F. Livermore filed suit here today for a divorce on grounds of desertion from Jesse L. Livermore of New York and Chicago. Details of the desertion charge were not set forth in the complaint.

CLARKSBURG, W.Va., Sept. 15 (AP). -- Jovial and happy-go-lucky, Louis A. (Louie) Johnson, new national commander of the American Legion, conceals behind his "good-fellow" exterior a quick-thinking shrewdness that has made him one of the most prominent attorneys in his adopted State of West Virginia.

Exposure of a ring of drug thieves that has been supplying "illegitimate cosmetic-shops and deep cut-rate drug stores" to the detriment of reputable drug-store owners was promised yesterday by William Finkelstein, executive director and organizer of the American Federation of Pharmacists.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Isn't the prohibition controversy being waged on a wrong basis, with resultant confusion and irritation? It is degenerating into a wordy warfare between those who want liquor and those who demand that the Federal Government shall prevent them from having it.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 15. -- After keeping the country in feverish suspense all night, expecting an aerial bombardment of almost any city. Chile's mutinous aviation corps was captured early this morning while feasting in celebration of its coup.

The liner Haiti, under construction for the Colombian Steamship Company at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company, will he launched tomorrow in the presence of officials of the line and guests, including representatives of the Shipping Board and men prominent in shipbuilding circles.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan announced yesterday that he would not hand down a decision before early next week in the suit brought by Mayor McKee to test the validity of the Mayoralty election that Tammany seeks to hold this Fall.

To remove what it considers an unjustified impression that the theatrical unions are "responsible to a considerable degree for the present unhappy economic condition of the theatre," the Actors' Equity Association recommends in the current issue of its magazine, Equity, that all theatrical groups meet before "unbiased and independent advisers" to arrange better working conditions.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The Duke of Devonshire Trophy remained in the possession of the senior golfers of the United States as they continued their unbroken string of nine victories in the international series with the Canadian veteran team today at the Apawamis Club.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Ad Liska, new hurler for the Phillies, won his first game in the National League today as the Quakers defeated Cincinnati, 7 to 4, to sweep the three-game series here.

READING, Pa., Sept. 15. -- Lightharness racing marked by blanket finishes, with twelve mile heats covered in an average of 2:06 3/4, featured the Central Circuit classes at the Greater Reading Fair today.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 15. -- The contact commission, which held a meeting during the night, has reported that a way out of the difficulty over the Dutch shipping conflict has been found by adding together the votes of the Amsterdam and Rotterdam meeting of the striking seamen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May one who has long read, and usually approved, your editorial page test this long-standing friendship by pointing out a fundamental disagreement? Already you have been so fair and tolerant that your followers always expect from you a just conclusion.

Charges that James B. Fisher, real estate operator, of 160 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, resorted to "duress and Fraud" in the formation of the J.S. Graham-Fisher Holding Corporation are contained in a complaint filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court by James S. Graham of the Hotel Touraine, Brooklyn, who seeks dissolution of the corporation and an accounting of its affairs, it was learned yesterday.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday that he would seek an amendment to the city charter to abolish the Department of Sanitation and restore the control of street cleaning and sewage disposal to the Borough Presidents of Queens and Richmond and to the Street Cleaning Departments of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Scientists never weary of dwelling on the unselfishness of the Newtons, Faradays, Henrys and Dewars, whose discoveries, made solely to widen the frontiers of physics or chemistry, have founded new industries and great fortunes. "Here's "to science, may it always remain "pure," was the toast of a famous chemist at a time when even laboratory workers knew their wines.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE CRANDE. Sept. 15. -- Former Mayor Walker recovered sufficiently today from the attack of indigestion that seized him yesterday to make his first appearance in the dining saloon since Tuesday, and also to toll in a sun bath chair between 4 and 5 P.M.

Under the auspices of the Mexican Chamber of Commerce of New York a dance was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt by members of the Mexican Patriotic Committee to celebrate the 122d anniversary of the independence of Mexico.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15. -- Harvard's football preparations started with a rush today. In the morning ninety-five players reported, every one hand-picked. That was at 10 o'clock.

Despite the vicissitudes of the unemployment insurance schemes in European countries no intelligent business man or socially minded person wants to abolish the system, declared Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Old Age Security, on his return on the Olympic yesterday from Europe, where he spent four months in an investigation of social insurance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Opening the Welfare and Relief Mobilization Conference at the White House today, President Hoover laid down as the aim of the nation's leaders in relief activities that "no man, woman or child shall go hungry during the approaching Winter."

The tax-day financing operations of the United States Treasury, involving a book-credit and cash turnover of more than $2,000,000,000, were completed yesterday without any disturbance of the money market. For the second time on record the Treasury's cash receipts and disbursements were so nicely balanced that no overdraft at the Federal Reserve Bank was needed, and at the end of the day the Treasury had a credit balance with the bank.

With plans for the intensified campaign for the re-election of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis beginning to take form, it was learned last night that the Republican leaders expect former President Coolidge to deliver at least one address on a major topic in the East for the party-ticket.
LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The last day for Britain to ask partial postponement of her debt payments to the United States slipped by today without any action being taken.

HAVANA, Sept. 15. -- Thirty tendors totaling approximately $2,500,000 of sugar stabilisation bonds, known set the Chadbourno bonds, were made today by holders to the Chase National Bank as trustee in response to advertised bids for the surrender of $1,200,000 of the securities for amortization.
Mayor McKee said yesterday at the afternoon press conference that he would consider John. H. Delaney his adviser on transit matters, a position Mr. Delaney held during the Walker Administration.

GENEVA, Sept. 15. -- While Japan was signing in Changchun a treaty recognizing the new State of Manchukuo, she was asking in Geneva that the League of Nations Council delay examination of the Lytton report on whether the present situation in Manchuria, or Manchukuo, had been achieved by violation of the League covenant and the Kellogg-Briand peace pact.
Analyzing steel consumption since the World War, The Iron Age reports that demand has been "tapering," but that the "fact has not generally been apprehended."

CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 15 (Canadian Press). -- Dissatisfied with the present price of wheat, Alberta farmers are holding their product off the market, selling only when money is required to pay debts, it was announced by the Alberta wheat poof today.

The decrease in August of 246,952 shares in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange was paralleled by a corresponding decline in the "in-and-out" daily short sales, according to the monthly bulletin of the Exchange.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Yale's football squad registered, ninety-two tonight after the first day of practice, devoted to three hours in the morning and two in the afternoon.

Mr. DANIEL F. FIELD, chairman of the Maine State Republican Committee, treated the Maine election in the ancient and proper way. National issues were not involved in it. The result was due to "local conflicts and rivalries." Representative TILSON was also faithful to the old school.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Sept. 115. -- The ceremony of the signing here today of the protocol according to Manchukuo de jure recognition by Japan was marked by subtle Oriental insistences upon Japanese precedence, which in Oriental eyes places Manchukuo virtually in the rank of a vassal State.

HOLLYWOOD,. Sept. 15 (AP). -- Jesse L. Lasky, pioneer movie executive of Hollywood, announced his resignation today from Paramount-Publix Corporation after eighteen years of service as first vice president, in charge of production.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Hoover Administration's program in dealing with "the most stupendous problems ever encountered by any government" is defended, and its results praised in the Republican campaign textbook for 1932, made public today by the party's national committee.

When Mayor MCKEE speaks of some of the new city departments as being "so overloaded with man"power that they almost sink of "their own weight" he aims a telling blow not only at the budget but at his predecessor. When Mayor WALKER took office he promised to overhaul the municipal government.

Federal agents continued raiding cordial stores yesterday, extending their activities well into the night to bring the total of the day's forays past the 100 mark, and revisiting some of the shops raided on Wednesday in an effort to keep them closed.

A softer market for Street loans, which went at 1 1/4 per cent, compared with 1 1/2 and 1 3/2 recently, was the only development to distinguish an otherwise quiet money market Stork Exchange call loans at 2 and period money 1 1/4 1 1/2 ruled again. Business money was likewise unchanged.

Ray Starr, a tall, slender right-handed pitcher from the Cardinals' Rochester farm, got his first major-league start at Ebbets Field yesterday and covered himself with glory and the Dodgers with chagrin.

Contracts for the renting of space In business buildings played a large part in real estate trading throughout the metropolitan area yesterday. This type of activity shared with apartment leasing in making up the bulk of trading.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15. -- The men oric career of Johnny Fischer, elongated University of Michigan junior, in national golf affairs was brought to a halt today, but it took the best golf that Francis Ouimet, the defending champion, had in his bag to do it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Senator Brookhart of Iowa, who will run independently on an anti-Hoover ticket, in a statement today attacked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for making a large loan to the Chicago bank of which Charles G. Dawes, former chairman of the corporation, is president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission received to timony today that the Associated Gas and Electric Company of New York had made profits of several million dollars by selling to associated concerns the right to collect fees from its subsidiaries for various services.

How war-weary stokers fomented between-decks sedition in the German Navy and led a mutiny which blazed into nation-wide revolution is told in "Death of a Fleet," by Paul Schubert and Langhorne Gibson, just published by Coward-McCann.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Coach Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler, beginning his first season, as head of Princeton's football activities, sent a squad of seventy Tiger gridiron candidates through two three-hour practice sessions on University Field today in the initial pre-season drill.

The Architectural League gave a dinner last night at its clubhouse, 115 East Fortieth Street, in honor of Charles A. Platt, president of the American Academy in Rome, and J. Monroe Hewlett, architect and mural painter, recently elected director of the academy.

ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- Definite progress has been made by Congress toward meeting the alms of labor, Senator Wagner told the State convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen tonight. He warned his hearers, however, that the merit alone of many measures sought was not sufficient to insure their final acceptance and urged that no effort be spared to support them.

Bonds of domestic corporations averaged slightly lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange, while United States Government issues and leading foreign loans were regularly higher. Trading approximated only $10,000,000, of which corporation issues accounted for $6,586,000.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 15 (AP). -- The approximate amount that would be paid veterans in each State, if the American Legion Bonus demand is met, Representative Wright Patman gave as follows:

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, will hold conversations here with a number of up-State party leaders in preparation for the State convention to be held at Buffalo on Oct. 3, it was learned last night.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15. -- The announcement today that Price Brothers Co., Ltd., had reduced their price on newsprint to their United States customers by $5.50 a ton caused little surprise in trade circles here, it being understood that various concessions had already been made.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Polo's annual championship for boys went to the Juniors at the Meadow Brook Club today when this team won the round robin for the Thorne Memorial Cup, played each season by boys under 21 years of age.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- Hermann Goering, as president of the defunct Reichstag, instituted libel proceedings today against Chancellor Franz von Papen because of the latter's accusation that Herr Goering acted unconstitutionally Monday when he refused to recognize the Chancellor's presentation of a decree of dissolution and ordered the vote that registered lack of confidence in the government.
LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Mahatma Gandhi will be released from the Yeroda jail at Poona as soon as he begins his hunger strike, it was announced officially today.

Delegates to the convention of the United Textile Workers of America, representing upward of 50,000 members, adopted a resolution yesterday "condemning in a most forceful manner" the expulsion of the bonus expeditionary force from Washington. The action was taken after Edward J. Meany, president of the District Council of Textile Workers of Philadelphia, a member of the executive committee of the B.E.F., had described the eviction of the ex-soldiers.

Justice William E. Morris of the Second Municipal Court in the Bronx was accused yesterday of not allowing the introduction of evidence and of premature Judgments by Matthew Levy as the latter withdrew as attorney for tenants of the Sholem Aleichem Apartments, 3,451 Giles Place, where a rent strike is being held by most of the 212 tenants.
CHUSCHILL, Man., Sept. 15. -- The only theatre in this most-northerly Canadian port was dark as a polar night today, after the management had struggled for a year to keep it going.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Vernon Gomez set out for his twenty-fifth seasonal victory today, but the things that happened to him aroused a deal of trepidation in the Yankee ranks, considering that within a short fortnight the slim southpaw ace is scheduled for his first world's series test.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Buzz Arlett's fifty-third home run of the year with two on base in the first inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a lead over Albany which was never overcome in today's game. The Orioles won, 7 to 3.

A gain of $16,783,000 in the gold stocks of the country was reported yesterday as a result principally of the release from earmarking by the Bank of France of $16,393,200 in connection with the redemption by the Paris-Lyons-Mediteranean Railroad Company of its 7 per cent bonds.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The National Democratic Club golf team conquered the National Republican Club, 38 to 12, at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Max Klipper resold to Herman Spingarn the four three-story brick taxpayers on a plot 76 by 100 feet at 197-203 Monticello Avenue, northwest corner of Jewetts Avenue, Jersey City. The seller, as mortgagee, acquired the buildings last Wednesday Under foreclosure of a mortgage made by Samuel L. Hirschberg on June 29, 1929, on which $63,038.51 was due.

The members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force who fled to Johnstown, Pa., after being driven out of Washington, formed "pretty much a cross-section of the citizenry of the whole country" and many of them "came out of backgrounds of refinement," according to an official report made public here yesterday by Amos R.E. Pinchot, brother of the Governor of Pennsylvania.

Captain Mousey Dinger, who has piloted the Elsie II about the waters of Fire, Island Lightship for many years, taking out part lee which returned with big catches, never has had a great deal of time to do any fishing on his own account, and he always has had the urge to show some of the other experts just how fish should be caught.
PARIS, Sept. 15. -- The bill for the conversion of about 85,000,000,000 francs [about $3,400,000,000] in French Government bonds will go before the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow afternoon.

As plaintiff in a partition sale Mary D. Gerard bid in the five-story building at 581-83 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-seventh Street. The sale was conducted by Henry Brady, auctioneer, the bid being $625,000. The action was brought against the Bankers Trust Company and James W. Gerard, executors and trustees of the late Marcus Daly.

The safety valve of the steamer Observation was found yesterday by a diver in the East River off 134th Street, where the boat was destroyed by an explosion a week ago with the loss of seventy-one lives. The valve was turned over to Federal and county investigators.

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were somewhat larger than in the preceding week, reports received by R.G. Dun Co. show that the decline from the corresponding period last year was substantially greater than was recorded the week ended on the previous Wednesday.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP). -- Strands of a woman's hair, found in Plymouth Harbor Tuesday entangled about a boat's mooring line, today brought the case of Mrs. Edith DuBois closer to being one of this State's most sensational disappearance cases.
In the collegiate scheme of extra-curricula activity the sophomore finds his metier in laying down the law and making life reasonably miserable for the lowly freshman.

For twenty years Representative CRISP, son of a former Speaker, has been a distinguished member from Georgia. It is the usual ambition of a Representative to be translated to the six-year tenure of the Senate. Upon the death last Spring of Senator HARRIS, Mr, CRISP avowed that ambition.

Commodity prices hardened yesterday after several days of unsettlement. The forward movement carried the grains up from a fraction to a full cent, while cotton was 3 points higher to 2 points lower. Strength was also evident in other sections of the markets.

GENEVA, Sept. 15. -- League of Nations officials have learned, from what they obviously consider a reliable source, that Bolivia in the past two years purchased $15,000,000 worth of arms in Great Britain. They are now taking a gloomier view of the Chaco conflict, especially since they recall that Bolivia during the same period bought $5,000,000 worth of arms in the United States, paying with money borrowed in the United States with Washington's approval.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Calumet Author, Henry Seaman's bay gelding by Belwin, won the Garden City Stake today after Why Not, the Riverhead trotter, had defeated him in the first heat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- An audit of another Insull corporation, the Mississippi Valley Utilities Investment Company, was filed today in the United States District Court. It was sent there by Eugene V.R. Thayer, receiver of the company, upon the order of Judge Walter C. Lindley.

Victorious candidates from Maine will be on display in the Democratic National Committee's show window in the Roosevelt campaign, which now has entered upon its active stage. Governor-elect Louis J. Brann, according to announcement last night at the Biltmore headquarters of the committee, will make his first appearance at a rally in Newark, N.J., tomorrow afternoon.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 15. -- Lieutenant Donald L. Truesdale of the Nicaraguan National Guard, a corporal in the United States Marine Corps to whom the Congressional Medal was awarded recently for exceptional heroism while serving with the Guard, was decorated with the Cross of Valor, Nicaragua's highest award, by President Moncada today.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., Sept. 15. -- For almost two hours this afternoon it appeared that Brig. Gen. Oscar Westover, acting chief of the army Air Corps, en route here from Washington by "airplane, had either met with an accident or had become lost in a heavy fog.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 15. -- Undaunted by a shortage of campaign funds, President Hoover moved forward today with plans for a more vigorous drive for re-election.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. In the subjoined comparative table all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

The railroads serving New York filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission tariffs for door-delivery in accordance with the plan recently announced. The service will cover Manhattan to 181st Street, the Bronx to 177th Street, Tremont Avenue and the Bronx River and south or west of these points; Brooklyn and Queens and seventy-five points in near-by New Jersey.

Morris Hillquit, national chairman of the Socialist party and one of the organization's outstanding figures, was unanimously nominated as the party's candidate for Mayor in the elections this Fall at the Socialist city convention, held last night at the People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

PRAGUE, Sept. 15. -- Czech Nationalist propaganda against Leon Trotsky's proposed visit to the Pistyan Spa apparently has been suecessful. Czech legionaires declare that M. Trotsky was a murderer of their comrades as the Soviet Commissar for War in that during the Russian civil war he sent telegraphic instructions to Soviet troops that all Czech legionaires caught under arms should be shot out of hand.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Speeches on causes, cures and ills of the current depression occupied the attention of three trade association conventions here today.

THERE were thirty-two qualifiers for the matchplay rounds of the national amateur golf championship at Five Farms and the geographic representation was worth noting, just for the sake of argument. The football season Is at hand and those reticent, bashful, modest Californians will probably have a few hesitant words to say about the poor, unfortunate, bedraggled, pale, anemic, hopeless and helpless little fellows who live Way Down East and can't play football a little bit.

FLYING COLORS, a revue in two acts. Words and music by Howard Dietz and Arthur Schwartz, Settings prepared and lighting arranged by Norman Bel Geddes; dances, and ensembles staged by Albertina Hasch; costumes designed by Constance Ripley; directed by Mr. Dietz; produced by Max Gordon.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- British Government funds made further headway on the Stock Exchange today on good Investment demand, particularly for the conversion issues. Elsewhere the markets were irregular because of failure of Wall Street to maintain early firmness yesterday, although there was some improvement here in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- President Hoover appealed today to private banking interests to furnish temporary financial aid to stock men and farmers during the current cattle moving and crop season until the new agricultural credit organization of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation could be brought fully into play.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 15. -- Immediate payment of the bonus in full was demanded by the American Legion by the overwhelming vote of 1,167 to 109 at the closing session of its annual convention here today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 16 -- Tommy Paul, regarded by the National Boxing Association of the United States as world's featherweight champion, was defeated tonight in a ten-round bout by Alberta (Babe) Arizmendi in the presence of 20,000 fans at Mexico City's big bull ring.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Speaking at a special luncheon meeting of the Westchester County Bar Association held here today in celebreation of the 145th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States, Dr. Jacob Gouid Schurman of Bedford, former president of Cornell University and former Ambassador to Germany, made a plea for a new era of liberalism in the government of this country.

The richest day's racing in America, and probably in the world, will be staged today at Belmont Park when the Futurity, the Jockey Club Gold Cup and the Grand National Steeplechase will be contested, in addition to three other events, closing the Fall meeting at this track.
READING, Pa., Sept. 16 -- Myles S. Weston of Newark, N.J., and Harry C. Corbin, the Reading horseman, divided the honors in the Central Circuit competition at the Greater Reading Fair today.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 -- Duquesne University's football team opened its 1932 season under the lights at Forbes Field tonight, defeating Westminster, 20 to 0.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 16 -- The nation was urged by Secretary Hyde today in dedicating a statue of Abraham Lincoln here to turn in these trying times to the faith and ideals of the martyred President.

Export Groups May Merge. Reports of the consolidation of export trade groups were revived in trade circles here this week with the American Manufacturers' Export Association and the National Foreign Trade Council named as the two organizations likely to merge.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Sept. 16 -- The will of James W. Johnson of Bernardsville, president of Johnson Johnson of New Brunswick, who died at sea on Sept. 1, was filed for probate yesterday. Mrs. Caroline Kay Johnson receives all the household and personal effects, the home in Bernardsville and $400,000. Public bequests are:

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- With the Reichstag dissolved and the political situation in abeyance pending the outcome of the election, the Cabinet has settled down to its practical work along the lines forecast in the seizure of Prussia by the Reich and the economic reconstruction program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The receivership audit of the Middle West Utilities Company, a holding concern in which the public invested $265,000,000 and the largest unit in the Insull public utility organization, was filed today in the United States District Court.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The record of Chancellor von Papen in the United States during the World War, when his recall was requested by the American Government for his activities while Military Attache of the German Embassy, was cast into the political broll here last night by Joseph Goebbels, lieutenant of Adolf Hitler.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Head Coach Howard G. Cann confined today's practice of the New York University football squad to a single workout for the first time since the group reported on Sept. 7. The drill, held in the afternoon, consisted of kicking, passing, line bucking and a signal session.

ROOSEVELT SPECIAL, CHEYENNE, Wyo., Sept, 16 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt said today that he would make "a little trip into the Middle West" after the Pacific Coast journey. It is understood that he will visit St. Louis and the "border" and Southern States on his second trip, which will start about the middle of October.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Rochester and Toronto divided their final games of the season today, each winning by 3 to 1.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- Foreign Minister von Neurath received Ambassador Francois-Poncet of Franca today and informed him the German Government did not intend to send another note to France on equality of armaments in reply to the recent French note.

Straw Votes as Guides. Newspaper men are so accustomed to be cited as prime examples of human ignorance, error, haste, superficiality and general worthlessness, that any opinion headed in the opposite direction is received in newspaper offices, first, with astonishment, then with curiosity, and only after that with a flash of gratitude in soft brown eyes.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 16 -- Former Mayor Walker of New York was in fetter health and spirits today, which he attributes to drinking a glass of red wine and smoking a cigarette after dinner last night, in accordance with his doctor's orders.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Al Simmons's thirty-third home run was the big punch in Lefty Grove's twenty-fourth victory, when the Athletics defeated the St. Louis Browns today, 3 to 2.

That the name of W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, may be brought before the Republican State Convention at Buffalo on Oct. 3 as a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination was regarded as possible, following a secret conference of Mr. Macy and a group of up-State party leaders held to discuss convention preliminaries.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 -- A continuous downpour drove Harvard's varsity football squad into the Briggs cage for its second practice session of the season today.

Forging ahead with his economy drive, Mayor Joseph V. McKee swung the axe yesterday on two sources of extravagance, and from a third quarter received an offer of voluntary salary reduction which he said would amount to $30,000,000 a year if all city employes would adopt the same course.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- The United States senior golf team had to be content today to share honors in the international triangular matches that brought them into competition with the representatives of Great Britain and Canada.

Never did a sweeter thought form in the brain of former Senator HENRY ALLEN, the rejected of Kansas, than the poll, now under way, of the 30,545 persons recorded in the new "Who's Who." He must have gone on the theory that most of the prosperous and distinguished are or ought to be or have been Republicans.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Mississippi's general gales tax has been accepted by the State's citizens with little quibbling, and is expected to be the means of pulling the Commonwealth out of a financial quagmire. State officials declare.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- The prospetctive continuance of the present Cabinet, entailing the complete divorce of Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, from his former post as Ambassador to London with a resulting vacancy there, has hastened the general shifting of German diplomatic representatives that has been impending for some time.

Confronted with the necessity of collecting a considerably larger campaign fund than had been contemplated in advance of the party defeat in Maine on Monday, campaign finances have been the topic of discussion at three conferences held this week at the WaldorfAstoria, Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee.

Establishment of a bona fide labor party whose candidates would not seek office on the ticket of either of the dominant political parties was declared to be the policy of the United Textile Workers yesterday at the closing session of its biennial convention.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 -- Three years ago Johnny Goodman of Omaha drove to California in a battered old car and gained nationwide prominence by defeating Bobby Jones, the defending champion, in the first round of the national amateur golf championship at Pebble Beach.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 15 -- President Mary E. Woolley of Mount Holyoke College, a United States delegate to the recent Geneva Disarmament Conference, said tonight that world public opinion was stronger than ever before for disarmament.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Whether there was a rooster at Fort McHenry during the bombardment by the British in 1814 has been a controversial matter for many years. Legend has it that a rooster, because of his happy crowing, made everybody feel a lot better during the battle.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The formation of the new national bank which General Charles G. Dawes and his associates are organizing to succeed the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company will be announced in a few days, according to well-founded reports in the financial district today.

William Woodward's Faireno, which clinched the 3-year-old championship last Saturday by a decisive Victory in the Lawrence Realization, will not be seen in action at Havre de Grace and probably not at other Maryland meetings in the near future because of an injury suffered in the running of the Realization.

Most people have supposed that the injection of religious prejudice into politics reached its most extreme form in the Presidential election of 1928. The array of secret forces, based upon appeals to ignorance, which was thrown against Governor SMITH simply because he was a Catholic, undoubtedly had a powerful if not a controlling influence in that campaign.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Vice Chancellor Alonzo B. Church of Newark, who was relieved of duty and salary last April following disclosures of a shortage in the accounts of Harry B. Hendricks, receiver appointed by Mr. Church for the Earl Radio Company, submitted his resignation to Chancellor Edwin Walker here today.

ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT SPECIAL, RAWLINS, Wyo., Sept. 16 -- Traveling all day through Wyoming, Governor Roosevelt this afternoon put the finishing touches on the railroad speech he will deliver tomorrow evening in the Mormon Tabernacle in Salt Lake City.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs took another stride toward clinching the National League pennant today by defeating the Phillies, 3 to 2, in a tight pitching duel between Bud Tinning and Eddie Holley while all the other National League clubs were idle.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Franklin H. Martin, director general of the American College of Surgeons, said here today that the college could announce next month that there are completed records of 1,100 cases, of cancer in the last five years that have been cured.
The seventh cooperative group exhibition at the Midtown Galleries, 559 Fifth Avenue, is now in progress. It will remain until the end of the month.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 16 -- The active South Shore campaign for Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney for Congress was opened this afternoon at the politically divided house of the Charles H. Sabins. Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was there to urge the candidate and the party on to greater things in Suffolk.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Twenty-eight Star Class yachts, one more than the record number last year, have been named for the international races starting tomorrow on Long Island Sound off the Pequot Yacht Club.

What was the first subway? The one which Mr. BELMONT built and Archbishop FARLEY blessed and Mayor MCCLELLAN opened in 1904? Oh, no! There had been a subway operating under Broadway thirty years before that, more than sixty years before people began riding in Mr. DELANEY'S new tubes.

New State and municipal bond issues to come up for award to banking houses next week aggregate $8,213,400, a sum well below the weekly average for the year to date, which is $19,403,499. This week's re-vised total was $17,564,057. The issues on next week's calendar are to meet requirements of forty communities throughout the country.

ATLANTA, Sept. 16 -- The Chattanooga Lookouts have won their first Southern Association pennant and Joe Engel, owner and president of the club, is being hailed as the man who manoeuvred the Lookouts into the championship and transformed Chattanooga into a red-hot baseball town.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 16 -- A series of upsets, which included the elimination of the medalist and two former winners of the tournament, marked the first two rounds of match play today in the Montclair Golf Club's sixth invitation tournament.

A cloud fell last night on the gay preparations for the annual "fiesta" held in Little Italy along Mulberry Street in honor of the feast of St. Gennaro. Mrs. Michelina Bucchia, 106 years old, and her husband, Frank, 104, will not play their accustomed leading parts in the celebration.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Racing to the front at the head of the stretch, Judge Lueders, from the stable of Ed Haughton, won an easy victory in the Momence Purse at Lincoln Fields today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Miss Muriel Bache Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lloyd Richards of 791 Park Avenue and Hazelmere, Great Neck, made her debut tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at the Turf and Field Club, Belmont Park.

Mayor McKEE has let it be well understood during the last few days that he is an organization man. He sent for JOHN MCCOOEY, the Brooklyn Democratic boss, to talk over the filling of a Vacancy on the magistrates' bench. Mr. MCCOOEY, be it noted, came to City Hall for the conference.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Identification by the French savant, Guillaume de Hevesy, of hieroglyphic script estimated to be 6,000 years old, which was found recently in India by Sir John Marshall, reveals that much of it corresponds exactly to inscriptions on tablets found on Easter Island off the Chilean coast.

GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- Germany formally refused to participate in the meeting of the disarmament conference bureau here next Wednesday in a letter to Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament Conference, received today and published textually.

BOMBAY, Sept. 16 -- Hopes of a compromise between the caste Hindus and the depressed classes have been raised by the more conciliatory attitude of Dr. B.M. Ambedkar, leader of the "untouchables." To a representative of The Times of India Dr. Ambedkar said today he was open to conviction and willing to conaider any proposal, although he would not allow the rights of the depressed classes to be curtailed.
DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Washington won the final game of the season with Detroit, 8 to 3, today and thereby secured an even break on the season's contests between the teams.

Trading was less active yesterday by 1,230,000 shares than on the day before. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,914,000 shares. The price movement was narrow. The only demonstration of strength was in the railway shares, which made a moderate advance.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Salaries of State employes may be slashed in the program of the Budget Advisory Committee, which has been studying the question of reducing the State expenses. The committee is expected to make public its recommendations about Dec. 1.

Various reasons were advanced yesterday to account for the $5.50-a-ton reduction in the cost of newsprint by Price Brothers Co., Ltd., one of the leading Canadian producers Overproduction and underconsumption, it was said, brought about an unhealthy condition in the market.

The price trend in commodity markets was irregular yesterday. Wheat closed up, but other foodstuffs were mixed. Cotton declined, as did print-cloths. Dairy products were firm. Rubber and hides declined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Charges that political capital was being made out of money available for the new Federal emergency building program were branded as "absolutely unwarranted by the facts" in a statement today by Ferry K. Heath, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, in charge of the building operations.

Those bluefish which invaded the well-known haunts of Great Kills, much to the joy of Staten Islanders and all those who fish in that locality, and then, after a stay of about a week or ten days, suddenly disappeared as if by magic, leaving all hands very pessimistic, have been located again.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- A forty-five-minute scrimmage featured the Princeton football squad's second day of pro-season practice today. Coach Crisler also sent his men through a two-hour morning drill despite a driving rain.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Activity in the wool market has slackened decidedly. Sales made during the week however, have been at prices fully equal to any previously made in the current upward movement; in fact, early in the week, fractional advances were secured on some medium grade wools, both greasy and scoured.

Courses of study in principles and clinical practice in the correction of speech disorders will be given throughout the year at Hunter College, City College, Fordham University and Brooklyn College, according to an announcement of the speech-improvement department of the Board of Education.

Delegates leaving the convention of the American Legion at Portland asserted yesterday that they are determined to "wage a peace-time fight for immediate payment of the cash bonus." Well, they must know, unless they are singularly dense to expressions of public opinion, that they will have a real fight on their hands.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Sept. 17 -- After a day of racking uncertainties occasioned by differences of opinion among Chinese leaders on methods of dealing with the crisis precipitated by Japan's recognition of Manchukuo, China last night finally dispatched its protests to Geneva and Japan and the other Nine-Power Treaty signatories.

A slight surplus and an increase in membership during the year were reported yesterday to the directors of the Audit Bureau of Circulation at a meeting of the board yesterday at the Hotel Astor, the last meeting prior to the annual meeting of the organization in Chicago in October.

The second annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association will be held today on the estate of the late John W. Sterling at Greenwich, Conn. The meeting of the association, which comprises the Millbrook Hunt, the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds, the Fairfield County Hunt Club, the Ox Ridge Hunt Club and the Watertown Hunt Club, is sanctioned by the Hunts Committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Syracuse Herald says members of the State Bridge Authority were prepared to oppose the attempts of a private corporation to obtain from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation funds for constructing a bridge connecting the Erie County mainland and Grand Island, in the Niagara River, and another from Grand Island to the Province of Ontario.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A party of five on a moonlight cruise in Upper Saranac Lake narrowly escaped drowning late last night when a thirty-foot craft piloted by Colonel John R. Dunlap of New York was rammed and sunk by another boat containing four young men.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Wall Street's rally yesterday as well as strength in the London metal market influenced favorably the stock market here today and the trend of prices generally was higher. Notable exceptions, however, to the improved tendency were the Banque de Paris, Lyonnaise des Eaux, Citroen and Pechiney, which moved lower.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Evening Bulletin today quotes Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, president of the National Economy League, as saying that immediate payment of the bonus, demanded yesterday at the national convention of the American Legion, will increase unemployment and continue the depression.
OMAHA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Slight, towheaded Johnny Goodman, who went to Five Farms to "shoot the works," was the toast of his home town tonight.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- The Soviet press devotes much space to Japan's recognition of Manchukuo but studiously refrains from comment, and even the headlines are strictly non-committal. The newspaper Pravda features cabled messages from New York and Tokyo stressing the asserted tension of American-Japanese relations.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Thred women patients at the Longview Hospital for the Insane died today because, Superintendent E.A. Baber said, a nurse misread an anesthetic formula.

When Governor ROOSEVELT set out on his Western journey the Republicans piously hoped that somewhere he would stub his toe. The trip is not yet half over, but there has been no toe-stubbing. On the contrary, the Democratic nominee has borne himself well.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 16 -- Former Yale guards and centres tonight were guests of the Yale Athletic Association in the first of three informal gatherings at Mory's Club to discuss football strategy as related to the middle of the line.

Uncertainty in the movement of prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday indicated that Wall Street was continuing to appraise critically the trend in general business. The share market was highly irregular, but it did not move out of a limited field.

These orders were issued yesterday: Baseball Notice. The Fire Commissioner and the Chief of Department are most anxious that the showing of the Fire Department be 100 per cent in the sale of tickets for the baseball game between the teams of the Police and Fire Departments, to be held at the Yankee Stadium for the benefit of the unemployed and needy.

The New York Stock Exchange has received the following notices of proposals: From the Sparks-Withington Company to reduce capital $252,561 by retiring 12,850 Treasury shares of common stock. A further reduction in outstanding shares from $4,445,222 to $2,251,685 has also been proposed.

Jerome Dresen, 30 years old, a millinery worker of 2,070 Sixty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was shot and fatally wounded yesterday morning in front of 661 Broadway, where he was picketing the Sally Hat Company against which a strike had been called by Local 42 of the Millinery Workers' Union.

Coach Lou Little ordered only one workout yesterday for the Columbia football team at Baker Field, rain canceling the morning session. The afternoon drill lasted three hours and Little drove the candidates at a fast pace.

Democratic leaders at Roosevelt headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore branded yesterday as an attempt to intimidate workers a campaign which has been begun by the National Association of Manufacturers to inform industrial workers throughout the country with regard to the benefits, from their viewpoint, of the protective tariff.

Despite the downward trend of savings-bank deposits which set in a few months ago, depositors in mutual savings banks in New York State have $67,624,382 more in savings than they had a year ago, according to the report for Sept. 1 issued yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- An arrangement for supervising the use of funds left in a will to seventeen residents of this city by Thomas Dunn of St. Louis was disclosed here today. The will, which disposes of an estate valued at more than $3,500,000 among forty-five heirs in various parts of the country, included the appointment of Miss Etta Manley, a niece of Mr. Dunn, to inspect the accounts and investments of the heirs.

The new $16,000,000 inland freight terminal at Fifteenth Street and Ninth Avenue, formally dedicated yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, was characterized as "a public benefaction" extending the principles of the postal service to merchandise by Governor Roosevelt, who paused in his swing around the country to send his congratulations to all those who had part in its construction.

BUFFALO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- After winning seven straight games, the Bisons bowed to the Montreal Royals today, 7 to 5, in the final of the three-game series. The Royals scored twice with two out in the ninth to win for Leo Mangum. Hits by Conlan and Paiement accounted for the runs.

That new tower rising in the neighborhood of Van Cortlandt Park, among the spires and minarets of the Manhattan skyline, marks the rearing of another football citadel in the process of becoming Father Knickerbocker's fourth major power on the gridiron.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 16 -- Lowering of the interest rates on the foreign debts of the Danubian countries was declared indispensable in a report drafted today for the financial committee of the Danubian conference here by the Swiss senior delegate, Herr Bachmann.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Making his first appearance in a show ring, Pi-Et-Ro of Cedar, owned by Mrs. Olivia Cedar of Pelham, N.Y., captured the highest honors today in the specialty show of the Brussels Griffon Club of America, held on the grounds of the Catawba Farm of Mrs. James Madison Austin.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- John H. Forsman conquered Dr. Thomas J. Conte, 3 and 2, and gained the final bracket in the New York A.C.'s annual golf tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today. The victor is a round ahead of the field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An enlightening service by THE NEW YORK TIMES is the airing of the bonus controversy. As an ex-service man and a member of the American Legion, I have a distinct recollection of the circumstances under which the adjusted service certificates were awarded and accepted by the beneficiaries.

One hundred and twenty-five years ago Thomas Lipps started making keys by hand in a little shop on William Street, near Liberty, and repairing the ponderous locks used by merchants of New York in those days. His business as locksmith passed through the family, and yesterday the firm, now known as Lipps, the Locksmith, observed the 125th anniversary of its founding at its present quarters, 206 Pearl Street.

With the seasonal upturn in business now in process, many lines are beginning to operate at the best levels of the year to date, according to the weekly reviews of trade and industry. The reviews report also that while the general level still continues below that of a year ago, some lines, notably the textiles, are running ahead of that period.

Following a rally of $1 a bale on Thursday, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday gained 10 points more in the morning trading, but hedging operations then sent quotations slowly downward to close at losses of 17 to 21 points.

The Anall Stable's Larranaga made it five in a row yesterday when he splashed over a sloppy track and through a driving rain at Belmont Park to take the sixty-third running of the historic Jerome Handicap, one of the oldest tests in the country for 3-year-olds.
