PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Officials of the Federal Seaboard Terra Cotta Corporation, with plants in this city, Woodbridge and South Amboy, announced today the receipt of the largest order in the terra-cotta industry in many years. The order is for the interior terra cotta for the new building of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Determined to avoid market forecasts and analyses of a political nature, the New York Stock Exchange has requested its member firms to file with it all telegraphic communications sent or received by them dealing in any way with political topics between Sept. 12 and Sept. 15, inclusive.

An explanation of the unexpected rise of $62,000,000 in brokers' loans in the week ended on Wednesday, when stock and bond prices were falling, was supplied yesterday by bankers who said the movement was connected with the government bond market rather than with the stock market.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 16 -- Re-created in the image of its great past, Raleigh Tavern, where royal Governors of Virginia danced and dined, where patriots led by George Washington, Patrick Henry and George Mason met and made history, was opened today as an exhibition building in the restoration of Colonial Williamsburg.

Senator RICHARDS, Republican majority leader, is responding gallantly to Governor MOORE'S invitation to all departments and agencies to cooperate with him in reducing salaries and trimming away unnecessary offices in New Jersey. But Mr. RICHARDS calls for "an even break."

ROME, Sept. 16 -- A general decrease of about 1 per cent in the interest rate on all deposits will be applied throughout Italy beginning Oct. 1 as a result of an agreement reached among all Italian banks and savings banks.

Shippers in Massachusetts and Connecticut lent their support yesterday to the Seatrain Lines, Inc., in the contest before the Interstate Commerce Commission, which centres about the rates which the Seatrain company plans to announce Oct. 6 for its new water-rail service between New York and New Orleans, via Havana.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The stock market generally was cheerful today, encouraged by the improvement yesterday in Wall Street. British funds advanced in brisk investment buying. Industrials showed a number of strong features, with a rise in Dunlop Rubber outstanding.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Responsibility for placing copies of Secretary Hurley's statement on "bonus marchers in Washington" before delegates to the American Legion national convention here yesterday was accepted today by Brig. Gen. Joseph P. O'Nell, retired, a friend of Mr. Hurley.

LONG BEACH, Gal., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Establishment of a five-day week for printers on newspapers operating on a six or seven-day schedule was voted by the International Typographical Union in convention here today, subject to referendum vote by unions of the international organization.

Closing of the city's Summer schools by the Board of Education next year would Result in a loss to the city of $890,000, in the opinion of Frederick Houk Law, president of the High School Teachers Association, who made a plea yesterday for the continuance of the Summer schools in letters to city and school officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- El Lagarto, winner of last year's President's Cup race, captured the first heat of the 1932 race on the Potomac today, defeating the two boats of Horace Dodge, Delphine IV and Delphine V. The second and third heats will be run tomorrow.

OUT in the hills of New Jersey there is a little, round man who would be king of the heavyweights, and nobody can blame him, because the position pays well. It was showering gold when Jack Dempsey was champion, and Jack was under a rainspout catching his share in a wash-boiler. Gene Tunney was paid almost a cool million for thirty minutes of exercise one evening by the shore of Lake Michigan.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roberts are giving a musicale tomorrow night at their home in Greenwich.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. WARROAD, Minn., Sept. 16 -- The cosmic rays are more intense near the poles than near the Equator, and their intensity increases continuously with altitude up to 19,000 feet. Additional details regarding the properties of these rays will be available when the reports of our nine associated expeditions working in as many parts of the world are brought together and digested.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Charges that the St. Louis San Francisco Railroad was "bled white" and was "unscrupulously divested of working capital in the common stockholders' thirst for dividends" were made in a brief filed in Federal court today by petitioners in the pending receivership suit against the railroad.

Pronounced completely recovered from the brief siege of illness that caused him to hurry home from Detroit last week with the fear of being stricken with an attack of appendicitis, Babe Ruth will start working out at the Stadium today in order to whip himself into shape for the coming world's series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A renewal of confidence in Germany, the United Kingdom, France and the Netherlands, contrasting generally with a continued low level of industry and trade, was reported, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly summary of the business situation abroad.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -- Encouraging increases in employment in the construction and manufacturing industries of California are reported by the State Labor Commissioner.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Sioux City and Woodbury County authorities worked secretly tonight on plans to clear near-by highways of farm holiday pickets after State military aid was refused them by Governor Dan Turner.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- "A little experimentation" in the liberalization of the anti-trust laws was advocated here today by Gilbert Montague, a lawyer, of New York City, as a movement that "might do much to relieve economic distress and unemployment."

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day high schools in the subjects indicated be issued as of the dates indicated to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and requirements therefor.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Former Governor Edward C. Stokes, chairman of the board of the FirstMechanics National Bank of Trenton, was named by the Republican State Committee today as chairman of a campaign committee to conduct the light in New Jersey for President Hoover and the party's candidates for the United States Senate, the House of Representatives and the State Legislature.

The Rev. James E. Kearney, pastor of the Church of St. Francis Xavier, the Bronx, will be consecrated Bishop of the Diocese of Salt Lake, Utah, in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Friday morning, Oct. 28. The day is the Feast of St. Simon and St. Jude. Father Kearney has named Bishop by Pope Pius XI early last July.

R. Stanley Dollar, president of the Dollar Line and of the United States Lines Company, returned from Europe yesterday on the United States liner Leviathan with an optimistic view on future conditions in shipping. He said as far as his com- pany was concerned he was well satisfied with present conditions, and added that business seemed to be improving.

Reports current last night concerning the possibility of Surrogate James A. Foley being pushed as a Mayoralty candidate this Fall were taken in political circles as the first evidence of activity on the part of the group in Tammany, headed by Edward J. Abearn, against the Curry-Walker regime.

FREDERICK, Md., Sept. 16 (AP) -- The memory of Roger Brook Taney, former Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court and author of the famous Dred Scott decision, will be honored tomorrow with the unveiling of a bust of the famous jurist at his former residence here.
PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 16 -- Graphic stories of fierce battering by storm of the steamship Manhattan on her second trip across the Atlantic were told when it reached Plymouth today.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 16 -- A few minutes after obtaining here today a decree of divorce from Jesse L. Livermore, New York stock market operator, on grounds of desertion, the former Dorothea Fox Wendt was married to Walter Longcope of New York City.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 16 -- T. Henry Clarkson of Lido, the defending titleholder, and F. Mack Fisher of Old Westbury were deadlocked today with scores of 178 after the second and final eighteen-hole round of the fourth annual Long Island Golf Association's seniors' golf championship at the Lakeville Country Club.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Laurence Tyson, a Congregational minister since 1925, who had been a leader of the Modernist wing during his twenty-eight years in the Episcopal Church, died yesterday of double pneumonia in St. Luke's Hospital after a week's illness.
The Italian liner Augustus will sail for Meiterranean ports today. Those booked include:

LA PAZ. Sept. 16 -- Demands for the immediate air bombardment of Asuncion, the capital, and other cities of Paraguay were made by crowds parading the streets of La Paz tonight after the official announcement that Paraguayan troops were bayoneting Bolivian prisoners and shooting Red cross stretcher-bearers who attempted to rescue wounded Bolivians in the fighting at Fort Boqueron.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Relief loans to the States of Arkansas and Montana, $502,000 to the former and $300,000 to the latter, were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The money is estimated as sufficient to meet the excess relief requirements of the two States for the rest of the year.

PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 17 -- The Chamber of Deputies at a special session lasting until 5 o'clock this morning passed the government's rente-conversion bill by a vote of 540 to 48. The measure, which it is hoped will pass the Senate in time to become effective before the Bourse opens Monday, affects 85,692,000,000 francs (about $3,427,680,000) in government bonds and other obligations.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Delaware River Joint Commission, meeting with representatives of three New York banking concerns today, unanimously rejected an offer of the banks to buy $15,000,000 of the $32,000,000 bond issue to reimburse the States of New Jersey and Pennsylvania for sums advanced for the construction of the Delaware River Bridge from Philadelphia to Camden with a ninety-day option on the remainder.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt in a statement issued by the Executive office tonight extended his New Year greetings to the Jewish residents of the State for the approaching Rosh ha-Shanah.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The interest of George Eastman in the movement to establish the thirteen-month calendar will be carried on with funds provided from his estate by the University of Rochester, chief beneficiary, in accordance with his wishes.

Applying the mandatory provisions of the veterans preference law, which gives preferment to veterans who can show some record of disability, Police Commissioner Mulrooney promoted yesterday to the rank of captain, Police Lieutenant Thomas F. Berkery, who has served with the Police Department for nineteen years, with the exception of a year's service with the navy during the war.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 16 -- An increase of more than 2 per cent in factory employment in Pennsylvania and gains of nearly 5 per cent in payrolls in August, compared with July, were reported today by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, which compiled data from 813 manufacturing plants employing about 216,000 workers with total weekly wage earnings exceeding $3,000,000.

A Federal investigation into the ownership and control of hundreds of cordial stores, where liquor is sold openly at prices below those quoted in speakeasies, was ordered yesterday by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney. At the same time agents of Prohibition Administrator Andrew McCampbell continued their drive against shops of this kind, bringing to close to 300 the number of raids in three days.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The Yankees finished their year's baseball bookings for the South Side of Chicago with an extremely easy 4-to-1 triumph today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The members of the Home Loan Bank Board were principally occupied today with the task of selecting 132 directors who will open the twelve home loan banks on Oct. 15. They expect to complete the task within a week.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Sept. 16 -- The severest earthquake since the 1931 disaster shook Poverty Bay, forty miles north of Hawke Bay, at 1:30 A.M. today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16 -- Miss Lucy Alien, daughter of Commander and Mrs. Archer M.R. Alien; Mrs. William A. Glassford, wife of Captain Glassford, United States Navy, and Commander Edmund S.R. Brandt were among those whose portraits were put on exhibition at the Art Association quarters this afternoon by Christine Tuck Curtiss.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Miss Mary Averell Harriman Rumsey, daughter of Mrs. Charles Carey Rumsey of Sands Point and the late Mr. Rumsey, was introduced to society tonight at a unique costume ball given by her mother. It was attended by almost 1,000 of the younger set and about seventy married couples from Long Island, Newport, Westchester and New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Illness knows no moratorium and in times of depression the number of the needy sick is correspondingly increased. Particularly sad is the plight of cancer sufferers, for, owing to their condition, they are unable to maintain themselves and constitute a grievous burden to themselves and their families or become public charges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A more cheerful view of the prospects for financing the Republican campaign was given to President Hoover late today by Joseph R. Nutt, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, who attributed the altered outlook to the recent Democratic Victories in Maine.

The National Economy League, of which Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd is president, and Archibald B. Roosevelt, secretary, attacked immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus on three grounds, in a statement issued yesterday by Mr. Roosevelt.

The American worker, on a production basis, is the poorest paid in the world, surpassing even the Chinese coolie, long the symbolic victim of economic oppression,who, in comparison, is richly rewarded for what he produces, according to a report on the energy survey of North America, made public at Columbia University yesterday.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- Manchukuo is still without accurately defined frontiers because of the great stretches of its western boundary that never have been properly delimited, but for practical purposes the new State has adopted the boundaries of the former Manchurian Government's administrative area as recognized by the Chinese Nationalist Government.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Boston Red sox won their fourth game of the year from the Cleveland Indians today, 6 to 2, in the final game between the two teams. The Indians won eighteen games from the Red Sox and took the series just concluded, two out of three.

HAVANA, Sept. 16 -- Extension until July 1, 1933, of the 700,000-ton sugar pool formed by Presidential decree on July 1, 1932, in an effort to bolster sugar prices was approved today by the Sugar Institute.

Seven men arrested Thursday night in a second-floor apartment at 47 St. Nicholas Avenue, where the police found more than $50,000 worth of loot which they said represented the proceeds of 150 burglaries in Harlem and the upper west side, were held without bail in West Side Court yesterday for hearing Wednesday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Duovac Radio Corporation of New York filed a suit in Federal District Court here today charging violation of the Clayton anti-monopoly act and the Sherman anti-trust laws on the part of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Western Electric Company, Inc., and the Electrical Research Products, Inc., Delaware corporations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The United States plans to retain her consuls in Manchuria indefinitely and have them deal informally with Manchukuo authorities when necessary in attending to American rights and interests. The consuls are accredited to China and will legally continue in that status.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Speaker Garner, ruddy with health and jubilant, wearing what he called a "Maina smile," reached the capital today after appearing with Governor Roosevelt at Topeka. He said that enthusiasm in the West, with normal Republican States 3 to 2 in favor of the Democratic ticket, justified him in claiming a Democratic victory in November by a 10,000,000 majority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Thomas H. Monro or Syracuse, chairman of the Council of Agritultural Markets in New York State, invited Governor Roosevelt today to seek a solution of the problem of the 73,000 milk producers of his own State before promising to "solve the surplus problems of the wheat and corn farmers."

The Professor or Economics who proposes to establish a temporary college where unemployed teachers and impecunious students can come together to mutual advantage has distinguished precedent. When ABELARD, by the favor of King Louis the Fat, was granted a desert place, in the territory of Troyes in France, he built in the fields "an oratory."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Exports and imports of the United States registered in August the first upturn since March, making a favorable trade balance of $18,000,000, as compared with an unfavorable balance of $1,871,000 for the same month last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- While the State's Attorney's office was starting today an investigation of the affairs of the Insull companies, an examination, of the auditors reports filed with the Federal court disclosed, in the opinion of statisticians reputedly versed in insolvency matters, that the receivers are "reasonably certain" to salvage "several hundred millions" for investors out of the properties.

THE conflict that has been going on in Soviet Russia between two factions of composers, one representing the young or the proletarian group and the other the old or the conservative group, has finally been concluded by an edict from the central committee of the Communist party at the instigation of Stalin.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31, 1932. ARGENTINA has had an opportunity during the last ten days of learning that there exists an American music having nothing in common with jazz, which in recent years hag become the popular South American conception of American music.
LONDON, Ont., Sept. 17 (Canadian Press). -- C. Ross Somerville, aptly called "Silent Sandy," was the mosttalked-about young man tonight in London particularly and Canada generally.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 17. -- A five-million-dollar shipbuilding program neared completion today when the steamer Haiti, second vessel to be built by the Colombian Steamship Lines, was launched from the plant of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

MIDTOWN Galleries -- Seventh group exhibition. Upon the whole a very creditable showing, in which Bertram Goodman, William Palmer, Dorothy Eaton, George Shellhase and Robert Stewart make a particularly strong impression.

Considering the tone of the brokerage-house comment following the political upset in Maine, a censorious attitude on the part of the Stock Exchange seemed to Wall Street to be entirely justified. Ordinarily the Exchange is not squeamish about political matters.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22. -- The current controversy between Wang Chingwei and Marshal Chang Hsueh-liang, the resignations of Ministers at the heads of all departments of the Chinese Government and the bitter disunity among the Chinese leaders has occasioned extreme pessimism among most of the foreigners living in this country.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- Peter Q. Light, owned by W.H. Wright, won the Chestnut Hill two-mile steeplechase, one of the feature events in the Wissahickon Farms Fall Hunts meet, which opened today.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 17. -- Facing a double-edged attack from wet Democrats on the one hand and a mixture of dry Republicans and Democrats on the other, former United States Senator James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo is facing a fight for the Thirty-ninth district seat in the House that, home opinion holds, may result in a Republican defeat for the first time in years.

MR. GREEN'S previous work for the theatre has colored a little this embittered story of the South. It is a tale not of the present generation but of a time some thirty or forty years ago when old and worn-out families still remembered vividly their prosperity in the days before the war -- and still living in memories of the past, had not yet been able to readjust themselves to changed conditions.

AMSTERDAM. IN an excellent biographical novel, "Jan Steen" (published by de Spieghel, Amsterdam), C.J. Kelk has written the life of one of the greatest Dutch masters, built up from material gathered in historic documents and from episodes portrayed in his pictures.

STRANGE to relate Reggie Fortune does not appear in this latest detective story by H.C. Bailey. Instead we have a new character bearing the euphonious name of Joshua Clunk, who is as different from his predecessor as a cabbage is from a rose.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 17. -- New York University's Team A repulsed Team B, 25 to 6, in a regular football game today, which marked the final day of intensive practice at the Violet training camp. Virtually every member of the squad participated in the contest.

MOUNT EVEREST, the earth's highest mountain, is to be assailed by climbers again, and much sooner than mountaineers have expected. Dispatches from London say the attempt is planned for next year. When the last expedition turned away in 1924, it was believed that many years, perhaps generations, might pass before another scaling party would be allowed to approach the great Himalayan peak.

HOLLYWOOD. RADIO may become an interesting adjunct to the screen. The cinema for some months has listened to radio continuities with an appraising ear in the hope that out of it all might come an idea that could be photographed.

RECENTLY in the window of a shop dealing with old things -- a veritable shop, not a "shoppe" -- appeared a small antique object, if sixty years or so constitute antiquity. It was a bank for pennies, shaped as the seated figure of a man.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 17. -- John E. Parker Jr., Yale golf captain, won the Montclair Golf Club's Sixth Annual Invitation Tournament today, defeating Jarvis Hicks Jr. of Hewlett, brother of Miss Helen Hicks, women's national champion, 4 and 3.

Sales of new Chevrolet cars and trucks in the first ten days of September were 8,529, an increase of more than 10 per cent compared with the total of 7,688 in the corresponding period of August, it was announced yesterday by H.J. Klinger, vice president and general sales manager of the Chevrolet Motor Company.

When Autumn came rustling across the landscape it was once the fashion to weep for the Summer that was no more. Tears from the depths of some divine despair stained the lines written tenderly indoors. For those who dwell in the sunshine, however, it is difficult to mourn the birth of any season.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16. -- There has been a striking change in the past few months in the Soviet attitude on world affairs. Instead of an outcry about an imminent war upon the "Socialist fatherland" by a capitalist coalition as a "unique issue of the world economic crisis," the Soviet press now gives dispassionate judgments on foreign events.

NOWADAYS when even the most sophisticated of highbrows no longer feels it necessary to dissemble his genuine, even if only occasional, enjoyment of crime literature, the makers of books in which murder or some other major offense against the law provides the main interest must do very much more than construct an intricate puzzle to engage the reader's wits.

With the remainder of the Republican State ticket still in doubt, Colonel William J. Donovan, who has made an aggressive pre-convention campaign, now appears to be the probable Republican nominee for Governor. This was the most concrete result of the secret conference between W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, and a group of party leaders from up-State, which came to a close yesterday.

TODAY. 1:00 P.M. -- WEAF -- Selections from the operatic works of Mozart and Wagner are included in this one hour and a half symphony concert under Erno Rapee's direction. The program opens with the overture to Mozart's opera "The Marriage of Figaro," followed by "Artist's Life," by Strauss; Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique" symphony; Liszt's "Les Preludes," and closes with Wagner's "Rienzi."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Chinese Government in its note to the United States protesting against the recognition by Japan of Manchukuo requests, in the name of the Nine-Power treaty, "that such measures be taken as will properly and effectively deal with the state of affairs brought about by Japan's acts of aggression in China."

Wets and drys contending for Congressional nominations in up-State localities will be an outstanding feature at Tuesday's primary election. The prohibition question also will figure in some primary contests over nominations for the Legislature.

LONDON. THE centenary of Sir Walter Scott's death has been celebrated now in England and Scotland for some six months, and one fact concerning it becomes increasingly clear: Namely, that in spite of two admirable new lives, many eloquent articles, pageants, dinners, speeches, exhibitions and letters to the press, there is a deep gulf fixed in this matter, a gulf that cannot apparently be crossed, a gulf between the young and the old.

The 145th anniversary of the adoption of the Federal Constitution on Sept. 17, 1787, by the convention in Philadelphia was marked here yesterday with military ceremony, patriotic addresses and calls to defend the Constitution from "enemies without and within," with a few references to the Eighteenth Amendment as a "stranger within the constitutional gates.

Every fisherman has his own ideas about how to catch fish, of course, and while most of them will agree in general, they disagree on the application of many of the theories, and there are plenty in the art of catching fish. But whenever some inventive mind discovers a successful means of luring a fish onto a hook he will be followed, if only he will make known his find.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- The British view of the German demand for equality in armaments was communicated today to the French Ambassador in London and transmitted by him late this evening to the Foreign Office here. After examining it Premier Herriot will decide whether he will go to Geneva for the meeting of the disarmament conference bureau or entrust the defense of the French position to War Minister Paul-Boncour.
PALO ALTO, Cal., Sept. 17. -- Stanford University opened its 1932 football season today by defeating the San Francisco Olympic Club, 6 to 0.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- One year ago Sunday Japan seized Mukden and the Sino-Japanese conflict began. One year Monday Japan solemnly assured the League of Nations Council it had taken "all possible measures to insure that this local incident will not lead to any more serious complications."

AMERICAN manufacturers of musical instruments read with interest of the recent multiplication by ten of the German tariff on saxophones. The exportation of saxophones to Germany will be unlikely to improve in the face of such a tariff, according to some American makers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Charles Cummings, a jewelry salesman who had boarded with Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. DuBois at their Tuckahoe home and had been missing since their tragic deaths, has set at rest reports that he might also be dead by telephoning to District Attorney Frank H. Coyne of Westchester County.

Advisory committees to act as mediators in the adjustment of debt burdens on real estate and to attempt to avoid the costly drain on values involved in foreclosures have teen set up by a number of realty boards in various parts of the country, points out the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17. -- The Question of the reappointment of Frank J. Tappen as deputy chief of the Nassau County Police Department would be an outstanding issue in the forthcoming Fall election, it was admitted by leaders of both major parties here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial in THE TIMES recently, reference was made to "Tirnan-og," "The Land of the Ever Young." Very few people outside of Ireland know that an opera was written based on that mythological heaven.

A week of reaction ended on the Stock Exchange yesterday in an uneventful market. As had been the case on several days, since the full force of selling pressure seemed to have spent itself, prices rose fractionally at the start but lost the advance before the closing.

MORNING ROUND. Hole 1, 424 Yards, Par 4. Goodman, with the honor, drove nicely 220 yards down the middle. Somerville half-topped his tee shot and then faded a spoon twenty-five yards short of the green. Johnny topped his second completely, the ball rolling barely 100 yards.

BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- The Reichstag election probably will take place Nov. 6. That date has been proposed to President von Hindenburg by the von Papen Cabinet, and the President is expected to accept it, whereupon Baron von Gayl, the Minister of the Interior, will set the official machinery in motion.

AFTER an apathetic Summer, the Presidential campaign of 1932 at last is under way. "Swinging around the circle," as the old political phrase expresses it, goes Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the Democratic candidate, so that the people from whom he is asking election to the office of the nation's Chief Magistrate may both see and bear him.

IT is easy to see that Bob Brown is a great humanitarian. Nothing but his love of mankind and his devotion to the foaming beer-pot has prompted him to bring the two together between the covers of a sturdy book. Although his writing looks a little boozy at times, it has an honest ring and an elegance of diction.

BERLIN. THE strongest political group in Germany, that of the Nazis, is more like an army than a political party. It expresses its emotions and aspirations principally by drilling and inarching and demonstrating. Even its leaders' orations and the pamphlets issued by its intellectual general staff have a military savor.

That the statistical position of the petroleum industry during July, although not so poor as indicated by the figures, was, nevertheless weak for that time of the year, is the conclusion drawn by William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from reports issued by the United States Bureau of Mines.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Winning the title of best in show for the sixteenth time, Champion Lone Eagle of Earlsmoor, the wire-haired fox terrier owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City, dominated the annual Tuxedo Kennel Club show held today on the Horse Show Grounds for the benefit of the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Lou Gregory of the Millrose A. A., New York, national six-mile champion and Olympic runner, romped home an easy winner in the feature fourmile special held at the Hinchcliffe City Stadium today in conjunction with the dedication of the new athletic field.

SALZBURG. WITH the performances of "Das Jungste Gericht," Margarete Wallmann reaches her third season as producer of dance dramas in the Salzburg festivals, and for her abililty to establish the dance in its large forms in such excellent society she is entitled to great credit.

A slight increase in Fall schedules over quotas planned two months ago, more decided expansion in budgets for 1933 and a restoration of longer-term planning were seen as major developments in the advertising field, following the recently improved tone in general business, by leading agencies interviewed here during the week.

ONCE more Germany is preparing for a major election, the fifth since last March. She has had in that short time two Presidential elections, one ballot for important State governments and a general poll for members of the Reichstag.
FOGELSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 17. -- Following is the text of the address of Vice President Curtis here today:

Following the grand finale of the motor-boat racing season at Bay City, Mich., where the national outboard championships will be held on Oct. 7, 8 and 9, with contestants from Maine to California, there will be a trek here for the rule-making to apply next year.

THE recent rise in commodity prices may, if continued, reverse a trend which has held without serious interruption for the past decade -- a decline in the cost of living. According to a recent survey by the United States Department of Labor, the prices of the necessities of life -- food, clothing, rents, fuel and light, and house furnishings -- have now dropped to where they were about fifteen years ago.

In a shot-putting exhibition that called for as much haste as finesse, since he had to catch a Boston-bound airplane, Leo Sexton of the New York A.C., the Olympic shot-putting champion, broke three world's records at the 129th track and field meet of the Winged Foot organization in its picturesque Travers Island setting yesterday.

AT last this admirable volume, already in its seventh German edition, has been translated into English and thus made available for many who might otherwise never have profited by its profound and searching analysis of certain basic principles in painting, sculpture and architecture as viewed in the light of historical development.
Under the heaviest Saturday trading in several years, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued downward yesterday and ended with losses of 32 to 35 points.

NOW comes Fall with its brisk weather to create another set of problems for the motorist. These problems, relating to such matters as safe driving and economical operation of the car, are not so acute as those which Winter will bring, but they merit attention nevertheless.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7. -- The eruption in the Andes last April, which, strewed volcanic ash over Buenos Aires and Montevideo, threw out more than 10,500,000,000 cubic yards of stone, sand and ash, or more than two cubic miles of volcanic material, according to estimates by a commission of scientists from the Argentine National Museum of Natural History.

BY taking measurements of 100,000 doughboys upon their return from the World War statisticians were able, with the help of a sculptor, to robot into being the mythical Average Man. There he stands (placed on view a few weeks ago) in a modest corner of the Museum of Natural History, and constituting one of the magnetic attractions of the Department of Eugenics.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- The Alsatian Senator Eccard today gave the Journal des Debats, for publication, the following letter that he had received from Dr. Nagelschmidt, a German citizen, concerning the status of Alsace and Lorraine:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17. -- Newton D. Baker suggested today the advisability of making two changes in the Federal Constitution, one to provide for party responsibility in the conduct of the government and the other to facilitate the conduct of international affairs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Looking at the taxicab industry from the public's standpoint, there are far too many cabs in proportion to the available riders. This oversupply has eliminated the profit and accentuated the traffic problem. Some of the driving is reckless.

Several problems of operation of the new union inland freight terminal, dedicated by the Port of New York Authority on Friday, await settlement in the next two weeks by a committee of railroad men who will direct the terminal's activities under an agreement with the Port Authority.

Mayor McKee will begin tomorrow a drive against objectionable burlesque shows by informing theatre owners that their licenses will not be renewed unless they remove offensive features of their productions, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Prime Minister MacDonald and his Cabinet Ministers began this week to reconsider their disarmament proposals of last July, which they hoped had disposed of the subject for a long time.

ELMIRA, Sept. 17. -- The contest between Representative Gale H. Stalker of this city, seeking renomination, and W. Sterling Cole Bath, an attorney, is being waged with increasing bitterness. Mr. Cole's campaign committee, headed by the City Chamberlain, A. Marshall Lowman, son of former Senator Lowman, the Republican county boss, who is nominally supporting Stalker, have resorted to an extensive advertising campaign involving Mr. Stalker's political record as well as his business affairs.

Lieut. Col. Harold E. Bartney, veteran aviator, outlined in 1921 the airways of this continent, and most of them are as he foresaw. Today his vision is concentrated on air paths over the ocean. The key to his plan is radio, serving four-main safety functions.

With attention converged as it now is upon the question of trade recovery, the actual course of business seems at the moment to be regarded with somewhat mixed impressions. Gratification at signs of improvement from the recent very low level of activity is tempered with something of disappointment that revival is so slow.

BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- Business on the Boerse was quiet today owing to the week-end, which in recent years has so frequently brought unpleasant news for the stock market. Prices, however, advanced and, although the changes were slight, prices showed marked regularity.

THIS cars which the automobile shows of next year will present in gleaming array are no undergoing a merry-go-round of practical tests under the scrutiny of engineers and tell-tale scientific instruments.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 17. -- The second of a series of three races for the Samuel Riker Cups, sailed by the Knockabout class of the Rumson Country Club, was held over the Shrewsbury River course today, with Harry L. McMahon's Ariel the victor over Edward Feidler's Snail, winner of the first race last Saturday.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 17. -- The economic committee of the Stresa conference adopted today, with minor amendments, the report on measures necessary for economic rehabilitation of Central Europe, and on Monday will be ready to make its recommendations to the main conference.

After the running of the Futurity turf classic race yesterday afternoon at Belmont Park, two notable entertainments were given here and at Lido Beach, L.I. At the Central Park Casino a special diversion called the "Futurity Gala Dinner Dance" took place in settings suggestive of the race course.

"DOC'S" place has changed. It offers a bewildering array of stuff alien to a pharmacy, and his duties have multiplied as competition has increased. But the man behind the prescription counter is the same "Doc," minus the boiled shirt and lawn tie, your father and grandfather knew.

LA PAZ, Sept. 17. -- The Bolivian Chamber of Deputies this morning approved the public protest against the alleged killing of a Red Cross brigade and the alleged slaughter of Bolivian wounded by the Paraguayans at Fort Boqueron.

THE country bristles with monuments to our great men -- little great men and big. Just a few of the very greatest have left behind enduring monuments literally of their own building. These had the luck to live on the land and not in changing cities ever at the feverish business of burying the dead past in the striving present.

THIS is the time of year when new radio sets appear. New York usually witnesses a big exhibition called the RadioElectrical World's Fair, but not so this season. It is the first time since the frenzied show of 1921 that the new receivers have not been introduced to the public in a large auditorium, such as Madison Square Garden or the Grand Central Palace.

WHILE the poignant phrase "the forgotten man" has been heard with increasing frequency since last April, when Governor Roosevelt used it in a radio address, it owes its genesis to an older decade. Professor William Graham Sumner of Yale, a noted opponent of socialism and protectionism, coined the phrase nearly half a century ago in a little treatise called "What Social Classes Owe to Each Other."
Closing quotations for active issues not traded in on the Curb Exchange yesterday:

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio. ANTIOCH COLLEGE has undertaken to stimulate business in its way. Some of the faculty and trustees have incorporated the Mid-West Exchange, a central clearing house for commercial goods, to find a market for the unused resources of the college as well as to help thaw out the industries on which it depends for its program of alternating work and study.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Governor Roosevelt's farm relief program was criticized by Secretary Hyde today in a speech at the Hamilton Club.

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- When Bay State voters enter the polling booths to mark their ballots at the November election they will find themselves confronted not only with the names of a battalion of candidates but with a cohort of interrogation, points. The settlement of some of these matters belongs to the United States Government, others to the government of the Commonwealth, and yet others to local communities.

THE booming of guns and the roll of a warship are to be heard and seen in the Germar audible film "Kreuzer Emden," which is now attracting throng to the Hindenburg Theatre. In the page from the history of the last half of 1914 one is apt to pay more heed to that gentleman, of the sea, Captain von Mueller, skipper of the Emden, than to his officers and crew or any of his victims.

Football and golf teams will share the distinction of ushering in the 1932-33 school year of athletics competition on Saturday, for along with the initial schoolboy gridiron games of the campaign, the opening matches in the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high school Fall golf championship tournament are slated.

VIENNA, Sept. 16. -- The mid-European and Balkan countries are beginning to realize that not the wisest form of extravagance for spendthrift States is the creation of armies of bureaucrats. Retrenchment in the leaner years is almost impossible, for governments naturally are reluctant to set the cogs of an all-powerful State machine revolving against themselves by wholesale dismissals.

PARIS. ALL-DAY ensembles, meaning something to wear from morning until midnight, are now practically a couture classic. The new morning-and-afternoon ensembles are even more wearable, especially for the business woman, who cannot very well go to her office in the morning -- at any rate during the Winter -- in a sleeveless decollete bodice of a diaphanous fabric, even if it is hidden away under what appears to be a tailored wool jacket.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- In the more than, three years of the economic depression, the end of which economic writers, statisticians and statesmen now see approaching, business concerns here have gone bankrupt, the standard of living has declined alarmingly, fortunes have been lost and the State has been forced to distribute subsidies to private business and has assumed control of many of the biggest concerns.

VERY little known in the United States, if known at all, Phyllis Bentley, one of England's younger women writers, will surely challenge attention by her novel "Inheritance," a dramatic narrative of Yorkshire, fresh in its handling and powerful in characterization.

Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker gave a dance last night at Kenwood, their country home in Mount Kisco, WestChester County, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Marcia Anne Tucker. The party was in compliment also to Miss Susan Kean Cutler, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Cutler.

The Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club, which conducts racing at Aqueduct, will begin tomorrow with the running of the first of thirteen stakes which are down for decision during the twelve-day meeting. The session will be the second of the Fall season on Long Island and will be followed by that at Jamaica and another at the Empire City course in Yonkers.

Speculative interest abated yesterday to such an extent that transactions on the Stock Exchange were of less than normal Saturday proportions. The turnover was 724,000 shares, compared with 1,498,000 shares on the same day a week before.

MADRID, Sept. 17. -- One hundred and five members of the nobility and officers are aboard the steamship Espafia in Cadiz Harbor ready to sail for exile at Villa Cisneros, far down on the torrid African coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Delphine IV, Horace Dodge's Gold Cup winner, captured the President's Cup today, being the only boat sent to the starting line for the second heat of the motor-boat classic on the Potomac River.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Ralph Kress led the Chicago White Sox to a ten-inning victory over the Philadelphia Athletics today by a score of 5 to 4. After helping in the early innings with a home run, two singles and a walk, Kress opened the tenth with his fourth hit, was sacrificed to second and scored on Funk's double.

THE histories of eminent families often tell more than the biographies of eminent individuals. Mr. Pound in the present volume selects a family closely interwoven with some of the most dramatic phases of English history and which has both literally and figuratively left its name on the map of the United States.

Because many countries are unable to make cash payments for goods, barter is again assuming an important place in world trade. In foreign trade circles it is believed this form of transaction may become general until numerous nations are able to effect economic rehabilitation.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Two raids by the police here today on an alleged gambling house and a speakeasy netted twenty-two prisoners and several van loads of gambling paraphernalia. Two assistant District Attorneys, a squad of detectives and a score of deputy sheriffs took part in the raids and herded the customers of the places into patrol wagons.

The New York Stock Exchange, Richard Whitney, its president, and forty members of its governing committee, including Warren B. Nash, treasurer, were named defendants yesterday in a suit for triple damages of $21,000,000 filed in United States District Court by Pirnie Simons Co., Inc., brokerage firm of Springfield, Mass.

The nation stands in need of college graduates with trained minds, who have been taught to think accurately and competently on many subjects, rather than specialized technicians, Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, warden of St. Stephen's College, Annandale-on-Hudson, declares in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday at Columbia University.

THE Artists who will appear as soloists with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra are made known this week. Ernest Schelling will appear as piano soloist during Arturo Toscanini's regime on Oct. 20 and 21. Three first desk men of the orchestra will also play under Toscanini: Mishel Piastre, concertmaater, Nov. 10 and 11; Alfred Wallenstein, first 'cellist, March 23 and 24, and Remo Bolognini, assistant concertmaster, April 5 and 7.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17. -- S.W. Isaac and R.H. Helsel tied for the high-scratch cup at the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Each had a straight string of 50 targets. In the shoot-off Isaac broke 25 straight to triumph, Helsel carding 23. G.E. Mole won the high-handicap cup.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 17. -- Another civil war has broken out with startling abruptness, this time between the forces of Governor Han Fu-chu of Shantung and Liu Chen-nien, an independent satrap of the Chefoo area.

The railroad managements will extend to labor on Tuesday an opportunity to discuss the proposal for another lowering of wages in the same hind of atmosphere that resulted in the negotiations of last "Winter in Chicago bringing about a 10 per cent reduction in record time.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Paris sees, early in September, the brief passage of many of our well known compatriots, likewise British and Continental notabilities, who are headed homeward or gathering in new groups for the characteristic Autumn diversions. France has no early September holiday, such as Labor Day at home, to mark the transition from seashore to mountains.

EVERY so often through the Winter there is transient at the Murray Hill Hotel, usually in an inside room on the fifth floor, a small, fierce-eyed individual, of graying mustache and adequate age, tweedish clothing, Habig fedora, huge bent bamboo cane, and a German cavalry overcoat, made for him with belt and saddle-split by a military tailor in Wiesbaden.
BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- The Reichsbank statement as of Sept. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

For the first time in several weeks, local commodity markets were generally reactionary last week. Declines in cocoa, rubber, hides, silk, wool tops and silver were for the most part attributed to technical readjustments and to profit-taking. Coffee continued its upward trend, while sugar was irregular.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Effective pitching by Merritt Cain enabled the Baltimore Orioles to take the opening game of the series from the Newark Bears, 7 to 4, today. Cain held the invaders to two hits and shut them out until the seventh inning.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 21. -- A little more than two years ago the Chinese Government announced that it would abolish the tael, which is a purely figurative monetary unit. The promise was made and forgotten, but now once more the Nanking regime is undertaking to abolish the tael, and to do so in three months.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22. -- The Chinese press is filled with reports that General Chiang Kai-shek, in furtherance of supposed plans to institute a dictatorship, is organizing a "Brown Shirt" Fascist movement, somewhat like the Fascist Black Shirts of Italy.

WHEN Congress convenes this Winter one of the interesting bits of unfinished business which is likely to come for early attention is the so-called McNary bill. This bill was introduced in the Senate last Spring at the same time that a similar measure was introduced in the House by Representative Robert Grosser of Ohio.

A large delegation of real estate brokers is assured for the twentyeigth annual convention of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards which will be held on the steamer Monarch of Bermuda from Oct. 8 to 13. J. Irving Walsh, president of the association, reports that extensive plans are being made to make the meeting the most interesting in the history of the association.

IF a man named Horatio Alger had known Buddy and Vilma Ebsen, the brother-sister dancing team which is appearing in "Flying Colors," Mr. Gordon's new revue at the Imperial Theatre, he might have composed about them one of his inimitable sagas.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 17. -- By defeating an eleven of the veteran St. George Cricket Club, 119 -- 44, at Warinanco Park today, the Brooklyn Cricket Club tied the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton team in the annual championship series of the New York and New Jersey Cricket Association and these two teams will compete for the title in Bay Ridge tomorrow.

IN bookkeeper's slang," says Mr. Helm as he defines the purpose of his book in his opening chapter, "the expense account is known as the swindle sheet. That meaning is in mind in choosing the title for this book. For this is a tale of the world's greatest swindle sheet -- the expense account of the Senate of the United States."
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Mariana and Happy the Great, both trotting stars from the Newbrook Stables, carried off the honors in the matinee at Weequahic Park today.

WASHINGTON. WITH the establishment of the Colonial and George Washington Birthplace National Monuments in Virginia -- the first to commemorate historic events in the Yorktown, Williamsburg and Jamestown sections and the second to maintain the reconstructed birthplace of our first President -- further progress has been made in the program of the Federal Government to preserve interesting areas.

A new football season, facing more in the way of readjustment to conform with ruin changes than any other season since 1905, starts on Saturday with the opening games or the schedules of a good many colleges throughout the country.

THE latest production to engage the attention of the unhurried William Harris Jr. is "Spring Song," a play by Bella Spewack, who, with her husband, is responsible for "Clear All Wires!" newly installed at the Times Square Theatre.

ALMOST every one is interested in whales, mammals in the form of fish, most gigantic of living creatures. But to some "Moby Dick" was at once too complicated on its technical side and too mystical on its poetic. The whale was both an anatomical and a symbolical figure.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- Geneva just now is living up to her name of being a unique centre for getting a world viewpoint. Now the League of Nations Secretariat officials are returning from their vacations, many of them returning from their homelands.

SLACK as the new season is in point of new productions, it has already improved upon the season of a year ago. It has turned up one consistently amusing farce, "Here Today," by George Oppenheimer with the advice, counsel and consent of George S. Kaufman; and too recently for the august exigencies of Sunday journalism it has produced a racy newspaper satire entitled "Clear All Wires!" by Bella and Samuel Spewack.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The author of "Behind the Door of Delusion," quoted in THE TIMES, is right in saying that mental hospitals include among their patients sane people.

BUFFALO, Sept. 17. -- Opening the Republican national campaign in Western New York today, Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, praised the record of the Hoover Administration and Challenged Governor Roosevelt to declare for the Hoover reconstruction measures or define specifically a substitute program.

MANILA, Aug. 17. -- Minor legislation has little place in the current session of the Philippine Legislature. A few bills have gone into the hopper, it is true, but the attention, of the law-making body is riveted upon three measures. They are the salary standardization bill, the insular budget and the administrative reorganization plan.

An Indication that the Pennsylvania Railroad may have sold some of its Lehigh Valley Railroad stock is contained in a statement of investments as of July 31 made public yesterday by the trunk line. This shows that investments in other than affiliated companies were $77,964,389 on July 31, against $109,082,791 a year before, a decrease of $31,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Despite the new manufacturer' excise and stamp taxes, which went into effect on June 21, the Federal Government's deficit on Sept. 15 was $452,368,943 as compared with $467,306,898 on the same date a year ago, a comparatively small reduction, according to the latest Treasury figures.
The Moral Is, Claim Everything. Once upon a time a Candidate, feeling a bit love after a long, hard day at Headquarters, confided to his National Chairman that he was worried about Pennsylvania.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Wind as sharp as a whetted knife greeted the twenty-eight Star Class sloops today in their first international championship race on Long Island Sound off the Pequot Yacht Club. There was a 25-knot westerly blow, verging on the force of a gale at the outset, but which diminished somewhat, and with it a tumbling sea.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 15. -- The Farmers Holiday Association received plenty of sympathy from the conference of Corn Belt Governors and Governors' representatives at Sioux City, but little else except rather carefully guarded endorsement of the object of its strike, but not of the method.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 17. -- Ten minutes after the Conte Grande anchored in the harbor of Gibraltar today British newspaper men came aboard and entered former Mayor Walker's cabin before he was dressed. They wanted to know if he intended to run again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- President Hoover spent the entire day planning with two of his major political advisers the "renewed effort" which he has demanded for the remainder of his campaign for reelection.

The fifteen-round heavyweight battle between Max Schmeling, former world's champion, and Mickey Walker of Elizabeth, N.J., scheduled for Friday night in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City, yesterday was postponed for the second time because of a boil on the left arm of Walker.

IT was his good fortune, says Edward Bliss Reed, to come across Kele's "Christmas carolles newely Inprynted" in the Henry E. Huntington Library some years after it had disappeared from general knowledge. He reproduces it here in its entirety for the first time, describing it as the earliest and most important printed collection of English Christmas carols that has escaped destruction.

IN looking for a name for his new operetta, scheduled to have its premiere in Vienna, during the coming season, Fritz Kreisler ran across "Sissy," the pet name Applied to the ill-fated Empress Elizabeth of Austria during the period of her engagement to Kaiser Franz Josef.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it had approved a loan of $3,850,000 to the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company for the building of the Dotsero cut-off.
IN answer to numerous requests the Federal Radio Commission, through Acting Chairman H.A. Lafount, has issued a definition of political use of radio.

Never in history has a pageant of greater promise been presented than the assembling, begun again last week, of the school children, the high school pupils and college students of America for another year's tuition, chiefly at public expense. It is estimated that one person in every four is in the schools either as pupil or teacher.

BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- For the first time since German "tars" gave an exhibition of goose-stepping along Fifth Avenue during the Hudson-Fulton Centenary in 1909 a German man-of-war, albeit a humble one, will pay New York a friendly visit next month.

The "definite program" offered by the Socialist party, in its national State and city platform, was contrasted with the "known policies'' of the Republicans, the "political compromises" of the Democrats, the "irresponsibility and cynicism" of the Communists, and the "honest muddle-headedness of the so-called Khaki Shirts, in a speech by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, yesterday afternoon at the Rand School or Social Science, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

Orders to be issued tomorrow by Mayor Joseph V. McKee will deprive twenty-five department heads of their official cars, forbid storage of any city car in a private garage and restrict the cost of city-owned automobiles to not more than $3,000 each.

The national amateur squash racquets championship for 1933 will be held Feb. 11, 12 and 13 at Detroit and the national intercollegiate tournament will be staged March 10 and 11 on the new Payne Whitney Memorial Gymnasium courts at Yale.

AT the first Meeting of the last short-lived Reichstag -- the meeting which closed upon the remarkable spectacle of Clara Zetkin's harangue -- there were revealed all the elements which make the present political situation here so much of a problem.

TOKYO, Aug. 30. -- One of the most colossal tax-dodging scandals in Japanese records is about to end in insignificant fines, according to the vernacular newspapers, by arrangement between the Finance Department and the offending company.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15. -- Southern California with all its Iowa antecedents and religious background is sliding from grace. When a vice squad with an old-fashioned Keystone Comedy leader raids a Greek classic drama or a Main Street honkytonk, a blase public snickers and moves on to the latest in movie scandals.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Triumphing in interesting extra-set semi-final round matches, Miss Joan Ridley of England and Miss Alice Francis of Orange, N.J., seeded No. 1 and 2 respectively, today gained the singles final of the annual women's invitation tennis tournament on the Ardsley Club's turf courts.

HAROLD LLOYD, whose comedy "Movie Crazy" is at the Rialto, is one motion-picture star who can walk on the street without being mobbed. The reason is that, without his famous glassless spectacles, it is not easy to recognize the comedian.

BUFFALO, Sept. 15. -- When the State campaign of two years ago was opening, THE NEW YORK TIMES in editorial correspondence from this city called attention to the "growing tendency among Republicans as well as Democrats to look to the metropolis for men of sufficiently large calibre to fill the biggest offices."

Condemning the bonus as extravagantly wasteful, vitally unfair to the taxpayers and tending to lower the dignity and worth of military service to the country in war, Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, wartime commander of the Twenty-seventh Division, warned yesterday in a radio debate that any extension of the bonus would increase the cost of government, and the cost of government must come down or the country would be on the road to ruin.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 17. -- With a five-run attack in the first inning, the Yankees today removed most of the suspense concerning the opening battle of their league season's last Western series, defending their lead successfully to take a 6-to-4 decision from the sixth-place Browns.

Occupation of Manchuria by Japanese spelled the end of any hope for development of American or English trade in that market, M.C. Avis managing director of the Symou Sheldon Company, Ltd. Far East trading corporation, told THE TIMES yesterday.

THE Discovery of Europe" is in part a personal record of travel and experience, of enthusiasm, partialities and tastes. In this it resembles Mr. Cohen-Portheim's earlier book, "England, the Unknown Isle." But here, as before, the personal record is subordinate to a more ambitious purpose.

BERKELEY, Cal., Sept. 17. -- Victories over the California Aggies and the West Coast Navy by respective scores of 20 to 6 and 13 to 0 launched the University of California football team today on its 1932 season.

Public construction accounted for approximately three-fourths of the structural steel tonnage for which contracts have been awarded this year, according to the magazine Steel. Not since the World War has the Federal Government made such large expenditures for construction as in the last fiscal year, the magazine says, adding that the States also as a group probably never before spent as much money for improvements in a similar period.

FEW things could be contrived to give a more solid feeling of optimism for a major branch of aviation -- air transport -- than the first birthday party of the Pioneer Air Transport Operators' Association, held last Monday night at Newark Airport.

TWENTY-NINE dramas, ranging from Sophocles to Barrie, are scheduled for presentation by the Radio Guild this Fall and Winter. Beginning on Oct. 10 the ethereal productions will be advanced from Friday to Monday at the request of high school and college listeners.

As briefly mentioned in dispatches from Wellington, one of the important acts of the last session of the New Zealand Parliament was abolition of the system of compulsory arbitration of capital and labor disputes that had obtained in that country for many years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The inestimable value of being country born and bred was again impressed upon me by reading on the editorial page of THE TIMES Esther Hall Smith's delightful contribution and appreciation upon the subject and under the head of the "Art of Eating Outdoors."

The moyen-age silhouette with lowered waistline, introduced by Jean Patou and the most "startling" of all the features of the recent Paris openings, is not for general American acceptance immediately, Tobe, fashion and merchandising counselor to retail stores, says in her report prepared especially for THE TIMES, reviewing the influence of the couturiers on current Fall apparel.

Many pastors returned last week from their Summer vacations and all will again occupy their pulpits this morning. At least two churches will resume its evening worship. More Sunday schools will reopen for the Winter. Next Sunday will see more pastors back, and by Sunday, Oct. 2, the usual Winter schedule will be well under way.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 14. -- A combination of the fiery impatience of President Luis Sanchez Cerro and the propaganda of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance in the capitals of Latin America is isolating Peru in a manner that is compared to the position of Soviet Russia, in an editorial in The Panama American.

By general consent, even of its members, the Disarmament Conference at Geneva yielded only the most meager and disappointing results. The resolution adopted at its close, containing though it did many excellent proposals, was little more than a program to be passed on to the next meeting.

IT is going to be a Winter of opulent beauty, so far as clothes are concerned. Paris has decreed it, New York has set the stamp of its approval on the dictum. The past two weeks have been an orgy of openings, at which imported Paris fashions, designs and adaptations by American creators have been displayed.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 15. -- Special registration of voters in Louisville has been unusually heavy this month, indicating an interest in the coming Presidential campaign not exhibited in 1928. For the first time in years, the Democrats have run well ahead of the Republicans in their additional registration, though the latter still greatly outnumber their opponents in the permanent listing.

OUR material standard or living has, except for temporary setbacks, constantly risen higher and higher until there has come not only a realization that we can but a determination that we shall have democracy in prosperity as well as democracy in politics and education.

DUBLIN, Sept. 2. EXPERIENCE teaches that the failure of many authors to fulfill the promise contained in their first efforts makes it unsafe to venture any predictions when a new writer appears at the Abbey Theatre.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 17. -- Abandonment of enforcement by the Federal Government of the principle of competition, a relic of the anti-monopolistic crusades of the early part of the present century, was advocated as a solution of the railroad problem by Governor Roosevelt in a speech at the Mormon Tabernacle here tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Mrs. Frances P. Garvan's Jumping Jack, superbly ridden by the veteran amateur, Crawford Burton, today captured the Connecticut Cup, s grueling three-mile test over a treacherous timbered course.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15. -- The unusual spectacle of the Republican candi- date for United States Senator going beyond his own party platform and indorsing, in effect, the prohibition repeal plank of the Democrats is seen in the action of Henry W. Kiel, overwhelming choice of his party in the primary election last month, when he ran as a dripping wet.

Louis J. Brann, Democratic Governor-elect of the normally rock-ribbed Republican State of Maine came to this city yesterday to be hailed by party leaders and to rally crowds as the symbol of national victory on Nov. 8.

In addition to the usual Hat of apartment rentals on the east and west sides of Manhattan, brokers yesterday reported a number of leases in the Greenwich Village section. Washington Square and suburban apartment space also appeared to be in demand.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- The popular proverb has it that thunder deal the air. From this point of view it is not a bad thing, perhaps, the just now thunder is rolling around the horizon of politics in Europe. The international atmosphere will be clearer once the storm has blown itself out.

AT a depth of 3,000 feet Dr. Beebe's empty bathysphere, a spherical diving bell in which he intends to descend to a depth of half a mile off the south shore of Bermuda to study marine life, sprang a leak when tested last week.

Accompanied by Paul Krichell, the Yankee scout, and assisted by some eight or nine semi-pro players as well as Sergeant Dan Tierney of the New York Police Department nine, Babe Ruth donned a uniform for the first time since his hasty retreat from Detroit ten days ago in fear of an attack of appendicitis, and worked out for an hour at the Stadium yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- The first tabulation of returns from the postcard poll of the list of names in Who's Who shows President Hoover leading Governor Roosevelt by more than 3 to 1, according to Republican National Heaquarters.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 15. -- With the quadrennial elections drawing nearer, the political situation here is more complex and scrambled than it has been for many years. Party lines have been broken and re-formed in recent months, and there are at present strong indications of much independent voting on Nov. 8.

Alter requiring daily reports for a year from its members concerning the size of their customers' short positions in stocks, the New York Stock Exchange has announced that weekly reports will be sufficient in the future. It also announced that reports on "in-and-out" short transactions, or those in which a sale, is covered on the same day, would be discontinued.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 17. -- A fleet of seventy-two yachts took part today in the annual Fall regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, with winds of varying strength testing the skippers.

Indian Summer weather brought more than 500,000 visitors to Coney Island yesterday afternoon for the baby parade which is the annual feature of the resort's Mardi Gras celebration. They lined both sides of Surf Avenue from Ocean Parkway to West Twentieth Street and applauded the colorful floats and improvised conveyances in the parade.

The oil-electric locomotive provides an opportunity for the railroads to reduce operating costs to meet declines in revenues, G.H. Froebel, engineer of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said yesterday. He predicted that use of the new machine would bring "revolutionary changes" in railway operation and added that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation now was enabling railroads to make economy-realizing capital improvements.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17. -- Abraham Frank, general manager of the Ambassador Hotel here and vies president of the National Ambassador chain, died today in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital, where he had undergone an operation for a kidney malady.
CLAREMORE, Okla., Sept. 17 (AP). -- James A. Reed, former Senator from Missouri, asserted here today that President Hoover has established "capitalistic socialism" in the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent statements by Svetozov Pribitchevitch, former Minister in Yugoslavia and now residing in Paris and Prague, have received world-wide press comment to the extent that they call for refutation.

Despite opposition of the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, Justice Frankenthaler in the Supreme Court yesterday allowed the Madison Investing Company, Inc., to intervene as a defendant in an action brought by Thomas W. Lament, chairman of the committee, for the courts guidance in the distribution of $6,952,148 to holders of defaulted Mexican Government and railroad bonds.
GENEVA, Sept. 17. -- There were four significant moves in the Manchurian question here today, one by each of the parties involved -- Manchukuo, the League of Nations, China and Japan.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 17. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt announced today that he would stop for two hours Sept. 28 at McCook, Neb., on his return trip from the Pacific Coast for a conference with Senator George W. Norris.

LESS favorable weather, the setback in security and commodity markets and political developments brought about some slowing down in the recent trade spurt during the week. Most merchandise departments felt this slackening.
"WHY call it Red Square," ask strangers, "when it isn't Red and isn't Square, but oblong?" The answer is, Russians don't call it Red Square, but Krasnaya Ploshchad instead.

DETROIT. AN indirect but none the less significant evidence of the automotive industry's confidence that 1933 is going to mark the beginning of better business is the attention it is giving to the national automobile shows.

Recent highway regulations put into effect by Virginia and West Virginia mark further progress in the move for equality in regulation for all forms of transportation which the railroads have urged for many years. The actions of these two States follow the upholding by the United States Supreme Court of laws regulating the operation of commercial highway vehicles in Texas and Kansas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Federal regulation of utility holding companies was recommended to Congress today by the Power Commission as "absolutely essential in the public interests."

BIRMINGHAM, Sept. 15. -- Proponents of a Federal sales tax who are hoping that the alarm with which politicians viewed it last Winter has been removed Sufficiently to make possible its enactment at the next session of Congress will find Alabama's present approach to the plan as a possible source of State revenue interesting if not altogether encouraging.

A NATION'S primary right is to be free of fear of invasion. Faith in the justice of this principle is so deeply ingrained in the American people that when they see territory overrun they are aroused and, as this monument testifies, instinctively resolve to throw their moral and, if needs be, their material weight on the Bide of the invaded.

INGENUITY never dies. Even the hammer-blows of depression have not dulled the inventiveness of the accessory designers, who continue to fashion new contrivances to pique the fancy of the gadget-minded motorist. The Fall catalogues fairly sparkle with fresh patterns in the way of trimmings, gewgaws, novelties, trinkets and whatever else comes under the generic term of automobile accessory.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- At the first session on a Saturday since July, the Stock Exchange finished an active week firm and cheerful. British Government funds made further headway, the funding loan reaching a record high price.

LONDON. IS it possible that, after all, the modern type of man is to prove also the most ancient? Those who regard such a supposition as unworthy of serious consideration should have been in London recently when prehistorians from all parts of the world met in congress to debate the problems of man's origin.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I noted with interest the letter of Edgar A. Van Dusen in THE TIMES in which he endeavors to dispute Mark Graves's remarks.

DETROIT. FROM a reliable but not official source it was learned last week that the well-known Ford trimotor passenger plane will no longer be built. At the present time building operations on planes at the Ford plant have been temporarily discontinued, but when and if the company decides to re-enter the manufacture of aircraft, the product, it is reported, will be a two-motored, or a single-powered, ship.

SEVERE and world-wide economic reaction has always brought into the foreground controversy over the gold standard. To the uncompromising adherent of the quantitative money theory, the 30 per cent fall in average prices of commodities since 1929 was on its face sufficient indictment of the system.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 5. -- The Chicago Exposition will probably have one unusual Belgian feature, of real value, whatever other exhibits go west. A flock of 800 trained pigeons, are to brighten up the Old Europe section of the 1933 exhibition.

AMSTERDAM. THE influence of pickled herring on sea power (a theme which Admiral Mahan seems to have overlooked) is recalled by the fact that the Hollanders have completed the great seadike across the Zuider Zee.

PINE VALLEY, N.J., Sept. 17. -- As the result of the first day of match rounds today, in the Crump Cup tournament, which the English players dominated, Cyril Tolley, former British amateur champion, the medalist, will meet George H. Flinn Jr., Oakmont, tomorrow in the semi- final.

THE first collected edition of Chaucer was published in 1532. Who is better endowed than Mr. Chesterton to mark the quadricentenary with vivid and pious commemoration? In a sense he is a contemporary of the poet. He loves the institutions and great names of the Middle Age, its exterior splendors and pageantries, the richness and variety of its life, the religion which was its heart.

Overhauled by a Westchester County motorcycle policeman after a wild chase-at seventy miles an hour along the Bronx River Parkway, three men, attempting to escape into the city with $1,600 they had just looted from the offices of the Continental Baking Company's plant in Mount Vernon, were stopped at 233d Street and Webster Avenue, the Bronx, just after 11 o'clock last night and compelled to alight from their roadster.

TOKYO. -- The career of Kosaburo Tachibana, whose name must not be mentioned in the Japanese newspapers and who is now in prison awaiting trial for his connection with the murder of Premier Inukai, is the best example that could be offered of the ferment of ideas which constitutes the new Japanese nationalism.

OUR Greatest Authors: How Great Are They?" asks Henry Hazlitt in the October issue of The Forum. In the article which bears this title Mr. Hazlitt appraises the leading American authors of today and attempts to estimate their chances of survival.

ROME, Sept. 16. -- The improved conditions in the United States, especially the more optimistic trend on the Stock Exchanges, had an immediate repercussion in Italy, where a resumption of brisk trading on all exchanges was noticeable, with a marked upward tendency in quotations.

PRESIDENT HOOVER'S attitude on domestic and international questions, not always understood by the leaders of his party, viewing his actions from the plane of practical politics. Is made understandable in a timely and thoughtful volume, "Herbert Hoover and American Individualism."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 12. -- Freedom of the press, here was threatened recently, as a result of a pronouncement of the Minister of Foreign Relations, Leonidas Pacheco, concerning a series of articles attacking General Sanchez Cerro, President of Peru, because of the imprisonment of the Aprista leader, Haya de la Torre.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- A soiree of "music and the dance" will be held on the evening of Sept. 25 at the Hotel Gramatan, Bronxville, for the benefit of the Westchester County committee of the American Society for the control of cancer. The artists will include Mme. Clarita Sanchez, Spanish soprano; Mlle. Sophia Delza, dancer; Floyd Townsley, tenor, and Ray Perkins, radio humorist.

An eighteen-hundred-dollar payroll hold-up in an elevator at 26 East Fourteenth Street had a thrilling sequel yesterday noon in a crowded five-and-ten-cent store at 20 East Fourteenth Street. There, after a tussle which caused considerable excitement among the customers, two armed men were arrested as the bandits.

WHILE debate over the prohibition question rages ever more fiercely in the United States, at least two countries of Europe are in a quandary over their production of alcoholic beverages.
