Scotland, burdened by the high taxes on the whisky it produces and with an oversupply of the spirits in its warehouses, has declared a "holiday" on whisky manufacture.
This Fall will see the greatest emphasis on quality in merchandise since the depression began as the result of efforts which started to take form last week.

STORIES about the Irish have a tendency to be wild tales. They go in for riot and revolution, leprechauns and fairy rings, banshees and ghosts, Irish-tenor sentimentality. Frank O'Connor's novel is not like that. It has its feet firmly planted on the ground, in the cheaper streets of Cork.

With 12,000 fans watching them appreciatively, the Dodgers and Reds split a double-header yesterday at Ebbets Field and displayed a variety of baseball that left nothing to be desired save a double victory for the Dodgers. Carey's men took the opener, 5 to 3, and the Reds captured the final contest, 7 to 6.

An aggressive Fort Monmouth polo team eliminated Fort Hamilton, 5 to 2, at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island yesterday. The contest was the first of a series to determine the championship of the Second Corps Area and was keenly fought throughout despite a slippery field which made hard playing dangerous.

Joseph E. Widener, president of the Westchester Racing Association, speaking last night as a lover of horse racing, stated at a dinner of the New York Turf Writers' Association that he hoped for an oppprtunity to present before the New York State Legislature plans for the benefit of the sport in New York State.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the death on Thursday in an automobile accident in Detroit of Lewis Ross Freeman 2d, who returned in July from Sumatra, where he had been superintendent of the plantations of the United States Rubber Company.

CAPE TOWN. ON the desert coast of Southwest Africa lies Luderitzbucht -- a town which has always depended for its wealth on diamonds, and which has now been ruined by the depression. Luderitzbucht may have to be abandoned until the diamond trade revives.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Every French athlete who took part in the Olympic Games at Los Angeles has had on his return home to answer, according to his capacity, the question, "What do you think of America?" Some of the answers have been penetrating and illuminating.

Two developments yesterday were viewed by political forecasters as auguries of a widespread drive to bring about the designation of Mayor Joseph V. McKee as the Democratic candidate for his present office should the courts rule that ah election must be held on Nov. 8.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Two light workouts featured the Princeton football squads' third day of practice on University Field today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17 (AP). -- An independent Republican party, endorsing President Hoover and asking for retention of all prohibition laws, was organized today at a convention called to nominate a State ticket.

THE harsh and rugged terrain of New England, hostile to agriculture though it be, has always been considered the prime American soil for producing scholars. Big butter-and-egg men might come out of the West, and gentlemen from the South, but culture and learning were thought to grow moat luxuriantly within a hundred miles of Boston.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The quest of John H. Forsman for the New York Athletic Club golf championship, which began ten years ago, terminated successfully today over the Winged Foot course, when he conquered John G. Anderson, a former titleholder.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The Indians kept in the running for third place today by defeating Washington, 5 to 4, in the opener of their series. The defeat cut the Senators' advantage for third place to three-and-a-half games.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP). -- My Dandy, the famous one-eyed horse from the Reichert Brothers' farm of Belleville, Ill., raced to an easy victory today in the Constitution Handicap at Lincoln Fields. Setting his own pace for the mile and a sixteenth, the 7-year-old son of Porte Drapeau -- Scepter and Staff easily outran his four rivals.

THREE years ago, at the height of the racketeering that bad taken possession of the limited-editions business, this column voiced its opposition to several organized attempts to convert individuals to the wholesale buying of fine books.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Carroll Thomas Hickey, who took part in three gold rushes -- Cripple Creek, Tonopah and Goldfield -- and afterward became a New York stock broker, died at the Holy Ghost Hospital here today after being ill for six months.

WILL your future income be increased if you receive a college education?" Within the next few weeks approximately 1,000,000 young men and women will enter our institutions of higher learning, persuaded to do so, many of them -- or their parents -- by the affirmative answer commonly given to that question.

IN Germany, as in America, the people are represented in the government by two institutions. One is the Parliament and the other is the President. Of course, in Germany we vote directly for the President without primaries. Now, a situation arises when one of these representative institutions -- the Reichstag -- has again proved itself, as it has done year after year, unable to create a government.
NEW YORK. Sir Thomas Grattan Esmonde, Bart, and Lady Esmonde of Ballynostra, Gorey, County Wexford, Ireland, are visiting Mrs. Stephen W. Carroll at Carroll Hall, Shelter Island.

Buyers arrived in larger number during the week, due to enthusiasm over retail improvement, and budgets were expanded to cover sudden needs, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Merchants, however, should be cautious with their commitments now, the buying firm adds, with consideration given the possibilities that Indian Summer and the political situation may bring a let-down in the spirited retail business enjoyed since Labor Day.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Table arrangements at bargain prices and exhibitions of flowers arranged by children were the principal features here today of the flower show of the White Plains and Central Westchester Horticultural Society. The show, which is being held at Playland, will close tomorrow night.

Discussion of the plans for an intensive equipment modernization campaign to be carried on among manufacturers by the National Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation developed wide differences of opinion as to the value of the movement in industrial circles last week.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having lately read a magazine article in which was made the startlingly incorrect statement that Peregrine White was the first white child born in North America, I have been impelled to compile the following account of "first-time" happenings:

TOPEKA, Sept. 17 (AP). -- A temporary order restraining Governor Woodring and Attorney General Roland Boynton from instituting receivership, ouster or charter forfeiture proceedings against ten Cities Service Company subsidiary gas distributing concerns operating in Kansas was signed late today by Judge George A. Kline of Shawnee district court.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 15. -- Agrarian Virginia, heretofore not more than mildly concerned about tariff measures, finds itself today writhing under the sting of reprisal applied by the British Imperial Economic Conference, recently adjourned at Ottawa.

IT may be that dark hair is a handicap in amateur golf. This is only a theory at the moment, but it is advanced after a scientific investigation of what went on at the Five Farms course just outside Baltimore this week. The blonds in pursuit of the national amateur golf title ran the dark-haired players right off the course.

The Bronx Landlords Protective Association announced yesterday that it had compiled a list of rentstrikers for the use of its members and was preparing legislation to be introduced in the Legislature in January making rent-strike agitation a misdemeanor carrying a penalty of arrest and imprisonment.

Jail sentences are to be asked for speakeasy owners, candy-store proprietors and other maintaining gambling slot machines of any kind in the city, it became known yesterday, as a result of the order of Mayor McKee to Police Commissioner Mulrooney that slot-machine gambling be stopped.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- France's first step toward removing her deficit brought about by the world crisis, a bill for a gigantic conversion operation combining all high interest bearing government obligations in a single issue at 4 1/2 per cent, passed the Senate today, was returned to the Chamber of Deputies and approved there and tomorrow will be promulgated as law.

CONGRESS was trying early last Summer, at the behest of President Hoover, to cut down the impending national deficit by slashing appropriations. A specially created economy committee of the House erased $48,000,000 from the appropriation for war veterans, figuring that that was so much to the good.

THE Rev. William Cole (1714-1782) was a curious and arresting parson of the English Established Church. His life was a thing quite apart from either that of the beef-eating, heavy-drinking squires, or that of the rationalistic thinkers of the age.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) . -- A swirl of statements and a blare of oratory brought the Massachusetts primary campaign near to a conclusion tonight as voters sought to map their course for next Tuesday's balloting through a throng of political aspirants.

QUINCY, Mass., Sept. 17 (AP). -- Charles E. DuBois in a letter left by him just before he committed suicide, and made public tonight by Jeremiah J. MacAnarney, his attorney, said that his wife committed suicide, that he secreted her body because he was convinced "people" would not "believe my story," and that he had not told the lawyer "the whole truth" because he wished to cover the good name of a good, pure woman."
LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Robert Somerset today sold his famous racing yacht Jolie Brise, known on both sides of the Altantic, to J.F.B. Gage, son of Colonel Gage, another noted yachtsman.

LONDON. IT is scarcely surprising that some of the reviewers of "The Fortress" should be impatient of its length. Hugh Walpole, says Clifford Sharp in The NewsChronicle, is intrinsically one of the two or three best novelists in England today, and he ought not to be allowed to expend his energy in piling up pages of what can only be called misplaced verbosity.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22. -- Notwithstanding the fact that the terrorist activities of anti-Japanese organizations and the failure of Chinese courts to punish the leaders were the principal causes of the Sino-Japanese clash at Shanghai early this year, the Chinese authorities are now permitting a revival of such activities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- In not a few quarters the return of Mayor Cermak from his European trip has been awaited with eager expectancy -- an expectancy of flattering faith in his ability to get things done. Chicago's Mayor went to Europe for rest, and found little of it.

Elihu Root has volunteered his services as a speaker in the campaign to re-elect President Hoover according to announcement made yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria headquarters of the Republican National Committee.

PIECES of furniture that would have been discarded or left in the attic not so long ago are now utilized in charming interiors. With proper color schemes, wall and window treatments, it is possible harmoniously to combine tables, chairs and decorative accessories of diverse types.

The establishment of a virtual protectorate by Japan over the newly created State of Manchukuo, consecrated by the treaty signed in the past week at Changchun, will give rise to a very nice diplomatic situation. It will be a situation in respect to which the alleged isolation of the United States will be put to the test for the reason that our latest foreign policy, the "Hoover Doctrine," may well be put into the balance.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Proving especially formidable in the singles matches, the United States seniors accounted for their third triumph since the international matches with the British and Canadian golfing veterans were inaugurated six years ago.

The shorter work week as a remedy for nuemployment and the immediate letting of contracts under the relief and construction bill recently passed by Congress were urged yesterday in radio appeals over WEAF by United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey and J. Cheever Cowdin, treasurer of the American Legion's national employment commission.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 17. -- Representative Frank Crowther faces threatening opposition for renomination in the Thirtieth district from John Barnes, an Amsterdam banker and knit goods manufacturer, who is running on an immediate repeal platform.

WASHINGTON. AS the navy's newest aircraft carrier, the Ranger, rises higher from her giant cradle at the Newport News shipbuilding yard with a speed that indicates she will be ready for delivery before the original date of May 1, 1934, officials of the Bureau of Aeronautics look longingly toward Congress, where funds to purchase the 114 airplanes necessary before the Ranger can be put into service must be appropriated.

Navy mine-sweepers will comb the bottom of the East River at 134th Street tomorrow in an effort to recover the boiler of the steamer Observation, which blew up on Sept. 9 with the loss of seventy-one lives. This announcement was made yesterday by District Attorney Charles B. McLoughlin of the Bronx, following a test which proved that the safety valve of the boiler was in good order.
The first building for commercial use to be erected as a part of the New York Central Railroad's west side improvement plan has been completed at 450 West Fourteenth Street.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 15. -- Governor Ruby Laffoon and State Treasurer Elam Huddleston assert that the financial affairs of Kentucky are in much better condition than has been represented by critics of the administration. A plan recently launched, they say, will take care of the outstanding treasury warrants, amounting to approximately $13,750,000, on which the State is paying 5 per cent interest.

WIDE RANGE, a term applied to the latest development in talking pictures, over which engineers have been working for the last eighteen months, is now ready for demonstration and use in theatres with the Western Electric sound system.

TO judge by the number of questions on the subject received during the past Winter, there should be considerable satisfaction over the issue of Victor Masterpiece Album 144, containing "Don Quixote," tone-poem of Richard Strauss, played by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the baton of that hitherto exclusive Columbia performer, Sir Thomas Beecham.

IN a land where famine has marched, in a country where starvation is familiar, a 62-yearold prisoner warns Prime Minister MacDonald that he will fast to death if special election privileges are granted to India's wretched "untouchables."
The resale of an unfinished garage structure in Jersey City featured the real estate market in New Jersey yesterday. Sales of small dwellings were reported in large volume.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17. -- With a great display of courage and golf shots, C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville, 29-year-old star from the Province of Ontario, won the national amateur golf title at the Five Farms course today, the second non-resident player to carry off the cup in thirty-six years of championship history.

New standards should be established by loaning institutions in the making of mortgages, points out Arthur C. Holden of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architecture. His idea is that mortgages should be passed upon not solely by the loaning committee of each individual institution, but each loan should be required to pass a district board of control.

Caring for the Body. Your wiser warning not to tamper with the human body appeared in an editorial recently. During diagnosis and treatment the human body is up against an array of disintegrating forces, and the slightest maladjustment may throw the whole system out of gear, eventually causing chronic invalidism.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 17 (Canadian Press). -- That Saskatchewan has staged a 90 per cent comeback in one year and the big crop areas of the Province represent substantial buying power this year is the finding of W.L. MacTavish, editor of The Winnipeg Tribune, who has been making a survey of conditions.
WHEN Edith Wharton elected to take the title of her latest novel from Emerson's lines.

Tour physicist is supposed to be a hard, matter-of-fact measurer who suppresses romantic speculation and talks only of energy, volts, ions and electrons. Confront him with a mystery and he proves to be as human as the rest of us. Consider the cosmic rays. For years MILLIKAN in this country and KOLHOER-STER, HESS, REGENER and others in Europe have been studying them only to their own mystification and ours.

The longest-priced winner in the history of the famous Futurity at Belmont Park scored yesterday before 20,000 astonished spectators when Lee Rosenberg's Kerry Patch drove down the Widener chute to victory in the forty-third running of the closing-day classic.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- Every one in Paris of all degrees and ages except Paul Gorguloff knew on Tuesday evening that when the daylight began on the morrow the man who murdered President Doumer would die. There were few people whose thoughts did not turn to him as they went to bed, for it is a dreadful thing to knowbeforehand the exact minute when death will come to any one.

FOGELSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 17. -- Proposing a national cooperative system of farm marketing and criticizing Governor Roosevelt for alleged failure to offer a concrete plan for agricultural uplift, Vice President Curtis opened the Republican campaign in Pennsylvania here today soon after the Republican State Committee had adopted a platform demanding repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and modification of the Volstead act.
ATLANTA, Sept. 16. -- Democratic State primaries in Georgia, Louisiana and South Carolina took the limelight, although the issues and backgrounds largely differed.

Feeling constrained to do something spectacular in the waning hours of a season toward which they had contributed little enough of this sort of thing, the Giants dealt the last, lingering pennant hopes of the Pirates a staggering blow at the Polo Grounds yesterday by upsetting them in the opening clash of a three-game series, 7 to 4.

ROME. "AND here," said our guide, with a gesture of pride as though he had built it himself, "is the apodyterium -- the ladies' dressing room." We gazed into a medium-sized room, with vaulted ceiling and walls still bearing the traces of rich frescoes.

While George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, continued his investigation of the ownership and management of cordial shops in Manhattan, prohibition agents, Who in three days had closed nearly 300 such stores, turned their attention yesterday to ''smoke shops'' in the Bowery and lower east side.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 17. -- Foreign Minister Roberto Urdaneta today confirmed the announcement in El Tiempo this morning of the probable failure of diplomatic negotiations to obtain Peru's assurance that she would not interfere in the projected operations by Colombian troops to recover Leticia, the town on the Upper Amazon seized by Peruvian citizens Sept. 1.

George M. Avent, Deputy Attorney General of this State, who was attached to the Bureau of Securities, with offices in the State Office Building, Manhattan, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 234 New Dorp Lane, New Dorp, S.I., after an illness of several days.

UNLIKE many estheticians who spin their theories of art and beauty by the sole aid of dialectics. Mr. Schoen in this book approaches the vexing problem of beauty with something more concrete than mere logic alone. His method is that of the scientist dealing experimentally with the raw stuff of which "art" is made, rather than that of the pure logician weaving abstractions about art and beauty.

OTTAWA, Sept. 15. -- Beset with financial difficulties more serious than those which confront any other Province in Canada, the Premier of British Columbia, Dr. F.S. Tolmie, leader of the Conservative majority in the Legislature, has announced that he favors a union Ministry as the way out.

An interesting reminder of an custom which does not attract as much attention, today as in form years, when private homes were more generally occupied than multi-family buildings, may be seen on the west Bide of Lexington Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- The British Government, through Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon, today completed drafting an expression of policy which it hopes and believes will induce Germany to return to the disarmament conference.

It is common knowledge abroad that there are many persons in this country who believe Japan should withdraw from the League of Nations. For such a question to have arisen there must have been a sense of grievance among our people against the League, particularly as a result of the Manchurian and Shanghai incidents.

MR. DURANT had many collaborators in the making of this book, for it is a symposium on that old, old question man has been asking himself in moments of despair, "Is life worth living?" ever since he developed the ability to think abstractly.

THE second edition of "American Composers," compiled by Claire Reis and published by the United States Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music with Juilliard Foundation aid, is an arresting document. Like all compilations, it has its limitations and incompletenesses -- aspects which few compilers may hope to eradicate until many editions of a work have been issued and repeated corrections made.

The agitation spread to the White House, from which the President issued a call to National Chairman Everett Sanders to make "renewed and stronger effort that the people may fully understand the issues at stake."

The agitation spread to the White House, from which the President issued a call to National Chairman Everett Sanders to make "renewed and stronger effort that the people may fully understand the issues at stake."

New issues of bonds announced last week for redemption in September before their maturity dates consisted only of parts of two municipal and industrial loans. The total for the month is now $25,361,300, compared with $56,143,000 in August and $116,518,000 in September, 1931, at corresponding dates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Smoot has an article on the tariff in The Saturday Evening Post. It is not the purpose of this letter to take issue with the arguments of that distinguished spokesman for the protected interests, but simply to call attention to a serious error of fact involving an honored name.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- The suggestion that the insolvent Karstadt Corporation, of which a shareholders' meeting was held Thursday, should require dollar bondholders to renounce their right to amortization at par and consent to the corporation repurchasing the bonds without limit at around the present Wall Street price of 25 has again raised the problem of other German repurchases of dollar securities at depreciated prices.

Seventy-five members of the National Rifle Association of America, from more than ten States, held their sixty-second annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The organization, which is the governing body of rifle shooting, represents 2,800 affiliated rifle clubs.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- Questionnaires have been sent to every candidate for State Senator and Assemblyman by the New York State Construction Council asking their positions on insuring the expenditure of all revenue collected from motorists and all gasoline taxes on highways of the State.

GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- As the League of Nations enters the second year of its conflict with Japan over Tokyo's methods of gaining its ends in Manchuria, it has to choose between two basic policies, in the view of a high official of the Secretariat, which forms the nearest thing to an executive the League has.

Efforts by city civil service employes to obtain signatures of property owners and merchants to protest against any cuts in their salaries were characterized as a "hold-up" and an attempt at thinly clothed "intimidation" in a statement issued yesterday by Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

First, I would reorganize the United States Department of Agriculture, looking toward the administrative machinery needed to build a program of national planning. I should be the last person in the world to become a harsh and thoughtless critic of a department that has done so many good things.

Thirty-two building trades workers will receive craftsmanship awards for their work on the new building of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The New York Building Congress will honor the men at ceremonies to be held Thursday morning in the new structure, on Fourth Avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The Bank of France return of Thursday, covering the position of Sept. 9, shows rather important changes in the gold reserve. That account increased 169,000,000 francs, and in well-informed circles the increase is ascribed to transactions of the Bank of France with other central banks having gold earmarked at Paris.

Democratic national headquarters made public yesterday a new series of eighteen polls through the country showing Governor Roosevelt leading President Hoover in all but one instance. From the Panhellenic Hotel at 3 Mitchell Place came an announcement of a poll among women revealing President Hoover leading, 64 to 42.

The Society for the Prevention at Crime which was represented last Friday at the conference in Police Headquarters on methods of cutting down policy slip and slot machine gambling, issued a statement yesterday that it believes that "the gambling racket is full of graft and could not exist without an alliance with dishonest officials."

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 18 -- A manufacturing and sales agreement between the Willys-Overland Company and the International Harvester Company is expected soon. L.A. Miller, president of Willys-Overland, said today that the two concerns were negotiating for cooperation.

Knowledge of self, which is the key to self-mastery and the fulfillment of our supernatural destiny, is completely ignored today in the avid search for other kinds of knowledge of far less importance, the Rev. John M. Quinn declared yesterday at High Mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The rank of hereditary Marquis has been bestowed upon Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, by Pope Pius XI, it became known yesterday through word received from Vatican City. The honor was conferred upon Dr. Ryan, it was said, in recognition of his service to education, the church, and to the community generally.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, behind Dean's pitching, took the second game of a double-header with the Braves, 5 to 2, today, after losing the opener, 3 to 2. The world's champions' victory was their only one of the three-game series.
Bent on playing out their string, some what may, the Pirates attacked our Giants with such ferocity at the Polo Grounds yesterday as to startle gathering of 15,000.

Two old stars of Ziegfeld shows, Eddie Dowling and Leon Errol, headline the vaudeville bills this week at the Palace and Loew's State theatres, respectively. In addition, each house presents a representative quota of radio entertainers, without which no bill is complete these days, and the reliable bone-limbering turns.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- While reliance is now being placed on increased tonnage to stop losses, producers point out that financial statements for the quarter now ending will be particularly illuminating, for they will supply information as to how much overhead has been reduced by the vigorous efforts that have been made, with punctilious attention to the smallest details.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Arthur Williams was host today at a luncheon at Brook Corners, his country home in Roslyn Harbor, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Myron C. Taylor and their house guest, the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A preliminary study of the possible effects on American agriculture of the commercial agreements signed at the Ottawa conference convinces the Department of Agriculture that the chief items involved in direct competition in the British market are wheat, apples, oranges, grapefruit, raisins, prunes, bacon and ham.

Those Republicans who have attempted to represent Governor ROOSEVELT as "another Bryan," with economic ideas destructive to the legitimate investments of the people, must have realized that this game is up when they read his speech at Salt Lake City on the railroads.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- Germany, judging by the newspapers to be issued tomorrow morning, is somewhat shocked to learn from the British note to all the powers interested in the Geneva disarmament conference that Britain is quite unsympathetic toward her desire to increase her armaments because her neighbors have not already decreased theirs to her level and show no particular wish to do so.

The establishment of an isolation unit at one of the general hospitals is recommended in a survey of hospital needs for communicable diseases in the Bronx issued yesterday by the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Hoover has decided to make only three campaign speeches, two in the mid-West and one in the East. Chairman Everett Sanders of the Republican National Committee announced tonight after a four-hour political conference at the White House.

SOUTHFORT, Conn., Sept. 18 -- J. Garland Miller, who has competed in numerous international Star Class contests but had never won a race in one, today came forth in his Flapper, which he sails over the Lynn Haven oyster beds of the Chesapeake, and led all of the other twenty-seven craft in their second contest of the present championship series.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 18 -- Berkshire Hunt and Country Club had its first drag hunt of the Autumn today and many members followed the hounds over five miles of trails. A hunt breakfast was served at the clubhouse at noon. Last night the club held a horse show dance with more than 100 exhibitors and members of the younger set at Lenox and Stockbridge attending.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Long, low apartment houses with abundant, open spaces at the sides and architecturally up to standards set by single dwellings in Montclair will be recommended for this town by its Planning Board in a report to the Montclair Board of Commissioners, according to Hugh R. Monro, chairman of the Planning Board.

A FEW days ago a golfer came from overseas with a strange assortment of ancient golfing weapons. His name was John Campbell and he told ship-news reporters that he was establishing an international golf museum at the James River Country Club at Newport News, Va. Of his treasure-trove he said, in part:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A Republican reply to Governor Roosevelt's Salt Lake City speech on railroads, made here today by William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, asserted that the Democratic Presidential nominee offered nothing new but in his plan had virtually adopted the essentials of President Hoover's railroad program already being carried into effect.

The cost of living is about to triple in Majorca, that alleged paradise for writers in the Balearic Isles, Donald S. Friede, vice president of Covici, Friede, publishers, said yesterday. Wearing a full, curly black beard, memento of his crossing from Spain to Brooklyn upon a Spanish tramp ship that was one month on the way.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 18 -- The schedules of iron and steel mills in the Mahoning Valley have been increased for this week. The output of ingots is 18 per cent of capacity.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 18 -- With one-third of his Western trip completed, Governor Roosevelt, left here tonight for Butte, Mont., convinced that he will carry most of the States through which he has traveled, and satisfied with the reaction to his two important speeches, the farm speech at Topeka, Kan., and the railroad speech here last night.

Gaston Lachaise, American sculptor, has been commissioned to model four sculptural panels for the Sixth Avenue front of the seventy-two-story RCA Building, the main unit in Rockefeller Centre, is was announced yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 15 -- The foreign trade of Puerto Rico, with a total value of $147,698,039 for the year ended June 30, showed a decline of $27,000,000 from the previous year. Of the total commerce, 92 per cent was with the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- When Mayor Cermak returned on Thursday from a six-weeks' tour of Europe he found another crime wave among the many problems confronting the city. While abroad Mayor Cermak had stated to foreign officials and the press that Chicago, with the imprisonment of Al Capone and many of his lieutenants, had won its war with gangsters.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Outplaying their opponents by a wide margin in the final two periods, John Hay Whitney's Greentree riders downed Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes, 14 to 8, today in the weekly high-goal polo exhibition, at the Sands Point Club.

Fourth place loomed as an unpleasant possibility for the Dodgers when the returns were all in at Ebbets Field yesterday, for Burt Shotton's ambitious Phillies won the game, 5 to 1; pushed themselves to within a game and a half of third place and at the same time lessened the Careymen's chances of displacing the Pirates.

A State Liquor Traffic Authority to control the manufacture, transportation and sale of liquor, following the termination of prohibition, was proposed yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an appeal to "public opinion throughout the length and breadth of the land."

Though weather conditions haven't been just right for the fishermen along the south shore of Long Island they have not given up to despair. There are several weeks of good fishing to come, most of them say, and even the pessimists haven't been completely sunk because there have been some very poor days in recent weeks and not any great fishing for several days.

Architects and building trades interests who have shown some anxiety over the fate of the new building code since Mr. McKee's accession to the Mayoralty are reassured by Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Dally Building Reports. The Dow Service writer says the code is in no danger of undue delay because of the city's change of Mayors.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A general selling holiday seeking higher farm prices was ordered to begin in all agricultural States of the Middle West and South at midnight Tuesday by the executive council of the National Farmers' Holiday Association in a meeting here today.

The Brooklyn Queens Transit Corporation, the surface-car subsidiary of the B.M.T., has filed with the Board of Taxicab Control a complaint against some fifty taxicab operators who are competing with its rolley lines by operating their cabs on a "jitney" basis, charging a five or a ten cent fare.

The population of New York City is increasing at a much greater rate than that of the country as a whole, according to a volume issued yesterday by Dr. Walter Laidlaw, executive secretary of the Cities Census committee, which shows radical changes here with reference to congestion, nativity, religion, distribution by age periods and borough populations.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 18 -- The value of gold produced in Ontario in the first eight months of this year was $30,839,592, against $27,525,332 in the same period last year. Ore milled this year was 3,618,157 tons, against 3,267,043 tons last year.

LEWES, Del., Sept. 18 -- Once again the old sloop Debraak sends out its lure of sunken treasure. Two salvage boats belonging to the Baltimore Derrick and Salvage Corporation will leave Baltimore tomorrow for the Delaware Capes, where, under the direction of Charles T. Jackson, deep sea diver, the search for the Debraak started in July will be continued.

A medical centre will be established soon at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, Mrs. Edward Jacobs, national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, declared yesterday morning at the opening session of the eighteenth annual Hadassah convention at the Hotel Commodore.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 17 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of l926, is 62.9, which compares with 63.2 a week ago, 62.5 two weeks ago, 61.9 three weeks ago and 61.8 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date was 66.3 in the first week of January.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- The German business outlook still shows signs of improvement. Bankruptcies in August were only 499, as against the high point of 1,455 last October. The daily average number of protested bills has sunk to 75, comparing with the maximum of 365 last September.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The statement of the British Government's view of the German demand for equality of armaments was made public here today by the British Embassy as follows:

In the Library Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum a collection of Chinese textiles owned by Paul E. Vernon is now on view to remain through Sept. 29. The exhibition includes, besides woven and embroidered textiles, a number of costumes, wrought iron panels and a group of toys.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Dr. Lauge Koch, veteran Arctic explorer, today returned from Greenland with the announcement that he had found evidence of one of the missing links in the chain of evolution -- a four-legged fish that walked ashore.

Encouraged by an active consumer response for better price merchandise, retailers last week showed a new faith in the current business revival by placing substantial orders for better goods for immediate and future delivery. In the wholesale apparel markets urgent mail and telegraph requests for Fall items were added to the heavy volume of purchases made by buyers through the week.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- While some of the major crimes decreased in the first half of this year, arson, burglary and forgery increased, Frank A. Leonard, statistician of the Department of Correction, stated today. The increase in arson was 33.12 per cent, burglary 18.79 per cent and forgery 21.23 per cent.

Nearly $7,000,000 was spent for unemployment relief by the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare in the first six months of its existence, according to a report sent by Commissioner Frank J. Taylor to Mayor Joseph V. McKee and the Board of Estimate and made public yesterday.

For years divers well-meaning spoil-sports in Maine have sought to do away with the September election. It is clearer than ever this year that to move it forward to November would impair that happiness of the greatest number which a wise State seeks.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Sept. 18 -- Taylorville citizens today dispatched county officers to Springfield to ask Governor Louis Emmerson for National Guardsmen here as a result of two bombing, laid to mine labor difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The next Congress will not be able to modify the Volstead act or submit a resolution to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment, according to F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, who has made a canvass of the recent primaries.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics lengthened their lead over Washington in the battle for second place in the American League to three and one-half games today by taking a double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 4 to 3 and 7 to 4.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Sands Point came back to the top of its form at Meadow Brook today to win the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup, most important of polo's handicap trophies, in a game packed full of all kinds of polo.

Signs of returning sincerity and confidence are present in the United States today, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street. Dr. Chalmers has just returned from Scotland, where he spent the Summer months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Representative Joseph W. Byrns of Tennessee, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, arrived here today to supervise an aggressive campaign in behalf of Democratic candidates for the House.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Aided by a magnificent anchor leg by Miss Lenore Kight, who was defeated by inches for the Olympic 400-meter championship, the Carnegie Library A.A. relay quartet from Homestead, Pa., won the national senior 880-yard relay swimming title today in the Briarcliff Lodge pool before a gathering that included Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes.
William J. Donovan, leading aspirant for the Republican nomination for Governor, pledged his full support to State Chairman W. Kingsland Macy in a letter made public yesterday.

The New Testament is a collection of tracts written by pamphleteers inspired to attack the problems of a struggling institution, says Dr. Ernest Findlay Scott, who holds the Edward Robinson Professorship in Biblical Theology at Union Theological Seminary, in a study of the Christian Bible, just published by the Columbia University Press.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The British note on Germany's demand for arms equality, which was handed to the French Government yesterday and published today was welcomed by French leaders who are willing to discuss the revision of Germany's status in the Council of the League of Nations.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Albany and Jersey City closed the International League season today by breaking even in a double-header. Jersey City won the first game, 5 to 3, and Albany the second, 8 to 7, in eight innings.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 18 -- The cotton market was influenced last week by the government's crop forecast issued on Sept. 8. It has become abundantly evident that the advance of 453 points, nearly $23 a bale, had resulted in the accumulation of large speculative long interest in the belief that the government would again reduce its estimate, from 11,306,000 bales to a figure less than 11,000,000.

The Squadron C quartet of Brooklyn, defending titleholder, was eliminated from the seventh annual championship military polo tournament of the Second Corps Area when it was upset by the alert Essex Troop team of Newark, 8 -- 3, yesterday at Governors Island.

Three 13-year-old boys emulated the customs of the country Saturday evening and went to Coney Island. They made wistful experiments with roller coasters, merry-go-rounds, mechanical race horses and the game that is played with baseballs and wooden milk bottles.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The India office states there is no foundation for the suggestion contained in a news agency message to the effect that the Secretary of State for India has canceled plans for the transfer of Mahatma Gandhi from Yerovda jail at Poona.

The use of principles laid down by Christ in social organization and reform was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Allen Clay Lambert, pastor of St. Thomas Lutheran Church, Topping Avenue and 175th Street, the Bronx, in his sermon.

The final movement of Beethoven's ninth symphony will be presented in the form of "a mammoth pageant symbolizing a dream of universal peace," with 1,500 participants in costume, in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 25, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Gains made in business in this territory in the last thirty to sixty days' are being held and further improvement in a few lines is apparent. There is also more disposition to look forward to a steady enlargement in consumption of manufactured and raw materials in leading lines, although the gains may not be so large or important as those already made.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Glass resolution, which is now the unfinished business of the United States Senate, provides, in the first sentence, that the Eighteenth Amendment be repealed. In the very next sentence, however, comes a provision that the sale of intoxicating liquors "for consumption at the place of sale (commonly known as a saloon)" is "hereby prohibited."

Declaring that Mayor McKee's independence of action since Mayor Walker's resignation has no significance to those demanding a permanent improvement in the municipal government, Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue and chairman of the City Affairs Committee, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall that "Walkerism" is certain to return unless an aroused electorate ends the evils of party politics by voting "for men, not symbols."

The soccer double-header at Starlight Park yesterday produced two well played games, as the Bohemian Americans beat the New York Giants 6 to 4 and the German Hungarians held the New York Americans to a scoreless tie.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 -- Miss Julia Berwind, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Beverley Bogert, Mrs. George Henry Warren Jr. and Miss Natalja Willard were among those who gave luncheons at their homes here today. Mrs. Forsyth Wickes entertained at Zee Rust.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The wheat markets of the world are more of a puzzle today than at any other time this season. All grains, particularly wheat, as well as cotton and stocks, have had serious setbacks. Wheat here is 8 cents a bushel below its recent high price, having lost 2 3/4 to 3 1/8 cents last week, and prices now are within 3 1/8 to 4 cents of the season's low point.

This year's amateur championship was probably the most exciting in American golfing annals. The standard of play was higher than ever before. One proof of this is that it required 152 for thirty-six holes to qualify -- the lowest figure on record.

With the Town Hall, in West Forty-third Street, packed to the doors and an overflow crowd of 500 or more in the street, the Socialist party opened its city campaign, yesterday afternoon with a mass meeting which for size and enthusiasm, party leaders said, has not been equaled for fifteen years.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- This week's abrupt reaction in the Wall Street stock market created no surprise to financial London. It found a more or less vivid reflection in the British markets for stocks and commodities, both of which are much under the influence of price movements at New York.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Chick Evans, veteran amateur of Chicago and George Voigt, Walker Cup star, defeated Jerry Travers, former national amateur champion, and Johnnie Kinder, New Jersey State open champion for the past two years, one up, in nineteen holes, in an exhibition match for charity today at the Montclair Golf Club.
LONDON, Monday, Sept. 19 -- The policy toward Germany revealed by the British Government is held by most London newspapers to be positive and timely.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- The report on Germany's foreign trade for August is regarded favorably. It shows increase in the export surplus, resulting mainly from reduced import of foodstuffs. Since that reduction was due to larger home harvests, it is not in any respect based on artificial measures.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Newark, new International League champion, closed the 1932 season by taking two games from the Baltimore Orioles today, 16 to 12 and 2 to 0.

The circumspection with which football is taken on the campus a City College, where the Phi Beta Kappa key, rather than the gold spheroid charm, is the characteristic watch chain pendant, may be roughly shattered by a stampede of enthusiasm over the Lavender varsity this Fall.

Based on the belief that James J. Walker will not be nominated, and that the courts will rule that a Mayoralty election must be held this Fall, several informal booms for the Democratic nomination were started in the last week.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- The loss of a ten-inning 2-to-1 decision to the Browns in their last American League game in the West today removed the Yankees' chance to tie their league record of 110 victories for the season, set up in 1927. By winning their five remaining games they can total only 109 for the campaign.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- London financial markets have suddenly shifted from a spirit of great optimism with rising prices into a mood of uncertainty with prices fluctuating rather feverishly. This applies both to the security and commodity markets.
DETROIT, Texas, Sept. 18 (AP) -- John N. Garner, Democratic vice-presidential nominee, won a race today against death threatening his mother, Mrs. Sarah Jane Garner.

PINE VALLEY, N.J., Sept. 18 -- T.A. (Tony) Torrance, captain of the British Walker Cup team, defeated Cyril Tolley, former British amateur champion, now residing in New York, in the final round of the Crump Cup tournament today over the Pine Valley Golf Club course.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recurrence of Brandywine Day on Sept. 11 recalled to mind the celebrated battle which took place that day in 1777. It has frequently been asked, Did the official United States flag first float in this battle? There are two other claimants for this honor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the editorial on Governor Roosevelt's Topeka speech you confess doubt as to what the candidate means by advocating a tariff benefit over world prices equivalent to the benefit given by the tariff to industrial products.

LULING, Texas, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Edgar B. Davis, oil and rubber man who spent nearly $1,500,000 to keep a play running on Broadway for two years because he thought people ought to see it, has struck oil again.

PENSION SCHOELLER, a film comedy in German, with Trude Berliner, Fritz Schulz, Truus van Aalten, A. Tiedtke, Else Reval, Fritz Hampers, Elga Brink, Paul Heidemann, Hedwig Wangel and Kurt Vespermann: directed by Georg Jacoby. At the Seventy-second Street Playhouse.

One of the most thrilling national amateur golf championships held in recent years ended on Saturday when C. Ross Somerville, the methodical, unemotional Canadian star, won the title at Five Farms in Baltimore by defeating Johnny Goodman of Omaha.

A year ago yesterday the Japanese forces in Manchuria began a series of actions which culminated last Thursday in the recognition by Tokyo of the "independent State" of Manchukuo and an offensive and defensive alliance between the two. Actually it means the establishment of a Japanese protectorate over China's four Manchurian provinces with an area of 400,000 square miles and a population of about 30,000,000, of which perhaps a quarter of a million are Japanese.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, faced with what is said to be the most critical relief emergency in the history of organized philanthropy, has drafted a group of former leaders to direct its 1932 campaign for a budget of $3,923,000 for the support of its ninety-one affiliated institutions, it was announced yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the federation.

MANCHESTER, Ky., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Two men were killed, one was wounded and another man and an elderly woman narrowly escaped being shot today as a feud that had its inception during the Civil War broke out anew in the shadows of the Clay County Court House here.

Everybody is bent on planning everything nowadays. A man -- especially a public man -- who isn't prepared to draw from his pocket a plan in thousands of words for restoring business, reforming the Government, or answering JOB'S question and showing how to bind the sweet influences of the Pleiades seems to his fellows like a creature living in a world not realized.

VIENNA, Sept. 18 -- After some difficulty your correspondent today succeeded in running to earth the headquarters of the self-styled Fascist International, established in modest premises on the Margaretenstrasse in Vienna.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The index of wholesale prices in France during August, as compiled by the Statistique Generale, is 394, compared with 404 for July and 455 for August, 1931. Native products averaged 445, compared with 468 in the preceding month and 521 last year; imported products are 404, comparing with 290 in July and 335 in 1931.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Washington and Cleveland split a double-header today, the Indians taking the first game, 7 to 3, and the Senators the second, 9 to 2. Although victory in one game gave the Indians two out of three in the series, the divided bill robbed them of a chance to gain in their battle for third place.

Denial that the building of the proposed St. Lawrence ship canal would benefit New England territory is made in a letter sent by William H. Chandler, manager of the traffic bureau of the Merchants' Association, to the secretary of the New England Traffic League, made public yesterday.

A gay public auction was held in Little Italy yesterday. There was no hammer nor was there a catalogue. Instead there were booming drums, a battery of persuasive auctioneers, several hundred eager purchasers and a wealth of classification-defying material for the block.

The three-story dwelling at 159 West Seventy-seventh Street has been leased by Joseph Peter to Thomas F. and Alice M. Sherlock of South Nyack, N.Y. The lessees have purchased the furniture of the former tenant. The lot is 17.6 by 102 feet. D.W. Childress and Jones Sullivan were the brokers.

Gandhi Opens a New Campaign. If GANDHI goes ahead with his plans to starve himself, in protest against the new electoral laws promulgated by the British Government, he will be putting the hunger strike to a novel use.

In some respects last week's most interesting incident, from the viewpoint of the existing financial situation, was Mr. Roosevelt's declaration of policy towards the railways. The platform of his party had made no reference to that problem; which left some unpleasant uncertainties in the mind of apprehensive people, supposing that party to be returned to power.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The pennant-bound Chicago Cubs defeated the Reds, 4 to 3, in a fifteen-inning game today, the last of the season here. Play was interrupted in the twelfth inning toy a heavy rain.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- New bottom prices for oats, the lowest since 1897, were made last week on the Board of Trade here. September sold at 14 7/8 cents a bushel, December 17 1/4 cents and May 20 1/4 cents. The close was at 15 3/8 cents for September, 17 7/8 cents for December and 20 5/8 cents for May.

A natural rebound from the gloom of a depressive period into a future of cheer was described to the congregation of the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, Sixtieth Street and Madison Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, in his sermon yesterday.

Plans are progressing rapidly for the second annual Peacock Ball in aid of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, to be held on the night of Nov. 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The "entire series of ballrooms has been taken for the event.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- Coming events cast shadows even in the Soviet Union, where much is veiled in mystery. There are two such shadows in today's press.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- O.M. Pearson's Bozo led eleven rival craft today in the Interclub Class event of the invitation regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club, which closed the organization's yacht-racing season.

ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 13 -- George Collins, secretary to former Mayor James J. Walker, who had a bad attack of liver trouble, was better today and the ship's doctor said that unless there was a relapse the secretary would land at Naples on Tuesday.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The British Government, in a sharply worded official memorandum, today took its stand squarely with France in rejecting the legality of Germany's claim to equal status and in denouncing in most emphatic terms her threat to rearm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Regardless of the bonus resolution passed by the American Legion in Portland, citizens may be reasonably assured that the day is still far off for the payment of the bonus. The Legion is not the dominant organization that many people suppose it to be.

Francis P. Garvan, head of the Chemical Foundation, declared in a statement made public yesterday that Governor Roosevelt, in his fight for the Presidency, was being made the object of "foul play." He voiced a demand for "fair play in politics," which he declared should be "as sacred to us as fair play in football or baseball."

SHANGHAI, Sept. 18 -- With the exception of a manhandling causing slight injuries to a Japanese who, disguised as a Chinese, was discovered attending a patriotic rally at Nanking, the much-dreaded first anniversary of the Japanese seizure of Mukden passed off without serious disturbances.

The twelve-day race meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will begin today with the seven-furlong Bay Shore Handicap as the feature. Morfair, owned and trained by J.P. Smith, seems certain to be the favorite, as only three others have been named, Dark Secret, Pardee and Halcyon.

In an open letter to Mayor McKee, made public yesterday, the City Affairs Committee urged him to stand by the four-year bond plan of subway financing sponsored by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation. Its abandonment, as recently urged by the Citizens Budget Commission, the letter declared, would mean an end to the five-cent fare on rapid transit lines, including the city's independent subway system.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Five men, two-officers and three outlaws, are dead as a result of pistol fights growing out of the slaying of Mrs. Susie Sharp, a motorist, in a hold-up on a mountain road two weeks ago.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- The reaction of the steel trade to the week's developments was one of disappointment that there were not more signs of improvement, and a conclusion that more time would be required than was expected for the steel industry to attain an operating rate of 25 to 30 per cent, approximately the rate estimated to be needed to cover fixed charges for the industry in general.

Representatives of patriotic societies throughout the city gathered yesterday morning at the Hall of Fame at New York University to observe Constitution Day and to place a wreath on the bust of George Washington. The ceremonies, broadcast over WEAF, were arranged by the New York University School of Law in cooperation with the American Bar Association.

Sam Medal, proprietor of a restaurant at 147 West Forty-seventh Street, has been missing since Sept. 6, it was learned yesterday when a police alarm was sent out for him. Tried for murder and acquitted in the Bronx in 1928, he is said to have been engaged since as a bookmaker.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Miss Joan Ridley of England conquered Miss Alice Francis of Orange, N.J., by 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, today in the singles final of the Ardsley Club's seventeenth annual invitation tourney.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 -- The Bolsa last week was the liveliest in many months, with sharp upward price movements, especially in government bonds, and with heavy trading which on several days reached totals of 3,000,000 pesos.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. J. William Kilbreth are expected at the Barclay Thursday.

Part of the work being done by some of the Hadassah's medical departments in Palestine is superior to that of similar agencies in Europe and America, particularly in the field of school hygiene, Dr. Haim Yassky said yesterday at one of the sessions of the eighteenth annual convention of Hadassah, national women's Zionist organization, at the Hotel Commodore.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Reserving the first eleven and the majority of the ranking substitutes for a scrimmage with the scrubs tomorrow, Coach Eddie Casey of the Harvard football forces today used the third and fourth string men in a 45-minute test.

Stone Webster, Inc., paid off all its own bank loans during the first eight months of this year, while its principal subsidiary, the Engineers Public Service Company, reduced its own and subsidiaries' bank loans by $3,720,000 during the same period. Other Stone Webster, Inc., subsidiaries reduced bank loans by $600,000, making total reductions of $6,220,000 by the group so far this year.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- All of the seeded players, excepting Miss Joan Ridley, ranked No. 1, took part in the first day's play of the Bronxville Field Club's fifth annual clay court Invitation tennis tourney today and advanced easily.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Three teams lied for the first prize in the Long Island Golf Association's first amateur-professional tournament, held at the Sands Point Club today. Each of the combinations scored a 69, two strokes below par.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney announced yesterday that, in compliance with Mayor McKee's order to him early last week, the police in four boroughs of the city had seized 239 alleged gambling slot machines and made 211 arrests of storekeepers and others for maintaining them.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Smead Jolley, outfielder, donned the catcher's mask, mask and chest-protector for the Boston Red Sox today and figured prominently in a 5-to-4 victory over the Tigers. Jolley hit a home run with two on base in the second.

The Giants and Braves, for whom the year promised to provide a much brighter finish some five months ago, settled down to the grim business of hustling through the final week of the season at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Cities Service Company interests in Federal court today challenged the validity of recent orders of the Public Service Commission, directing them to reduce their natural-gas rates to consumers in nearly 100 Kansas cities by approximately 25 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time of wholesale emotional condemnation of the head of the "Hutchinson Flying Family" for taking his children along, a further word on the subject may not be amiss.

Govt. Rossevelt Knows Where to Appropriate. If the Republicans can make good the charge that Governor ROOSEVELT stole his railroad program from them it will help to prove his fitness for the Presidency.

Business on the Stock Exchange fell off sharply yesterday as compared with the daily average of last week. The turnover was 1,296,000 shares. The market was the slowest since July 21, which was soon after the beginning of the recent upswing. The movement of prices yesterday was irregular, with final quotations showing moderate net losses, in the average.

Cornelius Whitney and his contract rider, Robby Robertson, scored a double and a triple, respectively, as the Queens County Jockey Club opened its Fall meeting at Aqueduct yesterday. Mr. Whitney's Halcyon won the Bay Shore Handicap, and his Pooks Hill captured the Sunrise Purse for 2-year-olds.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The publication yesterday of the British statement on disarmament, with its icy rebukes to Germany, leaves the Anglo-French entente stronger than when it re-emerged from the Lausanne conference two months ago.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Germany, it has been, decided, will make no formal reply to the British note to the participants in the disarmament conference on the subject of the German claim to arms equality. Nor will the Reich be represented at the sessions of the bureau of the conference, opening Wednesday.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Miss Nancy Fay Nicoll, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Matthias Nicoll Jr. of Loudon Woods, Rye, and Miss Eleanor Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Pierce Grant of Manursing Island, Rye, were introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by their parents at the Manursing Island Club.

Opposition to the plan for the reopening of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, at Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, was expressed yesterday when the proposal came before Supreme Court Justice Shientag for approval, because the program does not call for an immediate payment to the depositors in full.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Retail food prices in fifty-one cities of the United States showed an average decrease of two-tenths of 1 per cent on Aug. 15, as compared with July 15, the Department of Labor announced today, and an average decrease of about 15% per cent since Aug. 31, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Details were completed today for a more intensive campaign by the Republicans with the making of arrangements by which Secretary Mills, other members of the Cabinet and Vice President Curtis will take the stump in a drive in which President Hoover will participate with two speeches in the Corn and Wheat belts.

BUTTE, Mont., Sept. 19 -- Before one of the largest and most enthusiastic crowds yet encountered on his tour, Franklin D. Roosevelt promised today that if elected President he would call immediately after his inauguration an international monetary conference to consider the rehabilitation of silver.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 19 -- Requests for more than $1,000,000 for home mortgage loans have been received by F. Vail Spinosa, chairman of the committee appointed by Governor James R. Beverley to study the needs and necessities of establishing a branch of the Federal Mortgage Bank here.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The future unity of Britain's "National" Government is at stake in a struggle now going on in the Liberal party over continuance in the Cabinet of Sir Herbert Samuel, the Home Secretary, and Sir Archibald Sinclair, the Secretary for Scotland, who with Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, Lord Privy Seal, are the last out-and-out free traders left in the government.

When fear comes to political managers and candidates, they usually take good pains not to make public confession of it. They poohpooh defeat, minimize it and pretend to go on their way rejoicing. Chairman SANDERS treated the Maine election according to the old formula.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 19 -- Senator Antonio Barcelo, Liberal party leader, has filed protests with Executive Secretary Saldana against the registration of the Nationalist party for participation in the November elections. Both parties favor independence, the Liberals under United States protection while the Nationalists are for absolute severance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, Mr. Charles Edward Thomas of Indianapolis, Ind., in his interesting letter on "Old Altar Stones in America," suffers from a confusion of ideas. There are "altar stones" in the strict technical sense Of the term and in a wider sense.

HOULTON, Me., Sept. 19 -- An investigator for the Attorney General's department came to Aroostook County today seeking depositions from the election officials in charge of ten voting precincts in last Monday's State election, in which a Democratic Governor and two Democratic Representatives in Congress were elected by narrow margins.

Declaring that American business is closer to better times than most of its executives realize, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, yesterday told members of the Controllers' Institute of America that controllers are entering upon an era when they will be able to advise the spending rather than conservation of money.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- What the original baseball writer meant by a "crucial series" opens at Wrigley Field tomorrow before a crowd of championship-hungry Cub fans.

The nationalistic tendencies of an American fascism which is daily gaining in strength and the political apathy, indifference and cynicism of the people are leading the country to a catastrophe which can be staved off only by acceptance of the principles of socialism, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, said last night at a dinner in his honor at Mecca Temple.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 19 -- The Ministry of Premier F.T. Hamrin resigned today after having been defeated in yesterday's elections to the Swedish Riksdag, but King Gustav requested it to remain in office until a new government was formed.

MONTREAL, Que., Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Price Brothers Co., Ltd., will not be able to meet their liabilities to bondholders before Nov. 1. when the period of grace will expire for the bond interest defaulted on Aug. 1, unless assistance is received, according to a letter from, the company.

If it had been expected that Governor Roosevelt's declaration on Saturday evening of his railway policy would be received on the Stock Exchange by an enthusiastic rise, the expectation was disappointed. In yesterday's stock market there was an early though moderate advance, followed by subsequent loss of all the gain.

VIENNA, Sept. 19 -- The police here have confiscated nearly 110 pounds of pure gold (worth about $27,000) from Harry Gruenberg, an American dealer in precious stones and metals, and from a gold dealer named Springut and a Viennese gold merchant.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- The American Sheet and Tin Plate Company today increased to capacity its plant at Farrell, Pa., putting 1,800 men back to work. The plant normally employs 3,800 men.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Officials of the railroads and the railroad labor unions will meet here tomorrow in the first round of the expected long and bitter contest over a 20 per cent wage reduction. Secrecy veiled the arrangements for the meeting but both sides confirmed that it would be held.

BUFFALO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Delegates to the New York State Waterways Association convention met here today to decide what to do about the projected St. Lawrence waterway development. The international development of the river has the approval of some groups in the State, but is strongly opposed by others.

Speaking last night over the radio from station WOR, John W. Davis, Democratic candidate for President in 1924 and present vice president of the Citizens' Budget Commission, declared that taxes had reached the point where they were becoming confiscatory, and warned that existing conditions, unless speedily remedied, would mean government failure, big business failures and one-man failures.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Defeated by National Guardsmen in an attempt to hold a mass meeting here, nearly 600 striking miners this afternoon moved toward the Sangamon County line outside the jurisdiction of Christian County authorities and planned a protest meeting at Pawnee.

Delegates to serve in the nine divisions into which the Holy Name Society of the New York Police Department has been divided were named yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the officers of that organization held at the Hotel Astor. The presiding officer was the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, chaplain of the Police Department and spiritual director of its Holy Name Society.

The United States liner Leviathan will sail for Plymouth, Cherbourg and Bremen tonight. Among her passengers will be George W. Davidson, president of the Central Hanover Trust Company, with Mrs. Davidson; Dr. Henry H. Drewry, psychiatrist of Craig House, Beacon, N. Y., and Sir William Mitchell, vice chancellor of the University of Adelaide, South Australia.

Transit unification negotiations between the companies and public officials have come to a complete halt, with no prospect of progress until the doubts surrounding the future of Mayor McKee have been cleared away, Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of directors of the B.M.T. and Interborough, declared yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting of the former company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The plan proposed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler for liquor control, barring the saloon, and proposing a State authority to regulate the traffic after prohibition is ended, was rejected tonight by the Anti-Saloon League in a statement issued by Edward B. Dunford, its general counsel.

A lone patrolman who attempted to break up single-handed a Communist street-corner meeting was set upon, knocked down, kicked and struck last night, and four men, one a speaker at the gathering:, were arrested.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 19 -- The Marchioness, winner of the Hambletonian stake, trotted to an easy victory today in the $14,000 Kentucky Futurity for 3-year-olds, the opening-day feature. It brought the filly's winnings for the year to $52,440. In 1931, as a 2-year-old, she won $6,760.

If the Republicans nominate Colonel DONOVAN for Governor, as it is now probable that they will, he will evidently strive for party harmony. His letter pledging fealty, to State Chairman MACY, whether the nomination comes to him or not, was a political master-stroke.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Ellsworth Vines Jr. inaugurated his campaign in the defense of his Pacific Southwest singles tennis championship today by defeating his double, John Alman of South Pasadena, Cal., in love sets, 6-0, 6-0.

Federal investigators said yesterday they expected the surrender of Edward J. Moffett, long missing secretary treasurer of the Central Bank and Trust Company of Newark, N.J., to result in conspiracy indictments against twenty members of a liquor ring operating on both sides of the Hudson River.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The League Loans Committee of London has addressed a memorial to the government drawing attention to the present serious position of loans issued under the auspices of the League of Nations with the full approval of the British Government and requesting it to move that the League do everything in its power to safeguard the special status of these loans.

The depression has hit the Republican State Committee in New Jersey hard. On Friday it announced that the $90,000 deficit of the Baird campaign for Governor last year would have to be carried over while money was being raised for the needs of this year.
Former Governor Smith has made plans to remain silent on both. State and national politics until the Democratic State Convention is ready to open at Albany on Oct. 3, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A prediction that President Hoover would carry few States west of the Mississippi because of a "revolt" against the Republican party was made today by Representative Shannon, Democrat, of Missouri.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The American Medical Association voiced a protest today against government hospitalization.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The stock markets began the week depressed and dull, with most quotations lower, on news from the Continent and Wall Street. Investment in British funds continued, but the morning gains were lost in the afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Federal authorities today promised an investigation to determine whether the Federal criminal statutes were violated in the last desperate effort to stave off the crash of the Insull utilities organization last June.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- The Italian Foreign Ministry's first reaction this morning to the British note relative to Germany's demands for equal rights in armaments was disappointment, especially with the tone of the note, which was regarded as rather brusque in parts and rather vague as a whole.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 19 -- Police found yesterday, at the foot of a gigantic electric letter "H," evidence of a movieland tragedy -- the bruised body of a girl who failed.

PEIPING, Sept. 19 -- Governor Tang Yu-lin of Jehol telegraphed today to Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang in Peiping saying the Jehol commander at Chaoyang reported that Japanese planes were dropping leaflets threatening to raze the towns within eighteen miles of the Manchurian border unless the irregulars cease their activities and release Gonshiro Ishimoto at once.

J. Monroe Hewlett, architect and mural painter who recently was elected director of the American Academy in Rome, said yesterday on the eve of his departure that efforts would be made by the academy to further understanding among the architects, artists and sculptors of this nation.

BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 19 -- Exchange of views on the Stresa and world economic conferences dominated the World Bank board's monthly meeting here today. Except for an expected decision allowing Germany to lower its discount rate, wich was taken along lines forecast yesterday, the brief meeting devoted itself either to routine matters or to details connected with the Stresa and world conferences.

Kidnapped and held for $25,000 ransom, John Arthur Russell, 8-year-old son of a partner in a New York Stock Exchange firm, was mysteriously returned to his home at 114 Eighty-first Street, Brooklyn, just before last midnight. In the twelve hours for which he had been missing he had been the object of an unusually intensive police search.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- With the receipt of $41,679,744 in income taxes at the Treasury Sept. 16, the total for the month through that date was $84,385,412, a reduction of $69,000,000 as compared with the first sixteen days of September last year. For the fiscal year through Sept. 16 the total was $116,504,800, a decrease of $83,483,000 from last year.
BOMBAY, Sept. 19 -- Deaf to all pleas of his friends, Mahatma Gandhi today went ahead with plans to begin to "fast unto the death" at noon tomorrow.

KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Captain Nieto Gomez Elola, master of the sloop Julio which was seized with six Cuban political refugees last Saturday, testified today he had been tied below decks and his boat brought into United States waters after setting out from Havana on a proposed fishing trip.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Association of Commerce review of business for the week said that wholesale trade, Chicago employment, and telephone installations were increasing. The report said employment in 508 factories here increased 3.9 per cent in August over July and that payrolls went up 9.1 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Triumphing over the Dodgers by 5 to 3 today, the ambitious Phillies moved to within half a game of the third-place rung on the National League ladder and face tomorrow's contest with high hopes of tumbling Max Carey's men into fourth place.

Who but a biologist would associate breathing the air and walking on dry land? Yet brains and hands are no more intimately related than are lungs and legs. It is for this reason that Professor KOCH'S discovery of large numbers of early Stegocephalians in Greenland arrests attention.

School authorities are urged to exercise "the utmost care to avoid waste and inefficiency" and to limit the activities of training schools for teachers in a memorandum prepared yesterday by the governing board of the United Parents' Associations, copies of which will be sent to the Board of Education and the director of the city budget.

ALGONAC, Mich., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The feeling among residents of this small marine village tonight was that, barring bad weather or another mishap, a new world's speed record for motor boats will be set tomorrow morning on the St. Clair River here by a "home-town boy."

The new Eighth Avenue subway carried 1,240,704 revenue passengers between 12:01 A.M. on, Sept. 10 and midnight on Sept. 16, yielding a revenue of $62,035,20 for the first full week of operation. The average daily revenue was $8,862,17.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Connie Mack's score card won't wave from a world's series dugout this Fall -- but how he can sleep!
