SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 19 Eel-like in slipperiness, Bandit II, the Western Long Island Sound fleet's representative in the intei national Star Class competitior, came through the third race today to win by a margin so great it well could be said there was no second.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Premier Herriot received informal but positive assurances today from Senator Reed of Pennsylvania and Ambassador Edge that the United States was joining France and Great Britain in insistence that, whatever settlement was made regarding German equality rights there must not be any rearmament by any one, it is understood on excellent authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation granted a three-year loan of $2,000,000 to the Pennsylvania Railroad today for building 1,285 freight cars, thus affording work, in the Pennsylvania shops for about 700 men for five months, and additional employment in industries which will furnish material and specialties for the cars.
NEW YORK. Countess Eleanor Davico has come from Ancaster, Ont., and is with her brother, John G.F. Speiden, at 103 East Seventy-fifth Street, for several weeks before her return to Italy.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 19 (AP) -- While public demonstrations demanding war with Peru continued without abatment tonight, the Senate unanimously approved a $10,000,000 national defense bill on third reading. The bill was sent to the House, which passed it unanimously on first reading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway presents an interesting study in psychology, with an effect that seems to be quite the reverse of what might have been predicted before the opening of the line.

LA PAZA, Bolivia, Sept. 19 -- Officers arriving from the Chaco say the Boquero action is one of the biggest engagements that ever took place between South American nations. Both Paraguay and Bolivia are fighting desperately for a decision, although Paraguay has thrice as large an army there.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Arthur Henderson, president of the disarmament conference, in a letter to Foreign Minister von Neurath of Germany, today appealed for the return of the Germans to the Geneva sessions.

Two young men, operators of the elevators in 1,100 Park Avenue, were arrested yesterday and charged with three burglaries in the building, which contains sixty-four apartments. The prisoners gave their names as Frank Morris, 23 years old, of 356 East Eighty-eighth Street, and Cornelius Haggerty, 20, of 149 East Ninetieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Sept. 14 shows increases for the week of $221,000,000 in net demand deposits and $107,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Berlin is reported to have been as much surprised as offended by the British note repelling German proposals concerning armaments. The French Government had previously sent a pretty tart reply to the announced plans of the von Papen Cabinet.

Nothing of vital importance to the welfare of the modern theatre has been accomplished by the production of "Lilly Turner," which was acted at the Morosco last evening. Philip Dunning and George Abbott, who once wrote an epochal thriller dubbed "Broadway," have made this back-stage play from a story by Frances Fox Dunning.

Martin A. Klein of the Bohemian Gymnastic Association defeated William J. McAuliffe of the League of Neighborhood School Centres by a vote of 124 to 37 for the presidency of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union at the annual election at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn last night.

While police of the city were hunting for an ambulance in response to a radio alarm that it had been stolen from St. Vincent's Hospital at Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, traffic men on Lexington Avenue halted all cars to make way for a hurry call.

DETROIT, Texas, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The old Colonial house of the Garners was in gloom tonight as its mistress, Mrs. Sarah Jane Garner, mother of Speaker Garner, lay critically ill, her life slowly ebbing away.

Shopping throngs of holiday-like proportions on Saturday and yesterday yielded the best sales volume in many months for local department stores and specialty shops, retail executives here reported yesterday. In numerous instances the business on Saturday exceeded that of the same day a year ago, with comments generally indicating that so far as pieces of merchandise or individual transactions went the total proved Saturday the best day in two years.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday in a range of nearly $2 a bale and closed 6 to 10 points higher than on Saturday under a large volume of business.

The report of Commissioner TAYLOR on home relief during the six months ending June 30, 1932, tells what has been spent and the nature of the relief but could give no estimate of what it has meant to the half-million individuals saved from utter destitution.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Twenty State troopers swooped down on this Middlesex County borough shortly before midnight tonight and, using clubs instead of firearms, dispersed an angry mob of 3,000 men and women who had held forty private detectives from Newark and all fourteen members of the South River police force virtual captives in the Borough Hall for nearly six hours.

In making public yesterday a report on three years of progress by the iron alloys committee of the Engineering Foundation, at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, in its five-year program of research, Frank A. Sisco asserted that readjustment of the steel industry to quality instead of quantity production was inevitable.

Strength in long-term issues of the United States Government and in some domestic railroad obligations featured trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Activity was limited for the most part to a few leading issues, and the day's turnover amounted to only $7,915,500, compared with more than $10,000,000 on the last preceding full day's trading.

In a sudden move for conciliation with labor, the railroad managements suspended notices for a 20 per cent wage reduction which they were to have served yesterday on the unions and prepared to discuss with union officials today a proposal that the move be negotiated outside the provisions of the railway labor act.

The Club New Yorker, occupying a four-story building at 38 East Fifty-first Street, and with furnishings and equipment said to be worth more than $40,000, was raided last night by seven prohibition agents in evening clothes. After ordering out 150 men and women patrons, the agents made twenty-one arrests, including Ettore Bonomi of 416 West Forty-fourth Street, the manager, and Mero Morro of East Rutherford, N.J., the headwaiter.
TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- The War Office announces that reservists whose time has expired are being recalled from Manchuria and replaced by fresh drafts.

With the announcement yesterday that Earle W. Hopping would captain the opposition for the team picked by Thomas Hitchcock Jr. in the closing event of the Meadow Brook polo season next Saturday, the United States Polo Association also announced the complete line-ups for this special match.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The La Follette movement in politics, now in its second generation of dominance in Wisconsin, will face another test in tomorrow's primary when voters select candidates for State and national offices.

MANILA, Sept. 19 -- The Philippine Japanese Merchants' Association, through the Japanese Consul, entered a formal protest today against tariff bills now pending in the Legislature, declaring that they were discriminatory and counter to the spirit of the American-Japanese commercial treaty of 1911.

A group of water-colors by American artists opened yesterday at the Delphic Studios, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until Oct. 2. It is a sufficiently diverse display, containing work as strikingly dissimilar as that by Anton Refregier, incorrigible "modernist," and by Edith Nagler, whose flower subjects are conventionally pleasing (she won the Crowninshield prize for water-color recently in the annual Summer show at Stockbridge, Mass.).

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Per Albin Hansson, who is likely to be the next Premier of Sweden, began his career as a clerk in a cooperative store, left that to work on a Socialist newspaper, and in 1911 was elected to a seat in the Riksdag.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 19 -- The Paraguay Foreign Minister cabled to the commission of neutrals in Washington today that Paraguay was ready to suspend hostilities whenever she should, receive guarantees that Bolivia would be unable to use the truce to continue strengthening her positions in the disputed Chaco.
JOHN Q. CITIZEN, being duly sworn, took the witness stand. The examination then proceeded as follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- The spending power of the public can be increased quickly only by spreading available work over a larger number of workers, Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company, of New Jersey, told the Boston Conference on Retail Distribution here today in outlining the national share-the-work movement.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Definite signs of an improvement in business conditions were noted in a report made today by Henry H. Helman, executive manager of the National Association, of Credit Men, at a conference here of secretary-managers of the association.

Armed robbers stole the week-end receipts of dozens of Good Humor dispensing automobiles from the central garage and office of the Good Humor Company in Maspeth early yesterday and left four of the employes locked in a vault, where they were discovered, nearly suffocated, several hours later.

ABOARD S.S. CONTE GRANDE, Sept. 19 -- His health greatly improved by the sea voyage, former Mayor Walker of New York went ashore at Palermo today. Dressed in a biscuit-colored coat, a creamcolored shirt and trousers, a palegreen tie and tan-and-white shoes, Mr. Walker's sartorial display astonished Italian officials who greeted him at the pier.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- China's new civil war, which is stretching over an eighty-four-mile front across the entire base of the Shantung peninsula and involves much larger fighting forces than those of Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco clash, completGly supersedes the Chino-Japanese tension in public interest.

Jennie Scaccio, 17 years old, of 1,166 First Avenue, walking along Eighth Avenue near Thirty-ninth Street at 8:30 A.M. yesterday, on the way to work, was shot in the neck as some unidentified men engaged in a pistol fight in the street nearby.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The strong appeal to both sentiment and sympathy which we find in President Hoover's address to the Conference of Relief Workers, of course, will have response from all hearts, and, to some extent, from very many minds as well.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Clifford Sutter of Tulane University, who carried Ellsworth Vines to five sets in the recent national singles championship tournament, has been selected as the ranking intercollegiate tennis player of the country.

Thirty-six manufacturers of radio sets and parts are exhibiting their 1932-33 styles at a trade show at the Hotel Edison, Forty-seventh Street. The show opened yesterday in the ballroom and will continue until Saturday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- President Hoover's program to bring about economic stabilization was praised by Senator Fess of Ohio tonight as offering "relief to more people than all the proposals enacted since the Civil War up to 1931."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 19 -- In a statement issued today, Philip N. Krug, Democratic leader, charged the Republican Board of Supervisors had failed to supply an economical government. He declared that there were 125 county automobiles in operation and that almost every county employe "from the sealer of weights and measures to the chairman of the board" had a car at his disposal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With characteristic Republican omission of facts and distortion of logic, the latest attempt to mislead the voters comes in the form of a so-called "tariff education" card. According to THE TIMES, the first series of the cards contains the following "legend":

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Mrs. George H. Miles of Rumson, who refused to attend the Republican National Convention in Chicago as a delegate at large from New Jersey, presumably because of the party attitude toward prohibition, announced her resignation as president of the New Jersey State Women's Republican Club at a meeting of the board of governors here today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Associate Justice John Crawford Crosby of the Massachusetts Supreme Court and Mrs. Crosby entertained at dinner tonight at their home in Pittsfield for Chief Justice Arthur Prentice Rugg and Associate Justices Charles H. Donahue, William C. Wait and Henry T. Lummus.
Transfers of real estate recorded in Manhattan yesterday were confined mostly to east side properties. The conveyances were as follows:

Eight firemen were overcome by smoke or otherwise injured early this morning fighting a stubborn fire that swept the basement of the Columbia School of Journalism. The fire was discovered at 12:15 A. M. and three alarms were sent out by 1 o'clock bringing all available apparatus from the Morningside, Harlem and Yorkville districts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The public library is playing an important part in sustaining the morale of the country, Harry M. Lydenberg, president of the American Library Association, told members of the New York Library Association at the State organization's annual conference here today.

The Catholic Book Survey makes public today the sixth list of books recommended by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee. The list shows an increase in the number of titles under religion and a decrease in biography. The Survey remarks that there are "comparatively few juveniles, for, surprisingly enough, some of the books that have been most decisively rejected by the committee were intended for younger readers."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- F. Scattergood, general manager of the Los Angeles Bureau of Power and Light, after a conference with President Hoover today, said he had discussed the city's request for $22,800,000 from the Reconstruction Corporation to construct a transmission line from Hoover Dam to Los Angeles.

Bankers' acceptances outstanding at the end of August amounted to $681,465,807, or $23,180,785 less than the $704,646,592 at the end of July, Robert H. Bean, executive secretary of the American Acceptance Council, reported yesterday. At the close of August, 1931, they totaled $1,090,399,849, or $408,934,042 more than at the end of last month.

United States Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, placed on trial here yesterday for alleged violation of the Federal lottery laws, heard himself described by Assistant United States Attorney Louis M. Treadwell as the "Mussolini" of the Loyal Order of Moose arid the "great organizer" who conceived its nation-wide campaigns of charity balls.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19 -- A closer association of capital and labor for collective dealing in place of collective bargaining was advocated here tonight by John D. Rockefeller 3d in an address at a dinner marking the opening of the tenth year of the course in industrial relations at Princeton University.

Mayor McKee threw down, the gauntlet yesterday to producers of theatrical performances that he considered objectionable by ordering the closing of the Eltinge and Republic burlesque theatres on Forty-second Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
James Stewart Carstairs, noted artist and collector, died yesterday penniless and embittered. His death ended an unequal struggle between an aesthetic soul and unaccustomed poverty.

Night work on preparation of the 1933 budget was ordered yesterday by Mayor Joseph V. McKee, who wishes to have the tentative budget in shape well before Oct. 10. At the same time the Mayor arranged several conferences on budget reduction to be held later in the week.

Police Lieutenant THOMAS F. BERKERY, promoted to the rank of captain last Friday, entered the city's service as a patrolman in 1913. After ten years he was advanced to the rank of sergeant. In 1927 he was made a lieutenant. In 1928 he took the examination for captain.

Wilton Lackaye, the actor, who died on Aug. 21 at his home here, left the greater part of his estate, formally appraised for probate at "more than $20,000," to his widow, Katherine, according to the petition, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates' Court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Wholesale commodity prices advanced more than one per cent in August, as compared with July, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Answering a question, the Foreign Office flatly denied today the suggestion that a representative of the French Government was bargaining for the Grozny oil fields in return for French support of the Soviet Union in the Far East.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotation! are for three-four months' paper.

Columbia entered the final stages of its pre-season football training yesterday at Baker Field. Coach Lou Little had the Morningside aspirants out for two drills in preparation for the Lion's contest with Middlebury here Saturday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- The action of the wheat market today was discouraging to interests on each side An early advance occurred in the face of a decline in stocks, the December touching 54 cents a bushel, or 3/4 cent above the final figures of Saturday This brought in selling against offers.

In the current number of the Physical Review Professor A.H. Compton summarizes the results of his South American studies of the cosmic rays and piles up more evidence to show that the rays are not light-waves, as Professor Robert A. Millikan supposes, but true electrons or electrified bits of matter that are affected by the earth's magnetism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A belief that the American people are beginning to realize that intelligent economies in government costs are the way out of the present economic condition was expressed tonight by Silas H. Strawn.
State primaries for selection of national, State and local candidates end today with Democratic and Republican voting in New York, Massachusetts and Wisconsin.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Ten thousand racing enthusiasts welcomed the return of the sport to the Maryland mile tracks for the Fall campaign today. It was the first of the two welfare cards which precede the opening of the regular ten-day meeting of the Harford Association on Wednesday and General Manager Edward Burke estimated that approximately $20,000 had been raised for the unemployment relief funds.

An agreement for harmony and cooperation will be sealed today between Colonel William J. Donovan, aspirant for the Republican nomination for Governor, and W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, who until recently had observed an attitude of cold aloofness from the rapidly progressing movement for the former Assistant United States Attorney General and war-time commander of the "Fighting Sixty-ninth."

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt and Mrs. Calvin Coolidge, former mistresses of the White House, head a list of prominent women throughout the nation who have endorsed the candidacy of President Hoover and accepted membership on a board of counselors to assist in bringing about his re-election.

In the thick cover which abounds in many favored sections of New York State, including Long Island, the nimrods will find plenty of pheasant this year, in fact far more than in recent years, for the State Conservation Department has distributed 21,000 birds for the forthcoming pheasant season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Robert Moses Grove was not at his best today, but was good enough to account for his twenty-fifth victory of the American League season as Philadelphia defeated the Chicago White Sox, 9 to 6, in the final game of the season at Comiskey Park.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- After four years of fluctuating fortune and experimenting in styles of attack. Dr. Mal Stevens is in the position to put a Yale football team on the field which gives rich promise of becoming the apple of his eye. The 1932 edition of the Bulldog may not be the most successful eleven of the season.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt's Salt Lake City speech showed that he understood many of the problems confronting the railroads, W.R. Cole, president of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, declared today.

The committee of veterans who announced on Sunday its support of Controller Charles W. Berry for the Mayoralty nomination this Fall, if an election is held, will obtain an audience today with Tammany leader John F. Curry, and possibly with Brooklyn leader John H. McCooey, as well.

Joseph C. Baldwin 3d, minority leader of the Board of Aldermen, returned yesterday from Europe on the French liner Paris, expressing a degree of sympathy for former Mayor James J. Walker in the opinion that Mr. Walker had been "taken for a ride by his friends."

With the opening of classes yesterday New York University completed arrangements for the first of a series of welcoming exercises for an incoming group of 4,500 freshmen. Chapel exercises, student assemblies, fraternity parties and other activities continuing until Sept. 30 will bring together teachers and students.

Confidence in the outlook for the shoe and leather industries during the next six months was expressed yesterday by Fraser M. Moffatt, president of the Tanners' Council of America, in welcoming shoe manufacturers and retail representatives to the official opening of American leathers for Spring and Summer of 1933, at the Hotel Astor.

Ease in the outside market for call loans with the rate down to 1 1/4 per cent, was the only development of interest. Offerings were heavy at that figure but demand wag on a small scale. The Stock Exchange rate continued at 2 per cent. There were no other changes in the market, quotations for other classifications remaining unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The British assent to France's warning to Germany that the latter will be expected to live up to the Versailles Treaty as regards arms limitation today created a perplexing situation for the State Department, complicated by unofficial reports from abroad that American spokesmen had assured foreign diplomats the United States was in complete sympathy with the Franco-British attitude.
STRESA, Italy, Sept. 19 -- Plans for economic rehabilitation of Central and Eastern Europe, which have been thrashed out in committee, were accepted by the Stresa conference today in an open meeting.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept., 19 -- Miss Jane Brooks of Knickerbocker and Mrs. Walter MacGowan of Essex Fells scored 88s to tie for the medal in the qualifying round for the women's golf championship of New Jersey at the Echo Lake Country Club today.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- France's rente conversion law went into operation today with the authorized agencies receiving requests for reimbursement. Those wanting their money back have only six days in which to make application, after which the bonds are automatically regarded as converted.

Aiming at restabilization of the hotel industry throughout the country, a group of nationally known hotel men, bankers and industrialists has formed the Hotel Reconstruction Corporation. It plans to make the resources of the new venture immediately available to hotels and hotel companies in distress to the authorities in Washington and to courts handling receiverships of such enterprises.

The body of Frank Byrne, 33 years old, one of Wild Bill Lovett's old Brooklyn waterfront gang who was released from Clinton Prison a few months ago after serving a little more than seven years for robbery, was found in the East River off Fulton Street yesterday.

WORTHINGTON, Minn., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Picket lines of mid-Western farmers attempting to bring about higher prices for their products reached into new territory today with more than 400 "strikers" guarding highways in this vicinity.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Methodists from all parts of the world have gathered in London for the official celebration in Albert Hall tomorrow afternoon of the union of the three great branches of the Methodist Church, the Primitive Methodists, the United Methodists and the Wesleyans.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- Business on the Boerse continued quiet today, with stock prices declining gradually. The comparative strength of bonds prevented the downward tendency in stocks from assuming larger proportions. Stocks closed at the lowest quotations of the day. Mining shares, which for many weeks have been the centre of general interest, declined 1 to 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The annual crime bill of the United States is greater today than the annual cost to the nation of carrying on the World War, according to Gordon L. Hofstetter, executive director of the Employers' Association of Chicago.

THERE was a stir in scientific circles recently when Dr. Lauge Koch, explorer, announced from Copenhagen that on a trip to Greenland he had discovered petrified or fossilized remains of four-footed fishes. That's quite all right, but why did the scientific gentlemen never get into a stir about the famous Two-Legged Talking Crab (Callinectis Bipes Loquens) that has been walking a ound in baseball circles for years?
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 20. -- Governor Roosevelt's prepared speech here tonight was as follows:

After a day of intensive investigation the police were unable to find any trace of the "amateur" abductors of John Arthur Russell, 8 years old, son of Arthur S. Russell, Wall Street broker. The boy was released by his captors on Monday night after eleven hours in their custody and returned to his home.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20. -- For a team that has lost threequarters of its back field, including the intellectual Barry Wood, both of its guards and a tackle of the exceptional qualification of Dave Kopans, Harvard looks to be about as crippled as a mountain lion that has had its tail tied into a bow knot.

Stock Market and Convalescence. Wall Street has made up its mind, for the time being at any rate that the patient is not going to die. Having tobogganed from a state of dazzling optimism into a state of profound funk, the financial district is now inclined to be soberly cheerful.

County Judge John J. Fitzgerald held three men yesterday in 55,000 bail on charges of conspiracy in the operations of the City Pharmaceutical Association of 105 Court Street, Brooklyn, through which they were alleged to have intimidated druggists throughout the borough into joining the organization.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Failure of Westchester bank stocks to be listed with other securities in financial reports in New York City was criticized today at a meeting of the newly formed Westchester Clearing House Association, at which steps were taken to complete the organization and commence operations.
All is now harmony between Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican Gubernatorial aspirant, and W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee.

Wall Street Interest in the stock market abated further yesterday. The turnover was even, smaller than on the day before, but the price movement indicated that an effort was being made to bring about another advance in prices. The tone of the market was strong in the last hour and speculators began to bid for stocks with some determination.

Stewart Browne, president of the United Real Estate Owners Association, who has attended nearly every meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for the past eighteen years, gave yesterday his personal and professional opinion of the last four Mayors of New York City in an address to the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club at a luncheon in the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The stock markets continued quiet today, with most sections dull in tendency. The internationals improved in the afternoon on Brussels buying of Hydroelectric and Brazilian Traction. Most of the industrials were easier, with Dunlop Rubber, Imperial Chemical, Swedish Match and Cables and Wireless all lower.

The real estate, rolling stock and equipment of the old Dry Dock, East Broadway Battery Railroad Company were sold at foreclosure yesterday in the Vesey Street Exchange, 18 Vesey Street, by Joseph P. Day, auctioneer, under the direction of Ralph J. Barda, referee.

Controller Charles W. Berry's Mayoralty boom took a half step forward yesterday when a committee of war veterans who are urging his candidacy called upon John F. Curry, Tammany leader, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic chieftain, to ask that they back the Controller.

With the acquisition yesterday of extensive property, buildings and equipment formerly used by the Cornell University Medical College, New York University's program for a projected health centre in the Bellevue Hospital area has been further advanced, according to an announcement by Thomas J. Watson, member of the New York University Council.

Commissioner of Licenses Geraghty was ordered yesterday to show cause why he should not be forced to issue licenses to the Eltinge and Republic Theatres, burlesque houses in West Forty-second Street that were ordered closed the day before by Mayor McKee.

Graham M. Brush, president of the Seatrain Lines, Inc., which will open a rail-water-rail service between New York and New Orleans, via Havana, on Oct. 6, announced yesterday that rate schedules similar to those now charged by ship lines serving those ports would be filed by his company during the next two weeks with the Interstate Commerce Commission and the United States Shipping Board.

A 12-year-old boy and a patrolman assigned to guard a polling place in Public School 46, Brooklyn, were slightly wounded last night when pistols were used during a political argument in front of the election station.

General improvement in prices was registered in the wholesale markets yesterday. Advances were made in the grains, cotton, rubber, silk, hides and dairy products. Moderate losses were scored in sugar and cocoa. Other staples were steady.

Heavy rains in the Mississippi Valley as far North as Memphis steadied prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Although the marketing movement is increasing daily, unfavorable weather for picking counterbalanced hedging operations and final quotations were 4 to 7 points net higher.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Sept. 20. -- A thorough investigation of labor conditions in the needle industry here, which led yesterday to the mobbing of this town's fourteen policemen and forty special officers from a Newark detective agency, was started today by Middlesex County authorities.

The business methods of S.W. Straus Co., dealers in real estate securities were termed "vicious" yesterday by Lazarus Joseph. Assistant Attorney General, before Justice Alfred V. Norton in Supreme Court in Brooklyn. M. Joseph represented Attorney General Bennett in arguing the Attorney General's petition for a temporary injunction restraining the Straus concern from continuing the sale of securities except under terms fixed by Mr. Bennett.

A bondholders' action for the appointment of a receiver of sufficient funds of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation to meet the interest due on bonds held by those who have not assented to the hotel's readjustment plan was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Bernard Breslauer in behalf of himself and others similarly situated.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Accusing it of unpatriotic publications during the "Leticia affair," a mob today invaded the offices of the Communist newspaper Tierra, destroyed furniture and seized and burned copies of the newspaper. There were no casualties.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Demanding a Congressional investigation into the firing upon the members of the "bonus army" in Washington, and obligating himself to fight for the immediate payment of the bonus to needy veterans, Cornelius V. Whitney, Democratic candidate for Congress from the First New York District, made his first campaign speech here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Hoover today launched what amounted to a personal effort to prevent the breaking up of the disarmament conference at Geneva with a virtual appeal for Germany to withdraw her threat to leave the negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Hoover told Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania today that he could not intervene personally with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to further a relief loan to the State of Pennsylvania.

William Henry Tubbs, 32 years old, an unemployed house painter of 4018 169th Street, in the Broadway-Flushing district of Queens, was held without bail on a homicide charge by Magistrate Anthony Hoekstra in Flushing yesterday after he had told the police how he killed William Guirin Tubbs, 6 years old, the elder of his two sons.

Although the Board of Elections officials said last night that there was considerable confusion at yes- terday's primary because of errors made by the Burland Printing Com- pany in the printing of the ballots, spokesmen for the printing company contended they had completed "a 100 per cent job" and were looking for more printing work from the city.

Two men, pretending to be representatives of a home-relief bureau collecting donations, forced their way yesterday afternoon into the apartment of Mrs. Pauline Sorrd, 359 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, and demanded that she give them $5,000, which they asserted she had hidden in the apartment.

Vincent Astor's yacht the Nourmahal returned from Bermuda yesterday with a party of scientists and friends and about 600 specimens of tropical fish to be added to the collections of the Aquarium in Battery Park.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Monte Weaver of the Senators held the Red Sox to four hits today as he chalked up his twenty-second victory of the year by a 4-to-1 score. Weaver has lost only nine games this season.

Warren E. Wheeler, secretary of Jordahl Co., formerly the American Kreuger Toll Company, which was controlled by the late Ivar Kreuger, testified yesterday at a hearing in the bankruptcy case before Federal Referee Henry K. Davis that, on instructions from Anders Jordahl, head of the company, he had turned over to a "Mr. Lewis" two days ago the company books, which he had been ordered to produce at the hearing.

The total registration in all public day schools of the city is 1,120,541, an increase of 29,698, or 2.8 per cent, over the registration for the Fall term of 1931, according to official figures made public yesterday at the Board of Education. While the increase was most marked in the high schools, every branch of the day schools showed a rise in enrolment.

The literature of every civilized country bears witness to the immense influence of Sir Walter Scott in literature, John Buchan writes in his long matured biography of the Scotch romanticist published here by Coward-McCann today, the 100th anniversary of Scott's death.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Two men are dead and six others held by police following what authorities believe was a planned mass suicide attempt of eight unemployed ex-service men here tonight.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., will return to New York from The Eyrie, Seal Harbor, Me., next month.

NAPLES, Sept. 20. (AP). -- Italian newspapers were instructed to leave former Mayor Walker out of the news, and there was not a line printed about his arrival. The former Mayor secluded himself in his hotel, refusing to answer the telephone or to receive correspondents.

No educator can better appraise the reaction of the colleges to the Carnegie Foundation's devastating Bulletin No. 23 on organized football than Dr. HENRY S. PRITCHETT. His conclusion is that they were impressed by the revelations that college football has been changed from a sport to a "racket," but, after a few attempts to clean up, have mostly accepted the situation as one that cannot be changed.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The union of three Methodist bodies in Great Britain into one of the largest Protestant churches was completed this afternoon at Albert Hall before 10,000 persons. The culminating moment in the impressive scene was the reading by the Duke of York of a message from King George, in part as follows:

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20. -- Lyman Brusie took chief honors today at the Eastern States Exposition track with a pair of winners, Calumet Derby in the two yearold trot for Mohawk youngsters and Volo Yorke in the 2:13 trot. Directum Heir was the other winner, taking the 2:21 pace.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- Premier Herriot and the French delegation left tonight for Geneva to take part in the preparatory commission's disarmament negotiations. Late this afternoon the Premier and his Cabinet met to lay their plans, but it is understood that whatever the French are going to do will depend on events in Geneva in the next few days.

TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Petitions filed here last week for the recall of the Mayor and township council on charges of interfering with the city manager government, were declared insufficient today by Town Clerk Henry Diehl. Backers of the movement to oust the Mayor and council have ten days in which to correct the petitions.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- After opening weak and witnessing new losses today the stock market showed a tendency gradually to recover. The number of transactions was small, but a good part of the list closed above the opening figures. The rally was attributed mainly to optimism regarding the loan conversion, which failed to exert influence at yesterday's session of the Bourse.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- A constructive program of farm relief should be launched at once as offering not only the best solution of the problem of restoring consumer buying power and confidence, but as opening the way to "what is probably the quickest road to recovery from the depression," Dean Wallace B. Donham of the Harvard Business School declared today at the closing session of the Boston conference on retail distribution.

Dr. Charles Norris, the tall bearded Chief Medical Examiner of the city, whose fourteen years in that post have brought him face to face with death in all its forms, resigned yesterday in protest against orders from Mayor McKee to reduce his already small budget by an additional 20 per cent.

Phil Stark, promising lightweight had an easy time last night winning the decision over Steve Smith, veteran Bridgeport battler, in the feature bout of six rounds at the Queensboro Stadium. A crowd of about 3,000 saw Stark outbox and outfight Smith in every one of the six rounds to receive the unanimous decision from Referee Johnny McAvoy and Judges Tommy Shorten and Billy Jacob.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- With President Hoover's approval, the Treasury Department today made public a list of naval projects on which $8,800,000 will be spent in emergency relief construction work, of which $850,000 will be spent at the New York Navy Yard.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Bank failures in the United States in August dropped to 85, the lowest figure since May. It compared with 131 in July and 151 in June.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Incomplete returns from all parts of the Thirty-second New York District indicate that ancis D. Culkin of Oswego was reminated for Representative in the Republican primaries over Edmund R. Wilcox of Watertown by a majority of more than 8,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- To expe dite the granting of loans for selfliquidating projects and thus create additional employment, the Americar Engineering Council through W.S. Lee, president, and L.W. Wallace, executive secretary, has offered the services of leading engineers to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

BEAUMONT, Texas, Sept. 20. -- Beaumont captured the opening game of the Dixie Series with Chattanooga today when Hank Greenberg, former New York schoolboy, drove one of Clyde Barfoot's pitches over the left field fence in the seventh inning to give the Exporters a 1-to-0 , victory over the Lookouts.

The Musicians Symphony Orchestra, which presented five concerts last season in the Metropolitan Opera House with 200 unemployed musicians, will give two series of ten concerts each this season, according to an announcement yesterday. The concerts will be of the same character as those of last season and the same number of unemployed musicians will make up the orchestra, with prominent conductors and distinguished soloists contributing their services at each concert.

The success story of Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, of how he built the Loyal Order of Moose from "a minor affair" of 250 members into a $40,000,000 corporation of 600,000 members, was placed before a jury in Federal Court yesterday as part of the evidence on which it will be called to decide if one of the promotion programs constituted a lottery.

Being of a heroic frame of mind, Robert Middlemass, the actor, has written a comedy about the depression, "The Budget," acted at the rejuvenated Hudson last evening. With Lynne Overman and Mary Lawlor in the chief parts, it has a good front.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The free trade Liberal members of the British Cabinet are showing no disposition to leave their posts. Isaac Foot, Mines Secretary, tonight denounced the trade agreements made at the Ottawa Imperial Conference as "partisan not national," but added, "While they demand our opposition, we are and we desire to remain supporters of the National Government."

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Lieut. Gov. William S. Youngman piled up an imposing lead over Frank A. Goodwin for the Republican gubernatorial nomination as returns from more than a third of the precincts in the State primary were counted today.

Recent oil paintings and a group of water-colors by John Wenger were placed on view yesterday at the Montross Gallery, 785 Fifth Avenue. This exhibition will remain until Oct. 8. The gallery is open daily from 9 to 6, except Sundays.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Registration of voters here today for the November election exceeded the enrolment on Sept. 8, the first of three registration days, but fell short of the figures for the corresponding day in advance of the 1928 Presidential election, it was estimated tonight by the registration commission.

NAPLES, Sept. 20. -- James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, expressed annoyance today when, upon his arrival here aboard the steamship Conte Grande, he was told by newspapers interviewers that it was rumored he would meet Russell Sherwood in Italy.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, who was chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which raised about $20,000,000 for unemployment relief last Winter, was invited yesterday to form a similar committee this year and to head the new organization.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Outside trade In wheat on the Board of Trade here was at a minimum today, and pit brokers said the market now was almost a merchandising affair. Scattered buying based on strength in Liverpool and on firmness in stocks carried prices up moderately, but the advance was checked by selling against offers.

The abortive Archangel expedition with its toll of 244 American dead and 305 wounded was endorsed by General John J. Fershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force; General Peyton C. March writes in "The Nation at War" -- the memoirs of the army's wartime Chief of Staff, published today by Doubleday, Doran.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am an American officer who served as a regular throughout the World War, one who reads and thinks, owns a little property, pays taxes -- an average, responsible citizen. I served throughout the war because it was my professional and patriotic duty for which I had been trained, not for an adventure or emotional excitement.
BOMBAY, Sept. 20. -- Mahatma Gandhi solemnly began his "fast unto death" today behind the walls of Yerovda jail at Poona.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 20. -- Bruce F. Vanderveer, 19-year-old yachtsman of Great Neck, L.I., was fatally injured here tonight and three of his fellow-competitors in the International Star Class yacht races at the Pequot Yacht Club of South Port were hurt when an automobile crashed into a tree on Shore Road near the estate of F.P. Bedford.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Foreign competitors in the Pacific Southwest tennis championship suffered heavy casualties in the second round of men's singles today as three of the seeded stars were eliminated by Californians.

Whether the covenant of the League of Nations and the other treaties signed by Japan are interpreted literally or in a broader, "statesmanlike manner," the Japanese people honestly say that "we have, not violated any treaties to which we have been signatories," Dr. Inazo Nitobe, member of the House of Peers of Japan, asserted yesterday in a frank discussion of the charge of treaty violations.

Tuesday, Sept. 20, 1932. Street money relaxed again to 1 per cent, touched last Friday for the first time in months. This minimum rate was 1/4 under Monday's figure and was the result of the very heavy offerings emanating from banking and brokerage firms, with free balances over immediate needs.

Mrs. T.J. Lewis's How High won the featured Bellerose claiming stakes and a purse of $1,440 by a head from J.H. Louchheim's Fancy Flight in a thrilling finish yesterday at Aqueduct. Both racers are trained by Clarence Buxton.

As the political semi-finals in the form of State primaries and conventions drew to a close last night with the returns from New York, Wisconsin and Massachusetts, opponents of the Eighteenth Amendment declared and backed their declaration with records that there was a strong trend toward repeat in many parts of the country.

Mayor MCKEE insists that he is not a "reformer" of the theatre. The title matters little. His order closing two "burlesque" houses on Forty-second Street responds to elementary demands of public order and decency. The old-fashioned person may be shocked by such shows.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 20. -- In his telegram to President Hoover Governor Pinchot said "After two months of constant effort to get help for Pennsylvania's 1,250,000 totally unemployed and their wives and children, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation still persists in its cruel, needless and unexplained refusal to advance what Pennsylvania has every right to ask and to get.

Ninety-nine women golfers, including Miss Enid Wilson, winner of the British, title, are entered in the United States championship, which will be played over the Salem Country Club course, Peabody, Mass., during the coming week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Hoover will make his first campaign speech at Des Moines on Oct. 4, and it is understood that he will make his address a reply to Governor Roosevelt's farm proposals. He is planning an exhaustive analysis of the farm problem and the efforts of his administration to solve it.

Radio dealers from all parts of the United States and several foreign countries have registered at the Radio Trade Show at the Hotel Edison since the exposition opened on Monday, according to the hotel management. More than six hundred registered on the first day of the show and about the same number yesterday.

The deposit of notes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company with the respective protective committees formed before the receivership of the company, for the purpose of advancing unification of transit facilities in New York City, is continuing from day to day, it is indicated by the certificates of deposit for the notes listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

The football teams of Columbia and Manhattan met in one of their periodical scrimmages yesterday at Baker Field. Columbia, hard hit by injuries, sent a second-string back field against the Jaspers, and even the regular linemen saw little actual service.

Work tends to deaden worry. The Republican bigwigs, getting their second wind, are going to make an "intensive" campaign. Vice President CURTIS seems to have more than his share of territory. He is to spread all the way from Tennessee to the Pacific; and is to make "short talks," thereby dispelling the notion that his style is essentially Senatorial and extensive.

Today is the anniversary of an event which will always hereafter be remembered, in the traditions of finance, along with such historic "panic incidents" as the suspension of gold payments by the "United States Bank in 1837, the OverendGurney failure at London in 1866 and the Jay Cooke insolvency of 1873.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Douglas Waples, dean of the Graduate Library School of the University of Chicago, told the New York State Library Association today that his recent survey of the use of the library in the Bowery proved that 80 per cent of the residents of the area were readers.

FLORENCE, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Five masked robbers, armed with revolvers, forced two employes and three customers of the First National Bank into a back room of the bank building and removed $4,900 in bills and silver from the bank vaults with rubber gloves.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 20. --- Mrs. J. Laroque Anderson of Cherry Valley carried off the low gross honors today with a score of 85 in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Plandome Golf Club.

R.B. Odom of St. Albans Was the low-gross winner in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Pomonok Country Club, Flushing, L.I., yesterday, his score being 74, two over par for the 6,237yard lay-out.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP). -- After calling the St. Lawrence ship canal project "unnecessary" and "impracticable economically," the New York State Waterways Association made plans today to "sell" the New York barge canal in the Middle West and in Washington.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity is slightly lower, following the substantial increase recorded in the week which included Labor Day. For the week ended Sept. 17 it is 19.7, as against 20.2 for the preceding week and 41.8 for the corresponding week last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- State's Attorney Swanson today speeded his investigation of the Insull utilities receiverships. Pursuing his plan to ascertain whether criminal acts had been committed in the sales of securities to thousands of investors prior to the collapse of the Insull holding companies last Spring, he sent four assistants and an auditor on a hunt for personal records of Samuel Insull and his brother, Martin J. Insull.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Declaring three foreign powers had been antagonized by the disarmament policy of the British National Government, David Lloyd George made a renewed bid at Carnarvon tonight to rally supporters to his once great Liberal party and embarrass his former free trade colleagues who deserted him for the National Government.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Measures which he said would help maintain a balance between agriculture and industry were named here today by Sydney Anderson, Minneapolis miller, in opposing the voluntary domestic allotment plan, the newest form of farm relief.

Carrying its fight for a central postoffice in the Bronx directly to President Hoover, the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, Inc., through its president, George F. Mand, has written the President that no other community in the entire country with a total population of 1,300,000 is without a first class central postoffice.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- The Old Westbury and Hurricane quartets were the victors today in the annual sixteen-goal polo tournament for the Autumn Plates at the Meadow Brook Club. The former combination, aided by a six-goal handicap, defeated the Camels, 14 to 9, on Waterbury Field, while the latter team conquered Long Island, 15 to 8, on Whitney Field.

With United States Government securities in good demand and further advances in some railroad, public utility and foreign obligations, trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday spread out over the list more than on the preceding day.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 20. -- Miss Phyllis Boardman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Boardman of Manursing Island, Rye, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at the Manursing Island Club. The debutante, who was assisted in receiving by her mother, wore an Empire gown of green velvet.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Miss Rhea Clyman of Toronto, Can., correspondent here for The London Daily Express and newspapers in Canada, has been ordered expelled from Soviet Russia on a charge of writing false news about the country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20. -- Today's heat and yesterday's scrimmaging caused Head Coach Mal Stevens to limit Yale's morning and afternoon football drill to group work in fundamentals and to running off plays in a breaking-through drill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- A decided improvement in world financial conditions during the past month, particularly as to the gold situation and the large excess reserves of central banks, was pictured by the Federal Reserve Board in its September bulletin, made public today.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,191,600 barrels, as compared with 2,167,700 barrels daily in the preceding week, a gain of 23,900 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Important changes for the week included gains of 30,650 barrels daily in the output of East Texas and 7,000 barrels in Coastal Texas and a decline of 6,700 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Charges of third degree assault and neglect of duty against members of the Nassau County Police Department were transferred back to the county grand jury under an order signed here today by County Judge Cortland Johnson, who said that "the case was too serious to be tried before a village police judge and a jury of six men."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Reporting a marked increase in its seasonal business, the local plant of the Simmons Company, a leader in the mattress and bed spring industry, is working on a five and one-half day a week basis, with overtime work necessary at times to keep production abreast of orders.
GENEVA, Sept. 20. -- As the delegates assemble for the meeting of the disarmament conference's bureau tomorrow morning there is certain agreement on only one point, but it is unanimous there.

With "moving day" less than a fortnight distant, apartment rentals at, or close to, peak proportions were reported by brokers yesterday. The east side continues to lead in popularity among Manhattan lessees, though west side suites are being taken in large volume also.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 20. -- No more attentive audience ever greeted Governor Roosevelt than the young patients at the Children's Orthopedic Hospital, which the Governor visited today. They listened to the nominee from wheeled chairs and beds that were moved to the lawn in front of the hospital, while others stood, supported by crutches.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Miss Joan Ridley, the visiting English tennis star, made a brief but effective appearance to score in both the singles and doubles of the Bronxville Field Club's annual women's invitation tourney today.
HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- A bill introduced today in the Cuban Senate would grant exclusive rights for the sale of petroleum in Cuba to a large oil company for forty years.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Milwaukee Sentinel at 11:30 o'clock tonight said that on the basis of returns then tabulated former Governor Walter J. Kohler, regular Republican, had defeated Governor Philip F. La Follette, Progressive Republican, in their contest for the Gubernatorial nomination in today's primary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The United States, and, I believe, the leading countries of Europe also, are ready for an early comeback in industry and business unless stopped by governmental mistakes. In the United States everything will depend upon the action of Congress when it reconvenes in December.

Forging ahead yesterday toward budget economy as a means of obtaining further loans from the bankers, Mayor McKee received the first repercussion of his economy drive in the resignation of Dr. Charles Norris, Chief Medical Examiner, who gave up his post because of dissatisfaction with the Mayor's order cutting his budget by 20 per pent.

Felicitations and congratulations upon the completion of seventy-one years service in the employ of one department store were received yesterday from national leaders, including President Hoover, by William C. Creamer at a testimonial luncheon given by the executives and directors of Arnold Constable Co. in a meeting room of the building at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street.

Dr. Charles G. Purdy, 82 years old, of 151 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, a medical practitioner in Flatbush for more than forty years, was fatally injured yesterday when struck by an automobile while crossing Flatbush Avenue, at Schermerhorn Street. He was taken to Holy Family Hospital, where he died a few moments later of a fractured skull.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Three cards of 82, all returned by members of the youngest class in the tourney, that between 55 and 59 years, tied for the first round lead in the eleventh annual championship of the New Jersey State Seniors' Golf Association at the Shackamaxon, Country Club today.
With a broadened curriculum in both the engineering and art departments and with a freshman class of 721, Cooper Union is starting its new academic year with an enrolment of more than 3,000 students.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Taking the mound in place of the ailing Dazzy Vance today, Watson Clark turned in his nineteenth triumph of the season, holding the Phillies to eight singles and keeping the Dodgers from dropping into fourth place. The victory put Brooklyn a game and a half ahead of Shotton's sluggers.

Nine Pulitzer scholarships were awarded yesterday to successful competitors from a field of more than a hundred of the most promising graduates of New York City's public high schools, it was announced yesterday by the Pulitzer Scholarship Committee, of which Dr. Adam LeRoy Jones, director of admissions at Columbia University, is chairman.

Voters in New York, Massachusetts and Wisconsin went to the polls yesterday for the last of the State primary elections to be held this year. With voting light in New York City, because of lack of interest, the spotlight was turned on the fate of La Folletteism in Wisconsin, and the wet and dry contests in upper New York State, where wet leaders hope for anti-prohibition gains.

The Board of Taxicab Control is voluntarily going over its recent 1933 budget request for an appropriation of $125,000, in an effort to bring about economies suggested by Mayor McKee yesterday at a conference with Chairman Maurice Hotchner and his associates.
SEATTLE, Sept. 20. -- Revision of the tariff by reciprocal agreements for the purpose of restoring trade was advocated by Governor Roosevelt in a speech at the Auditorium here tonight.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 20. -- Two former finalists, one of them the co-medalist, were eliminated in the first round of the women's New Jersey State golf championship at the Echo Lake Country Club today.

Buyers' Registrations Lower. A drop in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total, however, remained well above the number listed in the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Edward Patterson, 25 years old, a petty but ambitious beer runner, was found dead yesterday morning in the hallway on the second floor of a rooming house at 51 Concord Street, Brooklyn, with four bullet wounds in the back of his head. The shots had been fired close enough to leave powder stains.

Having "laid the foundation for our economic recovery," President Hoover should be re-elected and permitted to continue the constructive work he has been doing, according to John N. Willys, automobile manufacturer and former Ambassador to Poland, speaking yesterday before the Controllers' Institute of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Preliminary steps which may lead to negotiations for a voluntary instead of a forced wage reduction were taken when representatives of the railroads and the brotherhoods met in an informal discussion here late this afternoon.

HAVRE DE GRACE. Md., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Her Grace, 5-year-old mare racing for tne Maryland sportsman, Ral Parr, drove to a clever victory in the Melody Purse, a test for fillies and mares at a mile and seventy yards, which featured the program of the second charity day today.

Along about the time the scoreboard revealed the news at the Polo Grounds yesterday that the Cubs, in distant Chicago, had definitely clinched the 1932 pennant of the National League, the Giants, who once entertained serious notions of achieving that signal honor themselves, did the next best thing toward relieving their feelings in the matter.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Cleveland took both games of a doubleheader today from St. Louis to gain a half game on the Senators and third place. The Tribe won the first game 5 to 2, and the second, 11 to 2.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 20. -- Communist disturbances occurred today when Queen Wilhelmina made her annual speech from the throne opening the new session of Parliament.

Organization control won the day in the primary elections up-State yesterday. Both wet and dry Republican incumbents in Congress who were backed by the party leaders defeated efforts to oust them on prohibition grounds, while the Democratic organization, supported aspirants for office in every instance were victorious.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Nearly 2,000,000 farmers in eleven Middle Western States, hard hit by debts and low prices, have been asked to begin tomorrow to withhold grain and live stock from the markets until they can be sold profitably.

The Rebuy Realty Corporation of 2,178 Broadway, New York City, resold to Adolph Vilardi of 19 Lafayette Avenue, Cliffside Park, the fourstory brick building containing fifteen apartments and a store on a plot 50 by 76 feet at 401-03 Twentyfifth Street, corner of Palisade Avenue, Guttenberg.

The bluefish have come back. The mysterious meanderings of this specie has had New Jersey and Long Island fishermen worried for some time. Just when they had it all figured out that blues should be running at their best they disappeared practically from all their known haunts and all the efforts of veterans to find them, save in one or two isolated cases, proved unavailing.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Mickey Walker's personal physician today dispelled rumors that Max Schmeling's opponent is being bothered with another boil. Walker, to substantiate this report, resumed boxing before a crowd of 250 interested spectators.
To the Editor of The New York Times: F.R. Eldridge's letter is very interesting. Unfortunately, It is also somewhat Incomplete.

STRESA, Italy, Sept. 20. -- The conference for economic and financial rehabilitation of Central and Eastern Europe closed today with the adoption of the report of the financial committee and a series of speeches in which members said if the conference had left many things undone it had at least taken a definite step toward its declared goal.

POONA, Sept. 20. -- Newspaper correspondents who called at Yerovda jail today as Mahatma Gandhi began his fast found the Nationalist leader to be his usual curious mixture of naive jocularity and spiritual seriousness.

VICHY, France, Sept. 20. -- Arguments for and against removal of the gall bladder were heard at today's session of the International Medical Congress being held here for the study of internal diseases.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- One sweep of Kiki Cuyler's lusty war club clinched the National League pennant for Chicago's hustling Cubs today and made his old Pittsburgh mates alsorans.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack's courtroom was turned into a classroom, in economics yesterday when Dr. Edwin R.A. Seligman, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia University, took the witness stand in the Government's suit to dissolve the Sugar Institute and testified that he approved the principles of the institute's code of ethics as fostering "true" competition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Increased consumption of textiles since midsummer was met by greater activity of cotton mills last month as compared with July.

Governor Roosevelt intends to speak out against immediate cash payment of the soldiers bonus in a campaign address within the next few weeks, it was made clear yesterday at Democratic headquarters. At the same time he is expected to put forward a program designed to insure relief for obviously needy veterans of the World War.

There was probably some exaggeration in the reports from Paris that Ambassador EDGE and Senator REED had assured the French Premier that the United States Government was with him as against the German proposals concerning disarmament.
SEATTLE, Sept. 20. -- Governor Roosevelt sent the following telegram tonight to his running mate, Speaker John N. Garner, on the death of the latter's mother:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The improvement in the industrial employment situation in July was well sustained, throughout August, with further increases in activities in certain sections of the country, the Employment Service of the Department of Labor said today.

Saying the receivership suit brought on Monday in St. Louis against the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway had been initiated by holders of only 175 shares of the company's preferred stock, E.N. Brown, chairman, asserted yesterday that this and similar actions were the efforts of small groups "to obtain some special advantage for themselves by ambarrassing the company in carrying out the readjustment plan."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much fallacious reasoning has been indulged in by those who find cause for alarm in the power of removal possessed by the Governor in such proceedings as those leading to the resignation under fire of former Mayor Walker.

Journeying through the silverproducing States, Governor ROOSEVELT could not well avoid saying something about what used to be glorified by Mr. BRYAN and others as "The White Metal." But everybody is the "friend of silver" nowadays -- with needed reservations.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 20. -- Ray Henley, 2:04 3/4, won the 2:13 class pace at the opening of the Allentown Fair today. Gay Hanover, 2:09 1/4, owned and driven by W.E. Turlington of Melfa, Va., captured the 2:25 class pace, taking a new race record.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was even more apathetic yesterday than on the day before. Transactions approximated 1,250,000 shares, which was well below the daily average of the last week, or of the last two months, for that matter. The trend was upward, fifty selected stocks showing a net gain of $1.89 for the group.

Drastic reduction in the city's expenditures for telephone service, electric light and power and printing of stationery and blankbooks is urged upon Mayor McKee in a letter made public yesterday by Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission.

The fight which the Real Estate Board of New York has waged for tax relief is reaching its climax and certain clearly defined political trends "encourage the belief that the era of reckless municipal spending is nearing its end," Anton L. Trunk declared yesterday in a speech accepting re-election to the presidency of the Real Estate Board.

That books are "a substantial world" is not a mere imagining of a great poet. The books in our public libraries hold in these days real worlds for millions "round which their happiness will grow." Mr. LYDENBERG, president of the American Library Association, spoke at the meeting of the New York Library Association of "practical everyday help" for which demands are made upon the libraries as never before:

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- The Prussian Ministry of the Interior, now under the jurisdiction of Chancellor von Papen in his capacity of Federal Commissioner for Prussia today announced that it would permit the Bund der Aufrechten, the notorious monarchical propaganda organization, to resume its activities in the State.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 21 -- The first annual flower show of the Red Bank Woman's Club, held this afternoon and evening at the clubhouse, included displays by fifty-eight members and thirty-two non-members. Twenty prizes were offered.

Wednesday, Sept. 21, 1932. Street money continued freely offered at 1 per cent. Business was on a small scale, however. Federal funds were done at 1/8 and governments at 3/4. Stock Exchange official rate remained at 2 per cent. Time money was dull at prevailing quotations, the business money market also ruling quiet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Testimony that the Associated Gas and Electric Company, in obtaining control of public utility operating companies, usually "wrote up" its investments in those concerns to a figure intended to represent their actual asset value, was given to the Federal Trade Commission today by W.J. Warmack, an examiner.

The status of West Forty-second Street as an amusement centre remained yesterday about as it was. The action brought by the two burlesque houses which had been ordered closed by Mayor McKee to force the Commissioner of Licenses to give them a license was adjourned until today.

Not So Infantile as We Look. An old friend, the notorious and incorrigible "infantilism" of the American people, turns up again in the October Scribner's, where ALBERT JAY NOCK has a parallel between European morals and our own.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 21. -- Wisconsin's Republican primary yesterday developed a landslide which overthrew the La Follette regime in the State. Almost complete returns show that ex-Governor Walter J. Kohler, conservative Republican, defeated Governor Philip F. La Follette by about 100,000 majority, unseating the La Follette "dynasty" at Madison and shattering the tradition that a La Follette has never been beaten in forty years.

After prices for cotton on the Cotton Exchange here had declined more than 2% cents a pound in three weeks, the market turned abruptly yesterday and rose $3 a bale, final quotations being 55 to 60 points higher than on Tuesday.

The prohibition plank in the Republican State platform to be adopted when the Republican State Convention meets at Buffalo on Oct. 3 will follow in general the lines of the widely criticized plank embodied in the national platform of the party, it was foreshadowed yesterday when the campaign book, under the title, "Facts for Voters of New York State," was made public at Republican State headquarters.

Alfred E. Smith, who four years ago was expressing himself on prohibition, the tariff and water power, stood before a televison and microphone in the studio of the Columbia Broadcasting Company yesterday and told the world some of the problems which he has encountered as editor of The New Outlook.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 21 -- The Sands Point team, which Thomas Hitchcock Jr. is forming for the special match Saturday, rode through a practice match on the Greentrre Field tonight, defeating the Hurricanes, 13 goals to 7.

APPLETON, Wis., Sept. 21 -- For the first time in the history of Lawrence College a building was dedicated today to the memory of a former Lawrence student. Honoring J.A. Kimberly, it was presented by J.C. Kimberly on the eightieth anniversary of his father's matriculation as a gift to the Institute of Paper Chemistry, affiliated graduate school.

Bertrand Russell lists some of the conditions under which children may grow up "fearless and fundamentally happy, without the resentment that comes of thwarting or the excessive demands that are produced by an atmosphere or hothouse affection," in his new book, "Education and the Modern World," published today by W.W. Norton.

Beginning an attempt to show that Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania profited personally from what it charges was a lottery run by the Loyal Order of Moose, the prosecution in his trial in Federal court proved yesterday that $127,418.50 of funds banked in the name of the organization department of the order was used to pay off a loan obtained by Mrs. Jean R. Davis, his wife.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 21 -- The malady from which Mrs. Mary Borah, wife of Senator Borah, has been suffering since Friday was diagnosed this afternoon as psittacosis, or parrot fever, by Dr. Ralph Falk when Mrs. Borah was taken to St. Luke's Hospital.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) -- With several recruits in the line-up, the Chicago White Sox took both ends of a double-header from the Tigers today, 11 to 3 and 3 to 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- With Federal aid for Pennsylvania's unemployed still deferred by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, plans are under consideration here for requesting a government loan to Philadelphia, independent of the rest of the State.

Returns from another group of ten cities in its Presidential poll were made public last night by The Literary Digest in advance of its first tabulated report of the vote by States which will be made public on Friday.

Open season for fox hunting was declared last evening in Central Park when Pete, a 3-year-old red fox, escaped from his cage in the Central Park Zoo. More than 200 persons, including mounted policemen, "sparrow cops," patrolmen, zoo attendants and pedestrians took part in the chase over hill and down dale with Pete ever in sight but beyond reach.

BOMBAY, Sept. 21 -- Strong hopes prevailed here tonight that the caste Hindus and "untouchables" would settle their political differences, thus enabling Mahatma Gandhi to abandon his "fast unto the death."

Mayor McKee, in what he called his first official address since he became "Acting Mayor," appealed for public support yesterday for the ball game between teams of the Fire and Police Departments for the unemployed, which will be played Sunday afternoon at the Yankee Stadium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to call attention to what seems to me to be one maladjustment in our civic affairs which might be remedied and help with the unemployment situation. I refer to the question of jury duty.

How a bundle containing $1,000 in counterfeit banknotes got into the prisoners' detention room on the second floor of the Tombs Prison last Monday is a problem Warden Robert Barr and government Secret Service operatives would like to solve.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 21 The twenty-first annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the Greenwich Garden Club, the Riverside Garden Club of Greenwich, the Hortulus Club of Greenwich, Rye Garden Club, Little Garden Club of Rye and New Rochelle Garden Club cooperating, opened this afternoon at the Y.M.C.A.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- Charles Gimbel, chairman of the board and vice president of Gimbel Brothers, who died Sept. 9 at Lake Placid, N.Y., bequeathed $10,000 to the Federation of Jewish Charities in this city, under terms of his will probated today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Federal Judge Walter L. Lindley issued today instructions to the clerk of the United States District Court here to vacate his order of Aug. 13 denying to the so-called O'Grady debenture committee the right to intervene in the receivership of the $250,000,000 Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and instead to permit the committee to become a party to the receivership proceedings.

One boy out of every four in Brooklyn is living in surroundings which make it more difficult than it should be for him to grow up to be a healthy, happy, normal, law abiding citizen, according to William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council, who declared yesterday that the citizens of Brooklyn were not doing enough to counteract the effects of such bad environment by financial support of agencies engaged in character-building among boys.

Apartment renters continued yesterday to show a preference for suites in buildings on the east side, although brokers and renting agents on the west side also reported a large volume of business in new and old buildings.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Victor Morawetz have returned from Paris and are at 39 East 79th Street for the Autumn and Winter.

A final settlement of the wage scale negotiations between Theatrical Protective Union No. 1 and the managers of legitimate theatres, represented by the League of New York Theatres, is expected to be reached on Sunday at a special meeting of the stagehands' organization, according to James J. Brennan, its president.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Ellsworth Vines Jr., national champion, was forced to his first three-set match in defense of his Pacific Southwest singles tennis championship today. The unexpected opposition came from John Olliff, Great Britain, who won a long first set, 11 -- 9, before Vines took the other two sets, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Helianthus, fleet 4-year-old from the Brookmeade Stable of Dodge Sloane, drove to a clever victory today in the Susquehanna Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth feature of the opening card of the regular Hartford Association's meeting.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Miss Clare Smith, the young Waterbury (Conn.) tennis player, accounted for the first triumph in the Bronxville Field Club's invitation tourney that can be classed as a surprising victory when she eliminated one of the ranking players in the Eastern list, Mrs. Christian Muhl, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, today.

John H. McCooey, veteran Brooklyn leader and key figure in the campaign this Fall in this city, took up active work for Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday at Democratic national headquarters. He said the city and State were in "good shape" for the national election.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Appointment of three trustees in whom shall be vested all the powers of the present board of directors of the Canadian National Railways is one of the outstanding recommendations in the report of the Commission on Railways and Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- New taxes and higher rates brought the total internal revenue receipts to $79,940,310 in August, an increase of $18,253,843 over July and of $11,546,170 over August, 1931. The figures were given out today in an analysis by the Internal Revenue Bureau of the first receipts on the basis of a full month's business under the "$1,000,000,000 revenue bill."

Massed at the back of the annual report of the Transit Commission is an almost impenetrable jungle of statistics. Columns of figures march down the pages like regiments on parade. Somewhere in equatorial Africa MARTIN JOHNSON discovered a lake so full of flamingos that only those on the edge could ever spread their wings and fly.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- At today's session of the Boerse the public was so reserved and cautious that expectations of a boom did not materialize. The improvement in Wall Street, reduction in the Reichsbank's discount rate, the fact that several large industrial concerns had hired additional men, an demployment of 24,000 more workmen by the Federal Railways had all combined to foreshadow another big advance in stocks and bonds.
