Behind rejection by the National Assembly of the treaty between Haiti and the United States is a spirit of antagonism to any kind of control or supervision by our Government, however helpful its purpose. After the transfer in November, 1931, of three of five departments to native officials, the Haitian press began to demand Haitians in the other departments, including finance.

George F. Walker, brother of the former Mayor, who died at Saranac Lake, N.Y., on Aug. 29 last, left an estate valued at $14,000 and no will, it was disclosed yesterday when Mrs. Lucy E. Walker, his widow, applied for letters at administration on his estate in Surrogates Court. Mrs. Walker and their two daughters.

Expressing the belief that unemployment distress during the coming Winter will be more severe than last, Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, anounced yesterday that he would acept the invitation, of the citizens group that asked him to lead once more in the formation of a committee like the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which he headed last year.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 21 -- R. C. Maxwell of Trenton, scored a 76 in the New Jersey seniors' golf championship at Shackamaxon Country Club today for a total of 166, tying him with Milton R. Brown for the lead at the end of the second-day standing.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Washington Senators outbatted the Boston Red Sox in both ends of a doubleheader today and won, 1-0 and 3-2. In the ten-inning opener the visitors tallied on singles by Bluege and Spencer and an infield out for the victory.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 21 -- The long latent Cabinet crisis in Hungary came to a bead this morning when the Premier. Count Karolyi, visited the Regent, Admiral Horthy at Goedoelloe, near Budapest, and tendered the resignation of his Cabinet, which was accepted.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 21. -- There are few teams in the East that have contributed more color and verve to football than have the Green-clad warriors of Dartmouth.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 -- Retention of the title to all water power sites by the people, governmental ownership and operation of public utilities, when necessary to obtain good service and fair rates, and Federal regulation of public utility holding companies to protect investors and insure fair treatment of consumers were advocated tonight by Franklin D. Roosevelt in his long-awaited water power and public utility speech in the municipal auditorium.

A statement that the book trade is "rather aKhast" at the latest effort of the Book-of-the-Montk Club to attract new subscribers by offering to give away copies of the current selection, is made editorially in the latest issue of The Publishers' Weekly, a 300-page Fall announcement issue distributed yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The Princeton football practice was shortened to two hours today as a result of the extreme heat. Intensive contact work was held for more than an hour with four teams alternating in the scrimmage.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Thursday, Sept. 22. -- Mrs. Dorothy Sims and Waldemar von Zedtwitz led a field of twenty-six teams as the first session of the New Jersey State mixed pair contract bridge tournament ended here early this morning. The leaders scored 202 match points.

Among the new pastors in Manhattan appointed by Cardinal Hayes yesterday was the Very Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Scully, who was promoted from the pastorate of St. Mary's Church, Kingston, to the pastorate of the Church of the Holy Trinity, Eighty-second Street, west of Broadway.
Mr. and Mrs. James Ruttenberg of New Haven, Conn., have bought a seven-room dwelling in Flushing from the Bogdick Corporation. The lot is 20 by 100 feet. The Walter O'Melia Company was the broker.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Archibald Roosevelt, son of President Theodore Roosevelt and secretary of the National Economy League, called for the formation of groups of men and women throughout the country to force the elimination of $452,000,000 from the Federal budget here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Efforts by the railroads to persuade their employes to enter into a conference to discuss wage reductions failed today when the Railway Labor Executives Association notified the Railway Management Committee that the labor executives unanimously opposed holding such a wage conference at this time.

Irked by what they consider an unreasonable delay in settling the terms of arbitration for printers in book and job offices, the Printers League section of the New York Employing Printers Association has posted notices for a 17 per cent wage reduction beginning on Oct. 16 and announcing the abolition of priority rules beginning on Oct. 1.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Without an appreciable increase in the volume of transactions conditions on the Paris Bourse improved today, the majority of the list advancing. The satisfactory manner in which the conversion of rentes seems to be progressing strengthens the domestic stocks, while rallies in copper, tin, rubber and cotton reported from Wall Street had the immediate effect of checking declines in the internationals.

The largest all-welded vessel ever built in a navy yard will slip down greased ways into the East River next Wednesday when a 120-foot self-propelled freight lighter, displacing 275 tons, is launched in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

GENEVA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A decision which may nullify the international convention for the limitation of the manufacture of narcotics has been made by the League of Nations' Supervisory Commission, it became known today.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The omission of any mention of the German claim to equality in the disarmament conference bureau's sessions at Geneva today, in the opinion of the London Times, has justified the protest that was made by the German representative in July when he announced his inability to vote for the resolution with which the conference adjourned.

Some disappointment is felt in the steel industry because business in September has "fallen short of even moderate expectations," but this is offset, to some extent, by further increase in confidence among producers and consumers, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday that it had no official jurisdiction over the operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway. William G. Fullen, chairman, and Leon G. Godley, commissioner, upheld a report by George H. Stover, counsel for the commission, holding that a municipality operating a rapid transit line is not a street railway corporation within the meaning of the Public Service Commission law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- A truce in the hostilities between Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco dispute appeared possible tonight when the Commission of Neutrals transmitted to Bolivia a five-point program for the cessation of fighting proposed by Paraguay.

For ten long innings Tom Zachary, veteran lefthander of the Braves, was giving Carl Hubbell, southpaw of the Giants, quite a battle at the Polo Grounds yesterday when the utter futility of things simply weighed him down.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The position of the Free Trade Liberal Ministers in Prime Minister MacDonald's National Government following today's conference of the executive of the National Liberal Federation appears to be that there will be no resignations at any rate until after the meeting of the Cabinet Sept. 28, at which the Ottawa agreements will be discussed.

WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Manitoba's new $4,000,000 bond issue will be placed on the market at $96.75 and will yield a little better than 5.95 per cent, E.A. McPherson, Provincial Treasurer, announced tonight. A syndicate of eight banking bouses is handling the issue.

In a few years wages will be higher than they were in 1929, even though commodity prices do not return to that level, according to an editorial in the current issue of The Business Week, published by the McGraw-Hill Company.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21. -- A report that the Manchukuo Government intends to refuse extraterritoriality to the nationals of countries which fail to recognize it is published here without comment. Soviet officials are equally reserved, but in reality it raises an issue for the Soviet Union, whose financial and business interests in Manchuria, not to mention the Chinese Eastern Railway, will be gravely menaced.
ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 21 -- At the opening of the Naval Academy on Friday the student body totaled 1,789 midshipmen. Rear Admiral Thomas C. Hart is superintendent for his second year.

William Bartley Knox, 28-year-old son of the late William Elliot Knox, former president of the Bowery Savings Bank, jumped or fell to his death from his eighth-floor apartment at 405 East Fifty-fourth Street early yesterday. The circumstances of his death led the police and Assistant District Attorney Saul Price to question Larry Morgan, a Chelsea pier checker, who slept in an adjoining room.

The decision of Justice MCGEEHAN of the Supreme Court that there is to be no Mayoralty election this November is on its face a careful and comprehensive piece of judicial work. No substantial argument of the counsel on either side was overlooked.

Existence of a Brooklyn kidnapping gang formed to hold prominent New York merchants for ransom in a house in East Flatbush completely equipped for the purpose was revealed yesterday after Hyman Jacobs, 27 years old, an ex-convict member of the band, was booked at police headquarters in Manhattan on charges of attempted kidnapping and extortion.

HAVANA, Sept. 21 -- Enormous interest has been aroused here by the proposal in Congress to grant a forty-year petroleum monopoly in exchange for payment of Cuba's debts, amounting to about $200,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The process of tuning up the Yankees, Babe Ruth inclusive, for the world's series a week from today had its official beginning in Shibe Park this afternoon and the evidence presented to about 7,000 hardy followers of the Athletics indicated that Manager McCarthy must cover a lot of ground between now and the twenty-eighth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Although indications of increased activity in industry as a whole are few. Secretary Chapin said today that individual instances of substantial gains were being received by the Commerce Department in increasing numbers.

Two infants were seriously injured and four other persons hurt last night by a runaway horse which became frightened by the blast of an automobile horn at Boynton and Westchester Avenues, the Bronx, and raced madly for half a mile through a crowded district, knocking over baby carriages and crashing into store windows.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21 -- General Goes Monteiro, the Federal Commander operating against the Sao Paulo rebels, issued a proclamation to the Paulistans today, by means of handbills dropped from planes, warning them that unless they cease bombarding open cities immediately he will retaliate.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 21. -- Scores of armored motor boats have brought important victories against the Communists to the Chinese Nationalist Armies under General Chiang Kaishek, according to dispatches from Hankow today.

Members of an advisory committee, who have been helping Beekman Street Hospital and interesting the downtown community in health protection, were the guests of the officers and directors yesterday for an inspection tour of the institution, followed by a buffet luncheon on the roof.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21 -- Al Capone, Chicago's one-time gang chieftain, tried to gain his freedom from prison via the habeas corpus route today, but spent a scant half hour in the open before he was whisked back to the penitentiary by a squad of officers.

The great libraries of Russia, containing some of the world's finest collections of valuable books, are almost impossible to buy from the Soviets, despite an announced intention to sell them, Percy H. Muir, a representative of a London bookseller, writes in the latest issue of The Colophon, published yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan ruled yesterday against the holding of a Mayoralty election this Fall, in an opinion that upheld all the contentions advanced by counsel for Mayor Joseph V. McKee, who sought last week adjudication in the courts of the length of his term of office.
"What is wrong with the anthracite industry?" was the subject of discussion yesterday at the mine wage conference at the Anthracite Institute, 19 Rector Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt's address at Salt Lake City on the position of the railroads has focused national attenion on this all-important problem still more closely. The situation is one that affects everybody, and it might be timely to review briefly the reasons why this problem exists and why its solution is of transcending importance to the entire country.

The old idea in the care and treatment of acute communicable diseases was that special hospitals should be at inaccessible points remote from the centres of population. This led to the selection of North Brother Island nearly fifty years ago as the location for the Riverside Hospital for Communicable Diseases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Wisconsin's primary election, in which the conservative Republican wing in this long-time progressive State was the victor, was hailed by Republican leaders here as a harbinger of the party's success in November. Democrats were equally optimistic that the upheaval would induce the La Follette Republicans to join the Democrats and swing the State to that party in the national election.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 21 -- MicRey Walker traveled six rounds today in the fastest clip he has displayed since he began training for his bout with Max Schmeling. Employing a freepunching style, Walker many times damaged his three mates, Paul Cavalier, Herman Heller and Pietro Corri, who faced Mickey for two rounds a piece.

The annual prize essay competition of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has for a topic this year "Why Has New York Become the Metropolis of Our Country and How Can I Help In Its future Development?" The Board of Education points out that essays should be written as soon as feasible, so that reports from individual schools can be sent out OB or before Oct. 24.

Robert Lee Eills, a broker, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against Morris Rose of 175 West Seventy-third Street, for the return of a $60,000 interest in an estate in Corsica which Ellis alleges Rose caused him to sign over through threats of arrest and exposure to the New York Stock Exchange.

Acting Captain George Burnell of the Arsenal station end a squad of patrolmen staged a polite raid last night on the residents of a new sub-urban development. The policemen, with apologies and good feelings on both sides, arrested for vagrancy twenty-five inhabitants of Hoover Valley, the shantytown that sprang up in the bed of the old lower reservoir of Central Park near the Obelisk.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Field manoeuvres of the First Division, under the command of Brig. Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook, were concentrated in a strong forward movement along the line from Arney's Mount to Georgetown today in the theoretical offensive campaign, against an imaginary enemy invading New Jersey from the coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Joseph M. Dixon, who was campaign manager for Theodore Roosevelt in 1912, and is now Assistant Secretary of the Interior, tonight criticized sharply what he termed Governor Roosevelt's "imitations of mannerisms and speech" of President Roosevelt.

Julius Weinstein, secretary of the Burland Printing Company, which printed the primary ballots used in Tuesday's primary elections, accused the Board of Elections yesterday of deliberately doing all it could to interfere with successful completion of the Burland contract, which was won over the board's opposition.

With the trading volume more than trebled as compared with the day before, the share market responded yesterday to such visible influences as advancing commodity prices and to the less tangible forces represented by a fresh revival of confidence in Wall Street.

MR. M.P. GREENWOOD-ADAMS of Australia and other distant parts met a Councilman from Melbourne here in New York recently, and apparently the meeting stirred him no little. The Melbourne Councilman was Frank Beaurepaire, Australia's great swimmer of other years. He bobbed up in knicker-bockers at Stockholm in 1912 and competed for Australia three times in Olympic Games before he retired from competition.

Dr. Edwin R.A. Seligman, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia University, took an oral examination in economics yesterday under cross-questioning by James L. Fly, special assistant to the United States Attorney General, in the prosecution of the government's suit to dissolve the Sugar Institute for alleged violations of the anti-trust laws.
Columbia's football team started to polish its offense and defense yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the opening encounter of the season on Saturday against Middlebury.

August Heckscher, capitalist and philanthropist, and associates are preparing to submit to the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners and Mayor McKee within the next few days plans for developing the entire seven-block city-owned area at Chrystie and Forsyth Streets, it was learned yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 21 -- Veterans of the Grand Army of the Republic proudly paraded again today, watched by 75,000 spectators, in the streets of Springfield.

The possibility of a price war in the newsprint industry loomed yesterday when the International Paper Company announced to contract customers a reduction of $7 a ton, bringing the price to $46 in the territory where the price had been $53. That territory includes this city and Chicago.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Christian R. Holmes of Sands Point, Port Washington, won six ribbons this afternoon in the first five sections of the seventh annual Fall flower show of the Westbury Horticultural Society, which opened today in the large hall on the Hicks nursery estate.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 21 -- T. Henry Clarkson of Lido successfully defended his Long Island seniors' golf title in a play-off today at the Lakeville Golf and Country Club with F. Mack Fisher of Old Westbury. Clarkson scored an 81 to Fisher's 84.

MOVILLE, Iowa, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Outlining measures which he believes will solve farm problems. Senator Brookhart in an address to farmholiday sympathizers tonight advocated governmental control of surplus crops, revision of the money standard and issuance of Treasury notes for veterans relief and public works.

PARIS, Sept. 21 (AP). -- France and Great Britain, were understood in authoritative American circles tonight to have given Senator David A. Reed an impression of "caution and reserve" on the subjects of Manchuria and Japan.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Paul Runyan of the Metropolis Club, with a par-shattering 67 over the long Rockledge course, led the field today in the qualifying round of the New England Open Golf Tournament.
BEAUMONT, Texas, Sept. 21 -- The dependable pitching of Alexander McColl enabled the fighting Chattanooga Lookouts to conquer Beaumont today, squaring the Dixie series at one -- all.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Two upsets, causing the elimination of Mrs. Norman Goldberger of Norwood and Miss Kathryn Bragaw of Essex County, marked the quarter-finals of the New Jersey women's golf championship at the Echo Lake Country Club today.

With a program including a discussion of their current problems as well as general economic conditions, delegates from all parts of the State will assemble today at the Westchester Country Club in Rye for the thirty-ninth annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

NEW,HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21 -- A plan designed to make most of the 6,000,000 farmers in the country selfsupporting and independent of prevailing economic conditions is proposed in the Autumn issue of The Yale Review, out today, by Dr. Alvin Johnson, Director of the New School of Social Research and associate editor of the Encyclopaedia of Social Sciences.

Less than a colmun will suffice for this morning's intelligence of the theatre. "Triplets," which was exhibited at the Masque last evening, touches bottom for silliness and ineptitude. In the depths of the wilderness this story of the marriage of three Jewish triplets to three Irish triplets might seem like a novelty, and the local guides and trappers might cackle over it for months.

Average daily electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, has dropped back sharply nearly to the level of the four weeks prior to Labor Day. The seasonally adjusted average for the week ended Sept. 17 is 210,100,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 216,600,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 236,500,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- An increase of one-half of 1 per cent in employment in August, as compared with July, in the sixteen major industrial groups of the United States was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

With the tabulation of final returns in the primary election in up-State New York claims of gains for prohibition change were made yesterday by wet organizations, although the five dry Republican candidates for renomination were victorious.

Action to vacate the equity receiverships of the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company, recently ordered by Seniors Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, was begun yesterday by Benjamin F. Johnson of Winchester, Ky., holder of 100 shares of Manhattan Railway stock.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 -- Eight favored players, three of them from the United States, one from England and four from Canada, marched into the quarter-finals of the Canadian women's open golf championship in a series of close matches today.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Sunny California shone today in the international Star Class championship out on Long Island Sound off the Pequot Yacht Club. Edward Fink sailed the Mist of the Long Beach (Cal.) fleet to the finish line 1 minute and 39 seconds ahead of T.D. Parkman and his Fleet Star III from Gravesend Bay.

In the greatest activity of the month, bonds moved up yesterday in all classifications on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government obligations continued in the van, three of the issues moving into new high ground for the year. Trading amounted to $14,257,000, comparing with $9,261,500 on the preceding day.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The better tendency in the stock market late yesterday was well maintained today with an expansion in business helped by firmness in Wall Street. British Government funds were quiet but firm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald deserves the gratitude of the community for his efforts to establish a court for adolescents. At present the age limit in the Children's Court is 16 years. That should be increased at least to 18 and probably to 19 years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- A boy and a girl in their teens fought death and blindness today while every official from Mayor Cermak down stirred to action in efforts to capture the persons who threw a bomb in front of the home of Judge John. P. McGoorty of the Superior Court last night, causing their injuries.

Wisconsin has committed sacrilege find rebelled against a prince of the blood. Governor KOHLER, defeated in the primaries two years ago, beat Governor LA FOLLETTE in Tuesday's primaries. Senator BLAINE has gone down before young Editor CHAPPLE, whose rather fantastic campaign seemed directed mainly against the University of Wisconsin and the Progressives, regarded as budding Communists.

Wood alcohol, believed by the police to have been sold in the narrow strip of the lower east side between Police Headquarters and the City Hall, has claimed nine lives since Monday. Four of the victims died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday, most of them within an hour or two after they had been admitted.

Indications that the radio industry is due to make a fairly rapid recovery from the slump that set in nearly two years ago were, observed yesterday at the radio trade show being held this week at the Hotel Edison.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Consolidation of government agencies directing personnel to eliminate "overlapping and duplication" was urged today by Thomas E. Campbell, president of the Civil Service Commission.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Zion's Herald today quotes Senator Borah as saying in a letter in reference to the Republican and Democratic platforms that "Those who are in favor of the Eighteenth Amendment have been adroitly and effectually disfranchised so far as the Presidential election is concerned."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Another day of torrid weather resulted in a call for light practice work for the entire Yale football squad in its two sessions today on Anthony Thompson Field.

In a letter to stockholders of the White Motor Company recommending prompt deposit of shares as proposed for a merger of that company with the Studebaker Corporation, officers of the company announced that of 40,000 shares of White Motor treasury stock, 15,000 would be distributed among key employes who, the Studebaker Corporation felt, should be retained in the consolidated company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 -- Despite a decreased Income from its investments, Harvard University will discharge none of its officers of instruction or administration, and will not reduce salaries in any of its departments, it was announced officially today.
Following is the text of the decision by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan holding that a Mayoralty election on Nov. 8 would be illegal:

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Associated Press has been reliably informed that Governor Roosevelt will comment on the soldiers bonus payment during the first half of October, perhaps in his second campaign trip in the mid-West and South.

Alleging that the textile factoring corporation of Bachmann, Emmerich Co., Inc., lost millions through alleged fraud, malfeasance, negligence and bad faith of the directors and officers, a score of stockholders filed suit in the Supreme Court to compel them to account for any losses for which they may be held responsible.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 21 -- Young Senator. 2:02 1/4. by The Senator, owned by the Cahill Brothers of Syracuse, annexed the 2:09 Trot, featuring the Central Circuit light harness classes at the Allentown Fair today.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- No formal reply to the letter that Arthur Henderson, chairman of the disarmament conference, sent in answer to the communication from Baron von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, will be forthcoming, it was stated at the Foreign Office today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21. -- The removal of competition between the Canadian National and the Canadian Pacific. Rallways and the joint operation of terminals and lines were recommended in the report of the Royal Commission on Canadian Railways, made public today.

Laying aside proposals for new sources of revenue pending completion of his retrenchment program, Mayor McKee took steps yesterday which he said would save more than $1,000,000 on the city's bill for light and power next year.

Cotton Goods Houses Encouraged. Restoration of the confidence so prevalent a few weeks ago was apparent in cotton goods selling houses yesterday as prices of the raw fibre grained consistently during the day. Agents had been made somewhat uneasy by the recent persistent decline in cotton, and the sharp upward reaction yesterday encouraged them considerably.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21 -- Toll Gate, from the J.D. Roddy Stable of Kingston, Ont., defeated a select field in the 2:09 class pace, feature event of the light harness program at the Eastern States Exposition Grounds today.

HARRISBUHG, Pa., Sept. 21 -- Asserting that "Pennsylvania asks for bread and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation gives nothing but words," Governor Pinchot today renewed his appeal to President Hoover for speedy consideration of this State's request for a relief loan of $10,000,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The Rutgers freshman class is overwhelmingly Republican in its politics, according to a questionnaire submitted by The Targum, undergraduate newspaper. President Hoover received 113 votes, Franklin D. Roosevelt 53 and Norman Thomas 20.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Wheat regained today almost as much ground as it had lost in ten days. At no time was there much selling pressure on the Board of Trade here, and with general buying in evidence prices were on the upgrade from the start, while the close was at the top at net gains of 2 1/2 to 2 5/8 cents a bushel.
EDINBURGH, Sept. 21. -- The centenary of the death of Sir Walter Scott was commemorated throughout Scotland today.

GENEVA, Sept. 21 -- The disarmament conference, or rather the bureau of nineteen powers to which it has been temporarily boiled down, resumed work in the Glass House this morning, with Germany's empty seat not directly mentioned by the delegates, except by Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Commissar.

The engagements of a number of players for forthcoming Broadway productions were learned yesterday. Additions to the cast of the George S. Kaufman-Edna Ferber play, "Dinner at Eight," announced to open at the Music Box Theatre on Oct. 22, include Malcolm Duncan, Hans Roberts, Mary Murray, Ethel Intropidi, Dorothy Walters, Sam Levene, George Henry Trader, Gregory Gaye, James Seeley, Clarence Bellair, Robert Griffiths, Ray Barrett and William McFadden.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Rogers Horns by was the "forgotten, man" of the Cub clubhouse today. He was ignored completely by his former mates as they cast their ballots on the division of their world's series money.

Edward J. Dowling, 56,years old, lawyer and former State Senator from Manhattan, who was the husband of a deceased sister of John H. McCooey, Democratic National Committeeman and Brooklyn leader, surrendered in District Attorney Crain's office yesterday on an indictment accusing him of the theft of $20,000 in Liberty bonds from a woman executor of an estate left to her two children.

The four-story dwelling at 136 West Seventy-eighth Street has been leased by Albin Maier to Cecelia Villata through Elizabeth C. Whittington, broker. The lessee bought the entire furnishings of the house.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21. -- A desperate battle in the depths of the Chaco jungle between embattled Bolivian troops and besieging Paraguayans is pictured in dispatches from Asuncion.

"Dear KINGSLAND" has replied in kind to "Dear BILL," and the Republican nomination for Governor, if it goes to Colonel DONOVAN, will go with the blessing of State Chairman MACY. They are agreed that every act of Mr. MACY, including his objection to the early pledging of delegates, has been done with an eye single to the objective of Republican success.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Headed by Senator Wagner and Representative Prall, a delegation of Now Yorkers conferred again today with the directions of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation concerning the $39,400,000 which has been asked as a loan to construct the Staten Island rapid transit tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- An increase in building activities during August was announced today by the Labor Department, Vhich reported also that July employment gains were well sustained during the ensuing month.

Without warning, the stock market took on new life yesterday and staged one of the widest advances of the year to date. Judged on the basis of the price averages, the rise was the most sweeping since Feb. 13. Transactions on the Stock Exchange approximated 4,350,000 shares, compared with 1,250,780 shares on the day before.
TUCUMCARI, N.M., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Father James K. Cox of Pittsburgh, candidate on the "Jobless Ticket" for President, was stranded here today with a party of ten on his national campaign tour.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 -- Following is the text of Governor Rooserelt's speech in the auditorium here tonight:
MADRID, Sept. 21. -- A shipload of nobles, members of families which have ruled Spain for centuries, sailed from Cadiz today for exile in the fever swamps of Africa.

Has not Governor ROOSEVELT the fear of Senator SMOOT before his eyes? When the Democratic candidate first began talking of his party's plank in favor of making with several countries agreements for reciprocal trade, the Utah Senator sternly rebuked him.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean allowed Cincinnati five hits as the St. Louis Cardinals today shut out the Reds, 2 to 0, in taking the second game of the series. Dean struck out five Reds.
GRANITEVILLE, S.C., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Textile mills here and at Vaucluse and Warrenville have resumed full-time operation, employing 1,300 operatives.

Broad rallies in wheat and cotton gave strength yesterday to the securities markets, setting in motion a buying movement in stocks that pushed prices 3 to 10 points higher for the widest advance since Feb. 13.

Unless unemployment is ended and the lost purchasing power of labor restored the depression will be prolonged to the point of complete economic collapse, Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia asserted last night. The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, he held, has been a mere costly palliative.

Five successive favorites won at Aqueduct yesterday, greatly cheering the form players, who had a rather hard time during the recent Belmont meeting and the opening days of the present session. Jockey Hank Mills was the riding star, getting a triple and a second with four mounts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Pittsburgh, clinched second place in the National League race today by beating the champion Cubs, 9 to 6. A four-run rally in the eighth inning against a patched-up Cub line-up accomplished the victory.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- The conflict between Chancellor von Papen as the Reich's Commissioner for Prussia and the Prussian Diet, which yesterday threatened to lead to the Chamber's dissolution, is now about to be settled.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The nomination of Lieut. Gov. William S. Youngman as the Republican Gubernatorial candidate and the apparent victory of John C. Swift for the Democratic designation for Lieutenant Governor stood out today as the high lights of yesterday's primary.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- A new world altitude record for planes with a 500-kilogram load was established at Villacoublay today by a French pilot named Signorin, who reached a height of 10,300 meters (33,784 feet).

Columbia concluded its heavy training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its season's debut tomorrow with Middlebury by engaging the New York University squad in a hard scrimmage. The session lasted an hour and a half, but most of the regulars were in action only for twenty minutes before they gave way to substitutes.

Indeterminate sentences of not more than three years in the penitentiary were imposed in Special Sessions yesterday by Justices Gresser, Flood and Fetherston on Aloysius R. Bittner, 32 years old, formerly a patrolman in the Meserole Avenue station in Brooklyn, and John Stanley, 40, of 611 West 171st Street, on their conviction last week on an oppression charge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that the pressure for bank, railroad and insurance loans had been materially reduced in the last month, a condition interpreted as reflecting the national pick-up.

Reaching the highest total since the first week in June, bank clearing for the week ended on Wednesday night increased 20.8 per cent from the preceding week. Although a slight gain is usual at this season the week's rise last year was only 2.9 per cent., according to R.G. Dun Co.

Plans and assignments for the campaign from Oct. 16 to Jan. 1, by which the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies intends to raise $1,700,000 to complete its 1932 budget were outlined last night in the Savoy-Plaza.

BOMBAY, Sept. 22. -- Some progress was made today in negotiations with Mahatma Gandhi on the third day of his hunger strike. Leaders of the caste Hindus and depressed classes will return tomorrow for what they hope will be a final settlement of the electorate dispute.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22. -- America was routed today from the men's singles of the Pacific Southwest Tennis Championships. A quartet of players from Great Britain, Japan and Italy won the quarter-finals, defeating Ellsworth Vines Jr., national singles champion; Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, Davis Cup stars, and Keith Gledhill, who holds, with Vines, the national doubles championship.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Leo Sexton of the New York A.C., the first representative of the United States to capture a championship at the recent Olympic Games at Los Angeles, was honored tonight at a testimonial dinner at the clubhouse of the Hempstead Lodge of Elks.
PARIS, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
NEW YORK. The Ambassador to Germany and Mrs. Frederic M. Sackett gave a luncheon at the Plaza yesterday.

In spite of the depression visitors at the State-owned spa at Saratoga Springs showed an unexpectedly small decline this Summer, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the Saratoga Springs Commission, the State agency which controls the spa, at the office of Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and a member of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to approve an application made by the receivers of the Seaboard Air Line for a $3,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. At the same time it approved a loan of $260,000 to the Gulf, Mobile and Northern.

An application for listing common capital stock issue of the Plymouth Oil Company, consisting of 1,050,000 shares of $5 par value each, has been made to the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. The shares have been listed on the New York Curb Exchange for several years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- European unemployment stood at a record level at the end of June of 11,878,000 persons in nineteen countries, the regional division of the Department of Commerce stated today. The total did not include Switzerland, for which the June figures were not available.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The serving of luncheon to 300 members of an economic conference at a government cafeteria last month, stirred a tempest today at a session of the House committee which is investigating government competition.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22. -- The "Harvest Moon" supper dance given at Newport Beach tonight by the Lions' Club attracted many of the colonists who have remained here for the late season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- An airplane campaign by Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Prohibition Forces, which will carry him into thirty-one States for more than 200 scheduled speeches in support of President Hoover, will start from Topeka, Kan., on Sept. 26.

LONDON, Friday, Sept 23. -- Under the banner heading, "Lord Snowden Wrecks Cabinet," the Laborite Daily Herald this morning says the Lord Privy Seal has forced Sir Herbert Samuel, Home Minister, and his free trade fellow Liberal Ministers to leave the government by preparing to resign himself.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Names of 205 persons and firms listed in a contract, the terms of which proffered them, according to John A. Swanson, State's Attorney, a total of 250,000 shares of Insull Utilities Investment, Inc., at $12 a share, were made public by that official tonight.

Joining the ranks of workers for the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Tammany Chieftain John F. Curry will swing into action at Roosevelt headquarters today at a conference called by John H. McCooey to discuss financing the campaign in the State.

For the benefit of any who did not know that Governor ROOSEVELT is opposed to government ownership and operation of the common run of electric public utilities, he has made his position clear. "I state to you categorically," he told his Portland audience, "that as a broad general "rule the development of utilities "should remain, with certain excep"tions, a function for private initia"tive and private capital."

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt, exhibiting outdoor grown fruit and vegetables from the Braes, her estate at Glen Cove, won twelve blue ribbons and three reds in the second day's judging of the seventh annual Fall flower show of the Westbury Horticultural Society being held in the large hall of the Hicks nursery estate here.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Alvin Crowder, ranking pitcher of the Washington Senators, won his twenty-fifth game of the season today, and his fourteenth in succession, as Washington took the series finale from the Red sox, 4 to 2. The victory gave the visitors a clean sweep of their four-game series.

In an effort to prove that the 1930 and 1931 charity balls held by the Loyal Order of Moose were only incidental to the operation of a national lottery, the prosecution in the trial of Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania yesterday traced tickets to the affairs from printers to prize winners through testimony of a long succession of witnesses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Charles R. Hardin in his letter to THE TIMES presents a remarkably thorough and correct analysis of the empty Glass amendment. As he points out, it starts by repealing the Eighteeenth Amendment and then immediately proceeds to re-enact the essential viciousness of that amendment -- to wit, Congressional control of the liquor traffic within the States.

VICHY, Sept. 22. -- At the final session today of the International Congress for the Study of Gall Bladder Diseases Dr. Samuel Weiss, a professor of the Polyclinic Medical School of New York, said the principal reason for the steady growth of digestive diseases in the United States was "undoubtedly the national habit of abusing the use of ice."

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Bullish sentiment on the Board of Trade here received a severe check today, and the wheat market, after going as much as 1 cent higher at the start, broke 1 5/8 to 2 cents a bushel from the early top on fairly general selling and closed at 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents lower on the day.

Sales of several homes in the Westport section of Connecticut were reported yesterday by William C. Codman Jr., broker. The Adirondack Lodge property, consisting of a main lodge, stables, cabins, garages and lake, with twelve acres of land, just outside of Westport, was purchased by Victor Kennard of Brookline, Mass., for his all-year home.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will put into effect today a reduction in the tank-wagon and service-station prices of gasoline throughout its territory of 3.2 cents and 2.2 cents a gallon. The oversupply of gasoline and widespread price-cutting were given as the principal reasons for the reductions by the company.

After several days of pronounced upward tendencies, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange turned irregular yesterday. Leading foreign issues continued to advance, but United States Government obligations closed with an assortment of gains and losses, while railroad issues, leaders in the upswing, became weak.

H.C. Phipps's Balios, a double winner at the Aqueduct Summer meeting, came back with a victory at his home course yesterday when he ran six fast furlongs in the Babylon Handicap, one of the Queens County Jockey Club's newer stakes, to win easily.

Through a gift of $250,000 by Mrs. Jacob H. Schiff in memory of her son, Mortimer L. Schiff, the Boy Scouts of America acquired yesterday 480 acres near Morristown, N.J., to be developed as a permanent reservation for the 2,000,000 Scouts in the world.

Considering the violence of Wednesday's advance, the moderate reaction yesterday occasioned little surprise in Wall Street. The net losses in a dozen or so stocks were rather sharp, but the average decline was small. Fifty stocks, for instance, showed a net drop of $1.54.

GREENWICH, conn., Sept. 22. -- Colonel and Mrs. William M. Colvin gave a tea dance at their home in Bellehaven, Greenwich, this afternoon to introduce their daughter, Miss Lucette Colvin, into society. The house was brilliantly decorated with smilax, chrysanthemums, yellow roses and other Autumn flowers.

There are some queer reasoners at Washington. The Republicans are finding crumbs of comfort in the result of the Wisconsin primary. Secretary MILLS is pleased because "you do not have to be a radical to win elections, after all." Two years ago Governor KOHLER was beaten on account of depression and unemployment, mild as they were compared with present conditions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the many compelling reasons why the Republican party should be repudiated at the polls this coming November is one which, although receiving little attention, nevertheless is vitally important because of its bearing on the reconstruction program that must be carried out during the next four years.
BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- Rear Admiral William S. Sims, retired, today described the system of Spanish-American War pensions as a "steal of the nastiest kind and an outrage to the American taxpayers."

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 22. -- A saving of $179,331 in the 1932-33 budget through the general reduction in all city employes' salaries and the elimination of many positions is recommended in the final report today of the Long Beach Citizens' Committee, which has been investigating this city's financial affairs for the last two months.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 22. -- Brown in 1931 had a good football team that went wrong because of lack of reserves after winning the first five games on the schedule.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 22. -- Captain William P. Wright of Chicago was elected commander-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic at the closing session of the annual encampment here today. His election was unanimous, the two other candidates, Harding I. Merrill of Kansas and Colonel Russell C. Martin of California withdrawing.

Tuna, which, seem to have been drifting away from the Long Island shore in the past few weeks, have been rediscovered on the Ridge near the Ambrose Lightship, just as old-time tuna fishermen predicted would be the case.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

TOKYO, Sept. 22. -- Japanese nervousness regarding United States policy in the forthcoming showdown on Manchuria is revealed by fears displayed here that Senator David A. Reed's mission to London and Paris

BERLIN, Sept. 12 (By Mail). -- A second respiration ferment, one that is not the haemin which controls the conveyance of oxygen from the lungs to the muscles and other tissues of the body has been found by Professor Otto Warburg, Nobel Prize winner, and his associate, Dr. Walter Christian of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Biology here.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 22. -- Out of a seesaw sailing contest came the Mist today, fourth in the last raca for the international Star class championship, but earning enough points to take the world's title away from Long Island Sound, where it had remained two years, to Long Beach, Cal.
PANAMA CITY, Sept. 22 (AP). --Approximately 100 Hindu merchants here began a twenty-four-hour hunger strike today in sympathy with the strike of Mahatma Gandhi.

Dr. Alfred B. Cassassa, one of the physicians handling city compensation cases who were accused by Samuel Seabury in the Hofstadter committee investigation of having split fees with Dr. William H. Walker, the former Mayor's brother, refused to take the stand yesterday at a continued informal hearing before the medical grievance committee of the State Board of Regents.

NEWCHWANG, Manchuria, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Another poignant appeal for the rescue of herself and Charles Corkran, another British subject who was captured by Chinese bandits about two weeks ago, was received today from Mrs. Kenneth Pawley, who said the bandits planned to shoot them in a week, after cutting off their ears.

Lawrence Tibbett, Metropolitan Opera baritone, returned on the Italian liner Saturnia yesterday from his first visit to Europe, convinced that it is not necessary for American singers to study abroad and that this country has everything to offer the aspiring artist.

The equity receiverships of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company were continued in force yesterday by Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting by his own designation as a district court judge.

Working toward the $30,000,000 saving that the Citizens Budget Commission contends can be made in the city's $1,000,000-a-day payroll, Mayor McKee disclosed yesterday that he had suggested voluntary pay cuts, which will not affect pension rights, in the Police and Fire Departments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Asserting that the American Red Cross faces the greatest emergency in relief since the World War, the central committee of the organization, at a special meeting today, adopted a resolution calling for greater support through increased membership.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Templemore and Ballymore, two imported geldings owned by Mrs. Florence Dibble of Oldtown Hill Farm, Newburyport, Mass., won their first leg on the Wissahickon Challenge Trophy at the opening of the Wissahickon Horse Show near Whitemargh today. The trophy, presented by William Wallace, is for two hunters of the same owner, ridden by amateurs in hunting attire.

Following the announcement of C. A. Davis, vice president of the General Water Works and Electric Corporation, that the company having determined its inability to pay interest due on Oct. 1 on the 1944 series of debentures had consented to receivership in connection with a small claim by a creditor, the readjustment committee headed by Wiley F. Corl made public yesterday a plan of reorganization with which, it said, the receivership proceedings would not interfere.

The possibility of a dairy farmers' strike in New York State, similar to the recent rebellion in Iowa against low prices, was foreseen here yesterday by George N. Allen, secretary of the emergency committee of the New York milk-shed, who described the situation among dairymen as "desperate" and likely to cause some "unpleasant action" if dealers continue to cut prices.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 22. -- John Dawson of Glen Oaks, Chicago, established a new competitive record for the Arcola course today with a medal winning 73 in the qualifying round of the fourteenth renewal of the historic Arcola invitation golf tourney.

"The League of Nations reminds one sometimes of a heap of toys collecting dust while waiting vainly for Little Boy Blue to come back," one of the anonymous authors of "Not to Be Repeated," subtitled, "Merry-Go-Round of Europe," writes in the section on Geneva.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Cathop, one of the shortest priced favorites to go to the post during the current Lincoln Fields meeting, finished third in the Allerton Purse, feature at seven furlongs. The Reichert brothers' Brown Wisdom, captured the race by three lengths eased up.

Money market was at a standstill so far as rate changes and business was concerned. No variation in quotations were reported, Street loans going at 1 per cent, while the Exchange rate remained at 2. Elsewhere, business was on a small scale at prevailing quotations.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Friday, Sept. 23. -- In an exciting round here tonight Mrs. P. Hal Sims and her partner, Baron Waldemar von Zedtwitz, held their lead in the mixed pair event of the New Jersey State contract bridge championships and captured the title by four match points covering two sessions of play.

The vicissitudes that beset "Susan Lenox -- Her Fall and Rise," before it finally was published six years after the death of David Graham Phillips, the author, are related in detail in Isaac F. Marcosson's biography of the important but almost forgotten journalist and novelist.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 22. -- While Governor Pinchot continued today his efforts to obtain President Hoover's intercession in behalf of a Federal loan for Pennsylvania's unemployed, the State Relief Board authorized Philip C. Staples, chairman of the Philadelphia County Emergency Relief Committee, to go to Washington to interview officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the interest of a loan for the State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Any failure to relieve the poor and distressed in Pennsylvania lies with Governor Pinchot and the Pennsylvania Legislature, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation stated tonight in replying to the Governor's charges that the $10,000,000 loan he seeks has been held up by "red tape."

First returns in the Literary Digest's nation-wide Presidential poll, covering five States and including 60,237 returned "straw" ballots, give President Hoover a slight lead of 539 votes over his Democratic opponent, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.
BOGOTA, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Official sources said today the 10,000,000-peso defense loan proposed following the demand for war with Peru over the Amazon port of Leticia was oversubscribed.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 22.-- In actively taking over the reins of Amherst College at its 112th opening today the new president, Stanley King, brought up two ancient problems -- compulsory chapel and the use of automobiles by undergraduates.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22. -- The United States' representation in the Canadian women's open golf championship was reduced to one player today with the victory of Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., and the defeat of Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo and Miss Fritzi Stifel of Wheeling, W.Va., in the quarter-final round.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The comparative peace of a Supreme Court room will become the front for the Oklahoma City oil proration "war" tomorrow, with State's attorneys taking the offensive, at least temporarily, from Governor Murray's National Guardsmen.

Under the guiding band of Edwin Howland Blashfield, distinguished American mural artist, the newly organized Carnegie Hall Art Association will open its gallery in Carnegie Hall at 4 o'clock Tuesday afternoon, Oct. 4. This enterprise, sponsored by eminent painters and craftsmen, will be "a centre where principals and patrons," according to the announcement, "will be able to establish a more friendly contact."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Representatives of about 2,000,000 railroad employes asked President Hoover today to make further Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to the railroads conditional upon the railroads maintaining wages upon the present basis.

AT SEA ON TUG FREEDOM, Sept. 22 (4:15 P.M.). -- Otis Barton and I have just emerged from the bathysphere after reaching a depth of 2,200 feet, practically half a mile, and more than 770 feet deeper than our quarter-mile record made two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt's utility speech at Portland was acclaimed by Democratic Senators here as the most powerful statement he has made in his campaign tour. Some of them suggested that it was a "body blow" at the administration's stand on the power question.

A street brawl involving several hundred members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which started last night in front of the Central Opera House in East Sixty-seventh Street near Third Avenue after the union's meeting at the hall, resulted in critical injuries to at least one of the participants, lesser injuries to several others and the arrest of two.

Mayor McKee extended the city's welcome yesterday to sixteen veterans of the Seventy-seventh Division who gave him national and regimental flags that had been carried overseas by units of the division.
PARIS, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Anglo-American-Rumanian oil conference to limit production and stabilize prires ended today what delegates described as a successful session.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- An audience that included Chancellor von Papen, Gerhart Hauptmann, Professor Albert Einstein and scores of other prominent personalities of the German political, musical and artistic worlds gave Ruggiero Ricci an enthusiastic welcome when the 11-year-old violinist made his first European appearance in Philharmonie Hall tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The stock market was strong today, with a big expansion in business. Overnight news from Wall Street brought brokers to their offices earlier than usual, and quotations forged ahead, with a pronounced upward movement in the internationals.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 22. -- Miss Clifford Watson, daughter of Captain and Mrs. Edward Watson of Peckisland Road, Greenwich, made her debut at a supper dance given by her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey S. Rockefeller of Meads Lane, Greenwich, at the Round Hill Club tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates made it three in a row over the champion Cubs today, taking the final game of the series, 7 to 0. Young Hal Smith, purchased from Kansas City, gave the Bruins but six hits as he blanked them. The triumph gave the Corsairs the season series with the Cubs, 13 to 9.

NAPLES, Sept. 22. -- The opinion that the Court of Appeals would uphold Justice McGeehan's ruling against a Mayoralty election this Fall was expressed here today by former Mayor Walker, who said he had cabled that opinion to New York.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 22. -- Paraguay's suggestions for truce terms submitted yesterday to the commission of neutrals in Washington were merely a device to gain time while she struggles for a military victory in the disputed Chaco region, the Bolivian Foreign Ministry asserted in a note cabled to the neutrals today.

A gain of $4,669,100 in the monetary gold stocks of the country was shown in yesterday's report of gold transactions issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The report showed imports of $2,844,700 gold and a net decrease of $1,824,400 in the amount of gold held under earmark for foreign account.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 21, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,269,000,000, a decrease of $24,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $972,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Unintelligent economy in public institutions is as harmful as unjustified expenditures, Lieut. Gov. Lehman said in an address here today at the dedication of Park Lewis Hall of the New York State School for the Blind.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- William Beck of White Beeches won the championship of the New Jersey State Seniors' Golf Association at the Shackamaxon Country Club today by returning a 36-hole total of 165. His final 18-hole score was 41, 42 -- 83.

Criticism of the practice of appointing the Irving Trust Company receiver in all equity and bankruptcy cases was expressed in a report issued yesterday by the special committee on United States courts and practices of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- France has no intention of recognizing the new State of Manchukuo, it was said today in a high official quarter, and the French view concerning the status of Manchuria is the same as that of the United States Government.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 22. -- One hundred Chattanooga veterans of various wars announced tonight the formation of what is designed to be a national organization known as "The American Veterans" for the purpose of combating efforts to influence the government into an immediate payment of the bonus, and to attempt to avert further bonus marches and checkmate the Communists, who, they charge, have invaded the ranks of the veterans, and are fomenting unrest.

While the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association began recruiting men yesterday to replace members of Typographical Union 6 on Oct. 1, when the present contract expires, the union officials declared that the only effect obtained by the posting of the notices of the new conditions by book and job plants was to solidify the ranks of the compositors.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Mrs. Samuel S. Laird of the Westchester Country Club finished five strokes in the lead today in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's one-day tourney over the Ardsley Club course. She had a low gross of 85, going out in 43 and coming back with a 42.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- The entire embassy staff waved farewell to Ambassador Edge this morning from the station platform when his train left for Havre, where he boarded the liner Manhattan to return to the United States.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The State Department of Banking and Insurance is restrained from allowing offsets of deposits against notes held by the closed Asbury Park and Ocean Grove Bank by a show-cause order returnable Oct. 6 issued by Vice Chancellor Major Leon Berry today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- A list of Samuel Insull's "preferred investors," who subscribed to common stock of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., at less than one-half the initial market price was made public today.

Jose Miguel Tarafa y Armas, president of the Cuba Northern Railroad Company and the Central Cuba Sugar Company, who died at his home in Havana on July 23, left a New York estate of about $600,000. Fernando J. Cancio y Erro, his Cuban executor, applied yesterday for letters of administration of the estate.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 22. -- Thousands of cheering Chattanoogans gave their champion Lookouts and their Dixie series foes, the Beaumont Exporters, a demonstration tonight rivaling that which marked the winning of the Southern Association pennant.

Herman Plaut, 60 years old, of 480 Park Avenue, for forty years an important figure in the gas and electric fixture industry in New York, died in the Hotel Endicott at Columbus Avenue and Eighty-first Street yesterday morning after firing a pistol shot into his heart, according to the police.

SACRAMENTO, Sept. 22. -- A bid for the support of the followers of Senator Hiram Johnson, Republican, was made this afternoon by Governor Roosevelt in a speech from the rear platform of his car to an enthusiastic crowd of about 10,000 of Senator Johnson's fellow townsmen.

Featuring a new bloom, to be known as the "Amelia Earhart," the annual dahlia and Fall flower show of the American Dahlia Society opened yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The exhibit, which includes competitive classes for professional growers, amateurs and garden clubs, will close tonight following the annual meeting of the society.

The One Hundred Glenwood Corporation, Norman Christie, president, sold to the S.C.S. Company the five-story, forty-family brick apartment house on a plot 78 by 146 feet at 100 Glen-wood Avenue, near the Boulevard, Jersey City. The house is valued for taxation at $196,400, of which $26,400 is the value of the land and $170,000 the building value.

GENEVA, Sept. 22. -- Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament Conference, promptly checked today a move by Sir John Simon, his successor in the British Foreign Office, to rule out "major political problems" from discussions of the Disarmament Conference's bureau.

The seven-month-long trial of the Federal Government's anti-trust suit to dissolve the Sugar Institute, one of the longest ever held in the Federal courts, came to an end yesterday, with the exception of the summing up by counsel, scheduled for twelve weeks hence.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22. -- Head Coach Mal Stevens today sent the Yale football regulars and reserves through a 45-minute scrimmage, the longest period of actual play ordered since the squad reported last week. With the first-string lineup maintained for fully thirty minutes, except for replacements of the ends, the regulars scored twice, netting 13 points, and checked the scrubs consistently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Brutal administration, insanitary living arrangements and other conditions amounting to virtual enslavement of Negro workers on the Mississippi flood-control project were charged in a report made today to Brig. Gen. G.B. Pillsbury, Assistant Chief of Army Engineers, by Miss Helen Boardman, formerly of the American Red Cross.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Chicago hit a home run, with the bases filled today in paying homage to Charlie Grimm's championship Cubs.

The Europa of the North German Lloyd Line will arrive today. Among her prominent passengers is V.J. Patel, first Indian Lord Mayor of Bombay and former president of the Indian Legislative Assembly. Others include Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen, chairman of the board of the British Tobacco Company; Lillian Gish, stage and screen star; Edward Plaut, head of Lehn Fink; Margalo Gillmore, actress; E.H. Sothern, actor, and his wife, the former Julia Marlowe.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 22. -- My Man, 2:04 1/4, by Host Peter, owned by Dr. J.A. Turlington of Melfa, Va., won the Washington Bicentennial Classic, featuring today's Central Circuit classes at the Allentown Fair. He established a new track record of 2:03 3/4 for pacers in the second heat.

Quality Emphasis Shows Gain. Reports in the wholesale market indicate that the projected quality movement is already bearing fruit in expanded commitments in better-grade lines of apparel and accessories. The call for better goods, that is, merchandise whose value is recognized, is coming not only from the larger stores but unexpectedly from many smaller stores throughout the country.

Joseph Horowitz, real estate operator of 825 West End Avenue, who admitted last year before Special Corporation Counsel Leonard Wallstein that he made large profits in sale of school and park sites to the city through his shrewdness in foretelling the locations, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for violation of the income tax laws in allegedly failing to report profits made on school sites and other deals.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined again to 94.8 on Sept. 20, with a loss of 0.9 from the previous week's 95.7 (reyised). Compared with a year ago, when it stood at 99.9, it showed a loss of 5.1. All the group indices declined, with the exception of the inactive chemicals index, which was unchanged.

John F. Curry called for a showdown on his leadership of Tammany Hall, at a meeting of the Tammany executive committee yesterday afternoon, and he received from the committee a vote of confidence and a pledge of "active and valiant support" in working for "the success of the party and all its candidates."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt received the most enthusiastic welcome of his Western tour here tonight.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. In the subjoined comparative table all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Careful attention to the subject of prohibition during the entire half century in which its importance has been growing has led me to a conclusion diametrically opposed to one of those announced by Dr. Butler in THE TIMES.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- Prehistoric man's habits, as revealed by excavations and findings in the caves of the Haute Garonne region of France, proved that heredity and environment had influenced equally the evolution of human culture, members of the American Club in Paris were told today by Townsend Russell, a representative of the Smithsonian Institution, who spoke at the regular weekly luncheon of the club.

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, announced yesterday that he had filed with the Shannon Congressional committee a protest against the awarding of shipbuilding and repair contracts by the government to its navy yards.

Inquiry among New York representatives of newsprint manufacturers yesterday developed that other companies are preparing to follow the lead of the International Paper Company, which cut prices $7 a ton this week. No new announcements of reductions were made, but paper men said their companies were considering the situation and that early statements could be expected.

New York City has arranged to borrow $20,000,000 under the $151,000,000 revolving credit placed at its disposal by a syndicate of thirty-three local banks. The loan will take the form of the sale of 5 3/4 per cent revenue bills dated Sept. 27 and due on Dec. 13.

Reactionary influences ruled most of the markets yesterday as the logical aftermath of the aggressive advances of the previous day. Stocks, bonds and most of the commodities lost ground, but the declines canceled only a portion of Wednesday's grains.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusro gained the final round in defense of her New Jersey State golf title at the Echo Lake Country Club today when she scored a par 83 in defeating her semi-finalist challenger, Mrs. H.D. Wimpfheimer of Hollywood, 2 up.

Miss Glair Biesinger, secretary to Anders Jordahl, head of the firm bearing his name, which formerly was the American Kreuger Toll Company, testified yesterday before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee in bankruptcy, that she had accompanied Warren E. Wheeler, secretary of Jordahl Co., to Canada last week after both had received subpoenas for their appearance at the hearing.

Before a group of several hundred building mechanics, gathered yesterday on the eighth floor of the new Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Building at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street, the New York Building Congress and officials of the insurance company presented craftsmanship awards to thirty-two workmen chosen for outstanding work on the structure.

The meetings of the National Liberal Organization now going on in England have revived the rumors that there will soon be a break in the National Government. Party pressure is applied to several members of the Cabinet who are Liberals to induce them to resign.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The Princeton football outlook brightened today with the initial appearance of Jack James, brilliant ball carrier of two seasons ago. James sustained an injury last year that kept him on the sidelines during most of the season and he resigned from the university last Winter.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 22. -- The Mexican Government issued a decree this evening virtually indicating a return of the country to the gold basis.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- "The new education" is dependent upon the library as one of its chief resources, Dr. Jesse Newlon, director of the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, told the State Library Association today.

It is announced that the expected appeal from the decision of Justice McGEEHAN will be pushed rapidly by lawyers acting for Tammany Hall. Let no one mistake their motive. It is of the highest professional honor and pride. In their disinterested capacity as eminent jurists they had given the opinion to the Tammany leader that a new election for Mayor must be held on Nov. 8.

Details of five housing projects to cost a total of about $72,000,000 and designed to provide the city's low-salaried workers with more than 45,000 modern, well-lighted and well-ventilated rooms at a maximum cost of $12.50 a room were announced yesterday by the State Board of Housing, and by Sloan Robertson, architects for August Heckscher, sponsor of one of the projects.

District Attorney McLaughlin of the Bronx announced yesterday that he had abandoned the search for the boiler of the steamer Observation, which he had hoped would reveal the cause of the explosion that wrecked the steamer on Sept. 9, bringing death to seventy-two men.

Demonstrating that whatever else may have been their shortcomings this year they still remain infinitely superior to the Giants, the Dodgers captured the final engagement of the campaign between the interboroug rivals in the one-day tournament at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The question of whether the Commissioner of Licenses is in effect a potential censor or just an official robot rested yesterday in the hands of Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag. The matter arose from a case brought before him by the managements of the Republic and Eltinge Theatres.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 22. -- The Midwest Refining Company is to be dissolved. Directors already have voted for dissolution and soon will call a meeting of stockholders. More than 99 per cent of the stock is owned by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana.

The financial statement of the Phoenix Securities Corporation for the year ended on Aug. 31 shows that the directors have invested about $500,000 of the corporation's funds within the last few months and will continue to put out available cash as security market conditions in their opinion warrant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every one will applaud the fine spirit in which, the people directly, through charitable organizations and municipal relief, have voluntarily carried the burden of unemployment distress in the Winters of 1930 and 1931, as well as the fortitude with which those unfortunately placed have borne their plight.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The desirability of establishing the milk producing industry of New York State as a public utility is being considered by the joint legislative committee investigating the industry, it was indicated by Senator Perley A. Pitcher of Watertown at the committee's hearing here yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22. -- Calumet Calling, pacing star of the W.H. Bird Stable of Revere, Mass., after capturing an event earlier in the week, triumphed in the 3-year-old pace today on the Eastern States Exposition track. Driven by the veteran Harry Brusie, he won in straight heats.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The Autumn plates went to the Hurricanes today as they rode over Old Westbury by 20 to 14 on Cochran Field at Meadow Brook in the final of the annual sixteen-goal event which features the late polo season.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Parry, racing for the Greentree Stable of Mrs. Payne Whitney, easily defeated four other fillies in the Meadows Purse, the mile and seventy-yard feature today at Havre de Grace.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., Sept. 22 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Declaring he was "opposed to cancellation of our foreign debts" and asserting that the United States "was the last great country to feel the depression and will be the first to recover," Vice President Curtis carried the national Republican campaign to the southern border of Tennessee tonight.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 22. -- Declaring that "the inevitable trend of pure democracy is toward concentration of power in aggressive blocs," President Ernest Martin Hopkins, at the opening of Dartmouth College today, criticized the sponsors of increased gratuities for war veterans, laid the "failure" of the Eighteenth Amendment to a lack of cooperation among those who supported it, and renewed his plea for an "aristocracy of brains" to offset the "idolizing" of mediocrity.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Declaring that President Hoover's reconstruction program had been the "only workable plan to break the depression offered by any man in or out of public life," Secretary Hurley tonight pictured Franklin D. Roosevelt as "at last" realizing that Mr. Hoover's program "has not forgotten any man or woman in America."
Approval of the stand taken by President Hoover on the bonus was voiced by a number of noted economists in a statement made public yesterday by the non-partisan fact-finding committee for Hoover.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Another prospective world's series ace was trumped with Philadelphia homers today, but the Yankees staged a finish that was truly championship in caliber to take a ten-inning 8-to-7 decision over the Athletics for an even break in the two-game series concluding the season's relations between the champions and ex-champions.

After conferences on Wednesday which led to no result, Nassau County Republican politicians continued yesterday to bring pressure to bear with a view of forcing F. Trubee Davison to withdraw as a Gubernatorial aspirant and make way for another Nassau Republican, James L. Dowsey, party leader of the town of North Hempstead, who is an aspirant for the nomination for Attorney General.

Among the chief occupations of the American citizen are (1) complaining about the quality of his government, and (2) ignoring opportunities to make it better. Georgia must be full of Democrats who deplore the sort of men that administer public affairs, but Georgia Democrats last week retired to private life Representative CRISP, whose courage and ability had been outstanding at the last session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- A delegation representing the National Woman's party, which included Amelia Earhart, called on President Hoover today and urged his support of the movement for extension of equal rights to women in the various States.
Revaluing the Corner Saloon. Dr. STELZLE'S letter about the oldtime saloon in yesterday's TIMES was by no means an unreserved apologia for the pre-Volstead institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- American holders of French bonds, ineluded in the recent $3,500,000,000 French conversion plan, who wish reimbursement instead of new 4 1/2 per cent bonds, must apply tomorrow to the nearest French Consul for the visa of their securities, according to the Commerce Department's finance division, which has just been so advised by Ambassador Walter Edge at Paris.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The body of a well-dressed man, identified from a card as Thomas N. Innes, a member of Elks Lodge 878 of Elmhurst, L.I., was found in the Tidal Basin at Potomac Park this, afternoon with his hands and ankles bound by a rope.

WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 22 (AP). -- John A. Machray, aged lawyer and churchman and rusted custodian of university and church endowment funds for thirty years, was sentenced to seven years in the penitentiary today for theft.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Workers for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment must take care not to delude themselves into thinking that "all is over but the shouting and the bonfires," Mrs. Charles H. Sabin warned the State convention of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform tonight.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- In a frank address before the annual convention of the New York State Coal Merchants Association today, Roderick Stephens, retail coal merchant of New York, analyzed some of the difficulties of the anthracite industry and asked the operators what they propose to do to restore the advantages that anthracite has hitherto enjoyed.
Polo's first civilian invasion of Argentina starts tonight with the sailing of the Grace liner Santa Clara, on board which will be the vanguard of the American party.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 22. -- Paul Runyan of the Metropolis Club continued today to lead the field in the New England open golf tournament. To the 67 he scored yesterday he added 71 today for an aggregate 138.

No more refreshing and challenging word has been spoken in these days of confused and confusing voices than that of President HOPKIKS of Dartmouth College at the opening of the academic year.
