He is aware that many of his assertions are "more definitely in the contro"versial field than is ordinarily ap"propriate to an academic address," but the times will not let him keep silent.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- An early solution of the disarmament impasse that has resulted in Germany's temporary withdrawal from the Geneva negotiations is looked for in official quarters as a sequel to President Hoover's recent statement and a more emphatic recommendation advanced by a section of the London press today.

Prices rose sharply again yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and a gain of more than a quarter cent carried the December to 7.75 cents a pound or virtually 100 points above the week's low quotations. The rapid advance ran the market into an increased supply of contracts, while profit-taking and Southern selling caused a setback of nearly $2 a bale, prices ending 2 points higher to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

Brokers and renting agents of business buildings in Manhattan reported a long list of new tenants yesterday. Some of the leases were for entire floors and represented a demand for office, showroom and loft space in scattered sections of the city.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 22. -- A demonstration designed by farmers' holiday leaders to impress President Hoover with agriculture's plight was planned today for the date on which the Chief Executive opens his campaign here.

Representative James S. Parker of New York, ranking member and former chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, accused Governor Roosevelt yesterday of deliberately misrepresenting in his speech at Portland the attitude of President Hoover with regard to Federal power regulation.

The engagement of two prominent stars for plays which are promised in the immediate future was among the many cast announcements made yesterday. Ina Claire, who has not been seen on the Broadway stage since the revival of "Our Betters" in 1928, has been engaged for the leading role in "Nine Pine Street," the William Miles-Donald Blackwell play which Ray and Hewes are producing.

Former members of the staff of The Campus, City College student publication, who resigned their positions on Monday in protest against alleged alumni interference in the running of the paper, made plans yesterday to launch a rival newspaper to be known as The City College Student, the first issue of which will be published Monday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Repeating a triumph scored earlier in the season in the New York State championships, Miss Carolyn Roberts of New Rochelle eliminated Miss Grace Surber, metropolitan clay court titleholder, in a thrilling quarterfinal match today in the Bronxville Field Club's invitation tennis tourney.

The directors of the Public Utility Holding Corporation of America voted yesterday to apply $2,000,000 for the acceptance of the lowest priced tenders of South American Railways Company 6 per cent convertible gold notes due on April 15, 1933. The offer will be outstanding up to and including Oct. 3.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 23. -- To Captain E.F. Carter of Sands Point fell the honor of being medalist in the Nassau Country Club's annual invitation tournament today, the former Irish golf champion being the only one in the large field who was able to give par a stroke-for-stroke battle.

John J. Sullivan, assistant chief inspector in charge of the city's detectives, collapsed at Police Headquarters yesterday morning while questioning prisoners at the line-up. He was resting comfortably last night in St. Vincent's Hospital and expected to be out in a day or two.

Presidential Candidates and State Frontiers. A ceremony which, only the hardest - boiled critic would wish to see disappear from our campaign ritual is the solemn and picturesque observance of Boarding the Train.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Mrs. Robert Bacon won two blue ribbons today in the table decorations section in the final judging of the annual Fall flower show of the Westbury Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the large hall of the Hicks Nurseries here.

While it has teen true at the League of Nations, as at various European capitals, that a watched crisis never boils, there is no denying that the League Council is facing decisions big with its own fate. Withdrawals from the League have been threatened. Germany and Japan are said to contemplate leaving it in certain eventualities.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- Tonight at the end of Foreign Minister von Neurath's first day in Geneva, the harassed statesmen here were only slightly, if at all, nearer a solution for that two faced puzzle: Precisely what is Germany's price to return to the disarmament conference and precisely what will the French, the British and others pay to get her back?

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- In sympathy with the reaction in Wall Street yesterday, prices on the Bourse declined today. During the early part of the session practically everything gained yesterday was lost, but late trading was featured by a gradual strengthening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- At the request of Secretary Stimson the delegation from the United States to a Geneva meeting to prepare for resumption of the disarmament conference will sail from New York early Sunday on the German liner Europa instead of a slower United States vessel.

Events of the last two days have indicated that Tammany has turned "thumbs down" on former Mayor James J. Walker in the coming Mayoralty campaign, according to information yesterday in usually well-informed quarters.

In recalling the political, legal and financial trials and tribulations that had to be overcome before the new subway became a reality, the public may overlook what it owes to the late Celonel JOHN R. SLATTERY. Although long a respected figure among engineers, he leaped into prominence but a few months ago, when the city was forced to operate the subway itself.

The money market was featureless. Offerings were in good volume, but demand was light. Quotations for all classes were unchanged. Street funds were offered at 1 per cent, Federals at 1/8, and the Stock Exchange rate was 2, all unchanged. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Detroit pitchers held St. Louis to seven scattered hits in two games today and the Tigers won the first, 6 to 2, and nightcap, 12 to 0.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Canvasback, owned by Robert McC. Shields, won the special Sound Interclub Class race conducted by the American Yacht Club today. Competing against six other craft, Canvasback, sailed by Gordon Raymond, covered the windward and leeward course of six and one-half miles in 1 hour 13 minutes 12 seconds, beating Lawrence Marks's Alberta by almost a minute.
NAPLES, Sept. 23. -- Loneliness beset former Mayor James J. Walker today, he admitted tonight after having spent a solitary day at his hotel here.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Sept. 23. -- Two hundred National Guardsmen tossed tear gas bombs today at crowds of striking miners who had gathered at Langleyville, a few miles from here, in an attempt to prevent workers belonging to the regular union from resuming operations in the Peabody Coal Company mines.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 23. -- George Starkie, 53 years old, an automobile dealer of Corona, Queens; two guests, Dominick Sumpter and Harry Sumpter, also of Corona, and Harry Barlow, Negro cook employed by Mr. Starkie, were hurled into Long Island Sound about three miles off shore here today by an explosion that wrecked the Pegusjo II, a forty-two-foot cruiser owned by Mr. Starkie.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- Before a wildly cheering audience of 16,000 persons in the Civic Auditorium, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, tonight aroused his hearers to the highest pitch of enthusiasm by declaring again for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, a plank in the party platform that he has not hitherto stressed in his tour through the West.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Premier Edouard Herriot consulted with his Cabinet this evening on the lines of French action at Geneva regarding disarmament and in the League of Nations Assembly and council meetings and received approval of the draft of the important speech he intends to make Sunday afternoon at Gramat.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Although they failed to win their fourth straight American League pennant, the Athletics assured themselves of the second-place cut in the world's series proceeds today by defeating the Washington Senators, 8 to 4, in the first game of their series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Calculators of the Democratic National Committee today estimated that the first poll made public by The Literary Digest showed a Democratic strength 20 per cent greater than in 1928. A like drift from the Republican party was registered in the recent Maine election.

Abandonment by the 150 East Forty-eighth Street Corporation of the erection of an apartment hotel at that address on June 1, 1931, resulted in the filing in Supreme Court yesterday by the Shelton Holding Corporation against the Detroit Fidelity and Surety Company of an application for an attachment against the property of the defendant on the ground that it is a foreign corporation.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Old Master, an imported English colt racing for the Howe Stable of New York, won by a nose from W.R. Coe's Laughing Queen today in the featured Penn Athletic Club Purse, for 3-year-olds at a mile and seventy yards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation heard a delegation from Illinois plead today for an emergency loan of $9,050,000, which would be in addition to the $9,000,000 the State has already received.

The monk in RABELAIS who argued against method and punctuality, that "hours are made for man, and not man for the hours," would doubtless protest against adopting the calendar for which Mr. EASTMAN labored in life and for whose continued advocacy the trustees of the University of Rochester have made provision in recognition of his interest.
BOMBAY, Sept. 23. -- Mahatma Gandhi today showed the strain not only of his fast but of prolonged interviews with leaders of the caste Hindus and "untouchables."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23. -- Federal Judge Faris today denied the first of two pending suits for a receivership of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad. The suit was filed Aug. 25 by Charles and Dora Gans, owning $3,500 of prior-lien bonds, who sought to prevent proposed reorganization.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23. -- Harvard College opened its 297th year today as some 1,000 members of the freshman class descended upon Memorial Hall and the yard from all parts of the world.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 23. -- Snapping out of the spell which Pitcher Rowe had held over them for eight innings, the Chattanooga Lookouts slammed, their way to a 3-2 victory over the Beaumont Exporters in the ninth inning today and took the lead in the Dixie Series, two games to one.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Mickey Walker nears the end of the long training siege ready for a hard fifteen-round battle, if necessary. As much was indicated today when he held his next to the last glove performance before a large crowd.

Retailers Making Better Payments. The active dress demand at retail has contributed in no small measure toward, betterment of the payments on merchandise by retailers, credit men reported here yesterday. Payments now were termed satisfactory, and in numerous instances are better than a year ago, it was said.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial clashed yesterday on the Mayor's salary-reduction plan, as its acceptance by 19,000 members of the Police Department, saving $4,587,673 in next year's budget, was forecast.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23. -- As news of consummation of the four-system consolidation plan for the Eastern railroads was being flashed across the country tonight William H. Boyd, an attorney for the Van Sweringens, in a radio address over WTAM called for inclusion of all carriers in such systems.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Results of a poll of Congressional candidates in New York State as to their "wet" and "dry" stands were made public today during the final session of the New York State Conference of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

For the first time since their triumphal march up Fifth Avenue in 1919 upon their return from France, veterans who served with the Seventy-seventh Division during the World War will parade along part of Fifth Avenue this afternoon as a part of their first general reunion since the war.

Mayor Joseph V. McKee came face to face with the city's hospital problems yesterday when he spent three hours on a thoroughgoing inspection of Bellevue Hospital, covering each building from basement to roof.

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Edwin M. Knowles China Company announced today that it owould resume full-time operations at its Newell, W. Va., tunnel kiln pottery within the next ten days and provide jobs for 750 men.

Final awards in the remaining competitive classes for amateur and commercial growers brought to a close the eighteenth annual dahlia and Fall flower show at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. The exhibit had opened under the auspices of the American Dahlia Society on Thursday with more than 1,000 entries in the 200 competitive classes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Can you spare me space for what is meant to be a good-humored and civil argument In support of the re-election of Mr. Hoover, without "calling names" and without challenging the physical or mental ability or the public spirit or sincerity of Mr. Roosevelt?

The policy of aloofness with regard to Governor Roosevelt's Presidential campaign that has been observed so far by Tammany Hall and allied Democratic organizations in this city came to an end yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- Hiram W. Johnson, California's senior Senator and Progressive nominee for Vice President with Theodore Roosevelt in 1912, expressed "appreciation" today for the tribute paid to him yesterday by Governor Roosevelt in his speech at the Senator's old home in Sacramento.

Investigating a report from a friend that there were large blackfish to be had in abundance in the waters off Riverhead, White Cap hastens to announce that the rumors are built upon a solid foundation of fact. Being an old-timer who has fished these and adjacent waters for a long time, White Cap writes that it seems funny that others haven't discovered the facts for themselves in recent weeks.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 23. -- Because of the American Legion's recent demand for payment of the bonus, Admiral William S. Sims, retired, who commanded the American naval forces in European waters during the World War, has resigned from honorary membership in the Legion.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 23. -- The Department of Loreto is ready to put 10,000 armed men in the field to hold the Amazon River port of Leticia, according to a special delegate from Loreto who arrived from Iquitos today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- With an opportunity of adding another tournament victory in two successive weeks, Miss Joan Ridley of England today gained the concluding round of the Bronxville Field Club's invitation tennis tournament after a testing semi-final match.

Thumping long lists of new books come from the publishers in the early Autumn, to set librarians scuttling -- probably for cover -- as they worry over finding shelf-room for all worthy and some unworthy newcomers. Librarians of experience undoubtedly have developed an automatic resistance to the onslaught.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- The sixty-eighth session of the Council of the League of Nations opened today with a decision to pursue a more energetic peacemaking policy in the dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay. This implies a stronger stand for the covenant in the League's conflict with Japan.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Organized to promote interest in libraries and their service, a citizens' library committee composed of leading educators, lawyers, clergymen, editors, authors and representatives of social organizations was announced tonight at the conference of the New York Library Association by Dr. Frank L. Tolman, president.

Jeremiah Sullivan, a bank messenger, was robbed of $3,676 by three armed men in an elevator at 46 West Twenty-third Street yesterday afternoon. Sullivan, carrying a payroll from the Bank of Yorktown branch at Thirty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue, was on his way to the offices of Max Udell Sons, Inc., on the fourth floor of a loft building at the Twenty-third Street address.

With the trading volume again receding slightly, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. United States Government obligations were irregularly lower, while domestic railroad issues turned from the preceding day's declines and moved generally higher.

The model housing project sponsored by August Heckscher for the seven blocks of city-owned land in the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area will perpetuate his name if the plans are carried out, it was learned yesterday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 23 -- New officers and directors of the Waterbury Clock Company were elected this afternoon after the Superior Court this morning had ended the receivership of the company and its subsidiaries, the Ingersoll-Waterbury Company and the Brach Time Company.

First Down. Amherst vs. Colby -- What No practice punts at all? For the first two weeks, at least, a fellow should be allowed two guesses on the outcome of each game. Who has followed secret practice at Colby? Who knows how strong that Amherst line will be for this game? Never mind. Mr. Coolidge went to Amherst. Colby is in Maine and Maine went Democratic.

Dr. Alcan Hirsch, chief consultant to the chemical industries of the Soviet, made public yesterday what he described as the first comprehensive report on the progress of the Soviet Government in the chemical industry.

Following four raids in the last four days on places in the financial district where securities were being sold by high-pressure methods, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. warned the public yesterday to beware of bucket shops and stock racketeering, which he had reason to believe had returned with the rise in the market.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- If there was a greater eleven in the country last year than was Army on the day it rose up in its might against Notre Dame at the Yankee Stadium, then a lot of football critics were afflicted with the grossest sort of astigmatism.
Twelve years of effort to unify the Eastern railroads ended successfully yesterday at a quiet meeting of executives in the Pennsylvania Station.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, meeting at the Westchester Country Club, today gave its approval to the establishment of a central State savings bank as a permanent institution for the protection of savings banks and their depositors against possible emergencies and loss.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Featured by a sixty-yard run by Weiner, Muhlenberg halfback, after intercepting a forward pass in the third period, Coach George Holstrom's Muhlenberg College eleven tonight defeated St. Joseph5s, 27 -- 0, at Muhlenberg Field.

Firovanti O. Miniutti sold to the Williams Holding Company, William J. Mathews, president, the four-story, nineteen-family brick apartment house on a plot 51 by 105 feet at 228-30 Stegman Street, near Jackson Avenue, Jersey City.

A non-Socialist liberal who is out fighting for votes for Norman Thomas and his running mate, James H. Mourer, sat in Mr. Thomas's office at 1st East Nineteenth Street, yesterday and told reporters why he believes every one who is not a conservative should cast his ballot this Fall for the Socialist ticket.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's address before the Commonwealth Club of Ban Francisco today was as follows:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Final recapitulation of the score here tonight in the first half of the team-of-four event of the New Jersey State contract bridge championships showed the team of the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York leading two Deal Club teams for first position.

Fundamental recovery in business appears to have been started definitely, although, last week's trend was more in the direction of a general leveling off after several weeks of gain, according to the weekly reviews of trade and industry. There have been no significant recessions recently.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- With the time limit for reimbursement expiring at noon tomorrow, Louis Gennain-Martin, the Finance Minister, tonight informed a meeting of the Cabinet that the prospects for the French rentes conversion operation were "clearly favorable."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Operators who bought wheat early today on the Board of Trade here under the influence of strength in stocks lifted prices about 3/4 cent a bushel soon after the opening. This put the local market out of line with Winnipeg and induced liberal selling here in spreading with the Canadian market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Gordon Gleason is somewhat sweeping in his statement that the Democratic platform "now turns toward international free trade." Nor can I agree with his conclusions as to the meaning of the Democratic tariff plank.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Sensational riding by Wayne Wright, who brought home the first three winners, including victories in the daily double, featured the program at Lincoln Fields today. All three were long shots.

A bolt of lightning, coming from a sky from which rain had not yet begun to fall, yesterday afternoon struck a wire mesh backstop on the athletic field of a Woodmere (L.I.) private school. Twenty-seven boys were gathered just under the net, receiving the first football instruction of the year.
Prices for cotton declined yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and trading ended with the list 18 to 25 points lower than on Thursday.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- J.H. Thomas, the Dominions Secretary, gave a hint today of the sort of criticism in store for three free trade Liberal Cabinet Ministers in the event they resign from the government next week, as is now regarded as highly probable.

With some of the best cross-country horses in training nominated, the thirty-fourth annual running of the Meadow Brook Cup Steeplechase will be held over the famous timber course on the estate of F. Ambrose Clark in Westbury today, preceded by the third renewal of the Wheatley Hills Cup over the brush course.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- New postage rates on parcel post mail matter will go into effect Oct. 1.

After all these years the bed is back, plumb in the middle of the stage. When the curtain rises on "The Stork Is Dead," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening, one of those lacy sleeping edifices, fresh from the storage warehouse, occupies the most conspicuous position on the stage and reminds us that the theatre is always trying to advance backward.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 23. -- After an all-night session in Bridgeport the race committee of the International Star Class decided this morning to eliminate two of the small sloops from the championship competition concluded yesterday on Long Island Sound off the Pequot Yacht Club.

Answering charges of price-cutting and failure to cooperate in efforts to stabilize the wholesale milk market and thus to prevent a threatened strike of up-State dairy farmers, three accused dealers here yesterday declared they had raised their prices on Sept. 20 as was done by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association.

Frank T. Hulswit, former president of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation, appeared yesterday before the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., to object to the plan of the receivers to effect a reconstruction of the company on the ground that it was unfair to the common stockholders.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 23. -- Among those who gave dinner parties tonight for week-end guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Fritz Chandler at Maplehurst, Mrs. Herbert Shipman at Seaview Terrace, Mrs. William Woodward at the Cloisters, Miss Julia Berwind at the Elms, Mrs. William P. Douglas at Cozy Nook and Commander end Mrs. R. P. Hinrichs at their home on Kay Street.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The women's golf championship of New Jersey was retained by Miss Charlotte Glutting, youthful representative of Baltusrol, in a well-played final at the Echo Lake Country Club today, but only after her subpar golf in the late stages had turned bad the courageous, uphill fight of he opponent.

In the soul of Celeste Bertuzzi there dwells an undying love of music. Under the kings and emperors of another day he would have been a virtuoso, drawing plaintive andantes from a violin or 'cello. Under the present dispensation he is an organ grinder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Several favorable factors in the business situation abroad during the last week were shown in the summary of world economic conditions issued today by Louis Domeratzky, Chief of the Division of Region Information of the Department of Commerce.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Sept. 23 (AP). -- A plea for the people to support the President in a time of depression as they do during a war was made here tonight by Vice President Curtis as he and Representative Maurice H. Thatcher, Senatorial nominee, made their second speeches of the day in opening the Republican campaign in Kentucky.

Alfred J. Talley, as executor and trustee of the Agnes H. Deane estate, has leased the three-story dwelling at 407 West 147th Street to Mrs. Julia Woodroffe. Joseph Hidalgo, broker in the deal, also rented for the Board of Transportation the three-story brownstone dwelling at 19 West Ninetieth Street to Mrs. G.M. Santi.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Surgeon General Hugh S. Gumming, whose 1929 campaign against psittacosis resulted in clamping down a strict parrot import quarantine, today warned that this method could not be expected to check new appearances of "parrot fever."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Opposition to payment of the soldiers' bonus before maturity in 1945 and a cut of at least $400,000,000 in Federal expenditures for veterans' benefits were recommended in a report submitted at today's session of the directorate of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
The price movement in commodities was void of a definite trend yesterday. Grains, cotton and hides sagged, but rubber, silk and eggs continued strong. Other staples were steady.

The committee of steamship owners which has negotiated during the last two weeks with the International Longshoremen's Association for a settlement of a wage-scale contract to become effective on Oct. 1 made another proposal last night, raising its offer to $1.05 an hour for overtime work and maintaining its scale at 75 cents an hour for a forty-four-hour week.

The Theatre Guild has advanced the New York opening data of "The Pure in Heart" from Nov. 7 to Oct. 31. Accordingly, the play's preliminary tour will begin on Oct. 3 in Baltimore, instead of a week later in Pittsburgh, as previously announced. Ruth Chorpenning is a late addition to the company, which is headed by June Walker and Osgood Perkins.

Ever since the American Legion at Portland voted overpoweringly in favor of immediate payment of the adjusted certificates of veterans of the World War, there have been multiplying signs of dislike and resentment within the organization itself. Many resignations have teen reported.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 23 (AP). -- The biggest production schedule since 1923, with a 300 per cent increase in the number of employes since Aug. 1, was announced today by Palmer Brothers Company, manufacturer of bed comforters.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The stock market today reacted from yesterday's activity, with dull conditions following overnight Wall Street news, although a harder tendency developed later in the day. Although less active, British funds continued firm.

Asserting that the oil industry had handled itself comparatively well in the last three years, Harry F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, said yesterday in an interview in Tulsa, Oklai, which was issued also through the company's office here, that a cut in the price of crude oil at this time would be a calamity.

The resignations of George K. Morrow as chairman of the Ward Baking Corporation and the Ward Baking Company, and of his brother, Frederick K. Morrow, as president of both, were announced yesterday. In a letter the former chairman said he was giving up the post to devote himself to his other interests -- as chairman of the board of the Gold Dust Corporation and chairman of the United Cigar Stores Corporation, which is being reorganized.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Bill Tilden was defeated by the French professional, Martin Plaa, in the semi-finals of the world's professional tennis championship tournament on the courts of the Rot-Weiss Club today. He was not eliminated, however, as the four semi-finalists are meeting in double elimination play.
Fortune Gallo will open a San Carlo season of grand opera on Oct. 10 in the New Amsterdam Theatre, giving a two weeks' season at popular prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover's prophecy of the abolition of poverty gives point to the remark of Phelps: "God Almighty never intended a politician to be happy, or tie would have given him at least five minutes' foresight." The essence of our national policy the past decade has been selfishness, which is proverbially short-sighted.

Sacramento gave HIRAM JOHNSON to the world. Governor ROOSEVELT took advantage of the piety of the native place to describe the Senator as "long a warrior in the ranks of true American progress" and to rejoice in one of his characteristic speeches denouncing the Administration without naming Mr. HOOVER.

Slowly but surely Pennsylvania is receiving a part of the unemployment fund it has been vociferously seeking from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The action here termed slow is called reluctant by Governor PINCHOT, who has been doing the vociferating.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23. -- The quotation of the dollar over the Mexican silver peso has undergone a sharp drop of twenty points within the last twenty-four hours and the dollar is now quoted at 3.13 against 3.33 yesterday and 3.80 less than six months ago.

TOKYO, Sept. 23. -- The earth's core is not fluid, as has been assumed, but a rigid body two and a half times harder than steel, according to the thesis that Japanese newspapers say Dr. Akitsune Imamura of the Tokyo Imperial University, noted physicist and seismologist, will advance in a paper to be read at the annual meeting of the Imperial Academy on Oct. 12.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23. -- A field goal by Sullivan, Duquesne University's quarterback, late in the fourth quarter defeated the West Virginia eleven, 3 -- 0, at Forbes Field tonight before a crowd of 35,000.

A crowd of 20,000, the largest ever to see a baseball game at Dexter Park, watched the New York Giants score a pair of runs in the first inning and three more in the sixth to beat the Bushwicks, 5-2, last night under the flood lights. Seventeen men saw action for the major league club.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Quarryman, owned by Mrs. William du Pont of Wilmington, staged a come-back late today to win the blue ribbon and gain a leg on the Venezuelan Trophy in the feature event of the second day of the Wissahickon horse show at Whitemarsh.

The football season at Columbia, which, supporters of the Blue and White are relying upon as the source for considerable cheering this Fall, will get under way today at 3 o'clock when the Lion eleven faces Middlebury College at Baker Field. A gathering of 15,000 is expected to witness the contest, which will be the sixth between the institutions.

A united campaign by more than fifteen organizations concerned with conservation of State parks and forests has been opened against the proposed Forter-Brereton amendment, listed for Fall voting, according to an announcement yesterday from the committee on State forest preserve policy, of which Samuel H. Ordway, president of the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks, is chairman.
BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The stock market continued extremely quiet today and prices were little changed from yesterday's levels. The bond market also was dull.

Thomas Hitchcock Jr. and the veteran Earle W. Hopping, who have figured in some of the most interesting play of the season, round out the high goal polo of the year with the special match at Meadow Broote today when they lead teams against each other.

William Woodward's Pardee, 10 to 1 outsider in the three-horse Bayview Claiming Stakes, feature at Aqueduct yesterday, triumphed by a nose over Cornelius Whitney's Mad Frump, with Charles H. Thieriot's Scout Master last.

Continuance of apartment rental activity was reported yesterday, Summer's end spurring dilatory seekers into a realization that Oct. 1 and the new leasing season are but a few days distant. A shift of interest to the west side of Manhattan was apparent, in contrast to the past several days, when the east side was the centre of attraction.
NEW YORK. Paul May, the Belgian Ambassador, is at the Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Miss Sylvia Rockin, 23, of 75-09 Ninety-seventh Avenue, Ozone Park, L.I., was found dead today in a houseboat anchored in Little River, a tributary of the Potomac.

James C. Stone, chairman of the Federal Farm Board, and John J. Hopkins, special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, will be among the speakers at the annual convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association at Niagara Falls on Oct. 11 to 13, inclusive.

David Herbert Lawrence, whose own book, ''Lady Chatterley'a Lover,'' is considered unprintable and unfit for sale in the United States in its unexpurgated form, was profoundly shocked by the memoirs of Casanova and had a "horror of all Don Juans, all knowing sensualists and conscious libertines," Aldous Huxley writes in the introduction to "The Letters of D.H. Lawrence," published by Viking today.

An advance that was sufficient to cancel Thursday's slow decline occurred on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but without arousing any great amount of enthusiasm. Trading showed a sharp contraction as compared with the day before. The volume was 2,195,000 shares, Which was about 1,500,000 shares Jess than on Thursday.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- Thirty-nine individuals, probably the largest number ever to participate in the division of one team's share of world's series spoils, were named on the list of shares ratified at a meeting of the Yankee players today for submission to Baseball Commissioner K. M. Landis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- A movement for a forty-hour work week to spread employment during the present emergency was started today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States immediately following a conference between President Hoover and Henry I. Harriman of Boston, president of the organization.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- Wide Walter Brown, first-year Yankee moundsman of impressive bulk and equally Impressive September effectiveness, qualified for at least honorable mention among prospective world's series aces today by blanking the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 0, before a ladies' day crowd of 8,500 in the opener of the last Yankee series of the league seaeon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- In identic notes to Bolivia and Paraguay the commission of neutrals has asked them to cease fighting over the Gran Chaco and accept a truce guaranteed by the presence of military representatives of neutral powers. The notes were sent yesterday and made public today.

Vithalbai J. Patel, Indian nationalist leader, who was released from prison in March and exiled from India because of his activities in behalf of Mahatma Gandhi, arrived yesterday to bring the message of India to the people of the United States.

Prominent clergymen will take part in the installation on Sunday evening, Oct. 2, of the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, who comes here from the pastorate of the University Methodist Church, Syracuse, N.Y., to become pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Bucknell opened its 1932 football season by defeating St. Thomas of Scranton, 36 to 0, under the floodlights tonight. Myers, right halfback, starred for the home eleven, scoring all five touchdowns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- New assurances that he would carry New York State in November were carried to President Hoover today by William N. Calder, former Senator from New York, and Federal Judge John Knight of the Western New York district.

It being generally accepted by the outstanding savants of the game that baseball, like all Gaul, is divided into three parts -- the defense, offense and general strategy-it seems logical enough to assume this basis to be as practical as any for comparing the relative merits of the Yankees and the Cubs.

A total of $173,327.29 of the proceeds from the Moose charity balls of 1930 and 1931, which the prosecution charges were lotteries, was traced into bank accounts controlled by Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania at his trial before Judge Frank J. Coleman and a jury in Federal court yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- While her fattier waited outside for her to finish, Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Dall made a speech today to 1,400 women at a tea in the Palm Room of the Palace Hotel.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Winchell Smith, the playwright, today advertised for Bale at auction Tuesday, the historic grist-mill between this town and tlnionville, which he bought and remodeled in World War days for the production of old-fashioned, stone-ground flour.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- At the wool auction today offerings of fine merinos and greasy crossbreds met a brisk sale at full current rates Some medium merinos were bought in, due to high limits. The good selection of South Americans offered sold freely to the home trade and Garmany at 10 to 20 per cent above prices to the last series.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- In calling upon North Arlington Borough to ray its debt of $11.981, Walter R. Darby. State Commissioner of Municipal Accounts, revealed today that more than $60.000 is due his department for audits and special services performed for various municipalities.

A petition to Mayor McKee requesting him to ask Dr. Charles Norris to reconsider his resignation as chief medical examiner "in the interests of his office and the public" was sent yesterday to the Mayor by the executive committee of the Medical Alliance, Inc., of 335 East Eighteenth Street, an organization of 400 physicians resident in New York City.

POONA, India, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Disquieting news that Mahatma Gandhi had taken a sharp turn for the worse came from Yerovda jail tonight after the Nationalist leader had gone for eighty-two hours without food in protest against the electoral system devised for the Indian Legislatures by the British Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The Shipping Board approved today an agreement between the Kokusai Kisen Kaisha and the McCormick Steamship Company covering shipments from Kokusai's Far East loading ports to United States Atlantic ports, with transshipment at Los Angeles Harbor, San Francisco or Seattle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- A five-point program for remedial action by business interests and the United States Government to remove foreign exchange restrictions upon American trade was recommended today by the foreign commerce department committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- In number and tonnage of merchant ships, the United States is second only to Great Britain, but in new vessels constructed over a period of four and a half years, the United States Is ranked by six maritime powers. Merchantmen flying the American flag bow only to Britannia, however, in speed and size.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 23. -- Following several days of anxious uncertainty, Asuncion spent a gleeful holiday today celebrating the recapture of Fort Falcon or Rojas Silva, which the Bolivians took from Paraguay on Sept. 6.

The Western Maryland Railroad reported yesterday an increase of nearly $10,000 in net income for August despite decreased gross revenue for the month, but other railroads did not show similar results. The Lehigh Valley reported an operating deficit of $108,716 in August and the Southern Pacific reported a net operating income of $504,548 for August, compared with $2,574,769 in August, 1931.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 23. -- The argument that Paraguay has already demonstrated herself the aggressor in the Chaco dispute has been placed before the commission of neutrals in Washington by Enrique Finot, the Bolivian delegate to the recent peace talks, it was revealed here today.

Among those who will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa are the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia, C.F. Kettering, vice president of General Motors Corporation, and Robert G. Stewart, president of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- For the first time in many months the Federal Reserve Board's summary of the business situation issued today showed an improvement in conditions.

New financing by States and municipalities scheduled for next week amounts to $17,502,413, of which about half will consist of two large city bond offerings and one State flotation. In all, fifty-one communities have advertised for bids on new issues.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The match play path of a tournament medalist is hard, Johnny Dawson learned today. After scoring a 67 this morning to cut six strokes from the course record he established yesterday in winning the medal, he met a tartar in Herbert Parker, Spring Brook Club player.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Head Coach Mal Stevens today selected two Yale elevens for an intensive drill in forward passing and a defense for it. More than an hour's work in this mode of play featured the morning and afternoon practice sessions, which lasted about five hours.

SAMUSHIRO, Japan, Saturday, Sept. 24 (AP). -- A good-will plane sponsored by the newspaper Hochi Shimbun took off this morning for Nome, Alaska, en route to San Francisco. The take-off was at 5:35 A.M. (4:35 P.M. Friday, New York Day-light Time).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Sept. 16 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 2,636,530 running bales, including 51,930 round bales, counted as half bales and 325 bales of American-Egyptian.
ATHENS, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP). -- A mine guard was seriously wounded today by snipers near the No. 267 mine of the Ohio Collieries Company, near Crooksville.

Sixty-three years after the men of Rutgers and Princeton played the first game of intercollegiate football, the new season opens this afternoon with games in the hundreds listed throughout the collegiate world and with the number of games running into the thousands when schools are included.

Quiet strength in the securities markets yesterday indicated that the recent speculative excitement was at an end for the time being. There was a slow advance on the Stock Exchange, in both stocks and bonds. Price movements in commodities were mixed, wheat and cotton showing losses while other staples were strong or steady.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP). -- With rookies in both line-ups, the Indians and Chicago staged a wild afternoon, in which the Tribe emerged victor by a score of 13 to 6 today.

A new era in the football history of Manhattan College will be opened today when the Jasper eleven, in its first start under the coaching regime of John F. (Chick) Meehan, encounters St. Bonaventure College of Olean, N.Y., on Manhattan Field. A capacity crowd of 6,000 is expected to turn out for the contest.

A protest against further examination of Warren E. Wheeler, secretary of Jordahl Co., formerly the American Kreuger Toll Company, was made yesterday by Loring M. Black, counsel for Mr. Wheeler, at a hearing in the Kreuger Toll bankruptcy case before Federal Referee Henry K. Davis.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech at the Civic Auditorium tonight was as foliates:

Declaring that he wanted to examine witnesses in order to "disclose assets not shown in the schedules which would benefit the estate to the extent of several millions of dollars," Mortimer Hays, representing several landlords, characterized the bankruptcy of the United Cigar Stores Company of America as "fraudulent" at a bankruptcy hearing yesterday before Referee Irwin Kurtz in the Wool-worth Building.

Quiet strength in the securities markets yesterday indicated that the recent speculative excitement was at an end for the time being. There was a slow advance on the Stock Exchange, in both stocks and bonds. Price movements in commodities were mixed, wheat and cotton showing losses while other staples were strong or steady.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- More than sixty communities in twenty-four States will receive cotton cloth made from the 500,000 bales of Farm Board cotton voted by Congress for distribution through the American Red Cross for clothing for the needy.

THE dream book has taken a long step forward into Intelligent society now that it can call itself "scientific" and derive its material from the books of some of the most noted psychologists of our time. The publisher's blurb gives this information concerning the authorship of this new venture in popularizing the scientific explanation of dreams: The name of the author carried on its title page, they say, "cloaks the identity of two collaborating author

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 24. -- The Prince of Wales resumed his old role of "the empire's best salesman" when he opened the great British trade exhibition here today. A hundred thousand Danes cheered him on his way to the ceremony, which symbolized Great Britain's determination to push her trade into new markets outside the empire.

Agreement among wholesale dealers in the move to stabilize the milk market and assure producers better returns brought comparative peace to the situation here yesterday, although one dealer issued a tirade against the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association and reports from up-State told of continued rebellion among the dairy farmers.

OF the three hundred copies that were made of this ambitious work, one hundred were offered to the members of the First Edition Club of London and only 180 for general sale. The volume, which is in format a little more than half the page size of THE TIMES Book Review, was carefully designed, with 111 illustrations reproduced in collotype.

FUGUE" is without doubt, one of the most beautifully written novels of this decade. Its English has the luminosity we find in Hardy, the authorized version of David's Psalms and D.H. Lawrence at his most serene; a packed luminosity that combines a clearness as of running water with richness of meaning and satisfying allusion.

HERE are two books dealing with a phenomenon in newspaper life that was practically unknown ten years ago, the column of the scandalmonger. Both Mr. Gauvreau and Mr. James are newspaper men -- the first, indeed, an editor, under whose direction this type of news gossip found its inception.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Miss Frances Carlene Haines Waitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Weymer H. Waitt of Ardsley-on-Hudson, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at the Ardsley Racquet and Swimming Club.

CHORAL music may be on the a verge of a renaissance in this country. In America, of late years, emphasis has been placed particularly upon instrumental and orchestral developments. Certain musicians and educators, it is true, have done noble work in strengthening choral traditions and improving technical and interpretative standards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Recommendations that railroads virtually be released from the strict regulations now surrounding them and be permitted to compete on equal terms with other carriers are contained in a report by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States made public here today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, their son, Atwater Kent Jr., and several other guests, who arrived from Bar Harbor on the Whileaway Friday night, entertained several Newport friends at luncheon on board today.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Babe Ruth hit his first home run since coming back to work and Charley Devens, former Harvard star, began his major league pitching career with an 8-to-2 victory by way of providing 7,000 Boston fans with something to remember for the local baseball season's final Saturday afternoon.

A revision of the transportation act to enable the railroads to reduce their debts and to build in good times reserves for bad times is recommended in a report on railroads submitted to the United States Chamber of Commerce. Asserting that changing conditions "point to the probability that the railroad plant will not be extended as in the past," the report cites a need for "reducing bonded indebtedness with the maturity of each issue."
FORLORN ISLAND, in the Bering Sea, inhabited by sixty Aleuts and visited by ships from the outside world, is the setting for Edison Marshall's latest story of adventure and love.

DUBLIN. THE Ireland of the future, toward which he is piloting a nation that is today the most belated and the most ambitious in Europe, was outlined by Eamon de Valera a few days ago in an interview which took place in the office where he, as President of the Executive Council, charts his course and that of the Free State.

SUCH a book as this account of the last Duke of Osuna enables plain Americans to understand a little better why the Spanish revolution was so long in happening, because it sets forth so starkly the potency of the weight that held the people down.

The application by Banking Superintendent Broderick for permission to turn over the assets of the closed labor bank, the Federation Bank and Trust Company, at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, to the reorganization committee for reopening, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Shientag.

PRESTO, change! Yes, it has been like that a magic transformation that has completely metamorphosed a section of the Long Island shore from straggling and crude little villages devoted to offshore whaling to Summer resorts and country estates that are the last word in luxury, smartness, modernity.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Tammany Hall's uncertainty toward Governor Roosevelt and Maine's Democratic sweep have had their bearing on the nation's opinion, but they stand no better chance of altering history than does the possibility of a break in the stonewall republicanism of rural Western New York, centring on former United States Senator James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo, who is running for Congress in the Thirty-ninth district.

A new set of colored maps showing Governor Roosevelt carrying every part of the country except New England and Kansas appeared yesterday at Democratic headquarters at the Biltmore. The maps, it was said, were based on all the polls received.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Cornell's football team, led by Captain Bart Viviano, who scored three touchdowns and place-kicked a point after touchdown, overwhelmed the University of Buffalo on Schoellkopf Field today, 72 to 0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A new and excellent book on Woodrow Wilson by Professor William E. Dodd has just appeared. Its concluding sentence contains the phrase that after leaving the Capitol on the morning of Harding's inauguration Mr. Wilson "limped away" to retirement.

WE who dwell by the dark river have to face the fact that "to every man upon this earth death cometh soon or late." However ingenious may be those physicians who, like Horatius at the bridge, defend the tottering span of life, they are only able, here and there, to reduce infant mortality and assist the aged by adding a year or two to the allotted three score and ten.

BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Two American balloons, one of which will be piloted by Ward T. Van Orman, thrice winner of the James Gordon Bennett Trophy, will start from Basle tomorrow in the 1932 edition of the world's best-known balloon contest.

VIENNA, Sept. 23. -- While efforts to reorganize the economic life of the lesser States of Central Europe and the Balkans are drawing to a close at Stresa, under the supervision of the great powers, in the capitals of the countries concerned the political skies are overcast by events in the larger nations, particularly in Germany.

BEFORE considering "Rip Tide" one should give heed to the explanatory subtitle insisted upon by the author, for if such heed be given at the outset misunderstandings, and consequent recriminations, are less likely to occur.

WHEN radio played its first rampant part in the 1924 political campaign there were predictions that the days of the traveling candidate were nearing an end. A new era was in sight. The candidate, whether it be for the Presidency, Governorship or Congress, could save time and expense by facing a mute microphone in a comfortable studio and talk to the electorate.

PARIS, Sept. 9. WITH the month of September the theatres are coming to life again, though slowly. Most of those which are reopening are doing so with revivals of successes of last season, but there are one or two new plays promised for various dates during the month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Speaker Garner, Democratic candidate for Vice President, hailed the campaign which Governor Roosevelt is making in the West today as an effective appeal which the Republicans have failed to answer.

IN the long record of major crimes in New York, comparatively few stand out as classics of their kind, for their mystery, the manner in "Which they were committed, the prominence of their participants or the certain something that focuses the attention of the nation on a case.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Detroit and St. Louis split a pair of extrainning games today, the Browns winning the nightcap, 5 to 4, in eleven innings, after the Tigers had won the opener, 1 to 0, in ten. St. Louis made three runs and Detroit two in the eleventh inning of the second game.

Owners of buildings in this city who put the management of their properties in inexperienced hands have turned to scientific methods in building management after paying the price of disorganized service, decreased rental values and other evils resulting from haphazard handling of their holdings, according to D. Donald Lent, operating engineer of the Loring M. Hewen Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- News today was more encouraging to holders of wheat. In addition to the buying by local professional traders and commission houses, bulls on the Board of Trade here had assistance from the East, and prices at the top showed about 1 7/8 cents above yesterday's finish.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Representatives of the stable of Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester, N.Y., through a series of spirited performances, carried off the major honors today in the nineteenth annual Greenwich horse show, held under the most delightful auspices on the grounds of the Greenwich Polo Club.
The Italian bid for a high position in the merchant marine of the world will reach its zenith on Tuesday when the super-liner Rex slips out of the harbor of Genoa for her maiden run to New York.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Grant and the Misses Kathrin and Carolin Grant have returned from Bar Harbor to 330 Park Avenue.

ALFRED, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- A promising Alfred University football team opened its season tonight with a 6 -- 0 victory over Defiance University. Henning scored in the middle of the third period after three plays brought Alfred from midfield.

THE American Spectator -- a Literary Newspaper, to be edited by George Jean Nathan, Ernest Boyd, Theodore Dreiser, James Branch Cabell and Eugene O'Neill, has announced the contributors to its first issue, which will appear on the stands Oct. 20.

Representatives of local banks and trust companies, members of the American Bankers Association, will leave this city on Wednesday for Los Angeles, Cal., to attend the annual conference of the association, which will be opened there on Oct. 3. About 2,000 bankers, drawn from all sections of the country, are expected to be in attendance when the convention begins its task of considering the problems confronting banking and the policies best suited for meeting them.

An analysis of orders received from a large number of representative stores throughout the country shows a far greater increase in consumer buying than was expected, resulting in an extremely strong demand for immediate delivery merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Officers and directors of the New York Plant and Flower Guild will hold a harvest day celebration Wednesday afternoon at the children's gardens maintained by the organization at Sixty-fifth Street and York Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Unemployment relief is becoming an increasingly serious problem. No one knows that it will not become chronic, as it has been in England on a large scale for twelve years. There are certain aspects of it which seem to me of vital importance, but which, because of their difficulties, those responsible for raising and distributing the funds seem most reluctant to face squarely.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- A sweeping Federal Investigation into the $2,000,000,000 crash of the Insull utilities organization will be launched on Monday morning, with every resource of the government thrown behind the inquiry, it was announced ioday by United States Attorney Dwight H. Green.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Despite Jimmy Foxx's fifty-seventh home run of the season, hit with the bases filled, the Athletics lost their last home game of the season to the Washington Senators today, 8 to 7, in ten innings.

Senator BORAH recently complained that he and other ardent champions of national prohibition have this year been "neatly disfranchised." This means, of course, that he considers both parties to have gone definitely Wet. He reaches this conclusion on the basis of the two platforms and the utterances of the two candidates in their speeches of acceptance.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Princeton University will begin its 186th academic year on Tuesday with two of its important offices occupied by temporary heads. Both the presidency of the university and the chairmanship of the board of athletic control will be filled by temporary executives.
The text of Controller Charles W. Berry's address on city economy before the Civil Service Forum at the Town Hall last night follows:
PARIS, CHANEL'S new corduroy suits are one more sign of the chic reconciliation between town and country clothes effected by the Paris couturiers this season.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Miss Jane Bancroft's chestnut mare, Likely Lady, was adjudged the champion of the three-gaited saddle-horse class in the feature event of the final session of the Springfield Horse Show in the Coliseum at the Eastern States Exposition tonight.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 24. -- The history and legend of Long Island will be retold and revaluated at the annual convention of the New York State Historical Society, which will meet here on Oct. 6 to 8, for their first convention in Long Island. Residents of the eastern end of the island are planning to take about 500 delegates expected at the convention on tours to historic sites.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Playing superb golf, Eddie Driggs of Cherry Valley, former Long Island champion, eliminated T. Suftern Tailer Jr., a clubmate and present metropolitan, amateur champion, by 2 and 1 in the quarter-final round of the annual invitation tournament it the Nassau Country Club today.

ALLENTOWN, N.J., Sept. 24. -- With the discovery that between $20,000 and $30,000 in cash was missing from the vault of the First National Bank of Allentown, a police alarm was broadcast today for the bank's teller, Morgan N. Buckalew, 47 years old, who received a fortnight's vacation yesterday so that the bank officials could check his books.

ALAN for cooperation between secondary schools and institutions of higher learning, submitted this year to all the accredited colleges and universities of the United States for the purpose of a broad experiment in secondary school education, has won a prompt and favorable response.

ROME, Sept. 23. -- Within the next few days it may be decided whether Italy will continue to be a member of the League of Nations. The Fascist Grand Council in its last session in April voiced disappointment at the failure of Geneva to solve all the major problems submitted, and resolved to consider at its next meeting which is scheduled for early in October the problem of Italy's resignation from the League.

Two motorcycle policemen with drawn pistols rescued three young Negroes from a mob in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn last night after a battered sedan, driven by one of the Negroes, had knocked down a 49-year-old man at Sutter and Christopher Avenues.

BOMBAY, Sept. 24. -- Leaders of the "untouchables" and caste Hindus today signed a historic agreement settling their political differences and foreshadowing a speedy abandonment of Mahatma Gandhi's "fast unto the death."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 24. -- University of Tennessee's football team opened its 1932 season today with a 13-0 victory over University of Chattanooga's Moccasins, the Chattanooga team holding the score down with a rugged defense. Tennessee showed a strong offensive.

PRIMED as it is with mathematics and sometimes involved in its mode of expression, Professor Hogben's book is stiff reading. On the other hand, it is by far the most authoritative and judicial consideration of the social implications of genetics and eugenics that has appeared in English.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 24. -- In two traffic accidents which occurred tonight within a few minutes of each other, Henry Dearborn Jr. of 280 Park Avenue, New York City, was killed and Medill McCormick, son of Mrs. Ruth Hanna McCormick Simms of Albuquerque, N. M., suffered a broken right leg.

Sir ALFRED EWING, president of the British Association for the Advancement of Science and late Vice Chancellor of the University of Edinburgh, after reviewing at length in his presidential address the "capacities and powers" which the cornucopia of the engineer has shaken over the earth, concluded his survey by saying that "man was ethically unprepared for such bounty."

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- An August rise of nearly 10 points in the New England Council's index of New England business activity is noted by the council. This is the largest upward movement between any two months in the history of the index, which now stands at about the same level as March.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 24. -- Though Governor Han Fu-chu of Shantung appears to be succeeding slowly in his campaign against Liu Chen-nien, it seems probable that Governor Han will lose the political and financial fruits of victory, as Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's naval craft, besides landing marines at Chefoo, have also seized Tengchow, an important revenue centre of Northern Shantung.

Production of motor cars in the United States and Canada will be shown to have been larger in September than in August for the first time in seven years, and contrary to the seasonal trend, according to Frazier Jelke Co. Their survey indicates for this month an output of 95,000 cars, against 89,850 last month.

AFTER eleven years of teaching in a girls' high school and a concurrent decade of marriage. Olga Calvius still loved her work and her husband, notwithstanding her frequent threats to give up teaching and the fact that Leopold was becoming more pedantic and less romantic.

LONDON, Sept. 10, 1932. AFTER months of vague reports and contradictory rumors one solid fact has emerged: London has given birth to a new orchestra. The new organization, however, does not rise, as was generally expected, from the ashes of the London Symphony Orchestra.
Editor, The New York Times Book Review: Hollister Noble's review of Basil Lubbock's "Bully Hayes, South Sea Pirate," was read by me on a little island called Norfolk Island, down toward the South.

LONDON, Sept. 10. I HAVE asked myself again, and again whether Jeffrey Dell, who has adapted "Firebird" from the Hungarian of Lajos Zilahy, has made any structural alteration on the original, for few pieces have more actively provoked my curiosity.

The food industry, which in 1929 accounted for 25 per cent of the nation's volume of business, has since increased in importance steadily and now accounts for 30 per cent of the annual total, it is computed. This increase has occurred in spite of heavy reductions in food prices.

I AM entirely in accord with Dr. Kilmer that the ideal way would be to require annually such physical examination. There are more than 2,500,000 drivers registered in this State and with a return of business activities to normal this figure will undoubtedly be increased by at least 300,000.

GENERAL PEYTON C. MARCH was Chief of Staff at the height of America's greatest war effort. When he returned from France in March, 1918, to take charge at the War Department the allied cause was at the depth of desperation.

THE most frequently misused and abused adjective in the English language is probably "charming," Book reviewers, more enthusiastic than judicious, are too often guilty of misapplying the word. Yet it has a place; and its place seems here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reader, from this small room, who digested your editorial on "Autumn," felt warmed, afterward. No new coat of gay colors, warm suits and shoes, nor hat of henna, could have given the satisfaction this "Autumn" did.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22. -- Gulf Coast fishermen have discovered that in union there is even more strength than they had imagined. With the farmers' strike of the Middle West as a model, the shrimp fishermen decided upon a similar strike to win what they called a fair profit from their labor.
LONDON, Sept. 23. -- All this week the British Government has been watching with unconcealed interest but much skepticism the drama being enacted behind the walls of Yerovda jail in India.

THIS novel of the transformation of Southern mountain people from farmers, hunters and moonshiners into millhands is one more milestone on the road to the return of "social consciousness" in American fiction. It is the sort of propaganda novel to which no sneer can be legitimately attached -- which is to say that its meaning rises out of people in dramatic conflict with other people and with the conditions of their life.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 24. -- A 2-year-old girl was drowned this afternoon when an automobile her mother was learning to drive developed a flat tire and plunged into the Ouimet Canal near the Lido Beach Country Club. The mother, Mrs. Lillian Grady, 38 years old, of 323 Beach Eighty-eighth Street, Hammels, Queens, and three other members of her family who were in the car were saved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- A suggestion that the United States might well afford, from a purely dollar-and-cents standpoint, to cancel the war debts owed by European countries, is made in a report on "The Interallied Debt; an Analysis," which is to be published by the Foreign Policy Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Sept. 17 increased, following the Labor Day holiday week, but, on a daily average basis, were lower than during the preceding week, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

LOUISE R. PEATTIE introduced herself last year with the publication of "Pan's Pariah" as a delightful spinner of the gossamer webs of fantasy. Having steeped herself in the memories of gods and men immanent everywhere in the historic stones of Provence, she told a tale full of the strange fragrance of that land, delicate as the work or James Stephens, and sometimes richer for its earthiness.

A year ago there was published an unpretentious but appealing little book called "Max, the Story of a Little Black Bear." When Max was a month old his mother was killed and he was adopted as a pet by the family of a mining engineer in the Rocky Mountains.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 24 (AP). -- An interlocutory injunction enjoining Kansas officials from enforcing gas rate reductions and beginning receivership proceedings against ten Cities Service subsidiaries was allowed here today by a three-judge Federal Court.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24. -- The Kremlin has decided upon a strong forward policy regarding the Soviet food difficulties. Two decrees published today mark the abandonment of the "Rightward swing" inaugurated by the measure adopted early in the Summer.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Edward J.A. Rook's sprightly chestnut gelding, King's Secret, captured a blue and a yellow in two jumping classes at the horse show conducted by the Saxon Woods Hunt Club on the club grounds today. Five events constituted the program.

FOR the first time in twenty-five centuries of suffering, there is heard today the articulate cry of the picturesque but tragically situated people who are known to the world at large as the Untouchables. At the door of civilization, hitherto closed to him by age-long custom, the forgotten man of India stands and knocks, demanding an immediate admission as a citizen in what, from time immemorial, has been his own country.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- Despite the exigencies of the electoral campaign which, it had been predicted, would prevent the United States taking an active part in European affairs, evidence has been accumulating in recent weeks that the State Department is showing the keenest interest in what is going on in the rest of the world.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, guided by the batons of Arturo Toscanini, Bruno Walter and Issay Dobrowen, the latter a young Russian musician, will be heard this season in a series of forty-two Sunday afternoon broadcasts over WABC's network beginning Oct. 9.

Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial, speaking as a city official as well as president of the Civil Service Forum, deliverad another attack on Mayor McKee's salary reduction plan yesterday in which he charged that the Mayor was "woefully ignorant" of the law governing pensions and retirement systems and labelled the members of the Citizens Budget Commission "representatives of invisible government."

THOUGH every one travels these days, there are still plenty of remote spots which few would reach without the aid of the films and the travel writers. Wyndham Lewis, with a penetrating eye, a nose for plots, a philosophizing tendency and a good stock of courage, has saved his readers the trouble of a trip through Morocco.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Making it a front race almost from the moment A.C. Bostwick dropped the flag and sent the nine starters away, T.W. Durants 6-year-old chestnut gelding Fugitive, well ridden by Randolph Duffey, took the thirty-fourth running of the historic Meadow Brook Cup over the three and a half miles of timber and stone walls of the course on the estate of F. Ambrose Clark here today.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 24. -- The threat of a third party hung over Democratic and Republican parties in New Mexico today as Senator Cutting completed a series of dramatic gestures with an announcement that his organization would file a third State ticket.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- A veteran Providence eleven was outrushed by Rutgers in the opening game of the season before a crowd of 6,000 persons today, but the Scarlet could not gain at crucial moments, and the final result was a 6 -- 6 deadlock.

THE Mizner family was a large and lively one and therefore Addison Mizner needed the whole of this ample volume in which to tell about their activities and peccadillos from their childhood in Benicia, Cal., until within recent years.

A newly formed theatrical organization, the Little Theatre Operating Company, has taken a year's lease on the Little Theatre in West Forty-fourth Street, with occupancy to start immediately. Although the new group will not enter the producing field, the house will be available for bookings, the first of which has been scheduled for late next month.

Max Schmeling, German fighter, who until a few months ago held the world's heavyweight title, launches his campaign to regain the crown tomorrow night against a man who would block his path to a return battle against Jack Sharkey, the champion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published an article, "Objections Voiced to Machinery Plan," in which it is noted that the plan of A.W. Robertson, chairman of the National Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation, has been criticized for prolonging the life of the inefficient units of industry and also as impracticable of financing.

THE novel that Sinclair Lewis planned to write about the labor question in America, only to sidetrack it for "Anne Vickers." has perhaps, been done by Sherwood Anderson in "Beyond Desire." Possibly Lewis gave up the idea of his novel because he found it beyond his powers; certainly the collective theme did not lend itself to individual portraiture, upon which Lewis has grown great.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 24. -- T.V. Soong, the Finance Minister and Acting President of the Executive Council, announced today that China immediately would begin collecting import and export duties on all goods to or from Manchuria. This will seriously disrupt much Far Eastern trade, as a great deal of tonnage for Manchuria is landed at Shanghai for transshipment.

THE ROXY is now playing host to "A Successful Calamity," the latest motion-picture venture with George Arliss. He was born George Augustus Andrews in London. The date was April 10, 1868. The father of young George was a printer and publisher, who was known to his neighbors for some miles around as "Duke of Bloomsbury."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The old jest as to mountains in labor bringing forth a puny mouse might well sum up what Geneva in the Swiss mountains offers to the world as a result of many months' mouthings in the Disarmament Conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Upon reading "Found on a Tombstone" in THE TIMES, it occurred to me that the writer of that letter, T. T. Maxey, might be interested in knowing something regarding that stone.

Archaeological discoveries of foremost importance in the field of medieval Spanish painting were made by Dr. Walter W.S. Cook, Professor of the History of Spanish Art at New York University, who returned to this country last week after spending two years in Spain as a research fellow of the College Art Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Doris V. Boice of Frinceton won the Rose Tree challenge trophy on the final day of the Wissahickon Horse Show at Whitemarsh today when her team of hunters defeated the entries of Mrs. R.L. Benson, also of Princeton.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22. -- The La Follette colors are wilting in Wisconsin politics. In the primary last Tuesday this strongly progressive, even radical, State turned to a more conservative philosophy. Two years ago Philip F. La Follette was nominated and elected in the depression.

Thomas Hitchcock's Escapade, described by several horsemen before the running of the Harbor Hill Steeplechase as the best 3-year-old jumper of the season, set a new track record yesterday at Aqueduct.

PARK BENCHES and bread lines of the great city are apt to be thought the most pitiable haunts of the unemployed. But through farm homes from one end of the country to the other is spread another army of the jobless, vocationally and educationally far more friendless, according to the Southern Woman's Educational Alliance.

After its three weeks' advance THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index has reacted slightly to 54.2 for the week ended Sept. 17 from 54.5 for the preceding week; in the corresponding week last year it declined sharply to 68.7 from 70.0. The principal cause of the decline was a sharp recession in the adjusted index of electric-power production from what appears to have been an abnormal peak registered in the week ended Sept. 10.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Several dinner and supper parties will be given tomorrow night at the Hotel Gramatan prior to a soiree of "music and the dance" for the benefit of the Westchester County committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer.
THE San Carlo Grand Opera Company will open a fortnight of opera at the New Amsterdam Theatre on Oct. 10.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24. -- Los Angeles, stronghold of Republicanism, turned out today to give a real Southern Californian welcome to Governor Roosevelt.

HOW a poor man and his wife lived, worked and played in England in the time of the Plantagenet kings is not easy to discover without much research. From novelists who laid their stories in the period, from the poems of Chaucer and from museums where relics are preserved one can get a vague notion of the life of the times, but it must be at best fragmentary and inaccurate.

IN his lightest manner, amusingly and with many touches of satire, E.F. Benson writes of Durham Square, its inhabitants and those who in one way or another are concerned with them. Although Durham Square is in London, it is one of those little communities whose small feuds and teapot tempests he describes so well.

A MONTH or so ago the editor of of Architecture (published monthly by Scribner's) wrote to about 1,100 manufacturers connected with the building industry, "asking them to tell us, in fifty words or so, of any new product or method or service first made available, or to be made available, in the calendar year 1932."

THE author of "The Good Earth." for as such her name has gone around the world, is establishing her fame in two distinct yet closely related ways. Mrs. Buck has proved herself a novelist of uncommon ability and a no less able interpreter of one people to another.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- Winston Churchill's statement to the Havas Agency yesterday that "although partially disarmed, Germany, in my opinion, is still the strongest power in Europe," was immediately taken up today by the entire Right press, which is inclined to agree with him.

A SEMI-DIESEL motor using fuel oil and said to be adaptable for use in motor vehicles as well as airplanes and boats was demonstrated recently at 607 West Forty-third Street by Captain Frederick A. Pippig, its inventor.

Social service nursing, in which Mayor McKee expressed special interest during his inspection tour of Bellevue Hospital last Friday, faces a severe curtailment in its work if the Mayor's plan for a 20 per cent budget reduction in the Hospitals Department goes through, it was learned yesterday.

NEW YORK is now to see whether primary school education of the "progressive" type usually undertaken only in expensive private schools can be given at a cost near what the city pays per pupil in a tax-supported system using the older methods.

WHILE trade held up to a fair level for the week, warm weather caused some further recession from the volume which was done earlier in the nonth. This was true of the local stores, and reports from other secions of the country indicated that the recent spurt had slackened.
