THERE are many automobile operators holding licenses to drive a car who are physically unfit to drive with safety to themselves or others upon the public highway. I know this to be so, because I have seen them in my work as a police surgeon.

Any compromise that brings to an end GANDHI'S hunger-strike against the British Government's scheme of separate electorates for the Untouchables may truly be termed a happy solution. It is certainly for the best interests of the Indian peoples that the great Hindu constituency should not develop new group cleavages in a country afflicted with too many factions and separatist interests.

In substitution for several individually operated plans, the Pacific Lighting Corporation and its five associated companies have undertaken a uniform plan of pension and benefit for its employes with the Metropolitan Insurance Company as underwriter and director of the program.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 24 (AP). -- A long pass and a 28-yard sprint across the goal line near the end of the game gave South Carolina a 7-to-3 victory over Sewanee today after the heavy Gamecock team had hammered unsuccessfully at its lighter opponent until that time.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Williams opened its football season with a victory over Rochester today, 6 to 0. The only touchdown of the game came in the first few minutes of play. A forward pass, Miller to Brown, brought the pigskin to the visitors' two-yard line, from which point Markoski carried it over.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Sept. 24 -- Governor Roosevelt was cheered tonight by 80,000 to 90,000 persons gathered at the Olympic Stadium to see the "motion picture electrical parade and sport pageant" to raise a fund for the Marion Davies Foundation for Crippled Children.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 24. -- Dartmouth's football squad, five teams strong, ran up a near-record score of 73-0 over Norwich University in the opening game of the season today. The big green fell a single touchdown short of the record gained two years ago.

"Can a person be a composer without knowing how to write music?" This is the question that is agitating music and legal circles in Yugoslavia these days. It appears that a gypsy orchestra leader named Misha Kurtovitch has brought suit against a Belgrade music publisher, a phonograph record company and a number of orchestras for royalties he alleges due him as composer of "The Little Red Fez," the most popular folksong now extant in Yugoslavia.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Syracuse University's sophomore team found its hands full in defeating a stubborn Clarkson team, 13 -- 6, tonight. The game, attended by a crowd of 10,000, was played in a continual heavy downpour of rain which handicapped both teams considerably.

Friends of President Hoover have taken exception to Governor Roosevelt's charge that he is satisfied with the present State supervision of electric-power utilities and is opposed to Federal regulation.

BERLIN. TO judge the present-day novel by the frenzied love stories and sensational tales of some of our youthful writers would be unfair. We have other authors, serious students of the most difficult social problems.

THESE first October days will witness the beginning of actual production on the Fox film version of Noel Coward's "Cavalcade." The film has been subjected to a preparation period unusual in the normally hurried precincts of the Hollywood studios.

MUSIC, the poets "heavenly maid," thinks of changing her evening gown for a blue gingham dress and studying to become a nurse. The career of an entertainer is well enough, but "Isn't there more that I can do?" she asks, looking around at a troubled world.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 12. -- Residents in the Belgian Congo tell a story about the visit of the Prince of Wales to the pigmy country. Anxious to study the habits of these little folk, the Prince asked the local Governor to arrange matters. By some mysterious agency the pigmies learned that something special was wanted for that particular Prince, so their prices soared accordingly.

DRIVING a Pierce-Arrow 12-cylinder roadster, Ab Jenkins last Monday sped 2,710 miles around a circular course in 24 hours, averaging 112,91 miles an hour, considered a new record for sustained high speed, it ia reported. The run, made on the salt tied at Salduro, Utah, was sponsored and the record authenticated by the Salt Lake Chamber of Commerce, company officials said.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Thomas Hitchcock Jr. led a Sands Point team to victory over Eastcott in the final high-goal event of the Meadow Brook Club polo season today. Hitchcock hit and rode in brilliant form at No. 2, playing the major role in the building of 14 goals for his side which held Eastcott to 9.

The jazz bands of Harlem are constantly bringing new ideas into music, but the creators of the ideas have not yet learned how to develop thoroughly what they create, George Gershwin, who came out of Broadway into critical esteem in music with his now world-known "Rhapsody in Blue," said yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Four robbers who paid their way tonight into the Huntington Theatre and then attempted to loot the safe in the manager's office shot their way to freedom when they were surprised at the safe.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Tracy H. Lewis of the New York A.C. won the sixth annual trapshooting championship of Long Island over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the title from a field of eighty-three gunners by breaking 99 out of a possible 100 targets.

Stricter regulation is at hand for the public utility industry regardless of the outcome of the national election in November, in the opinion of utility leaders, who view the statements of the principal Presidential candidates as reflecting a strong tide of public opinion aroused by the Insull and other sensational failures.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Sept. 24. -- An army reserve officer and his mechanic escaped serious injury here today when the Curtiss Falcon biplane in which they were flying turned over on its back in landing. The plane was damaged considerably.

Having won their party spurs two years ago by rolling up a vote of more than 190,000 for their candidate for Governor, the extreme drys who in 1930 formed the Law Presservation group will exercise their party prerogatives this year for the first time in a Gubernatorial election by holding a State convention and nominating candidates for State offices.

Asserting that business establishments should begin at once to shape operating budgets for 1933, Dr. T. H. Brown, professor of business statistics at the graduate school of business administration, Harvard University, told THE TIMES yesterday that business problems likely to be encountered in the coming year make a carefully constructed budget of more than common value.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 22. -- Both parties claim Rhode Island for November, but the Democrats have the edge today. They are sanguine, but not overconfident, shrewdly apprehensive of the skill and strength of the Republican organization which long has dominated the State and more harmonious than in years before.

Indictments charging coercion were returned yesterday by the grand jury in Brooklyn against Max Ginsberg and Robert Weiner because of their activities as solicitors for memberships in the City Pharmaceutical Association of 105 Court Street, Brooklyn, which has been under investigation by District Attorney Geoghan for several weeks.

Columbia University will begin its 179th academic year on Wednesday with about the same number of students as last year, when the total enrolment was 35,866 resident students and 10,045 non-resident students, it was said yesterday by Edward J. Grant, registrar of the university.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA. Inc. EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 23. -- After struggling 150 miles on frozen feet through an Arctic blizzard, after cutting three of his toes off with a razor by the flickering light of a blubber lamp, after having been caught with no food, in the Arctic night, miles out at sea on shifting ice-floes -- Napoleon ("Nap") Verville, 32-year-old Edmontonian, is back in this city.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 22. -- An example of legislative generosity under the guise of economy can be found in Indiana, where the General Assembly has voted more money to local governmental units for road and street purposes than ever before.

The third anniversary of the beginning of the present depression was marked last week by a stronger tone in the financial markets than had been noticeable at this season of the year since 1928. Wall Street dates the depression from Sept. 19, 1929, when stock averages reached their historic high points.

NOT long after they dug New York out from under the great blizzard of 1888 the turf followers of those days went out to see the first running of the Futurity and witnessed what the railbirds considered an astonishing upset. Salvator -- the magnificent Salvator -- was beaten a head in the stretch drive by Proctor Knott.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The shortage in meat resulted today in a government edict under which supplies will be collected from the whole peasantry under a system operated in the same manner as taxation. For the next fifteen months every peasant family most deliver to the government at fixed prices a certain percentage of the meat produced.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- By the margin of ninety-five points and five hits, Carl Thompson of Pinehurst, N.C., today led Donald MacKenzie, Greenwich, Conn., defending champion, in the race for the men's championship after the first round of the annual Metropolitan Archery Association tourney on the Scarsdale High School Athletic Field.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- For the second consecutive week Miss Joan Ridley of England emerged victorious in tourney play when she defeated Miss Norma Taubele of New York, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, in the final round of the Bronxville Field Club's invitation tennis tournament today.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The marriage of Miss Florence Conant Harriman, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles C. Harriman of 105 State Street, Albany, and Diamond Point, N.Y., to Jean B. Thorner of Zurich, Switzerland, son of Frau Thorner Suchs of Zurich, took place this afternoon at St. John's Community Church, Diamond Point, Lake George.

FOLLOWING the example of New York, Antwerp is solving one of its traffic problems by the construction of two tunnels under the Scheldt -- or the river Escaut, to give it its French name. Work has been under way since March, 1931, and is due to be completed some time next year.

Sarkis Katchadourian's facsimile "reconstructions" of Persian frescoes, exhibited last Spring at the Musee Guimet in Paris, have been brought to America by the American Institute of Persian Art and Archaeology, and will be shown for the first time in this Country in an exhibition opening Oct. 12 at the Museum of Modern Art.

The Giants defeated the Phillies in both ends of the double-header at the Polo-Grounds yesterday. The double triumph, combined with the Dodgers' victory, clinched third place for Brooklyn and enabled the Giants to tie the Cardinals for sixth place.

Housing property deals, which have provided the bulk of real estate trading during the past week, were foremost on yesterday's list of new transactions. The demand for well-located residential buildings has been emphasized all week long by the largest volume of apartment rentals announced in some time.

Rising cloth and clothing prices, continued "quality" propaganda and prospects of better consumer response during the Fall have resulted in a general trading-up movement on a minor scale among men's clothing stores throughout the country, according to opinions expressed in retail circles here yesterday.

The text of Controller Berry's speech appears on Page 36. Mayor McKee's plan for a voluntary reduction in the salaries of the city's 147,000 civil service employes as part of a widespread economy program was assailed last night by Controller Charles W. Berry, who declared that such reductions should be made only as a last resort.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Hatless and panting from the exertion of a half-block sprint after the motor car carrying Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mayor John C. Porter offered the Democratic Presidential nominee a belated welcome today after first refusing to greet him because he "is a wet and I am a dry."

ONE of the nation's oldest institutions -- the United States Coast Guard -- has just opened the new buildings of its academy on a forty-acre site overlooking the Thames River at New London, Conn., a port closely linked to the sea.

IN last week's Paramount offering, "The Night of June 13," the producers have made something that is refreshingly different and for the most part quite an intelligently conceived drama. It deals with the selfishness of a group of residents of a New York suburb, called Glenwood Park, in giving false testimony at a murder trial merely to cover up incidents in which they had taken part on the memorable June 13.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech at Los Angeles today was as follows:

MADRID, Sept. 23. -- The time has passed when events in Spain could be watched as dramatic but scarcely important in the world scale. There are gentlemen with grimly fixed ideas at the helm here now and they are driving Spain along a stern path toward a fixed goal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Mrs. V. M. Duncan's Little America raced to a popular victory today at Lincoln Fields in the Elmhurst Purse at seven furlongs. Cleverly rated by Jockey M. Calvert, the 4-year-old daughter of High Cloud -- Donna Barton raced to the front soon after the barrier was released and had one length and a quarter advantage over Colonel E.R. Bradley's Broad Meadows at the finish.

THIS book is complete in itself." says Mr. Holbrook Jackson, "but I like to think of it as a part of its predecessor. "The Anatomy of Bibliomania." It is, in fact, a natural and indeed necessary corollary to Mr. Jackson's monumental synthesis and triumphal garland of the love of books in all its forms and expressions.

The election of officers of the American Chemical Society for 1932-1933 by professional divisions was announced yesterday by Dr. L.V. Redman, president of the organization and vice president and director of research of the Bakelite Corporation, Bloomfield, N.J.

MANILA, Aug. 20. -- An amendment to the Jones law, the organic act, or quasi-constitution, of the Philippines will be asked at the current session of the Philippine Legislature to enable the islands to institute sufficiently high tariffs to stop dumping from Russia and Japan.
Following a reaction of almost a half cent a pound from the high levels of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed with net advances of 11 to 14 points.

ALLEN H. EATON, of the staff of the Russell Sage Foundation. Department of Surveys and Exhibits, says in his preface that there is no danger that we cannot Americanize our immigrants, but that there is very real danger that we may overlook and lose some of the much-needed contributions to the enriching or our national life and culture which they are able to make.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 17 amounted to 587,302 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 85,478 cars more than in the preceding week, 155,312 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 365,259 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

SINCE satire and melodrama are the forms most characteristic of the current American theatre, the good showman puts them together, as Bella and Samuel Spewack, authors, and Herman Shumlin, director, have done in "Clear All Wires!" In discussing these centrifugal cartoons it is advisable to regard the director as one of the collaborators.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Fast-running Colgate backs and a deceptive offense that baffled the opposing forwards gave Colgate a 41-to-0 victory over St. Lawrence in the opening game of the season today.

The appointment of Canon PATRICE FLYNN, Cure of the Church of the Madeleine, a Paris-born Irishman, as Bishop of Nevers takes one back to the chapter in Mr. T.R. GLOVER'S "Greek Byways" on "The Wandering Greek." The Corinthians "used to say of the Athenians "that they were born neither to rest "themselves nor to let anybody else "rest."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Frederick William Wile, Washington correspondent for The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, will be the featured speaker at the dinner of the annual newspaper institute of the New Jersey Press Association at Rutgers University, Oct. 10.

WHEIST the Yiddish theatre of the city called a halt to last season quite early in Spring, it seemed that the inevitable doom which has been predicted for some time was about to overtake it. But inevitable catastrophes have a way of holding off, and the beginning of the new theatrical year finds Second Avenue and its affiliates displaying all the outward signs of activity of the millennial days ten years ago.

BERLIN. THE German National Socialist party has recently issued, in form of a pamphlet for the guidance of its speakers, an outline of the economic program it proposes for Germany. It is particularly interesting because, as the depression has advanced, there have come repeated appeals from various quarters for some form of inflation or for other experiments with the currency.

THE ONLY RULING QUEEN. THE Netherlands is such a neat, well-ordered country that both "Dutch Communists" and "Dutch Fascists" sound like contradictions in terms. Yet last Tuesday, when Queen Wilhelmina rode through the streets of The Hague to open Parliament, there were uplifted palms of Fascists and the clenched, raised fists of Communists.

The Arcadia Knitting Mills, Inc., describing itself as the largest manufacturer of knitted rayon cloth in the country, filed suit for $20,000,000 in the Supreme Court yesterday against the Viscose Company, called the largest manufacturer of rayon yarn in America, on the ground that its business will be ruined because of an alleged breach by the Viscose Company of an agreement to furnish it all the yarn it required in its business.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24. -- The Soviet oil trust signed a contract today with Kojiro Matsukata of Japan to deliver 200,000 tons of oil to the Matsukata interests in Japan.

Reduction of the Fire Prevention Bureau's 100 inspectors and the 450 inspectors in the Tenement House Department is expected through a plan made public yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Manhattan building superintendent, who will tell Mayor Joseph V. McKee this week how overlapping and duplication can be eliminated in the three departments maintaining inspection services.

AN END OF OUR ROPE. By SILAS M. STRAWN, Former President United States Chamber of Commerce, addressing the National Municipal League in Washington. TAXES must be reduced, because, to use a hackneyed phrase, we have reached the end of our financial rope. The people generally are rapidly coming to a realization that the cost of our governmental functions has reached a stage where it is impossible to raise sufficient revenue to meet it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Managers of sixteen Regional Agricultural Credit Corporation offices met today with Ford Hovey, in charge of agricultural activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and received the regulations which will govern loans of that character.

Watson Clark registered his twentieth victory of the season as the Brooklyn Dodgers clinched third place in the National League baseball race by defeating the Boston Braves 3-2, yesterday before 4,000 at Ebbets' Field.

OF the eight conductors who will appear as guest directors of the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra, the ensemble of 200 unemployed players which will give twenty concerts at the Metropolitan beginning Nov. 1, five will make their only New York appearances of the season with this orchestra.

THE Graf Zeppelin completed her tenth transatlantic crossing of the Summer last week carrying passengers and mail from Rio de Janeiro to Friedrichshafen, and the fact attracted no more attention than the sailing or the arrival of a coastwise freighter in New York Harbor.

An oval-backed upholstered chair, once owned by George III, is included in a quantity of fine furniture and decorative art objects covering a wide range of periods, which appears in the first catalogue of the season issued by the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The general downward trend of the preceding week was for the most part reversed in the local commodity markets last week. Cocoa and sugar continued to move lower, but coffee maintained its upward trend and was rejoined by rubber, hides, silk, silver and wool tops.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The most important event of the four-day New Jersey contract bridge championships, the team - of - four match, was won today by the team headed by George Reith of the Knickerbocker Whist Club, New York. Mr. Reith and his partners romped through the series of hands and won the championship from the two expert teams of the Deal Club of Elberon, N.J.
Playing for the first time under a new coach, a new system and the new football rules, Manhattan's inaugural bow as a future gridiron power was tempered somewhat with disappointment yesterday.

PROBABLY all things do come to those who wait. At all events we have waited, and it has come: the long-desired catalogue of the water-color paintings, pastels and drawings in the permanent collections of the Brooklyn Museum.

JOPLIN, Mo. THE hill-billy of the Ozarks is going in for education, and beans and "'taters" are paying the bill. That mountainous region of Southern Missouri and Northern Arkansas bearing the legendary Indian name "Ozarks," where for so many years progressiveness has been conspicuously absent, can no longer be said to lack educational opportunity.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Frederick Perry, second ranking tennis player of Great Britain, won the singles championship of the Pacific Southwest tournament today by scoring a scintillating straight-set victory over Jiro Satoh, Japan, who had beaten two of the world's best players to reach the final.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22. -- Taxes thrust themselves into the consciousness of this community in a rather exceptional way with the 8-cent reduction in the city and county tax rate adopted by the Board of Supervisors as a result of savings effected under the new charter.

VIENNA. SINCE wherever one moves in European dance circles there are reverberations from the choreographic contest held in Paris in July by the International Archives of the Dance, it is has seemed emminently desirable to see so many of the winning compositions as possible, even at the cost of traveling pretty generally back and forth across Central Europe to do so.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: I should like to take exception to various statements made by the reviewer of E.F. Benson's book on Charlotte Bronte which are obviously unfounded and a denial of very evident truths.

Henry Siegel sold to the Charle Holding Corporation the three-story frame flat with store at 389 Central Av., assessed at $29,000, and the two-story frame dwelling on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 10 Charles St., Jersey City, assessed at $6,500.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- The League of Nations thirteenth ordinary Assembly opens in the Electoral Hall here Monday. It means the League is thirteen years old. That age, which some think is unlucky, finds the League in the most dangerous situation it has yet known.
The men of the Seventy-seventh marched up Fifth Avenue again yesterday.

IF hardly a week passes without some reference to the cosmic rays in this department it is because of the activity of European and American physicists in studying them and because they stand out as the great mystery of science.

PEIPING, Aug. 24. -- Because the Nanking Government a few months ago awarded a large contract for new Chinese postage stamps to an engraving concern in Europe, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing here was threatened with the necessity of dismissing its 2,000 employes.

TOKYO, Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Government already has granted de facto recognition to Manchukuo by accepting her consuls, it was stated by Japanese officials commenting upon reports that such recognition was to be accorded. De jure recognition from Russia, which remains aloof from the comity of nations, they added, was less important than from the other powers.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 24. -- The Amherst football team opened its season today by defeating Colby, 13 to 6. The victors' new Warner offense failed to click in the first half when the play of both teams was marred by repeated fumbles.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24. -- The Holy Cross eleven came through the hardest fought opening game in the history of the college today, defeating New River State College by 13 to 6.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24.-- Captain Berlinski's 75-yard run through a broken field in the third quarter gave Bloomfield high a 6-to-0 victory over St. Peter's Prep of Jersey City in the opening game of the scholastic season today.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- The stock market today displayed the same dulness that has characterized it for several days. The governmental decree reducing interest rates will not be given out in full until Monday. In consequence there were numerous and varied conjectures toward the end of the session.

BERLIN. -- Language, like civilization, is progressive. It never stays put. Constantly it is expanding, taking in new words made necessary by scientific invention; adopting former outcasts because they are needed to fit modern conditions and adapting existing words to new uses.

WALDO FRANK in his foreword to this story of love, lust and revenge south of the Rio Grande, calls Mariano Azuela "one of the most eminent novelists of contemporary Mexico." Azuela is a doctor by profession and a revolutionist by conviction.

Bequests to charity totaling approximately $40,000 were canceled from the will of Morris Lurie, chain store owner and merchant, when a codicil to the testament was filed with the petition for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- President Hoover conferred today on details having to do with his opening campaign speech to be delivered at Des Moines Oct. 4.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, predicted in a speech here today that the women of the United States would mobilize at the polls in November to defeat President Hoover.

Following the example of shipbuilders in protesting against the government policy of awarding contracts for the construction and repair of ships to navy yards, the New York and New Jersey Dry Dock Association has filed a statement with the Shannon Congressional committee, which is investigating the field of government competition with private business.

Knocked down by an automobile at Metropolitan Avenue and Leonard Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, Abraham Yellowitz, 13 years old, of 685 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn, was picked up by the driver, carried five miles to a vacant lot in Astoria, Queens, and dumped out, unconscious.

At a special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on Thursday, drastic reductions of Federal, State and city expenses will be urged. The meeting was called in response to a petition of members. It will be the first special session devoted exclusively to the discussion of business that the chamber has held in several years.

The Broadway clean-up, which begun with the closing of two burlesque shows on Forty-second Street by order of Mayor McKee, and resuited in the demolition of spectacular displays on the fronts of theatres reminiscent of the old Bowery days at Coney Island, continued yesterday with the announcement by the Broadway Association that it would do all in its power to have the laws enforced against offenders.

THE Paris imports are in New York.They are as exciting as it was expected they would be. The drama of the Winter's fashions is represented in a story that fluctuates as easily as stock market quotations. It has its highs and its lows.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 20. -- Elections have been called for Oct. 30 and 31 to fill the term of President that was made vacant by the disqualification of President-elect Neptali Bonifaz by Congress because of alleged Peruvian citizenship when the Constitution provides that only native-born Ecuadoreans may fill the office of Chief Executive.

The Folk Festival Council announced yesterday a Folk Festival ball -- with every one present joining in the dancing -- to be given on the evening of Oct. 29 in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. Forty ethnic groups belong to the council, of which Dr. John H. Finley is chairman and Thomas L. Cotton vice chairman.

GREAT BRITAIN established a commission recently to frown upon lotteries. Hardly had Sir Sidney Rowlatt taken office as chairman when he received an earnest letter from an American inquiring how to get a ticket in the Irish Hospitals Sweepstake.

DR. WALTER DAMROSCH has some new ideas about educational broadcasting based on four years' experience at the microphone. He intends to try them out this season in his music-appreciation lectures formulated specially for schools.

ONE does not easily put this book down without reading it all through, nor afterward escape from the deep and haunting impressions it leaves upon the mind. A good many hooks have been written from inside insane asylums, or from memories of them, or knowledge about them.

The view that "American policy in the Far East has been a series of fits and starts followed by retreats," is expressed by Tyler Dennett, former historical adviser in the Department of State and now Professor of International Relations at Princeton University, in an article on "America's Far Eastern Diplomacy" in the October Current History.

As the third quarter of the year moves into its final week, managers of general-management investment trusts are confident that, barring some wholly unexpected market catastrophe, their showing will be better than for any quarter since the first in 1930.

HAILAR, Manchuria, Aug. 18. -- Out here the world depression is being felt as much, perhaps, as anywhere. But every one, at least, has a job. So severely are some of the Mongol Princes being pinched by low markets that they have found it necessary this year, for the first time, to borrow money to pay taxes.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 23. -- The Samsun-Sivas railway, entirely owned and built by the Turkish Government, has just been completed and soon will be opened to traffic. Completion of this line, the most important for both economic and military purposes, is a further step toward realization of the government's plans to link by rail or road the whole of Turkey.

HARTFORD, Sept. 22. -- The old-fashioned town meeting, with modern voting machines instead of paper ballots in many places, and no longer offering a test of prohibition sentiment by the question whether a town should be "license" or "no license" for the ensuing year, is still a lusty ancient in Connecticut, and on the first Monday of October, 129 of the 169 towns will elect their Selectmen and other officials.

The prospect of selection of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman as Democratic candidate for Governor was held yesterday by local leaders to have been enhanced by the abandonment of Tammany aloofness from the campaign of Governor Roosevelt for President.

WHILE some elements of the situation remain uncertain, evidence has been accumulating recently of a fundamental change in Russian foreign policy and in the international position of the Soviet Government. Developments indicate that Soviet Russia is abandoning the so-called Rapallo policy -- that is, her pro-German orientation -- in favor of a rapprochement with France and Poland.

IN the Metro film version of "Payment Deferred," which is now being prepared for the cameras, Charles Laughton will repeat the murderer role which first brought him to the attention of the American public. The cast which has been brought together for the picture includes Maureen O'Sullivan, Neil Hamilton, Verree Teasdale and Dorothy Peterson.

SEVERAL interrogations are prevalent just now, and of these one of the most piquantly mocking is "Whither?" Art, to be sure, is always standing on the door-step ready to step out into a new day; but where the path may lead, no man can with certainty declare.

Federal agents and the police have been making a search for Joseph Bloom of 275 Central Park West, proprietor of a restaurant at 151 West Fortieth Street, who on Sept. 7 was reported to the police of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station as missing, it was disclosed last night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24. -- With the opening of the new academic year at Harvard, returning students find completed the last major construction in the Harvard House Plan, the new "C" Entry of Adams House on the former site of Russell Hall at Plympton and Bow Streets.

AS the curtain rises on another season, drama fills the air. The radio sketch is now riding the crest of popularity, with the mystery drama in the ascendency. Sax Rohmer, the creator of the sinister Dr. Fu Manchu, has arrived in this country to attend final rehearsals and witness the premiere of his satanic Oriental sketches before the WABC microphones.
Right Candidates in Wrong Years. If only there were some Einsteinian device by which Time could be remodeled so that a man might be elected President in 1928 by voting for him in 1932!

Demobilization. It happened in Rome. The armies that the Senate had sent against the Barbarian returned victorious to plunder their own land. It always happens -- the conquering hero return's with his bayonet fixed and his eyes on the treasury.

NEEDLECRARFT," declares the editor of this beautifully made quarto volume, "is coming back into its own." In this belief that there is "in every part of the country a revival of interest in decorative stitchery as well as in the more practical forms of sewing," this work has been prepared to deal with every branch of needlecraft in a practical way and to demonstrate the best methods.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 24. -- Flashing a strong aerial attack, Drexel Institute's football team gained a 13-13 deadlock with Lehigh's sturdy eleven in Taylor Stadium today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Amos Alonzo Stagg's forty-first squad of Chicago Maroons today gave him a point for every year of his service on the Midway, as they opened their season with a 41-to-0 victory over Monmouth, College.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- Preliminary unofficial estimates of the tourist trade in France this year show the expected heavy decrease, not only from the peak years up to 1929 but even from last year, which was considered bad enough.

AFTER all, and despite a midweek report to the contrary. "Humpty Dumpty" had a big fall in Pittsburgh, week before last. The musical show is now in process of extensive revision, and it appears that Jack Haley and Jack Whiting have been summoned to be the new head men.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 24. -- The University of Kentucky opened its season today by defeating Virginia Military Institute, 23 to 0, in a Southern Conference game.

A BIOGRAPHER of oceans is Stanley Rogers. Some years ago he decided that it would be an interesting job to write the life story of each one of them. So he began with the Atlantic and found the work so interesting that after he had finished he went right on to do the story of the Pacific.

HAILAR, Manchuria, Aug. 17. -- Propagandists for the new State of Manchukuo are active in these Mongolian highlands. For one thing, they have been distributing widely among the Mongols lithographed postcards bearing the likeness of Henry Pu Yi, Manchukuo's Chief Executive.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Republican leaders "realize they are defeated on the facts, so they are trying to win with fables," James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, said tonight in a radio address. He added:

THE "mad musician" is Beethoven; but Mr. Schauffler hastens to inform us that the title is ironic. The people of Vienna began to call him so about 1815. Mr. Schauffler assures us that he was saner than those contemporaries.

CENTRES of interest other than the fireplace are emphasized in recently decorated interiors. In apartment-house homes many rooms lack a hearth and mantel to provide a dignified focal point, end the ingenuity of the architect or decorator is called upon to create a new one.
AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Cooper Union proved unable to cope with the Massachusetts State football machine, which ran up a 50-to-0 score on Alumni Field today. Louis Bush tallied five touchdowns.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- From all parts of the country the building and loan industry has received reports of better collections on loans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- More than $9,000,000 was authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today in loans for emergency relief work, bringing the total loans for that purpose so far up to $33,002,239.

A FIRST example of the absorption, for administrative purposes, of Italian national conservatories by the Dopolavoro, or State Recreational Movement, is seen at Trieste in the fusion of the Conservatorio Giuseppe Verdi with the Conservatorio Giuseppe Tartini in a new institute to be known as the Ateneo Musicale Triestino.

Candidates for seven vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in the First and Second Judicial Districts will be picked at judicial conventions to be held on Thursday. Advance indications have been that, with one exception in each district, there will be no endorsement by either of the two major parties of the candidates nominated by the other.

VIENNA, Sept. 24. -- The splendid sarcophagus of King Charles X of France and those of five Princes and Princesses of his Bourbon line have been shipped by rail from the Schoenbrunn Palace in Vienna to the Franciscan monastery at Castagnevizza, Italy, where they lay before the war and to which they are being restored.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The Newark Bears, winners of the International League championship, await the first game of the little world's series here on Tuesday when they will meet the Minneapolis Millers, title winners of the American Association, at Ruppert's Stadium.

TURIN, Aug. 30, 1932. A MODERN experiment in the revival of the ancient tradition of the mystery play is now being carried out at the Sanctuary of Oropa, near Biella (Italy) in the suggestive background of the pine grove which, from the 3,550-foot summit of the hill above this town, dominates the plain of the Po from Turin to Novara and commands a wide view of the Alps of the Monte Rosa region.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- On the evening of his second day in Geneva, Baron von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, called on Arthur Henderson and paid his respects to the president of the disarmament conference, whom he had still been studiously avoiding at noon.

Champion drivers of the scooter, the pushmobile and the velocipede, representing nine New York City playgrounds and ranging in age from 3 to 11 years, monopolized the spotlight yesterday afternoon in Central Park, when for the first time the historic Mall and band plaza were thrown open for a "play day" by the Bureau of Recreation, Department of Parks.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- The Quaker City's big annual poker game has started. The first deals have been made in a card tournament which, will decide what the 1933 tax rate is to be. That long suffering kibitzer, the taxpayer, is watching each play, wondering whether he can control himself any better than he did last year, when he finally jumped in and broke up the game.

LONDON. As far as the mass of people are concerned, declares The News - Chronicle editorially, poetry is a dying art. We have a great number of accomplished writers of verse, a few of whom may justly be called poets, but as a body our poets fail to touch the public.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 9. -- Hungary, one of the many Central European countries which allows begging by license, has just adopted a new scheme to circumvent unlicensed mendicants.
Middlebury's brave little band of warriors came down from Vermont yesterday to be grist for Columbia's 1932 football mill.

HAVANA, Sept. 22. -- It is becoming increasingly evident that Cuba must make a deep cut in the $51,700,000 budget for 1932-33. Dr. Orestes Ferrara, Provisional Secretary of the Treasury, has stated that a reduction of 10 per cent will be necessary, but brands as untrue the report that President Machado intends recommending a 25 per cent slash in a message to Congress.

PARIS. IT is hard to think of more than 80,000,000,000 francs of gold as anything but an arithmetical figure with as much validity as the 3,000-odd light-years of distance between us and the Milky Way. That much money to the average wage earner is not only incomprehensible but unreal -- a mere convention used by international bankers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Butler presents a very interesting proposal to those who advocate, upon the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, an effective control over the manufacture and sale of liquor.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23. -- This week witnessed a wholesale reorganization of Soviet higher education following the reform a month ago of the primary and secondary school system.

Duck hunters throughout the country are very much interested in a bill which will come before the next Congress and which if enacted will tax each duck hunter $1 for a license. At Baltimore last week during the convention of International Game and Fish Commissioners a resolution was adopted unanimously favoring the bill, providing certain changes were made in it.

Over and above the echoes of the anvil chorus banging on the alleged pusillanimity of the League of Nations there is sounding in a good many ears in this country the question as to what the United States has done that is any better.

SOME 5,000,000 automobiles in this country lie unused during the first three months of every year because their owners can't afford to pay the registration fee on top of Christmas expenses and "Winter bills. Shift the registration date from Jan. 1 to a less onerous time, say April 1 or July 1, and these 5,000,000 cars will go back on the road for twelve solid months of motoring.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent complains in THE TIMES of loss of sleep because of noises in Noroton, Conn. I do wish he or she would come to Maine. We mourn the loss of the bird companions we used to have in the metropolitan district.

With Roosevelt sentiment apparently rampant in normally Republican territory in the West, the Eastern wing of the Republican National Committee is preparing to make this State, New England, Pennsylvania and New Jersey a hotly contested battleground in their fight to re-elect President Hoover.

A NOTABLE contribution to the Scott centennial is Willam C. Van Antwerp's "A Collector's Comment on his First Editions of the Works of Sir Walter Scott," just published by Gelber, Lilienthal, Inc., of San Francisco.

LEWES, Del., Sept. 24. -- The Continental, a 100-ton marine derrick belonging to the Philadelphia Derrick and Salvage Corporation, equipped with modern salvage devices, will join tomorrow in the daily dawn-to-dark search for the British sloop-of-war Debraak, which sank off Cape Henlopen on May 31, 1798, with $10,000,000 in Spanish gold reported on board.

DETROIT, Sept. 22. -- This city's financial entanglement, which a few days ago seemed almost too complicated for unravelment, seems to be on the point of loosening up so that the strings may be unsnarled.

Evidences of the conservative manner in which the railroads have been adjusting their expenditures to the needs of traffic appear in a statement issued by the American Railway Association, reporting that the carriers had placed in service in the first eight months of the year only thirty-five new locomotives, compared with 103 in the same period last year.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- The stock markets ended the week cheerfully. British funds were firm but quiet. The war loans received support. Prospects of an early labor agreement in the cotton industry led to buying of textiles and firmness prevailed in rayons.

THE last three and a half years have been momentous in world affairs. All around the globe a spirit of unrest has been making itself felt. Revolutions have wiped out existing governments, nations in both hemispheres have taken up arms against one another, and financial strains have caused the machinery of many countries to creak.

THE local aviation world is wondering what Mayor McKee is going to do with Floyd Bennett Field. Since the tragic death of Colonel Peter J. Brady, who had been appointed deputy commissioner of docks in charge of the airport, the place has been vacant Major J. Nelson Kelly has been and still is the director of the airport and its activities.
ATHENS, Sept. 24. -- The Greek Government has taken special military and police measures to preserve order at the general elections tomorrow.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Sept. 24. -- Dark Secret, from the Wheatley Stables, won the $20,000 added Potomac Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth, the feature race today, outclassing a flashy field of 3-year-olds. W.R. Coe's Osculator was second and Gallant Sir, a Westerner, was third.

For the first time in four long years New York will be able to take more than a passive interest in a world's series, for when organized baseball's greatest show unfolds itself Wednesday in the twenty-ninth renewal of these annual clashes between the pennant winners of the present two major circuits, the Yankee Stadium will provide the setting.

Except for a flurry in the railway shares in response to the announcement that an agreement had been reached on the Eastern trunk-line consolidation plan, yesterday's trading on the Stock Exchange was of a routine Saturday character. The total volume was 1,336,000 shares, compared with 724,500 on the previous Saturday.

BASLE, Sept. 23. -- The three-legged program for the return of England and other nations to the gold standard is being studied, in World Bank circles with a view to discussing at least two of the points at the world conference, with the other one -- debt settlement -- probably to be handled through diplomatic channels in Washington.

VANCOUVER, Sept. 22. -- The Provinces of Western Canada are giving a lead to the rest of the Dominion in disposing of party government. The movement, which began on the Prairie two years ago, coincident with the heavy loss incurred in backing the finances of the wheat pool, has now extended to British Columbia.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The German Government is about to launch an ambitious and almost fantastic scheme for the physical training of German youth -- a pet hobby of the Field-Marshal President and an ideal cherished with equal fervor by patriots generally as an indispensable offset to a vanished compulsory military service.

SYDNEY, Aug. 22. -- The untamed Northern Territory, home of roving blacks, alligators, sugar cane and fever, will form the seventh State of Australia if the plans of Archdale Parkhill, Commonwealth Minister of the Interior, meet Cabinet approval here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES printed extracts from the report of Technocracy, a group of industrial engineers with which Columbia University is cooperating. It gives the installed horsepower of the United States as one thousand million, to direct which fewer than one million men are required as against ten thousand million men that would have been needed "under any previous industrial system."

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The clearest exposition of Germany's grievance against the Geneva Disarmament Conference and the frankest statement to date of her intentions as to the future is contained in a new article written by General Kurt von Schleicher, German Minister of Defense, for the weekly Heimatsdienst.

IT is seldom that questions of foreign policy decide a national election in any country, least of all in the United States. Inevitably, however, these questions are bound to attract a certain amount of attention in the present campaign. Some of the most burning issues in American politics during the last twelve years have been over international questions, such as the League of Nations, the World Court, naval parity and the intergovernmental debts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Criticizing the Commerce Department's "international balance of payments for 1931" as suppressing or distorting facts in the interests of political expediency, Ray O. Hall, former Assistant Chief of the Finance Division of the department, in a letter to Secretary Chapin demanded today that the publication be withdrawn from circulation.

THE collectors or Wagner are complaining about being neglected. Not since the third H. M.V. album of "Siegfried" excerpts, imported in the Spring and only Just released in London, have they had any occasion for excitement -- or so they claim.

On the 143d anniversary of the establishment of the postal service, President HOOVER will tomorrow lay the cornerstone of the new Postoffice Department Building in Washington. It will in time join the magnificent group of new Federal structures in and about the "triangle" south of Pennsylvania Avenue which will stand as a lasting memorial to the planners and builders of this generation.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Sept. 24. -- A protest against violent attacks in Japanese newspapers in Manchuria on the Mukden and Dairen branches of the National City Bank of New York for obtaining "important" Manchurian photographs was made to the Japanese authorities today by the United States Consul General, Merl S. Myers.

INSURANCE against illness and unemployment and other phases of the attempt to gain security included under the general term of social insurance have inspired so much discussion and legislative experiment that such a dispassionate, judicial and comprehensive presentation of the scheme as this book affords should be welcomed by every one who is interested in it or wants to inform himself about its purposes and methods.

Damage estimated at from $150,000 to $200,000 resulted early yesterday from a fire at the car barns and repair shops of the Interborough elevated lines in the block bounded by Lexington and Third Avenues and Ninety-eighth and Ninety-ninth Streets. Six elevated cars were destroyed but no one was injured.
LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Leaders in the British Government lost no time today in considering the Hindu settlement.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 24. -- John Dawson of Chicago tonight possessed a qualifying medal, a course record and one leg on the Arcola Cup, which has been in competition.since 1916, to show for his efforts in the Arcola Club's invitation golf tournament.

Brig. Gen. Pelham D. Glassford, superintendent of the Washington police, said here yesterday that he had heard numerous reports of another "bonus march" on Washington in December, but that he was not worried about the prospect.

It would be highly unusual if our women's golf championship left the country so soon after the men's, but there is grave danger that a foreign entrant will carry off the women's title at the Salem Country Club, Peabody, Mass., this week, just as C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville of Canada won the Havemeyer Cup at Baltimore a week ago by defeating Johnny Goodman of Omaha in the final round of the national amateur.

IN this tale of a Broadway musical comedy production one notes the sure touch of a writer thoroughly at home with his theme. Mr. Ropes shows his familiarity not merely with the well-known types of the musical comedy stage, from producers, directors and stars down to choristers and showgirls, but with the less publicized professionals of vaudeville circuits.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Results of a poll of some of the leading advocates of unemployment insurance and old-age pensions, made public here today by Mayor Daniel W. Hoan of Milwaukee, chairman of the Socialist national campaign committee, indicate their dissatisfaction with the Democratic national plank on the subject.

Stimulated by activity and strength in railroad obligations, the general trend of prices for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was higher yesterday. Trading was at a greater rate than on the preceding Saturday and also based on the two hours of activity, than on the preceding day.

RUNNING, as it does, to very nearly 900 pages, this collection of the letters of the late D.H. Lawrence seems formidable indeed. Lawrence was an indefatigable correspondent and these letters, taken as a whole, have in them more that is likely to interest the casual reader than have most collections of epistles from literary pens.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 24 (AP). -- A bad storm was reported on the Bering Sea late today in the path of the Japanese good-will plane, bound for Nome, Alaska. Rain and wind were reported from St. Paul Island, off the Alaska mainland, and from the freighter Northland, east of St. Lawrence Island.

MOSCOW, Sept 14 (Associated Press by Mail). -- Soviet Russia is preparing for the opening in a few weeks of one of the longest airplane passenger lines in the world and at the same time is speeding plans for its first regular airship service.

Because of the present financial difficulties of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, it was thought in railroad circles yesterday that the Baltimore Ohio would be the first of the trunk lines to profit by the agreement for consolidation in the pact which was reached on Friday by the New York Central, the Pennsylvania, the Baltimore Ohio and the Chesapeake Ohio-Nickel Plate systems.

LECTURES, gallery talks, study hours and story hours are offered each year by the Metropolitan Museum, which constantly enlarges this service by introducing new courses and amplifying the scope of others. A folder giving full information concerning this year's program may be obtained upon request from the museum's secretary.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24. -- The Pittsburgh Panthers opened their season today with a 47-to-0 victory over Ohio Northern University before 15,000 fans at the Pitt Stadium. Most of the game was played by the Panther reserves, who gained consistently against the invaders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The champion Cubs, using a second string line-up after the regulars had almost thrown the game away, rallied in the late innings today to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 8 to 6, and end their three-game losing streak.

THE eleven men of Mr. Mead's title are the eleven apostles left after the death of Judas, the organizers of Christianity, and for his purpose in this book they symbolize the spirit of Christianity as it has marched down through the ages. He begins with the crucifixion of Christ, and he thus visions the apostles and their mission as they set forth upon what he calls their "march" after the resurrection:

More families will move this Fall than last year, according to present information. This was borne out yesterday by Consolidated Gas Company figures as to the number of orders received to lock or unlock customers' meters, these figures being considered by the company a barometer of moving conditions.

LAKE COMPOUNCE, Conn., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Secretary Doak today asked the working man to support President Hoover for re-election on the grounds that Republican tariff and immigration policies were designed and had been administered for the benefit of labor.

With the expressed purpose of seeking a balanced consumption, production and distribution of commodities in this country to provide for a high standard of living, the American Engineering Council has completed a work program for a broadgauge study of all economic factors as a basis for a "comprehensive feasible national program."

IN Garram, the boy of the Hill Tubes, who is Garram the Hunter in the book by that name published two years ago and who in this volume becomes leader and chief, Herbert Best has created a very real and human character who seems likely to have a lasting place among the heroes dear to young readers.

A BLEMISH on Lord Kitchener's early career has been removed by the publication recently of one of his letters. While he was serving in Cyprus as a surveyor in 1882 he asked for a week's leave of absence and it was granted. He used the opportunity to go to Alexandria in order to watch the bombardment of the port by British and French ships, sent there to suppress a rebellion.

DANVILLE, Ky., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Bringing the Republican campaign to the blue grass region, Vice President Curtis today told an audience that packed the county courthouse and overflowed into the street that Mr. Hoover was the only President who ever took action in a business depression.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 22. -- The refusal of Lewis S. Pope to accept the decisions of two Democratic executive committees that Hill McAlister is the Democratic nominee for Governor has precipitated a three-cornered fight which political observers say has become so bitter that the Republicans will be the only winners.

WITH both parties pledged to it, the long-delayed international monetary conference seems sure to be called in a relatively short time. Last Monday, in a speech at Butte, Mont., in the heart of the silver region, Governor Roosevelt promised that, if he were elected President, he would summon such a conference "without delay or evasion."

Business recovery will bring with it important changes in retail buying practice, chiefly in the limiting of purely "defensive safeguards" surrounding buying which have added to the costs of both production and distribution, according to James L. Fri, merchandising authority here.

TAXATION of motor vehicles has become "exorbitant and discriminatory," and is proving a serious obstacle to the recovery of the industry, Alfred Reeves, vice president of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, declared in addressing the Pennsylvania Automotive Association in Harrisburg last Monday.

WHEREEVER the demand for profound social and political changes to meet new conditions reaches the stage of action -- and that means almost everywhere in the world of today -- youth is found in the fore-front.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- The rentree, as Paris calls the general return from Summer vacationing, has no fixed single date for every one. The drift back to the city, however, usually becomes noticeable by the middle of September, and continues crescendo until by early October many of the characteristic social activities are in full swing.

Brokers and renting agents added many names to the lists of tenants in Manhattan apartment houses yesterday. Renting of this type has been heavy all week long and showed no signs of diminishing yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- Japan was rebuked in the League of Nations Council today by Eamon da Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council and head of the League Council, for prejudicing settlement of the Manchurian question by recognizing Manchukuo while the problem was pending here.
BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 24. -- Following the administration early today of serum for psittacosis, or parrot fever, Mrs. William E. Borah showed improvement this evening.

FORLI, Italy, Sept. 24. -- At the opening meeting of the permanent wheat committee today, Premier Mussolini announced that this year's wheat crop was the largest in Italian history, amounting to 276,000,000 bushels.

A general check-up of all places where professional hair dyeing is done in the city was ordered yesterday by Health Commissioner Wynne, who said there had been a large increase Recently in the use of hair dyes in beauty parlors and homes, and that those that contain aniline derivatives not infrequently cause skin and scalp troubles which sometimes result seriously.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 24. -- Villanova paraded through to a 26-2 victory over Ursinus in the opening football game of the season for both teams today.

THE International Aeronautical Federation decided at its Spring session this year to entrust the Swiss Aeroclub with the organization of the Gordon Bennett balloon race for 1932. The Swiss club then left to the section of Basle the carrying out of the arrangements necessary to secure the full success of this famous aeronautic fixture.

while business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was of only normal Saturday proportions, price movements were such as to indicate a further return of confidence in Wall Street. There was a gradual advance in stocks and bonds, with the railway departments of both markets setting an example for other groups.

MONTROSS GALLERY: Recent oils and a group of water-colors by John Wenger, also well known as a designer for the stage. His work in the oil medium generally shows insecure organization, though the brushwork can be vigorous and nearly always there is an element of decorative -- occasionally of persuasively lyric -- charm.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 22. -- Although differing as to the extent of the trend, Democratic and Republican leaders are agreed that this year North Carolina will give a larger vote to the Democratic national ticket than to the State ticket.

THIS enlightening work on the origin, organization and constitutional development of the much-talked-of and little-known League of Nations comes at the right time. One of the proofs of this leaps to the eye. Felix Morley wrote this book unaware that near the time of its publication Secretary Stimson would declare that the Briand-Kellogg pact had implicitly established for the world the revolutionary principle that war anywhere is the concern of nations everywhere.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 24. -- With the sailing today of the twenty-first regatta, the championship season of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound was concluded. There were eighty-one craft in the event, held by the Port Washington Yacht Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 24. -- Housewives of the State are urged by Consumers' Information Service, just established by official order of Charles E. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, to buy and can tomatoes, peaches and pears, to aid in keeping down the cost of living during the Winter.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 24. -- A warning to the bankers of America that the people are tired of their methods was sounded tonight by United States Senator Royal S. Copeland in a speech in the Guild Hall here before an audience of about 450 persons.

The map of crops appearing in connection with BERNHARD OSTROLENK'S understanding and comprehensive article in the Special Feature section of THE TIMES today on The Farmer's Plight (which urbanites especially should read) suggests what a long way we have traveled since the poor Greek farmer Heronax at the end of his harvest paid his homage to the goddess of agriculture and to the Seasons" whose feet are in the furrows."

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Redmond Cross introduced their daughter, Miss Emily Redmond Cross, to society this evening at a large supper dance in their country home here. The dance, to which nearly 500 friends had been invited, was preceded by a large dinner party.

Small lots of foreign bonds, as well as some municipal obligations, were added last week to the list of those caHed for redemption before their maturity dates. The total of bonds called for payment this month is now $25,406,300, compared with $56,243,000 in August, and with $116,522,500 in September, 1931, at corresponding dates.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24. -- In a session lasting until 3:30 o'clock this morning the Chamber of Deputies approved a measure legalizing divorce.

THE farm crisis confronting the nation has again been vividly brought to the forefront by recent events, notably the series of producers' strikes and the conference of mid-West Governors called to deal with agricultural problems.

TOKYO, Sept. 2. -- During seventeen days in August eighty bandit attacks were reported by The Manchurian Daily News, a Japanese paper published in Dairen. The tale is incomplete for ordinary banditry is not news in Manchuria and only the larger raids are reported in the newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Purchasers of crops mortgaged to the government for loans must pay the amount of indebtedness direct to the Department of Agriculture before any payment is made to the farmer, under a ruling by the department.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Evalee Hanover, 2-year-old trotting filly, owned and driven by Edward S. Concord of Glen Ridge, and John March, pacing gelding owned by Ed Mansfield of Hoboken, scored upsets at the Weequahic Park matinee today.

WITHOUT crowding his novel in the least, Burris Jenkins has packed into "Torrent" a variety of themes sufficient to equip two or three average tales. First in order of importance, no doubt, comes the romance, which is modern in setting but highly conventional in spirit.

Contending that American purchases of products from the Soviet actually total far more than official figures would indicate, exporters last week suggested that indirect purchases of Russian merchandise be considered when Americans are accused of banning Soviet goods.

President Hoover, speaking from the White House, will deliver a message by radio Thursday night to 2,000 women from the Eastern States in sesson at the Second Annual Women's Conference on Current Problems, a non-sectarian and non-political meeting arranged by The New York Herald Tribune.

The United Fruit Line in November will transfer the steamships Toloa and Ulua to its service between New Orleans, Havana and Central America. Effective with the sailing of the Toloa on Nov. 12 from New Orleans, a regular twelve-day cruise service will be started, the itinerary including the Panama Canal Zone | and Honduras.

Formation of a comprehensive national commission for the protection of all institutional holders of the $11,000,000,000 of United States railroad bonds, with former President Calvin Coolidge as its head, will be announced early next week, the financial district heard again, yesterday.

FRIDAY night will usher into the Mayfair RKO's film version of "A Bill of Divorcement," the play by Clemence Dane. John Barrymore is the star, and his leading ladies are two -- Billie Burke, who makes her first appearance in talking films, and Katharine Hepburn, who makes her screen debut.

Winding up the championship campaign in much the same manner in which they had begun it, by tripping over the Phillies, the Giants yesterday brought to a close one of their most disastrous seasons in thirty years, the end finding them lodged in a tie for sixth place with the Cardinals who, a year ago this time, were girding themselves for a world's series combat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nations do not trade with one another by swapping money; they exchange commodities and services, and offset their balances of payment by means of credits when available or by shipments of precious metals when credit cannot be obtained.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 25. -- Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vatiderbilt gave a dinner at Beaulieu this evening in honor of their daughter, Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis, who observed her birthday anniversary.

Marine Transport for Tammany. What is the world coming to when Mr. CURRY'S mobilized legions must play second fiddle to a teachers' convention? The Tammany delegation to the Democratic State Convention next week will go to Albany by boat and will sleep on board during their stay because there is no room for them in the hotels.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25. -- The Russian internal position offers a superficial parallel with the state of affairs existing in 1921 prior to the introduction of the New Economic Policy, but the differences are greater than the similarities, and even in the latter there is an enormous change of degree.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Cleveland won the first and tied the second game of a double-header with the Chicago White Sox in the final play of the 1932 baseball season today. The Indians won the first game, 6 to 4, and darkness ended the second in the fifth inning with the score 5-all.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- President Hoover will lead the nation tomorrow in observance of the 143d anniversary of the postal service when he lays the cornerstone for the new Postoffice Department Building on Pennsylvania Avenue.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Eddie Driggs of Cherry Valley, former metropolitan and Long Island amateur champion, won the annual invitation golf tournament of the Nassau Country Club today by turning back David Gamble of Race Brook, 1 up, in an eighteen-hole final-round match.

There will be two openings in the Broadway playhouses tonight - "Success Story," the first production of the Group Theatre's season, at Maxine Elliott's, and "Belmont Varieties," which will have its postponed premiere at the Belmont.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- A year ago a stalwart, clear-eyed young man of 30 took over the coaching reins at the University of Pennsylvania and introduced the system of football in which he was schooled by Glenn Warner at Pittsburgh.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 25. -- The Southern Pacific Railroad of Mexico, which has been operated by the government for two months because a strike had paralyzed its operation, will be returned to its owners tomorrow or next day, it was announced today.

GENEVA, Sept. 25. -- The thirteenth annual Assembly of the League of Nations will be opened tomorrow by the man who during the war that produced this league was sentenced to death -- Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great deal of publicity has been given lately to the idea of spreading work among employes. This is the essence of the New Hampshire Plan, which has received the support of President Hoover and many wellknown industrialists.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The annual exclusive regatta of the handicap class, in which time allowances are based on the performances of the boats instead of on their construction, was held today with eleven of the craft, all sloops, starting from Hicks Ledge, off here.

The tools of science were described as the tools of good or evil, depending on the spiritual force of the person who uses them, by the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, Dean Emeritus of the Divinity School of Yale University, in a sermon yesterday in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Not even waiting for the football season to reach its full stride, the familiar upset came into the picture on Saturday, the outstanding example being the defeat of California on the Coast by Santa Clara. This was perhaps the only game in which the result brought with it unexpected defeat, but in several other instances tie scores and small margins of victory were surprising.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Organization of a National Progressive League to support Franklin D. Roosevelt for President was announced here today, with Senator Norris of Nebraska, independent Republican, as chairman of its national committee and Frederic C. Howe of New York as secretary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Miss Jessie Dell, Civil Service Commissioner, today denounced as a violation of the merit system, as well as a penalty on marriage, the section of the economy act providing that, in any reduction of personnel, husbands or wives living with each other shall be dismissed before others in their class, and giving preference in appointments to other than married persons if husband or wife already is in the government service.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25. -- With the opening of Yale's academic year Thursday several new buildings will be placed in use for the first time, these including the Hall of Graduate Studies, the Sterling Divinity quadrangle, the Payne Whitney gymnasium, the Ray Tompkins House, new headquarters of the Yale Athletic Association, and a building for the Sheffield Scientifc School, composed of Sheffield Hall, Sterling Tower and Strathcona Hall.

Franklin D. Roosevelt is revealed as a man of moderate means, with an income increased to fair proportions by his State salary and his wife's investments and activities, it was announced yesterday in the current issue of Fortune magazine.

The capitalistic system "under which the Western world has made its astonishing progress of the last century has developed deep-seated defects which threaten its existence unless they can be cured," according to Sir Arthur Salter, leading British economist.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Poppy, owned by Roy Manny, was the winner today of the last race of the Inter-Club class series for the Donald L. Coursen Memorial Trophy. Poppy won by 31 minutes over the second-place yacht, E. Moxham's Jester.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- A statement that Governor Roosevelt, took a stand five months against immediate cash payment of the soldier bonus, is made in a letter written by Robert W. Woolley, former member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, to George R. Hunt of Lexington, Ky.

It is many a year since any professor of geology has taught that the earth has a molten interior. The theory was a consequence of the nebular hypothesis. Thrown off by the primeval spinning sun, what was more natural than to suppose that the earth cooled progressively from an incandescent ball of gas to a seething liquid and finally to a solid washed by oceans?

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25. -- Appraising the character of the slight increase in demand for steel, manufacturers have been turning to the view that it is general rather than seasonal. A seasonal bulge would last only a short time, leaving trade disappointingly poor in the late weeks of the year.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 25. -- When the Newark Bears entertain the Minneapolis Millers in three baseball games this week, something new in the way of the national game will be presented to this rabid baseball city.

The stage is set for the closing bout of the year's outdoor boxing season, a struggle of fifteen rounds, or less, between Max Schmeling, German, who formerly held the world's heavyweight title and Mickey Walker, Elizabeth N.J.) ring product, who has held the world's welterweight and middleweight championships, and aspires to the mantle of heavyweight king.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Joseph M. Dixon, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, who was chairman of the Progressive National Committee in 1912, discussed in a statement tonight Governor Roosevelt's remark in California last week that "he voted for T.R."

Life without God is without a purpose, a jig-saw puzzle which cannot be fitted together, said the Rev. J. Herbert Smith, associate rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, in his sermon yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 23. -- Governor James R. Beverley, in his first annual report to Secretary of War Hurley, calls particular attention to the population problem of the island as being fundamental and largely controlling the standard of living, health and labor conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Competition of the Federal Government with private business was sharply attacked in a report by Henry D. Sharpe of Providence, R.I., chairman of a special committee, made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Heads of Federal investigating agencies will combine forces tomorrow to plan their scrutiny of the complex Insull utilities system. United States District Attorney Dwight H. Green will head the investigation, ordered to ascertain if the financial experts employed by Samuel Insull in building his utility holdings into a $3,000,000,000 organization "violated any statutes of the United States."

Persons prominent in the theatrical world, in sports and many other walks of life, an assemblage of more than 1,200, joined last night in honoring Joe Weber and Lew Fields, famous comedy team, in a golden jubilee celebration held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

Now that it is clear that the predictions which were made under the intoxication of the stock market advance in July and August have been only partially verified, the financial community appears to have resigned itself to the prospect of a slow recovery in trade and industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Signs of real business improvement are coming slowly, the American Federation of Labor asserted in its monthly survey issued today, adding that increased consumer buying is needed to bring full recovery.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- A soiree of music and the dance was held tonight at the Hotel Gramatan here for the benefit of the Westchester County committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer.

While the warm weather slowed up retail buying slightly last week, a substantial volume of business was received, particularly for apparel, in the wholesale markets. Stores were more interested In obtaining immediate deliveries of merchandise already ordered than in placing new commitments, as many sales were reported to be lost through inadequate stocks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Farm Board agencies may enter the wheat market to obtain 15,000,000 bushels of wheat for China if the deal can be financed through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or other government agency.

Positive information that Arturo Toscanini, distinguished conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, is in excellent health, having the free use of his arm, has been received from persons close to Mr. Toscanini, who sailed for New York yesterday on the Bremen to commence orchestral rehearsals on Sept. 29.

The business leaders of America are likely to become fixed in a castelike group, similar to the hereditary aristocracies of Europe, if present trends continue, according to statistics presented by F.W. Taussig and C.S. Joslyn of Harvard University in "American Business Leaders," published today by Macmillan.

The attacking of our religious ideas and standards by men of outstanding intellect and force should be welcomed rather than frowned upon with uneasiness and apprehension, for "if our idea of God is to be splendid, it must be splendidly assailed," the Rev. ,Frank Kingdon, pastor of Calvary Methodist Church, East Orange, N.J., told the congregation yesterday at St. Nicholas Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CALCUTTA, Sept. 25. -- Armed with bombs, muskets and revolvers, a band of Bengal terrorists swooped down late last night on the European Institute at Chittagong, within a short distance of the armory where the famous Chittagong raid occurred two years ago, killing one person and wounding eight.

Three new plays bound for Broadway next weak will begin, tryout engagements tonight. Henry Myers's comedy, "The Other One," will start a week's run at the Country Play-house. Westport, Conn., preparatory to its New York premiere next Monday evening at the Biltmore Theatre.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 25. -- President Alfaro will not give a statement regarding an alleged plot to overthrow the government on Oct. 1, the date for the inauguration of Harmodio Arias. The plot is reported in The Panama American today, with the allegation that former President Harmodio Arosemena, ousted by the last revolution, is one of the leaders.
