The preliminary work on the Lusitania peace memorial at Cobh (Queenstown), Ireland, has been satisfactorily completed, and it is hoped the monument "will be finished by next Summer, according to an announcement yesterday by the Lusitania Memorial Committee, of which William H. Vanderbilt is chairman and Mrs. J. Borden Harriman secretary and treasurer.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Orders from the East were in the market here last week for choice and fancy steers weighing 1,150 to 1,275 pounds. They sold readily at $9.50 to $10.35, the latter being the top. The bulk of the steers ranged around $6.50 to $9, and the average for the week was $7.85, a drop of 40 cents, compared with the previous week, while a year ago the average was $8.85.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Chicago's National League champions closed their regular season today by taking a 5-to-3 defeat from the eighth-place Cincinnati Reds, ending the campaign with a record of 90 victories to 64 defeats.

The retail trading area of New York City includes the five boroughs of the city and twenty-three suburban counties within a radius of sixty miles from City Hall and has a population of 12,055,187, according to a survey to define the area, just completed by the Merchants Association of New York in cooperation with the Publishers Association of New York City.

Governor ROOSEVELT may be indulging in a bit of harmless political coquetry when he tells the people who flock to see him in the West that he wishes to get into contact with them so as to learn their needs. But they are the ones who are actually making the contact.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Before a big and enthusiastic crowd the honor of being named best dog in show at the Camden County Kennel Club's open-air exhibition at the Camden Airport today was won by Dr. A.A. Mitten's English setter Champion Blue Dan of Happy Valley.

Lack of time prevented a full two-inning's match for the Paterson C.C. and the Ardmore C.C. of Philadelphia when play was resumed yesterday to decide the winner of the United States Cricket Association Cup at Llvingston Park, S.I., nd Paterson therefore gained the verdict on the first innings, 179-79.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 25. -- A detective sergeant, was shot and killed and more than twenty other persons were beaten, stabbed or shot in a riot this evening between armed factions of the United Mine Workers of America and the Progressive Miners' Organization.

BOMBAY, Sept. 25. -- Eight doctors called at Yerovda jail in Poona today to visit Mahatma Gandhi, who grimly refused to end his long fast until the British Government approved yesterday's settlement between the caste Hindus and the "untouchables."

Beyond repeal of prohibition "lies the excess of the American people, which knows no bounds," declared the Rev. John L. Davis, pastor of the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, 135 West Fourth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning. It was that excess, Dr. Davis said, that brought about the saloon originally and that will bring it back again after repeal.

BARCELONA, Sept. 25. -- Hundreds of thousands of Catalans, many from the countryside in short bloomer-shaped trousers and red caps and others residents of Barcelona, turned out today with waving flags and great enthusiasm to welcome Premier Manuel Azana as he officially presented the autonomy statute passed by the Spanish Cortes to the President of the Catalan Generalidad, Colonel Francisco Macia.

Journalism, "the chief agency of our present civilization for the advancement of human relationships," should be fully recognized today as a leading profession and an essential pubic service, Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The stock markets at the moment are proving somewhat disappointing to optimists. For one thing, Wall Street has developed instability which, although not surprising, is checking the renewed expansion of speculative activity here.

An affirmative vote on the proposed $30,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief and a negative vote on the proposed constitutional amendment to permit new types of recreational facilities in the forest preserve were urged yesterday by the Citizens Union.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard's employes will not be reduced and the yard will receive its full share of work during the Winter, according to Secretary of the Navy Adams, in a letter to Representative Emanuel Celler, made public yesterday. Secretary Adams's letter was in response to one from Mr. Celler, which charged that the Brooklyn yard was not receiving a fair allotment of naval construction and repair work.

The Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, World War chaplain and chaplain of the Police Department in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, began his duties yesterday as pastor of Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, Forty-second Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where he succeeds the Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, noted war chaplain, who died in June.

An encouraging response for subscriptions has been reported for the fashion show and entertainment in aid of the social service auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital, which will be held Oct. 6 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many tables and boxes, have been reserved for the night show, which will follow a special dinner, and for the afternoon event, which will be preceded by a luncheon.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- Summarizing the conditions under which the great French rentes conversion will be effected, now that the six-day time limit for reimbursement has elapsed, Finance Minister Germain-Martin, said tonight the reimbursements would total only 2.5 per cent of the total of 85,000,000,000 francs [$3,332,000,000] involved.
NEW YORK. The Spanish Ambassador, Senor Don Juan Francisco de Cardenas, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, in a statement tonight contended that the primary election results so far showed no real losses for the drys and that "there has been no reversal of public sentiment on the liquor question."

Negotiations over a new wage scale for stagehands, carried on through the Summer between Theatrical Protective Union 1 and the League of New York Theatres, representing the producing managers, were successfully concluded yesterday, when the union membership, meeting in Palm Garden, 306 West Fifty-second Street, voted to accept a one-year agreement which calls for reductions in salary of 9 per cent for department heads and 7 per cent for other workers.

Five men and a girl were wounded last night in a knife battle at Elizabeth and Hester Streets between members of two families. Although the police were unable to determine the cause of the affray from any of the participants, they believed it was the climax of a blood feud having its roots in the combatants' native Sicily.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- Measurement of cosmic ray intensity recorded at an altitude of 27,000 feet during the total eclipse of the sun last Aug. 31 indicates that the part of the rays responsible for the daily change in intensity on the earth's surface emanate from a much more extended region of space than the sun itself, Captain A.W. Stevens of the United States Army Air Corps at Wright Field reports.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Reduction in the discount rate to 4 per cent and the government's new plan to restore the liquidity of commercial banks brought further improvement in business sentiment this week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Reports from a large number of industries as well as general business organizations covering a wide range of territory throughout the Middle West, Southwest and Northwest indicate a steady gain in sales. Sales in most lines have exceeded last year's in dollars and in numerous lines actual tonnage is larger than a year ago.

There is an abundance of small mackerel off Fire Island Light, according to the latest report from the fishermen in those waters. The arrival of the mackerel has been awaited with some concern by the old-timers not alone in that locality but all along the coast where the mackerel are wont to come.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Introduction of the Quebec system of liquor control in New York would mean an annual drink bill of nearly $500,000,000, said Fred A. Victor, State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New York, speaking in the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church here today.

The first annual report of Dean ACKERMAN of the Columbia School of Journalism, made public today, covers more than the activities of that institution. These are adequately described, as are the important changes in the courses of study inaugurated by the new Dean.

The formation of a national committee against prepayment of the bonus was announced yesterday by S. Stanwood Menken, organizer of the National Security League, in a statement declaring that the "greatest financial raid in history must be stopped."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25. -- Governor Pinchot today forwarded to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation a report on relief work in the sixty-four Pennsylvania counties to which the corporation has not allotted Federal aid. He admitted in a letter to Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the corporation, that the report was based largely on guesses rather than statistics and that the figures in many cases "will not be worth the paper they are written on."

In a step toward complete ownership of three of its subsidiaries, the Atlas Corporation has renewed offers made to stockholders of the Ungerleider Financial Corporation, Securities Allied Corporation and Federated Capital Corporation on June 4, and has extended these offers to permit those who wish to obtain an in-come-bearing security to accept Atlas preference instead of its common stock in exchange.

Dairymen at Adams Centre and Pierrepont Manor, N.Y., who had threatened a milk strike, went ahead with shipments of milk to the metropolitan market yesterday when assured that the United Milk Products Company would do everything possible to induce its distributers to maintain prices, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx blasted his fifty-eighth home run of the season in a perfect day at bat, but the Senators defeated the Athletics by 2 to 1 today in closing their 1932 rivalry.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- The strongest "No!" France has uttered since Germany forwarded her demand for equality rights was made today by Premier Herriot in a speech in the little town of Gramat in Southwestern France. The Premier indicated the Assembly of the League of Nations is going to study the possibility of a new covenant guaranteeing security to all nations, including Germany, which would automatically solve the whole controversy.

Mayor McKee's leadership in the Board of Estimate is scheduled for its first major test when the matter of Queens bus franchise awards comes up for settlement in the next few weeks, according to those in close touch with this phase of the city's transportation problem.

A driverless sedan which had been set in motion and abandoned by a group of boys rolled across Delancey Street near Essex Street last night. killing one woman and injuring three others before it crashed into another automobile which was being driven up the street.

IF the proposed affair isn't postponed again, Mickey Walker will climb through the ropes and go after Herr Max Schmeling in the Garden Bowl on Long Island this evening. The Rumson Bulldog will not have to go far because it will be only a 24-foot ring and Max plans to meet him half-way.

MADISON, Wia., Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Republican and Democratic parties were termed tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, "merely glass bottles with different labels, and both of them empty of any medicine for the sickness of our times."

Captain Bob Volmuth was drowned yesterday and his death brought grief to hundreds of children and their parents whose homes overlook the Hudson River near 136th Street where the captain's houseboat lies at anchor.

With legal details pertaining to the sale of remaining assets of the American Natural Gas Corporation completed, plans are nearly ready for the reconstitution of the properties formerly owned by this company under a new company to be incorporated for the purpose, in which certain security holders of the liquidated company will share.

The seventeenth issue of "Who's Who" (1932-33) contains a study of nearly four thousand sketches which appeared for the first time in 1928-29. The results, so far as the investigations parallel each other, are "almost identical" with those of the earlier entrants into this transient house of eminence.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The German industrial improvement is considerable and is accompanied by price rises in consumption goods branches. Cotton, woolen and linen spinners and weavers have taken on new hands.

LEONARDTOWN, Md., Sept. 25. -- Seizure by Federal prohibition agents of $18,000 worth of imported liquors at a mansion near Plum Point, built by Felipp Barada, a former attache of the Peruvian Legation, and later occupied for a time by his nephew of the same name, led early today to the kidnapping of the agents by hi-jackers.

Launching a sixteen-hit attack against three pitchers, the Boston Braves defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers, 13 to 7, yesterday at Ebbets Field in the closing game of the National League baseball season for both clubs. The crowd of 5,000 saw the Braves overcome Brooklyn's 6-to-1 lead to down the third-place Dodgers for the fifteenth time in their twenty-two meetings of the 1932 campaign.
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- There was every expectation tonight that Prime Minister MacDonald would announce his acceptance of yesterday's Hindu settlement with certain minor reservations tomorrow morning.

The Non-Partisan Fact-Finding Committee for Hoover announced yesterday that the recovery of business was genuinely under way. It based its announcement on opinions of some of the country's leading economists and lawyers without reference to the recent rise in the stock market.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 25. -- The 1932 high-goal polo season came to an end at the Sands Point Club today as the Old Westbury quartet downed the Aiken team, 13 to 10, in a closely contested engagement, which was played for the benefit of the unemployment relief fund of Port Washington.

While the current month has brought some tangible improvement to support the vague optimism that accompanied the recent advance in security and commodity prices, the most that can be said thus far is that business activity seems to be responding to the seasonal influences making for expansion, says the Guaranty Survey, published today by the Guaranty Trust Company.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25. -- Following the drop in prices that started when the government's crop forecast was issued on Sept. 8, the cotton market has developed a substantial recovery. There was a decline of virtually $15 a bale from the season's high mark, reached a few days before the official estimate was issued.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 25. -- While State troopers were combing Suffolk and Nassau Counties last night for the three bandits who, a few hours previously, had shot their way out of the crowded Huntingdon Theatre, killing a constable and wounding a watchman, a rookie special constable of Huntington walked into Police Headquarters with one of the bandit trio.

NAPLES, Sept. 25. -- Former Mayor James J. Walker of New York sailed for Genoa today abroad the Dollar liner President Pierce. The ship left Naples two hours late owing to the arrival of a cablegram for Mr. Walker just before sailing time.

Governor Roosevelt led President Hoover 168,869 to 128,465 in a compilation of all polls tabulated at Democratic headquarters during the last week, it was announced there yesterday. The list of polls follows:

One of the larger entertainments planned for this season is the Fall military ball to be held the night of Oct. 22 under the auspices of the Seventh Regiment Yorktown Society. The event will take place in the regiment's armory at Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 25. -- Three adventurers today kidnapped an airport watchman here, stole a commercial airplane and apparently tried to fly to the rebel capital of Sao Paulo, but the attempt ended in death for all four.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Princess Dayang, daughter of the Sultan of Sulu, says the United States owes her fourteen islands, but government geographers so far have located only seven.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The Yankees and Red Sox closed their American League season today with their roles reversed, the Yanks making only six hits and one error for each of their safeties to lose to the tailenders, 8 to 3.

ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT SPECIAL, WICKENBURG, Ariz., Sept. 25. -- Governor Roosevelt was on his way east today, convinced from his reception and the information he has received that he will carry he three States of the Pacific Coast, California, Oregon and Washington, and add their thirty-five electoral votes to his column.

Champion Right o' Way Again, the beautiful terrier by Champion Hagerty's Surprise out of Larsen's Bitter Sweet, owned by Cornelius J. Bahnken of Brooklyn, was named best in show last night at the annual exhibition of the Long Island Boston Terrier Club in the clubhouse of the Brooklyn Elks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It the National Economy League, of which Rear Admiral William S. Sims, retired, is an active officer, wishes to be taken seriously in its campaign against pensions and disability allowances, it would do well to supply its speakers with more complete data than those used by the Admiral in his Boston speech of Sept. 22.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Nathan William MacChesney, director of the National Hoover-Curtis Organization Bureau, today announced the formation of a national committee of physicians and surgeons with Dr. Herman Louis Kretschmer as its chairman.

Coming to the offensive in our analysis of the Yankees and Cubs, we arrive at that domain dominated completely by the American League champions, if measured by the yardstick provided by the past season's statistics. Only a casual glance at the latest available records is needed to reveal this very forcibly.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 25. -- Manager Bert Niehoff of Chattanooga, Southern Association champion, was forced to use three pitchers to stave off a spirited ninth-inning rally today and save the fourth game of the Dixie series, the Lookouts defeating Beaumont, Texas League champion, 6 to 4.

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- Premier Herriot's speech at Gramat today is regarded in political quarters as not promoting the cause of disarmament and considerably complicating the situation created by Germany's move for parity rights in armaments.

POINT JUDITH, R.I., Sept. 25 (AP). -- Five men were rescued and five others helped to safety by Coast Guardsmen at the height of a sudden electrical storm which swept across the harbor here shortly before sunrise today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos the ceremony yesterday at Meaux, when the United States gave back the Statue of Liberty, there was an amusing side to the situation.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 25. -- Leading manufacturers of the country were urged tonight by James H. Rand Jr., chairman of the board of Remington Rand, Inc., to increase their payrolls for at least sixty days as a means for boosting the public buying power so that the present upward trend might be turned into a solid revival.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Cardinals and the Pirates broken even today. Pittsburgh won the first game, 7 to 1, and St. Louis took the nightcap, 7 to 4, as the season closed.

Walter Connolly, who is again to appear under the management of Gilbert Miller this season, has been selected by Mr. Miller to play opposite Pauline Lord in "The Late Christopher Bean," which Sidney Howard has adapted from the French. Mr. Connolly was last seen with Helen Hayes in Molnar's comedy, "The Good Fairy."

In an address before an organization of city employes of which Deputy Controller PRIAL is the president, Controller BERRY announced yesterday his long-awaited plan for municipal retrenchment and economy. In most respects it is an admirable platform, on which all interested in preserving the city's credit may safely take their stand.

The Police Department baseball team defeated its traditional rival, the Fire Department, in their annual game at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and thereby gained possession of the Mayor's Cup. A crowd of 40,000 that included Mayor McKee attended and saw the policemen triumph by virtue of a three-run rally in the eighth inning, 5 to 4.

With the score knotted at 9-all at the close of the scheduled six periods, Lieutenant Don Galloway tallied after four minutes of the "sudden-death" overtime chukker to give the West Point Officers a 10-9 triumph over the Princeton R.O.T.C. in a preliminary match in the seventh annual military championship polo tournament of the Second Corps Area yesterday at Governors Island.

Three armed youths held up eleven persons early last night in the clubhouse of the Corona Park Golf Club at 111th Street and Forty-sixth Avenue, Corona, Queens, obtained $200 from the victims and $1,100 of greens fees and escaped after locking the golfers and employes in the locker room.

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 25. -- At the stroke of 9 tomorrow morning, Miss Estelle Lawson of Greensboro, N.C., will drive a ball off the No. 1 tee on the Salem Country Club course and the women's national championship, the last major golf event of the year, will be in motion.
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- The London Times, the most settled in its habits of any newspaper in the world, will appear in a completely new dress beginning with the issue of Oct. 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- With economic recovery emphasized in its statement of principles as the leading problem confronting the American people, a Hoover Club of Pennsylvania has been organized by a group of prominent Republicans to promote the President's cause in this State.

Attributing most of the evils of modern society, to "our strange and peculiar divorce laws," the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday denounced as "unpatriotic, mercenary and unmoral" States in which easy divorce laws prevail.

Benny Friedman's Brooklyn Dodgers opened the National Football League season in the metropolitan district yesterday with a 7-0 victory over Dan Blaine's Stapleton eleven at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island, before a crowd of 9,000.

Connecticut Republicans may well pray to be delivered from professors in politics. As if Professor-Governor CROSS hadn't given them worry enough, Professor ALBERT LEVITT and Professor MILTON CONOVER, Independent Republican candidates for Governor and Senator, are again interfering with the beneficent designs of that somewhat waning potentate, the Hon. J. HENRY RORABACK.

Brig. Gen. Pelham D. Glassford, superintendent of the Washington police, and Mrs. Corinne Roosevelt Robinson, sister of the late Theodore Roosevelt, called upon the veterans of the Seventy-seventh Division to take arms against the depression last night at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt, which ended the division's three-day reunion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Seldom has the average wheat trader of the world been so uncertain as now regarding the trend of the market in the immediate future. Factors that in normal conditions might be expected to cause rather drastic advances or declines have had little or no effect on the markets for a long time.

Announcing the formation of a Republican-for-Roosevelt League yesterday, Richard Washburn Child, life-long Republican, made public a letter from Colonel Edward M. House which said that Republican shifts into the Democratic column would make certain the election of Governor Roosevelt.

The address of Controller Charles W. Berry before the Civil Service Forum on Saturday night was generally accepted yesterday as drawing the battle lines in the Board of Estimate, with the issue the five-cent fare as against maintenance of the salaries of the civil service employes.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 26. -- President Hoover's assertion that the German armaments problem is "solely a European question" was sharply challenged today by Lord Dickinson, better known as Sir Willoughby Dickinson, one of the foremost advocates of the League of Nations and disarmament in Great Britain.
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Soviet Russia today commemorated the fortieth anniversary of the literary activity of Maxim Gorky.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Illinois Democrats will tell James A. Farley, Democratic National chairman, in a conference here tomorrow that they expect Cook County to roll up large pluralities for Franklin D. Roosevelt and for Judge Henry Horner for Governor.

One of the most annoying things to the Republicans in the Democratic nominee for President is his name. Some of them are inclined to think it unsportsmanlike for FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT not to have changed it when he ran for office. They complain that thousands of Western Republicans believe that he is THEODORE ROOSEVELT or a son of the late President.
LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The British Government today enabled Mahatma Gandhi to end his hunger strike by accepting with much friendly phraseology the agreement reached by the Hindus at Poona Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Josephus Daniels, Secretary of the Navy under President Wilson, stopping in Washington today at the close of his speaking tour in behalf of the Democratic Presidential ticket, predicted that the entire region west of the Mississippi would be solid for Roosevelt and Garner Sentiment, he asserted, is stronger there than in 1916, when it was swept by Woodrow Wilson.

A continued disagreement on the wage scale of longshoremen of the deep-sea lines in New York and other port cities on the North Atlantic was indicated last night, when reports of the action of branches of the International Longshoremen's Association, hurriedly summoned to consider an offer of $1.05 an hour for overtime work, were received at the headquarters of the association, at 265 West Fourteenth Street.

Reactionary tendencies developed yesterday in the bond list on the New York Stock Exchange. All departments closed for the most part lower on the day. The trading volume was off somewhat from recent levels, with a turnover of $10,177,100, comparing with $10,544,000 on last Friday.

Charles Scribner was elected president of Charles Scribner's Sons yesterday, the third of that name to head the publishing firm founded by his grandfather in 1846. Interviewed yesterday in his office, he announced that Maxwell Perkins, editor in chief of the house, had been elected vice president, and that John Hall Wheelock had replaced Mr. Perkins as secretary.

The pending Interborough equity receivership, brought about with the company's consent, by action of a creditor with a claim for only $27,000, is a typical case justifying Governor Roosevelt's recent plea for "a thorough overhauling of the Federal laws affecting receiverships," according to a statement issued yesterday by Nathan L. Amster, chairman of the Manhattan Railway Stockholders' Protective Committee.

Reorders on Active Goods. While reorders by mail were quite numerous here yesterday, reflecting fill-ins on active items in last week's retail trade, the stimulus of increased buying budgets earlier in the season has become less. Many out-of-town retailers, it was explained, have about covered their early season requirements and are now awaiting consumer Fall buying to open up in earnest.
The lease of the store and basement, occupied as a drug store, in 1,340 St. Nicholas Av., held by Irving Moldow from the Myra Realty Corp., has been canceled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The privilege of engaging in part-time or vacation employment to pay their way through American schools, colleges or universities has been withdrawn by William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, from foreign students admitted without regard to quota limitations to study at approved instiutions in this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attitude to the bonus is well known. I was among the very first members of Congress to oppose the initial bonus as proposed over twelve years ago, but I can see no just cause for the campaign of vilification indulged in by Mr. Hoover and his Cabinet against the so-called Bonus Army.

Resumption of business in money in the new week witnessed a continuance of Street funds at 1 per cent. Offerings were heavy at that figure, but demand was small. Stock Exchange rate for call loans remained at 2. Elsewhere time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were quiet and unchanged in quotation.

As one step in the program of the national committee on Industrial rehabilitation in the Second Federal Reserve District, which includes New York, industrial executives will be urged to proceed toward modernization of their plants now, it was announced yesterday by Major General James G. Harbord, chairman of the committee for this district.
The Yankees, champions of their league for the first time in four years, yesterday began preparations for their battle with the Cubs in the 1932 world's series starting tomorrow.

Those interested in preserving the forests of the Adirondack and Catskill regions from encroachment and commercialization will have an opportunity this Fall to make their voices heard. Along with the referendum on the proposed $30,000,000 State bond issue for relief, which should receive unanimous support, there will be submitted to the people at the election on Nov. 8 a proposed amendment to the Constitution which should be rejected.

The convictions that a billion dollars reduction can be made in Federal expenditures, that a saving of around one hundred million dollars is essential in city expenditures and that many millions can be pared from the costs of State government are expressed by Thomas J. Watson, president of the Merchants' Association of New York, in his annual report for the last fiscal year, which is made public in today's issue of the association's bulletin.
Extensive trading in New Jersey housing properties was reported yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The stock markets were dull today, with little business in spite of favorable weekend developments. The assented war loan was a strong feature of British Government funds, which were generally firm and cheerful. The textiles were better following settlement of the cotton mill strike, but lost some of the improvement in profit-taking.

Political subdivisions, like New York City, or Monmouth County, or Delaware, are easy to define and describe, Communities bound together by social, economic or commercial ties present greater difficulties, as every census expert will tell you.

For the seventh consecutive month, the Reading Company showed in August an increase in net operating income compared with the corresponding month a year previously. Gross earnings in August, however, continued below 1931 levels. Net operating income in August exceeded $1,000,000, the road's first monthly result above $1,000,000 net this year.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26. -- E. R. Hicks of Little Rock, Ark., told the convention of the National Association of Securities Commissioners today that "fraudulent stock and bond operators -- bluebeards in the securities field -- rob the public of more money each year than all the petty thieves, bandits and bank robbers combined."

A suit to padlock the clubhouse of the James W. Brown Association, Inc., 2,017 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, named for the Democratic leader of the Second Assembly District in the Bronx, was begun in United States District Court yesterday by Assistant United States Attorney Earle N. Bishopp, in charge of the padlock division of the United States Attorney's office.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 26. -- Mrs. Albert M. Briggs won six blue and red ribbons this afternoon in the annual Fall flower show of the garden department of the Garden City-Hempstead Community Club, which was held in the Garden City Casino for one day.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 27. -- A gloomy view of the Franco-German situation is taken by The London Times, which editorially say's the two countries, on whose collaboration European peace must be based, seem "to be drifting steadily further apart."

A guarantee against the upheaval certain to follow any attempt at an immediate application of ultra-Socialist doctrine is presented in the Socialist campaign textbook, made public yesterday over the name of Norman Thomas, the party candidate for President.

A third plan for development of the seven-block Chrystie-Forsyth Street area near the Manhattan end of the Manhattan Bridge was submitted to Mayor Joseph V. McKee yesterday by Howe Lescaze, architects, who said they could house 1,500 families at a cost of $10.95 a room a month, compared with the $12.50 specified in two other plans previously submitted.
A. C. Schwartz's Tickory Tock, full sister to the Hopeful winner Tick On, captured the Beldame Handicap, feature at Aqueduct yesterday.
Cross-currents developed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and, after advancing more than a dollar a bale at one time, prices closed 2 to 6 points higher than on Saturday.

Quotations for Over-the-Counter Securities are unofficial. Those included in these tables are obtained from many brokers and dealers. The source which supplied any quotations in this list will be given upon request.

Echoes of the Summer are encountered at the Macbeth Gallery which yesterday opened a showing of oils collected from various an colonies. Thirty-six canvases have been arranged to advantage in the two large exhibition rooms, for the most part artists being represented by a single picture each.

G. HERMAN RUTH is warming up for his tenth world's series. He wandered into his first one somewhat by accident. He happened to be a young pitcher with the Red Sox in 1915 and the Red Sox had a good team that year, good enough to win the American League pennant and to defeat the Phillies four games to one in the world's series.

GENOA, Sept. 26. -- James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, arrived here today from Naples on the steamship President Pierce. At the Miramar Hotel, Mr. Walker said his secretary, George S. Collins, who has been ill, was better. "He is going up, while I am going down," said the ex-Mayor.

The body-and-soul clinic, which offers free treatment to the ill, the insane and the neurotic, was reopened yesterday in a rented lodge room in the Stuyvesant Casino, at Ninth Street, two blocks down Second Avenue from St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, from which it was excluded after a ten-year occupancy, on Aug. 1, when the vestry decided to restrict the use of the church to the canonical forms of worship provided in the Protestant Episcopal prayer book.

Offering will be made here today of a $60,000,000 issue of one-year 4 per cent bonds of the Dominion of Canada by a group headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, it was announced here last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading THE TIMES yesterday I was impressed by your editorial on communicable diseases. The need for a "separate institution for contagious diseases in a remote location" is of course outmoded.

The Mayor's Official Committee for the Relief of the Unemployed and Needy, in a report yesterday to Mayor McKee, announced that from Oct. 31, 1930, to June 30, 1932, the committee collected $3,124,345.52 for the needy unemployed and disbursed $2,930,566.85, leaving a surplus of $179,062.73.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 26. -- Faced by a $600,000 deficit for the rest of the year, Rochester's Republican city administration today grasped at all possible ways to effect the largest reduction ever attempted in the costs of running the city.
Max Schmeling weighed 188 1/2 pounds as he entered the ring to fight Mickey Walker who scaled 174 1/2.

In their first official statement giving their side of the controversy with Typographical Union 6, the Printers' League section of the New York Employing Printers' Association denied the union statement, published yesterday, that the employes had tried to "effect a speedy adjustment" of the new contract, while the employers had delayed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Discovery of skeletons of an ancient, narrow-headed people far under the surface of desolate Kodiak Island, off the coast of Alaska, is announced by Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, noted anthropologist of the Smithsonian Institution, who has just returned from there.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 26. -- Warnings against pagan materialistic tendencies of some psychiatric clinics for child guidance marked discussions at the convention of the National Conference of Catholic Charities which opened here today.

MADRID, Sept. 26. -- In a decision that will affect business houses and commercial enterprises throughout the world the tariff commission of the International Telegraphic Conference voted by 28 to 10 today to abolish ten-letter in favor of five-letter code words.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Sept. 22 there appeared in THE TIMES a letter from the Rev. Charles Steizle on the general topic of "The Old Saloon," in which he expressed commendation, in many ways, both of saloonkeepers and of the saloon as a clubhouse for the workingman -- perhaps a little too much from the standpoint of an idealist.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26. -- Captain Patrick MacNamara, R.N., naval attache of the British Embassy at Washington, and Mrs. MacNamara are visitors here. They visited the naval training station today where, after being shown about, they were the luncheon guests of Captain and Mrs. Gilbert J. Rowcliff.
Mickey Walker's heavyweight championship aspirations were spiked by the right hand of Max Schmeling, former title-holder, last night in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City.

There can be no return to prosperity unless the purchasing power of the farmer is restored, Alfred Gosse, head of the Washington State Grange, declared in an address here last night at a dinner of the Eighth National Cooperative Congress at 49 East Twenty-fifth Street.

Uncertainty in the crude oil situation is almost entirely responsible for the current weakness in gasoline prices, according to Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute. Mr. Beaty is of the opinion that the oil industry is not confronted with an era of prices below the cost of production and believes that if producers will courageously face conditions and reduce crude oil production to a proper level a perfectly healthy condition will result.

After warning students that the probability of winning coins in a slot machine was slight, Dr. E. E. Free, science lecturer at the New York University School of Commerce, dropped a coin in one of the machines during an experiment at the university yesterday morning and drew eight slugs.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 26 (AP). -- While a threatening mob of striking coal miners were held in check by police in the streets outside, twenty-five officials and organizers of the United Mine Workers of America were released today on bond from the city jail, where they had been held on charges of inciting to riot.

The five Democratic county leaders of the Second Judicial District gathered yesterday in the office of John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, and discussed several candidates for the three Supreme Court nominations to be filled at the judicial convention Thursday.

President DE VALERA of the Irish Free State has spoken twice at Geneva, first as presiding officer of the Council of the League of Nations, and then at the first meeting of the Assembly. On both occasions he falsified the predictions that the former Irish rebel was bound to say something inflammatory or disrupting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 26. -- The bid of the Bank of America for $4,574,000 municipal construction and relief bonds was accepted today. For the relief bonds, amounting to $2,160,000, the bid was $2,163,456 and the interest charge fixed at 4 1/2 per cent.

The World Exchange Bank, 174 Second Avenue, which paid out nearly $1,000,000 to its depositors, representing 100 cents on the dollar, on July 31, 1931, four months after it was closed and taken over for liquidation by State Banking Superintendent Joseph A. Broderick, has declared a capital stock dividend of $3 a share on its 5,000 outstanding shares of $100 par value, representing a disbursement of $15,000.

A motion for dismissal of the lottery indictment against Senator James J. Davis was denied by Judge rank J. Coleman in Federal Court yesterday with the observation that "the evidence thus far adduced must justify the jury, if it believes the witnesses and approves the government's inferences, in finding that there was a lottery and that Davis, almost inevitably, must have known that tickets were shipped across State lines.''

A valuable and comprehensive exhibit of stamps, old documents, diaries, pictures and models dealing with the history and development of the postal service was opened yesterday in the reproduction of Federal Hall in Bryant Park.

WASHINGTON, Iowa, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Senator Smith W. Brookbart, for eight years a storm centre of Iowa and national politics, returned to the political wars today as a third party nominee for re-election.

BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 26 (AP). -- One of two American balloons tonight was believed to be the victor in the James Gordon Bennett Trophy race after all the other entrants had been reported grounded.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Cornelius Whitney's Disdainful qualified for her engagement in the $20,000 Eastern Shore Handicap Wednesday when she defeated eleven other 2-year-old fillies over the five and one-half furlongs of the Gadabout Purse, feature today at Havre de Grace.

With an "obituary" of The Campus, for twenty-six years the official undergraduate newspaper at City College, in the place of its leading editorial, The City College Student, rival paper published by former members of the staff of The Campus who resigned last week in protest against alleged alumni interference, appeared for the first time yesterday coincidentally with the first Fall issue of its rival.
TORONTO, Sept. 26. -- The Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., with plants and offices throughout Ontario, was declared bankrupt today by Justice Sedgewick at Osgoode Hall.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 26. -- In specifying a cessation of hostilities at Fort Boquefon, where Paraguay is attacking the Bolivian garrison, Bolivia did not mean to convey in its last note to the neutrals at Washington that the proposed truce should be limited to that particular area, it was explained today.

WILLIAMS, Ariz., Sept. 26. -- Making a shift in his campaign plans, Franklin D. Roosevelt decided today to take four days' rest in mid-October at his Winter home in Warm Springs, Ga., and make a speech at Atlanta.

Speaker John N. Garner arrived in the city yesterday confident in the success of the Democratic ticket and voicing firm conviction that former Governor Alfred E. Smith would work actively for the national slate.

California as Ordeal California lives up to the precedent for earthly paradises by harboring a serpent within its lovely precincts. The name of the snake is Local Politics, and it lures to destruction Presidential candidates who go to California and immediately proceed to make a "break" and throw away the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Republican campaign, which will reach its height with President Hoover's first campaign speech in Des Moines, on Oct. 4, is now gaining momentum. The big guns are scheduled to appear on many fronts during the present week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Uncertainty as to the authority of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make an $8,000,000 loan directly to China to enable the sale of 15,000,000 bushels of privately owned American wheat was apparent in government circles today following yesterday's conference at the White House between President Hoover and administrative officials.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 26. -- Milk producers in Monroe and Livingston Counties appeared to be on the verge of a strike today. It is expected that unless the Dairymen's League is able to find a way out of the present price situation and submit it at the meeting at West Henrietta Grange Hall tomorrow night a "holiday" will be declared.

POONA, India, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The news of the approval of the Hindu pact in London caused great rejoicing throughout India. At Simla the halls of the Indian Legislative Assembly echoed with loud cheers and there was a similar demonstration in the Council of State.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 26. -- Dr. Robert S. Sackett, an instrue in psychologcy at the New Jersey College for Women, awakened abruptly this morning on the floor of the Creative Women's Studio next door to his home at 36 Bayard Street here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Finished manufacturers comprised 43.3 per cent of the total United States exports in August.

Having disposed of the offense, which revealed a powerful hand for the Yankees and the defense, wherein the Cubs appeared to hold the edge, we now come to the third and final chapter of our analysis, the department of strategic manoeuvres, or, as some might prefer to call it, the domain of the master mind.

Following England's example, France has carried through successfully a great operation in national finance. A law approved last week by the French Parliament provided for the conversion into lower interest rates of the most burdensome part of the national debt -- the "rentes" bearing interest at 5, 6 and 7 per cent.

An Investigation by the Attorney General into the movement to stabilize the milk market through increases in the wholesale price was sought yesterday by Eisenberg Farms, Inc., Brooklyn dealers, who charged the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association with an effort to eliminate competition.

Faced with the problem of yielding to the demand for economy in the city government, and a sharp reduction in the budget, consideration is being given in Tammany to consenting to a modification of the city's subway financing policy, as preferable to pay cuts in the ranks of the civil service employes.

Tribute to the work of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which, comprises all Reform congregations in the United States and Canada, and the urgent needs of the union at the present time were voiced by Ludwig Vogelstein at the first meeting yesterday afternoon of a special committee which has been established in Congregation Emanu El on hehalf of the welfare of the union.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The sale of 15,000,000 bushels of American wheat or flour to China, a deal involving about $9,000,000 in gold, appeared practically assured today as negotiations between the Chinese Government and the Federal Farm Board, begun in June, seeme'd to He nearing a conclusion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Gettin Even, cleverly ridden by Jockey G. South, outfooted a fair field in the feature race at Lincoln Fields today, winning by two lengths from Ben Creech's Whipper Cracker, the favorite.

At an emergency conference called by the Children's Welfare Federation yesterday to devise means to combat curtailment of child health work a resolution was adopted calling upon the 258 member organizations and the city departments concerned with health work among mothers and children to maintain all such health work in their budgets for 1933.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- Exactly what Premier Herriot intended in yesterday's speech by linking American policies to the League of Nations plans for a new covenant of peace remains obscure today. Efforts to ascertain, from the Foreign Office and the American Embassy what connection there could be between Secretary Stimson's doctrine of consultation in case of a war menace, President Hoover's disarmament plan and the negotiations now going on at Geneva met with failure.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Andrew W. Robertson, chairman, of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, declared tonight in an address before the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association at the Westchester Country Club, that manufacturers should begin now to make investments in plant machinery and factory equipment to prepare for the needs of the future.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Eva Davenport, prominent actress of long ago, and in private life, Mrs. Neil O'Brien, died at 8 o'clock this morning at the home of her daughter, Mrs. John J. Levenson, 6 Gedney Esplanade, this city. She was 74 years old and had been an invalid for several years.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 26. -- Paul Runyan of the Metropolis Country Club of White Plains and Dannie Williams of the Shackamaxon Country Club tied at 69, two under par, for low individual score at the Upper Montclair Country Club today in a joint medal play tournament held for members of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Professional Golfers' Associations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Using the trowel with which George Washington laid the cornerstone of the Capitol in 1793, President Hoover today laid the cornerstone of the $10,000,000 Postoffice Department Building, thereby commemorating the 143d anniversary of a government establishment which he described of "a living service of thousands of skillful and devoted men and women."

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Miss Helen Hicks, defending titleholder failed today by the margin of one stroke to qualify for match play in the national women's golf championship. She is one of the few champions in the history of the tourney to meet with a setback in the qualifying round.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Dr. Walter Blair Stewart Jr., a children's specialist of this city, who has been in charge of infantile paralysis cases at the Municipal Hospital for Contagious Diseases here, has been stricken with the disease and is being treated at his home, it became known today.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Frederick S. Moseley Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the Hon. Mrs. Michael Scott and Miss Victoria Brady.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Four optimistic developments marked the business situation today in the Pittsburgh area.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday issued a list of bonds Which have matured, and which may be removed from the list on Nov. 1, unless special circumstances warrant their retention. The removal of such bonds from the list was authorized by the committee on stock list on Aug. 31.

Thousands of passengers on rapid transit lines were delayed for periods ranging from eighteen minutes to more than an hour in the morning rush hours yesterday because of mishaps that caused blockades on the Long Island Railroad and the city's new Eighth Avenue subway.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 26. -- Rain today forced a postponement until tomorrow of the fifth game of the Dixie series between Chattanooga and Beaumont.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26. -- Mayor Howard Jackson announced today that the proposal for $22,000,000 city improvement loans would not be put on the ballots in November, as had been planned. The Mayor said that the city would adopt a pay-as-you-go policy during the economic crisis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Political candidates are very busy these days in promising new devices for the restoration of prosperity, but it would be well if they were conversant with that wise paragraph which appears in Buckle's "History of Civilization" to the effect that no great forward movement in legislation was ever promoted by anything new, but, on the contrary, by the repeal of bad laws previously enacted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley issued subpoenas today summoning two officials in the Insull utilities organization to appear in Federal court here Thursday and tell under oath all they know of the Insull failure.

Millinery this Fall and Winter is going to be worn tilted forward. This trend was evidenced last night at the, fashion show held at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Millinery Quality Guild and La Protection Artistique des Industries Saisonnieres, an organization comprising twenty-five Parisian milliners and modistes.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- The Republic Steel Corporation announced that a patent-infringement suit instituted against the company was dismissed today in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia. The suit was filed by Dr. Frank A. Fahrenwald of the American Manganese Steel Company and the Southern Manganese Steel Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- President Hoover has appealed to leading railway presidents of the country, as well as to representatives of railway labor, to postpone the discussion of further wage cuts until the end of the present year.

Sweeping condemnation of the attitude toward young prisoners and the routine of their incarceration at New Hampton Reformatory, New Hampton, N.Y., is contained in a year-long survey completed yesterday by Dr. Nathan, Peyser and presented to Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction, whose department supervises the institution.

By this time "Success Story" in any of its forms is not particularly original, nor has John Howard Lawson told it particularly well in the version played at Maxine Elliott's last evening. But he has imparted to it something better than skill. He has given it moral fervor.

CHERBOURG, Sept. 26. -- An explosion in the French submarine Persee today killed a civilian marine engineer and a civilian mechanic and injured four members of the crew so seriously they are not expected to live through the night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Picturing President Hoover as having "courage and backbone plus," Senator Arthus Capper of Kansas tonight declared that Mr. Hoover was the "best bet" for the next four years of reconstruction and urged that the government not be turned over to "a lot of new and inexperienced hands."

Refusing to enter a "political controversy" with Controller Charles W. Berry over the Controller's speech attacking his salary-reduction plan last Saturday night, Mayor Joseph V. McKee told 500 representatives of police associations yesterday that a 6 per cent flat cut in salary for all city employes would assure continuance of the city payrolls.

A free-rent "racket," operated by prospective tenants who obtain keys for inspection of quarters and then move in, is troubling realty agents in Camden County, N.J., according to Ethel Tanger, executive secretary of the county real estate board.

The newly organized Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts, which is composed of men of national prominence and has as its object the study of problems arising from the war debts owed to this country by European nations, came definitely into existence yesterday with the election of permanent officers and the announcement of a program for the remainder of the year.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- John Maurice Braen, 24 years old, who had been searching for his parents and relatives since he learned at the age of 21 that he had been adopted shortly after his birth, told today of a family reunion at which he met forty-four relatives, including three half-sisters and four half-brothers.

The insular microcosm, according to Governor BEVERLY'S report, reveals many of the ills of the macrocosm. Christened so as to suggest riches, it is unable to feed its own people, despite the largest sugar crop in its history. There is unemployment, yet the island could, if agriculture were organized and industries encouraged, easily care for even a greater population.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- President Hoover's address at the cornerstone laying for the new Postoffice Department Building today was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Directors of the Federal Home Loan Banks at Little Rock (Ark.) and Indianapolis were named today by the Home Loan Board, completing the organization of four banks of the system. Boards for the Cincinnati and Los Angeles banks already have been selected.

The final standing of the Sound Interclub Class yachts in the series of twelve races held during the Summer months for the Donald L. Coursen Memorial Trophy, announced yesterday by the class committee, shows that the prize went to Cornelius Shields's Aileen with a percentage of .808.

MUNICH, Sept. 26. -- The government will issue a decree this week introducing import quotas for a number of agricultural products. This was revealed this morning by Minister of Agriculture von Braun in a speech before the agricultural council of Bavaria.

Dorothy Hall, Broadway actress, and her husband, Neal Andrews, head of Inecto, Inc., cosmetic manufacturers, have agreed to separate. They have been married for six years. Mr. Andrews said yesterday that he and his wife had signed the following agreement:

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Within half an hour after Frank J. Tappen had been reinstated to the post of deputy police chief of Nassau County, from which he had been suspended in connection with the death of Hyman Stark during alleged "third-degree" treatment, the Board of Supervisors abolished the position today on the recommendation of Chief of Police Abram W. Skidmore.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Anticipating that as a result of the Liberal attitude toward the Ottawa agreements, Prime Minister MacDonald may have to reconstruct his entire Cabinet, King George has decided to return from Balmoral, Scotland, and will arrive in London on a special train Friday morning.

Harry N. Simon, a vice president of the Manufacturers' Trust Company, collapsed last night at the close of an impromptu speech before about 200 members of the Mahopac Democratic Club, a Tammany district organization, at its Quarters, 3,686 Broadway.

Lee Smith, president of the Willow Brook Dairy, has bought 45,000 square feet of industrial property in Mount Vernon for improvement with an additional plant. The parcel fronts 550 feet on both Washington Street and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Up on the second floor of a white Colonial clapboard house hard by the campus Gilmour Dobie lies upon a bed of pain and discourses on politics and the economic situation while the Cornell football squad works out at Schoellkopf Field under the direction of his assistant, Jim Tattersfield and Captain Viviano.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Republican and Democratic candidates for one of Ohio's seats in the United States Senate debated the prohibition planks of their respective party platforms here tonight, each charging the other with insincerity.
A fisherman always has his troubles, according to Captain Monsey Dinger. It's either too many fish of one kind or not enough of another or poor weather or weather that's just too good.

ABOARD CUB SPECIAL, FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 26 (AP). -- To the tune of cheering thousands at Chicago and along the route, Charlie Grimm's Cubs headed toward New York and their big world's series adventure tonight.

The waters of Long Island Sound have become discolored with a reddish brown substance in the last few days to such an extent that fishermen report the disappearance of fish life, while observers on shore assert that they have seen fish at the surface gasping for air or trying to leap to shore to escape the ill effects of the water.

Anthony Paul Kelly, dramatist and scenario writer, was found dead late yesterday in his furisfied apartment at 410 West 110th Street where he had committed suicide during, the night by inhaling gas. He left a note to the police explaining that he was hopelessly ill of tuberculosis and could not endure his illness any longer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Reports from abroad indicating imminent publication of the so-called Lytton report on the Chino-Japanese hostilities over Manchukuo have aroused keen speculation here over the Japanese reaction to an adverse report, and the effect of such reaction on the United States.

GENOA, Italy, Sept. 26. -- One of the greatest events in Italy's recent mercantile marine history will take place tomorrow when the 28 1/2-knot, 50,000-ton liner Rex steams out of this harbor at noon for New York via Nice and Gibraltar carrying 1,400 passengers, including 300 in the first class, 500 in the special class and tourist class and 600 in the third class.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Troops once more patrolled the Hocking Valley coal fields, the answer of Ohio today to a fresh outbreak of warfare between miners and operators, which, within the past twenty-four hours, has claimed two lives.

Reactionary influences were at work in all of the markets at the beginning of the new week. Stocks, bonds and commodities declined. In no instance was the weakness promoted by major news developments, so Wall Street fell back upon the familiar explanation of a "technical readjustment."

Five municipalities in Northern New Jersey, including Jersey City and Hoboken, were placed on reduced water allotments yesterday as a result of a depleted supply in the Boonton Reservoir. The reduced supply also will apply to the United States Immigration Station at Ellis Island, which draws water from, the same source.

A nation-wide expression of confidence that the turn has been reached in general conditions and in security prices is shown in the first returns from a Wall Street poll of 1,441 investment houses and banks throughout the country.

Five touchdowns were scored by the N.Y.U. varsity at Ohio Field yesterday in a scrimmage against the second team. Four reserve linemen who started on Team B performed so well against the first eleven that Coach Howard Cann promoted them to first-team berths before the combat drill was three-quarters completed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26. -- The science of medicine has progressed at a rapid pace, but the application of business principles to the medical profession is still in the "ox-cart stage," Edward .A. Filene of Boston said in an address tonight before the Clinical Congress of the Connecticut State Medical Society.

The Louis K. Liggett Company, which operates a chain of 555 drug stores throughout the United States, will have to undergo a reorganization unless it can obtain a substantial readjustment of its rents, it was announced yesterday by George M. Gales, president of the company, and vice chairman of Drug, Inc., the holding company which controls the Liggett organization.

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd of Philadelphia, the only woman in the history of golf to win the British and American titles in the same year, qualified for the championship at the Salem Country Club today for the sixteenth time.

TORONTO, Sept. 26. -- R. S. McLaughlin's Happy Hopes, the only 2-year-old in a field of eight in the featured William Mulock Cup Handicap at Woodbine today, scored by a nose over J. C. Fletcher's 6-year-old campaigner Lindsay. Uvira was third.

In a bid for the farmer's vote, the national Republican leaders are urging the nomination of Sherman J. Lowell of Fredonia, N.Y., for some place on the Republican State ticket, preferably for Controller. Mr. Lowell is a former Master of the National Grange, a member of the United States Tariff Commission, and an advocate of high tariff.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Tomorrow at 2 o'clock in the Ruppert Stadium the opening guns of Newark's first Little World's Series battle will be fired, with Donie Bush directing the manoeuvres of the invading Minneapolis Millers and Al Mamaux evolving the strategy of the Newark Bears.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today modified the conditions it imposed in approving a recent loan of $6,800,000 to the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, deciding to permit an advance of $1,200,000 for payment of interest obligations without the road's complying with the conditions.

BOMBAY, Sept. 26. -- Mahatma Gandhi ended his six-day hunger strike in Yerovda jail at Poona today after being told the British Government had accepted "with great satisfaction" the principal terms of the settlement between the caste Hindus and the Untouchables.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 26. -- Formation of the Hansson Cabinet has now been completed as follows:

Stocks moved lower yesterday in less active trading and Wall Street spoke of the decline as a "corrective reaction." The volume was slightly less than that of Friday, which was the final five-hour day of last week. After opening with fractional gains, the market drifted lower by easy stages throughout the remainder of the day, closing a trifle above the low levels of the day.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26. -- Dr. John T. Dorrance, who, as president of the Campbell Soup Company, amassed a fortune of $115,000,000, died a legal resident of Pennsylvania and his estate owes the Commonwealth $21,000,000 in inheritance taxes, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- The disarmament conference's bureau adjourned today to Oct. 10, when it will take up Arthur Henderson's proposal for the calling of the general commission to discuss Germany's demand for arms equality.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Houses with Eastern connections helped the wheat market several times today and offset the bearish activities of the local element and the spreading operations between Chicago and Winnipeg Prices held within a range of about a cent, fluctuating erratically, with the finish unchanged to 1/8-cent lower.

Mayor McKee and Controller Berry joined in a bitter battle for control of the Board of Estimate in directing the course of city economy yesterday and for more than an hour launched attacks at each other in the coldly polite phrases of a Board of Estimate meeting.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Preparations for united action by electrical manufacturers to take full advantage of an upturn in business which is confidently expected in the near future, were urged tonight by F.A. Merrick, president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, and Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, in addresses before the National Electrical Manufacturing Association, which is meeting here in annual convention.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- J. Donald Brennan, portly young ace of Al Mamaux's championship Newark Bears, sent his mates away to a lead in the opening game of the little world's series today by shutting out the Minneapolis Millers, 11 to 0, with four scattered hits.

William M. Moore's Vander Pool captured the featured Arverne Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Morfair, the odds-on favorite, unseated his jocket at the start. Vander Pool, 9 to 2, won by a length and a half from Cornelius Whitney's Halcyon, and earned a purse of $1,425.
The stenographic transcript of the controversy yesterday between Mayor McKee and Controller Berry, at a meeting of the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate, is as follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Wheat traders expressed today the belief that a practical deadlock had been reached in the market. Prices on the Board of Trade here fluctuated erratically within a range of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel, with local sentiment rather bearish, but there was no material pressure, while buying by houses with Eastern connections was sufficient again to check declines.

The Citizens Budget Commission fought back yesterday against assertions that it was seeking to serve real estate interests alone and attacked Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial's plan for circulation of petitions by the Civil Service Forum against pay reduction of city employes as "sheer sophistry."
CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 27. -- Harmony prevailed at the Republican State Convention here today despite a clash over a proposed prohibition plank.

The directors of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation and those of the American Can Company declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividends on the common shares of their companies. Allied Chemical's payments of $1.50 a share have been maintained since 1927, while American Can has been paying $1 quarterly since Feb. 15, 1930.

There was no feature to the trading in money. An undertone of ease pervaded all sections due to the free supply of funds on offer, contrasted with the light demand. Quotations for all classes remained unchanged.

The manner in which Senator James J. Davis turned over all his personal finances to Fred W. Jones, one of the two men to whom he sold his $600,000 organization contract with the Loyal Order of Moose, was told to the jury in Federal court yesterday as his lottery trial continued before Judge Frank J. Coleman.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- Nicolas Titulesco's resignation as Minister to London and permanent delegate of Rumania at the League of Nations is taken here as making certain not only the imminent signing of the Rumano-Soviet treaty of non-aggression hut the signing of a Franco-Soviet pact of the same nature as well.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Secret Service agents in Boston received word from New York today that two men known as Frank Marlow and Frank J. (Big Frank) Caiola had been arrested there on information provided by an alleged distributer of counterfeit bills.

A plan for the merger of $45,000,000 electric light and power properties in New Hampshire and Vermont, involving the Grafton Power Company and the Connecticut River Power Company, both subsidiaries of the New England Power Association, has been submitted to the Public Service Commission of each State.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, asserted tonight that the re-election of President Hoover was a way to "safe-guard the gains made under prohibition."

Bonds moved Irregularly higher yesterday in small trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover was $8,336,500, the smallest amount for any full day since Aug. 19. Domestic corporation bonds were irregular, while foreign issues and United States Government obligations were steady.

Dr. Charles Norris, Chief Medical Examiner, who resigned last week because of proposed budget reductions affecting his department, resumed his post yesterday at the solicitation of Mayor Joseph V. McKee.

Puerto Rico, a rectangular island about 100 miles long and 30 miles wide, was ceded by Spain to the United States in 1898. The following year it was swept by a damaging hurricane and has been visited almost yearly since then by storms.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27. -- The New York Stock Exchange is considering the adoption of a rule which would prohibit the participation by specialists or their partners in any pool operation which might unfairly influence the specialist in the conduct of his business, Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange, declared tonight in an address before the Industrial Club and the Chamber of Commerce of St. Louis.

ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT SPECIAL, Trinidad, Col., Sept. 27. -- Further appeal to the Progressives of the country was made today by Governor Roosevelt in a speech at Lamy, N.M. As a result he seemed assured of the support of Senator Bronson M. Cutting and the Progressive Republicans of this section and of winning the State's three electoral votes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Secretary of State Stimson said flatly tonight that the United States insists that the adviser to Liberia to be appointed by the League of Nations have sufficient authority to correct conditions of slavery and forced labor reported to exist there.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Prime Minister MacDonald is making an eleventh-hour effort tonight to prevent the impending defections from the coalition government at tomorrow's Cabinet meeting, when three Ministers are expected to resign because of their objections as advocates of free trade to the Ottawa agreements.

The tenement at 431 West Thirty-eighth Street, owned by the Port of New York Authority through its subsidiary, the Badger Realty Company, was put up at auction yesterday and was bid in by the port body's holding company for $35,000. The property was put up in foreclosure on a lien of $32,000 subject to a prior mortgage of $25,000.

The appointment of a committee representative of both major political parties to study the situation of the railroads and to present for public approval recommendations as to what steps are desirable to improve their position was announced at the Hotel Plaza last night by Walter H. Bennett, president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

A vast overgrowth of primitive microscopic cells, considered by biologists to be the original source of all vegetable life, were believed responsible yesterday for the discoloration of the water of Long Island Sound, resulting in the death of thousands of fish.

In an affidavit filed yesterday in the United States District, Court Victor J. Dowling, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division, declared that he had severed his connection with the law firm of Chadbourne, Stanchfield Levy before he was appointed on Aug. 6 as one of the receivers of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

The report of the royal commission on the Canadian railway situation last week was seen as a vindication of his policies by Sir Henry Thornton yesterday in the first interview which he has given here since he resigned from the presidency of the Canadian National Railways on Aug. 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Does anybody know when a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to an industrial corporation on a first mortgage on the land, buildings, machinery, , on a basis of 25 per cent of the actual value of the assets, is obtainable and when it is not, and the procedure to be followed to obtain such a loan?

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Vice President Curtis closed a two-day campaign trip in West Virginia tonight with an address outlining relief measures of the Hoover Administration and praising the Republican tariff.

Both the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company will go on the air with radio accounts of the world's series games which will be played in New York and Chicago, the first broadcasts being of today's game in the Yankee Stadium.
With the Fall apartment renting season nearing an end, several hundred leases were reported closed by brokers yesterday in various parts of Manhattan and hi some suburban districts.

Some of the reports and comments on the political news of the day seem, to imply that the American people are like children in believing seven impossible things before breakfast. Incidents of Goverernor ROOSEVELT'S Western trip, and assurances solemnly given him by local statesmen who have climbed upon his train, are magnified out of all proportion to their real importance.

Annette Hoyt Flanders, who won the gold medal in landscape architecture last Winter at the Architectural League exhibition, opened a one-man show yesterday, with a private view in her new studios at 381 Park Avenue. There will be other private showings through the remainder of the week, and beginning next Monday the exhibition will be open to the public until the end of October.
The Greenwich House Music School of this city will benefit by a recital to be given by Albert Spalding the night of Oct. 7 in the auditorium of the Greenvale School in Roslyn, L.I.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- A complete shake-up in the affairs of the Middle West Utilities Company, holding corporation for the Insull enterprises, was announced tonight by Edward N. Hurley and Charles A. McCulloch, receivers in equity for the $1,000,000,000 group, which serves 6,300,000 customers in thirty-two States and Canada.

According to Captain Felix Dominy of East Hampton, bluefish have never been running better than during the past week, and he reported yesterday that weather conditions were ideal. Captain Dominy, who is looked upon as something of an expert on bluefish around the Hamptons, brought in seventeen blues, weighing from four to seven pounds, while fishing with a friend, Ben Barnes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Assertions that President Hoover has placed 550 persons in the Justice and Commerce Departments under civilservice protection by Executive order were made today by Senator Harrison in a statement Issued through the Democratic National Committee.

Baseball's greatest show of the year, climaxing nearly seven months of intensive training, planning and overheated competition, will go on display today when the New York Yankees, champions of the American League, and the Chicago Cubs, standard hearers of the National League, clash in the Yankee Stadium in the first game of the 1932 world's series.

Indications are that by the end of this year probably 1,000,000 persons will have received relief or other forms of social service from the 900 welfare and health agencies which clear their cases through the Social Service Exchange, according to a statement made public yesterday by William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Farm real estate taxes an acre increased 150 per cent between 1913 and 1930 in the New England States, the Department of Agriculture today reported after a survey of about 4,000 farms in that section.

Assets of the Kreuger Toll Company believed to be worth $3,000,000 or more were juggled in connection with a loan of $180,000 to the late Ivar Kreuger for one of his many companies and now are held by the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation, according to testimony given yesterday before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee.

ATHENS, Sept. 27. -- One hundred and fifty persons are known to have been killed and 1,000 injured on the Greek peninsula of Chalcidice by a series of earthquake shocks that began at 10 o'clock last night and continued with almost unabated violence today.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Prince of Wales's final, appearance in connection with the British Trade Exhibition here today convinced observers of his genius as a salesman, but failed to impress sartorial experts who recalled his reputation as "the well dressed man."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Next week the Treasury Department will reach a decision as to the character of its Oct. 15 financing, which will include the retirement of $333,492,500 in 3 1/8 per cent certificates of indebtedness.

Business on the Stock Exchange fell off sharply yesterday as compared with the day before. The volume was 1,398,000 shares; it was 2,084,000 on Monday. Stocks were highly irregular yesterday, but they closed with moderate gains in the main body as well as in the average of industrials.

Railroad earnings for August reported yesterday showed continued declines in net operating income, although the percentage of decline was reduced in some cases, compared with previous months, by reductions in expenses.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the country last week was 2,178,550 barrels, compared with 2,191,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 13,050 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A drop of 14,700 barrels in the dally output of East Texas was the most important change.

Despite the protests of some of its member lines, the New York Shipping Association, acting for the deep-sea ship lines of New York and other North Atlantic ports, yesterday accepted tae demand of the International Longshoremen's Association for a wage rate of $1.10 an hour for overtime, at a meeting at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.
