Wrapped in part of a blanket and securely bound with heavy rope and twine, the body of Charles S. Bonanno, 37-year-old Manhattan real estate operator, was taken from the East River at the foot of Jay Street, Brooklyn, yesterday by the crew of the government engineering tug Leland.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The home of Judge Webster Thayer, who presided at the Sacco-Vanzetti trial in 1927, was destroyed by an explosion just before dawn today.

The Rev. Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the "Fighting Sixty-ninth" Regiment, who died on June 26, in his sixty-second year, left an estate of more than $2,500. His will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Three armed men held up Dorio Gastano, 62 years old, on his nine-acre farm at Fresh Meadow Road and Seventy-fifth Road in the Flushing-Hillcrest section of Queens last night, felled his wife, Carmelia, 59, with a blow from the butt of a pistol and escaped with the farmer's life savings of more than $10,000.

Efforts to reduce crude oil production and so to prevent a reduction in crude oil prices were being discussed yesterday by proration agencies and oil company executives throughout the country. The leading crude oil purchasing companies are said to be reluctant to make a reduction in crude oil prices just now, but the consensus is that unless production is further reduced a price cut is inevitable.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Sept. 27. -- Mexico will serve notice of withdrawal on the League of Nations in the immediate future, according to information in Senate circles to be published tomorrow by Universal.

Province of Saskatchewan. A new issue of $2,500,000 Province of Saskatchewan twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1952, will be offered today at 96.48, to yield 5.80 per cent, by a group of Canadian banks and investment houses, of which the Dominion Securities Corporation is manager.

Negotiations are under way for the organization of an opera company, headed by outstanding stars like Maria Jeritza, Beniamino Gigli, Feodor Chaliapin, John Charles Thomas and Titta Ruffo, to present opera this season at the Casino Theatre in competition with the Metropolitan Opera, it was revealed yesteray.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 27. -- Receipts of hogs here and in the West today exceeded trade requirements and prices dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, pigs and underweight stock showing as much as 50 cents under yesterday's market. Shippers land others were virtually out of the market for weights under 175 pounds.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) . -- Roger Peckinpaugh will manage the Cleveland Indians in 1933 for his sixth consecutive year, with Bib Falk, pilot of the Toledo Mud Hens this season, as his assistant.

One-year 6 per cent notes of the Government of the Dominion of Canada in the amount of $60,000,000 were placed on the market yesterday by a banking syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Fortes Corporation and were reported entirely sold before noon.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27. -- Dr. Robert B. Greenough, consulting surgeon of the Massachusetts General Hospital, asserted today in an address at the Clinical Congress of the Connecticut Medical Society that 60 per cent of cancer cures were reported at the hospital over five years in low malignancy types and 33 per cent in medium malignancy types, but that there were practically no cures in cases where tumors contained high malignancy cells.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Franklin W. Fort, chairman of the Home Loan Bank System, said today he had reported to President Hoover that all twelve of the branch banks would be opened for business by Oct. 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Employe stock ownership plans were criticized as "packed with dynamite" by Dr. C.C. Balderston, Professor of Industry at the Wharton School of Commerce and Finance at the University of Pennsylvania, in an address today before the annual conference of the Life Office Management Association.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- Chancellor von Papen tonight issued a denial of all charges made against Germany last Sunday by Premier Herriot of France. Herr von Papen contended France was unwilling to come to an understanding with Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Without taking a stand for or against the labor record of President Hoover, Vice President Curtis, Governor Roosevelt or Speaker Garner, the American Federation of Labor submitted to all of its members a detailed report showing the position each of these candidates has taken on questions in which organized labor is interested.

TOKYO, Sept. 27. -- The Soviet Government is reported negotiating with a Japanese company for the export to Japan of 20,000 tons of Russian wheat. Although grain production in Russia is inadequate for her domestic needs, this transaction is proposed to pay for Russian purchases of industrial materials from Japan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- In a speech before the Chicago Bar Association today, Norman Thomas, the Socialist candidate for President, said that the "strange adventures of the Insull holding companies illustrate the racketeering stage which capitalism has reached in its dying hours and the necessity for public ownership of public utilities.

State leaders began yesterday to prepare for the Democratic State Convention at Albany next week, with the backers of Mayor John Boyd Thacher of the capital city threatening a floor fight and Alfred E. Smith looming more likely as the man to place the name of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in nomination.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Ral Parr's Her Grace galloped to an easy victory over three other fillies and mares in the featured Martha Washington Purse of a mile and seventy yards today at Havre de Grace.
ATLANTA, Sept. 27. -- Clark Howell Sr. accepted late today the appointment to membership on the national non-partisan railroad commission, whose personnel was announced in New York.

Mayor McKEE is one of the leading advocates of the Triborough Bridge. Last Spring, when Mayor WALKER was intent on making "bookkeeping gestures" to please the bankers, it was the then President of the Board of Aldermen who gave the resolution rescinding some $213,000,000 of public improvements that title, and at the same time objected to the proposal to stop work on the bridge.

Next Monday the school at 441 Madison. Avenue will reopen for its fourth season. The pupils who have already been accepted must be far more eager than the traditional schoolboy dragging his heels. This school, the Neighborhood Playhouse Studios, takes young people of promise who want to learn dancing, acting and all the arts related to the theatre.

Mixed Dressing. Win, lose or draw, this will probably go down as the Strange Interlude among world's series. Strategy, scouting and inside stuff are just matters of dark laughter at the moment. The Cubs are going into a world's series and the man who probably knows more about them than anybody else will be in the opposite dugout in charge of the rival forces.

The Appellate Division reserved decision, yesterday, after bearing two hours of argument on the appeal of the Board of Elections, Tammany Hall and the Socialist party from the recent decision of Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan, holding that Acting Mayor Joseph MeKee is entitled to hold office until Jan. 1, 1934.

The story of his career in boxing is told by Gene Tunney in "A Man Must Fight," published today by Houghton, Mifflin. Tunney, the undefeated, retired heavyweight champion of the world, says in his book that Jack Dempsey suffered a "spiritual tragedy" through fighting him when he might have fought and defeated the Negro contender, Harry Wills.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27. -- Closing with a rush, the Roslyn polo team turned back Long Island on Meadow Brook's Whitney Field today to ride into the final round of the twelve-gold tournament for the Autumn plates. The score was 13 -- 9.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- The stock market today recovered after yesterday's declines despite several discouraging factors. News of Wall Street's weakness yesterday and uncertainty over the international political situation caused an irregular opening, but repurchasing after yesterday's declines soon developed and the Bourse closed without losses and in some instances with gains on the day.

President Hoover must lead his own campaign with vigor if he is to be reelected in November, Samuel S. Koenig, veteran New York County Republican chairman, said last night at a meeting of the New York Young Republican Club at the National Republican Club.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Winged Foot Golf Club team of John G. Anderson and Mike Brady has made more or less a habit of winning the amateur-pro event that precedes the Westchester open championship.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 27 (AP) -- After a few days' lull Farmers' Holiday Association members today again resorted to highway picketing in an effort to keep farm products from markets.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Assertions that "every State west of the Mississippi" would be carried by Governor Roosevelt were made before Illinois Democrats today by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

The schooner Effie M. Morrissey slowly plied its way through New York Bay yesterday afternoon amid the shrieking whistles of other ships in the harbor which saluted her captain, Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, on his return with the schooner from a fifteen-week expedition to the Arctic Circle, where a monument to Admiral Peary was erected.

Chicago's entrants in the world's series arrived on a special train at Pennsylvania Station at 9:58 yesterday morning. There were about a hundred in the party and a crowd of about the same size was on hand to greet the invading host.

The Rev. Charles A. Weber, 64 years old, pastor of the Moravian Church at Castleton Corners, S.I., and his wife Anna, 62, were seriously injured yesterday afternoon when an automobile in which they were riding crashed into, a telephone pole on Clove Road, near Serpentine Road, Concord.

Nervous fluctuations continued in yesterday's trading on the Cotton Exchange, and after frequent erratic changes over a range of $1 a bale the list ended 3 points higher to 7 points lower than on Monday.

Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction for the last five years, handed his resignation to Mayor McKee at the City Hall yesterday afternoon. He will leave office Friday and the next day will become executive vice president of the National Broadcasting Company.

When Governor ROOSEVELT signed last year the bill creating half a dozen needless Supreme Court judges in the Brooklyn and Long Island District he expressed the pious hope that the voters would prevent the nomination of unfit men. But the bipartisan deal for the division of the judicial spoils went through without any real let or hindrance.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27. -- Following their debate here last night on the merits of the prohibition planks of their parties, Senator Robert J. Bulkley of Cleveland, Democratic candidate for re-election, and Attorney General Gilbert Bettman of Cincinnati, his Republican opponent, renewed their controversy today as they warmed up for another prohibition debate scheduled for Thursday night in Cleveland.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Lord Essendon, chairman of Furness, Withy Co., told the American Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon today that the present deep-rooted depression in shipping demanded international cooperation as an alternative to the departure from the British policy of equal treatment for ships of all nations.

Resumption of activities throughout the country resulted in a general increase of nearly 2 1/2 percentage points in the rate of steel ingot production throughout the country in the week ended on Monday, according to compilations by Dow, Jones Co., which credit the United States Steel Corporation with a gain of 3 1/2 per cent, and between 1/2 and 1 per cent for the independent companies.

Buyers' Total Still Over Year Ago. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week, but remained above the total reached in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- A Syracuse team that was composed largely of sophomores went out on Archbold Stadium Field Saturday night in a pouring rain, ran into much stiffer opposition from a scrappy Clarkson Tech eleven than it had bargained on and fumbled so atrociously as to throw a big scare into its coaches and the 5,000 who saw the game.

Two tracts comprising 11,000 lots east of Mays Landing, N.J., have been bought from Atlantic City Shore Gardens, Inc., Max Germain, president, by the United States Development Corporation, Jacob J. Greenbaum, president, for immediate development as a Summer bungalow colony, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Dr. William de Kleine, medical director of the Red Cross, was making contact tonight with the army and navy surgeons general to locate needed supplies for Puerto Rico.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP REX, AT SEA, Sept. 27. -- Amid the strains of a military band playing the Fascist hymn while 5,000 persons stood at attention, the 50,000-ton liner Rex sailed on her maiden voyage for New York from Genoa at noon today.
Europe has accepted Ellsworth Vines Jr. as the world's greatest tennis player on the strength of his successive victories over Henri Cochet of France, former world's champion, during the past season.

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Radio messages of mysterious origin, reported by an amateur operator today, told of having heard from the missing Japanese good-will fliers Sunday afternoon, about twenty-four hours after they should have landed at Nome, Alaska.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Little America, fast-breaking filly owned by Mrs. V.M. Duncan of New York, led from start to finish in winning the featured event at Lincoln Fields today, a six-furlong dash.
TOKYO, Sept. 27. -- Press telegrams announcing that Nanking will cease payment of Japan's share of the Boxer indemnity are not officially confirmed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Three of the five destroyers authorized by the Seventy-first Congress, the construction of which was held up by the President's order as a measure of economy, will be laid down shortly at the navy yards in New York, Philadelphia and in Boston, Secretary Adams announced today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been the proud boast of free America that she was free of an irresponsible secret police power. No imperial ukase, no lettres de cachet in her story!

The experience of plant executives in spreading work during the depression probably will lead to a more general adoption of the five-day week as a regular operating schedule, according to the findings of the National Industrial Conference Board, whose survey of the shorter work week was made public yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to withdraw a passage printed on pages 388 and 389 of my book "The Spirit of World Politics" as based on insufficient evidence and as disputed by strong counter-evidence now brought to my attention. This passage referred to Professor Albert Einstein's address in New York on March 4, 1931, from which I quoted, on the strength of my memory, two sentences as follows:

Society girls and stage folk, in humorous versions of what the correctly dressed young woman will not wear this season, were featured at the fashion show which formally opened the new Tailored Woman Shop, 729 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.
Richard J. Comerford and Catherine McMurtry gave to Mary Costello a mortgage for $5,366, due three years hence, at 6 per cent on the three-story frame dwelling at 317 W. 26th St.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was quiet today, and in the absence of support nearly all sections were dull. The assented war loan was still active in British funds, but dropped on profit-taking. Others were in less investment demand.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 6 (AP) (By Mail). -- One hundred and fifty thousand Chinese have died in the last five months of cholera, dread disease of Asia, which has run over China this year in the most severe epidemic since 1919.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- In the expectation that Legislatures in many States will pass laws, enabling building and loan associations, life insurance companies and savings banks, now ineligible, to become members of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, the system's board has devised a plan whereby the institutions concerned can subscribe for stock "conditionally."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- William C. Ferguson, president judge of Common Pleas Court No. 3 and senior judge in length of service in the Philadelphia courts, died in Chestnut Hill Hospital today in his sixty-ninth year. Judge Ferguson under-went an operation for appendicitis last Monday.

POONA, India, Sept. 27 (AP). -- A benign but toothless smile lighted the features of the Mahatma M.K. Gandhi today as he watched the Indian children celebrating his sixty-third birthday -- by the Hindu calendar -- in the Yeronda jail yard.
Joe McCarthy and Charlie Grimm, managers of the New York Yankees and Chicago Cubs respectively, last night made the following statements for THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The two finalists of the 1924 championship, Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd and Miss Mary K. Browne, passed out of the 1932 women's national golf tournament at the Salem Country Club today.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles B. Alexander will arrive today on the Ile de France and go to her home at 4 West Fifty-eighth Street. With her is Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 27. -- Chattanooga, Southern Association champion, won the Dixie series today, 4 games to 1, clinching the title, by defeating Beaumont, Texas League champion, 7 to 3.

HAVANA, Sept. 27. -- Dr. Clemente Vazquez Bello, president of the Cuban Senate and an aspirant for the Presidency in the 1934 election, and three prominent members of the Opposition party were slain and two others were gravely wounded as a wave of assassinations swept over Havana today, taking its toll both in the administration and in the Opposition ranks.

In an effort to put life into the Eastern campaign to re-elect President Hoover, Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, will arrive here today for conference with leaders at the Waldorf-Astoria headquarters of the committee.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Mrs. Richard P. Limburg from Century tallied the best gross score, an 86, to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament over the Tamarack Country Club course today. The unfavorable weather reduced the entire list considerably and many of those entered did not return cards.

The Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, will arrive on the French liner Iie de France today to make several addresses here. Other prominent passengers include the Right Rev. Mgr. Filippe Bernardini of Washington, dean of the faculty of canon law at the Catholic University of America; Sir Philip Sassoon of England, Irvin Cobb, author; Frank Hague, Mayor of Jersey City; Anthony H.G. Fokker, airplane designer, and Grace Moore, singer.

The withdrawal of privileges hitherto enjoyed here by non-quota foreign, students violates the spirit of welcome shown them by our own students as well as by university and college authorities. It might be argued that a foreigner who had not, in part at least, worked his way through college could not quite know our educational advantages.
Sales of four apartment houses in the Bronx were reported yesterday by J. Lemle Sons, brokers in the deals. All of the purchases were said to be by investors.

An immediate reduction in the electric light rates to effect an annual saving of $19,000,000, or about $12 a family, for the 800,000 domestic consumers in the city was urged yesterday by Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, in a letter to Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission.

After an extensive tour abroad in search of cosmopolitan talent, Mr. Carroll has set up a new edition of the "Vanities," which was displayed at the Broadway Theatre last evening. If you con your program carefully, you will discover in it "charming," "sophisticated" and "rising" stars from all the more famous capitals, one of whom has given three command performances before the King and Queen of England.

Max Schmeling will sail on the liner Bremen for Germany at midnight on Friday, richer by more than $55,000 as a consequence of his spectacular eight-round knockout victory over Mickey Walker. The outcome makes his path to another bout with Jack Sharkey and the world's heavyweight title less obstructed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, told newspaper men after a conference with President Hoover today that he had reported retail sales in the automobile business during August had experienced their "first real rise since the depression began."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Tariff Commission listened to charges today that methods used in selling Russian asbestos in this country violated the unfair trade practices section of the 1930 tariff law.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 27. -- A hurricane swept through Puerto Rico today and lumbered on, leaving a death toll that probably will mount into hundreds, and property damage that will finally be calculated in the many millions of dollars.

Germany's aspirations for equality in armaments, as expressed in recent diplomatic correspondence with the governments of her opponents in the World War, are justified by the need for national defense and as a measure for her internal recovery and reestablishment of her international standing, according to Gustav Krupp von Bohlen, head of the famous Krupp works at Essen.

Danny Alvino, right guard on the Fordham University reserve eleven, received a slight concussion of the brain in a scrimmage between the second team and the freshman eleven at Fordham Field yesterday. He complained of dizziness last night and Dr. Gerald P. Carroll, university physician, examined him.

While State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. was requesting Eisenberg Farms, Inc., Brooklyn milk dealers, to amplify their charges that the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association was endeavoring to eliminate competition by wholesale price-fixing, Commissioner of Health Wynne announced yesterday that he had been assured by the emergency committee of the New York milk-shed that there would be no milk strike.
Speaker John N. Garner, Democratic candidate for Vice President, declared frankly yesterday that he would keep silent on immediate cash payment of the bonus for the duration of the national campaign.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Merger of the Milwaukee (Wis.) Tool and Forge Company, the Pressed Products Company of Napoleon, Ohio, and the Saturn Electric Water Heater Company of Bryan, Ohio, was announced today by a citizens' committee of Defiance, where the new concern will set up operations.

Mr. JAMES J. WALKER, sometime Mayor of New York, sailed yesterday from Genoa for his native village. It is good to know that he has almost recovered from the effects of his arduous labors and struggles. It is a pleasure to hear that a personage so thoroughly modern has demonstrated the falseness of the old Latin saw: "They who cross the sea change their sky, not their mind."

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Oregonian tomorrow will carry a signed statement by Paul M. Callicotte, widely known Portland mountaineer, in which he declares his belief that he is the man who placed the suitcase bomb in the San Francisco Preparedness Day parade on July 22, 1916, which cost ten lives and sent Tom Mooney and Warren K. Billings to prison for life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The Re construction Finance Corporation in a sudden burst of speed today authorized loans of $13,000,000 for construction of a highway and railroad bridge across the Mississippi River at New Orleans, $105,000 for additions to a municipal power plant at Madison, S.D.; $315,093 for the relief needs of Atlanta, Ga., and $86,160 for similar purposes in Klamath County, Ore.

Underlying strength, in the share market yesterday did not relieve the monotonous dullness of trading on the Stock Exchange. The volume was small, even by comparison with the drab days of the recent past, and the price movements were negligible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Three days remain for the German Government to reach a decision as to whether it will meet the $8,000,000 due to the United States Friday on mixed claims and Army of Occupation costs.
VIENNA, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The earthquake that rocked the Greek peninsula of Chalcidice last night was also felt in Bucharest, where the tremors lasted twelve minutes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Assertions that "Roosevelt is a big vote-getter for Hoover," made by Republican leaders in States traversed by the Democratic nominee, were given out today by Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The national executive committee of the Labor party will present a report at the annual conference at Leicester next week condemning the national government which, it says, has obtained a further lease on power by "exploiting patriotic sentiments and by panic-mongering calumny and misrepresentation."

Not So New As Solid. Mr. HOOVER may unintentionally be lending aid and comfort to the Demecrats by urging change and novelty. In his telegram of congratulation to Messrs. WEBER and FIELDS he said that the country would benefit greatly by the invention of a "resoundingly good joke."

More than 700 students at Columbia University will be affected by the ruling of William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, forbidding foreign students admitted to the United States on a non-quota basis to engage in part-time or vacation employment as a means of paying their way through American educational institutions, it was revealed yesterday by officials of the university.

Mr. and Mrs. William D. Bloodgood of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mabel Lansing Bloodgood, to Guy B. Bostwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy O'Donnell Bostwick of Suffern, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- William G. McAdoo, former Secretary of the Treasury, who is the Democratic nominee for the Senate in California, will be opposed by the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment. The decision was announced today by Jouett Shouse, president of the association, who added that the organization would support Tallant Tubbs, the Republican Senatorial nominee.

BUCHAREST, Sept 27. -- The resignation of Nicolas Titulesco as Rumania's permanent delegate to the League of Nations and Minister to London has created a sensation here and is likely to have serious political consequences.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Negotiations between the railway companies and their workers concerning wage rates will open on Friday. The four big railway groups are expected to submit claims for "substantial relief" in respect of labor costs.

Relying upon the prospect of a Court of Appeals decision paving the way for nomination of its own candidate for Mayor at an election to be held Nov. 8 to choose a successor to former Mayor James J. Walker, Tammany Hall is using the Mayoralty ambitions of Controller Berry to place Mayor McKee in a position where he will be unacceptable, it was reliably reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- President Hoover appointed today Charles R. Crisp of Georgia, acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee at the last session of Congress, to fill the Democratic place on the Tariff Commission made vacant by the recent death of Commissioner Lincoln Dixon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Hope for the safety of the Japanese aviators who started on a flight from Tokyo to San Francisco was raised here this afternoon when the Navy Department received an intercepted Japanese radio message that a plane was signalling at the head of the River "Mantanu" in Alaska, but later it appeared the signals might have come from two lost American aviators.

Manhattan's east side -- not generally recognized as a part of the farm belt -- was the scene of two "harvest festivals" yesterday afternoon. Both festivals were celebrated by farmers of rather tender years, the average age being somewhere between 7 and 14, and both were held amid displays of produce which, for sheer profusion, as well as for the size of individual specimens, would have shed lustre on a respectable county fair.

What promises to be the first move in railroad consolidation since the heads of the Eastern trunk lines agreed last week to accept the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of unification for this region was disclosed yesterday to be under contemplation by the Baltimore Ohio group of the four systems set up under the plan.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28. -- Asserting that after a two months' search they had located the wreck of the sunken steamship Merida off the Virginia capes, Theodore Miller and Lawrence Bowdoin, students in the Johns Hopkins School of Engineering, and David Hughes, a graduate, have returned here.
Two railroads with adjustment plans for security holders announced progress in these plans yesterday and at the same time issued warnings on what would result should the plans fail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Francis King Carey in THE TIMES, entitled "Democratic Shortcomings," seems to challenge as irrational those who may disagree with him. His vote for Mr. Hoover in 1928 and his declared intention to vote for him this year are personal privileges which no one will deny him the right to exercise.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- C. E. Nicholson, famous designer of racing yachts, is preparing plans for a 200-ton steel boat conforming to the class of the universal rule for submission to William Lawrence Stephenson, owner of White Heather II. Although it would be possible to offer a challenger for the America's Cup with such a craft, neither Mr. Stephenson nor Mr. Nicholson has given any hint that this is the intention.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Johnny Farrell and George Kerrigan found the going a bit easier than the others in the field of eighty-nine who competed at Wykagyl today in the first thirty-six holes of the Westchester open golf championship, tying for the lead with cards of 150.

United States Ambassador Walter E. Edge will arrive from France today on the United States liner Manhattan. Other prominent passengers are Professor Julian S. Huxley, author and scientist, and M.B. Lehman, Paris banker. The Manhattan's list also includes:

The first of a series of reports on the need for making more adequate provision for the training of gifted children in the high schools was made public yesterday by Harold G. Campbell, Deputy Associate Superintendent of Schools. The report deals with the teaching of modern foreign languages, and recommends a two-fold grouping of pupils, with the average and above average in one group and the slow pupils in the other.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Cub fans, parked by the thousands around radio sets and scoreboards, took the defeat of their heroes today in the first game of the world's series philosophically.

Speaking at the annual opening exercises of Columbia University yesterday in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, criticized both President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt for what he characterized as their dodging of the three big problems upon the solution of which world recovery depends.

Disapproval or a proposal to increase workmen's compensation insurance rates by about 9.2 per cent on Oct. 1, as urged by companies writing such policies, was announced yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Insurance Superintendent.

Contracts representing expenditures of more than $27,000 were awarded yesterday by the Board of Education for alterations and repairs at school buildings in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, and plans were approved for expenditures of about $138,000 for furniture, alterations and repairs for schools in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Although the mechanistic theory will not explain everything about illness, clinical medicine will make most progress if it adheres to the mechanistic idea in its researches, according to Dr. Rustin McIntosh, Carpentier Professor of Diseases of Children at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and physician-in-chief of Babies' Hospital, who addressed the students of the medical school yesterday morning at the opening exercises of the academic year.

H. G. Wells's new novel will be published in England next month with the title, "The Bulphington of Bulp." Doubleday Doran, publishers for Mr. Wells in this country, list it simply as "novel," with no title given. Titles change on the way across the Atlantic.

JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Addressing a Republican rally in the Civic Auditorium, Secretary Hurley declared tonight that Franklin D. Roosevelt "has not had the nerve to come out in the open" on the bonus question.

The Standard Oil Company of NewYork, Inc., yesterday reduced the tank - wagon and service - station prices of gasoline 1 cent a gallon in the New York metropolitan district, Long Island, Westchester, Connecticut, Albany and Buffalo. In Boston a reduction of 1 1/2 cents a gallon was made.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 28. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of Upperville, Va., and New York annexed the first championship award as the annual Fall Bryn Mawr Horse Show opened today. Her Bon Diable carried off the rosette in the thoroughbred colt class, reserve going to Mrs. Dean Bedford from the Fox Hall Farm.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- The bond market predominated at today's session of the Boerse, with mortgage and treasury bonds and municipal loans advancing. Stocks were relatively firm after losses earlier in the week, but the turnover remained small. The merger of the Meyer banking firm with Schwartz, Goldschmidt Co. aroused hopes for increased activity by the combined house in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Chairman Summers of the House Judiciary Committee said today that "resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment was a foregone conclusion" and that it may be considered at the coming session of Congress.

Connie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, last night announced the sale of outfielders AlSimmons and Mule Haas and Infielder Jimmy Dykes to the Chicago White Sox for an unannounced amount of cash.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Senator Smoot of Utah, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, asserted today that the Republican party in the coming December session would not increase taxes but would make radical reduction in governmental expenditures to balance the budget.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Six institutes in regional fields of international affairs, maintained at different colleges and universities, will be merged with that at the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va., it was announced today by Chester D. Pugsley, founder of the institutes.

Reports to date indicate that gross and net operating incomes of the railroads in August showed not only a substantial increase, partly seasonal, from the preceding month but also smaller percentages of declines from the same month last year than were reported for July.
Mary T. Higgins gave a mortgage for $3,000, due in three years, at 6 per cent, to the trustees of David L. Whitmore on 284 Wadsworth Av.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Representative Hamilton Fish discussed with President Hoover today the keynote speech which Mr. Fish will make before the Republican State convention at Buffalo on Monday, and afterward denied reports that the address would deal with communism or the bonus army.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28. -- The first move to apprehend the persons supposedly implicated in the bombing of the home of Judge Webster Thayer, presiding justice at the Sacco-Vanzetti trial, was made this afternoon when, the police asked for a check-up of three automobiles, two with New York registrations and one registered as of California.

BUFFALO, Sept. 28. -- "The transportation problem of today is the result of an orgy of subsidized transport," said J. J. Pelley, president of the New Haven Railroad, in an address here today before the Great Lakes Regional Advisory Board.

Fourteen parcels of real estate in Manhattan and the Bronx were put up at-auction sales yesterday as the result of liquidation proceedings. All the offerings were bid in by parties of interest who acted to protect their mortgage liens.

The crew of the Coast Guard station at Potunk, near Westhampton, L.I., has gone on a fish diet and for the next few days will have nothing but bluefish served as the piece de resistance and all because one of the members proclaimed himself a gourmet and said he craved a greater variety in his food than had been served in recent days.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Although trading on the Stock Exchange was still restricted today, the tendency of prices was better following less disturbing foreign news and encouraging reports of American business. British Government funds attracted renewed buying, and most issues regained recent losses.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- While about 150 persons awaited questioning here today in connection with Federal raids last night the glistening bars and gambling equipment with which they were familiar, either as operators or patrons, were being carted away to warehouses.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28. -- Malcolm Farmer, Chairman of Athletics at Yale, tonight announced the appointment of graduate advisory committees in all five major sports.

What has become of the fine old-fashioned party leaders who sneered at the absurd pretensions of the other side and "claimed everything"? Particularly among Republicans just now are found a surprising number of faint hearts and feeble knees, not to say cold feet.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Sept. 1 shows the following principal changes during August. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Sept. 28 (AP). -- William G. McAdoo, Democratic nominee for Senator, announced today that he "will not accept dictation" of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment on the liquor question.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Further evidence that Franco-American trade relations are gradually improving was seen today in a promise by the Ministry of Commerce to increase substantially the quota on radio equipment imported from the United States. This came as a direct result of the establishment by the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris of a bureau to control distribution licenses or import permits among accredited representatives and agents of American radio manufacturers in France.

Irresponsible tenants and the general public can be made tax conscious by the use of "double" leases Hinder which a tenant will pay a certain fixed sum as rental and another sum based upon the tax rate on the rented property, George L. Allin, real estate lawyer, told members of the Penn Zone Property Owners' Association yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Governor Clinton.

GENEVA, Sept. 28 -- The sudden departure tonight of Baron Konstantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, followed an announcement that Premier Edouard Herriot of France would address the League of Nations Assembly tomorrow.

The contract under which the Moose charity balls were promoted, obligating the propagation department of the order to pay out many thousands of dollars, was repudiated by three members of the Moose Supreme Council in Federal Court yesterday to support the contention of Senator James J. Davis, on trial for alleged violation of the lottery law, that he knew nothing of the lottery aspect of the affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Hoboken Manufacturers Railroad Company amended its application before the Interstate Commerce Commission today to issue $160,000 securities to modernize its terminal facilities. The railroad detailed amounts to be spent for the purchase of locomotives and flat cars, rearrangement of terminal facilities, strengthening of a trestle and the purchase and installation of a freight car elevator; also to dredge at its New York harbor terminal.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. James Arniel of the Woodway Country Club, Stamford, Conn., won the husband-and-wife golf championship of the metropolitan district at the Green Brook Country Club today after tying at 84 with Mr. and Mrs. Henry March of the North Shore Country Club, Glen Head, L. I.

Jacques Deval, the French play-wright and novelist, will arrive on the Bremen today to attend the final rehearsals and opening performance of his play, "Mademoiselle," in which Grace George, Alice Brady and A. E. Matthews will appear at Princeton, N. J., on Saturday night.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28. -- From the air the Puerto Rico storm area looks as follows:

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 28. -- Caterwaul, an early season challenger for 2-year-old turf honors from Cornelius Whitney's barn, galloped back into the championship picture today with a striking triumph over twenty other leading juveniles in the twentieth running of the $20,000 added Eastern Shore Handicap at Havre de Grace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No subject of Investigation is more difficult than the effect of exchange conditions on trade. But these facts stand out in consequence of the investigation by the Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures of the House of Representatives:

Max Schmeling's next local ring engagement will be against Primo Camera, Italian giant, or Max Baer, California heavyweight, according to present plans, the match being scheduled for next January or February. In the meantime Schmeling, who sails tomorrow night at midnight for Germany, will do no fighting.

MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Work in the cotton mills of Lancashire, which has been suspended for some time as a result of a textile workers' strike, began generally to be resumed today following the signing of a peace pact yesterday.

Serge Koussevitzky, who arrived yesterday on the Ile de France after a Summer spent in Europe, revealed that he was planning to present his usual quota of symphonic novelties this season, his ninth as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

Park Avenue continues to be a favorite residential thoroughfare among those seeking extensive living quarters this Fall, according to indications contained in long lists of new rentals announced by brokers and managing agents yesterday. Home hunting was widespread throughout the city, but it showed a tendency to centre on Park Avenue.

With Mr. COOLIDGE as chairman, a committee of five distinguished members has been formed for the purpose of "examining all phases of "the transportation problem and "recommending a solution." It is fitting that the initiative in organizing this committee should have been taken by a score of great insurance companies and by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The race, it seems, is not always to the swift, so that when a surprisingly agile Bruin contrived to get away to a flying start, he erred when he thought he could outgallop the hunter's barrage which was being laid down at his heels.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Chicago Democrats are preparing for a welcome Friday to Governor Roosevelt which they think will eclipse the local demonstrations for Wilson and Bryan as Presidential candidates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A new intercoastal carriers' agreement providing for a surcharge of 3 per cent on both eastbound and westbound cargo, except refrigerated cargo, passengers' baggage and automobiles, was approved today by the Shipping Board.

At first it was a game, and every one had a fine time, but the situation on Pier 60, North River, has reached a point where longshoremen go about their work mumbling and muttering. Hurrying sailors pause suddenly to gaze dreamily into the dark heights of the pier.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Trial of a suit asking $105,000 for engineering services in planning a proposed $40,000,000 stadium which was to have been built between the Harlem River and Fifth Avenue, north of 138th Street, in New York City, was started here late this afternoon before Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, the leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was the guest of honor last night at a private dinner at the Unity Club in Brooklyn. His fellow guests included John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, and many leaders of Jewish philanthropic activities in the borough, headed by Presiding Justice Edward J. Lazansky of the Appellate Division and Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May.

With fans from virtually every section of the country included in their ranks, in addition to a few from Canada, spectators at yesterday's opening world series game were slow in arriving, undoubtedly because of the unsettled weather that prevailed throughout the morning.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 28. -- A grave series of risings against Manchukuo and the Japanese, ranging from Manchouli, near the Siberian border in Heilungkiang Province, to Angangki, 400 miles eastward and just south of the Japanese military base at Tsitsihar, and on to Paiyantala, 250 miles to the south, was reported in dispatches from Manchuria today.
More than 160 defendants seized in 300 cordial-shop liquor raids two weeks ago were arraigned before United States Commissioner O'Neill yesterday and one-fourth of them were freed.

Sentences of three months each in the workhouse were imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on a Hindu herb "doctor" and two Negroes for practicing medicine without licenses, and a similar sentence on another Negro for a similar offense was suspended.

OYSTER BAY, L,. I., Sept. 28. -- Mrs. Charles B. F, McCann, exhibiting dahlias, outdoor flowers, fruit and vegetables from Sunken Orchard, her estate near here, won today seventeen blue ribbons and nine red ribbons in the first day's judging of the annual Fall flower and vegetable show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society being held in the auditorium of St. Dominick's Roman Catholic Church here.

Privately owned shipyards have offered to finance the construction of three naval destroyers until June 30, the end of the government's fiscal year, as an inducement to the Navy Department to order them at an early date, the National Council of American Shipbuilders announced yesterday.

Reports from Paris and leading stores throughout this country on women's fashions were presented yesterday at a luncheon meeting of The Fashion Group at the Hotel Ambassador. About 300 persons attended. The fashion reports were submitted by Miss Marion Taylor, president of the group.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28. -- Puerto Rico began the work, of rehabilitation in her hurricane-wrecked areas today, hardly twenty-four hours behind the tropical storm that had killed 200 or more islanders and wrought millions of dollars' damage.
ABOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Her husband's campaign tour became almost a Christmas shopping trip today for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, told an audience here tonight that only ten States would have to enact legislation for liquor control if the Eighteenth Amendment was repealed.

McCOOK, Neb., Sept. 28. -- Exchanging compliments and expressing approval of each other's views on public questions, Governor Roosevelt and Senator George W. Norris, Progressive Republican, joined today in urging disregard for party lines in this year's Presidential election.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Harvard will take the field against Buffalo on Saturday in its opening game with at least four of its players not in uniform, according to an announcement made today by Dr. Brader, team surgeon.
MAYOR JOE McKEE threw out the first ball. It was a change of pace, the same delivery he used when he took charge of things at City Hall.

All that Mayor MCKEE says about Commissioner PATTERSON is true and to the point. His retirement as head of the Department of Correction is a loss both to the city and to the cause of prison reform. His original appointment to that post was at the hands of Mayor WALKER, who deserves credit for choosing so competent a Commissioner and giving him such constant support.

While the share market made some progress yesterday, the trading was of a routine and colorless character. Stocks were allowed to drift aimlessly a good part of the day and the fact that their trend was upward indicated that the line of least resistance lay in that direction since there were no powerful impulses on either side of the market.

The hurricane in the West Indies and the earthquake in Greece and the Balkans have made doubly striking the feebleness of man in the presence of such convulsions of air, earth and sea. There are memories of like disasters in comparatively recent years in these regions of the earth: the violent hurricane of 1928 in Puerto Rico and the earthquake centring in Corinth in the same year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Complaints of dumping of steel products and rubber-soled shoes received from American manufacturers have led the Customs Bureau to begin an investigation into the alleged unfair practices of foreign exporters and to require bond from importers of these articles.

SCARBOROUGH-ON - HUDSON, Sept. 28. -- Robert H. Brooke and Enos Booth shared the honors of the first day's play in the annual metropolitan seniors golf championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Eastern bulls for the third straight day came to the assistance of the wheat market today when support was apparently needed. An early break on the Board of Trade here was followed by aggressive buying by commission houses, part of which came from the same interests that had been active on the buying side on Monday and again yesterday.

Discovery by Barnum Brown, curator of fossil reptiles at the American Museum of Natural History, of the most complete skeleton found so far of a nodosaurus, a species of armored dinosaur that roamed over the Western plains some 100,000,000 years ago, in the age of reptiles, was revealed yesterday at the museum by Walter Granger, curator of fossil mammals.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 28 -- Summer colonists here have cooperated with the townspeople in arranging the thirteenth annual exhibition of handiwork which opened today at Sedgwick Hall under the auspices of the Lenox Library Association, of which Grenville Lindall Winthrop is president.
McCOOK, Neb., Sept. 28. -- Following is the text of the speech "by Franklin D. Roosevelt today at the meeting attended, by Senator Norris, Independent Republican:

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The political tension created by Chancellor Von Papen's reply to Premier Herriot on disarmament, coinciding with the impending month-end settlements, resulted in a steady decline of quotations at today's session of the Bourse. Losses in some of the leading stocks were particularly sharp, notably shares of the Bank of France, which were down 195 francs; Suez Canal, down 140, and Credit Foncier, off 100.

BOMBAY, Sept. 28. -- The formal consultations among the caste Hindus having ended, encouragement a now being given to the opening of their temples to the Untouchables. A number of temples were opened to them in Bombay today, but others still remain strictly orthodox.
The peripatetic library of the Bronx began rolling along its bookish way yesterday morning after a brief inspection at Borough Hall by Borough President Henry Bruckner and a few other officials.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- Three of the most pressing problems facing the Kremlin today are, first, the State campaign to mobilize grain and food for the needs of urban and construction workers and the army; second, the development of Soviet trade, and third, the production of consumers' goods, all of which are closely connected.

The Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, England, arrived on the Ile de France yesterday at the invitation of a committee of churchmen organized for the exchange of speakers between this and other countries.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- Henry Berenger, who negotiated the Franco-American debt accord, again takes the stand today that war debts and reparations are indissolubly linked and that, since France is canceling reparations, the United States must cancel the war debts.

Mrs. Ruth Irwin, wife of Charles C. Irwin, a vice president and director of S. W. Straus Co., investment brokers, was killed about noon yesterday when she jumped or fell from a window of her suite on the fifteenth floor of the Hotel Ambassador.

Preparations for a Mayoralty election this Fall, depending, however, on a favorable decision by the Court of Appeals in the suit now pending, have already been begun by Tammany and its allies in the city, it was disclosed yesterday.

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 28. -- With two exceptions, today's second-round matches in the national women's golf championship at the Salem Country Club were mostly one-sided affairs, with the favorites moving one rung closer to their goals.
The Yankees fell one run short of tying the world's series record for runs scored by one team in a world's series game, but the game tied the record for scoring by both teams in one game.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 28. -- Federal troops have captured eleven cities on the eastern front in forty-eight hours, It was announced today, in the swiftest and most sensational drive since the Sao Paulo rebellion began nearly three months ago. The Federals believe the end of the struggle is near.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, said yesterday that his organization would take immediate steps to close the bungalow colony at Wolf's Pond Park, a city park at Princes Bay, S.I., declaring that the presence of the ninety privately built bungalows was "the most disgraceful condition I have ever seen."

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, returned to the city yesterday after swinging through the West with Governor Roosevelt. He asserted that enthusiasm displayed on the tour clearly indicated a sweep for the Democratic nominee.

Gov. Roosevelt Not Under False Colors. It is gratifying to see the campaign at last getting down to fundamentals. In Iowa it has been charged against Governor ROOSEVELT that he is only an amateur agriculturist and that his farm at Hyde Park is long on polo fields, tennis courts and sunken gardens, and short on silos and hog lots.

President BUTLER'S address at the opening of Columbia University's "academic year" was not in the least academic. It did dot smell of the lamp in the cell of a cloistered philosopher. It dealt directly and boldly with public questions of vital concern to this country and to the whole world.

The bond market remained irregular yesterday, with domestic and "United States Government issues lower on the average, while foreign Bonds reached slightly higher levels. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to $8,966,000, compared with $8,336,500 the day before.

BELMONT VARIETIES, a revue in two acts. Sketches and dialogue mostly by Helen and Nolan Leary and Sam Bernard 2d; music and lyrics mostly by Serge Walter, Sam Bernard 2d, Alvin Kaufman, Charles Kenny, Henry Lloyd, Mildred Kaufman and Robert Burk. Staged by Max Scheck and Sam Bernard 2d; produced by Richard G. Herndon.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Stopping off at Republican Headquarters today on his way West for a strenuous speaking campaign, Vice President Curtis challenged recent Democratic claims of strength.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Waiving the ninety-day notice required in the debt pact, Secretary Mills today permitted the postponement of a payment due day after tomorrow from Germany on army of occupation costs and mixed claims amounting to $7,800,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The House Postoffice subcommittee investigating the postal service went on record today as favoring restoration of the two-cent postage rate on first-class mail to "provide more revenue and work opportunities."

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company, defending before the Appellate Division yesterday the suit by the city to declare illegal the operation of 43 per cent of its bus routes, asserted that the city was now attacking the same law under which it sued for and won 5 per cent of the money received by the bus company from advertising in coaches, besides 5 per cent of the gross fares.

An application of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation to list 508,100 additional shares of $1 par value common stock has been approved by the Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. The company has received permission also for canceling its authority to list 499,752 shares reserved for the exercise of option warrants which expired on Aug. 15.

With the Republican State Convention to begin its sessions on Monday, Assistant Secretary of War F. Trubee Davison is preparing to take his fight for the Gubernatorial nomination to the floor of that gathering, despite the growing strength of Colonel William J. Donovan's boom and the prospect that the latter will be picked for first place on the State ticket.
Taking his title from a statement by John D. Rockefeller that "God gave me my money," John T. Flynn calls his biography of John D. Rockefeller, published today by Harcourt, Brace, "God's Gold."

Governor Roosevelt has hurt rather than helped himself as a candidate for President by his Western trip, Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared upon his arrival here yesterday from Chicago, where he spends most of his time at the principal Republican national campaign headquarters.

DOYLESTOWN, .Fa., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Several hundred persons fled in panic today as two of nine lions on exhibition at the annual Bucks County Fair escaped from their cages and charged across the infield section of the racetrack.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Lew Plummer of Baltimore, former Notre Dame football player who is now a heavyweight wrestler, was critically injured tonight in his match here with Jim McMillen of Illinois.

An exhibition of photographs by Berenice Abbott has been opened at the Julien Levy Gallery, 602 Madison Avenue, to continue until Oct. 15. Like Sterling Blazy, whose exhibition at the Cheshire Gallery was reviewed yesterday, Miss Abbott was born in Ohio and she, too, fails to get into Edna Maria dark's recently published book, "Ohio Art and Artists."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Led by Frederick Perry of England and Jiro Satoh, Japanese ace, favorites stroked through third-round matches today in the men's singles division of the Pacific Coast tennis championships.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Cornelius Whitney's Habanero, with Jockey Gilbert Elston up, won the outstanding race at Lincoln Fields today over a heavy track. Altmark, public choice, was second in the seven-furlong event. Switch saved the short end of the purse.

The establishment of a credit pool to relieve the financial pressure on some of the member groups of the Consumers' Cooperative Movement was approved yesterday at the final session of the eighth biennial national congress of those organizations, held in the Russell Sage Foundation building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The sale of Outfielders Simmons and Haas and Infielder Dykes of the Athletics, announced in New York tonight, caused surprise among baseball fans in this city.

Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial launched another offensive against Mayor McKee's pay-cut plan yesterday when he stiffened the opposition ot 2,000 school teachers by telling them that salary cuts made in the 1933 budget would never be restored because the 1934 budget would show an increase of $16,000,000 from debt service and other items over 1933.

Great interest is being shown by prominent women in the forthcoming fashion show in aid of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital, which will be held Oct. 6 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. There will be two complete showings, one in the afternoon, which will follow a special luncheon, and another in the evening, which will be preceded by a dinner.

An easier tone in time money, with maturities up to ninety days bid and doing at 1 per cent, was the feature. This was a drop in the outside date of 1/4 and the lowest in more than ten years. It was a reflection of the huge supply of funds awaiting employment. Elsewhere Stock Exchange call loan rate and business money were unchanged in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A moratorium on 75 per cent of the government's crop-production loans to wheat farmers until Congress shall have had an opportunity in December to pass upon a definite extension was declared today by President Hoover.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many foreign students in attendance in American schools and colleges, who have been dismayed by the recent ruling of the Department of Labor that they cannot continue to earn money for payment of any part of their expenses without for-feiting their student status, are entitled to know that the courts will probably protect them against deportation on this ground.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- Louis Masson, director of the Opera Comique, today handed in his resignation to Under Secretary of State for Beaux Arts Mistler, who accepted. The Opera Comique, which throughout the Summer season had been closed for repairs and renovation, has not yet reopened and Masson will remain in charge until Oct. 15, when the official season is scheduled to begin.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 28. -- Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott signed an order today authorizing the receiver to convey, to a new corporation an option to repurchase the American Gas and Power Corporation stock sold by the receiver, A. E. Fitkin, in January.

Appointment of a committee of five prominent men, headed by Calvin Coolidge, to study legislative and other means for helping the railroads met with favorable comment in railroad circles yesterday, although officials who discussed the move were particular to stress that the railroad managements were not involved in its activities.

The will of former State Senator Martin G. McCue, Tammany leader of the Twelfth Assembly District and clerk of the Surrogate's Court, who died on Sept. 19, was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court after it had been removed from Mr. McCue's desk in the Hall of Records on an order of Surrogate John P. O'Brien.

Probably it is easier for a woman than for a man to understand "Bidding High," which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening. Lois Howell, who generally composes costume and period dramas, has written this one from a woman's point view. It is the fable of a treacherous little minx, who lies, cheats, betrays and slanders and who collects two husbands within six months.
MUKDEN, Manchuria, Sept. 28. -- Fifty Japanese and Koreans were safely evacuated to Tsitsihar when the irregulars captured Angangki, just south of Tsitsihar, today.

ABOARD S.S. REX, Sept. 28 -- Former Mayor Walker of New York seemed depressed today and said that he did not feel as well as he has recently, Mr. Walker had remained up until 1 o'clock this morning talking with E.T. Stotesbury and awaiting news from New York which failed to come.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28. -- The Argentine Chamber of Deputies at 2 o'clock this morning approved a bill authorizing the executive power' to join the League of Nations with a reservation withholding recognition of the Monroe Doctrine as a regional agreement.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 28. --In spite of its limited enrolment of 1,000 students, Colgate University has one of the finest football traditions of any college in the East. Far sheer devotion to the game and team loyalty the men of Chenango Valley stand unsurpassed and their morale is responsible in no small part for the remarkable success which the Maroon has achieved in competition with universities that have far more manpower to draw upon.

Confirming previous estimates, indicating a substantial increase in the rate of steel-ingot production, The Iron Age, in its weekly review, draws attention to the scattered improvement in business and cites factors which promise a further enlargement of activity within the next month or two.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Always an ardent dry, I now favor repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Contrary, however, to the tenets of most anti-prohibitionists, I believe that the national dry law is a success in promoting temperance, and is by far the most effective control we have ever had over the liquor traffic.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Forty States, the District of Columbia, Hawaii and six foreign countries are represented in the class of 1936 at Yale University, which began the academic year today. There are 231 from New York State and 222 from Connecticut.

HARRISBURG, Ill., Sept. 28. -- Acting on information given in an anonymous letter sent to Colonel Lindbergh, and then here by New Jersey authorities, Dennis Lawrence, 30, an itinerant photographer, is held in Saline County Jail here as a suspect in connection with the death of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today made $597,600 available to Colorado to meet current emergency relief needs in twenty counties. This is the second loan that Colorado has received. Ten days ago $250,000 was advanced for four counties.

Mrs. Anna Weber, wife of the Rev. Charles A. .Weber, pastor of the Moravia Church of Castleton Corners, S. I., died at St. Vincent's Hospital at West New Brighton yesterday from injuries received in an automobile accident on Tuesday afternoon. The automobile was driven by her husband, who was seriously injured, but it was said at the hospital that he would recover.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- While State's Attorney Swanson spent five hours today questioning Marshall E. Sampsell, once an executive in the Insull utilities enterprises, John Hampton, Assistant State's Attorney, returned from New York and reported having found there a secret panel in the Eastern headquarters of the Insull subsidiaries.
NEW YORK. The Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, and his wife Lady Florence Cecil, are at the Biltmore.

Broadening of the work of the committee on intellectual cooperation of the League of Nations, with special emphasis on the promotion of disarmament and the strengthening of the machinery of peace, was predicted yesterday by Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University, who has been elected a member of the committee by the League Council.

Columbia concluded its heavy work yesterday in preparation for its meeting with Lehigh here on Saturday. The Lions engaged New York University in a ninety-minute scrimmage at Baker Field. No touch-downs were permitted.

Important railroads in the East and West are prepared on certain conditions to comply with the appeal made by President Hoover on Monday that they postpone discussion of a further wage reduction until Jan. 1. The conditions would involve a temporary extension of the present 10 per cent reduction agreement beyond its present date of expiration, Feb. 1.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 28. -- A five-day technical congress of French language countries, attended by more than 1,000 delegates, closed in Brussels today. It registered the following recommendations:

Although the weather in almost all cotton producing sections continued unfavorable, prices on the Cotton Exchange came under selling pressure yesterday and closed at the bottom at losses of 6 to 10 points.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. We won the first game and are mighty pleased about it. But we don't underestimate the Chicago Cubs. They are a smart hustling ball club and showed plenty of courage by fighting as hard as ever when six runs behind.

HAVANA, Sept. 28 -- Police believed tonight they had thwarted a plot to assassinate the highest functionaries of the Cuban Government by the discovery that Colon Cemetery, near Havana, where the body of the assassinated Dr. Clemente Vasquez Bello, President of the Senate, was expected to be buried, had been mined with more than 300 pounds of dynamite.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Following a long defensive drill against the second eleven, the Princeton varsity, in a 30-minute scrimmage against the scrubs, scored four touch-downs on University Field today.

With speculators assuming a disinterested attitude, the share market furnished no excitement yesterday. The turnover on the Stock Exchange, amounting to 1,381,000 shares, was a trifle smaller than that of the previous day. The market was irregularly higher at the opening; prices fluctuated within a narrow range in the forenoon; advancing tendencies appeared in the early afternoon, to be followed by a steady but dull movement the rest of the day.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Dennis Lawrence of this city, mentioned in connection with the Lindbergh kidnapping case in Harrisburg (Ill.) dispatches patches, lived in this city about eighteen months. "When he came here he said he was a native of Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- While officials here awaited more detailed information today on the extent of the damage in yesterday's hurricane in Puerto Rico, President Hoover wired Governor James R. Beverley expressing his sorrow over the disaster and requesting a report "on the salient facts."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Dr. James C. Alien of Bonnie Briar negotiated his home course in low gross figures of 80 today to win a Westchester Golf Association one-day tournament. The field was reduced by the morning rainfall.

With victory in the world's series first game to mellow their morale, the Yankees in their clubhouse under the grand stand after the battle made no pretense of concealing their exuberance at the ease with which runs rolled over the home-plate for them once Lou Gehrig had smacked his homer in the fourth inning.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. I know it sounds a bit flat to say today is another day, but that's the way I feel about it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Directors for the Eighth and Tenth districts of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, with headquarters, respectively, at Des Moines and Topeko, were announced today by Chairman Fort. Each bank will be capitalized at $7,500,000.

New Tork University faculty members and undergraduates yesterday joined in the protest against the ruling of Secretary of Labor Doak which prevents foreign students admitted to the United States on a non-quota basis from seeking either part-time or vacation employment.

MANILA, P. I., Sept. 6 (A. P. by Mail) . -- Assurance that more than $7,000,000 in bonds sold in the United States thirty years ago to finance the purchase of 410,000 acres of "friar lands" will be redeemed when due in 1934 was given by Serafin Hilado, Director of Lands, in reporting on the amortization fund.
Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Tuesday --2 per cent for the best names. The qoutations are for three-four months paper.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Sept. 28. -- Although she lost the third heat to Peter Guy, Rose Marie Abbe annexed the the 2:14 pace, best event of the harness races at the fair today. John Hartman of Trenton, N. J., drove Lullesta to victory in the 2:24 trot and scored behind Calumet Celtic in the 2:24 pace.

Although it is believed that news of the end of the rebellion in Brazil, which many traders expect almost daily, would mean a sharp break in the prices of coffee, quotations for future deliveries of the coffee bean continued yesterday to advance on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28.-- Psychobeurotic conditions which arise usually from both physical and psychic causes and become manifest at times of unusual stress upon the patient are no longer thought of as diseases, according to Dr. Lewellys F. Barker, Professor Emeritus of Medicine at Johns Hopkins University, who addressed the final session of the Clinical Congress of the State Medical Society at Yale Medical School today.

Tired of the parochial and partisan treatment of international affairs by the majority of the Senate, JOHN SHARP WILLIAMS left it in disgust at the end of his second term. He spent the rest of his life, perhaps not the least happy part of it, on his plantation, watching the world with a tolerant and humorous philosophical eye.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- A.C. Blumenthal, New York theatrical man and close friend of former Mayor Walker, revealed here tonight that he had discussed with one of the attorneys for Libby Holman Reynolds "whether Mr. Walker would be an asset to her defense" in her trial for the murder of Smith Reynolds, her husband.

The depression has found the Lutheran Church, like the world, in "excited bewilderment," the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, declares in the report he will make to that body at its blennial convention in Philadelphia, Oct. 12-18.

For the second day in succession six favorites were defeated at Aqueduct yesterday, making a sequence of thirteen losing choices since Portam won last Monday. One favorite, Mrs. T.J. Lewis's How High, got home first, but he was disqualified when two of the four jockeys in the race lodged claims of rough riding.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting as a District Court judge, granted yesterday the application of the holders of 7 per cent guaranteed stock of the Manhattan Railway Company to intervene in the pending equity receivership actions against the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 28. -- There are 3,200 election districts in Michigan. The Republican party was born "under the oaks at Jackson." To carry the mother State for Franklin D. Roosevelt, on the basis ot the 1928 returns, the Democrats must reverse sentiment at the rate of 100 votes per district.

The stock of the Ohio Match Company, regarded as an asset of the Kreuger Toll Company, was purchased for the late Ivar Kreuger through the Eddy Match Company of Canada with $6,000,000 furnished by the Dutch Kreuger Toll Company and the Swedish Match Company, it was brought out yesterday by Donald Duncan of counsel for the trustee in the bankruptcy case before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 -- The final results of the Greek elections indicate that of the 250 seats in the Chamber the Venizelist Liberals won 102, the Royalist People's party 96, the Progressives 15, the Agrarians 11, the Communists 9, the Farm-Labor bloc 6 and the Radical Nationalists 5, while 6 seats were scattered among minor parties.

Complete elimination of child labor in the United States and shortening of the hours of labor as steps in the solution of the unemployment problem and promoting the welfare of the present as wel las of future generations were recommended by President Hoover in a message broadcast from the White House last night to The New York Herald Tribune's Women's Conference on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The Bourse remained quiet today, with the volume of transactions small, but what movements were recorded were mostly toward recovery. The market sagged at the opening but was strengthened by covering purchases for the monthend settlements.

To correct abuses which have been the subject of frequent criticism the New York Stock Exchange has adopted a rule which forbids the participation, either directly or indirectly, of members or their partners in pool operations in stocks for which such members are the accredited specialists.
Amalita S. Thompson gave to Jacob Mayers a mortgage for $5,500, due Sept. 1, 1935. at 6 per cent, on 25 E. 93d St., subject to a first mortgage for $24,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Extension of the partial moratorium on crop loans declared by President Hoover yesterday to aid wheat farmers on the West was promised by the White House today to cotton and tobacco growers of the South, provided a comparable need could be shown.

Professor Julian S. Huxley, who is at once one of the best known of British biologists and an author with a following in literature that many popular writers might envy, talked briefly of science and poetry on his arrival here yesterday from England. A grandson of Thomas Huxley, defender of Darwin, and brother of the novelist, Aldous Huxley, the scientist is here on a lecture tour.

A sort of dazed admiration for Vernon Gomez, the slim southpaw conqueror of his team in the second world's series game, was Manager Charlie Grimm's chief post-battle reaction yesterday as he and his Cubs rapidly dressed in their Yankee Stadium locker-room.

BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- The Boerse opened firm today, but in the course of the day a general downward movement began, the result of declines in Bemberg and Siemens Halske of about 5 per cent and 4 per cent, respectively. The interest of the public continued to be concentrated in the bond market, which generally was firm.

A sterling silver scroll "in recognition of his services which have contributed so greatly to advancing the status of the engineering profession" was presented last night to Dr. David B. Steinman, president of the National Council of State Boards of Engineering Examiners and designer of some of the world's most notable bridges, at the dinner held in connection with the council's annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Gains in United States Government bonds and moderate improvement in domestic issues characterized trading yesterday in the bond market, where foreign issues were somewhat heavy as a group. In the domestic lists most rails were strong, industrials were unchanged and utilities averaged slightly lower.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Weakness in the wheat market in Winnipeg overshadowed all other influences today in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade here. Houses with Eastern connection were fair buyers at times, but the market reacted quickly when support was withdrawn.

Basil Harris, vice president of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, operator of the United States Lines, has informed Mrs. David D. Caldwell of Washington, vice president general of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, that he considers the association is not doing its bit to help maintain an American merchant marine by using the French liner Champlain to travel to Paris on an official pilgrimage next Tuesday.

Mayor McKee may remain in office after the first of the year only if he is elected Mayor Nov. 8, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in a four-to-one decision reversing Justice John E. McGeehan of the Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Revelations that startled those who heard them were made today in the Federal Court and State Attorney's investigations of the crash of the $2,000,000,000 Insull utility empire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Groups of eleven directors each for the Federal Home Loan Banks for the Fourth District at Winston-Salem, N.C., and the Seventh District at Evanston, Ill., were announced today by Chairman Fort of the Home Loan Bank Board.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 29 -- Faulty running of two of the three turbodynamos that operate auxiliaries including ventilation, lights, the kitchens and the water supply caused the new Italian liner Rex to remain at Gibraltar today while repairs were being made.
