WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Star pro Juventute with wreath of the Catholic Boys' Brigade of the United States was presented to President Hoover today in token of the achievements of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection.
The text of President Hoover's radio address last night from Washington to the New York Herald Tribune's Women's Conference on Current Problems at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria follows:

New York City will save $1,147,471 on the construction of the second section of the West Side Highway, which Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan announced yesterday would be opened to the public at the end of November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railway Company today to issue $20,000,000 worth of notes, or as much of this as may be necessary, to take up unpaid portions of a bond issue due Oct. 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To understand the position taken by Germany at the present time on equality in armaments, one must read the short preamble to Part V of the Versailles treaty, which is as follows:

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 29 -- The home of Albert J. Davis, former jockey and cabaret dancer, now a horse-show exhibitor, was badly damaged by fire of undetermined cause tonight. The two upper floors of the three-story frame house of twelve rooms in Cedar Swamp Road here were burned out, while the first floor was flooded.

PEIPING,. Sept. 29 -- United States and Japanese diplomatic advices from Manchuria today confirm reports that Manchukuo troops, instigated by irregulars, revolted and aided in the capture of Manchuoli, as Well as in taking Chalainoerh and Hailar yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- A torchlight parade will be part of the Democratic welcome to Governor Roosevelt on his arrival in Chicago tomorrow night-provided the torches can be found.

The new plan for the recapture of the American Gas and Power System by holders of securities of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation, approved on Wednesday by Chancellor Wolcott of Delaware, will afford an opportunity for owners of class A and class B common stock of Commonwealths Power to play a dominant part in reorganizing their system unless the creditors, debenture holders and preferred stockholders exercise fully their rights under the plan.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 29 -- About fifty members of the Artists and Writers' Golf Association, most or them New Yorkers, will pass the week-end of Oct. 9 at the Greenbrier. Grantland Rice, editor of The American Golfer, is president of the organization; R.L. Goldberg, cartoonist, is vice president; C.D. Williams, secretary, and Arthur William Brown, treasurer.

Americans are inclined to accept modestly foreign estimates of their radio entertainment as compared with the European. They do not deny that their programs are commercial, supported by advertisers, while the European have no such ties, with the exception of France, where private and governmental broadcasting exist side by side.

Arturo Toscanini, conductor, returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday for the Fall season with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. After the ship entered Quarantine and later moved toward her pier, Mr. Toscanini kept to his cabin most of the time, emerging onec to have his passport examined and again just before the liner docked.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Feminine enemies of the Eighteenth Amendment turned today to the American Bar Association for advice on procedure for holding State constitutional conventions in the event Congress submits another amendment to the States, dealing with liquor control.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Up to the time of the present economic depression the treatment accorded to foreign students by our officials, governmental and university, was very generous. They were welcomed to our colleges and universities, in many cases granted unusual opportunities for study, and generally, when it was necessary, not only permitted but even assisted to obtain employment.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- Paraguayan forces are reported to have recaptured Fort Boqueron in the Chaco region after twenty days of battle and that, with the collapse of the Sao Paulo rebellion after eighty days of fighting, is expected here definitely to mark the end of hostilities in two South American wars involving about 200,000 men.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In common with many others who have been associated with Lieut. Gov. Lehman, we want to acknowledge the debt that we owe to him.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of Franklin D. Roosevelt's speech here:

Tammany and the Republican organization in Manhattan joined last night in nominating a judicial slate for three of the four Supreme Court vacancies in a deal unequaled in its unexpectedness and its implication of friendship between the two organizations in a bitter political year.

As the Citizens Budget Commission pointed out yesterday that school teachers in Rochester and Syracuse had voluntarily reduced their salaries, Robert E. Simon of the United Parents' Association joined with the teachers in their opposition to any form of salary reduction.
The following is the text of Justice John V. McAvoy's opinion upholding the majority view of the Appellate Division that there must be a mayoralty election this November:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A petition that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation establish an agriculture credit corporation in the First Federal Land Bank District, comprising New York, New Jersey and the New England States, was presented today by a delegation of agricultural leaders.

Unusual activity is apparent in the suburban home field of Northen New Jersey, according to C. Carlton Colyer, Inc., which reports the sale of eleven one-family houses during the past eleven days. Numerous other dwelling deals have been closed.

Bank clearings in the last week declined $1,372,716,000 from the preceding week, reversing the better trend shown recently. The total at twenty-two cities in the United States was $3,919,244,000, a decrease of 43.9 per cent from that of the corresponding period last year.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 29 -- The establishment of training camps for reserve officers was ordered by the government today and the newspaper El Tiempo predicts that war with Peru is inevitable.

SALONIKI, Greece, Sept. 29 -- Continuous earth convulsions -- one shock at 6 o'clock this morning being more violent than any other -- added today to the hardships of the survivors of Sunday's earthquake in the Chalcidice peninsula.

A "national quality movement" to foster consumer confidence in merchandise values, combat hoarding of buying power and speed business recovery was launched yesterday at a meeting attended by 130 leading retailers and manufacturers, held under the auspices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Elimination from the Federal budget of the $450,000,000 expenditure on veterans of both the World War and the Spanish-American War who were not injured in those conflicts was urged by Archie Roosevelt, son of President Roosevelt, before 250 members of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers at their annual convention today.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Marquess of Douglas and Clydesdale, 29-year-old heir of the Duke of Hamilton and member of Parliament for the Scottish constituency of East Renfrewshire, is expected to set out next month to fly over Mount Everest (29,000 feet) highest mountain in the world.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 29 -- The Nassau County grand jury refused today to indict thirteen members of the county Police Department on assault charges in connection with the alleged assault on three prisoners, who were arrested with the late Hyman Stark. Stark, it was charged, had been beaten to death following his capture on charges of assaulting and robbing Mrs. Valerie Hizenski on July 15.

Ambassador Walter E. Edge returned yesterday from France on the United States liner Manhattan, bringing a draft of the French counter-proposals to the United States bid for a new commercial treaty. He said he did not know what part he would play in the coming campaign, but pointed out that part of his visit would be devoted to a holiday during which he could follow his own inclinations so far as political activities were concerned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 28, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,251,000,000, a decrease of $18,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $759,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Reports in Brooklyn realty circles that a deal was pending by which the Baltimore Ohio would purchase the old B.M.T. building at Montague and Clinton Streets were denied yesterday by Ralph Jonas, head of the Long-Brooke Corporation, which owns the property.

President Hoover has virtually saved the country while his Democratic opponent, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, in the course of his campaign for the Presidency, has been teaching Socialist doctrine and at the same time seeking to hold on to conservatism, according to Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

HAMILTON, Ont., Sept. 29 -- The Board of Evangelism and Social Service of the United Church of Canada declared in a report issued today that married persons may employ birthcontrol methods providing these are justifiable "under all the particular circumstances and in the light of Christian conscience."

The trustee in bankruptcy for the Kreuger Toll Company will claim 60,000 shares of the Ohio Match Company, which are believed to be worth about $3,000,000, it was indicated yesterday at a hearing before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee. The Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Company, now holds 57,000 shares of Commercial and Industrial Products, holding company for Ohio Match.
Tony Canzoneri, lightweight champion of the world, knocked out Lew Kirsch of the east side in the third round of a non-title bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Stadium last night.

Presidents of savings banks joined yesterday in endorsing the appointment of the committee headed by Calvin Coolidge which will investigate the railroad situation with a view to recommending legislative and other means for improving the position of the carriers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 29 -- Cut off from their chief source of food, the Sao Paulo rebels asked today for an end of the civil war that has racked Brazil for three months.
LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Charles E. Arnott, president of the Standard-Vacuum Company, returned here on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday after having attended conferences in Paris with Rumanian oil companies on control of the foreign market. He said the international oil companies and the Rumanian group reached an agreement satisfactory to all, the details of which were highly technical.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The lion's share of the honors at the Bryn Mawr Hound Show went to W. Plunket Stewart's Cheshire fox hounds from Unionville, Pa., today, including sixteen of the twenty-three ribbons offered on the morning card and numerous prizes later.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A huge export project whereby the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would help to facilitate the sale abroad of American grain was urged upon President Hoover today by representatives of the Chicago Board of Trade.

Weakness in wheat and cotton was assigned yesterday as the cause of the slugglish decline on the Stock Exchange. The volume was only slightly less than that of the day before. Selling was never aggressive, but the market was allowed to drift steadily lower and to close in listless fashion, with net losses of from 1 to more than 3 points in the leading issues.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Recommendations designed to ease the lot of mortgage-burdened farmers were decided upon today by financial leaders assembled at the behest of President Hoover.

Standings of the Atlantic Class sloops on the season's racing were announced yesterday by Kingsley Kunhardt, chairman of the class. His Noiram took first place in the championship series on Long Island Sound and in the Gould Trophy series.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 -- In a final effort to turn back the tide which is sweeping Indiana into the Democratic column this year, the Republicans are hastily rebuilding their State organization.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- Following is the text of the address by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, before the Republican State Convention here today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Employment in trade unions gained slightly in August and during the early part of September, the American Federation of Labor asserted tonight in a statement issued by President William Green, based on its monthly survey of the situation.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 29 -- A landslide for Governor Roosevelt was predicted by Richard F. Mitchell of Fort Dodge, Democratic National Committeeman, who joined the Roosevelt party at Omaha today.
WEATHER clear; track heavy. Don Vernon Gomez, the young Hidalgo from the lower Pacific slope, was selected to face Lonnie Warneke, the young dirt farmer from Mount Ida, Ark.

Jobbers Await Cotton Estimate. Dry goods wholesalers reported yesterday that they were marking time, as far as purchases in the primary markets were concerned, until the government cotton crop report is issued next month. Uncertainty over the cotton price has been the main factor retarding commitments, it was said, and if the estimate is at all bullish, large scale buying will be resumed.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Energetic protests to the French Government by French importers of Belgian Congo and American copper may result in a reclassification of that metal in the French customs regulations whereby it will be subject to a tax of only 2 per cent instead of the present 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Commenting upon Secretary Hurley's speech in Johnson City, Tenn., attacking Governor Roosevelt's utility program, Representative Byrns, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, declared today that this Cabinet official had convicted the administration of "inertia" and of a shifting policy on control of interstate utilities.

Overnight news from Brazil indicating that the backbone of the rebellion that has been going on there for almost three months had been broken resulted in the most active trading session in the past two years in coffee on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, with December Santos delivery breaking the limit of 200 points on the opening transaction.

The Man Who Reclaimed His Head," current at the Broadhurst Theatre, will be withdrawn after tomorrow night's performance. It is expected that the next occupant of the house will be the new Arthur Hopkins production, "Rendezvous,'' a play by Barton MacLane, with the author and Ruth Fallows in the principal roles.

As It Should Be at the Stadium. Thus far it has been a world's series reflecting the dominant mood of the world today. The first two games have eschewed the fireworks and gone in for the normal and the expected.

Professor Reinhold Niebuhr, who occupies the chair of Applied Christianity at the Union Theological Seminary and is chairman of the organization committee of the Thomas and Maurer Committee of Ten Thousand, composed of non-Socialists who are supporting Norman Thomas and the Socialist ticket, in a statement made public yesterday pronounced the organization of Senator George Norris's National "Progressive League for Roosevelt, "the last dying gasp of liberalism in America."

The Eltinge and Republic Theatres, West Forty-second Street burlesque houses, lost yesterday their application to Supreme Court Justice Shientag for a writ of mandamus to compel Commissioner of Licenses Geraghty to renew their licenses in order that they might reopen.

Although the last few months have seen a steady increase in cooperation between American Christians and Jews, the followers of Adolf Hitler, German Nazi leader, have established groups or "cells" in the United States, Roger W. Straus, one of the chairmen of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, said yesterday in a statement issued by the conference on the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which will begin tonight.

LA PAZ, Sept. 29 -- Reports from Asuncion that Paraguay had captured Fort Boqueron after a battle of three weeks cast a pall of gloom over La Paz today, which was broken at 11 o'clock tonight with an announcement by the General Staff that the Bolivian troops still held their ground.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 -- A long blocking and tackling drill and a forty-minute scrimmage comprised Harvard's workout today in preparation for the opener with Buffalo Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plan suggested in a letter to THE TIMES by Ernest G. Draper for accumulating an unemployment reserve fund by a tax on industry in periods of normal activity is commendable in its basic features, in that it stresses the value of preparedness by foresighted effort.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29 -- With the little world's series standing at one victory each for the Newark Bears, International League champions, and the Minneapolis Millers, American Association flag winners, the rival managers were preparing today for the battle tomorrow afternoon which will close the series in the East. Play will start at 2 P.M.
BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- A fighting message from former President Coolidge was read as the keynote at the Republican "night before" dinner on the eve of the party's State convention tomorrow.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 29 -- During the second day of the Bryn Mawr horse show two women riders were injured today in spectacular spills and removed to the hospital.
Real estate trading in Manhattan yesterday was confined largely to leasehold deals, most of which involved dwellings.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday conformed to the prevalent mood of uncertainty. The market declined far enough to cancel Wednesday's gains in trading that involved only about 45,000 fewer shares, the total volume being far below what the brokers have recently come to consider a "normal turnover."

A gain of $2,532,200 in the monetary gold stocks of the country was shown in the statement of gold transactions published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Imports of $1,630,700 were listed and a decrease of $901,500 in gold earmarked for foreign account.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Streit will give a small dinner dance at their home, 1,040 Fifth Avenue, Oct. 14 for their debutante daughter, Miss Nannette Streit. Mr. and Mrs. Streit will give a reception at their home on the afternoon of Nov. 18 for the formal introduction of their daughter.

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 29 -- Two years ago when the women's metropolitan championship was being played at the Engineers Club in Roslyn the matches were followed by a 20-year-old New Jersey girl who was heard to remark, "Gee, I wish I could play that kind of golf."

Freight revenue of the Northern Pacific Railway in the third week of September showed an increase from the same period a year previously, which was the first time in two years in which an increase was shown on an annual basis, it was said yesterday by Charles Donnelly, president.
PRINCETON, N.J. Sept. 29 -- The hours between 3 and 5 o'clock Saturday afternoon will be a momentous period in Princeton gridiron history.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 29 -- The reputed largest single-story food warehouse in the United States was dedicated here tonight before more than 4,000 persons, including representatives of the State, county and city and several leading food, manufacturers of the East.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Brig. Gen. William S. McNair, who was 64 years old last Sunday, will retire with the rank of Major General tomorrow at his post as commandant of the Fourth Coast Artillery District, at Fort McPherson, Ga.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 29 -- The government is sending warships to Antofagasta to "dominate" the army units there that have defied the government.

Weakfish of good size are to be had in Great South Bay, but whether the fisherman should use worms or a hair lure is something he will have to decide for himself. An able exponent of the hair lure returned yesterday from a day's fishing off the inside wreck with the information that he found the hair lure one of considerable attractiveness to the weaks and one that brought him very good resuits.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 29 -- General Julius Goemboes, Minister of War in the late Karolyi Cabinet, as he was also in the preceding Bethlen Cabinet, was entrusted this evening by the Regent, Admiral Horthy, with the formation of a new government. He accepted the commission and already rumors have composed a list of new Ministers which, however, is incomplete.

"Fifth Avenue Week," the avenue's silver jubilee celebration of its career as a business street, will begin tomorrow and continue through Oct. 8. The Fifth Avenue Association, which is Sponsoring the celebration, also called "Quality Week," announced yesterday that already more than 100 stores in Fifth and Madison Avenues had pledged their cooperation in special displays and exhibits and that art galleries, banks, hotels and public institutions would participate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A radio message indicating that only three men of the thirty-five officers and members of the crew of the freighter Nevada had survived a wreck on the rocks, of a Northern Pacific island was received by the Dollar Steamship Company here tonight.

J.H. Louchheim's Master Charlie colt Uncanny won the featured Stony Brook Claiming Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct in hollow fashion after the field had been reduced to three starters. At 9 to 10, Uncanny made a show of his opposition to win the mile test by five lengths in 1:39 1-5 over a fast track.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 29 -- An expedition has left Cairo to explore some of the more inaccessible portions of the Libyan Desert, vast areas of which still remain entirely unknown.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Cash sales of retail establishments showed a sligh't increase, while open-credit and instalment sales decreased slightly in the first six months of the present year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- In the field of public financial retrenchment much has been accomplished, but the government is still far short of ultimate objectives, Arthur A. Ballantine, acting Secretary of the Treasury, declared today before the annual convention of the Morris Plan Bankers Association.
The peak of the Fall apartment moving season was passed yesterday with augmented crews of public utility workmen and van owners busy filling last-minute orders for changes in all parts of the city.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann of Sunken Orchard, Oyster Bay, with seventy-five points won the sweepstakes prize this afternoon, on the closing day of the annual Fall flower and vegetable show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society in St. Dominick Auditorium.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Adolphe Pons's Mad Pursuit raced to his second victory at Havre de Grace today when he beat five other 3-year-olds in the Trophy Purse, feature offering.

Although a virtual settlement had been reached in negotiations to stabilize the wholesale milk market and prevent a threatened strike of dairy farmers, the activities of a recalcitrant group of dealers led the emergency committee of the New York milkshed yesterday to view the movement as doomed to failure unless persistent price-cutting ceased.

Among east side rentals announced yesterday was one of an apartment of thirteen rooms in 21 East Seventy-ninth Street to Frank A. Shea, member of the firm of Shea McManus, stock brokers. The lease was negotiated by Pease Elliman, brokers for Douglas L. Eliman, brokers, for the building.

Senator Royal S. Copeland and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, took the witness stand yesterday to vouch for the good character and honesty of Senator James J. Davis as his trial on charges of participating in a nation-wide lottery went through its ninth day in Federal Court before Judge Frank J. Coleman and a jury.

Marked progress in the reduction of member-bank indebtedness and the piling up of excess member-bank reserves, made possible by the return flow of currency and by gold imports, was revealed in the weekly Federal Reserve statement published yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Irwin Kurtz, referee in the United Cigar Stores Company of America bankruptcy, ordered yesterday the disaffirming or canceling of 151 leases held by the company in cities throughout the United States. The leases had been made for periods of one to 100 years, the longest having still eighty-nine years to run.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- Official records attesting the safety of trust funds in the hands of banks and trust companies during the depression, even in case of suspensions, were cited here tonight by Francis H. Sisson, vice president of Guaranty Trust Company of New York, in addressing the tenth Regional Trust Conference at a dinner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Arthur M. Hill, president of the National Association of Motor Bits Operators, which opened its convention here today, in an address declared that buses paid for the use of the highways and that the orderly growth of highway transportation was hampared by the failure of Congress to enact regulating legislation.

The expansions of Japan and the United States are not in each other's way, strategically or commercially, writes Hugh Byas, Tokyo correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in the current issue of "Contemporary Japan," a quarterly review published by the Foreign Affairs Association of Japan.

Offering of $3,879,000 city of Baltimore (Md.) 4 per cent bonds and registered stock will be made today by a banking syndicate headed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation. The bonds, $2,963,000 in amount, due serially from 1937 to 1964, are priced to yield from 3.50 to 3.80 per cent.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Stanley Baldwin, former Conservative Prime Minister and Lord President of the Council in the present coalition government, was made Lord Privy Seal tonight, with the approval of King George, to succeed Viscount Snowden.

HAVANA, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Manuel de la Cruz Conservative minority leader in the House of Representatives, and Dr. Pedro Cue, attorney and professor at Havana University, have taken refuge in the Uruguayan Legation under the asylum agreement adopted at the sixth Pan-American conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Formal application for an $8,000,000 loan to construct a high-speed transit line across the Delaware River Bridge between Philadelphia and Camden was made to the Reconstruction Finance Corpoiation today by the Delaware River Joint Commission.

The central office workers of the General Motors Corporation in New York and Detroit will be placed on a five-day week tomorrow, but the weekly salaries of the 10,000 to 15,000 employes affected by the change will not be reduced. The new schedule, which is in line with President Hoover's plan for spreading employment, will not involve wage earners who are employed in the company's plants on an hourly pay basis.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Tax receipt figures for August, which were published today, show heavy reductions both as compared to those of August last year and as to budgetary estimates.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Despite a let-down on the last nine holes, Miss Betty Pietsch, the young golfer from Tamarack, today won the one-day tourney of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Association over the Bonnie Briar course. She scored a 38 -- 44 -- 82.

The observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, will begin at sundown today and will be observed by Jews the world over. It will be the year 5693 in the Hebrew calendar. Its celebration will continue through tomorrow and Sunday. Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, will begin at nightfall, Oct. 9.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 29 -- Governor Roosevelt received an enthusiastic welcome here today. The Governor addressed 2,000 stock-yard workers at South Omaha, spoke to 16,000 or 18,000 persons from the steps of the court house and had a chicken dinner at the farm of Gus Sumnick at Waterloo.

Lonnie (that's his baptismal name) Warneke was discussing the unfortunate fate of the Cubs in the series opener. It was the eve of his own first appearance as a world's series pitcher. He was in a thoughtful mood.

"Pack Up Tour Troubles," fulllength comedy featuring Laurel and Hardy, opens at the Capitol today. The stage show offers Duke Ellington and his orchestra, James Barton, Benny Rubin, Prances Williams and Mills, Kirk and Martin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Backed by official data to show that unless the United States begins a definite naval construction program in the next year this country will be a poor third among the navies of the world in 1936, the highest officers of the Navy Department will support at the next session of Congress a naval construction program along the lines of the Vinson $616,000,000 ten-year construction plan.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- Declaring that President Hoover's "sure decision" and intelligent leadership had averted nation-wide economic disaster, Secretary Mills told the Michigan Republican State Convention today that the country had no one else to whom it could now entrust the uncompleted task of reconstruction.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 29 -- Revision of the tariff by reciprocal arrangements with foreign countries to restore the market for American farm products was put forward tonight as a partial solution of the farm problem by Governor Roosevelt.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- The "very, very great importance" of Secretary Stimson's speech on Aug. 8 was stressed in the League of Nations Assembly this morning by Premier Herriot of France in a speech, in which he carefully avoided any direct reference to the German or Manchurian questions.

The belief of James J. Walker that he will receive a chance for a "vindication campaign" was indicated yesterday in dispatches from the Italian liner Rex, when the vessel, on which he had started homeward, was delayed at Gibraltar by engine trouble.

Courtlandt Otis, new president of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce, said at a luncheon in his honor at the Harvard Club yesterday that if the various payments to war veterans were continued on the present scale they would amount by 1966 to $4,000,000,000 a year, the equivalent of our entire national budget today.

Scholarships have been awarded to thirty members of the entering freshman class of Columbia College, according to an announcement in the first issue of The Columbia Alumni News, published today. Twenty received honor scholarships and ten got Columbia University Club awards.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Tony Manero, a golfing instructor at a driving range in Mamaroneck, came back to a place among tournament winners by capturing the Westchester open championship over the Wykagyl Country Club course today.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Enos Booth of Sleepy Hollow won the annual seniors' metropolitan golf championship today when, for the second successive day, he carded an 81 over his home course to register a two-day total of 162, six strokes less than William Beck of White Beeches, who gained runner-up honors.

Federal Judge Martin T. Manton erved notice yesterday that he inended to retain control of the equity eceivershlps he granted to the Inerborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the I.R.T. operated Revated lines.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The stock market brightened somewhat today and British Government funds scored fresh gains. Among the industrials good investment buying of Cables and Wireless continued and shares were higher. The industrials otherwise were inactive.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Victor Wilbour, artist, who died May 17, 1931, leaving $1,844,125 gross and $1,673,664 net, showed that, by reason of the renunciation of two beneficiaries named in the will, the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences receives the bulk of the estate.

No sooner has a truce been apparently declared between the Mayor and the Controller, than war breaks out again over salary cuts. As usual, it is Deputy Controller PRIAL who leads the attack on the Mayor. Having won a victory over Mayor WALKER, and followed that up by taking his own chief into camp, Mr. PRIAL appears to be intent on pressing his advantage, with scant regard for his enemies, in whatever station.

A request that unemployed garment workers receive the opportunity to make up garments for 263,000 needy families, instead of having the work done by volunteers, was served on the American Red Cross and the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union.

SAN JUAN, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Banco Territorial y Agricola de Puerto Rico, one of the oldest financial institutions of the island, closed its doors this afternoon with the explanation that exceptional demands as a result of the hurricane made the step necessary.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Miss Charlotte Glutting, who eliminated the great Miss Enid Wilson of England in the women's national golf championship today, might have been a ranking tennis player if she hadn't decided golf was her game.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Yale, in its final hard practice for the opening game of the season with Bates in the Bowl Saturday, scrimmaged an hour and a quarter today with the scrubs.

Increasing strength by Governor Roosevelt has left the Presidential race close in only five States, James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, said yesterday. He predicted that the Governor would carry New York by a greater plurality than the record-breaking mark of 1930.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The New York State Council of Parks will recommend that $1,000,000 of the $6,624,000 State park budget for 1933 be allocated to Westchester for the construction of the Pelham-Port Chester Parkway, a route parallel to the Boston Post Road along Long Island Sound, it was announced here this morning by the Westchester County Park Commission.

William E. von Glahn, 35 years old, former chief bookkeeper in the branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company at Eighth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, was sentenced to from three to ten years in Sing Sing by Judge Levine in General Sessions yesterday for a $87,500 shortage in his accounts.

Chairman SANDERS has broken forth from the clouds in full midday splendor. You can't look at him without shading your eyes. All things work together for good for them that love the Republican party. The Republican campaign is going like a house afire.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The signal to set the Republican campaign into fun stride with an intensity intended to grow until election day will be President Hoover's first campaign address next week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 30. -- The property, franchises and business, both gas and electric, of the Annapolis Chesapeake Bay Power Company were purchased at auction at a receiver's sale today by the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore.

The return movement of gold to the United States, which Started after withdrawals on a large scale had ended in mid-June, became more pronounced in September, when, for the first month since May, 1931, there were no exports here, while imports increased steadily as the month advanced and included consignments from two countries that earlier in the year had reduced heavily their balances here.
A.G.B.S. Solo for Rosh ha-Shanah. "You asked for a shofar blast and now you have got it." Thus BERNARD SHAW concludes his New Year's greetings to the editor of The American Hebrew and Jewish Tribune.

HELSINGFORS, Sept. 30. -- Remarkably liberal changes in the new Finnish drinking law are foreshadowed in a bill that the Cabinet decided today to introduce in Parliament as a result of a comprehensive investigation of the liquor situation after the abolition of the prohibition law.

Governor Roosevelt in a long-distance telephone conversation with John. H. McCooey, national committeeman and Brooklyn leader, at national headquarters last night asked Mr. McCooey to use his influence to obtain for Herbert H. Lehman the nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Non-quota students are permitted to accept a scholarship or fellowship, but only those now in this country who were admitted prior to last August are included in the modification of the "no-work" order recently issued by Secretary Doak under which students, though forbidden to engage in part-time or vacation employment for money, may work in return for room and board.

Tammany-controlled members of the Board of Estimate joined Controller Charles W. Berry yesterday in an attack that destroyed Mayor Joseph V. McKee's leadership of the board. That leadership passed into the hands of the Controller, whose policy, the Mayor charged, involved an increased subway fare.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The market for hogs was erratic again today. Hogs averaging 250 to 280 pounds were scarce and held around yesterday's prices, but other kinds were weak to 10 cents a hundredweight lower, with some 170 to 200 pound averages down as much as 15 to 20 cents less.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30. -- Luis Leon, leader of the dominant National Revolutionary party in the Chamber of Deputies, former Minister of Commerce and holder of other Cabinet posts, said in a statement tonight on the papal encyclical:

The imported thoroughbred Cock Robin, by Jackdaw from Red Linnet II, owned by Richard Whitney, showed his heels to eight rivals at Aqueduct yesterday in a finish that was as gallant as it was surprising. A converted steeplechaser, Cock Robin, making his twenty-fourth start of the year, gained his first victory.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Sept. 30. -- With Robert Lesley, the venerable Pennsylvania enthusiast and donor of the trophy, present to greet the members of the team as they came into the clubhouse tonight, Pennsylvania had a margin of exactly half a point at the conclusion of the inaugural day's play in the Lesley Cup matches.

A suit charging violation of the anti-trust laws and asking $1,125,000 damages was begun in United States District Court yesterday against the recently organized Music Dealers Service, Inc., and two dozen leading sheet music publishers. The suit was brought by the Richmond-Mayer Music Corporation of New York and Richmond-Mayer of Chicago, Ltd., and charges a conspiracy to destroy the business of the plaintiffs as music jobbers.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- The stock market was irregular today. After a brief rally the list sagged and it closed at the day's low level. The session was featured by severe carry-over terms applied to some categories of rentes, not including the converted issue, which have been accumulated by certain holders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Disclosure to the public of the names of banks and other financial institutions borrowing from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is preventing the restoration of confidence for which the corporation was created, and "is fraught with much danger to the borrowers," Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the corporation, advised South Trimble, Clerk of the House, in a letter revealed today.
The stenographic transcript of the budget discussion between Mayor McKee and Controller Berry yesterday follows:

Representative F.H. La Guardia conferred yesterday with officials of the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union, the Emergency Unemployment and Relief Committee and the American Red Cross in an endeavor to work out a solution of the problem involved in the conversion of 4,700,000 yards of cloth into garments.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 30 (AP). -- National Guardsmen laid aside their guns today by order of Governor Beverley to become for the moment carpenters and masons in the rebuilding of the city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The directors of the $4,000,000 Seneca Iron and Steel Company of Blasdell have approved of transfer of the company's assets to the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Alex Paterson, treasurer of Seneca, announced today.

C.B. Heiserman, vice president and general counsel of the Pennsylvania Railroad, retired yesterday from that office after having headed the railroad's legal department nearly ten years. He was 70 years old on Sept 18.
ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- New York City will not be permitted to tap Nassau County water resources for an additional 100,000,000 gallons daily the State Water Power and Control Commission ruled today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 30. -- The most irrational situation to be found in any football camp in the country obtains here along the banks of the Severn in Uncle Sam's Naval Academy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The New York Yankees received a reception on their arrival today quite unlike anything ever extended a visiting team in a world's series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The business situation abroad showed encouraging features in a number of foreign countries, but in others there was no improvement, the Bureau of Foreign Commerce showed today in its weekly survey of the foreign situation.

It should be understood that Mr. VAN SCHAICK, State Superintendent of Insurance, has not finally rejected the proposal to increase workmen's compensation insurance rates, which was the subject of recent hearings in this city. He has simply deferred decision for a few weeks until he has had a chance to investigate the "adequacy and reasonableness" of the new schedules.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission decided today that the New York Telephone Company acted improperly in charging to operating expenses a contribution of $75,003 to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Fund of New York City.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30. -- Addressing a Republican rally here tonight, Secretary Mills accused Franklin D. Roosevelt of "openly and directly" misrepresenting, in his Sioux City speech, the position of President Hoover.

The Bronx grand jury returned an indictment for manslaughter, second degree, yesterday against Alexander Forsyth, part owner of the steamer Observation, which blew up on the East River on Sept. 9 with a loss of seventy-two lives. The grand Jury also submitted to Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dora a presentment carrying strong inferences of neglect and inefficiency in the United States Steamboat Inspection Service and assailing its methods.

The means by which a single financial monarchy might arise in the United States if "big business" is allowed, to continue its mergers unhindered are discussed by Dr. Frank Albert Fetter, Professor of Political Economy at Princeton University, in Facing the Facts: An Economic Diagnosis," published yesterday by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- That the result of the discussion of the disarmament problem in Geneva was altogether negative and that no arguments had been advanced that might have induced Germany to modify or amend her demand for arms equality was the essence of statements by Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, at a press conference today on his return.

Many foreign bonds, particularly those of Argentina, Colombia, Germany and certain ones of Brazil rose briskly in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Considerable irregularity appeared in the domestic list. Treasury issues were mixed, the higher-priced issued declining while the less active 3 to 3 3/8 per cent notes went up slightly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- To permit a greater degree of fleet training and save considerable money in oil fuel, the scouting force of the navy, comprising nine cruisers, thirty destroyers, eleven submarines and the aircraft carrier Lexington, was ordered today to remain in the Pacific until the latter part of March next year.

A man who described himself as Robert Green, 32 years old, an unemployed railway clerk living at the Bowery Branch of the Y.M.C.A., was captured after a chase in lower Broadway yesterday. The police said he had held up John Warner of 194-08 112th Avenue, St. Albans, Queens, an employe of Miller, Dodge Co., brokers at 71 Broadway, and the brokerage firm's $1.164 payroll was found in his clothing.

MADRID, Spain, Sept. 30. -- Premier Azana told the world today in staccato words at Santander that Spain was indeed in the grip of a grim revolution. Speaking on the eve of the reopening of the Cortes before crowds of cheering Spaniards, who greet him wherever he goes, he flatly told the church Spain was a lay State and the power of the church was going to be smashed.

After a period of unsettlement in the early dealings, followed by a moderate recovery, the share market settied down yesterday to a monotonous routine. No progress was made in either direction. Transactions made up a smaller total than on the day before, so that trading was the slowest in more than two months for a full five-hour day.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The German Andes expedition, having succeeded in ascending several previously unconquered peaks in Peru, is proceeding with its scientific program, especially of mapping the country, according to cable received today from Dr. P.H. Borchers, leader of the expedition, from Huaraz, Peru.

PONCA CITY, Okla., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Vice President Curtis said tonight that measures undertaken by the Hoover administration have, placed America in a position whence the nation would be able to start on a new and lasting period of prosperity.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 30 (AP). -- W.W. Vaughan's Canron raced to a clever victory in the featured Frederick Purse of a mile and seventy yards today at Havre de Grace. Under the seasoned guidance of Jockey Jimmy McCoy the 3-year-old daughter of Catalan set all her own pace and crossed the last line enjoying a length and a half margin over Aegis.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Further reduction in rallwaymen's wages was proposed today, it was announced after a joint conference of representatives of the railways and the National Union of Railwaymen.

The call for a convention of Democratic county committee members, to be held next Thursday night in Madison Square Garden, to name a candidate for Mayor, was sent out yesterday without the sanction of Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State and leader of the Bronx organization, or the signature of Harry B. Chambers, chairman of the Bronx County Democratic Committee.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Two of Donie Bush's Millers hit home runs while only one of Al Mamaux's Bears was able to emulate their feats, so the American Association champions took the decision, 2 to 1, in ten innings today. The two clubs departed for Minneapolis with the Millers holding the edge on the International League flag winners in the little world's series, two games to one.
Changes in money rates in September were slight, call funds being offered at the same rates as prevailed in August, while time loans were made at fractionally lower quotations.
BRIDGEWATER, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Jesse Harding Pomeroy, the nation's most famous convict, died last night on the State prison farm here in his seventieth year. Death was due to natural causes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Speaker Garner, resting here while undecided whether to enter into an active campaign, today thoroughly approved of Governor Roosevelt's Sioux City speech, in which the Presidential candidate insisted that the tariff must be reduced to a "competitive basis" and taxes must be reduced in the nation, State and local communities.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $20,210,308, compared with a revised total of $19,080,674 for this week and a weekly average for the year to date of $19,080,674. Issues of securities will be floated by forty-eight communities.

The railroad committee of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York recommended yesterday to the executive committee that the association go on record as opposing the operation of the Seatrain Lines, Inc., in their proposed new service between New York and New Orleans, via Havana, because it would "tend to disrupt the rate structures of the water and rail lines in the territory affected."
A cage in the Prospect Park zoo was being prepared last night to house the roving silver fox whose swiftness of foot had set at naught the ingenuity of Greenpoint's police and citizenry for two days.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 30. -- Interest in the annual Fall tennis tournaments was accentuated today with many additional entries and the arrival of a number of players.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- A decided improvement in individual lines of American export trade, was recorded during the first six months of 1932, compared with the same period last year, it was announced today by the foreign commerce department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 30. -- The text of Secretary Mills's address delivered here tonight, is as follows:

The American Contemporary Gallery, at 1269 Madison Avenue, which began its career this week, has opened with an attractive group of lithographs by a score or more of artists, including A. Grant Arnold, from whose press all of the prints have come.

George Bernard Shaw's "Shofar-Blast," with "its insulting sentiments and language," published yesterday on the occasion of the Jewish New Year, was denounced as "an affront to the Jewish people and their faith" by Rabbi Louis I. Newman in his Rosh ha-Shanah eve sermon last night before Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Twice thwarted in her past endeavors to win the women's national championship, Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago again has fought her way to a place in the final, in which she will face the golfer who has balked her on both previous occasions, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare Jr., now of Philadelphia.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- Whether Germany takes part or not, the disarmament commission is going to proceed with its work, Norman H. Davis said here today. The American delegate, with Admiral Hepburn and Allan Dulles, arrived here from the liner Europa this morning and went on to Geneva tonight.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 30. -- following is the text of the address delivered at the Eagles Club here today by Governor Roosevelt:

Refusal by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company as trustee under a $15,000,000 issue of Prudence Company bonds in 1926 to permit the Prudence Company to withdraw $889,551 of the $5,343,810 in cash deposited as part security for the bonds led to the filing by the Prudence Company of a suit yesterday for a judgment that it is entitled to with-draw the money.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- Yale University today announced tanking scholars in the studies of junior year for the class of 1933; ranking scholars in the studies of sophomore year for the class of 1934; ranking scholars in the studies of freshman year, class of 1935.

The reaction in political circles yesterday to the bipartisan deal which resulted in the nomination of Samuel H. Hofstadter to the Supreme Court was that the Republican organization had deprived itself of the central figure needed to make "Tammany corruption" an issue in either the city or the State campaigns in the next year or two.

The first major default in the repayment of a matured security by a solvent railroad since the depression began will take place today, when $20,000,000 of unsecured three-year 6 per cent notes of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Rail-road fall due without there being sufficient cash in the company's treasury with which to meet the obligation.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the beat names. Thursday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-tour months' paper.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I saw the article in Tuesday's TIMES with regard to the recent discoloration of the waters of Long Island Sound. I hope nobody is unduly alarmed about this condition. It is nothing new, nothing strange, and nothing mysterious, unless the ways of nature are mysterious.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- Temple University's eleven vanquished Thiel College, 31 to 0, tonight. The victors showed a powerful offensive, which their opponents were unable to check, and rolled up five touchdowns.

For the first time in railroad history, current liabilities of the railroads of the country exceeded current assets on July 31. The excess of the liabilities was $7,000,000. The roads operated at a net loss of $31,304,848 in July and at a net loss of $148,687,052 in the seven months to July 31.

Stockholders of the Chrysler Corporation were asked yesterday by Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the board, in a letter accompanying dividend checks, to urge government economy on their Representatives and Senators in Washington and to request the revision of the "existing discriminatory" tax burden imposed on the automobile industry.

New financing in September was the smallest for any month since May and consisted entirely of bonds. The total was far below that for September last year and less than a fourth of that of September, 1930, Twenty-seven bond issues aggregating $98,328,000 were offered, against twenty-five, amounting to $120,638,000, in August, and twenty-one, totaling $143,380,000, in September, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Further loan of $12,461,350 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Chicago North-western Railway Company was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Of the sum authorized, $5,000,000 will be used for paying off 50 per cent of bank loans made through Kuhn, Loeb Co., which are due Oct. 13.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- The United States, through Hugh R. Wilson, moved that the Hoover plan for a one-third arms reduction be the basis for discussion, in the disarmament conference's committee on effectives, which opened today. Mr. Wilson urged that the principles on which the plan is based be first considered with the view to defining terms before turning to the arithmetical side of the question.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The American Government's views on the proposed Franco-American commercial treaty should be ready to transmit to France next week, Ambassador Edge said today after a conference with Secretary of State Stimson. Mr. Edge arrived in Washington this morning, in response to orders to come from Paris and discuss the pact.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 30. -- Pactolus, a 2-year-old chestnut colt by Snob H out of Queen Mab II, owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Old Westbury, carried off the championship in the breeding division as the thirteenth annual Piping Rock horse show opened today on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- There was no excited throng in Downing Street today but the deliberations of the British Cabinet at Number 10 were of far more vital significance to this country and the world at large than its session two days ago when the first break in the government occurred and a crowd assembled outside the house to cheer the seceding Ministers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, in a statement today denied William G. McAdoo's assertion that the association opposed him for Senator in California because it was influenced by New York financial interests and was interested in the return of the saloon.

Coincident with the night-and-day rumble of moving vans through the city, numerous apartment rentals were reported by brokers yesterday the end of the old leasing period While the last-minute rush has subsided, a continuance of activity is expected, owing to holdover leases for short periods, the usual flux of the city's population and possibilities of business betterment.

Ending his first vacation in twelve years, Uncle Robert, veteran radio performer and philanthropist, will return to broadcasting tomorrow between 12:30 and 1:30 P.M. over Station WPAP. He will be accompanied by his "Radio Pals." Harry Good-win, managing editor of The Bronx Home News, will speak.
BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Loyola -- There are four sets of brothers on the Boston College squad. This may turn out to be a family-picnic. One vote for Boston College.

Further indications that the rapid decline in bank credit has terminated and that the position of member banks of the Federal Reserve System has been strengthened appeared in the last month, says the current monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Mr. OWEN YOUNG'S mother's country-wise distinction between unemployment and leisure, though not in formal terms, cannot be improved upon even by the makers of dictionaries:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Despite a substantial response to the appeal for stock subscriptions in the Federal Home Loan Banks, it was believed today that the Treasury would be called upon to subscribe a large portion of the $125,000,000 authorized by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Reports coming from Iowa today that farmers ers protesting against Republican policies were preparing to heckle President Hoover during his Des Moines speech caused Democratic national headquarters here some little concern.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the viewpoint of a small country banker and wheat grower in Montana I have read with a good deal of interest numerous speeches, editorials and letters in THE TIMES, dissecting wheat-growers and diagnosing our ills.

A law doctrine known as "cy pres" -- meaning "as nearly as may be" -- has been availed of in England and in some of our States. It permits the use of trust gifts for related purposes when it has been found impossible to devote them to the specific objects named by the donors.

The New York Telephone Company was denied the privilege of introducing evidence of its financial structure at the inquiry by the Public Service Commission into the charges for hand phones, when the hearing was resumed yesterday on the complaint of the City Affairs Committee against the "excessive" monthly rate of 25 cents for "French" telephones.

To the Editor of The New York Times: News from Geneva supplies a most perfect substantiation of THE TIMES editorials emphasizing the point that the League, to an ever-increasing degree, is determining world policies of vital interest to the United States, and the inevitable corollary that our non-membership is a handicap in that it prevents us from having a real voice in their accomplishment.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- Yale and Bates held their final practice sessions in the bowl today preparatory to opening the Yale season tomorrow. About 7,000 spectators are expected.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- A reward of $50,000 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the dynamiters who wrecked the home of Judge Webster Thayer was proposed by Governor Ely today and backed by the Governor's Council.

Tax payments to the city, which two months ago were running more than $19,000,000 behind last year, have picked up so briskly in recent weeks that they are now only about $17,600,000 behind 1931, according to figures made public yesterday by City Collector William Reid Jr.
Contracts for the leasing of entire buildings in Manhattan yesterday indicated a preference for the west side on the part of the new tenants. Most of the deals were for dwellings.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 30. -- Following is the complete official English text of the encyclical letter, Acerba Animi, of Pope Pius XI, dealing with present conditions in Mexico and addressed to the Archbishops, Bishops and Ordinaries of Mexico as wide public today:

The formation of a National Bureau of Engineering Registration to investigate and verify the records of applicants for licenses to practice professional engineering, and to issue certificates of qualification to those fully complying with standard requirements, was approved yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Council of State Boards of Engineering Examiners at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Samuel Insull, the collapse of whose $2,000,000,000 public utility system has caused Federal and State investigations, was charged today by John A Swanson, State's Attorney, with having knowledge and "having authorized and sanctioned" the use of money of the various Insull utility companies for the marginal protection of some personal brokerage accounts of his brother. Martin Insull.

With slightly more than 200,000 votes counted, Governor ROOSEVELT now has a narrow lead over President HOOVER in The Literary Digest's poll. The totals are 102,185 to 100,323. These ballots come from eleven States. Mr. ROOSEVELT is ahead in California, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, West Virginia and (shades of QUAY and PENROSE!) Pennsylvania.

Improvement in business is indicated by reports to Bradstreet's from fifty-five important centres. It is stated that while the gains are largely seasonal "the upward trend is something to cause hope."

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 30. -- In a sharply worded encyclical issued today Popa Pius XI again strongly protests against the situation created for the Catholic Church in Mexico by the "iniquitous and impious" church laws. [The full text of the encyclical is printed on page 6 of this issue.]

Supreme Court Justice McGeehan granted yesterday the application by bondholders of the International Match Corporation for the removal of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company as trustee of $100,000,000 of bonds of the company. He named as substituted trustees the Manufacturers Trust Company, Edward Ward McMahon of 1 Cedar Street and Harry M. Burning of 100 Broadway.

The first of the month and the first issue of New Outlook come together. Besides the editor's there are many well-known names among the contributors. Former Governor FORT. ARCHIBALD ROOSEVELT, Senator WAGNER, OWEN YOUNG have pieces.

NETCONG, N.J., Sept. 30. -- The truth about Tammany Hall and civic corruption in New York City Is concealed by the public schools of that city, it was charged here tonight by Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, in an address before the Teachers' Union Conference, which opened this evening for a three-day session.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt received from Chicago tonight one of the greatest demonstrations ever accorded a candidate.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Massachusetts Republicans in State convention here today declared in favor of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment with the proviso that the saloon must not return. Consisting of thirty-one words, the plank read:
Realty activity in New Jersey reported yesterday covered a wide range, extending from a development project to small housing deals.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 30 (Canadian Press). -- The Toronto Stock Exchange decided today to continue trading in the common and preferred shares of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company despite the proceedings to wind up the corporation. Dropping of these issues from the New York and Montreal Stock Exchanges left the Exchange here the only recognized market for the securities.

Joseph A. Jenkins, who took over the organization work formerly dominated by Senator James J. Davis in the Loyal Order of Moose, yesterday described Mr. Davis as an "extraordinary man who does extraordinary things" as the trial of the Pennsylvania Senator continued before a jury and Judge Frank J. Coleman in Federal court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The board of governors of the West-chester Clearing House Association at its first meeting, held last night in the White Swan Inn here, instructed the association's clearing house committee to prepare detailed plans for the establishhment and maintenance of a central office for clearing the checks of member banks.

Highway contracts have reached a total of $15,000,000 for the third consecutive week, this figure being more than double the average weekly awards for the year. The Engineering News-Record reports. All heavy engineering contracts reported for the week ended Sept. 26 totaled $23,850,000, which is slightly above the weekly average for the month.

NEW YORK. A dinner, followed by dancing, will be given by Walter P. Chrysler Jr. and his brother, John F. Chrysler, for Miss Victoria Brady, a debutante of the season, on Oct. 15 at the home of their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Chrysler, in Great Neck, L.I.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The farm mortgage conference convened here at the suggestion of President Hoover, with representatives of bankers, insurance companies, joint stock land banks and the Federal Government participating, announced today that a drive against "needless foreclosures" had been launched.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30. -- A large order for munitions has been just received from the Brazilian Government by the Winchester Repeating Arms Company of this city, which was recently merged with the Western Cartridge Company.

There was a slow recovery on the Stock Exchange yesterday, prices showing an unimportant net change as compared with the day before. If there was any appreciable result it was represented by a slow decline in the composite averages. However, in the main body of stocks the losses and gains represented an almost complete standoff.

Tank-car gasoline in the mid-continent field was available as low as 3 3/8 cents a gallon yesterday, according to reports from Chicago. In both the East Texas and North Central Texas areas, low octane gasoline in tank-car lots was said to be available at around 3 3/4 cents.

Football for the season of 1932 dispenses with nearly all its preliminaries with the games of today, and by the time the closing whistles have been sounded by the referees on the gridirons of several hundred colleges and universities tonight a new season for practically all of the leading teams of the country will have been started.
GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- Aristide Briand's European Union Commission met today for the first time since his death.

Eleven States, normally Republican in a Presidential year and including the home States of the Republican and Democratic nominees for President, which are represented in the second instalment of The Literary Digest's nation-wide Presidential poll, in the aggregate give Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt a slight lead over President Hoover, his Republican opponent.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The stock market was more cheerful today. British Government funds were linn and in keen demand. One of the best sections in the industrials were the textiles. Cables and Wireless again was active and higher, and Dunlop Rubber spurted following the dividend announcement.

The detailed plan of a liquor-control system for the State of New York endorsed by a conference group of leaders in education, social welfare, religion and medicine was made public yesterday by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, chairman of the conference group and head of the New York State division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

Alfred E. Smith's first contribution to the New Outlook, on sale today, contains an attack upon what has come to be regarded as a vital part of Governor Roosevelt's campaign -- his appeal to and for the "Forgotten Man."

The Hutchinson Flying Family, headed by George R. Hutchinson, whose plane was forced down in Greenland while on a slow-stage flight to Europe, will return today on the Champlain of the French Line. In the party are Mrs. Hutchinson, their two daughters and the crew, numbering four.

More than 5,000 persons attended the services in observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, held last evening in the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. About 3,000 filled the main body of the temple and 2,000 more heard the services through amplifiers in the Isaac M. Wise Memorial Hall on the lower floor of the building.

The Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, England, and Bishop William T. Manning will be guests at a luncheon given by the Church Club, an organization of Protestant Episcopal laymen, on Tuesday at the Lawyers' Club, 115 Broadway.

SALONIKI, Greece, Sept. 30. -- Eleven more earthquake shocks in the last twenty-four hours have kept the inhabitants of Saloniki in a perpetual panic. No work is being done anywhere and the people are still in the streets and squares, where they spent all last night.

The recent ruling of the University of the State of New York restricting examinations for students from foreign medical schools discriminates against reputable French universities. Charles de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General here, declared yesterday at the laying of the cornerstone of the addition to the French Institute in the United States.

Thursday's break in the prices of cotton was followed yesterday by almost equally sharp recoveries on the Cotton Exchange here, resulting from an increased trade demand and active covering. Some local liquidation and Southern selling caused reactions from a moderate opening advance, but the offerings were readily absorbed and prices turned upward.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- Preparations for the observance of President von Hindenburg's eighty-fifth birthday on Sunday suggest that it will be chiefly observed by the Reichswehr and the navy, both of which will honor their Commander-in-Chief with military festivities in which band concerts will be a feature.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- October wheat in Winnipeg dropped today to the lowest price on record on that Exchange, touching 49 cents a bushel, with longs liquidating on the way down. The decline from yesterday's finish was only fractional, but it was sufficient to start general selling in small lots on the Board of Trade here, with longs going out of their holdings on the way down.

Fifth Avenue's celebration of its silver jubilee as a street of commerce begins today and will continue until Oct. 8. More than 150 stores are co operating in offering special display during the week, the Fifth Avenue Association, Inc., sponsor of the celebration, announced yesterday.

Almost before we know it the two conventions will be meeting to nominate a Governor for this State. Another nomination which they will have to make, and which they ought to make jointly, is that of a Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals. Until recently it has been everywhere taken for granted that Judge POUND would be named by both parties.

A list of four plays definitely scheduled for production this season either in New York or on the road by the New York Repertory Company, under the direction of Lawrence Langner, was announced yesterday. The schedule includes "The Man With a Load of Mischief," in which Jane Cowl is now appearing in Boston.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 30. -- Twenty-six experts from the dock yard here who have been wonting on the turbodynamos of the liner Rex under Captain Vernon Sharpe, naval superintendent, since the ship arrived yesterday, expected to finish their job in time for the liner to sail about 8 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Replying to the speech by Secretary Mills in Detroit which laid to world conditions the severity of the depression in the United States, Senator Swanson, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial committee, asserted in a statement today that the economic troubles were due largely to the Smoot-Hawley tariff act.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- In the commanding general's tent on the eve of the world's series "Western warfare, a new record for poise and equanimity was probably set tonight by Joseph Vincent McCarthy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30. -- With the arrest in Oakland today of four more members of what was called the "machine-gun robbery gang," two of them women, the police see a possibility that they are on the trail of the kidnappers of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr.

What is being hailed at New York University as the beginning of a newera in its football history will be inaugurated today when the latest Violet eleven opposes Hobart at Ohio Field. A capacity crowd of 15,000 is expected to witness the only N.Y.U. contest to be placed on the college campus this season.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Winning six blue ribbons, including one annexed by Crumpet, 6-year-old bay gelding, in the triple-bar jump, Frederick Wettach's Trillora Farm of Shrewsbury gained major honors at the opening of the seventh annual two-day Montclair horse show in the Montclair Riding Club ring today.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Reports of the most serious floods in twenty years, in which atleast seven lives have been lost, came from Northern Mexican points today.

The hunting season opens today on a wide front throughout the United States and Canada, and because of the efforts of the Federal Government and the various State conservation departments it is probable that one of the best seasons in many years will be enjoyed by an army of hunters that is estimated at 7,600,000.

RIO DE JAKEIRO, Sept. 30. -- The federal government laid down its terms of surrender to the Sao Paulo rebels today, and General Bertholdo Klinger-Holfer, the insurgent commander, had until midnight to accept or reject them.

WASHINGTON. SLEEK new train will slide out of the Union Station yards tomorrow afternoon and turn westward. With all of its shining cars, its brightly polished brass trimmings, it will be to the average bystander just another, though more beautiful, train.

Mayor McKee will be a candidate for his present office, running as an independent Democrat on a platform of "sound economy in municipal government," if there is a special elecion on Nov. 8, and Tammany Hall, at the city-wide convention next Thursday night, ignores him in favor of former Mayor James J. Walker or some other candidate, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 28 aggregated $3,853,000,000, or 24 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 43 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

As the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad failed to pay the interest and principal due yesterday on its $20,000,000 of unsecured 6 per cent three-year notes, the New York Stock Exchange ruled that the notes and certificates of deposit therefor be dealt in "flat" and that to be a delivery the notes must carry yesterday's interest coupon.

Bonds called for redemption in September before their dates of maturity were fewer than half of those in August and under one-quarter of last year's total for September. They aggregated $25,406,300, compared with $56,238,000 in August and $116,522,500 in September, 1931.

ACTOR, dramatic author, composer and manager is the designation in the theatrical Who's Who which serves as a prelude to the two and a half columns devoted to the achievements of George M. Cohan, who is emerging as a talking picture actor at the Paramount this week in "The Phantom President."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Harvard's opening game against the University of Buffalo today developed the expected riot of touchdowns and points. Ten times the Crimson crossed the Buffalo goal Jine, winning by 66 to 0, but being six points short of Cornell's count against the same eleven last week.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- Blind men and women walking through the streets with and without guiding dogs are not unusual in Germany, where thousands of blind war veterans, assisted by public institutions, have set their minds on becoming independent once more.
TOKYO. A SPEECH on foreign policy during the special session of the Japanese Diet contained one of the strangest declarations of faith ever addressed to that assembly of hardboiled politicians.
Chicago, Oct. 1. -- Governor Roosevelts speech at the banquet here tonight was as follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- At last in New England the problem of the diversion of freight traffic from the railroads to other transportation agencies is under discussion in the light, not of general estimates and more or less accurate guesses, but of cold facts. For the first time a comprehensive review of the actual situation has been made by a railroad expert.

JAMES J. WALKER may not be permitted to run again for Mayor this November, but the Dial Press is seeing to it that he is not forgotten. They are publishing "Jimmie Walker, the Story of a Personality," by Louis J. Gribetz and Joseph Kaye, this week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the opinion of your correspondent, S.L.G. Knox, on the subject of the dole as it works in England, and apparently intended as a warning to this country.

THE unemployed in all parts of the country are suffering from justifiable mental depression. Anything that can be done to fill the time which now hangs heavily on their hands with something interesting and stimulating is of real social and economic value.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Three gunners tied for the high scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. They were G.E. Mole, G.V. Birrell and R.H. Helsel. Each had 49 out of a possible 50 targets. In the first shoot-off, Helsel and Birrell again tied with 25 straight.

For the first time in three years, reports of earnings of many industrial companies are likely to show normal seasonal expansion for the third quarter of this year, according to brokers who have made a survey of the activities of representative units.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- Among the major industries of France which have been hit hardest by the economic crisis is the wine trade, particularly in the export field. An idea of how badly it has suffered may be gained from statistics just issued by the International Bureau of Wine.

The New York Curb Exchange has received notice that the principal and interest due yesterday on Silica Gel Corporation live-year 6 1/2 per cent gold notes are not being paid, and the committee on securities has ruled that until further notice the notes shall be dealt in "flat" and toba a good delivery must carry the Oct. 1, 1932, coupon.
WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Lakewood High School's eleven scored its third straight victory of the season today, defeating Woodrow Wilson, 19 to 0.

The Philadelphia Grand Opera Company will suspend performances for the present season, meanwhile planning for a new form of opera for next season which will need a year to be brought to maturity. This announcement was made yesterday jointly by Mrs. Joseph Leidy, president of the company; Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, chairman of the board; Mrs. William C. Hammer, vice president and general manager, and the company's committees.

GENEVA, Oct. 1. -- Geneva tonight sits awaiting the Lytton report on China. League of Nations officials and others are on edge lest various efforts to buy the report cause it to leak out before its official release at 1 P.M. tomorrow.

THE aim of Mr. Wickham's very attractive book is to afford "a fair impression of what is best and most typical in village scenery." But he goes about it in a way different from any other approach that has heretofore been made to the English rural scene and one that is original with him.
