COOLER weather had a tonic effect on trade as the week drew to a close and sales again picked up. The religious holiday restricted volume yesterday. Activity was marked in the women's wear sections and certain housefurnishing lines attracted good demand.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Tammany's war board, beaded by John F. Curry and accompanied by John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, went into conference here tonight and emerged at the end of an hour and one-half with the name of Senator Wagner as keynote orator for the Democratic State Convention opening here on Monday.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 29. -- His policy for conservation and development of the nation's water power resources and regulation of the public utility companies engaged in production and distribution of power has won Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt many ardent supporters in the Pacific Northwest.
GENEVA, Oct. 1. -- The disarmament conference's committee on effectives today adopted a working program based on the Hoover plan, urged yesterday by Hugh R. Wilson, spokesman for the United States.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- His Elegance, the well-known chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, took the rosette as grand champion, hunter at the Piping Rock Horse Show today. The award was the feature of the closing day of the thirteenth annual exhibition and proved a popular one.

A boxing show in which two world's champions will appear for charity rings down the curtain on the outdoor season this week. In addition a program which features a former champion heralds the beginning of a new indoor season.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Playing an intersectional football game, Colgate defeated Case today, 27 -- 0. The home team scored in every period despite stubborn opposition by the Case eleven and the constant threat of passes hurled by Red Hubbard, Case quarterback.

WHEN Governor Roosevelt in his present speech-making tour has wanted an illustration for his water-power plank he has found it in four great projects, all of them involving vast expenditures of public money, all of them advocated because they promised to return far more in public benefit than they cost in money, and the sum total of them outweighing almost any other single constructive enterprise of mankind except the building of roads and railroads.

POTSDAM, Germany, Oct. 1. -- The National Socialist youth field day opened tonight with a huge mass meeting in the Potsdam Stadium, where about 30,000 boys and girls in Drown uniforms listened spellbound to Adolf Hitler's oratory. The youthful Nazis have come to Potsdam from all parts of the country, and many hiked for many days because they did not have the fare.

The anti-crease process for finishing cotton, rayon and other textile fabrics, invented in England and obtained by an American company during the week as a licensee, was regarded yesterday as an encouraging indication of the rapid strides made in textile research and gives promise of further advances in the near future.

The last race meeting of the year on Long Island under Jockey Club jurisdiction will begin tomorrow with the opening of the Fall session of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica. There will be twelve days of racing and some of the best-known stakes in the New York area will be renewed.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Oct. 1. -- Equipoise, champion of the handicap division, jumped from eleventh to sixth place on the all-time list of American, money-winning thoroughbreds when he scored a smashing victory in the $20,000 added Havre de Grace Cup Handicap before 20,000 spectators today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- With full realization that their party has much at stake in the coming election, Republican leaders from all parts of the State are assembled here in a serious mood for the convention, which will begin its sessions on Monday.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Former governor Smith, who is chairman of the board of directors' of the State Fish, Game and Forest League, has declared his opposition to the proposed Porter-Brereton amendment to the State Constitution which will be submitted to voters at next month's election.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- Liberal increases in import quotas, varying from 10 to 30 per cent, are granted American trade in the new figures for the last quarter of 1932 issued today. This news, which was received with great gratification in American business circles here, had been foreshadowed by the recent favorable action taken regarding the importation of American fruit.

VIENNA, Sept. 20. -- The old Hapsburg aristocracy of Austria has been split into two camps by the new Austrian entail bill. Prince Anton Sigismund Khevenhueller, the enormously wealthy bead of a famous Austrian family, leads one camp, and the opposition is grouped around a distant relative, Count Franz Khevenhueller, owner of Hoch Osterwitz, the castle of Feuchtwanger's "Ugly Duchess," and Count Coloredo.

THE ninety-first season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society opens on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Arturo Toscanini. The first program of the season will consist of Brahms's Third symphony, Debussy's "La Mer," Bach-Schonberg's Prelude and Fugue in E flat and Tansman's Four Polonaise Dances, which will have their first American performance.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1. -- Tulane's big Green Wave, meeting one of its hardest early season opponents, conquered the Texas Aggies today, 26 to 14, before a crowd of 18,000.

Chancellor Franz von Papen believes in doing things. He wants German debts reduced. So he will sena commissioner to tell American bankers they must reduce them. He wants arms equality. So he demand the right to abrogate treaty restrictions and reorganize Germany's defenses.

WHEN to the sessions of sweet silent thought that widely respected actor of old, K.H. Sothern, summons up remembrance of things past, he is inclined to sigh over the chronic softening of the American theatre's arteries.

IN this biography of Sitting Bull, chief of the Hunkpapa Sioux, Stanley Vestal has written not only the story of an individual Indian, but, in a way, the whole story of the plains Indians during the middle and latter parts of the nineteenth century.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- On Nov. 6 a new Reichstag is to be elected and after this year's unparalleled abundance of elections the German peopie are looking forward to the forthcoming campaign with a mixture of boredom and disgust, and, not the least, a great deal of embarrassment.
Professor Albert Einstein's answer to the question, "Is There a Jewish View of Life?" is printed in the current issue of Opinion, a journal of Jewish life and letters.

DR. IMAMURA, a distinguished Japanese authority on earthquakes, has made it known that next October he will read before the Imperial Academy of Japan a paper in which he will advance the theory that the core of the earth is solid.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20. -- In his search for specimens forming a connecting link between vertebrates and Invertebrates, William Patten, Professor Emeritus of Zoology at Dartmouth College, again spent several weeks during the Summer excavating the rich deposits of Silurian fossils on the Baltic island of Oesel, now a possession of Estonia.

WARSAW, Sept. 30. -- The westbound Moscow train stops an hour in the Warsaw railway station. Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, has been a frequent passenger on the train, but he rarely leaves his car here and refuses to talk to newspapermen or to pose for cameramen and he receives only members of the Soviet Legation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Frederick Perry, veteran British Davis Cup player, today eliminated Jiro Satoh, Japanese Davis Cup player, in a hard-hitting semi-final of the forty-third Pacific Coast tennis championships, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- George town University opened its football season today with a 26-0 victory over Mount St. Mary of Emmitsburg Md.

Aided by a four-goal handicap, the Essex Troop polo team turned back the Fort Monmouth quartet, 5-4, to gain the final round of the Second Corps Area championship yesterday. The game was contested at Governors Island, where the final will be played next Sunday.
Another challenger for 2-year-old honors came to the fore at Aqueduct yesterday when Repaid, bearing the Quincy Stable colors, scored in the Junior Champion, $2,500 added closing-day feature.

ATHENS, Sept. 30. -- The Greek elections, as expected, deprived Premier Venizelos of his majority and increased the Royalist representation in the lower chamber almost fivefold. They failed, perhaps fortunately for Greece, to give the Royalist parties that clear majority which Premier Venizelos had declared would be countered by armed force.

"THE INVASION" is a historical novel of several generations that is a curious combination of a genealogical compendium and descriptive writing of a cool, translucent beauty. Unfortunately, the sense ot beauty that is Janet Lewis's is the sense of beauty of a poet of the external world; it is not made germane to the problem of the novelist, historical or otherwise.

VIENNA, Oct. 1. -- A Cabinet Council today decided, whether in earnest or only as a gesture, to empower the State to sequestrate the property of leading officials of the defunct Creditanstalt, the collapse of which, two years ago, embarrassed twothirds of Austrian industry which it controlled and has kept State finances in hot water ever since.

John McKenzie, Dock Commissioner, agrees with agitators for sites for the storage and breaking up of old hulks as a means of clearing public waterways of floating material. Control of driftwood in New York Harbor, he says, is one of the most difficult problems which his department faces.

THE family Adler, which one statistician reckoned to number about 4,020 and of which at least seventeen members are now in active service on the stage, held something of a reunion last Monday evening when "Success Story," the John Howard Lawson play with which the Group Theatre has started its season, opened at Maxine Elliott's.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 1 (AP). -- General Bartolome Blanche, who resigned tonight as Provisional President in the face of a threat of civil war, held the reigns of government temporarily as riotous conditions flared in the capital.

For four years John Doe not only drew an annual salary of $9,000 as head of division in a government bureau but retirement pay of $187.50 a month under the emergency officers' retirement act. His only war service was office work in the War Department in Washington the last three weeks before the Armistice.

LOS ANGELES; Oct. 1. -- Forty or more persons are believed to have been drowned when a forty-foot wall of water swept down the narrow Tehachapi Canyon late last night after a cloudburst over the mountainous region southeast of Bakersfield.

WHEN Cezanne first rumpled the still-life tablecloth (could it have been in a fit of rage over the difficulties involved in striving to bring Poussin closer to nature and in striving, as well, to make of Impressionism something more "solid"?) he unwittingly created a problem of the most insidiously taxing sort for earnest young art students, even for accomplished painters, of succeeding decades.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are many logical reasons why the metric system should not be adopted by the English-speaking races, some of which are as follows: We must, on account of the system of natural relations, use measures that are permutable with circular measure in order to obtain the advantage of certain mathematical formulae.

A 3-yard line plunge by Guyon for a touchdown in the first period and Lawrence's successful try for the extra point, enabled Yonkers Central High School to top the Jamaica High eleven. 7 -- 6, before a crowd of 2,000 at the new Jamaica Stadium yesterday.

VIENNA. ROYALTY temporarily or eternally dispossessed, seems to have two assured places of refuge in this modern world. One is on the Riviera, the other is in the grave. Alive, royalty is still a social adjunct; dead, it surpasses democracy as a museum exhibit.

An Old Roman Custom. An article in THE TIMES, under the caption "Walker is Shelved," carries a classical reference, "thumbs down,'' which I know is a common error and seems to be widely quoted and misused. I quote from "Roman Antiquities" (Alexander Adam, LL.D., rector, Edinburgh) as to the proper use of the term.

OTTAWA, Sept. 29. -- Canada has 728,664 farms, an increase of 17,574 since the census of 1921, and for every 2.27 farms there is an automobile. The number of motor cars and trucks, owned on the farms has more than doubled in every Province during the last ten years, although there is a wide variation in the provincial rates.

The year 5693 of the Hebrew calendar was observed yesterday with traditional Rosh ha-Shanah services in all the city's synagogues. In many instances the economic depression provided the text for rabbis urging their congregations to place their faith in spiritual values rather than in a self-sufficient materialism.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The play-by-play description of the third game of the world's series follows:

BUT of Japan have come occasionally during recent years accounts of the man Toyohiko Kagawa and the marvel of his life and character, and some translations of his writings and addresses. But this book furnishes the first full biography to appear in English.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- "Continuation of undue discrimination and rebating by highway and water carriers" will stifle the country store and small industries, E.G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation and chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said tonight at the annual dinner here of the Society of Officers of the Eastern Associations of Railroad Veterans.

Beginning the new month without any flourishes, the stock and bond markets were characterized yesterday by extreme dullness. Indeed, the dealings in stocks were the slowest for a Saturday in eight years with two exceptions. Measured by the number of separate issues traded in, the market was the narrowest since July 9.

AN Irish poet has written, in prose, a romance that is of the very essence of poetry; for "The Bright Temptation" has in it everything of Shelley out the meter and the heartache. It is a romance of love and of Ireland when she was still young enough, in history, to be suffering the not unbearable tedium of growing pains.

PANAMA CITY, Oct. 1. -- Dr. Harmodio Arias for the second time took the oath as President of Panama before the National Assembly, the Supreme Court, the diplomatic corps, officials of the Panama Canal and United States Army and Navy officers at 3 P.M. today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- With his Western trip nearly at an end, Governor Roosevelt prepared today to put up a fight for the nomination for Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor of New York State when he arrives at Albany Monday morning, just before the Democratic State Convention opens.

TOKYO, Oct. 1. -- The Lytton report is more favorable to Japan than was expected, and it is clear that official opinion here is considerably relieved. Premier Saito and Admiral Uchida will reserve detailed comment until the report has been fully studied, and Minister of War Araki appears inclined to follow their example.
PARIS, Sept. 22. -- The fashionable restaurants have seen quite a number of Americans these days, some heading for the homeland, others settling down in their residences here.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press). -- The first stage in the giant 500,000-horsepower hydroelectric power development undertaken by the Beauharnois Light, Heat Power Company at Beauharnois, Que., about twenty-five miles from Montreal, has been successfully completed and the delivery of power to meet contracts has been begun.

George R. Hutchinson, 30 years old, who heads the family of "flying Hutchinsons," which ended its slowstage airplane trip to Europe among the icebergs of the Greenland coast, returned yesterday on the French liner Champlain undaunted by the illluck which brought disaster to the expedition and determined to try it again "some day soon."

Thousands of shoppers viewed the special window displays of jewelry and merchandise and visited exhibitions of historical prints and fashion modes of the "gay nineties" yesterday as Fifth Avenue opened its silver jubilee celebration. All day crowds gathered in front of the windows where the historical data and costly exhibits of gems were shown.

MANILA, Aug. 26. -- Dr. Stanton Youngberg, director of the Philippine Bureau of Animal Husbandry, celebrates today the twenty-fifth anniversary of his arrival in the Philippines by presenting to the islands and to science a unique gift. He offers the eradication of rinderpest, formerly the most disastrous animal scourge in the Philippines.

TOKYO. PLEASED to meet you" has been Japan's answer to the moving picture's introduction of America. Despite a highly productive local industry, the best and biggest of the Japanese picture theatres show only foreign films.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Opposed to a big, heavy Amherst team that offered fierce resistance on the defense but little in the way of an attack, Princeton made its debut under its new mid-Western coaching regime today with a clear-cut victory in Palmer Stadium.

MAYOR McKEE is not the first New York Mayor to refuse to have the Mayor's so-called "lamps of honor" set up in front of his residence. Robert A. Van Wyck, Mayor from 1898 to 1901, also declined the honorary lights, stating that they served no useful purpose.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Charges that enrolled Democrats have been discharged from unemployment relief jobs and Republicans hired to take their places were made in a letter by Morton S. Clark, president of the Silver Lake Heights Civic Association of Baldwin, which was made public today by the Nassau County Democratic Committee.
DAIREN, Manchuria, Sept. 1. -- A new seaport for the Orient -- a rival of Vladivostok and Dairen -- will be in the making within another year.

STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, Sept. 23. -- The solid success achieved by the new Shakespeare Memorial Theatre in the first year of its existence is strikingly demonstrated by some preliminary figures of the attendances during the birthday and Summer festivals.

MADRID, Sept. 30. -- Russia has developed into a big stumbling block at the International Radio and Telegraph Conference. The biggest problem to be settled here, in the opinion of most of the delegates, is the allocation of wave lengths to keep the air free from interference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Sharp criticism of the Hoover Administration for taking credit for measures designed to relieve the credit stress of the farmer, was voiced today by Chairman Steagall of the House Banking and Currency Committee in a statement issued through the Democratic National Committee.

The quarterly reports of the Second National, Third National and Fourth National Investors Corporations, affiliated investment trusts of the National Investors Corporation, showed that as a result of the rise in security prices during the third quarter of this year net assets of the three trusts had increased $6,307,849 in value, based on market prices of Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 24 totaled 595.746 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 8,444 cars more than in the preceding week, 142,290 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 354,917 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Governor Roosevelt's presence probably reminded Ruth and Gehrig of the last Presidential election year, when they gave a homer-shooting performance in St. Louis as the quietus to the 1928 Cardinals in the last game of the series.

BUT the five hansoms were there. The count began with the one with yellow wheels and the ancient white horse and the stout, weather-beaten red-nosed old cabby nodding on his perch in front of the Plaza. It ended with the one with the chestnut nag in the shafts -- the chestnut with three white feet -- drowsing beside the curb just where General Sherman looks across at the Dark Lady of the Fountain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Detailed estimates of work at Crysler Island in the St. Lawrence waterway project, putting the probable expenditures at $274,742,000, were made public at the State Department today as an appendix to the report of the joint board of engineers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES printed the recent radio speech of H.I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. I was deeply interested in the whole of his address, but more especially in the part dealing with prohibition and his comparison with the British policy of handling the liquor traffic.

AS THE result of considerable checking, some independent investigation and a little guesswork, here are the shows which should arrive in this town during the month of October. Omitted, of course, are this week's premieres, which are to be found elsewhere in these pages.

DENVER, Sept. 29. -- The discovery of a skeleton chained to a rock at a deep level in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains in Southern Colorado has prompted an exploration of this territory which, according to legends of the Southwest Indians, once was worked for gold deposits by Spanish explorers.

OTTAWA, Sept. 29. -- Canada, according to the latest check-up, has 85,885 miles of surfaced highways, and owes for them approximately $400,000,000. This is one of the reasons why taxes have mounted in recent years to heights which are causing not a little concern to the nine provincial governments.

Charges that the Treasury Department moved without legal warrant in ordering importers to post "suspected dumping or anti-dumping bonds" covering importations of steel and of canvas-top rubber-soled shoes, were made by the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., yesterday in a telegram to Secretary Mills requesting suspension of the order and an early hearing on the question.

FROM the Cos Cob Press comes an early copy of the score for piano and voices of Louis Gruenberg's "opera in two acts, a prologue, an interlude, and six scenes," after the drama of Eugene O'Neill, "Emperor Jones." This opera will be the American novelty of the Metropolitan Opera Company's season of 1932-33.

Exhaustive studies that are being made of the National Electric Power Company and its subsidiary holding companies on behalf of the protective committees for holders of debentures of the parent company and the National Public Service Corporation, principal unit of the system, are expected to result in the early introduction of plans for a reorganization of the former $600,000,000 Eastern utility properties of the Insull group.

Mayor McKee issued a proclamation yesterday calling attention to the beginning of the "Share-the-Work" campaign throughout the nation tomorrow and urging all residents of the city to give the movement their utmost support for the general good of the community.
SOUTHBORO, Mass., Oct. 1. -- St. Mark's opened its season today by losing to a strong Boston Latin school eleven, 12 to 0.

SCHEDULED air lines operating within the borders of the United States, report the statisticians of the Aeronautics Branch, Department of Commerce, carried 53,759 passengers in the month of July. Thirtyone operating companies reported.

We are witnessing a curious reversal of one of MACAULAY'S historical epigrams. He spoke of the paradox of conflicts in Europe causing red men on the banks of the Mississippi to slaughter each other. Today the flow of subtle hut powerful influence is in the other direction across the Atlantic.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 1. -- South Carolina, with a big and versatile team, handed Villanova a surprising 7-to-6 defeat today. This was the first time the Carolina collegians ever played in the North.

PEABODY, Mass., Oct. 1. -- With the most devastating golf ever witnessed in the women's national championship. Miss Virginia Van Wie, 23-year old Chicagoan, captured the title at the Salem Country Club today when she defeated Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, five-time champion, 10 up and 8 to play.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Sept. 29. -- Lack of money with which, to purchase wheat for Fall seeding may cause an appreciable reduction in the 1933 acreage. There is considerable talk of seed pools and other emergency financing for the great hard-wheat belt in Southwest Kansas and Northwest Oklahoma.

Prices of commodities were slightly lower last week in the local futures markets, Coffee, which had had a spectacular rise previously, broke sharply in the middle of the week. There was an improved tone to sugar futures, while cocoa and rubber were lower, Silk was inactive with price changes small

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 29. -- After the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed, where will wet States get their whiskey? This is a question which will be propounded in the near future, and Kentucky is ready to answer it.

COPENHAGEN. IN an impressive audience room in the Town Hall of Copenhagen a husband and wife are seated at a conference table facing a mild-looking official in spectacles. "You are agreed," the official is saying, "that you want to separate with a view to getting a divorce?"

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1. -- For forty years Wisconsin has been hearing from the La Follettes and their followers about the "new deal" on the day when those who govern America will firmly place human rights above property rights and never forget which shall remain uppermost.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 1. -- A Pur- due football team, looking much like that which last year tied with Northwestern and Michigan for the West- ern Conference championship, ran all over the Kansas Aggies today. 29 to 13.

THERE is no denying, and certainly no wish to deny, the interest of the volume of etchings issued under the title "The Bicentennial Pageant of George Washington" in cooperation with the United States George Washington Bicentennial Commission and with its approval.

ESSEN, Germany. TO SEE Kurt Jooss's ballet, "Der Grune Tisch," presented in his home theatre, the charming little municipal opera house, is to lay once and for all the ghost of slander which whispers that only the lack of serious competition allowed the German groups to win all the awards in the Paris choreographic competition held by the International Archives of the Dance.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- The biggest exhibition of the history and most recent development of flying as a sport that Germany, and probably the world, has ever seen was opened here today with 500 invited notables crowding the large exhibition hall at the foot of the Funkturm for the ceremonies.

Sir Arthur Salter, director of the economic and finance section of the League of Nations, will head the list of speakers at the international university conference under the auspices of New York University at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Nov. 15, 16 and 17, Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown announced yesterday.

A New England carved mahogany claw-and-ball-foot card table, believed to be the only authenticated American piece of its type, is included in a collection of American Chippendale, Hepplewhite, Sheraton and the more primitive so-called Pilgrim period furniture of maple and hickory, the property of Benjamin Flaydorman, which will be sold Wednesday and Thursday afternoons at American Art Association Anderson Galleries.
WARDEN LEWIS E. LAWES tells the story of the prisoner who was being examined by a psychiatrist. "What made you take to crime?" the inquisitor asked. "Don't ask me, Doc," the prisoner replied.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The Chicago Joint Stock Land Bank, a $40,000,000 farm mortgage institution, was placed in receivership today. A.C. Williams, Acting Commissioner of the Federal Farm Loan Board in Washington, announced the appointment of John B. Gallagher of Chicago, president of the bank, as receiver.

The 184 members of the New York County Republican Committee in the Fifteenth Assembly District were urged yesterday by Keyes Winter, their leader, to demand of State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter an immediate repudiation of his Tammany nomination for the Supreme Court seat now held by Samuel I. Rosenman, former counsel to Governor Roosevelt.

ROME, Sept. 10, 1932 THE quadrennial Rossini commemoration of Pesaro coincided this year with the fiftieth, anniversary of the celebrated musical lyceum which bears the composer's name and was founded through the legacy left by him in honor of his native town.
NEW YORK. The Right Rev. James De Wolfe Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and Mrs. Perry are at the Gramercy Park.

Alfred E. Smith's belief, as expressed in his first signed editorial in the New Outlook, that the best interests of the nation would be served by the election of the Democratic ticket was hailed yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, as an "unqualified endorsement" of the Democratic party and ticket.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Cub fans today qualified for serious consideration if ever a world's baseball championship is awarded for indomitable faithfulness to a lost cause. Their loyal after-game reception to the badly battered Grimm men was as sensational as the mighty hitting of the Babe and Gehrig, which made the third straight world's series game the third straight Cub defeat.

INDUSTRY is not alone in turning the corner to meet prosperity half way. With as sturdy a faith in the future, new schools as well as factories are being opened this Fall. At least six such ventures of widely different sorts are starting hereabouts, and all are trying out novel schemes, most of which, however -- significantly enough in times of stress -- are adaptations of the socalled "progressive" theories of education.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- The United States proposal to reduce military effectives, which Hugh R. Wilson presented at Geneva yesterday, met a notably friendly response here today. The French were gratified because their thesis that all sorts of military formations must be taken into account had been incorporated in the United States plan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Officials of the twelve Home Loan Regional Banks today were summoned by Franklin W. Fort, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, to meet in Washington Wednesday for conferences on methods of operating the banks.

Although registration at Columbia University for the current school year has not been completed, preliminary figures made public yesterday by Edward J. Grant, registrar, indicate that this year's enrolment will show approximately 1,000 fewer students than last year.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 1. -- Production of nickel in Canada in July was 2,959,231 pounds; in the previous month, 3,162,310, and in July, 1931, 5,309,456, the Dominion Government announces. Exports of nickel in ore, matte or speiss in July were 782,500 pounds, made up of 503,800 pounds shipped to Norway, and 278,700 pounds to the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The third game of the world's series today between the Cubs and the Yankees was marked by an even dozen record performances, in nine of which Babe Ruth's exploits were involved.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 3. -- The Chinese Government must recognize as legal and lasting the redistribution of farm lands which has been made in the Communist-controlled areas of China and never attempt to return the lands to capitalist property owners.

The Art Students' League begins its fifty-eighth year tomorrow. Five artists have been added to its teaching staff: Walter Pach, well-known critic and painter, who recently organized an American room at the Louvre in Paris; John Steuart Curry, Luigi Lucioni, Arthur Young and Hang Hofman.

IN the tumult of a Presidential campaign it is easy to forget that behind the blazoned personalities of the candidates there stand other personalities, their wives, who may become a force to be reckoned with in public life.

General Charles Hitchcock Sherrill, Ambassador to Turkey, who says his ambition is to double the trade of the United States with that country, as he did in the case of Argentina when he was United States Minister there, expresses the highest admiration for President Mustapha Kemal.

IT took Men to do these things. Such men the ancient Greeks immortalized in song as heroes and set them only a little below their gods. The Vikings dowered such men with a glowing admiration that created for them a deathless Valhalla.

A listing of the multifarious activities engaged in by the more than 43,000 men and women who received 2,600,000 days of work in the last year through the efforts of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau of the Emergency Unemployment and Relief Committee was made public yesterday by Raymond W. Houston, assistant director of the bureau.
Democracy as Fashionable Ailment. The young man was down in the mouth about democracy. It wasn't working, that was plain enough. And the reason it didn't work was that it was based on a lie.

POINTING out that receipts for August from the Federal motor excise taxes amounting to $12,547,621 were "40 per cent" below expectations. Thomas P. Henry, president of the American Automobile Association, in a statement last week saw as "fully sustained" the contention that higher motor levies "would have a hampering effect on highway transport."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- President Hoover received today a memorandum from Jose L. Pesquera, Resident Commissioner from Puerto Rico, and Merton L. Corey, Scarsdale, N.Y., financial counsel for the Puerto Rican Department of Agriculture, setting out the plight of the island possession and recommending immediate relief in handling both the human problem resulting from the recent hurricane and the financial crisis augmented by the depression.

Bonds hardened somewhat yesterday in the slowest Saturday trading since Nov. 21, 1931, when sales on the New York Stock Exchange aggregated $4,054,000. Yesterday's volume was $4,169,000, comparing with $6,772,000 a week ago. Domestic and foreign bonds finished irregularly higher, while United States Government issues were slightly firmer in light dealings.

FOR the first time since the vigorous offensive which led to the adoption of the Eighteenth Amendment the friends of prohibition find themselves this year facing a formidable counteroffensive. They are rallying all their forces to meet the crisis, lest prohibition be repealed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Samuel Instill; his son, Samuel Insull Jr., and Martin Insull, his brother, were asked today by cable and telegraph by State's Attorney Swanson if they would return voluntarily from the foreign countries in which they now are, to explain certain phases of the collapse of the public-utility enterprises which they dominated.

Reports from the Federal Reserve districts last week indicated a gain in business activity as a whole, although not every section shared in the recovery. The Atlanta area reported the largest rise in wholesale trade since 1927, with department stores reporting business materially exceeding the normal seasonal rise.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29. -- Pittsburgh and Allegheny County are in a particularly fortunate position in the State-wide movement for reduction of the cost of local government. They have a joint committee of the Legislature to hear their complaints and recommendations and report to the Assembly.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 1. -- Rebels sacked the village of San Francisco del Carnicero, twenty miles north of Managua, this morning, burned several public buildings and carried off a number of women and children, according to reports to the National Guard here.

OMAHA, Sept. 29. -- With one candidate now in the heart of the corn belt and arrangements under way for the reception of another, the interest, if not the enthusiasm, of this area is distinctly focussed on national politics.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- In all discussions centring around France's policies in the Far East, one fact which has been overlooked must be borne in mind. This is that France, through her immensely rich possession of Indo-China, has a great stake in preserving her influence in that part of the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent reference to Majorca brings pleasant memories. When A. M.S. Hutchinson, the author, went to the island of Majorca some time ago, he expected to be met by ferocious natives garbed in tiger skins and armed with their famous slings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A reopening of the Interstate Commerce Commission's investigation into the reasonableness of newsprint freight rates in the East for further consideration was urged in a joint petition filed with that body today by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the Publishers Association of New York.

LONDON. THE Ottawa, conference has much more than a purely economic significance. It illustrates the stage now reached in the evolution of the British Empire and may indicate the way in which it will develop in future.
BETHAYRES, Pa., Oct. 1. -- The King's Oak steeplechase, one of the features of the annual Huntingdon Valley Hunt Meet at the Justa Farms track today, was won by George W. Elkins's Willingdon.

MANILA, Aug. 26. -- To a small luncheon given recently for members of the Philippine Senate, Governor General Roosevelt invited the father of Senator Benigno Aquino, and as a mark of respect for his age seated the aged General Servillano Aquino at his right.

DETROIT. HENRY FORD once more occupies the spotlight of the automobile industry, this time while competitors speculate as to what will be his next move in the intensive struggle looming in the popular-price field.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Displaying an offensive that seemed to function smoothly at times, but which occasionally bogged down, Ohio State defeated Ohio Wesleyan, 34 to 7, before an opening day crowd of 17,115 today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As so much is being said and written about farm relief, I think I may tell of some of the actual experiences of one family in Missouri, in the lean days during and following the Civil War. At the beginning of the war, we, a family of father, mother and three children, lived on a farm of 160 acres.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team, after a slow start, hit its stride and hammered a 38-0 victory over Franklin and Marshall College before a crowd of 15,000 at Franklin Field today.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Ridden by its owner, Mrs. J.T.A. Potter, of Mount Kisco, Frederick Philip, a bay mare, won premier laurels in the open jumping class at the second annual horse show conducted by the Lawrence Farms today on the Lawrence Hunt Club grounds.

"What Cars Could Be." AUTOMOBILES could have twice the acceleration of present-day cars; they could have twice the inside space for the same wheelbase and tread; they could be more comfortable and roomier, with movable seats; their gasoline mileage could be doubled; they could be considerably lighter in weight and lower in price.

THE civilized world lies tossing on a bed of sickness; doctors of economy have gathered round to feel her pulse and find out the nature of her ailment. Watch in hand, they have made a diagnosis; they assure sympathetic bystanders that the world suffers from a "circulatory failure."

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- Strong but chiefly philosophical criticism of the predominance and effects of American educational methods in China is expressed unanimously in the report of the educational mission that the League of Nations sent to China last year at China's request.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Intense disappointment is felt in Chicago because of the hostile attitude of the Legislature toward the housing bills introduced by the State Housing Commission at the special session now in progress. Hope for their passage virtually has been abandoned, and with that hope goes the prospect for any immediate effort to reduce unemployment by slum redemption and extensive building of lowrental dwellings.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- On the eve of the opening of the Sing Sing prison football season, Miguel Galveron, 36 years old, a New York City hold-up man, who was sent to the prison eight weeks ago by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions for a term of ten to twenty-five years, escaped from the prison yard this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Four home runs, two by the master hitter of them all, Babe Ruth, and the other pair by his almost equally proficient colleague, Columbia Lou Gehrig, advanced the New York Yankees to within one game of their third World's Series sweep today.

New York City bonds broke from 1 1/2 to 2 points further yesterday as small holders, disturbed by the action of Controller Berry and the Tammany members of the Board of Estimate in taking control of the 1933 budget out of the hands of Mayor McKee, hastened to dispose of their investments.

RECENTLY there was celebrated at Rheims the 250th anniversary of the discovery of champagne. A crown of vine blossoms was placed on the effigy of Dom Perignon, who was for forty-five years a cellarer of the Abbey of Hautvilllers.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 1. -- Miss Emilie S. Bromley's Rockabye, capably ridden by Morris H. Dixon, won the Melbrook Bowl, feature event on the final day's program at the Bryn Mawr horse show today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 29. -- Next Thursday afternoon the Governor General will drive in his state carriage to the Parliament buildings where, with all the formality and traditional ceremony of Westminster, he will open, in the name of the King, the regular session of the Parliament of Canada.

THIS is the best-dressed number of The Colophon we have seen. It is richer pictorially than ever before, but, what is more important, the quality of its illustrations is superb. The best example of the care being lavished upon these volumes occurs in the plates adorning George W. Davison's article.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Army met a strong opponent in the Furman University eleven of Greenville, S.C., today in the cadets' opening game of the season, played before 10,000 spectators in Michie Stadium. The cadets won, 13 to 0, but the two touchdowns came far apart and with a lot of hard work sandwiched in between.

LONDON, Sept. 17 A SECOND play by the previously unknown dramatist, Philip Leaver, of whose comedy at the Haymarket I wrote in these columns recently, has now appeared at Wyndham's, and we are left to wonder by what astonishing turn of fortune's wheel he was enabled to jump from obscurity into the uncommon position of having two pieces from his pen occupying two of the principal theatres in London.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 29. -- Seldom, if ever, in the history of the Commonwealth has a Ministry been assailed by so many hostile forces as have beset the Ministry of Premier Joseph A. Lyons in the last month. The assault began immediately when Premier Lyons presented his budget for 32-33.

THROUGHOUT history the country that has been regarded as the one of first importance has been the country that most interested the people of other lands. We acquired that position as the result of the World War, hence, the movement of foreign student to this country assumed large proportions only after that event.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 1. -- Penn State opened its season today by defeating Lebanon Valley, 27 to 0. The Lion varsity played only in the first half, scoring once in the first and twice in the second quarter. Harper and Sigel were the outstanding Penn State backs, the latter's 34yard run in the third quarter leading to the only score of the second half.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1. -- The Tennessee Volunteers opened another Southern Conference campaign today with a smashing 33 to 0 victory over the University of Mississippi. The victors showed greatly improved form over their opening game against Chattanooga.

Manufacturers are beginning to catch up on deliveries and the situation with respect to back-orders has been cleared considerably, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Retail reports continued good, with resulting calls for rush shipments in the local market.

THE LIVING SYMBOL. BACK in 1915, Berlin's Platz der Republik was Konigsplatz. In its centre rose a sixty-foot wooden statue, and as the months passed by its dull color was transformed into a metallic sheen. Long queues of people stood first to await their turn to buy iron, silver and gold nails and then to alive those nails into the wooden effigy.

WHEN James Haizlip crossed the country in 10 hours and 19 minutes he was asked if he thought the record would soon be broken. A few days later when Major James H. Doolittle established a land plane speed record of 296 miles an hour he was asked if the speed he had been flying affected him in any way.

Investigation of American colleges and universities, which he charges teach "subversive" doctrines, and of International House, which he termed a "hotbed of radicalism," was urged yesterday by Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive committee of the National Civic Federation, in a letter to Secretary of Labor Doak.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The radio debate begun last night between the resigned and the remaining Cabinet Ministers continued tonight when Sir Herbert Samuel, former Home Secretary, made an impassioned plea to the people that it was time the real voice of the nation be heard.

Paintings from the estate of Fannie Miller Bross and others will be offered in the first sale of the season at the National Art Galleries, Inc., in the Rose Room at the Hotel Plaza, on Thursday evening. The collection was placed on exhibition yesterday.

WHILE he was serving his last term as United State Senator from Mississippi, John Sharp Williams told the Legislature at Jackson, "I'd rather be a dog and bay the moor than serve a moment beyond my present incumbency."

ATLANTA, Sept. 29. -- There is an impression in the East that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt's pre-election visit to the South has something to do with the prohibition question. One inference is that the Democratic Presidential candidate is coming into this section to square himself on the dry issue with Southern drys.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 1. -- On its seventh annual attempt William and Mary realized its ambition by defeating Navy at football today, outplaying the midshipmen and winning by 6 to 0. The one score of the game was a touchdown made in the third quarter by Palese.

FRIEDELL has far some respects outdone himself in this third and final volume of his great cultural survey of Europe. A style that was brilliant before is often more brilliant now, the irony and sarcasm are even more devastating, and the intellectual penetration is more acute.

On the eve of the publication of the Lytton report it seems plain that in the League of Nations argument with Japan over Manchuria the strongest pressure will have to come from outside the League, namely from Secretary STIMSON. At Geneva it is to be expected that China will continue to be as outspoken as she has been.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- In the darkness at the close of a rare Autumn day, Alfred Delmont of Wynnewood, Pa., made the award of best in show, the final event of the tenth annual exhibition of the Westbury Kennel Association, which was held today on the polo field of the J.S. Phipps estate in Old Westbury.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 1. -- Outplayed by St. Thomas College of Scranton in the first half, Western Maryland rallied to triumph, 12 to 6. Western Maryland scored three points on a placement kick in the first period, seven on a touchdown and conversion in the third, and two on a safety in the final chapter.
The New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday letters which it had received from R.M. Estes. Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenue interpreting several provisions of the revenue act of 1932.

Unable to stop its opponents' brilliant forward passing and running attack, the C.C.N.Y. football team dropped the opening game of its season yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium, bowing to the strong Catholic University eleven of Washington, D.C., 47 to 0.

PARIS. THE big velvet vogue has inevitably fostered dressy afternoon suits. They are liked by girls and younger women because they are more youthful and less formal in effect than long-coat ensembles, even when the richness of their materials places them in the super-luxury class.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1. -- Wisconsin today sustained its reputation of never having met defeat on the gridiron at the hands of Marquette, but was pushed to the limit to gain a 7-2 victory in the opening game of the season.

EXEUNT, exeunt omnes. They all go out. But the sparkle of yesterday's stars of the stage still registers warmth in the hearts of those who refuse to have their memories clouded by the twinkling but elusive personalities of today's silver screen.

Former President Calvin Coolidge will speak in behalf of President Hoover at a rally to be held in Madison Square Garden the night of Oct. 11, it was announced yesterday at Republican National Committee headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

IT is usually a devious path that young singers, actors and orators follow from a college campus to the microphone. Most of the collegians who find a career awaiting them in the broadcasting studios progress by circuitous routes, seldom by deliberate planning.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The resignations this week of the free trade Ministers from the coalition Cabinet committed to a conservative program of protection have squeezed much of the hypocrisy out of the British political situation.
George Washington High School's football team registered a 14-0 triumph over Curtis High in the season's opener for both at the George Washington High School Stadium yesterday.

PANAMA, Sept. 27. -- Minority members of the National Assembly have attacked the modification of the liquor-smuggling treaty between the United States and Panama, although the proposed change is designed only to permit transportation of liquor from one part of Panama to the other through the Canal Zone, in which the Volstead act is in force.

On the whole, Governor ROOSEVELT got a "good press" for his Portland address dealing with the regulation of public utilities. Much of the comment, whether favorable or unfavorable, cut across ordinary party lines. The New York Herald Tribune, for example, referred to the Democratic candidate's speech as "easily "the best of his Western trip * * * based "on a genuine familiarity with the mate"rial under discussion."

THE day of the Amazons is not past if reports from South America, where a woman, Santa Dica, is said to be leading federal volunteers against the Sao Paulo rebels in Brazil, are to be trusted. There have been, of course, many women warriors whose courage led them at various times to take desperate chances for a cherished cause.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 (AP). -- President Paul von Hindenburg will celebrate his eighty-fifth birthday tomorrow with his Fatherland still in the throes of political unrest and another Reichstag election only a few weeks away.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1. -- Kentucky won its second Southern Conference football game today, defeating Sewanee by 18 to 0. Bach returned a Sewanee punt 51 yards for the first touchdown. Kercheval made the other Kentucky touchdowns, one on a line plunge after Kentucky had recovered a fumble on Sewanee's 9-yard line and the other on a 38-yard end run.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The formal opening of the new clubhouse of the Wykagyl Country Club, here, was celebrated tonight with a dinner dance.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Niagara's strong football team, displaying particular strength on the line, held Cornell to a 7 -- 0 victory in their annual game on Schoellkopf Field today.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1 (AP). -- With the Pittsburgh franchise again not operating and Ottawa back in the fold, the National Hockey League will have a nine-club circuit this Winter, the board of governors decided at the semi-annual meeting today.

September sales of men's clothing and furnishings by department stores and specialty shops here made the most favorable comparison with the corresponding period of 1931 of any month of the current year, according to estimates by store executives yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 1. -- Brown University opened its football season today by scoring a 19-0 victory over Rhode Island State College. Brown staged three marches, each for over 70 yards, to score its touchdowns, and on three other occasions was turned back when inside Rhode Island's 20-yard line.

HOLLYWOOD. BEHIND George M. Cohan's caustic interview published upon his return to New York after making "The Phantom President" for Paramount is another and quite different story. It is Hollywood's story and the town admits it as such, but with it is submitted the record of the filming of Mr. Cohan's first talking picture as substantiating evidence.

The hunting season having begun, nimrods are turning their attention to what particular upland or wild water fowl it is most desirable to shoot, both from a sporting standpoint and from the standpoint of the table. Of course, if one is hunting for deer he usually does so because for one reason -- a good deer steak is a rarity indeed.

FOURTH of the Mogul Emperors of India, Jahangir was the first "born in the palace," and the first to be weakened by the enervating heat of the country. Absolute ruler over the land conquered by his great-grandfather, he was a curious mixture of cruelty, indolence and good-nature.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1. -- Sixteen thousand men are engaged in battle in the Chaco region in the largest conflict yet waged in the unofficial war between Paraguay and Bolivia.

Henry S. Prichett, president emeritus of the Carnegie Foundation and a trustee of the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace, returned from Europe yesterday with Mrs. Prichett on the Holland-America liner Statendam.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. THE history of the stage in Chicago this Fall would be like a page out of the chronicles of the Dark Ages, when there wasn't any drama, if "Another Language" and "Of Thee I Sing" hadn't come along to brighten the dismal picture.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 1. -- Northwestern had to call in three cripples, Captain Pug Rentner, Dick Fengl and George Potter, to quell Missouri's unruly Tigers today, but did a thorough job after getting started, winning by 27 to 0.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra will begin its fifty-second season at Symphony Hall in Boston with a pair of concerts on Friday and Saturday. Serge Koussevitzky, who arrived from Europe last week, will open his ninth season in this country.

ROME, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini announced his "invincible repugnance" to the word "intellectuals'' today when he addressed a peace meeting attended by 10,000 Fascist leaders, representing 120,000 Italian grain workers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of the genesis of the incandescent electric lamp, which was observed three years ago, and of the opening of the first electric light and power plant in New York, which was celebrated recently, glowing and merited tribute was paid to Thomas Alva Edison.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Senator Smoot of Utah, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and co-author of the Smoot-Hawley tariff bill, struck back tonight at Governor Roosevelt's criticisms of Republican tariff policy with categorical replies to what he termed "errors" by the Governor.

THE machine-gun style of narrative, short explosive sentences, sometimes only a word to a line, in which "Death of a Fleet" was written, is not best suited to a subject so important as the mutinies in the High Sea Fleet which ended in the collapse of the German Navy in the World War.

ORONO, Me., Oct. 1. -- Presenting a diversified attack on reverse and spin plays, the University of Maine Bears got their new shift functioning properly today and rolled roughshod over the Connecticut Agricultural College by a 33 to 0 tally.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1. -- Good fortune handed the University of Southern California its first victory of the Pacific Coast Conference football season today at the expense of Washington State, the score being 20 to 0.

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Endorsement of the national candidates, Franklin D. Roosevelt and John N. Garner, was voted by the Massachusetts State Democratic Convention by acclamation and without debate here today when it adopted a platform also approving the national party platform and the State ticket headed by Governor Ely.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Acclaimed by 2,500 men and women as the next President of the United States, Governor Roosevelt tonight aroused the enthusiasm of the Illinois Democracy by repeating his advocacy of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and modification of the Volstead act.

SOME time ago Paramount asked thirty well-known writers what they would do if a million dollars were suddenly to fall in their laps. Now, under the title "If I Had a Million," the picture, is being prepared for production under a unique schedule which will utilize virtually every player at the Paramount studio.

Prominent members of the stage and screen and many members of society attended the opening last night of the Pierrette Dansante Club in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The occasion inaugurated a series of Saturday night supper dances, which will be continued through the season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- President Hoover was urged today to make Ohio the scene of his second campaign speech, several of his advisers pointing out that his presence in the Buckeye State would be effective in stirring up Republican workers and overcoming a reported Democratic trend.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19. -- Never since the Pacific scooped out the rugged California coast line has there been such, a scrambling of issues and candidates, of pros and cons, as are presented to the voters of this fair Commonwealth a month before election.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 5 -- After a year of parleying, the Chinese banks have finally submitted to a levy on banknotes, and have paid into the Nanking treasury $3,060,000, as tax for one year on Banknotes outstanding.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 3. -- By adding 10 per cent to all freight charges on all Chinese railroads, the Ministry of Railways will try to break up a "squeeze" system which has developed to such an extent that shippers use the railways only when they cannot use ships or junks, and which has made shipping by rail so precarious that banks refuse to make loans against bills of lading.

THE journey to Europe two years ago of American aviators flying American military equipment is beginnning to bear fruit. Major James H. Doolittle and two companions took three military planes abroad for the Curtis-Wright Export Corporation and flew them first in Turkey and then in several other countries.

HIGHLY stimulating in your issue of Sunday, Sept. 18, was Mr. Downes's article, entitled "Orchestral Market." in which he set forth some of the things which are troubling orchestral conductors and their boards of directors this year, notably the part of his very able article devoted to a discussion of the subject of performing fees.

The reduction by Great Britain and France of the annual charges on their internal war debts through their successful operations for conversion of bonds invites comparison of the burden of interest charges on the war-time borrowings of the United States and its allies in the war.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 1. -- New Hampton Prep was turned back by Andover in the opening game of the season today, 25 to 0.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30. -- Soviet observers see the rest of the world on the brink of disaster. The League of Nations is held to be bankrupt in prestige and impotent to tackle the most vital issues of disarmament and Manchuria. In Soviet opinion, the Manchurian problem is far the more important.

MORE books and autograph letters of Dickens are offered for public sale each year than corresponding writings of any other author. That is partly because he was so prolific and his editions so large, but mostly because there is still more demand for him than for any one else.

Realty interests generally expressed disappointment yesterday over the tentative assessment figures for next year as announced by the Department of Taxes and Assessments. Several organizations voiced the opinion that the net reduction of slightly more than $719,000,000 was too small to afford much relief from what they termed the "present unbearable burden of taxation against the property owners," and said that the new figures were out of line with the general trend of values.

Since adjournment of Congress in July a committee appointed Toy the House of Representatives has been taking testimony on the Government's activity in fields once thought to be reserved to private enterprise. Hearings have been held in different cities. Various Federal activities have been explored.

More of the city's pastors will return to their pulpits this morning after having been away through the Summer. Afternoon and evening worship will be resumed in numerous churches. Vested choirs will again take their places in their stalls. Not a few Sunday schools will reopen for the Winter.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 1. -- V.P.I. upset Georgia in a thrilling game today, 7 to 6. Casey crashed through Georgia's defense from the 4-yard line for the V.P.I. touchdown in the second period. Hite kicked the extra point.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. AFTER hesitating uncertainly on the brink for some time, the new season has at last dived off. It hit the water gracefully enough, but, as it is still under the surface, we don't know in what state it may reappear to our anxious eyes.

GRIDIRON heroes are in the making. The big intercollegiate football games will soon be in full swing. Everywhere girls are wondering how many of the big events they will attend. They, like the captains, are counting ton scoring goals, but whether they get over the line depends not on forward passes, but in a large measure on what they wear.
EXHIBITION by Young Painters: Sponsored by the College Art Association. This opened last Monday at the Ferargil Gallery. It remains until Oct. 15. Reviewed Sept. 27 and on this page.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Captain Larry Schlums advanced the ball 145 yards out of a total of 327 gained by Wesleyan, to lead his team to a 16-to-6 victory over Union College today.

RADIO comedians on furlough from the stage are confronted with a new problem. In the theatre a joke may last a year but on the air it is good for only one performance. The ethereal comedians cannot turn the jokes out fast enough, so they have sent an urgent call for jokesmiths to assist in preparation of the broadcasts.

THE first murder in this exceptionally well-wrought detective story occurs in an orchard adjoining a commodious English farmhouse where several artists and a writer of mystery dramas are in residence as paying guests of the dour rustic landlord.

ROME, Sept. 18. -- Since the proclamation of the Corporative State," the Fascist regime has been striving to organize all employers and workers into corporations and syndicates, which represent the class interests of every branch of the nation's productive activities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The government went into the second quarter of the fiscal year today with a deficit of $402,320,914, as Treasury officials were preparing estimates for the budget which goes to Congress in December and were considering the possible necessity for additional economy and taxation measures.

Only a small proportion of exporters doing business with South American nations have stopped shipping there because of current exchange difficulties, according to a survey completed last week by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene D. Klein of 211 Central Park West gave a reception and dinner last night in the Italian Garden of the Ambassador to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. Mr. Klein and his wife, the former Miss Fanny Kreielsheimer, were married in the Terrace Gardens, then located on Fifty-eighth Street near Lexington Avenue, by the late Rev. Dr. Huebsch of the Central Synagogue.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday made up the smallest total for a Saturday since July 9. They were only about one-fourth as large as those of the previous Saturday, the figures being 338,000 shares, compared with 1,336,170. Price movements were as sluggish as might be expected in such a dull market.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Mystifying opponents as well as 15,000 spectators with intricate reverses, Stanford University opened its 1932 Pacific Coast Conference football season today with a sparkling 27-to-0 victory over Oregon State College.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Saratoga mineral waters, bottled and sold, are not subject to a Federal tax, Attorney General Bennett decided today in a ruling sent to the Saratoga Springs Commission. A Federal tax of 2 cents a gallon was enacted by Congress.

MICKEY WALKER bounded out of his corner in the eighth round in the Garden Bowl on Long Island last Monday night, thus furnishing the spectators with the sight of a man leaping to his own conclusion. As the crowd trudged away from the scene the general opinion seemed to be that the next heavyweight champion of the world would be Herr Max Schmeling of Bremerhaven, Germany.

The cotton market lost yesterday a good part of Friday's advances. Covering on the previous day had cased the technical position, and Southern hedging and scattered selling increased yesterday under the influence of relatively easy Liverpool cables and reports of more favorable weather in the South.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 1. -- Charges that Governor Roosevelt headed a concern organized in 1922 "to speculate in German marks and misery" were made by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan in an address at a Republican rally here tonight.

SOMEWHERE in a large school system of a large city a story is going the rounds which elicits chuckles from those who hear it, particularly if they themselves are part of the pedagogic scheme. It is said that at the commencement exercises of one of the populous high schools a youth sat waiting for the usual "rights, privileges and immunities" to be conferred upon him.

THERE is nothing topheavy about the millinery mode this season. Well-dressed femininity is going to be decidedly light-headed if it follows the trail blazed by Paris modistes. Hats are soft as pussy willows and light as thistledown.

RETURNED from Europe, Boston's Mr. Parker has been getting back into the journalistic swing by, among other things, interviewing the Lunts, Lynn and Alfred, who have been in the Transcript's territory on behalf of "Reunion in Vienna."
PARIS. DUHAMEL'S new novel has a title that will be the despair of translators: "Tel qu'en lui-meme enfin . . . " The words are taken from the first line of an admirable poem of Mallarme's:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Playing in a continual downpour, Syracuse University buried St. Lawrence under an avalanche of touchdowns to score a 54-to-0 victory tonight. The rain failed to hamper the Orange as much as it did last week.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Williams met its first defeat in five years on Western Field today, bowing to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute of Troy by a score of 7 -- 6.

The plan of operation of the Rehabilitation Corporation, an organization sponsored by the Anaconda Copper Company, the First Bancredit Corporation of St. Paul, Minn., the Crane Company and the American Brass Company, subsidiary of the Anaconda Company, was made public here yesterday by Spruille Braden, vice president and general manager.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Oct. 1. -- For the first time in twelve years, a Pennsylvania team of golfers was able to carry back home the Lesley Cup, which a Philadelphian, Robert A. Lesley, put into competition more than twenty-five years ago.

ROME, Sept. 30. -- One of the most colossal tasks to which Italy has applied herself under the Fascist regime is the total reclaiming of all the vast tracts of swampy ground scattered throughout the territory in which malaria still reigns supreme.

ALTHOUGH "Clear All Wires!" is the most nearly expert of the new plays, "Success Story" is, in the opinion of this column, the most stimulating. When John Howard Lawson writes a play he runs a temperature; the longer you sit before his raging character study the more likely you are to catch some of the fever yourself.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., sprang two upsets today to gain the final of the first annual men's Invitation tennis tournament at the Sleepy Hollow Manor Club. Shields also won two matches.

TO those who do not choose their books from the French on the basis of what can be read "without the possibility of a blush" it would be unfair to recommend "Magnificat." Thirty years ago Edmund Gosse was gladdened and surprised to find in Bazin one living French novelist whose work might safely be put into the hands of cloistered virgins.

THE announcement of the plans of the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra, which will begin its series of twenty concerts at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 1, brought an immediate response from other cities in the form of delegations of unemployed musicians.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The popular racing jacket of Colonel Edward R. Bradley of Lexington, Ky., was carried to victory in the Stickney Purse at Lincoln Fields today. Under a perfect ride by Jockey J. Smith, Ballygran, 2-year-old son of Bubbling Over, led the small field from start to finish.

THE only effective way of silencing criticism of the League and bringing to its support millions who at present stand aside in apathy or look at its activities with undisguised cynicism is to show unmistakably that the covenant of the League is a solemn pact, the obligations of which no State, great or small, will find it possible to ignore.

SHOULD there be any doubt as to the state of affairs in the recording world, current events should dispel them. It is to be hoped that readers are not tiring of being informed that the chief functions of the gramophone are preservation and supplying a means of exploration.

New York University's footbali team yesterday opened the new season by defeating Hobart, 33 to 0, before 10,000 spectators at Ohio Field, and for the first time in seven years started along the gridiron path without the guidance of Chick Meehan.

BERLIN, Sept. 19, 1933. THE young season is already a good month old. It began in the depths of a sweltering August, when the Stadtische Oper, after a short Summer's breathing spell, invited its patrons to consider an elaborately decorated revival of Lortzing's "Undine."

With a drive and a zest that bespoke greater things ahead, Fordham opened another chapter in its volume of football history by vanquishing the University of Baltimore eleven, 69 to 0, at Fordham Field yesterday.

New York University's footbali team yesterday opened the new season by defeating Hobart, 33 to 0, before 10,000 spectators at Ohio Field, and for the first time in seven years started along the gridiron path without the guidance of Chick Meehan.

BERLIN, Sept. 19, 1933. THE young season is already a good month old. It began in the depths of a sweltering August, when the Stadtische Oper, after a short Summer's breathing spell, invited its patrons to consider an elaborately decorated revival of Lortzing's "Undine."

With a drive and a zest that bespoke greater things ahead, Fordham opened another chapter in its volume of football history by vanquishing the University of Baltimore eleven, 69 to 0, at Fordham Field yesterday.

RADIO is blessed with a new idea on how to stop man-made static from bombarding the programs. Several manufacturers are introducing simple gadgets to perform the trick. It is heralded as of "major importance in the realization of noiseless reception."

The Rockefeller fortune, held by John D. Rockefeller and his son, John D. Rockefeller Jr., has been severely affected by the depression and may now rate as one of the minor large fortunes of this country instead of the greatest in the world, in the opinion of John T. Flynn, economist and biographer of the elder Rockefeller.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1. -- Georgia Tech's eleven opened the 1932 season today with a decisive 32-to-14 victory over Clemson. A feature was a 50-yard run for a touchdown by Galloway, Georgia Tech halfback, in the quarter.

FEW motion pictures have been endowed with the magnetic quality of "Maedchen in Uniform" ("Girls in Uniform"), the German-language film with subtitles in English which is now at the Criterion. It is a model of restraint, with excellent contrasting character studies, and the fine acting coupled with the artistic direction lends to it a lifelike impression seldom found in a screen work.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- A golfer who has trod the fairways of more than 1,000 different courses in the past twenty-two years, Ralph A. Kennedy of Winged Foot and the New York Athletic Club, recently stroked his way over the picturesque links of the Sagamore Golf Club at Bolton Landing, and at the end of his round classified it as one of the six best courses he has ever played.

DRESDEN, Oct. 1. -- Eugen d'Albert's last opera, "Mr. Wu," on which the 68-year-old pianist-composer was working at the moment of his sudden death in Riga last March, was produced here for the first time anywhere on Thursday night and performed simultaneously at Wiesbaden, Breslau, Aachen, Danzig and Freiburg the next evening.

An action that observers declare will come as near to providing the mythical "bank that cannot fail" as the present civilization will allow, was taken by the savings banks of New York State when their annual convention last week approved unanimously the establishing of a central bank to act as a modified Federal Reserve System for savings banks.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- Yale's first victory of the new football season was postponed today by a fighting eleven in scarlet jerseys from Bates College in Maine.
PASADENA, Cal., Oct. 1 (AP). -- A single photograph perplexed noted scientists today and amazement threatened to upset accepted theories regarding the structure of the atom.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- A deadlock between the boards of trustees of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown over a name for a proposed consolidation of the two villages was broken tonight when a joint meeting of the boards decided to retain the name Tarrytown by a vote of 12 to 2.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Miss Virginia Van Wie started her sports adventures as a football player and wound up as the American women's golf champion.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Springfield College opened its 1932 football season this afternoon by defeating East Stroudsburg, 20 to 0. The Maroons scored touchdowns in the first, second and fourth quarters, Captain Bob Brown accounting for two of them.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Crumpet, the Trillora Farm's brilliant bay gelding, and winner of three blue ribbons in yesterday's competition, won the jumping championship of the seventh annual twoday Montclair horse show by scoring a spectacular victory in the hunter and jumper sweepstakes today at the Montclair Riding Club ring.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 1. -- The Bogota Press insists that unless and until Peru's forces interfere with the Colombian expedition sent to re-establish Colombian authority in the port of Leticia, seized by Peruvians Sept. 1 as an internal police action, there is no international question between Colombia and Peru that can be submitted to arbitration by the League of Nations or another tribunal.

In the famous low-temperature laboratory of the University of Leyden, Professor KEESOM has succeeded in reaching a temperature of minus 272.29 degrees centigrade, which is but 71 degree above theoretical absolute zero. Separated from the outer air by shells of liquid hydrogen and liquid air and by vacuous spaces is the holy-of-holies -- a spoonful of liquid helium.

LONDON. THE most important biographies of the forthcoming season are likely to be political. We are promised, at long last, the first two volumes of J.L. Garvin's "Joseph Chamberlain" (Macmillan), which will trace his career as far as 1835, when he became Colonial Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The erection of several lights to mark the recently opened deep water channel in the Hudson River has been started by the Federal Lighthouse Service in cooperation with the State of New York, the Commerce Department stated today.
GIBRALTAR, Oct. 1. -- Seventy-five first-class passengers, including former Mayor Walker of New York, left the liner Rex this morning when they found her still at Gibraltar with no signs of moving.
MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Oct. 1. -- The University of Pittsburgh routed West Virginia's eleven today, 40 to 0.

Turning against China virtually the same weapons with which the Nanking Government is attacking Japan before the League of Nations, the Tokyo Government, in its White Book released yesterday, charges Chi- nesa "treaty violation" and "acts of hostility" with responsibility for Japanese actions in Manchuria.

RICHMOND, Sept. 29. -- If the shift in sentiment on the prohibition issue in the rest of the country during recent years has been as startling as it has been in Virginia, there would seem to be little doubt that the next Congress will vote to submit the question of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to the States.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 1. -- General Bartolome Blanche, acting President since Provisional President Carlos Davila was forced out by a revolt last month, resigned tonight. He planned to deliver the government into the hands of Humberto Oyanedel, President of the Supreme Court.

GIBRALTAR, Oct. 1. -- Declaring that it was imperative that he should get in touch with New York by telephone as soon as possible, in order to ascertain how things were going there and to reply to important political questions, former Mayor Walker and his party left the Italian liner Rex here today and started overland for Paris.

Behind a well masked attack that packed power, speed and precision Columbia cleared the decks for its game with Princeton next week by administering a sound beating to Lehigh before a crowd of 20,000 at Baker Field yesterday. Tallying a touchdown in the first seven minutes of play after a 75-yard march, the Blue and White went on to bury the Bethlehem team under a 41-to-6 score.

Not the least important of the problems which will face both retailers and manufacturers during the period of business recovery and in the eventual establishment of economic stability will be those dealing with the pricing of goods, according to views expressed in retail quarters during the week.

Determined to protect at all costs their own local control, and avowing that their attitude toward the State ticket and especially the Gubernatorial candidacy of Lieutenant Governor Lehman was "up in the air," the city's Democratic leaders, headed by John F. Curry, left for Albany at 5:30 yesterday afternoon to prepare for the opening of the Democraitc State Convention on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Although valued at considerably less than in 1931, nearly half of the chief commodities imported were received in larger quantities during the first six months of 1932 than in the corresponding period of last year, according to a foreign trade review made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
