PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- Following is the text of the address of Secretary Stimson before the Union League Club tonight:
BERLIN. SPEAKING in the Reichstag twenty years ago, Herr von Oldenburg Januschau made the now historic remark that the most effective political instrument in Germany was a "Lieutenant and ten men."

THE classic utterance of Matthew Arnold on the poet Shelley, calling him a beautiful and bright angel, but insisting that he moved ineffectual wings in an empty void, has seemed to many to apply (with certain variations) even more pertinently to Algernon Charles Swinburne.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Overcoming a big weight handicap, Rutgers defeated Pennsylvania Military College today, 20 to 6. The visitors scored first, but after that their attack weakened and a fast and aggressive Scarlet team had all the better of the play.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Holy Cross scored its second victory of the season today by beating Providence College, 26 to 6, a duplicate of the 1931 victory over the Friars.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Down-State Illinois is warming up to Judge Henry S. Horner, Democratic nominee for Governor. A month ago there was grave doubt among his supporters whether he could so tar cut the Len Small majority outside of Cook County as to be able to win with the margin which Chicago and its satellite communities are expected to give him.

Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, the explorer, will be ready to lead another expedition to Eastern Mongolia as soon as the Japanese have dispersed the bandits and irregular troops and restored peace in Manchuria, where he will have his new base, he said in an interview yesterday.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 1. -- Dartmouth's eleven ran into unexpected opposition from Vermont today and the visitors from Burlington put up a plucky battle before submitting to the big Green, 32 -- 0.
VIENNA, Sept. 17. -- At Ried-im-Innkreis police court today an almost medieval story was told of how two gypsies had reaped rich plunder from superstitious Austrian peasants.

THE seventy-third year of Worcester music festivals will take place this Fall from Wednesday evening through Saturday afternoon. Six concerts in all will be presented, one on Wednesday evening, one each in the afternoon and evening both on Thursday and Friday and the final one on Saturday afternoon.

BUFFALO, Oct. 1. -- With his wife at the controls for a major portion of the trip, F. Trubee Davison, Republican candidate for the nomination for Governor of New York and Assistant Secretary of War for Aviation, braved a hazardous headwind to fly here today in his own amphibian from Locust Valley, L.I.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I reply to the two correspondents who, in letters appearing in THE TIMES, take exception to statements of mine made in "Some of Our First Happenings"?

A reduction of $719,151,858 in the assessment on taxable real estate in New York City is shown on the tentative assessment rolls for 1933, made public yesterday by James J. Sexton, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments. The tentative assessment for 1933 is $18,225,064,709.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Governor Roosevelt's attack on international lankera for selling foreign securities to American investors was challenged today by the Republican National Committee, which cited the fact that ten years ago the Democratic nominee himself was president of a concern to sell German marks to American investors.

A new racket among truckmen in the city, growing out of the Autumn moving season last week, was reported by Detective O'Brien of the Radical Squad in Tombs Court yesterday when one truckmen was released in $1,000 bail for hearing next Thursday on a conspiracy charge made by another truckman.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1. -- The Chamber of Deputies is planning a vigorous offensive against Argentina's high protective tariff policy at the next regular session of Congress following the appointment last night of a committee of nine to study possible reforms in customs laws during the recess.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- An East Boston alien was arrested today in the investigation of the explosion at Judge Webster Thayer's home in Worcester as police pressed their hunt following the offer of a $50,000 reward for apprehension of the bombers.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- Secretary Stimson, reviewing tonight the achievements of the Hoover Administration in world affairs, challenged the nation to name any other American administration "which by leadership in times of peace has in so brief a period so powerfully and beneficially affected so many great nations."

ATHOUGH over the past several years he has produced several long poems, including the unforgetable "Tristram." Edwin Arlington Robinson has published no volume containing only new shorter pieces. All other reasons aside, therefore, the collection of poems bearing the title "Nicodemus," with ten other pieces following the title poem, must perforce awaken the liveliest curiosity.

DALLAS, Sept. 29. -- It may be difficult to understand, but Texana sometimes put aside politics for business. In recent weeks, despite the burning issue of Fergusonism, there has been marked apathy in matters political and more serious attention has been given to apparently improving economic conditions, due mainly, of course, to the better cotton market.

Taking stock in a brief pause at the three-quarter post, Wall Street summarizes the business and financial situation roughly as follows: The security markets are in a state of suspended animation with speculative interest at a low ebb. Business continues to expand cautiously, indications pointing to a slight improvement in company earnings for the third quarter.

AT the forthcoming election the voters of New York State will ballot on the Porter-Brereton "recreational amendment" to the State Constitution permitting within the Forest Preserve "such recreational facilities as are not inconsistent with its general wild forest character."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The great god politics has overshadowed all else for the last week, and, since the Democrats are on the offensive, it would appear to have heen a Democratic week. The Republicans have yet to bring up their heavy artillery, but Governor Roosevelt has covered the greater portion of a transcontinental tour that has left no doubt of his campaigning ability.

Tasting victory for the first time under the regime of its new coach, Chick Meehan, the Manhattan eleven overwhelmed the St. Joseph College team of Philadelphia, 32 -- 2, before a crowd of 12,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

ALTHOUGH popular opinion holds that Colonial furniture was little affected by fashion, nevertheless, records of the past and a study of eignteenth-century pieces still surviving show that vogues were as important then as now.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 1. -- Exeter defeated the University of New Hampshire freshmen, 14 -- 6, today in its opening game of the season. The victors' first touchdown resulted from a long forward pass, Kidd to Chubet, which put the ball on the 5-yard line, and from there Biladeau went over, Kidd's kick for the extra point was good.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The Axon, sailed by Miss Lorna Whittelsey, this year's champion of the Long Island Sound interclub class, scored a victory today in the special class yacht race on the Sound, a post-season event which was attended with surprisingly good weather for October.

It is remembered that THOMAS JEFFERSON desired to have inscribed upon his tomb not the offices that he had held but a list of the things that he had done. President HOOVER could wish, whatever his term of office, to have written of his life when it has come to an end that he was a friend to the children of the world.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 1. -- Johns Hopkins University ushered in its 1932 football campaign today with a 21-to-0 victory over Washington College of Chestertown, Md.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29. -- There is one feature of Governor Pinchot's conflict with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in connection with obtaining a relief loan for Pennsylvania which escaped attention at the time, hut which is now causing considerable comment.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2. -- Finance Minister Hueyo won a decisive and perhaps final victory over the inflationists when at the last meeting of the Senate at this year's ordinary session he obtained postponement of the project to issue 300,000,000 pesos ($75,000,000) secured by national mortgage bank bonds.

The increasing trend toward better merchandise was indicated here last week in the wholesale markets by a sharp increase in the number of requests for higher-price goods. Buying activity continued brisk in nearly every department. One of the few exceptions was the better dress coat market, which is still slow.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 2. -- The Canadian Parliament will assemble on Thursday and remain in session for at least six weeks, when it will be adjourned until late in January. On Oct. 13 the trade agreement between Canada and Great Britain will be tabled in Parliament and made public simultaneously in London, although the British Parliament does not meet until Oct. 18.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- The trusty right arm of Benny Friedman, coach, captain and quarterback, gave the Brooklyn Dodgers a 14-0 victory over the Boston Braves in the opening game of the National Professional Football League at Braves Field today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The 1932 world's series was featured by seventeen outstanding additions to the list of championships records. Altogether in four games, fifteen records were broken and two others equalled. Babe Ruth figured in exactly thirteen record feats.

Alarmed at reports from Albany indicating that political considerations might result in the shelving of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, business and civic leaders joined yesterday in urging his nomination for Governor upon John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, and John H. McCooey, his Brooklyn ally.

Mayor CURLEY, returning to his Boston after traveling 10,000 miles, was greeted by 10,000 of his people. Marching in triumph from train to platform, he was surrounded by enthusiasts bearing banners on each of which was inscribed the name of a city that he had entranced.

ADAMS CENTRE, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP). -- "It will take only about one week to drive out the New York distributers who have been upsetting the market by price cuts," said a statement issued today by Rowland M. Sharpe, chairman of the emergency committee of the New York Milkshed, Bradley Warden of Adams Centre, and Barney Clifton, spokesman for the Boonville producers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- States and several cities are moving to expedite low cost housing and slum clearances, with the aid of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the council of the American Engineering Council said in a statement from its headquarters today.

The last month brought further recovery from the period of fear and credit strain, as it gave some indications of expanding business activity, says the current bulletin of the National City Bank. Nevertheless, the bank sounds a note of warning against the tendency to expect too rapid a revival.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Princeton University completed its last fiscal year, ending June 30, without a deficit, according to Edward D. Duffield, acting president of the university, in a statement appearing in the current issue of the Princeton Alumni Weekly.

Observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, 424 West Thirty-fourth Street, reached its culmination yesterday morning with a solemn jubilee mass attended by many leaders in the Catholic clergy here. The celebration, which began Sept. 21, will end today with a solemn requiem mass.
The Chase National Bank will receive until Thursday tenders of New South Wales external 5 per cent sinking fund bonds of 1968, to be purchased at par and interest with $120,509 in the sinking fund.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- A new theory that cosmic rays are electrically charged particles shot from some unknown source in remote interstellar space was tentatively presented today by Professor Arthur H. Compton. He returned Friday to his laboratory at the University of Chicago, after roving the Western Hemisphere since March measuring the intensity of these mysterious emanations.

At the State convention in Albany, the leaders of the Democratic organization in Greater New York will be, as it were, put through a searching examination under the eyes of the people of the whole State. What will be tested is not merely their political sincerity but their political sagacity.

The Board of Estimate members who voted Saturday to strip Mayor McKee of the exclusive power to prepare the tentative budget for 1933 did so, not because of any desire to assume direct responsibility for municipal expenditure, but because of a wish to protect the payroll positions of workers in the Manhattan, Brooklyn and Richmond organizations, friends of Mayor McKee declared yesterday.

An automobile, out of control, bounced over the curb of the Grand Concourse in the Bronx yesterday, between East 181st Street and East Burnside Avenue, knocked down and seriously injured a young couple, and careened back to the street, only to run on to the sidewalk again in the next block, where it felled four pedestrians, including two children.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- Three young men and a young woman were killed here late this afternoon when a Stinson Junior monoplane went into a nose dive just north of the Clintonville Road and crashed to the ground.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The New York A.C. nine scored one run in the ninth to register a 3-to-2 triumph over the New Rochelle A.C. at City Field today before 5,000.

The Third Avenue Railway Company reports for the fiscal year ended June 30 a consolidated net income of $460,138, as compared with $289,379 in the preceding fiscal year. Total operating revenues were $15,816,699, against $16,876,128, while operating expenses were reduced to $11,729,538 from $12,867,296.

MADRID, Oct. 2 (AP). -- James J. Walker is expected to sail for New York on Tuesday at Cherbourg aboard the liner Europa. [The Europa is due in New York next Sunday, three days after the Democratic City Convention in New York to select a candidate for Mayor.]

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 2. -- The market for cotton contracts here was erratic and nervous last week. Trading alternated between periods of quiet and great activity and prices, after tending to rally early as a result of excessive rains in the cotton region, dropped sharply in the latter half of the week, lowering the level nearly $3 a bale and carrying values below the 7-cent line for most of the trading months.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 2. -- Marking the opening of the Fall hunt season, Mrs. Fay Ingalls, M.F. H., Bath County Hounds, and Mr. Ingalls were hosts to more than ninety persons at a hunt breakfast held today at the Cascades Inn. The inn was attractively decorated for the occasion.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- With the Guber-natorial situation holding the spotlight for the entire day, the makeup of the rest of the slate of nominees to be chosen at the Democratic State Convention did not get past the preliminary stage today.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- It is known here that the line Secretary of State Stimson will take following the issuance of the Lytton report is to press for a conference among China and Japan and the neutrals on the future of Manchuria. It may be said there is some support for that view here.

The Public Service Commission was accused yesterday by Louis D. Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, of failing to regulate in the public interest the "exorbitant rates" of telephone, gas and electric utility companies. Mr. Waldman called upon the commission to "state publicly the controlling reasons" for its alleged failure to take the initiative in protecting the interests of the public.

The new union inland freight terminal of the Port of New York Authority, which covers the entire block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and West Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, will be opened today to the shippers and consignees of less-than-carload freight in the port district.

DETROIT. Oct. 2. -- Three leaders of religious thought, Protestant, Catholic and Jewish, were cited today by Governor Roosevelt to support his declaration for a more equitable distribution of wealth, first voiced in a speech at San Francisco.

In a closely fought and exciting game, the Governor's Island quartet defeated West Point, 7 -- 6, before a crowd of 3,000 at Governors Island yesterday and gained the final round of the Second Corps Area championship polo tournament. The home team will play Saturday's winner, Essex Troop, in the final next Sunday.

YOUNGSTSOWN, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- For the first week in October Mahoning Valley iron and steel companies report production schedules around 20 per cent of capacity, with a distinctly improved sentiment pervading the industry, and expectations of substantial betterment during the month.

Entering the year's final quarter with a purposeless spirit in striking contrast to the vigor and determination that were evident less than three months ago, the security and commodity markets are plainly reflecting the financial uncertainties of the season.

A ruling permitting the marine insurance companies a free hand in writing insurance on imports and exports so long as the subject matter of the insurance maintains its character as such has been made by State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick.

The sports program of Manhattan College will be augmented this week by the initiation of two new divisions of ahtletic activity, 150-pound football and 150-pound rowing, it was announced yesterday by John F. (Chick) Meehan, director of athletics.

Mayor McKee admitted yesterday that he did not know what his next step would be in his campaign to reduce the city's budget, but he reiterated emphatically that he intended to devote his "whole energy" and "entire attention" to New York's financial affairs, despite the abrogation of his budget-making powers by the Board of Estimate on Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noted with interest the communication in THE TIMES relative to theological discussions which were held in a typical saloon. The writer is quite correct. How many times the town atheist banged his empty schooner on the bar with the query, "Where did Cain git his wife?

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- This week witnessed many new indications of industrial recovery. About a score of mills report taking on new men, and several agreements have been concluded to maintain or advance prices.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2. -- From the little village of Gerasimovka In the Ural Mountains has come a story of how two young brothers, who denounced their own father for counter-revolutionary acts as president of the village Soviet, were slain for revealing a kulak gang's activities against the State.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- In Illinois the Republicans admit that things seem to be set against their national ticket, partly, because Len Small, their candidate for Governor, is willing to trade the White House for the State House at Springfield. But they have not abandoned the battle.

The effect of the depression which has swept from the college campus much of the gay background against which the undergraduate posed his studies has also adversely affected college enrolments, a survey of twenty-four colleges and universities of the country indicates.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- Today was the eighty-fifth birthday of President Paul von Hindenburg, and from end to end of Germany it was celebrated with a quiet sincerity that showed how great is the hold of this simple soldier and true patriot on national sentiment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The world champion Yankees and their Cub victims failed to break the record for the biggest player melon in the world's series, but it was a bumper of the $363,822.27 variety.

TOKYO, Oct. 2. -- The view of the Japanese Foreign Office after twenty-four hours' study of the Lytton report is that in the main it is a valuable and fair document, but that its suggestions for a settlement are useless because Japan's policy, clearly marked by her recognition of Manchukuo, is irrevocable and cannot even be discussed with the League of Nations.

Far-reaching changes in the plan and scope of missionary work in the Far East are recommended in the report, now having its final editing, of the appraisal commission of the Laymen's Foreign Mission Inquiry, it was announced yesterday by Albert L. Scott, chairman of the inquiry.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Resignations from the British Cabinet this week, were not unexpected and they have been completely ignored as adverse market factors here, financial circles attaching no serious importance to the changes. The Continent, however, being extremely sensitive to political happenings and not understanding British politics, has been prone to give exaggerated prominence to the latest developments.
Seven Yiddish theatres in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx began their seasons over the week-end, coincident with the Rosh ha-Shanah holidays.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- Retreating from their prohibition repeal demand of 1930, State Republicans appeared likely tonight to go on record for the liquor control stand advocated by President Hoover in his speech of acceptance.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- "I am the happiest man in all the world."

A "psychic baseball championship" series, open to more than 350,000 high school boys and members of Y.M.C.A. branches, Boy Scouts of America, Catholic and Jewish organizations and boys' clubs in the metropolitan area, with a $1,000 scholarship as a prize for the winner, was announced yesterday by the Community Councils of the City of New York.

United action by library schools throughout the country to adjust their enrolment to the estimated need for trained librarians is urged by Dr. Charles C. Williamson, Dean of the Columbia University School of Library Service, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday at Columbia.
DES MOINES, Oct. 2. -- Iowa has gone Democratic, according to the count of more than 75,000 ballots returned in a State-wide straw poll being conducted by the Des Moines Register and Tribune.

Fear that anti-religious governments in the Orient might bar the progress of Christian missions there was expressed in a plea for the support of Catholic missionary enterprises yesterday at a rally of more than forty units of the Brooklyn Conference of the National Catholic Students' Mission Crusade, held in the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Bed-ford and Atlantic Avenues.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2. -- Newark's big batting guns, silenced in the last games in their home park, banged loudly today, and when the echoes died away they had projected the International League champions back into the running in the little world's series by a 5 to 2 victory over Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, Oct 2. -- Arthur A. Ballantine, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, denied in a statement tonight assertions imputed to Representative Steagall of Alabama that there had been wholesale foreclosure on farm mortgages despite the increased capitalization of these banks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Anti-Saloon League leaders will formulate plans to fight modification of the Volstead Act and a repeal amendment in the next Congress at a national convention here from Dec. 15 to 18. The convention has been called at this time, F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the league, said today, to make a definite nation-wide appraisal of election returns and "formulate the league program in opposition to modification or repeal."

Detailed plans for the decorative work in the International Music Hall in Rockefeller Centre and the names of more than a score of artists and sculptors chosen to execute the work were announced yesterday by the developers of the $250,000,000 midtown amusement and commercial project.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The stock markets continue healthy, but speculative enterprise is checked by irregular commodity price movements and the erratic tendency of the New York market. Primary commodities movements still exercise a powerful influence here upon sentiment, and as long as the tendency is upward the markets are certain to continue resilient in the belief that Wall Street invariably will respond.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- On the eve of the Democratic State Convention, the picture was presented tonight of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith working separately but toward the same end, the nomination of Herbert H. Lehman for Governor.

Plans are now being made for the annual Victory Ball to be held Armistice Eve., Nov. 10, at the Waldorf-Astoria. Brigadier General Cornelius Vanderbilt will be chairman of the ball and Major General William N. Haskell head of the executive committee.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Asserting that Governor Roosevelt "has consistently failed to remember the forgotten men, women and children of our slums," Charles Solomon Socialist candidate for Senator, told an audience here this afternoon that Federal, State and municipal governments should mobilize their resources to provide public housing at cost in a war of extermination on the alums of the nation.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 2. -- Astrild, the Class R boat owned by Ted S. Clark of the Manhasset Yacht Club, scored over six other craft to win the William H. Childs Perpetual Challenge Trophy today.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The outlook for the continued service of foreign loans seems to be improved. Transfer is not endangered for the moment, as the decline in the Reichsbank's reserves has ceased and the reserves have risen 36,000,000 marks (about $8,570,000) since mid-July.

Immediate action toward the creation of a municipal housing authority and the adoption of a building program of dwellings for low-scale wage earners was urged upon Mayor McKee and other members of the Municipal Assembly yesterday in a letter from the Public Housing Conference, of which Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch of Greenwich.

STAND aside and give the Bates boys room to cheer. That was a great game they put up against Eli Yale, and if there are any more shocks like that coining at New Haven, the undergraduates and citizens of the town will walk wide of the Harkness towers. They may come tumbling down.

The National Association of Manufacturers, representing all the major industries of the United States and several thousand plants throughout the country, pledged its cooperation yesterday to the "share-the-work" movement started by President Hoover through the coordinating committee headed by Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Little change was apparent in the world's wheat situation last week other than the unusually strong support given to the Winnipeg market. While this was regarded as a dominating influence in checking a decline, it also was taken as an admission that artificial methods must be used to maintain even the present low level of prices.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Cornelius B. Zabriskie will return today on the Franconia from Bermuda and will be at the Pierre for the Winter.

Governor Lawrence M. Judd of Hawaii and John C. Kelley, public prosecutor of Honolulu, will meet here today to examine the advisability of retrying or dismissing the case against the four natives accused by Mrs. Thomas H. Massie of assaulting her at Ala Moana a year ago.

BOONVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Following the lead taken last night by dairy farmers at Adams Centre and Pierrepont Manor, producers in the Boonville area this afternoon voted to withhold milk shipments to New York City until price cutting ceased. The action was taken by 85 per cent of those present at a meeting in this Oneida County village and followed more than two hours of heated debate participated in by about 75 men.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 62.2, which compares with 62.4 a week ago, 62.9 two weeks ago, 63.2 three weeks ago and 62.5 four weeks ago. The highest average of the year to date was 66.3 in the first week of January.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The so-called Lytton report on Manchuria, a document of 100,000 words made publio simultaneously here and at Geneva today, contains the findings of a commission of five men selected by the Council of the League of Nations to carry out a Council resolution adopted on Dec. 10, 1931, containing the two following provisions:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- As President Hoover polished his first campaign address today for delivery Tuesday In Des Moines, Republican leaders squared off for what promises to be the bitterest windup of all recent Presidential contests.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 2. -- The most brilliant social event of the season was a poverty supper dance held at the Riverside Yacht Club last evening. More than 250 persons were present, the majority of whom appeared in costume. Mrs. Charles G. Muller received the prize for the women and to Leonard Hatch was awarded the prize for men.

Sir Thomas Lipton, that pioneer in the uses of advertising and mass selling who cut his name in one of the great stones of an Egyptian pyramid and spent a fortune in spectacular efforts to lift the America's cup, wrote an autobiography before his death last year which is published today by Duffield Green.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Denouncing the Democratic party as "the crowning spectacle of political degeneration," the Rev. John Haynes Holmes in a statement sent from New York and made public here today urged liberal voters to rally around the candidacy of Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Improvement in most lines of trade and industry continued last week in the West and confidence also increased. More factories were started after having been idle for months and others already in Operation reported enlarged outputs and the employment of more men.

Secretary Doak's order prohibiting non-quota foreign students from working their way through American colleges was attacked as stupid by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, at 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Thirty-five thousand Brooklynites cheered Mayor Joseph V. McKee at Ebbets Field yesterday at the graduation exercises of the Police Academy. It was his first visit to the borough since he became the city's chief executive.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much Interested in the experiment being conducted in Boston, as reported in THE TIMES, whereby unemployed teachers are enabled to exchange their services in return for experience.

The Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, who began yesterday his twenty-second year as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue, scored the American people in his morning sermon for their inability to recognize real leaders.

MUKDEN, Oct. 2. -- Japan had receive assurances of full cooperation from Soviet Russia in the bandit suppression campaign in North Manchuria, Lieut. Gen. Tenukuni Koiso, Chief of Staff of the Japanese forces in Manchuria, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Stories that President Hoover was once a British voter, which were circulated in 1928, and officially denied as untrue by Secretary Kellogg, have again appeared and today William R. Castle, Assistant Secretary of State, issued a formal declaration that the reports were entirely false.

Scarcity Value of Child Life. The world's ever-increasing interest in child welfare reflects the growing scarcity value of the child. There are fewer children in the world today, relatively, than there were ten years ago; many fewer than twenty years ago; a great many fewer than fifty years ago.
Governor's Campaign on Coast Is Feature at Embassy Newsreel.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Amid the applause of the resident cheering section and most of the 300 outsiders who had paid their way in, Sing Sing's football team opened its 1932 season today with a 19-to-6 victory over the Clover Athletic Club of the Bronx.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2. -- Banking changes made necessary by the nation's natural financial evolution will have principal consideration of American Bankers' Association delegates, meeting in annual convention this week, the association president, Harry J. Haas, said on arrival from Philadelphia.

So far as can be judged from the general conclusions announced by the Lytton report on Manchuria, it is a document at once comprehensive, penetrating and impartial. This was to be expected from the high character and special knowledge of the men selected by the League of Nations to serve upon a commission for the conduct of this inquiry.

Between 800 and 1,000 persons sailed from pier 52, North River, yesterday morning on the excursion steamboat Favorite for a day's outing supposedly arranged by the Unity Social Club. But mingling with them were twelve headquarters' detectives who brought the outing to an unexpected close last night by arresting twenty-six of the passengers as common gamblers and seizing a quantity of gambling paraphernalia.

It is easier to read Mr. DURANT than to turn to the philosophers on whom he hangs his stories. It is more entertaining to go to a movie of the African pigmies than to make a lonely pilgrimage to the Andaman, Islands. It is both jollier and cheaper to take dinner guests to a lecture on the social sciences than to study them at first hand.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2. -- President Rodriguez assailed in the strongest terms this evening the recent Papal encyclical "Acerba Animi," describing it as "characteristic of the Pope's proceedings" and "full of false declarations regarding Mexico."

Well-known figures in political, industrial and educational circles will participate in a radio campaign for the Republican national ticket this week, it was announced yesterday by David Hinshaw, director of the radio division of the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The appointment of Donald R. Richberg, general counsel for the Railway Labor Executives' Association, as executive chairman of the National Progressive League, was announced today. Senator Norris is chairman of the league.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, commenting on the announcement that former President Coolidge would speak in New York City on Oct. 11, asserted in a statement tonight that Mr. Coolidge would present "actual facts" rather than the "impossible promises" of Governor Roosevelt on the stump.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The return of Samuel Insull Jr. from Paris, where his mother is ill, for questioning in connection with the bankruptcy action against two of the Insull investment companies, was requested Friday by Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- A late Fall has enabled the corn crop to mature without damage from frost. Estimated yields are a fair average as to ears and bushels, but the fodder crop has been reduced by dry warm weather and is reported by some experts as the smallest in recent years.

A band of robbers, with, a five-pound sledge, spent Saturday night in the two-story building at 144 Columbus Avenue, at Sixty-sixth Street. They jimmied open four offices on the second floor, and cracked two large safes, one of the safes happened to be unlocked, so perhaps they just did it for the record.

ABOARD WALKER TRAIN, Hendaye, France, Oct. 2. -- With twenty-four hours' growth of beard on his usually clean-shaven face, former Mayor Walker spent an hour in Madrid today, and tonight he was speeding northward toward Paris, where he expects definitely to determine his future plans after communicating by telephone with his advisers in New York.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 2. -- Joseph von Sternberg, film director, passed through here today on his way to Mexico City. He left by plane. The director will gather material in Mexico, Cuba and Haiti for new moving pictures.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War, withdrew early this evening as a candidate for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, and his action will leave the State convention which opens tomorrow free to nominate Colonel William J. Donovan on the first ballot.

The foreign debt of Germany at the end of last February is placed at about $4,912,000,000, of which about 40 per cent is held in the United States, according to an analysis made by the National Industrial Conference Board. This sum, the Conference Board explains, does not include direct investments by foreigners in stocks, bonds and landed property in Germany, which, if included, would raise the total foreign investments then to about $6,193,000.000.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- The acceptance of a Tammany endorsement for the Supreme Court bench by State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, chairman of the committee that investigated Mayor Walker and other New York City officeholders, was denounced on all sides here today by his fellow Republicans, assembling for their State convention.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Except that Harvard showed a well-balanced first-string football team and a very promising rushline, the Cambridge coaches today regarded the ten touchdowns made against Buffalo Saturday as of little value.
The Staten Island Stapletons and the Chicago Bears battled to a scoreless tie in a National League football game yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, S.I., before a crowd of 8,000.

Historians of the future reviewing our epoch may consider it as one in which "a new and enthusiastic devotion to spiritual riches was born," declared the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin; president of the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, in his sermon there yesterday morning.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The yachting season for the Larchmont Yacht Club came to a close today with the last of the series of postseason races on the Sound.

Corruption, selfishness and moral degradation are eating at the heart of New York City, the Rev. Dr. Henry Howard declared yesterday in his sermon at the Fifth Avehue Presbyterian Chureh, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Dr. Howard has just returned from England after a three-month visit.

DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- Governor Roosevelt in effect served notice today on John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn. Democratic leader, that he was 100 per cent back of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2. -- Sentiment in the steel trade underwent a distinct improvement last week, partly because of a slight increase in buying but chiefly on account of improved appearances. Steel ingot production increased only slightly from the 16 per cent rate of the preceding week, a marked increase in the Chicago district being partly offset by decreases elsewhere.

The consolidates statement of the American Smelting and Refining Company for the six months ended on June 30 shows a net loss of $3,442,047 after all charges and reserves, including a charge against operations of $3,112,501 to cover revaluation of metal stocks in excess of normal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Lytton report on Manchuria was received with intense interest in official circles here, and it is generally believed, following a hasty perusal of its contents, that it broadly coincides with many points of the position taken by the United States.
Keen rivalry featured the soccer clash between the New York Americans and the New York Nationals-formerly the Giants, at Starlight Park yesterday. The game opened the National League season.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The War Ministry announced today that Paraguayan cavalry, engaged in the campaign against Bolivian forces for possession of the disputed territory of Gran Chaco, had re-occupied Fort Pitiantuta. [Fort Pitiantuta, also known as Fort Mariscal Lopez, is about 75 miles south of Fort Boqueron, which Paraguay captured last week after a battle of three weeks.]

To the Editor of The New York Times: With both major political parties committed to change of highly unsatisfactory conditions surrounding the problem of prohibition and regulation of alcoholic liquors, it becomes important to consider some practical matters relating thereto.

Criticism by Mrs. C.N. Edge, a member of the National Association of Audubon Societies, of Dr. T. Gilbert Pearson, president of the association for seventeen years, and of other officers and directors, was answered yesterday in letters sent out from the organization's headquarters at 1,775 Broadway to its 9,000 members throughout the country.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 2. -- Within a stone's throw of "Home, Sweet Home," the childhood home of John Howard Payne, the laboratory players of Columbia University will present Payne's operetta, "Clari, the Maid of Milan," in which "Home, Sweet Home" was first sung in London in 1823, at Guild Hall here Saturday evening.

POTSDAM, Oct. 2. -- While all the rest of Germany today was honoring its President on his eighty-fifth birthday, Adolf Hitler and his lieutenants in the National Socialist private army spent the afternoon reviewing 20,000 boys and girls whom they have enrolled in the Hitter youth movement to support the Nazi program in the elections of the future.

WATERTOWN, N.T., Oct. 2. -- Forty thousand quarts of milk from nearly 600 farms in Jefferson, Oneida and Lewis Counties will be withheld from New York City tomorrow morning in the first milk strike of North Country farms since 1916.

With the realization that the unemployment relief problem will be more pressing and serious during the coming Winter than at any other time during the depression, business leaders are responding promptly to the appeal of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee for speedy organization of fund-raising groups.

Wider study of the Bible as a means of enriching the individual and elevating the moral and religious level of the community was urged yesterday in a Rosh ha-Shanah sermon by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein at the Institutional Synagogue, 148 West Eighty-fifth Street.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The play-by-play description of the fourth game of the world's series follows:

Plans are progressing rapidly for the fashion show in behalf of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital, to be held Thursday afternoon and night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The mighty New York Yankees smashed their way to another decisive victory over the Chicago Cuba today and captured the 1932 world's series In four straight games. The triumph restored the baseball championship to the American League.

WESTBURY. L.I., Oct. 2. -- Led by the brilliant around play of G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, the Aiken Cyclones won the twelve-goal Autumn plates polo final on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club today, routing the Roslyn quartet, 18 to 8.

The Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Lord Bishop of Exeter, England, declared in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning that the great problem the world must solve was how to stop "the pagan institutin, war," and that this could not be done until men had learned to love one another in what he called "a pan-national peace."

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Farmers in the West marketed live stock freely in the last month and this materially depressed prices. Shipments here in September were 32 per cent larger than in either of the preceding two months, but dropped 12 per cent as compared with September, 1931.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 2. -- The quarrel between the capital and the provinces gave Chile a new chief executive today, but the quarrel raged on so fiercely that it already has been described as civil war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The texts of Chapters IX and X of the Lytton report to the League of Nations on the quarrel between China and Japan, which set forth its main conclusions and recommendations for settlement, are as follows:

Low scores, tie scores and a more generous springing of upsets than usual marked the final returns of football's first full afternoon of activity under the new rules of 1932 and aroused the thought that perhaps these revised regulations were proving themselves a boon to the little fellows who, in the past, have been offered up as victims for the start of play by the larger colleges.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- As foreseen, the rentes conversion was a great success and the treasury will have to redeem only 2,000,000,000 francs (about $78,000,000), this being 2 1/2 per cent of the 85,000,000,000 francs involved.

In the World War one of the most difficult manoeuvres which the recruit had to master in the "School of the Soldier" was "marching to the rear" The sergeant calls out, "To the rear, march!" At the word of command, "given as the right foot strikes the ground," the soldier must "advance "and place the left foot; turn to the "right-about on the balls of both "feet and immediately step off with "the left foot."

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Donald Freeman, managing editor of Vanity Fair, was fatally injured shortly before 8 o'clock last night when the roadster he was driving crashed into a traffic stanchion on the Bronx River Parkway Extension at Mohansic and overturned.

Fanciful decorations have been devised for the setting of the Fall military ball to be given by members of the Seventh Regiment on Oct. 22 in the regimental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. Under the supervision of Oscar Paul Yerg, the decorative scheme will represent a scene in Cairo.

The Morvich colt, Morfair, speed star of the recent Saratoga meeting, but a non-winner since then, is scheduled to start this afternoon in the Interborough Handicap, feature on the opening day of the Jamaica meeting. The session will run for two weeks before the swing is made to Empire City, which will see the end of the regular Metropolitan season.

GENEVA, Oct. 2. -- The Lytton report, issued here today by the League of Nations Secretariat, finds absolutely and unanimously against Japan on every important point in her conflict with the League of Nations and the United States over the methods she has been using in the past year to advance her case with China.

Announcement is made today of the forthcoming report of a commission that has been making "the "most comprehensive examination "which has ever yet been made of "the missions effort of the Protestant Christian churches in the Par "East."

Freight car loadings came through with exactly the normal seasonal increase, thus sustaining the adjusted index unchanged at the advanced level of 52.5 established in the week ended Sept. 17. In the corresponding week test year, when car loadings were undergoing a cyclical decrease, the adjusted index was down 1.4 points to 65.0.
The Columbia University Council revealed last evening that it had taken action banning all outdoor student meetings at the university.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The Earl of Lytton arrived in England today from the Far East completely recovered from the illness which had compelled him to write parts of his League of Nations report in a hospital at Peiping. He said he was not surprised to learn the Japanese contended acceptance of the report was impossible because they already had recognized Manchukuo.

PARIS. Oct. 3 -- Trading was dull on the Bourse today, with offers exceeding demand throughout. The volume of transactions was extremely small and even rentes were affected. One of the few issues which escaped the downward tendency were Young Plan bonds, which caused surprise here in view of the Franco-German tension.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The stock market, especially the Industrials, was depressed today by Continental influences. British Government funds were little changed, the conversion loan being dull. Japanese bonds were weakened by developments in the Far East.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- Although the Franco-Japanese treaty of 1907 guaranteeing mutual aid to assure security and peace in those regions of the Far East in which France and Japan have "territorial rights" is still in force, it has not played any part in the present Manchurian controversy, it was authoritatively said here today.

The New York University football team began active preparations for Saturday's contest with Rutgers by engaging in a three-hour practice session at Ohio Field yesterday. Rutgers will be the first of seven major opponents the Violet will meet at the Yankee Stadium this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A Japanese Government bond issue of about 2,400,000,000 yen (about $555,000,000 at yesterday's rate) is expected to be made in the near future in an effort to meet the government deficit, the Commerce Department was informed today in a communication from H.A. Butts, United States Commercial Attache at Tokyo.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Harvard's line coaches were in good humor today when it was announced that Roger Hallo-well, varsity centre, had suffered no consequential injury in the Buffalo game and that Warren Casey, first substitute halfback, who has been, on the sidelines for several weeks, is now ready for Scrimmage work.

Vander Pool, the son of Campfire and Bramble Rose, which races for William M. Moore, gained his second Jamaica stake victory through a disqualification when he was placed first yesterday in the Interborough Handicap, opening-day feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's twelveday meeting.

Seven railroads filed yesterday at the New York offices of the Board of Engineers of the War Department a protest against the proposal now before Congress that the Federal Government improve, maintain aid operate the Erie and Oswego canals, or New York Barge Canal, without taking title to the properties.
BUFFALO, Oct. 3 -- The address delivered by W. Kingsland Macy, permanent chairman of the Republican State Convention, follows:

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 3 -- Can Herbert Hoover say anything at Des Moines tomorrow which will dispel the black shadow that hangs over the farmsteads of Nebraska and his own political prospects in the State? Few people with whom discussed the situation in Nebraska seem to think so.

Mayor McKee May Lead Us Out of Slough of Despond. To the Editor of The New York Times: The possibility of placing such a man as Joseph V. McKee permanently in the Mayor's office is beyond question the most encouraging and inspiring prospect that has come to the intelligent people of New York in many years.

The story of a stirring battle with a 380-pound tuna fish, a battle that did not end until darkness almost hid the tuna in murky waters nine miles southeast of the Ambrose Lightship, was told yesterday by the veteran mackerel-boat pilot, Captain Nard Renda of the beam trawler Mabel M., out of Sheepshead Bay.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP). -- With cannon crashing a salute and flags fluttering above military and civic parades, Iowa will herald tomorrow the return of its most distinguished native son -- President Hoover.

When The London Times of Oct. 3 reaches this country, its readers here will at first think that it has suffered a sea change. The very title on the first page is to be changed from the familiar Gothic to a plain Roman lettering. Also the rules at the top of the page are changed along with the date line.

Doubtless from motives of envy and jealousy Republican bigwigs have been trying to silence or smother our old Kentucky friend, "BOB" LUCAS, executive chairman of the Republican National Committee. He has been surveying the West and the Mid-West from a Pullman car window and otherwise.

BATH, Me., Oct. 3 -- John R. Houghton, 36, was a scion of a wealthy old Bath family whose ancestors were prominent in the shipbuilding industry in the days when the United States held the supremacy of the seas.

Leasehold deals in Manhattan and sales of housing properties in New Jersey furnished the bulk of light realty activity in the metropolitan area yesterday. There was recorded also the sale of four taxpayers and twenty-seven one-car garages in Jersey City.

The French, liner Champlain, sailing today for Plymouth, and Havre, will take a delegation of Daughters of the American Revolution who are going to Paris to dedicate a tablet in honor of 133 Frenchmen who died at the Battle of Yorktown. The pilgrimage is headed by Mrs. David D. Caldwell, Vice President-General of the National Society of the D.A.R. Others on the Champlain's list include:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 3 -- Provisional President Abraham Oyanedel and his newly formed Cabinet held their first meeting today to adopt measures for the maintenance of order and to prepare for the Presidential elections set for Oct. 30.

The Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan may resign from the co-pastorate of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. It was said last night. It is expected that he will make a statement of his plans in his sermon Sunday, but no one would comment on what it might be.

A disposition to await developments in the Southern spot markets and the government's crop report was reflected yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here by a reduced volume of business and somewhat irregular fluctuations in prices. Unfavorable weather news and reports of a continued firm basis in the South, combined with little Southern selling, gave the market a fairly steady undertone, however, and the close was at net advances of 2 to 8 points.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- On Oct. 15, when Supreme Court Justice Joseph Morschauser sits in Special Term at White Plains, he will appoint Several referees to hear testimony on writs or certiorari asked by the City of New York for a review of assessments on watershed property in Westchester and Putnam Counties.
BUFFALO, Oct. 3 -- A plank declaring for repeal of the prohibition amendment was turned down by the resolution committee of the Republican State Convention here tonight by vote of 35 to 7.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. John F. Vichert of Rochester was nominated for Governor by the Law Preservation party at its State convention here today, but he declined. However, Henry A. Castor, State Secretary, said he believed "the Rev. Vichert would accept after the Rochester delegates had conferred with him."
BERLIN, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Sept. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Increases in exports in August to eighteen foreign countries including the United Kingdom, Canada, Germany, France, Italy and the Scandinavian countries were shown in the Commerce Department's monthly foreign trade analysis, made public today.

If, as tradition remembers, there was placed on PLATO'S door the inscription "Let no one who is not a geometrician enter," Professor MONTAGUE of Columbia University would have been given cordial welcome by the "Instar Omnium." But the geometry of the Columbia Professor of Philosophy is not that of PYTHAGORAS or EUCLID.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- Wearied by two nights of train travel, James J. Walker declared on his arrival in Paris this morning that it was not for him to say whether he would be a candidate for re-election as Mayor of New York.

A smaller percentage of decrease in car loadings in the fourth quarter of the year than was shown in the third quarter was forecast yesterday by the thirteen Shippers' Advisory Boards. The boards estimated that the decline from the corresponding period last year would be 10.4 per cent in the fourth quarter, compared with an estimate of 21.1 per cent in the preceding quarter.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- The Democratic State platform, as adopted by the convention here tonight, pledged the mobilization "of every resource of the State to make sure that no one shall go cold, unsheltered or hungry" this coming Winter.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 3 -- At the dedication of the new Sterling Divinity Quadrangle of Yale University today, President Angell said that, in a time when many voices are pronouncing obituaries upon religion, Yale proclaimed her faith "in the enduring value of spiritual forces by dedicating to their cultivation these gracious and beautiful buildings from Yale's great benefactor, John W. Sterling."

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- The Lehman forces up-State lost half of the votes from Broome County, which is entitled to nine delegates, this evening as the result of a compromise that settled a contest over the seating. The compromise was arranged in an executive session of the credentials committee, over which Daniel F. Cohalan presided.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Sept. 28 shows increases for the week of 129,000,000 in net demand deposits, $13,000,000 in time deposits and $64,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $23,000,000 in loans and investments and $12,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Four closed Pennsylvania banks will advance 10 per cent of their deposit liabilities to depositors next Monday, the payments totaling more than $700,000, the State Department of Banking announced today.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- The most complimentary comment on the Lytton report to be found in the German press is that it proposes a pretty weak compromise. Most papers are more outspoken in their criticism of the situation created by the report.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Asserting that Illinois and the Chicago Sanitary District "for twenty-five years have defied the Federal Government and the rights" of Ohio, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin, the Attorney Generals of these States asked the Supreme Court today to enforce its decree of April, 1930, against water diversion from the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence watershed.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Receivership proceedings were started in the United States District Court today against the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company, known as the Nickel Plate Road.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Hoover, in her role of helpmate to her husband is going into Iowa her home State as well as his, to bid for the vote of the farmer's wife as well as the vote of the farmer.

Asserting that the "long-suffering, too often inarticulate majority" in this country was being taxed without representation by an organized minority. Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, speaking yesterday at a luncheon at the Advertising Club, called for general support of the program of the National Economy League, of which he is chairman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A finding by the Interstate Commerce Commission that the long-and-short-haul provisions of the Pennsylvania Constitution involve unjust discrimination against interstate commerce was recommended in a tentative report to the commission today by Howard Hosmer, an examiner.

The cornerstone of South Hall, Columbia University's new $3,500,000 library, was laid yesterday afternoon at exercises held on the Morningside Heights campus. The library is the gift of Edward S. Harkness.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP). -- More than 3,600 men and women returned to work today in the Pittsburgh district's great industrial plants. Resumptions within the next week will restore jobs to about 1,830 more.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- In pointing out to the Yale varsity football squad the mistakes made during the scoreless tie with Bates on Saturday, Head Coach Mal Stevens said today that the team's play was sluggish.

A new regulation for football this year which has not occasioned the discussion some of the others have aroused requests the coaches of various teams to put it in writing when they make a substitution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Returning from a Western political trip, Senator Wheeler of Montana today predicted that Governor Roosevelt would probably make a clean sweep in the States west of the Mississippi, with only three States now in doubt -- Wyoming, Colorado and Utah.

Undaunted by the Board of Estimate's action last Saturday in removing his control over preparation of the tentative budget. Mayor Joseph V. McKee pressed on with his own budget policy yesterday by ordering the retirement of 128 city-owned automobiles to save $600,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Notice was given today by Acting Secretary Ballantine that bids would be received for about $75,000,000 in 92-day bills up to 2 P.M., Eastern Standard Time, Oct. 7.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Denouncing the Anti-Saloon League as a racket, "quite as profitable as that of Al Capone and his cohorts in the illicit beer and whisky trade," former United States Senator James A. Reed of Missouri, urged the support of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for President by all voters who wished to abolish an "intolerable law."

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- In a dramatic move toward republicanism Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, has swept the King's representative in the person of Governor General James McNeill out of office. Mr. McNeill is closing Viceregal Lodge in Dublin and, with the British Army already gone, the last relic of British rule will in a few weeks have disappeared.

It is absolutely necessary to raise $233,000 by a city-wide campaign between Nov. 2 and 16 to maintain Y.W.C.A. work in 1933, according to Mrs. Frank C. Munson, chairman of the annual budget campaign of the association, who informed members of the Maintenance Committee yesterday that receipts from association activities had decreased 38 per cent while demands for help of various kinds had increased greatly.

Two young men who are alleged to have swindled more than fifty of the city's two-day-a-week emergency laborers out of a half a month's pay were arrested last night. The detectives who took them into custody after several weeks' investigation decribed the swindle as one of the most contemptible of their experience.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Indictment of Samuel and Martin Insull will be sought before the October grand jury tomorrow morning, State's Attorney Swanson announced tonight after failing to receive replies from the brothers on whether they would "return voluntarily" from their present abodes, Paris, France, and Orillia, Ont., respectively.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Pressure from Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, working together as of old toward a common objective, seemed tonight to have assured the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor by the Democratic State Convention tomorrow.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 3 -- A shower of real champagne spattered the bow of the Santa Lucia and sprayed those in the front row on the launching platform this morning as the third of four $5,000,000 ships built for the Grace Line slid down the ways of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The prospectus for the giant conversian loan designed to reduce the Australian Government's interest burden is to be issued tomorrow. It is understood the interest rate will be 4% per cent.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Members of the American Bankers Association, controlling resources of more than $60,000,000,000, who gathered here today to consider the economic problems of the day, heard speakers stress the acuteness of the present situation, but agree generally, as it was expressed by one, that "the general economic situation seems at this time to be definitely on the mend."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like you to know what an important part THE NEW YORK TIMES has played in my police career. I have been a constant reader many years, and have found THE TIMES valuable not only for its specific information of importance to members of the police force, but also for the valuable and readable general information it contains.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 3 -- A dummy scrimmage against Fordham plays featured today's practice of the Bucknell squad. The line proved adept in work on the Maroons' quick opening play, heretofore a puzzle to the Bisons.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- The German Andes expedition reports the discovery of a valley with many ruins from the Inca days where no white man had ever been. A cable received from Dr. P.H. Borchers, leader of the expedition, from Yungay, Peru, follows.

HOPEWELL, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Johnny Kinder, young New Jersey open golf champion and professional at the Green Brook Club, today won the State P.G.A. medal with a 36-hole total of 145 at the Valley Country Club.

After a heated discussion, during which the charge was repeatedly made that the Gibson unemployment relief committee discriminated against Protestants and favored Jews and Roman Catholics, the presbytery of New York voted yesterday to conduct a drive in all its churches from Oct. 15 to 31 for $250,000 to care for Presbyterian needy this Winter.

TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Admitting that the amended petitions for the recall of the Mayor and Council of the township of Teaneck now contain sufficient signatures, Henry Diehl, Clerk, declared this morning the petitions were invalid "because they do not contain a general statement of grounds for removal, being based purely on opinion."

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- For five days the Kremlin labored on three of the most pressing problems -- Soviet as opposed to private trade; the output of consumers' goods; and iron and steel production -- and then brought forth three resolutions to skip like mice across the pages of the newspaper Pravda.

THE Yankees flattened the Cuba in four straight games and left them a mediocre assortment of animal rugs. National League rooters are now going around on their hands and knees and refusing to give their right names when questioned. Woe, woe, unutterable woe!

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Renewed and increased activity in the cause of accident prevention to combat the serious effect of the depression upon individual and public safety was pledged today by 4,000 delegates to the annual congress and exposition of the National Safety Council.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Following is the text of the speech delivered by Senator Robert F. Wagner today at the Democratic State Convention:

If the present system of voting is continued, Tammany Hall probably can put James J. Walker back in City Hall at any time its leaders wish, Norman Thomas and Paul Blanshard, Socialist party leaders, assert in "What's the Matter With New York?" published today by Maemillan.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The way was cleared tonight for the nomination by the Republican State Convention of Colonel William J. Donovan for Governor on the first ballot by unanimous vote, as well as the nomination of Assistant Secretary of War F. Trubee Davison for Lieutenant Governor and of Chief Judge Cuthbert W. Pound of the Court of Appeals for the place he now holds under appointment from Governor Roosevelt.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Yale, Princeton and Columbia appear on the Williams basketball schedule for the coming season.

The seatrain New York, first of the two new ships built by Seatrain Lines, Inc., to transport loaded freight cars between New York and New Orleans, via Havana, arrived for the first time yesterday afternoon at her, terminal near the foot of Fourteenth Street, Hoboken, to the accompaniment of shrieking whistles of passing river craft.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 -- Dr. Kisaburo Suzuki, leader of the Seiyukai [Majority party] today described the Lytton commission's "suggestions" to the League of Nations concerning Manchuria as "castles in the air."
Manhattan Lodge, No. 45, I.B.P.O.E., gave Manhattan Temple a mortgage to No. 93, I.B.P.O.E., for $2,500, payable five years hence at 6 per cent, on 266 W. 139th St.

OL' MAN SATAN, a play in three acts and thirty-seven scenes, with incidental music by Donald Heywood. Staged by William A. Shilling; scenery by Continer Goldlng; produced by Shillwood Productions. At the Forrest Theatre.

The New York Yankees, world's champions once more by virtue of their four smashing triumphs over the Cubs, arrived from Chicago yesterday prior to scattering to the four winds until the training call finds them back at St. Petersburg next Spring to begin another season.

Mayor McKee suggested to the teachers, principals and other employes of the city's school system yesterday afternoon the same opportunity he has offered to the policemen and firemen to take voluntary pay cuts and help the city reduce its budget by $100,000,000.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Following is this text of the platform adopted by the Democratic State Convention:

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- The night session of the Democratic State Convention was called to order by Temporary Chairman Robert F. Wagner. The playing by the band of "The Star-Spangled Banner" and a prayer by Rabbi Shepard Z. Baun of Albany opened the meeting at 8:45 P.M.

MUNICH, Oct. 3 -- The National Socialists are preparing to fight the coining election with as much fervor as if it were the first rather than the sixth of such contests this year. They speak privately of sensational surprises in store for their opponents. So for the wearied German people there is another period of bitterness and vituperation ahead such as marked the former electoral conflicts.

GENEVA, Oct. 3 -- The League Council's committee for organization of the world financial and economic conference decided today to hold this conference in London and to invite Soviet Russia and all other nonLeague members.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 3 -- Many colonists gathered this afternoon on the lawns of the Casino tennis courts to watch the opening play in the annual Middle Atlantic Intercollegiate Lawn Tennis Tournament, which will continue through Thursday.
Developments yesterday in the transportation field were construed in transit circles as indications of a movement for a general rise in rapid transit fares.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- The keynote of Democracy's campaign in the East was sounded at the opening session of the Democratic State Convention here at noon today, when United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, temporary chairman, took for the theme of his speech the text that "The nation cannot afford to enter upon the era of reconstruction with the handicap of a President who has so often been wrong, late and futile."
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 2 per cent for the best names.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The whole system of Great Britain's naval defenses, both at home and overseas, is likely to be recast as an outcome of the Ottawa conference, it is stated on the authority of Hector C. Bywater. The London Daily Telegraph's naval correspondent.

With progress reported from half the members of the coordinating committee of the twelve Federal Reserve Districts, the "share-the-work" movement began a nation-wide attack on unemployment yesterday under the leadership of Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, chosen by President Hoover to lead the movement.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 3 -- While two Chinese leaders voiced approval today of the report to the League of Nations of the Lytton commission on Manchuria, the press and another official took an adverse view.

The new union inland freight terminal of the Port of New York Authority at Eighth Avenue and West Fifteenth Street was opened yesterday without ceremony to shippers and consignees of freight in the port district. Equipped to handle about 250 trucks at once, the terminal was used by only forty trucks and it functioned well, officials said.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A meeting to discuss an extensive program of "rehabilitation" for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was intimated by Andrew Robertson of Pittsburgh, president of the Hoover committee for industrial rehabilitation, in an address today before Northern Ohio manufacturers.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- Officially launching the intensive Presidential battle in California for the Republican party, Secretary Mills told a rally here tonight that Governor Roosevelt was a man who "practically admits the depression has him licked before tie starts."

To the Editor of The New York Times: An article in THE TIMES this morning may give your readers a wrong impression of my position on the question of the proposed reductions in teachers' salaries. Incidentally, I am not "head" of the United Parents' Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Standard Oil of Indiana is now operating all its refineries on a policy of dividing up work to keep men employed, according to an announcement made tonight by Edward G. Seubert, president, to 200 representatives of employes and management attending the company's fourteenth annual industrial relations conference.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Two college generations have matriculated and passed into the alumni ranks at Rutgers since Homer Hazel and Benkert wore the Scarlet with such distinction, as to win national recognition.

The extent to which any type of political action on the part of the churches is proper and desirable, and the general question of the relation between church and State is being studied by a special committee of the Federal Council of Churches, working through the research department of the council.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- By forbidding Italian banks to allot any foreign exchange to Italian importers of German goods, Premier Mussolini has replied to the shift of the German Government from tariffs to quotas in agrarian goods. When the decision of Signer Mussolini was communicated to the Reichsbank it was immediately realized here that this was an extremely serious development, the implications of which would extend beyond the realm of Italo-German trade.

The trial of Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania came to a sudden close yesterday with one of the jurors. Harry F. Moore, a photo-engraver, of 104 West Eighty-fourth Street, facing a hearing and a possible jail term for improper conduct.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT HOOVER'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Oct. 3 -- President Hoover, traveling on a Pennsylvania Railroad special train, was crossing the Appalachian highlands tonight on his way to the Middle West in quest of votes for his re-election in November.

Last February President HOOVER issued an executive order "covering" some two hundred employes of the Department of Justice into the classified civil service. He followed that up in March by another order classifying three or four hundred positions in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce which had been exempted from competitive examination.

For the first time in the history of New York City, as at present constituted, local property owners are about to enjoy the benefit of reduced assessments. The tentative footing for 1933 is $18,225,064,709, which compares with a final assessment of $18,944,216,567 this year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP). -- Better regulation of the power industry was advocated tonight in a speech by George Otis Smith, chairman of the Power Commission.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- The Federal Government's policy of stimulating farm mortgage credit was criticized here today before the trust company division of the American Bankers' Association convention by Thomas C. Hennings, vice president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 3 -- The opening of the annual Fall tennistournament today attracted scores of visitors many of whom entertained with luncheons at Fassifern Farm, the Cascades and the Casino Terrace and with teas.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 3 (AP). -- Judges of the nation's senior circuit courts today declared in favor of legislation to speed up the machinery of the law by avoiding undue delays in cases under appeal.

The Artists of Carnegie Hall opened yesterday with a private view, their first exhibition in the new gallery, the hall's transformed, lounge. The exhibition will be open to the public today and continue until the end of the month.
BUFFALO, Oct. 3 -- The text of the keynote speech delivered by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. at the Republican State Convention here today fallows:

DUBLIN, Oct. 3 -- It is believed here nobody will be nominated to the vacant post of Governor General and that a commission of three High Court judges, including the Chief Justice of the Free State, may be asked to discharge the duties of the office pending a definite decision.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 4 -- The Daily Mall today publishes a statement by Princess Helen of Rumania in which she attributes to King Carol, her former husband, persecution and bad faith. She declares Carol, resentful of the sympathy the British public has shown for her during her last fortnight's reunion in London with her son, Crown Prince Michael, has harshly ordered the boy to return home.

A temporary truce was called yesterday in the struggle of the Printers League Section of the New York Employing Printers Association and Typographical Union 6 as the result of a conference between a joint committee of the employers and the local union with Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 3 -- Seeded players in the twentieth annual Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament either won easily or were inactive because of byes as play began today at the Casino courts.

The Committee on Securities of the New York Curb Exchange rules that hereafter deliveries against transactions in the American Corporation common stock purchase warrants must be in the form of "stamped" certificates indicating that the exporation date of the warrants has been extended to Oct. 1, 1933, and that the subscription price at which common stock may be purchased through exercise of the warrants has been reduced from $10 to $5 a share.

BUFFALO, Oct. 3 -- Republican support for Joseph V. McKee as an independent candidate for Mayor on Nov. 8 is unlikely, it was indicated here today as the New York City Republican leaders gathered for the opening of the party State convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A general belief that the United States will await action by the League of Nations before taking a stand on the Lytton report regarding Manchuria was strengthened today when it was learned that no arrangements have been made for participation by this country when the League Council takes up the report on Nov. 14.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Actual fighting has occurred in the revolt in Northern Chile, according to information received in official circles here, and the situation there is much more serious than is indicated to news dispatches. The condition is even described as "civil war," with hostilities threatened in the South as well as the North.

Detective Louis Walters of the Eighteenth Division Gun Squad, on vacation and out in his automobile yesterday, stopped for a traffic light at Queens Boulevard and Maurice. Avenue in Elmhurst. A sedan in the other traffic lane contained four men.

The election of Governor Roosevelt would suspend business recovery for at least a year, E.F. Hutton, Industrialist and financier, asserted last night in a radio address over a National Broadcasting Company network. The speech was a part of the first of a series of "feature broadcasts" sponsored by the Republican National Committee.

An effort will be made at a special meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York to be held Thursday night to name an independent slate for the Supreme Court to oppose State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and Aron Steuer, beneficiaries of the "deal" whereby Tammany and the Republican organization in Manhattan and the Bronx joined in nominating them for judicial posts.

BOONVILLLE, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- three hundred milk producers supplying the New York City market withheld their milk today from plants of the United Milk Products Corporation in Boonville, Adams Centre and Pierrepont Manor.
