WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Officers for seven of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks which will be opened Oct. 15 were announced today by Chairman Franklin W. Fort of the Home Loan Bank Board. He also stated that he had called a conference for Wednesday with all the hank officials in Washington, including those for the Newark institution and four other districts not yet named.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Operation of Appalachian Coals, Inc., selling agent formed by 137 producers in the high volatile area of Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee, was held in violation of the Sherman anti-trust act today in an opinion rendered in the United States District Court for Western Virginia.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ladfield, an outsider paying $42,70 and racing for Mrs. Charles Crane, won the feature of the Welfare Day racing program which opened the Maryland State Fair Association's season today.

Savings totaling $100,000,000 in the city budget for 1933, wider autonomy for the city in shaping its expenditures by curbing legislative interference in the city's fiscal affairs and simplification of the "very clumsy and costly complex of borough and county administrations" as further economy steps were urged by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in radio address last night under the auspices of the Citizens Budget Commission, of which he is president.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Reading, who are arriving from London this week, will be at the Waidorf-Astoria.

American Business Shares, Inc., and the Domestic Capital Corporation, investment trusts with leanings from the fixed type and toward the general management style were announced yesterday as having been formed. They are of the "open-end" variety, with capital raised through a sustained subscription program lather than by public offering of any stipulated number of shares at once.

The financial community continued yesterday to wait patiently for the appearance of a new speculative incentive, which brokers believe is necessary to end the present stalemate. Trading for the day on the Stock Exchange was only 1,002,000 shares, the smallest turnover since July 21, when the Summer advance was just getting under way.

Fifth Avenue that was once the residential "Quality Street" has now become, in long stretches of it, the "Quality Street" of business, of art and of cultural institutions. The transformation has been wrought on a majestic scale and with such lavish adorning as no other street in the world can boast.

New public financing in the United States, exclusive of domestic and Canadian municipal offerings, declined 76 per cent in the first nine months of this year compared with the corresponding period of last year and fell 88 per cent below the total for the first nine months of 1930, according to a compilation by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- The Rudolf Karstadt Aktiengesellschaft has requested its American agent, Dillon, Read Co., not to distribute among its bondholders the $193,000 of its American loan which was to be drawn Nov. 1 for redemption. Instead the company will pay this amortization instalment to its trustee in New York, which is to keep it until the question of reorganization of the Karstadt concern is settled.

In his address at Philadelphia on Mr. HOOVER'S foreign policies, Secretary STIMSON, evidently in reply to Governor ROOSEVELT, opposed the plan for special trade agreements. He put the thing on high ground. To him it seemed impossible that the United States would ever wish even to seem to "prefer one cus"tomer nation to another, or pur"chase favors for one American "product at the expense of another."

Money market was as lifeless at the resumption of business in the new week as on any day in the preceding period. Funds were in good supply for every class of accommodation but demand was light. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 per cent, outside trades went at 1, and governments and Federals at 1/2 and 1/8, respectively.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company, which was closed by the State Banking Department on Oct. 30 last year, reopened its doors yesterday morning. During the first two hours of business 500 customers visited the bank's quarters at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Music dramas in which the orchestra and all vocalists will be hidden from the view of the audiences and only mimes, chosen for their dramatic ability and physical suitability for their roles, will appear on the stage are to be presented by the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company during the season of 1933-1934, it was announced today by Leopold Stokowski, musical director of the opera company and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

With the passing of Summer the hunter looks over his weapons, lays in a stock of cartridges, repairs his outfit, inspects his dog's and prepares for his Fall campaign. The katydid has been heard in the land, and the open season comes with frost and perhaps with a powdering of snow.

With the trading volume sinking again, the range of bond prices yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was narrow and the trend generally down. United States Government obligations were irregularly lower, while foreign government loans showed strength in spots.

Stocks continued to drift aimlessly yesterday within the narrow limits to which they have been confined for nearly two weeks. The prevalent apathy was reflected also in the bond market and in commodities. The general trend was downward, but with no acute weakness displayed in any of the markets.
Columbia directed its football practice session yesterday at Baker Field toward its first major objective of the season, its combat with Princeton on Saturday.
GENEVA, Oct. 3 -- The land of Babylon Nineveh and Bagdad entered the League of Nations here today under the name of Iraq as the League's fifty-seventh member.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3. - The Chamber of Deputies tonight approved a resolution calling for the deportation of Mgr. Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores, Apostolic Delegate and Archbishop of the State of Morelia, as an undesirable foreigner. A committee was named to urge immediate action by President Rodriguez.

The special statutory court which was organized early this year to pass upon a petition of the Transit Commission for an injunction to prevent the Pennsylvania Railroad from charging the Long Island Railroad an additional $1,000,000 a year rent handed down a decision yesterday denying both temporary and permanent restraining orders.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 3 -- Brazil's civil war was at an end today after three months of severe fighting and exactly two years after the overthrow of fee city of Sao Paulo from its position of dominance in Brazilian politics. More troops were engaged in the conflict than in any other in the New World except the Civil War of the United States.

BUFFALO, Oct. 3 -- Four electors-at-large and forty-three district electors to represent the State in the Electoral College were chosen today by the Republican State Committee. They will cast the forty-seven electoral votes of the State for President Hoover if victorious.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The stock markets were more cheerful today, although business continued on a small scale. Rapid success attended the conversion of the Australian loan, the issue of L12,360,000 being subscribed in forty-five minutes. It was the first issue offered since the removal of the Treasury's restriction on the market for capital.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Oct. 3 -- J.E. Krause, city councilman, and Hugo Schmolcke of Ketchikan are said to be the first men who ever shot through the white waters of Devil's Elbow and Buck Bar on Stikine River in an eight-foot rubber boat.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The Republican leaders of New York City will hold a conference within the next two days to decide the party position on the city Mayoralty election, if there is to be one.

Columbia's football squad went through a long scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its meeting with Princeton on Saturday. The session was enlivened consideraby by the return of Captain Steve Grenda, veteran guard, who has been on the injured list for two weeks.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 -- Following is the text of the speech of William Donovan, accepting the Republican nomination for Governor:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Federal marines entered the port of Santos today and occupied Fort Ataipu, while the Cruiser Bahia removed twenty mines from the harbor entrance, planted there while the Federal, Government enforced a blockade during the recent Sao Paulo rebellion.

George Grosz, German satirical artist, who came to this country in June to conduct a class at the Art Students' League, intends to become a permanent resident and a citizen of the United States, he disclosed yesterday at a tea in the Beaux Arts, 310 East Forty-fourth Street.

Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The Commonwealth at Massachusetts awarded yesterday an issue of $3,465,000 of 3 1/2 per cent water and sewer bonds to a banking group consisting of Estabrook Co., R.L. Day Co., Inc.; The First of Boston Corporation, the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and Jackson Curtis on a bid of 102.28.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Announcement of directors for the Third District Home Loan Bank, to be located at Pittsburgh, was made today by Chairman Franklin W. Fort of the Home Loan Bank Board.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Great Britain took steps today toward a four-power conference in London, with the understanding that the United States would be asked to send an observer, to consider Germany's withdrawal from the disarmament conference at Geneva and to attempt to find some solution of the difficulties growing out of that action.

The two major political parties in their 1932 platforms make the same promises of governmental economy and consolidation that they incorporated in their 1928 platforms "with no definite step toward its accomplishment," except the feeble attempt in the last session of Congress, declares Alfred E. Smith in an article entitled "They're Wasting Your Money" in the November issue of Red Book.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 -- The text of the Republican State Platform is as follows:

WAUKESHA, Wis., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Andrew Jay Frame, dean of Wisconsin bankers, died here today at the age of 88. Seventy years a banker, Mr. Frame was active until a few weeks ago as chairman of the board of the Waukesha National Bank.

ABOARD THE LINER REX, at Sea, Oct. 4 -- The Rex, averaging 25.10 knots, had completed a run of 624 miles at noon today, the biggest ever made by an Italian steamship. The best run by another Italian vessel is 545 miles, by the Conte Grande.

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday advanced the price of lead 15 points to 3.25 cents a pound here. In St. Louis the price was advanced 10 points to 3.10 cents. Advances of 10 points were made on Monday.

DES MOINES, Oct. 4 -- Declaring that the "foundations of recovery" had been builded, President Hoover said tonight in his first campaign speech that the "great battle" to protect "our people at home" had been won.

John J. Robinson's Manya, daughter of Master Charlie and Mary Ford, surprised many spectators at Jamaica yesterday when she finished strongly in the featured Lynbrook Claiming Stakes to win by a nose at 6 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Reflecting some replacement by national bank notes, the Federal Reserve notes outside the Treasury in circulation or held by the issuing banks declined $79,173,002 between Sept. 1 and Oct. 1, while national bank paper increased $43,862,780.

YORK, Pa., Oct. 4 -- The track trotting record was lowered at the opening of the York County Fair races today by Joe Watts, gelding, owned by William B. Eckert of Reading. Driven by Goodhart, Joe Watts raced the second heat in 2:06 1/2. The previous record was 2:06 3/4.

NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt have left Beaulieu, their estate in Newport, and are at their home in New York. Mrs. Vanderbilt will leave tomorrow for a stay of a few weeks at the Homestead in Hot Springs, Va.

Representatives of ship lines, railroads and commercial groups concerned with water transportation left for Washington last night to oppose at a hearing today before the United States Shipping Board the application of Seatrain Lines, Inc., for permission to operate its proposed service in the transportation of loaded freight cars by water between New York and New Orleans, via Havana.

Students of Columbia University formally protested yesterday afternoon against the new university ruling prohibiting outdoor meetings and requiring supervision of all indoor meetings open to the public by a faculty member of professorial ranking.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- If Germany and the United States will agree to attend the proposed conference in London for a "study" of Germany's claim to equality of rights in armaments, then France will join in, Premier Herriot in substance replied today to Sir John Simon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Until the Court of Appeals decision is handed down no one, of course, can foretell whether an election for Mayor will be held this Fall. There is little reason, however, to hesitate, while waiting for such decision, or to debate to whom support should be given if an election is ordered.

William Joseph Donovan is both a soldier and an attorney. War-time commander of the "Fighting Sixty-ninth," he won more than his share of medals -- which he gracefully handed on to the regiment. As Federal attorney, for his district, and as assistant to the Attorney General of the United States, he prosecuted anti-trust cases with the sama vigor he had shown at the Argonne.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- The delegates to the Democratic State Convention, assembled in the Albany Armory this afternoon, were advised by T. Arthur Hendricks, permanent chairman, to spend the afternoon looking at the points of historical interest in and around Albany while waiting for the convention to be called to order again this evening.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, the choice of Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, was nominated for Governor by acclamation at the Democratic State Convention tonight.

The adjusted index of steel-mill activity is 22.9 for the week ended Oct. 1, as against 22.2 for the preceding week and 40.8 for the corresponding week last year. Weekly estimates by The Iron Age and Steel averaged 16 per cent of capacity in September, while those by The American Metal Market averaged 15 1/2 per cent.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Governor Roosevelt's address at the Democratic State Convention tonight was as follows:

Every reader of the Hon. WILLIAM KINGSLAND MACY'S speech at the Republican State Convention must regret that the Islip statesman has given up to party what was meant for mankind. Honey drops from his lips. History is wax in his hands. He wears with grace the purple toga of rhetoric.

William A. Brady has advanced the New York opening date of "Mademoiselle," the Jacques Deval play which he is producing with Grace George and Alice Brady in the stellar roles. "Mademoiselle," now in Philadelphia, will come to the Playhouse on Tuesday, Oct. 18, instead of early in November, as previously scheduled.

Public school teachers appealed to the public yesterday by radio for support in the fight to protect their salaries against the reductions proposed in the city's economy drive. The Kindergarten-6B Teachers' Association, the Teachers' Welfare League and the Teachers' Union, which have opposed Mayor McKee's reduction proposal, were sponsors of the broadcast over WABC.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 4 -- A total of 128 members of last year's freshman class at Smith College made the honor roll for the year. There were 585 in the class and, according to President William A. Nielson, the high percentage of those qualifying for the honor list reflects an increasing seriousness on the part of the students.

The Federal Government ended the first quarter of the new fiscal year with a deficit of $402,000,000. This has to be set against earlier assurances of a balanced budget. All four sources which contribute revenue to the Treasury have fallen short of expectations.

Joseph Vincent McCarthy of Buffalo, who in his second year as the Yankees' manager achieved his first American League pennant and the third clean sweep in world's series play to the credit of Colonel Jacob Ruppert's club, probably will sign a three-year managerial contract next week.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York opens its ninety-first season tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall, Arturo Toscanini conducting. The program includes the Bach-Schonberg Prelude and Fugue in E-flat, Brahms's Third Symphony, four Polish dances by Tansman and Debussy's "La Mer."

Puzzled for a time by a note that indicated murder, the police concluded that Miss Marian Elliot Jennison, 25 years old, of Milford, N.H., who was found dead yesterday in her room in the Hotel Cadillac with a bullet wound behind her right ear, had committed suicide.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 4 -- A motion for alimony of $200 monthly and counsel fees of $2,500 was argued before Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Druhan here today in the suit for divorce brought by Elizabeth V. Loeb, a school teacher of Cambridge, Mass., against William Loeb Jr., son of William Loeb of Oyster Bay, formerly secretary to President Theodore Roosevelt, and now vice president of the American Smelting and Refining Company.

Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, climbs through the ropes tonight for the last time before he defends his title against Billy Petrolle next month. The titleholder is to battle Frankie Petrolle, younger brother of Billy, in a ten-round bout at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, as the feature of a boxing carnival arranged in the interests of the Seventh and Eighth Masonic District Camps.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- Aboard the liner Europa, sailing from Cherbourg today, are Frederick M. Sackett, the United States Ambassador to Berlin, and Friedrich Wilhelm von Prittwitz, German Ambassador to Washington, one returning to his post, the other to discuss with President Hoover and Secretary of State Stimson the outlook for the world economic conference, for which he is helping prepare, and also hoping to take some part in the election campaign.

To the Editor of The New York Times : One of the most significant discoveries that can be made in the field of industrial hygiene is that protective measures may bring operating economics at the same time that they save the lives of workers.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Seven robed judges of the Court of Appeals heard arguments today for and against a Mayoralty election in New York City this Fall and prepared to render a speedy final decision.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Inspired no doubt by the fact that the golf season is drawing to a close, 121 women turned out today for a one-day tournament sponsored by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Westchester Country Club.

Preliminary plans for a nation-wide movement to provide wholesome food through the publication of low-priced menus for housewives whose incomes have been depleted as a result of unemployment were discussed yesterday at a meeting of the trustees of the Golden Rule Foundation at the Uptown Club, 60 East Forty-second Street.

The Presidential veto power is the essential factor in the current election campaign. Dayid Lawrence, editor of The United States Daily, told members of the Bond Club at a luncheon in his honor at the Bankers Club yesterday.
A good start proved to be more necessary than usual to the golfer who hoped to win the William Henry Beers Memorial Trophy tournament at the Fox Hills Golf Club, Clifton, S.I., yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- The enrolment of Princeton University for the current year, totaling 2,301, exceeds by one student the largest undergraduate body in the history of the university, it was announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar.

A "hard-working, early-rising" jurist, noted for his breadth of view and his readable, compact decisions, Cuthbert Winfred Pound, chief judge of the Court of Appeals, was hailed as another "liberal" when he was appointed by Governor Roosevelt last March to succeed Benjamin N. Cardozo, who resigned to become associate justice of the United States Supreme Court.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Sympathizers with the farmers' holiday movement paraded in Des Moines today in protest against agricultural and economic conditiions only a few hours before the appearance of President Hoover, here to make a major campaign address.
Figgy the Monk was captured yesterday on Pier 62, North River, but his captors had to use Mike, another monkey, to get him.

Accidents may not be exclusively a product of the machine, age. Knights in armor fell off their horses and broke their collar-bones long before automobiles were invented, and ladies tripped on castle stairs who never dreamed of slippery bathtubs.

PARIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- John G. Hopper, an American mining engineer formerly of Oakland, Cal., today disclosed details of dueling Sept. 1 in Marly-le-Roi Forest, near Paris, in which one American and two French-men were injured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Senator Pittman of Nevada predicted today that every Western State except perhaps three, would go Democratic. He traveled on the Roosevelt train throughout the West and spent most of his time conferring with Democratic leaders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Announcement of the award of Harvard prize scholarships to entering freshmen from thirteen preparatory schools was made today by the committee on scholarships of Harvard College. The awards were made by the headmasters of the schools to the "outstanding student" of each school preparing to enter the college.

Negotiations continued yesterday between committees of the Employing Printers Association and Typographical Union 6 in an effort to reach an agreement in the book and job section of the printing industry.

HAVANA, Oct. 4 -- Oppositionists, fearing for their lives because of the present political turmoil, continue to seek protection from foreign diplomatic representatives here. This was learned today when Dr. Ricardo Gutierrez Lee, Charge d'Affaires of the Colombian Legation, formally advised the Cuban Department of State that three Cuban youths, Elicio and Fernandez Arguelles and Julio Rabel, nephews of ex-President Menocal, were now in that legation.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 4 -- The Battle of Fort Boqueron, in which fewer than 600 Bolivians are declared to have held off more than 8,000 Paraguayans for three weeks, has stirred patriotic fervor here more than anything else that has happened in the recent clashes with Paraguay.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Nevada Stock Farm's Hygro, ace of the Western sprint brigade, raced to an impressive victory in the $5,000 added Capital Handicap, feature today at Laurel.

Policies of other nations are so greatly influenced by the public opinion of this country that the United States has within its grasp the power to aid in reducing wars, declared the Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, England, speaking at a luncheon yesterday in his honor at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

Rallying to support of Mayor Joseph V. McKee's budget-reduction policies, four important business and civic organizations condemned the Board of Estimate yesterday for its abrogation of the Mayor's control of the 1933 budget as the board prepared to hold its first meeting on the tentative budget at the City Hall this afternoon.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Vermont State Republican Convention today adopted a platform which called, among other things, for submission by Congress of a proposal to repeal or modify the Eighteenth Amendment.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 4 -- Victor Downs, 44 years old, of Quogue, L.I., was indicted by the Suffolk County grand jury today on a charge of first-degree murder in connection with the death of Frank Tuthill, "corn doctor," of Quogue, whose body was found in an automobile two weeks after he had been reported missing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- "Eternal vigilance," and "safety first" were suggested as twin mottoes for accident-prevention campaigns in an address today by William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, at the annual congress of the National Safety Council.

MONTREAL, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Success which has been achieved at McGill University, Montreal, in finding a method of obtaining X-ray photographs of the liver and spleen through the use of a solution of thorium dioxide is chiefly of interest because of the great possibilities that it envisions in the future, according to authorities of the McGill Medical School.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Declaring that "happier times surround the nation" after months of difficulties and dangers, President H.J. Haas opened the general sessions of the American Bankers Association today with an optimistic message. He contrasted present conditions with the situation when the bankers convened last year and financial institutions were "at the very bottom of the slough of depression."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- A 90-yard run for a touchdown from the kick-off by Eddie Masavage featured the scrimmage between the Pennsylvania varsity and second team today as a tune-up for the Swarthmore game. With Masavage in the back field were Don Kellett of Brooklyn, Ed Lewis and Melville Chamberlain, substituting for Fullback Carl Perina.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Burton Mansfield, lawyer, banker, twice State Insurance Commissioner and a leading layman of the Protestant Episcopal Church in Connecticut, died today at his home here of a heart attack. His age was 76. Mr. Mansfield had been a delegate to the general convention of the national church since 1898, a distinction shared by few of the leaders of the church.
DES MOINES, Oct. 4 -- Following is the text of President Hoover's speech at the Iowa State capital today:

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The rapidity with which, the State of New South Wales's great conversion was taken up in London today has had a most encouraging effect on members of the Australian Government in particular as well as Australians generally.

WESTFIELD, N.J. Oct. 4 -- The Town Council authorized today the issuance of $250,000 in temporary loan notes. They were taken by the National City Company of New York at 5 1/2 per cent. Of the proceeds, $192,123.16, will be used to retire notes falling due soon.

TONY CANZONERI is evidently a throw-back to the old days when the boy lighter used to say: "Yeah, you and your brother, too!" Tony plans to take on Frankie Fetrolle at Ebbets Field this evening and next month he expects to meet Brother Billy in a championship battle.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 4 -- The strident tones of denunciation of the Lytton report to the League of Nations on Manchuria adopted by the Chinese press and many political leaders indicate the bitterest disappointment and justify the assumption that China had hoped the League would order Japan to evacuate Manchuria immediately under threat of combined action by tne world's armies and navies if evacuation were refused.

Several new records for the New York Cocoa Exchange were made in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, Howard T. McKee, president, reported yesterday. A marked increase in trading over the preceding year also was recorded.

The Palestine Economic Corporation made public yesterday a report showing further economic progress in Palestine in the last year despite the difficulties of the depression. There were no bank failures in Palestine during the year and only one credit cooperative society was liquidated.

CHERBOURG, Oct. 4 -- Complaining that he was as tired as when he left New York last month, former Mayor James J. Walker sailed for home aboard the Europa today. But despite his weariness his attitude was unmistakably that of a man prepared to seek vindication from the voters and confident that the Court of Appeals and Tammany Hall would give him the opportunity to do so on Nov. 8.

Tuesday, Oct. 4, 1932. No feature attached to the business in money. The same small volume of trades representing chiefly routine requirements was about all that was done. Quotations in every instance ruled without a change from Monday.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The market for securities here fluctuated sharply today but closed on a note of greater firmness. After an opening rally there was a period of selling which, in turn before the closing, gave way to a general recovery which left quotations at the end of the session for the most part with gains over yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Schedules for the varsity and freshman soccer and cross-country teams and freshman and second varsity football were announced today by the Harvard Athletic Association.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Cleveland Plain Dealer and The Cleveland News announced today that they have been placed under joint ownership through the formation of the Forest City Publishing Company, a 59,000,000 holding concern.

A sharp decline in the number of retail failures featured business defaults for the week ended Sept. 29, according to Bradstreet's. The retail failures totaled 312, which compare with 355 in the preceding week and 319 in'the corresponding week a year ago.

While Wall Street was a trifle more interested in yesterday's share market than in that of the previous day, the proceedings were drab and colorless from the speculative viewpoint. Trading on the Stock Exchange continued to reflect the uncertainties of the season.

BASLE, Switzerland, Oct. 4 -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of Sept. 30, as made public here today. Figures are in Swiss gold francs at par, 19.3 cents:

An art gallery on the street level of the Carnegie Hall studios, where the artists who are tenants upstairs will exhibit each month's work, was formally opened yesterday at a tea, with addresses broadcast through Station WOR.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Another grant was made today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to Pennsylvania, the new loan being $3,342,183 for relieving distress in sixty-four counties in October. A loan of $2,500,000 was granted to the State on Sept. 22.
Borrowings by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange stood at $379,801,583 on Sept. 30, an increase of $48,102,263 from the total of $331,699,320 shown in the compilation as of Aug. 31.
BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- On his eighty-fifth birthday President Paul von Hindenburg received 22,000 gifts and congratulatory letters and more than 1,700 cablegrams and wireless messages.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's revocation of an order suspending reduced rates on coal from Western Pennsylvania to Northern Ohio returns a potential market of from 3,000 to 4,000 tons a day to this area and means work for about 600 miners.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Former Governor Smith's speech nominating Herbert H. Lehman for Governor at the Democratic State Convention tonight was as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Connie Mack, manager of the Athletics, termed himself a failure today, denied reports he planned to break up the team, and declared he is through with player deals that would make strong clubs stronger.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Walter Johnson is out as manager of the Washington American League Club.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Brooklyn's district leaders this afternoon broke up the Tammany-Brooklyn alliance by telling John H. McCooey they were for the nomination of Herbert H. Lehman for Governor and would "bolt" the McCooey leadership unless he could see the situation as they saw it.

Having at last become convinced of the desirability of sex, Lenore Ulric tosses Herself with conspicuous abandon into the part of a torrid temptress in Gladys Unger's "Nona," which sizzled at the Avon last evening. If the entertainment is pretty shoddy, after all it is through no lack of vehemence on Miss Ulric's part.

DES MOINES, Oct. 4 -- Every word of the 10,000 which the President uttered here tonight in an effort to check the flight of the Iowa farmers from the re-election standard of a native son must, according to conservative calculations, reverse the present intention of three out of four voters to support Franklin D. Roosevelt if the speech shall achieve its mission.

The comment of Dun's mercantile agency in its summary of last month's business failures, that at no time during the present year has the record appeared more encouraging, is one of the indications, now happily numerous, of the drift of affairs in a normal direction.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- John W. Dickinson, banker and Scarsdale civic worker, who died Sept. 24 in California, left $40,000 in specific bequests to churches and educational institutions and divided his residuary estate between the Village of Scarsdale and the Scarsdale Congregational Church, according to his will filed here for probate this afternoon.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 4 -- The annual Founder's Day exercises at Lehigh University tomorrow morning will be featured by the conferring of seven masters and twenty-four baccalaureate degrees.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade here were firmer today, the trade having reports that President Hoover's speech tonight would be constructive and conservative. This brought in persistent scattered commission-house buying of wheat, and while the trade was not large there was no pressure of consequence.

Harry F. Moore of 104 West Eightyfourth Street, the juror who caused a mistrial of the lottery case of Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, was fined $100 by Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman yesterday, with the alternative of spending five days in jail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Chinese official approval of the Lytton report is contained in a carefully worded statement issued today by Dr. Lo Wen-kan, Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Nanking Government, through the Chinese Legation here.

Just as veteran fishermen predicted, bluefish are running again in the vicinity of Fire Island Light and indications are that for the rest of this month the blues will be plentiful. They have acted strangely all year, but the patient old-timers have maintained that October would see larger runs than at any other time this season.

More than 2,800 men have been laid off in the last three weeks by the Brooklyn Edison Company, according to a letter addressed to Governor Roosevelt yesterday by the Brotherhood of Edison Employes, who request an immediate investigation by the Public Service Commission and the State Labor Department.

Preliminary steps in the formation of a men's wear division of the Better Business Bureau of New York were completed yesterday, when five leading manufacturers in the clothing and furnishings industries were appointed to serve as an organization committee together with a similar number of retailers, already named.

Gains In resources and deposits in the three months ended with September were shown by most of the State banks and trust companies that yesterday issued statements of condition as of Sept. 30, in response to the call of the State Superintendent of Banks.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 4 -- Among the numerous untoward developments which came about on the gridiron Saturday was the difficulty experienced by Lafayette in eking out a 6-0 victory over Muhlenberg.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- The teast of Secretary Mills's speech before the annual convention of the American Bankers' Association was at follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in the first seven months of its existence, made cash disbursements of $1,182,734,958.02 in aiding the recovery of agriculture, commerce and industry, the corporation announced today in a summary covering operations up to Aug. 31.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Over objections by counsel for the defendant film companies, documents and evidence concerning procedure against unfriendly theatre owners were admitted today by Judge C.C. Hincks in the United States Court, where a jury is hearing the $1,000,000 damage suit of Allan C. Morrison, former owner of the Majestic Theatre of Hartford, against the Fox, Vitagraph and United Artists companies and the New Haven Film Board of Trade.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- The text of the speech of Lieut. Gov. Lehman, accepting the nomination for Governor at the Democratic State Convention tonight, was as follows:

Judge John M. Woolsey of the United States District Court denied yesterday the motion of Benjamin F. Franklin, holder of 100 shares of Manhattan Railway 5 per cent stock, for a hearing before the full bench of eight judges on his application to vacate the Interborough and Manhattan, receiverships ordered last month by Judge Martin T. Manton of the Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting as a District Court judge.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation has contracted to purchase the majority interest of the South Penn Oil Company in the Penn Mex Fuel Company. The consideration involved is slightly more than $1 a share cash and additional payments to be made quarterly over a period of time as crude oil is recovered from the properties of Penn Mex. Fuel.

The charge that the Soviet Government yielded to pressure of "the forces of American race prejudice" in abandoning recently the production of the film "Black and White," for which twenty-two American Negroeg had been invited to Russia, is contained in what purports to be "the inside story" of the incident published yesterday by The New York Amsterdam News, a weekly newspaper issued in Harlem.

With a goal of 10,000,000 members and the announced intention of "combating legislation for prepayment of the bonus," an organization to be incorporated as the National Committee Against Prepayment of the Bonus held its first meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon and elected S. Stanwood Menken national chairman.

Mortimer N. Buckner, chairman of the hoard of the New York Trust Company, was re-elected president of the New York Clearing House Association and George W. Davison, president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, was elected chairman of the Clearing House committee at the annual meeting of the association yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Come On, owned by A.C. Urban, raced to an easy victory in the featured Ivanhoe Purse at Lincoln Fields today, beating Out Bound over the mile route.

The Metropolitan Museum will place on public view today in its Room of Recent Accessions an archiac Greek statue, a full-length standing figure of the "Apollo" type, which is considered, and certainly with full justification, "one of the most important acquisitions ever made by the museum."

Edward F. Albee, president of the Keith-Albee-Orpbeum Corporation and for many years associated with the late F.F. Proctor in vaudeville enterprises, left an estate appraised yesterday at $3,837,614 gross and $3,270,012 net. He died at Palm Beach, on March 11, 1930.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- A sixty-minute scrimmage featured the Princeton football practice on University Field today. Two varsity teams alternated on defense and offense against the third and scrub elevens, respectively.

Renewed activity in apartment leasing was reported by brokers yesterday. While the demand for suites has abated considerably since the beginning of the month, seekers of new quarters still are providing a large amount of business for the rental agencies.

Reports that State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, Republican, intends not only to retain his Republican and Democratic nominations for the Supreme Court bench but also to remain at the head of the legislative investigating committee, gave further impetus yesterday to the movement, sponsored by leading members of the Bar Association of the City of New York, to place an independent judicial ticket in the field against him and City Court Judge Aron Steuer, Democrat.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that the incomparable band of patriots and statesmen who established the American Republic overestimated the capacity for popular government of the American people. A government such as ours calls for the highest order of public spirit and intelligence.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Herbert H. Lehman started his political career by getting lost in the State Capitol.
TOKYO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Cabinet decided today that the Lytton Commission's report on Manchuria to the League of Nations did not constitute cause to alter its Manchurian policy.

An 11-year old boy was crushed to death and another was injured at 7:30 o'clock last night when an automobile plunged over a five-foot sand embankment into a ditch in which they and five other boys were playing at 122d Street and 109th Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Before an enthusiastic audience which filled to capacity the spacious Broadway Auditorium Colonel William J. Donovan tonight received official notification of his nomination for Governor by the Republican, convention a few hours earlier, and formally opened his campaign with a speech of acceptance which brought the crowd to its feet repeatedly in tumultuous cheering.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Yale coaches today sent the varsity eleven through a rugged forty-five minute scrimmage in the first practice since Bates held the Elis to a scoreless tie last Saturday. The varsity tallied twice and registered a placement goal after one of the touchdowns for a 13 to 0 victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The importance of trade between the United States and the British Empire was shown today in a detailed analysis of American foreign trade for the first six months of 1932, compiled by the Foreign Commerce Department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Buyers Here Register Drop. Buyers registered in the marked during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
COLISEUM, DES MOINES, Oct. 4 (AP) -- This huge hall was practically filled tonight half an hour before President Hoover arrived.

Danny Rosen, east side featherweight, added Patsy Larocco of Harlem to his list of vanquished rivals last night in the feature six-round bout at the final outdoor boxing show at the Queensboro Stadium.

CADIZ, Spain, Oct. 4. -- A story of how hunger, suffering and humiliation were the lot of the flower of the old Spanish aristocracy -- the 138 noblemen, army officers and members of their families exiled to Africa by the republic -- was told today when their exile ship returned.

There will be no wage reduction in the anthracite industry, it was indicated by developments yesterday when committees of the anthracite operators and the United Mine Workers of America resumed the parleys interrupted ten days ago. The conference became deadlocked after three hours when the miners remained adamant to the operators' plea for a wage cut and then was adjourned.
Sales and long-term leases on various properties in Manhattan were reported by brokers yesterday.

Works of members, some forty in all, are being shown in an exhibition at the Fifteen Gallery. An "Interior," by Winthrop Turney, presents a charming arrangement of blue and white ware on a table with a bit of copper lambently reflecting the glow which suffuses the canvas.

With transactions varying little from the million-share business of Monday -- which contrasted with three to five million shares in the markets of two or three weeks ago -- prices of stocks swung back and forth yesterday within narrow limits. In the end, net advances and net declines were perhaps numerically equal, but the changes were unimportant.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Large loans, unsecured and unrepaid, were revealed as made by the Public Service Trust, an Insull subsidiary, in an audit report filed today as an exhibit in the Insull companies' bankruptcy proceedings.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on technological progress, wherein you find the President in error, I think that the figures which you are using and have used several times before are not related to the facts.

A wide variety of retail business enterprises was represented in leases of store locations in Manhattan yesterday. This form of renting dominated the business end of real estate trading and was featured by the signing of contracts for retail store outlets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Several bright spots in the economic situation in foreign countries were noted in a midweek review based on radio and cable messages to the Department of Commerce made public today.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- W. W. Waters, leader of the bonus army march on Washington, was reelected National Commander of the Bonus Expeditionary Force at a wild session of the organization's national convention late today.

The short story is essentially journalistic, essentially ephemeral, and very rarely rises to the level of literature, Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, who has read rather more than 60,000 short stories during her twenty-two years of teaching college students how to write them, said in an interview yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Samuel Insull and his brother, Martin Insull, deposed executives of the $2,000,000,000 Insull utility system now in receivership, were indicted by the Cook County grand jury today on charges of embezzlement and larceny through the abstraction of a total of $514,942.74 from two financing companies of their system to support a marginal stock market account maintained by Martin Insull.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- Part of the mines that blockaded the great coffee port of Santos during the three months of civil war in Brazil were cleared away today and the harbor was opened to shipping, with naval pilots serving as guides through the lanes between the mines that remain.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The Republican State Convention ended its labors at 3:44 o'clock this afternoon after nominating a ticket and adopting a platform in which tax reduction and retrenchment in governmental expenditures were stressed as outstanding issues.

HONOLULU, Oct. 4 -- Corroborating the statement of Mrs. Thalia Massey in Philadelphia, Captain F.J. Horne, chief of staff of the Pearl Harbor Naval Base, today said that three sailors reported seeing her abduction, that this information was given to the authorities, and that nothing was done about it.

HOPEWELL, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Clarence Clark, professional at the Forest Hill Field Club, Bloomfield, and defending champion in the New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association tournament, survived the first two rounds of match play at the Hopewell Valley Golf Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- A nucleus fund totaling "something less than $50,000" has been pledged by "several prominent and responsible business men" for the formation of a new grand-opera organization to produce opera at popular prices, with a $2.50 top, in Philadelphia this season, Mrs. Edith C. Corson said today.

About 1,150,000 persons, or more than one-third of the working population of New York City, are unemployed, while a year ago the total was 800,000 to 1,000,000, according to an estimate prepared for the executive committee of the Welfare Council and made public yesterday by William Hodson, executive director.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, who started the little world's series strongly favored to win and lost ground when Minneapolis won the second and third games, were reinstalled as favorittes tonight Without swinging a bat all day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt in his address at Sioux City made it startlingly plain how dependent this country is on its export trade. At last, it would seem, an American who is not an "export man" has grasped this evident" fact.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,172,000 barrels, compared with 2,178,550 barrels in the preceding week, a decrease of 6,550 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 7,700 barrels daily in the output of East Texas and decline of 4,900 barrels daily in the production of California were the most important changes.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- General Edward Martin, chairman of the Republican State committee, predicted today a "normal" Republican majority for this State in the Presidential election.

VATICAN CITY, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Church officials withheld official comment tonight on the expulsion from Mexico of Archbishop Ruiz y Flores, pending confirmation from their own sources, but unofficially the opinion was voiced in high Vatican circles that Mexico's action would result in a quick reply.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Activity looking to the early launching of the Treasury's $100,000,000 emergency construction program has begun in the office of the Supervising Architect, with the taking of site bids for several hundred projects, some of which will get under way within the next six months.

DES MOENES, Iowa, Oct. 4 -- Iowa, the home State of Herbert Hoover, gave him a rousing welcome when he came back home today to ask that he be continued as President of the United States. From the time he entered the State around noon he met one cheering crowd after another until he faced a turnout of about 100,000 at Des Moines.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- So weakened by lack of food and water that he could not move nor raise his voice above a faint whisper, Miguel Galveron, 36 years old, a convict who disappeared after noon mess on Saturday, was found at 5 o'clock tonight on a pile of cotton bales in the old Sing Sing prison cell block.

Winthrop Ames in Retirement. The best way to define a perfect moment is by example. It was a perfect moment in New York one night half a dozen years ago when the British House of Lords marched upon the stage of the Booth Theatre amid the plaudits of the lower middle classes in WINTHROP AMES'S production of "Tolan-the."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a statement today said that local union No. 306 associated with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Operators of the United States and Canada was the only organization recognized by the federation "as clothed with authority to represent and speak for motion-picture operators in New York City and vicinity."

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Zombro Hanover, bay horse, owned by William Hodson of Hartford, was driven to an impressive victory in three straight heats in the 2:07 pace at the Danbury Fair today. Toll Gate, Canadian gelding, finished second in the first brush but was able to do no better than fourth in the next two.

Yesterday St. FRANCIS of Assisi walked the earth, again in the adoring memory of a world that more than ever needs his nourishing and consoling ministry and gospel. Many millions, without taking the vows of his order, have found themselves in such a state of poverty as he eagerly chose for himself.

Three detectives from Brooklyn Polce Headquarters arrested four men on a hold-up charge early yesterday morning at a dance hall at 2,780 Stillwell Avenue, Coney Island, during, what the police described as a "wine and chicken" dinner arranged to raise a $10,000 fund for defending gangsters and racketeers.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- The defeat tonight of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, in his efforts to block the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor by the Democratic State convention not only spelled the fracture of the Tammany-Brooklyn alliance but even a revolt in Tammany itself, and the nomination of former Mayor Walker for Mayor Thursday night is rendered much less probable.

GENEVA, Oct. 4 -- Anglo-American naval talks are expected here to begin in a few days in London, with Norman H. Davis representing the United States. These talks will be aside from the proposed conference on German arms, which the British announced today.

Edward Rothschild of Brooklyn purchased from Mary A. Foley and Mary Healy the four-story, twenty-three-family apartment house known as Fairview Arms, on a plot 42 by 132 feet, at 126-28 Fairview Avenue, near the Boulevard, Jersey City. The flat is valued for taxation purposes at $95,000, of which $15,100 is the value of the land and $79,900 the building value.

Babe Ruth, before bustling out to a golf course yesterday, declared he saw no reason why he should not play regularly in the outfield for the Yankees in 1933, to round out his twentieth full season in the major leagues.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Secretary Mills told the American Bankers Association at a special session of its annual convention tonight that, while it is too early to claim complete victory over the forces that brought on the financial crisis, the banking and credit structure has been made secure.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- Playing against blustery winds and in intermittent showers, Miss Frances "Williams, Lehigh Valley star, today won the qualifying medal and also established a new low-score tournament record in the Berthellyn Cup golf event over the Huntingdon Valley course.

Princeton's visit to Baker Field this week for the game with Columbia means a renewal of relations, for the two teams have played in the past, and a return to familiar scenes for the Tigers. A good many years ago the Yale-Princeton games used to be played in the city, the players stopping at the Murray Hill Hotel and driving to the scene of action in open, horse-drawn buses.

Prices for cotton advanced early yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here as a result of unfavorable weather reports and reduced estimates of this year's crop, hut the gains were almost all lost in later trading under realizing and scattered selling.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- The State Department of Health announced exclusion orders today against fifteen plants for failure to comply with the standards set by the 1932 Legislature for the importation of milk and cream into New Jersey.
Procter Gamble, soap manufacturers, are the latest recruits to the "share-the-work" movement, it was announced yesterday. A statement on the company's action said:

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange adopted yesterday a rule forbidding the participation by specialists or their partners in a pool dealing in securities in which a member of the Exchange is a specialist. The Exchange's action followed the adoption of a similar rule by the New York Stock Exchange last week.

LEICESTER, England, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) -- George Lansbury, parliamentary Labor leader, today scored the National Government in a bitter speech delivered before the annual meeting of the Labor party.

Accompanied by a sharp decline in wheat, the stock market passed yesterday through the severest reaction since October of last year, with active issues on the Stock Exchange showing net losses of 2 to 8 points. The day's turnover was 2,951,000 shares, against 1,240,000 on Tuesday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 5. -- The seventy-third music festival of the Worcester County Music Association opened in historic Mechanics Hall tonight, Albert Stoessel conducting. This will be the last festival in the old hall, for the city's new $2,000,000 municipal Memorial Auditorium will be ready next year.
NEW YORK. Mrs. J. West Roosevelt, after a visit with her son, Nicholas Roosevelt, American Minister to Budapest, is arriving today on the Paris.

When the dwelling at 491 Manhattan Av. was sold by Helen Sloyan to the 207 W. 40th St. Corp., Jacob Sachs, president, the buyer gave back a purchase money mortgage for $2,000, due in three years at 6 per cent, subject to a first mortgage for 57,500. This mortgage is a lien on all furniture and chattels on the premises.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Differences developed today among leaders of the milk strike aimed against Eisenberg Farms of Brooklyn, through the United Milk Products Corporation.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- Governor Roosevelt, put aside his campaigning clothes today and buckled down to the job of clearing up the accumulation of work that had piled up on his desk while he was on his Western trip.

The decision of Argentina to reenter the League of Nations after twelve years of absence was hailed by the League of Nations Association, Inc., of 6 East Thirty-ninth Street last night as signifying a triumph both for Argentina and the League.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 5. -- Exeter easily defeated New Hampton Academy in soccer today, 4 to 0. Pellegrino, Hecht and Wilson scored in quick succession. Pellegrino accounted for his second score in the last period.

The fifty-eight-acre Gordon Drummond farm on the north side of Tinton Avenue, Eatontown, has been bought by Miss Myra Florian of Rumson from the Broad Street National Bank of Red Bank for a reported price or $12,500. The tract, sought in 1868 from Washington L. Hope by the late Mr. Drummond, was acquired by the bank last April in a mortgage foreclosure.

Miss Lilyan Tashman, motion picture actress and the wife of Edmund Lowe, screen star, was hurriedly operated upon yesterday afternoon in Harbor Sanitarium for an acute attack of appendicitis. At a late hour last night her condition was said to be "satisfactory."

Governor Roosevelt's mind is open on the question of recognizing Soviet Russia; if elected he will consider the question impartially and from all angles. The Governor has set forth this attitude in a letter to the publication Soviet Russia Today in response to an inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Shoe production in the United States in August jumped 50 per cent over July and amounted to 30,717,759 pairs of boots and shoes, other than rubber, compared with 20,442,068 during the previous month, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Auditions will be held next week at the Ludium Studio, 214 W. 96th St., for scholarships which the studio will give in piano, voice and violin to grammar school pupils as well as to older students. Applications must be made in writing.

Three exhibitions call the gallery visitor southward, toward Washington Square. The Downtown Gallery has assembled about twenty paintings as a prelude to the season, recent paintings and sculptures by American contemporaries. The paintings range from the humor of the mottled kitten in Peggy Bacon's "Allure" to Marsden Hartley's gloomy green New England land- scape.

During the last hundred years the world's Jewish population has grown from 3,000,000 to 16,000,000, having quintupled in numbers from 1825 to 1925, whereas Europe, America, South Africa and Australia increased their population only three and a half times, according to figures published in the current number of the Menorah Journal by Jakob Lestschinsky of Berlin, an authority on Jewish demography.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5. -- The American Bankers Association adopted a resolution today denouncing "excessive governmental borrowing and excessive taxation," demanding that expenditures and taxation be sharply reduced.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 5. -- A certificate of incorporation for the Nassau Philharmonic Society, Inc., was signed here today by Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Druhan. The application was made by James N. Gehrig, Hempstead attorney and president of the society, following a meeting of the recently organized group last week.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The stock markets were more active today with some expansion of business. Although British funds were dull in early trading, they improved in the afternoon.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, en route to Washington, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Colonel Lindbergh today passed on to President Hoover his "best wishes" for success in the campaign. A telegram from the flier was placed on the Hoover special at Fort Wayne, Ind., as the Chief Executive was returning from his first campaign address since accepting the nomination delivered at Des Moines last night.

"When Ladies Meet," Rachel Crothers's latest play, will be presented at the Royale Theatre tonight by John Golden. In the company will be Frieda Inescort, Walter Abel. Selena Royle, Spring Byington and Herbert Rawlinson.

Amoskeag Company -- Year ended June 30: Net profit after expenses, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, $667,594, equal after $360,000 preferred dividends paid, to $3.41 a share on 90,181 common shares, against $852,803, or $5,21 a common share, in preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Department of Agriculture today announced a plan for extending crop-production loans in cotton States by accepting the staple as collateral on the basis of 9 cents a pound on middling seven-eighths inch.

The College Art Association opened yesterday at the Newhouse Galleries, 578 Madison Avenue, one of its new traveling shows, called "Comparisons and Contrasts." This exhibition had its premiere last month at the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London. It will remain at the Newhouse until Oct. 22, continuing thereafter its circuit.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Samuel Bingaman, who retired five years ago as a partner in the New York commission house of George M. Rittenhouse Co. and who had lived here for over forty years, died in the Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital last night following injuries received in an automobile accident at Torrington, Conn., yesterday afternoon.
W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, made a scorching demand yesterday upon State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter to repudiate the Tammany nomination for the Supreme Court bench.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Six men, supposedly representing the New York City brokerage house of S.E. Price, 11 Stone Street, were arrested today in a five-room suite at the Morrison Hotel, from which, police said, they were conducting a high-pressure stock-selling campaign by telephone.
The Sun, New York's Republican evening paper, came out editorially yesterday in support of the candidacy of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor on the Democratic ticket.

MONTREAL, Oct. 5 (AP). -- After more than four years spent in clearing the way, hearing of the $3,400,000 suit brought by the State of New York against the heirs of the late John M. Phillips, New York sewer pipe contractor, reached the Superior Court today.

Although the new "Americana" revue, which came to the Shubert last evening, seems a little confused in its ideas, some of it is extraordinarily beautiful. Mr. Shubert, who has seldom been so prodigal in the past, has mounted this one to the most exacting taste.

OIL CITY, Pa., Oct. 5. -- Daily production of the oil field last week was 25,963 barrels, against 29,839 in the week of Oct. 3, 1931, a drop of 3,876 barrels. In the week the daily average rose 1,392 barrels. In the Allegany field a decline of 1,524 barrels to 6,566 daily was reported for the week.

After establishing a new high mark for the upswing in the early part of September, stock prices declined sharply in the second week, canceling nearly 25 per cent of the gains made in the recovery, then rallied abruptly to a level around which they moved irregularly to the end of the month, closing at prices approximately the same as those at the end of August.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Fresh outbreaks of rioting among unemployed persons kept the police active in various parts of England today, and in North Shields a big demonstration was followed by fierce baton charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Speaker Garner replied to President Hoover's Des Moines address today with a charge that the President had been inconsistent in his attitude on farm mortgages and a statement that "broken promises cannot be explained away."

Samuel W. Gumpertz, Coney Island showman and real estate operator, and Miss Edith I. Green of 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, Manhattan, his secretary for twenty-two years, were married yesterday by Deputy City Clerk Thomas F. Maher in the Municipal Building in Brooklyn.
